title: Sununu Says Cable Clears Bush of Role In Iran-Contra Case
description: John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, said in an interview broadcast today that documentary evidence clears President Bush of accusations that he sought aid for the Nicaraguan rebels at a 1985 meeting with the President of Honduras.

title: Suit on South Africa Sale by Mobil
description: The black chemical workers union has sued to stop the sale of the Mobil Corporation's assets in South Africa until the company negotiates a procedure for withdrawing from the country, the union said Saturday.

title: Washington Talk: Congress
description: Like a plant seeking sunlight, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia has strained toward the glow of the news media for many years. Now he is basking in it.

title: Cavaliers Top Bulls To Even Series
description: Ron Harper outscored Michael Jordan, 31-30, and Larry Nance scored 8 points during a 13-6 third-quarter flurry as the Cleveland Cavaliers beat the Chicago Bulls, 96-88, today to even their playoff series at one game each.

title: Leslie Lynn Wed To J. A. Rahl Jr.
description: Leslie H. Lynn, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Myron Horwitz of New York, and J. Andrew Rahl Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. Rahl of Evanston, Ill., were married yesterday at the restaurant Bouley in Manhattan. Judge Bruce Kaplan of Family Court officiated.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of April 30, 1989: MONDAY Atlantic Richfield Co MCN Corp Cooper Tire & Rubber Co NCH Corp General Motors Corp Source Cap Inc Jefferson Pilot Corp Stride Rite Corp La Z Boy Chair Co West Inc MBIA Inc TUESDAY Carlisle Cos Inc Kansas Pwr & Lt Co Diam Sham R & M Inc Koger Pptys Inc Emerson Elec Co Liberty Corp S C Georgia Pac Co Monarch Mach Tool Co IE Inds Inc Sun Expl & Prod Co Kans City Pwr & Lt Co U S Surgical Corp WEDNESDAY Amer Gen Corp Pepsico Inc Gen Housewares Corp Thomas & Betts Corp Grt Northn Nekoosa Corp Utilicorp Utd Inc Hanna M A Co Williams Cos Inc IBP Inc Wynns Intl Inc McKesson Corp THURSDAY Apache Corp Hannaford Bros Co Avemco Corp Landmark Bncshrs Corp Avon Prods Inc Paine Webber Grp Inc Coachmen Inds Inc RLI Corp Coastal Corp Southdown Inc Contel Corp Texas East Corp Enron Corp Wendys Intl Inc FRIDAY Atlanta Gas Lt Co Timken Co Cenvill Invs Inc Van Dorn Co Potlatch Corp Vulcan Matls Co Ryder Sys Inc

title: Lloyds Quits Role in Treasury Debt
description: Lloyds Bank P.L.C. announced that it was withdrawing as a primary dealer in Treasury securities, effective immediately. The London-based bank said that while it had not lost money in its Treasury operation, ''our return on capital invested has not been commensurate with what the bank obtains in other businesses.''

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Account
description: * Homart Development Co., Northeast division, to Cosmopulos, Crowley & Daly, with an undisclosed budget.

title: Washington Talk: Guestlist; A Catalogue of Insiders and Their Influence
description: Book parties here, book parties there, book parties all over in cities of respectable size. And Tuesday evening at the Cosmos Club there is what some might consider the quintessential Washington event.

title: ...as Japan Questions American Commitment
description: When the Control Data Corporation, one of two manufacturers of supercomputers in the United States, abruptly dropped out of the race to build the fastest machines in the world, the Japanese were both startled and a bit apprehensive.

title: Female Runners Find Older Can Be Better
description: FEMALE runners who reach their 40's can look forward to continued improvements in performance, better health and the confidence to cope with the stresses of mid-life more than nonexercisers, according to Priscilla Welch, who won the New York City Marathon at age 42 in 1987.

title: Leiter's 'Great Future' Will Be as a Jay
description: During the winter before last season, the Yankees refused to trade Al Leiter. He was, they said, one of four young players who were untouchable. If Elliot Ness had been so untouchable, Robert Stack and Kevin Costner would have never made a television series and a movie about him.

title: An Icy Reception for Austria's Bid To Join the European Community
description: After months of debate, the partners in the Austrian Government's coalition have formally agreed to apply for membership in the European Community, but it is an open question whether the community nations want Austria.

title: Hoch Wins on 5th Extra Hole
description: Three weeks after he failed to win the Masters because he missed a 2-foot putt on the first playoff hole, Scott Hoch won the $1.25 million Las Vegas Invitational today by rolling in an 8-foot birdie putt on the fifth hole of a sudden-death playoff with Robert Wrenn.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Publishing; U.S. Houses Acknowledging Value of Book Fairs Abroad
description: BOOK fairs abroad have become increasingly important to American publishers, which are growing more international in ownership and in their publishing vision. This year American publishers can choose among at least 15 of the fairs, from Spain to Singapore and from Brussels to Belgrade.

title: Supercomputers Worry U.S....
description: The Control Data Corporation's hasty withdrawal from the supercomputer business has sharpened the debate over whether new Japanese competition to build and sell the powerful computers is threatening the dominance of the United States in the field.

title: U.S. Tops Costa Rica in World Cup Play
description: The United States earned its first points in its quest to qualify for the World Cup finals for the first time in 40 years with a 1-0 victory today over Costa Rica.

title: Lori B. Schneider Becomes a Bride
description: At the Crest Hollow Country Club in Woodbury, L.I., Lori Beth Schneider, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Schneider of New Springville, S.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Jean-Pierre Riou, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Marcel Henri Riou of New York. Rabbi Joshua Glasser performed the ceremony.

title: Hospital Union Elects Leader
description: Dennis Rivera, executive vice president of the long-troubled Local 1199 of the Drug, Hospital and Health Care Employees Union, was elected president of the union on Saturday, winning 90 percent of the 22,000 ballots cast.

title: What a National Service Plan Should Include; Free to Drop Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Drug Tests Face Test
description: A drug-testing program for high school athletes in Woodstock, Vt. -the first such program in the state and, possibly, the nation - has been started despite controversy over its implementation.

title: Review/Dance; City Ballet's Menu Offers Balanchine With Debuts
description: Dancing on a brand-new resilient stage floor just completed for its new season, the New York City Ballet served up an all-Balanchine feast on Saturday that was studded with fine debuts and excellence all around.

title: Last Laugh to Chaplin
description: To the Editor:

title: Walter Malley, 49, Editor at Buffalo News
description: Walter Malley, deputy managing editor of The Buffalo News, was killed yesterday morning in an automobile accident in West Seneca, N.Y. He was 49 years old and lived in Elma, N.Y.

title: Trump Move in Nevada
description: Donald J. Trump, the billionaire developer, formally made his long-expected move into Nevada gaming last week by filing incorporation papers for Trump Nevada Inc. Mike Rumbolz, former chairman of the Nevada Gaming Control Board, will serve as president of the Las Vegas-based company that will hold the Trump Nevada casinos. Mr. Rumbolz said Mr. Trump had not announced his plans for Nevada and would not seek a gaming license until he bought a property.

title: One More Ending For Forest Hills
description: When it was the home of the United States Nationals and then the Open, the West Side Tennis Club at Forest Hills was considered the American equivalent of the All-England Club. With its stately clubhouse and rich grass courts, situated in a residential neighborhood in Queens, Forest Hills invited comparisons with Wimbledon.

title: Judy Sharpe Marries
description: Judy Sharpe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Sharpe of Manhasset, L.I., was married yesterday to Phillip Alder, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Geoffrey Alder of Nottingham, England. Dr. Barbara Duffy Spencer, of the Ethical Humanist Society of Long Island, officiated at the Mill River Club in Brookville, L.I. Mrs. Sharpe-Alder, a graduate of Ohio University, is an associate at Periodical Studies Service, a magazine publishing consulting company in New York. The bridegroom, a graduate of London University, teaches and writes about contract bridge. His previous marriage ended in divorce.

title: NATO's Disquiet: A Strategy at Risk
description: Last month, a NATO military exercise came to an abrupt end when the West German and Turkish participants objected to an American proposal for the hypothetical use of battlefield nuclear weapons against an enemy on German and Turkish territory.

title: A Day Celebrates 200 Presidential Years
description: With solemn-faced actors reprising the first inauguration and a two-hour parade filling the narrow streets of lower Manhattan, New York City celebrated 200 years of Presidential government yesterday.

title: In Washington, Just a Hint of the Alliance's Angst
description: In London, Bonn, Paris and Rome, indeed right across Western Europe, politicians and large segments of the public are hotly debating the new rifts in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization that West Germany has laid bare for all to see.

title: Wregget Answers The Bell as a Hero
description: Ken Wregget heard the rumors back in March, and as a result the speculation began to circulate in his mind, too. As the Maple Leafs shopped to see what they could get for him, Wregget wrestled with what a trade might mean for him. He wasn't unhappy in Toronto, but he also thought he might be better off elsewhere.

title: Washington Talk; Government's History As Told From Within
description: Of all the uses and abuses of history, perhaps the gravest - and surely the most annoying - is to ignore the subject and its practitioners.

title: Rate Outlook Appears Uncertain
description: Economic data to be released in the next few weeks will be critical in determining the course of interest rates, credit market participants and analysts say.

title: Penn State Network
description: Lionvision is the name of a new satellite television network soon to be offered to fans of Penn State sports at a cost of almost $1,300. Early responses indicate that the break-even point of 2,500 subscribers will be met easily.

title: Mindy Schneider, Hospital Executive,And Dr. Michael S. Lesser Are Wed
description: At the Hotel Pierre in New York, Mindy Lois Schneider and Dr. Michael Scott Lesser were married yesterday by Rabbis Irving Greenberg and Joseph Singer. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Schneider of New York and Palm Beach, Fla. Mr. Lesser is the son of Dr. and Mrs. David Lesser of Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Thursday about the National Magazine Awards misidentified the author honored in the reporting category. She is Robin Wright, not Robin White.

title: In China, Protest Proves Easier Than Organization
description: When thousands of cheering and banner-waving Qinghua University students left campus last week to join an enormous demonstration that crumpled police lines and forced the Government to agree to a discussion, they forgot one thing: their leaders.

title: Texans in House Close Ranks to Fight for Wright
description: Jim Wright is more than just the Speaker of the House, more than the nation's top ranking Democrat, second in line for the Presidency.

title: Investors Hop On Bulls' Bandwagon
description: WHEN the latest upward explosion in stock prices began, the portfolio managers who run mutual funds were much more bullish than the investors in the funds. But the investors seem to have gotten the bullish religion in April, fund managers say.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Bridge
description: A declarer in a suit contract must be sensitive to the possibilities of promotion, and South on the diagramed deal had a special reason for having this subject on his mind. It was played in a private duplicate game Thursday, and the player was Phillip Alder of Manhattan, a British immigrant who is probably the world's only full-time freelance bridge writer.

title: Leiter Sent To the Jays For Barfield MURRAY CHASS
description: First place used to be so common that it was part of the Yankees' name, as in ''the first-place Yankees.'' Not long ago, superstar was attached to Jesse Barfield's name, as in Jesse Barfield, superstar.

title: Clemens Outpitched by Ryan
description: Nolan Ryan won the first battle between the best fastball pitchers in Texas today, leading the Texas Rangers past Roger Clemens and the Boston Red Sox, 2-1, on Rafael Palmeiro's two-run homer in the eighth inning.

title: Hundreds Die in Month of Clashes On 2 Sides of West African Border
description: Mobs of Mauritanians attacking Senegalese have reportedly killed more than 400 people in the Mauritanian capital this month in the worst ethnic violence there in recent years. The violence has since spread to this West African nation, where mobs of Senegalese have burned and looted property belonging to Mauritanians. Nearly 40 Mauritanians have reportedly been killed here in the last two days.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 London and Bonn agreed to differ on NATO disarmament strategy and declared that they were looking to the alliance meeting at the end of May to restore a common front. Page A1

title: 'Concert Against AIDS'
description: A Canadian chamber ensemble, the Tudor Singers of Montreal, is to join the Oratorio Society of New York at Carnegie Hall tomorrow at 8 P.M. in a benefit, ''In Concert Against AIDS.'' Funds raised will go to a group residence for AIDS patients, Bailey House of the AIDS Resource Center. Tickets are $25 to $200. Information and reservations: 876-2250.

title: The Russians' New Weapon Against Radiation Is Lawsuit
description: Frightened by Chernobyl and emboldened by the fledgling environmental movement, ordinary Muscovites have gone to court charging that nearly forgotten, decades-old radioactive wastes are being unearthed dangerously amid their apartment towers.

title: Av Westin to Leave ABC
description: Av Westin, the former executive producer of the prime-time ABC News program ''20/20,'' has announced plans to leave the network to form his own production company, probably with the backing of either the Walt Disney Company or Warner Communications. Mr. Westin has been producer of the ABC ''Burning Questions'' documentaries since 1987, when he was removed from ''20/20'' after a dispute with Roone Arledge, the president of the news division. Mr. Westin's contract with ABC News has expired, and he said Friday that while he hoped to produce work independently for the network, he expected to be out of his office at ABC by the end of June.

title: School Reform, in Voters' Hands
description: Should public officials, political leaders and employees of New York City's Board of Education be prohibited from serving on community school boards? Just days before tomorrow's election of 288 local school board members, U.S. District Judge Mark Costantino said no.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Omnicom Officer Denies Buying Boase Shares
description: Fred J. Meyer, the chief financial officer of the Omnicom Group, has denied that the giant marketing-communications company is acquiring shares in the Boase, Massimi & Pollitt Partnership, the British advertising agency fighting a hostile takeover bid by a French agency.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Washington created a living, functioning government. He brought together men of genius - a team of giants, with strong and competing views. He harnessed and directed their energies. And he established a precedent for 40 Presidents to follow.'' - President Bush. [ B2:2. ]

title: Review/Opera; Assessing Some Voices in Their New 'Ring' Roles
description: The Metropolitan Opera completed its first one-week ''Ring'' cycle in half a century to the sound of roof-ringing cheers Saturday night; it was one of those standing ovations that sweeps across the house like a wave. Now Wagnerians have had the chance they need to experience the great cycle, the new production and James Levine's musical interpretation within the time span for which Wagner conceived the work.

title: Abortion Protesters Tagged
description: Frustrated after a judge dismissed charges against 86 anti-abortion demonstrators whose police identifications he questioned, the Buffalo police used new methods in arresting more than 40 protesters over the weekend. Each suspect was tagged by number and photographed with the arresting officer.

title: An Uproar Over Billboards in Poor Areas
description: At bus stops and subway stations in inner cities around the country, a well-dressed black trumpeter grins from a Benson & Hedges billboard and says his brand of cigarettes is ''for people who like to smoke.''

title: 2 U.S. Seamen Lost Off Japan
description: Three crewmen on a United States Navy submarine were swept overboard by a wave today as the vessel, the Barbel, was on surface patrol off a Japanese island. One man was rescued and two were missing, American officials said. In Washington, a Defense Department spokesman said he had heard reports of the missing men but had no details. There were no reports of injuries to the other crewmen.

title: What a National Service Plan Should Include
description: To the Editor:

title: Up to $600 Million Worth of Art Being Auctioned Over 12 Days
description: Works of art estimated to be worth as much as $600 million are to be auctioned in New York City over the next 12 days in a series of sales starting tomorrow night. By the time the last hammer falls, the expectation is that the soaring art market will have reached new heights and that record-breaking prices will have been paid for works ranging from a Picasso self-portrait to prints by Jasper Johns.

title: PARAGUAY VOTING IN OPEN ELECTION
description: Waving from an open Jeep, Domingo Laino smiled giddily as his balloon-festooned campaign caravan passed the Palace of Government here, command center for 35 years of the dictatorship of Gen. Alfredo Stroessner.

title: In Africa, Pope Smiles on Local Custom
description: At the end of an outdoor beatification ceremony here today, two dozen barefoot boys and girls danced before Pope John Paul II while a congregation of hundreds of thousands sang a lilting hymn in the Malagasy language.

title: Sandlot to the Ballet Stage: Edward Villella Is Honored
description: Edward Villella, one of the great American ballet stars, owes his career in dance to a baseball accident. In 1946, when he was 10 years old, Mr. Villella was knocked unconscious in a sandlot ball game in Bayside, Queens, where he grew up. His mother wanted to keep him off the streets as a result, so when she enrolled her daughter in the School of American Ballet, she mentioned that she had a son at home. '' 'My God, a boy,' they said, and I got brought in,'' Mr. Villella recalled in a recent interview.

title: Presidential Descendants Have a Great-Great-Grand Time
description: This morning, on the occasion of the bicentennial of the first President's first inauguration, about 100 First Descendants got together for breakfast at Fraunces Tavern on Broad and Pearl Streets, to discuss who was related to whom.

title: Henry Hope, 83, Retired Indiana Professor
description: Dr. Henry Hope, a retired professor of fine arts at Indiana University and the first director of its art museum, died Thursday morning at Bloomington (Ind.) Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

title: Review/Music; Cast Changes in Met's 'Elisir'
description: The Metropolitan Opera's revival of its 1960 ''L'Elisir d'Amore'' production this season revolves around the considerable virtues of Luciano Pavarotti's Nemorino and Kathleen Battle's Adina. But at the Saturday matinee, there were newcomers to two of the secondary roles in this light-spirited Donizetti opera.

title: 4 Takeovers by the F.D.I.C.
description: Federal regulators have taken over four more insolvent savings and loan associations in three states, bringing the total under Government control to 220 in 32 states.

title: The Bleakest Business Address in America
description: This is the coldest, nastiest place in America to do business, a place where it can snow on the Fourth of July and where even now the only sign of spring is that snow by the roads is beginning to turn brown from dust.

title: Black and Hispanic Officials Are Cool to 2-House Plan
description: A range of black and Hispanic officials and community groups in New York City say they are not persuaded that proposals for a two-house city legislature would adequately increase opportunities for minorities to win seats or power in a reconstituted city government.

title: Sergio Leone, 67, Italian Director Who Revitalized Westerns, Dies
description: Sergio Leone, the Italian director who revived western films in the 1960's and added distinction and style to a genre known as spaghetti westerns, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Rome. He was 67 years old.

title: Beth Ruskin Weds an Editor
description: Beth Jane Ruskin and Fred Michael Weiler were married yesterday at Agudath Shalom Synagogue in Stamford, Conn. Rabbi Morris Gorelick performed the ceremony.

title: Bitter Debates Await Return Of Lawmakers
description: With lawmakers pressing to finish this year's legislative business in eight weeks, as opposed to last year's 11-month marathon, the New York Legislature returns here Monday for the second half of a session that is expected to be dominated by issues of crime and justice and a lack of money.

title: Catskills in Identity Crisis Over Room Tax
description: When Sullivan County officials realized last fall that the growing cost of government was about to send property taxes soaring, they began looking for a less painful solution. They found thousands: the out-of-towners who come to the Catskills' resort hotels.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about Thursday's stock trading and a brief report in the Company News pages carried an erroneous closing price in some editions for Union Pacific, based on the New York Stock Exchange listing supplied by The Associated Press. The stock closed up $5.25 a share, to $71.375, after the company said it planned to buy back some of its common stock.

title: The Kangaroo Kid and Some Related Matters
description: IT was once put to Ted Williams this way, ''Ted, it's said that you were such a great hitter because you had such incredible reflexes that you were 1 in 10 million, and your eyesight was so extraordinary that you could read a license plate a block away.''

title: Deborah Ann Lafer Weds Howard Scher, Physician
description: The marriage of Deborah Ann Lafer, a daughter of Fred S. and Dr. Barbara Lafer of Wayne, N.J., to Dr. Howard I. Scher, the son of Charles and Dr. Goldie Scher of New York, took place at the Central Synagogue in New York yesterday. Rabbis Martin Freedman and Stanley Davids officiated.

title: What a National Service Plan Should Include; Keep It Voluntary
description: To the Editor:

title: Fresh Trouble for Familiar Face in Detroit Politics
description: Coleman A. Young, the Mayor of this troubled city and one of the country's first black mayors, appears headed for more difficulty than usual if he runs for a fifth term in November, as most Detroiters expect him to do.

title: Treasury Is Selling Only Bills This Week
description: This week's schedule of new Treasury issues is confined to the bill market, beginning with today's regular weekly auction of new three-month and six-month bills totaling $14 billion, followed by a $9 billion auction on Thursday of a new one-year bill.

title: Paris Journal; Building of the Bastille, Opera Bouffe in Progress
description: ''You can look with your ears and hear with your eyes!'' exclaimed Michael Dittmann, emitting a booming ''la'' note that ricocheted off the wall of the 2,700-seat auditorium, rippling across to the other side as if in a canyon. The scenic director of the Bastille Opera pivoted and watched the la's rolling progress with deep professional satisfaction.

title: Deborah Zuckert And Ira J. Levy Have Wedding
description: At the Inn at Longshore in Westport, Conn., Deborah Ellen Zuckert, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Owen Mack Zuckert of Stamford, Conn., was married yesterday to Ira Jay Levy, the son of Maurice Levy and Gloria Levy, both of Brooklyn. Rabbi Robert J. Orkand officiated.

title: Ralph Adams, 76, Dies; Bush War Rescuer
description: Ralph E. Adams, a World War II submariner who helped rescue a downed flier who is now President of the United States, died of cancer at his home on April 21. He was 76 years old. Mr. Adams, a career Navy sailor, was was part of a rescue party sent from the submarine Finback on Sept. 4, 1944, to pick up Lieut. (j.g.) George Bush, one of the lieutenant's crewmen, and three fliers from another plane shot down by the Japanese. They were found in a rubber raft about 70 miles off Osaka, Japan. Lieutenant Bush had been piloting a single-engine bomber.

title: Ellen Rowe Weds Lewis W. Siegel
description: Ellen A. Rowe, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph M. Rowe of Dearborn, Mich., was married yesterday to Lewis W. Siegel, a son of Edith D. Siegel of New York and the late Marcus S. Siegel. Rabbi Michael Greenwald officiated at the Tavern on the Green in New York.

title: So Who's Digging Up All That Scandal in Tokyo?
description: The skyscrapers housing Japan's most powerful Government offices lie in a central Tokyo district called Kasumigaseki, which means the gate enshrouded by fog.

title: Critic's Notebook; TV and the Public Figure: Drama vs. the Melodrama
description: Television news did not emerge unscathed from the barrage of recriminations that followed the Senate's rejection of former Senator John G. Tower for Secretary of Defense this year. Some partisans of the toppled former senator attributed his defeat to a political cabal gleefully abetted by the usual liberal cadre in the press and on the screen.

title: Review/Flute; Paula Robison Plays Vivaldi
description: The flutist Paula Robison presided over a lively evening of Baroque chamber music in the Medieval Sculpture Hall of the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Saturday evening. Her partners in the endeavor were Kenneth Cooper, harpsichordist; Martha Caplin and Carol Zeavin, violinists; Linda Moss, violist; Annabelle Hoffman, cellist, and Sara Thompson, bassist.

title: Indian Art vs. Artifact: Problem of Ambiguity
description: The construction of a new wing at this city's most popular museum, the Museum of Anthropology, and an exhibition opening soon at its leading art museum highlight what is becoming a much-debated question throughout Canada: How are exhibiting institutions to treat both old and new works by American Indians?

title: Betsy Ross Races Attract Top Sailors
description: A new yacht-racing series in New York Harbor is drawing competitors who are among the top female sailors in the United States.

title: Oil Means Comfort to Alaska Natives but Peril to Their Culture
description: Oil, which recently brought disaster to southeastern Alaska, has brought something very different to the native peoples here, 850 miles to the north: comfort, convenience and the seeds of destruction of their way of life.

title: Chief to Leave Fireman's Fund
description: The Fireman's Fund Insurance Company said that William M. McCormick would resign as chairman, president and chief executive by the end of the year. Jack Byrne, chairman of the Fireman's Fund Corporation, the holding company, will assume Mr. McCormick's duties in an acting capacity.

title: Lois M. Brenner, Lawyer, Is Wed To Robert Stein
description: Lois Margaret Brenner and Robert Stein were married yesterday at the bride's home in New York. Jacqueline Silbermann, Administrative Judge of the Civil Court of the City of New York, performed the ceremony.

title: Spree by Thomas Sinks the Celtics
description: Isiah Thomas has a broken bone in his left hand that throbs every time someone hits it. He has played cautiously for three weeks, picking his spots to score while letting teammates carry the load offensively.

title: Corrections
description: A list of Queens community school board candidates on Tuesday misidentified a candidate in District 30.

title: Spanish-Language Cable Network Gaining
description: Galavision, a Spanish-language cable network, is eroding the lead of the two largest Spanish-language broadcasting networks in the United States.

title: Communist Rebels in Manila Kill Two of Aquino's Guards
description: Communist guerrillas shot and killed two of President Corazon C. Aquino's security guards here today, the police said.

title: 'Think Globally, Act Locally,' Hoffman Said
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviets Detain Sellers of Dissident Literature
description: The police detained leaders of underground political groups today after they defied a Government warning and gathered to sell copies of their illegal publications on a crowded pedestrian mall.

title: Bass Cuts Mifflin Stake
description: A group led by Robert M. Bass, the Texas investor, disclosed last week that it had whittled its stake in the Houghton Mifflin Company, the book publisher, to 1.1 percent, from 5.6 percent. The Bass Group said in a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission that it had sold the stock because it appeared to be ''reasonably priced'' and added that the group still regards the company as ''one of the nation's leading publishers.''

title: Farm Loan Agency Picks Its First Chief
description: Henry D. Edelman, a first vice president specializing in government finance at Paine Webber Inc., has been named the first president and chief executive of a new Federal agency, the Federal Agricultural Mortgage Corporation.

title: 2,900 Arrested as Students Protest in Downtown Seoul
description: Students and workers fought the riot police with firebombs and rocks in downtown Seoul today after troopers blocked a rally called by labor and dissident groups to mark May Day. More than 2,900 people were arrested.

title: Floating for Fish
description: Float tubes offer fishermen a way to move quietly across the water in search of their catch. But, like inner tubes, they can tip over.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on Wednesday about steaks described the grading of Certified Angus beef incorrectly. The beef is graded by the Government as either choice or prime and also conforms to specifications set by the American Angus Association, a private beef cattle registry.

title: Dr. Ellen Mellow Wed To Dr. Robert J. Kaner
description: Dr. Ellen Mellow, a fellow in cardiology at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania, was married yesterday to Dr. Robert J. Kaner, a pulmonary physician at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center and a research associate at New York Hospital. Rabbi J. Rolando Matalon officiated at the New York home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Bruce Mellow.

title: Garcia Covers the Waterfront
description: If Salvador Garcia of Mexico had not fallen at the start of the Boston Marathon two weeks ago, he would have probably finished the race and have been too exhausted to run today in the New Jersey Waterfront Marathon.

title: Runners Reassess Their Vulnerability
description: A RUNNER who was raped at gunpoint in Central Park at dusk one March day six years ago remembers how invincible, invulnerable and completely in control of her life being fit had made her feel.

title: Steven Taub Married To Debra K. Anderson
description: Debra K. Anderson, an associate with the law firm of Lerch, Early, Roseman & Frankel in Bethesda, Md., and Steven P. Taub, an associate in the Washington law firm of Crowell & Moring, were married in New York yesterday at the Terrace at Butler Hall at Columbia University. Civil Court Judge Harold Silverman officiated.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
At $5 an Hour, It's Tennis Everyone?
description: LEAD: INTO the hopper of inexpensive things to do in New York goes a very unlikely option: tennis.

title: Industrial Rebound Is Reported
description: After three consecutive months of faltering growth, the business activity of industrial companies grew at a faster pace in April, according to a report to be released today by the National Association of Purchasing Managers.

title: Rape Suspects' Neighbors Feel Accused
description: The Schomburg Plaza apartments rise tan and tall at the northern tip of Central Park, perched between affluence and poverty, between crack houses to the north and million-dollar cooperatives to the south on Fifth Avenue, between the extremes that so often define life in New York City.

title: Facing Space, After the Cold War
description: America's space program began and blossomed in competition with the Soviet Union. But with the rivalry easing, it's possible to think what was unthinkable during the chilly cold war years: Let the superpowers give up costly competitive extravaganzas and go into space together.

title: Political Memo; Jackson's Possible Run for Capital Mayor Has Echoes for '92
description: It is rare that a bit of iffy political news coming three years before a Presidential election sends such a large jolt through the system. But when the news involves the Rev. Jesse Jackson, some electricity is inevitable.

title: Business Digest
description: The Media Business WPP Group has begun an assault on another U.S. ad agency, making an unsolicited $730 million offer to buy the Ogilvy Group. If the bid succeeds, it will create the world's second-largest advertising company, after Saatchi & Saatchi, which like WPP is based in London. A merger would join some of the best-known names in advertising and continue the wave of mergers that has transformed the ad and marketing-communications industries. [ Page A1. ] Alcohol and tobacco ads aimed at minorities are under attack, as blacks suffer disproportionately from some diseases linked to drinking and smoking. Surveys indicate a wide disparity in the number of billboards in black and white communities. [ D10. ] Britain's Sunday newspapers are being transformed by a fierce competition for readers, amid declines or small gains in the circulation of the five papers in the upper end of the market. [ D10. ] A Spanish-language cable network is gaining on two broacasting competitors. After two years of operation, Galavision is seen in two million U.S. households on 300 cable systems. [ D10. ] Overseas book fairs have become more important to American publishers, which have grown more international in focus. At least 15 of the fairs will take place this year. Publishing. [ D10. ] Magazine ads that talk, pop, light up or play music may be dazzling, but the high cost has prevented widespread use. Rather, these dimensional ads are the choice of companies that want to make a one-time splash. Advertising. [ D11. ] The Economy The industrial growth rate picked up in April after three months of faltering activity, the nation's purchasing managers reported. Several categories in the monthly survey advanced; most surprising was a strong gain in orders for exports. [ D1. ] Jury selection begins today in the trial of Paul A. Bilzerian on securities-fraud charges. The trial is likely to test the credibility of Boyd L. Jefferies, a Government witness in several cases. [ D2. ] Companies A debate on Japanese competition in supercomputers has sharpened with the withdrawal of Control Data from that business. The concern is whether Cray Research is in danger of losing its lead, which could harm the nation's technological prowess. [ D1. ] Japan views Control Data's decision as another sign that the goals of U.S. companies do not mesh with those of the Government. [ D1. ] Fast-food outlets may soon accept credit cards. The three leading credit card companies are exploring the concept, and test-marketing has begun. ''Fast food is one of the biggest unpenetrated segments'' for credit cards, one analyst notes. [ D1. ] Airlines hope to entice vacationers by offering free or $1 flights for children, a move started by Continental last week. There have been signs that leisure passengers, put off by quickly rising fares, will take to their cars this summer. [ D1. ] International Report Austria will seek European Community membership. But news of the application received a lukewarm reception from West Germany, France and the Benelux countries. [ D8. ] Boeing and McDonnell Douglas have taken two approaches to the Chinese market. The stakes are high, with China needing as many as 1,000 new planes. Beijing also plans to pick a foreign partner to help it make a jetliner for sale around the world. [ D8. ] Today's Columns The futures of Kodak and Polaroid are at stake in a trial expected to begin today. At issue is how much Kodak owes for infringing on instant-photography patents. Business and the Law. [ D2. ] Mutual-fund investors have belatedly caught the fever that gripped portfolio managers when stocks began to rise. Equity fund sales surged in April. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D6. ] New economic reports are seen as crucial in determining the course of interest rates, which may be as low as they can go unless there are more signs of economic softening. Credit Markets. [ D7. ]

title: Business and the Law; Polaroid v. Kodak: Future on the Line
description: AFTER more than a decade of bitter legal wrangling, the moment when it counts is at hand in the huge patent fight between the Eastman Kodak Company and the Polaroid Corporation.

title: Brett May Miss a Month
description: George Brett tore a ligament in his right knee Saturday night and will be sidelined at least a month.

title: Shuttle Awaits New Fuel Pump and New Launching Date
description: Engineers decided today to replace an apparently defective fuel pump in the shuttle Atlantis in an operation that space officials said would set back the launching for the shuttle's mission until at least Friday or Saturday.

title: Campaign Matters; Park Rampage And Mayor Race: Fear and Politics
description: Last month's Central Park rampage underscores the average New Yorker's vulnerability, the banality of the evil personified by the teen-age suspects, the fragility of the social contract in the face of wanton violence and the apparent inability of the criminal-justice system to contain it.

title: Review/Theater; Sobol's 'Ghetto,' a Holocaust Drama With Music
description: At the bare minimum, dramatic works about the Holocaust have an obligation to restore vivid immediacy to horrors that scoundrels and the passing of time would have the world forget. As presented in good conscience but with scant competence by the Circle in the Square, Joshua Sobol's ''Ghetto'' is too lifeless to meet this minimal requirement. A tedious stage treatment of the Holocaust, however well intentioned, is a trivialization of the Holocaust. One need only look at all the dozing faces in the audience to see that ''Ghetto'' is aiding rather than combating historical amnesia.

title: Fears of Pesticides Threaten American Way of Farming
description: Miles of radishes, great stands of celery and fields of sweet corn, carrots and lettuce thrive in southern Florida's fertile mucklands, a powerful testament to the union of engineering, biology and chemistry that has fed America for two generations.

title: Selling Planes to China: High Stakes
description: In competing to supply the vast Chinese appetite for new airplanes, the Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation have taken two basic approaches: selling and manufacturing.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Magazines Go Beyond The Pop-Up
description: MILLIONS of readers blinked twice when they opened Time magazine in September 1986 and watched the Transamerica tower rise from its pages. Three years later, experts liken the insurer's ad to the Ford Model T -pioneering but technically unspectacular.

title: Jury Selection to Begin in Bilzerian Securities-Fraud Case
description: Jury selection will begin today in the first case against a takeover artist since the recent wave of Wall Street scandals began.

title: NEITHER GIVES WAY
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany forcefully reaffirmed their differing positions on NATO arms control strategy today and both declared that they were looking to the alliance summit meeting to restore a common front.

title: Top Credit Card Companies Explore Fast-Food Tie-Ins
description: Like titans curious but still wary of each other, the credit card and fast-food industries are exploring an alliance.

title: Senator Fights to Be Taken Seriously in Jersey Race
description: Senator William J. Gormley of Atlantic County, a moderate in a field dominated by conservatives, is hoping lessons from past campaigns and instincts born of a lifelong immersion in politics will enable him to pull an upset in the June 7 Republican primary for governor.

title: Books of The Times; Kennan's Wide World, Sketched From Its Details
description: Sketches From a Life By George F. Kennan 365 pages. Pantheon. $22.95.

title: Outdoors: Course For a Newcomer To Art of Casting
description: TO many, fly fishing is an art learned over a lifetime.

title: Angered by Attack, Trump Urges Return Of the Death Penalty
description: The full-page advertisements placed in four New York newspapers today by Donald J. Trump calling for reinstatement of the death penalty grew out of the real-estate developer's ''deep-seated feeling that what's happening in society today has to be stopped,'' Mr. Trump said in a telephone interview Saturday.

title: Continental's Child Fares Are Matched
description: Seeking to lure vacationers away from their cars and onto airplanes, the big air carriers have scrambled to follow the lead of Continental Airlines and offer discount fares that allow children to fly free or nearly free this summer.

title: 'Think Globally, Act Locally,' Hoffman Said Let the 60's Rest
description: To the Editor:

title: At 80, Phipps Hopes Easy Goer Closes Chapter on Derby
description: AT the crest of the blacktop road that winds amid the woodlands of his Long Island estate, past the stone pillars and around the circular driveway, through the front door of the brick mansion and down the hall in the wood-paneled library, Ogden Phipps is looking at a notebook.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Tailoring Your Outdoor Adventures
description: LEAD: IT is never too early to start planning your outdoor vacation.

title: What, When and Where of the School-Board Vote
description: Amid accusations of misdeeds and mismanagement on some New York City community school boards, city voters and parents of children in the public-school system will vote tomorrow for members of the 32 decentralized community school boards. At stake are 288 seats, 9 on each local board. The elections are the eighth since the system was decentralized in 1970 to provide community control of local schools. Education officials and community leaders have pushed for more community involvement in the elections in hopes of insuring that people concerned with education, not politics or personal gain, will be elected. Here are answers to some of the most frequent questions about the elections: Who Can Vote and Where All registered voters - those who are registered to vote in general elections - can vote in the school elections. There are three million such eligible voters. In addition, those who have registered as ''parent voters'' are also eligible. Those include parents of children in the public schools who are not United States citizens and thus not able to vote in general elections as well as parents who have children attending a public school in a district other than where they live and who want to vote in the other district. There are 55,000 parent voters.

title: Let Settlers Shoot, Israelis Ask
description: Responding to increasing violence in the occupied territories between Palestinians and Jewish settlers, two Israeli Cabinet ministers demanded today that the settlers be allowed to shoot more freely in clashes with Arabs.

title: A Rocket With Finesse
description: Twenty years ago, Rod (the Rocket) Laver became the only tennis player to win the Grand Slam twice. The left-hander, who first accomplished this amazing feat in 1962, repeated it in 1969 by using a variety of strokes - cross-court volleys, pinpoint lobs and soft drop shots -rarely seen in this day of the blistering forehands and two-handed backhands.

title: Body of Young Woman Is Discovered in a Park
description: A 19-year-old woman was found strangled in Fort Tryon Park in the Inwood section of Manhattan on Saturday morning, the police said.

title: Strong Medicine for Weak S & L's
description: The savings and loan rescue taking shape in Congress improves on President Bush's original plan by making the owners and stockholders of savings and loan associations risk more of their own money and less of the public's. But the House Banking Committee now threatens to weaken the plan with exemptions and a tacked-on subsidy scheme for low-cost housing. Loopholes and piggy-backing only invite more trouble.

title: Arafat: Yes and No to Elections
description: Israel's Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir, has presented a plan for Israeli-supervised elections in the occupied territories. The elections would produce Palestinian representatives who would negotiate with Israel on interim autonomy for the West Bank and Gaza Strip. He did not address what, if anything, might follow the interim arrangement. Israel's Foreign Minister, Moshe Arens, said later that the interim period would serve as a ''test of cooperation and co-existence.'' It would be ''followed by negotiations on the final settlement, in which Israel will be prepared to discuss any option.''

title: 14 Sewer Plant Permits Are Ruled Illegal
description: The state water-pollution permits that New York City needs to operate its 14 sewage treatment plants were issued in violation of the law, according to a ruling issued last week.

title: Question Box
description: Hubbell vs. Spahn Q. Did Warren Spahn ever win a game against Carl Hubbell? A. By the time Spahn started winning games in the National League, and he won 363 of them, Hubbell was starting his second year of retirement after notching 253 victories, all in the National League. The two Hall of Fame left-handers had one season in common, 1942, when Hubbell's career was in its twilight and Spahn's was dawning. Hubbell, who turned 39 years old that season, won 11 games for the New York Giants, then was 4-4 in 1943 before calling it a career. Spahn, 21 years old, neither won nor lost a game for the Boston Braves in 1942, and in the four games he got into, he didn't win much praise, either: 15 innings pitched, 25 hits and 11 walks allowed, and an earned run average of 5.74.

title: Louisiana Crushes Tax Overhaul In a Defeat Damaging to Governor
description: Gov. Buddy Roemer's tax overhaul package, which would have shifted the burden from business, was handed a crushing defeat Saturday by voters who bridled at prospects of higher taxes.

title: Nancy Shadick, Physician, Weds
description: Dr. Nancy Ann Shadick and Dr. William Lawrence Marshall, residents in internal medicine at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, were married yesterday by the Rev. Orlanda Brugnola, a Unitarian minister, at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club in Scarborough, N.Y.

title: Treatment of Carriage Horses Is a Blight on New York's Image
description: To the Editor:

title: Tucker Enjoys Shot's Reality
description: Did Rick Pitino really dream that Trent Tucker would beat the Philadelphia 76ers with a 3-point shot? Or did he tell Tucker of the dream before the game as a motivational ploy to pull the leader of the team's ''Bomb Squad'' out of a slump?

title: INSIDE
description: Cracking the Japan Scandal The dark-suited, unsmiling men of the Tokuso, the Tokyo special prosecutors' office, last week helped topple the Government. They gained praise, and some criticism, for their handling of a corruption scandal. Page A8. Revising the '92 Script The battle for the Democratic Presidential nomination in 1992 will be dramatically different from the last two campaigns if Jesse Jackson decides to run for Mayor of Washington.

title: Deborah Yourish Weds A. J. Porges
description: At Temple Beth Shalom in Roslyn, L.I., Dr. Deborah Miriam Yourish and Andrew Jay Porges, both graduates of the Cornell University Medical College and doctors at New York Hospital, were married yesterday by Rabbi Joseph P. Sternstein. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Yourish of Lido Beach, L.I. The bridegroom's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Irwin G. Porges of Searingtown, L.I.

title: A Land of Heated Sewers
description: Long before oil hit the beaches of southeastern Alaska, the industry had dumped something else here on the northern edge of the state: money, by the hundreds of millions of dollars each year, into the local government.

title: Lisa Pam Yarvis Weds Richard J. Sobelsohn
description: Lisa Pam Yarvis, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Martin R. Yarvis of Long Beach, L.I., was married in Cedarhurst, L.I., yesterday to Richard Jon Sobelsohn, a son of Mrs. Arthur Gladstone of Shelter Island, L.I., and the late William Sobelsohn. Rabbi Morris Feldman performed the ceremony at Temple Beth-El.

title: Walkout at Tavern on Green
description: A long-simmering labor dispute erupted yesterday when dozens of workers at the Tavern on the Green restaurant in Central Park walked off the job. Warner LeRoy, who operates the restaurant, issued a statement acknowledging that some workers had walked out. ''We are hiring a new staff and we will be open for business as usual on Monday,'' he said. A union spokesman did not immediately return a telephone message. But a management employee and a union worker, both of whom did not want to be identified, said that the dispute involved employees' choice of a union and a recent dismissal of a union shop steward.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Credit Card Shift to Chiat
description: Facing intense competition from Visa and Mastercard, as well as from its own products, American Express switched its $25 million gold card account on Friday from McCann-Erickson to Chiat/Day, New York, and its unit, Perkins/Butler Direct Marketing.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * American Express Co., the financial services company, named Edwin M. Cooperman president and chief executive of the North American division of its American Express Travel Related Services Co. subsidiary.

title: First Inaugural Address Was Very Private Affair
description: In the first inaugural address by a President of the United States, delivered 200 years ago yesterday, George Washington established a pattern followed by many of his successors - trying to heal a deeply split nation.

title: Whither Europe?
description: ''Whither Europe?'' is a question that usually causes great, jaw-locking yawns in the U.S. But in a few years, the nations of Western Europe are scheduled to come together in some vast Single Market that some fear will rival economic superpowers like the U.S. and Japan. Time now to size up the myth and reality of ''1992.''

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the target release dates for major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday Construction Spending March Tuesday New-Home Sales March Factory Orders March Wednesday New-Car Sales April Productivity 1st Qtr. Thursday None Friday Employment April Consumer Credit March

title: What Kids Who Aren't Wolves Say About Wilding
description: LEAD: ''She was every bit as vibrant and as vernal as a flower in the spring,'' was the way her former professor at Yale described the young woman who was chased, thrown to the ground, dragged, hit with a brick and a lead pipe, raped, slashed and left for dead in Central Park, two-thirds of the blood drained from her body.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Evert Upset by 15-Year-Old: Monica Seles proved yesterday that she was better at playing tennis than figuring the odds. Seles, 15 years old and unlisted in the world ranking because she has played only five professional events, won her first pro tournament, upsetting top-seeded Chris Evert, 3-6, 6-1, 6-4, in the Virginia Slims of Houston tournament. On Saturday, she had given herself only a 5 percent chance of winning. As it turned out, that's all she needed. ''Even in the first set today, I didn't think I had a chance to win,'' Seles said. ''In the second set I loosened up a bit and played better on a few points than Chris.''(AP) Mancini Tops Becker: Alberto Mancini of Argentina outlasted Boris Becker of West Germany, 7-5, 2-6, 7-6, 7-5, yesterday to win the Monte Carlo Open in a match that lasted more than four hours.(AP) Kelesi Is Beaten: Second-seeded Arantxa Sanchez of Spain defeated top-seeded Helen Kelesi of Canada, 6-2, 5-7, 6-1, yesterday in the final of the tournament at the Royal Tennis Club of Barcelona.(AP) GOLF Geiberger and Henning Win: Al Geiberger and Harold Henning birdied the final three holes yesterday to take a one-shot victory over Bob Charles and Bruce Devlin in the Legends of Golf tournament with a record-tying 29-under-par total. Their 72-hole score of 251 tied the record set in 1987 by Orville Moody and Bruce Crampton.(AP) Postlewait Triumphs: Kathy Postlewait shot a final round three-under-par 69 yesterday to post a one-stroke victory over Val Skinner in the L.P.G.A. Sara Lee Classic. She finished with a 13-under-par 203 and collected a first-place check of $63,750, the biggest on the tour for a 54-hole tournament.(AP) HOCKEY Finland Routs U.S.: Finland rallied from two goals down to defeat the United States, 6-2, yesterday to clinch fifth place in the world championships. The United States team finished in sixth place with a 4-1-5 won-tied-lost record.(AP) HORSE RACING Proud Puppy Stays Unbeaten: Proud Puppy, ridden by Jose Santos, remained undefeated in five career starts with a seven-length victory yesterday in the $87,300 Bouwerie Stakes for 3-year-old fillies at Aqueduct. Tim's Lady was runner-up in the field of six, a half-length ahead of Twixt Appeal. Proud Puppy sped seven furlongs on the good track in 1:23 4/5 to earn $52,380 for Paul Labe and returned $3.40, $3 and $2.60 across the board as the odds-on choice.

title: Greensboro Journal; Croquet Finds a Home Deep in Rural Georgia
description: The clink of champagne glasses and the thwack of wooden mallets on plastic croquet balls are hardly sounds common to rural Georgia, but they mingled here today. The game favored by the landed gentry of 19th-century England, which has its own blue-blood pedigree in the United States, has found a home in this community halfway between Atlanta and Augusta.

title: Mets' Streak Ends in Loss To the Astros
description: Some things simply do not figure. David Cone does not struggle in the third inning; the Mets do not normally succumb to Dave Smith in the ninth. But today at the Astrodome, both happened.

title: Group Recalls Its Memories Of Holocaust
description: Several thousand people, many of them Holocaust survivors and their families, gathered in midtown Manhattan yesterday to honor the victims of the Holocaust and to commemorate the anniversary of the Warsaw ghetto uprising in which Polish Jews fought the Nazis in 1943.

title: Wilkerson Powers Cubs Past Padres
description: Curt Wilkerson doubled and tripled, scored two runs and drove in another today to lead the Chicago Cubs to a 7-3 victory over the San Diego Padres.

title: In Kabul, Bitterness Toward the U.S. Is Emerging
description: When foreigners entered the sunny courtyard of Baz Mohammed Mohmand's home on a hillside above Kabul today, there was a moment of agitation. ''It was one of their rockets!'' cried Sayed Ibrahim, Mr. Mohmand's 22-year-old son-in-law, motioning toward visitors who had been introduced as coming from the United States. ''Why should they come in here?'' In reality, the projectile that struck the home on Thursday morning, killing Mr. Mohmand, who was a senior official of the Bank of Afghanistan, two daughters and a son, was almost certainly a 107-millimeter rocket manufactured in China. Packed with shrapnel and designed to shower jagged metal shards over a wide area, the Chinese rockets have become the favored weapon for many of the guerrilla bands besieging Afghanistan's towns and cities.

title: British Papers Intensify Fight for Sunday Reader
description: Fierce competition for readers and scoops is transforming the high end of the Sunday newspaper scene in Britain.

title: Gun on Warship Is Reported To Have Misfired Before Blast
description: A 16-inch gun in the battleship Iowa's No. 1 turret misfired shortly before the fatal explosion in the turret behind it, The Virginian-Pilot and Ledger-Star reported today.

title: British Ad Group Bids for Ogilvy; Deal Would Create No. 2 Agency
description: The WPP Group P.L.C., the British holding company that two years ago executed a hostile takeover of J. Walter Thompson, has opened an assault on another venerable American advertising company, the Ogilvy Group.

title: Chevrier Helps Recharge Hawks
description: Alain Chevrier does not like to think about last year's Stanley Cup playoffs. Demoted at season's end to the No. 3 goalie for the Devils, Chevrier dressed for the playoff games in street clothes and watched the action from the grandstand.

title: David Rothstein
description: Dr. David Rothstein, a general practitioner in Jackson Heights, Queens, for 50 years, died of bone cancer Friday at his home in Southbury, Conn. He was 88 years old.

title: Royal Par Industries reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
Taipei Official Visits China Unofficially
description: Forty years after Communist forces sent China's Nationalist Government fleeing to Taiwan, Taiwan's Finance Minister today became the first Taiwan Government official to return.

description: See accompanying notes for speical items.(Loss) *Loss in year-earlier period.

description: The Eglevsky Ballet presented a program of oddities in Adams Playhouse at Hofstra University tonight. Not the least of these oddities was the rarely seen ''Carnival in Venice,'' also known as ''Satanella,'' choreographed by Marius Petipa to a grandiloquent score by Cesare Pugni.

title: Death Penalty Law in Illinois Struck Down
description: A Federal judge struck down the death penalty law in Illinois today, raising doubts about the fate of 121 prisoners on the state's death row.

title: Park Tavern Finds Pickets On the Menu
description: The tuxedoed waiters of Tavern on the Green, who usually thread their way past crowded tables, were outside the Central Park restaurant yesterday, marching on a picket line. And the customers inside were standing on a buffet line.

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Vernitron in Accord To Buy Kollmorgen
description: LEAD: After months of pursuit, the Vernitron Corporation, a manufacturer of electromechanical equipment, succeeded in reaching an agreement yesterday to buy the Kollmorgen Corporation for $25 a share, or $320 million.

description: To the Editor:

More Still Unites Than Divides Blacks and Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: OSHA Seeks $1 Million Fine For Contractors in Explosion
description: The Labor Department today cited two contractors for safety and health violations and proposed $1.15 million in fines for a methane gas explosion that killed three workers in a sewer tunnel project.

title: Market Place; Major Test Looms At Western Union
description: A YEAR and a half after it was restructured, a slowly recovering Western Union Corporation faces a major test. Unless it can quickly persuade bondholders it is moving toward financial health, it may not be able to do so.

title: Algo Group Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Warning On Trade 'Bashing'
description: President Bush's chief economist, Michael J. Boskin, warned today that ''bashing'' trade partners like Japan could lead to a trade war and a recession.

title: Analytical Surveys reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Corrections
description: A picture caption in SportsMonday this week about horse racing misidentified the race won by Bold Ruler. It was the 1956 Futurity at Belmont Park, for 2-year-olds, not the Belmont Stakes, which he lost in 1957 as a 3-year-old.

title: Film Theme Park Opened by Disney
description: The Walt Disney Company opened its $400 million Disney-MGM Studios theme park today. The 135-acre complex blends film making with backstage studio tours and ride-through, walk-through attractions. Movie and TV production began last summer on its three sprawling sound studios and back-lot street scenes.

title: Japanese Wage Growth
description: The average Japanese worker's monthly wage climbed 3.6 percent after inflation in the last fiscal year, the highest real growth rate in 14 years, the Labor Ministry said today. The wage rose to 343,716 yen, or $2,565, in the fiscal year ended March 31. The last time real growth in wages was higher was in the 1974 fiscal year, when it climbed 5.9 percent. The wage figure includes twice-a-year bonuses, overtime pay and various allowances.

title: Q&A
description: Logic of Fahrenheit Q.If the centigrade (or Celsius) and Kelvin temperature scales are based on natural phenomena like the freezing and boiling points of water and absolute zero, what is the logical basis for the Fahrenheit scale? A.Daniel Gabriel Fahrenheit, who devised the scale, wanted natural reference points, but he did not choose wisely, said James Schooley of the National Institute of Standards and Technology.

title: Flyers Stun Canadiens in Opener
description: Rick Tocchet played hurt, Derrick Smith played cannily and Ken Wregget played worried as the Philadelphia Flyers once again made do without Ron Hextall.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Crystal Brands Inc., Southport, Conn., an apparel maker, appointed Richard P. Thrush vice president and controller.

title: Nobody Tells the Truth
description: Nobody is telling the truth. In weeks of arguments and pronouncements about West Germany, NATO, the Soviet Union and short-range nuclear weapons, no diplomat, politician or national leader has had the courage to say plainly what lies beneath it all. It is this fear: West Germany, already the dominant economic power in Western Europe, will use the Gorbachev openings to become the dominant economic power in Eastern and Central Europe as well. Huge amounts of West German money and technology will pour into the Soviet Union and its allies, leading to a West German-Soviet economic and political alliance.

description: b-Net income The company said revenue figures in the latest quarter included results from recently acquired U.S. subsidiaries. Results are in Canadian dollars.

description: John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, said in an interview broadcast Sunday that documentary evidence clears President Bush of accusations that he sought aid for the Nicaraguan rebels at a 1985 meeting with the President of Honduras.

title: The Liberal Party in New York Has Always Been About Choice

description: Herbert H. Denton Jr., The Washington Post's correspondent in Canada, died of pneumonia Saturday at a hospital in Toronto. He was 45 years old and suffered from AIDS.

description: In the high reaches of the Japanese Government, many officials know both English and the United States. Few senior American officials know Japanese or Japan.
