Judge Permits U.S. To Order Shrimpers To Help Sea Turtles
description: The Government can require Atlantic and Gulf Coast shrimpers to equip their nets with a device intended to save sea turtles in danger of extinction, a Federal judge ruled today.

title: Gerald Wilkinson, 50, Indian Youth Director
description: Gerald Wilkinson, executive director of the National Indian Youth Council, died last Thursday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington after suffering a heart attack while on a business trip. He was 50 years old and lived in Albuquerque, N. M. Mr. Wilkinson, a Cherokee Catawba Indian, was born in Statesville, N. C., and attended Duke University and the Columbia University Law School.

title: Charles Punia
description: Charles Punia, a New York real-estate developer for more than 60 years, died Wednesday at his home in Brooklyn after a long illness. He was 86 years old.

title: AIDS Drug Wins Support
description: A Food and Drug Administration advisory committee unanimously recommended today that the agency give final marketing approval to a drug to prevent AIDS-related pneumonia.

title: Dollar at 1989 High vs. Yen Despite Action by 2 Nations
description: The dollar rose yesterday, hitting its highest level of the year against the yen despite dollar selling by the Federal Reserve and unusual intervention by the Bank of Japan.

title: CNW to Discuss Bid With Japonica
description: The CNW Corporation, the railroad holding company that is the target of Japonica Partners, said it would meet with its suitor to discuss the offer but also said it would scout for other ways to maximize shareholder value. Shares of CNW, which operates the Chicago and North Western Transportation Company, rose $1, to $43.25 yesterday, in active trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Prosecution Case to Reopen In 'Night Stalker' Murders
description: A witness against the defendant in the ''Night Stalker'' serial murder trial failed to tell the whole truth, the prosecutor in the case disclosed today.

title: 2 Killed as Renewed Fighting Threatens Truce in Lebanon
description: Fighting with artillery and rockets broke out again today between Muslim and Christian forces in the capital, threatening a three-day-old cease-fire called by the Arab League.

title: Insituform Gulf South Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Service for Harold Hayes
description: A service for Harold T. P. Hayes, a former editor of Esquire magazine, will be held Monday at 11 A.M. in the auditorium of McGraw-Hill Inc. at 1221 Avenue of the Americas, at 48th Street. The magazine will sponsor the service for Mr. Hayes, who died on April 5 in Los Angeles at the age of 62.

title: Bowdoin Prepares a Travel Guide for Tourney
description: Tournament time is near and Bowdoin College has a problem, one that could mean playing four games within five days and bus trips galore.

title: Some at CUNY See Possible Tuition Rise As Albany Betrayal
description: The protests that continue to disrupt the City University of New York system have been fueled by a growing perception among students, especially minority-group members, that the university is slowly abandoning its historic mission to educate the working-class, student protesters say.

title: For Fall, Attention Shifts to the Legs
description: Legs. They are what's left to look at when the skirt vanishes. When Karl Lagerfeld subtracted the skirt from his longer Chanel suits recently in Paris, he acknowledged what trendy young people are wearing in all the world's fashion capitals: jackets plus tights or skinny pants.

title: Philip Spina, 93, Dies; Tile Company Founder
description: Philip Spina, the founder and retired president of Standard Tile, one of the country's largest tile distributors, died of complications from a fall on Sunday at Mercy Hospital in Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 93 years old and lived in Rockville Centre.

title: Raw Fish Warning
description: Surgeons operating on a young man for what they thought was appendicitis found a rude surprise instead: a two-inch-long red worm.

title: N.F.L. Considers Making Changes at the Top
description: The search for a new commissioner to succeed Pete Rozelle is part of a plan to reorganize the National Football League's management.

title: Frank Gehry Wins Award In Architecture
description: Frank O. Gehry, the Los Angeles-based architect whose work is noted for its harsh, unfinished materials and its juxtaposition of simple, almost primal geometric forms, became the 12th winner of the Pritzker Architecture Prize yesterday. One of architecture's most prestigious awards, the $100,000 prize was established in 1979 by the Pritzker family, owners of the Hyatt hotel chain.

title: General Trustco of Canada Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Ketema Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $7,877,000 for the quarter and $12,559,000 for the year. The losses from discontinued operations for the quarter and year included a $6.5 million charge for the phaseout of Symult Systems Corp. The latest year also included a $1.6 million charge associated with the company's spinoff from Ametek Inc., completed Dec. 1, 1988.

title: The Germans Need A Nuclear Arsenal
description: LEAD: Rather than bicker with Bonn over one nuclear issue after another, the Bush Administration should withdraw the United States promise of providing a nuclear ''umbrella'' for Europe. At the same time, Washington should encourage Bonn to build is own limited but credible nuclear arsenal to deter a Soviet attack.

title: W. Paul Stillman is Dead at 91; Banker Led Newark Preservation
description: W. Paul Stillman, a banker, insurance company executive and major force in the preservation of downtown Newark, died Sunday at Mountainside Hospital in Glen Ridge, N.J. He was 91 years old and lived in Fair Haven, N.J.

title: F.B.I. Examines Actions of Police at Arizona State
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation is examining the conduct of the Arizona State University campus police in an April 15 incident in which two black students were handcuffed and said they were bullied by officers as a crowd of white students yelled racial slurs.

title: Altex Resources Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Perkins Family Restaurants reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: PATTERNS
description: J. Crew Goes Retail

title: U.S. Facing A Struggle After Victory
description: The uninspiring performance of the United States in its World Cup qualifying game against Costa Rica Sunday substantiated Coach Bob Gansler's claim that the Americans have a long way to go before they can be considered the favorite in their battle with four other nations in the region.

title: USX to Modernize Plant in Gary, Ind.
description: The USX Corporation's. chairman, David M. Roderick, told shareholders at the annual meeting that the company planned to spend $240 million to modernize its largest plant, at Gary, Ind. The keystone of the improvements will be a continuous slab caster designed to shape 1.6 million tons of molten steel directly into slabs, using less energy and less time and leaving fewer blemishes in the steel.

title: Navy Relieves Ship Captain
description: The commander of a Newport-based frigate that collided with another ship 12 days ago has been relieved of his duties on the frigate, the Navy said today. Comdr. Lewis Athow of the frigate Trippe was temporarily assigned to Naval Surface Group 4 in Newport, the Navy said.

title: Strictest Rules On Water Use Are Imposed
description: New York City yesterday imposed the most stringent drought-emergency measures of an arid spring and also began drawing millions of gallons of water from the Hudson River to handle what could be the worst water shortage in the city's history.

title: Magma Power Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Magma's latest first quarter results included for the first time its 50 percent share of operating results of the partnerships which own two newly constructed geothermal power plants.

title: Nuclear Metals Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Farmer Brothers Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Wendy's International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
description: The latest first quarter results included a one-time $5,191,000 gain from an accounting change and an extraordinary gain on the early extinguishment of debt of $339,000.

title: Making Things Worse
description: Will the brutal attack on a jogger by youths rampaging through Central Park be an issue in the New York City mayoral primaries and election? Almost certainly it will, to the city's detriment, though probably no mayor could have prevented this random crime - including the one to be elected in November, whatever he might promise in the interim.

title: Portec Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Mandarich Absent
description: The Green Bay Packers' Tony Mandarich, the 315-pound offensive lineman from Michigan State who was the second overall choice in the National Football League's college draft last month, did not appear yesterday at a Packer mini-camp for rookies and free agents started in Green Bay, Wis. Vern Sharbaugh of Cleveland, Mandarich's agent, said the lineman did not show up because he was still unsigned and had not been able to get a physical examination to complete an insurance policy with Lloyd's of London.(AP)

title: INSIDE
description: Many Experiments, No Proof of Fusion Physicists said many experiments have failed to validate a claim that nuclear fusion had been achieved in a jar of water. Those unable to repeat the experiment included the California Institute of Technology and the Oak Ridge National Laboratory. Science Times, page C1. New Drought Measures New York City imposed more stringent restrictions to cope with what could be the worst water shortage in its history. Page B1. Total 'Ring' Immersion A milestone at the Metropolitan Opera: the weeklong performance of Wagner's ''Ring'' cycle. Donal Henahan's review is on Page C15.

title: House Panel Sticks to Tough Savings Guidelines
description: In its third day of deliberations on the Bush savings rescue plan, the House Banking Committee today beat back a major challenge to the tough capital provisions it approved last week.

title: General Automation Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary gains of $19,000 for the quarter and $279,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss d-After extraordinary gains of $182,000 and $672,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: Review/Opera; After a Week of Total Immersion, Some Reflections on the Met 'Ring'
description: At a time when many new productions of ''Der Ring des Nibelungen'' might be more aptly entitled ''Der Ringling des Barnum und Bailey,'' the Metropolitan Opera's staging of Wagner's epic has cast a vote for the notion that maybe, just maybe, the composer knew best. Since September 1986, when the Otto Schenk staging began taking shape with a ''Walkure'' that tried to respect that peculiar idea, the Metropolitan's trend-bucking project has aroused widespread suspicion, even resentment. ''Traditional,'' ''conventional,'' ''regressive'' and ''childishly representational'' were some of the nicer epithets thrown about in lobbies and in print.

title: GSW Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Robert Half International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest quarter net results included gains of $360,000 from the repurchase of 7.25 percent convertible subordinated debentures.

title: Western Micro Technology reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Sega Account Goes to Bozell
description: Sega, a Japanese-owned video game manufacturer, awarded its $10 million advertising account yesterday to the Los Angeles office of Bozell. The agency prevailed over

title: PBS and 2 of Its Affiliates Dispute Film on Palestinians
description: Two New York City affiliates of the Public Broadcasting Service have become involved in a dispute between a documentary film maker and PBS over a film about the plight of the Palestinians.

title: Baldwin & Lyons reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Raymond Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago first quarter results included a gain from an accounting change of $1,489,000, or 25 cents a share.

title: Ben & Jerry's Pact
description: Ben & Jerry's Homemade Inc. has agreed with Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream Inc. to have some of its ice cream made at Dreyer's Indiana plant. James Miller, general manager for Ben & Jerry's, said that the company had exhausted its capacity and that demand for the ice cream was far outstripping supply.

title: WPL Holdings Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
As Farms Falter, Rural Homelessness Grows
description: In a steady stream driven by bleak economics in America's farm country, a new class of homeless people is emerging from rural areas: farm families and others who are out of work because farms are faltering.

title: PhoneMate Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Corrections
description: The Guide column in the Westchester Weekly last Sunday gave incorrect dates for two performances of the opera ''La Cenerentola'' by the Bronx Opera Company. It will be performed at Lehman College Theater on May 12 and 13, not this Friday and Saturday, and at Hunter College Playhouse in Manhattan on May 19 and 20.

title: Joslyn Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Japanese to Buy Hotel Bel-Air
description: A Japanese hotel operator has agreed to purchase the landmark Hotel Bel-Air here from the Rosewood Property Company of Dallas for about $110 million, Rosewood said today.

title: New Campaign Fund Law Starts Shakily in New York
description: New York City's new campaign finance law got off to a shaky start yesterday as a score of candidates who were scheduled to make their initial campaign financial reports had to get extensions instead.

title: Anne S. Glushien, 72, Artist and Translator
description: Anne Sorele Williams Glushien, an artist and translator, died of Alzheimer's disease Sunday at her home in Great Neck, L.I. She was 72 years old.

title: Kirwan, Chairman Of State Democrats, Says He Will Resign
description: The Democratic state chairman, Laurence J. Kirwan, said yesterday that he would resign his position and recommend the committee's executive director, John A. Marino, as his successor.

title: San Francisco Journal; Undercurrent of Ill Will Grows With Chinatown
description: A visitor to this city's North Beach neighborhood could easily assume that the traditionally Italian community and its recently arrived Chinese neighbors have settled into the most harmonious blending of cultures since Marco Polo helped turn the Orient's noodles into Italy's spaghetti.

title: Mabaie Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Atlantic Southeast Airlines Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Ex-C.I.A. Aide Is Arraigned
description: The former Central Intelligence Agency station chief in Costa Rica, Joseph Fernandez, pleaded not guilty today to four criminal charges in connection with his role in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Max Gewirtz, 98, a Retired School Official
description: Max Gewirtz, a retired assistant superintendent of New York City schools, died of pneumonia yesterday at Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 98 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Remember Roosevelt, Not What He Wanted
description: With mortality on his mind on the day of a relative's funeral in 1941, President Franklin D. Roosevelt broached the issue of memorials with Justice Felix Frankfurter of the Supreme Court.

title: Baker Would Ask Cutoff of Funds If U.N. Agencies Upgrade P.L.O.
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that he would urge President Bush to withhold United States financial contributions from any United Nations agencies that grant full membership to the state recently proclaimed by the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Abduction of 2d Baby Reported by Couple
description: A couple has reported that their infant daughter was kidnapped, three years after they reported the abduction of another baby girl in another town, the authorities say.

title: High Court to Consider Detroit Papers' Deal
description: The Supreme Court agreed yesterday to consider whether Detroit's two daily newspapers should be allowed to merge their business operations under an exemption from Federal antitrust law.

title: Fretter Inc reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
Florida Public Utility reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $431,000 from an accounting change.

title: Indiana Pastor and 3 in Family Are Found Slain
description: A minister, his wife and two of their children were found dead in the church parsonage Sunday, and the police said all appeared to have been shot at close range by the same weapon.

title: Trustcorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
American Filtrona reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Self-Serve Gas Banned Again
description: New Jersey's 40-year ban on self-service gasoline stations received a boost today as the State Senate overwhelmingly passed a bill retaining it. Supporters said the measure, passed 32 to 4, is meant to meet a judicial test of the ban. Sponsors said self-service would mean higher prices and inconvenience and would jeopardize smaller stations and hurt senior citizens who have difficulty pumping gas. Only New Jersey and Oregon ban self-service stations.

title: Suncoast Savings & Loan reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Matec Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The latest first quarter loss included an after-tax restructuring charge of $192,000.

title: Saratoga Processing reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Cuts Are Studied in Louisiana
description: Gov. Buddy Roemer said today that budget reductions forced by rejection of a tax overhaul package will ''go beyond common sense,'' adding that he is studying closing some universities and hospitals.

title: S.E.C. Levies $469,763 Fine in Revco Case
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today imposed for the first time a monetary penalty on someone who had passed along insider information to friends who profited from the knowledge but who did not profit himself.

title: Eldon Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Our Towns; Colt Strikers See Reason for Hope In 'For Sale' Sign
description: The last time Robert Trinks punched a clock at the Colt Industries firearms plant was on Jan. 23, 1986. He has been on strike ever since. So have about 750 of the company's 1,100 workers. The rest quit. Or crossed the picket line. Or died. Twenty-five have died so far. ''I don't know anyone who has given up on the strike in the past year except guys who died,'' Mr. Trinks said. ''And you can't argue with that.''

title: In Wake of Attack, Students Gather to Seek Harmony
description: With the city's emotions still raw two weeks after an attack on a jogger by a group of teen-agers in Central Park, about 200 New York City public-school students, teachers and officials gathered in the park yesterday to appeal for harmony in a ceremony of songs and speeches.

title: Jogger's Outlook Better, Doctors Say
description: The jogger who was raped and beaten by rampaging teen-agers last month in Central Park has improved substantially, and experts said yesterday that it was likely she would survive and leave the hospital to live independently. But it is also likely, they added, that she will have at least some permanent brain damage.

title: General Looks Like Winner in Paraguay Election
description: Gen. Andres Rodriguez, the army commander who ended 35 years of dictatorship with a coup in February, appeared this morning to have won an overwhelming victory in Paraguay's presidential elections.

title: EAC Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $2,806,000 and $1,404,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $1,019,000 for the quarter and $1,472,000 for the year. The company said the losses from discontinued operations resulted primarily from the discontinuance of its Stalker Corporation subsidiary, which was sold on April 20, 1989.

title: Coherent Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Berkeley Undergraduates to Take Courses on Ethnic Groups
description: Students at the University of California at Berkeley, where no one ethnic group is a majority among undergraduates, will be required to take a comparative course on American ethnic groups to graduate beginning in 1991.

title: Environmental Control Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Business and Health; A.T.&T.'s Effort To Curb Costs
description: IN bargaining that could set a pattern for many large corporations with strong unions, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company is calling on its employees to pay a larger share of their health-care expenses.

title: Richmond Top Rookie
description: Mitch Richmond, who averaged 22 points in the 79 games he played for the Golden State Warriors in the regular season, was named the winner of the Eddie Gottlieb Trophy yesterday as the National Basketball Association's top rookie. The 6-foot-5-inch Richmond, a first-round draft choice from Kansas State, helped the Warriors improve their record from 20-62 last season to 43-39 and a playoff berth this season.(AP)

title: California Microwave reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
South Korea Slips on Road to Democracy
description: To the Editor:

title: Physicists Challenge Cold Fusion Claims
description: Separate experiments by many research groups have failed to validate a claim by the University of Utah to have achieved nuclear fusion in a jar of water, physicists reported today.

title: A 'Mountain Goat' for Desks Where Mice Fear to Tread
description: THE problem with mice - the computer variety - is that they need a relatively uncluttered chunk of desk space in which to roam. As the user pushes the soap bar-size mouse around the desktop, the cursor moves across the computer screen in a corresponding direction.

title: Sir John Boyd, 71, a British Union Leader
description: Sir John Boyd, a miner's son who fought off leftists to lead the powerful British union of engineering workers, died Sunday at his home in Eastbourne, south of London, the BBC said today. He was 71.

title: Electronic Tele-Communicaions Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: BTU International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Nash-Finch Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bridge
description: When a young team wins two significant events within a short period it is reasonable to conclude that the players are on their way to the top. Judith Fields, Mamdouh Guenena, John Scheuermann and Mark Lake, all of Manhattan, captured the Flight B Regional Swiss Teams in Hofstra, L.I., on April 2. Five weeks earlier, with Mark Stratton playing instead of Lake, they had won the Flight B Grand National Team title and qualified for playoffs in Chicago in July. All five players are members of the Culbertson Club at 24 Fifth Avenue in Manhattan.

title: Oregon Steel Mills reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $639,000 from an accounting change. The shares outstanding reflected the sale by the company in April 1988 of 2,104 shares of common stock.

title: O'Reilly Quits Post As Bruins' Coach
description: Citing a desire to spend more time with his family, Terry O'Reilly resigned yesterday after more than two seasons as coach of the Boston Bruins.

title: Williams Cos reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain from discontinued operations of $94,900,000.

title: Worldcorp Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included net from discontinued operations of $3,200,000.

title: Czech Gold Venture
description: Czechoslovakia is negotiating with four foreign companies on a joint venture to resume gold mining near Prague, a geological official was quoted as saying last week. Talks with the companies, including two from Australia, involve an operation that would start in 1991, with an estimated potential of 100 tons of gold, said the official, Josef Pravda, head of the Czech Geological Bureau. The names of the companies were not disclosed. Gold has not been mined in Czechoslovakia on a substantial scale for decades.

title: Commodore International Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $600,000 for the quarter and $7,600,000 for the 9 months.

title: The Worm and the Apple; Hampers, and Pampers, in the Park
description: A Ton of Manure

title: 'Rocket-High' Knicks Go for the Knockout
description: The crush in the Philadelphia 76ers' dressing room after their 107-106 loss to the Knicks Saturday was beginning to subside. Off in the corner, Maurice Cheeks was still in uniform; so was Charles Barkley, a towel over his head.

title: Anti-Apartheid Worker Killed
description: A white anti-apartheid campaigner was shot and killed today outside his home by an assailant firing from a passing car, the police said.

title: Playboy Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $84,000 for both periods, and a tax credit of $159,000 and $894,000 for the latest quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,716,000 and $1,634,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and a tax credit of $447,000 and $2,204,000 for the same periods, respectively. The year-ago third quarter net from continuing operations included income of $610,000 from a federal income tax refund.

title: Investor Buying Texas Air Stock
description: Michael H. Steinhardt, a New York money manager, has again acquired more than a 5 percent stake in the Texas Air Corporation.

title: Impatience Not a Virtue For Yanks
description: With the impatience of a midtown Manhattan cab driver at rush hour or a celebrated Tampa shipbuilder at any hour, the Yankees decided that Al Leiter was not worth waiting for. And now the Toronto Blue Jays will mine the potential of the 23-year-old left-hander after a trade for Jesse Barfield, a right fielder of diminishing returns since 1986 when he hit 40 homers and drove in 108 runs.

title: Sanctions Could Double the Price of Some Japanese Goods
description: Japanese facsimile machines, telephone switchboards and cordless telephones are among the products that could face 100 percent duties, doubling their price in this country, under trade retaliation plans being formulated by the Bush Administration, trade officials said today.

title: Precision Castparts Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Shelter Components reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $156,000 loss from discontinued operations.

title: India Puts Off Missile Test
description: For the second time in two weeks, a last-minute technical hitch forced India today to postpone the scheduled test launch of a long-range missile. A Defense Ministry official said no new date had been set for a trial of the rocket, which has a striking distance of more than 1,500 miles and is to carry a one-ton technical payload.

title: Is That a Grimace? Ask a Pigeon
description: PIGEONS have been taught to recognize human facial expressions, upsetting long-held notions that only humans had evolved the sophisticated nervous systems to perform such a feat.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: ENVIRONMENT
description: President Bush and his Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, William K. Reilly, have repeatedly proclaimed American readiness to assert leadership in cleaning up the world environmental mess. And many say the Administration has played the issues cannily, demonstrating a keen sense of damage control in its first major test, Alaska, where Mr. Bush abandoned his early defense of Exxon. But the United States call to lead a global march for environmental reform has led to challenges from Congress and other world leaders to clean its own house first.

title: Jefferson-Pilot reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an investment gain of $8,006,000. c-After an investment loss of $234,000.

title: New Uprising Victims: Suspected Arab Informers
description: A Palestinian shopkeeper suspected of being an informant for Israel was stabbed to death by hooded youths today, bringing the number of accused collaborators killed by fellow Arabs in the occupied territories to six in the last week.

title: Notes and Bonds Slip in Light Day
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds slipped in thin trading yesterday, as dealers sold securities in reaction to a report from the nation's purchasing managers that suggested the economy gained some strength in April.

title: Nycor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $871,000 from early extinguishment of debt. Year-ago quarter results restated to reflect year-end adjustments for warranty and inventory.

title: Tuition Protests Spread to Most CUNY Campuses
description: Demonstrations against budget cuts and likely tuition increases spread to most campuses of the City University of New York yesterday, with students seizing more administration buildings, marching in the streets and blocking traffic in Manhattan, Queens and Brooklyn.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Rural homelessness is growing faster than we can keep track of it. People are living in railroad cars and tar paper shacks. Shelters in tiny towns we've never heard of are operating at or above capacity and are turning people away.'' -Bill Faith, head of the Ohio Coalition for the Homeless. [ A1:2. ]

title: By Design; A Scarf, as a Skirt
description: If you're good at wrapping packages, this will be a cinch. In a jiffy, you can whip up your own version of this season's stylishly sexy sarong skirt. All you need is a large scarf - preferably a pareo, roughly 57 inches by 72 inches - a full-length mirror and a little practice.

title: Plains Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago quarter results are restated to reflect applicaiton of pooling-of-interests accounting for the 1988 acquisition of Midland Resources.

title: Judge Warns of Mistrial if Secrets Used in North Case Are Disclosed
description: The judge in the trial of Oliver L. North said today that he might declare a mistrial if news organizations succeeded in their effort to force disclosure of a classified exhibit introduced into evidence in the trial.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the dispute in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization over short-range nuclear weapons described the replacement for the Lance missile incorrectly. The new missiles are to have increased range, but not increased explosive yield.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday misidentified Dr. Danny Hillis. He is founding scientist of Thinking Machines Inc., a supercomputer manufacturer based in Cambridge, Mass. The company's president is Sheryl Handler.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-13 Which is the authentic P.L.O. voice? American officials say they are not sure, but will use the dialogue to test and strengthen the P.L.O.'s commitment to moderation. Page A1

title: Savings Bonds To Yield 7.81%
description: United States savings bonds will earn interest at a rate of 7.81 percent in the next six months, the highest rate of return in three years, the Government announced today.

title: Allied Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $78,135 gain from the cumulative effect of an accouting change.

title: WESTERN OFFICIALS ARE NOW HOPEFUL ON A NATO ACCORD
description: The elements of a compromise on the contentious issue of short-range nuclear missiles are beginning to emerge in hurried consultations among the members of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, senior diplomats from several nations say.

title: Medical Imaging Centers reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Revenue under management totaled $13,544,655 for the latest first quarter, compared with $7,531,931 for year-ago period. The company said revenue under management included revenue generated from Medical Imaging Centers it operates, but does not totally own.

title: Geriatric & Medical Centers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a gain of $5,468,000 on sale of property. c-After a gain of $1,448,000 from the sale of property for the quarter and 9 months.

title: Chinese Students Try Networking
description: Students from several Chinese cities gathered today at Beijing University to discuss plans to expand their pro-democracy movement and to form links with schools throughout the nation.

title: Review/Pop; Songs of a Lebanese Star
description: The singer Magida el-Roumi, one of Lebanon's biggest pop stars, came to Hunter College on Saturday night with a 19-piece orchestra and swarms of dancers. Miss el-Roumi, dressed in formal evening clothes, wandered between near-European pop and Middle Eastern pop, turning phrases into a flutter of windblown notes or keeping them glued to a melody. Using a talent for understatement, she made her songs into carefully calibrated shows that when she moved her hips slightly, suggesting a touch of sexuality, had the audience roaring.

The latest year included a pretax gain of $3,180,430 from writedown of long-term investments in and proxy receivables from Crazy Eddie Inc., compared to a $9,829,573 pretax gain in the prior year.

title: Carlesimo Staying Put
description: P. J. Carlesimo ended speculation that he might take the head-coaching job at Kentucky by announcing today that he would remain at Seton Hall.

title: Kashmir's Jewel Now Choked by Silt and Sewage
description: DAL LAKE, for centuries the sparkling centerpiece of Kashmir, is on the verge of ecological disaster, scientists and environmentalists say.

title: Jackson Exhorts Striking Miners in Virginia W
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson encouraged striking coal miners on Sunday to continue nonviolent civil disobedience to force concessions from Virginia's biggest coal company, saying ''we will not surrender.''

title: Data Design Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

The company said the latest quarter and 9 months operating losses are after an unrealized loss of $5,877,000 from the writedown of the company's marketable securities portfolio for both the quarter and 9 months, and provisions for the estimated loss on disposal of certain assets of $850,000 and $2,050,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: ARCO Net Rises 75.6%
description: The Atlantic Richfield Company said today that its first-quarter net income rose 75.6 percent from the period a year ago, largely because of a one-time gain from the sale of its stake in a chemical company.

title: Vote for Better Schools
description: Today, New York City voters can help make the public school system more effective for all students. Each of the city's 32 nine-member Community School Boards is up for renewal, and every registered voter, parent or not, is eligible to participate.

title: Moscow Represses Freud's Slip Into Print
description: One hundred thousand freshly printed copies of ''Essays on the Psychology of Sexuality,'' the first Soviet book of Freud's writings since the early Bolsheviks pronounced him taboo, are being held by the authorities and may never reach the reading public.

title: Careers; Building A Better Accountant
description: THE heads of the Big Eight accounting firms are not happy about the education of young people entering the profession.

title: In-State Commuting (and Woes) Rising in New Jersey
description: Admittedly 58-year-old William R. Wright of Cranford was gung-ho for mass transit. A railroad buff, veteran commuter and assistant sales manager, he had gladly taken the 40-minute train ride to Manhattan every workday for 28 years.

Yanks Name Richman
description: Arthur Richman, who left the Mets last March after serving with the team since 1965, was named the Yankees' vice president of media relations yesterday, replacing Harvey Greene.

title: Debentures Priced by Fannie Mae
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, also known as Fannie Mae, yesterday priced $500 million worth of indexed sinking-fund debentures due in 1999 through various securities dealers.

title: Quayle Meets Sihanouk to Back Him
description: Vice President Dan Quayle met here today with Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the leader of the Cambodian coalition opposed to the Vietnamese-backed Government in Phnom Penh, to show American support for the Prince before his negotiations with the Cambodian Prime Minister.

title: How to Recapture School Dropouts
description: New figures confirm that one in every four New York City public school students drops out of school, despite special programs. Schools Chancellor Richard Green voices concern over the high rate and suggests the need to restructure the system profoundly. That's a sobering conclusion but there is encouraging evidence, and a growing national consensus, that less radical approaches can do the job.

title: Deerfield Federal Savings & Loan reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Construction Outlays Fell 0.3% in March
description: Because of a sharp drop in outlays for highways, construction spending in March declined for the third consecutive month, the Government said today. It was the first time that building activity had shown such weakness since early 1981, just before the last recession.

description: b-Net loss

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Frenchwoman Gains: Christine Damas of France defeated Sabine Auer of West Germany, 6-0, 5-7, 7-5, yesterday in first-round play at the Virginia Slims tournament in Hamburg, West Germany. In other matches, Jo-Anne Faull of Australia beat Silke Frankl of West Germany, 6-3, 6-2; Nathalie Tauziat of France downed Petra Huber of Austria, 6-2, 6-2, and Silke Meier of West Germany defeated Steffi Menning, 6-2, 6-4.(AP) Azar Advances: Roberto Azar of Argentina defeated Michael Robertson, 4-6, 7-6, 7-6, yesterday in the opening round of the Nabisco men's tournament in Munich, West Germany. In other matches, Tore Meinecke of West Germany beat Jaroslav Bulant of Czechoslovakia, 7-6, 6-3; Andres Vysand of the Soviet Union eliminated Thomas Enqvist of Sweden, 6-1, 6-2; Marian Vajda of Czechoslovakia beat Christian Miniussi of Argentina, 6-4, 2-6, 6-4, and Hansjoerg Schwaier of West Germany defeated Franco Davin of Argentina 6-4, 4-6, 6-2.(AP) YACHTING Rough Seas for Regatta: The Betsy Ross Bowl, a new 10-boat regatta in New York Harbor that has attracted some of the top female sailors in the United States, got under way yesterday, but because of bad weather, only one of two scheduled races was completed. The boat being used is the J-24, a 24-foot sloop, and each one is sailed by a team of five. The winning skipper yesterday was Mary Brigden of the United States Naval Academy.

title: Arkla Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the decline in earnings per share compared to last year was largely related to warm weather and to the continued oversupply of natural gas.

title: Dreyer's Grand Ice Cream Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Feast for the Ear a la New Orleans
description: A cooling breeze across the New Orleans Fair Grounds ruffled the 10-foot-high, turquoise-and-peach feathered headdresses of the Original Yellow Jackets as they drummed and chanted about ''raisin' hell'' on Mardi Gras morning. A short stroll away, Boogie Bill Webb was plunking out a sly, lowdown blues, ''Drinkin' and Stinkin'.'' Ricky Skaggs crooned a country song about a blue heartache. Under the white roof of the gospel tent, the members of the St. Theresa Catholic Gospel Choir were praising Jesus, their gray robes swaying. Other groups - jazz, rock, blues - held forth on five other stages.

title: Grim Seeds of Park Rampage Found in East Harlem Streets
description: IN seeking to explain the savage pack attack in Central Park last month, anthropologists and sociologists who have studied East Harlem outline a chilling picture of how the street culture there could have fostered a rampage that otherwise appears senseless.

title: McDonald & Co Investments reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $314,000 from early retirement of debt.

title: Nipsco Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Worm and the Apple; Dads Change Diapers, Too
description: It took five years and $35 million to renovate the Central Park Zoo, and the city seems to have thought of just about everything to make the place comfortable for both beasts and people - except the possibility that a man might need to change a baby's diaper. The city rates a worm for its oversight.

title: Business People; A Major Realignment Set by Black & Decker
description: The Black & Decker Corporation yesterday announced a major realignment of its management in the aftermath of the company's acquisition of the Emhart Corporation.

title: American President Cos Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Theater; Bill Irwin Tussles Anew With the Modern World
description: Any fears that Bill Irwin, having arrived on Broadway, might have gone Broadway are quickly dispelled in ''Largely New York,'' the sweet, brief show that the invaluable New Vaudeville clown brought to the St. James last night. While Mr. Irwin may now be playing across the street from ''The Phantom of the Opera,'' he is congenitally incapable of succumbing to high-tech glitz. Not that he doesn't make a good-natured try. ''Largely New York'' opens with Mr. Irwin attempting to manipulate the theater's many curtains with an elaborate remote control. One is relieved to see that he need merely push a few buttons to gum up the works entirely (and hilariously) before retreating to his natural terrain, the bare stage.

title: United Pact To End Suit By Patrons
description: United Airlines said today that it had formalized a change it made in its frequent-flier program two years ago to mollify angry customers.

More Still Unites Than Divides Blacks and Jews; Slavery Remembered
description: To the Editor:

description: To the Editor:

title: Lobsters May Explain Aggression In Humans
description: LOBSTERS are normally solitary creatures of the deep. But when placed together in a tank they will fight continually until one emerges dominant. The winner stands tall, on the tips of its legs, while the loser lies flat on its belly.

title: MCI Gets Contract
description: The MCI Communications Corporation said the Westinghouse Electric Corporation had given it a five-year contract worth $75 million to $100 million to expand and enhance its voice and digital communications network. The U S Sprint Communications Company and the American Telephone and Telegraph Company also bid for the contract, MCI said.

title: First Midwest Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Piano; Cherkassky's View of Liszt
description: Shura Cherkassky's muse is liable to drop in on him at any moment. Mr. Cherkassky seems happy when it does and follows trustingly wherever it chooses to take him.

title: Up Against the Wall: Murphy Bed's Name
description: The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit in Manhattan declared that anyone who might feel the need to manufacture a bed of the type that has stumped the likes of Charlie Chaplin and Jackie Gleason can call it, if they want to, well, what else? A Murphy bed.

title: Associates of Wright in Venture Defend Profitable Drilling Deal
description: The participants in an oil well venture that produced a substantial profit for Speaker Jim Wright vehemently defended the arrangement today, charging that the House ethics committee's investigative report was full of distortions and errors.

title: Board's Fate: New Design In Governing
description: Sometime this week, perhaps as soon as today, the commission rewriting New York City's Charter will vote to recommend abolishing the Board of Estimate. The death of the city board, which has been at the center of civic affairs for 91 years, will mark a major turning point in New York's political history.

title: No Meeting for Rose
description: Pete Rose, manager of the Cincinnati Reds, who is under investigation by the baseball commissioner's office, said he had no plans to meet with A. Bartlett Giamatti when the Reds come to New York tomorrow for a two-game series with the Mets.

title: Texaco to Stay In South Africa
description: Texaco Inc. will not follow Mobil Inc. in withdrawing from South Africa, Texaco's president, James Kinnear, said today.

title: Tornadoes Hit North Florida
description: Tornadoes touched down across the Florida Panhandle today, but no one was hurt and there was little damage, the officials said. At Eglin Air Force Base, aircraft hangars, dormitories and office buildings were slightly damaged.

description: After income from discontinued operations of $140,000 and share earnings were less than one cent a share. c-Net loss and included a loss from discontinued operations of $507,000.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; 'Bloom County' To End Aug. 6
description: The cartoonist Berke Breathed will discontinue his Pulitzer Prize-winning comic strip ''Bloom County'' on Aug. 6 and begin a new, Sunday-only strip the next month. The announcement from The

title: U.S. Ex-Officials Urge Talks on NATO Missiles
description: A bipartisan group of former Government officials, endorsing a policy rejected by the Bush Administration, said today that the United States should agree to open talks with the Russians on reducing short-range nuclear weapons in Europe.

title: Critic's Notebook; Television and the Attack in Central Park
description: With everyone casting about for explanations for last month's gang assault on a jogger in Central Park, attention has, as usual, turned to television, which often receives a share of the blame for dismaying social ailments, including crime, illiteracy and general sloth. The blame-television-first reaction is instantaneous, like pressing the buzzer on a game show before the other contestants.

title: Shearson to Buy Scherer
description: A yearlong battle to force the sale of the R. P. Scherer Corporation ended today when the company agreed to be taken private by Shearson Lehman Hutton Holdings and its merchant banking partners, who are supplying the financing for the $406.7 million buyout.

title: First Federal Savings & Loan Assn of Fort Myers, Florida reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Gooden Is 5-0; Unfazed By Slip
description: For six innings tonight, Dwight Gooden sailed through the Braves' anemic lineup, apparently oblivious to the rain-soaked turf that made the area around the pitching mound slippery and treacherous.

title: Chess
description: It used to be that, if you were leading a tournament, you took an early draw in the last round to guarantee a tie for first place. This was the counsel of Mikhail Botvinnik of the Soviet Union, who dominated chess from 1948 until 1963. His idea was that the last round was too nerve-racking, that anyone who went all-out for a victory would blunder and lose. But just look what following this idea got the Yugoslav grandmaster Ljubomir Ljubojevic.

title: Ranchmen's Resources Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: In the latest quarter, after preferred-share dividends net income equalled less than one cent. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Aguirre Helps Pistons Put Celtics on the Brink
description: When Mark Aguirre was traded to the Detroit Pistons in February, his new teammates were concerned. The Pistons didn't like some things they had heard about Aguirre, whether they were true or not. So several days after he joined the team, Aguirre was taken to dinner by Isiah Thomas, Bill Laimbeer, Rick Mahorn and Vinnie Johnson. Actually, the dinner was more like an inquisition.

title: Review/Recital; Pianist's Tribute to Schnabel
description: Tung Kwong-Kwong, a pianist, left China in 1947 to study with Artur Schnabel, and eventually settled in New York, where in 1971 she established the Si-Yo Music Society. On Sunday evening, Miss Tung played a Carnegie Hall recital offered both as a tribute to Schnabel (who died in 1951) and as a benefit for Si-Yo, an educational and concert-presenting organization.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council Meets at 10 A.M.

title: Cheney Remarks on Soviet Future Ruffle the White House's Feathers

title: In Science, Error Isn't Fraud
description: LEAD: Prof. David Baltimore of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology is under attack by Representative John Dingell of Michigan. Why should anyone outside of the Government or basic biomedical research care? To begin with, it is a good story; beyond that, the process of scientific investigation itself is at stake.

title: The P.L.O.'s Many Voices Differ About Its Commitments to the U.S.
description: Since Yasir Arafat renounced terrorism and recognized Israel's right to exist in December, he and other Palestinian leaders have spoken in a multitude of voices, sometimes affirming but more often contradicting those original commitments.

title: Xoma Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Suspicious Drug Vials Found In Lenox Hill Storage Room
description: Detectives investigating how two patients at Lenox Hill Hospital received potentially fatal doses of a paralyzing drug last month have found three ampuls of the drug, five ampul caps and a cellophane syringe wrapper in a storage room next to the operating rooms, the police said yesterday.

title: EXXON GIVES PLAN ON CLEANING COAST
description: Exxon officials today released a revised plan for cleaning 364 miles of Alaskan coastline fouled by the nation's largest oil spill, but said their proposal requires a suspension of local environmental laws.

title: Baby-Food Makers Confront British Contamination Scare
description: For the past week Britain has been grappling with its worst-ever case of food tampering. Jars of baby food have been contaminated across the country.

All were playing first-round matches in the Eagle Tournament of Champions in front of fewer fans than were watching John McEnroe practice. And McEnroe is not even entered in the singles draw.

FSX: Icing on the Cake For General Dynamics
description: Some jet fighters are faster. Others can carry more weapons. And some definitely are more modern in design. But the General Dynamics Corporation is betting that its popular F-16 is going to go on and on. Company executives believe that at least another 2,000 of the $15 million planes can be sold before the fighter becomes obsolete, making it one of military aviation's best sellers.

title: The U.S. vs. the U.S. on the FSX
description: President Bush has now improved the terms of the $7 billion FSX fighter plane deal that the Reagan Administration reached with Japan. If Congress goes along, Mr. Bush will have removed a growing irritant in relations between America and a valued ally.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Time May be Running Out at Ogilvy
description: One of Ogilvy & Mather's most famousadvertisements was headlined: ''At 60 miles per hour, the loudest noise in this new Rolls-Royce comes from the electric clock.'' Many in the advertising industry now believe a clock is ticking for Ogilvy.

Moore had been appointed president and chief executive of their new joint venture company, the Hitachi Data Systems Corporation. The joint venture was formed to acquire National Advanced Systems Inc., the former National Semiconductor Corporation unit that resells Hitachi mainframe computers.

title: Guide for Jungle of Computer Terminology
description: ''TO click a mouse is to press one button very briefly (usually the leftmost button if there is more than one). By contrast, see press. See also double-click.''

title: Books of The Times
description: The America of T. Coraghessan Boyle is a wild and crazy place, where anything can happen. In his most recent novel (''World's End''), a garrulous epic that chronicled the fortunes of several generations of a single family, ''the barbaric new world'' of America spawned ghosts and demons, not to mention every imaginable variety of human eccentricity and prejudice. His collections of short stories (''Greasy Lake and Other Stories,'' ''Descent of Man'') have also tended to pivot around the strange and the surreal: neighboring survivalists, holed up in the wilderness to await the apocalypse, come to blows; a group of hippies watches television and smokes marijuana as the skies begin to rain blood; a rowdy gang of teen-agers discovers a bloated corpse in the neighborhood lake.

description: If the River Was Whiskey By T. Coraghessan Boyle 224 pages. Viking. $17.95.

title: Review/Comedy; Moynihan and Green Satirize Life
description: Jackie and Jerry Diamond, the most fully realized characters created by the young comedy duo Moynihan and Green, are an unflappably upbeat show-business couple whose act suggests a third-string Steve Lawrence and Eydie Gorme. Performing their tribute to Michael Jackson, the Diamonds praise him as ''a very talented Negro lad'' and go on to mutilate his songs by interpolating stale hipster's slang into the lyrics. ''This cat is not the one,'' Jerry Diamond sings in his dreadful revised version of ''Billie Jean.''

title: With Rose Out, Reds More Than Manage
description: Paul O'Neill drove in five runs and Jeff Reed had five hits tonight as the Cincinnati Reds routed Montreal, 19-6. It was the most runs ever scored against the Expos.

title: Sea-Exploring Robot Is Recovered Off Italy
description: THE underwater robot Jason and a companion vehicle have been recovered after breaking loose from a tether Wednesday while descending to the wreck of an ancient Roman ship, the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution reported yesterday.

title: In Careful Test, Parkinson's Patient Shows Gains After Fetal-Cell Implant
description: THE first patient in the United States to have human fetal cells implanted in his brain as a treatment for Parkinson's disease is showing small but steady improvement nearly six months after the surgery, his physician said yesterday.

title: Dow Down 3.84 Points, Closing at 2,414.96
description: Stocks retreated yesterday in a decline that traders attributed to renewed concern that the Federal Reserve Board might be forced to tighten interest rates.

description: Ten years ago, Britain was the sick man of Europe, its industries crumbling, its economy paralyzed by intractable labor disputes, its political and intellectual leaders resigned to genteel but inevitable decline.

description: b-Included a charge of $134,000. c-Included a special gain of $122,000. Figures are in Canadian funds.

description: The House Armed Services Committee plans to hear the views of Soviet officials as well as Pentagon leaders as it drafts the defense budget, Representative Les Aspin said today.

Treasury Delays Action On Fringe-Benefit Rule
description: The Treasury said today that it would not enforce until Oct. 1 a new fringe-benefit regulation that the business community considers onerous, particularly for small companies.

title: Alan D. Ferguson, 75, Former Yale Official
description: Alan Douglas Ferguson, an educational administrator and former assistant dean at Yale University, died of a pulmonary embolism Wednesday at the Lahey Clinic Medical Center in Burlington, Mass. He was 75 years old and lived in Lexington, Mass.

title: Broken Nose for Ellis
description: Dale Ellis, a high-scoring guard for the Seattle SuperSonics, suffered a fractured nose Sunday in his team's playoff victory over the Houston Rockets in Seattle. Bill Boenke, a SuperSonics spokesman, said Ellis would make the trip to Houston for Game 3 but that it was doubtful he would play.(AP)

title: Texas Instruments Patent Settlement
description: Texas Instruments Inc. said it had reached a patent cross-licensing agreement with Micron Technology Inc. of Boise, Idaho, that will end patent litigation between the companies. Micron will pay Texas Instruments $38.2 million to cover royalties on Texas Instruments patents on dynamic random access memory chips.

title: Carson Pirie Accepts New Bergner Bid
description: After rejecting two takeover offers by the same bidder, Carson Pirie Scott & Company, the Chicago retailer, yesterday accepted a sweetened price of $453 million from P. A. Bergner & Company, a Swiss-owned retailer with 31 stores in the Midwest.

title: Eric Nord, 69, Is Dead; Owner of the Hungry I
description: Eric Nord, a nightclub owner who provided a platform for counter-cultural performers, died of heart and kidney disease Wednesday at the Skyline Convalescent Home in San Jose, Calif. He was 69 years old and had lived for several years in nearby Los Gatos.

title: Santa Anita Cos reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: Johnson Controls Inc., a Milwaukee-based maker of automated building controls, has agreed to buy Pan Am World Services, a subsidiary of the Pan Am Corporation, the two companies said yesterday.

description: The Supreme Court ruled today, 5 to 4, that a current Federal law cannot be used to force lawyers to donate their services to the poor in civil cases.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: School Elections
description: New York City voters will go to the polls today to choose the members of the city's 32 community school boards. Registered voters, as well as parents of students in the public school system who have registered as ''parent voters,'' are eligible to cast ballots.

title: Omnicare Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $330,000 from an accounting change.

title: Rite Aid Stock Falls on Bribe Charge
description: The stock price of the Rite Aid Corporation fell yesterday for the second consecutive trading day after charges of attempted bribery were brought in Cleveland last week against Martin L. Grass, its president.

title: Outclassed Horses Compromise a Classy Race
description: There is a race track adage that says ''never knock a horse until he's been dead for 25 years'' because horses make fools of handicappers every day. But the prospective field for the 115th Kentucky Derby Saturday makes it awfully tempting to break that rule.

title: COURT, 6-3, EASES TASK OF PLAINTIFFS IN JOB-BIAS SUITS
description: The Supreme Court, ruling in a significant job discrimination case, today made it easier for plaintiffs to prevail in many lawsuits based on sex, race and age discrimination in employment.

title: Liggett Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Shares outstanding for 1988 reflected the October 1987 split of Liggett's outstanding common stock into 20 million shares. Accordingly, the calculation of the shares outstanding for the prior year assumed that the stock split occurred on April 1, 1987.

title: Pacific Northern Gas Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Ames Department Stores Inc., Rocky Hill, Conn., said J. Baker Inc., Hyde Park, Mass., which has the licenses to operate the shoe departments in Ames stores, would acquire the licenses to operate the shoe departments in the 315-store Zayre division of Ames. The transaction is valued at $60 million.

title: Shearson Sued On Teamsters
description: The Labor Department filed suit today against Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., an investment manager and eight trustees of $561 million in union benefit funds, accusing them of abusing their positions for financial gain through stock deals and other transactions.

title: Birth of a Voting Bloc: the Hasidim and Orthodox Organize
description: ''There are people in the audience who are candidates for citywide office. There are people who are soon to announce their candidacy,'' smiled Rabbi Morris A. Shmidman, looking out over what he described as ''a sea of black hats'' worn by Hasidic and Orthodox Jews and introducing the visiting dignitaries. ''There are also some people in the audience who are not candidates. They're a little hard to find.'' The annual awards dinner of the Council of Jewish Organizations of the Borough Park section of Brooklyn the other night was packed with candidates and officeholders, pilgrims paying tribute to the growing political power of New York City's Hasidic and Orthodox communities and their ability to deliver tens of thousands of votes in a solid block.

title: PSE Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Home Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago quarter income is restated to reflect an accounting change. The company said the latest and year-ago quarters included benefits of $2 million and $3 million, respectively, attributable to the fresh start provision of the Tax Reform Act of 1986. Latest quarter earnings included results of Carteret Bancorp. acquired in August 1988. Latest quarter included realized gains of $8 million; year-ago quarter included realized losses of $4 million on the sale of investments by insurance subsidiaries.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Edberg and Jaite Advance: Stefan Edberg of Sweden defeated Andres Vysand of the Soviet Union, 6-3, 3-6, 7-5, and Martin Jaite of Argentina beat Jimmy Connors by 6-4, 6-1, yesterday in second-round matches of the $205,000 Munich Nabisco tournament. Carl Uwe-Steeb of West Germany defeated fellow West German Tore Meinecke by 6-3, 6-2 in another second-round match.(AP) YACHTING Brigden Is Leader: Mary Brigden of the United States Naval Academy is the leading skipper after two days of the Betsy Ross Bowl, a new 10-boat regatta that features some of the top female sailors in the United States. The three-day regatta in New York Harbor concludes today with two races.

title: Review/Television; An Imaginary Meeting of Dr. King and Malcolm X
description: If the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X had met for an hour or so, what would they have found to say to each other? Jeff Stetson undertook to answer that question in a 1987 one-act play, an American Playhouse adaptation of which can be seen tonight at 9 o'clock on Channels 13 and 49. Although neither the clash of principles nor the affinity of personalities portrayed here offers any surprises, the scenes in which the men reveal the shared pain behind their very different philosophies of the racial struggle are compelling.

title: Omnicom Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Ogden Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Budget Games
description: The House and Senate are about to approve their respective versions of a fiscal 1990 budget resolution that will supposedly reduce the deficit to $100 billion next year. Anyone who believes that number needs a refresher course in capital games.

title: Jerusalem Journal; The Elusive Shimon Peres: Waiting for His Cue?
description: The conventional wisdom on Shimon Peres these days is that he seems to have disappeared.

title: Cuomo Blocks a Rise in SUNY and CUNY Tuition
description: An hour before the legal deadline, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo tonight blocked a $200-a-year tuition increase for students of New York's State University and City University systems.

title: Volvo-Ford Accord
description: The Volvo North America Corporation said it had agreed to pay $30 million to the Ford Motor Company in exchange for additional shares in the Hertz Corporation, which Ford acquired in 1987. Ford said at the time that it did not intend to keep its majority ownership, and last August it sold a 20 percent stake in the car-rental agency to Volvo. The new investment, which is expected to be made by June, would raise Volvo's stake in Hertz to 26 percent and decrease Ford's stake to 49 percent.

title: Nobility Homes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 28
description: b-Net loss

title: Treasury Securities Up, Aided by Strong Dollar
description: Prices of Treasury securities jumped in light trading yesterday, helped by favorable technical conditions as well as a strong performance by the dollar.

title: Driver Harris Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $58,000 and $43,000 for the latest quarter and year- earlier period, respectively.

title: Harvard Re-rejects R.O.T.C.
description: Harvard's undergraduate student council has reversed a decision to ask the Reserve Officers Training Corps back to the campus, ruling that inviting R.O.T.C. back violated the student constitution. But the debate is not over. On Sunday night, with about 400 students attended the meeting, the student council voted 43 to 39 against a week-old resolution, approved 41 to 24 the week before, to ask the administration to negotiate with the military and bring back R.O.T.C.

title: Geraghty & Miller reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pepsico Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 25
description: Year-ago results restated to report under the equity method of accounting certain previously consolidated foreign joint ventures of Kentucky Fried Chicken, due to a reduced ownership interest. The restatement did not affect net income. The year-ago period's net included a one-time $14.5 million pretax reorganization charge, or $10.4 million after-tax, in domestic soft drinks.

title: Reviews/Music; Two Sides Of a String Quartet
description: The Takacs String Quartet, an ensemble that was formed in Hungary in 1975 and is now based in the United States, revealed two sides of its interpretive personality on Sunday afternoon at Alice Tully Hall when it played music by Haydn, Beethoven and Szolt Durko.

title: Micro Bio-Medics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After tax credits of $8,000 for the latest first quarter and $12,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Donegal Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: Import Duties On Bearings
description: The United States will impose extra duties on most imported bearings to offset what it calls dumping by nine countries, an independent Government agency decided today.

title: Thermo Instrument Systems reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
L.I. Track: A Deal Gone Bad Could Bring Millions
description: Ten months after Roosevelt Raceway was closed, the grandstand at the once-premier harness track on Long Island is crumbling, its three principal owners are being investigated for possible financial irregularities and critics say the owners may reap more than $100 million in profits after acquiring the track chiefly through tax breaks.

title: Sci-Med Life Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net loss

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
President of E-Systems Will Succeed Its Chief
description: LEAD: Though the Bush Administration's proposed cuts in military spending cloud the horizon of many companies, E-Systems Inc., a Dallas-based maker of reconnaissance and surveillance systems, appears to be gaining momentum.

title: Adaptec reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Despite Troubles, Rose Keeps His Door Open
description: Pete Rose, in his underwear and red shower shoes with No. 14 inked on, was seated against a white wall in the visiting manager's office in Olympic Stadium several hours before the Cincinnati Reds' game against the Expos here Monday night. His legs were crossed; his left arm rested on the back of the chair, and he held his head in his hand. The manager of the Reds was not looking too good, nor sounding very well, either.

title: Ramada Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 30
description: b-Net income and after a gain of $487,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Kodak's Net Drops 23.1%; Stock Slumps
description: The Eastman Kodak Company yesterday reported lower-than-expected first-quarter earnings, prompting a selloff of Kodak stock by investors already worried about the outcome of a trial to assess the company's liability for infringing the Polaroid Corporation's instant photography patents. The trial began on Monday. Kodak said it earned $200 million, or 62 cents a share, in the quarter, down 23.1 percent from $260 million, or 80 cents a share, a year ago. Sales rose 17.1 percent, to $3.9 billion, from $3.33 billion a year ago.

title: Study of U.S. Jobs Program Calls for Focus on the Poor
description: Federal job training programs should be refocused on high school dropouts, welfare recipients and others ''who have low incomes and lack the basic skills necessary to perform well in the labor market,'' a Labor Department study says.

title: Real Estate; Foreign Cash Pouring Into Older Hotels
description: WHEN a new marquee was hoisted above the entrance to the former Madison Avenue Hotel on East 77th Street last month, it represented more than a name change for the 63-year-old hotel.

title: Raymond James Financial Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said 1988 revenue for both the quarter and six months have been restated to segregate the results of its real estate subsidiary, Sunstyle Corp., which was spun off effective Sept. 30, 1988.

title: Noble Drilling Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
About New York; A Bronx Booster Who Gets Paid To Be a Nice Guy
description: There are two kinds of telephone men. One kind was the father in Tennessee Williams's ''The Glass Menagerie,'' who appeared only in a picture over the mantel.

title: Anne Ackerman, Political Worker, 75
description: Anne Ackerman, a political worker whose support was courted by candidates for condominum board member to President, died of cancer Monday at her home. She was 75 years old.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Executive Changes listing of Business Day on Monday misidentified the new executive vice president and general counsel of Keycorp, a financial services company based in Albany. He is Walter V. Ferris; Victor J. Riley Jr. is the president and chief executive.

title: Macmillan Appointment
description: Donald L. Fruehling on Monday was named the president of the new Maxwell-Macmillan International Group. He will be reponsible for the company's hard-cover and paperback book publishing businesses outside the United States, and he will continue to serve as a director and group vice president of Macmillan Inc. Mr. Fruehling had been the president of the Maxwell Pergamon Publishing Corporation, a subsidiary of the Maxwell Communication Corporation that specialized in educational and professional publishing. Before that, he was an executive vice president at McGraw-Hill Inc. Maxwell bought Macmillan for $2.5 billion in November.

title: Fisher Scientific Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Lifetime Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Help for Deaf Jurors
description: Los Angeles County, settling a lawsuit brought against it by an organization for the deaf, has agreed to provide interpreters who will translate court proceedings into sign language for hearing-impaired people called to jury duty.

description: b-Net income and after a gain of $748,000 from an accounting change.

title: Wellco Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Paxar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest period's sales reflected about a $3.8 million contribution from Rospatch, which was acquired in August 1988.

title: Pollock Price Among Records at Sotheby's
description: Jackson Pollock's silvery ''No. 8, 1950,'' in black, white, yellow and aluminum paint in the artist's mature drip style, was sold at Sotheby's last night for $11.55 million, a record at auction for a work by the artist and the second-highest price at auction for a work by any contemporary artist.

title: Scientific-Atlanta Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Plexus Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Pepsico Posts 46% Increase In Earnings
description: Pepsico Inc., which has been recently riding a wave of consumer favor, said yesterday that first-quarter earnings rose 46 percent, to $165.1 million, or 62 cents a share, up from $113.3 million, or 43 cents a share, a year earlier.

title: Reeves Communications reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and after tax credits of $14,000 for the quarter and $1,330,000 for the 9 months.

title: NVR LP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said 1988 figures were restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: Jersey Health Care Bond Yields Set
description: The New Jersey Health Care Facilities Financing Authority is initially pricing $59.5 million of revenue bonds with a maximum yield of about 7.324 percent for an issue due 2018 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. The initial pricing for the negotiated issue is subject to change.

title: Japan Deal Questioned By G.A.O.
description: The General Accounting Office has challenged one of the Bush Administration's arguments for going ahead with a $7 billion agreement to produce a jet fighter with the Japan Defense Agency.

title: In China, Economic Tremors Shake Deng's Rule; Not a Retreat at All
description: To the Editor:

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Georgia-Pacific Elects Head of Unit President
description: LEAD: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation, one of the largest forest products companies in the United States, said yesterday that it had elected Ronald P. Hogan, the head of its building products division, to succeed Harold L. Airington as president and chief operating officer, beginning on July 1.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: FOR years, Gorky's, a popular cafe in the downtown warehouse district, was a Bohemian institution renowned for its muffins (poppyseed, sour cream, pumpkin and apple bran) and its music (jazz, rhythm and blues, new-age and fusion). But when Fred Powers took over in 1985, he wanted to expand.

title: McGwire's 2-Out Slam Beats Jays
description: Mark McGwire hit a grand slam with two outs in the ninth inning off Tom Henke tonight to give the Oakland Athletics an 8-5 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays.

title: Mutual Federal Savings & Loan reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Kansas Power & Light Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: b-Net loss

title: Factory Orders Rose 0.7% in March
description: Orders to United States factories for manufactured goods increased seven-tenths of 1 percent in March, the Government reported today, led by strong aircraft orders. But analysts still saw signs in the report that the economy was cooling off.

title: ProGroup Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Slow Pace Toward Doctorates Prompts Fear of Unfilled Jobs
description: Students are taking longer than ever to earn doctorates, about seven years compared with five and a half years in the 1960's. The slow pace is causing government officials and educators to fear there will be growing shortages of college teachers, scientists and many other professionals in coming years.

title: Superior Electric reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Arline Thomas, 85, 'Bird Lady' Who Rescued Wildfowl, Is Dead
description: Arline Thomas, known as ''the bird lady of Queens'' for the number of wild birds she sheltered and rescued, died of congestive heart failure Monday at Huntington (L.I.) Hospital. She was 85 years old and lived in Hollis, Queens.

title: New-Home Sales Down 5.5% in March
description: Sales of new homes dropped 5.5 percent in March after plunging 10.5 percent in February, the Government reported today, as higher interest rates took their toll on the housing market.

title: Community Board Reaffirms Its Opposition to Tower Plan
description: Community Board 7 on the West Side of Manhattan voted last night to reaffirm its opposition to a proposed skyscraper on the New York Coliseum site at Columbus Circle.

title: Bridge
description: A complex story concerning the Women's Team Trials, due to start in Memphis on May 17, received another twist yesterday - a legal challenge may result in the event being postponed.

title: Tainted Verdicts Resurrect Specter of Executing the Innocent
description: The recent release of a former death row inmate, belatedly found to have been wrongly convicted, underlines a quietly acknowledged danger in the American judicial system: the virtual certainty of sometimes executing innocent people.

title: Citicorp Rates Off at Auction
description: Interest rates at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper, which were up and down in April, began the month of May yesterday with a modest decline.

title: Oral Roberts Move
description: Oral Roberts, the evangelist, announced yesterday that the university in Tulsa, Okla., that bears his name is withdrawing from the National Collegiate Athletic Association and will seek membership in the National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics. Roberts said the decision was part of a series of financial cutbacks necessitated by a sharp decline in contributions to the university.

title: Tylan Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $255,000 pretax gain.

title: Lincoln National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for 1988 have been restated for an accounting change.

title: Sotiros Cachules, 75, Former Bank President
description: Sotiros N. Cachules, a former president of the Atlantic Bank of New York, died of complications Sunday after surgery at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. He was 75 years old and lived in Valley Stream, L.I.

title: PARAGUAY GENERAL WINS CONCLUSIVELY
description: ''Many irregularities'' flawed Paraguay's presidential elections, but fraud was not widespread enough to change the outcome, a group of international observers concluded today.

title: Oil Companies Never Wanted Canada Pipeline
description: To the Editor:

title: Actress Being Honored
description: The actress and director Geraldine Fitzgerald is to receive a lifetime achievement award from the National Society of Arts and Letters at a dinner Saturday at 7 P.M. at the Players, 16 Gramercy Park South. The nonprofit society fosters the work of young artists, and the award to Miss Fitzgerald is in part for her educational work. Information: 486-0566.
