NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15 Government subsidies on wheat sales to the Soviet Union were approved by President Bush, the first time his Administration has authorized such export subsidies. Page A1

title: Weyenberg Shoe reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Jackson Optimistic on Justice Dept. Choice
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson predicted today that there would be no ''substantial opposition'' to the Justice Department selection of a black Republican lawyer from Detroit to lead the department's civil rights division.

title: Abrams Endorses Dinkins; Offers Praise for Judgment
description: Attorney General Robert Abrams, one of the state's leading Democrats, endorsed the Manhattan Borough President, David N. Dinkins, for mayor yesterday over Mayor Edward I. Koch.

title: Sierra Health Services reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $96,000 for the latest first quarter and $69,000 for the year-ago period.

description: The company said the latest first quarter included $6.7 million in costs related to company's response to a hostile tender offer from A. Copeland Enterprises.

description: b-Net income The company said the 1988 loss was due mainly to lower prices for crude oil and natural gas, lower sales of crude oil and the writedown of property, plant and equipment of $24 million. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Jack Rosen, Cartoonist And Builder's Aide, 75
description: Jack Rosen, a cartoonist and public-relations adviser, died of pneumonia Saturday at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn. He was 75 years old.

title: Palfed Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago per-share net restated to reflect a 5-for-4 stock split distributed Dec. 15.

title: Topics of The Times; Justice Strays in Suffolk
description: A troubling report by New York State's Commission of Investigation charges incompetent, improper and possibly illegal conduct by the Suffolk County District Attorney's office and the county police. Gov. Mario Cuomo and Attorney General Robert Abrams have rightly moved to appoint a special prosecutor.

title: New I.B.M. System Links Voice and Data
description: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced a series of products yesterday designed to integrate its data processing and voice systems.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption last Friday with a Weekend section guide to the Washington Inaugural bicentennial gave an incorrect year for the publication of ''The Inauguration of Washington'' by Currier & Ives. It was 1876, not 1789.

title: Reagan Arms Adviser Says Bush Is Wrong on Short-Range Missiles
description: Paul H. Nitze, the Reagan Administration's top arms control adviser, said today that President Bush was making a serious mistake in refusing to open talks with the Soviet Union on short-range nuclear missiles in Europe.

title: Ross, A J Logistics reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $262,050 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Senior Aide to Arafat Wounded in Lebanon
description: The senior Palestine Liberation Organization official in Lebanon was wounded today in an assassination attempt in Sidon, the police said.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council ECONOMIC COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. SOCIAL COMMITTEE - 3 P.M.

title: Kickoff Classic Is a Sellout
description: For the first time in its seven-year history, the Kickoff Classic will be a sellout.

title: Dollar Continues to Climb After Central Banks Act
description: The dollar resisted a coordinated round of dollar selling by the Federal Reserve, the Bank of Japan and at least five European central banks yesterday and rose against both the mark and the yen.

title: Texas Air Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $33.5 million from the sale of assets.

title: Pistons' Defense Smothers Celtics' Season
description: The Detroit Pistons employed another bruising defensive display tonight to beat the Boston Celtics, 100-85, and sweep their first-round playoff series, 3-0.

title: Motoring for a Fall
description: The Romans cooked in leaden pots, and so the empire fell, done in by lead poisoning. This theory won't beguile people who know that the Roman Empire was as old as biblical Methuselah and that old age eventually fells everything, empires and redwoods included.

title: Murray Is Re-Hired
description: The Washington Capitals yesterday ended speculation that Coach Bryan Murray might be let go because his Patrick Division championship team was eliminated in the first round of the Stanley Cup playoffs by the Philadelphia Flyers in six games. The Capitals instead announced the signing of Murray, who has coached Washington since 1981, to a two-year contract. He was in the final year of a five-year agreement that would have expired on June 1.

title: Xoma Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Time Air Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Physicists Debunk Claim Of a New Kind of Fusion
description: Hopes that a new kind of nuclear fusion might give the world an unlimited source of cheap energy appear to have been dealt a devastating blow by scientific evidence presented here.

title: Sigma-Aldrich Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Stocks Lose Ground as Dow Falls by 12.10
description: Stock prices retreated yesterday as investor concern continued over the course of the economy and whether the Federal Reserve Board will tighten interest rates.

title: Western Playboy Is Well
description: Western Playboy, the Jim Beam and Blue Grass winner and likely fourth choice in the Derby, seems to have fully recovered from the minor leg infection that had made him a questionable starter in the Kentucky Derby on Saturday.

title: Aftermath of a Capital Drug Raid: Cocaine and Crime Flourish Still
description: What was probably the biggest drug raid ever in this city has provided its own elation and letdown for law-enforcement officers who are struggling against the nation's worst cocaine epidemic.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL President Bush approved Government subsidies on the sale of 1.5 million metric tons of wheat to the Soviet Union. Mr. Bush has often argued against farm trade subsidies. [ Page A1. ] The G.A.O. said the technology the U.S. is expected to receive from Japan as part of the FSX deal is already well known. [ D1. ] American and Japanese officials say the fighter accord has changed very little in imposing safeguards on technology to be transferred to the Japanese. [ D13. ] COMPANIES Texas Air reported heavier losses for the first quarter, but analysts found hope in Continental's earnings. [ D1. ] Marvin Davis and NWA agreed to a standstill for two months in his attempt to acquire the parent of Northwest Airlines. [ D1. ] Pepsico's earnings rose 46 percent, to $165.1 million, or 62 cents a share, in the first quarter. [ D5. ] Chrysler's earnings rose 90.8 percent, helped by a special charge in the first quarter of last year. Without the charge, Chrysler's quarterly profit would have increased 26.7 percent. [ D2. ] Eastman Kodak's earnings were lower than expected in the first quarter, and its stock fell $3.25 a share. [ D5. ] ABC dropped ''Crimes of Passion II'' from last Saturday's schedule after it failed to attract any paid advertising. [ D1. ] International Thomson agreed to pay $810 million for the Lawyers Co-operative Publishing Company. [ D21. ] Ediciones Anaya of Spain has bought Dearmas, the largest publisher of magazines in Latin America. [ D23. ] I.B.M. introduced products designed to integrate its data processing and voice systems. [ D5. ] One of the Philippines' oldest business families succeeded in fighting off a bid for its copper company, the nation's largest. [ D5. ] MARKETS The dollar resisted a round of selling and rose against the mark and the yen. [ D17. ] Crude oil prices fell below $20 a barrel [ D17. ] Stock prices retreated amid concern over the course of the economy. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 12.10 points, to 2,402.86. [ D10. ] Prices of Treasury securities jumped in light trading, helped by favorable technical conditions and the dollar. [ D19. ] Yields were flat on C.D.'s and bank money market accounts for the week ended yesterday. [ D19. ] The Government said Paul A. Bilzerian used ''trickery and deceit'' to enrich himself, as his securities fraud trial opened. [ D19. ] THE ECONOMY Sales of new homes dropped 5.5 percent in March after plunging 10.5 percent in February. [ D6. ] Orders to factories increased 0.7 percent in March, largely on the strength of aircraft orders. [ D6. ] A savings industry rescue plan was approved by the House Banking Committee that imposes tougher capital standards. [ D2. ] TECHNOLOGY A future in which plastic waste is easily recycled is being tested at a plant in Brooklyn. [ D1. ] An inexpensive sensor can tell whether package handlers have roughed up a personal computer or a priceless vase. [ D9. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Louisiana voters rejected a modest first step toward buttoned-down government. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Yields on ''junk bonds'' have been rising in the last month, as a supply of new issues hits the market. Market Place. [ D10. ] J. Walter Thompson has returned to eminence under the ownership of WPP. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D1. ]

title: At the Nation's Table
description: WHEN customers asked Frances Maldonado to serve high tea at Enchantment Delights, her cafe in the Old Town section, she wasn't sure what to do. A native New Mexican, she had never been to England and had no idea of English traditions.

title: ABC Cancels Crime Show That Fails to Get Any Ads
description: ABC announced yesterday that it had dropped a dramatized crime program from its prime-time schedule last Saturday night after the show failed to attract any paid advertising.

Fast of Ramadan Ends With Feasts

Takeover Bid Fails in Manila
description: One of the oldest business families in the Philippines today succeeded in fighting off a takeover bid for the country's largest copper producer.

title: Wine Talk
description: TWO weeks ago, virtually unnoticed, an event took place in Manhattan that could change the way wine is sold in New York: A collection of some 150 bottles of wine went on the block at a public auction.

title: Charter Panel Rejects Estimate Board and Turns to Council
description: The panel that is writing a new charter for New York City yesterday rejected proposals to preserve the Board of Estimate or to create a two-house city legislature to assume some of the board's powers. It turned instead to consideration of an expanded City Council of 60 members that would include the five borough presidents.

title: Grumman Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the increased interest costs caused a $5 million reduction in net income.

title: Edward Ochab Is Dead; Poland Ex-Official, 83
description: Edward Ochab, the former Polish Communist Party leader and president, has died in Warsaw, the official Polish press agency said today. He was 83 years old, the agency said.

title: What's New? J. Walter Thompson
description: An analyst recently asked Bruce Crawford, who returned to the advertising business as president of the Omnicom Group after four years of running the Metropolitan Opera, what had changed in advertising during his absence.

title: University of California In a $375 Million Offering
description: The Regents of the University of California are offering about $375 million of outstanding variable-rate demand bonds through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation. The bonds will be converted to fixed-rate bonds on June 1.

description: b-Net income

title: 80 NATIONS FAVOR BAN TO HELP OZONE
description: As concern grows that manmade chemicals are destroying the ozone layer in the atmosphere, 80 nations indicated today that they would favor banning production of certain harmful substances by the end of the century.

Wilkins's Overtime Shot Gives Knicks Sweep
description: It was another dramatic finish for the Knicks tonight, and this one gave them a three-game sweep of the Philadelphia 76ers in the opening round of the National Basketball Association playoffs.

title: Cedar Income Fund 1 reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $93,633 from expenses incurred in connection with the proposed merger with Cedar Income Fund 2 Ltd.

description: Year-ago first quarter results were adversely affected by a $93 million provision for the closing of some of Chrysler's Accustar subsidiary plants.

title: In Rift at Cornell, Racial Issues of the 60's Remain
description: Cornell University, which just commemorated the 20th anniversary of the takeover of the student union by black students, now finds itself wrangling with students and faculty members over some of the same issues it confronted in 1969.

title: Corrections
description: The ''Our Towns'' column on April 18 about Lyme disease listed a disease erroneously among those named for localities. Kawasaki disease is named for Dr. Tomisaku Kawasaki, the Japanese physician who first described it.

title: Oil Spill Traced to Cruise Ship
description: A mysterious oil spill in March that contaminated beaches on two islands has been traced to an inter-island cruise ship, the Coast Guard announced Monday. Oil samples taken from the S.S. Independence matched samples taken from beaches on Lanai and Molokai and from a slick between the islands, said Capt. Gordon Piche of the Coast Guard. He said the ship apparently dumped about 10,000 gallons of bunker fuel oil into the ocean by accident while pumping fresh water out of ballast tanks on March 24.

description: Usually, when Gerald Wilkins makes his move to the basket, he takes long gliding steps and floats by the opposition in trajectories that put him arm's reach from the basket.

title: Sally Kirkland, 77, Editor at Life; Brought Readers European Styles
description: Sally Kirkland, a chronicler of fashion for more than 30 years, died of emphysema Monday at St. Vincent's Hospital. She was 77 years old and lived on the Upper East Side of Manhattan.

title: BAKER IS ADVISED TO RESIST SOVIETS ON AFGHAN TALKS
description: A committee of the National Security Council has recommended that Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d resist Soviet demands for negotiations to bring about a political settlement of the Afghan war when he visits Moscow next week.

SUBSIDY ON WHEAT FOR SOVIET SALES APPROVED BY BUSH
description: President Bush, who has argued against farm trade subsidies and urged that they be curtailed worldwide, approved Government subsidies today on the sale of 1.5 million metric tons of wheat to the Soviet Union.

title: Races for School Board Pull Few Voters to Polls
description: Against a backdrop of allegations of misdeeds and mismanagement in many of New York City's decentralized school districts, voters in all boroughs went to the polls yesterday to elect local school board members to oversee the city's 32 local school districts.

title: Derby: One Race And Many Parties
description: LEAD: Lela Randle Watson is making baked beans - a large quantity of baked beans. She is taking the week off from her office job to work in her kitchen, adding secret ingredients as she pours the beans from gallon grocery cans into oversize foil containers, enough to feed 200 people at the Randle family's Kentucky

title: The Stone Wall Undermining NATO
description: Finally, West German leaders are beginning to advance a policy on short-range nuclear weapons that makes sense. Chancellor Helmut Kohl now speaks of linking talks on these weapons to reductions in nonnuclear forces in Europe. And Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher speaks of limiting rather than eliminating these weapons that are so important to the nuclear deterrent.

title: Market Place; Uneasy Outlook For 'Junk Bonds'
description: YIELDS on ''junk bonds'' have been rising in the last month, as a supply of new issues hit the market at the very time that some of the largest buyers moved to the sidelines. The yield on the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Index of two dozen actively traded high-yield issues jumped to 13.76 percent in mid-April from 12.95 percent in early March as prices fell.

title: Arafat Makes Formal Visit to France
description: Yasir Arafat, chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, registered a major advance today in his quest for international recognition and respectability when he was formally received by President Francois Mitterrand.

title: KN Energy Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
MRRM Inc reports earnings for
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: German With a Dream: Genscher Sees a New Age, but His Critics Worry
description: As turmoil swept through West German politics and the North Atlantic alliance, one man seemed to stand serenely and triumphantly content. For Hans-Dietrich Genscher, this was a moment to savor.

title: Jersey City Mayor and Three Guilty in Officer's Demotion
description: Judge Harold A. Ackerman of Federal District Court here ruled today that Mayor Anthony R. Cucci of Jersey City and three other officials violated the constitutional rights of a detective by demoting him because he supported an opponent of Mr. Cucci in the 1985 elections. The judge ordered the defendants to give the officer, Abad Perez, $29,298 in back pay and damages and to reinstate him.

title: Jersey City's Revaluation Raising Anger and Despair
description: Few communities approaching a property-tax revaluation have faced a more daunting task than this city across the Hudson River from Manhattan. And few have seen the job, once done, create so much anger, despair and bitterness.

title: Dissident Chinese Gather in the West
description: It was 70 years ago that a movement of Chinese students and intellectuals, shocked by their Government's weakness in the face of Japanese aggression, engaged in a period of soul searching and re-evaluation known as the May Fourth Movement. A result was the formation of the Communist Party that now rules China.

title: An Actor's Fantasies, Real as Life
description: He is an Irish aristocrat, yet his name is Casimir. He talks ceaselessly about his wife and children, yet they may not exist. He is an extravagantly silly fellow in a yellow tie, green sweater and plaid jacket, frequently given to boyish ecstasy, and yet he is capable of dissolving in tears at the sound of his father's voice. If at times Casimir skips excitedly like an enormous child in adult's clothes, he is also a figure of extraordinary pathos.

title: Ply Gem Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $600,000 from a change in accounting.

description: Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 3-for-2 stock split, paid in September 1988.

description: The ability to play the piano well and to play it well in public are often not the same thing. Carol Ferri, who gave a solo recital at Merkin Concert Hall on Sunday night, is a piano teacher in New Jersey and also a stage professional, though evidently not on a full-time basis.

title: Cluett, Peabody Exploring Options
description: Farley Inc. said its West Point-Pepperell subsidiary had retained Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. to explore ways to maximize the value of West Point's Cluett, Peabody division. Cluett, Peabody makes men's apparel under the Arrow, Coulours by Alexander Julian, Burberry and Gold Toe labels.

description: On the River Styx And Other Stories By Peter Matthiessen 208 pages. Random House. $17.95.

description: A Federal district judge has ruled that Salvadorans may not be deported from detention centers that the Government has established here in South Texas without being apprised of their right to legal counsel at deportation hearings.

title: 'Unknown' Rookie Jolts John on 7th-Inning Single
description: Tommy John was sailing along on the mound for the Yankees last night until he got to the seventh inning and encountered an unfamiliar face.

description: The Denver City Council has abolished a 36-year-old zoning ordinance that made it against the law for unmarried couples to live together in some of the city's more affluent neighborhoods.

description: The Navy has determined that the turret aboard the battleship Iowa that was severely damaged by a gunpowder explosion two weeks ago can be repaired, but officials said today that because they had not yet figured out the cost, no decision has been made whether to go ahead.

description: Because of Ascension Thursday, alternate-side parking rules will be suspended in New York City tomorrow. Other regulations remain in effect.

description: Every so often, the old pols on Capitol Hill demonstrate anew the manipulative skills that got them into positions of power in the first place. The latest example, the Democratic maneuver on the Medicare surtax, was the political equivalent of a karate chop on one of the year's hottest issues.

description: Toole's First Novel

The company also said the 1988 first quarter final loss included a special credit of $24.8 million reflecting a gain on the sale of two iron ore carrying vessels.

description: IN ordinary American cities the aroma of espresso does not emanate from local department stores. Nor can it be purchased on street corners and in libraries. But Seattle is no ordinary American city.

description: At a demonstration plant in an old warehouse in the Greenpoint section of Brooklyn, bags of trash from 19 McDonald's restaurants and several nearby school cafeterias are being loaded into a hopper and carried by conveyor belts through machines that chop, sort and separate the refuse.

title: Cargo Industry Drafts Plan to Curb Smugglers
description: The leader of a longshoremen's union says his members may stop unloading ships from drug-producing countries as members of the cargo industry work out a plan to curb drug smuggling.

title: Julia Smith, 78, Composer and Pianist, Dies
description: Julia Smith, a composer, pianist, teacher and writer on music, was found dead of a heart attack in her Riverside Drive apartment Thursday morning. She was 78 years old. Miss Smith was born in Denton, Tex. She was graduated from North Texas State University in 1930 and completed her education at the Juilliard Graduate School in New York and at New York University, where she received her Ph.D. in 1952.

title: Cowboys Dismiss Brandt
description: Gil Brandt, the last member of the group that built the Dallas Cowboys, was dismissed yesterday by the club's new owner, Jerry Jones. Brandt said that Jones told him money was the reason for the dismissal. ''He'll probably fire four or five scouts,'' Brandt said.

title: Review/Pop; A Cool Maureen McGovern
description: Maureen McGovern may be the closest thing that America has produced to a homegrown Julie Andrews. Unflappably demure and upbeat, the 39-year-old singer - who gave her first solo concert at Carnegie Hall on Monday evening - possesses formidable technical resources of which the most spectacular is a pop coloratura register from which she delivers piccololike tones in perfect pitch.

title: Nomura Chief in U.S. Reported Going Home
description: Masaaki Kurokawa, the chairman of the Nomura Securities Company's New York operations and a man known for his fondness for the Green Bay Packers, is returning to Tokyo after a relatively brief two-and-a-half-year stint in the United States, people close to Nomura said.

title: Polydex Pharmaceuticals Ltd reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-After a special gain of $273,402. c-Net income and after a $1,036,648 gain on sale of discontinued operations. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Layoffs at Jaguar
description: The luxury car maker Jaguar P.L.C. laid off more than 8,000 workers today because of a dispute that has paralyzed production. Jaguar said production of 870 cars worth nearly $:22 million ($37 million) had been lost since warehouse workers walked out last week, contending that a manager assaulted a shop steward.The layoffs involve plants in Coventry, in central England, and Castle Bromwich, in the north. Union leaders were not available to comment.

title: From Pennsylvania, Bit of Burgundy
description: A FORMER Hudson Valley wine maker is making Burgundian-style wines in the Brandywine Valley of southeastern Pennsylvania. Pure Burgundian style, marked by restraint, is, he says, a rarity on the East Coast.

title: INSIDE
description: Chinese Protests Spread

title: Magazine Publisher Is Sold
description: Dearmas Publishing Group, the largest publisher of magazines in Latin America, has been sold to Ediciones Anaya S.A., one of the biggest book publishing companies in Spain, the companies announced on Monday. Terms were not disclosed, but people at Dearmas said the price was $300 million.

description: Here is some free advice for Jesse Jackson as he ponders whether to be a candidate for mayor of Washington D.C.: Run, Jesse, run.

description: Sudanese rebels, who have seized more than 12 towns in the southern Sudan in the last four months, have declared a cease-fire and challenged Prime Minister Sadiq al-Mahdi to join them in peace talks.

description: Barbara Zinn Krieger is about to realize a producer's fondest and most elusive dream - the opening of a permanent theater of her own. After eight years of presenting plays, musicals, chamber music and jazz in small, makeshift quarters on East 26th Street, Ms. Krieger's nonprofit Vineyard Theater is to dedicate its new home today in the Zeckendorf Towers on Union Square.

title: Eating Well
description: ONE of the most helpful convenience foods on the market, minced garlic in oil, should not be taken for granted, the Federal Food and Drug Administration has warned.

title: SIHANOUK PLACES CONDITION ON RULE
description: In talks on the future of Cambodia, Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the leader of the coalition opposed to the Vietnamese-backed Government, today requested further constitutional changes before he would be willing to return, the Cambodian Prime Minister said.

description: More Elbow Room

title: Staff Move by Sears
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company's Merchandise Group said it would move 1,500 employees from its catalogue division out of its Sears Tower headquarters to a Sears-owned building in Skokie, Ill. Initially, some 650 catalogue advertising and merchandising employees will move between Aug. 1 and Sept. 15. Other parts of the catalogue group are set to move later to the Skokie building and another location, the retailer said. Sears announced in October that it was selling the Sears Tower.

title: Zapata Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

New Yorkers Told Drought Plan Must Stay
description: New York City asked its rain-soaked residents yesterday not to allow an occasional soggy day to lull them into complacency about the need for stringent conservation measures imposed recently.

title: Reviews/Music; Marlboro Ensemble Ends Season At Tully Hall
description: The Musicians From Marlboro chamber-music series is observing its 24th season. A spinoff from Rudolf Serkin's Marlboro Music Festival in Vermont, it combines a sprinkling of veteran instrumentalists with younger players to form touring ensembles, which in New York play at both Alice Tully Hall and the Metropolitan Museum. Monday night was the final performance of the season at Tully Hall.

title: Colts Sign Rison
description: Just nine days after the National Football League draft, the Indianapolis Colts yesterday announced the signing of their first-round pick, Andre Rison, the 22d pick over all, who is a wide receiver from Michigan State. Jim Irsay, the Colts' general manager, said the 5-foot-10-inch, 185-pound receiver signed a five-year contract worth $3 million early yesterday morning. ''Signing Rison early was a unique opportunity because of his value to the team,'' said Irsay.

title: Paskey Dedomenico, 78, Pasta Producer
description: Paskey Dedomenico, a food manufacturer whose best-known product was Rice-a-Roni, died Saturday after a brief illness. He was 78 years old.

title: Law Review At Columbia In a Dispute On Bias Plan
description: An affirmative-action program at The Columbia Law Review that goes far beyond similar plans at other student legal publications has renewed a debate over how to preserve the quality of the prominent review while remedying discrimination.

title: United Cities Gas Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Country Pride to DDB
description: Conagra, a diversified maker of food products, yesterday awarded the $10 million advertising account for its Country Pride chicken to the Chicago office of DDB Needham Worldwide. The account had been handled by John Malmo Associates, a Memphis agency.

title: Wright, on Defense, Sends Word That He Is Still Legislative Chief
description: Recognizing that a speedy resolution to his ethical problems is now out of reach, House Speaker Jim Wright is trying to send a simple political message these days: he is still Speaker, still in command and still conducting legislative business.

title: Dawson Geophysical reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a tax benefit of $74,000 for both the quarter and 6 months. c-Net loss

title: System for United To Avert Collisions
description: United Airlines said it would equip its entire fleet with the TCAS collision avoidance system made by the Collins Air Transport division of the Rockwell International Corporation. TCAS, which stands for Traffic Alert Collision Avoidance System, alerts pilots to a developing collision course and tells them to climb or descend.

title: Microwave Cooking
description: RADISHES have been so abused by being tortured into roses and other trimmings for salads that many cooks have forgotten that they make a wonderful vegetable.

title: Burst of Selling Late in Day Sends Crude Oil Below $20
description: A late burst of selling sent crude oil prices plunging below $20 a barrel yesterday in New York, despite feverish last-minute buying by a few large trading houses seeking to protect their positions.

title: Rowan Cos reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago quarter results are restated as a result of a change in the company's accounting policy for its oil and gas operations.

title: ISLAMIC MILITANCY ON RISE IN INDIA
description: Officials here and in New Delhi say that an armed underground movement, encouraged by local Islamic leaders and supported by Pakistan, is threatening the sensitive frontier state of Jammu and Kashmir.

title: Giuseppe Cardinal Siri Of Genoa Is Dead at 82
description: Giuseppe Cardinal Siri, the Archbishop of Genoa and a frequent candidate for the papacy, died of a heart ailment today, an official at the diocesan chancellery said. He was 82 years old.

title: American Biltrite Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Private Domains: Inside Corporate Dining Preserves
description: INSIDE Clarence House, a small textile company on the East Side of Manhattan, lies a spectacular dining room. Every detail, from the padded taupe wool walls to the individual crystal carafes of wine at every place, was designed to reflect the firm's reputation for luxury and exclusivity.

title: North Jury Ends 10th Day Without Verdict
description: The jurors in the Oliver L. North case stepped up the pace of their deliberations today but called a halt this evening with no sign of progress toward a verdict.

title: Carlesimo Can't Gamble On Kentucky
description: While running alongside the University of Kentucky campus recently, a solitary jogger noticed a music club advertising a group called Ten Foot Pole. If the jogger hadn't been quite so sweaty, he might have poked his head in to ask if anybody knew the ironic history of that name.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: TUNA steak is probably the most universally popular fresh fish in this country, and certainly one of the most versatile for home cooks. I recently came across some fascinating lore about this noble species while browsing through the definitive Encyclopedia of Fish Cookery by A. J. McClane (Holt, Rinehart & Winston, 1977).

title: 'Cake Bible' Is Cookbook of the Year
description: ''The Cake Bible'' by Rose Levy Beranbaum (Morrow, $25) was named book of the year yesterday in the Food and Beverage Book Awards sponsored by the International Association of Cooking Professionals and Joseph E. Seagram & Sons Inc.

title: Ikko Kasuga, 79, Japan Opposition Figure
description: The founder and former chairman of Japan's opposition Democratic Socialist Party, Ikko Kasuga, died of pneumonia today at Nagoya City University Hospital, hospital officials said. He was 79 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''All nations that value democracy, that understand free and fair elections are the very heart of their democratic system, should speak out against election fraud in Panama. And that means the democracies in Europe.'' - President Bush. [ A3:4. ]

title: Bank Yields Reported Flat For Week
description: Yields for certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts were flat for the week ended yesterday.

title: Boom Summer for Film Sequels
description: In the seven weeks from late this month to the middle of July, Hollywood will release more sequels to blockbuster movies than at any time in its history.

title: Topics of The Times; Surrogate Mother
description: The woman looked out a window of the Manhattan Surrogate's courtroom at a dingy sight: a grimy fifth-floor ledge littered with bits of cellophane, a cigarette butt and, of course, a pigeon. This pigeon, though, sat strangely still and silent, serene even, as it nestled among the steely spikes meant to deter its presence. Was it sick or injured?

title: Cold Water on Cold Fusion
description: LEAD: Two chemists, Stanley Pons at the University of Utah and Martin Fleischmann at the University of Southampton, England, startled the world this spring with an announcement that they had achieved nuclear fusion at room temperatures. As evidence, they cited the production of ''excess'' amounts of heat in an electrochemical apparatus and the observation of neutron production.

description: b-Included income of $6,624,000 from discontinued operations and a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $23,674,000. description: Robbie Ftorek, who guided the Los Angeles Kings to their third-best regular-season record ever this season, was dismissed yesterday after nearly two years as their head coach.

description: The Walt Disney Company said today that its net income in the quarter ended March 31 increased 24.1 percent over the corresponding period last year, largely because of sharply higher profits at its theme parks.

description: Pope John Paul II landed in southern Africa today, and wasted no time lashing out against apartheid and urging Zambia to take the lead in bringing peace to this troubled sector of the continent.

title: Review/Film; Aggressive Objects Take It Out on Helpless People
description: The eight short works in ''Jan Svankmajer: Alchemist of the Surreal'' are tiny, esoteric masterpieces that blend spectacular animation with good old-fashioned surrealism. Only in the bizarre world of this Czechoslovak film maker would ''Punch and Judy'' have the alternate title ''The Coffin Factory'' and show puppets escaping from prettily decorated coffins. Childhood toys and games are Mr. Svankmajer's favorite vehicles for his playful meditations on death.

description: A senior Reagan Administration official charged today that American allies, particularly West Germany, had ignored hundreds of diplomatic protests leveled by the United States in recent years over exports of weapons technology to the Soviet Union and the third world.

title: A Summer Everlasting: Little League Turns 50
description: The umpire crouched behind the plate as Keith Weglarz rocked into his windup. Behind him, the White Sox infielders pounded their gloves, leaned forward and began the ritual chant that signals the coming of another spring in America: ''Hey batterbatterbatterbatterbatter!''

title: Kean Proposes a Test of His Plan To Offer School Choice to Students
description: To improve public schools by making them compete for students, Gov. Thomas H. Kean proposed a pilot program today in which parents in six districts could choose the schools they want their children to attend.

title: Thatcher's Ottoman Empire
description: LEAD: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher of Britain, a champion of Mikhail Gorbachev's liberalization policies, seeks to strengthen him at home by enhancing his prestige abroad. She has publicly expressed hope that Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania will remain quietly within the Soviet Union - even though Britain has never legally recognized the annexations of those countries.

title: Thomson in Deal for Lawyers Co-op
description: The International Thomson Organization announced yesterday that it had won a multimillion-dollar bidding contest for the Lawyers Co-operative Publishing Company.

description: Executive Order 12676 of April 26, delegating authority to provide assistance for the Nicaraguan resistance.

description: Wendy Wasserstein's ''Heidi Chronicles'' won the Outer Critics Circle award for best Broadway play Monday, and ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway'' was named best Broadway musical.

title: Government Opens Case Against Bilzerian
description: In opening arguments in his trial on securities fraud charges, Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida investor who owns the Singer Company, was described by the Government as a takeover artist who used ''trickery and deceit'' to enrich himself.

title: Bergner May Keep Milwaukee Base
description: The chairman of P. A. Bergner & Company said he was inclined to keep the department store company's headquarters in Milwaukee after acquiring the Chicago-based Carson Pirie Scott & Company. Bergner and Carson announced on Monday that they would merge in a $453 million deal. The combined companies will control more than 60 stores in Wisconsin, Illinois, Indiana, Minnesota and Iowa.

title: M.I.T. Study Asks Change
description: A study by the Massachusetts Institute of Technology released yesterday calls for widespread changes in the way American companies operate, saying that manufacturers must pay stricter attention to retraining, technology and basic education to improve the country's international competitiveness.

title: American Financial Enterrises reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter included a gain of $9.1 million from the company's share of Penn Central's gain on the disposal of its foreign wire and cable operations. At March 31, American Financial owned about 21 percent of both Penn Central Corp. and Sprague Technologies Inc.'s common stock.

description: b-Net income

title: Flames Beat Blackhawks And Continue Their March
description: Al MacInnis assisted on goals by Jamie Macoun and Joe Nieuwendyk and led a defense that held Chicago to nine shots in the first two periods as Calgary opened the Campbell Conference finals tonight with a 3-0 victory over the Blackhawks.

title: Piccadilly Cafeterias Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $2,551,000 from an accounting change.

title: Economic Scene; The Last Laugh Of the Kingfish
description: CAN Louisiana, where every man is king providing he has a brother-in-law in the Legislature to steal the throne, make the break with its raffish, populist past? Louisianians who thought the state was ripe for change were in for a rude shock last Saturday as the voters rejected a modest first step toward buttoned-down government.

Fiscal 1988 loss from continuing operations included non-recurring charges aggregating $96,000, exclusive of income tax recovery, relating to severance payments to a former officer of the company and legal costs relating to arbitration proceedings with the former officer.

title: Ringold Journal; A Stretch of River That Time Forgot
description: By quirk of history, a shank of sagebrush country that the Government set aside nearly half a century ago as home for some of the nation's darkest nuclear secrets has become one of its brightest natural wonders.

title: 6,000 Shanghai Students Hold Pro-Democracy March
description: Thousands of students marched through Shanghai today, in the first indication that China's pro-democracy movement had spread in a major way to the nation's largest city and economic capital.

title: New Countdown Starts For Shuttle Launching
description: An abbreviated countdown began today for the launching Thursday of the space shuttle Atlantis on its delayed planetary mission.

title: KOHL IS OPTIMISTIC ON NATO HARMONY
description: As consultations continued in an effort to avoid a serious rift in the Atlantic alliance, Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today that West Germany was willing to modify its call for East-West talks on short-range nuclear weapons.

title: Pact on the FSX Appears Little Changed
description: As the details emerge, the agreement reached last week between the United States and Japan to build the FSX fighter appears to be littled changed on the safeguards on the transfer of technology to the Japanese, officials on both sides say.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: THE CAPITAL
description: After dinner the other night at a party in Washington, an out-of-town visitor, a businessman, posed a pungent but seldom-asked question.

title: Judge Rejects Effort to Stop S.I. Navy Port
description: Citing national security concerns, a Federal judge in Brooklyn yesterday removed the last major obstacle to the Navy's plan to open a new port on Staten Island that critics have said will be a base for nuclear weapons in New York harbor.

title: Bush Warns Panama on Election Fraud
description: President Bush warned Panama today that the United States will not recognize the presidential election on Sunday if the results are rigged. He said it was evident that the Government of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega was ''ready to resort to massive election fraud.''

title: Atlanta Post for a USA Today Editor
description: The publisher of The Atlanta Constitution and The Atlanta Journal announced yesterday that Ron Martin, second-ranked editor at USA Today, would become the editor of the newspapers on Sunday.

title: A Panel Dooms Estimate Board
description: The commission writing a new charter for New York City rejected a proposal to preserve the Board of Estimate, in effect recommending it be abolished.

title: House Panel Passes Its Version of Savings Plan
description: After considering more than 100 amendments, the House Banking Committee today approved its version of the Bush savings and loan rescue plan. The legislation imposes tougher capital standards on the industry than the White House plan, while providing subsidies for low- to moderate-income home buyers.

title: Emerson Electric Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: The Chrysler Corporation yesterday reported a 90.8 percent increase in its first-quarter net income, helped by a special charge in the first quarter of last year.

title: Carl Clemens, 83, Ex-Publisher in Queens
description: Carl E. Clemens, a reporter, editor and publisher of The Ridgewood (Queens) Times, died Monday at his home in Ridgewood. He was 83 years old.

description: In ''Growing Up in America,'' a documentary feature opening today at the Bleecker Street Cinema, Morley Markson, the film maker, revisits nine of the 1960's counterculture figures who were the subject of his 1971 documentary ''Breathing Together: Revolution of the Electric Family.''

Panel Gives Ladies' Mile Historic District Status
description: Ladies' Mile, a nine-block-long stretch of architectural grandeur that once epitomized elegance in Manhattan, was designated a historic district yesterday by the New York City Landmarks Preservation Commission.

description: * BCE Development Corp., Vancouver, British Columbia, a subsidiary of BCE Inc., said it would sell all of its American real estate assets, which have an estimated book value of $1.4 billion.

description: b-After a tax credit of $2.8 million. c-After income from discontinued operations of $1.6 million and a tax credit of $3.5 million. Year-ago period has been reclassified.

title: Bold Plan for NATO
description: The frantic diplomatic merry-go-round to prevent a dust-up at NATO's summit meeting isn't good enough. No doubt some kind of compromise formula will be found to paper over the dispute on negotiating with the Soviets for cuts in short-range nuclear weapons.

title: Protest in Tompkins Square Park Draws 300 Officers and 16 Arrests
description: More than 300 police officers in riot gear descended on the Tompkins Square Park area yesterday, where hundreds of people were protesting the demolition of a city-owned building.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: IT'S not easy being a cook in New Orleans. First of all, anybody with a family recipe for alligator sausage or etouffee considers himself a cook, not to mention the hundreds of professional cooks responsible for New Orleans's culinary reputation.

title: Guilt Admitted in Racial Killing
description: A man has pleaded guilty to murder in the racial slaying of a black man whose head was struck so hard with a baseball bat that the bat split.

title: Ojeda Changes Speed, Tries Fast Lane and Gains First Victory
description: After five starts and no victories this season, Bob Ojeda finally broke his slump. The 31-year-old lefthander scattered five hits over eight innings tonight as the Mets ended a five-game road trip by beating the Braves, 7-1, for their 10th victory in the last 12 games.

title: Administration Says Pact With Japan Protects Technology
description: Top Bush Administration officials told Congress today that safeguards written into a revised agreement with Japan on co-producing a new jet fighter make it practically impossible for Tokyo to use the technology to further Japanese ambitions in civil aviation.

title: Rangers Vanquish Frustrated Yankees
description: Don Mattingly said the word over and over again tonight. Frustrating. That was how he felt. He is 26 games into the season, and he cannot escape the dull sensation. But he is not alone. The Yankees, whose offense has sputtered and coughed for a month now, were held to two hits by a rookie pitcher and handed a 4-1 loss by the Texas Rangers at Arlington Stadium. Their collective frustration continues.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16 President Bush's rejection of talks with the Soviet Union on curbing nuclear armed short-range weapons came under fire from Democratic Congressional leaders. Page A1

title: Derlan Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: How to Pay the Public's Tuition Bill
description: Gov. Mario Cuomo has vetoed a proposed tuition increase for New York's public universities. The veto looks like a capitulation to angry student demonstrations. But Mr. Cuomo has frequently voiced opposition to a tuition increase. And he insists that administrative savings at the State University of New York and the City University of New York would spare making students pay more. His veto now forces the universities to make an effective counterargument.

title: ANTITRUST EASING WILL BE PROPOSED TO AID TV EFFORT
description: The Bush Administration is preparing to propose a major relaxation of antitrust laws, with the goal of permitting companies like Motorola, A.T.&T. and I.B.M. to work together to produce high-technology equipment, starting with high-definition television sets.

title: Poor Children Hospitalized More Than Others, Data Say
description: Children from poorer families are likelier to be hospitalized, and for longer periods, than those whose families have more money, a new study indicates. The researchers suggested that the disparity may stem from access to routine medical care.

title: Parley Aims At Nurturing Black Youths
description: In the face of sobering statistics about dropouts, crime and drugs among young black men, a conference here early this week examined half a dozen volunteer efforts aimed at learning, pride and responsibility.

title: U.S. Policy on Arms Talks: Continuity
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d will inform Soviet leaders next week that the United States will stick with the basic framework of the strategic-arms treaty as negotiated under President Reagan, Administration officials said today.

title: Changes Are Needed By Celtics
description: It is an unusual position for the proud Boston Celtics.

title: Captives at the Opera: Fans Dig In for Wagner
description: New York's music lovers have been '' 'Ring' cycling'' lately, a rarely indulged passion sometimes compared to a ''runner's high'' but infinitely more cultivated and sedentary: It involves 16 hours of sitting.

title: NATION'S SCHOOLS TERMED 'STAGNANT' IN FEDERAL REPORT
description: The Bush Administration said today that the performance of the nation's schools was ''merely average'' and ''stagnant,'' with no improvement despite increases in spending.

title: General Re Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After realized gains of $23.7 million. c-After realized gains of $5.9 million and net from discontinued operations of $6.6 million. The company said the 1988 first quarter figures have been restated to reflect discontinued operations and the adoption of accounting changes which require the inclusion of realized investment gains or losses in the revenue and operating income of the corporation.

title: Agency Bars Paying Whistle-Blowers for Silence
description: An electrical foreman at a Texas nuclear plant was paid by his former employers in exchange for a promise not to tell Federal officials about what he says were safety problems there, even if subpoenaed.

title: Wheatland to Merge 2 Units; Publishing Chief Is Leaving
description: Reflecting dissatisfaction with their lagging publishing operations, Ann Getty and Lord Weidenfeld announced yesterday that Weidenfeld & Nicolson and Grove Press, the publishing arms of the Wheatland Corporation, would be combined into a single company, to be called Grove Weidenfeld.

title: Review/Music; It's Germany in the 1600's, Viols, Cornets, Sacbuts et al.
description: The New York Consort of Viols and the New York Cornet and Sacbut Ensemble count as two of this city's veteran Renaissance and early Baroque performing groups. They arose some 15 years ago in the wake of the New York Pro Musica, and hence represent the fragmentation of the early-music scene here since the demise of that estimable institution.

title: Consumers Water Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest first quarter included a gain of $300,000 from the sale of property.

title: Market Place; Investors Favor Savings Industry
description: FEW industries have as much going against them as the savings and loan business. But many savings institution stocks have come alive in the last month, and the group has outperformed the stock market.

title: Horizon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $469,000.

title: Amvestors Financial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings have been restated to reflect 25 percent stock dividends paid July 15, 1988 and May 1, 1989.

title: Ravitch Formally Joins Mayoral Race
description: Calling himself an independent outsider and ''the guy the politicians have called on to solve the problems,'' Richard Ravitch formally announced his candidacy for mayor yesterday.

title: Life Insurer In New York To Be Sold
description: The First Executive Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell a subsidiary, the Executive Life Insurance Company of New York, to an outside group for about $460 million.

title: HEALTH: Medical Technology; New Device Is Seen as Boon for Oxygen-Dependent Patients
description: A new device that greatly eases breathing for patients dependent on oxygen therapy has proved so successful in clinical tests that it is now being studied for broader uses in the United States and abroad. The device, which is portable, allows oxygen-dependent patients to pursue normal activities like dining out, traveling and even playing golf.

title: Top Surf Casters Hoping to Heave Way to Title
description: rrSpectators will be able to watch some of this country's top distance surf casters heave 5 1/4 sinkers 700 feet and more this Saturday and Sunday at Cape Henlopen State Park in Lewes, Del.

title: A Warhol 'Red Marilyn' Sets Record at Christie's
description: Andy Warhol's ''Shot Red Marilyn,'' was auctioned last night at Christie's for $4.07 million, the highest price ever paid at auction for a painting by the artist. The 40-inch-square painting brought double the price expected and was the highest sum paid for a work in Christie's sale which totaled $31.8 million. Of the 66 lots offered, 6 did not find buyers.

title: Former Capital Official Indicted
description: A Federal grand jury indicted two men today, including a former top city official who is a friend of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., on charges of fraud, bribery and conspiracy involving $3 million in city contracts.

title: El Salvador Benefit
description: To raise funds for 13 repopulated rural towns in El Salvador, the Nest Foundation will hold a benefit sale of 60 contemporary paintings at the Leo Castelli Gallery, 578 Broadway, at Prince Street, through Saturday. Susan Rothenberg, Francesco Clemente and Claes Oldenburg are among the artists who have donated their work. Gallery hours are Tuesdays through Saturdays 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Information and reservations: 941-7962.

title: Ruotsalainen a Devil?
description: Reijo Ruotsalainen, the Finnish defenseman, who played for the Rangers for five seasons, is expected to sign with the Devils today. The 28-year-old Ruotsalainen, an offense-minded defenseman, scored 89 goals and had 217 assists in five seasons with the Rangers. He was traded to the Edmonton Oilers by the Rangers in 1986 and won a Stanley Cup with the Oilers in 1987 after joining them late in the season. The Oilers left Ruotsalainen unprotected in the 1987 waiver draft and he was claimed by the Devils.

title: Bronx Firehouse Closes Pending a Court Ruling
description: A South Bronx firehouse was shut last night after a state appellate court denied a motion to prevent the city from closing the firehouse while a lower court judge decides its permanent status.

title: Argentina Begins Policies to Try to Stabilize the Economy
description: Argentina put into practice today a series of tax, pricing and exchange policies intended to stabilize the economy and turned to the country's largest corporations for $500 million in loans.

title: Cuomo Hints at Inquiry Over 5/ Bottle Deposits
description: Frustrated because the State Legislature has refused to act on his attempts to recover unclaimed bottle deposits, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today threatened to appoint a special commission to investigate the bottling industry if the lawmakers did not take action.

title: Day After Tuition Veto, CUNY Protest Goes On
description: One day after Gov. Mario M. Cuomo vetoed a proposed tuition increase that had prompted demonstrations throughout the City University system, students remained entrenched yesterday in administration buildings on 10 campuses. They said they would not surrender until the state guaranteed that the university's budget would not be cut further.

title: Choice of New Immigration Head Is Reported
description: The White House is expected to nominate a St. Louis politician and longtime supporter of President Bush as Commissioner of Immigration and Naturalization, a Justice Department official said today.

title: Jerusalem Remains Committed to Allowing Access to Holy Sites
description: To the Editor:

title: Pasture Greener in Right for Yanks
description: It's only a patch of grass - sometimes it's even artificial - but the Yankees have a lot of money invested in it, more than $4.5 million.

title: Review/Music; A Pianist's Particular View
description: One doesn't normally think of Beethoven's final piano sonata as a youthful, bristling work. But at Weill Recital Hall on Monday evening, Thomas Otten played long stretches of the piece as if it were the work of a young firebrand. And if he was not entirely convincing, he made a compelling case for his point of view.

title: Graceful Glass, Shaped by a Master
description: Archimede Seguso is a tall, thin man with the erect carriage of a grenadier. How does an 80-year-old maintain such straight shoulders, yet spry movement? Possibly by spending 67 years doing the craft equivalent of pumping iron: blowing glass.

description: LEAD: Domestic vehicle sales were slightly weaker in late April than they had been a year earlier, but they finished the month strong enough to allay fears that substantial production cuts would be needed later this year.

description: Pat Burns, the Canadiens' coach, joked that he relied on the suggestion of his son when he made the decision to give Patrick Roy, an unflappable goaltender against every team but the Flyers, a second chance in goal against them tonight.

title: Reviving a Hotel With Paint and Fantasy
description: As soon as the artist and rock guitarist Samoa got a glimpse of Room 208 of the New Leonard Beach Hotel here, it was obvious to him what he had to do: tattoo it. So he did.

title: Review/Theater; A Motown Songwriter Is Revisited
description: ''A Thrill a Moment,'' a new musical revue built around the work of the veteran Motown songwriter William (Mickey) Stevenson, resurrects an era of black music that, given today's aggressive hard-edged rap, seems downright quaint in its innocence.

title: Review/Theater; Literate Insults in a Sea of Sexuality
description: Early in David Mercer's ''No Limits to Love,'' which is being given its New York premiere at the New Theater of Brooklyn, there is some light banter about the inanities of the British theater of the 1970's. Three characters are discussing a play they recently saw. Why, one asks, was everyone in the cast having sex with one another in the second act? The answer (something about socioeconomic conditions in Britain) is unimportant. But it is the sort of question one might ask leaving ''No Limits to Love.''
