title: LIBERALS' LEADER IN CANADA TO QUIT
description: John N. Turner, the opposition leader who campaigned against the free-trade agreement during an unsuccessful bid to regain the Prime Minister's post, announced today that he would resign as Liberal Party leader.

title: License Step For Seabrook
description: The Seabrook nuclear plant took a small step toward winning a low-power license yesterday when the staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission concluded that the owners had met the commission's special requirements on financing for decommissioning.

title: Campaign Matters; Tammany Tiger Loses Teeth But Adds Stripes
description: rrPolitical bosses have fallen on hard times.

title: Clippers-Walton Suit Ordered to Arbitration
description: The Los Angeles Clippers and Bill Walton were ordered yesterday by a Superior Court judge to go to arbitration in an attempt to resolve differences over a lawsuit in which the Clippers say Walton failed to live up to his contract.

title: Productivity Rises 0.5% In Quarter
description: Business productivity rose at an annual rate of five-tenths of 1 percent in the first quarter of this year, with manufacturing workers significantly increasing their output per hour.

title: Houston Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said earnings for the latest first quarter would have been $51.6 million, or 43 cents a share, had it not been for the recording in March 1989 of certain cost deferrals related to 1988.

title: Bridge
description: A celebrated investor once offered a possible silver lining for jail overcrowding. ''If I ever go to jail,'' said Warren Buffett of Berkshire Hathaway, ''I'd want my cellmates to be bridge players.''

title: Bush Nominee Backs Business With Pretoria
description: President Bush's nominee for a top State Department position said today that the Government should encourage American companies to stay in South Africa so they could set an example of socially responsible behavior for local South African businesses.

title: S.E.C. Moves Against Four
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today charged four former officials of the Systems and Computer Technology Corporation with preparing false and misleading quarterly financial statements for the Malvern, Pa., computer services company in 1984.

title: Treasury Bonds Fall Sharply
description: Treasury bond prices fell by more than half a point near the close of trading yesterday after the Treasury Department dashed hopes that bonds to finance the savings industry rescue plan would come from the existing pool of long-term Treasury debt.

title: Interleaf Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $50,000 for the quarter and $1,411,000 for the year.

title: Herman H. Cohen, 86, C.P.A. and Lawyer
description: Herman H. Cohen, a certified public accountant and lawyer who practiced in Manhattan for more than half a century, died of kidney disease Saturday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: From Toothpaste Boxes to Radio City
description: DONALD DESKEY, who died last Saturday in Florida at the age of 94, was one of the last leaders of the generation of industrial designers that included Raymond Loewy and Norman Bel Geddes.

title: Alien Wins Lottery and Right to Stay in U.S.
description: Four days after winning a $5.3 million lottery jackpot, a Nicaraguan immigrant today won political asylum in this country when immigration officials reversed an earlier decision denying his application.

title: Koch Voices Some Doubts On Charter
description: In his most detailed response to the efforts of the New York City Charter Revision Commission, Mayor Edward I. Koch said he has ''some doubts'' about a proposal that would radically alter the shape of a government he has led for more than 11 years.

title: The Dollar's Stubborn Strength
description: Despite repeated efforts by central banks to knock it down, the pesky dollar is proving surprisingly resilient this year because it has become one of the safest bets in the huge, $400 billion foreign exchange market.

title: Judge in North Trial Extends Jury's Hours to Speed Verdict
description: The judge in the trial of Oliver L. North said today that he had extended the jury's working hours but would take no other steps to hasten its deliberations. The jurors today completed their 11th day of deliberations.

title: Poverty and Prayers Greet Pope in Zambia
description: A few hundred yards from where the papal caravan had turned down a gravel road to the skillet-flat field and another Mass, Alfred Phiri bent over his hoe today and tilled the tomato garden behind his small house.

title: Ex-City Official in Michigan Pleads Guilty to Drug Count
description: A former Charlevoix City Attorney, Jeffery W. Van Treese, pleaded guilty Tuesday to possessing cocaine.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Computer Factory Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. School Restores A Palace
description: CHARTERED by an act of Congress in 1905, the American Academy in Rome is an interdisciplinary center for study of the fine arts and humanities. The Academy's 10-acre, 10-building compound includes Villa Aurelia, a 17th-century summer palace.

title: Marine Pilot Killed in Crash
description: A military jet crashed during a training flight today, and the pilot died from injuries suffered when he ejected moments earlier, Marines Corps officials said. The single-seat AV-8 Harrier crashed about 9 A.M. near a training airfield at the Marine Corps Recruiting Depot near Beaufort. The pilot, whose name was withheld, was one of 25,600 marines and sailors taking part in the Solid Shield '89 training exercise, which began today and is scheduled to run until May 20.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: REPLACING a toilet is a major project, but it is not as difficult as might be imagined. The hardest tasks are usually selecting a new toilet and removing the old one. This article deals with replacing the most common toilet, the freestanding type with the tank mounted to the bowl.

title: Inmates Find Comfort in a Voice From Home
description: Speaking in the language of the streets of San Juan, the grizzled evangelist recounted his personal journey through the degradations of alcoholism, drugs, prostitutes and violent brawls.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Vieira Upsets Sukova: Andrea Vieira, an 18-year-old Brazilian, upset second-seeded Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, 7-5, 1-6, 6-4, at the Virginia Slims women's tournament in Hamburg, West Germany. The match was interrupted by darkness Tuesday, and Vieira completed the victory when it was resumed yesterday. Sylvia Hanika of West Germany reached the third round by beating Patricia Tarabini of Argentina, 6-3, 6-1. Arantxa Sanchez of Spain defeated Wiltrud Probst of West Germany, 6-2, 6-2, while Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria beat Christine Damas of France, 6-2, 6-3. Nicole Jagerman of the Netherlands earned the right to become top-seeded Steffi Graf's first opponent by defeating Gisele Miro of Brazil, 6-3, 6-1. Graf advanced to the third round by default when another West German, Sabine Hack, fell ill and withdrew. (AP) YACHTING Brigden Wins Regatta: Mary Brigden of the United States Naval Academy won the Betsy Ross Bowl, a three-day regatta featuring leading female sailors, in New York Harbor yesterday. Heather Gregg of Harwick Port, Mass., placed second, and Heidi Ziegler of Darien, Conn., third. ROWING Princeton Overcomes Yale: Princeton dominated its heavyweight regatta with Yale yesterday on the Housatonic River in Derby, Conn., winning the varsity and freshman races and losing the junior varsity match by half a second. After an even race for 1,500 meters, Princeton drew away to win the 2,000-meter contest by 3.2 seconds, in 5 minutes 24.4 seconds. The Princeton freshmen won by three-quarters of a boat length despite a collision in the final 150 meters when Yale moved into Princeton's lane.

title: Cineplex Bidders Sought
description: The two senior officers of the Cineplex Odeon Corporation said today that they were seeking individual partners or corporations that might be interested in bidding for control of the motion picture and theater company. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Garth H. Drabinsky, chairman of Cineplex Odeon, and Myron I. Gottlieb, vice chairman, said no group had been formed and no other managers had joined their efforts. Mr. Drabinsky and Mr. Gottlieb control 10.5 percent of the Toronto-based company's stock. Cineplex's stock fell 25 cents a share today, to $15, on the New York Stock Exchange. At the current market price, the company is worth more than $810 million.

title: Judges Back Homosexual Soldier; Basic Bias Issue Is Left Unsettled
description: A Federal appeals court here today ordered the Army to make an exception to its ban on homosexuals and allow a former sergeant who is gay to re-enlist.

title: Study Sees Release of Radiation In Ohio as 6 Times U.S. Estimate
description: The Fernald nuclear weapons plant in Ohio released up to six times as much radioactive uranium dust into the atmosphere as the Government has disclosed, according to a private study released here today.

title: Zenith National Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included net capital gains equaled to 3 cents a share. Per share results reflected, retroactively, a 10 percent stock dividend paid on Aug. 12.

title: 'Trovatore' and 'Lucia' To Be Sung in the Parks
description: Performances of Verdi's ''Trovatore'' and Donizetti's ''Lucia di Lammermoor'' are to be offered by the Metropolitan Opera in its 23d season of free outdoor operas in New York and New Jersey parks.

title: Review/Cabaret; Gloria DeHaven's Songs
description: To find the kind of cabaret act that most singers have to pull out of thin air, Gloria DeHaven simply turns to her parents, the singing-and-dancing team of Mr. and Mrs. Carter DeHaven, and to her own career in Hollywood musicals of the 1940's and 50's. At Rainbow and Stars, the cabaret on the 65th floor of the RCA Building (30 Rockefeller Plaza), where she opened a three-week engagement on Tuesday, Miss DeHaven is drawing on both sources to create an act that turns what might be presented in glamorous terms into a warm, chatty, intimate recollection of a memorable era of popular music.

title: RLI Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Varco International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said results for the latest first quarter included the impact of the acquisition of the BJ Machinery division, concluded on Sept. 29, 1988.

title: Cuomo Vetoes Increase in Aid To Wildlife Lab
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, acting on an unusual request from one of his commissioners, has vetoed the Legislature's decision to direct extra funds to a state laboratory run by a wildlife pathologist who has frequently criticized state environmental investigations.

title: Demand for Used Jets Sends Prices Soaring
description: Frustrated by huge backlogs for delivery of new planes from manufacturers like the Boeing Company and the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, many airlines have decided to buy used jetliners. And despite growing concern about structural problems in aging aircraft, demand is higher than ever, causing prices to skyrocket.

title: Walter Blucher, 88, Urban Planning Expert
description: Walter H. Blucher, an authority on city planning who was a former director of the American Society of Planning Officials, died of bone cancer April 20 at his home in Napa, Calif. He was 88 years old.

title: H & R Block Is Busy
description: H & R Block Inc. said today that tax-preparation business at both company-owned and franchised offices worldwide rose 7.2 percent, to $630.9 million, in the year ended April 30, from $588.7 million a year earlier.

title: Why So Long In Pete Rose Inquiry?
description: rrMore than two months ago, on Feb. 20, in the Major League Baseball offices at 350 Park Avenue, Pete Rose met with both Bart Giamatti, then the commissioner-in-waiting, and Peter Ueberroth, his predecessor. Asked the next day if gambling had been discussed, the Cincinnati Reds' manager said, ''That's not the reason.'' Ueberroth also tried to defuse the situation.

title: Trimas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company's year-ago first quarter results are pro forma, reflecting the October 1988 acquisitions of nine operating businesses from Masco Industries as if they occurred Jan. 1, 1988. Trimas became a publicly-held company on Feb. 14, 1989, when Masco Corp. distributed 1.4 million Trimas common shares to Masco Corp. shareholders. Trimas had actual 1988 first quarter net income of $2,120,000 on $15,560,000 in sales.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Two Daring Campaigns Receive Andy Awards
description: The Advertising Club of New York bestowed Andy awards on two daring campaigns at its annual awards ceremony last night. Levine, Huntley, Schmidt & Beaver won two prizes -for best television campaign and individual ad - for ads that featured some of the world's less savory political strongmen as part of a strategy to promote the Beneficial Corporation as a more humane lending institution than traditional banks.

title: International Telecharge Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Albany Allows 'Poison Pills'
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today signed into law a bill allowing New York corporations to institute ''poison pill'' shareholder rights plans.

title: Blue Jays' Flanagan Shuts Out Athletics
description: Mike Flanagan pitched a four-hitter tonight as the Toronto Blue Jays beat the Oakland Athletics, 2-0.

title: Kelly Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
description: Sales represents sale of services.

title: CMS Enhancements Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said year-ago quarter and 9 months results are restated to reflect the issuance of 1,274,464 contingent shares to company founders in January 1988.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Counting Viewers of Hispanic TV
description: UNIVISION and Telemundo, the two largest Spanish-language broadcasting companies in the United States, have always had a compelling sales pitch. Spanish-speaking consumers, they would say, make up a large and fast-growing market, and the best way to advertise to them is on television in their own language.

title: Sihanouk Says He May Return as Head of State
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the former Cambodian leader, indicated today for the first time that he is prepared to return home as head of state in a government dominated by men installed by the Vietnamese Army in an invasion 10 years ago.

title: Accord on U.S. Beef Exports
description: The United States and the European Community today announced an agreement that American officials predicted would clear the way for small amounts of American beef to be exported to the European Community.

title: United Savings & Loan reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Tax Collections Off, Threatening Kean Budget
description: Gov. Thomas H. Kean said today that state tax collections, with the exception of the income tax, were continuing to fall below expectations, and that an anticipated $290 million budget problem could grow to between $400 million and $550 million in the next budget year.

title: Home Owners Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $2,320,000 from the early extinguishment of debt for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income d-After a gain of $2,742,000 from the early extinguishment of debt.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: MY brother-in-law speaks of going to Scotland again this fall. He and my sister were there two years ago, he playing golf and she looking for tall people with hazel eyes and crooked teeth. It was a joke we had. Our paternal grandfather, who died before we were born, came from Scotland, and anyone who fit his description was, we figured, a relative. My sister looked our name up, too. As near as we could tell from the printout, it was French a millenium or so back and translated to, I think, ''shortsighted.''

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: SEVENTEEN-YEAR-OLD Joseph Cacciato, a senior at Scarsdale High School in Scarsdale, N.Y., is looking forward to a formal prom night on June 26. With the help of his parents, he's been arranging for a tuxedo, a limousine (which he and his date will share with two other couples) and a fancy dinner in Manhattan to be followed by the prom in Westchester and a sunrise breakfast and gathering with classmates at Jones Beach on Long Island.

title: Review/Dance; Honoring a Pioneer Who Tried to Keep the Steps Fresh
description: Dancers, choreographers, teachers and dance lovers gathered Sunday afternoon at the Jose Limon Studio for ''Weidman Celebration,'' a program honoring Charles Weidman, one of the pioneers of modern dance. During the 1930's and early 1940's, Weidman was co-director, with Doris Humphrey, of the highly influential Humphrey-Weidman Dance Company, and until his death in 1975 at the age of 74 he remained a respected choreographer and teacher.

title: Turning Up The Heat With Class
description: IT is what most people consider a low-profile product: the thermostat that hangs inconspicuously on a wall, tended to only when the temperature in a house needs regulating.

title: Micron Products reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Money Fund Yields Mixed
description: Yields offered by money market mutual funds were mostly down in taxable funds but up in tax-exempt funds for the week ended yesterday.

title: LCS Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $42,000 for the quarter and $66,000 for the 6 months.

title: A Rarity by Rossini Is Revived to Acclaim
description: Rossini wrote ''Zelmira'' in 1822 for the woman he loved, and took it triumphantly to Vienna, London and Paris. But that was almost the end of ''Zelmira,'' a dramatic opera that was neither lost nor forgotten, but is virtually unperformed today. For more than a century, musical directors and singers have gone out of their way to avoid this complicated and majestic work.

title: American First reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $8,379. c-Net loss and after income from discontinued operations of $295,975.

title: Pan Am Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest quarter results included income from discontinued operations of $3.7 million, compared with $6 million for the year-ago period.

title: Vast Majority Is Pro-Choice, Not Pro-Abortion; Right of Privacy
description: To the Editor:

title: Investors Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: John J. McNamara, 79, Ex-Head of M & M
description: John J. McNamara, a former president of M&M Candies, died last Thursday after suffering a heart attack while visiting relatives in DeKalb, Ill. He was 79 years old and lived in Bakersfield, Calif.

title: Citadel Holding Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said its earnings and net interest margin reductions were primarily caused by a significant rise in its cost of funds. The company also said contributing to the declines in earnings and margin was an increase in loss provisions and expenses on real estate and loans, which were $2,161,000 in the latest quarter, compared with $543,000 for the year-ago first quarter. Deferrals of loan fee origination costs, required by recently enacted financial accounting rules, were lower in the current quarter than in the 1988 quarter, further reducing net income by approximately $540,000.

title: Cocaine Use in Pregnancy Amounts to Child Abuse, a Judge Rules
description: A woman who was found to have used cocaine during her pregnancy, even hours before giving birth, has been convicted by a Juvenile Court judge here of prenatal child abuse and neglect.

title: Metro Datelines; Kingsbrook Nurses Meet With Mediator
description: A Federal mediator yesterday called together leaders of striking nurses and officials of the Kingsbrook Jewish Medical Center to try to end a walkout that began April 24.

title: Mother Is Charged Because a Son Is California Street Gang Suspect
description: Employing a new state law intended to hold parents responsible for the criminal activity of their children, the police here have arrested the mother of a 17-year-old suspect in a rape case on the ground that she condoned his membership in a street gang.

title: Bolar Pharmaceutical reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said earnings for the latest first quarter were less than anticipated because of high research and development expenses, $6.2 million for the latest quarter, compared to $3.2 million for the year-ago first quarter.

title: Bhopal Case Ruling Due
description: India's Supreme Court said today that it would rule next week on petitions challenging a law under which the Union Carbide Corporation paid $470 million in compensation to victims of the Bhopal gas disaster.

title: CSS Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Europe Cites U.S. Barriers To Trading
description: The European Community's executive branch today released its 1989 report on trade barriers imposed by the United States, singling out 42 regulations and trade practices that it said impede imports from the 12 community nations.

title: Bush Buoys Horseshoes Industry
description: The world's largest maker of horseshoes is hoping that President Bush will pitch the backyard sport into popularity and increase horseshoe sales.

title: Critic's Notebook; Turn in Fiction: The New Post-Minimalism
description: In a typical scene from a trendy new novel, the men from the county road crew get off work. Ed King heads for the Hill Top Tap and Sam Hall for the Mohawk Grill, where they gossip about their co-worker, Aubrey Wallace, who drove off in his pickup truck one lunch hour and hasn't been heard from since.

title: Washington Talk; Politics
description: A Congressman from a Midwestern state says hardly a year goes by when he does not turn down an offer from a banker or a builder in his district to earn a quick buck from a special deal.

title: TV Notes
description: Contract Is Rejected The National Association of Broadcast Employees and Technicians rejected a contract offer yesterday from Capital Cities/American Broadcasting Companies that the network called its final offer. ABC's contract with the union expired March 31. The union stressed that while a vote to reject the offer was not a vote to strike at this stage, such an action remained a possibility. ABC, in turn, has said it was prepared to use management and other personnel to fill essential jobs in the event of a strike.

title: Koch Administration Considering A Surcharge on City's Income Tax
description: The Koch administration is considering proposing a surcharge on the New York City income tax to help balance the budget for the coming fiscal year, a city official said yesterday.

title: Aggressive Inquiry Is Promised on Housing Fees for Top Republicans
description: Congressmen from both parties vowed today to conduct an aggressive investigation of a Federal housing program described by the chairman of the House Banking Committee as an illegal political fund for the benefit of high-ranking Republicans.

title: Bird reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a pretax gain of $1,339,000 from the sale of certain operations. The company said in both periods, net income did not cover preferred stock requirements.

title: Cuomo's Veto Of Tuition Rise Draws Attack
description: Legislators reacted angrily today to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's veto of a tuition increase for New York's State University and City University systems, saying that the Governor would either have to find more money for higher education or bear the responsibility for the cuts in programs that would occur.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Alleghany Corp. said it would acquire Sacramento Savings and Loan Association, a California institution with 43 branch offices, from the H. N. and Frances C. Berger Foundation for $150 million.

title: National Sea Products Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We used to think that Taiwan was a wretched place, but then we discovered it isn't like that.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Lois Wyse, Grandmothers' Grandmother
description: SHE runs a business, plays tennis, wears size 6 and knows her way around Paris.

title: Fear Of Freedom
description: Why is American television so shallow? Why is it so rarely willing to explore controversial issues more deeply than in shout shows?

title: HDR Power Systems reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
KEY RATES
Dubuque Journal; Iowa Betting on Riverboat Gambling
description: Dubuque will never be Monte Carlo, but it may be the closest thing to it in these parts by 1991, when the Midwest is to get its newest vice: riverboat gambling.

title: Rescue Capsule Saved Only 1 On Sinking Soviet Submarine
description: The Soviet experimental attack submarine that sank in the Norwegian Sea last month was equipped with a rescue sphere that malfunctioned when five trapped crew members tried to escape, an American official and Soviet publications say.

title: Tri-State Motor Transit Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Investment Firm Stake By Met Life
description: In a move that would increase its influence on Wall Street, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company has agreed to buy a 10 percent stake in CS First Boston Inc., the two companies announced yesterday.

title: Why Soak Everybody, for the Rich?
description: It's unfair. It's harmful. It's unnecessary. Three strikes: Yet President Bush's plan to lower the capital gains tax keeps resurfacing when it should be buried, once and for all.

title: Buffton Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $719,000 from an accounting change for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: South Africa Planning Election for Sept. 6
description: President P. W. Botha said today that a general election would be held Sept. 6. He is expected to retire soon afterward.

title: Sears Expansion
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company said it would open 20 Brand Central home appliance and electronics ''superstores-within-a-store'' in the Chicago area within 60 days. These outlets will be in addition to the 110 that opened within the last month, Sears said. The first Brand Central superstores, which opened last year in 18 Sears stores in Indiana and Kentucky, were an ''instant success,'' the retailer said. As a result, Sears said, it is expanding the concept to 400 stores this year and all of its stores next year.

title: Harris Steel Group Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $5,252,068 from discontinued operations and a $2 million special charge. c-Net loss and after a gain of $505,216 from discontinued operations and a $10 million special charge. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Drug Trial Starts For a Principal From the Bronx
description: Lawyers for Matthew Barnwell contended yesterday that the New York City elementary school principal, who went on trial yesterday on a drug charge, was a victim of a ''police frame-up.''

title: Expeditors Intl of Washington Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Park Victim, Out of Coma, Says 'Hello'
description: The jogger who was raped and beaten in Central Park has emerged from her nearly two-week coma, whispering a hoarse ''hello'' to her brother and, her doctors said yesterday, appearing to smile.

title: Dr. G. Alx Galvin, 83; Led Physicians' Group
description: Dr. G. Alx Galvin, a doctor who was the first black to become president of the New York State Academy of General Practice, died April 16 while visiting a sister in Baltimore. He was 83 years old and lived in Ithaca, N.Y.

title: Rose Report Is Being Assembled
description: The lawyer who has been investigating Pete Rose for the last two months will submit his report to Commissioner A. Bartlett Giamatti next week, baseball's deputy commissioner said yesterday.

title: Review/Music; Works of the 20th Century In Benefit for AIDS Center
description: The Oratorio Society of New York teamed up with the Tudor Singers of Montreal on Tuesday evening for a concert of 20th-century music at Carnegie Hall as a benefit for Bailey House, an AIDS resource center in Manhattan.

title: Salomon Names Head Of Asset Management
description: Salomon Brothers Inc. announced yesterday that it would enter the institutional investment management business and said it had hired Michael F. Holland, president of First Boston Asset Management Corporation, to head the operation.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ogilvy's Net Up 10.8% in Quarter
description: Three days after becoming the target of a takeover attempt, the Ogilvy Group reported yesterday that its first-quarter earnings rose 10.8 percent from the comparable period last year.

title: Metro Datelines; National Guard Joins Fight Against Drugs
description: New York State will get $1.8 million in Federal aid to help the National Guard fight illegal drug traffic, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said yesterday.

title: Wilander Takes Slide From No. 1 to Steppingstone
description: It might not be long before tennis fans begin calling Mats Wilander Magic for the disappearing act he has been practicing this year. In what may be the most dramatic turnabout in the era of open tennis, the quiet, introspective Swede has gone from No. 1 in the world to a steppingstone in just eight months.

title: Grawemeyer Award To Composer-Teacher
description: Chinary Ung, a composer and an associate professor of music at Arizona State University in Tempe, has won the $150,000 Grawemeyer Award for music.

description: To the Editor:

title: Talking Deals; Sea Containers' Novel Defense
description: SINCE March, when a big Swedish ferry company, Stena A.B., announced that it owned 8.2 percent of Sea Containers Ltd., a company based in Bermuda that also operates European ferry services, Wall Street professionals have been loading up on Sea Containers' stock.

title: Carter-Wallace Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Metro Datelines; Teamsters Officials Indicted in Extortion
description: Five people, including two teamsters' union officials and an associate of John Gotti, were indicted yesterday in Federal District Court in Brooklyn on charges of extorting money from air-freight companies at Kennedy International Airport.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Homart Development Co., Northeast division, to Cosmopulos, Crowley & Daly, with an undisclosed budget.

title: Groups Consider Takeover of Colt
description: A competing handgun maker and striking employees have separately expressed interest in buying Colt Firearms, which was put on the market last week by Colt Industries. The Smith & Wesson Corporation, the pistol maker owned by the Tomkins Corporation, said it had contacted Morgan Stanley & Company, the investment firm hired by Colt to sell the unit. And the United Automobile Workers union said the striking workers plan to bid for the unit. The workers walked out three years ago.

title: Salami Tactics
description: What a weird May Day: First, hardly anybody came to the Communist Party parade. Then the party leader, at an open town meeting, was asked what happened to the borrowed $18 billion that has become an intolerable debt burden. Finally, the state television gave equal time to panels run by the nascent opposition parties.

title: Top Drug Fighter Seeks Punishment Certainty
description: William J. Bennett, the director of drug control policy for the Bush Administration, said today that a good way to deter drug dealers and abusers is to make certain they know they will face stiff punishment if caught.

title: Xtra Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,043,000 for the quarter; the year included $297,000 in income from discontinued operations.

title: A Glittering Gathering Lobbies for the Arts
description: ''The insurance companies do it, the oil companies do it, and I'm glad the entertainment industry does it, too,'' said Senator Christopher J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, as he looked at a crowd that included Charlton Heston, Agnes de Mille and Joseph Papp. ''Business is done here,'' the Senator added.

title: Christine Jorgensen, 62, Is Dead; Was First to Have a Sex Change
description: Christine Jorgensen, a former Army private from the Bronx who underwent surgery and hormone treatments in Denmark in 1952 to change from a male to a female, died of cancer yesterday in San Clemente, Calif. She was 62 years old.

title: Inspiration Resources Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter results included a $2.1 million equity loss from the company's 50 percent interest in two gold affiliates.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on April 16 reported a debate at Brown University about a student magazine, Issues Monthly. It had published confidential university documents, which Brown officials said were obtained from searches of office trash. A dean questioned the university's financing of the magazine.

title: Canadian Pacific reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said first quarter results reflect mainly reduced volume of railway traffic, especially grain, and lower income from forest products. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Travelers Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter results included net realized investment gains of $1 million, compared with net realized investment losses of $11 million for the year-ago period. Travelers said its adoption of FASB 97 reduced its latest quarter net by $7 million, and its year-ago period's net by $6 million.

title: Legal Services: Answering the Call

His answer was a surprising ''no.'' Mr. Mallard said he might volunteer for a securities or bankruptcy case, but he wasn't a civil rights litigator. The court ordered him to take the case anyway. Mr. Mallard sued, took his own case to the United States Supreme Court - and won, 5 to 4.

title: Q&A
description: Treating Cedar Siding Q.My son recently moved into a new contemporary house that has an exterior partly of stone and partly of natural vertical cedar siding. He has been told that the cedar has to be treated with some kind of preservative every two or three years - at a cost of about $2,000 each time. Is this treatment necessary? A.Theoretically, a good grade of cedar siding needs no treatment to withstand the elements. But if left untreated the cedar will often discolor unevenly in various sections and airborne pollution or mildew may darken it. In addition, untreated cedar siding is more prone to splitting, cracking or checking. That is why most experts recommend applying a sealer or preservative every few years.

New York's Cool Blues, With a Hint Of Memphis
description: Blues music usually comes with a geographic tag, indicating a school of musicians: Chicago blues, Texas blues, Memphis blues and West Coast blues all have their masters, their rules and their sounds. New York blues - raw, gospel-influenced and conversant with jazz - blossomed after World War II until the early 60's and yielded a huge amount of music. But where other blues centers had their big names, New York - fed by the twin sources of North Carolina emigrants and unemployed swing-jazz musicians - had no major figures. Instead, it had flocks of talented sidemen, usually put to service backing visiting musicians in the studios. Because of this, New York blues has been traditionally overlooked by music fans and historians.

title: 500 Years of Art, for Seeing or for Sale
description: ART at this moment is almost everywhere in Manhattan, and almost everything is art. It may come with august credentials -in the auction houses, quite often, and in the Goya show at the Metropolitan Museum of Art - and downtown it may come with no credentials at all (and possibly be none the worse for that). It comes in storefronts, in grand uptown mansions, in museums famous worldwide and in multi-purpose buildings on 57th Street where a false step may put you in line for a shampoo and set. Most of the time it will cost you not one cent. Is there a better bargain? (The Auctions column appears on page C24; the reviews of gallery and museum shows are on pages C28-C30.)

description: In the coal fields of Virginia, the cries are of scab and giveback. But when the United Mine Workers of America confronts the management of the Pittston Company at its annual meeting next week, the ostensible issues will be far different: ''poison pills'' and secret voting for shareholders.

title: Scientists Defend Changes in Disputed Study
description: In a battle over scientific credibility, the Secret Service today said that notebooks connected with a disputed scientific paper had been altered, while scientists denied any wrongdoing and argued that any changes in the notes were irrelevant.

title: The Law: At the Bar; Stage-struck lawyer who commutes between careers in Washington and on Broadway.
description: More than most, lawyers are familiar with farce. But Ken Ludwig is one lawyer who creates it on the stage rather than the courtroom.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Dozens of subpoenas were served on commodity traders and Federal postal inspectors reportedly searched two offices as part of a sweeping investigation of commodity exchanges in New York. One focus of the inquiry was said to be trades executed to incur tax benefits illegally. [ Page D1. ] A proposal to help U.S. companies gain a foothold in high-definition television is expected to get wide support, in both Congress and industry. [ D3. ] The Pentagon may spend millions to keep the development of a new Marine Corps aircraft going, even though Defense Secretary Cheney plans to kill the project on Oct. 1. [ A1. ] The insurance reform initiative passed by California voters last fall was upheld almost totally by the state's Supreme Court. [ A1. ] INTERNATIONAL Canada inaugurated the longest rail tunnel in the Western Hemisphere, completing a task begun in haste and nationalistic anxiety more than a century ago. For the first time, trains carrying raw materials from the Canadian interior can run smoothly and without interruption to West Coast ports for shipment to the Pacific Rim countries. [ D1. ] Crucial negotiations to reduce Mexico's bank debt have reportedly been moving slowly because commercial banks have objected to the size of Mexico's proposal and are still uncertain about what incentives for debt reduction they will get from the I.M.F. and the World Bank. [ D2. ] THE MARKETS The stock market continued its weeklong retreat, with the Dow Jones industrial average falling 8.80 points to 2,384.90. [ D6. ] Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in light trading, but the day was highlighted by the successful sale of $9 billion worth of new one-year notes. [ D12. ] The dollar finished at varied levels against major foreign currencies as Federal Reserve intervention and a comment by the central bank's vice chairman sent mixed signals. [ D13. ] Commodities trading slowed in New York on news that the Government had subpoenaed the records of several firms and traders. Energy futures were mixed as crude oil futures rose over increased concern with North Sea oil production. [ D13. ] COMPANIES Many of the nation's biggest retailers reported strong April sales, paced by reinvigorated buying of women's apparel. Analysts predicted an improved second quarter. [ D1. ] I.B.M. is said to have expressed interest in joining a $4 billion government-backed European semiconductor research project, but European companies are reportedly blocking its entry. [ D1. ] The chairman of Avon Products reiterated that it intended to remain independent and to focus on its core beauty and direct-selling businesses. [ D5. ] CNW said it was meeting with potential bidders besides Japonica Partners. [ D5. ] Lilco warned that there could be serious power disruptions across Long Island this summer because of rising demand. [ B2. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The mine workers' union, in its strike against Pittston, is trying an unorthodox tactic, turning its focus from givebacks to ''poison pills'' and mounting a proxy fight over issues near and dear to institutional investors. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D1. ] U.S. budget and trade deficits pose an increasing risk to the nation's and the world's economic stability, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York warns. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Takeover battles in the advertising industry are another sign that a roster of talented individuals is less important in the contemporary agency business than global reach, academic observers say. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D15. ]

description: After waiting nearly an hour for the clouds to part, the astronauts of the space shuttle Atlantis rocketed into orbit today and sent a radar-mapping spacecraft on a 15-month, 795-million-mile journey to Venus.

title: Students at 10 CUNY Campuses Vote to End Their Tuition Protests
description: Leaders of a coalition of students occupying administration buildings on 10 CUNY campuses voted yesterday to accept an amnesty proposal and end sit-ins by this morning, three days after Gov. Mario M. Cuomo vetoed a proposed $200-a-year tuition increase.

The provision for loan losses was $10.5 million for 1988, compared with $2.8 million for 1987.

description: The gap between the nation's richest and poorest cities widened in 1987, with the Connecticut suburbs of New York remaining on top in personal income and Texas towns along the Mexican border remaining last, the Government reported today.

title: Johnson's Home Run Ends It In 10th
description: Months ago, the trade rumors were fierce and frequent and his next supposed place of employment changed nearly daily. Howard Johnson, understanding he couldn't determine where he might play, resolved to control completely the one place he'd have to make his living no matter what uniform he wore: the small chalk rectangle called the batter's box.

title: Review/Theater; Trying to Outsmart Death With a Cross-Country Trip
description: Tina Howe is one of the smartest playwrights we have, but does she really believe she can outsmart death? That seems to be the case in ''Approaching Zanzibar,'' her new play at the Second Stage. In this determinedly uplifting comedy, an American nuclear family confronts its mortality, then bounces back at once with renewed hope. And I mean literally bounces back. The evening ends with the characters jumping around an aged matriarch's death bed shouting ecstatic cries of ''Paradise!''

title: The Law; 'The People's Court': The Case for and Against It
description: It is a case of art altering life. ''The People's Court'' is an eight-year-old syndicated adventure in courtroom verite, the only such television program to use real people, real small-claims cases and a retired judge.

title: Bush Is for Sanctions on Chemical Arms
description: In an abrupt shift from the policy of the Reagan Administration, the Bush Administration said today that it would accept legislation to impose economic sanctions on countries that use chemical weapons and on companies that assist in the production of such weapons.

title: Dining Out Guide: Brooklyn
description: This is a summary of restaurant reviews that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current. Adele (Diner's Journal, Feb. 10, 1989), 501 11th Street (718-788-4980) - This former carriage house in the Park Slope section offers classical music and candlelight. An enticing starter is a duck consomme with foie gras dumplings. Roast duck is moist, with a black pepper sauce. Appetizers are $6 to $8, entrees $18 to $22. Dinner 6 to 10:30 P.M. Tuesday to Saturday, brunch 11:30 A.M. to 3 P.M. Sunday. Aunt Sonia (Diner's Journal, Jan. 13, 1989), 1123 Eighth Avenue, at 12th Street (718-965-9526) - This is a down-home, no-frills restaurant that turns out engaging budget fare. A terrific starter is blackened chicken croustades. Chicken also comes in a special Caribbean dish. Appetizers are $4.95 to $6.95, entrees $8.95 to $16.95. Dinner 5:30 to 10:30 P.M. daily (until 11:30 P.M. Friday and Saturday); brunch 11 A.M. to 3 P.M. Saturday and Sunday. De'Vine (Diner's Journal, July 10, 1987), 396 Seventh Avenue, at 12th Street (718-499-9861) - Billed as Brooklyn's first wine bar, this is a cheerful and casual spot in the Park Slope section. A full menu of terrines, salads, pastas and seafood is served. Appetizers are $4.95 to $6.95, entrees $9.95 to $14.95. Dinner 5 P.M. to midnight Tuesday to Thursday and Sunday (until 1 A.M. Friday and Saturday); brunch noon to 6 P.M. Sunday. Closed Monday. Gage & Tollner (Diner's Journal, Jan. 20, 1989), 372 Fulton Street (718-875-5181) - The menu of this 110-year-old landmark has been revitalized by Edna Lewis, the author of three books on Southern cuisine. Her contributions include well-seasoned chicken cooked in parchment and pan-fried quails with spoon bread. The best dessert is her bitter-chocolate souffle. Dinner appetizers are $4 to $6.50, entrees $9 to $18.50. Lunch noon to 3 P.M. Monday to Friday; dinner 5 to 10:30 P.M. Monday to Thursday (until 11:30 P.M. Friday), 4 to 11 P.M. Saturday, and 4 to 9 P.M. Sunday; brunch noon to 4 P.M. Sunday. Peter Luger

Rape - the Silence Is Criminal
description: The brutal rape and beating of a young woman who was left for dead by a teen-age gang was the most vicious in a series of assaults in Central Park on April 19. It was the only one involving sexual violence. Explanations that rely on race or class alone miss the key role that gen-der played: The jogger was victimized because she was a woman, and the boys apparently acted out of a misguided notion of how to prove their manhood.

description: b-Included a gain from discontinued operations of $12.7 million, or 16 cents a share. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $11 million, or 14 cents a share. Prior period results have been restated to reflect implementation of SFAS 97, which increased reported net income for the first quarter of 1988, principally in the Individual Financial Services segment, by $7.3 million.

title: 21 Strikers Arrested at Mine
description: State police arrested 21 strikers today for blocking the entrance to a mine run by the Pittston Coal Group. The demonstrators, members of the striking United Mine Workers, were trying to maintain pressure on the mining company as federally mediated talks over a new contract were beginning. The strike began April 5, It affects about 1,500 miners in Virginia and West Virginia. Two hundred other union miners working at Pittston operations in Kentucky have not left their jobs.

Mr. Irwin has said that the comedy at the St. James Theater is ''full of language but none of it written.'' The Tony nominations will be announced Monday.

At the center or around the edges, in commercial galleries as well as the area's venerable alternate spaces, in exhibitions of artists young and old, well established and unknown, there is a lot to see.

title: Review/Film; This Campus Has Debaters As Its Heroes

title: Ruble Flood Is Criticized
description: The Soviet Union has printed so much new paper money that it could buy all the goods in Western Europe if the Europeans would accept the ruble at the official rate, a group of economists said today.

description: A customer standing in line at a bank in East Harlem was shot to death yesterday afternoon by a man who grabbed an envelope from him and then ran, the police said.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums GRACE CHURCH SCHOOL MAY FAIR, a spring festival, rain or shine, with games, rides, toys, new and used books, a white elephant booth, live entertainment and food, from snacks to take-home delicacies, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. tomorrow, 10th Street, between Broadway and Fourth Avenue. Admission: $1. Information: 475-5609. ''A STREET PERFORMERS' FESTIVAL,'' an annual fair sponsored by the Friends Seminary, 11 A.M. to 3 P.M., tomorrow, rain or shine, with Rosie and Herbert's Little Circus (performance: 3 P.M.), games, hayrides, crafts, attic treasures, a silent auction, and homemade foods, 222 East 16th Street. Admission: children, $2; adults, $3. Information: 979-5030. ''COME BACK, AMELIA BEDELIA'' AND OTHER STORIES, a musical revue, presented by Maximillion Productions, for children 3 to 6, 1:30 and 3:30 P.M. Sunday, at the 92d Street Y, 1395 Lexington Avenue. Tickets: $8 and $12. Information: 427-6000. SPRING FAIR, sponsored by the Educational Alliance West, 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. Sunday, with games, arts and crafts and entertainment, 21 East 13th Street. Information: 463-8588. SPRING FAIR, sponsored by the Calhoun Parents Association of the Calhoun School, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. tomorrow, with a giant crawl-through maze, children's games, old and new books, toys, games and housewares, and hot and cold ethnic food. The school is on 81st Street, between West End Avenue and Riverside Drive. Admission is free. Information: 877-1700. BJ'S KIDS MICRO-MARATHON, a run for children, through 12 years old, 11 A.M. tomorrow, sponsored by BJ's Kids Daycare Community, at Riverside Park, track at 73d Street, at the Hudson River. Registration: $4. Information: 877-0684. ''THE FUN SHOW,'' a show by Stan Burns, a ventriloquist, 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at the Puppet Playhouse, Murphy Center at Asphalt Green, 555 East 90th Street. Tickets: $3.50. Reservations: 369-8890. ''THE ALICE-IN-WONDERLAND GAME,'' the Lewis Carroll story adapted by Lee Frank, with music by Jerry Markoe, presented by On Stage Productions, 1 and 3:30 P.M. tomorrow, and Sunday, at 413 West 46th Street. Last shows. Admission: $5. Information: 666-1716. RIVERSIDE CHURCH TOWER, a 392-foot-high structure at 490 Riverside Drive, at 120th Street, providing views of the Hudson River, New Jersey and Manhattan. Elevator to the 20th floor and one flight of stairs lead to the bell tower, where visitors may view the 74-bell carillon. Daily from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M. (not Saturdays) and 12:30 to 4 P.M. Sundays. For children over 6 and adults. Admission: $1. Information: 222-5900. ''THE SEAPORT EXPERIENCE,'' a film spectacle about the South Street Seaport, with 104 projectors and special audio effects, 10:30 A.M. to 3:30 P.M. Mondays through Thursdays and 10:30 A.M. to 6:30 P.M. Fridays through Sundays, at the Trans-Lux Seaport Theater, 210 Front Street, at the Seaport. Children, $3.25; adults, $4.75. Information: 608-7888.

title: California Court Upholds Car Insurance Rate Cuts
description: The California Supreme Court today upheld a ballot initiative passed by voters here last fall that would drastically reduce auto and casualty insurance rates and impose strict state regulation of the insurance industry.

title: Katy Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,704,000 for the latest first quarter and $279,000 for year-ago period.

title: American Western reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After net non-recurring expenses of $204,000 incurred in connection with the acquisition of 499,404 common shares of American Western from Terry and Robert Dornbush, the former owners of Dixie Bag Co. The purchase of this stock was made by American Western's stock ownership plan on April 29, 1989. c-Included a credit of $875,000 representing cumulative effect of an accounting change. The latest year's first quarter sales included purchases of Dixie Bag Co. in May 1988 and the Exxon private label bag business acquired in October 1988.

title: Filtertek Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $820,000 from the sale of the company's French facilities.

title: Groupe TCG Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: New Buyout Fund Set by Brentwood
description: Brentwood Associates, a Los Angeles-based investment firm that specializes in leveraged buyouts and venture capital investments, announced yesterday that it had completed a $140 million leveraged management buyout fund.

title: RAC Mortgage Investment Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago results are not comparable because the fund began operations in February 1988. The company said the loss was due to a $5.62 million charge from a valuation adjustment on investments in certain mortgage-backed residual interests.

title: Federal Express
description: The Transportation Department has given final approval to the Federal Express Corporation's takeover of the Flying Tiger Line Inc. air-cargo service of Tiger International Inc. The acquisition was conditioned upon Federal Express giving up its United States-Japan small package service. The approval came after the White House said it would not object to the takeover. The Justice Department said earlier that it would not oppose the $880 million deal, which was announced in December. The acquisition gives Federal Express, based in Memphis, a foothold in the international air-cargo business.

title: Report Says Beathard Will Leave Redskins
description: Bobby Beathard, the Washington Redskins' general manager, will not return to the team after his contract expires next month, according to a report in today's Washington Post.

title: Key Production Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company was formed last October.

title: Irwin Toy Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: American International Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said an accounting change reduced year-ago quarter net by $2 million. Share earnings are after deduction in 1989 and 1988 of preferred stock dividends of $2.9 million and $2.3 million, respectively. Latest quarter included realized capital gains of $37,361,000; year-ago quarter included realized capital gains of $42,755,000. The company said it included in its 1989 first quarter results were ''fresh start'' tax benefits, which reduced the provision for income taxes by about $17 million. In 1988, the comparable ''fresh start'' figure was $25 million.

title: PWA Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Carolina Freight Fills Top Executive Post
description: LEAD: The Carolina Freight Corporation today named Kenneth E. Mayhew, Jr., an accountant by training who has had substantial experience in operations at the company, to be its president and chief executive, effective Aug. 10. He succeeds K.G. Younger, who will stay on as vice chairman until his retirement next year.

title: Northgate Exploration Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Accounts
description: * Connor Toy Corp., to Bohbot Communications, for its media planning, with a budget of $2.5 million.

title: Mechanical Technology reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $412,000 and $671,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $117,000 and $135,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. Latest six month results included gains of $286,000 from the implementation of FASB No. 96.

title: Metro Datelines; Ward Proposes Cameras in the Park
description: Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward suggested yesterday that cameras be placed in desolate areas of Central Park to alert the police to roving gangs.

title: Ravel and Poulenc
description: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center is to perform Ravel's Introduction and Allegro for Harp, Winds and Strings, Poulenc's Sextet for Piano and Winds and Schubert's ''Two Cellos'' Quintet at Alice Tully Hall tonight at 8. The program closes the society's 20th season, and marks the end of Charles Wadsworth's tenure as its founding artistic director. It is being repeated tomorrow afternoon at 2, and Sunday afternoon at 5:30. Tickets are $20 for tonight's and Sunday's concerts, and $17.50 for t

title: Arab Economic Policy a Target
description: Except for the richest Persian Gulf oil producers, Arab nations suffer from economic policies that encourage citizens to send their money abroad, a leading regional economist said in a published report this week.

title: Bush Gets Appeal for Freer Trading With Soviets
description: The surviving co-author of the 1974 Jackson-Vanik Amendment withholding trade benefits to the Soviet Union until it allowed for free emigration called on the Administration today to waive the amendment because of the liberalizing policies of Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: Foss Conducts
description: Lukas Foss is to conduct the Brooklyn Philharmonic in a program of American and French music at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Ashland Place, tonight at 8. The program includes Aaron Copland's ''Outdoor Overture,'' the world premiere of Jay Anthony Gach's ''Chant,'' Ravel's ''Daphnis et Chloe'' Suite No. 2, and the Saint-Saens Second Piano Concerto. Shura Cherkassky is to be the soloist in the Saint-Saens. The program will be repeated tomorrow at 8 P.M. and on Sunday at 2 P.M. Tickets are $14 to $22. Information: (718) 622-1000.

title: Margate Ventures Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Fairmount Chemical Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Euro-Nevada Mining Corp reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Former Curator Charged In Theft of 'Tracy' Strips
description: The case of the missing ''Dick Tracy'' comic strips has been solved, the police say. And, as the legendary detective himself might have deduced, it looks like an inside job.

title: H. F. Eggert Jr., 74, Ex-Insurance Executive
description: H. Fletcher Eggert Jr., a retired insurance executive, died Wednesday at St. Luke's Hospital in Jacksonville, Fla., after a brief illness. He was 74 years old and lived in Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla.

title: Review/Theater; An Asian Alice Who's on the Edge of Noir
description: In his theatrical work, Ping Chong draws together ingredients from various arts, both performance and graphic, and then offers his own sardonic commentary. His puckish wit would seem to be most appropriate to a freehand interpretation of ''Alice in Wonderland,'' and so it is - up to a point.

title: Retail Sales Gained in April On Strong Apparel Buying
description: With reinvigorated consumer buying of women's apparel, many of the nation's biggest retailers yesterday reported strong April sales, prompting analysts to predict an improved second quarter.

title: Nichols-Homeshield Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sterling Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $631,500 and $562,800 for the quarter and year, respectively, and the quarter also included a charge of $250,200 from a reversal of a tax credit.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: The General Electric Company's aircraft engine division announced new orders totaling $355 million, as its orders so far this year match those for all of 1988. More than $5 billion in new jet engine orders have been awarded this year to G.E. and CFM International, a G.E. venture with Snecma, the French manufacturer.

title: Former Florida Prison Guard, 31, Is Electrocuted as Killer of Girl, 8
description: A former prison guard who suffocated an 8-year-old girl 11 years ago was executed today in Florida's electric chair.

title: Kohlberg, Kravis Cuts Kroger Stake
description: Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, which owned nearly 10 percent of the Kroger Company from a takeover attempt, has apparently sold some of its shares. A block of Kroger stock totaling 7.8 million shares was sold on Wednesday to an unidentified buyer on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Would-Be West Side Developers Still Target Striped Bass Habitat
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Datelines; Racial Task Force For Schools Is Urged
description: The Connecticut Board of Education has voted to ask Gov. William A. O'Neill to appoint a task force to study ways to desegregate public schools in Connecticut.

title: Review/Film; An Innocent's Journey on the Rocky Road to Miss Right
description: ''Getting It Right,'' the new English comedy opening today at the 57th Street Playhouse and other theaters, is about Gavin Lamb, a West End London hairdresser, 31 years old and still an innocent when it comes to sex. Gavin is terrified of people, especially of beautiful young women. He lives at home with Mum and Dad in a lower-middle-class suburb.

title: Review/Cabaret; A Gilded Bag of Ditties
description: Christopher Mason, the much-publicized society songwriter whose ditties poke mild fun at New York's rich and powerful, brought his bag of tunes to the Oak Room of the Algonquin Hotel (59 West 44th Street) on Tuesday for a three-week engagement.

title: Global Reach Gains Edge Over Talent
description: THE current takeover battles in the advertising industry are another sign that a roster of talented individuals is less important in the contemporary agency business than global reach, academic observers of advertising say.

title: Review/Midtown Galleries; Four Blocks on 57th Street, a Treasure House of Modern Art
description: There may be more Old Masters uptown and more contemporary art downtown, but the galleries along 57th Street continue to provide as comprehensive a view of 20th-century art as can be found almost anywhere in the world. One need only traverse the four blocks between Seventh Avenue and Park Avenue to realize that this remains the case.

title: Corporate Management Group Inc reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
Realcap Holdings Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Latest year loss included a writedown of $630,000 on its oil and gas assets. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Trump Atlantis Bid Challenged
description: As Donald J. Trump's agreement to buy the Atlantis Casino Hotel from the Elsinore Corporation is questioned by the casino's state-appointed conservator, at least five higher offers have been made for the troubled gaming hall.

title: 2 Hurt in Laboratory Blast
description: Two explosions injured two graduate students conducting an experiment at Northwestern University on Wednesday, starting a fire, Fire Department officials said. The explosions apparently resulted from the experiments, said Mike Tirrell, a spokesman for Northwestern. The victims had been working with an ether-like solvent, said Pat Tremmel, another Northwesten spokeswoman.

title: Cost of Iowa Repair Is Put at $15 Million or More
description: The cost of repairing the battleship Iowa's gun turret in which 47 sailors died in an explosion last month would be $15 million to $20 million, the Defense Department estimated today.

title: Greyvest Financial Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: EVERS IS DEFEATED IN FIFTH-TERM BID
description: Charles Evers has lost his bid for a fifth term as Mayor of Fayette, but he is not expressing disappointment.

title: Interim Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Mesa Airlines reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Revenue represents operating revenue.

title: Sealright Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Wright, in a Texas Venture, Got Money Others Couldn't
description: House Speaker Jim Wright received payments of at least $22,000 from a $100,000 investment in a Texas nursing home business at a time when the company was in financial trouble and many other shareholders were seeking unsuccessfully to obtain such payments, according to documents and people involved with the company.

title: Urging Chinese Democracy, 100,000 Surge Past Police
description: A defiant and enthusiastic crowd of more than 100,000 workers and students forced its way through police cordons in the capital today to demand more democracy, and smaller demonstrations were held in many other cities around China.

title: MCN Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Wednesday about the possibility of tuition increases at the State University of New York and the City University of New York misstated the current rates. Full-time students in the State University system pay $1,350 a year; those in the city system pay $1,250.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Betty Carter

title: Jason Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bush Is Said to Plan a Brief Budapest Visit
description: An aide to Karoly Grosz, the Communist Party leader, said today that President Bush would visit Budapest in July.

title: Review/Museums; Goya's Dark Vision at the Met, and What's to Be Seen Elsewhere
description: There are not many artists the American public would rather see than Goya. Much of the 19th-century French art so beloved in America begins with him. His appeal cuts across classes and styles. He was at once court painter, protest artist and visionary expressionist whose art is bigger than any style he used or cause he served. He belongs to his time, yet he seems less a historical individual than a force of nature.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11 Jalalabad has become a testing place for the rebels, who have driven Soviet troops from Afghanistan and for the Government the Russians left behind. Page A1 Soviet scholar ties Russian Army to Kabul Coup A6 In Beijing, an enthusiastic crowd of more than 100,000 workers and students forced its way through police cordons in the capital to demand more democracy. A8 Hope for a common Western position on short-range nuclear missiles was expressed by President Bush. But he did not indicate any change in his opposition to negotiations. A7 Because of new Soviet policies, a co-author of the Jackson-Vanik Amendment witholding trade benefits until Moscow allowed for free emigration urged that the amendment be waived. A6 Strugglers against tyranny gathered in Washington to discuss a revolution that was extending democracy through Latin America, Eastern Europe and China. A5 The U.S. will impose sanctions on countries that use chemical weapons and on companies that assist in the production of such weapons, the Bush Administration said. A3 In Senegal, menace lingers after strife A3 Israeli border police opened fire without restraint when they killed five Palestinians last month, before trying to subdue demonstrators, an investigation concluded. A10 In Britain's North Sea oil fields, a pair of production shutdowns in the past few weeks are the latest in a series of incidents that began last summer. D1 National A12-25, A36 Oliver L. North was convicted of shredding documents and two other crimes, but he was acquitted of nine other charges from his role in the Iran-contra affair. A1 Mysteries of the Iran-contra affair remained unsolved in the trial of Oliver L. North. But the case tossed off some tantalizing new leads about the role of George Bush. A1 After 12 days together, the 12 jurors said an emotional prayer that one juror said was the turning point in deciding the North case. A19 News analysis: Ollie-mania faded from the public mind by the time the verdict was finally handed up. Oliver L. North was not the shining patriot he once seemed. A18 The space shuttle rocketed into orbit as the astronauts aboard prepared to send a radar-mapping spacecraft on a journey to Venus. A1 To keep developing a Marine aircraft for another five months, the Pentagon is considering diverting millions of dollars even though Defense Secretary Dick Cheney plans to kill the project on Oct. 1. A1 Jim Wright received at least $22,000 from a $100,000 investment in a Texas nursing home business at a time when the company was in financial trouble. A1 Inquiry asked on Los Angeles Mayor's stock deals A12 California's car insurance rates, the third highest of any state's, may be in for drastic reductions as a result of a state Supreme Court decision that upheld a voter referendum imposing the cuts. A1 Four commodity exchanges are being investigated in New York; dozens of subpoenas were served. Federal postal inspectors searched two offices. D1 Dr. C. Everett Koop is resigning as Surgeon General after nearly eight years of surprising both liberals and conservatives with his stands on smoking, AIDS and abortion. A12 Washington Talk A20 When the U.S. meets the Soviet Union on Wednesday, the agenda will include environmental problems, drugs, international terrorism and missile proliferation. Regional B1-5, B24 Critical gaps in AIDS services are being discovered by the thousands of New Yorkers. Existing programs make up a patchwork of care, not a full system. B1 A Staten Islander who was paroled recently was charged with raping a 15-year-old girl and may be charged in similar attacks on two other women in Manhattan. B1 A battle is raging in Hoboken, N.J., for the soul of the old seaport gone chic. On one side are residents; the other side is the Mayor. B1 Smuggling of illegal immigrants bound for Chinese sections of New York City is the charge faced by six people arrested by the authorities. Some were arrested in Toronto. B3 Criticism of the child-welfare agency was echoed by a report commissioned by the agency itself. The report found sloppy procedures within New York City's Child Welfare Administration. B1 Problems of the foster-care system are made worse when child-welfare workers permit monitoring procedures that are ''absolutely shocking,'' a Family Court judge said.B2 New York State's public universities have yet to achieve the reputation enjoyed by large universities in other states, a point that is emerging in the tuition debate. B3 Students voted to end their sit-ins in administration buildings on 10 CUNY campuses, three days after Gov. Mario M. Cuomo vetoed a proposed increase in tuition. B3 If PATH motormen decide to strike, the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey has a plan, released yesterday, for transporting commuters between New Jersey and Manhattan. B5 Lilco warns of summer problems B2

Cello and Piano
description: Richard Locker, a cellist, and Alison Deane, a pianist, are to perform the Debussy and the Chopin Cello Sonatas and the Beethoven Cello Sonata in F (Op. 5, No. 1) at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street, on Sunday at 3 P.M. Admission is free. Information: 874-5210.

description: b-Net loss

Le Peep said it provided $777,867, including salary and benefits to be paid to former officers and other employees as well as other costs related to the physical move and closure of its Syosset office.

description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $8,823,000. c-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $1,667,000.

Canadian Tire Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $38,000. Year-ago revenue is restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

description: Results are in U.S. dollars. All conversions are at the Dec. 31, 1988 exchange rate of 113.30 Spanish pesetas to U.S. $1.00. Share earnings represent American Depositary Share (ADS); each ADS represents one-half of one ordinary share.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 468 money market mutual funds increased by $1.20 billion, to $304.17 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The 141 institutional funds had an increase of $1.20 billion, to $75.5 billion. The assets of the 232 general-purpose funds were up by $119.80 million, to $99.78 billion. The 95 broker-dealer funds decreased by $120.1 million, to $128.90 billion, the institute said.

title: Soviets Report Player Defected to West
description: Aleksandr Mogilny, a 20-year-old forward on the Soviet national hockey team, defected to the West, apparently to play in the National Hockey League, according to reports in the Soviet media.

title: Economic Scene; A New Warning On the Deficits
description: THE Federal Reserve Bank of New York, in its 74th annual report, just warned that the United States budget and trade deficits pose a clear and increasing risk to the nation's and the world's economic stability. E. Gerald Corrigan, president of the New York Fed, wrote that the gaps between American exports and imports, between domestic spending and output, and between saving and investment constitute ''the most formidable problem facing the U.S. and the global economy over the next three to five years.''

title: James W. Rodgers, Lawyer, 81
description: James W. Rodgers, a retired partner in the law firm of Townley, Updike, Carter & Rodgers, died of a heart attack on April 29 at Phelps Memorial Hospital in North Tarrytown, N.Y. He was 81 years old and lived in North Tarrytown.

title: Gibbons, Green Separation
description: The co-founders of Gibbons, Green, van Amerongen - Leonard I. Green and Edward W. Gibbons - are splitting up, they announced yesterday. The firm, established in 1969, was one of the early progenitors of the leveraged buyout movement. Among the companies it has taken private are the Ohio Mattress Company, Budget Rent-a-Car and Kash n' Karry Food Stores Inc.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * A.M.E. Inc., Burbank, Calif., said it had received a $10-a-share offer from A.M.E. Holding Co., a company formed by Lawrence J. Berkowitz. It is not affiliated with A.M.E. Inc.

title: House and Senate Approve $1.17 Trillion Budgets
description: The House and the Senate today approved separate $1.17 trillion budgets for the 1990 fiscal year that call for minimal deficit reduction and postpone painful tax and spending decisions that lawmakers and the Bush Administration were unwilling to face this year.

title: Broad Support Sen for Incentives on New TV Technology
description: The Bush Administration can expect wide support in both Congress and industry for its anticipated proposal to relax antitrust laws to help American companies gain a foothold in high-definition television and other budding technologies, lawmakers and industry executives said today.

title: CPT Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included loss provisions of $5.3 million on the sale of the company's foreign subsidiary and $1.2 million for ongoing restructuring related to the firm's downsizing, and $1.6 million in other non-recurring expenses for the quarter and the 9 months included charges totaling $8.1 million. c-Included income of $1 million from the sale of real estate for the quarter and the 9 months included income of $3.1 million from unspecified non-recurring items.

title: American Bankers Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an after-tax investment income of $1.2 million on proceeds from the sale of the company's U.K. subsidiary. Year-ago first quarter net included earnings from the company's former U.K. subsidiary, which was sold in December.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the continuing protests at the City University of New York misidentified the City College building shown. It was the North Academic Center, not the administration building.

title: Software Developer In I.B.M. Accord
description: Interactive Images Inc., a developer of software for I.B.M. PC-compatible computers, signed a development and licensing agreement with the International Business Machines Corporation. The company, based in Woburn, Mass., said I.B.M. would become a minority owner under an accord that covers its Easel program.

title: At Nightly Feasts, Nation's Wealth Is Devoured
description: At dawn on Saturday, or maybe Sunday, when a slender crescent moon has crossed the sky and signaled month's end, the Muslims of Egypt and many other lands will begin a feast for three days to mark the close of Ramadan, Islam's annual time of daytime fasting.

title: Midwest Grain Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest quarter net results included a pretax gain of $2,547,000, which is the company's estimate of insurance proceeds related to an accident at a production facility, and a pretax charge of $1,476,000 from the reduction of an investment in a former subsidiary.

title: Canadians Open 9-Mile Rail Tunnel
description: Canada inaugurated the longest rail tunnel in the Western Hemisphere today, completing a task begun in haste and nationalistic anxiety more than a century ago.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error an article yesterday about radiation releases at the Fernald nuclear weapons plant in Ohio misstated the role of a company that formerly operated it.

title: Tears, Not Cheers, in Argentina
description: Argentina's May 14 Presidential election should be cause for celebration. For the first time in 60 years, a civilian President will have survived long enough in office to see his successor elected. Raul Alfonsin has done more than merely survive. He has skillfully guided Argentina to a freer, more tolerant, more democratic civic culture.

title: The Guilty Verdict
description: Please, wait - just a few questions about that gang of thugs arrested for beating and raping the jogger in the park. Who ruled they are guilty? What judge listened to the arguments of their defense lawyers? When did he make the crucial decision about admissibility of their confessions? What did he then say to the jury before they filed out to consider a verdict? What jury?

title: Bluffers Steal Works of Dali and Matisse in Rio
description: Six armed men bluffed their way into this city's second-largest art museum on Wednesday night and stole Chinese porcelain, 19th-century Brazilian silver and paintings by Salvador Dali and Henri Matisse that were estimated to be worth $10 million.

title: Condo to Rise in Downtown Hartford
description: Linden Court, a 30-story condominium tower, will begin rising this summer on an eight-acre tract opposite Bushnell Park because city officials here are now using a carrot-and-stick approach to encourage residential development downtown.

title: U.S.-Soviet Talks Turn To New Public Dangers
description: Its proponents call it the future. Its opponents call it global baloney, ''globaloney'' for short.

title: Consolidated Products reports earnings for Qtr to April 12
description: The company said year-ago figures have been restated to reflect an accounting change and the effect of a 10 percent stock dividend paid in January 1989.

Employers Casualty reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: Bell Suspended
description: George Bell, the Toronto Blue Jay outfielder, has been suspended for two games, Bobby Brown, the American League president, announced yesterday.
