Saucier Ltd. as of Dec. 7, 1988, when Atlantique acquired the company. Atlantique said the $7 million charge in the latest period was incurred in connection with the acquisition of J.M. Saucier. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Canadiens Bounced Flyers' Checks
description: The deflation of the Flyers happened swiftly and thoroughly.

title: I.B.M. Faces Europe Bar To Chip Role
description: The International Business Machines Corporation has expressed interest in joining a $4 billion government-backed European semiconductor research project, industry officials say, but European electronics companies are blocking I.B.M.'s membership.

description: b-Included tax credits of $918,000 and $497,000 for the latest and year- ago periods, respectively.

title: Parks vs. Development: Battle for Hoboken's Salty Soul
description: A battle is raging for the soul of this old seaport gone chic.

North Sea Oil Mishaps Cost Up to $4 a Barrel
description: A pair of production shutdowns in the last few weeks are the latest in a series of incidents in Britain's North Sea oilfields that began last summer. The unexpected troubles of the world's sixth-largest petroleum producer have been the main force propping up oil prices recently. Today, when it was announced that a major field would be back on stream later than expected, prices jumped sharply in commodities trading.

title: Review/Film; Ken Russell Goes Back To Lawrence For Love
description: From the early moments of his new film, when a glittering rainbow arches over emerald green meadows, it is apparent that Ken Russell is the purest interpreter D. H. Lawrence could have hoped for. That is not unadulterated praise. ''The Rainbow,'' adapted from Lawrence's 1915 novel, comes saddled with all the author's strengths and flaws - heavy symbolism, a feel for the land in the mortal grip of industrialization, swift turns of emotion, high-blown speeches about how men and women might love while remaining independent.

title: Larry Fleisher, 58, Former Head Of Pro Basketball Players' Union
description: Larry Fleisher, the former head of the National Basketball Players Association, died yesterday after playing squash at the New York Athletic Club.

description: A new political controversy is swirling around Jim Wright after an article described the criminal record of a top aide. Page A14.

title: Review/Film; A Resolute Boil Becomes A (Growing) Cross to Bear
description: In the wonderful world of London advertising, Bagley (Richard E. Grant), a handsome young man given to immaculate tailoring, has a reputation as a genius. Then suddenly, unaccountably, he faces a block on his new campaign for a skin cream.

description: The Knicks went back to work yesterday and the subject was Michael Jordan.

title: Long Trail of the Iran-Contra Case
description: Aug. 4, 1981: Maj. Oliver L. North of the Marine Corps is assigned to the White House with the National Security Council. December 1981: President Reagan signs a ''finding'' authorizing a covert Central Intelligence Agency operation to support the Nicaraguan rebels. December 1982: Congress passes the first of several Boland Amendments barring use of Federal money to overthrow the Government of Nicaragua. 1984: Colonel North is assigned by security council superiors as the White House link to the contras. October 1984: Congress passes a stricter version of the Boland Amendment, cutting off all military aid to the contras. The ban held until October 1986. February 1985: Using dummy corporations abroad, Lieutenant Colonel North and two associates, Richard V. Secord, a former Air Force major general, and Albert Hakim, an Iranian-born arms dealer and businessman who is now an American, make the first of six arms purchases for the contras. Money comes from private contributors and a secret $32 million contribution by King Fahd of Saudi Arabia. Colonel North and his associates eventually spend $16.5 million for military aid for the contras. Mr. Hakim, Mr. Secord and a third associate, Thomas C. Clines, retain $4.4 million in commissions. 1985: Press accounts link Colonel North to a private network supplying military aid to the contras, promping Congressional letters of inquiry. Colonel North helps prepare answers denying any involvement but later admits the denials were false. July 1985: Israeli Government officials tell Robert C. McFarlane, the national security adviser, that Iran wants to open a ''political discourse'' with the United States, an overture that leads to the first shipment of American arms to Iran and to the release of one of the seven American hostages held by terrorists. July 1985: Mr. Secord agrees to begin an airlift to supply the contras. Nov. 19, 1985: Mr. McFarlane assigns Colonel North to handle logistics for a second shipment of Hawk missiles to Iran. He turns to Mr. Secord for assistance. The North-Secord-Hakim network ferrying arms to the contras also acts as the agent for future secret shipments of American arms to Iran. April 4, 1986: Colonel North outlines a plan to divert $12 million in profits from the Iran arms sales to the contras. The memorandum is prepared for Rear Adm. John M. Poindexter, who succeeded Mr. McFarlane as the National Security Council adviser, to relay to the President. Admiral Poindexter later testifies that he never showed President Reagan the memo. May 25, 1986: Mr. McFarlane, Colonel North and other American officials fly to Teheran with spare parts for Iran's Hawk antiaircraft missiles. They meet for four days with Iranian officials, but fail to win the release of all the American hostages. Aug. 6, 1986: Colonel North meets with 11 members of the House Intelligence Committee and denies raising money for the contras or offering them military advice. Colonel North later testifies that he lied in this session. Nov. 3-6, 1986: Press accounts say Washington sent arms to Iran. Nov. 12-19, 1986: Colonel North and other White House officials prepare inaccurate chronologies of events in the Iran affair to deal with any repercussions that might arise. Nov. 21, 1986: Colonel North is told that Justice Department officials will inspect his files the next day, and he begins shredding documents. Nov. 22, 1986: Justice Department officials discover in Colonel North's office an April 1986 memo to the President mentioning the diversion of money to the contras. Nov. 24, 1986: Attorney General Edwin C. Meese 3d goes to the White House and tells the President of the diversion of funds. Nov. 25, 1986: Mr. Meese announces the diversion. The President announces the resignation of Admiral Poindexter and the dismissal of Colonel North. Feb. 26, 1987: A Presidential commission, headed by former Senator John G. Tower to study the operations of the National Security Council, concludes that the President's top advisers were responsible for creating the chaos that led to the Iran-contra Affair. The report asserts that Mr. Reagan Reagan was largely out of touch with operations by the council staff. July 7, 1987: Under a grant of limited immunity, Colonel North begins six days of televised testimony before Congressional committees investigating the Iran-contra affair. He says he has no idea whether the President knew of the diversion of funds. He also says that the Director of Central Intelligence, William J. Casey, approved the diversion and that the sales were originally intended as an exchange for the hostages. Nov. 18, 1987: The Congressional Iran-contra committees, which heard more than 250 hours of testimony from 28 public witnesses, concludes Mr. Reagan failed to live up to his constitutional mandate to ''take care that the laws be faithfully executed.'' The committees say he bore ''the ultimate responsibility'' for wrongdoing by his aides. It finds Mr. North to have been the point man in a ''cabal of zealots.'' March 16, 1988: Colonel North, Admiral Poindexter, Mr. Secord and Mr. Hakim are indicted on charges of conspiring to defraud the Government by illegally providing the contras with funds from the sale of American weapons to Iran. March 18, 1988: Colonel North resigns from the Marine Corps and says he might subpoena the Government's ''highest-ranking officials'' to defend himself. Nov. 21, 1988: Federal District Judge Gerhard A. Gesell says he will grant Mr. North's lawyers ''wide latitude'' to cross-examine Government witnesses about ''involvement in sensitive matters.'' Nov. 30, 1988: The White House announces that it intends to stop the release of secret documents Mr. North wants to use in his defense. Dec. 12, 1988: Judge Gesell gives defense lawyers until Jan. 3 to select 300 classified documents for public disclosure in the trial. Dec. 30, 1988: President Reagan and Vice President George Bush are subpoenaed to testify as defense witnesses; Judge Gesell later refuses to enforce the subpoenas. Jan. 5, 1989: Lawrence M. Walsh, the special counsel, asks the court to dismiss two important charges against Mr. North because of problems over the use of classified documents, after earlier dropping two lesser charges, leaving 12 criminal counts against him. Feb. 21, 1989: Main stage of Mr. North's trial opens after 11 months of delays and pretrial maneuvering. April 6-13, 1989: Mr. North begins six days of testimony. April 20, 1989: After reading final instructions for two hours, Judge Gesell sends case to the jury. May 4, 1989: Jury convicts Mr. North of three counts, obstructing Congress, destroying documents and accepting an illegal gratuity and acquits him of the other nine charges.

title: Review/Film; 'Out of The Dark,' Phone Sex
description: Michael Schroeder's misogynistic thriller ''Out of the Dark'' is a movie so desperate for attention that it will stop at nothing to titillate. Opening with extreme closeups of a psychopathic killer tearing at his own flesh with a knife while growling sadistic warnings to a telephone sex partner, it sinks to a nadir of repellent kinkiness during a motel scene in which turbulent lovemaking is photographed to suggest murder.

title: Perched Above Jalalabad, Rebels Try 'Regular War'
description: ''Before, we hit and run,'' said Haji Din Mohammed, the top field commander of the rebels besieging Jalalabad. ''Now we hit and sit. It's conventional war. It's not guerrilla war.''

title: Review/Film; The Downs And the Ups: That's Life
description: An old man faces death. A baby is born. Lovers quarrel. Hope is lost, then regained.

title: Richard K. Kaufmann, Stockbroker, Dies at 87
description: Richard K. Kaufmann, a stockbroker for more than 60 years, died of heart disease yesterday at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

description: As the Philadelphia buzzer was groaning to signal game's end, and the ample Charles Barkley was toppling like a tree to the floor in disappointment, someone on the Knicks found a broom in the vicinity of his bench Tuesday night and a bunch of the players went off the court pushing it.

description: Two of Madison Avenue's largest advertising companies have reported increases in their first-quarter earnings.

At Stanford, Leftists Become Censors
description: Now it's the left that is trying to restrict free speech. Forgetting that until recently left-wing views were the usual targets of suppression, the left - those who have been strong advocates of civil liberties and the expression of minority views - now seeks to silence opponents.

title: Hawks Even Series With Flames
description: Steve Larmer, Denis Savard and Steve Thomas scored in the opening six minutes, and Alain Chevrier made 22 saves tonight as the Chicago Blackhawks defeated the Calgary Flames, 4-2, evening the Campbell Conference finals at one victory apiece.

title: Greiner Enegineering reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said share earnings and shares outstanding for 1988 have been adjusted to reflect the 25 percent common stock split in the form of a dividend issued on Dec. 2, 1988.

title: Review/Uptown Galleries; Life's Carnival, by Old Masters
description: If you have never set foot in an auction house, let alone heard people break into applause when records are broken, you may not think that everyday life in uptown Manhattan is much affected by the two weeks in May in which a million dollars is very much ''not what it used to be.'' But the truth is that during those two weeks money talks even louder than usual, not just in response to the auctioneer's gavel, but all over town. People buy more, dress up more, eat more, drink more, flirt more, ride around more and boast more. Directly or indirectly, all those things cost money.

title: Ex-Chancellor Of Schools Vies For Comptroller
description: Citing his experience as an appointed official, Frank J. Macchiarola, the former New York City schools chancellor, yesterday announced his candidacy for New York City comptroller, his first bid for elective office.

title: Where the Elite Meet to Eat
description: On a recent sparkling lunch hour, a New Yorker strolled through midtown Manhattan to see what other New Yorkers were doing. They were picnicking.

title: Fund Officials Warn Exxon
description: Representatives of the three leading New York City pension funds threatened to vote their six million shares of stock in the Exxon Corporation against management at the shareholders meeting May 18 if executives do not demonstrate that they will take steps to avoid accidents like the Valdez oil spill.

title: Easy Goer's Steam Causes Fumes
description: Shug McGaughey, Easy Goer's trainer, was steaming for about half an hour this morning after the Kentucky Derby favorite did exactly what he has been bred and trained to do: He pricked up his ears down the stretch and ran after another race horse.

title: Football's Poor Cousin Pits Army-Air Force
description: A rugby player at the major service academies, Air Force, Army, or Navy, is usually a former football player who was either too small, too inept or too fed up to continue with that sport.

title: Auctions
description: Act II of the May auctions extravaganza begins tomorrow, offering major Impressionist and modern artworks, Art Deco furnishings, a Manhattan town house designed by Philip Johnson, tribal art and a bounty of prints ranging from Rembrandts to Rauschenbergs. The sales follow a week of record-breaking contemporary-art auctions at Sotheby's and Christie's, and are organized by these houses and by Habsburg, Feldman, a two-year-old Geneva-based concern that is holding its first art sale in Manhattan. The works to be auctioned are to be exhibited this weekend.

title: Schoenberg and Liszt
description: The pianist Emanuel Ax is to play Beethoven's ''Pastoral'' Sonata (Op. 28), Schoenberg's Six Pieces (Op. 9), the Brahms Third Sonata and works by Liszt at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday at 3 P.M. Tickets are $11 to $20. Information: 874-6770.

title: Organists' Benefit
description: The American Guild of Organists is presenting a marathon benefit concert to raise money for AIDS patient care tomorrow from 10 A.M. to 9 P.M. at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, in the Citicorp Center, Lexington Avenue at 54th Street. Among the organists who are to perform are Harold Stover, Leonard Raver, Donald Joyce, Gerre Hancock, Sarah Davies, Gwendolyn Toth, William Whitehead, Walter Hilse and John Weaver. The music to be played includes Baroque through contemporary works. Suggested donation is $10. Information: 935-2200.

title: Black Professionals Battle Isolation
description: When Charles H. Johnson tells his friends where he lives and works, he says this response is not uncommon: ''What the hell are you doing in Boston?''

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Guest List; Across the River and Into the New Frontier
description: Among the things one can always count on from the Kennedy clan is a sterling guest list. Friday will be no exception, as 70 political literary friends gather for lunch at the home of Ethel Kennedy to honor the winners of this year's Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Book Awards.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TWON
description: McCorkle's Pop-Jazz Susannah McCorkle, Fat Tuesday's, 190 Third Avenue, at 17th Street (533-7902). A perceptive pop-jazz vocalist with buttery-smooth phrasing, Susannah McCorkle is performing material from her new album, ''No More Blues'' (Concord Jazz). High points of the record include a wistfully caressing ''P.S., I Love You'' and a bubbly ''Fascinating Rhythm.'' The singer's cool, sultry delivery conveys a steady, low-flamed eroticism. Without ruffling a phrase, she insinuates delicate, expressive shadings into lyrics that give everything she sings a subtle, personal touch. Shows are tonight and tomorrow at 8, 10 and midnight and on Sunday at 8 and 10 P.M. There is a $15 cover charge and a $7.50 minimum tonight and tomorrow, and a $12.50 cover and $7.50 minimum on Sunday. Scottish Revival

title: Humbler, Agassi Tries To Cope With Success
description: A year ago at Forest Hills, Andre Agassi was regarded as a youngster on the rise in a sport dominated by a handful of players who appeared to have secured a lifetime membership in the top 10. He was as new to the fans then as his blue denim shorts were to tennis fashion.

title: Northwestern Public Service Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Vitronics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
TV Weekend; A Charming Man in Wartime England
description: If you missed episode 1 of ''The Charmer,'' the latest offering of ''Masterpiece Theater,'' it is not too late to catch up. Channel 31 is running a repeat broadcast tomorrow at 8 P.M. And there are five hours still to come of this engaging adaptation of a trilogy by Patrick Hamilton, who, as the durable and useful Alistair Cooke informs us, was a popular novelist of the 1930's.

description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $1 million. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: WRIGHT AIDE'S PAST SHOCKS CAPITOL
description: The political struggle of Speaker of the House Jim Wright took a bitter twist today when the criminal record of one of Mr. Wright's closest aides was resurrected by a newspaper and then pounced on by the Republican Congressional Campaign Committee.

title: Our Towns; Ready, Set . . . Now Peel, Poach, Broil and Blanch
description: Who wouldn't want to win the Nabisco? Kevin Walker had rehearsed his broiled scrod three times, his berry sorbet six times, in the days leading up to the cook-off. Leonard Thompson was so jumpy the night before that at midnight he went over his shrimp creole again. He knew he was cutting it close. The three-course meal could total just 600 calories; his was 598.

title: Skirts Are Shorter, but Prices Are Higher
description: To the Editor:

title: 3 Suspects Are Arrested in Rapes
description: A Staten Islander who was recently paroled was charged yesterday with raping a 15-year-old girl and may be charged in similar attacks on two other women in Manhattan, the police said.

description: LEAD: The stock market continued its weeklong retreat yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 8.80 points to close at 2,384.90.

description: Bowing to pressure from Congress and the aviation industry, the Pentagon is considering diverting millions of dollars to keep the development of a new Marine Corps aircraft going for another five months, even though Defense Secretary Dick Cheney plans to kill the project on Oct. 1.

title: Honoring Baldwin
description: James Baldwin's work will be celebrated at 6:15 tonight at the West Side Y Center for the Arts, 5 West 63d Street. The Writer's Voice program is to feature readings by Amiri Baraka; a 1986 Nobel Prize winner, Wole Soyinka, Budd Schulberg and others in a benefit reading for the Frederick Douglass Creative Arts Center. Tickets are $10. Information: 787-6557.

title: KMW Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The latest third quarter included a charge of about $250,000 from previously reported staff reductions.

title: Sheik Abbas, 77, Dies; Rector of Paris Mosque
description: Sheik Abbas Ben Sheik el-Hocine, rector of the Great Mosque of Paris and considered the top Muslim religious authority in France, died Wednesday night after suffering a heart attack, officials said. He was 77 years old.

title: Prayer Was the Turning Point, a Juror Says
description: Each morning, the jurors began their deliberations with a prayer, but this morning's prayer, led by Caswell Hartridge, a retired bus driver, was especially emotional.

title: Corporate Culture Clash
description: Americans alarmed by Japanese investment in U.S. business and real estate can relax a little. T. Boone Pickens, the corporate raider from Amarillo, Tex., has bought 20 percent of the Koito Manufacturing Company, a big producer of auto headlights. Now the Japanese are alarmed.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF Levi Sets Pace in Dallas: Wayne Levi finished off a 62 with a birdie on the final hole yesterday just before darkness halted play to take the lead in the uncompleted first round of the storm-disrupted Byron Nelson Classic in Dallas.

title: Robert J. Craft, Physician, 89
description: Dr. Robert J. Craft, a general practitioner in Harlem for more than 50 years, died of congestive heart failure Wednesday at the Bayberry Nursing Home in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 89 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Pittston Bank Is Criticized
description: The United Mine Workers of America and a New York community activist group yesterday joined forces to criticize the lending policies of the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and file a complaint with the Federal Reserve to stop Manufactures Hanover from buying 11 branches of Goldome Savings Bank.

title: Restaurants
description: As the physical dimensions of Little Italy have diminished over the years, slowly squeezed by swelling Chinatown and other neighbors, so too has the quality of food there. While Mulberry Street's fading Old New York image still lures the tourists, New Yorkers from other parts of town no longer consider it the epicenter of authentic Italian cuisine.

title: Gulf Air Flights to Iran
description: Gulf Air will resume flights to Iran after an eight-year interruption because of the Iran-Iraq war, the Gulf News Agency said today. The Manama-based airline's first flight will be on May 13 from Abu Dhabi in the United Arab Emirates to Shiraz in central Iran, a company spokesman said.

title: Country Lake Foods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the decline in profit in the latest first quarter was mainly due to the writeoff of receivables from a major customer who is in default. The writeoff reduced profit by about $550,000.

title: Car Crash Kills Girl, 9; Police Officer Arrested
description: A 9-year-old girl was killed today in an automobile accident on the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway, and a New York City police officer was charged with drunken driving and vehicular homicide in the crash.

title: Hecla Mining reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The latest first quarter included a one-time litigation settlement of $1.6 million.

title: Hiding Behind Hormones in Milk
description: Bovine growth hormone, synthesized in bacteria by the new techniques of genetic engineering, may make cows produce some 15 percent more milk. Such a spectacular productivity gain should delight consumers with lower prices and dairy farmers with higher profits. Then why are farmers from New York to Minnesota organizing to oppose the new technology?

title: INSIDE
description: Futures Market Subpoenas

title: Devils Sign Ruotsalainen
description: Reijo Ruotsalainen ended a two-year absence from the National Hockey League and signed a contract with the Devils today, said General Manager Lou Lamoriello. Neither Lamoriello nor Ruotsalainen, a defenseman, would discuss contract terms.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page headline on April 15 about an Israeli police ban on attendance at Al Aksa Mosque in Jerusalem by nearly all Palestinian residents of the occupied territories described the action incorrectly. It was not the first such ban. The headline, ''For the First Time, Israel Restricts Palestinians' Freedom of Worship,'' was also imprecise in describing the limits placed on the Palestinians' freedom of worship; the restriction affected access to Al Aksa Mosque only.

title: Grubb & Ellis Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Senegal Strife Leaves Air of Menace
description: For two weeks, the tranquillity of this West African country has taken on an air of menace as thousands of Mauritanians, fearing attack by their Senegalese hosts here, have fled or gone into hiding.

title: Garan Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Perestroit the Way the Real Perestroiniks Do
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Jazz; A 19-Year-Old Trumpeter From Texas
description: Given the now regular profusion of young jazz musicians, it's no surprise that Roy Hargrove, a virtuoso 19-year-old trumpeter from Texas, plays on such a technically accomplished level. What is surprising about Mr. Hargrove, who played at Birdland on Monday night, is his emotional self-assurance. Mr. Hargrove has the courage to play with sadness, which automatically separates him from most other young musicians.

title: Overmyer Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sun Exploration Becomes Oryx
description: The Sun Exploration and Production Company has changed its name to the Oryx Energy Company to reflect its independence from the Sun Company, which spun it off in November. Oryx is named after a large antelope with long straight horns. The name change was approved on Tuesday by shareholders.

title: One-Year U.S. Notes Sold at 8.44%
description: Prices of Treasury securities inched higher in light trading yesterday highlighted by the successful sale of $9 billion worth of new one-year notes.

title: Frank O'Rourke, Is Dead at 72; Author of Westerns and Mysteries
description: Frank O'Rourke, a prolific, versatile and popular writer of novels, westerns and mysteries and earlier of short stories and sports fiction, died after a long bout with asthma on April 27 at his home in Tucson, Ariz. He was 72 years old.

title: Review/Pop; Tammy Wynette: Nashville and Glitter
description: Country music's ''new traditionalism'' movement hasn't yet reached Tammy Wynette, a Nashville hit maker since the 1960's. At the Bottom Line on Tuesday evening, for her first New York shows in eight years, Ms. Wynette retained the paradoxes of the old Nashville mainstream, with glittery gowns, cooing backup singers and pop ballads swathing her Mississippi twang and the remnants of honky-tonk.

title: Perkins Papers Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds. The company said earnings in the latest period were hurt by a two-and- a-half week maintenance shutdown of the Candiac paper mill requiring the purchase of high-cost replacement tonnage.

title: Datamarine International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Why the North Verdict Is Welcome
description: The jury's verdict in the Oliver North trial is cause for satisfaction, not elation or disappointment. The ambitious former National Security Council staff member is guilty of three serious felonies but not guilty of nine others. He emerges as neither national hero nor villain.

title: Copter Crash Kills 5 Marines
description: An American military helicopter making a night training flight hit a high-tension power line and crashed in southern France, killing five marines, officials said today. The UH-1 Huey, from the amphibious assault ship Guadalcanal currently in port in Toulon, exploded when it hit a hillside about 9:45 P.M. Wednesday near Rougon, a village 500 miles southeast of Paris. A local resident saw the explosion and called firefighters. The police said all five men aboard were killed.

title: Lord Martonmere, 83, Bermuda Ex-Governor
description: Lord Martonmere, the former Governor General of Bermuda and a member of the British House of Commons for 33 years, died on Wednesday at his home in Lyford Cay, Nassau, the Bahamas, after a brief illness. He was 82 years old.

title: Review/Music; A Night Off From Valhalla, With Mozart
description: James Levine had Wednesday evening off, between conducting ''Die Walkure'' and ''Siegfried'' in his third and final ''Ring'' of the Metropolitan Opera season. What to do with those idle hours? Mr. Levine did not collapse onto a masseur's table or sleep the time away with his phone turned off. He spent the night making music as a guest pianist with the Vienna Chamber Ensemble at Carnegie Hall.

title: Board of Estimate Approves Project for Columbus Circle
description: The New York City Board of Estimate last night approved a scaled-down design for a skyscraper on Columbus Circle, resolving one of the city's most divisive and prolonged real-estate battles.

title: Kansas City Power & Light Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Camreco Inc reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Pennsylvania Move On Sale by Eastern
description: The Pennsylvania Attorney General said he had sought court action to block Eastern Airlines' $70 million sale of most of its gates at Philadelphia International Airport to USAir Group Inc. Eastern, a unit of the Texas Air Corporation, has been in bankruptcy since March 9, five days after its machinists went on strike. The airline said on March 8 that it would sell 8 of its 10 Philadelphia airport gates to USAir.

title: Milken Terms Renegotiated
description: Federal prosecutors and lawyers for Michael R. Milken have renegotiated some terms of a pretrial agreement after a Federal judge earlier this week found it to be unenforceable.

title: Favored Easy Goer Is an Outsider of Sorts
description: A field of 16, ranging from sublime favorites to ridiculous long-shots, was entered today for the 115th Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs on Saturday.

title: Former Piedmont Head Pushes Bid for Eastern
description: William R. Howard, former head of Piedmont Airlines, is not holding back in the effort to put together his own reorganization plan for Eastern Airlines.

title: Hanover Insurance Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Producing and Shaping Superconductor Material
description: Researchers at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology received a patent this week for a method of shaping high-temperature superconducting material into wire, coil, sheet and other useful forms. M.I.T. had announced previously that it would receive the patent, but it was not issued until Tuesday.

title: The Delta Blues, Crack and the Devil
description: LEAD: They say Robert Johnson spent his last hours on all fours, crawling back and forth and barking like a dog.

title: Bethlehem Steel in Pact With Union
description: The Bethlehem Steel Corporation, the nation's second-largest steelmaker, reached an agreement with the United Steelworkers Union yesterday on a 50-month contract that will restore wages to the level union members enjoyed before agreeing to concessions seven years ago.

title: Micropolis Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Unitil Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Your Money; What to Consider In Money Funds
description: Money market funds are enjoying a resurgence of popularity, and it is no surprise.

title: Concession to Chris-Craft on Warner
description: In an effort to break a stalemate between two long-feuding executives and get on with an $18 billion merger, Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. said yesterday that they were willing to concede that Warner had violated a contract with Chris-Craft Industries.

title: Stocks Mixed as Slide Erases Rally
description: LEAD: The stock market closed mixed yesterday as late profit taking and program trading erased what had been a sharp rally in the Dow Jones industrial average.

title: O'Neill Rejects Using Troops in Drug Fight
description: Five city ministers appealed today to Gov. William A. O'Neill to send the National Guard into New Haven to help stop drug-related violence, but the Governor immediately rejected the request.

title: Northwest Machinists Plan Takeover Move
description: The machinists' union at Northwest Airlines said yesterday that it opposed the buyouts or restructuring programs for the carrier that had been proposed so far and that it would begin to develop a plan of its own to gain control of the airline with a friendly investor.

title: 40 Riverdale Students Hurt In Bus Accident in Catskills
description: Forty teen-agers and at least two teachers from the Bronx were injured late this afternoon when the bus taking them home from a camp in the Catskills missed a curve and plunged into a creek, the New York State police said.

title: Secrets Of the Svelte
description: Many persons have written begging me to divulge my weight-loss secrets. And why not? Why bother losing weight except to bore people by talking about it?

title: Colonial Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Script May Be All Easy Goer Follows Today
description: It was shortly after 3:30 P.M. last Aug. 19, in front of the ancient and rickety wooden stands of Saratoga Race Track in upstate New York, that it began to look as if the 115th Kentucky Derby here at Churchill Downs might be different from most.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With picking the right sunscreen
description: Sun-wary people face a bewildering array of protective lotions and creams this season. The countless formulas made for different skin types include preparations for the eye area and lips, products that are waterproof or water-resistant, things made especially for children and colored nose coatings and lip protectors in flashy red, pink, yellow, orange, blue and green.

title: Reviews/Pop; Fighting the Good Fight To a 1970's Reggae Beat
description: Rastafarian faith becomes liberation theology in the songs of Bunny Wailer. Mr. Wailer frames political questions in moral terms, naming Lucifer as the cause of human conflict and insisting that the struggle for human rights is the struggle of good against evil.

The company attributed the sales increase in the latest year to its acquisition of Heidi's Pastry Inc. and Westbrae Natural Foods Inc.

description: The flagship store of Carson Pirie Scott & Company on State Street in Chicago may be converted to a multi-use real estate development, according to papers filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission by P. A. Bergner & Company, which this week agreed to buy Carson Pirie Scott for $453 million in cash.

title: Bridge; Fewer women than usual enter next week's Cavendish International Charity Pairs.
description: The Cavendish Invitational Charity Pairs, which will begin in a week, will have fewer women than usual playing because several stars have chosen not to enter this year. There will be four mixed partnerships: Linda Lewis and with Eddie Wold, Kathie Walvick and Walt Walvick, Kay Schulle and John Mohan, and Kyoko Mizutani of Japan and Akio Hirokawa.

title: Sympathy For Derby 'Muskrats'
description: The Kentucky Derby would be such a wonderful event if only they didn't let all these horses in it.

title: Claude Benjamin, 81, A Longtime Songwriter
description: Claude A. (Bennie) Benjamin, a songwriter who composed ''I Don't Want to Set the World on Fire'' and other popular tunes, died after a long illness Tuesday at Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital in Manhattan. He was 81 years old.

title: Damaged Battleship Is to Return To Sea Before Repair, Officers Say
description: The Navy has tentatively decided to return the battleship Iowa to sea duty before repairing her badly damaged turret, both to avoid disrupting operational and shipyard schedules and to save money, Navy officers said today.

title: Boyd's Career in Doubt
description: Dennis (Oil Can) Boyd's career with the Boston Red Sox may be in jeopardy unless he develops a new delivery.

title: Mattingly, Balboni Power Yankees
description: In their first four weeks, the Yankees were simply a team that depended on guile more than grit. When they won, it was by moving runners from base to base, by slipping ahead early and hoping that their pitching held up. But tonight at Comiskey Park, they tried a different approach.

title: Moscow May Get McDonald's by '90
description: Moscow could have its first McDonald's fast-food restaurant by the end of the year, a spokesman for the joint-venture company Moskva McDonald's said. The company, which plans to open 20 of the American-style hamburger restaurants in the capital, expects to finish work on a building on Pushkin Square in the center of the city by December, he said.

title: Transtector Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a non-recurring pretax trade credit of about $152,000, recorded as a reduction to the cost of goods, and a tax credit of about $69,000.

title: Latin Festival
description: Music of the Andean highland will be performed at 8 P.M. this evening as part of a monthlong Latin festival at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, at Amsterdam Avenue and 112th Street. The musical group Inkhay will combine the ancient music of the Incas with European instrumentation. Tickets are $10. Information: 662-2133.

title: Murdoch to Sell Travel Businesses
description: Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation agreed yesterday to sell its travel-related publications to Reed International P.L.C., Britain's largest publishing company, for $825 million.

title: Drexel Lost $167 Million In 1988, Court Papers Show
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. lost $167 million last year, according to documents released yesterday as part of a court case. The loss would have been $261 million but for an accounting change related to the treatment of income taxes.

title: Continental Medical Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Corrected from yesterday.

title: Banks to Offer Mexico Smaller Debt Reduction
description: Mexico and its commercial bankers yesterday adjourned their talks on debt reduction for a week so the bankers could finish work on a proposal that would offer less than Mexico has sought.

title: N-Plant Reports Water Leak
description: The Oyster Creek Nuclear Generating Station, out of service for repairs, reported a water leak today inside the plant's drywell. No radioactivity was released during the incident, which lasted from 2:40 A.M. to 3:10 A.M., plant officials said. Operators were filling reactor systems with water for testing when safety valves began leaking, said a statement by GPU Nuclear Corporation. Operators repaired the leaks, the statement said.

title: Alloy Computer Products reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: BRITAIN TO EXPEL 3 SOUTH AFRICANS
description: Britain ordered the expulsion of three South African diplomats today in retaliation for Pretoria's reported involvement in an arms deal with a paramilitary group in Northern Ireland.

title: Capital Holding Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included pretax realized capital losses of $17.4 million. c-Included pretax realized capital gains of $19.9 million.

title: A Columbia Class of '39 Catches Up on the News
description: They wrote their articles on typewriters, not computers. They argued about the politics of the day - the Spanish Civil War. And they paid $400 for a year's tuition at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism.

title: War Stills Ancient Villages on Kabul's Lifeline
description: After a decade of war, the horrors of Afghanistan have become widely known. But here in the mountains of the Hindu Kush, along a river valley fabled for its harsh beauty since the time of Jesus, recent fighting has left a scene of devastation that goes beyond what westerners have previously known about the conflict.

title: Forrest C. Lattner, 87, an Investment Banker
description: Forrest Comer Lattner, an investment banker, philanthropist and oil executive , died of a stroke April 28 at Bethesda Memorial Hospital in Boynton Beach, Fla. He was 87 years old and lived in Delray Beach, Fla.

title: LAC Minerals Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Cavaliers Edge Bulls in Overtime to Force Game 5
description: Larry Nance scored 27 points and Mark Price added 24 to offset a 50-point performance by Michael Jordan tonight, and the Cleveland Cavaliers evened their three-of-five-game playoff series against Chicago at two apiece with a 108-105 overtime victory.

description: b-Net loss The latest first quarter's results included a $441,000 net gain on the sale of H&H Group's investment in Re Capital Corp., net of $75,000 in expenses incurred in the sale. The year-ago results were restated to include the operations of Capital Trust Management Corp., which merged with a subsidiary of H&H Group in April 1988. The year-ago results included acquisition expenses of $218,000 incurred in the acquisition of Capital Trust, and a loss of $226,000 on disposal of a common stock investment.

title: Dr. John R. Heller Jr. Dies at 84; Headed National Cancer Institute
description: Dr. John R. Heller Jr., a former director of the National Cancer Institute and former president of the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, died Thursday at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md., five days after he suffered a stroke. He was 84 years old and lived in Bethesda.

title: After 553,058 Years, a Win!
description: LEAD: Apparently sane individuals drove hundreds of miles and waited in lines for hours last month to purchase a single commodity. It didn't happen in Moscow; it happened in Pennsylvania. The commodity was Super 7 tickets in the Pennsylvania lottery.

title: Soviet CNN Broadcasts Expected
description: An official of Turner Broadcasting System Inc. said today that he expects the Cable News Network to be broadcast live to the Soviet Union, possibly as soon as August.

title: Officer, 26, Shot in Harlem In Drug Buy
description: A 26-year-old New York City undercover police officer was critically wounded by shotgun blasts last night during a drug-buy operation in Harlem.

title: American Physicians Service Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $2,002,000 from discontinued operations.

title: U.S. Assails South Korea On Currency
description: The Bush Administration complained today that South Korea was continuing to maintain its currency, the won, at an artificially low level that gives it a trade advantage against the United States.

title: Wicks Hurt in Accident
description: Sidney Wicks, the former star forward at U.C.L.A. who played for Portland, Boston and San Diego in the National Basketball Association, was seriously injured yesterday morning when his car was struck by a truck carrying cement near San Diego, authorities said.

title: Shuttle's Venus Probe Is Right on Target
description: Bound for Venus, the Magellan spacecraft cruised serenely far away from Earth today on a course so accurate that only a few normal correction maneuvers should be required over the next 15 months to reach the cloud-shrouded planet 795 million miles away.

title: Douglass Watson, 67, Theater and TV Actor
description: Douglass Watson, an actor who appeared on the NBC television soap opera ''Another World'' for 15 years, died of a heart attack Monday while vacationing in Arizona, the network announced. He was 67 years old.

title: Judge Refuses to Bar Payouts By Manville Asbestos Fund
description: A Federal bankruptcy judge in Manhattan yesterday declined to block payments being made to victims of asbestos by a special fund set up by the Manville Corporation.

title: Governors Assail U.S. Effort To Clean Up Nuclear Waste
description: Expressing their ''concern, frustration and anger,'' the Governors of 10 states wrote the Secretary of Energy yesterday to criticize Federal efforts to clean up pollution at the plants that make nuclear bomb material.

title: United Brands Co. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
2 Brooklyn Rape Suspects Charged in 2d Case
description: Two young men accused of raping a woman at knifepoint and throwing her from the roof of a three-story building in Brooklyn were charged yesterday with raping another woman on a roof two doors away in March, the authorities said.

title: Loss Widens At Savings Unit
description: The Western Savings and Loan Association, which wiped out the equity of its shareholders and fell below regulatory capital guidelines at the end of 1988, reported on Thursday that it had a $99.8 million first-quarter loss. Its loss a year ago was $1.9 million.

description: Latest quarter results included $325,000 aftertax gain from the settlement of a long-term receivable which had been reserved.

title: Reviews/Pop; Satire by Marilyn Michaels
description: Like many performers who specialize in impressions, Marilyn Michaels is a much stronger singer when she is imitating someone else than when just being herself.

title: Commodity Inquiry Said to Have a Second Focus
description: An important focus of an investigation of traders at four of New York's commodity exchanges that was disclosed Thursday is an activity that is the commodity market's equivalent of insider trading, people involved in the inquiry said yesterday.

title: Election Fund Sentencing
description: A former Unisys Corporation employee today was ordered to perform 200 hours of community service for concealing illegal political donations from military contractors to a Congressman.

title: S.O.I.  Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Florida Won't Retry Man in Poisoning Case
description: A special prosecutor said today that the State of Florida would not retry James Joseph Richardson, who had spent the last 21 years in prison for the deaths by poisoning of his seven children.

description: b-Net income and after a credit of $886,000 from an accounting adjustment.

title: Back on the Trolley or Aboard the Electric Bus?; Wake Up, New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Pretoria Won't Bend on Namibia
description: South Africa today rejected a proposal by the United Nations Secretary General that its forces in Namibia stop their search for guerrillas and return to their bases.

title: DOLLAR GAINS DESPITE RISE IN JOBLESS AND SALES BY FED
description: The dollar, which continues to baffle many traders and economists with its persistent strength, climbed again yesterday despite an unexpected rise in the unemployment rate and repeated rounds of dollar-selling by the Federal Reserve and other central banks.

title: In New York City, Power to the People
description: LEAD: The New York City government proposed by the chairman of the Charter Revision Commission recognizes that our politics are driven by self-interest. And that's why it would make a better government.

title: Chrysler Agrees to Sponsor Toned-Down 'Nightingales'
description: Aaron Spelling Productions has agreed to tone down the sexually suggestive scenes in ''Nightingales,'' and the Chrysler Corporation has agreed in principle to sponsor the show.

title: Review/Music; A Leinsdorf Program Gives Instrumentalists Their Hour
description: The knack for putting together consistently imaginative concert programs is one that only a few conductors ever acquire. Erich Leinsdorf, as New York Philharmonic audiences have long known, is one of the few. It is a little odd: he has access to the same music libraries as everyone else. But his long experience, catholic sympathies and thoughtfully skewered view of the orchestral repertory combine to give many of his programs a fascinating look and, often enough, a satisfying sound as well. These days, what with good conductors at a premium, he is beginning to look like a giant.

title: Investors Sue Penny Broker
description: A group of New England investors has filed a class-action lawsuit seeking hundreds of thousands of dollars from Blinder, Robinson & Company, a Denver penny-stock brokerage.

title: Industrial Countries to Aid Poorer Nations on Ozone
description: The Western industrialized countries and Japan agreed today to help developing nations adhere to a worldwide ban on a class of chemicals that is destroying the protective layer of ozone in the atmosphere.

title: Grantham Journal; Where Chicken Margaret Is Served (but Rarely)
description: The lack of enthusiasm being displayed for the hometown girl who made good was enough to make Joe Flatters take matters into his own hands.

title: Review/Dance; Balanchine Revival and a Birthday
description: The New York City Ballet revived George Balanchine's 1972 version of ''Danses Concertantes'' for the first time since 1977 on Thursday night. But first things first. When members of the audience found an insert in their programs that said ''Happy Birthday Lincoln!'', no one thought that Honest Abe was being honored three months late.

title: Robert Di Scipio Weds Miss Glavin
description: Christine Elizabeth Glavin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Francis Glavin of Greenwich, Conn., was married there yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Michael the Archangel to Robert Michael Di Scipio, a son of Mr. and Mrs. R. Michael Di Scipio of New Canaan, Conn. The Rev. Lawrence J. Carroll performed the ceremony. Mrs. Di Scipio, a graduate of Holy Cross College, is a buyer in New York for Ann Taylor Inc., the women's clothing company. Her father, who recently retired as a vice chairman of Xerox in Stamford, Conn., is to become the president of Babson College on July 1.The bridegroom, a lawyer in Stamford, graduated from the University of Michigan and the Pace University School of Law. His father owns Di Scipio & Associates, an advertising and public-relations company in New Canaan.

description: Bobby Beathard, who built the Washington Redskins by relying on his instincts, said yesterday that he had resigned as general manager for the same reason.

description: Making New York City's five borough presidents part of an expanded City Council to enhance their power in a new government would probably be legal. But a broad cross-section of politicians and civic group leaders say they do not think it would be a good idea.

title: Turnout of 6% In School Vote Is Lowest Ever
description: Despite an intensive effort to get a large turnout, fewer people voted in Tuesday's community school board elections in New York City than in any since decentralized school operation began in 1970, according to tentative figures released yesterday.

Melee Site Quiet, but Police Stand Guard
description: More than 200 police officers stood stoically in a cold rain on the Lower East Side yesterday, guarding a two-block area around a demolished building where squatters used to live, while a bulldozer slowly chewed through the rubble of the site.

description: b-Included a loss of $9.9 million from a merger termination fee paid to Dana Corp. c-Net income On March 23, Cooper Industries acquired 83 percent of Champion Spark's common stock.

title: Rebuilt Cars: States Seek More Data For Buyers
description: Legislation that requires automobile dealers to tell customers when a ''used'' car is actually a body shop's assemblage of salvaged parts has been approved by about two dozen states and is being considered by others. The states are acting to cope with a boom in the unregulated market for rebuilt cars.

title: How, and Whether, to Keep the Beeps
description: What's to become of New York City's five borough presidents, whom headline writers call ''the beeps''? That question is putting the Charter Revision Commission through contortions as it designs a new government for the city. Meanwhile the five panicked beeps toss up self-serving ideas that offend common sense. History, comity and practicality weigh in favor of saving the boroughs and their presidents, but only if constructive executive roles can be devised for them.

title: University Science Partners reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

description: The Bolshoi Opera and the Kirov Ballet, the largest opera and ballet companies in the Soviet Union, have joined forces with a London-based theatrical promoter, the Entertainment Corporation, to market their image throughout the world.

description: b-Net loss and after a charge of $1,345,110,000 from an accounting change for disallowed costs. The latest first quarter's net did not cover preferred stock requirements. Lilco said its net income in the latest quarter was reduced by about $100 million, or 87 cents a share, because of its previously announced decision to discontinue accruing the allowance for funds used during construction on its Shoreham investment effective Jan. 1. The charge for a change in accounting in the year-ago period resulted from the company's adoption of SFAS 90, which required a writedown of the company's investments in Shoreham, Nine Mile Point 2 and Jamesport.

description: Six weeks after Pete Rozelle announced that he was stepping down as N.F.L. commissioner as soon as a successor could be found, the owners' committee formed to find a successor has decided it needs some help.

title: Parents of Baby Slain in '86 Are Suspected in 2 Murders
description: Robert and Paula Sims, who reported the abduction of two children in the last three years, are now suspects in the slaying of their 6-week-old daughter three years ago, the chief investigator said today.

title: Jaime Barrios, 43, Latin Film Maker, Dies
description: Jaime Eduardo Barrios Perez de Arce, a Chilean film maker, died April 18 after a heart attack at his home in Manhattan. He was 43 years old.

title: Iranian Urges Wider Terror Against West
description: The Speaker of the Iranian Parliament urged Palestinians today to kill Westerners wherever they find them, attack American interests worldwide and hijack airplanes to obtain their rights from Israel.

description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $543,000 for the quarter and $849,000 for the 9 months.

title: Pit Bull Kills Boy, 3
description: Dustin Webb, 3 years old, has died of wounds inflicted by his grandparents' pit bull terrier, the authorities said. Dustin died Thursday at John Sealy Hospital in nearby Galveston a day after he was attacked by the dog in the backyard of his grandparents' home. His grandmother, Geraldine Webb, was in the house. The child was pulled away from the dog only after his grandmother and a neighbor fought the dog off, Police Chief Mark Wicker said.

description: Dr. Nestor John Totero, a psychatrist and surgeon, died of a heart attack Thursday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

description: A 20-year-old Soviet hockey prodigy arrived in the United States yesterday afternoon, a day after he stunned the international hockey community by becoming the first top Soviet player to defect to the West, in this case to the Buffalo Sabres of the National Hockey League.

description: Herschel C. Loveless, Governor of Iowa from 1957 to 1961, died of lung cancer Wednesday in a hospital in Winchester, Va., where he lived. He was 77 years old.

title: COMPANY NEWS
description: Farah in Talks On Company Sale Farah Inc., a maker of jeans and popular sportswear, said it was in substantive talks to sell the company for at least $69 million. Farah, which makes clothes under its own name and the Generra label, gave no other details. A full buyout of Farah would value the company at $69 million based on its stock price today of $11.125, unchanged from Thursday.

title: Jurors See North as a Scapegoat for His Superiors
description: The jurors in the trial of Oliver L. North saw the defendant as a scapegoat blamed unfairly for following the instructions of his superiors, and that is why they voted to acquit him on the nine charges that involved lying to Congress and Federal investigators.

title: Matches Postponed By Rain
description: The second annual Port Washington Tennis Academy Tournament of Champions began play with doubles matches yesterday, featuring the return of John McEnroe, who spent some of his youth on those indoor courts on Long Island. Port Washington redux was necessitated by another day of rain at Forest Hills, which forced postponement of the singles quarterfinals.

title: Soviets Identify A 2d Gas Used In Georgia Strife
description: After weeks of official delay, the Georgian authorities have identified a second type of toxic gas used by troops in a fatal clash with demonstrators here last month.

title: Lebanon: Cry, My Beloved Country
description: LEAD: The Lebanese are accused of being the authors of their tragedy, the victims of their own hatred. They are asked to become reconciled with each other - as if they are the only ones on the Lebanese scene. Walls are built by the occupiers just to prevent us from meeting and talking. Our freedom is chained; our thoughts are imprisoned.

description: Reeling from a sharp decline in advertising revenue, McCall's magazine is being sold to Diamandis Communications Inc., perhaps as early as this weekend, magazine industry executives said yesterday.

title: Thakin Soe, Burmese Communist, 83
description: U Thakin Soe, one of Burma's most prominent Communist leaders, died on Thursday after a long illness, reports said today. He was 83 years old.

title: Shoppers Stray, Merchants Scramble
description: Because so many consumers have just said no,price increases for most clothing have moderated and are now running below the cost of living. This comes after two years of clothing prices rising faster than inflation.

title: What China's Students Want
description: China's youth have taken to the streets in a stunning challenge to authority. They feel they are being asked to forgo the higher living standards enjoyed by non-Communist Chinese and the new freedoms enjoyed by many non-Chinese Communists. No wonder they are in open revolt. And it's not just students. Their original demonstrations in Beijing have spread to other cities and won the support of other classes. The conservative Communist leadership that not so long ago bemoaned student apathy now needs to radically readjust its assumptions. Already it has shifted to more conciliatory language. Its ability to accommodate the student movement's ideas will help determine China's political and economic future.

title: Choral Concert

Tickets are $12. Information: 362-8719.

title: I.B.M. Computers
description: The International Business Machines Corporation plans to introduce two long-awaited new models in its Personal System/2 line on Tuesday, according to several industry executives close to the company. One of the personal computers will be a portable based on the Intel 386 microprocessor chip. This machine has been expected by many computer industry observers for a number of months. It will directly compete against the Compaq Portable III, a popular portable computer. A second model, a desktop computer, which may be labeled the PS/2 Model 55, will be based on a more economical 386SX microprocessor chip. The less expensive chip matches many of the features of the full 32-bit system but permits computer makers to design less expensive computers. Information on the price of the new computers was not available.

title: Promoting 'Femininity'
description: When a company refuses to promote a woman, who must prove that the decision did not turn on illegal sex discrimination? The Supreme Court now rules that the woman making the claim must first show that illegal bias played some role. Once that is shown, however, the burden is on the company to justify its decision. It's a balanced, sensible judgment in a case that started nine years ago.

Throughout his seven years of service - he has now announced his retirement as of July - he has put medical integrity above personal value judgments and has been, indeed, the nation's First Doctor.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Pearls as Gifts
description: Pearls have never been more popular, and they are likely to be welcomed on Mother's Day. Simulated pearls are fine, but if your budget allows, cultured ones will make a more enduring gift. These are grown in oysters after the insertion of beads, causing the oyster to cover the bead with coats of nacre. There is no industry standard, but Mikimoto, one of the largest distributors, and other dealers grade pearls in descending order as AAA, AA, and A. An 18-inch strand of 6-millimeter pearls at Mikimoto ranges from $710 to $2,300. Here are some characteristics of pearls. Luster: Also referred to as brilliance. The longer the pearl remains in the oyster, the more nacre builds up and the deeper the radiance. Shape: Perfectly round pearls command the highest price. Odd-shaped pearls are called baroque and are less expensive. Color: Color produced by Japanese oysters is basically white, with varying shades of cream, gray, blue, gold, silver, pink and pink rose. Pink pearls are the most expensive, followed by white. Large blemishes decrease value. Source: Yoshi Watanabe, vice president, the Mikimoto America Company, New York.

Open Mind, last year's champion 2-year-old filly and unbeaten in four starts at 3, rallied from far back on a sloppy track to score by 2 1/4 lengths. Earlier this week Mr. Steinhardt purchased 94,700 USAir shares on the open market for prices ranging from $43.08 to $43.79 a share. USAir closed today at $44, up 12.5 cents a share, on the New York Stock Exchange. NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-6 George Bush and Helmut Kohl discussed their differences over short-range nuclear missiles by telephone, and Administration officials said the United States was hopeful of a compromise on the issue. Page 1 News analysis: Missile policy, especially President Bush's hard line on short-range missiles, dominates conversation in Washington and in capitals abroad, among those who follow foreign affairs. 6 Bush nominee calls treaty on strategic arms a priority 3 Soviet troops used a second toxic gas in a fatal clash with demonstrators in the Republic of Georgia last month. The second gas was a powerful tear gas that raised international concern during the Vietnam War. 1 In Afghanistan, devastation goes beyond what Westerners have previously known about the conflict. Dozens of ancient villages have been bombed, rocketed and shelled into oblivion. 1 An Iranian leader urged Palestinians to kill Westerners wherever they found them, attack American interests worldwide and hijack airplanes to obtain their rights from Israel. 3 Chinese newspapers displayed new openness in their coverage of a large demonstration on Thursday, after studiously ignoring pro-democracy protests for the last two weeks. 4 Britain expelled three South African diplomats in retaliation for Pretoria's involvement in a weapons deal with a paramilitary group in Northern Ireland. 3 South Africa rejects a U.N. proposal on Namibia 4 Western nations and Japan will help developing nations comply with a worldwide ban on certain chemicals that are destroying the protective layer of ozone in the atmosphere. 6 National 7-9, 28 Job growth slackened decisively in April, while the unemployment rate rose three-tenths of a point to 5.2 percent, the Government reported. The data confirms a weakening of the economy over several weeks. 1 Jobless rate up in New York and New Jersey 8 Jurors saw North as a scapegoat and several said they felt the defendant was blamed unfairly for following his superiors' instructions. That is why they voted to acquit him on nine of the charges. 1 George Bush's spokesman skirted questions about a pardon for Oliver North, who was convicted of shredding Government documents and two other crimes stemming from his role in the Iran-contra affair. 9 News groups in settlements with U.S. on North trial exhibit 9 The F.B.I. must overhaul its system for promoting Hispanic agents and those from other minority groups, a Federal judge announced. The judge said employment decisions had long been marred by discrimination. 1 Bound for Venus, the Magellan spacecraft cruised serenely far away from Earth on a course so accurate that only a few normal correction maneuvers should be required over the next 15 months of its planned journey. 7 The East could face shortages of electricity this summer because peak demand is rising so fast that it threatens to outstrip supply, according to utility experts. Brownouts and blackouts may occur on hot days. 33 Jim Wright pledged to block legislation in return for $250,000 in contributions to a political action committee, according to a savings and loan executive who testified in a Federal District Court. 8 Wright, in a speech at home, argues for his achievements 8 Dan Quayle, in a brief visit to Alaska, said the Exxon Corporation must do more than it is doing to clean up oil spilled by a tanker in Prince William Sound. Mr. Quayle was returning to Washington from a trip to Asia. 7 Governors from 10 states are angry about pollution at the government plants that make bomb material and laggard cleanup efforts. They released a strongly worded letter to the Secretary of Energy. 7 Rupert Murdoch agreed to sell his travel-related publications to Reed International, Britain's largest publishing company, for $825 million. The high price is an indication of the boom times in the travel business. 33 Regional 29-32 A police officer was shot and critically wounded by shotgun blasts during a drug-buy operation in New York City. The 26-year-old undercover officer was found on a sidewalk after entering a car to buy drugs. 29 Over 200 police officers guarded a two-block area around a demolished building three days after squatters vigorously protested its destruction. No one could enter the area without a police escort. 29 The Navy closed its investigation into the death of a Marine guard from Long Island who was fatally shot in El Salvador last year. The Navy said the death was self-inflicted, but the Marine's family is not so sure. 29 Gerald Cardinale offers himself as the Republican Party's most conservative choice for governor in New Jersey. But what seems to distinguish him most from the others is that his campaign is the angriest. 29 The Jersey City races are oddly dull as the campaigns for mayor and nine Council seats near Election Day on Tuesday. Elections used to mean excitement and street theater in the city. 30 Voter turnout was 6 percent Tuesday in New York City's school board elections. Fewer people voted than in any school board election since decentralized school operations began in 1970. 31 Two men accused in one rape in Brooklyn were charged with raping another woman on a nearby roof in March. The charges were filed after a 39-year-old woman saw the men's faces on a television news report. 31 The Central Park rape victim continues to improve 31 The Mayor and union leaders agreed on a plan that would save New York City $150 million a year in pension costs and avoid the layoffs of city employees in the coming year. 30 Borough chiefs on Council: plan attracts little support 31
