title:
ART;
Works of Grit and Precision in New Haven
description: LEAD: THE physical setup of the New Britain Museum of American Art is a strong ally of representational art. The old wing is a converted house, so the galleries are small and intimate. A narrative incident reads as well here as a lush abstraction does in a large white-walled space. The museum's collection, therefore, is long on figurative work and even celebrates pure illustration.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: CARGO. By Jane Rawlinson. (Andre Deutsch/David & Charles, $19.95.) In ''Cargo,'' the third novel by the British writer Jane Rawlinson, Ophelia Lapierre's beloved grandmother imparts the lessons of ''real hist'ry.'' ''I ain't talking 'bout no corn laws, chil','' says the old matriarch. ''I ain't talking 'bout no William the Conqueror, I talking 'bout your relatives and how you come to born on this island.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: GOING DUTCH Smile when you suggest ''Going Dutch'' at Hofstra University. The people there take the hint literally, and today, for the sixth year in a row, the Hempstead campus will celebrate its Dutch heritage with a Dutch Festival. The four-hour program begins at noon.

title: Rocky and Bullwinkle Brave the Comeback Trail
description: Moose and squirrel are back. In the summer of 1964, when we last left our heroes - that plucky little rodent with the aviator helmet and his tall, antlered friend with the dimwit voice - you'll remember that their cartoon show had been canceled by NBC. Rocky and Bullwinkle, along with those sinister spies, Boris (''Keel Moose'') Badenov and Natasha (''Boris, dollink'') Fatale, just couldn't, it seemed, pull in the ratings.

title: LIKE ME, NEED ME, NOTICE ME
description: WHY ME? The Sammy Davis Jr. Story. By Sammy Davis Jr., Jane Boyar and Burt Boyar. Illustrated. 374 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

title: Chrysler's U-Turn in Car Design
description: The Chrysler Corporation has looked down the road and does not like what it sees.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Penn State; Ban on Smoking Sparks a Promise Of a Challenge
description: Ardent smokers at Penn State University say they will not hide their lights under bushels, in bathrooms or anywhere else for that matter in the face of a policy announced this month to ban smoking in virtually all university buildings and vehicles.

title: Assessing the Risks of Visiting Israel
description: DESMOND and Jennifer Hall had an argument of sorts just before their marriage in March. Should they go to Israel for their honeymoon?

title: An Accord, Loosely, on Ozone Protection
description: THOUGH the ozone layer is eroding and there are signs that the global atmosphere is warming up, many leaders of third world countries have felt that environmentalism is a luxury they simply cannot afford.

title: TIME INC. MEANS BUSINESS
description: Among the ''lush excesses'' of my own experience at Time Inc., where I was a reporter for Sports Illustrated in 1956, was breakfast at the bargaining table (''Time Inc. Means Business,'' by Lester Bernstein, Feb. 26). In those days, management and the Newspaper Guild (of which I was an active member) sat at a pristine, linen-draped table with a skyline view. Coffee was served from a sterling silver service, with irresistible pastries. The ritual symbolized that patriarchal era to me, calculated, I felt, to undermine the urgency of our contract demands.

title: Airport Curfew Plan Is Revived, With Noise Level as Guide
description: TWO members of the County Board of Legislators have proposed that a mandatory curfew be instituted at the County Airport to ban noisy planes from midnight to 7 A.M. Although not a new idea, the proposal has become a practical option, its supporters say, because the county has the data it requires to identify offenders and to substantiate the need for a mandatory curfew.

title: A Day to Step Out of Studio 'Isolation'
description: RUTH DUCKWORTH'S serene porcelain forms are matte white, eggshell thin and precise. In contrast, Albert Paley's decorative ironwork seems to exert an inner energy as its dark and twisted rods culminate in whiplash swirls. Works by these two internationally known craft artists are featured in an exhibition on view at the College Art Gallery of Montclair State College.

title: On the Big Questions, the Jury Is Still Out
description: IT took the jurors in the trial of Oliver L. North 12 days and a prayer to reach conclusions about the Iran-contra affair. History may need more help and certainly more time.

title: WHAT THE TECHIES WROUGHT
description: WEST OF EDEN The End of Innocence at Apple Computer. By Frank Rose. 356 pp. New York: Viking. $19.95.

title: Suburban Steeplechase: The Commuter Derby
description: AND they're off. Trotting down the runway with eyes stuck on watches and hands filled with coffee cups, briefcases and newspapers, they pant toward the whistle. Nobody smiles, nobody talks, nobody looks at anybody.

title: U.S. Researchers Find Big Field of Geysers in Mediterranean
description: A robot submersible, transmitting video pictures to scientists and schoolchildren by way of its long tether and radio links, has revealed a field of hot geysers on the floor of the Mediterranean Sea 110 miles southwest of Naples.

title: THE POLITICIANS: Avoiding Decisions
description: On June morning in 1984, I drove by taxi from Beirut to Jerusalem. The Beirut taxi driver took me as far south as the Israeli army lines, about 25 miles from the border, where I had to get out with my suitcases and golf clubs and drag them through the Israeli checkpoint and down a stretch of road to link up with another Lebanese taxi that would take me to the Israeli border.

title: What Acquiring Minds Want to Own
description: ''ENQUIRER GRASS TO GROW UNWATCHED. GARDENERS REJOICE.''

title: PASTIMES: Bridge
description: The Cavendish Club's Invitational Charity Pairs, one of the world's strongest annual events, will be slightly different this year. There will be 40 pairs instead of 36, and play next weekend will be at the Westbury Hotel, 69th Street and Madison Avenue instead of the host club.

title: In the Trenches
description: IN 1979, SHORTLY AFTER THE Oakland (Calif.) Museum put on display a Rand McNally globe of ocean-floor relief, Pierina R. Nicholson, an associate curator of earth sciences, noticed what she thought was an error in the definition of the Amazon River delta. ''So I got a map of the coast and it verified my instinct,'' she recalls, and thus she was off on a project that 10 years later remains at least a year and a half from completion - the first globe to present an accurate, scientific rendition of the world's ocean floor.

title: ...A 100th Birthday Counters the Silences in a Family's Life
description: MY grandfather will turn 100 next week. He is the same age as the Eiffel Tower and 100 years younger than the French Revolution. From the neighboring Cote d'Azur, from Paris, from all the provinces of France, from New York, from Virginia, from the French West Indies, the family will travel to the south of France to celebrate with him.

title: Budget and TaxesKey Nassau Issues As Race Shapes Up
description: NASSAU County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta, a candidate this year for the ninth time in the last 15 years, probably has shaken more hands and mailed more letters to constituents than any Nassau politician on the scene today.

title: Vermonters Organizing Opposition to Gas Pipeline
description: Angry Vermont residents are mobilizing in opposition to a plan to run a natural-gas pipeline across the state from the Canadian border.

title: Whitbread Sail Race Adds a U.S. Port
description: Planners for the Whitbread Around-the-World Race added an American port to the itinerary this year. But there still may not be a United States team in the sailboat race.

title: Reds Struggle but Rally to Defeat the Phillies, 7-4
description: Todd Benzinger hit a go-ahead single in the fifth inning and Paul O'Neill and Ron Oester drove in two runs each tonight as the Cincinnati Reds rallied and beat the Philadelphia Phillies, 7-4.

title: Baruch's Minority Alumni Seek a Separate Group
description: A Federal court is weighing a dispute between the administration of Baruch College and a group of minority graduates who want to form their own alumni association.

title: SPIES & THRILLERS
description: WEAPON by Robert Mason (Putnam, $18.95) has an unusual and amusing premise. Meet Solo, a $2 billion robot designed for the Army by a brilliant American. Solo is going to be the ultimate soldier. He is packed full of gadgetry that gives him amazing strength and speed. He reads codes, picks up transmissions from space satellites and has his own kind of intelligence. For his final test he is sent to Costa Rica, close to the Nicaraguan border, to work with the contras. But a major problem develops. Solo refuses to kill.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending April 22 MANHATTAN Chelsea $540,000 147 West 15th Street (La Fabrique) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,900-sq.-ft. prewar loft-co-op; dining room, large kitchen, high ceilings; maintenance $1,043, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: Kingman Associates) Upper West Side $320,000 145 West 79th Street (Manchester House) 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,000-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining foyer, remodeled kitchen; maintenance $535, 16% tax-deductible (Broker: Klara Madlin Real Estate) Upper West Side $300,000 200 West 86th Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,200-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining foyer, two exposures; maintenance $761, 45% tax-deductible (Broker: Eden Realty) Washington Heights $150,000 120 Cabrini Boulevard (Castle Village) 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,000-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; part-time doorman, dining foyer, remodeled kitchen, roof deck, Hudson River view; maintenace $612, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: J.H. Taylor Co.) West Side $700,000 115 Central Park West (72nd St.) (Majestic) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,535-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, manned elevator, maid's room, windowed kitchen, Central Park view; maintenance $1,190, 40% tax-deductible (Broker: B. J. Gottesman) BRONX Parkchester $82,000 2150 Tremont Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 900-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; dining area, large kitchen, Manhattan skyline view; maintenance $275, 30% tax-deductible (Broker: Marland Real Estate) Riverdale $116,000 3671 Hudson Manor Terrace 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 750-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, dining area, pool, c/a; maintenance $434, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Stephen Eldridge Realty) BROOKLYN Bay Ridge $205,000 656 90th Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, attached brick house; dining room, large kitchen, finished basement, 20- by 50-ft. lot; taxes $839 (Broker: Mcpyel Associates) Marine Park Area $242,500 2048 East 35th Street 2-family, semi-attached brick house; 3 bedrooms, 2 1/2 baths, dining room, large kitchen in primary unit; studio on first floor; new windows, 1-car garage, 20- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,200 (Broker: Fogarty Real Estate) Park Slope $207,500 99 Berkeley Place 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,500-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; dining room, large kitchen, private garden; maintenance $400, 58% tax-deductible (Broker: Marilyn A. Donahue) QUEENS Flushing $258,500 47-23 164th Street 3-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, detached colonial; dining room, large kitchen, 1-car garage, 40- by 140-ft. lot; taxes $1,350 (Broker: Century 21/Weber & Rose) Rego Park $99,900 65-15 Alderton Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,000-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; dining area, terrace, Manhattan skyline view; maintenance $500, 52% tax-deductible (Broker: Century 21/Best) STATEN ISLAND Dongan Hills Colony $545,000 52 Francis Place 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, single-family, detached, center hall colonial; dining room, recreation room, den, fireplace, cathedral ceilings, 2-car garage, 100- by 107-ft. lot; taxes $1,000 (Broker: Century 21/Appleseed Agency) New Springville $151,000 28 Belmar Drive East (The Oaks) 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,400-sq.-ft. condo; dining area, large kitchen, pool, tennis; common charge $150, 100% tax-deductible (Broker: Schlott Realtors)

title: U.S.ISN'T PLANNING EAST EUROPE TALKS
description: The Bush Administration has rebuffed a suggestion that the United States seek talks with Moscow on a new political arrangement for Eastern Europe, Administration officials say.

title: Outdoors; Sharks Attract Protectors
description: A rapidly expanding market for shark meat and shark fins has prompted the Mid-Atlantic Fishery Management Council to call for emergency restrictions on harvesting the animals.

title: E. L. Doctorow and Other Famous Writers I Have Never Met
description: MY friend Pam returned from a trip to California. Instead of telling about California, Pam was much more excited about the flight she took to get there.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Bloomingdale $187,000 102 Rafkind Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 28-year-old Cape Cod; full basement, deck, h/w floors; taxes $2,967. Brielle $146,000 613 Borris Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 8-year-old ranch; fireplace, 2-car garage, deck, pool; taxes $1,339. Jackson $110,000 234 Burke Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 50-year-old ranch; dining room, 4.4-acre lot, partially finished basement; taxes $1,360. Mahwah $215,000 18 Hillside Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 52-year-old colonial; full basement, h/w floors, new kitchen; taxes $1,552. Manalapan $218,000 22 Devon Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 7-year-old colonial; 2-car garage, patio; eat-in kitchen; taxes $2,757. Orange $85,000 440 Conover Terrace 5-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 46-year-old colonial; living room with fireplace, eat-in kitchen, 2-car garage; taxes $2,175. OTHER AREAS Washington, Conn. $358,500 196 Baldwin Hill Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath Cape Cod; hardwood floors on first floor, 1.3 acres; taxes $2,104. Mount Pleasant, N.Y. $285,000 25 Jackson Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 32-year-old ranch; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, family room, wood-burning stove, deck; taxes $4,500. Southold, L.I. $150,000 250 Rambler Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; finished basement, deck, private beach rights, attached 1-car garage; taxes $1,200.

title: Solo vs. Package
description: To the Editor: As a participant last November in a T.W.A. Getaway tour to London, I agree with Stanley Carr (''Solo or Package?'' Travel, March 5) that there are definite cost advantages to package tours. But these savings can be expensive in the form of discomfort, sleepless nights and ruined vacations.

title: Laurel Colvin Is Married
description: Laurel Colvin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Emmett Colvin of Dallas, was married yesterday in New York to Helio Fred Garcia, a son of Anezia M. C. Garcia of New York and the late Dr. Frederick C. H. Garcia. The Rev. F. Forrester Church officiated at the Unitarian Church of All Souls. The bride is a member of the education faculty at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The bridegroom is a managing director at the Sawyer/Miller Group, a communications and political consulting firm in New York.

title: 'It's Part of the Legacy of Being Human'
description: IT'S like the light at the end of the tunnel. Winter is over, and the sunshine, scents and colors of spring invite even the most serious-minded out to play. The experience is commonly known as spring fever, and people find it harder to work and carry out their assigned responsibilities.

title: Hispanic Actions: Views and Facts
description: On behalf of the Westchester County Hispanic Advisory Board, I commend you for your insightful article on the assertiveness of the Hispanic community to improve its status in Westchester County [ ''Hispanic Residents Striving for Political and Economic Gains,'' April 16 ] . We are pleased by your coverage and equally hopeful that in future editions the other issues presented in our report, ''Westchester Hispanics: An Agenda for County Action,'' will be closely examined, especially the considerable concern of quality education for Hispanic youths.

title: Jan Tuttle Weds at Harvard
description: Jan Soltis Tuttle and Dr. Benjamin Winthrop White were married yesterday by the Rev. Preston B. Hannibal, an Episcopal priest, in Memorial Church at Harvard University. Mrs. White is the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Michael Soltis of Stratford, Conn. Dr. White is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederic L. Peter White of St. James, L.I.

title: Filling the Antitrust Void
description: TRY your hand at antitrust law: Competing manufacturers of television sets illegally agree to overcharge retail merchants $100 for every set the retailers buy. The retailers unwittingly pass along the entire $100 overcharge to unsuspecting consumer purchasers. Who has the right to sue to collect damages from the manufacturers?

title: Shopping Around for a Credit Card Deal
description: Holders of credit cards, take note: Now just may be the time to shop around to see if you are getting the best possible deal.

title: Reviews/Music; Pro Arte Quartet's Mixed Bill
description: The Washington Square Contemporary Music Series presented a concert Wednesday night at Weill Recital Hall of a Wisconsin-based string quartet with a San Francisco-flavored program. Of Washington Square or even New York, there was precious little; of interesting music, there was a fair amount.

title: Residents Oppose a Halfway House
description: LEAD: A HALFWAY house for patients recovering from mental illness is being opposed by residents here who argue that a better location away from the local high school could be found.

title: Leonide Massine - Ripe for a Reappraisal
description: ''Les Presages,'' which Leonide Massine choreographed in 1933 for Colonel de Basil's Ballets Russes de Monte Carlo as the first of his symphonic ballets, was one of the 20th century's most controversial dance works. Anyone who saw the Paris Opera Ballet's astonishingly vivid revival in Paris this spring might wonder at the esthetic pettiness of the original protests.

title: Four Vocal Concerts Vie as Seasons End
description: THE rush of seasonal finales brings with it a crowded calendar today and a busy weekend to come. Four vocal events are on this afternoon's roster.

title: Knicks' Focus Shifts to Cavs
description: The Knicks went through a 90-minute practice yesterday at their SUNY-Purchase training camp and switched their concentration from the Chicago Bulls to the Cleveland Cavaliers.

title: 130 Are Said to Die in Pirate Attack on Vietnamese Refugees
description: About 130 Vietnamese refugees were massacred or left to drown last month by pirates who attacked their boat off the Malaysian coast, refugee officials said on Friday, citing the account of the only refugee known to have survived the ordeal.

title: 6 Are Dead as Tourist Plane Crashes in Jungle of Yucatan
description: A plane carrying American tourists crash-landed in a remote jungle of the Yucatan Peninsula, killing 6 people and injuring 10, officials said today.

title: 'THOU SHALT SETTLE FOR LESS AND LESS'
description: LEAD: THE LOST SISTER By Robert Love Taylor. 280 pp. North Carolina: Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill.

title: THE REMARKABLE LIFE OF AN INCORRIGIBLE KID
description: THE BABE A Life in Pictures. By Lawrence S. Ritter and Mark Rucker. Illustrated. 282 pp. New York: A Baseball Ink Book/Ticknor & Fields. $40.

title: PHILIP MORRIS'S BIG BITE
description: There is considerable irony in Philip Morris's sponsorship of athletic events like the Virgina Slims tennis tournament. It seems unlikely that the participants in these tournaments smoke. If they did, they would have neither the respiratory capacity nor the stamina necessary to compete as professional athletes. ROBERT J. YAES, M.D. Lexington, Ky.

title: Reviews/Dance; Pretty Boy Floyd and Shakespeare
description: A lot goes on at once in ''Outside the Law,'' presented by the Irondale Ensemble Project on Wednesday night at the Rapp Arts Center. The group, which also works with troubled children in the New York City school system, has woven a populist telling of the story of the notorious bank robber Charles (Pretty Boy) Floyd and a little topical satire into the fabric of Shakespeare's ''As You Like It.'' The results are mixed, though at their best they are very good.

title: Hungarian Radio Broadcasts Long-Banned Revolt Speech
description: Breaking a long taboo, the Hungarian radio today broadcast a speech first made by Prime Minister Imre Nagy on the day that Soviet tanks entered Budapest to suppress the 1956 rebellion. In the speech, Mr. Nagy said the invaders intended ''to overthrow the legal Hungarian democratic Government.''

title: White Plains Acts on Farmers Market
description: LEAD: LAST summer, a Columbia County farmer, Stephen E. Yandik Jr., packed his truck full of fresh-picked fruits and vegetables before 6 A.M. each Saturday morning and took the two-hour drive to the farmers market in the parking lot of the Presbyterian Church of White Plains.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN THE CREDIT DEPARTMENT;
New Credibility for the Corporate Bill Collector WHAT'S NEW IN THE CREDIT DEPARTMENT
description: LEAD: The credit department has long been viewed by others in companies as little more than a bill collector. But growing in complexity and sophistication, it is slowly shedding its green-eyeshade image and gaining respectability.

title: Art and Horticulture Combine in Stamford Silvermine Show
description: FLORISTS, greenhouses and garden clubs have joined some 200 artists in ''Festival '89,'' an exhibition of art, crafts and decorative home accessories at the Silvermine Gallery at Metro Center in Stamford through May 13. There are fresh flowers, silk flowers and paintings of flowers.

title: Cynthia Rodgers Weds Physician
description: Cynthia Joanne Rodgers, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. John Barclay Rodgers Jr. of Delmar, N.Y., was married yesterday to Dr. Barry Miles Belgorod, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Howard Belgorod of New York. John A. Greco, an Episcopal archdeacon, officiated at the Lotos Club in New York.

title: MaryBeth Gallagher Becomes a Bride
description: MaryBeth C. Gallagher and Albert R. Hughes 3d were married yesterday at St. John's Roman Catholic Church in Collingswood, N.J., by Msgr. John Manion.

title: Towns Acting to Overcome Housing Scarcity
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH many Long Island towns and villages agree there is a crisis in affordable housing, most tenaciously honor the time-honored tradition of one house, one family.

title: How's the Roller-Coaster Rivalry? Looking Up, of Course
description: A summertime ritual is under way at amusement parks across the land: the competition to have the tallest and fastest roller coaster. And within weeks of the opening of a new record-holder for height at the Six Flags Great Adventure park in Jackson, N.J., an even taller one has started rolling at the Cedar Point amusement park here.

title: ROLL OVER, SPINOZA
description: THE LATE-SUMMER PASSION OF A WOMAN OF MIND By Rebecca Goldstein. 261 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

title: Miss Englert Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Englert of Centerville, Mass., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Gretchen Elise Englert, and David Harold Neal, the son of Mrs. Harold Neal Jr. of Stuart, Fla., and the late Mr. Neal.

title: TIME INC. MEANS BUSINESS
description: One of Time Inc.'s failed publications was not listed in your article. That magazine was called Letters. It started as a free eight-page supplement to Time to accommodate the overflow of letters to the editor. When it reached 20 pages, ads were solicited. In 1937, three years after it started, circulation reached 25,000 a year. At that point, Letters folded. CARL U. FAUSTER Toledo, Ohio

title: Wright's Path to Power: From Young Idealist to Debt-Ridden Investor
description: ''My finances are in shambles,'' the diary entry reads. ''With what unbelievable folly have I so long ignored them and let them drift. In my 30th year, I was the richest young man in town. In my 50th - well, I'm driving a 10-year-old car, owe so God-awful much money I'll need luck to pay it off. ''But I will, somehow I will.'' Representative Jim Wright of Fort Worth wrote those words in his personal diary in 1971, which he made available to The Fort Worth Star-Telegram for a special section it printed when he was named Speaker of the House in 1986.

title: Sweet Success
description: He has been in the major leagues for only a month, but Ken Griffey Jr. of the Seattle Mariners has had a candy bar named after him. The Ken Griffey Jr. Milk Chocolate Bar wrapper will sport 1 of 12 different images of the center fielder in action, according to the distributor, Mike Cramer.

title: A Baseball Man on the Deal as an Art
description: The movement and trading of players' contracts is the most glamorous part of a baseball operation, but it is also one of the most dangerous, and it requires a great deal of thought, study and planning.

title: SHOPPERS World; At Cambridge, Bookstores in Volume
description: IF, like me, you love books, if it is unlikely you will emerge from a good bookstore before closing time - they may even have to turn the lights off to persuade you to leave - then you will no doubt love Cambridge.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Miami of Ohio; Serenade of Sons Now Sings Praises Of Daughters, Too
description: For 80 years, students at Miami University of Ohio sang a school song that included phrases like, ''Thy sons have quested from thee.'' In that time, those sons went off to fight in two World Wars and battles in Korea and Vietnam. But for 89 years, daughters, too, have attended Miami, and a little war has been fought and won to convince the university of their contributions.

title: The Virtues of Standing Apart
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Wild Ducks'
description: To the Editor:

title: Lanie and Marek Cecula - Ceramic Artists
description: They work in a sliver of a storefront in SoHo and create ceramic pieces - espresso cups, platters, dinnerware, teapots and vases - with an innovative twist. Lanie Cecula, 37 years old, and her husband, Marek, 45, who own Contemporary Porcelain, settled in their shop at 105 Sullivan Street (between Spring and Prince Streets) in 1976. Since then they have become leaders in modern ceramic design.

title: Schools Learn to Aid Pupils With Cancer
description: LEAD: CHRISTOPHER FALLON'S leukemia was diagnosed in July 1987, when he was 8 years old. By that September, most of his hair had fallen out, and he worried about starting third grade. Although his mother had obtained permission from the principal for her son to wear a hat, twice on the first day of school the principal spotted

title: Philip Johnson Town House Brings $3.5 Million at Auction
description: A Manhattan town house designed by Philip Johnson in 1949 for Blanchette Rockefeller, the wife of John D. Rockefeller 3d, was auctioned yesterday at Sotheby's for $3.5 million. The brick-walled converted 1860's carriage house at 242 East 52d Street was bought by an unidentified foreign buyer, competing with eight other people - several Americans and at least one Japanese bidder who was in the room.

title: A Call for Testing All Transit Workers
description: PRODDED by reports that the captain of the Exxon Valdez was drinking before the catastrophic oil spill, more people here are asking whether transportation workers should be randomly tested for the nation's most pervasive drug, alcohol, as well as illegal ones like cocaine and marijuana.

title: The Bountiful Tables of the Lot
description: THERE are many reasons why the Lot, as well as the departments that spread out from its boundaries, has maintained a gastronomic culture all its own. This ocher-hued, rustic land offers no easy access to Paris, and even Bordeaux and Toulouse - the closest major cities - remain a world apart. The culinary richness of its farmers and independent country folk has remained relatively undiminished, as well as widely envied, by the rest of the country.

title: STRANGERS IN THE UNIVERSE
description: LEAD: OTHER PEOPLE'S TRADES By Primo Levi. Translated by Raymond Rosenthal. 222 pp. New York: Summit Books. $18.95.

title: The Superpowers Decide Clients Are Too Expensive
description: THERE is a new sound coming from the third world - the sound of superpowers pulling up stakes. From Afghanistan to Syria to Cambodia to Ethiopia to Angola to Nicaragua, both the United States and the Soviet Union are looking for the exits. And as they take their cold war home with them, both are coming to recognize the nasty, tribal and intractable nature of some regional conflicts that have consumed them for decades.

title: 'The Wages of War'
description: To the Editor:

title: Bristol
description: To the Editor: It was a delight to read about the early engineering triumphs of Isambard Kingdom Brunel (''A Bristol Visit Anchored in the Past,'' Travel, March 26).

title: THE LADY AND THE SCAMP
description: ELIZABETH BARRETT BROWNING A Biography. By Margaret Forster. Illustrated. 400 pp. New York: Doubleday. $19.95.

title: TITLE SEARCH FOLLOW-UP
description: Citing biblical allusions in current book titles, William Safire mentions ''Still Small Voices,'' by John and Janet Wallach, which profiles a variety of Arabs and Israelis who ''strive to make their lives amid the violence of the West Bank and Gaza'' (On Language: ''Title Search Follow-Up, April 2).

title: Backstage With the Lighting Designer
description: JOHN H. HASTINGS is talking in numbers. ''Fourteen and fifteen at full and five at seven,'' he says through headphones. ''Four and five at five and seven through nine out.''

title: Personal Service
description: To the Editor:

title: Paul H. Maenner And Sarah Bower Wed in Bronxville
description: Sarah Palmer Bower, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard H. Bower of Bronxville, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Paul Herbert Maenner, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John R. Maenner of Omaha. The Rev. Frank A. Goodwin performed the ceremony at the Reformed Church.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: MAMARONECK HARBOR'S WEST BASIN;
A Sewage-Treatment Project Yields to Passion for Boating
description: LEAD: THE sun is high, the water is warming and it looks as if boats will be able to come and go from Mamaroneck Harbor's West Basin after all.

title: Marilyn Quayle Is Tackling Disasters as Her Cause
description: In Australia, Marilyn Quayle was briefed on floods and cyclones. In Java, she flew over active volcanoes and stalked killer insects in rice paddies. In Singapore, she sailed on a yacht around the harbor checking on oil tankers and contingency plans for spills. In Thailand, she discussed reforestation.

title: A Slippery Slope to Peace?
description: Weapons of war are tangible.

title: Kathleen Battle to Join The New Haven's Finale
description: Although their subscription seasons have officialy ended, neither the Hartfordd nor the New Haven symphony is ready for summer vacation.

title: Answering the Mail
description: Q. Eight years ago, I had the outside of my house covered with California redwood that was finished with polyurethane varnish. This gave it a beautiful shiny color that everyone admired. After about two years, however, the front of the house started to get dull and spotty looking. I was advised to sand this and reapply polyurethane. I have done this several times, but it seems to be required about every year. The house is ready to be done again. What do you suggest?

title:
IDEAS & TRENDS;
The Elk Are Back, Aided By the Hunter Population
description: LEAD: EARLIER this year at a convention in Seattle that elk aficionados call an elk camp, a guided hunting trip in the mountains of northern Arizona was auctioned to a Montana attorney for $52,000. It was a record price for a chance to shoot an Arizona elk, a reflection of a rising interest in elk hunting.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: 'Petrol Police' Patrol Border Of Singapore

title: Theatrical Casting Can Be High Drama
description: Shirley Rich, the acknowledged doyenne of theatrical casting directors, claims there are even people in the entertainment industry who still don't understand what she does. ''They confuse us with agents,'' says Ms. Rich, whose career spans virtually the history of casting directors, from her first job as an assistant to Rodgers & Hammerstein to the present. ''We are gaining recognition,'' she says. ''We're now listed on the title page of the program instead of the back with the theater physician or the producer's accountant.''

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: SOUTH OF THE BORDER. By John Byrne Cooke. (Bantam, $17.95.) Thanks to the screenwriter William Goldman, most of us assume that Butch Cassidy died a violent and cinematic death in Bolivia. Among historians of the old West, however, controversy rages on. Did Cassidy take a new alias and survive into the 1930's?

title: Chronicle of Priesthood Unfolds in ''Mass Appeal''
description: ''MASS APPEAL'' is one of the decade's few American plays that homogenizes the ingredients for popular and artistic success. The play was the work of a 29-year-old playwright when it was first produced in 1980, and it manages to be as thoughtful as it is entertaining.

title: PERVERSITY RAISED TO A PRINCIPLE
description: ERIC GILL A Lover's Quest for Art and God. By Fiona MacCarthy. Illustrated. 338 pp. New York: A William Abrahams Book/E.P. Dutton. $26.95.

title: Emily A. Kawata Becomes a Bride
description: At the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York, Emily Akemi Kawata, a daughter of Mary Kawata of New York and the late George Kawata, was married yesterday to Dr. Brian Phillip Kunzelmann, the son of Janice M. Kunzelmann of Macon, Ga., and John P. Kunzelmann of Longwood, Fla. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth O. Jones performed the ceremony.

title: Tax Quarrels Among States Go Back a Long Way
description: THE furor over New York State's decision to increase tax rates of wage earners from out of state has revived an issue that Alexander Hamilton had probably thought was settled with the signing of the Constitution.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Eight years ago, I had the outside of my house covered with California redwood that was finished with polyurethane varnish. This gave it a beautiful shiny color that everyone admired. After about two years, however, the front of the house started to get dull and spotty looking. I was advised to sand this and reapply polyurethane. I have done this several times, but it seems to be required about every year. The house is ready to be done again. What do you suggest?

title: FINDING 'THE ZONE'
description: I have observed the phenomenon among surgeons. There are times when these physicians describe their work as occurring far faster than anticipated: time has ''dilated,'' and movements are performed flawlessly. I suspect there are many occupations in which the techniques described in your article can be utilized to enhance performance. JEFFREY L. KAUFMAN, M.D. Albany

title: Understanding and Punishing Teen-Age Violence in Park Attack; Senseless Tragedy
description: To the Editor:

title: SPA LIFE
description: The word spa is dusted with a bit of magic.

title: Pace of Bridge-Raising Fosters Optimism
description: WITHOUT a day to waste, employees of the state's Department of Transportation, the Metro-North Commuter Railroad and Conrail, plus private consultants and contractors, are working at a relentless pace to raise the vertical clearances at bridges crossing the Hudson rail line from Westchester to Albany County by Aug. 15. And it looks as though they will make it. The high-priority, state-financed project will enable the General Motors Corporation plant in North Tarrytown to transport its new line of mini-vans by triple-stacked rail carrier in time for arrival at automobile showrooms across America this fall. Many bridges between North Tarrytown and Selkirk, N.Y., a Northeastern rail hub near Albany, are too low to permit passage by the modern rail carriers. Less Risk of Damaging Vehicles

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Berkeley; Grad Students' Strike Cancels Many Classes
description: Just two weeks before final exams begin, students at this University of California campus had to cross picket lines to attend class during a two-day strike by graduate students last week.

title: Name That Decade
description: WHAT ARE WE going to call the decade after the decade of the Nineties?''

title: Ex-Dictator Favored in Bolivia Election
description: In 1971, Gen. Hugo Banzer Suarez seized power in Bolivia and ruled for seven years, jailing thousands of opponents and exiling others.

title: A No. 2 and a No. 3 Unite to Be No. 1
description: Carl Thackery of England and Barbara Moore of New Zealand captured the men's and women's races of the 10-mile Trevira Twosome in Central Park yesterday, but they lost the overall competition.

title: ...But the Federal Government Has to Do Its Share
description: NEW JERSEY'S housing crisis - rising homelessness, declining homeownership and skyrocketing rents - can be managed, but only with a renewed commitment from the Federal Government.

title: 3 PALESTINIANS DIE AND 138 ARE HURT IN FIGHTING IN GAZA
description: At least three Palestinians were killed and more than 138 others were shot and wounded today during the most violent day of rioting in the Gaza Strip since the Palestinian uprising began 17 months ago.

title: Social Events
description: Aiding Black Charities

title: Fleisher Service Tomorrow
description: Senator Bill Bradley of New Jersey, a former player with the Knicks, will deliver the eulogy tomorrow at a memorial service for Larry Fleisher, the former head of the National Basketball Players Association. The service will be held at the Community Church of New York, 40 East 35th Street, at 11:30 A.M. Mr. Fleisher died Thursday at the age of 58.

title: THE SOLDIERS: Anger and Frustration
description: The warrens and alleyways of the Nablus casbah are desolate and still. For the fifth straight day, the 20,000 Arab residents of the ancient market are under curfew, locked in their homes night and day as punishment for the killing of an Israeli soldier a few days earlier. But as Moshiko Giat, a reserve paratrooper, and the seven other members of his patrol move through the narrow twisting corridors, pressing themselves tight against walls, pointing their automatic rifles around every corner before they turn, it's clear they feel a strong threatening presence.

title:
LONG ISLAND INTERVIEW: JACK KRUMPE;
The Business of Bringing People Together, for Work and Play
description: LEAD: JACK KRUMPE, who has two homes on Long Island, has been chairman and chief executive officer of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan since October 1986.

title: Father Divine's Legacy
description: To the Editor:

title: UGANDA'S LEGACY
description: Ryszard Kapuscinski's article, ''Uganda: After the Terror'' (March 12), is a devastating portrait of the legacy of killing, torture, looting and harassment that took place during the regimes of Milton Obote and Idi Amin.

title: Play the Blues, Man! And They're Still Doing It
description: The juke joint is nameless, a shack made of unpainted boards sitting just off a county road surrounded by cotton fields. But inside, James McElroy, guitarist with Roosevelt Barnes and the Playboys, is shouting, ''It's star time!'' A stir ripples through the crowd packed into the shack's two front rooms as Roosevelt (Booby) Barnes strides purposefully from the back, resplendently dressed in an iridescent blue jacket and tight drainpipe trousers.

title: A Little Quiz for the Comfortable
description: Jamie Mambro and Jay Williams, two advertising executives, are working to help the homeless here with a campaign to benefit the Pine Street Inn, a shelter that provides lodging, food and medical services for 1,200 men and women a day.

title: FINDING 'THE ZONE'
description: Lawrence Shainberg's article ''Finding 'The Zone' '' (April 9) interested me greatly. I believe that it explains what can happen to even your common, garden-variety walker.

title: TALKING: Home Sales; Attracting Foreign Buyers
description: FOREIGNERS in growing numbers are among the potential buyers of resale homes these days - both suburban houses and urban apartments - as the world increasingly becomes a global village.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: ANTHONY TASCIONE;
The Eviction Process in Public Housing
description: LEAD: WHEN Jack F. Kemp, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, talks about the problems that public-housing authorities are having evicting convicted criminals, Anthony Tascione knows what he means. For six years Mr. Tascione has been director of the White Plains Housing Authority, one of seven such authorities in the county - the others are in Yonkers, Mount Vernon, Port Chester, Peekskill, Greenburgh and New

title: PASTIMES: Stamps
description: As collectors become swamped with new issues, they try to categorize their interests.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Eight years ago, I had the outside of my house covered with California redwood that was finished with polyurethane varnish. This gave it a beautiful shiny color that everyone admired. After about two years, however, the front of the house started to get dull and spotty looking. I was advised to sand this and reapply polyurethane. I have done this several times, but it seems to be required about every year. The house is ready to be done again. What do you suggest?

title: Mary Bausman Is Married
description: The marriage of Mary Frederika Bausman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Bausman of Greenwich, Conn., to Peter Lawrence Watkins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Hiram W. Watkins Jr. of St. Louis, took place yesterday at St. Francis Xavier Roman Catholic Church in Brooklyn. The Rev. Vincent Corso officiated. Mrs. Watkins teaches English at St. Vincent Ferrer High School in Manhattan. The bridegroom teaches religious studies at Bishop Kearney High School in Brooklyn.

title: 'Arizona Is Lost, Next Is San Francisco'
description: The Bush bailout plan for savings institutions calls for dismantling the three-member Federal Home Loan Bank Board and placing it under the Treasury. And since passage seems almost certain, some board members are beginning to leave.

title: Bad Bets
description: To the Editor:

title: No Headline
description: In the early 1980's, state-owned British Airways P.L.C. was known for its service - infamously so. One well-worn joke was that B.A. stood for ''bloody awful.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Auto Racing Senna Gains Pole Spot: The world Formula One champion, Ayrton Senna of Brazil, gained the pole position for the Monaco Grand Prix as he blistered the Monte Carlo streets in a qualifying best in the second practice session yesterday. Senna toured the twisting, 2.068-mile circuit in 1 minute 22.308 seconds. That bettered the previous qualifying best on this current layout of 1:22.627 set by his McLaren-Honda teammate, Alain Prost of France, in 1986. Senna averaged 90.45 miles an hour. Prost came in second at 1:23.456.(AP) Tennis Edberg Is Upset: Martin Strelba of Czechoslovakia, ranked 90th in the world, defeated Stefan Edberg of Sweden, 6-3, 6-3, in the $205,000 Bavarian Open yesterday in Munich, West Germany. In the championship match today, Strelba will meet Andrei Chesnokov, who beat a Soviet countryman, Aleksandr Volkov, 6-2, 7-5, in a rain-interrupted match. Strelba's previous best performance came last year when he reached the semifinals of the Grand Prix tournament in Prague.(AP) Graf Advances in Hamburg: Top-seeded Steffi Graf of West Germany and Jana Novotna of Czechoslovakia won their semifinal matches in the $200,000 Hamburg Virginia Slims tournament yesterday in West Germany. Graf, the top-ranked woman in the world, struggled in the first set after losing a 5-1 lead but rallied to win seven games in a row and crush Bettina Fulco of Argentina, 6-4, 6-0, in 61 minutes. Novotna overcame an ankle injury, swirling winds and the the loss of the second set to beat fourth-seeded Arantxa Sanchez of Spain, 7-6 3-6, 6-1.(AP) Rowing Northeastern Upsets Harvard: Northeastern's heavyweight varsity crew upset previously unbeaten Harvard yesterday in their annual regatta on the Charles River in Boston. The Huskies turned the Crimson's favorite strategy to their favor when Coach Buzz Congram's crew broke away after clearing the Massachusetts Avenue bridge at the 1,300-meter mark. Harvard could not catch up in the final 500-meter sprint and lost by half a boat length. The times over the wind-blown 2,000-meter course were slow, 6 minutes 25.8 seconds for Northeastern, 6:29.13 for Harvard. This was the first victory for the Huskies over a Crimson varsity in a dual regatta after nine losses going back to 1968. Northeastern had lost to Harvard by one length last month at the Redwood Shores regatta in California and had also lost to Yale. In a concurrent regatta over the same course, Wisconsin's heavyeight varsity won the Cochrane Cup race by almost two lengths over Dartmouth with Massachusetts Institute of Technology third. Track and Field Meet Records Set: Five meet records were set yesterday on the first day of the Heptagonal championships at Columbia's Lawrence A. Wien Stadium. In the 10,000 meters, Greg Whiteley of Brown posted a new meet mark of 29 minutes 14.45 seconds. In the women's 10,000, Pam Crandell of Dartmouth set a new meet mark of 34:11.36. Bob Lesko of Yale set a meet record in the men's 800 meters, winning his heat in 1:49.02. Sarah Beasley, a Dartmouth senior, led off the day with a record hammer throw of 155 feet 7 inches, and Diana Wills of Army bettered the meet record of 19-6 3/4 in the long jump three times, ending up with a mark of 20 feet 1/2 inch in repeating her 1988 victory in the event. Beasley came back to win the shot put. Chris Athanasia, Yale's outstanding javelin thrower, won with a toss of 221-8, better than the 216-7 of Myles Derieg, a Princeton freshman. Olympian Powers Club: Jim Fleming, who ran on the Virgin Islands Olympic team last year in Seoul, South Korea, won two individual events and anchored the New York Pioneer Club to victories in the 400 and 800-meter relays yesterday in the New York Relays at Downing Stadium on Randalls Island. Fleming, 22 years old, reached the quarterfinals of the 200 meters in the Olympics and yesterday had a winning time of 10:37 seconds in the men's open 100 and 21.18 seconds in the 200. The Pioneers took the 400-meter relay in 42.20 seconds. Golf Mize Earns a Tie: Larry Mize made a 25-foot birdie putt on the final hole to complete a seven-under-par 63 and moved into a tie with Wayne Levi for the third-round lead in the $1 million Byron Nelson Classic yesterday in Dallas. Mize played the back side in 31. The 197 totals for Levi and Mize matched the lowest 54-hole score on the PGA Tour this year.(AP) Rain Suspends L.P.G.A.: Jody Rosenthal made six consecutive birdies to charge into the lead before play was suspended midway through the second round of the L.P.G.A.'s Crestar Classic in Chesapeake, Va. Half of the 136-player field was still on Greenbrier Country Club's 6,275-yard course when lightning, rain and an hailstorm forced suspension of play. (AP) Mowry Leads by 1: Larry Mowry shot a five-under 67 yesterday to take a one-stroke lead over Gay Brewer in the RJR at The Dominion seniors tournament in San Antonio. Mowry, who shot an opening-round 66, was at 11-under 133 after two trips around the 6,649-yard Dominion Country Club Course. Brewer, the first-round leader, shot a 69 after an opening-round 65. Harold Henning and Miller Barber were next at 136.(AP) Rugby Air Force Wins: Scoring the winning 4 points in the final minute on a penalty play, Air Force beat Army, 17-16, yesterday in a semifinal game of the intercollegiate championships at Colorado Springs. In the other semifinal, Long Beach State defeated Penn State, 18-9, as Brett Bowden, the captain, scored 14 points.

title: Harlem Group to Lead Fund-Raising Appeal
description: A Harlem-based philanthropic organization has edged out the United Way for the right to solicit contributions from 73,000 Federal employees working in New York City.

title:
FOCUS: St. Louis;
Bold Rebirths for Industrial Dinosaurs
description: LEAD: THE 158 acres of property at the intersection of Natural Bridge Avenue and Union Boulevard in north St. Louis is a ghostly reminder of the industrial past. The land, site of a General Motors plant that closed in 1987, also has great potential, especially in the mind of Mathew B. Librach, president of Clark

title: International Intrigue
description: Does the National Football League have an ulterior motive in creating that new trans-Atlantic league, which is due to start operations next spring as the International Football League?

title: Susan T. Corney Is Wed in South
description: Susan Tyler Corney, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert T. Corney of Nashville, was married yesterday to Peter Cornelius Van Allen, a son of Dr. and Mrs. James A. Van Allen of Iowa City, Iowa, and Southampton, L.I. The Rev. Eric Greenwood Jr. performed the ceremony at St. David's Episcopal Church in Nashville.

title: The Man Who Energizes the Hulk
description: AMONG his colleagues in the comic book industry, John Byrne of Fairfield is known as Mr. Fixit. His specialty is the makeover: assessing a floundering superhero and making changes to increase sales.

title: Ross Lewis - Subway Muralist
description: In the beginning there were scraggly mustaches inked onto the faces on advertising posters. Then came the age of graffiti, when no subway was safe from egos and spray cans.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing; 3 Hamlets That Make A Lasting Impression
description: This is the kind of place you leave reluctantly, looking back. There are shops with bells on the doors. Roads that wind past grazing horses. And yard sales where children set up shop in a wagon and sell homemade cookies for a quarter.

title: Blue Jays Lose to Angels as Leiter Makes Debut
description: Johnny Ray drove in the go-ahead run with a single today as the California Angels rallied for two runs in the ninth inning and beat the Toronto Blue Jays, 5-4. It was the fourth victory in a row for the Angels and their ninth in 10 games.

title: SPA LIFE: WHAT THEY'RE WEARING IN ACTION
description: GRAY SWEATS JUST DON'T CUT IT ANYMORE. THOSE who are serious about exercise - the ones with board-flat stomachs who visit spas once a year and health clubs once a day -are just as serious about dressing for action.

title: Greenwich Led State In Smog Last Summer
description: GREENWICH, which has for several years had some of the best air in the state, had the worst during the hot summer of 1988, according to a state report.

title: SPA LIFE: THE HOMEBODIE
description: My father is one of the few people I know whose stationary bicycle doesn't double as a clothes rack. But then again, he's also one of the few people I know who keeps a special notebook in which he records the number of miles he rides each day. A recent 8 A.M. phone call heralded news that in two years he'd clocked enough miles to have pedaled from Virginia to Los Angeles and back. Next to the bike is a big black rowing machine, plus sets of free-weights and a bright blue rubber mat.

title: 2 Men Arrested in Shooting of Officer
description: Two men are being held in what Police Commissioner Benjamin Ward called the ''execution type'' shooting Friday night of an undercover officer as he tried to buy several thousand vials of crack from them. A third suspect is being sought.

title: Baryshnikov Searches for The Heart of 'Swan Lake'
description: Tomorrow, when his staging of ''Swan Lake'' launches American Ballet Theater's eight-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House with a gala, Mikhail Baryshnikov will be imagining that somewhere in the audience is a budding romantic who must be placated. The 41-year-old artistic director of the company seems to have had his former, impatient self in mind when re-staging ''Swan Lake,'' having said his main goal was to direct the ballet toward such an emotional climax that few would dare leave the theater early. Mr. Baryshnikov's eyes brighten when contemplating that people might even weep.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Wells, Me.; Town Seeking An Open Beach
description: IN an effort to preserve public access to mile-long Moody Beach, the town of Wells is preparing to get two appraisals of the beachfront lots, one for buying easements for recreation and onefor buying the land outright. If the cost is too high, said Jonathan Carter, the Wells Town Manager, the town will ask the state to buy the beach through its program of buying public lands.

title: With Trumpet Fanfare, Feast Benefits the Arts
description: AMID the fanfare of trumpets, guests in formal attire with brightly plumed masks, strolling musicians and mythological creatures including a griffin and a 27-foot dragon, a Renaissance feast was recently held to benefit the John Harms Center for the Arts in Englewood.

title: ABC-TV Extends Triple Crown Pact
description: ABC Sports announced today that it had reached agreement to televise the three Triple Crown races through 1992.

title: Jazz With A Purpose, At Its Source
description: The day started with a funeral. It was no one I knew, but he was a member of the Prince of Wales Social Aid and Pleasure Club, founded 1928, which sponsors full jazz funerals for its members. While visiting New Orleans for the Jazz and Heritage Festival that ends today, I'd tuned in the Saturday morning brass band show on WWOZ. The announcer mentioned a jazz funeral at 10 A.M. and an address, and I made tracks. I'd heard New Orleans brass bands in concert and on record, but never in the streets where, nearly a century ago, they had spawned jazz.

title:
FOCUS: St. Louis;
Developers Plan Bold Rebirths for Industrial Dinosaurs
description: LEAD: The 158 acres of property that spread out from the intersection of Natural Bridge Avenue and Union Boulevard in north St. Louis are a ghostly reminder of the industrial past. The land, site of a General Motors plant that closed in 1987, also has great potential, especially in the mind of Mathew B.

title:
ART;
Ideas and Form on the Edge
description: LEAD: ADVENTUROUS art can be provocative and stimulating, and when it is selected by a knowledgeable panel, it is worthy of serious consideration. This is the premise behind ''On the Cutting Edge,'' at the Fine Arts Museum of Long Island in Hempstead.

title: Cynthia Frank Married To David Bick Edelson
description: Cynthia Ellen Frank, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Howard J. Frank of Englewood, N.J., and East Hampton, L.I., was married yesterday to David Bick Edelson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kenneth J. Edelson of Ridgewood, N.J. Rabbi Jack Bemporad officiated at the Plaza Hotel in New York.

title: Legal Constraints on Sharing Ideas
description: At one end of the conference hall a scientist stood in front of a video screen, doing what appeared to be a feeble attempt at break dancing. He waved his arms, hopped on one foot, bobbed and weaved like a boxer, poked his fingers into the air as if he were popping invisible balloons. A large crowd of his colleagues at the Computer Human Interaction 1989 conference here watched in amazement.

title: Nightclubs Find Their Differences Popular
description: ALMOST any nightclub has flashing lights, loud music, disk jockeys and plenty of dancing. Some clubs, though, have gone beyond the usual trappings, searching for the distinction that lures, the catch that catches.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Antique Houses in New Developments
description: NEW ENGLAND'S unique supply of early American architecture has generated something of a growth industry in preservation. Antique houses are being acquired in increasing numbers, dismantled clapboard by clapboard, numbered and catalogued down to the last fireplace brick, strap hinge and beaded molding, then rebuilt across town or even in another state.

title: Schools Say Inflated Grades Cut Grants
description: THE recent awarding of New York State scholarships to high school seniors by a rating system of combined S.A.T. (Scholastic Aptitude Test) scores and grade-point averages has aroused strong criticism from many Long Island school districts.

title: Cambodia Deserves Better Than Guns
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk and Prime Minister Hun Sen of Cambodia seem to be converging on a workable deal for their country when Vietnam ends its occupation in the fall. Into this welcome development comes a proposal by Representative Stephen Solarz, chairman of the House Foreign Affairs subcommittee on Asia, to send military aid to non-Communist rebels in a coalition led by the Prince but dominated by the dreaded Khmer Rouge.

title: Bush, Not Kohl, Is Undermining NATO
description: Throughout the West, hopes are running high for far-reaching negotiated cuts in nuclear and conventional arms.

title: Vermont
description: To the Editor: On snow-bright days in winter this Vermonter, transplanted to Michigan, wishes she were close enough to ''skip school'' to Smuggler's Notch.

title: New Zimbabwe Party Takes Aim at Mugabe
description: A former ally of President Robert Mugabe started an opposition political party in Harare this week, the first new party to be formed in Zimbabwe since independence in 1980.

title: A DISTANT RUMBLING IN THE TOWNSHIP
description: TO EVERY BIRTH ITS BLOOD By Mongane Serote. 206 pp. New York: Thunder's Mouth Press. Cloth, $19.95. Paper, $10.95.

title: New York in Flower
description: New York City is not usually thought of as sylvan, but that's just what it is at this time of year. A street in Greenwich Village, for instance, is canopied with white blossoms, the pear trees on both sides having met and married in its center. The pink of cherry blossoms clashes with the red of old brick houses all over town, and magnolia trees are flaunting their last candles.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Dykstra and Wilson Platoon?
description: I can't imagine the Mets without Mookie. He's the heart and soul and humor of the team, and my favorite baseball player.

title: Ins and Outs of Settling Claims After a Plane Crash
description: LITIGATING suits for surviving family members after someone dies in an airplane accident is a highly specialized area of the law. Wherever the crash and wherever the trial, the same lawyers are likely to battle over responsibility for the deaths and how much the victims might have earned had they lived.

title: Seton Hall Treated Unfairly
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Park Avenue Festival, Park Avenue South between 32d and 23rd Streets will be closed today from 8 A.M. to 7 P.M. Because of the Five Boro Bike

title: Reviews/Dance; Otrabanda And People Gone Wild
description: The first half of ''Quasi-Kinetics,'' presented by Otrabanda at La Mama Annex on Thursday night, is like an endless evening spent with one of the ruling-class bores who populate New Yorker cartoons. In the theater-dance piece, written and directed by Roger Babb, a man and a woman talk exhaustively of appearances and the way they see each other.

title: Entrepreneurial Spirit and Social Goals
description: ''ALL of us who work with her are convinced that were it not for her calling, she would surely be the head of a Fortune 500 company today,'' said Marge Lovero, director of the Entrepreneurial Center at Manhattanville College here.

title: Like the West Coast City It Is, Seattle Is Tired of Developing
description: BLESSED with a majestic natural setting, this city has always prided itself on holding onto its quality of life even at the expense of business expansion. In the last two decades, half-built freeways were stopped in mid-construction, renovation plans for the pleasantly chaotic Pike Place Market were voted down, and parks were built on covered highways and old industrial sites.

title: Correction
description: Because of a computer entry error, the paperback fiction best-seller list published on April 30 reversed the ranking of two books. ''The Drawing of the Three,'' by Stephen King (Plume/NAL), should have been No. 1. ''Tapestry,'' by Belva Plain (Dell), should have been No. 2.

title: Death Masks, Death Warrants And a Revolution
description: The timing could hardly be better. Two hundred years ago, almost to the day, on May 5, 1789, Versailles witnessed the opening session of the Estates-General, soon to become the National Assembly. That day is usually viewed as marking the starting point of the French Revolution.

title: Carol Cossum Weds
description: At the Presbyterian Church of Mount Kisco, N.Y., Carol Anne Cossum, the daughter of Mrs. Richard E. Burns of Chappaqua, N.Y., and William Edward Cossum of Ellenton, Fla., was married yesterday to Michael Maurice Maher, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice Joseph Maher of Malden, Mass. The Rev. Jack S. Miller officiated. The bride is a pension benefits analyst at Mercer Meidinger Hansen, a benefits consulting firm in New York. Mr. Maher is a director of finance in New York for American Express Retail Travel Services.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Howard; Men Are Boxing Their Hair for Fun And Attention
description: Men on the Howard University campus are boxing themselves in - in terms of hairstyles, that is. One of the newest cuts - or more accurately, shapes -to catch the fancy of black men in particular resembles a box. The sides of the head are shaved close, and the top is squared off and leveled, leaving three to four inches of hair standing at well-clipped attention.

title: Olive-y Olive Oil
description: To the Editor:

title: 'The Wages of War'
description: To the Editor:

title: SPA LIFE: SPLIT THE DIFFERENCE
description: ONE OF MY FIRST LESSONS AT THE New York Restaurant School nearly six years ago was the easiest: If you boil heavy cream, it thickens into an instant sauce. Spike it with vermouth or applejack, whisk in a little Pommery mustard or a touch of thyme, and shallots or ginger, or both, and you've got everything covered from chicken and fish to pasta and veal.

title: Joan Harney Wed To Dr. J. C. Wiles
description: The marriage of Joan Waugh Harney, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Selby Harney of Hilton Head Island, S.C., to Dr. John Christopher Wiles, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Gordon P. Wiles of East Lyme, Conn., took place yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in East Lyme. The Rev. Steven E. Hulme officiated.

title: Route 1: The Boom and the Aftermath
description: LEAD: THREE years ago, when Dianne Brake began her work as associate director of the M.S.M. Regional Council, a nonprofit planning advisory group serving Middlesex, Somerset and Mercer Counties, she interviewed the planners and administrators of 22 municipalities in the region to find out about the development occurring in their towns.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: DOUBLE VISION: My Life in Film. By Andrzej Wajda. (Holt, $19.95.) Any word from the great Polish film maker Andrzej Wajda (whose works include ''Ashes and Diamonds,'' ''Man of Marble'' and ''Danton'') is reason for celebration. ''Double Vision,'' however, is not really a memoir or - as some will anticipate from the man who filmed the birth of Solidarity (in ''Man of Iron'') - a political essay, except in the broadest sense.

title: Suffolk Weighs Plastics Delay
description: LEAD: EARTH, air, fire and water, the four ancient elements, plus oil, paper and plastic are swirling in uneasy combination in the Suffolk County Legislature, where the cosmic is often mixed with the commonplace.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Everyone's laundry is dirty these days, a little bit at least.

title: PROUDLY AMERICAN
description: SKETCHES FROM A LIFE By George F. Kennan. 365 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $22.95.

title: A DRAMA OF WAR MADE MEMORABLE BY JOHN GIELGUD
description: Herman Wouk's novelized version of World War II rumbles to an 11 1/2-hour close on ABC this week, beginning tonight at 8 with a three-hour episode. Here, surely, is a landmark in television excess. The tally so far: 18 hours of ''The Winds of War,'' which did very well in the ratings, and 18 hours of the first part of ''War and Remembrance,'' which didn't.

title: In Cornerstone's Shakespeare, Romeo Raps
description: Until recently, the people of this small town in the southwest corner of Mississippi didn't see much in common between themselves and Shakespeare. They read his plays in school and left it at that. But when the Cornerstone Theater Company showed up and started building a stage in their local movie house, Shakespeare became the talk of the town.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Santiago
description: As rivers go, the Mapocho sets no standards for either beauty or might, but at this time of year a walk along its south bank as the river flows past Parque Forestal in the center of Santiago has the feel of a walk by the Seine in autumn. This is not an accident. The park, with its immense old trees, dusty footpaths and gaslights, was designed by Georges Dubois, a French landscaper, in 1901. Several other Santiago landmarks of that era were also of French design.

title: On Fusion, the Chemists Have the Ball Now
description: IT is not often that the public gets to follow a scientific controversy blow by blow as if it were a football game.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Markups for Electricity; New York Landlords Buy Wholesale and Sell Retail
description: AS New York City struggles to remain a competitive alternative for small businesses and manufacturers, one of the vexing problems is that commercial landlords are allowed to buy electricity at regulated wholesale rates, then charge tenants any price they want for that power.

title: Bilingual Counselor Wins National Honor
description: LEAD: A BILINGUAL guidance counselor at Roosevelt High School in Yonkers, Orquidea Organes Sanso, is modest about her newest title - 1989 Reader's Digest American Hero in Education. ''It's my first time in the spotlight,'' she said. ''I was a little taken aback.''

title: Reviews/Music; Mozarteans On Period Instruments
description: One of the nice things about hearing period-instrument concerts these days is that the instruments themselves are generally well played and less of an issue than they used to be. This is by way of saying that when the Mozartean Players came to the Metropolitan Museum on Friday night, Mozart, Beethoven and Haydn were more on our minds than what they were being played on.

title: Youth Strives Against Disability
description: LEAD: FOR all of his almost 19 years of age, Robert Miller has waged a constant battle against a congenital kidney obstruction. He has weathered the traumas of a life-threatening disability with indomitable spirit, even when doctors offered little hope that he would make it.

title: Lawyers Pondering Pro Bono Legal Aid
description: LEAD: A Bellmore mother of two in her mid-30's was being physically abused by her husband and was looking for a legal way out.

title: Correction
description: A picture last Sunday with an article about the United Nations' special representative for Namibia was captioned erroneously by The Associated Press and published in error as a result. It showed Lieut. Gen. D. Prem Chand, commander of the United Nations military force in Namibia, not Martti Ahtisaari, the special representative.

title: A Continent's Referendum on Democracy
description: BEGINNING this month and continuing through the next year, voters in more than a dozen Latin American countries will be going to the polls to render judgment on a decade of hardship. Though the 1980's have been marked by the disappearance of military dictatorship and the emergence of democratic civilian rule in one country after another, that shift, like the coming cycle of presidential elections, has occurred against a backdrop of a continentwide economic crisis that has left the people disenchanted and newly implanted institutions vulnerable.

title: POSTINGS: Brooklyn Renovation; Time to Shine
description: When the Williamsburgh Savings Bank opened its 29-story headquarters at One Hanson Place in 1929 it became the focal point of downtown Brooklyn and, at 512 feet, the tallest building on Long Island, from the East River to Montauk. The four-faced clock tower was the world's tallest and even larger than London's Big Ben. But in recent years, despite landmark status, the building fell into neglect.

title: A Pioneer In Boat Design
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Garden City Scrutinizes Plans for a Plum
description: LEAD: IN terms of location and size, an 18.5-acre site on Franklin Avenue in Garden City, occupied for 79 years by Doubleday & Company, has few equals among Nassau County properties due for development.

title:
Maplewood and South Orange Journal;
Plan to Ease School Overcrowding Arouses Dispute
description: LEAD: AT the South Mountain Elementary School in South Orange, the kindergarten building intended to house one class has been subdivided by a wall to provide a second classroom. In the same school district, the Seth Boyden School in Maplewood must use its art room for several purposes.

title: Rent-Control Battle Looms in Albany
description: NEW YORK STATE'S rent regulation law will expire on June 15, and what landlords call a wall against new housing and fair profit and tenant groups depict as a last defense against price gouging and eviction will once again be the focus of legislative battle.

title: INSIDE
description: Elections on Generals: Panama and Bolivia Vote

title: LODGE CHALLENGES REBUFF OF BLACKS
description: This small rural community is challenging longstanding voting rules of the Benevolent and Protective Order of the Elks on the ground that it promotes racial discrimination.

title: Satyajit Ray Gives Ibsen A Bengali Spin
description: Satyajit Ray, Sidelined for more than half a decade by heart disease, is about to return to the cinema world with his 26th feature film - and first screen adaptation of a play, Henrik Ibsen's ''Enemy of the People.''

title: Votes in Congress; Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York
description: Senate

title: Lilco's Incompetence, Shoreham's Cost
description: The letter from Herbert Jaffe [ ''Power Panaceas Are a Delusion,'' March 26 ] supporting Shoreham is the usual cry from a speculator trying to rescue an unwise investment.

title: Ladies' Mile District Wins Landmark Status
description: Ladies' Mile - an area of turn-of-the-century architecture between West 15th and West 24th Streets, near Broadway - was designated a historic district on Tuesday by the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission, after years of campaigning by such community groups as the Drive to Protect the Ladies' Mile District and the Historic Districts Council.

title: THE CALL OF HTE WIND AND THE KOOKABURRA
description: THE ROAD FROM COORAIN By Jill Ker Conway. 238 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Hoffman Estate: $2,000
description: Abbie Hoffman gave away hundreds of thousands of dollars but left an estate worth only about $2,000, says his attorney, Gerald Lefcourt. ''It's not that he didn't take in a lot of money - it's just that he didn't keep it,'' Mr. Lefcourt said Thursday. Mr. Hoffman, 52 years old, killed himself April 12 in his apartment near New Hope, Pa.

title: Subtidal Land Leases Seen as Step Backwards
description: On the essay March 19 that proposed leasing subtidal lands (''Tapping Income Buried in Public Land''), I offer the following comments to present a balanced view of this issue.

title:
MUSIC;
Secrets of Success For Roberta Peters
description: LEAD: THE image of the temperamental operatic prima donna does not fit the soprano Roberta Peters, whose gracious manner and level-headed approach to her career contrast sharply with the explosive manner of other artists of her caliber.

title: Paying a Price
description: ''Being good in business is the most fascinating kind of art,'' Andy Warhol once said. That Mr. Warhol's pop art is both good business and fascinating was demonstrated last week when his portrait, ''Shot Red Marilyn,'' a 1964 depiction of Marilyn Monroe, was auctioned at Christie's in New York. The price, $4.07 million, was the highest ever paid at auction for a painting by the artist, who died in 1987. The previous record for the artist was $3.9 million for a painting called ''Marilyn Monroe (Twenty Times).'' The price of last week's Marilyn, a 40-inch-square work with a red background, was double what had been expected. Said Leo Castelli, the dealer who first exhibited the painting in 1964, ''That's a good price.''

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: May 7, 1989
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 4 THE DRAWING OF THE THREE, by Stephen King. (Plume/NAL, $12.95.) Continuing the horror story begun in ''The Gunslinger.'' 2 5 TAPESTRY, by Belva Plain. (Dell, $4.95.) The changing fortunes of a New York banking family between the two world wars. 3 * 14 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Dell, $4.95.) A woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family. 4 2 LIGHTNING, by Dean R. Koontz. (Berkley, $4.95.) ''Far Side'' cartoons. 3 41 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/Harper & Row, $8.95.) These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Changing a View
description: Liberals were wary and conservatives were elated when C. Everett Koop, an opponent of abortion, became the Surgeon General of the United States in 1981. Last week, some liberals probably moaned and some conservatives no doubt sighed with relief when he announced that he would resign in July. The 72-year-old pediatrician led attacks against smoking and the AIDS epidemic. His stands at times were surprising, like his statement that there was no conclusive evidence that abortions harmed women. Dr. Koop gave no reason for resigning, but friends said he was angered that President Bush had not asked him to stay beyond the end of his current term in November. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, called him ''a voice of honesty, integrity, compassion and plain good sense.''

title: A CONFESSOR AT THE FUNERAL
description: THE DISTANT LOVER By Christoph Hein. Translated by Krishna Winston. 179 pp. New York: Pantheon Books. $16.95.

title: BRITISH SOCCER: THE DEADLY GAME
description: WE WERE IN THE ARSENAL STADIUM IN North London. Arsenal was playing Manchester United, and losing, 1-0. A few yards away from us, the Manchester fans were howling for victory. Pete, seated behind me, was not pleased.

title: Interfaith Chapter Marks its 30th Year
description: LEAD: MARGARET GILMORE, executive director of the Greater New York region's National Conference of Christians and Jews and a founder 30 years ago of the organization's Westchester chapter, recalled a conference she once organized.

title: ENGLAND SWUNG
description: LEAD: BAD GIRLS, GOOD WOMEN By Rosie Thomas. 664 pp. New York: Bantam Books. $18.95.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu; A Meaty, Mustardy Flank Steak With Vegetables
description: A quick and easy Sunday meal is flank steak glazed with maple mustard, accompanied by potatoes with broccoli and onions. And putting the grocery store to work as a sous-chef takes much drudgery out of preparing this, or any other, meal.

title: DATA UPDATE: May 7, 1989
description: *4*BUILDING PERMITS ISSUED (Housing units) Mar. 89 Feb. 89 Mar. 88 New York 4,243 2,065 4,716 New Jersey 2,554 1,905 5,703 Connecticut 816 584 2,070 *3*(Source: Census Bureau, U.S. Department of Commerce) *3*MORTGAGE INTEREST RATES (Averages) Last Week Previous Week Year Ago New York Conventional (30-yr) 11.36 11.34 10.55 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 9.48 9.52 7.68 New Jersey Conventional (30-yr) 11.11 11.11 10.39 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 9.23 9.23 7.57 Connecticut Conventional (30-yr) 11.25 11.30 10.51 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 9.68 9.76 7.80 Co-ops (N.Y.) title: Information, Please: Phone Companies vs. Newspapers
description: AFTER several failed experiments earlier in the decade, the newspaper industry all but abandoned its quest to develop electronic systems that would allow subscribers to read the news on a home video screen. Now newspapers and other vendors of information are being upstaged by the telephone companies, which are seeking to stake their claim in the emerging field of electronic publishing.

title: Charles Holmes Weds Margaret Hicks
description: Margaret Elizabeth Hicks and Charles Broadfoot Holmes were married last evening at St. James Episcopal Church in Wilmington, N.C. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Robert Cook and the Rt. Rev. Thomas Henry Wright, who retired as the Episcopal Bishop of the Eastern Diocese of North Carolina and is the bride's great-uncle.

title: Plan to Freeze Suffolk Wages Hides the Truth
description: THE proposal recently defeated by the Suffolk County Legislature to freeze the wages of county employees deserves further examination: not because it was right, but because its motivation is so dangerously wrong.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Virginia; Steeplechasing As Cocktail Party Despite the Mud
description: In spring a young person's fancy turns to steeplechasing. So popular is the sport now that not even heavy rains could stop thousands of students at the University of Virginia, and many alumni, from traveling five miles last week to attend the Foxfield Races, the main spring event here, both as spectators and, in one case, as a jockey.

title: Medieval Sorcery, Modern Fest
description: ''FLING any stuffed cats lately?'' - Flemish villagers may well accost each other, in the Belgian city of Ieper.

title: Peter J. Mongeau And Kelley Smith To Wed in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roy C. Smith 4th of Upper Montclair, N.J., and Chatham, Mass., have made known the engagement of their daughter Kelley MacGregor Smith to Peter John Mongeau, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Maurice G. Mongeau of Attleboro, Mass. An August wedding is planned.

title: Former Air Force Specialist Arrested on Spying Charges
description: A former Russian-language specialist for the Air Force has been arrested here on espionage charges, accused of trying to give American military secrets to the Soviet Union.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Punk Voice

title: Kathryn Deane Wed in Bermuda To R. T. Krantz
description: St. Mark's Anglican Church in Smith's Parish, Bermuda, was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Kathryn Morgan Deane, a daughter of Marjorie S. Deane and Disque D. Deane of New York, Greenwich, Conn., and Tuckerstown, Bermuda, to Richard T. Krantz, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Krantz of New York and Boca Raton, Fla. The Rev. Michael Hinton performed the ceremony.

title: Ms. de Marneffe Becomes Bride Of M. P. Trimble
description: Colette de Marneffe, a daughter of Mrs. Anthony Ferranti of Arlington, Mass., and Dr. Francis de Marneffe of Cambridge, Mass., and Dublin, N.H., was married yesterday to Martin Paul Trimble, a son of the Rev. and Mrs. James A. Trimble of Philadelphia. The bridegroom's father, assisted by the Rev. John E. Midwood, performed the ceremony at St. John's Memorial Chapel of the Episcopal Divinity School in Cambridge.
