title: A Leader Going Out In Style
description: For his farewell appearance this afternoon as artistic director of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, Charles Wadsworth had a range of choices. He could have stepped out of character and taken a solo piano turn with something valedictory such as Beethoven's ''Lebewohl'' Sonata. Many in the Alice Tully Hall audience for this final concert of the society's 20th season will be in the mood for something at least that sentimental. But the irrepressible Mr. Wadsworth, who helped found the organization and performed in its first concert on Sept. 11, 1969, will exit more appropriately, as a chamber musician in Poulenc's Sextet for Piano and Winds, a jaunty piece that might have served as a shuffle-off number for Maurice Chevalier.

title: Miss Hughes Wed in Jersey
description: Noreen Elizabeth Hughes, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Hughes of Oceanside, L.I., was married yesterday at the Blawenburg (N.J.) Reformed Church to Robert Roelofs Verbrugge, the son of Helen R. Verbrugge of St. Paul and the late Dr. Frank Verbrugge. The Rev. Frank Piazza officiated. Mrs. Verbrugge is a marketing director at Advanced Care Products, a manufacturer of health-care products in Raritan, N.J., and her husband is a district manager at the American Telephone and Telegraph Company in Bridgewater, N.J.

title: City Gardens: Retreats Complete With Weeds
description: Fifteen stories above Fifth Avenue, Earl Reiback has planted more than 500 petunias, impatiens, pansies and other flowering plants that will transform his terrace into a garden worthy of a country estate.

title: Miss Curran Wed To J. C. DeHaven
description: At St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Chapel in Oyster Bay, L.I., Lecia Raleigh Curran, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henry M. Curran of Oyster Bay, was married yesterday to James Carroll DeHaven, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William F. DeHaven of Stockton, N.J. The Rev. Daniel Gallagher, a cousin of the bride, and Msgr. John J. Bracken, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE FEMALE FEAR. By Margaret T. Gordon and Stephanie Riger. (Free Press, $19.95.) In ''The Female Fear,'' Margaret T. Gordon and Stephanie Riger attempt to portray rape not merely as crime statistics but as the cause of a debilitating fear afflicting most American women. The authors surveyed nearly 5,000 women and men in Chicago, Philadelphia and San

title: Donna Zaccaro Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. John A. Zaccaro of Forest Hills, Queens, have made known the engagement of their daughter Donna Anne Zaccaro to Paul Arthur Ullman, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Ullman of St. Louis. The couple plan to marry in October.

title: Drought Water Rules Threaten Tree That Grows in Brooklyn
description: To the Editor:

title: Steinbrenner's Delusions
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: NEW YORKERS, Etc.
description: A funny thing has been happening to that most ubiquitous of New York accessories. It's become non-status-y, which does not mean un-status-y.

title: An Alliance Against an Old Threat In Cambodia
description: GIVEN that the country in question is Cambodia, where the forms of tragedy seem too numerous for such a small setting and the cast of characters outsized, the very idea of diplomatic progress toward a settlement seems a challenge to the darker gods.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Glen Burnie, Md.;
Airport Area Taking Wing
description: LEAD: AS land values rise and the state works to complete several major transportation projects, the character of commercial development around the Baltimore-Washington International Airport is changing from warehouses and light industry to office buildings and hotels.

title: For Charles Schwab, a Time to Tinker
description: Time weighs heavily at Charles Schwab & Company, the nation's largest discount broker. Transactions are down and so are profits. The days of pre-crash trading volume have become a distant memory, and employees have been encouraged to take three-month ''sabbaticals'' at one-quarter pay or to work part time to cut costs.

title: In Southwest France, Rich Rural Peace
description: REASONS for going on holiday are as various as types of human temperament. Some people go to have the kind of good time they find elusive amid the restrictions and responsibilities of home. Others, like pilgrims of the Middle Ages, visit the sacred places; nowadays, less often the sacred places of religion than of art or politics. The Marxist believer needs to genuflect in Moscow or Havana, the lover of traditional jazz wants to feel that he has trodden the sidewalks of Basin Street. Others travel in search of things they used to love at home, but which seem to have become extinct there.

title: Raising a Bar
description: Perry J. Watkins made it no secret that he was gay when he was drafted in 1967, but the Army said he could be discharged only after homosexual activity was proved. By 1984, Mr. Watkins was a sergeant with an exemplary record, a career soldier like his father. But the Army discharged him under a rule change which said that avowed homosexuality barred military service.

title: A 25th Reunion Revives the Ambivalence of High School
description: NEXT Saturday, I'll be driving out to Long Island to take part in the 25th reunion of my graduating class from high school. The event is one to which I am looking forward with mixed feelings - much like the mixed feelings with which I approached high school itself so many years ago.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Dykstra and Wilson Platoon?
description: I guess if your taste runs toward muscle-bound bull terriers and huge chaws of tobacco, you may prefer Dykstra. Personally, I prefer the bighearted, soft-spoken Mookie, motoring down the basepaths. JESSICA REGELSON Brooklyn

title: Children's Illustrations, From 1880 to 1940
description: IN his art of around 1908, Matisse was inspired, he said, by his children's crude attempts at drawing. What his children probably liked was the kind of images now being shown by the Museum of Cartoon Art in Rye Brook under the title, ''Childhood Enchantments.''

title: Delivering Cheer and Concern To a Family's Door for 38 Years
description: I AM not sure whether I've just been lucky with my mailmen or if all letter carriers are the interested, caring people both of mine have been. I do know that the two men who have delivered my mail over the 38 years I've lived in the same house have indeed been special deliverers.

title: THE BOY IN THE PHOTOGRAPH
description: Donald Fine's article brought back memories of my own meeting with the great Babe Ruth. Every year my dad, a few pounds lighter than the Babe, would take me to the exhibition game between the Yankees and the Albany, N.Y., Senators, of the old Eastern League.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: 200 YEARS OF QUILTS Among the events scheduled to celebrate Fairfield's 350th birthday is a joint exhibition at the historical society and the public library called ''Sunbursts, Baby Blocks and Crazy Quilts: Two Centuries of the Quiltmaking Art in Fairfield.''

title: Schools' Problem of Racial Disparity Also Reflected In Teaching Staffs
description: THE issue of race came up last week in Lynette Grande's third-grade class. ''We were talking about it,'' Mrs. Grande said, ''and I asked the kids whether they thought of me as their teacher or as their black teacher. They thought about it.''

title: The Minimum-Wage Fight Isn't Really About Pay
description: IN a Congressional session thus far devoid of serious policy-making, it is probably fitting that the first showdown between Democrats and President Bush comes over the largely symbolic question of how much to raise the minimum wage.

title:
GARDENING;
Plans and Notes Can Smooth the Way
description: LEAD: EXPERIENCED gardeners probably fall into one of two categories when it comes to planning: Those who keep meticulous notes and sketches and those who play it by ear year after year.

title: Sander Simon, Publisher, 84
description: Sander Simon, a former construction and manufacturing executive who also published books on sports figures, died Friday at his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 84 years old.

title: FINDING 'THE ZONE'
description: What Lawrence Shainberg is talking about in his article is a realization of the Tao, an attainment of oneness, the arrival at the simple truth. The phenomenon is not just experienced by world-class athletes, nor is it reached only from within the arena of sports.

title: Park Bandshell
description: To the Editor:

title: Champions Turn Out For a Cause
description: The champions turned out the other night. Florence Griffith Joyner, the Olympic gold medalist, and Jim Burt of the New York Giants were among those honored at the 17th annual Dinner of Champions of the National Multiple Sclerosis Foundation, which raised more than $2 million at the Marriott.

title: A Disabled Man Fights For the Right to Strive
description: Kevin G. McGuire has been a paraplegic since he was 7 years old, when a drunken driver veered onto the baseball field where he was playing. But he has always held fast to his hopes and dreams.

title: 'I Had Never Heard Such Silence'
description: ''Before I came here . . . I thought swimming was me and my friends taking turns running through the open fire hydrant,'' says Jonathan, 9 years old, the guest of a Fresh Air Fund host family in Massachusetts. Jonathan was one of nearly 10,000 inner-city youngsters between the ages of 5 and 12 who spent a free vacation in the country last year. Since 1877, more than 1.6 million poor children from New York City have shared Jonathan's experience. The program opens its annual fund drive today.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Dykstra and Wilson Platoon?
description: They should play Lenny Dykstra in center and Mookie Wilson in right. They are both better players than Darryl Strawberry. Look what happened to Lou Gehrig: He was sitting on the bench, Wally Pipp got sick, Lou went in and Pipp never played first base again for the Yankees. If a man can hit and field, he must play and not sit on the bench. LEO SMITH The Bronx

title: Enclosing an Interior Doorway
description: ENCLOSING an interior doorway by sheathing it with wallboard is an easy remodeling project. It is also a good way to gain experience for more extensive wall remodeling.

title: Canton's Other Game
description: On Aug. 2, it will be 10 years since Thurman Munson, the Yankee catcher, was killed while practicing landings and takeoffs at the Canton-Akron Airport in Canton, Ohio, where he lived.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Watertown, Mass.;
Nuns' Condos Selling Briskly
description: LEAD: A CONDOMINIUM project developed by the Dominican Sisters of St. Catharine is proving a success in an otherwise lackluster condominium market. The order, which is based in Springfield, Ky., developed the 59-unit project, Siena Village, to finance the nuns' continued residence on the site of a former Catholic girls' school in

title: Frank (Bud) Kelley, Pilot, 74
description: Frank (Bud) Kelley, one of the first Americans to fly a jet airplane, died Wednesday after suffering a stroke. He was 74 years old. As a test pilot for the Bell Aircraft Corporation, Mr. Kelley flew an early jet, the XP-59, on Nov. 16, 1942, over Muroc Dry Lake in the Mojave Desert, said Donald S. Lopez, deputy director of the National Air and Space Museum. He is survived by his wife, June; two sons, two daughters and six grandchildren.

title: About Cars; A Marathon for Methanol Use
description: Chris Blyseth is sitting next to me, trying to accommodate his 6-foot-6-inch frame to the Chevy Corsica's average American bucket seat. In back, Jose Musso is talking about the car and what he, Chris and seven other members of their team have done to it.

title: Jacqueline Carr Weds
description: At the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York, Jacqueline Marie Carr, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Ronald E. Carr of New York, was married yesterday to Richard B. Lonoff, a son of Violet Lonoff of Toms River, N.J., and Harold Lonoff of Maplewood, N.J. The Rev. Dr. F. Forrester Church officiated. The bride, who will retain her name, is a portfolio manager at the New York investment firm of Reich & Tang.

title: Earl (Red) Blaik, 92, Army's Top Football Coach
description: Earl (Red) Blaik, one of college football's foremost coaches, died yesterday at a nursing home in Colorado Springs, two days after breaking a hip in a fall. He was 92 years old.

title: Stephenie Miller Wed in Delaware
description: Christ Church Christiana Hundred in Greenville, Del., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Stephenie Florence Miller, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Miller of Woodstown, N.J., to James Graham Reinhard, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John J. Reinhard of Greenville. The Rev. Adam M. Lewis performed the Episcopal ceremony. The bride, a graduate of the University of Delaware, is a credit analyst at Equibank Delaware in Wilmington. Her father is the president of the First Home Savings Bank in Penns Grove, N.J. Mr. Reinhard, the president of Treescapes, a landscaping company in Wilmington, attended the Kent School and Roanoke College. His father, a thoracic surgeon, retired as director of the department of surgery at the Medical Center of Delaware.

title: Principal's Jury Told to Continue
description: The judge in the trial of Matthew Barnwell, a Bronx elementary-school principal charged with buying two vials of crack, has ordered the jury to continue its deliberations today, despite a note from jurors indicating a deadlock.

title: Nelson's Warriors Blend Unpredictability and Ability
description: The fascinating aspect of the Golden State Warriors' success this season is that they have dared to be different.

title: When Crimes Become Symbols
description: ON April 19, a 28-year-old woman was discovered in a Manhattan park, brutally raped and beaten into a coma. On April 29, a 19-year-old woman was found dead, strangled and probably raped, in another Manhattan park. The two women, both of whom moved to New York City to advance their careers, were nine years apart in age; the incidents were separated by only 10 days and 100 blocks.

title:
DINING OUT;
Japanese Charm and Space in Pearl River
description: LEAD: ONE has to hand it to a restaurant that surrenders space, which might have held quite a few additional tables and chairs, to decor that has no function other than pleasing the esthetic sense of patrons.

title: Panama Vote Sharpens Polarization
description: Abel Melendez hates politics.

title: At Least 10 Are Killed in Lebanese Fighting
description: Syrian and Christian gunners plunged into heavy artillery duels across Beirut and in nearby hills today, ending a nine-day-old truce. The police said 10 people were killed and 33 wounded.

title: Fruit Growers Pull Commercials To Protest Report by CBS on Alar
description: The Washington State Fruit Commission, a trade association of growers, has withdrawn $71,300 worth of television advertising for Northwest cherries from three CBS affiliates to protest a recent news report about Alar.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Eight years ago, I had the outside of my house covered with California redwood that was finished with polyurethane varnish. This gave it a beautiful shiny color that everyone admired. After about two years, however, the front of the house started to get dull and spotty looking. I was advised to sand this and reapply polyurethane. I have done this several times, but it seems to be required about every year. The house is ready to be done again. What do you suggest?

title: Steaming Into Yorkshire's Past
description: THE piercing, high-pitched whistles. The elegant, high-stepping locomotives, the clouds of steam, the delicate carriages with compartments opening directly to the outside, ''The Lady Vanishes,'' ''The Thirty-Nine Steps,'' all those other Hitchcock movies - the British have been carrying on a love affair with railroads practically since they invented them, more than 150 years ago.

title: Nightclubs Now: Lasers and Late Nights
description: THE ladies' drink of the night is no longer Seven and Seven. It's Sex on the Beach. The lindy, stroll, frug, jerk, twist and hustle have given way to no-name dancing. ''Call it freestyle,'' shouts one dancer as he flails his arms and bends his knees.

title: Women Playwrights: Themes and Variations
description: Women are finally emerging as forces to contend with in the theater, says the playwright Tina Howe. They can write as feminists, says Ntozake Shange, and they can try to present a uniquely female perception of the world - a world in which their reality has often been illegitimate, or silent. They can, says Cindy Lou Johnson, try to understand in some way what goes on between men and women. They can engage in their own personal, esthetic quests, says Ms. Howe. But whatever they write, says Wendy Wasserstein, the more women who create plays, the more voices and life experiences that are heard, the better the world, and the theater, will be.

title: Miss Supplee Has Wedding
description: Pamela Miller Supplee and Robert Hugh Jiranek Jr. were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Redeemer in Bryn Mawr, Pa., by the Rev. Mark Andrus. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Henderson Supplee 3d of Bryn Mawr. Mr. Jiranek is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jiranek of Danville, Va.

title: Drawing; graph of pretax income of all New York Stock Exchange members firms doing business with the public, 1986-1989* (*Projection) (Source: Lipper Analytical Services) (pg. 1); photos of Felix Rohatyn; Stephen Robert (pg. 8); chart of some top brokergae firms, their current employment, peak number of employees, and likely changes they are to make (pg. 8); graph of employees of all firms doing business on The New York Stock Exchange, 1981-1989* (*Projection) (Source: Lipper Analysis Services) (pg. 8); Why Wall Street's So Topsy-Turvy
description: These days the word from Wall Street is hardly cheery. The profitability drought has produced almost daily reports of layoffs, not to mention word that businesses are being cut back or even eliminated.

title: Bank Builds New High-Rise
description: THE 1968 HemisFair tower is still the tallest structure in San Antonio, but 10 blocks away workers are putting the finishing touches on an office high-rise that will be the city's tallest commercial building.

title: Sculptures Re-Create the World of Myth
description: LEAD: IF it had not rained that Halloween night five years ago, melting down the ferocious head of his 16-foot papier-mache dragon, T. Oliver Kopian never would have created what he calls ''rubber plush.''

title: Understanding and Punishing Teen-Age Violence in Park Attack; Labels Distract
description: To the Editor:

title: A Run-Aground Barge Spills Gasoline Into Hudson River
description: A barge carrying more than 2 million gallons of unleaded gasoline up the Hudson River ran aground in heavy weather early yesterday and spilled an estimated 77,700 gallons into the river, the Coast Guard said.

title: DATA BANK: MAY 7, 1989
Chang on Rise but He's Still Not in Agassi's Act
description: There were times last year when Michael Chang was reduced to a footnote in the Andre Agassi story. Agassi had flair - a punk rock hairdo and equally colorful personality -plus a game that vaulted him to six tournament titles and No. 3 in the world. Chang preferred a brush cut and an impassive expression on the court, masking his emotions. His rise was steady, one rung at a time.

title: Star-Crossed Lovers in 'Delancey'
description: YEARS ago, there were matchmakers who arranged for young men and women to meet the perfect marriage partner. Today, as singles bars and pages of personal ads attest, it seems even more difficult to meet that special someone.

title: Soviet Rider Has Tour Lead
description: Vyacheslav Ekimov of the Soviet Union overcame punishing hills and treacherous terrain to win the first stage of the inaugural Tour de Trump bicycle race this afternoon.

title: PHILIP MORRIS'S BIG BITE
description: Your article on Philip Morris offered (between the lines) some good management advice: 1. Don't be arrogant. 2. Don't underestimate the competition. 3. Don't be stale in marketing. 4. Don't be wasteful. 5. Study, then act swiftly. ROBERT B. ALEN Los Angeles

title: CAMPUS LIFE: SUNY at ALBANY; Everybody Into the Water, Even at 50  [ degrees ]
description: One might not think a 50-degree temperature and a thick cloud cover is swimming weather, especially for students who are supposed to be in class. But at the State University here, thousands of students defied murky skies to brave murkier waters on Wednesday, celebrating a spring ritual known as Fountain Day.

title: Deborah Doyle and Dennis Allen Are Married
description: Deborah Sherman Doyle, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Xavier Doyle of East Brunswick, N.J., was married in Baltimore yesterday to Dennis Michael Allen, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. John Allen of Franklin, Ohio. Deacon Michael Silvas performed the ceremony at the Roman Catholic Shrine of the Sacred Heart.

title: FASHION: On the Street; Suits Are the Order For Lunch in the Park
description: Eating in Central Park is usually an opportunity for dressing down. After all, who needs to get fancy for a picnic on the Sheep Meadow? But the luncheon held last Wednesday at the Rumsey Playfield in the park was a special occasion, the annual Frederick Law Olmsted Awards, and those who attended did some serious suiting up. Pastel colors, fitted jackets, narrow skirts and important pieces of jewelry were the order of the day, as were large buttons and flowers, which appeared both in pots and on hats. The lunch was held by the Women's Committee of the Central Park Conservancy. The proceeds will be donated to the North End Discovery Center, a visitors' and education center to be built on the Harlem Meer, and to the park's security program.

title: Reviews/Dance; People's Cruel Games, In 'Blueberry Hill'
description: Precocious youngsters from places other than New York City once dreamed of growing up to lean on marble mantelpieces and utter witty repartee just like characters in the movies. Now they dream of coming to New York to be performance artists - to judge by ''Blueberry Hill,'' a performance piece presented by Byron Suber on Thursday night to a wildly cheering audience at the Club at La Mama.

title: Pratfalls and Nitwits, Leopards and Hawks
description: Stand back - the superlatives are going to intersect here, the result of the long-overdue video releases of two classic screwball comedies by Howard Hawks, 20TH CENTURY (1934, RCA/Columbia Pictures Home Video, $69.95) and BRINGING UP BABY (1938, Turner Home Video, $19.98).

title: Park Bandshell
description: To the Editor:

title: Making Voting Easier
description: Trying to reverse the decline in voter turnout, Congress is advancing a bill that would allow people to register by mail and other means. Page 33.

title: Q and A
description: Visiting Cebu

title: On Atlantis, Smooth Sailing and Photos of Lightning
description: The astronauts of the space shuttle Atlantis photographed lightning in storms over Africa and conducted metal-processing experiments today as they orbited Earth on a mission scheduled to end Monday afternoon.

title: How to Tap the 'Zest Factor'
description: I the predawn hours of Feb. 18, 1987, a fire of unknown origin destroyed much of the complex equipment at New York Telephone's Bushwick Central Office. More than 40,000 customers - including hospitals and police - were out of service. Ordinarily, damages this extensive would take six months or more to repair. But a determined team of company employees, with help from American Telephone and Telegraph, Bellcore and Northern Telecom, set the astounding goal of restoring service in three weeks. On March 5, a week before the deadline, full service was restored.

title: U.S. and Britain Move To Tighten Air Security
description: Immigration officials from the United States and Britain are considering tightening security by conducting immigration checks before passengers board airplanes, American officials say.

title: NASTY REIVIEWS: EASY TO GIVE , HARD TO TAKE
description: Some years ago, when ''Books Do Furnish a Room'' - the 10th novel in Anthony Powell's 12-volume sequence ''A Dance to the Music of Time'' - was published, an American reviewer, Marvin Mudrick, addressed himself in no uncertain terms to the limitations of the novel and of the sequence. ''Powell's method of getting on with the story must be the most ponderously inefficient of all time,'' Mudrick sweepingly began, noting that when a character is introduced, Powell's narrator spends three or four pages speculating on the probable nature of this figure, who, it may be, ''is blond, has small ears, and wears a black overcoat.'' Later in the novel, when ''the overcoat turns up,'' our narrator seizes on new bits of evidence which, at further length, confirm or change his expectations of the character.

title: THE SPY FORM SOUTH BEND
description: TERRITORY OF LIES The Exclusive Story of Jonathan Jay Pollard: The American Who Spied on His Country for Israel and How He Was Betrayed. By Wolf Blitzer. Illustrated. 336 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $22.50.

title: NEW JERSEY Q & A: DR. JOSE LOPEZ-ISA Helping Argentina on Education
description: ON this picturesque college campus - once the site of a golf course - educational advances have been made over the years at Bergen Community College, and many educators take pride in that feeling.

title: In White Plains Schools, Chess At 9 and 10 Is the Right Move
description: THE chase was on. The king moved across the top of the board, with the queen a few squares behind. The rook readied for a checkmate. And 15 pairs of eyes followed in hot pursuit. ''What's the right move?'' the teacher called out. ''Don't let the king escape.''

title: PASTIMES: Camera
description: Along with the latest examples of film technology, new cameras keep coming across my transom. Most are me-too models of the point-and-shoot variety, of interest only because they fill a marketing niche in their makers' product lines. But a few are curious enough to make me load them up instantly and head out the door.

title: TESTING IDEAS ON HIS PLUSE
description: SELECTED PROSE By Louis Simpson. 516 pp. New York: Paragon House. $24.95.

title: C. R. Cachera Wed To Laura Farrand
description: At St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York, Laura G. S. Farrand, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John E. Farrand of Watch Hill, R.I., was married yesterday to Charles Rene Cachera by the Rev. John Andrew.

title: A Harlem Church Welcomes A Bishop on Her First Visit
description: When Josephine Green started singing in the choir of Saint Philip's Episcopal Church in Harlem 51 years ago, the notion of a woman holding high office in the diocese, or even leading a congregation in prayer, was unthinkable. ''We thought God - a man; our father - a man,'' she said. ''Anything with authority was male, even in the household.''

title: U.S. SAYS SOLDIER CRIPPLED SPY POST SET UP IN BERLIN
description: Investigators have concluded that James W. Hall 3d, an Army warrant officer court-martialed earlier this year for espionage, severely damaged several electronic eavesdropping operations aimed at Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, Government officials say.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: STRANGER IN SAVANNAH. By Eugenia Price. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The ''stranger in Savannah'' is Mark Browning, a native of Philadelphia who was captivated by the sultry city in the early 1800's and remained there to become one of its leading citizens. But in 1854, when Eugenia Price's latest novel opens, his loyalties are with the Union, putting him at odds with most of the people around him, including his wife, who feel that secession is the only way of maintaining the South's independent way of life.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on April 16 with a review of ''Child of Paradise: Marcel Carne and the Golden Age of French Cinema'' misidentified the actress shown. She was Maria Casares, not Arletty.

title: Prospects; The Flaw in the FSX Deal
description: The Bush Administration announced on April 28 that it had concluded an agreement with Japan for the co-development of a new jet fighter called the FSX. The deal would transfer American airframe and electronic technology to Japan and transfer Japanese composite material technology back to the United States. Forty percent of the new plane, which is based on the F-16, would be built by the General Dynamics Corporation. Critics argue that the deal does not provide enough benefit to the United States. Four experts give their views on the FSX. Mel Levine Member, House of Representatives Subcommittee on International Economic Policy and Trade and co-chairman of the House Export Task Force.

title: Miss Raso Weds Herman Raspe
description: Adele Marguerite Raso and Herman Henri Raspe, both lawyers in New York, were married yesterday at the Most Blessed Sacrament Roman Catholic Church in Franklin Lakes, N.J., by the Rev. John C. Wagner.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN THE CREDIT DEPARTMENT;
CREATING A 'PORTFOLIO' WITHTHE AID OF COMPUTERS
description: LEAD: Credit managers are no longer judged, as they once were, simply by the average number of days it takes their company to be paid by customers. ''That number indicates when companies are paying, not the probability of payment,'' said John S. Sargent, president of Credit and Management Systems Inc., which sells credit-management software.

title: Israel: Mired in the West Bank
description: In the 16 months of the Arab uprising in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, thousands of Israeli soldiers have dodged stones and Molotov cocktails, many of them thrown by children.

title: Boeing-South Africa Deal Draws Criticism
description: Boeing confirmed today that it would sell up to $512 million worth of 747 jumbo jets to South Africa in a deal that drew strong criticism from members of the state's Congressional delegation.

title: A Romantic Style Gets Back to Its Roots
description: The Gothic revival style in 19th-century European furnishings was spurred in the late 1820's by the spread of nationalism and religious revivalism. What resulted was chairs, chests, clocks and tablewares embellished with Gothic spires, trefoils, crosses and knights in shining armor, images spiced by fantasy and enriched by glitter or the jewellike colors of medieval stained-glass windows.

title: Leon Kirchner, Pianist, To Be Honored by Y
description: The 92d Street Y will end its season this week with a program in honor of the pianist Leon Kirchner's 70th birthday. The concert will be given twice, on Tuesday and Wednesday at 8 P.M., and will include Mozart's Wind Serenade in E flat, Schoenberg's Chamber Symphony and Mr. Kirchner's Piano Trio.

title: Elizabeth Sands And L. T. Petty To Marry in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Keating Sands of Oyster Bay, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter Elizabeth Douglass Sands to Lawrence Talmage Petty, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Robert Petty of Chevy Chase, Md. The couple plan to marry in October.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN THE CREDIT DEPARTMENT;
 WILL THE D.&B.; DEBACLE HELP TRW IN THE TRADE CREDIT RING?
description: LEAD: Thirteen years ago, TRW, the queen of consumer credit services, challenged the empire that Dun & Bradstreet had ruled since 1851. But dethroning the monarch of commercial credit proved difficult. ''We got our brains kicked in when we tried to compete head on,'' said John N. Taussig, vice president of TRW's business credit division.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Nanuet
description: ALTHOUGH Nanuet comprises only 5.3 square miles, it is Rockland County's hub. The county's major highways - Routes 59 and 304, the Garden State Parkway extension, the Gov. Thomas E. Dewey Thruway and Palisades Interstate Parkway - transit it. It is also the site of the Nanuet Mall, the county's largest shopping center, with 120 stores anchored by Sears and Macy's.

title: Lawrence Gresser, 80, Retired Queens Judge
description: Lawrence T. Gresser, a retired judge of the Queens Criminal Court, died of heart disease on Monday at the John F. Kennedy Medical Center in Atlantis, Fla. He was 80 years old and lived in retirement in Lake Worth, Fla., and on Shelter Island, L.I.

title: Bodies of 2 Boys Are Found Floating in Bay
description: The bodies of two young boys were found floating in Sheepshead Bay last night and were believed to be those of playmates missing since Friday from their Brooklyn home, the police reported.

title: On the Loose In Bright Mykonos
description: IN the darkness before dawn, the port of Piraeus, Greece, near Athens, is already rumbling to life. Sleepyheaded backpackers are coughed from the bellies of large cargo and passenger ferries, as others wait in line to load. These ocean-going ferries carry supply trucks, the lifeline to outlying islands, as well as tourists and Greek families on vacation.

title: Poll Watching Becomes A Growth Industry
description: THE proliferation of elections in Latin America and other places where democracy has a tenuous hold has led to a boom in business for election observers who check whether the process is free and fair.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
ELEGANT, MAJESTIC AND WEARY
description: LEAD: Brian Lanker presents 75 portraits in black and white of black women who have made estimable contributions to the United States in I DREAM A WORLD: Portraits of Black Women Who Changed America (Stewart, Tabori & Chang, Cloth, $35; Paper, $19.95). This exquisite volume of photographs and interviews is an arresting testament to women's diversity.

title: POSTINGS: Home Away From Home; Suite Hotels for Long Island
description: Seeking to capture a new line of hotel business, a Long Island development company will build in Suffolk and Nassau Counties in the next several years four all-suite hotels designed for guests who want to spend more than just a night or two. Gary Krupnick, president of the Westwood Companies of Hauppauge, L.I., said construction would start this summer on the first, a 141-unit hotel at Aero Drive and Johnson Avenue, in Islip. The $14 million project is adjacent to MacArthur Airport. The remaining sites have yet to be chosen.

title: On Some Ball Clubs, Pitchers Are Not the Weakest Hitters
description: The designated-hitter rule states specifically that a hitter may be used to bat for the pitcher, but why discriminate against other poor hitters?

title: The Age of Aquarius, 2 Decades Later
description: IT doesn't matter that ''Hair,'' which first opened off Broadway in 1967, is dated. It was dated in 1972, when the Broadway production was still running.

title: Not A Monarchy
description: Defenders of Oliver North reacted to the jury verdict by arguing that the three charges on which he was convicted were ''trivial.'' The whole prosecution was a waste of money, Senator Orrin Hatch and others said.

title: Maggy Sterner, TV Producer, Marries
description: Maggy Sterner and Robert L. Drogin were married last evening at Bargemusic, a floating chamber-music hall at the Fulton Ferry Landing in Brooklyn. Rabbi Emily Faust Korzenik officiated.

title: THEY WATCH WHAT WE WATCH
description: ON MAY 15, NBC WILL BROADCAST ONE OF THE POTENTIALLY most controversial programs it has ever made: ''Roe vs.

title: Retirees Losing Purchasing Power
description: David R. Kotok's recent article, ''Inflation's Threat to Pensions'' (Opinion page), does not address the problem of an insufficient cost-of-living allowance in the New Jersey pension system.

title: Winning Photos
description: ''Eyewitness: The 32d Annual World Press Photo Contest Award-Winning Photographs'' can be seen at the Nikon House Gallery in Rockefeller Center through May 20. The 100 photographs were judged the best of the entries from 1,295 photographers, publications and press agencies of 62 participating countries. Hours are 9:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M. Tuesdays through Saturdays. Admission is free. Information: 586-3907.

title: Two-House Legislatures Began in Greece
description: To the Editor:

title: J. D. Orris Fiance Of Andrea Bass
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gene Bass of Jericho, L.I., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Andrea Faith Bass and Joel David Orris, a son of Ruth Schwartz of Springfield, N.J., and the late John L. Orris.

title: Television in the Beginning
description: American television last week celebrated its 50th birthday. The first scheduled telecast took place April 30, 1939, and featured an all-time superstar. It showed Franklin Delano Roosevelt speaking at the just-opened New York World's Fair.

title: For the No-Frills Bride, Wedding Suits
description: For brides-to-be who do not want to wear a traditional wedding gown because they do not want to look frilly and demure, there is another option: the bridal suit. It is also the outfit of choice for many women who are marrying for the second time or in an intimate ceremony.

title: For Young Poets, a Chance to Meet Kindred Souls
description: The young poet nervously recited his work, then spent several long moments in what must have seemed like purgatory until the critic finally spoke.

title: THE LONELINESS OF THE FAMILY MAN
description: ABSENT FRIENDS By Frederick Busch. 278 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Cast Rises to Challenge With 'All My Sons'
description: THE sounds of sniffles emanating from the George Street Playhouse these matinees and evenings are those of an audience in the grip of a great, affecting play.

title: Weakened Flyers In Serious Trouble
description: The Flyers, who like to cause trouble, are in it.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Brunch; A Bistro's Organic Touch
description: This is a listing of Manhattan restaurants reviewed by Bryan Miller in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Bernard Organic French Cuisine

title: Both Races Mourn A Foe of Apartheid Slain at His House
description: Several thousand black and white mourners converged here today for the funeral of David Webster, a university professor prominent in the anti-apartheid movement who was shot and killed on Monday.

title: N.Y. Airport Curfew Is Proposed Again
description: CONNECTICUT opponents of the Westchester County Airport last week praised a proposal by two Westchester legislators to ban noisy flights at night.

title: Overactive Machinery
description: FROM TIME TO TIME, NOT INTENDING TO, I imagine myself in charge of my own body. It's a faintly unpleasant sensation: sitting there in the cockpit, worrying whether everything is operational. The scariest part, easily, is the stomach.

title: Rebecca C. Matthias - Entrepreneur
description: Becoming pregnant at the height of the dress-for-success look in 1982 nearly squelched Rebecca C. Matthias's budding career. Helping to start a computer company in Boston, Ms. Matthias, then 28 years old, searched in vain for appropriate attire for her calls on local bankers.

title: Monuments of Medieval Strife
description: TOURING the fortified towns, called bastides, in southwestern France, gives travelers a glimpse of medieval life and a chance to explore some of the earliest examples of urban planning, in a lovely rural setting.

title: Understanding and Punishing Teen-Age Violence in Park Attack; Unrecorded Incidents
description: To the Editor:

title: Vantage Point
description: To the Editor:

title:
PASTIMES: Gardening;
A Broccoli That Is Big in Taste as Well as Size
description: LEAD: For years I've treasured the ability of a single planting of broccoli to keep producing heads and florets from June until late fall. But I didn't think the flavor of this near-perfect garden crop could improve - until Romanesco came along.

title: As Drought Proceeds, Views Diverge
description: NEW YORK CITY and Westchester County may share the sources of their drinking water, but the same cannot be said for their approaches to its use, especially during a drought.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Dykstra and Wilson Platoon?
description: A great ball team is like an ensemble company: the best players in there every day, at the same position, learning to play together as a unit. Players do best when they are happy with their jobs and feel that management has a total commitment to them, even when they're in a slump. The platoon system may seem expedient on paper, but it does not work in the hearts of dedicated players or fans. While Wilson is a fine talent, I'd make Dykstra the every day center fielder. DIANE COFFIELD Great Neck, L.I.

title: NONFICTION
description: LEGEND: The Only Inside Story About Mayor Richard J. Daley. By Frank Sullivan. (Bonus Books, $17.95.) King Richard the tyrant, the arrogant ruler of Chicago, the enemy of the masses - or so the national image of Richard J. Daley was often cast. Why then, it might have been asked, did so many people vote for him? In ''Legend,'' a highly readable, insider account of the man some described as ''America's most powerful and controversial urban official,'' Daley's press secretary Frank Sullivan explains how the former Mayor of Chicago understood the people and how they understood him. ''He talked to real people, not intellectuals or moralists,'' Mr. Sullivan writes. ''He cut through the distancing layers of political rhetoric which separate most elected officials from their constituents. Daley was the essence of all the people who live on the side streets of any great city and he spoke to these people directly.'' A populist, a loyalist and an autocrat - a politician who never entered a television studio - Daley ran the city in a manner that will likely never be repeated by his successors, including his son Richard M. Daley, who was elected last month. Mr. Sullivan paints a favorable but not cheerleading portrait of the last of the big-city bosses. The Mayor's admirers and detractors alike can find plenty of ammunition in this book to justify their claims. Mr. Sullivan defends Daley, who died in 1976, against charges that he was a racist or an anti-Semite, but notes that the Mayor had no blacks and only one Jew in his inner circle of advisers. But there is little question about how Daley felt toward reporters. Mr. Sullivan, a former reporter for The Chicago Sun-Times who says he had not always voted for Daley - until he came on the payroll - recalls the enmity the boss held for journalists. ''There is nothing more immoral than a newspaper man,'' Daley once said to Mr. Sullivan. ''You ought to know, Frank, you were one of them.''

title: In Jewelry, Choices Sacred and Profane, Ancient and New Age
description: Religious symbols, icons and amulets are moving from the fringes to the mainstream of fashion jewelry. From Christian Lacroix's stylized crosses to the new-age crystals of Tina Chow to the talismans created by craft jewelers, there are choices for many tastes and budgets.

title: K.G.B. Is Seeking a Friendlier, More Upbeat Image
description: The K.G.B., the Soviet security force once synonymous with state terror, has become the latest convert to glasnost, promising the public that it plans ''an expansion of democracy'' in its operations.

title: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: The Accused 1988. Paramount Home Video. 1 hour, 50 minutes. $89.95. Laser disk (Image Entertainment), $34.95. Closed captioned. R. Jodie Foster won an Oscar as the victim of a boozy gang rape in the back room of a bar. Kelly McGillis is Katheryn Murphy, the assistant district attorney who, after letting the rapists plea bargain their way to lesser charges, prosecutes three of the witnesses on grounds that they actively encouraged the assault. Jonathan Kaplan's film ''is consistently engrossing melodrama, modest in its aims and as effective for the cliches it avoids as for the clear eye through which it sees its working-class American lives.'' (Vincent Canby) The Lair of the White Worm 1988. Vestron Video. 1:23. $89.98. LD (Image), $39.95. R. Suggestions of snakiness are everywhere in Ken Russell's tongue-in-cheek horror tale, loosely based on the Bram Stoker novel, of a huge legendary white serpent and present-day snakepersons who are very much caught up with the idea. ''Slither in,'' says one, himself secretly a reptile. With ''at least as much potential to give offense as some of the director's more frenzied efforts, [ the film ] also has a welcome element of droll humor.'' (Janet Maslin) Full Moon in Blue Water 1988. Media Home Entertainment. 1:26. $89.95. LD (Image), $39.95. R. A number of talented actors try to get in touch with their characters' feelings in this comedy-drama set in Texas. Floyd (Gene Hackman) wrestles with the mysterious disappearance of his wife; Louise (Terri Garr) loves Floyd despite his preoccupation with his missing spouse; the General (Burgess Meredith) is the local eccentric that every film about life in a Southern town feels it must have. ''The most interesting character is Floyd's missing wife, who, though mourned, is never explained.'' (Canby) Madame Sousatzka 1988. MCA Home Video. 2:01. $89.95. LD (Image), $39.98. PG-13. Shirley MacLaine plays a ''magnificent relic'' of a piano teacher shepherding a hand-picked group of prodigies in this film by John Schlesinger. ''Festooned with fringed shawls and clanking beads, spraying herself furiously with perfume when she becomes flustered, and made up garishly as the very essence of faded glory, Miss MacLaine rivets the attention at every turn.'' (Maslin) The Iron Triangle 1988. International Video Entertainment. 1:24. $89.95. LD (Image), $39.95. R. The Viet Cong are freedom fighters and Haing S. Ngor, who won an Oscar for his role in ''The Killing Fields,'' is a fair-minded North Vietnamese officer in Eric Weston's film about the other guys' side of the war. As a U.S. Army captain who is taken prisoner, Beau Bridges gives a solid performance, but though the film ''means to inform as well as entertain, its main problem is that it is clumsily written and directed.'' (Canby) Mr. and Mrs. Smith 1941. Turner Home Entertainment. 1:25. $19.98. LD (Image), $39.95. Alfred Hitchcock had his own way with comedy, too, even this mountain of nonsense about a marital contretemps starring Carole Lombard and Robert Montgomery. ''When Mr. and Mrs. Smith try to recapture an ardent courtship in a half-forgotten spaghetti tavern,'' wrote one reviewer in 1941, ''the director sets a most sinister cat on the table to stare at the soup.''

title: Riding Appalachia's Rapids
description: SOME come for the thrills. Paddling madly, they raft the Gauley River's Pillow Rock rapid, dropping 25 feet in 20 yards, and shoot through Lost Paddle - a half mile of the highest-rated rapids run by commercial outfitters anywhere - and plunge 14 feet into Devil's Hole at Pure Screaming Hell.

title: Unknown Londoners and a Well-Known Russian (Peter Schaaf); (Eastfoto) (Richter)
description: Last season Ian Hobson gave a three-concert series at Merkin Hall, attended by small but fascinated audiences. He called it the ''London Piano School,'' and it was a retrospective of composers - some of them so minor that not even experts knew their names - who were active in London from about the 1760's to the 1870's. Mr. Hobson learned the music as a labor of love, and a large part of the three concerts has now been put on CD (Arabesque Z6594/5/6) and cassette (ABQC 6954/5/6).

title: Susan Starr Walker Plans to Marry Andre R. Wyss, a Ph.D. Candidate
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Dodsley Walker of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Starr Walker, to Andre Robert Wyss, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert P. Wyss of Manhattan Beach, Calif. A July wedding is planned. Miss Walker, a research assistant at the Lamont-Doherty Geological Observatory of Columbia University, is a graduate of the Chapin School and the University of Colorado at Boulder. She received a master's degree in geography from Hunter College. Her father, the organist emeritus and choirmaster emeritus of the Church of the Heavenly Rest in Manhattan, is the founder and conductor of the Canterbury Choral Society. Her mother, Janet Hayes Walker, is the founder and the producing director of the York Theater Company in New York.

title: WHEN BASEBALL WAS A GAME
description: SUMMER OF '49 By David Halberstam. Illustrated. 304 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $21.95.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Queens High-Rises; A 'Luxury' Building Comes to Rego Park
description: IT has taken 30 years to do it, but Jerrold A. Lieberman and Peter Brock have come along to develop a long ignored residential site in the Rego Park section of Queens.

title: Living Up to a Name Promising Much
description: MICHAEL ANTHONY JOSEPH TOSCANO must be a confident man. Imagine naming your restaurant Creative Cuisine. That's right, Michael Anthony's Creative Cuisine. It's in East Moriches, and with that monicker is a tempting target for any critic inclined to take a cheap shot.

title: Up to 20,000 Strikers Take Over Polish Mines
description: Up to 20,000 miners were occupying four Polish copper mines today because they feared that the Communist Government might not give them the pay increases that it had promised in talks with the Solidarity trade union.

title:
GARDENING;
Plans and Notes Can Smooth the Way
description: LEAD: EXPERIENCED gardeners probably fall into one of two categories when it comes to planning: Those who keep meticulous notes and sketches and those who play it by ear year after year.

title: Sunday Silence Takes Derby in Upset
description: Sunday Silence scored a two-and-a-half-length upset victory over Easy Goer in the 115th Kentucky Derby today at Churchill Downs, but the only thing that seemed right about the race was that the two best colts beat the others.

title: Italy's Communists Try Not to Be Ideologues
description: HAVING broken with Moscow as far back as the early 1970's, Italy's Communist leaders are savoring the fact that their criticism of Stalinism and their calls for democracy have been echoed by Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ''When we used to say these things, we were considered heretics,'' the party's new leader, Achille Occhetto, recalled.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: BANANA DIPLOMACY: The Making of American Policy in Nicaragua, 1981-1987, by Roy Gutman. (Touch-stone/Simon & Schuster, $9.95.) Step by step, a Newsday correspondent traces the decisions that led to the United States' entanglement with the Sandinistas and the contras. Last year our reviewer, Linda Robinson, said the book is ''superb journalism, asking the right questions and making crucial distinctions - rare qualities in this polarized debate.'' CHILDREN OF THE ARBAT, by Anatoly Rybakov. Translated by Harold Shukman. (Dell, $4.95.) DuringJU the early years of Stalin's reign, a group of young friends in Moscow's bohemian quarter learns the limits of free expression. When it was published in 1987, after two decades of suppression, this semi-autobiographical novel was called the most anti-Stalinist work ever to appear in the Soviet Union. Last year our reviewer, Irving Howe, said although the writer stays well within the officially countenanced confines of dissent, for some ''this novel will come as a revelation. In its depiction of the years of terror, it is candid and strong.'' AMERICAN HIGH: The Years of Confidence, 1945-1960, by William L. O'Neill. (Free Press/Macmillan, $9.95.) A historian looks back on the Eisenhower era and decides that it wasn't really so boring after all. In 1987 The Times's Walter Goodman said the author ''gets a little Panglossian'' at moments but the book ''should set readers of a certain age to musing fondly over what it was about the postwar decade that made it the best years of so many American lives.'' THE GREENLANDERS, by Jane Smiley. (Ivy, $4.95.) For 500 years, the Norse emigrants who followed Eric the Red to Greenland built a life of prosperity, then slowly they began to disappear. ''Like a minutely detailed tapestry, 'The Greenlanders' chronicles hundreds of episodes and tributary episodes,'' our reviewer, Howard Norman, said when this historical novel was published last year. ''Given the vast template of History, it is impressive how Ms. Smiley is able to telescope certain incidents, unravel personalities in a few paragraphs, delve into a kind of folkloric metaphysics - she is a diverse and masterly writer.'' O COME YE BACK TO IRELAND: Our First Year in County Clare, by Niall Williams and Christine Breen. (Soho Press, $8.95.) This true story about two Irish exiles who flee Manhattan for a cottage in their native land is ''a delightful romance about what some guardians of the national reputation have called 'the Ireland that matters,' '' John P. Harrington said here in 1988. MY FIRST LOVES, by Ivan Klima. Translated by Ewald Osers. (Norton, $7.95.) In a series of four tales of love and politics, a Czechoslovak writer tells about growing up in a land under siege by Nazism, Communism and other obsessions. Last year our reviewer, Jack Sullivan, noted that none of Ivan Klima's work is published in his own country. ''This seems a peculiarly defensive kind of repression, even for a totalitarian state, for 'My First Loves' is a deeply personal book, more given over to restless fantasies about sex, death, and coming of age than to political commentary. . . . These stories carry the burning authority and desperate eloquence of a survivor.'' THE GROUNDING OF MODERN FEMINISM, by Nancy F. Cott. (Yale University, $10.95.) A historian shows that from the beginning, the feminist movement has been split between the conflicting needs of more radical career women and comparatively conservative members of the working class. The book is ''detailed, well-written, scrupulously documented,'' Nina Baym said in The Book Review last year. BINO, by A. W. Gray. (Onyx/New American Library, $3.95.) When his client is murdered, a Texas lawyer finds himself pursued by drug dealers and politicians. ''Mr. Gray writes with a pen dipped in hemlock,'' Newgate Callendar said here last year. ''Repulsive fat cats, unscrupulous politicians and shameless hypocrites are taken for a lovely ride. So is the F.B.I.'' STEINBECK: A Life in Letters, edited by Elaine Steinbeck and Robert Wallsten. (Penguin, $14.95.) This collection of John Steinbeck's letters is ''surely his most interesting, plausibly his most memorable, and in the oddest ways arguably his best book,'' our reviewer, Saul Maloff, said in 1975. WHISTLEJACKET, by John Hawkes. (Collier/Macmillan, $7.95.) A young fashion photographer documents the decay of a rich family with some strange ideas about horses. Last year our reviewer, Patrick McGrath, called the novel ''a brilliantly sustained reflection on surface and depth, illusion and exposure, and the construction of meaning.'' FAMILY MEMORIES: An Autobiographical Journey, by Rebecca West. Edited by Faith Evans. (Penguin, $7.95.) When these recollections about the writer Rebecca West's relatives were published last year, our reviewer, Humphrey Carpenter, said they struck him as ''little short of a miracle. It is almost entirely about grandparents, aunts and uncles, and it is one of the most absorbing memoirs I have ever read.'' THE CONGRESSMAN'S DAUGHTER, by Craig Nova. (Seymour Lawrence/Delta, $8.95.) Pregnant and unwed, teen-age Alexandra Pearson returns home and finds herself trapped into marriage by the terms of her father's will. In 1986 our reviewer, Sven Birkerts, said Craig Nova brings the story ''to a flashing finish, balancing off the requisites of plot with the resolution of his deeper concerns.''

title: A Cheerful Cafe in South Norwalk
description: OPENING a new restaurant is an act of faith, and in the last few years there have been a number of such acts along Washington Street in South Norwalk. The latest is Cafe Parfait, an informal storefront restaurant lodged a few doors from the corner of South Main Street.

title:
GARDENING;
Plans and Notes Can Smooth the Way
description: LEAD: EXPERIENCED gardeners probably fall into one of two categories when it comes to planning: Those who keep meticulous notes and sketches and those who play it by ear year after year.

title: Second Thoughts on Memorial for McAuliffe
description: Three years ago it would have been unthinkable for Marion Copenhaver, a state legislator here, to do what she did last month: urge a cutoff of state money for the Christa McAuliffe planetarium, a monument to the Concord teacher who died in the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger.

title: Historic House To Be a Home Again
description: LEAD: LITTLE more than 100 years ago, St. John's Episcopal Church of South Salem spent $6,000 to expand a small house at the corner of Elmwood Road and Route 123 into a 22-room boys' academy. There, according to Lewisboro historical records, orphans were guaranteed shelter under its tiled, mansard roof.

title: Town Is at Odds Over Water Tower
description: LEAD: A 60-year-old water tower that is no longer used and reportedly has no historical significance has been the cause of modern-day feuding in the Town of East Hampton.

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: ''I didn't submit a game for a brilliancy prize because the International Chess Federation judge was one of my opponents in the tournament and he had been irritating me,'' said Grandmaster Walter Browne of Berkeley, Calif.

title: Extra Agents Reduced in Border Crackdown
description: A sharp drop in the number of Central Americans trying to enter the United States has prompted the Border Patrol to scale back extra forces detailed to the South Texas border, immigration officials say.

title: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months.

title: Proposal For Stores Is Opposed
description: LEAD: TWO years ago, residents of the small seaside community of Atlantic Beach thought they had won a battle to save a dozen private beach clubs from being developed for oceanfront condominiums.

title: South Africa Guerrillas Resist Political Shifts
description: The African National Congress is standing firm, some would say intransigent, at a time when the political ground has begun shifting around Africa's oldest national liberation movement.

title: CONSUMER RATES
OUTSIDE WASHINGTON, SCANDAL IS DEFINED AS ISSUES IGNORED
description: The talk started with Jim Wright, the beleaguered Speaker of the House of Representatives, and moved on to governmental ethics in general, but it came out pretty soon that people hereabouts do not consider any of that to be the main thing wrong in Washington.

title: Preserving a Natural Heritage, Here and There
description: A SEVEN-FOOT-TALL wigwam, stands at the center of the new permanent exhibit that will open this afternoon at the Connecticut State Museum of Natural History in Storrs. The exhibit is the latest development at a museum which, at seven years old, is growing and thriving despite lacking its own building.

title: 85% of Drivers on Interstates Are Speeders
description: THE average speed on Interstate Highways in Connecticut has risen in recent months, with at least 85 percent of drivers ignoring the 55-mile-per-hour limit, according to the State Transportation Department.

title: Waiting for Motherhood
description: THE flashing red lights of the school bus demanded that I stop. As the children manuevered down that last large step, they absent-mindedly went their separate directions home. The afternoon was sunny and warm. The lights turned off and the line of cars proceeded.

title: Affordable Housing: State Has Ideas...
description: WHAT do schoolteachers, police officers, sales clerks, secretaries, nurses, carpenters and accountants in New Jersey have in common? They all have a difficult time finding affordable housing. The problem is not new to the state. What is new is that New Jersey's lack of affordable housing now threatens the quality of life for many more of its residents. In fact, every one - rich or poor, young or old - will feel its impact because of its long-term effect on the state's economy.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-23

title: Testing Time for Canada's Political Opposition
description: John N. Turner's decision to step down as leader of Canada's Liberal Party has given the political opposition a window for renewal that may not open again for several years.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: GIRL IN A TURBAN. By Marta Morazzoni. Translated by Patrick Creagh. (Knopf, $16.95.) The opening story in Marta Morazzoni's first collection is an oblique account of the death of Mozart. The maestro has come to an elegant and peaceful villa to compose his Requiem in solitude. But instead of translating the chaos of everyday sound into ordered and transcendent music, he is confused and distracted by the stillness of the villa and its verdant gardens.

title: Understanding and Punishing Teen-Age Violence in Park Attack; As You Sow
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Temptation' Eases Through The Back Door
description: It's not often that a distributor downplays its own release of a major film, but next month MCA Home Video, in what amounts to a secret operation, will issue Martin Scorsese's explosively controversial ''Last Temptation of Christ'' without so much as an announcement, let alone advertising and promotion.

title:
WHAT'S NEW IN THE CREDIT DEPARTMENT;
AS THE RISKS RISE, A RUSH TO INSURE ACCOUNTS RECEIVABLE
description: LEAD: The wide availability of commercial credit information in America makes many European executives quiver. For years, American companies have freely handed over information about their customers' payment histories to Dun & Bradstreet, which compiles the data into credit reports for sale. But no comparable credit service exists in

title: 14 Newspapers Called Top Small Publications
description: A committee of the American Society of Newspaper Editors has selected 14 small newspapers for recognition as the best in the United States.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Coram $123,000 998 Skyline Drive 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 10-year-old ranch-style condominium; dining room, eat-in kitchen, swimming pool, golf course; monthly common charges $140, taxes $2,200. Hicksville $160,000 60 Bruce Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 31-year-old ranch; dining room, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,400. Patchogue $107,500 41 Miller Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 53-year-old Cape Cod; dining room, eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $1,400. Roslyn $342,000 52 Wildwood Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 40-year-old colonial; dining room, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $4,000. Southold $150,000 250 Rambler Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; finished basement, deck, private beach rights, 1-car garage; taxes $1,200. Westbury $250,000 879 Baldwin Drive 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 32-year-old split level; finished basement, den, 2-car garage; taxes $6,800. OTHER AREAS Washington, Conn. $358,500 196 Baldwin Hill Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath Cape Cod; hardwood floors, 1.3 acres; taxes $2,104. Mount Pleasant, N.Y. $285,000 25 Jackson Road 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 32-year-old ranch; fireplace, eat-in kitchen, family room, wood-burning stove, deck; taxes $4,500. Manalapan, N.J. $218,000 22 Devon Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 7-year-old colonial; 2-car garage, patio; taxes $2,757.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: IT was warm, almost hot. The daffodils were spent, and the magnolias were making pink puddles beneath their limbs. On the hillside surrounding Pluckemin the tulip trees were in flower, the oaks in tassel, and the hillsides! The hillsides were so green with new growth you'd hesitate before saying they weren't yellow.

title: More Memories Of Sugar Ray
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
INVESTING;
Buyer's Market for Insured Municipals
description: LEAD: Insured municipal bonds have become unusually cheap in comparison to uninsured bonds, thanks to a pricing war among the insurers. Struggling to hold market share, companies that insure municipal bonds against default have been slashing premiums.

title: Miss Middleton Engaged to Wed F. G. Oswald 3d
description: Mr. and Mrs. Henry Bentivoglio Middleton of New York and Greve, Italy, have announced the engagement of their daughter Laurinda Payson Middleton to Frank Graf Oswald 3d, a son of Mr. Oswald of Port Washington, L.I., and Audrey Clinton Oswald of New York and Newport, R.I. An October wedding is planned.

title: Donna Donahue Weds J. F. Devaney
description: Donna Marie Donahue, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel J. Donahue of Glen Rock, N.J., was married yesterday to Joseph F. Devaney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Dominic Devaney of East Northport, L.I. The Rev. Luke McCann performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Mount Carmel Roman Catholic Church in Ridgewood, N.J.

title: Tibetans Fear Loss of a Safe Haven in Nepal
description: Tibetan exiles in Nepal, fearful that their country of refuge will grow more dependent on China because of an Indian economic blockade, say they are worried about their future in this land, where they are prohibited from taking part in anti-Chinese activities.

title: They Needed Yaz
description: It's always a thrill when the old box scores come alive, and Red Sox fans responded with old-fashioned cheers yesterday when Bernie Carbo got two hits for the Red Sox Old-Timers in a game against the Equitable All-Stars at Fenway Park. There were also cheers for such rival old-timers as Bobby Richardson and Curt Flood, who got three hits apiece, and Bill Mazeroski and Joe Torre, who each got two, but the bigggest ovation of the day was reserved for an old-timer who didn't play.

title: Peter E. Baccile Weds Katie King, Interior Designer
description: Katherine Masury King, a daughter of Mary S. King and Henry L. King, both of New York, was married yesterday to Peter Eugene Baccile, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas J. Baccile of Fayetteville, N.Y. The ceremony was performed at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola in New York by the Rev. John Garvey.

title: EDWARD ABBEY: STANDING TOUGH IN THE DESERT
description: Edward Abbey, who died in March at the age of 62, seemed, at his best, the nonpareil ''nature writer'' of recent decades. It was a term he came to detest, a term used to pigeonhole and marginalize some of the more intriguing American writers who are dealing with matters central to us - yet it can be a ticket to oblivion in the bookstores. Joyce Carol Oates, for instance, in a slapdash though interesting essay called ''Against Nature,'' speaks of nature writers' ''painfully limited set of responses . . . REVERENCE, AWE, PIETY, MYSTICAL ONENESS.'' She must never have read Edward Abbey; yet it was characteristic of him that for an hour or two, he might have agreed.

title: Queens Man Charged in String of Robberies
description: A 30-year-old Queens man suspected in 29 robberies at knifepoint, mostly of senior citizens, was arrested and charged with eight of the robberies last night.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Miami of Florida; Women's Hair Is Scrunching Up For Cool's Sake
description: What's up in women's hairstyles at the University of Miami is, well, hair - in stiff, spirited ponytails that look like palm trees sprouting atop the head. The stiffeners of choice include scrunchers, crunchers and plain old wool.

title: Few Answers on Defection
description: Aleksandr Mogilny, the Soviet hockey player who defected in Stockholm earlier this week to join the Buffalo Sabres of the National Hockey League, spent his first full day in the United States in seclusion today as club officials discussed his future with American immigration officials and the N.H.L. president, John Ziegler.

title: Lower East Side: Directors Love It To a Fault
description: The Pat Hearn Gallery once occupied the northwest corner of Sixth Street and Avenue B in Alphabet City. One of the slickest galleries of the now defunct East Village heyday, Hearn's prompted marvel when in the mid-1980's it moved even farther east to an even slicker location on Ninth Street between Avenues C and D. What could possibly be over there? Absolutely nothing. Shells of buildings and some funky car repair depots fueled by cannibalized parts pilfered off stolen and abandoned autos. The only way to get to Hearn's gallery was in a limo; even cab drivers balked.

title: In the Northeast, States Face Budget Squeezes
description: Taxes and fees are going up $1 billion in New York State. New Hampshire has frozen state hiring. Elizabeth, N.J., has laid off about 225 city workers. Here in Boston, officials expect hundreds of layoffs of teachers and municipal employees.

title: Williams Upsets Xu in Platform At World Cup
description: A hectic week for Wendy Lian Williams, a United States Olympic bronze medalist, ended with an upset victory over the Olympic gold medalist, Xu Yanmei, in the women's platform event today at the World Diving Cup.

title: Susan Bunnell, Executive, Wed
description: Susan Ward Bunnell, a daughter of LeRoy H. Bunnell Jr. of Red Bank, N.J., and the late Barbara Grove Bunnell, was married yesterday to Arthur Harold Tildesley Jr., a son of the Rev. and Mrs. Arthur H. Tildesley of Fair Haven, N.J. The Rev. George J. Willis Jr. and the bridegroom's father officiated at St. George's-by-the-River Episcopal Church in Rumson.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
Motherhood Isn't the Same Since They Changed the Rules
description: LEAD: I COULD not wait to become a mother. What power, what confidence, what authority went with the job. Saying things like, ''No dessert until you finish that liver.'' ''No TV for a week.'' Or, ''Because I said so, that's why.''

title: U.S. Plans to Cut Off Nonfood Aid to Sudan
description: The United States is preparing to cut off economic assistance to the Sudan, one of the most underdeveloped countries on the continent and a major aid recipient in Africa.

title: Shellfishers May Benefit From Threat by U.S.
description: LEAD: SOME shellfish dealers in the state may benefit from a surprise threat by the Federal Food and Drug Administration to remove them from its list of certified marketers.

title: Amy Hildreth Marries
description: Amy Elizabeth Hildreth, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Burgess H. Hildreth of Reisterstown, Md., and Gregory Lang Billhardt, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack L. Billhardt of New Canaan, Conn., were married yesterday at Grace United Methodist Church in Baltimore by the Rev. Dr. Frank Edward Trotter Jr. Mrs. Billhardt, an accountant at Arthur Andersen & Company in Stamford, Conn., graduated from the University of Richmond, as did her husband, a co-owner of Four Seasons Farm, a fruit and produce market in Darien, Conn.

title: No Gain But No Pain Either
description: ''DID you know that Jane Fonda is 52 years old?'' my 13-year-old daughter asked. That was a loaded question if I ever heard one. ''Yes, I know that,'' I replied, and waited for the other shoe to fall. ''She looks really good,'' my daughter said. ''Yes, she does.'' I had my hand on the cookie jar as I answered her, but I removed it when she came into the kitchen.

title: Violinist Keeps Talent Close to Home
description: SEVERAL years ago, when the virtuoso violinist Albert Markov toured here and abroad, he kept running into his neighbors. ''From Darien and Rowayton, my musical neighbors were there,'' he said.

title: Norway Details How Heavy Water Went to India
description: Norwegian investigators say they have evidence that material that could be used in the manufacture of atomic weapons was illegally shipped to a Bombay company in 1983. The company is listed in the Bombay telephone directory as an affiliate of the Indian Government's Department of Atomic Energy.

title: 113th Campaign Beginning for the Fresh Air Fund
description: For about 10,000 disadvantaged children from New York City, images of steaming concrete and open fire hydrants will be replaced this summer by flowered fields and cooling ponds because of the Fresh Air Fund, which begins its 113th fund-raising campaign today.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about preschool programs misidentified the state agency providing a free booklet, ''Choosing a Child Care Center.'' The booklet is available from the Division of Youth and Family Services, 1 South Montgomery Street, CN 717, Trenton 08625.

title: Basic Tomato Sauce, South of the Border
description: A BASIC tomato sauce to use with pasta, meatloaf or in casseroles is frequently prepared and seasoned Italian-style. Onions, garlic, olive oil and herbs such as oregano and basil flavor the sauce.

title: SANCTUARY OR PRISON?
description: CHANGING HABITS A Memoir of the Society of the Sacred Heart. By V. V. Harrison. Illustrated. 254 pp. New York: Doubleday. $18.95.

title: Wallowing in Iran-Contra
description: Let's finally put Iran-contra behind us and get on with the business of government. That sentiment is proclaimed most loudly by supporters of Oliver North but is heard on all sides. That will not happen soon, nor can it, for this monumental affair is about government's most important business.

title:
PASTIMES: Gardening;
In Pursuit of the Perfect Tomato
description: LEAD: To stake or cage? To prune or not? These questions, and more, invariably arise when gardeners talk about the best way to raise tomatoes.

title: Memos to Meese Are Heard in Wedtech Trial
description: E. Robert Wallach sat wordless in a Manhattan courtroom last week while a Federal prosecutor read a torrent of Mr. Wallach's printed words into the record of the latest corruption trial involving the Wedtech Corporation.

title: Review Process
description: To the Editor:

title: COLD HANDS
description: The splendid article by John Stone on ''Why Some Hands Get So Cold'' had one important omission (Body and Mind, March 12). The application of biofeedback techniques allows the patient literally to warm up cold fingers by releasing the spasm of the artery in the hand. Patients are conditioned to observe the changes on a sensitive thermometer so that they master the ability to increase the finger teperature. Many people can learn these techniques in a very few sessions. This alternative to medication ought to be considered in all cases. ELLIOT WINEBURG, M.D. Mount Sinai School of Medicine New York, N.Y.

title: Lower Manhattan Welcomes a Library
description: After five years of postponed hopes and a dramatic appeal from 100 schoolchildren at City Hall last year, lower Manhattan has a library of its own.

title: THE BOY IN THE PHOTOGRAPH
description: I felt the same embarrassment Donald I. Fine did when my father, his ever present Voigtlander camera swinging from its strap, tried to get me to stand next to Al Jolson so that he could take our picture in front of a hotel in Miami, Fla. (About Men: ''The Boy in the Photograph,'' April 2). The smiling ''Jolie'' even offered me a nickel to pose with him. I would not.

title: Charity and Comedy Both Begin at Home
description: RECENTLY, a local church held its annual clothing drive, designed to bring relief to needy people in the area. Since ours is a family with six children - four sprouting lads and two hemline-conscious maidens - we have much to offer, and participate every year.

title: Mets Beat Astros On Johnson's Homer
description: Howard Johnson celebrated his one-week anniversary as the No. 2 hitter in the Mets' lineup yesterday by doing what he has done since he became the No. 2 hitter. He produced a big hit.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: DEXTERITY. By Douglas Bauer. (Simon & Schuster, $18.95.) As the title implies, Douglas Bauer's first novel is a case study of dexterity in both its literary aspirations and in the day-to-day survival of its characters. Ed King is the chief put-down artist on his county road crew, known for his quick jibes.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: CULTURE IMAGES An exhibition of almost 100 framed and captioned photographs from the collection of the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Manhattan will be on display for one week at Abbott House in Irvington. Dr. Kenneth B. Clark, the psychologist and author, will open the exhibition at 1:30 P.M. today, and Donald Bogle, a film critic, will present a slide show and discussion on ''Black Images in American Film, 1903-Present,'' at 3:30 P.M.

title: Joan D. Wetmore To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Thomson Wetmore Jr. of Amenia, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joan Dixon Wetmore, and Walter Wallace Yahn, the son of Nedra Guyette of Farmington, Me., and the late Wallace Yahn. The wedding is planned for next month.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: AVIATION INDUCTEES Four New Jersey men whose names are engraved in the history of aviation will be inducted into Teterboro Airport's Aviation Hall of Fame at a benefit dinner in Cresskill on Wednesday.

title: Patricia G. Canan Engaged to Wed
description: Patricia G. Canan and Charles R. Canan of Rochester have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Ellen Canan and John H. Grady Jr., a son of Mrs. John H. Grady of Greenwich, Conn., and the late Mr. Grady.

title: Neighbors Complain As Nightclub Crowds Turn to Violence
description: At a time when the patrons who made them successful are giving way to a younger, more violent crowd, several of New York's downtown discotheques are struggling to survive under the scrutiny of city authorities and community leaders.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: The Best Defense Like most small-business owners, Wanda McCabe will take new customers any way she can get them. Well, almost any way. The owner of a driving school in Lindenhurst recently had a potential client drop in a little too unexpectedly.

title: PHILIP MORRIS'S BIG BITE
description: L. J. Davis's article about Philip Morris Companies and their search for new fields wherein to invest their vast profits reminded me of the cocaine drug barons and their search for ways to launder their poison profits (''Philip Morris's Big Bite,'' April 9). The Surgeon General of the United States has labeled tobacco an addictive drug, so there is indeed more than a casual similarity.

title: PASTIMES: Numismatics
description: Every coin collector looks for mint errors on coins. Even the young collector will look to see if there is a miss-strike or double-strike on a cent or nickel. The days of finding a three-legged buffalo are perhaps over - more recent coins fill our pockets - but still the search continues. One extremely rare error is the brockage.

title: YANKS ADMIT WORRY ABOUT PITCHING STAFF
description: One week ago, the Yankees traded away a significant part of their pitching future. Today, as a sudden snowstorm blew through town and temperatures fell toward freezing, they faced a problem that eventually could make them regret the deal.

title: Craze for Sports Goes Too Far
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: DEAR, SLOVENLY MOTHER MOSCOW
description: THE BEGINNING OF SPRING By Penelope Fitzgerald. 187 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company. $18.95.

title: A CHINESE LESSON IN POLITE PROTEST
description: For anyone tempted to think that rebellious Chinese students must be fighting for capitalism and multi-party democracy, a banner fluttering over People's University marchers on Thursday was a rude shock. It read, ''We firmly support the correct leadership of the Communist Party.''

title: Town Seeking An Open Beach
