description: IN an effort to preserve public access to mile-long Moody Beach, the town of Wells is preparing to get two appraisals of the beachfront lots, one for buying easements for recreation and onefor buying the land outright. If the cost is too high, said Jonathan Carter, the Wells Town Manager, the town will ask the state to buy the beach through its program of buying public lands.

title: When Crimes Become Symbols
description: On April 19, a 28-year-old woman was discovered in a Manhattan park, brutally raped and beaten into a coma. On April 29, a 19-year-old woman was found dead, strangled and probably raped, in another Manhattan park. The two women, both of whom moved to New York City to advance their careers, were nine years apart in age; the incidents were separated by only 10 days and 100 blocks.

title: When Berlitz Is Not Enough
description: CONFRONTATION with alien tongues sorts travelers into three groups. The adepts, at one extreme, ''have an ear.'' Landing in Madrid for breakfast, they're able to chat up the waiter by dinnertime. At the other extreme are the blithely monolingual, confident that pantomime, loud repetitions of their native speech and the kindness of strangers will carry any day. In the middle is my group, the tongue-tied. Although we can read a bit and understand some of what others say, easy speech remains tantalizingly elusive.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Eight years ago, I had the outside of my house covered with California redwood that was finished with polyurethane varnish. This gave it a beautiful shiny color that everyone admired. After about two years, however, the front of the house started to get dull and spotty looking. I was advised to sand this and reapply polyurethane. I have done this several times, but it seems to be required about every year. The house is ready to be done again. What do you suggest?

title: Gen. Adnan Khairallah, 50, Dies; Iraqi Defense Chief and Adviser
description: Gen. Adnan Khairallah, Deputy Commander in Chief of Iraq's armed forces and Defense Minister, was killed on Friday in a helicopter crash in a sandstorm in northern Iraq, President Saddam Hussein said today. General Khairallah was 50 years old.

title: STREETSCAPES: The Half Moon Hotel; A Symbol of Coney Island Is About to Be Eclipsed
description: IT was once Coney Island's Statue of Liberty, an impressive symbol beckoning to passing oceanliners. But now the Half Moon Hotel, having spent its waning years as the Metropolitan Jewish Geriatric Center nursing home, is scheduled for demolition as soon as the home completes a new building.

title:
INVESTING;
Airline Losses Are AAR's Gains
description: LEAD: Recent news reports about the aging of the world's commercial air fleets have helped the performance of the AAR Corporation's stock. The company, based in Elk Grove Village, Ill., overhauls aircraft and provides parts.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Dykstra and Wilson Platoon?
description: Where else but in New York can you find someone who has the qualities of a Mookie Dykstra? His enthusiasm and energy will carry him 162 games. He gives 20 home runs, 120 r.b.i.'s, 50 stolen bases and an insurance policy. Not only do I hope he stays, perhaps he should run for mayor. He symbolizes what New Yorkers are, and want to be: competitive and dependable. Surely a man for all seasons. RANDY McKENNA Astoria, Queens

title: Review/Music; Canadian Pianist Evokes Varied Modern Influences
description: Christina Petrowska, a Canadian pianist, presented a program of contemporary music Thursday night at Merkin Concert Hall. It was an evening full of worthy composers and not uninteresting pieces. But there was a curious sameness to the music, one that seemed to speak as much of Miss Petrowksa's sensibility as it did of the composers.

title: Who'll Get The Tickets?
description: To the Editor:

title: JACK KEMP FACES REALITY
description: JACK F. KEMP, THE FRESHLY MINTED Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, was stabbing forcefully at a plate of lasagna in a Baltimore soup kitchen when Bryant Cochrane, a young black man who said he was homeless, pushed through a crowd to beard the famous visitor. Cochrane wore a blue T-shirt and sneakers; Kemp, a dark suit, collar bar and tasseled loafers.

title: A Sculptor Who Really Gets Into His Work
description: Antony Gormley is both director and actor on a sculptural stage as spare as anything in Beckett. He is the mind deciding where his figures will go, and he is the body from which his squatting, flying and tumbling figures are cast in plaster and then fixed in lead. Even when there are two figures and they seem to be a man and woman in sexual union, the molds were taken from him alone.

title: POSTINGS: Fannie Mae Experiment; Senior Thesis
description: To provide low-cost housing for people 62 years old and older, the Federal National Mortgage Association has made $100 million in new mortgage money available to lending institutions under four innovative programs. The pilot project will provide 1,400 low-cost mortgages throughout the country to see if the programs are viable options for people at or near retirement age. The aim is to balance their desire for independence with their potential physical and financial limitations.

title: POSTINGS: 6-Unit Co-op
description: Six years ago, Mayor Edward I. Koch announced a program to create 180 apartments in unused buildings where painters, musicians, dancers, actors and other artists could live and work. In the 1983 statement, the Mayor praised artists for giving ''the city much of its vital personality and international prestige'' and said the city had to provide low-cost housing to help keep them in New York. Yet so far the program has produced only 12 units and on Friday six more will be formally opened in Brooklyn.

title: Competing Designs on Shoreham's Remains
description: DELAY, the tactic that Shoreham opponents used to drive the Long Island Lighting Company into a deal to kill the reactor, has a new champion: the United States Secretary of Energy.

title:
GARDENING;
Plans and Notes Can Smooth the Way
description: LEAD: EXPERIENCED gardeners probably fall into one of two categories when it comes to planning: Those who keep meticulous notes and sketches and those who play it by ear year after year.

title: Rape in the News: Mainly About Whites
description: LEAD: A 29-year-old woman goes to the top of a 21-story building to watch a sunrise. There, two armed men rape her and force her to jump from the roof. She grabs a television cable that miraculously breaks her fall. She holds on, naked and screaming, until residents of the building save her life. The story makes the inside pages of New York's newspapers.

title: THROWING THE BOOK AT THE COURTS
description: tr,br1WITH JUSTICE FOR NONE Destroying an American Myth. By Gerry Spence. 370 pp. New York: Times Books. $18.95.

title: Canine Social Set Steps Out
description: More than 50 dogs were the guests of honor at a book party in Central Park Thursday evening and they seemed to get along at least as well as people do at most cocktail parties.

title: Scandal in the Moonlight
description: What business do city officeholders have also holding time-consuming posts in political parties? None, in the view of Frederick A. O. Schwarz Jr., head of New York City's Charter Revision Commission, who would ban such behavior.

title: More Tuition Was Too Much to Ask
description: GIVEN the sharp rise in the cost of going to college in recent years, a $200 tuition increase - and the first since 1983, at that - might seem relatively low. But the turbulence of the last two weeks has demonstrated that a tuition increase of any amount remains a politically delicate, sometimes explosive, subject for New York State's public universities.

title: A Step Is Taken Toward 911 System
description: IF a stranded motorist in Westchester is lucky enough to find a phone, the hard part is still to come: determining how to get help when there are 145 different police, fire and emergency medical services in the county, each with its own jurisdiction.

title: Suns Beat Warriors In Opener, 130-103
description: Dan Majerle, the Phoenix Suns rookie guard who was a distant runner-up to Golden State's Mitch Richmond in this year's rookie of the year voting, got a little satisfaction today.

title: ALIENS IN THE TRIBE
description: A STRANGER IN HER NATIVE LAND Alice Fletcher and the American Indians. By Joan Mark. Illustrated. 428 pp. Lincoln: University of Nebraska Press. Cloth, $32.95. Paper, $16.95. RUTH BENEDICT Stranger in This Land. By Margaret M. Caffrey. Illustrated. 432 pp. Austin: University of Texas Press. $24.95.

title: Correction
description: An article in the Education Life section on April 9 about an elementary-school class in holography misstated the exposure time for a laser beam to produce a hologram, or three-dimensional image. It was 10 seconds.

title: Leader of Drug Cult Is Reported Killed
description: The ringleader of a drug smuggling cult that killed 15 people has been slain in a gun battle with the Mexico City police and his girlfriend has been captured, the police said Saturday.

title: U.N. Health Agency Seeks Compromise on P.L.O.
description: The World Health Organization is planning to offer increased medical aid to Palestinians living in the Israeli-occupied territories as part of an emerging compromise aimed at preventing the United States from withdrawing from the organization, diplomats say.

title: Questions of Law Live On After Father Helps Son Die
description: When his baby's eyes dimmed, Rudy Linares cradled the limp child in his arms and ran terrified through the streets to a firehouse, shouting tearfully, ''Help me! Help me! My baby is dying.''

title: Family Court Buildings Found 'Deplorable'
description: New York City's Family Court buildings are so deplorable ''they undermine the administration of justice,'' a private watchdog group has concluded.

title: Sports of The Times; Sweaters, Defectors and Soviet Sports
description: More than a quarter of a century ago, before all a Russian athlete wanted out of an American sports tour was a few pairs of blue jeans, Valery Brumel, then the holder of the world high-jump record, was in New York for an indoor track meet at Madison Square Garden. While on display at a track writers luncheon, he was asked where he had purchased the elegantly colorful sweater he was wearing. His interpreter hardly hesitated, befitting suspicions that he was really a KGB agent.

title: THE GHOST OF THE GREAT MOLE HUNTER
description: DECEPTION The Invisible War Between the KGB and the CIA. By Edward Jay Epstein. 335 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $19.95.

title: Q and A
description: Tax on a Brownstone

title: Satyajit Ray Gives Ibsen A Bengali Spin. . . And Reflects on Life and Art
description: Satyajit Ray is no campaigner, preferring to make films - ''a sort of social service'' - and to write, illustrate, design and publish an original magazine for children; but his values are essentially those of the earlier generation. His gifted grandfather and father felt the same; they founded and edited the magazine until their premature deaths, generating a stream of stories, verses, riddles, drawings and paintings that easily bear comparison with Lewis Carroll's and Edward Lear's. In 1987, for the centenary of his father's birth, Mr. Ray made a documentary film about him. It opened with a series of his father's enchanting illustrations and the comment, ''There can be very few Bengalis who do not know these characters.''

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
Building on Spec in a Slow Office Market
description: LEAD: THE wave of economic growth that has swept over Bridgewater in the last decade, molding it into a commercial hub in central Somerset County, continues as retail and office buildings rise within its 32 square miles.

title: A Word of Thanks To a Hospital
description: Yes, there may be overcrowding in the emergency rooms of Westchester hospitals [ ''Signs of Crisis in the Emergency Room,'' April 9 ] . And yes, people are quick to criticize and publicize the negative. But, I want to acknowledge a favorable experience.

title: No Headline
description: The panel rewriting New York City's charter rejected a proposal yesterday to have the five borough presidents serve on an expanded City Council and decided instead to recommend new administrative roles for them.

title: Boiling Point
description: To the Editor:

title: Parent's Loss Leads To Camp-Safety Gains
description: LEAD: THANKS to a bereaved parent's personal crusade of nearly a quarter-century, children going to camp this summer will be safer than they used to be.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: LIFE SKETCHES. By John Hersey. (Knopf, $19.95.) In his 75 years, John Hersey has published 17 novels, five nonfiction books and numerous articles. ''Life Sketches'' is a collection of profiles and sketches published in The New Yorker and elsewhere, and, like most collections, it is uneven. Some of the portraits are as well crafted as a finely etched print, while others suffer from overindulgent editing - too much ponderous detail, dwelled on too lovingly.

title: Bay Area Brewpubs: Beer at the Source
description: CALIFORNIA still has the jump on the rest of the country when it comes to pioneering America's revolution in food and drink. Lately the state has turned its attention to beer; the repeal in 1976 of a Prohibition-era law against homebrewing has allowed a new generation of homebrewers and microbreweries to flourish. The revolution skyrocketed, however, in 1983, when California became the first state to repeal laws forbidding the sale of beer in breweries.

title: Two Chinas May Never Become One, But They Are Becoming Friendly
description: CHINA'S six-decade civil war may be ending. The bearer of the olive branch was Shirley Kuo, Finance Minister in the Taiwan Government, who last week became the first Nationalist official to return to China since the Communist victory in 1949.

title: BREEDING HORSES AND OPENING SHOPPING MALLS
description: THE ENCHANTED GLASSBritain and Its Monarchy. By Tom Nairn. 414 pp. New York: W. W. Norton & Company. Paper, $12.95.

title: Buffalo Agrees to Integrate Its Public Housing
description: For at least a decade, this city's public housing authority has discriminated against minority tenants and condoned segregation, a Federal order made public this week says.

title: A Treasurehouse for Architecture
description: If the Canadian Center for Architecture were just a bit better known, and if it cast its net wider to include all of the visual arts, then it might just be confused with the Getty Museum in California. For the Canadian Center, like the Getty, is an immensely ambitious museum and research center, financed by the foresight of a single donor. Like the Getty, it has built up a collection of extraordinary stature in a remarkably brief time. And like the Getty, it is staffed by a cadre of serious scholars, who labor in an environment that their colleagues in older institutions envy.

title: Racquet Article Misses the Point
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Is It Time to Buy?
description: To the Editor:

title: Oregon Coast: Chilly Solitude And Beauty
description: MOST people never dream of packing rain slickers and woolen gloves for midsummer shoreline vacations. Nor do they relish the idea of waking at 4 A.M. But fishermen, neophyte and seasoned alike, flock to the central Oregon coast in the hope of catching some of the state's prized salmon and crustaceans.

title: Comings and Goings
description: The 1988 champion, Bob Charles of New Zealand, will defend his title at the Nynex/Golf Digest Commemorative golf tournament at Sleepy Hollow Country Club in Scarborough-on the-Hudson, N.Y. May 17-21. . . . Mickey Mantle, the former Yankee slugger, and Phil Esposito, the current Ranger general manager, will be honored tomorrow at a lunch benefiting the Greater New York March of Dimes Birth Defects Foundation.

title: Question Of the Week; Should Dykstra and Wilson Platoon?
description: For four years, Lenny Dykstra and Mookie Wilson have platooned in center field for the Mets with productive results. But the time has come to give Dykstra the chance to prove he can be the everyday center fielder. Given the chance, I feel he can hit left-handed pitching. Wilson is a streak hitter and a good fourth outfielder. DORIS BAUER Rego Park, Queens

title: Reporter's Notebook; Election Long Over, Pope Still Seems to Be Stumping
description: There are startling similarities between an American Presidential campaign and a papal voyage like the nine-day African trip that Pope John Paul II completed today in this capital.

title: Reviews/Dance; Balanchine's Brahms, Robbins's Bach
description: The New York City Ballet danced only two works on Friday night at the New York State Theater: George Balanchine's ''Brahms-Schoenberg Quartet,'' in its first performance of the season, and a repeat performance of Jerome Robbins's ''Goldberg Variations.'' But no one could complain that the program was flimsy.

title: A Granddaughter's Fear
description: I WAS TALKING BUSINESS with a colleague late one afternoon when the first call came. The voice on the other end was loud and panicked; my colleague looked over at me, horrified.

title: Review/Theater; A String Quartet Tours the World, in 'New Cities'
description: In ''New Cities,'' performed by the Talking Band at La Mama, music is bread, not the food of love, for a string quartet on a world concert tour. A problem is that the bread provides not much sustenance most of the time for the weary and homesick musicians.

title: FINDING 'THE ZONE'
description: As a law enforcement officer, I have reached the zone that Lawrence Shainberg describes - albeit only in later years - particularly when I have been working with younger, more excitable officers in life-threatening situations. It seems as if time slows down, sometimes frighteningly so - so that everything becomes clear, and I make no errors. I attribute this effortless state to experience and proficiency, as I recall nothing like this happening to me during combat in Korea. CHARLES RITZBERG Probation Warrant Officer, Retired The Bronx

title: The Beat Goes On - And Time Stands Still
description: ''American Bandstand'' notwithstanding, the measure of a commercial dance record is almost never its beat. The history of dance music is one of bad records with good beats and good records with monotonous thuds. The beat is at most an instigator, a means toward a greater reward.

title: Freedom of Speech And 'Hateful' Ideas
description: The article on the German-American Bund (''Jerseyana,'' April 9), informative and interesting on the surface, offers an excellent example of misguided ''reasoning,'' replete with dangerous assumptions and conclusions lurking behind the facade of fair-seeming words.

title: BEST SELLERS: May 7, 1989
description: Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 10 THE SATANIC VERSES, by Salman Rushdie. (Viking, $19.95.) Two emigres from Bombay enact the roles of good and evil in contemporary London. 2 2 7 A PRAYER FOR OWEN MEANY, by John Irving. (Morrow, $19.95.) A schoolboy who accidentally killed the mother of his best friend turns into a prophet with a message for our times. 3 3 11 STAR, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) The crossed paths of a man and a woman who are destined for stardom in different professions. 4 5 2 THE NEGOTIATOR, by Frederick Forsyth. (Bantam, $19.95.) An American expatriate thwarts terrorists' attempts to prevent the signing of a disarmament pact. 5 4 5 THE JOY LUCK CLUB, by Amy Tan. (Putnam, $18.95.) The tensions and bonds shared by Chinese- American women and their immigrant mothers. 6 6 5 WE ARE STILL MARRIED, by Garrison Keillor. (Viking, $18.95.) Stories, poems and satirical pieces, mostly reflecting life in Minnesota during the Reagan era. 7 7 4 KILLSHOT, by Elmore Leonard. (Arbor House/ Morrow, $18.95.) Two thugs out to assassinate a man and a woman who discovered their crime. 8 8 10 BILLY BATHGATE, by E. L. Doctorow. (Random House, $19.95.) The life of the 1930's gangster Dutch Schultz, as seen by a bright youth from the Bronx. 9 1 THE DIAMOND THRONE, by David Eddings. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $18.95.) Magic, chivalry and high adventure in a fantasy kingdom called Elenia. 10 * 10 30 BREATHING LESSONS, by Anne Tyler. (Knopf, $18.95.) The many facets of a 28-year marriage are revealed during a drive to a friend's funeral. 11 11 12 CAT'S EYE, by Margaret Atwood. (Doubleday, $18.95.) A woman's visit to her native Toronto leads her to reflect on the changes time has wrought. 12 9 11 THE EDGE, by Dick Francis. (Putnam, $18.95.) Murder and mayhem on a luxury trans-Canadian train trip. 13 12 9 THE LONG DARK TEA-TIME OF THE SOUL, by Douglas Adams. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.) The detective of ''The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy'' pursues the meaning of an explosion at an airport. 14 13 40 THE CARDINAL OF THE KREMLIN, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan races to the rescue of an American secret agent. 15 1 THE TEMPLE OF MY FAMILIAR, by Alice Walker. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) The relations of the species, races and sexes through the past 5,000 centuries. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 1 27 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $15.95.) Inspirational essays about everyday matters. 2 2 2 LOVE AND MARRIAGE, by Bill Cosby. (Doubleday, $16.95.) Observations on the elations and frustrations of romantic relationships. 3 3 55 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A British scientist reviews efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 4 4 15 BLIND FAITH, by Joe McGinniss. (Putnam, $21.95.) The family tragedy that came to light after the 1984 murder of a Toms River, N.J., woman. 5 6 8 ''FUNNY, YOU DON'T LOOK LIKE A GRANDMOTHER,'' by Lois Wyse. (Crown, $12.95.) An advertising woman's reflections on her role as the grandparent of eight. 6 5 4 CITIZENS, by Simon Schama. (Knopf, $29.95.) A history of the French Revolution. 7 9 11 INNUMERACY, by John Allen Paulos. (Hill & Wang, $16.95.) Americans' mathematical illiteracy and its consequences for our culture. 8 7 3 OUT OF THE BLUE, by Orel Hershiser with Jerry B. Jenkins. (Wolgemuth & Hyatt, $17.95.) The autobiography of the Los Angeles Dodgers' pitcher. 9 8 12 THE BLOODING, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Morrow, $18.95.) The murder of two teen-age girls in an English village is solved through genetic clues. 10 12 2 GOLDWYN, by A. Scott Berg. (Knopf, $24.95.) The life of the pioneering motion picture producer. 11 10 6 INTELLECTUALS, by Paul Johnson. (Harper & Row, $22.50.) An account of the role writers and critics have played in Western society during the past two centuries. 12 * 11 4 WORDSTRUCK, by Robert MacNeil. (Viking, $18.95.) The co-host of the ''MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour'' recalls his boyhood in Canada. 13 15 14 LEGENDS, LIES, AND CHERISHED MYTHS OF AMERICAN HISTORY, by Richard Shenkman. (Morrow, $15.95.) An expose of tall tales that have become part of our national heritage. 14 * 16 24 A BRIGHT SHINING LIE, by Neil Sheehan. (Random House, $24.95.) A biography of Lieut. Col. John Paul Vann that is also a history of American involvement in Vietnam. 15 * 14 20 ''WHAT DO YOU> CARE WHAT OTHER PEOPLE THINK?'' by Richard P. Feynman with Ralph Leighton. (Norton, $17.95.) Memoirs of the Nobel Prize-winning physicist. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 2 GOING WITHIN, by Shirley MacLaine. (Bantam, $18.95.) A ''guide for inner transformation'' through meditation. 2 2 15 WEALTH WITHOUT RISK, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) A Florida entrepreneur's advice about how to make a personal fortune. 3 3 96 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level. 4 5 8 ONE UP ON WALL STREET, by Peter Lynch with John Rothchild. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) Advice on investing in stocks from a veteran fund manager. 5 4 13 THE WAY THINGS WORK, by David Macaulay. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.95.) Explanations in pictures and text. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Final Rounds or Not, Wright Keeps Punching
description: JIM WRIGHT, says an old friend, has his jaw out and the bit in his teeth. That's Texas talk for he has not yet begun to fight. The one-time boxer is hunkering down for his final battle, a fight to convince the House ethics committee that he did not break the rules of Congressional conduct.

title: Juliann Davidson a Bride
description: Juliann Davidson and Marc Chusid were married yesterday at Holy Trinity Lutheran Church in Long Beach Island, N.J., by the Rev. William Rosenow. The Rev. Paul White, a Presbyterian minister, assisted. The bride, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Davidson 2d of Wayne, Pa., is the vice president of sales communication at MTV Networks in New York. The bridegroom, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Chusid of Irvington, N.Y., and Long Beach Island, is the creative director at Lifetime Television in Astoria, Queens.

title: Blair Landau Is Married
description: At the Unitarian Church of All Souls in New York, Blair Susan Landau, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Loeber Landau of New York, was married yesterday to Charles White Trippe Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Trippe of Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. F. Forrester Church.

title: Understanding and Punishing Teen-Age Violence in Park Attack
description: To the Editor:

title: STILL SUBVERTING THE CULTURE
description: THE TERRIBLE THREES By Ishmael Reed. 180 pp. New York: Atheneum. $16.95.

title: Common Sense Seems to Be In Short Supply
description: Few people enter a theater hoping to hate the movie, but, having paid their seven bucks, they don't take kindly to insult. Movie patrons are a prickly, unreliable lot. Friends one minute, adversaries the next. They want to believe, and they do believe, sometimes doggedly, until that moment when belief becomes insupportable. Then they become bored, maybe rude. If they're movie reviewers, they turn mean.

title: Rose Fed Up
description: After being hounded for weeks by reporters, photographers and camera crews, Pete Rose is beginning to get a bit testy. When the beleaguered Cincinnati Reds manager returned to duty on Friday after missing four games with bronchitis, he angrily waved off a television crew that closed in on him as he entered the dugout in Cincinnati before the game.

title: FICTION
description: GOLDILOCKS. By Andrew Coburn. (Scribner's, $17.95.) Crime novels - unlike mysteries, which usually rely heavily on plot - are successful largely due to their interesting characters and their mood of psychological tension. The most effective, like those by Dashiell Hammett and Raymond Chandler, create sinister worlds we don't mind visiting, but certainly wouldn't care to live in. In ''Goldilocks,'' the former crime reporter Andrew Coburn (the author of ''Off Duty'' and ''The Babysitter'') has created just such a world of small-town corruption and double-dealing. Set in New England, the novel opens as Louise Baker dumps her latest paramour, Henry Witlo, a psychotic Vietnam veteran, because her invalid, blue-blood husband has just been released from the hospital. Louise has worked her way up the ladder of criminal success by taking over an ex-boyfriend's loan-sharking business. This fragmented novel chronicles her struggles as she strives to handle an insurrection by her own henchmen (including the local chief of police), as well as a Government investigation into her criminal activities. Mr. Coburn, using a series of short takes, alternates the woes of Louise Baker with the misadventures of Henry Witlo as he sinks his hooks into the newly widowed Emma Goss, who, using an interesting form of passive resistance, gives Henry more than he bargained for, slowly turning him from victimizer to victim. Although Mr. Coburn is not quite in the class of Hammett et al., he does have a nearly flawless ear for dialogue, which makes this tautly written novel move along at a smooth and satisfying pace.

title: FICTION
description: THE PORT OF MISSING MEN. By Mary-Ann Tirone Smith. (Morrow, $17.95.) Reading this delightfully unexpected, offbeat little book is like taking a ride on the Crazy Mouse at the carnival: you never know what twists or turns it will take next. Mary-Ann Tirone Smith's third novel, ''The Port of Missing Men,'' is set in 1936; as it begins, our heroine, 15-year-old Lily Neelan, and her mother, Gertie, are on board the Normandie. Lily has just won two gold medals for diving at the Olympic Games in Berlin. Naturally, Lily is the toast of the luxury liner; for her part, Gertie is wasting no time trying to snag a rich man. Through a series of cleverly interwoven flashbacks, we learn that Lily has no father, that Gertie has been a prostitute and that one of her tricks, a down-and-out former baseball player named Johnny Q, used to baby-sit with Lily while Gertie was working. A friend of Johnny Q's, a swimming pro named Eddie G, took one look at the shy, skinny Lily and announced she was ''built to dive'' - and the two of them proceeded to train her. Meanwhile, back at the boat, Gertie gets her man, a very rich German named Albert Rexhault whose father, just like Lily's, is a missing man. Kindred spirits, Lily and Rexhault decide to trace their origins together, and the adventure begins, taking them from New York to New Haven to New Orleans and finally to a lost island off the Florida Keys. Lily meets Cary Grant, Zelda Fitzgerald and Ernest Hemingway, falls in love, becomes a spy, lives in a brothel and, in a hilarious episode, discovers that she was named by her grandmother's parrot, Rum Keg - and that she just may be the great-granddaughter of the pirate Jean Laffite. Too fantastic, you say? Maybe so, but it's fun all the way.

title: High Technology May Get a Break

He said the priority category for such special treatment is high-definition television, a technology that provides a sharpened TV picture and could produce important advances in semiconductors and telecommunications. The policy change would have to be approved by Congress. *

But they've retained his melodic sense and his impassioned pessimism, and at the Bottom Line on Friday his four-piece band put across the new songs with a precise wallop that didn't flinch from noise.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Auto Racing Senna Triumphs in Monaco: Ayrton Senna of Brazil avoided traffic and accidents yesterday in winning the Monaco Grand Prix for the second time, beating his McLaren-Honda teammate, Alain Prost. Senna's winning time was 1 hour 53 minutes 33.251 seconds as he beat Prost by 52.528 seconds. The two now are tied for the lead in the drivers' standing with 18 points each. Italians took third, fourth and fifth in the 77-lap race on the twisting 2.068-mile course, a total of 159.236 miles.(AP) Horse Racing Arlene's Valentine Wins: Arlene's Valentine, ridden by Julie Krone, scored a neck victory over Fourstardave in the $88,200 Fort Marcy Handicap for 3-year-olds and up at Aqueduct. Sunshine Forever, last year's turf champion and the odds-on favorite, was third, 1 1/2 lengths farther back. Arlene's Valentine returned $15.40 for $2 to win.(AP) Running Groos Wins in Pittsburgh: Margaret Groos, overcoming rain, wind, snow flurries and a Soviet runner's persistence, broke away with four miles to go to win her second consecutive Pittsburgh Marathon by more than 4 minutes. Groos, a disappointing 39th in the Seoul Olympics, ran shoulder-to-shoulder with Ramilya Burangulova of the Soviet Union for the first 21 miles, then opened up a 14-second lead over the next mile and was nearly a mile ahead by the finish line. Groos collected $30,000 for winning, the only major American marathon that features female runners. Ken Martin, who outkicked John Tuttle over the final half mile to become the race's first men's repeat champion, won $15,000 of the $209,000 purse, all but $33,800 of which went to the women.(AP) Tennis Chesnokov Prevails: Andrei Chesnokov of the Soviet Union, a winner at Nice two weeks ago, beat Martin Strelba of Czechoslovakia, 5-7, 7-6, 6-2, in the final of the $205,000 Bavarian Open. Strelba, who upset top-seeded Stefan Edberg in Saturday's semifinal, was playing in his first Nabisco Grand Prix final. (AP) Graf Is Victor: Steffi Graf of West Germany won the the $200,000 Hamburg Virginia Slims tournament by default when her opponent in the final, Jana Novotna of Czechoslovakia, was unable to play because of an ankle injury. Novotna twisted her ankle during Saturday's semifinal against Arantxa Sanchez of Spain. (AP) Track and Field Princeton Wins: Princeton's men's and women's track teams won their respective team titles in the Heptagonal championships at Columbia's Lawrence A. Wien Stadium. The Tiger men ran up 135 points to 110 for second-place Dartmouth. The Princeton women's team scored 145 points, with Dartmouth again second, with 111. Rugby Title to Air Force: In Colorado Springs yesterday, the host school, the Air Force Academy, won the 10th intercollegiate championships by defeating California-Long Beach, 25-7. Air Force had reached the final three times before, but had never won. Army beat Penn State, 38-10, to finish third. Dog Show Bulldog Is Best: A red brindle bulldog with white markings, Ch. Hetherbull Bounty's Frigate, owned by Jean and Robert Hetherington of Pine Island, N.Y., led a field of 3,438 dogs yesterday at the 60th all-breed show of the Trenton Kennel Club at Mercer County Park in West Windsor Township, N.J.

title: Guy Williams, TV and Film Actor Who Played Zorro, Is Dead at 65
description: Guy Williams, who played the swashbuckling black-masked hero Zorro on television in the late 1950's, was found dead Saturday, apparently of a heart attack, at his apartment in Buenos Aires, the Buenos Aires police said yesterday. He was 65 years old.

title: Susie Berg Waldman, 66, Writer and Editor
description: Susie Berg Waldman, a writer and editor, died of bone cancer and pneumonia yesterday at New York University Hospital in Manhattan. She was 66 years old and lived in Riverdale.

title: Hughes Is Sued Over Radar
description: A manager at the Hughes Aircraft Company has accused the company in a Federal lawsuit of overcharging the Government by $40 million for the radar system for the F-18 fighter jet and B-2 stealth bomber.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Tesoro's Ex-Counsel Returns to a Top Post
description: LEAD: M. Richard Stewart, a former general counsel of the Tesoro Petroleum Corporation, has returned to the troubled company to fill the president's post left vacant by the unexpected and unexplained departure last month of the company's president and chief executive, Dennis F. Juren, who had been at Tesoro for 19 years.

title: Magazines Raise Reliance on Circulation
description: The advertising slump that has plagued consumer magazine publishers for two years has allowed circulation directors to try out at last the role of primary breadwinner.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; a Redesign For Departures
description: The American Express Company sees advertising gold in its platinum card holders, so the company has announced a redesign and repositioning of Departures, a travel publication that goes free-of-charge to its top customers. Starting with the September/

title: Rains Fail to Relieve Drought Restrictions
description: Heavy rains in the last few days increased the water level in the reservoirs that feed New York City, but drought restrictions remain in effect, officials said yesterday.

title: Anne Rittenberry Becomes a Bride
description: At the Reformed Church in Rhinebeck, N.Y., Anne Boughton Rittenberry, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James Giles Rittenberry of Poughkeepsie, N.Y., was married yesterday to Walter M. Steppacher 4th, the son of Walter M. Steppacher 3d and Margery D. Steppacher, both of Poughkeepsie. The Rev. C. Keith Geense, a reformed minister, officiated.

title: Rising Oil Prices Put Gabon on the Brink of Prosperity
description: The strong increase in world oil prices has come at an opportune time for Gabon, the smallest producer in the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.

title: Reviews/Music; Da Vinci in Chamber Works
description: The Da Vinci Players, a flexible chamber ensemble, performed a Mozart Clarinet Trio, a group of Louis Spohr songs and string quartets by Schubert and Smetana on Saturday evening at Weill Recital Hall.

title: Applied Bioscience Internaional Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Family Steak Houses reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $146,500 from an accounting change.

title: U.S. Decline in Electronics
description: An agency within the Commerce Department has prepared a draft report that says the nation's electronics industry is eroding. It attributes the decline to both concerted subsidies by foreign governments and the laissez-faire policies of the United States.

title: Turbo Resources reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a special gain of $782,000. The company said the loss for the latest first quarter was after the payment of preferred share dividends of $3.2 million. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: In Soviet Georgia, a Longing for Freedom but Little Sense of How to Get It
description: Speaking in the smoke-filled kitchen of an apartment in Tbilisi's west side, four dissidents shared their vision of Georgia's future.

description: b-Included tax credits of $125,000. c-Net loss

title: Bio-Rad Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Elderly Swap City's Streets For Adventures in Camping
description: As a welfare worker in the 1950's, Marie G. Kalish had sent dozens of disadvantaged youths to summer camp and seen them emerge with new interests. Thirty years later, she did the same thing herself, finding not only an interest in the theater but a new career.

title: Comes the Reaction
description: The 20th century has taught the world this lesson: You cannot have freedom without some insecurity; you cannot have security without giving up some freedom.

title: Rivals Are Stealing Fords' Thunder
description: At a news conference in December, Darrell Waltrip lamented that he and everyone else who raced Chevrolets on Nascar's Winston Cup circuit would be chasing the drivers of the new Ford Thunderbird for the first eight races of the season, while they waited for the Lumina to make its debut, which it did yesterday at Talladega, Ala,, in the Winston 500.

title: Banta Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $340,000 for the latest quarter and $341,000 for the year-earlier period. The latest year's first quarter sales included sales of $52,349,000 from an acquisition which was accounted for as a purchase effective April 1, 1988.

title: O'Connor Visits Park Rape Suspects
description: John Cardinal O'Connor said yesterday that he had visited the six suspects accused of assaulting a 28-year-old woman as she jogged in Central Park last month and ''reminded them that God loves everybody, regardless of what we may have done.''

title: More Than a Place to Sit
description: With the arrival of the 1989 baseball season comes a new stadium seat that does more than give you a place to sit.

title: Toni Castellucci Married To Dr. Albert D. Helfrick
description: The marriage of Toni Castellucci, a daughter of Isabelle Venezia of Wanaque, N.J., and the late Judge Robert C. Ricker of the Passaic County (N.J.) Municipal Court, to Dr. Albert D. Helfrick, a son of Mary Helfrick of Westville, N.J., and the late Eugene Helfrick, took place yesterday at the Community Church of Smoke Rise in Kinnelon, N.J. The Rev. Charles L. Higgins, a minister of the Reformed Church of America, officiated.

title: Boyfriend Surrenders After Woman Is Slain
description: A woman was fatally stabbed early yesterday at a Harlem apartment, and her boyfriend turned himself in at a Bronx police station house.

title: Henley Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and after income of $171 million from discontinued operations. The year-ago income from discontinued operations included a gain of about $165 million on the January 1988 sale of M.W. Kellogg Co. Year-ago earnings were restated to reflect as discontinued operations the results of Wheelabrator Group Inc., M.W. Kellogg, Henley Manufacturing Corp., and other manufacturing companies, and to reflect the consolidation of Signal Landmark Holdings Inc.

title: Shearson Unit Cuts Sale Of Realty-Partner Stakes
description: In a move reflecting problems throughout the industry, the real estate arm of Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. announced Friday that it would no longer sell interests in real estate partnerships to individuals.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Old Standbys Dominate Print Survey
description: THE foundations of memorable television advertising - emotion, humor and fancy production - have little impact in print advertising, a consumer survey by a leading independent research group found.

title: Five Years After Settlement, Agent Orange War Lives On
description: Five years after the $180 million settlement in the case brought by thousands of Vietnam veterans and their survivors against the makers of the herbicide Agent Orange, the outcome of the complex civil case is still being criticized by veterans and undergoing scrutiny by the legal community.

title: If Radiation Were the Color and Texture of Oil; A Birth on L.I.
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S.-Taiwan Negotiations Stalled
description: Officials of the United States and Taiwan failed to reach agreement today on trade differences after five days of talks in which the Americans urged the Taiwanese to liberalize import practices even further.

title: WPP Tells Ogilvy It Will Raise Offer
description: The bitter battle between two of the world's leading marketing communications companies intensified during the weekend when the WPP Group P.L.C., the British parent of the J. Walter Thompson advertising agency, told the Ogilvy Group Inc. that it would raise its bid for the company.

title: Circadian Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Long-Distance Event That's Not So Lonely
description: ONE day several years ago, Chris Turney, a collegiate long-distance runner, went to watch an event called ride and tie, and it quickly piqued his curiosity.

title: Commercial International reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-After a gain of $148,000 from cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Separate Paths of Pain Lead to Abortion Clinic
description: In the moments before her abortion, the 16-year-old girl held her boyfriend's hand and talked of plans to be a doctor when she grew up. Soon this unpleasant day would be over, she said, her parents none the wiser, and she could return to the routines of high school and friends.

title: Sequent Computer Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $386,000 and $160,000 for the latest and year- ago periods, respectively.

description: b-Included extraordinary gains of $14,934 for the quarter and $44,801 for the 9 months. c-Included extraordinary gains of $56,650 and $135,268 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Roto-Rooter reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting change of $282,000.

title: Treasury Refunding Begins Tomorrow
description: The Treasury's largest financing of the quarter begins tomorrow with traders expecting interest rates of close to 9 percent for all three new issues of notes and bonds totaling $28.75 billion.

title: Tax Watch; States to Collect Mail-Order Taxes
description: CONSUMERS who shop at catalogue stores like L. L. Bean Inc. and Lands' End Inc., in part because no state sales taxes are collected on their purchases, may be in for a shock later this year. In an aggressive move to increase revenues, state governments are taking action to collect sales taxes from mail-order retailers.

title: CHARGES OF FRAUD MAR PANAMA VOTE
description: LEAD: The opposition claimed a pattern of fraud throughout the country today as Panamanians voted in unexpectedly large numbers in a national election that became the cornerstone of the American effort to oust Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega as Panama's real leader.

title: Their Trade Outrages - and Ours
description: The United States plays plenty unfair in foreign trade but you'd never know it from the sanctimonious attack that Washington is about to launch against the ''unfair'' trade restrictions of other countries. It's a dangerous strategy that risks more restrictions, not fewer - and a global recession. The best course against such foreign offenses is more parry, less thrust.

title: Quake in California
description: A mild earthquake was felt in Southern California Saturday night but there were no immediate reports of injury or property damage, the authorities said. The quake came at 11:07 P.M. and measured 3.7 on the Richter scale of ground motion and released energy, said Robert O'Rourke, a spokesman for the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. The temblor was centered one mile northwest of Brea.

title: 20 Die and 100 Are Wounded in Beirut Shelling
description: More than 30 hours of intense shelling in both sectors of the Lebanese capital left 20 people dead and about 100 others wounded, the police said today.

title: Soviet Army, Exiting, Says, 'Come Visit'
description: Bringing a touch of its new openness to the normally secretive Western front, the Soviet Union today let several dozen reporters onto a tank base to watch preparations for the withdrawal of some of its forces from Eastern Europe.

title: Softsel Computer Products reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Gunman Killed in Kansas Store
description: A gunman described as mentally disturbed was killed and a police officer was wounded today when gunfire erupted at a crowded Wal-Mart store. The police went to the store after receiving reports that an armed man was threatening to harm himself or others.

title: 20th Century Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
At Home, Wright Girds For Capitol Fight Ahead
description: Speaker of the House Jim Wright visibly brightened as he flew home to Fort Worth the other night; he brightened at the Texas businessmen who came to shake his hand and he beamed at the constituents who waved and smiled.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Press; News Companies Test Foreign Waters, but Only With a Toe
description: EVEN the largest American newspaper companies have generally considered themselves local businesses, and have limited their horizons for growth to this country's borders. But some newspaper companies are now gingerly dipping their toes into foreign markets or expanding their existing investments abroad.

title: Kerkhoff Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Included tax credits of $33,000 for the quarter and $429,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Research Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Dance; How a Little Troupe Grew
description: The little company just grew. As its name implies, 3's Company and Dancers was founded by three dancers. But since its debut in 1974, this San Diego troupe has gradually expanded, and on Saturday night it brought 10 dancers to New York and the Merce Cunningham Studio in works by its current directors, Jean Isaacs and Nancy McCaleb.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Citicorp named Michael B. Kelland group executive in charge of its Latin American investment bank, based in Sao Paulo, Brazil.

title: Diving; American Wins a Gold Medal
description: Mark Lenzi, a junior at Indiana University, continued his rapid climb as a world-class diver by winning the men's 1-meter springboard event today as the FINA World Diving Cup ended.

title: Bush Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Dr. Feit, Endrocrinologist, Weds Alan Lourie, Lawyer
description: Dr. Helen Feit, the chief of endocrinology at the Philadelphia Geriatric Center and an assistant professor of medicine at the Medical College of Pennsylvania, was married yesterday to Alan Ira Lourie, an associate in the Philadelphia law firm of Michael Steiman. Rabbi Sheila Weinberg officiated at Congregation Beth Am Israel in Penn Valley, Pa.

title: Medical Graphics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Canseco's Wrist Is Injured Again
description: Jose Canseco reinjured his left wrist today on the second day of his rehabilitation assignment with the Huntsville Stars, the Oakland Athletics' Class AA farm team.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Quayle Sets His Own Pace on Tour Of Lands in East Asia and the Pacific
description: As Vice President Dan Quayle took off from Bangkok on Thursday, he felt good.

title: Corralling the Audiences, Cowboy and Other
description: How do you lasso the urban cowboy and pull him into the theater - the Orpheum Theater, to be precise?

title: Quake in Remote China Area
description: A strong earthquake rocked a remote region of China near the Burmese border early today, toppling homes and cracking streets, the official New China News Agency said. The quake, measuring 6.3 on the open-ended Richter Scale, was centered in Hepai and Sipaishan in the southwestern province of Yunnan. No deaths or injuries were reported.

title: Chaparral Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Publishers Experiment With Lower Prices
description: Bantam Books this week is shipping to bookstores almost 100,000 copies of ''Creature,'' a 329-page horror novel by John Saul. A hardcover novel of that length would normally carry a retail price of $18.95. But to entice Mr. Saul's large paperback audience to buy his book in hard cover, Bantam has priced it at $12.95.

title: Saztec International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Race May Skip a Cycle
description: The Coors International Bicycle Classic, America's premier cycling race, may not be held this year, its owner-director said. And if the race is run it will have another name and sponsor. But he said that in any event he was confident the race would be run next year.

title: On the Day After, Circle of Confusion
description: It was easier this morning to sweep away the tons of garbage from the Churchill Downs infield than the confusion and disappointment surrounding Saturday's peculiar 115th running of the Kentucky Derby.

title: Ryan, Beck & Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Outdoors: Pursuing Black Bass With a Fly Rod
description: TROUT are their classic quarry, but some enlightened freshwater fly fishermen have learned that the black basses, both smallmouth and largemouth, are also a delight to catch.

title: Janet Kollek Wed To David Evans
description: Janet Kollek and David R.H. Evans were married yesterday on board the motor yacht Salisa M berthed on the Hudson River. Rabbi Joel M. Goor officiated.

title: Lendl Teaches Agassi a Thing or Two
description: The twinge Andre Agassi felt in his back on Saturday could have very well been a case of growing pains. After persevering in a succession of three-set matches in the Eagle Tournament of Champions, the 19-year-old tennis Bon Jovi discovered yesterday that there is more that separates him from Ivan Lendl than the distance from baseline to baseline on the green clay courts at Forest Hills.

title: Harcourt Loss Widens
description: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich Inc. said Friday that its loss widened to $116.1 million in the first quarter from a $35.3 million loss in the period a year ago. Revenue rose 14 percent, to $315.5 million, froi $276.7 million a year earlier. Losses increased largely because of rising interest rates on the company's debt and higher marketing costs for new products in the schooh publishing division. The losses were offset by better performances in the coipany's amusement park and insurance businesses, Harcourt said.

title: Jury Deadlock Brings Mistrial For Principal
description: The trial of Matthew Barnwell, the Bronx elementary school principal whose arrest on a drug charge touched off an investigation into corruption in the city's community school boards, ended in a mistrial yesterday when the jury declared that it could not reach a verdict.

title: IPL Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Jane Silfen Marries
description: Jane Leslie Silfen and John Richard Goldman, 1985 graduates of the University of Michigan who received law degrees from Yeshiva University in 1988, were married last evening at the Century Country Club in Purchase, N.Y. Rabbi Daniel Wolk officiated. Mrs. Goldman, a daughter of Martin E. Silfen and Norma L. Silfen, both of New York, is an associate in the New York law firm of Silfen & Glasser, where her father is a partner. Mr. Goldman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert S. Goldman of Rye, N.Y., is an associate in the New York law firm of Herrick Feinstein. His father retired as the president of Morrison's Stores, a family-owned chain of 26 women's clothing stores in New York, Connecticut and the Middle West.

title: Citicorp Bill-Paying Plan
description: Citicorp Global Payment Products will offer an electronic payment service to utilities, enabling consumers to pay bills by directly transferring money from their checking accounts. Called Zapcheck, the service will be offered to electric, gas, water, sewer, telephone and cable television companies, with the cost based on the volume of payments processed. Under Zapcheck, money will be transferred on a set date each month from the customer's checking account to the utility by Citibank in New York.

title: Elizabeth Taylor, Reporter, Is Wed To James Kaplan
description: Elizabeth Taylor, a correspondent in Chicago for Time magazine, was married there yesterday to James Kaplan, a partner in the Chicago law firm of Altheimer & Gray. Rabbi Arnold Wolf officiated at Spiaggia, a restaurant.

title: Reviews/Music; A Sniff of 1930's Romance In a Budapest Parfumerie
description: ''She Loves Me,'' Jerry Bock and Sheldon Harnick's jewel box of a musical about the amorous shenanigans in a Budapest cosmetics shop in 1930, is a show ideally suited to the resources of the Opera Ensemble of Manhattan.

title: Suspect in Officer's Shooting Surrenders at Church
description: A former security guard sought in the shooting of an undercover police officer turned himself in to the authorities yesterday afternoon, ending a two-day manhunt.

title: For West Bank Arabs, Education Has Been Deemed a Criminal Act
description: Every day, hundreds of Bir Zeit University students disguise their textbooks, talk their way through army checkpoints and sneak off to secret classes in church basements, clubs and professors' homes.

title: Prosperity From Asia Has West In Conflict
description: On the Olympic Peninsula west of here, news of the two biggest economic transactions in the area's history might have been greeted by parades in the chronically depressed region. Instead, the new Japanese owners of the area's largest paper mill and a resort site are being snubbed as colonial masters by some longtime residents.

title: Swank Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and included a $243,000 loss from discontinued operations.

title: Scientist Says Budget Office Altered His Testimony
description: The White House's Office of Management and Budget has changed the text of testimony scheduled to be delivered to Congress by a top Government scientist, over his protests, making his conclusions about the effects of global warming seem less serious and certain than he intended.

description: Latest first quarter results included an aftertax title loss provision of about $2.6 million.

title: Apogee Robotics reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Nuvision Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Sales represent systemwide sales.

title: Up in the Air (60 Feet High) For 2 1/2 Hours
description: While trapped for two-and-a-half hours inside a carnival ride, suspended upside down 60 feet in the air, Tracy Burgher of Queens felt cold, bruised and scared. But what hurt worse, the Far Rockaway teen-ager said, was that afterward no one from the carnival said they were sorry.

title: Not-So-Equal Coaching
description: A not so funny thing happened to women on the way to athletic equality with men. They lost about half the coaching positions they held before the drive for parity began.

title: CDN Home Shopping Network Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income Year-ago figures are restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Tokyo Journal; Tired of Politics as Usual, She's Ready, as Usual
description: With a confident voice and a jab of her hand, Takako Doi sounds and looks persuasive when condemning the ''money and greed'' in national politics. Less certain is whether the Japanese political world is prepared for the leadership of Miss Doi.

title: Karen M. Lawson Wed To Lawrence S. Karpen
description: The wedding of Karen Megrail Lawson, a daughter of Nancy Lawson and Dr. Edgar Lawson, both of Charlottesville, Va., to Lawrence Steven Karpen, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sanford Karpen of Bayside, Queens, took place yesterday in a Quaker ceremony at the Shelley Ridge Lodge in Philadelphia. Mrs. Karpen graduated from George Washington University and the Family Institute of Philadelphia. Mr. Karpen, a magna cum laude graduate of the State University at Albany, received a Ph.D. degree in clinical psychology from St. Louis University. Both are in private practice in Philadelphia, she as a family therapist and he as a psychologist.

title: National League; Giants Beat Cards; Mitchell Belts 11th
description: Don Robinson scattered nine hits and hit a home run run today, and Kevin Mitchell added his 11th homer as the San Francisco Giants beat the St. Louis Cardinals, 5-1.

title: Medalist Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $44,000.

title: Arafat Denounces Iranian's Call For Revenge Killing of Westerners
description: Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, today denounced an Iranian leader's call for the killing of Westerners in retaliation for Palestinian deaths in the Israeli-occupied territories.

title: The W.H.O.'s Health, and the P.L.O.
description: There's a chance that the World Health Organization this week will vote to admit the Palestine Liberation Organization as a member ''state.'' If that happens, Washington warns that it will protest by not paying its annual dues of $73 million, a fourth of the W.H.O.'s budget. These moves would cripple a useful agency - without any advance in the P.L.O. quest to regain the West Bank and Gaza Strip.

title: Empire of Carolina reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said a decline in the value of its marketable securities resulted in a loss from investment income of $7.3 million for the latest quarter, compared with a loss of $2.6 million a year earlier.

description: The company said second quarter results included Thermco Systems, which was acquired on Dec. 15, 1988.

title: Miami Backers Hail North Speech
description: Oliver L. North attacked Congress before a cheering crowd of supporters Saturday, saying too many members of Congress interfere in foreign affairs. But he avoided any mention of his recent conviction on three felony charges.

title: Dallas and Fort Worth Mayors Win; Ex-Mayor Takes San Antonio
description: The Mayors of Dallas and Fort Worth easily won re-election Saturday and San Antonio's former Mayor regained her office by a commanding margin.

Official Expects PEN To Admit Soviet Group
description: International PEN is expected to admit a recently formed Soviet chapter this week in a move that would open the writers' group to artists from the Soviet Union for the first time in 65 years.

title: Black Bass in the Northeast
description: New York has an abundance of black bass waters. Fully exploring the bass fishing in just the Thousand Islands area of the St. Lawrence River would take half a lifetime. New York's general black bass season opens June 17 and closes Nov. 30; the daily bag limit is five fish, minimum length 12 inches. Exceptions are listed in the regulations guide provided to the purchaser of a fishing license.

The bride is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Cioffoletti of Tuckahoe, N.Y. Mr. Sadoff is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Elliot Sadoff of the Bronx.

description: The California Supreme Court ruling upholding the main provisions of a sweeping insurance-reform initiative has generated a bitter debate over what constitutes a fair profit for insurance companies.

title: Market Place; Tenneco Deals Called Unlikely
description: TENNECO INC. was a favored punching bag on Wall Street a year ago, branded as a lumbering conglomerate that was too tolerant of losses in an age of leaner, sharper competitors. The company answered with fireworks last October, auctioning its huge oil and gas properties for $7.6 billion in cash and then quickly spending $1 billion to buy 21 million of its shares and paring debt by $4 billion.

title: Bass Runs All Over The Mets
description: He had reached base with apparent ease, run with complete impunity and scored runs with a more than sufficient regularity. Kevin Bass, though, was not about to speak with anything but respect afterward.

WASHINGTON TALK: CONGRESS
description: One member of Congress says he can't seem to get himself out of bed in the morning. Another sits up late at night talking with his wife about how rotten things are at work.

title: Nabisco Bonds Coming to Market
description: The ''junk bond'' market, beset by worries about a slowing economy, is facing a record-sized array of new high-yield securities for RJR Nabisco Inc. this week, investors and underwriters said. The bonds are expected to total nearly $4 billion.

title: Review/Television; 'U.S. and Philippines': History and Duty
description: From the defeat of Spain in ''the splendid little war'' that brought the United States possession of the Philippines around the turn of the century, to Gen. Douglas MacArthur's redeemed promise of World War II, ''I shall return,'' the prevailing policy toward those whom William Howard Taft called ''our little brown brothers'' has mixed paternalism with profit.

title: A Health-Care Taboo Is Broken
description: Facing at least $5 billion in employee medical costs this year, many automobile industry executives acknowledge that their efforts to control costs have failed, and they are calling for drastic changes in the way the nation pays for health care.

title: Reviews/Music; A Soprano Quits After She Is Booed
description: The Italian soprano Katia Ricciarelli quit La Scala opera house today after having been being booed in her first performance there in four years.

title: Squash Titles on the Line
description: As sports go, squash racquets has never exerted mass appeal. So to help assure a large turnout for the 57th world professional championships, which begin in Manhattan today, the organizers have been concentrating on some satellite attractions.

title: Rollins Environmental Servces Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures reflect a 5-for-4 common stock split in September.
