description: b-Included a tax credit of $534,000. c-Included a loss on early extinguishment of debt of $6,594,000. The company said there were no extraordinary items in the year-ago third quarter.

title: Mountain Sickness a Sneaky Ailment
description: THE main problem with altitude sickness is that most people don't recognize that they have it. The symptoms are usually mild and may resemble flu or some other short-term illness. But a recent study that explores acute altitude, or mountain, sickness indicates that one out of every four people get ill when they go 6,000 feet or more above sea level.

title: O'Connor Didn't Boast of Stopping Cuomo Run
description: To the Editor:

title: Stimulant Said to Ease Problems From AIDS
description: A psychiatric researcher says the mental and emotional troubles caused by AIDS virus infections eased after patients in a new study took the anti-hyperactivity drug Ritalin.

title: Mudd Is Winner In Playoff at Nelson
description: Jodie Mudd rolled in a 12-foot birdie putt on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff today and defeated Larry Nelson to capture the Byron Nelson Classic.

title: Testimony on North May Be Used Against Others
description: Witnesses in the trial of Oliver L. North provided damaging testimony likely to be used against John M. Poindexter, the former national security adviser, and three other men awaiting trial in the Iran-contra affair, Government officials say.

title: Applied Biosystems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sports of The Times; Some Questions About the Pete Rose Dossier
description: THIS may or may not be the week that was.

title: Question Box
description: Rookies Enshrined Q. How many National Basketball Association players have been voted both rookie of the year and into the Basketball Hall of Fame? A. Since the inception of the award 36 years ago, nine former players can list both honors on their resumes, with five other former rookies of the year considered shoo-ins for enshrinement when eligible. The following is the list of players voted best among the rookie crop and the cream of the pro crop, along with their rookie seasons, their team and their year of enshrinement in parentheses:

title: CFS Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $14,000 for the latest quarter and $24,000 for year- earlier period. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: 7 Years Into Term, Kean Finds the Honeymoon Is Over
description: Times have turned sour for Gov. Thomas H. Kean. As budget woes increasingly define his last year in office, politicians and academics question whether Mr. Kean, despite great popularity at home and national stature, can accomplish any of his major remaining goals.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Monday None Tuesday None Wednesday None Thursday Retail Sales ... April Friday Producer Prices ... April Business Inventories ... April

title: Nursed Back to the Top
description: To be named top dog at the Westminster Kennel Club show at Madison Square Garden takes generations of proper breeding, a lifetime of meticulous grooming and training, and days of intense preparation.

title: Bridge
description: If your partner is playing well, there is a temptation to overbid a little when you are about to be dummy. North carried this principle a little too far on the diagramed deal and landed South in a ''hopeless'' slam.

title: Review/Music; Thoughts on the Final Cast As the 'Ring' Cycle Closes
description: Assembling the various casts for this spring's ''Ring'' cycles at the Metropolitan Opera has been a ponderous exercise in international logistics. The final configuration for the season came together last week when Wagner's four operas were played on Monday, Tuesday, Thursday and Saturday nights.

title: TV Notes
description: Hunter's Future

title: Susan R. Sklar Married
description: At Temple B'nai Abraham in Livingston, N.J., Susan Rebecca Sklar, the daughter of Kathryn K. Sklar of Brackney, Pa., and Robert A. Sklar of New York, was married yesterday to Aryeh Lev Friedman, the son of Rabbi and Mrs. Barry Friedman of South Orange, N.J. The bridegroom's father and Rabbi Chaim Freed officiated. The bride, a graduate of the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University, is a film editor in New York. The bridegroom, an appraiser at James Felt Realty Services in New York, graduated from Yeshiva University.

title: Greyhound Lines of Canada Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Argentina's inflation rate was 33.4 percent in April, according to official figures released Friday. The figures do not reflect the fact that prices of items like flour and sugar have doubled or trebled in the last few weeks. Private economists predict that the consumer price index could rise 50 percent in May, exceeding the record of 42.23 percent set in March 1976.

title: A SOVIET GENERAL SEES AFGHAN CHIEF
description: In a development that appeared to reflect the growing military strains facing the Government, the Soviet Embassy announced today that a high-ranking Soviet military officer made a four-day visit here last week for talks with civilian and military leaders.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Saturday incorrectly described the planned flight of the Magellan spacecraft. Although the orbits of Venus and the Earth are only 26 million miles apart, the spacecraft will travel 795 million miles, passing around the Sun, before it reaches Venus.

title: Santa Fe Loses Round in Court
description: The Santa Fe Pacific Corporation said Friday that a United States District Court judge had denied its motions to set a new trial and to overturn a $1.04 billion jury award against it in the coal slurry case involving Energy Transportation Systems Inc.

title: In Mexico City, Music for a Cause
description: It has become one of the longest running, most popular shows in Mexico, and you don't even need a ticket to get in. For weeks now, dissident members of the local musicians' union have been performing at the busiest intersection of the Mexican capital, protesting, in the way they know best, what they say is ''the lack of democracy'' in their union.

title: Hungary Deal For 13 Banks
description: Thirteen Western European banks have paid $110 million for 49.65 percent of Hungary's leading lighting company. The banks plan eventually to list the company's shares on Western stock exchanges, in the first such offering of its kind. Shares in the company, Tungsram, were bought from the Hungarian Credit Bank Ltd. The banks were led by Austria's Girozentrale und Bank der Oesterreichischen Sparkassen and included Credit Lyonnais, Banque Nationale de Paris and Deutsche Bank Luxembourg.

title: QMS Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $195,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $753,000 for the 6 months.

title: Hilton Head Journal; Island Residents to Vote On Slowing Its Growth
description: In the late 1950's, when development began on this barrier island, the idea was to create the ideal community: An exclusive, thoroughly planned private enclave that would blend seamlessly into the marshes and dense forest of the island.

title: Green Questions Himself in Loss
description: Today, the Yankees ran out of comebacks. They had won two games in two nights with late-inning home runs, but there was nothing left, so they returned home tonight with a 6-2 loss to the Chicago White Sox and with Manager Dallas Green questioning himself.

title: Showboat Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $1,484,000 from an accounting change.

title: Enterra Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
N.H.L. Playoffs; Canadiens Get 3-1 Series Lead
description: When the game ended, the Canadiens took an instant too long in congratulating each other following yet another shutout against the Flyers, and the Flyer fans did what their team had been unable to do: They attacked them.

title: Finding the Funds to Produce Public TV
description: Producing a film series for public television, said Stanley Karnow, the journalist and film maker, reminded him of a line from the comic strip ''Popeye.''

title: Leader in Cult Slayings Ordered Own Death, Two Companions Say
description: The leader of a drug-smuggling cult that is believed to have killed 15 people and buried their bodies along the United States-Mexican border ordered his own killing when the police closed in on him, two of his companions said today.

title: Self-Defeating Feminism
description: LEAD: It used to be the claim of feminists that women should be permitted - indeed encouraged - to do anything they are willing and able to do, that they seek no special privileges but only the opportunities available to men, that they want only to be judged by the same standards as men.

title: Dopson Finds A Home
description: Changing cities and leagues has turned it around for John Dopson.

title: Boom! Bang! Waking Up to Tour de Trump
description: GOOD MORNING, honeymooners. Before you order Sunday brunch, before you peek out the window much earlier than you planned to, you should know the source of that unsolicited wake-up call.

title: U.S. AND RUSSIANS WORKING TOGETHER IN EXPLORING SPACE
description: American and Soviet space officials and scientists are quietly collaborating on the exploration of the planets, taking advantage of warmer political relations to arrange exchanges of researchers, data and flight instruments between the two nations.

title: In Brazil, Terror, Crime and Old-Time Politics
description: Why are the golden youths of Ipanema beach laboring weekends for Lula, the presidential candidate of Brazil's left-wing Workers Party?

title: Door Blows Off Conrail Train And Picks Up One Passenger
description: The door of a traveling freight train blew off, swooped up a Brooklyn man standing in a glass booth at the Beacon station and dumped both about 25 feet down the tracks, the police said today.

title: Guest Shot to Death At a Basement Party
description: A party guest was shot and killed early yesterday morning when someone fired a semiautomatic weapon into a basement full of people attending a farewell party.

title: House Feud Prompts Cheers Instead of Jeers
description: On the 51-member House Banking Committee, everyone is buzzing about it privately, few are willing to discuss it openly and the consensus is that it may be the best thing that has happened to the panel in years.

title: Corrections
description: A story on Wednesday about an affirmative-action plan at The Columbia Law Review misidentified the ethnic background of several students who had initially expressed opposition to the plan. The students are Asian-Americans.

title: Argentine Military Junta Leader Is Out of Jail
description: A former commander of the Argentine Air Force, Orlando Ramon Agosti, was released from prison today after completing his sentence for torture of political prisoners during the 1976-83 military regime.

title: State Companies Thrive in France
description: The notion that every nationalized company is stodgy, bloated and unimaginative runs into a wall in France.

title: Susie Berg Waldman, 66, Writer and Editor
description: Susie Berg Waldman, a writer and editor, died of bone cancer and pneumonia Sunday at New York University Hospital in Manhattan. She was 66 years old and lived in Riverdale.

title: Echo Bay Mines Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Scor US Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $12,286 gain from utilization of net operating loss carryforward by an affiliate. The company said operating income for the first quarter of 1988 had been restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: Robert Thomases, Educator, 71
description: Robert Thomases, an educator and former director of a camp for disturbed children, died Thursday at his home in Rhinebeck, N.Y. He was 71 years old.

title: Nortek Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-Included income of $500,000 and $1,100,000 from discontinued operations for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively, and gains of $1,250,000 and $2,650,000 for the same periods, respectively, from the retirement of debt. c-Net income Year-ago first quarter results also included a loss of $1,150,000 from the reduction in the company's investment in a business sold in the second quarter of 1988 and a net gain of $900,000 from the sale of operating facilities.

title: Martin L. Mellman, 69, Is Dead; Led Democrats in Nassau County
description: Martin L. Mellman, the former chairman of the Nassau County Democratic Party, died of undetermined causes Friday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 69 years old and lived in Port Washington.

title: British Fusion Effort Fails
description: Britain's top atomic energy laboratory said today it had failed to generate large amounts of energy by nuclear fusion at room temperature, despite the cooperation of a chemist who played a major role in a claim last month that such fusion had been achieved. The announcement dampened hopes of finding a cheap and limitless source of energy.

title: Artificial Intelligence
description: THE ''AI Catalog'' from Thinking Software is a wonderful potpourri of programs for all personal computer users, from the rawest beginner to the experienced DOS jockey, including those who are just out for a good time.

title: Borden Withdraws Products in 2 States After Taint Is Found
description: Borden Inc., the world's largest dairy company, said it pulled its products from shelves in Mississippi and Louisiana today after finding milk with traces of a toxic substance from contaminated feed.

title: Bob Cooke, Sports Editor, 75
description: Bob Cooke, the sports editor of The New York Herald Tribune from 1945-65, died Sunday. He was 75 years old.

title: Unicorp American Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter results included a pretax gain of $9 million recorded on the sale of three properties and the results of the Lincoln Savings Bank FSB.

title: First Johns Hopkins Loss Makes Syracuse No. 1
description: In the rain and mud at Towson, Md., last Saturday night, the Johns Hopkins team's grasp at an undefeated season fell one goal short. The Tigers of Towson State upset the Blue Jays, 9-8, when Glenn Smith's shot at 12 seconds of the second overtime period went past Quint Kessenich, the Blue Jays' all-America goalie.

title: Study Rejects Requiring School Bus Seat Belts
description: The National Research Council, in a report commissioned by Congress, today recommended against requiring seat belts in school buses. It said the potential safety benefits, saving one life a year, were not worth the cost, estimated at $40 million annually.

title: Precambrian Shield Reources Ltd reports earnings for
description: The company said some year- earlier figures have been restated. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: British Oil Output Drop
description: British North Sea oil output this month could drop to its lowest level in a decade because of offshore accidents, allowing Norway to move into the top spot in Western Europe's monthly production table for the first time since 1976. Gareth Lewis-Davies, an analyst at Woodmac, a brokerage that specializes in the study of North Sea oil developments, said the drop in British ouput was temporary and caused largely by the closing of the Brent pipeline system on April 18 after a gas explosion.

title: Spending Is Catching Up With Revenue for Cities
description: Cities and counties in the United States are increasing their spending faster than their income is rising, according to two new Census Bureau reports.

title: SWISS HALT PLANS FOR PLANT IN IRAN
description: A Swiss company has abandoned its plans to build a chemical plant in Iran that American officials feared could be used to make poison gas, Swiss officials say.

title: Work by Marc Chagall Sets Record at Auction
description: Marc Chagall's ''Violinist With the World Upside Down,'' from 1929, was sold last night for $4.6 million, a record at auction for the artist, in an auction held by Habsburg, Feldman, a Geneva-based auction house. The work was sold to the Fujii Gallery of Tokyo, Pablo Picasso's ''Dream,'' from 1932, which was bought for $6.3 million by an American collector who was not identified, was the highest price of the sale, held at the Regency Hotel in Manhattan. The auction, which totaled $26.3 million, offered 57 paintings, of which 19 did not sell.

title: New Methods Fuel Efforts To Decode Human Genes
description: EVEN while the huge project is still being debated and organized, researchers are making major technical advances that will speed the mapping and analysis of the entire human genetic apparatus.

title: Public Shop Or Private, What's Best?
description: The battle by the publicly held Ogilvy Group to remain independent in the face of a hostile bid by the WPP Group has sparked a debate in the advertising industry about the relative merits of public versus private ownership of agencies. Publicly held agencies, including the WPP Group, say that only public ownership can provide the resources necessary for growth, even if it makes an agency vulnerable to market pressures. Private agencies say that only they are free to serve clients without outside interference. Several agency and corporate executives discussed this issue yesterday. Clay S. Timon Vice president and director of worldwide advertising, Colgate-Palmolive

title: Cuomo, Leaving Funding Vague, Vows to Expand Fight on Crime
description: Calling for an ''all-out, all fronts fight'' against crime in New York City, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo yesterday proposed a major expansion of the state and city criminal justice systems, including additional police, probation officers and prison cells.

title: Bridge
description: One North American team to go the World Championships in Perth, Australia in September will be decided in Memphis next week. But another has already secured its place in the tournament.

title: Stanford Journal; New Campus Test: Computer Voting
description: The cover of the official handbook for the election of officers of the Associated Students of Stanford University features a drawing of a personal computer gleefully stomping on a ballot box stuffed with old-fashioned paper ballots.

title: La Teko Resources Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $107,000 from debt retirement for both periods. c-Included an extroardinary gain of $1,459,000 from debt retirement.

title: Parlex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a loss of $511,044 from discontinued operations. c-Included losses of $105,354 and $178,670 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Latest period results included results of Parlex Nevada Inc., which was formed Feb. 1, 1988, while the year-ago period results included only two months of operations from Parlex Nevada.

title: Fires Kill Two Adults And Two Children
description: Fire sped through a three-story house in Queens early yesterday, killing two young sisters, and two men died in a Manhattan fire that fire officials said might have stemmed from drug use. The fires left 44 people homeless. In the Queens fire, Harjindar Kaur, 6 years old, and her sister, Kamaljit Kaur, 11, died when fire gutted the house they lived in at 94-17 41st Avenue in Corona, a Fire Department spokesman, Efrain Parrilla, said.

title: For East Harlem Teen-Agers, Posses Mean Violence
description: In East Harlem, in an area of broad streets and red-brick high-rises just north and east of the green canopy of Central Park, street violence is as much a part of growing up as listening to rap music, teen-agers say: it has its own rhythms, and it is everywhere.

title: Mark Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: In the latest first quarter, net income equalled less than one cent a share. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Bankeno Resources Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said in both the latest and year-ago first quarters, after preferred-share dividends, there were no earnings applicable to common shares. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Moe Goldman, Ex-Basketball Player, 75
description: Moe Goldman, a standout basketball player at City College who later played professionally with the Philadelphia Sphas, died Sunday. He was 75 years old.

title: FINANCE/NEW ISSUES;
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, priced $850 million of short-term fixed- and floating-rate notes yesterday that will be offered to the public through various securities dealers.

title: 4th Man's Trial Starts In Killing of Officer
description: The fourth man charged with the execution-style murder of a rookie police officer in Queens went on trial yesterday after his lawyer failed in a last-minute effort to delay the trial because of publicity from court proceedings against the other three.

description: Bicycle Days By John Burnham Schwartz 253 pages. Summit Books. $18.95.

title: Rig Count Up in Week
description: The oil and gas rig count rose last week by 13, to a total of 764, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. A week earlier, the number of working oil and gas rigs had fallen by 16, the company said. A year ago, the count totaled 897. The count, a widely watched industry index of drilling activity, reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil as of last Friday.

title: Smithsonian Pact Will Move Indian Collection to Capital
description: An agreement to transfer the world's largest collection of Indian artifacts from the Museum of the American Indian in New York City to the Smithsonian Institution was signed today by the secretary of the Smithsonian.

title: Anthony Posillipo, 81, Former Rye Supervisor
description: Anthony J. Posillipo, the former supervisor of the Town of Rye in Westchester County, died of pulmonary edema Saturday at United Hospital in Port Chester, N.Y. He was 81 years old and lived in Port Chester.

title: Victory in Overtime Gives Flames 3-1 Lead
description: Al MacInnis broke a 1-1 tie 15 minutes 5 seconds into the overtime period tonight to give the Calgary Flames a three-games-to-one lead over the Chicago Blackhawks in the Campbell Conference finals. Game 5 of the Stanley Cup semifinal playoff series will be in Calgary on Wednesday night.

title: Brilliance and Recklessness Seen in Fusion Collaboration
description: THE two chemists who started a scientific furor by claiming to have achieved low-temperature fusion in a jar of water may not be widely known, but friends and acquaintances say they are a fascinating pair with unique strengths and weaknesses.

title: Barrington Petroleum Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: A Memo to James Baker
description: LEAD: Dear Secretary Baker, The first encounter between a new administration and a Soviet leader is always fateful and too often the source of grave misunderstanding. If you follow the briefing books prepared by the State Department for your meeting this week with Soviet leader Mikhail Gorbachev you may well repeat that sad history as well as abdicate leadership of the

title: Herman's Ads Go to Saatchi
description: Herman's Sporting Goods Inc. took its first steps into television advertising yesterday, and Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising was the beneficiary. A Saatchi spokesman estimated that the account would be worth $15 million in annual billings.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Home Section on April 27 about the Ceremonial Court exhibition at the Smithsonian Institution Museum of American History omitted the names of the artists who executed trompe l'oeil murals in the exhibition. They were Tania Vartan, William Graf, James Childs and Pierce Rice.

title: Ex-Mayor of Wayne Gets 33 Months in Jail
description: Louis V. Messercola, the former Mayor of Wayne, N.J., was sentenced yesterday to 33 months in prison for trying to extort $50,000 from a developer, and a Government sentencing report revealed that he had a history of abusing power.

title: Penguin Official Leaves
description: The Pittsburgh Penguins' assistant general manager, Eddie Johnston, said yesterday he was leaving the club to look for another job in hockey.

title: Coscan Development Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Market Place; Precipitous Drop In Cash Flows
description: CASH flow has become the investment theme of the 1980's. For much of the decade, investors who focused on corporate cash flow, which was growing much more rapidly than reported earnings, were able to turn in a superior performance. Expectations of rising cash flows were a major reason that companies were willing to go deeply into debt to make acquisitions and leveraged buyouts.

title: PATTERNS
description: Decision for Dior

title: Lendl Breezes Past Yzaga, 6-2, 6-1
description: There were suitcases to pack and last-minute details to attend to and even an appointment to keep at Forest Hills before Ivan Lendl boarded a flight to Europe last night where he will spend the next nine weeks in pursuit of the French Open and Wimbledon titles.

title: I.O.C. Official Questions Drug-Testing Method
description: A senior officer of the International Olympic Committee today raised questions over the intent and integrity of drug-testing procedures used by the International Amateur Athletic Federation, the world governing body for track and field.

title: Canadiens Confident Of Eliminating Flyers
description: There is restraint and moderation in their method, and discipline is their password, which is why the Montreal Canadiens aren't chortling just because they are a game away from becoming the Wales Conference representative in the Stanley Cup final.

title: All Seasons Resorts Inc reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: Latest year included a $1,299,000 net gain from restructuring of debt and a tax loss carryforward of $150,000. Prior year included net gain of $53,000 from debt restructuring and a tax credit of $384,000. Sales represents sales of memberships.

description: The Society of Professional Journalists is to honor The Riverdale Press of the Bronx for courage in continuing to publish after the newspaper's offices were firebombed Feb. 28.

Dan Kahn, Columnist, 56
description: Dan Kahn, an advertising writer and columnist for Newsday, died of cancer Sunday at his home in Rockville Centre, L.I. He was 56 years old.

description: Interest and other income for the year-ago 6 months included pretax gains of $395,000 on insurance settlements, $317,000 on the settlement of litigation, and $370,000 on the sale of securities.

North Is Viewed as Misguided
description: A majority of the American people view Oliver North as ''well-meaning but misguided,'' according to a Gallup Poll taken after Mr. North's conviction last week on criminal charges stemming from his role in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Woman Behind the Symbols in Abortion Debate
description: Norma McCorvey sat in a downtown diner here, eating lunch and talking of her life as ''Jane Roe,'' the pseudonym she used in the 1973 Supreme Court case that created a constitutional right to an abortion. In the adjacent booth a young man eavesdropped for awhile, then stood up slowly and approached her table. For a moment, Ms. McCorvey looked frightened.

title: Credit Report Division Reorganized by D.&B.
description: Reacting to customer lawsuits and publicity about claims of improper sales practices in its credit services division, the Dun & Bradstreet Corporation has reorganized its business information group and shuffled some senior executives, including the head of the credit services area.

title: 2 Women Are Stirring Up Politics in Buenos Aires
description: Fighting to keep his place in eight lanes of bumper-to-bumper, side-by-side traffic, the taxi driver gripped the steering wheel and held forth on his dissatisfaction with the choice of presidential candidates in the May 14 elections.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Bolivian presidential election misidentified a candidate. He is Gen. Hugo Banzer Suarez.

description: Latest quarter and year results included a 17 cents a share charge relating to the settlement of a patent infringement suit and a gain of 12 cents a share on the sale of its condom product line.

title: INSIDE
description: New Look at Agent Orange A Federal judge ordered the Veterans Administration to reconsider its policy of denying most Vietnam veterans' claims of harm from Agent Orange. Page A24. Censorship Confirmed The White House said it had censored a Government scientist's testimony on global warming, as Britain called for international action on the problem. Science Times, page C1. Japan and Lost U.S. H-Bomb A hydrogen bomb, lost off an aircraft carrier in 1965, is on the ocean floor 80 miles from a Japanese island, and Japanese are angry. Page A3.
