description: Revenue represents total revenue.

title: Stopping 'Great Scorer' Is Knicks' Top Objective
description: The Chicago Bulls had long felt the need for a low-post center.

title: Bakkers Move Ministry To a Mall in Orlando
description: Jim Bakker relaunched his television ministry today in a nearly deserted shopping center on the outskirts of this central Florida city.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * B. Altman & Co., the retailer, named Barbara Haskett vice president of public relations.

title: Stranded Sailors Rescued
description: The Coast Guard on Sunday rescued 41 sailors stranded on a Bering Sea island for two days after their skiff capsized in rough seas. The crew from the Coast Guard cutter Jarvis used a raft and small boat to shuttle the sailors from St. Matthew Island to their crab-processing ship after harsh weather subsided, Lieut. Jeff Merrell said. Those rescued were reported in good condition. The sailors had been stranded after leaving their ship for a beachcombing trip, the Coast Guard said.

title: Bulls Eager to Take Next Playoff Step
description: Minutes after the Chicago Bulls' heart-stopping playoff victory Sunday, someone asked Doug Collins how he felt. The Bulls' coach was honest; he said he was drained. But he also said he felt a sense of anticipation looking ahead to Chicago's next challenge, the Knicks.

title: 2 Shows on Tony List 10 Times
description: ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway'' and ''Black and Blue'' received 10 nominations each yesterday to lead the race for the 1989 Tony Awards. Ken Ludwig's ''Lend Me a Tenor'' got 7, and Wendy Wasserstein's Pulitzer Prize-winning ''Heidi Chronicles'' and the musical ''Starmites'' each got 6. ''Our Town'' and Bill Irwin's ''Largely New York'' came in with 5, including 3 for Mr. Irwin.

title: Wright Presses Battle on Latest Allegations
description: Speaker of the House Jim Wright, batting aside one allegation of impropriety after another, denied today that he had ever held up legislation in exchange for campaign contributions or taken a free ride on the plane owned by the operator of a chain of nursing homes.

title: Criterion Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a pretax charge of $383,000 from the company's proposed merger with Transamerica Corp.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: First Came the Pharaohs, and Now the Greens
description: Bahaddin Bakri is a Green. He wants Cairo to be clean. He is a man with problems.

title: Johnson Is Top 6th Man
description: Eddie Johnson of the Phoenix Suns, who led all non-starters in the National Basketball Association in scoring with a 21.5 average, yesterday was named the winner of the league's Sixth Man Award. The 6-foot-9-inch Johnson received 33 votes from a nationwide news media panel. Thurl Bailey of Utah was second with 26 votes and Dennis Rodman of Detroit was third with 17. Johnson finished 19th in the league in scoring.

title: Q&A
description: Yawning Q. Why do my mouth and eyes sometimes water when I yawn? A. The American Medical Association says that medical authorities believe the watering of the eyes may result from pressure on the main tear glands, at the outer margins of the eye sockets, because of the facial contortions involved in yawning. The involuntary act of yawning usually includes opening the mouth very wide while slowly taking in a deep breath.

title: Accounts
description: * Crestar Bank, Richmond, to Altschiller Reitzfeld Davis/Tracy-Locke, Richmond, with a budget of $5 million.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES I.B.M. will introduce a series of software programs that will make it possible for desktop computer users to obtain information from a larger mainframe or minicomputer and integrate it into a program on a local machine. The programs, to be introduced next week, are regarded as I.B.M.'s most significant software announcement in years. [ Page D1. ] The strike at Eastern Airlines has provided a textbook example of how adept the airline industry has become at using sophisticated computer programs to sell seats at the highest possible price without appearing to have raised prices and risking public ire. Eastern's rivals have done very well during the strike. [ D1. ] The two major unions at Northwest Airlines are seeking to put themselves into the takeover fight for NWA, the airline's parent. But neither the pilots' nor machinists' union has indicated whether it favors management, Marvin Davis, the first suitor, or one of other possible buyers. [ D1. ] The criminal investigation of trading practices at commodity exchanges in New York is examining whether brokers and traders illegally shared information with each other about customer orders, sources said. Such sharing of information would constitute a conspiracy and would violate Federal laws. [ D1. ] Dun & Bradstreet has reorganized its business information group and shuffled some senior executives, including the head of the credit services area. [ D2. ] Goldman, Sachs is entering the asset management business and has named Leon G. Cooperman to run the operation. [ D5. ] Varity agreed to buy Fruehauf for an estimated $650 million in cash, stock and notes. Varity made two earlier attempts to acquire Fruehauf. [ D5. ] At least 18 insurers have asked the California Insurance Department for exemptions to the state requirement that they roll back rates 20 percent. The insurers say the requirement will impose a hardship on them. [ D8. ] Fairchild agreed to be acquired by Banner for $18 a share in cash, or a total of $265 million. [ D5. ] Avon Products filed a lawsuit seeking to prevent a partnership of Amway and Irwin L. Jacobs from buying more Avon stock [ D5. ] Banc One and Barnett Banks are considering making offers for 20 banks formerly owned by Mcorp, according to one banking consultant in Texas. [ D19. ] Turner Broadcasting said its operating profit rose 24 percent in the first quarter, as revenues climbed 27 percent. [ D22. ] Brant Publications has acquired Interview magazine from the estate of Andy Warhol for a price said to be about $10 million. [ D22. ] MARKETS Stock prices continued their retreat and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 5.49 points, to close at 2,376.47. It was the seventh straight loss for the Dow. [ D10. ] The dollar rose broadly in brisk trading and reached its highest level against the West German mark since August, despite more dollar-selling by the Federal Reserve. [ D20. ] Treasury securities prices fell slightly in light trading despite a drop in oil prices and a surge in the dollar's value. [ D19. ] Crude oil prices fell below $20 a barrel, while unleaded gasoline contracts plunged on the New York Mercantile Exchange. [ D20. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Executives should think like corporate raiders, said Louis L. Brindisi, a senior partner at Strategic Compensation Associates. Talking Business. [ D2. ] Cash flow has become the investment theme of the 1980's. But now there are signs that corporate cash flow is slowing to levels of the 1981-82 recession. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D10. ] The advertising industry is debating the relative merits of public versus private ownership of agencies. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D23. ]

title: Burson's Brace Is Off
description: Doctors in Columbus, Ohio, removed yesterday a traction brace that had held the Ohio State player Jay Burson's head and neck rigid since a neck injury in mid-February cut short his senior season.

title: Ingles Markets reports earnings for Qtr to March 25

BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Computer Sciences Moves To Focus on Private Sector
description: LEAD: The Computer Sciences Corporation, a large Government contractor based in El Segundo, Calif., has created a group to concentrate on the growing demand by corporations to computerize, and has named Thomas P. Gerrity to run it.

title: V. Hall Everson Jr., Executive, 92
description: V. Hall Everson Jr., a former state representative from Greenwich, Conn., for 40 years, died, apparently of a heart attack, Saturday at the Hospital of St. Raphael in New Haven. He was 92 years old and lived in Branford.

title: Stone Is a Big Block In the Yankees' Path
description: The bombs returned to the Bronx last night, but they weren't unleashed by the team that bears no resemblance to its ancestors.

title: Strike at Eastern Cuts Into Discounts
description: The strike at Eastern Airlines has provided a textbook example of how adept the airline industry has become at using sophisticated computer programs to sell seats at the highest possible price without appearing to have raised prices and risking public ire.

title: Economic Watch; Making a Risky Life Bearable: Better Data, Clearer Choices
description: Aflatoxin in corn, alar in apples, bovine growth hormone in milk, cynanide in grapes, faulty wiring in jet aircraft: what Science magazine has labeled ''the scare of the week'' is taking a psychological toll.

title: General Ceramics reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Soviet Author With Strong Feelings About PEN
description: As a short-story writer, Tatyana Tolstaya deals in ambiguities. As a Soviet citizen, she knows how to live with them. ''Things can be good, while also being bad,'' said the 38-year-old great-grandniece of the author of ''War and Peace.'' ''We can understand contradictions.''

title: George Weston Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $37.3 million on the sale of a division. c-Included a gain of $64.3 million on the sale of Interbake Canada. Listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Topping 20 Years of Dance With Even More Dancing
description: There are times when ghosts must be faced and consoled. That is the message of ''To Comfort Ghosts,'' a dance by Dan Wagoner that will be performed tonight through Sunday by Dan Wagoner and Dancers in the company's spring season at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street). And facing his own ghosts is what Mr. Wagoner continues to do on this 20th anniversary of his company, in new dances and with a new post, assumed despite self-doubt, which is to take him to London in August to lead the London Contemporary Dance Theater.

title: Addicts' Children Are Youngest Torture Victims
description: To the Editor:

title: Two Officers At Times Unit
description: The New York Times Company's magazine group announced the appointment of two senior financial executives yesterday. The appointments will take effect July 1, said William T. Kerr, president of the group.

title: Amtech Systems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $9,000 and $102,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included tax credits of $39,000 for the quarter and $60,000 for the 6 months.

title: Ford Raises Prices
description: The Ford Motor Company raised the prices of three car lines and some options because of higher costs for material and labor. Ford said base prices for the Ford Festiva, now about $6,500, would rise 1.7 percent; the Mercury Tracer, now about $8,900, would rise 1.3 percent, and the Lincoln Continental, now about $28,900, would rise 1.5 percent.

title: Voice of America Has Won the Ear of China
description: The real news does not travel fast in this Communist country, at least through official channels. So when the streets here swell with protesters, people all over China tune in the Voice of America.

title: H.U.D. Aide Says Developer Paid Watt $300,000 for Minimal Work
description: The chief investigator in the Department of Housing and Urban Development offered a more detailed account today of what H.U.D. officials have described as widespread influence-peddling by prominent Republicans involved in a Federal housing subsidy program. He said that former Interior Secretary James G. Watt had apparently done ''minimal'' work to earn $300,000 in consulting fees.

title: Dynamic Capital Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: U.S. Appeals Court Rejects Restrictions On Abortion Clinics
description: A Federal appeals court in Boston ruled yesterday that an effort by the Reagan Administration to prevent Federally financed family planning clinics from helping women to obtain abortions was unconstitutional.

title: IPM Technology reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss c-After losses from discontinued operations of $27,000 for the quarter and $51,000 for the 9 months.

title: Crable's Career Ends Because of Knee Injury
description: Bob Crable's injury-plagued career as a Jets linebacker, following his selection as the club's No. 1 draft pick of 1982, has officially ended. A knee injury suffered late in the 1987 season that required surgery and sidelined him all of last year was too much to overcome. The Jets will formally announce the 29-year-old's retirement today at a luncheon unveiling their 1988 highlight film. Crable played in only one full season, 1986.

title: General Metal & Abrasives Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Give Police Big White Front and Back Numbers
description: To the Editor:

title: OIL CONCERNS FACE CHARGE IN INQUIRY
description: Senate investigators contend that some oil companies have cheated Indians and the Interior Department out of millions of dollars of oil and oil royalties.

title: Fairchild Accepts Bid By Banner
description: Surrendering after a five-month struggle to remain independent, Fairchild Industries agreed today to be acquired by Banner Industries for $18 a share in cash, or a total of about $265 million.

title: Circo Craft Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: MGM Grand Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $1,454,000 and $311,000 for the latest and year- ago periods, respectively.

title: Christiana Cos reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included net from discontinued operations of $182,000 for the quarter and $41,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss d-Included losses from discontinued operations of $70,000 and $596,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and the 9 months also included a gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $743,000.

title: Doskocil Cos reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-Included tax credits of $773,000 and $513,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively. The latest quarter results reflect the acquisition of Wilson Foods Corp. in the fourth quarter of 1988.

title: Mets Silenced by Reds in 2d Straight Shutout
description: The pitch was outside, and so Dave Magadan dropped his bat and began to walk toward first base with two out in the seventh inning. Trouble was, it was only the third ball. Magadan, alerted to the fact and then considerably embarrassed by it, had to turn and pick the bat up again. He then promptly struck out.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-17 Election fraud by Panama's military has robbed the opposition of victory, declared former President Jimmy Carter, a leader of an international delegation monitoring Panama's presidential election. Page A1

title: The Romanov Mystery (Continued)
description: LEAD: When Elizabeth II visits the Soviet Union in June, she will be the first British monarch to do so since George V declared 70 years ago, ''I hope that no member of my family will ever shake hands with the murderers of my cousins.''

title: Jersey Long-Shot Links Cities and Suburbs
description: Barbara Boggs Sigmund, a long-shot candidate for the Democratic nomination for governor, is the Mayor of Princeton, a college town that is the silky essence of the suburban dream. But she is basing her quest partly on a belief that the days of the suburban boom are over and that the coming era belongs to the cities.

title: The Six-Letter Word
description: Hundreds of thousands of people march in the streets. The police are pushed back, and a Government shakes in fear of its own citizens.

title: WestAir Holding Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Robins's Net Rises by 12.7%
description: The A. H. Robins Company, the pharmaceutical maker in its fourth year of Chapter 11 bankruptcy reorganization, today reported a 12.7 percent increase in earnings for the first quarter of 1989.

title: Buffets Inc reports earnings for 16wks to April 19
Colleges Welcome Research Gifts but Ask More for Buildings
description: American foundations gave more than $1.6 billion last year to colleges and universities, but the money was mainly for research, and academic leaders say the grants neglected the worsening decay of collegiate buildings and classrooms.

title: Gendex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
N-W Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Elma M . Comer, 71, Brooklyn Psychiatrist
description: Elma M. Comer, a retired Brooklyn psychiatrist, died of emphysema April 16 at her home in Cayuga Heights, N.Y., a suburb of Ithaca. She was 71 years old.

title: I.B.M. Plans Major Move In Software
description: In its most significant software announcement in years, the International Business Machines Corporation will introduce next Tuesday a collection of software programs that will provide the same ''look and feel'' to users of most of its machines, from personal computers to mainframes.

title: Still Limping Along
description: When I criticized President-elect Bush for indecision last December (he had ''hit the ground limping,'' I wrote), the remark was labeled a ''cheap shot.'' Now that Mr. Bush actually is having to face Presidential decisions, it looks more and more like an expensive truth.

title: A Health System That Needs Surgery
description: LEAD: Americans are ready for a major change in the system of financing and delivering health care. The magnitude of their disenchantment is dramatically portrayed in the results of a new health care survey conducted by the Harvard School of Public Health and Louis Harris and Associates.

title: RULE OVERTURNED ON AGENT ORANGE
description: A Federal district judge has thrown out the Veterans Administration's rules on health damage attributed to the herbicide Agent Orange and has ordered the agency to reconsider claims of more than 31,000 Vietnam War veterans.

title: Biopharmaceutics reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $13,501 for the quarter and $11,991 for the 6 months. c-Net loss and included income from discontinued operations of $7,991 and $60,901 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: 5 Minority Builders Chosen In Pioneering Housing Plan
description: New York City yesterday awarded five minority-owned construction companies contracts to build affordable housing in a new program intended to help such companies break into the city's mainstream real-estate development industry.

title: Borland International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Jersey Suit Alleges Bias in Raising of Beach Fees
description: Belmar raised beach fees in 1986 in part to keep blacks from visiting the seashore community, a state attorney said today in opening one in a series of trials aimed at lowering the cost of using New Jersey beaches.

title: Pilot License Review
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * BBA Group P.L.C., a British automotive and textiles company, said it had agreed to acquire 80 percent of IGH, a privately owned U.S. textiles company, for a maximum of $66.6 million.

title: Centrust Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said its loss for the quarter was attributable to the amortization of good will. The company also said its gain on the sale of investments fell to $11,771,000 from $25,396,000 in the year-ago period.

title: Refugees and Density
description: To the Editor:

title: State Environmental Gadfly Nettles New York Officials
description: There is little dispute that Ward B. Stone is a thorn in the side of his employer, the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation.

title: Canyon Resources reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said the loss resulted from the company's upgrading of production facilities and marketing development activities.

title: Aaron Rents Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago earnings included a gain of $472,000, or 10 cents a share, from an accounting change.

title: Ex-Dictator and Businessman Leading in Bolivia Vote
description: With more than 40 percent of the vote in Bolivia's presidential elections yet to be counted, a former dictator and a wealthy businessman both declared victory today.

title: Shuttle Lands Safely In Gusting Winds
description: EDWARDS AIR FORCE BASE, Calif., May 8 - Heralded by its trademark double sonic boom, the space shuttle Atlantis dropped through scattered clouds above the Mojave Desert and glided to a safe landing today in gusting winds.

title: Catalina Lighting Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Interview Magazine Is Sold
description: Brant Publications Inc., which publishes Art in America and Antiques magazines and special interest antiques books, has acquired Interview magazine from the estate of Andy Warhol.

title: 2 Bankers May Bid for Former Mcorp Units
description: Two prospering regional banking companies, the Banc One Corporation and Barnett Banks Inc., are considering making offers for 20 banks formerly owned by Mcorp that are now controlled by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, a Texas banking consultant said today.

title: Alexander Baltzly, 97, Retired Dean at N.Y.U.
description: Alexander Baltzly, a history professor and former assistant dean at New York University, died Sunday at the Georgian Retirement Home in Evanston, Ill., where he lived. He was 97 years old.

title: Diabrasive International Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Review/Music; Wadsworth's Farewell to Chamber Society
description: When Charles Wadsworth walked away from 20 years at the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center on Sunday afternoon, he may have taken the organization along with him. The society - which played a typically Wadsworthian program of Ravel, Poulenc and Schubert on this occasion - will retain its name, it will still play in Alice Tully Hall and it will keep on doing its paper work in the offices just a few feet away.

title: Insurers Seeking Relief On California Rate Cut
description: Three business days after the California Supreme Court upheld the main provisions of an initiative requiring insurance companies to roll back rates 20 percent, at least 18 insurers have asked the California Insurance Department for exemptions on the ground that the change would impose hardship on them.

title: Dow Declines 5.49 as Retreat Continues
description: LEAD: The stock market continued its retreat yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average fell 5.49 points to close at 2,376.47.

title: U.S. Confirms It Lost an H-Bomb Off Japan in '65
description: Japan's tense relationship with the United States military worsened today with the disclosure that a hydrogen bomb, lost off an aircraft carrier 24 years ago, remains on the ocean floor 80 miles from a Japanese island.

title: PEN Members Urged Not to Criticize Iran
description: Members of PEN should avoid further criticisms of Iran's death threats against the British author Salman Rushdie, the group's president said today.

title: Lumet to Begin Filming Movie in New York
description: Sidney Lumet, the producer and director, announced yesterday that he would begin shooting his next film, ''Q & A,'' on location in New York City Sept. 5. The criminal-justice drama, to be written, directed and produced by Mr. Lumet, is based on the novel ''Q & A'' by Edwin Torres, a State Supreme Court justice in Manhattan.

title: Summer Coats
description: How many times in the summer have you wished for a wafer-thin coat? They're nice to toss on when it rains or it is a bit cool, or when you want to create a dramatic billowy effect. Yet these coats are always hard to find, particularly when warmer weather arrives. There are a few around town now, though they are apt to be available in limited quantities only.

title: CULT CHIEF'S DEATH SUSPECTED AS FAKE
description: The leader of a Mexican cult that smuggled drugs may have faked his death to make the police end their hunt for suspects in the ritual murders of 15 people, a United States investigator said Monday.

title: Stokely USA Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for 1988 included $3,740,000 in non-recurring gains.

title: Derby Crowd Showed Dark Side
description: Perhaps the ugliest moment of a Kentucky Derby utterly lacking in beauty came moments after the race was over Saturday, when Easy Goer was greeted by booing as he returned to be unsaddled after his second-place finish.

title: New Warning Device May Aid Planes in Avoiding Collisions
description: On a recent sunny day over Cape May, N.J., two airplanes at the same altitude converged on a head-on collision course at a combined speed of 650 miles an hour.

title: Rocky Mount Undergarment reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $21,000 and $19,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Varity to Acquire Fruehauf For Estimated $650 Million
description: The Varity Corporation agreed today to buy the Fruehauf Corporation for an estimated $650 million in cash, stock and notes.

title: Scintrex Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Atlantis Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $584,000. c-Net income and included income from discontinued operations of $821,000.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: JUSTICE
description: To all appearances, Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist came as a supplicant to testify before the House Post Office and Civil Service Committee last week.

title: First Liberty Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Tourism in Australia
description: Tourism has overtaken coal as Australia's second-largest source of foreign revenue, the Tourism Minister, Graham Richardson, said today. Foreign visitors spent more than $4.16 billion in Australia in 1988, edging out coal exports, which brought in about $4 billion, Mr. Richardson said in a statement. Wool remains Australia's largest export earner, accounting for more than $4.96 billion in 1988.

title: Vending Machine Kills Youth
description: A 23-year-old University of Kansas student who was rocking a vending machine that failed to release a can of soda after he had deposited 50 cents was fatally injured Saturday when the machine fell on him, the authorities said.

title: Talking Business with Brindisi of S.C.A.; When Executives Act Like Raiders
description: For five years, Louis L. Brindisi has been trying to make corporate executives think like corporate raiders. Mr. Brindisi, a senior partner with a newly formed firm called Strategic Compensation Associates, a joint venture between Korn/Ferry International and the Management Compensation Group, argues that a ''raider mentality'' - a strong concern about the company's stock price -can help executives make their businesses more productive and profitable.

title: Exxon Says U.S. Barred Quick Move on Spill
description: Top Exxon executives contradicted state and Federal officials today, insisting that they had repeatedly urged the prompt use of chemicals to disperse the nation's largest oil spill but the Federal authorities turned them down.

title: Demeaning Chaplin
description: To the Editor:

title: Morrison Petroleums Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Here Comes Mr. Jordan, At Altitude
description: When he first ascended into the National Basketball Association's stratosphere, Michael Jordan was considered a medley of Julius Erving, Elgin Baylor and Earl (The Pearl) Monroe. But now, after four seasons at altitude, Michael Jordan is incomparable. Nobody knows that better than opponents assigned to cover him. Actually, those assigned to try to cover him.

title: A Change of Command At Metropolitan Life
description: The Metropolitan Life Insurance Company said yesterday that John J. Creedon, its president and chief executive, will retire on Sept. 1. Robert G. Schwartz will assume his positions and continue as chairman.

title: Telxon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included gains of $65,000 and $499,000 from foreign tax credits for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included gains of $84,000 and $121,000 from foreign tax credits for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Minnova Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Jailed Greek Banker's Tale of Greed: Slush Fund and Soccer Team
description: From behind the barbed wire of a small village jail here, the former president of a Greek bank has been telling a story of financial corruption in the Greek Government that has swirled around the resignation of the Deputy Prime Minister and the arrest of several high Government aides.

title: Northwest's Unions Join Bidding Fray
description: The two major unions at Northwest Airlines - the pilots and machinists - are seeking to put themselves into the takeover fight for NWA Inc., the airline's parent.

title: Review/Dance; Perilous Voyage in a Realm Of Clatters, Rasps and Sighs
description: Over the years, choreographers have often created dances about people struggling on perilous journeys. It's understandable that they should do so, for struggle and peril lend themselves to choreographic treatment. At their best, such dances are metaphors for life's mystery and uncertainty. At their worst, they are cliche-ridden.

title: No Headline
description: Three people were arrested over the weekend in New York City on charges of heroin trafficking that officials said resulted from an unusual tip by law-enforcement authorities in China.

title: A Reprimand At Northrop
description: The Northrop Corporation has reprimanded its chairman, Thomas V. Jones, for the manner in which he led the company's efforts to sell the F-20 fighter jet to South Korea, the military contractor's proxy statement says.

title: Saatchi in Japan
description: In Japan, Saatchi & Saatchi consolidated its advertising subsidiaries on Friday, merging Tokyo-based Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising K.K. with another Saatchi holding, Yomiko DFS. The new agency will be named Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising, Japan. Yomiko DFS was itself a joint venture of Yomiko, Japan's seventh-largest agency, and Dancer Fitzgerald Sample, which was acquired by Saatchi in 1986.

title: Turner Broadcasting's Operating Net Is Up
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. said yesterday that operating profit for the company's first quarter rose 24 percent, to $52 million, or 25 cents a share. Revenues climbed 27 percent, to $232 million, from $182.6 million a year ago.

title: Security Federal Savings & Loan Cleveand reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $80,000 from prepayment of debt. Per share figures for 1988 are not available because the company converted to stock ownership on Jan. 15, 1988.

title: Corrections
description: An article in the Health pages on Thursday about Micro-Trach, a device that eases breathing for patients dependent on oxygen, misstated the prospects for marketing it. Ballard Medical Products said it was talking with the developer but had not yet signed a marketing agreement.

title: Giant Planet
description: Astronomers have detected the effects of a giant planet in orbit around a star. But having gained one planet, scientists have lost a planetoid in the solar system, which has now been classed a comet.

title: Schult Homes Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-Included a tax credit of $78,000. c-Net income d-Net loss

title: Pittway Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said year-ago results included a cash distribution from its Metco Properties real estate venture of $873,000 and the operating results of Saddlebrook Resorts Inc., which was sold in November 1988.

title: Florida Employers Insurance reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Canam Manac Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included special gains of $3,681,000 for the latest quarter and $266,000 for the year-earlier period. The company said the drop in sales is largely due to an accounting change. Sales is subsidiaries Manac and MRM Steel are now accounted for on an equity basis. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Scientists View the Universe In an Ordinary Pile of Sand
description: BY observing the tiny avalanches produced when a trickle of sand falls on top of a sand pile, scientists are probing the hazards of collapsing silos, the probabilities of earthquakes and the structure of the entire universe.

title: Moderation, Iranian Style
description: In a recent sermon, Hashemi Rafsanjani, the Speaker of Iran's Parliament, urged killing five Americans, Britons or Frenchmen for each Palestinian casualty in the West Bank uprising against Israel. Americans or Frenchmen, he asserted, make better targets than Israelis, who are ''a bit difficult to kill.''

title: Chicago Trader May Bid on Eastern
description: Joseph Ritchie, a leading futures trader in Chicago, has asked Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. to advise him on the possibility of making a bid for Eastern Airlines, the investment firm said yesterday.

title: EnergyNorth Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Elbit Computers Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Revenue represents total revenue.

title: MAI Hopeful on Bid
description: MAI Basic Four Inc. said today that it expected the United States District Court to vacate on May 15 a preliminary order enjoining completion of MAI's offer for Prime Computer Inc. The court ruled previously that the injunction would be automatically lifted 10 days after MAI filed an affidavit containing a mailing of financial information. MAI said it mailed to Prime's stockholders on Friday and filed with the Securities and Exchange Commission summary audited financial information about Drexel Burnham Lambert, which is financing the offer, for the year ended last Dec. 30.

title: Review/Theater; Tesich and the Past That Haunts
description: Joe, a prominent building contractor and apostle of the American Dream, worked his way up from scratch after returning from decorated service in Vietnam. He had to start out in garbage. In ''The Speed of Darkness,'' Steve Tesich's first new play since 1980, Joe (Bill Raymond) pays thanks for his success at the televised award ceremony naming him South Dakota's Man of the Year. As he tells his fellow citizens, he owes everything to ''your trash and filth and waste that you wanted to be taken anywhere and buried out of sight.''

title: Technical Communications Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-Net loss All per share figures are fully diluted.

title: Jumbo Jet Narrowly Misses Small Plane Over the Pacific
description: An Air New Zealand jumbo jet carrying 350 people swerved to avoid a small plane less than 500 feet away over the Pacific Ocean, officials said today.

title: Fleisher Is Eulogized
description: Larry Fleisher, who died on Thursday, was eulogized as ''the most successful labor leader of the 20th century'' by Senator Bill Bradley, Democrat of New Jersey, one of a dozen speakers at a memorial service for the former head of the National Basketball Players Association yesterday at the Community Church of New York on East 35th Street.

title: Calcutta, at Age 300, Is Planning a Long Party
description: India's biggest city is getting ready to celebrate a birthday.

title: N.H.L. Silent on Mogilny
description: John Ziegler, the president of the National Hockey League, said yesterday that the league would not have any comment on the Aleksandr Mogilny affair until a careful study is made of a report by the Buffalo Sabres.

title: Tally Brown, 64, Dies; Singer and an Actress
description: Tally Brown, an actress and a cabaret performer, died after a stroke on Saturday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. She was 64 years old.

title: American Technical Ceramics Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $200,000.

title: Patrick Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $125,000 from an accounting change.

title: Jose Carreras Postpones Carnegie Hall Recital
description: The Spanish tenor Jose Carreras has postponed his recital at Carnegie Hall, scheduled for tomorrow evening, because of an ear infection that prevents him from flying. The performance has been rescheduled for May 25.

title: Fearful of Outbreaks, Doctors Pay New Heed To Emerging Viruses
description: COULD another AIDS virus soon appear, this time spreading relatively easily in coughs and sneezes?

title: National Bancshares Corp of Texas reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The provision for possible credit losses totaled $18 million for the latest first quarter, compared with $8.9 million for year-ago period.

title: Cottar's Camp Journal; Great White Hunter: Endangered but Not Extinct
description: Amid the hoarse call of the hyrax echoing through the trees and roars from lion resounding across the plain, the last of East Africa's great white hunters gathered here to evoke a past of grand safaris and alluring danger.

title: Bush Confers With Top Advisers On Response to Charges of Fraud
description: President Bush met with top advisers today to consider how to respond to evidence of fraud in Panama's presidential election, White House officials said.

title: Halliburton Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results included gains of $1.3 million for the latest first quarter and $9 million for the year-ago period, both from accounting changes.

title: Panel to Discuss Threats to Rushdie
description: The issues - First Amendment, legal and publishing - raised by the Iranian threats against the life of Salman Rushdie, the author of ''The Satanic Verses,'' are to be discussed in a seminar tomorrow sponsored by Volunteer Lawyers for the Arts, a New York public-service group.

title: Clevetrust Realty Investors reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After gains from the early retirement of debt of $84,000 for the quarter and $266,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss

title: Peru's Prime Minister Quits as Strife Surges
description: The Peruvian Prime Minister resigned today in the face of a wave of leftist guerrilla violence, including the assassination of two lawmakers over 10 days.

title: American Resource Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
White House Admits Censoring Testimony
description: The White House confirmed today that it had censored Congressional testimony on the effects of global warming by a top Government scientist, but it insisted that the changes reflected policy decisions, not scientific conclusions.

title: Bell Begins Penalty
description: George Bell, the Toronto Blue Jays' outfielder, began serving a two-game suspension yesterday after withdrawing an appeal for a hearing.

title: National Pizza Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 28
description: Latest quarter results included reserves of $330,000 for expected losses on disposition and sale of certain closed units and equipment and $413,000 of expenses related to the tender offer for shares of Skipper's Inc., which was abandoned in March 1989.

title: Bomem Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said earnings are down partly due to the reevaluation of deferred charges resulting in a double charge and reducing first quarter earnings by $65,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Careers; New Courses Urged to Aid Productivity
description: WHEN educators talk about improving industrial productivity, a change in schooling and training is high on their agenda.

title: Treasury Issues Dip in Quiet Day
description: Prices of Treasury securities dipped slightly in light trading yesterday despite a big drop in oil prices and a surge in the value of the dollar, developments that normally tend to be viewed favorably in the credit markets.

title: L.I. Starts A Dogfight In Congress To Save F-14
description: Each Wednesday morning Long Island's five Congressional Representatives meet behind closed doors to map strategy in the campaign to save the Grumman Corporation's F-14 Tomcat fighter.

title: A H Robins Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said that included in first-quarter operations of 1989 was a provision for impairment of investments of $18.3 million, which recognizes the impairment of the company's investment in subsidiaries located in Colombia and Venezuela and projected losses on disposition of certain assets. First quarter 1988 results included a charge of $30.2 million relating to costs and expenses that the company anticipated would be incurred as a result of its proposed Chapter 11 plan of reorganization and merger with American Home Products Corp.

title: OPEC Output Spurt in April
description: OPEC's oil output registered a faster monthly rise in April than in any other month since last autumn, with an average of 20.9 million barrels produced daily during the month, Petroleum Intelligence Weekly said today.

title: A.A.U. All-Stars Win
description: Although the New York Amateur Athletic Union All-Star team that went against the Soviet junior national basketball team at St. John's University last night was without the help of Kenny Anderson, who is still nursing a sore ankle, it did not need the 6-foot-2-inch all-American from Archbishop Molloy.

title: KEY RATES
Linamar Machine Ltd() reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Corrections
description: The Eating Well column in The Living Section on March 29 misstated the fat content of a three-strip serving of bacon. As a fitness program manager has recently written to point out, the fat accounts for 81 calories and 77 percent of the caloric content.

title: Large Volcanic Eruption Could Damage Ozone, 2 Researchers Report
description: A MAJOR volcanic eruption could significantly accelerate the destruction of the earth's protective ozone layer by industrial chemicals, two atmospheric scientists have reported.

title: Consolidated Energy Partners LP reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: The latest quarter included proceeds of $456,000 from a gas contract buy-down settlement. Year-ago quarter included a $1,199,000 non-cash equity loss from an investment in a hotel partnership.

title: Barclays Bank Plans Public Offer
description: Barclays Bank P.L.C. plans to raise $200 million in the United States in a public offering of fixed-rate noncumulative preference shares through an underwriting group led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., a unit of the American Express Company; Goldman, Sachs & Company, and Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: American Captial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company's figures reflect the results of its 70 percent owned subsidiary, Transcapital Financial Corporation, and the company's real estate operations.

title: Campaign Trail; Republicans Deny Stein a Coronation
description: The proposed Staten Island jail and public campaign financing will probably cost City Council President Andrew J. Stein, a Democrat, the Republican nomination and virtual coronation for another four-year term.

title: Norman in Tournament
description: Greg Norman of Australia yesterday became the last player from 1988's four-way, first-place playoff at the Manufacturers Hanover Westchester Classic to commit to play in this year's tournament at the Westchester Country Club in Harrison, N.Y. The other three in the playoff who had enrolled earlier for this year's event, to be held June 8-11, are David Frost of South Africa, Ken Green of West Palm Beach, Fla., and Seve Ballesteros of Spain, the eventual winner of the playoff.

title: Vestige of Book Row: Ex-Owner on Sidewalk
description: With all the alarm about the situation of the homeless, the problems of George Foss, who is shopless, is far down the list of things New Yorkers are worrying about. Yet, Mr. Foss's appearance as sidewalk purveyor on Broadway after a working lifetime under a roof is something of an exclamation point at the end of a New York cultural chapter that was called Booksellers' Row.

title: India to Pay Bhopal Heirs
description: The heirs of 2,000 adults killed in the 1984 Bhopal gas disaster will begin receiving monthly compensation checks from the Government on Tuesday, officials said today.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly DISARMAMENT COMMISSION - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Economic and Social Council ECONOMICS COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. SOCIAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Mr. Bush's Sweet Wheat Deal
description: Cynical politics! Betrayal of the taxpayer! Soft on the Russians! On every side, President Bush's decision to subsidize wheat sales to the Soviet Union has ignited heated criticism. But even on brief reflection, the criticism looks hasty, even unfair. The costs of Mr. Bush's decision are small. The potential benefits are substantial. In terms of overall American interests, it's a sensible policy.

title: Sea Containers
description: Federal District Judge John G. Penn of Washington refused to give Stena A.B. of Sweden an injunction to prevent Sea Containers Ltd. of Bermuda from buying back its stock. The judge said Stena, a ferry company with 8.2 percent of Sea Containers' stock, had failed to establish that Sea Containers' disclosure papers were false and misleading. Two Sea Containers subsidiaries have been buying big blocks of their parent's stock as a takeover defense.

title: Four Seasons Hotels Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Biomira Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: The White House and the Greenhouse
description: The world has started to take very seriously the established threat to the life-protecting ozone layer from industrial chemicals. Many countries are now eager for President Bush to take the lead on another threat to the global climate - the feared warming of the earth's atmosphere by pollutant gases like carbon dioxide. But despite Mr. Bush's ringing campaign pledge to do just that, his Administration flounders in confusion and timidity.

title: Illinois Man Implicates Wife in Infants' Deaths
description: A man whose two infant daughters died under similar circumstances within three years told police that his wife was upset after giving birth and apologized both times for not having boys.

title: Polish Miners Continue Strike, Rattling Solidarity
description: Strikes by thousands of workers at Polish copper mines continued today after talks failed to produce an accord on pay. The strikes pose a serious challenge to the Government and are an acute embarrassment to the national leadership of the Solidarity trade union.

title: Brandon Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 26
Confidence Off For the British
description: Britain's small businesses are suffering from the sharpest decline in confidence in almost seven years, according to a big industry study released today.

title: Ascot Investment Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars. The company said its earnings turnaround is due to the completion of its corporate reorganization.

title: Fairfield Communities Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Resetting Body Clock
description: HIT the ground running after a long flight and the effect of jet lag may be reduced, researchers say.

title: Bank of New York Merges Branches
description: The Bank of New York Company, which has been consolidating the operations of the Irving Bank Corporation, said yesterday that it would combine its suburban New York branches with four independent banks owned by Irving.

title: Kadar, Ill, Loses Party Posts
description: Janos Kadar, who ruled Hungary from the Soviet suppression of the 1956 uprising until his ouster last May as Communist Party leader, was removed today as the party's president and expelled from the Central Committee.

title: Consolidated Mercantile Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the net income in the latest period included a $5,384 special gain, compared with a $61,010 special gain in the year-earlier period. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Monenco Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $49,000 from discontinued opertions for the latest period; the year-ago period included a loss of $627,000 from discontinued operations. Revenue is from continuing opertions. Figures are in Canadian funds. The year-earlier figures have been restated.

title: Our Towns; Pasture Puzzle: Who 'Borrowed' A Plywood Cow?
description: The new suburban Wilton is teeming with prosperous executives riding high in their weekend Broncos. The old, rural Wilton is Eugenia Slaughter. For half a century, Mrs. Slaughter has lived here on 20 acres of lush, rolling fields that are divided by stone walls and anchored by a 1757 farmhouse with a tilted red barn.

title: British Laborite Tries to Ease Antinuclear Line
description: After winning an election for a parliamentary seat last week with a bigger majority than expected, the opposition Labor Party is debating ideas that its leader, Neil Kinnock, hopes can end its losing streak of three straight general elections.

title: Heist, C H Corp reports earnings for
description: b-Net loss

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Washington Talk page yesterday about the National Transportation Safety Board misidentified its chairman. The acting chairman is James L. Kolstad.

title: Increased Enrollments Raise CUNY Costs
description: To the Editor:

title: Honoring the Power of the Hill's Unelected
description: As Congressional insiders know, it is not always the elected official who calls the shots in major matters of policy or those minor things called favors. It can be one of the powerful among the ever-changing 14,000 staff members on Capitol Hill.

title: 2 Urge Extending Passaic Tunnel Plan
description: Five years ago, the Passaic River in New Jersey overflowed its banks. Three people lost their lives, scores were injured, and more than 9,000 had to be removed. Thousands of homes and businesses were damaged at an estimated cost of $330 million.

title: United Healthcare Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company attributed the drop in revenue to the sale of its Peak Health Care unit in 1988. On a same-store basis for the first quarter, however, the company said it generated a 35 percent increase in revenue, compared to the first quarter of 1988.

title: New Division Is Planned By Goldman
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company announced yesterday that it was entering the equity investment management business and named Leon G. Cooperman, the firm's highly regarded market strategist, to run an expanded asset management division.

title: Fight? What Fight?
description: Dallas Green, the Yankees' manager, yesterday dismissed a weekend tussle between Rickey Henderson and Mel Hall as ''no big deal.'' It was, however, the second incident in three weeks involving the two players, who are friends.

title: Surgery for Mathews
description: Greg Mathews, a St. Louis Cardinal left-hander, will undergo surgery on his pitching elbow later this week and will miss the remainder of the season. The surgery on Mathews, 26, will involve the transfer of ligaments from his right wrist to his left elbow. After having soreness during spring training appearances, Mathews was sent to Louisville for a 20-day injury-rehabilitation assignment. He experienced more pain in Louisville.(AP)

title: AL Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''The Government is taking the election by fraud. It's robbing the people of Panama of their legitimate rights.'' - Jimmy Carter. [ A1:6. ]

title: New Ways To Interact Electronically
description: THE conceptual boundary between humans and computers, called the interface, is the area of some of the most intriguing research in science. Dozens of new ideas were on display last week in Austin, Tex., at the annual conference of the Association for Computing Machinery's Special Interest Group on Computer and Human Interaction.

title: Hearings Are Held On Acne Drug Dangers
description: Several medical experts and a Federal health official testified today that a drug company's program to educate doctors and young women about the risks of severe birth defects from the anti-acne drug Accutane was inadequate.

title: Physicians Insurance Co of Ohio reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Included a tax credit of $123,800 and $134,500 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively, and the year- ago quarter also included net from discontinued operations of $110,070.

title: Baldwin Technology Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Shares outstanding adjusted for Aug. 15, 1988 stock split.

title: Expanded Metal Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a special gain of $72,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: BAKER PLANS TEST OF 'NEW THINKING' WHILE IN MOSCOW
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that he was carrying a series of proposals to Moscow that would test whether there was really ''new thinking'' in the Kremlin.

title: Revenue Properties Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $176,000 and $200,000 for the latest and year- ago periods, respectively. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: CGC Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Lucille Ball Acted as Cultural Ambassador
description: To the Editor:

title: Interco to Sell Central Hardware
description: Interco Inc. said it would sell its Central Hardware Company subsidiary for about $245 million to a group formed by Salomon Brothers Inc. and an affiliate of Handy Andy Home Improvements Centers Inc. The deal is expected to be completed by June 12. Central Hardware operates 38 large do-it-yourself home-improvement centers in the Middle West.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: CYCLING A Top Sprinter Takes 3d Stage: Eric Vanderaerden of Belgium used team strategy, then sprinted away from a dozen riders yesterday to claim the Lehigh Valley to Harrisburg Road Race, the third stage of the Tour de Trump. Vanderaerden, considered one of the world's finest sprinters, rode conservatively into a steady headwind in a pack of about 50 riders during much of the 116.3-mile race through the farmlands of central Pennsylvania. He finished with a time of 5 hours 30 minutes 45 seconds. Dag Otto Lauritzen of Norway finished 12th and was awarded the same finishing time as the winner to maintain his 17-second overall race lead over Hank Lubberding of the Netherlands. Paul Curran of England remained third, 55 seconds behind the leader. Davis Phinny of Boulder, Colo., was the top American finisher, placing fourth.(AP)

title: White House Admits Censoring Testimony; British urge rapid action
description: Britain today called for the rapid drafting of a new international convention to deal with the problem of global warming, saying rising temperatures could lead to disruption of normal life, political tension and war.

title: Commodity Inquiry Focuses On Sharing of Order Data
description: The criminal investigation of trading practices at four New York commodity exchanges is examining whether brokers and traders illegally shared information with each other about customer orders, allowing them to make trades before the orders changed market prices, people involved in the inquiry said yesterday.

title: Chess
description: In a game that opens up as many complex and bewildering possibilities as chess does, there is a natural inducement to head for the simple, sure thing, the pattern that gives you all the winning chances, or at least denies the opponent any. The trouble is that there is nothing simple about such a project.

title: Southland May Sell Its Stake in Citgo
description: The Southland Corporation, the owner of 7-Eleven convenience stores, said it might sell its half-interest in the Citgo Petroleum Corporation and all or part of its distribution and food centers in order to reduce the debt it incurred in a leveraged buyout last year. Southland's bank debt totals $1.56 billion.

title: Eleanor Brenner's Recipe: Fit and Price
description: Eleanor P. Brenner is beginning to believe she has succeeded on Seventh Avenue. Her styles are sold in 400 stores around the country. She has developed a faithful coterie of followers, including Joan Mondale, who write her fan letters, turn up at her fashion shows and buy her clothes.

title: Turner Broadcasting System Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest first quarter results included a $3.1 million gain on the sale of land.

title: 2 Disappointments for ABC, Low Ratings and an Ending
description: ABC suffered two major disappointments yesterday, getting disastrously low initial ratings for the first installment of the conclusion of ''War and Remembrance'' and canceling ''Moonlighting,'' once the network's second most popular show.

title: Southland Corp reports earnings for
description: b-Included an extraordinary charge of $56,047,000 from a debt exchange. Southland reported $17,336,000 as its equity in the after-tax earnings of Citgo for the latest first quarter, compared with $17,975,000 for year-ago period.

title: Thousands of Shells Again Batter a Weary Beirut
description: The shaky truce between warring Lebanese factions seemed to have crumbled today as heavy fighting in and around Beirut continued for the third day.

title: The Editorial Notebook; For Foundlings, a Refuge
description: Foundlings are often the stuff of Bible stories (Moses in the bulrushes) and fairy tales (princes placed on humble doorsteps). But they are also the reason the Sisters of Charity opened a hospital in New York City 120 years ago. In the hospital's first 10 weeks, 123 abandoned babies were given to the nuns.

title: Batus Inc reports earnings for
description: The results do not include the acquisition of Farmers Group Inc. which was acquired on Dec. 31, 1988 for $5.32 billion. Batus Inc. is the holding company for the U.S. B.A.T. Industries Plc.

title: German Magazine Says Iran Paid for U.S. Jet's Bombing
description: Iran ordered the destruction of Pan Am Flight 103 and paid Ahmed Jabril, the leader of a Palestinian group, $1.3 million to carry out the attack, a West German magazine said today.

title: Fairfax Financial Holdings Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: BOSTON U. WEIGHS INVESTMENT PLAN
description: In an effort to raise its endowment, Boston University plans to take out life insurance policies on some of its students and alumni, hoping to collect hundreds of millions of dollars when they die.

title: Jews Stalk Arabs After Israeli's Death
description: For the second time in less than a week, angry Israelis roamed the streets on Sunday night and again this morning, shouting ''Death to Arabs!'' as they looked for Palestinians they could lynch, this time in retaliation for the death of a soldier whose body was found on Sunday with a bullet to the head.

title: Nord Resources Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Somerset Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income The company said the latest fourth quarter and year losses are due principally to increases in loan loss reserves.

title: Cassidy's Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a special gain of $365,008. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Noriega Stealing Election, Carter Says
description: Former President Jimmy Carter, a leader of an international delegation monitoring Panama's presidential election, declared tonight that the armed forces were defrauding the opposition of victory.

title: Frederic Mueller, 53, iModern-Art Collector
description: Frederic Bernhardt Mueller, a former partner in the Pace Gallery, a prominent contemporary-art dealership in Manhattan, died on May 1 at his home in Oahu, Hawaii. He was 53 years old.

title: AHA Automotive Technoloies Corp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and included a special gain of $1,749,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Akzo's Head Sees Need For More U.S. Investors
description: Aarnout A. Loudon, the chief executive of the big Dutch chemical company Akzo N.V., is seeking to broaden American investment in the company. So it was fitting that he was in New York yesterday as Akzo began selling its shares on the over-the counter market in the form of American depository receipts.

title: Crude Oil Falls Below $20; Unleaded Gas Also Plunges
description: Crude oil prices fell decisively below $20 a barrel yesterday, while unleaded gasoline contracts plunged the daily limit on the New York Mercantile Exchange.

title: Beneficial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Kenneth Lynch, 82, Modern Blacksmith And Artist in Metal
description: Kenneth J. Lynch, a skilled blacksmith who created many pieces of metalwork adorning New York City buildings, directed repairs on the Statue of Liberty in the late 1920's and twice restored the weather vane on Boston's Old North Church, died Thursday at his home in Wilton, Conn., after a long illness. He was 82 years old.

title: Rawley Helps Twins Set Back Red Sox
description: Shane Rawley scattered eight hits in seven and two-thirds innings, and Kirby Puckett ended an 0-for-15 slump with a run-scoring double tonight to lead the Minnesota Twins to a 4-2 victory over the Boston Red Sox.

title: Presidents Of Boroughs: Vestigial Or Vibrant?
description: No other matter has so troubled and divided the commission rewriting New York City's charter as what to do with the borough presidents. Underlying the question is an even more fundamental debate about how New Yorkers perceive themselves and how those perceptions should be accommodated in the structure of municipal government.

title: White House Says Bush Will Call Meeting About Global Warming
description: The White House said today that President Bush would call an international meeting to consider a response to global warming and other environmental problems.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertsing; Addendum
description: * Hill & Knowlton Inc., the public relations firm, said it had agreed to acquire United Public Relations of Melbourne, Australia.

title: Canadian Occidental Petroeum Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a special gain of $3.2 million.

title: Green Mountain Power reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Company News; G.M. Plans Some Summer Closings
description: The General Motors Corporation said it planned to shut down some of its assembly plants for a month or longer this summer to help reduce inventories and provide time for plant retooling as part of its previously announced plan to reduce production in the third quarter of the year.

title: Pentagon Budget Keeps the Cold War Cold; Missile Breakthrough
description: To the Editor:

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: ANCHOVIES, a staple of Mediterranean cooking, have never had widespread appeal in this country. For one, fresh anchovies are rarely available to the home cook here. Typically they are sold salted in jars or cans, yielding a product that has little relation to fresh anchovies, although the salted ones can be put to good use in many ways.

title: Mother Charged After Her Baby Dies of Cocaine
description: The mother of a baby whose death was linked to her cocaine abuse in pregnancy has been charged with involuntary manslaughter.

title: Stern but Steady on Panama
description: The year's prize for brazenness goes to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama. With all the world watching, including two former U.S. Presidents, he turned a 3-to-1 victory for the opposition into a triumph for his own hand-picked presidential candidate, Carlos Duque. According to Jimmy Carter and surveys coordinated by the Roman Catholic Church, the winner by a landslide was the challenger, Guillermo Endara.

title: Currency Markets; Rise in Dollar Fades After U.S. Comments
description: The dollar ended slightly lower against the mark yesterday after comments by American officials dampened speculation in the United States and in Europe, traders said, of a change in the policies of the Group of Seven industrialized countries.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on April 14 about the use of foreign repair stations by United States air lines incorrectly described maintenance work done on Continental Airlines Boeing 747's by an Australian company. With the special permission of the Federal Aviation Administration, Continental has had maintenance work performed in Australia since last October.

title: Chemdesign Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $189,459. The company went public May 3.

title: Hawks' Rebirth Reflects Coach's
description: This probably will not be Mike Keenan's championship season. After losing in overtime here Monday night to the Calgary Flames, Keenan and his Chicago Blackhawks trail in that Stanley Cup semifinal series, three games to one.

title: Elster Finally Bobbles One, but Mets Win
description: Keith Hernandez thought he might be imagining things as he stood at second base in the fifth inning tonight. Hernandez, a 35-year-old first baseman with a suspect leg, looked first to his left, where he was sure he saw Gary Carter, a 35-year-old catcher with two gimpy legs. Hernandez then squinted to his right at Sam Perlozzo, the third-base coach, and heck if he didn't see the sign for a hit-and-run.

title: Bikers Trade Goodies For Time
description: These are big boys wheeling into the Blue Ridge the way they wheel through the Alps and the Pyrenees. They ride through rain and they ride through cold and yesterday some of them rode right through lunch.

title: Review/Theater; 3 Women and the Common Ground They Seek
description: There are some absent friends you don't realize how much you've been missing until they suddenly pop up again. Eileen Heckart, who has been away from the New York stage throughout this decade, is definitely one of them.

title: Dr. Harry Ungerleider, Cardiologist, Dies at 93
description: Dr. Harry Eduarde Ungerleider, a cardiologist who specialized in heart research, died of a heart blockage last Wednesday at St. Jude's Hospital in Fullerton, Calif. He was 93 years old and lived in Anaheim, Calif.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Andrews Group Inc., said its Four Star Holdings Corp. unit had extended its offer to purchase all common shares of New World Entertainment Ltd. for $8.95 a share in cash until June 2.

title: Chevron Sale
description: The Chevron Corporation said that it would accept bids for its oil and gas exploration and producing properties in Spain and that it had recently distributed material about a possible offer to some potential buyers. The Spanish properties consist of 3 oilfields and 14 offshore exploration permits and are being offered as a single package.

title: Man Sentenced in Brooklyn For Murder and Sex Attacks
description: A 25-year-old man who was convicted of one murder and seven sexual assaults near the campus of Brooklyn College was sentenced yesterday to 188 1/2 years to life in prison.

title: Domain Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Animal Rights and Others
description: To The Living Section:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''All of the expensive things in the health care system are being expended on people whose cause of illness is not natural - drugs. We are pouring blood, medicines, antibiotics into a large drug patient population that requires intensive care.'' - Dr. William M. Stahl, chief of surgery at Lincoln Hospital. [ B5:1. ]

title: Mostly Mozart Festival Planning 43 Concerts
description: This summer's Mostly Mozart Festival will include Kathleen Battle singing Bach and Mozart arias, two evenings of Mozart operas in concert version, two Bastille Day concerts featuring the flutist Jean-Pierre Rampal and a concert of Mozart and his contemporaries on period instruments. The festival runs from July 11 to Aug. 26 at Avery Fisher Hall.

title: North Carolina's Reid Decides to Become Pro
description: J. R. Reid said yesterday he would give up his final year of eligibility at North Carolina and would enter the National Basketball Association draft. Reid said he convinced his mother that turning pro was best for him after he promised her he would obtain his degree next year.(AP)

title: A Hearing on Organic Food
description: A hearing will be held in Albany next Wednesday on proposed legislation governing organic food sold in New York State. At issue is a bill, introduced by Assemblywoman Gloria Davis, a Bronx Democrat who is the chairwoman of the Assembly's Task Force on Food, Farm and Nutrition Policy., to provide a legal definition of several terms used in marketing food that is free of pesticides.

title: About Education
description: There is a story in academic circles about a noted scientist who had just ended his lecture. A graduate student came up to say he had not understood the underlying theory, and the professor patiently started the explanation over again.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Common Stock

title: Tiny College Lands Big Speaker: Bush
description: The president of Alcorn State University has asked every President since Lyndon B. Johnson to speak at the black college's commencement. He was a bit surprised when one accepted.

title: Pentagon Budget Keeps the Cold War Cold
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge
description: The first Soviet bridge players to compete in the United States will arrive in New York City today after overcoming a visa problem with the help of Senator Rudy Boschwitz, Republican of Minnesota. They are Ain Otstavel and Hillar Sula, both Estonians, and they will play in two Cavendish Club invitational events beginning Saturday, then in a tournament in Memphis, and finally, once more in New York, in the Eastern Regional championships.

title: Market Place; Behind the Plunge At a Video Chain
description: THE Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation, one of the largest video store chains, ran into a wall yesterday, as a respected analyst criticized the company's accounting policies.

title: Bubbling With Plans at Bank Street
description: The other day, Dr. Joseph Shenker, the new president of the Bank Street College of Education, was manipulating two hand puppets, a genial orange cat named Clever Kitten and a malicious gray fox called Slippery Slick.

title: Anarchy in the Streets
description: LEAD: There's blacks with knives and whites with guns fighting in Howard Beach There's no such thing as human rights when you walk the New York streets A cop was shot in the head by a 10-year-old kid named Buddha in Central Park last week The fathers and daughters are lined up by the coffins by the Statue of Bigotry You better hold on something's happening here You better hold on - meet you in Tompkins Square The dopers sent a message to the cops last weekend They shot him in a car where he sat And Eleanor Bumpurs and Michael Stewart must have appreciated that $

title: Cliffs Drilling Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Hampton Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Vermont Justice Faces Fight Over Retirement
description: Vermont's court administrator said Monday that he had acted to force the retirement of a Supreme Court Justice who is fighting mandatory retirement.

title: Pioneer Financial Services reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said that latest quarter results included $6,000 in realized investment losses and $51,000 in realized investment gains for the year- ago period.

title: Franc Ricciardi, 65; Executive and Teacher
description: Franc M. Ricciardi, the founder and chief executive of the Richton International Corporation, died of cancer Monday at Valley Hospital in Ridgewood, N.J. He was 65 years old and lived in Ridgewood.

title: Atlantic Financial Federal reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After gains from the repurchase of debentures of $687,000 and $1,334,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net income and included tax credits of $2,592,000 for the quarter and $6,877,000 for the 6 months, and gains of from the repurchase of $672,000 and $1,191,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: BBC Employees Strike
description: Journalists and technicians at the British Broadcasting Corporation began a 48-hour strike today, severely disrupting radio and television programs.

title: 1,000 Chinese Journalists Call For Greater Freedom of Press
description: In the strongest appeal so far for freedom of the press in China, more than 1,000 journalists from official news organizations signed a petition that was presented to the Government today calling for talks with China's leaders.

title: Mills B. Lane Jr., Atlanta Banker, Is Dead at 77
description: Mills B. Lane Jr., an Atlanta banker who exerted strong influence in Southern politics in the 1960's, died Sunday at his home in Savannah, Ga., where he had lived in retirement for 16 years. He was 77 years old.

title: Some Top Universities in Squeeze Between Research and Academics
description: Despite glowing reports of successful multimillion-dollar fund-raising drives, many of the nation's top research universities are having trouble sustaining both advanced research and strong undergraduate liberal arts programs.

title: Company News; I.C.H. May Make Bid for Integrated
description: The I.C.H. Corporation said today that it was considering making a tender offer for control of Integrated Resources Inc. Integrated, a New York-based financial services concern, has 7.2 million shares outstanding. Based on today's closing price of $15.875, the whole company has a market value of $114.3 million. I.C.H. already controls 714,000 Integrated shares.

title: Alaska Officials Press Complaints Against Exxon on Cleanup of Oil
description: Alaska officials came to Washington today to press their complaints that the Exxon Corporation had misled the state about its ability to clean up an oil spill and was grossly exaggerating its success in cleaning up oil spilled in March from the tanker Exxon Valdez.

title: Books of The Times; Motherhood as More Than a Woman's Work
description: Maternal Thinking By Sara Ruddick 291 pages. Beacon Press. $24.95.

title: 'Yo Picasso' Brings $47.9 Million at Sotheby's
description: Picasso's ''Self-Portrait: Yo Picas-so,'' a 1901 blue-period painting that was bought in 1981 at Sotheby's for $5.8 million, was sold last night, again at Sotheby's, for $47.9 million. The price was the second highest paid for an artwork at auction, a figure exceeded only by the $53.9 million paid in November 1987 in the same rooms for van Gogh's ''Irises.''

title: For Movies' Tough Guy, a war at Home
description: It's always a guessing game in this town. Who will be next? What star will have his or her private life splashed all over the media in some seamy lawsuit brought by a lover done wrong? The current target is none other than Dirty Harry himself, a.k.a. Clint Eastwood, who, at age 58, with his laconic sneer and tough-guy epithets, has become a virtual American icon. A recent Esquire cover story noted that in 1985 young Americans put Mr. Eastwood at the top of their list of heroes, ahead of Ronald Reagan, the Pope and Mother Teresa.

title: Photo of Rod Strickland of the Knicks, and the Bulls' Horace Grant scrambling for the ball at Madison Square Garden. (NYT/Angel Franco) Knicks Fall as Jordan Takes Off in Overtime
description: The game went into overtime deadlocked, 103-103, last night at Madison Square Garden. It was the cue for Michael Jordan to take over. He did.

title: Castelli Gives Major Work to the Modern
description: The art dealer Leo Castelli has given the Museum of Modern Art a major work of postwar American art, Robert Rauschenberg's 1955 ''Bed.'' A pre-Pop icon whose use of everyday objects influenced Andy Warhol, Claes Oldenburg and their generation, ''Bed'' is a large ''combine painting'' composed of the artist's quilt, sheet and pillow savagely attacked with thick paint.

title: Administration Lobbies for its Savings Plan
description: The Bush Administration moved today to prevent the House Ways and Means Committee from approving a plan that would put the Government's entire cost of the savings and loan rescue on the books.

title: McCaw Cellular Communications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: McCaw said cellular service revenues in the period rose 74 percent to $68 million from $39 million a year earlier. The company said its latest quarter loss resulted from a hugh debt load incurred in acquiring the rights to offer cellular phone service. At March 31, the company had long term debt of $1.97 billion. The company currently owns the rights to sell to 50 million potential customers. It said higher interest expenses increased the loss.

description: Tony Mandarich, the offensive tackle who was the second player picked in the National Football League draft, was talking recently about the improbable prospect of his fighting Mike Tyson.
