Results Plus
description: TENNIS Maleeva Wins: Manuela Maleeva led a parade of favorites through the second round of the Italian Open women's championships yesterday in Rome. Second-seeded Maleeva of Bulgaria downed Barbara Romano of Italy, 6-3, 6-2; No. 3-seeded Helen Kelesi of Canada romped over 17-year-old Silvia Farina of Italy, 6-2, 6-2, while fourth-seeded Aranxta Sanchez came on strong in the second set to beat Linda Ferrando of Italy, 7-5, 6-1. (AP) Chang Prevails: Second-seeded Michael Chang, ranked No. 20 in the world, was extended to three sets yesterday before turning back unseeded Jimmy Brown, 3-6, 6-3, 6-4, in the first round of the $220,000 United States men's clay court championships at Charleston, S.C. In the one upset of the day, Barry Moir defeated No. 7-seeded Paul Annacone, 6-2, 3-6, 6-4. After splitting the first two sets, the players each held service only once through the first eight games of the third. With the set tied at 4-4, Chang broke Brown in the ninth game, then held service to win the match. (AP) Cycling Dutchman Takes 4th Stage: Gert-Jan Theunisse of the Netherlands left a pack of 20 riders with a mile and a half left yesterday and easily won the rain-dampened fourth stage of the Tour de Trump race. Theunisse, 26 years old, the 11th-place finisher in last year's Tour de France, was timed in 4 hours 41 minutes 54 seconds in the 111.5-mile leg from Gettysburg, Pa., to Winchester, Va., which progressed south on country roads into Maryland and ended under slippery conditions in northern Virginia. Eric Vanderaerden of Norway, winner of Monday's third stage, outsprinted Davis Phinney of Boulder, Colo., to finish second in 4:42:04. Phinney's effort, in the same time as Vanderaerden, was the first top-three finish by an American. Dag Otto Lauritzen of Norway retained his overall lead, finishing sixth. He holds a 17-second margin over Henk Lubberding of the Netherlands with a cumulative time of 20:32:56. Theunisse is third. The race featured a 40-mile breakaway by Mike Engleman of Santa Cruz, Calif. After riding alone for nearly two hours, he was caught and eventually finished 20th. (AP)

title: A Two-Year Siege of the Noriega Regime
description: June 6, 1987: Col. Roberto Diaz Herrera, second-in-command of the Panamanian Army, publicly accuses the commander, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, of electoral fraud and political murder. The accusations set off the first anti-Noriega protests, which the police suppress with tear gas and clubs. June 10: President Eric Arturo Delvalle, installed by General Noriega, declares a state of emergency suspending most basic rights. The opposition announces the creation of Civic Crusade, a coalition of about 200 business and labor groups. July 26: A man is shot and killed during an opposition march in the town of El Valle, the first fatality in the unrest. The opposition press is shut down. Sept. 24: In a sign of the erosion of longstanding United States Government support for Panama's military-dominated Government, the United States Senate unanimously approves a non-binding resolution urging Panama to establish a civilian government or face a cutoff of American aid. Feb. 4, 1988: The first of two drug and racketeering indictments against General Noriega is handed up by a Federal grand jury in Tampa, Fla. Feb. 25: President Delvalle tries to dismiss General Noriega, but is instead ousted himself by the National Assembly and goes into hiding. Former Education Minister Manuel Solis Palma, a Noriega ally, is appointed acting President. March 4: Panama closes banks after huge withdrawals by depositors. March 16: General Noriega puts down a coup attempt led by the police chief. Continuing street protests bring the capital to a halt. April 8: President Reagan prohibits American companies and the Government from making payments to Panama. Some $56 million in Panamanian accounts in American banks are frozen. May 8: Panama's banks open for limited withdrawals after a two-month closure. May 25: Secretary of State George P. Shultz announces that talks on a deal for General Noriega's departure have collapsed. Sept. 27: Mr. Solis Palma, at the United Nations General Assembly, condemns United States ''aggression'' against Panama. April 7, 1989: Panama announces the arrest of a United States citizen accused of running a clandestine anti-Noriega radio. Government officials say it is part of a United States plot to create unrest. May 7: National elections take place with charges of fraud by the opposition. Exit polls give the opposition a large lead. May 9: First official results give General Noriega's candidate a 2-to-1 lead. President Bush declares the elections fraudulent and calls for international pressure for General Noriega's ouster. Reuters

title: Costa Ricans Protest
description: The Costa Rican soccer federation announced yesterday it was protesting what it called poor treatment of its players and ''extremely bad refereeing'' at an April 30 World Cup qualifying game in Missouri against the United States. Willi Oconotrillo, the federation's manager, said Costa Rica was lodging the protest with FIFA, the sport's governing body. Costa Rica lost the game, 1-0. Oconotrillo said Rodolfo Martinez, the Honduran referee at the match, annulled two Costa Rican goals that the team is convinced were scored within the rules.(AP)

The collection of Impressionist and modern art, French 18th-century furniture and Chinese, English and German porcelains is valued at $105 million to $140 million, which is believed to be the highest estimate for a single collection in auction history.

description: The Army's growing reliance on reserve units is undercutting the ability of the United States to fight a multiple-front war, a new report says.

title: Kemper Financial Picks A Chairman for Invest
description: The Kemper Financial Companies said yesterday that James R. Boris had been named chairman of Invest, a company that provides products and services to financial institutions.

title: Corrections
description: A review and picture caption on Monday about a revival of the musical ''She Loves Me'' misidentified the producing company. It is the Opera Ensemble of New York, not of Manhattan.

title: Fine Wines From Lesser Vintages
description: Yves Fourault, the export director of Chateau Beychevelle, a leading Medoc estate, placed a glass of his 1987 vintage next to his 1984. His New York audience of 80 followed suit. They tasted. They compared. And they listened as he recalled a sometimes forgotten axiom: lesser vintages can yield fine wines.

title: Landmark Panel Vetoes Request to Raze Church
description: The Church of St. Paul and St. Andrew was denied permission yesterday to tear down its 92-year-old building on the Upper West Side of Manhattan, despite the congregation's contention that maintaining the landmark imposes a financial hardship.

title: 7 Wounded in New Violence In Disputed Azerbaijan Area
description: Seven people were wounded on Friday in renewed ethnic clashes in Nagorno-Karabakh, the press agency Tass said today.

title: Alaska Imposes Oil Tax Rise On 2 Big North Slope Fields
description: Alaska has enacted a tax increase on oil from two huge North Slope fields after the State Senate, responding to constituents' anger over the Exxon Valdez spill, ended its longtime resistance to the idea and sent the legislation Monday to Gov. Steve Cowper.

title: Recapturing the Joy of Police Work
description: When Jim Carvino arrived in Boise, Idaho, a few weeks ago to become Police Chief, he already had tactics in mind for handling the ''cruising'' problem he had heard so much about.

title: Gateway Communications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Negatively impacted by a one- time elimination of $67,000 of inter- company profit in inventory purchased in the recent aquisition of Micro Networks Pty. Ltd. (Australia).

title: Sea Galley Stores reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and included a tax credit of $62,000. The company attributed the loss in the latest first quarter to a combination of lower restaurant sales; a budgeted increase in marketing expenditures; training and other initial costs associated with the opening of its third ranch and home location in Mount Vernon, Wash.; and $81,000 in costs relating to three repossessed restaurants.

title: Ex-Mayor's Comeback Fails As Omaha Elects New Chief
description: P. J. Morgan, a millionaire businessman, was elected Mayor today, ending a political comeback attempt by Mike Boyle, who was ousted from the job in a recall vote two years ago.

title: Transcript of Bush's News Conference on the Panama Vote
description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's news conference today on the Panamanian elections, as recorded by the Federal News Service: OPENING STATEMENT

title: At Seedy Mall, Bakkers Make Bid for Revival
description: A boarded-up department store in a nearly deserted shopping center has been turned into a television studio for a new television program put on by the evangelist Jim Bakker, the latest move in his efforts to rebuild his television ministry.

title: Sonesta International Hotels reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bush Says He'd Hoped North Would Be Cleared of Charges
description: President Bush, in his first public comment on the Oliver North verdict, said today that he had ''wanted all along to see him exonerated.''

title: Leningrad Journal; It Hurts to Be Old and Poor in a Classless Society
description: In a spare, sunny cafeteria on a quiet street in this city's center, an organization of volunteers has won a battle to overcome public and official attitudes toward the country's poor.

title: Nairobi Orders Ban on 2d Magazine in a Year
description: A lively, up-and-coming weekly news magazine has been banned here, making it the second publication to be barred in the last year.

title: Company News; RJR Nabisco Plans to Sell Europe Units
description: The long-expected downsizing of RJR Nabisco Inc. began yesterday with the announcement by the food and tobacco giant that it had put five big European food businesses on the block.

title: 2 CHEMISTS DEFEND FUSION EXPERIMENT
description: Two chemists who assert that they have created nuclear fusion in a jar staunchly defended their experiment at a meeting Monday night, saying they had new evidence that their device produces bursts of energy.

title: High Seas, Haute Cuisine
description: LEAD: IT'S not hard to turn out a first-class meal on a 96-foot ketch heeled over 30 degrees and slamming through the sea at 20 knots in a galley the size of a postage stamp. Not, that is, if you have the agility of Olga Korbut, the culinary knowledge of Escoffier, the savoir-faire of Maurice Chevalier and the sense of humor of Mel Brooks.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertsing; K Mart and CBS to Join In Promotion
description: CBS, once known as the Tiffany network, has decided to shop at K Mart.

title: Debt Relief For Farmers
description: The Government's chief farm lender may lose as much as $4 billion as it plows through a backlog of $9 billion in bad debts stemming from the farm crisis of the early and mid-1980's, agency officials said today.

title: Community Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the year-ago share earnings figure was not available because no stock was issued prior to last November.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertsing; Johnson Wax Shifts Accounts
description: SC Johnson & Son shifted more than $35 million of accounts to Foote, Cone & Belding yesterday, consolidating its $90 million advertising business at the agency's Chicago and San Francisco offices.

title: Food Notes
description: Great Labels

title: Dawson Is Hurt
description: Andre Dawson, the Chicago Cubs' slugging outfielder who was the National League's most valuable player in 1987, has torn cartilage on the inside of his right knee and will undergo arthroscopic surgery tomorrow.He is expected to be lost to his team for at least a month. Dawson, who has had two previous operations on each knee, may also have damaged cartilage on the outside of the knee.

title: Prof. Karl Brunner Is Dead at 73; Economist and Early Monetarist
description: Karl Brunner, an economist who was a pioneer and a leading member of the monetarist movement, died yesterday at his home in Rochester after an extended illness. He was 73 years old.

title: Checks for Pesticide Increase in Arkansas At Processing Plants
description: An Agriculture Department official said today that all federally inspected plants for slaughtering poultry and hogs in Arkansas had been put under ''intensified surveillance'' for traces of the pesticide heptachlor, which has been found to cause cancer in animals.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertsing; People
description: * Madigan Pratt has been named executive vice president of Kaprielian/ O'Leary Advertising.

title: Muslim Side in Lebanon Keeps Up Fierce Shelling to Deny Foe Arms
description: Determination by Syrian troops and their Muslim militia allies to prevent new arms shipments from reaching Christian forces is keeping artillery battles at fierce pitch here despite an Arab-brokered cease-fire.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Districtspeak; The making of a Deal on a New Jet Fighter
description: A Senate Armed Services subcommittee met this afternoon to consider the Bush Administration's deal with Japan on the joint development of a new military plane, the FSX, or Fighter Support Experimental. The Senate Foreign Relations Committee will take up the FSX issue on Wednesday. In the Senate's background material is the transcript of a special form of communication, ''an oral exchange,'' in which governments reach for a diplomatic understanding before arriving at a more binding written agreement. Here are the words spoken last month by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and the Japanese Ambassador, Nobuo Matsunaga, that became the oral exchange on the FSX fighter.

title: 'Plain Folks' of Pro-Choice
description: To The Living Section:

title: Top Trader In Futures Subpoenaed
description: One of the richest and most influential commodity traders in the world was subpoenaed last week as part of the Government's civil investigation of trading on the floors of four New York commodity exchanges, people involved in the case said last night.

title: Pop Life
description: Mellencamp on Losers

title: Court Overturns Conviction In Day-Care Sex Scandal
description: The state's highest court yesterday overturned the conviction of a former teacher on rape and sodomy charges stemming from a scandal at a Bronx day-care center five years ago that helped focus attention on the sexual abuse of children.

title: New Polish Devaluation
description: Poland devalued its currency, the zloty, Monday for the fifth time this year, reducing its value by 4.23 percent, according to new exchange rates published by the official press agency P.A.P. There were three devaluations last month, the most recent on April 24. The new official rate, which applies only to foreign tourists and foreign trade dealings, is 710 zloties to the dollar, compared with 680 on Friday. The zloty has been devalued by almost 30 percent since Jan. 1, when the rate was 503 to the dollar.

title: Company News; One Hurdle Left for Minorco After Gold Fields Ends Suit
description: Minorco S.A., the overseas investment arm of South Africa's Anglo American mining group, advanced to a final hurdle today in its battle for control of Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C.

title: Warriors Get Even
description: Chris Mullin scored 37 points, and Winston Garland scored 5 of his 11 points in a decisive 7-0 run late in the fourth quarter tonight as the Golden State Warriors beat the Phoenix Suns, 127-122, to even their Western Conference semifinal playoff series at one victory apiece.

title: Philadelphia Fare on Hold
description: Judge Samuel Lehrer of Common Pleas Court today barred the Southeastern Pennsylvania Transportation Authority from raising fares on subways, buses and trolleys until a higher court decides whether the poor got a fair chance to be heard.

title: Wal-Mart Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
A Dizzy Gillespie Film
description: ''A Night in Havana: Dizzy Gillespie in Cuba,'' a documentary on the jazz trumpeter's visit to Cuba in 1985, will be screened at the Bleecker Street Cinema, 144 Bleecker Street, next Tuesday at 6 P.M., in advance of the film's premiere there. A reception at the Village Gate, 160 Bleecker Street, will follow. The evening's proceeds are to benefit the Jazz and Contemporary Music program at the New School for Social Research. Tickets are $10; $100 tickets include two free drinks and admission to the Blue Note, 131 West Third Street, where Mr. Gillespie is to perform at 9 P.M. Information: 741-8950.

title: Not All the Food at Airports Is Earthbound, a Sampling Finds
description: SPENDING three weeks on the road and passing through 16 airports is reason enough for forming opinions about regional foods. While airports are seldom known for the quality of their food, for many travelers they provide the only taste of local specialties.

title: Denver Judge Voids Plan to Use Fees on Airlines to Pay for Airport
description: A Federal judge has ruled that airlines cannot be forced to pay for a new Denver airport through higher usage fees, and the decision is expected to limit local governments' ability to raise funds to finance future airports, industry experts said yesterday.

title: Psicor Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Finevest Foods Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Genisco Technology reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $32,063 and $72,435 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss

title: Chyron Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $143,000. c-Net income and included a gain of $515,000 from a change in accounting.

title: Centex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $50,100,000 from an accounting change. Th company had net from operations for fiscal year ended March 31, 1988 of $24,063,000, or $1.50 a share.

title: Credit Markets; U.S. Notes and Bonds Off in Moderate Trading
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell sharply in moderately active trading yesterday, as dealers sold securities in advance of upcoming auctions of 10-year notes and 30-year bonds.

title: McCann Leads Jersey City Voting But Cunningham Forces a Runoff
description: Former Mayor Gerald McCann, who was defeated four years ago after a bitter campaign that saw the city's minority-group voters and tenant associations oppose his re-election, made a comeback today, finishing first in a field of 10 mayoral candidates and winning a spot in a runoff that will be held on June 13.

title: Presidential Life reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest quarter results included a gain of one cent a share from investment gains versus a gain of seven cents a year ago. Year-ago results are restated to reflect the adoption of FASB 97.

title: Semiconductor Orders Rise
description: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator showed continued strength as United States semiconductor orders reached another all-time high in April, a trade group reported today.

title: WRIGHT'S LAWYERS SEEK CURB ON FOE
description: In the first move of an all-out defense against charges of Congressional misconduct, Speaker Jim Wright's new team of lawyers filed five motions with the House ethics committee today, including one that would bar the committee's counsel from contact with committee members outside formal channels.

title: Slogans Ready, Solidarity Takes Stab at the Hustings
description: In a concrete schoolyard in the Nowa Huta district of Cracow, Mieczyslaw Gil's jabbing hand seemed to be poking a hole in a wall of popular doubt about Poland's coming elections.

title: Swift Energy Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
At Kaffeeklatsch, L.I. Taxpayer Gives Cuomo an Earful
description: Carolyn Schiller wrote an impassioned letter to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to complain about her skyrocketing property taxes and to invite the Governor to drop by and discuss the issue ''face to face.'' That was in February.

title: HOUSE PANEL SEES 4 SOVIET OFFICIALS
description: Customarily, the House Armed Services committee's hearing room is the imposing setting for testimony by the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the Defense Secretary and, occasionally, high-ranking intelligence officers.

title: Haupt's Latest Gift to the Met: $1.5 Million for the Cloisters
description: ''Do you remember the first gift you ever gave the museum?'' Philippe de Montebello, director of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, asked Enid A. Haupt yesterday. ''It was 1946, you gave us $10 and it has been uphill ever since.''

title: Information Solutions reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company changed to a calendar year-end for 1989. In the first quarter ended April 30, 1988, Information Solutions reported a loss of $570,688 on sales of $1,721,515. Latest quarter net equals less than one cent a share.

title: Duran Goes to Court
description: Roberto Duran, the World Boxing Council's middleweight champion, who is hoping to fight the winner of next month's Sugar Ray Leonard-Thomas Hearns fight, will be in court in Miami Thursday to settle his financial difficulties with the Internal Revenue Service.

title: Starving for Art
description: It is a truth universally acknowledged that artists starve. Unless they hit it big, that is; then the feasting is high on the hog. What is not so generally acknowledged is that those who always eat high on the hog are apt to be starving for artists.

title: One Liberty Properties reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
As Spain Heeds Europe's Call, the Americas Fret
description: With 1992 marking both the fifth centenary of its discovery of the Americas and a turning point in its integration into Europe, Spain is already feeling the tug between its old ties to Latin America and its new links to Western Europe.

title: Opposition Tells Noriega to Face the Facts and Asks the U.S. to Hold Its Fire
description: The Panamanian opposition tried today to bring pressure on Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to accept the results of Sunday's election, which the opposition, backed by the opinion of independent observers, contends that it won.

title: Review/Dance; New 'Swan Lake' Opens Ballet Theater Season
description: Relax. Mikhail Baryshnikov's ambitious new production of ''Swan Lake'' for American Ballet Theater is not nearly so eccentric or revamped as advance word had it.

title: Bank Funds, C.D.'s Show Little Change
description: Yields for certificates of deposit and bank money-market accounts showed little change for the week that ended yesterday. But more deposit rates were beginning to decline than a week earlier.

title: Daimler Forgoes Song and Dance
description: At a dinner preceding Daimler-Benz's news conference last year to report 1987 earnings, a cabaret star performed a song-and-dance routine about the company's history and future. At this year's dinner, not a sequin was in sight.

title: KEY RATES
Senate's Inquiry on Cheating Of Indians Cites Oil Concern
description: Investigators implicated a Kansas-based oil company today in testimony before a Senate panel that is checking allegations that millions of dollars in oil and royalties have been stolen from Indians.

title: National Intergroup Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $460,000 for the quarter and a loss from discontinued operations of $13,839,000 for the year; a loss from disposal of discontinued operations of $2,988,000 and $4,398,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; and an extraordinary gain of $1,300,000 and $11,015,000 for the same periods, respectively. c-Included $1,433,000 income from discontinued operations, a $745,000 loss from disposal of discontinued operations, a $92,000 extraordinary gain, and a $2,655,000 gain from an accounting change. d-Net loss Latest year results included $7,813,000 provision for the sale of a Luxembourg facility. Year-ago quarter results included $2,099,000 income from discontinued operations; a $745,000 loss from disposal of discontinued operations; a $908,000 extraordinary charge; a provision of $24 million for an anticipated loss on the sale of an aluminum plant; and a charge of $7.6 million for elimination of a deferred gain previously recognized. Prior-year results included $24,000,000 provision for the sale of a Luxembourg facility.

title: Handy & Harman reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Soviets Buy American
description: Donald M. Kendall chuckles about his gibe at Brent Scowcroft. ''We're disarming the Soviet Union faster than you are,'' the head of Pepsico told President Bush's national security adviser.

title: Canal Pacts: U.S. Looking At Dire Straits
description: The Panama Canal treaties, once again the subject of debate here, help explain why the United States has an exceptionally deep interest in the stability and internal affairs of Panama.

title: Michigan Building Agency Sets $158 Million Offering
description: The Michigan State Building Authority is tentatively offering $158 million in tax-exempt revenue bonds with a maximum yield of about 7.35 percent for an issue due in 2008 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Janice Poliak, Philanthropist, 79
description: Janice Poliak, a philanthropist whose donation helped establish the Center for the Study of First Amendment Issues at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, died of lung cancer yesterday at Danbury (Conn.) Hospital. She was 79 years old and had homes in Redding, Conn., Manhattan and Montego Bay, Jamaica.

title: K. Fenton Trimingham, Executive, 75
description: K. Fenton Trimingham, a former president and chairman of the board of Trimingham Bros. Ltd., one of Bermuda's largest department stores, died of a heart attack Sunday in Antigua. He was 75 years old and lived in Paget, Bermuda.

title: General Magnaplate Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Regulators Criticize Oyster Creek Plant
description: Radiation controls at the aging Oyster Creek nuclear power plant have grown lax, and overall operations in recent months have been inconsistent, Federal regulators say.

title: Teacher and a School Official Are Charged in Cocaine Sales
description: A Brooklyn high school teacher and a central Board of Education administrator were charged yesterday with selling cocaine to undercover police officers, the Brooklyn District Attorney said.

title: World's Top-Selling Car
description: The Ford Motor Company said its Escort model was the world's best-selling car in 1988 for the seventh consecutive year. It said the Toyota Corolla was the second-most-popular car.

title: Drug-Free Therapy Has Helped Thousands
description: To the Editor:

title: Prism Entertainment reports earnings for Year to Jan 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $179,000.

title: F.D.A. Bribe Charges Filed
description: Federal bribery charges were filed in Baltimore yesterday against Charles Y. Chang, a former branch chief in the Food and Drug Administration.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: Ameron Inc., Monterey Park, Calif., which makes construction products, named Lawrence R. Tollenaere chairman and chief executive and Thomas J. Keefe president.

title: Rangers' Leach Is Questioned
description: Rick Leach, the Texas Rangers' designated hitter, who did not show up for the game with the Yankees Monday night, reappeared yesterday afternoon. When he did, he learned he had received a summons for having marijuana in his luggage.

title: A Victim of Tuna
description: Here is a puzzle:

title: Viacom Antitrust Suit Against HBO
description: Worried by the increasing competition from Time Inc.'s Home Box Office in pay television, Viacom Inc., which owns Showtime, said yesterday that two of its subsidiaries had filed an antitrust suit against HBO and other Time-controlled cable operations, including Manhattan Cable Television Inc., in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Return of the Pressure Cooker: Nutritious Meals in a Hurry
description: LEAD: IF you're looking for a fast track to home-cooked meals consider this: There is a single pot in which you can prepare many main-course dishes in a matter of minutes.

title: Study Weighs Excise Tax Rise
description: The Government could obtain as much as $75.3 billion over five years if it decided to raise various excise taxes by enough to compensate for inflation since 1965, the General Accounting Office reported today.

title: Esposito's Daughter Sentenced in Fraud
description: The daughter of the former Brooklyn Democratic leader Meade H. Esposito was sentenced yesterday to one year of house arrest and fined $250,000 for tax fraud.

title: Mogilny Files Application For U.S. Political Asylum
description: Aleksandr Mogilny, who left the Soviet national team in Stockholm last week to play for the Buffalo Sabres, filed for political asylum today in the United States.

title: Reno Journal; Casino Glitz Is Clearer Through Smokeless Air
description: In a city where gaudy neon advertises potential pleasures at every turn, the Ponderosa Casino has only one neon sign. Its message: ''No smoking.''

title: Glaxo Holdings Names New Chief Executive
description: Ernest Mario, who heads Glaxo Inc., a large American pharmaceutical concern, yesterday was named chief executive of Glaxo Holdings P.L.C., the parent company based in London.

title: Security Federal Savings & Losn Cleveland reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $80,000 from prepayment of debt. Per share figures for 1988 are not available because the company converted to stock ownership on Jan. 15, 1988.

title: Dona Guimaraes, 63, an Editor Of the Times Home Design Section
description: Dona Guimaraes, editor of the Home Design and Entertaining sections of The New York Times Magazine, died of lung cancer Monday night at New York Hospital. She was 63 years old and lived in Manhattan and Quogue, L.I.

title: Lawson Mardon Group Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Paul Dessibourg, Restaurateur, Dies at 62
description: Paul Dessibourg, a restaurateur and head waiter who was associated with Le Pavillion, La Grenouille, La Cote Basque, and Le Perigord, among other New York City restaurants, died Monday at Mt. Sinai Hospital after a brief illness. He was 62 years old and lived in Astoria, Queens.

title: Sex Harassment Suit Accuses Disk Jockey
description: A former radio personality at a Norwalk station charged in a lawsuit that a disk jockey and the station manager had sexually harassed her on and off the air.

title: Death in Dominican Strike
description: A 24-hour general strike over food prices and inflation paralyzed Santo Domingo and about 20 other cities today. A youth was killed and 20 people were arrested in clashes with the police.

title: Solidarity Joins Warsaw in Urging End to Strikes
description: With unaccustomed harmony, the Government and Solidarity appealed today to striking workers at copper mines in southwest Poland to go back to work.

title: Japan Bids Welcome (in 7 Figures) to Reagan
description: Upset about recent strains in relations with the United States, Japan is making lavish plans to welcome former President Ronald Reagan to Tokyo later this year for 10 days of speeches, ceremonies and visits with business and political leaders.

title: India Presses, And Nepalese Feel the Pinch
description: A smallcrowded bridge over a shallow stream here on the border between India and Nepal has become the focus of a political and trade confrontation between the two neighbors that has generated resentment on both sides and hard times in the Himalayan kingdom.

title: Somerset Bankshares Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
description: b-Net income The company said the latest fourth quarter and year losses are due principally to increases in loan loss reserves.

title: Society's Swans Glide Through Ballet Benefit
description: After the final curtain call for American Ballet Theater's new ''Swan Lake'' at the Metropolitan Opera House, a corps of social swans glided out to dance in the tent that Blaine Trump had pitched on the Lincoln Center Plaza.

title: OPEC Could Raise Output
description: Rising global demand for crude oil might permit the Organization of Petroleum of Exporting Countries to lift its output next month, Subroto, the organization's Secretary General, said today.

title: Chefs Who Owe It All to Mom
description: IT is the relationship, they say, that is at the crux of all love affairs to follow. So it should come as no surprise that food is no exception. Ask any number of chefs from whom they learned to love to cook and chances are they'll say, their mother.

title: Corrections
description: The Off Off Broadway listing of the Arts and Leisure Section last Sunday gave an incorrect telephone number for the Riverwest Theater. The number for the theater, which is presenting ''Chekhov in Love,'' is 243-0259.

title: 10 Held in Drug Trafficking
description: Ten people were indicted yesterday on charges of running a drug trafficking ring at a city housing project in the Bronx, where four apartments were seized by Federal marshals.

title: Aon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Guatemala's Civilian Chief Foils a 2d Coup Attempt
description: Loyalist troops crushed a coup attempt today by air force officers and soldiers, the second abortive attempt in a year to topple the young democracy of President Vinicio Cerezo.

title: Citicorp Rates Fall
description: Interest rates declined yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper. It was the second straight drop this month. The bank holding company said it sold $50 million in 91-day paper at an average rate of 9.595 percent, down from 9.679 percent last week. It also sold $50 million worth of 182-day paper at an average rate of 9.423 percent, down from 9.561 percent. Citicorp said it expected to sell the same amounts of commercial paper at its auction next week.

title: Stewart Sandwiches reports earnings for Qtr to March 24
description: b-Included a tax charge of $89,188 and $92,566 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: About New York; Finland's Sauna: Where the Mists Of Discord Fade
description: We take you to a high-powered business meeting, that pulsing lifeblood of New York City. The location is big time: the 43d floor of 30 Rockefeller Center.

title: Review/Piano; Bach Specialist Plays Chopin and Brahms
description: Edward Aldwell's reputation as a Bach pianist has expanded over the last half-dozen years but is still inexplicably confined to a comparatively small circle of musicians and connoisseurs, many of whom were present to cheer his recital on Monday evening at Merkin Concert Hall. If the leisurely pace of Mr. Aldwell's career is by his own choice, one can only applaud such rare circumspection in a gifted artist. A more likely reason, I suspect, is the nature of the traditional piano audience itself, which pays dutiful homage to Bach but, given the choice, votes to hear Chopin and Brahms.

title: NBC Leads the Ratings For 46th Straight Week
description: NBC dominated the prime-time television ratings last week for the 46th consecutive time, tying a record set by CBS in the 1962-63 season. While NBC had 6 of the top 10 shows, according to the A .C. Nielsen Company, ''Roseanne,'' on ABC, continued to displace ''The Cosby Show,'' on NBC, in the No. 1 position.

title: Yankees Walk Over the Rangers
description: The Texas Rangers injected the Yankees' offense with Charlie Hough last night, and he was one of the best antidotes the Yankees have had for their anemic offense.

description: b-Net income

title: Poulin Helps Flyers Escape Elimination
description: The embattled Flyers, who didn't play as warily as they felt, will live to fight another day.

title: Dow Declines by 5.14 as Retreat Continues
description: LEAD: The stock market fell again yesterday and the Dow Jones industrial average recorded its eighth loss in a row.

title: Ex-Chairman of State G.O.P. To Head Lauder's Campaign
description: George L. Clark Jr., a former chairman of the New York State and Brooklyn Republican organizations, was appointed chairman of the Ronald S. Lauder mayoral campaign yesterday.

title: Review/Television; Vidal Draws a Bead on Good-Bad Old Billy the Kid
description: Tonight's two-hour play on the TNT cable channel at 8 o'clock is billed as ''Gore Vidal's Billy the Kid,'' but it is more like Billy the Kid's Gore Vidal. The essayist and novelist, known for construing American history in his fashion, has accepted many of the conventions of the Western form in his script about one of the most written-up good-bad boys of the old West. The result is an O.K. low-key show that brings the smiles and yawns of familiarity.

title: 31 Newcomers on Black Business List
description: Thirty-one new companies joined the list of the nation's 100 largest black-owned industrial and service companies, according to an annual survey compiled by Black Enterprise magazine.

title: Top Producer Replaced At NBC Sports Division
description: Terry O'Neil has been appointed the executive producer of NBC Sports.

description: The company said share earnings are fully diluted, reflecting $20 million of convertible subordinated debentures which the company redeemed on Feb. 28, 1989.

title: Convergent Solutions reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting change of $191,000.

title: O. Edmund Clubb Is Dead at 88; China Hand and McCarthy Target
description: O. Edmund Clubb, a United States Foreign Service officer who became a major target of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy's investigation of supposedly disloyal Americans in the State Department in the early 1950's, died of Parkinson's disease Tuesday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Palenville, N.Y.

title: Rockefeller Center Properties Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $5,027,000, or 13 cents a share, resulting from the company's program to repurchase a portion of its outstanding convertible debentures.

From 'Big Blue' to Big Blue: Find Another Name, or Else
description: Who is the true Big Blue?

title: DISPUTED ELECTION NULLIFIED; Bush's Trap On Panama
description: President Bush's effort to win international support for the ouster of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian military leader, is an attempt to turn a crippling liability into a diplomatic asset.

title: Contenders For Rich List
description: Bragging rights to the title ''richest man in America'' may have just changed hands: Institutional Investor reports that Ronald O. Perelman, chairman of the Revlon Group, has upstaged Sam M. Walton, the founder and chairman of Wal-Mart Stores Inc. of Bentonville, Ark.

title: Officials Blame Each Other for Failing to Cut Crime
description: Crime has rapidly eclipsed other issues as the most pressing problem facing New York City, officials at all levels of government say.

title: Charter Panel Is Proposing Planning Unit
description: The commission rewriting the New York City charter proposed a new City Planning Commission yesterday that would initiate broad zoning laws and oversee most decisions on using public and private land.

title: Acting Chancellor: Tough Man but Seeker of Consensus
description: To whatever degree an acting schools chancellor can have an impact on the system, the tenure of Bernard Mecklowitz is likely to be characterized by collegiality in reaching decisions and ''no dilly-dallying'' toward achieving goals.

title: BENTSEN AND BUSH CLASH ON SURTAX
description: There was another skirmish today in the battle between the Administration and Congress over the surtax many older Americans are paying for extended benefits under the Medicare program. Congressional economists project a large surplus, while the Administration, in a new study, projects a large deficit.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Campbell Soup In Settlement
description: The Campbell Soup Company agreed yesterday to pay $315,000 to nine states to settle lawsuits over disputed claims in its advertising. The states accused Campbell of running ads that made fraudulent nutritional claims about some of its soups. In settling the suits, Campbell did not acknowledge any wrongdoing.

title: Moore Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
In Concrete, Sentinels Of Time
description: FOR Miguel Goarmon Palma, a Portuguese artist, time is truly of the essence. An exhibition of 16 of his clocks opens today at Modern Stone Age, a gallery at 111 Greene Street, between Prince and Spring Streets, in SoHo.

title: Inspection of Seafood Gets Yeutter's Backing
description: Agriculture Secretary Clayton K. Yeutter today endorsed mandatory health and safety inspections of all commercial seafood destined for consumption in the United States.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball BOSTON (AL) - Extended the contract of Dwight Evans, outfielder, through the 1990 season with an option for 1991. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Activated Greg Brock, first baseman, from the 21-day disabled list and assigned him to Beloit of the Midwest League for a 20-day rehabilitation period. Sent Joey Meyer, first baseman-designated hitter, to Denver of the American Association. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Traded Ken Oberkfell, infielder, to San Francisco for Roger Samuels, pitcher. Basketball L.A. CLIPPERS (NBA) - Announced the resignation of Jack Gallagher, director of public relations, effective May 19. Colleges BETHEL - Announced the resignation of Felix Grimmett, men's basketball coach, to become an assistant coach at Emporia State. DAYTON - Named Tom Conroy, Clarence Carter, and Tom McConnell, assistant basketball coaches. DePAUL - Named Robert Collins assistant men's basketball coach. EASTERN KENTUCKY - Named Mike Pollio men's basketball coach. FLORIDA - Named Jim Weaver associate athletic director for men's spring sports. ILLINOIS - Named Dana Brenner and Bob Todd associate athletic directors. ROCHESTER - Named Kevin Naughton head men's lacrosse coach and assistant football coach. RUTGERS - Announced the resignation of Pat Coyle, assistant basketball coach. Football L.A. RAMS (NFC) - Signed Richard Ashe, tight end; Robert Harrison, fullback; Rick McLeod and Robert Sledge, offensive tackles; Ronald Nesbitt, guard; Gregg Wolfson, safety; Marty Zendejas, place-kicker, and Tyrone McCullough, wide receiver. PITTSBURGH (AFC) - Signed Scott Garl, defensive back; Eric Wilkerson, running back, and Cammie Collins, linebacker. TAMPA BAY (NFC) - Signed Walter Odom and William Harris, tight ends; John Adleta, nose tackle; Jeff Garinca, center; Richard Gould, guard; Kemit Kendrick, safety; Maurice Oliver, linebacker, and Todd Smith, wide receiver. Soccer MAJOR INDOOR SOCCER LEAGUE -Named Earl Foreman commisioner.

title: Has Success Spoiled Seton Hall?
description: You don't have to travel far on the Seton Hall campus to be reminded that the Pirate basketball team came within a couple of free throws of a national championship this season. Congratulatory banners are still hanging and Final Four T-shirts are still in fashion among the 8,800 students at the school.

title: Soviet Center and Periphery Still Struggle; Give Lenin Credit
description: To the Editor:

title: Allegations on Rose
description: A former friend of Pete Rose says he plans to tell a Federal grand jury that the Cincinnati Reds' manager gambled and knowingly associated with wealthy drug traffickers, The Cincinnati Post reported today.

title: Q&A
description: Fluorescent Lamp Hum

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;  People
description: * Steve Burger has been promoted to director of media operations at Bayer Bess Vanderwarker.

title: Shakespeare Wrote Shakespeare. Believe It.
description: To the Editor:

title: Bush Is in Excellent Health, Doctor Says After Checkup
description: President Bush today completed a three-hour physical examination, and his doctor said afterward that Mr. Bush ''is in extremely sound physical condition.''

title: Heavy Use of Aspirin Substitute Is Linked to Kidney Disease
description: Heavy and prolonged use of acetaminophen, the active ingredient in many painkillers used as substitutes for aspirin, may lead to kidney disease, researchers reported yesterday.

title: F W Woolworth Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
Chairman Retires at Natural History Museum
description: Robert G. Goelet retired as chairman of the American Museum of Natural History on Tuesday, it was announced yesterday. His successor is William T. Golden, who has been a museum trustee since 1968 and is chairman of the New York Academy of Sciences.

title: Washington Talk: Exact Words; Weeding Out Traitors to Nurture Loyalty
description: From the Security Education Handbook, produced by the Department of Energy's Office of Safeguards and Security, which is charged with ''procedures for implementation of a security education program for Department of Energy employees,'' particularly those in the nuclear weapons program:

title: Deaths of Dolphins Along Atlantic Tied To a Natural Toxin
description: A natural toxin from the Gulf of Mexico that flowed north in red tides probably helped kill hundreds of bottlenose dolphin along the Atlantic Coast in recent years, a Canadian marine biologist told a House panel today.

title: Practicing What They Preach
description: THE Brooklyn-based Old-House Journal, the bible for owners of historic houses, has long counseled its ardent subscribers against home ''remuddling,'' or renovations to avoid, as well as other fine points of historic preservation.

title: Lancaster Colony Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

BUSINESS PEOPLE;
D.F. King Owner Moves To Position of Chairman
description: LEAD: D. F. King & Co., a privately held financial communications company that solicits shareholders' proxies and advises corporate management in takeover battles, has elevated its longtime senior executive and owner, John W. Cornwell, to the position of chairman.

title: Reviews/Dance; Two Ballet Theater Newcomers in 'Swan Lake'
description: Andris Liepa, a leading dancer from the Bolshoi Ballet who is on leave to dance with American Ballet Theater this year, and Christine Dunham, one of the company's new principals, stepped into the main roles of ''Swan Lake'' Tuesday night for the first time at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Police to Investigate Sex Abuse at Princeton
description: A Princeton University graduate student who maintains he was sexually abused by a faculty member last fall has given a statement to the Princeton Township police describing the incident.

title: S.E.C. Backs Changes In Securities Arbitration
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission today unanimously approved changes in the securities industry's arbitration system, which is being used to settle a growing number of disputes between brokers and clients.

title: Recruiting Reagan
description: The payoff scandal that toppled a Japanese Prime Minister is now reaching out to entangle a former U.S. President.

title: Cae Industries Ltd reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-After a $399,000 charge from the sale of the Cae metal abrasive division. c-Included a $2,217,000 gain. Year-ago figures have been restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: The Long And the Short
description: It was 1974 when scientists first calculated that chemicals used in aerosol sprays and other products would deplete the earth's ozone layer. The Du Pont Company, dismissing the finding as ''speculative,'' fought proposed legislation. To restrict the chemicals ''would cause tremendous economic dislocation,'' a Du Pont official said.

title: TV Program On Abortion Loses Ads
description: Pressure from a fundamentalist religious group has prompted several advertisers to withdraw from ''Roe vs. Wade,'' a dramatization of the 1973 Supreme Court decision that legalized abortion, NBC executives said yesterday.

title: Bush Condemns Attack; Weighs Sending Troops
description: President Bush today condemned attacks on opposition leaders in Panama, and a White House official said tonight that there is ''a strong possibility'' that Mr. Bush would increase the number of United States troops in Panama to protect American citizens and servicemen.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions of Business Day yesterday misidentified a New York commodity trader who received a subpoena from the Commodity Futures Trading Commission as part of its investigation of the futures markets. It was Paul Tudor Jones 2d (not John Tudor Jones) who said he had been informed that he was not a target of the investigation.

title: A MISSING H-BOMB RUFFLES JAPANESE
description: Japan's Foreign Minister said today that his country was ''seriously concerned'' about the loss of a hydrogen bomb off Okinawa 24 years ago, and said Japan would press for ''full details'' about the incident from the United States.

title: In China Asylum Case, Abortion Isn't the Issue
description: To the Editor:

title: Navy Fire Victims Named
description: The Navy today released the names of the six sailors killed Tuesday in a fire on the supply ship White Plains in the South China Sea. Killed were Baxter Lesarlley, of Santa Fe, N.M.; Jon Rummel, of Elmira, N.Y.; Muoi Cao, of Ventura, Calif.; Todd Follis, of Zuni, N.M.; Paul Novotny, of Howells, Me.; and Darryl Edwards, of Flossmoor, Ill. A fuel leak apparently sparked the fire in the ship's main engine room, the Navy said.

title: Pentagon Off Target by $150 Billion, Studies Say
description: Despite large cuts already undertaken by Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, the Pentagon's spending plans will exceed what it is likely to get from Congress by at least $150 billion over the next five years, according to two reports released today.

title: Fire Kills Half a Million Mice
description: About 500,000 laboratory mice were killed and four construction workers and a firefighter were injured today in a fire at the Jackson Laboratory, the world's leading nonprofit supplier of genetically identical mice used in research on cancer, AIDS, diabetes and other human diseases. The cause of the blaze, which broke out at 1:15 P.M. in a building used to house and breed mice for research, has not been determined.

title: Peanut Use Rises in U.S.
description: United States peanut consumption rose by 10.8 percent in the first eight months of the current peanut marketing year from the period a year earlier, according to a Department of Agriculture report. It said that Americans ate 18 percent more peanut butter, 7.2 percent more salted nuts and 1.2 percent more candy bars containing nuts in the period. Don Koehler, executive director of the Georgia Peanut Commission, said the increased demand represented about $85 million in added sales for producers nationwide.

title: Washington Talk; Justice
description: In a chamber awash with hyperbole, Representative Lee Hamilton is known as a man of caution, hardly the sort who would pick a fight with the President of the United States.

title: Rent Panel Backs Increase, Up to >9 1/2%
description: Saying they lacked any real input or power, two members of the New York City Rent Guidelines Board resigned in protest yesterday, just moments before the board proposed increases of 6 1/2 and 9 1/2 percent on one- and two-year lease renewals for rent-stabilized apartments.

title: DISPUTED ELECTION NULLIFIED
description: Paramilitary squads attacked the opposition presidential and vice-presidential candidates today, severely beating them with steel pipes and baseball bats as soldiers stood by.

title: Monarch Capital Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a charge from the early extinguishment of debt of $1,437,000. Year-ago first quarter restated to reflect the adoption of new accounting standards.

title: Record Alligator Is Caught
description: A trapper has harpooned the biggest alligator on record in Florida, a 13-foot, 10 1/2-inch reptile that weighed 1,043 pounds. Biologists needed a tow truck to maneuver the animal onto three scales. Columbus White, a licensed trapper, hauled the alligator out of a lake near Gainesville April 17 because patrons of a nearby fish camp felt threatened, the Florida Game and Freshwater Fish Commission said Tuesday.

title: Schools Chancellor Green Is Dead; New York System Faces Disarray
description: Dr. Richard R. Green, the head of the New York City schools for only 14 months, died suddenly after an asthma attack early yesterday, leaving the leadership of the nation's largest schools system in disarray.

title: U.S. MAY REVAMP ITS SALARY SET-UP
description: Spurred by difficulty in hiring qualified people in expensive cities around the country, the Government seems likely to abandon its uniform pay system in which Federal clerk-typists in New York City, for example, earn no more than those in Little Rock, Ark.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: A FEW weeks ago, with too much to think about, I sought out an old comfort zone: the balcony of City Center. Here I used to sit, watching Diana Adams and Jacques d'Amboise and Arthur Mitchell and Tanaquil LeClercq dispensing Balanchine to the world; and here I sat again, watching the Paul Taylor Dance Company. I have been looking at dance for a long time now, without always knowing precisely what I was looking at, and it is to me what the Marx Brothers were to Woody Allen in ''Hannah and Her Sisters.'' Explanation, affirmation, consolation.

title: Hal B. Wallis Collection Sells for $39.6 Million
description: The Impressionist and Post-Impressionist works collected decades ago by Hal B. Wallis, the movie producer - two by Monet and one each by Degas, Pissarro, Bonnard, Mary Cassatt, Jean Edouard Vuillard and Henri Fantin-Latour - were auctioned last night at Christie's for $39.6 million, about $10 million above the house's most optimistic expectations.

title: Hicks & Haas Founders Split
description: The two principals of Hicks & Haas, the five-year-old leveraged buyout group whose $4 billion in acquisitions include the Dr Pepper/ Seven-Up Companies and A & W Brands, Thermadyne Holdings and the Sybron Corporation, said today that they would go their separate ways.

title: Debate Intensifying On Screening Tests Before Kindergarten
description: The screening of children to determine whether they are ready for kindergarten has become the focus of an intense debate among early childhood experts, teachers and parents around the country.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Two Small Agencies Join Hands
description: AFTER a five-month engagement, the marriage of Partners & Shevack and Kornhauser & Calene took place yesterday, joining two small agencies that have extensive package-goods experience, each of which was struggling to surmount a painful divorce.

title: Personal Health
description: The last two decades have seen a dramatic improvement in the ability to prevent and treat life-threatening heart disease. Changes in living habits, like eating less fat, stopping smoking and getting more exercise, are stemming the epidemic of coronary deaths. And the lives of those already afflicted with heart disease are being prolonged by coronary care units, pacemakers, bypass surgery and drugs that stimulate the heart, thin the blood and lower cholesterol and blood pressure.

title: GAF's Net Up 11.9% in Period
description: The GAF Corporation announced Tuesday that its earnings rose 11.9 percent in the first three months of this year, its last quarter as a public company.

title: Books of The Times; Israeli Persepctives: Popular and Purist
description: His Daughter By Yoram Kaniuk Translated by Seymour Simckes. 293 pages. George Braziller. $17.50. For Every Sin By Aharon Appelfeld Translated by Jeffrey M. Green. 168 pages. Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $15.95.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: TO many parents, the thought of their children going through puberty raises feelings ranging from ambivalence to dread. The physical changes in their children are a sign that their relationships are going to change as well. Parents expect that the surge of hormones that leads to new body hair, changing shapes and cracking voices will also bring about dramatic changes in their children's behavior, including increased moodiness, defiance and outbursts of anger.

title: In China Asylum Case, Abortion Isn't the Issue; Tomorrow's Rights
description: To the Editor:

title: An Investment Set by Warner
description: Warner Communications Inc. agreed yesterday to purchase a majority interest in a new partnership that will own The American Lawyer magazine and other legal and business publications. The publications are now owned by Associated Newspapers of Britain through its American Lawyer Newspapers Group Inc. Terms of the arrangement were not disclosed.

title: TV Notes
description: Filling Sawyer's Shoes

title: West German Arrested in Libyan Chemical Case
description: The former director of the West German chemical concern accused of helping Libya build a chemical weapons plant was arrested today on suspicion of violating West German export laws.

title: New Bids Received For Eastern
description: America West Airlines Inc. submitted a bid of $415 million for Eastern Airlines' northeastern shuttle yesterday, topping Donald J. Trump's $365 million deal and raising the prospect of a bidding war for one of Eastern's most valuable assets.

title: Japanese High School Opens in Tennessee Town
description: This country's first Japanese high school to be fully accredited to both American and Japanese standards opened today in the community of Sweetwater, 40 miles south of here.

title: Algo Group Inc reports earnings for
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Bach's Heirs May Play Jazz
description: Carl Philipp Emanuel Bach, who in 1762 set the standard for what a piano-playing musician should be, would find his heirs more likely playing at the Village Vanguard or the Blue Note than at Carnegie Hall. Far removed from the Chopin-Tchaikovsky-Rachmaninoff virtuosos being turned out by music schools today are jazz pianists with a knowledge of keyboard harmony and improvisional gifts that would probably warm Bach's heart.

title: Metro Datelines;
description: A courier carrying more than a million dollars' worth of gemstones was robbed at gunpoint yesterday afternoon on a highway near Kennedy International Airport, the police said.

title: Barred by W.B.C.
description: The Italian heavyweight Francesco Damiani has been barred from the World Boxing Council's rankings and the organization will not certify his fights for two years, WBC President Jose Sulaiman announced yesterday in Inglewood, Calif.

title: Japan Negotiating Image Appears to Be Shaken
description: The image of Japan as an unflappable trade negotiator, able to build a consensus and present a united front while Washington dissolves in fractious disorder, has been a bit shaken in recent days.

title: Campaign Matters; Charter Debate: Uplifting Words, Cranky Emotions
description: To the Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden, the plan for a new city charter ''would have a collection of neighborhoods, divided along racial, ethnic and religious lines, squabbling for crumbs from an all-powerful mayor.'' But far from an investiture, the incumbent, Edward I. Koch, fears the proposal might result in a chief executive bound in red tape.

title: BRIDGE
description: The businessmen are favored to beat the legislators when they face each other at the Capitol Hill Club in Washington this afternoon.

title: Taylor Is Acquitted Of Drunken Driving
description: Lawrence Taylor, the Giants' celebrated outside linebacker, was found not guilty today of a charge of driving while intoxicated.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We declare the election celebrated May 7 null in totality.'' - Yolanda Pulice Rodriguez, head of Panama's electoral commission. [ A1:6. ]

title: Transtech Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included net from discontinued operations of $17,925,042.

title: PEN Votes to Admit 2 Chapters in Soviet Union
description: The PEN international writers' association voted unanimously today to admit a Russian and a Lithuanian chapter, ending a 65-year quarrel with Moscow, an official of the association said.

title: Video-Store Chain Defends Auditing
description: The Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation said its accounting policies were ''conservative and fairly reflect the economics associated with a rapidly growing business.'' H. Wayne Huizenga, the chairman of the video-store chain, said a negative report on its accounting by Bear, Stearns & Company was ''inaccurate and grossly misleading'' but did not specify which parts were such.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Economy

title: Move Made In Congress On Japan Deal
description: Senator Robert C. Byrd introduced an initiative today intended to give Congress a more active voice in the United States-Japan fighter project.

title: In Chelsea, The Cry Is 'Fore!'
description: ''PEOPLE are getting out of the bar scene and leaning toward recreation,'' said 24-year-old Kevin Milkey, explaining the creation of Putter's Paradise in Chelsea, a new 18-hole indoor miniature golf course, complete with plastic flamingos and rotating bananas.

title: John Martin, Ex-Prosecutor, Recommended for Judgeship
description: John S. Martin Jr., a former Federal prosecutor, has been recommended for a judgeship in Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: Swiss to Curb Bank Secrecy
description: The Swiss Government described plans today to outlaw money laundering and prevent criminals from abusing Swiss bank secrecy.

title: Dismissals of 150 Due at Pepperell
description: West Point-Pepperell Inc., the Georgia-based textile company acquired by Farley Inc. in February, said it was dismissing 150 corporate employees in a restructuring. Toni M. Cauble, a spokeswoman, declined to say how many executives remained at Pepperell, though an analyst called the layoffs significant.

title: Rape Charge Is Dropped In Case At L.I. School
description: The Suffolk County District Attorney's office today dropped charges against Quincy B. Troupe, a student at the State University of New York at Stony Brook who had been accused of raping another student.

title: Article 227889 -- No Title
description: Hamleys, the toy shop that has been a part of London for more than two centuries, has been sold, and its new owners plan to expand operations to the United States and Japan.

title: 5,000 Chinese Students Hail Journalists
description: Wearing colored headbands and shouting slogans against censorship, more than 5,000 students paraded today on bicycles to the offices of several official newspapers to show support for journalists who have called for greater press freedom.

title: What Chancellor Green Started
description: Just over a year ago, Richard Green swept confidently into New York City on a powerful wave of expectation that he could turn a badly demoralized school system around. Politicians and educators had reached a rare consensus on the need for reform; everyone looked expectantly to the man from Minneapolis, the city's first black Chancellor. But Dr. Green, who died yesterday at the age of 52, always put his task in simpler terms. ''My mission is to serve children,'' he said.

title: Teachers' Unions Blight Education
description: LEAD: The future of public education - for better or worse - lies, in part, in the hands of the teachers' unions. Unfortunately, as states have enacted bargaining laws for public employees, teachers' unions have become more militant about rights for their members. This militancy has resulted in a number of problems for boards of education, including contractual constraints on their ability to respond to criticism, a lower priority assigned to servicing students and a perceived decline in the quality of education.

title: South Korea Prime Minister Conditionally Offers to Quit
description: Prime Minister Kang Young Hoon said today that was willing to bow to opposition demands to resign if he is held responsible for mishandling state affairs like the wave of political violence.

title: Beirut Shelling and Talks Go On
description: Arab mediators intensified their efforts to stop the fighting in Lebanon today as heavy shelling continued in Beirut and neighboring mountain towns and villages.

title: 2 Accused of Computer Crimes in TV Rivalry
description: Two former employees of a Tampa television station were charged today with stealing information by tapping into the computer of a competing station in what an investigator called ''an unusual case of media espionage.''

title: Dibrell Brothers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Kidder Is Sued By F.S.L.I.C.
description: Federal regulators said today that they had sued the Wall Street brokerage firm Kidder, Peabody & Company and a California investment group for $24 million over activities linked to the failure of a savings and loan association. The civil complaint by the

title: Resort's Voters Reject Move to Limit Growth
description: Residents of this resort have rejected a proposal to limit growth that would have tied construction permits to how long motorists must wait at lights.

title: Impeachment Voted; Federal Judge Faces A Trial in the Senate
description: The House today impeached Federal District Judge Walter L. Nixon of Mississippi, who is serving a five-year sentence for perjury, and sent the case to the Senate for trial. The vote was 417 to 0.

title: Who Can Shoot Down the Osprey?
description: Will America's defense spending be determined by the national interest or by parochial politics? The answer will be evident from the fate of an airplane called the Osprey, the single major new weapons system that Secretary of Defense Cheney proposes to cancel.

title: No Headline
description: Around Tompkins Square Park in an area called Alphabet City, because of avenues named A, B, C and D, are 16 abandoned tenement buildings occupied by people who simply took them over.

title: Coleman Will Return
description: Derrick Coleman, a junior forward at Syracuse University, announced yesterday he would return to the Orangemen for his senior year rather than surrender his eligibility and make himself available for the National Basketball Association draft.

title: 30-Year Term for Financier
description: Henry Ghorman, a Miami Beach financier accused of embezzling at least $20 million entrusted to him by about 50 south Florida doctors, was sentenced today by a Federal judge to 30 years in prison and a fine of more than $12 million.

title: Latin Nations, Though Disgusted by Noriega, Remain Wary of U.S.
description: As the political crisis in Panama deepens, Latin American countries are finding themselves torn between their disgust at the vote fraud apparently committed in the presidential election and their traditional desire not to become too closely aligned with the United States.

title: Gertrude Rosenthal, A Curator, Dies at 85
description: Dr. Gertrude Rosenthal, chief curator emeritus of the Baltimore Museum of Art and a member of its staff from 1945 to 1969, died on Monday after a long illness, at Union Memorial Hospital in Baltimore. She was 85 years old.

title: Mets Overcome Bumbling and Fumbling Reds
description: Infielders for the Reds were throwing balls into the outfield, and the pitcher was throwing them against dugouts and backstops. As a result, the Mets were left with only a couple of minor difficulties as they romped around the bases in the sixth inning. Stay out of the way of the mayhem and don't get caught doubled up in laughter.

title: Capital Cities Names a Vice President
description: James J. Allegro was named senior vice president of the network group of the Capital Cities/ American Broadcasting Companies yesterday. Although the position has been newly created, the responsibilities are similar to those previously held by Robert A. Iger, who recently succeeded Brandon Stoddard as president of the entertainment division of the network.

title: Western Investment Real Esate Trust reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included gains of $47,000 on sales of real estate investments.

title: Review/Theater; Familiar 'Playboy' Story With Unfamiliar Words
description: In ''The Playboy of the Western World,'' John Millington Synge wrote about an Ireland in which the ''springtime of local life'' had not been forgotten. The same is certainly true of Trinidad in 1950, as richly represented in Mustapha Matura's affectionate Caribbean salute to Synge, ''The Playboy of the West Indies.'' The play is running at the Yale Repertory Theater after productions at other regional theaters.

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column in Business Day on April 13 about the promotion of consumer products in movies referred incorrectly to appearances arranged for Molson beer. It was a company called Advertising in Movies, not the Entertainment Marketing Group, that placed the beer in the film ''Wall Street.'' Molson was not used on television in ''Thirtysomething'' or ''Dallas.''

title: Chevy's Answer to Ford's Taurus
description: In the perpetual crosstown rivalry between Ford and Chevrolet, Chevy is delivering what it hopes will be its most powerful punch of the decade.

title: Next Wave Opens Oct. 3 With World Premiere
description: The 1989 Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, devoted to avant-garde performing arts, will open on Oct. 3 with the world premiere of a music-theater piece by Laurie Anderson entitled ''Laurie Anderson - Empty Places.'' Ms. Anderson's first new evening-long work in six years, ''Empty Places'' will be a solo performance with Ms. Anderson re-inforced by an arsenal of electronic audio and visual machinery that is her most sophisticated yet.

title: Dow Rises 3.12, Its First Gain in 9 Sessions
description: The Dow Jones industrial average snapped its losing streak yesterday after eight days of declines, but volume continued at a pedestrian pace. The Dow ended up 3.12 points, to 2,374.45.

title: Metro Datelines; Trump Gets Licenses For Two Casinos
description: The Casino Control Commission voted today to renew Donald J. Trump's casino licenses, with a warning about his competitors.

title: Disarming of Contras: Procedures Set
description: After intense negotiations, Central American diplomats say they have agreed on a plan to disarm Nicaraguan guerrillas under United Nations supervision once a date is set for the rebels' demobilization.

title: Clare Kellogg Stout, Naturalist, 81
description: Clare Kellogg Stout, a naturalist and an authority on mollusks, died of cancer Monday at her home in New Canaan, Conn. She was 81 years old.

title: Merc Task Force Proposes An End to Cross-Trading
description: A task force of the New York Mercantile Exchange yesterday proposed a ban on cross-trading, in which a broker through his own account takes the opposite side of a customer's order instead of buying or selling for the customer on the floor.

title: Head of Insider Inquiry Is Leaving the S.E.C.
description: Gary G. Lynch, the lawyer who led the Securities and Exchange Commission's investigation into insider trading and securities fraud on Wall Street, said yesterday that he would leave the agency in mid-July.

title: Israelis Said to Kill 2 Arabs in West Bank
description: Two Palestinians were reported killed today by Israeli soldiers in the occupied territories, Arab reports said.

title: EX-AIDE DESCRIBES JACKSON CAMPAIGN
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson's refusal to condemn Louis Farrakhan personally was based on a political calculation that nothing he could do would satisfy Jewish voters, a new book on Mr. Jackson's 1988 Presidential campaign says.

title: Tests Seem to Link Astaphan to Steroids
description: The anabolic steroid found in Ben Johnson's drug test at the 1988 Seoul Olympics apparently came from a supply of drugs given to athletes training under Charlie Francis by George (Jamie) Astaphan, the doctor from St. Kitts who had provided drugs for the group regularly since 1984.

title: Pistons Shut Off Bucks And Win Opener, 85-80
description: Bill Laimbeer scored 6 of his 19 points in the final minute and the Detroit Pistons held Milwaukee to 11 points in the fourth period to beat the Bucks, 85-80, in the first game of their second-round playoff series tonight.

title: Prosecution Says It Has Witness in the Park Attack
description: The prosecution in the case against six youths indicted in the rape and attempted murder of a jogger in Central Park disclosed yesterday that it had an eyewitness who has not been charged in the attack.

title: Reviews/Dance; The Balanchine Who Was a Master of Classic Simplicity
description: George Balanchine's ''Ballo della Regina,'' performed by the New York City Ballet on Tuesday night at the New York State Theater, is an exuberant, often giddy exercise in classical dancing set to rollicking music from Verdi's ''Don Carlo.'' There are passages for the corps filled with the simplest and least adorned of classroom steps, and so the ballet, like some of the choreography Balanchine made for children, offers yet another look at Balanchine as a master of vibrant simplicity. ''Ballo della Regina'' also offered fresh challenges to Merrill Ashley, for whom it was created in 1978, drawing a new lightness and dramatic coloration from a ballerina known primarily for her strong technique.

title: Metro Datelines; Adopted Girl Returned to Parents
description: A judge ruled yesterday that an 11-month-old girl should be returned to her biological parents because the father, who was not married to the mother at the time, did not consent to the child's adoption.

title: Hungarian Cabinet Is Purged
description: Prime Minister Miklos Nemeth of Hungary purged half his Cabinet today and brought in six new ministers to create a younger, more unified Government.

title: Events: Wave Hill's 25th Anniversary
description: A Quarter Century, Wave Hill, Independence Avenue and West 249th Street, the Bronx, 212-549-3200.

title: It's a Grand Season for Walking Tours
description: ''ENLARGE! Enliven! Enlighten!'' says the tour guide in ''Lettice and Lovage,'' the Peter Shaffer hit in London. Enlarge indeed. This eccentric guide varnishes her facts as regularly as the Victorians varnished their woodwork. Not to worry. In return for her ''enhancement'' of Elizabethan history, this theatrical fancifier wins her audience, if not historical purists.

title: Shoddy Lawyers Called Court Threat
description: Lawyers in New York City courts are increasingly concealing facts, baiting judges and using other tactics that obscure the truth, judges and legal experts told a hearing panel yesterday.

title: Review/Dance; The Torment of Visions In 2 Pieces by Dan Wagoner
description: Mirages may be only illusions, yet they can cause real psychic distress to those who behold them and believe in them. The power of such phantasms was depicted in two enigmatic and eloquent works that Dan Wagoner and Dancers presented Tuesday night in the opening program of their week's engagement at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Saturday about a reunion of the Columbia School of Journalism class of 1939 misidentified the teacher to whom Bernard Redmont referred when he recalled, ''He asked us to use whatever color paper we could write on the fastest, so I always used green.'' It was the author Walter B. Pitkin, not Douglas Southall Freeman.

title: Another Rights Group Accuses Egypt of Torturing Detainees
description: For the second time this year, Western human rights monitors have accused the Egyptian police of torturing political detainees.

title: Charles Evers Ends Long Democratic Tie To Join Republicans
description: The civil rights campaigner Charles Evers, Mayor of Fayette, says he plans to abandon his longstanding Democratic affiliation to join the Republican Party.

title: Washington Talk; Two House Freshmen Reflect Clash of Cultures
description: Every two years, a select band of men and women enter the House of Representatives for the first time: the ''freshman class.''

title: Laurentian Group Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: RISE OF 2 PLATEAUS LINKED TO ICE AGES
description: The rise of two great plateaus, one under the Rockies and one under the Himalayas, altered the world's air circulation enough to set the stage for the ice ages, according to a hypothesis presented here today.

title: Inter-City Gas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Lester Baum, 85, Ex-West Side State Senator
description: Lester Baum, a former State Senator, City Councilman and Alderman in the La Guardia administration, died of a heart attack April 26 at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 85 years old.

title: U.S.-SOVIET TALKS ON ARMS RESUMING IN GENEVA IN JUNE
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union agreed today to resume the long-delayed negotiations on reducing long-range nuclear missiles and bombers by the end of June, Soviet and American officials said.

title: Job Training for Hard Cases
description: Congress and the Bush Administration are working to reform the Job Training Partnership Act. There is broad consensus that the law, which now provides relatively quick job placements for the ablest of the poor, ought to be encouraging training of the most disadvantaged. That's a laudable goal, but a better way to achieve it may be to expand the Job Corps.

title: Fund Yields Are Steady
description: Yields offered by money market mutual funds were generally flat in the week ended yesterday.

title: Wright Lawyers Ask Panel to Dismiss Ethics Charges
description: Lawyers for Speaker Jim Wright asked the House ethics committee today to dismiss the major charges of misconduct against him, saying that even if details of the allegations were true, he did not break House rules.

title: Avon Offer Is Official: Amway Bids $39 a Share
description: In a widely expected hostile takeover bid by one direct-selling merchandiser for another, the Amway Corporation offered yesterday to buy Avon Products Inc. for $39 a share, or nearly $2 billion in cash.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: REPAIRING minor damage to wallboard can be done by amateurs, even those with little experience in home repair. The most important requirements are patience and a light touch.

title: Offensive Savvy and Lead Lost by Knicks
description: Rick Pitino and his coaching staff prepared for the Knicks' practice yesterday by breaking down the tapes of Tuesday night's 120-109 overtime loss to the Chicago Bulls.

title: Bay Financial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The year-ago quarter loss included a $213,000 gain from the disposition of investments. The latest 9 months and year-ago 9-months included gains from the disposition of investments of $610,000 and $3,528,000, respectively.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
