description: Torrington Co., a bearing maker and unit of Ingersoll-Rand Co., to Keiler Advertising, Farmington, Conn., with a budget of $1.4 million.

title: Skill vs. Comprehension in Piano Contests
description: Next month's winner of the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition will almost certainly be a brilliant technical player. But whether this same player will also be a well-rounded and versatile musician is another question.

title: 15 Historic Houses Saved From Obscurity
description: New York City owns 15 house museums built between 1650 and 1850, but few New Yorkers can name them. The city's Department of Parks and Recreation hopes to change all that by holding its first Historic Houses Festival from Saturday through May 21.

title: INSIDE
description: Oil Spill Cleanup Expanded Exxon increased its cleanup crew in Alaska by nearly half, but Federal officials said the job could still drag on into next year. Page A27. Arrest in Libya Plant Case Bonn charged the former head of a West German company with helping to build a Libyan plant capable of making chemical weapons. Page A14. Welfare Changes Urged A Ford Foundation study recommended sweeping changes in America's social welfare system at a cost of $29 billion. Page A22.

title: HEALTH: Pediatrics; Many Children Using Medication Improperly, A New Study Finds
description: Almost half the young Americans using prescription drugs are not taking the medication correctly and may be jeopardizing their health, according to a new study by a health information organization.

title: Novo-Nordisk reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The results are in U.S. dollars and had been translated at the March 31, 1989 exchange rate of U.S. $1.00 equals Dkr. 7.3640. Share earnings represent American Depositary Share (ADS). The first quarter reflected the merger of Novo Industri A/S and Nordisk Gentofte A/S, which was approved on April 20. The 1988 figures for the merged company were included in the results for purposes of comparison and calculated on a pro forma basis. The results pertain to the merged company, Novo-Nordisk, as the merger is retroactive to Jan. 1, 1989.

title: The Trade-Off For a 'Poison Pill'
description: BUSINESS leaders and politicians in New York State have maintained that one big reason for rushing a ''poison pill'' law through the Legislature last week was to help the Ogilvy Group of New York, one of the world's largest advertising companies, fight off a hostile takeover offer.

title: Endesa reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures were converted from Spanish pesetas at the May 9 exchange rate of 118.818 pesetas to the dollar. Share earnings represent American Depositary Receipt.

title: BMA Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the results for both periods have been restated to reflect new accounting standards.

title: Stockton Journal; Where 5 Died, a Monk Gives Solace
description: There were ghosts in the playground of the Cleveland Elementary School here, and fear in the hearts of Cambodian parents and their children, until the Venerable Dharmawara Mahathera came to the schoolyard several months ago to offer a blessing.

title: London Exhibition By Pioneer Ceramist
description: At the time of his death in 1917, William de Morgan, a pioneer ceramist in the English Arts and Crafts movement, was better known for his best-selling novels than his hand-painted pots.

title: National Health Laboratories Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Kentucky Star Is Tennessee-Bound
description: Denny Crum, the coach at the University of Louisville, said yesterday he would honor a request from Allan Houston, the state of Kentucky's scholastic Mr. Basketball, to be released from a national letter-of-intent he signed last November to attend Louisville.

title: Bethlehem Job Pact
description: The international executive board of the United Steelworkers of America has approved a preliminary contract with the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, a union spokesman said. The proposed 50-month contract, which includes an 8.09 percent wage increase, was approved on Friday by the presidents of Bethlehem's union locals. The company's 20,500 union employees will vote on the accord in a few weeks, the spokesman said.

title: Metro Datelines; Ruiz Draws 6 Months In Lying to Get Loan
description: State Senator Israel Ruiz Jr. was sentenced to six months in prison yesterday for lying on a bank loan application.

title: Tiny Tech's First Steps
description: SOME babies should have no trouble learning the colors of a zebra: they are growing up with them.

title: Kerr Glass Manufacturing Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $250,000. c-Net income Year-ago first quarter also benefited from $274,000 of other income, primarily relating to a reduction in a reserve for restructuring costs.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council ECONOMIC COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. SOCIAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Hall Adds Members
description: Elected by a nationwide panel of 100 turf writers to the Museum of Racing's Hall of Fame at Saratoga Springs, N.Y., were Chris McCarron, the jockey; the late Jim Maloney, a trainer; Black Gold, the winner of the 1924 Kentucky Derby; Affectionately, a filly who won 28 of 52 starts in the mid-1960's, and Alydar (the sire of Easy Goer), who finished second to Affirmed in all three Triple Crown races in 1978.

title: After Failure of Coup in Guatemala, Cheers Go Up
description: Thousands of cheering demonstrators clogged Guatemala City's central square today to show their support for President Vinicio Cerezo while politicians and diplomats puzzled over a coup attempt on Tuesday.

title: A Peculiar Twist Arises In Complex NWA Battle
description: In the complex effort to gain control of NWA Inc., the parent company of Northwest Airlines, two of the leading suitors are now competing with themselves to strike a deal.

title: 4th Suspect Arrested in Shooting of Officer
description: A fourth suspect was arrested last night and charged with attempted murder in the shooting last Friday of a 26-year-old undercover police officer during a drug-buy operation in Harlem, the police said.

title: Safely Satisfying Kitty's Lust for Greens
description: When Pat Smith, public affairs director for the Borough President of Brooklyn, dares to bring a plant home his cat soon nibbles a little off every leaf. ''We call her Agent Orange'' he said.

title: Thermo Electron Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
'Lonesome Dove' Dispute Highlights Growth in Books on Tape
description: Larry McMurtry's Pulitzer Prize-winning novel ''Lonesome Dove'' provided CBS with a mini-series that attracted large audiences earlier this year. Now a legal battle has erupted over rights to an audio version of the novel.

title: Making TV Interesting When Set's Off
description: AS a household object, the television has been neglected by designers, says Andrew Hunt, a New York painter.

title: GAF Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $6,553,000 from the extinguishment of debt, representing the after-tax effect of the write-off of debt discount and deferred financing costs in connection with the tender for the company's senior subordinated notes and debentures. c-Included an extraordinary gain of $875,000.

title: Executive Says He Paid Interest On Wright Loan
description: A Texas nursing home executive said today that his company provided money to pay Speaker Jim Wright's interest on a $100,000 bank loan. Mr. Wright took out the loan to finance his investment in the nursing home company.

title: Barfield May Have Key To Ending His Slump
description: Jesse Barfield did not get his wish last night.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Monday with an article about auto makers' calls for changes in the financing of health care misstated the timing of severance benefits to 200,000 former employees of General Motors. Benefits were paid in 1987 to those who had been laid off, but they were no longer covered in 1988.

title: Keep Savings and Commercial Banks Separate in Thrifts Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: Chief Executive Named For Equitec Financial
description: Richard L. Saalfeld, a former Bank of America executive, has been named chief executive of the Equitec Financial Group, a financial services company he hopes to lead back to profitability.

title: Hormone Offers Risks To Cows and Humans
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Endeavour' Is Name Chosen For the New Space Shuttle
description: NASA's newest space shuttle, being built to replace the destroyed Challenger, will be called the Endeavour. It will be named after the flagship of James Cook, the 18th century English explorer.

title: New Housing Down by 13%
description: The number of new houses and apartment buildings completed in the United States fell by a sharp 13 percent in March from February, after rising 4.2 percent in February, the Commerce Department said today.

title: Peruvian Rebels Attack City
description: Shining Path rebels rocked this central Peruvian city with about 50 bombings before dawn today, heralding the start of a three-day general strike called by the guerrillas. The police said the rebels' targets included banks, factories and the municipal soccer stadium, and guerrilla bands also set fire to buses and cars. There were no immediate reports of injuries.

title: Baby Is Due On 'Sesame,' And Even Oscar Is Glad
description: The Muppet residents of ''Sesame Street'' - Big Bird, Telly Monster, even Oscar the Grouch - can barely contain their excitement.

title: Topics of The Times; Sidewalk Enrichment
description: A New York man who makes a habit of picking up coins on the street returned from a visit to Cambridge, Mass., to report that Harvard Square is paved with silver. In New York, he's used to finding pennies. But in just two days at a Harvard reunion, he netted four dimes.

title: American League; Blue Jays Again Halt A No-Hitter In the Ninth
description: Tom Lawless broke up Mark Langston's no-hit bid with a pinch-hit single to center leading off the ninth inning today as the Blue Jays rallied for three runs in the inning to beat the Seattle Mariners, 3-2.

title: Tainted Milk and Meat Raise Vigilance
description: Persistent contamination of milk and meat by toxic substances, both natural and synthetic, has prompted the Federal and state governments to intensify food inspections in the South and Midwest.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Johnson Wax, Racine, Wis., the consumer-products manufacturer, named Laurance R. Newman senior vice president of its worldwide service businesses.

title: Results Plus
description: BOXING McCallum Takes Title: Mike McCallum wore down Herol Graham of Britain in the final rounds in London yesterday to win a split decision and capture the vacant World Boxing Association middleweight title.

title: Soviet Center and Periphery Still Struggle
description: To the Editor:

title: Iraq in Deal With G.M.
description: Iraq's Trade Minister, Mohammed Mahdi Salih, said today that Iraq had signed a contract with the General Motors Corporation to import 10,000 Chevrolets and Oldsmobiles from the United States. The cars will be 1990 models. The Iraqi press agency quoted Mr. Saleh as saying Iraq had already imported 5,000 Chevrolet Celebrity cars under a contract signed last year. Iraq said earlier this month that it had signed deals with General Motors and Mercedes-Benz of West Germany for the production of pickup trucks, heavier trucks, buses and passenger cars.

title: Reviews/Concert; Yo-Yo Ma, With Cello and Friends, Takes a Detour
description: Any highly successful instrumentalist must worry about becoming trapped in routine. Yo-Yo Ma, the Boston-based cellist, appears to have addressed the problem by giving periodic concerts that stand solidly outside the mainstream. Monday night at the 92d Street Y, he and two Boston colleagues offered an entire evening of 20th-century music.

title: HEALTH: Psychiatry; Treatment Plan for Deaf Overcomes The Language and Culture Barriers
description: In a novel effort to help a segment of the population that has often been overlooked by psychiatrists, a Philadelphia hospital has established a mental health program for deaf people.

title: Atmos Energy Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
For Prudent Novices, Canoe and Kayak 101
description: There's no law against setting forth on a river or lake in a canoe or kayak with no experience in handling such craft, but it is both foolish and unrewarding.

title: Southern Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
McCallum to Go Pro
description: Napoleon McCallum, a running back sidelined for two years by his obligations to the Navy, won approval yesterday to pursue his football career with the San Diego Chargers during his off-duty hours.

title: Custom Shoes for Just the Right Fit
description: MANY famous feet have wandered into Mathias Bootmaker on East 69th Street, a small Victorian-looking shop that displays its sensible custom shoes complete with their hardwood lasts. Paul Newman had a pair of boots made there. Rex Harrison bought two pair: a sport shoe made of ostrich and velvet monogrammed slippers. Frank Sinatra and Clark Gable chose needlepoint slippers.

title: Railroad Stake Sold
description: George Soros, a New York money manager, has sold his 7 percent stake in Kansas City Southern Industries. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Mr. Soros gave no reason for the sale. Last May, Kansas City Southern's stockholders rejected a proposal from Mr. Soros to break up the railroad company and spin off its non-transportation operations. Mr. Soros last week sold 730,000 shares on the open market for prices of $38.28 to $39 each. The stock of the company, based in Kansas City, Mo., slipped 25 cents today, to $37.75, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: House Panel Rebuffs Bush on Part of Savings Plan
description: Despite more than an hour of pleading by Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, the House Ways and Means Committee today gave preliminary approval to a plan that would put most of the cost of President Bush's savings bailout package on the Government's books.

title: Now, Address The Details
description: The United States and the Soviet Union have agreed on the main outlines of how to cut long-range nuclear arms, but they differ over key details.

title: Ford Foundation Urges Big Changes in U.S. Social Programs
description: Criticizing America's social welfare system as outmoded and failing young and old alike, a Ford Foundation study recommends sweeping changes that would affect tens of millions of people even while it concedes that daunting political and budget obstacles are in the way.

title: Remember That Drought? It Looks Like a Washout
description: Just seven weeks after a drought emergency was declared in New York City, so much rain has fallen that the drought appears to be a washout.

title: Inside Jalalabad: A Sad, Crumbling Shel
description: After nearly 10 weeks of the most intensive bombardment in Afghanistan's decade-old war, this city has been reduced to a sad, crumbling shell of the place favored for centuries by Afghanistan's poets and kings.

title: International Thomson Oranisation Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $475 million on the sale of oil and gas operations. c-Net loss and after income from discontinued operations of $14 million. Year-ago figures have been restated. The company is listed on the Toronto and London stock exchanges.

title: EMC Insurance Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $250,771 from an accounting change under SFAS No. 96.

title: Continental Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a $300,000 loss from discontinued operations. The company said the 80 cents a share in the latest quarter does not include a tax benefit resulting from the fresh start provision of the Tax Reform Act of 1986. First quarter 1988's $1.42 share earnings included a 22 cent fresh start benefit. In the first quarter of 1989 the company realized pretax capital gains of $6.6 million, compared with gains of $9.6 million for the same period last year. Results for the prior year have been restated to reflect the adoption, in the first quarter of 1989, of the statement of Financial Accounting Standards No. 97, which requires that realized capital gains and losses be reported on a pretax basis as part of operating revenues.

title: Giant Yellowknife Mines Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Continental Can Loses Pension Case
description: The Continental Can Company developed a secret and sophisticated computer program that it used to deny pension benefits to longtime employees, a Federal judge ruled today.

title: Safeway Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 25
description: b-Net loss

title: Cling! Clang! Ring! Music to Their Ears
description: THE message was as clear as a you-know-what: New York's bellologists think the streets would be safer if New York's bicyclists had you-know-whats on their handlebars.

title: Watson Calls for Easing Tour's Barrier to Foreigners
description: Seve Ballesteros, the Spaniard who is among the best two or three golfers in the world, should be allowed to play wherever he wants whenever he wants, according to Tom Watson.

title: U.S. PETROLEUM DATA
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: National League; 10 Runs, 15 Hits, 1 Brawl Lift Expos
description: Tom Foley hit three doubles and a single to drive in three runs, and Bryn Smith allowed three hits in seven innings tonight to lead the Montreal Expos to a 15-hit, 10-1 victory over the Astros in a game marred by a bench-clearing brawl that brought the ejection of a Houston coach and three Expo players.

title: Here's How to Get Noriega
description: By all accounts, the Panamanian strongman, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, has stolen the Panamanian election.

title: Alaska Cleanup May Drag Into '90, U.S. Says
description: The Exxon Corporation agreed today to expand its cleanup crew on the Alaska shoreline by nearly 50 percent, but Government officials said the company had not persuaded them that the job could be finished before next year.

title: Iranian Official Denies Threat on Westerners
description: The Iranian Speaker of Parliament, Hojatolislam Hashemi Rafsanjani, today withdrew his call for Palestinians to kill Westerners, saying his remarks had been distorted.

title: Planning a Garage Fit for Caesars
description: UNLIKE those in Las Vegas, Nev., casino hotels in Atlantic City have been characterized by the mundane. The bland, even bleak, exteriors are a marked contrast to Atlantic City's past, when grand hotels brought drama and whimsy to the seaside.

title: Formal Garden, Oldest in U.S., Grows Again
description: ON Sunday, the oldest formal garden in America will officially be opened, culminating six years of painstaking archeological research and educated second-guessing.

title: BRIEFS
description: * A.M.E. Inc., Burbank, Calif., said that its board had rejected a takeover offer by A.M.E. Holding Co. and that it would continue to explore alternatives for maximizing shareholder value.

title: Los Angeles Museum Gets $60 Million in Art
description: Modern art valued at more than $60 million, including a classic ''drip'' painting by Jackson Pollock, has been donated to the Museum of Contemporary Art here.

title: Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
United Capital Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest quarter results included the operations of Metex Corp. from March 3, the date of acquisition. Year-ago quarter results included a tax credit of $476,000.

title: Pistons Top Bucks; Lakers Lead, 2-0
description: Detroit, which trailed by 48-39 at the half, held Milwaukee to 11 points in the final quarter last night and beat the Bucks, 85-50, in the first game of their Eastern conference semifinal series, at Auburn Hills, Mich.

title: Topics of The Times; The Weight of Centuries
description: Sing another ''Happy Birthday'' to Irving Berlin. At 101 years old today, he may be America's most celebrated and adored centenarian, and is certainly the most melodic. Otherwise, according to a report by the Census Bureau, he's fairly typical.

title: Met Pitchers Blanked on Shutouts
description: Some people look for signs in the stars; the Mets may want to consider checking for signs in shutouts.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: The Transco Energy Corporation expects to realize up to $600 million for the remaining oil and gas properties in its exploration partnership, its president, George S. Slocum, said after Transco's annual meeting. The company said in January that it would liquidate Transco Exploration Partnership Ltd. because of persistently low oil and gas prices. The sale price is a ''ball park figure'' based on the partnership's reserve base of about 500 billion cubic feet, Mr. Slocum said.

title: Unofficially, Era of Carter Is Still Here
description: He is in some ways the last person one might expect to be sitting at the right arm of a Republican President and reporting on world affairs.

title: For Openers, Belmont Gets '90 Breeders' Cup
description: A wet and bone-chilling opening day at Belmont Park yesterday was brightened by the announcement that the stately Long Island track has been chosen to host the 1990 Breeders' Cup races.

title: Jefferies Cites Trading Ties To Bilzerian
description: Boyd L. Jefferies, one of the Government's main witnesses in a number of cases arising from the Wall Street scandals, testified yesterday that he had illegally schemed with Paul A. Bilzerian to violate Federal securities laws.

title: New York Area Retail Sales Up
description: April sales among several of New York's biggest retailers increased by an average of 7.3 percent in the city and 8.9 percent in the metropolitan area from the period a year ago, a spot-check found yesterday. All of the reporting retail companies had year-to-year gains in both the city and the region.

title: Allies Break Ranks And Lose Influence
description: The latest rise of the dollar is a sign that economic cooperation among the industrial allies on matters like budgets, trade balances and interest rates has been floundering and is undermining their ability to keep their currencies stable.

title: Vestron Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a loss of $1,301,000 from operations of discontinued retail video stores and a loss of $2,400,000 from the estimated operating losses of the stores during the disposition period. c-Net income and included a loss of $738,000 from operations of retail video stores. The latest first quarter revenue does not include revenue of $6.4 million associated with discontinued operations. The year-ago first quarter revenue does not include revenue of $2.3 million associated with discontinued operations. The year-ago first quarter results are after a $15.7 million gain on a settlement in connection with the final agreement with Hemdale Film Dorp. and Home Box Office Inc.

title: Agency, Railroad and Crew Blamed for Iowa Train Wreck
description: Failures by the Iowa Interstate Railroad and the Federal Railroad Administration to enforce operating rules, along with a tired train crew's error, caused the collision of two freight trains in Altoona, Iowa, last summer, Federal safety officials have concluded.

title: Martha Graham at 95: Work, Work, Work
description: Martha Graham will celebrate her 95th birthday today. ''I'm interested only in the future, in going on,'' the renowned choreographer said recently.

title: Hamilton Oil Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income of $2,001,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Flames Eliminate Hawks, Gain Final
description: The Calgary Flames advanced to the Stanley Cup finals for the second time in four years with a 3-1 victory tonight over the Chicago Blackhawks.

title: Green Escaped Troubled Youth To Win Praise
description: Dr. Richard R. Green had a hard-scrabble boyhood in Minneapolis, where he rose to be an innovative School Superintendent before becoming Schools Chancellor in New York, where he died early yesterday at the St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 52 years old and lived on West 61st Street.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: SUNY Officials Seek Agreement on Budget
description: State budget officials and administrators of New York's public universities met today to discuss how to make up nearly $50 million that was lost last week when Gov. Mario M. Cuomo vetoed a tuition increase. Negotiators refused to say whether any agreements had been reached.

title: Culiacan Journal; In a Most Unsaintly City, a Bandit Wears a Halo
description: He was hanged as a bandit on May 3, 1909, his death mourned by the poor he had defended and celebrated by the government that had placed a hefty bounty on his head. But 80 years after his death, Jesus Malverde is a source of civic pride here, venerated as a saint by common people throughout northwestern Mexico.

title: Texas Student Charged In Cult Leader's Death
description: An honor student at Texas Southmost College and two other members of a drug-smuggling cult said to have killed 15 people were charged tonight in the weekend deaths of their leader and his bodyguard, the authorities said.

title: 10-Year U.S. Notes Sold at 9.18%
description: Treasury securities prices slipped further yesterday as market participants struggled through the second leg of the Treasury's quarterly auctions.

title: Nervous Wall St. Fears a 'Melt-Up'
description: ALMOST 19 months ago, stocks plummeted in what was often called a market ''meltdown.''

title: Pilot Buzzes Boston Airport, Shooting Up the City
description: A man who the police said had just killed his ex-wife commandeered a small plane and terrorized the city for three hours early today, firing a semiautomatic weapon while flying within 50 feet of motorists and buildings.

title: Dior Confirms Ferre Will Replace Bohan
description: After months of speculation, the House of Christian Dior said it plans to announce today at the Hotel de Crillon in Paris that Gianfranco Ferre will take over the design of its couture collection, ready-to-wear and furs.

title: TOM BRADLEY SAYS JUDGMENT WAS BAD
description: Mayor Tom Bradley, the target of a wide-ranging inquiry by the city prosecutor, said today that he had made an error of judgment in accepting outside income that he acknowledged created the impression of impropriety.

title: Successes and Setbacks Marked Green's Tenure
description: After some hesitant early steps in his brief tenure, Dr. Richard R. Green was beginning to have an impact on New York City's huge school system.

title: N.Y.U. Show Of Show Sets
description: MANY designers tend toward the theatrical. But in the case of a show now at the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University, theatricality comes honestly. Costumed mannequins suspended from the ceiling and intricate models of sets are part of ''Design Show 1989 - New Works for Stage and Screen.'' The show highlights the work of 16 graduate students and teachers of set design, including Anna Louizos, who drew this imaginary film set.

title: Flyers' Sincere Strategy: Imitation
description: The Flyers have unveiled the only way to stay playoff contenders: They have to play more like the Canadiens than the Canadiens do.

title: When 15 7-Footers Trailed Him
description: It was said that he was one of the most powerful men in basketball, perhaps in sports, and one of the least known. He was under 6 feet tall and plumper than you might imagine a sports hero. He peered out at the world through dark-rimmed glasses, and often wore clothes so ill-matched that one of his friends, Oscar Robertson, recalled, ''He was color blind, but I didn't know that for years. I used to wonder why he dressed so bad.''

title: Fort Howard Planning To Sell Cup Operations
description: The Fort Howard Corporation, the paper products company that was taken private last year for $3.55 billion, said yesterday that it intended to sell its cup operations.

title: Building With Mud And Much More
description: WITH a Cambridge University science degree and a Harvard doctorate in nuclear physics, Ashok Khosla began his career like many other talented young people in the undeveloped world: he went into Government service, and then joined a United Nations agency. A little over five years ago, he got off that track. ''I found that all these things were a lot of talk and hot air,'' he said. With a few like-minded people, he founded a new kind of development organization, calling it Development Alternatives.

title: Farm Banks Unit Prices 1990 Notes
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation yesterday priced a $650 million offering of consolidated systemwide floating-rate medium-term notes due on May 17, 1990, through underwriters led by Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc.

title: Evaluation For Leach
description: Rick Leach, the Texas player who disappeared for 24 hours earlier in the week, underwent medical evaluation yesterday and, a baseball source said, he will begin a counseling program for an unspecified reason.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 25 about the presentation of a Winston Churchill Award to former President Ronald Reagan gave an incorrect date. According to a letter sent this week by the Winston Churchill Foundation of the United States, the award will be given on Wednesday at a dinner at the Beverly Hilton Hotel; the date was not May 7.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article yesterday about the business dealings of House Speaker Jim Wright referred incorrectly in some copies to the status of proceedings in the House ethics committee. The committee has found that Mr. Wright may have violated House rules - not that he definitely did - in regard to his income from book royalties and in payments to his wife by a Texas businessman.

title: Yanks Heading West, Perhaps Into Trouble
description: The last time the Yankees made a 10-game trip to the West Coast they had one of their three most successful three-city Western journeys ever. But the last time they went to the West Coast they suffered their most disastrous three-city Western journeys ever.

title: KENYA TO SEEK BAN ON TRADE OF IVORY
description: In a reversal of position, Kenya announced today that it would seek a worldwide ban on the trade of ivory, a move intended to preserve its fast dwindling elephant herds.

title: Ford Might Sell Rouge Steel Unit
description: The Ford Motor Company said it had received an offer for its Rouge Steel subsidiary and was in serious negotiations to sell the unit, the nation's No. 8 steel producer. Ford is the only United States car maker producing its own steel, but Rouge has earned only $40 million in the last decade, while Ford has invested $400 million in it over the last six years.

title: Zoning Upheld Against Stores For Sex Books
description: New York State's highest court today narrowly upheld the right of municipalities to enact zoning laws that force bookstores and theaters that sell sexually explicit material to move out of downtown shopping areas and into less-visited neighborhoods like industrial districts.

title: Grace Choral Society
description: Alexander Rom will conduct the Grace Choral Society of Brooklyn in Carl Orff's ''Carmina Burana'' and Prokofiev's ''Alexander Nevsky'' tomorrow evening at 7:30 at Grace Church, 254 Hicks Street, at Joralemon Street, Brooklyn Heights. Tickets are $7.50. Information: (718) 624-1850.

title: Our Towns; Near Yale, Grief Over a Big Man Off Campus
description: These are not cheery times in Wooster Square, an old, once-seedy Italian neighborhood near Yale University that in recent years has become a stylish favorite among those with a taste for Brooklyn-style brownstones and National Register of Historic Places plaques.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the Chevrolet Lumina referred incorrectly to a fabric-protection product and misidentified its manufacturer. It is Scotchgard, from the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company, not Du Pont.

title: A Book Fair in an Unfriendly Country Can Speak Volumes
description: To the Editor:

title: Defense Keeps Bulls From Staging Late Rally
description: When the Knicks built a 12-point lead in the fourth quarter on Tuesday, the Chicago Bulls came back to win.

title: Reviews/Film; Swamp Thing, Rescuer of Damp Damsels
description: ''The Return of Swamp Thing,'' opening today at the Warner and other theaters, is intended for people who missed the 1982 ''Swamp Thing'' and don't want the bother of renting the videocassette.

title: Wright Aide Quits Amid Furor on '73 Crime
description: House Speaker Jim Wright's top political and legislative aide, who was imprisoned 16 years ago for an attack on a woman, resigned today after publicity about his past caused a furor and heightened the turmoil around Mr. Wright.

title: Giamatti Schedules a Hearing For Rose to Respond to Report
description: Commissioner A. Bartlett Giamatti yesterday scheduled a hearing for Pete Rose for May 25, an indication that he feels he has enough evidence of possible wrongdoing to warrant giving the Cincinnati Reds' manager an opportunity to defend himself.

title: Enough Ads Are Expected For NBC's Abortion Film
description: Advertising executives said yesterday that despite pressure from conservative religious and anti-abortion groups, NBC would have no difficulty finding enough advertisers for ''Roe vs. Wade,'' a dramatization of events leading up to the 1973 ruling by the Supreme Court legalizing abortion.

title: 2 Officers Charged in a Racial Assault on a Man
description: Two New York City police officers were charged yesterday with beating a man and subjecting him to racial abuse, the latest indictment in an investigation of allegations of brutality by white officers against minority-group members in Queens.

title: Memorial for Marie Syrkin
description: A memorial service for Marie Syrkin, an author, an editor and a teacher who was active in Zionism, is to be held at the New-York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, at 77th Street, on Tuesday at 6:30 P.M.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: WHITE HOUSE
description: So you thought a nice guy like George Bush wouldn't have an enemies list?

title: Review/Concert; Pinnock and New Ensemble Play Mozart as He Heard It
description: Births are generally accompanied by lusty squalling, which serves as welcome evidence of life. It was not terminally troubling, therefore, to hear some raucous sounds from the Classical Band in its premiere concert under its music director, Trevor Pinnock, on Wednesday evening at Kathryn Bache Miller Theater. There is a definite place in New York for an ensemble of period instruments devoted to giving musicologically scrupulous performances of 19th-century works from a time roughly bounded by Haydn and Schubert. Time and more rehearsals will tell if the Classical Band is that ensemble.

title: Stood Up for Prom, She Files a Lawsuit
description: A 15-year-old girl is suing the boy who was to take her to the high school prom, contending he owes her about $50 for the shoes, flowers and hairdo she never got to wear.

title: S.E.C. Censures Options Exchange
description: In a rare move, the Securities and Exchange Commission said today that it had formally censured the Chicago Board Options Exchange for failing to enforce its trading rules in 1985, when the exchange was facing intense competition for options contracts.

title: A Lawyer Vanishes, Leaving a Trail of Fraud Charges
description: One Friday night in February 1988, a client and friend of Peter G. Schmidt was startled to encounter Mr. Schmidt in the arrival area at the Miami airport. Hours earlier, he had spoken to Mr. Schmidt in New York, and had arranged to see him there over the weekend. Something had come up suddenly, Mr. Schmidt told him. But he said he'd return shortly, and suggested they meet for dinner the next day.

title: Scribner Name and Store Are Sold to B. Dalton
description: B. Dalton Bookseller Inc. has acquired the Scribner bookstore name from the Macmillan Publishing Company and Rizzoli International. The transaction, for an undisclosed price, was announced yesterday by Leonard Riggio, president of B. Dalton.

title: Degradable Plastics and Recycling Don't Mix; Misguided Campaign
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Foote, Cone Profit
description: Foote, Cone & Belding Communications said yesterday its first-quarter earnings were flat compared with the corresponding period a year ago. The Chicago-based company reported net income of $2.4 million, or 24 cents a share, in the first three months of 1989, compared with $2.39 million, or 28 cents a share, in 1988. Because the agency issued more shares last year, earnings per share dipped almost 17 percent. Foote, Cone attributed the lackluster performance to a $264,000 loss in Europe.

title: The Park Attack, Weeks Later: An Anger That Will Not Let Go
description: From Donald J. Trump's high-pitched, high-profile call for the death penalty to a mother quietly talking about getting a gun, from a flood of venomous calls on radio talk shows to a young woman vowing to do harm to the next man who harasses her, the city's voices have taken on an angry edge in the weeks since a woman was beaten and raped in Central Park and left for dead.

title: U.S., in a Shift, Seeks Treaty on Global Warming
description: In an important switch, the White House told American negotiators in Geneva tonight to lead the way toward an international treaty to control global warming.

title: If Amway Wins Avon, It Will Sell Retail Unit
description: The Amway Corporation said yesterday that if its $2 billion bid to buy Avon Products Inc. was successful, it would sell Avon's profitable retail division.

title: Soviet Cuts Will Help Bonn's Cause
description: The new cuts Mikhail S. Gorbachev plans in Soviet short-range nuclear arms are of only modest military significance.

title: Hooker Stores' Cash Troubles
description: The American retail operations of L. J. Hooker Ltd., the Australian developers, ''are having some cash flow problems,'' said Michael Babcock, chairman of Hooker's retail operations in this country.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Companies

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday THE WESTERN REPRISED

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''THE MAGIC HAT,'' a puppet show by George Latshaw, 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at the Puppet Playhouse, Murphy Center at Asphalt Green, 555 East 90th Street. Tickets: $3.50. Reservations: 369-8890. STORY HOUR, in which Nancy Willard, an author, and Barry Moser, an illustrator, will entertain children ages 6 to 10, at 12:30 P.M. Sunday, at Eeyore's Books for Children, 2212 Broadway, at 79th Street. Free. Information: 362-0634. THE INTREPID, the aircraft carrier sea-and-air space museum, 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Wednesdays to Sundays, with the last tour at 4 P.M., at Pier 86, at 46th Street. Admission: children, $2.50, the elderly, $4; others, $4.75. Information: 245-2533. ''THE SEAPORT EXPERIENCE,'' a film spectacle about the South Street Seaport, with 104 projectors and special audio effects, 10:30 A.M. to 3:30 P.M. Mondays through Thursdays and 10:30 A.M. to 6:30 P.M. Fridays through Sundays, at the Trans-Lux Seaport Theater, 210 Front Street, at the seaport. Children, $3.25; adults, $4.75. Information: 608-7888. EXHIBITION OF CHILDREN'S BOOK ILLUSTRATIONS, a new show of original artwork, including the works of Maxfield Parrish, Arthur Rackham, Edmund Dulac, Kate Greenway, Charles Dana Gibson and others, at the Museum of Cartoon Art, Comly Avenue, Rye Brook, N.Y., in Westchester County. 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Tuesdays through Fridays and 1 to 5 P.M. Sundays. Admission: children, 5 to 12, $1 (under 5, free); students and the elderly, $2; others, $3. Information: (914) 939-0234. ''ARLECCHINO'S HEART OF GOLD,'' a play with audience participation, 1 and 3 P.M. Saturdays, and ''The Rose That Refused to Bloom,'' a musical, 1 and 3 P.M. Sundays, at the 13th Street Repertory Company, 50 West 13th Street. Tickets: $4. Information: 675-6677. ''MOSTLY MAGIC,'' a magic-and-comedy show with audience participation, presented by Torkova and Imam, at 2 P.M. Saturdays at 55 Carmine Street. Admission: $7.50. Reservations: 924-1472.

title: Progress Toward The Past
description: It has been 15 years since expectations were this high, when the heartbeat of Madison Square Garden could be heard in the decibel count generated by more than 19,000 connoisseurs of the city game. The spring of 1974 marked the end of a glamorous era in New York sports, a time of Frazier, Reed, Bradley, DeBusschere, Monroe, Barnett and Company, and Streisand, Redford, Woody and Dancing Harry, too.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Sherman Sings

title: A Mentor And Money Impel Lopez
description: Nancy Lopez has a special place in her heart for the Chrysler-Plymouth Classic. First, because she has won the Ladies' Professional Golf Association event four times and second, because of her friendship with the late Peter Busatti, the founder of the tournament.

title: Sri Lanka Talks With Rebels
description: After 10 years of violence that has cost this small nation at least 10,000 lives, the President of Sri Lanka opened peace talks today with ethnic Tamil guerrillas.

title: Justice Dept. Will Delay Any Inquiry on Wright
description: The White House and the Justice Department have pledged to the House ethics committee that the Justice Department will not undertake any investigation of House Speaker Jim Wright until after the committee has completed all its work, senior officials on Capitol Hill said today.

title: 'USA' Show Creator Quits
description: Steve Friedman, who created ''USA Today: The Television Show,'' has resigned, effective May 29, as president of GTG East, which produces the program.

title: Unarmed Midgetman Missile a Failure in First Test
description: An unarmed Midgetman missile tumbled off course and was destroyed over the Pacific Ocean today about 70 seconds after the Air Force launched the first test flight of the new weapon, which has been at the center of a political struggle between Congress and the Pentagon.

title: BEIRUT RIVALS VOW TO RESPECT TRUCE
description: Arab mediators arranged a new cease-fire between Lebanon's warring factions today, but artillery bombardment continued long after the truce was supposed to have gone into force.

title: Grand Jury Indicts Secord Again, This Time on 9 Charges of Lying
description: Richard V. Secord, the former Air Force major general who sold weapons to Iran and diverted profits to the Nicaraguan rebels, has been indicted on nine criminal charges of lying to and obstructing the Congressional committees that investigated the Iran-contra affair, it was announced today.

title: Economic Scene; Rich and Poor: The Gap Widens
description: WHY are the rich getting richer and the poor getting poorer in the United States - even as the long expansion in national income continues?

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council Meets at 10 A.M. ECONOMIC COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. SECOND COMMITTEE - 3 P.M.

title: Sunny Days! It's a Girl!
description: It's a girl!

title: Pop/Jazz; Continent Of Music: Africa Onstage
description: WHEN the Batwa pygmies of northern Zaire creep across a fog-shrouded stage at 8 tonight at the City Center, their appearance will mark the beginning of nearly two hours of extraordinary music, dance and costumes from Africa. With its Broadway pacing, the exceptionally high quality of its performers and the sheer number of acts - eight, including 54 performers - the new show ''Africa Oye'' is unparalleled.

title: 'Star Wars' Plan Facing a Delay, Its Director Says
description: The Bush Administration is delaying development of key parts of Ronald Reagan's antimissile plan for two years while it studies a proposal that could radically alter it, the project's new director said today.

title: Stocks Up for Second Day; Dow Gains 8.43
description: LEAD: The stock market moved higher yesterday for the second day, as the Dow Jones industrial average gained 8.43 points to close at 2,382.88.

title: Review/Art; In SoHo, 2 Shows Referring To Painting's Recent Past
description: Sparsely installed in two of SoHo's most prestigious galleries and accompanied by a catalogue with an introduction by Gore Vidal, Philip Taaffe's new paintings appear to be wired for high-voltage art-world stardom. Perhaps to their credit, most of them fail to qualify. There's something admirable about Mr. Taaffe's refusal to produce a string of well-coordinated winners. He seems to be considering too many ideas about painting, taste and abstract subject matter to settle down.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * ASDA Group P.L.C., London, a British store group that has been surrounded by takeover speculation recently, said it had learned that the Belzberg family of Canada had built up a 3 percent stake in the company.

title: Aggressive and Exhaustive Lawyer: Richard John Phelan
description: Richard J. Phelan of Chicago, the investigator on the brink of bringing down the Speaker of the House, was once described as a lawyer who takes a ''wide-angle approach'' to his cases.

title: Behind Bulls' Fire A Coach to Match
description: Doug Collins attended a Broadway play Wednesday night, enjoying a temporary escape from the stress of coaching the Chicago Bulls. A few years ago, Collins might have felt guilty taking a break during the playoffs. But while Collins remains one of basketball's most intense coaches, he is gradually learning to relax. At least until the game begins. ''Doug hasn't changed on the sidelines during games, and frankly, I have urged him to remain who he is,'' said John Bach, one of the Bulls' assistant coaches. ''He's the emotional fuel that this team needs. The Doug Collins you see at a game is a very emotional, excitable, quick-thinking man. It drives players, it excites them, it angers them, and it motivates them.

title: Iran to Seek Loans Abroad
description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, Iran's supreme religious leader, has given his approval for foreign borrowing, newspapers in Iran reported Wednesday. Iran's High Council for

title: Clippers Eye Valvano
description: The Los Angeles Clippers said yesterday that they would meet with the North Carolina State coach, Jim Valvano, on Wednesday to discuss the team's vacant head coaching position. But Art Kaminsky, Valvano's agent, denied that a meeting had been scheduled. Kaminsky said that Valvano and Sterling have never spoken to each other and that Sterling didn't seem to be in a hurry to fill the position.

title: At the Movies
description: Weegee's Photography

title: U.S. Troops To Go Slowly Into Panama
description: The United States armed force ordered into Panama by President Bush today will be relatively small and will move slowly into Panama over the next three weeks, apparently as the result of a compromise between the Defense and State Departments.

title: INSIDE
description: Kenya Seeks Ivory Ban Kenya will seek a ban on ivory trade, a move intended to preserve dwindling elephant herds. Page A5. Drought Stunts Wheat Crop Despite sharp increases in acres planted, farmers will produce the smallest winter wheat crop in 11 years because of drought. Page A12. More Charges for Secord The former Air Force major general who sold arms to Iran was indicted on nine more charges. Page B8. Slim Victory for Jet Fighter The Senate Foreign Relations Committee rejected, 9 to 8, a bid to kill the FSX deal with Japan but will allow the full Senate to vote on it. Page D1. Hearing for Pete Rose The Cincinnati manager is to respond on May 25 to a report on an inquiry into his activities. Page B17.

title: GORBACHEV HANDS A SURPRISED BAKER AN ARMS PROPOSAL
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, told Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d today that Moscow plans a small cut in its nuclear arsenal in Europe by the end of the year, State Department officials said.

title: Adelman to Stay On As Trail Blazer Coach
description: Rick Adelman, who became interim coach of the Portland Trail Blazers in February, will be retained as head coach through next season, the club announced yesterday. Harry Glickman, president of the team, said no other candidates were interviewed.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Bella Luna

title: Eastern Entices Another Suitor
description: A group led by William Howard, former chairman of Piedmont Airlines, has made an offer to take over Eastern Airlines, promising full payment for the airline's secured and unsecured creditors, people involved in Eastern's bankruptcy talks said yesterday.

title: Transcript of President's Statement at White House on the Crisis in Panama
description: Following is a transcript of a statement at the White House by President Bush today, as recorded by the Federal News Service:

title: Two Jersey Officials Indicted In Political Vengeance Case
description: Mayor Nicholas J. Cicco of Guttenberg and a City Councilman there were indicted today by a Federal grand jury over the dismissal of two special policemen and a 76-year-old crossing guard who refused to back a local election slate.

title: Attack on Broadcasters Attacks the Public
description: To the Editor:

title: Ryan Strikes Out 11 As Rangers Win, 6-3
description: Nolan Ryan pitched a five-hitter and struck out 11 tonight, and Pete Incaviglia drove in four runs for Texas as the Rangers defeated the Kansas City Royals, 6-3.

title:
About Real Estate;
Two Towers With Customized Condos
description: LEAD: It is not easy to customize units in an apartment building under construction. Plumbing lines, wiring and support columns are all interrelated with apartments on the floors below and above.

title: Auctions
description: Print Market Soars

title: Administration Proposes Creating Oil Spill Fund
description: The Bush Administration proposed comprehensive legislation today establishing a Federal fund to pay for cleaning up oil spills, an idea that had languished in Congress for years until the recent Alaskan spill.

title: Mortgage Rates Rise
description: Interest rates on both fixed-rate and adjustable-rate home loans rose in April to their highest levels in more than three years, the Government reported Wednesday. Fixed-rate mortgages in early April rose 0.21 percentage point from the previous month, to 11.58 percent, and adjustable-rate mortgages rose 0.37 point, to 10.14 percent, the Federal Home Loan Bank Board reported. Those were the highest levels since December 1985, when fixed-rate mortgages averaged 12.01 percent and adjustable-rate home loans averaged 10.39 percent.

title: Newmont Sees Big Payout From Revamping Peabody
description: The Newmont Mining Corporation, the nation's largest gold producer, announced a plan yesterday to recapitalize its 49.97 percent stake in the Peabody Holding Company in a complex move that would bring Newmont a dividend of $425 million.

title: Muzzle the Stanford Bigots
description: LEAD: As a black woman attending Stanford University, I feel that no one should be allowed to promote racially derogatory ideas on this campus.

title: A Book Fair in an Unfriendly Country Can Speak Volumes; Not a Moneymaker
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Weekend; Two Channel 13 News Programs Offer Hot Issues Cooly
description: Early in the now-ending television season, Channel 13 inaugurated two news programs, the weekly ''Metro Week in Review'' and the nightly ''11th Hour.'' They can be seen tonight, in that order, from 10:30 to 11:30. With tabloid-style shout shows causing a clamor on several other channels, both of these adult efforts to discuss goings-on in the New York metropolitan area deserve a warm, if belated, welcome and good wishes for the future.

title: Henry Kaiser, 77, Dies; Labor Lawyer 40 Years
description: Henry Kaiser, a labor lawyer and general counsel of the American Federation of Musicians, died of cancer Wednesday at George Washington University Hospital in Washington. He was 77 years old and lived in Chevy Chase, Md.

title: Blowouts
description: Never has there been a worse time to be an umbrella than during the last few weeks in New York. It's not the rain - rain is what umbrellas are for. The problem has been the wind.

title: Amgen Rises $3
description: Shares of Amgen Inc., a biotechnology company based in Thousand Oaks, Calif., rose $3, to $40, in over-the-counter trading yesterday after a Food and Drug Administration advisory committee recommended approval for erythropoietin to combat anemia in patients with kidney problems, before or during dialysis treatment. Analysts said the recommendation, although not binding, meant the drug was close to approval.

title: For Want of Plane, Cuomo Skips Meeting
description: A 22-year-old state aircraft used to transport Gov. Mario M. Cuomo had its latest bout with balkiness today, leaving Mr. Cuomo unable to attend a meeting with fellow governors in Ottawa.

title: 2 Charged in Bribery In Hotel Inspections
description: A hotel manager and a hotel fire safety director have been arrested on charges of paying cash bribes to an undercover agent posing as a building inspector to have code violations overlooked, the city Department of Investigation said yesterday.

title: Snub Lies in Waiting for Gorbachev in Shanghai
description: When Mikhail S. Gorbachev strolls on Chinese streets during the summit meeting planned next week to end three decades of hostility between China and the Soviet Union, he is expected to face a snub so blunt as to remind him that there is still a chill in the air.

title: Japan Deal Passes Test In Senate
description: The Bush Administration won a narrow tactical victory today when the Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved, by a 9-to-8 vote, the agreement to build an advanced fighter with Japan.

title: Citibank Seizes $80 Million In Ecuador Bank Deposits
description: In an unusual move, Citibank yesterday seized about $80 million in deposits from the central bank of Ecuador to pay off an outstanding trade loan.

title: In the Court of Public Opinion
description: So public are the political crimes of Panama's self-anointed leader, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, that everyone with a television set becomes a member of the grand jury. One does not have to be a lawyer to draw up an indictment. To see television pictures, laboriously obtained, of the general's goons battering his unarmed political challengers is to grasp the scale of his offenses.

title: Denouncing Fraud, Bush Bolsters Force in Panama
description: President Bush announced a series of measures today to encourage the resignation or ouster of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega as Panama's military leader.

title: House Votes Increasing Minimum Pay to $4.55
description: The House voted today to raise the minimum wage to $4.55 an hour by October 1991, leaving only a final Senate vote before the bill goes to President Bush, who has promised to veto it.

title: Swedish Savings Plan
description: The Swedish Finance Minister, Kjell-Olof Feldt, proposed Wednesday that the Government force Swedes to save money to cool the country's overheated economy. Under his plan, private citizens and companies would add 4 percent to their tax bills.

title: Degradable Plastics and Recycling Don't Mix
description: To the Editor:

title: Rules on Posting of Pesticide Use Overturned
description: A state judge overturned regulations today that would have required farmers, restaurants, hotels and other businesses to notify the public when they planned to use pesticides.

title: The Weapons of Hell
description: At least we will know where to put the blame. If the day comes when the terrorist nations use the weapons of hell against us or other enemies, at least we will know that.

title: Hernandez Is Accepting New Order With the Mets
description: Keith Hernandez walked into the clubhouse here Tuesday afternoon and strode straight past his locker directly to the lineup card posted next to the door to the field. He found his name written into the sixth spot in the order, where it had never been before in his six years with the Mets.

title: Huge Peronist Rally Ends Campaign
description: The memory of Juan D. Peron came vibrantly alive in Argentina today as Carlos Saul Menem, the Peronist presidential candidate, ended his campaign to outpourings of adoration and expectation.

title: Jones, Day Law Merger
description: The nation's third-largest law firm, Jones, Day, Reavis & Pogue of Cleveland, announced yesterday that it would merge with Hansell & Post, an 80-lawyer firm in Atlanta. With the merger, Jones, Day will have 1,020 lawyers and 10 offices in the United States and 5 overseas.

title: Degradable Plastics and Recycling Don't Mix; New York Sorts It Out
description: To the Editor:

title: Dining Out Guide: Mother's Day
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current. American Festival Cafe * (July 27, 1984), 20 West 50th Street (246-6699) - This engaging restaurant in the lower plaza at Rockefeller Center has put together a special Mother's Day menu for Sunday. Appetizer choices include lobster chowder and an eggplant lasagna. Among entrees are breast of chicken stuffed with vegetables and tournedos of beef with peppers and Armagnac. Deserts include Mother's Cake. A prix fixe three-course meal is $29.50 (children half price). Seatings at noon, 2, 4, 6 and 8 P.M. Gotham Bar and Grill *** (Oct. 4, 1985), 12 East 12th Street (620-4020) - This spacious and comfortable multi-tier dining room is celebrating Mother's Day with a special brunch. To start, there are a charcuterie platter of sausage, smoked ham and prosciutto; corn-and-clam chowder, and, among various salads and vegetable plates, the Gotham's signature seafood salad or a couscous salad with golden raisins. Entrees include whole poached halibut and snapper; roast chicken, and grilled leg of lamb with fresh fava beans. An enticing dessert is strawberry shortcake. The prix-fixe three-course buffet brunch, served from 11:30 A.M. to 2:30 P.M., is $45. Greene Street Restaurant ** (April 29, 1988), 101 Greene Street (925-2415) - A rose will be presented to every mother at this theatrical multi-tier SoHo loft. Specials for the day include appetizers of lobster ravioli in a tomato butter sauce or beefsteak tomatoes and mozzarella in basil olive oil; entrees of veal steak with spatzle and baby vegetables or sea bass wrapped in crisp thin potatoes and served with carrot mousse and baby vegetables. For dessert, there is a classic cheesecake with strawberries. Throughout the day and evening there is jazz by Lynn Bernstein on piano and Lisle Atkinson on bass. Appetizers are $5 to $10, entrees $10 to $23. Open noon to 9 P.M. The Polo ** (Sept. 2, 1988), Westbury Hotel, Madison Avenue and 69th Street (535-9141) - The chef of this patrician refuge has a special menu for the holiday. The appetizer is goat-cheese ravioli with a salad of walnuts and baby lettuce. The entree is roast spring lamb with garlic-whipped potatoes and grilled fennel. Mothers receive an extra dessert of white chocolate mousse cake wrapped as a gift with candied ribbons and flowers. The three-course prix fixe menu is $58. Open noon to 10 P.M. Prunelle ** (May 23, 1986), 18 East 54th Street (759-6410) - A three-course Mother's Day lunch is on hand at this handsome, understated dining room with its lavish flower displays. A satisfying meal would be an appetizer of shrimp and leeks in phyllo followed by a triple-roast dish consisting of roast sliced fillet of beef, fillet of veal and boneless duck served with watercress and mustard sauce, and ending with green-apple mousse with ginger caramel and melon sauce. Prix fixe $38. Lunch from noon to 3:30 P.M. Windows on the World * (July 4, 1986), 1 World Trade Center, 107th floor (938-1111) - A lavish spread is available at this perch above the World Trade Center, with stunning views of the city. Appetizers include crab-and-shrimp salad with grapefruit, asparagus with chive sauce and a red snapper terrine. This is followed by a soup, perhaps chicken consomme with spinach pasta. Among entrees are roast rack of lamb with thyme and tomatoes and fricassee of lobster and sea scallops. Spring vegetables and gratin potatoes are accompaniments. Next comes salad greens with balsamic vinaigrette, then a selection of desserts based on recipes submitted by the kitchen staff members to re-create their mothers' desserts. The five-course meal is $31 to $39. Seatings are at noon, 2, 4:30 and 7 P.M.

title: Zoeller Rekindles Spark To Grab First-Round Lead
description: Because of all his back problems in recent years, a growing family and his age, Fuzzy Zoeller has placed competitive golf down a notch or two on his priority list.

title: Volley Could Mean Advantage Moscow
description: Western military analysts say that by announcing plans to scrap some short-range nuclear weapons, Mikhail S. Gorbachev gave West Germany support in the campaign for talks on such weapons.

title: Negotiators Reach Accord on the 1990 Budget
description: Senate and House negotiators agreed today on a $1.17 trillion Federal budget for the 1990 fiscal year, a spending plan that leaves many prickly decisions for later.

title: Writers Guild Votes
description: The Writers Guild of America, East has voted overwhelmingly to affiliate with the A.F.L.-C.I.O. The union, which represents 3,200 writers of television shows and feature movies, CBS and ABC news writers and other news personnel, voted Wednesday night to become part of the Department for Professional Employees of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., which already includes such unions as the Screen Actors Guild. The affiliation does not affect the Writers Guild of America, West. A spokesman for the eastern guild, Martin G. Waldman, said his union would continue to join with the western guild in negotiating national contracts.

title: Books of The Times; A Novelist's Story of Love, Pain and (Neon) Signs of Life
description: The Neon Bible By John Kennedy Toole 162 pages. Grove Press. $15.95.

title: Review/Film; Pryor and Wilder Pool Handicaps in 'See No Evil'
description: Wally (Richard Pryor) is blind, but refuses to acknowledge the fact. He will not carry a white cane. Being blind is not something he mentions at job interviews, though the fact inevitably creeps out. Wally is so desperate to pass for sighted that when he rides the subway, he pretends to read the paper.

title: Sears Still Looking
description: Sears, Roebuck & Company is still searching for a new headquarters for its 6,000-person merchandising group, but the group prefers to stay in the Chicago area, said Edward A. Brennan, Sears's chairman. At a news conference after Sears's annual meeting, Mr. Brennan said Sears continued to review relocation proposals from cities around the country. He said Sears would announce its decision in June. Mr. Brennan also said negotiations continued for the sale of the Sears Tower here.

title: Hilton Sale Hinted
description: Stock in the Hilton Hotels Corporation surged $6.50 a share today, to $72, on the New York Stock Exchange after Barron Hilton, the company's chairman, suggested at the annual meeting that he might contemplate selling all or part of the hotel and gaming concern. ''While we are not seeking buyers for the corporation, should we receive an expression of interest from a qualified party, the board has a fiduciary responsibility to give it careful consideration,'' Mr. Hilton said.

title: Arthur C. Austin, 77, A Longtime Conductor
description: Arthur C. Austin, a former conductor and radio producer, died of cancer Tuesday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: PATH and Engineers in Tentative Accord
description: The National Mediation Board announced yesterday that negotiators for PATH and Local 497 of the Brotherhood of Locomotive Engineers had reached a tentative agreement after more than three years of talks.

title: Reviews/Art; Fame in No Hurry for Arnold Friedman
description: If during his lifetime Arnold Friedman never enjoyed the success he deserved, the painter has received his share of attention lately. Friedman's work was shown sporadically before his death in 1946, and during the next 34 years it appeared in only 11 exhibitions of one sort or another.

title: Reviews/Art; From a Land of Conflict, Works by Israelis
description: For the sequel to her exhibition on Israeli artists for the Jewish Museum in 1980, Susan Tumarkin Goodman, its chief curator, has zeroed in on one theme. She writes in the catalogue that all 18 artists in her current show express ''abhorrence of the wars that have been the constants of their nation.'' As a result of the present political climate, Mrs. Goodman says, more Israeli artists than ever before are giving ''expression to their country's social and political problems.''

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; French Firm Raises Bid For Boase
description: ADVERTISING'S other hostile takeover battle - Boulet Dru Dupuy Petit's bid for Boase Massimi Pollitt Partnership - grew hotter yesterday when the French company raised its offer to 345 pence a share, or about $5.77.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 468 money market mutual funds rose by $2.9 billion, to $307.06 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 141 institutional funds increased by $1.29 billion, to $76.8 billion. The assets of the 232 general-purpose funds were up by $1.03 billion, to $100.80 billion. The 95 broker-dealer funds increased by $573.5 million, to $129.47 billion, the institute said.

title: 'Chu Chem' to Close
description: ''Chu Chem,'' a musical with book by Ted Allan, music by Mitch Leigh and lyrics by Jim Haines and Jack Wohl, will close after the matinee on Sunday at the Ritz Theater, 225 West 48th Street. Directed by Albert Marre, the play will have run for 24 previews and 45 regular performances.

title: U.S. WON'T APPEAL AGENT ORANGE CASE
description: The Department of Veterans Affairs announced today that it would not appeal a Federal court decision that may require it to pay disability benefits to thousands of veterans exposed to the chemical defoliant Agent Orange in the Vietnam War.

title: Software Industry in Uproar Over Recent Rush of Patents
description: Suppose someone were granted a patent for the opening four notes of Beethoven's Fifth Symphony. Any composer who used that short sequence of notes would probably have to pay a royalty, and the music world would be in turmoil.

title: T.B. Hogan Sr., 71; Led Trustees of Pace U.
description: Thomas Bernard Hogan Sr., an accountant and a former chairman of the trustees of Pace University, died Tuesday at his home in Spring Lake, N.J. He was 71 years old.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Atmos Energy Corp., Dallas, a natural gas distributor, promoted Robert F. Stephens and James F. Purser to executive vice president.

title: In Pursuit of the Clever Quotemaster
description: Their names can be found in Rolodexes all over town. They are the Washington quotemasters, those political analysts, economists, Sovietologists and Washington hostesses who are masters of the acute observation, the pithy quote, the succinct declarative statement.

title: Man Alters Account Of His Wife's Death
description: A man who had said that he killed his wife by accident while trying to swat insects now says that he beat her for calling him lazy, the police said.

title: New Orleans Journal; Project on Piety Street: Reclaim Crack Houses
description: The street signs say Abundance, Pleasure, Industry and Piety (and the nearby housing project is named Desire).

title: In the Footsteps of Saint-Exupery
description: WALKING tours have become a bustling and imaginative industry. As the weather begins to turn warm, tours proliferate to the point where it is possible, as it is this weekend, to choose from walks in most of the boroughs with a staggering variety of themes. New Yorkers now know a good deal more about the city's nooks and crannies and its cultural and social history. But each season there are surprises.

title: Kenneth Roberts, 76, Former House Member
description: Kenneth A. Roberts, a former Democratic Representative from Alabama who was wounded in a 1954 shooting in the House of Representatives, died Tuesday at his daughter's home in Potomac, Md., after a long illness. He was 76 years old and lived in Anniston, Ala.

title: Koch, in Split With Some Rivals, Urges Fast Choice of Schools Chief
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch said yesterday that he hoped the New York City Board of Education could select a Chancellor to succeed Dr. Richard R. Green by the time school starts in September, if not earlier.

title: Catapulted from obscurity by a teen-age rape suspect whom he actually likes
description: Howard J. Diller began leafing through the blue message slips strewn about his desk. ''Here's 'Wanda' from Channel 2,'' he said. ''Jim Kunin from People magazine. Here's Magee Hickey from Channel 4 and Terry Landau from NBC. Tim Minton, Channel 7. Pablo Guzman, Channel 5. Michael Stone from New York magazine.''

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11 Moscow will cut its nuclear arsenal in Europe by the end of the year, Mikhail S. Gorbachev told Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d at a meeting in the Kremlin. Page A1

title: 2 Wall Street Firms Join To Buy Savings Units
description: With great fanfare, two of Wall Street's leading investment banks said yesterday that they were teaming up with another partner to mine investment opportunities in the troubled savings and loan industry.

title: Paris Journal; Pardon My English, but Did Someone Say 1992?
description: Linguistically speaking, it was a stab in the back. As President Francois Mitterrand was mobilizing diplomatic and political energies to prevent French from losing its privileged position in the new Europe, one of the nation's most prestigious organizations, the Pasteur Institute, decided to publish its research bulletins under English titles.

title: Duran and I.R.S. Settle
description: To help settle a debt of about $1.6 million to the Internal Revenue Service, Roberto Duran has agreed to give half his income between now and Aug. 8 to the I.R.S.

title: Lingering Drought Stunts Wheat Crop
description: Despite a sharp increase in acres planted with high hopes last fall, American farmers this year will produce the smallest crop of winter wheat in 11 years because of drought, the Agriculture Department reported today.

title: Four-Legged Stand-Up Comedy
description: IN ''Only Kidding,'' Jim Geoghan's acidly funny dissection of the stand-up comedy jungle, Andrew Hill Newman and Paul Provenza portray a rising young comedy duo whose partnership explodes when one wants to sign a contract with a sleazy club owner and the other doesn't.

title: League Post Filled
description: Carl F. Ullrich, the director of athletics at Army, was named executive director of the Colonial League. Ullrich will serve in a dual capacity as West Point's director and the Colonial's leader for the 1989-90 academic year and then become the full-time executive director.

title: Rosemary Clooney
description: Skitch Henderson will conduct the New York Pops in selections from Andrew Lloyd Webber's ''Phantom of the Opera'' tonight at 8 at Carnegie Hall. The program will also include performances of songs by George Gershwin, Frank Loesser, Johnny Mercer and Rodgers and Hart by Rosemary Clooney and the Concord All Stars. The program will be repeated tomorrow at 2 P.M. Tickets are $15 to $40 for tonight's concert, and $13 to $20 for tomorrow's. Information: 247-7800.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm worried about the lives of American citizens, and I will do what is necessary to protect the lives of American citizens.

title: Canadiens Advance To Stanley Cup Final
description: In Mats Naslund's opinion, there was never any doubt that the Canadiens would overcome the passion and turbulence that accompany any series involving the Philadelphia Flyers.

title: On Stage
description: 'Perestroika' at Purchase This summer is the last call for the Pepsico Summerfare festival held at the Performing Arts Center in Purchase, N.Y. After 10 years and contributions of almost $10 million, Pepsico, which produces the festival with the State University College at Purchase, is pulling out because, a spokesman said, ''it is felt that the amount involved is too much to devote to one project.''

title: Suns Top Warriors
description: Tom Chambers scored 31 points, including 12 in the fourth quarter, as Phoenix revived tonight after losing a 17-point lead to down Golden State, 113-104.

title: Savings Unit Outflow High
description: Customers at savings and loan associations withdrew $8.5 billion from their accounts in March, the Government said today in a report that showed only slight improvement from the sharp outflow of the first two months of this year.

title: Review/Film; On Shaving, Furry Aliens Turn Into Valley Guys
description: On its silliest level, ''Earth Girls Are Easy'' is about three life-sized, fur-covered creatures - one red, one blue, one yellow - whose spaceship crashes into Geena Davis's swimming pool. On a slightly less goofy level, it is a nostalgic chance for baby boomers to escape to the toy-and-television culture of their childhoods. Julien Temple's film is inspired by the Jetsons, flying-saucer movies and old Hollywood musicals seen on television. It is a joyfully chaotic and wildly uneven work that shows Mr. Temple's roots in music videos.

title: Leading the Attack on Wright
description: Some Wright critics worried when Richard J. Phelan, a Chicago Democrat, was named to investigate him.

title: Review/Film; A Woman Visits the Child She Was in the Holocaust
description: The American woman who walks through the gate to a peasant's cottage in Poland looks calm and cheerful, dressed as if she were heading off to a Mets game. In her navy windbreaker and tinted designer glasses, the middle-aged woman who is called Aunt Sally throughout ''Voices in the Attic'' resembles everyone's kind down-to-earth suburban aunt. But in this scene, deep into Debbie Goodstein's film about her family's survival of the Holocaust, Sally is heading back to the house where she and 15 other members of her family hid from the Nazis for two years in a cramped attic without plumbing, electricity or even room to stand up.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a computer error, a chart in the Sports Pages yesterday showing sites of the Breeders' Cup thoroughbred races carried an incomplete entry for 1986 in some editions. The races that year were held on Nov. 1 at Santa Anita Park in Arcadia, Calif.

title: Mayor Rescinds Mitchell-Lama Plan
description: A regulation that could have forced many New York City residents in subsidized middle-income housing to move into smaller apartments was rescinded yesterday by Mayor Edward I. Koch, who took the unusual step of rejecting a regulation adopted by his own administration.

title: Rock Mecca Endangered By Condos
description: For the last 15 years, while most of the beach front of this tattered resort town was having trouble attracting more than sea gulls, the Stone Pony was becoming something of a legend as a blue-collar rock-and-roll Mecca.

title: Blood Match Is Made In Case, Officials Say
description: Blood found on the clothes of three of the six youths charged in the attack on a woman jogger in Central Park matched that of the victim, law-enforcement officials said yesterday.

title: Market Place; Global Traders Get New Vehicle
description: DO American financial markets need a quick and easy way to bet on the direction of stock prices in the rest of the world? The answer will start to become clearer today, as futures and options begin trading on an index of foreign stocks.

title: T.V.A. to Retire High-Rate Bonds
description: The Tennessee Valley Authority plans to retire about $750 million of high-interest bonds and save itself $30 million in interest payments annually.

title: Retail Data Push U.S. Bonds Up
description: The Treasury successfully completed the final stage of its quarterly auctions yesterday as market participants received an unexpected psychological lift from a retail sales report that was much weaker than anticipated.

title: KABUL URGES BUSH TO PURSUE PEACE
description: A senior Afghan official called today for the Bush Administration to acknowledge that Muslim guerrillas will not capture the strategic city of Jalalabad and that a negotiated peace in Afghanistan is essential.

title: Review/Dance; Working a Trend, but With Originality
description: Dan Wagoner is a choreographer who has always gone his own way, seemingly working within certain trends hovering in the air but actually applying a twist of fervent originality.

title: Prominent New Yorkers Meet on Growing Crises
description: About 15 prominent public figures -leaders in business, politics, labor, religion, education and other fields - met informally yesterday to discuss what many called a growing crisis of problems threatening the future of New York City.

title: At the Summit, a Volcano
description: They didn't plan it this way. The first Chinese-Soviet summit meeting in 30 years was originally designed to put the long-strained relations between the two largest Communist nations on a stable and more friendly basis, address disagreements accumulated over many acrimonious years and gain an advantage in the triangular relationship involving China, the Soviet Union and the United States.

title: Paramount Sues Viacom Over Fees
description: Paramount Pictures, a division of Gulf and Western Inc., yesterday filed an $88 million lawsuit against Showtime Networks; its owner, Viacom Inc., and Viacom's parent, National Amusements Inc. Paramount said that Showtime, the nation's second-largest pay-television service, was refusing to pay all the fees to which it had agreed for the right to run 75 Paramount films.

title: Asthma Deaths Center on 2 Groups, Experts Say
description: Medical experts say that increasingly the victims of fatal asthma attacks fall into two groups: black and Hispanic people, who often lack access to medical care, and patients who have suffered from the disease for a long time, treating it themselves using prescribed medications.

title: An Unpresident for the City Council
description: The panel now rewriting New York City's charter has decided, too hastily, to save a non-job - the City Council presidency. The Charter Revision Commission has time to reconsider. So does the incumbent, Andrew Stein, whose intense, effective lobbying to save his title ignores a distinction essential to sound redesign of the government. The skill of people now in office should not be confused with the future value of the positions they hold.

title: Alar Ban Is Coming
