description: The Environmental Protection Agency said today that it expects within 10 days to begin formal steps to ban the apple-ripening agent Alar, which has been called a health threat, especially for children. The process could take as long as three years. The Processed Apples Institute said sales of such products as juice and sauce are off 20 percent from last year because of fears about Alar use by some growers.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Gerard A. Byrne has been named executive publisher of Variety, the entertainment industry newspaper.

title: 2 Ford Grandsons Get Key Committee Posts
description: Two grandsons of Henry Ford, the founder of the Ford Motor Company, were named yesterday to the executive and finance committees of the company's board, an important step toward their goal of keeping a family member at or near the top of the company.

title: Review/Music; The Experimental Bang on a Can Festival
description: Now in its third year, the Bang on a Can Festival has emerged as one of New York's most vital forums for new music, concentrating on downtown experimentation but remarkably wide-ranging within that broad category.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a new book on the Rev. Jesse Jackson's 1988 Presidential campaign omitted the names of the book and its publisher. The book, by Elizabeth O. Colton, is ''The Jackson Phenomenon: The Man, The Power, The Message.'' It will be published by Doubleday.

title: VENEZUELA URGES TALKS ON NORIEGA
description: The President of Venezuela said today that he had asked the Organization of American States to sponsor an emergency meeting of the foreign ministers of all Western Hemisphere countries, to be held in Washington early next week, to seek a diplomatic solution to the deepening crisis in Panama.

title: A Seamless Safety Net
description: The Federal safety net is sagging. In the 1930's it was possible to fashion a social welfare policy around a few key ingredients - old-age pensions, unemployment insurance, aid to dependent children. But now, says an ambitious new Ford Foundation report, insuring a basic standard of living will require a policy that spans the whole life cycle of people in need.

title: Pretoria Cabinet Aide Quits; Tried to Coax Blacks to Talks
description: The South African Cabinet minister in charge of largely unsuccessful efforts to draw black leaders into negotiations announced his resignation today.

title: Max Gordon, 86, Jazz Promoter And Founder of Vanguard, Dies
description: Max Gordon, who for 54 years operated the Village Vanguard, one of the most influential clubs in jazz history, died yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 86 years old.

title: Dunkin' Donuts Bid Is Weighed
description: An investment group that last month acquired a 7.6 percent stake in Dunkin'

title: Review/Dance; City Ballet On Love, Death And Desertion
description: The end of a love affair can seem like a death. And if a lover repeatedly abandons a beloved, each departure can be a new death.

title: A Chance for Budget Honesty
description: The House Ways and Means Committee wants President Bush to face up to the true budgetary costs of bailing out bankrupt savings and loans. The committee is right. Mr. Bush's financing plan is a transparent effort to avoid the appearance of a bigger budget deficit. It's also needlessly expensive.

title: Bennett Boots It
description: When does a ''boot camp'' look too much like a ''concentration camp'' to be tolerated in America? When you seize thousands of drug users and throw them into military-style camps for harsh punishment and ''psycho-correctional therapy.''

title: Retail Sales Rose 0.4% In April
description: The nation's retail sales rose four-tenths of 1 percent in April, a smaller rebound from the lackluster trend of the two previous months than economists expected.

title: Noriega's Foes Say Vote Must Stand
description: The Panamanian opposition today rejected the Government's decision to annul the presidential election and said it was prepared for talks only if Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega stepped down as military leader.

title: U.N. Doubling Size of Police Force in Namibia
description: The United Nations said today that it was doubling the police part of its Namibian peacekeeping force as part of an effort to get the stalled independence process moving. The step followed complaints of intimidation and lawlessness in the South African territory.

title: Segal Awards to Singer And to 'Sarafina!' Cast
description: The third annual Martin E. Segal Awards were presented yesterday to Andrea Gruber, a 23-year-old soprano with the Metropolitan Opera Young Artists Program, and the 23 core cast members of the Lincoln Center Theater production ''Sarafina!,'' the South African musical now at the Cort Theater.

title: In Vietnam, Education Holds a Revered Place
description: To the Editor:

title: Sears Names Chairman Of Allstate Insurance
description: Wayne E. Hedien has been named chairman and chief executive of the Allstate Insurance Group, Sears, Roebuck & Company announced yesterday.

title: Polish Copper Miners End Strike and Gain Pay Raises
description: Miners at four southwestern copper mines ended a six-day strike today and returned to work after winning 30 percent pay increases and higher bonuses, a Solidarity spokesman said.

title: For the Record
description: Constitutional Physics

title: Vogueing Against AIDS: A Quest for 'Overness'
description: The wilder side of downtown and uptown club culture met in the middle of town Wednesday night, at Roseland, on 52d Street between Broadway and Seventh Avenue, for a party that was anything but middle of the road. Produced as a benefit for the Design Industries Foundation for AIDS, the Love Ball, as it was called, was to the typical charity affair what the Sex Pistols were to Mozart.

title: Financial Aid Proposal
description: Dick Schultz, executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, said yesterday that he favored the adoption of a rule that would enable athletes who need financial aid to receive funds over current Federal limitations.

title: A Medieval Marketplace
description: The Church of the Holy Trinity, 316 East 88th Street, is to hold its annual Medieval Marketplace tomorrow to raise money for its community outreach programs, which include a soup kitchen, a shelter for the homeless, an AIDS ministry and a summer day camp. The 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. event is to feature musicians playing medieval hurdy-gurdies, puppeteers, home-baked goods, antiques, collectibles, clothing, toys and books. An auction is to begin at 3 P.M. A raffle will award Broadway show tickets, dinners at New York City restaurants and other items. Admission is free. Information: 289-4100.

title: EXXON HEAD SEEKS ENVIRONMENTALIST TO SERVE ON BOARD
description: The president of the Exxon Corporation, bowing to pressure from pension funds holding about $1 billion in the company's stock, said yesterday that he would recommend that an environmentalist be named to Exxon's board.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Marilyn Crispell

title: Review/Theater; 'On the Town' Is Revived in Washington
description: ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway,'' with its artfully selected collage of musical excerpts, arouses the audience's eagerness to see fresh revivals of the individual shows. The Arena Stage is the first to oblige, with a return engagement of ''On the Town,'' that high-spirited, ingenuous evocation of a dreamland New York, circa 1944.

title: Knicks Take Air Out of Jordan to Even Series
description: Mark Jackson ran the Knicks' offense last night with a purpose, and this time he included Kiki Vandeweghe and Patrick Ewing. And Charles Oakley rebounded the way he is expected to.

title: Levitt Leaving Amex To Pursue Publishing
description: Arthur Levitt Jr., who in 11 years as chairman presided over a revival of the American Stock Exchange, announced yesterday that he would resign to devote himself to running his communications company.

title: KEY RATES
After Debate, Schwarz Yields on Land-Use Plan
description: Two weeks ago, the chairman of the panel that is rewriting the New York City Charter proposed radically altering the way that public and private land is governed. On Wednesday, he proposed that such decisions be made much the way they are now, but by an appointive body instead of by elected officials.

title: Two Palestinians Slain In Clash With Troops
description: Army troops fatally shot two Palestinian teen-agers today, Arab reports said, and hundreds of Israelis screaming ''Death to the Arabs!'' stoned Arab-owned cars in a protest over the slaying of a soldier.

title: Police Say Bank Robber Ignored Lesson 1: Be Firm
description: Bringing new meaning to the adage ''crime doesn't pay,'' the police yesterday arrested a Brooklyn man in Manhattan and accused him of being ''probably the least successful bank robber we've ever had.''

title: Woody Herman Shaw, 44, Jazz Trumpeter, Dies
description: Woody Herman Shaw, a leading jazz trumpeter, died of a heart attack Tuesday at Bellevue Hospital. He was 44 years old.

title: Olga Meyer, 87, Dies; Organized Volunteers
description: Olga Melchior Meyer, the former chief coordinator of volunteers for the New York Metropolitan Committee for Unicef, died Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. She was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: In a Roguish Gallery: One Aging Black Ballerina
description: Eleanora Antinova, an aging American black ballerina who long ago danced in Diaghilev's Ballets Russes, is outrageous, egomaniacal, grande dame-ish and full of pain. She is also the alter ego of Eleanor Antin, a white performance artist, who made Eleanora up out of whole - well - tulle in the mid-1970's, and has been playing her ever since.

title: Subroto Sees Strong OPEC
description: The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will regain much of its former power to control oil prices during the 1990's, but it intends to keep prices stable, its Secretary General, Subroto, said today.

title: New Efforts Developing Against the Hate Crime
description: An old kind of crime is attracting a new kind of attention from Congress and from state legislatures, social agencies and a number of police officials around the country.

title:
THE LAW;
New Law Erects Barriers to the Federal Docket
description: LEAD: Beginning next Thursday, thousands of civil lawsuits will be barred from the Federal courts as a result of rule changes that were passed by Congress in November almost unnoticed by many practicing lawyers.

title: Hassler Whitney, Geometrician; He Eased 'Mathematics Anxiety'
description: Hassler Whitney, a mathematician who made important contributions in geometry and who was deeply involved in improving the teaching of mathematics, died Wednesday at Princeton Medical Center two weeks after suffering a stroke. He was 82 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: Review/Art; The Frick's West Gallery Is Given a New Old Look
description: One of the better-kept secrets of the season in New York City is the astonishing change that has come over the West Gallery in the Frick Collection. This was always one of the great rooms of the world. The room was very handsome, though no longer in its first freshness. The mix of painting, sculpture and furniture was just about perfect. The choice was everywhere apt and nowhere predictable. The three 17th-century Persian rugs that ran down the center of the room were marvels of their kind, The Italian Renaissance chests, the long table and the Savonarola chairs had an air of weighty assurance.

title: Restaurants
description: In three and a half years, Union Square Cafe has garnered a well-deserved national reputation as a paragon among a new breed of restaurants that might be called international bistros. Danny Meyer, the engaging young American owner, studied in Italy and France, but clearly his soul resides in Tuscany. Both his original chef and a recent replacement come from orthodox French backgrounds. Yet while the culinary compass here has fluttered back and forth over the years, the ship has never strayed off course.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: AUTO RACING Sullivan Has Surgery: Danny Sullivan, the 1985 Indianapolis 500 winner, suffered a mild concussion, a broken right forearm and a bruised right foot yesterday when his race car crashed hard against the third-turn wall in practice in Indianapolis. He underwent surgery late yesterday at Methodist Hospital, where he was reported to be in good condition and was being kept overnight.(AP) TENNIS Lendl and Becker Breeze: Ivan Lendl trounced Patrick Kuehnen of West Germany, 6-1, 6-1, and Boris Becker routed Martin Jaite of Argentina, 6-2, 6-2, as the top-seeded players moved easily into the quarterfinals of the German Open in Hamburg. The top-seeded Lendl needed only 56 minutes to beat Kuehnen, a member of West Germany's Davis Cup team. Becker was nearly as effective in sweeping past Jaite in 80 minutes.(AP) Gilbert Upset: Tim Wilkison captured the first nine games in stunning top-seeded Brad Gilbert, 6-0, 6-1, yesterday in the quarterfinals of the United States clay court championships in Isle of Palms, S.C. Wilkison, ranked 125th in the world, won the match when Gilbert was assessed his third code violation.(AP) DOG SHOW Britt Best of Boxers: Ch. Berena's Tribute to Fa-Fa, a 2-year-old brindle, yesterday was chosen best of breed at the 46th annual specialty of the American Boxer Club in the Holiday Inn North at Newark Airport. There were entries from 36 states, six Canadian provinces, Puerto Rico and Bermuda. Britt, as the dog is called, is a son of the late Ch. Wagner's Wilvirday Famous Amos, who triumphed in the national specialty for four years. CYCLING Vanderaerden Is Leader: Eric Vanderaerden of Belgium continued his surge toward the lead yesterday, claiming his third victory of the Tour de Trump race in the 97-mile sixth stage from Charlottesville to Richmond. He also won last night's nine-mile Richmond individual time trial in 18:47 and trails the overall leader, Dag Otto Lauritzen, of Norway, by one minute with three stages left. Vanderaerden, who rode conservatively through much of the rolling back roads course, followed several of his teammates on the final of two 3.5-mile laps in the financial district of the state capital before outsprinting the field for the victory in 3 hours 21 minutes 29 seconds. Michael Zanoli of the Netherlands finished second and Vyacheslav Ekimov of the Soviet Union was third.(AP)

title: Winning Colors Looks to Get Untracked
description: When was the last time Winning Colors won a race? Unlikely as it seems, she has not seen a winner's circle since last year's Kentucky Derby.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about oil-production shutdowns in the North Sea misstated the timing for a resumption of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation's operations at its Piper Alpha platform, which was severely damaged in a gas explosion last July. Occidental will submit its plans for restarting production on Piper Alpha to the British Government this summer, and, if the Government approves, the company said it hopes to resume operations by 1992. Production at two related fields, Claymore and Scapa, which were also damaged in the Piper Alpha explosion, are expected to resume in late May.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Gold Greenlees to Buy Agency in Minneapolis
description: Gold Greenlees Trott P.L.C. added a second American agency to its growing network yesterday, agreeing to buy Martin/Williams Advertising, based in Minneapolis, for up to $15.5 million. Martin/Williams joins Babbit & Reiman, an Atlanta agency, under the umbrella of Gold Greenlees, which is based in London and owns two British agencies.

title: Wherein Sour Cream Is Allowed to Deviate
description: A notice issued Wednesday by the Food and Drug Administration: ...In accordance with 21 CFR 130.17 concerning temporary permits to facilitate market testing of foods deviating from the requirements of the standards of identity promulgated under Section 401 of the Federal Food, Drug and Cosmetic Act (21 U.S.C. 341), F.D.A. is giving notice that a temporary permit has been issued to H. P. Hood Inc. ...

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Johnson Gets His Man
description: After an early morning altercation in Toronto yesterday involving Ben Johnson and five other men, Johnson pursued one of the men and apprehended him, the police said.

title: Reviews/Film; 'Fistfighter,' Barehanded Vengeance
description: George Rivero, the silver-haired star of ''Fistfighter,'' looks far too mature for the role of a man who can whip to a quivering pulp anything that stands in his way. As C. J. Thunderbird, a muscle-bound drifter who sets out to avenge the death of a boxer friend, he creams several fighting machines that are younger, meaner and hulkier than he is.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Photographers Snap for Fuji
description: For years, Kodak has rhapsodized about its film as a way to capture life's precious moments. In a new advertising campaign, Fuji Photo Film hits the same notes - but picks up the tempo a bit.

title: Officers Shoot Man Who Pulled a Gun
description: Police officers shot a man they were chasing after he had pulled a gun on them yesterday in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Leonard Kudisch, 77, Advertising Researcher
description: Leonard Kudisch, an advertising research executive, died Thursday at Beth Israel Hospital in Boston after a long illness. He was 77 years old and lived in Brookline, Mass.

title: Howard Corcoran, 83, Retired U.S. Judge
description: Howard F. Corcoran, a retired judge of the Federal District Court for the District of Columbia, died of complications of cancer Thursday at his home in Washington. He was 83 years old.

title:
Books of The Times;
How Returning Veterans Have Fared
description: LEAD: The Wages of War By Richard Severo and Lewis Milford Illustrated. 495 pages. Simon & Schuster. $21.95.

title: Review/Cabaret; Steve Ross in Rarer Songs of Noted Names
description: Steve Ross's program at L'Omnibus de Maxim's, Madison Avenue at 61st Street, where he will be singing at the piano Wednesdays through Saturdays until June 3, pays its respects to the well-established sources one might expect in such a setting - Cole Porter, the Gershwins, Noel Coward.

title: Awash in Copies, O'Neill's Aides Denounce Fax Attacks
description: A fierce lobbying campaign against a bill banning unsolicited facsimile advertising may have backfired when Gov. William A. O'Neill's fax machine was jammed for hours with unwanted messages.

title: Teledyne Aide Is Sentenced
description: A former lobbyist for Teledyne Electronics was sentenced today to six months in prison for his role in a scheme to pay bribes for inside information about a military contract.

title: MUSLIM STUDENTS MARCH IN BEIJING
description: In the first demonstration by a Chinese minority group since a wave of student protests began last month, about 2,500 Muslim students marched to the city's central square today to protest the publication of a book they say blasphemes Islam.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 4 about Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's veto of funds for a New York State wildlife pathology laboratory referred incorrectly to Ward Stone, the laboratory supervisor. He is not a doctor.

title: Okinawa Is an Island That Lost Its Culture
description: To the Editor:

title: Add Kiki To Knicks' Chemistry
description: In the weeks before the Knicks finally acquired Kiki Vandeweghe, every New York basketball lab technician wondered how the 30-year-old jump-shooter with the bad back would affect the ''chemistry'' of this young team. But as the Knicks awaited today's third game of their Eastern Conference semifinal with the Bulls in Chicago, their test tubes were bubbling over with a new potion. Nearly three months after his arrival, the real Kiki Vandeweghe had finally stood up and stood out.

title: R. Philip Custer, 85, Researcher on Cancer
description: R. Philip Custer, emeritus senior member of the Fox Chase Cancer Center, Philadelphia, whose career in cancer research spanned nearly six decades, died of congestive heart failure May 3 at his home in Narberth, Pa. He was 85 years old.

title: L.P.G.A. Lead Is Shared by 3
description: Laura Davies, Cindy Rarick and Marci Bozarth shared the lead today after the first round of the Chrysler-Plymouth Classic, the 13th Ladies' Professional Golf Association event this year.

title: Saturday News Quiz
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 48.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the People listing of the Advertising column in Business Day yesterday referred incorrectly in some editions to the magazine that has named George C. Fields Jr. as publisher. It is Decorating Remodeling.

title: Spare Parts Are Paying Off Big for Bucks
description: The Milwaukee basketball team is called the Bucks in the dictionary sense of a male animal; especially, a deer or antelope.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''A new relationship cannot simply be declared by Moscow, or bestowed by others. It must be earned because promises are never enough. The Soviet Union has promised a more cooperative relationship before, only to reverse course and return to militarism.'' - President Bush. [ 1:6. ]

title: Probable Successor to Botha Calls for Black Political Role
description: The man who is widely expected to be South Africa's next President today promised a restructuring of the Constitution to give the black majority a greater political role, but ruled out majority rule.

title: Charter Panel Has Quickly Produced a Consensus
description: Changing a government while the old one and the people who run it are still around is never easy. And nothing shows more surely how troublesome that process can be than the efforts of the New York City Charter Revision Commission.

title: U.N. Health Agency Defers P.L.O. Application to 1990
description: The World Health Organization today set aside a Palestinian application for admission as a member state. The application had been strongly opposed by Israel and the United States.

title: Midori, Now 17 and in the Mainstream
description: Midori, the remarkable Japanese violinist, is 17 years old now, and despite her diminutive stature has long since graduated to a full-size violin -a Guarnerius del Jesu, in fact, which not all 17-year-olds get to play. She and her mother and her management have been properly cautious about capitalizing on her fame as a prodigy. She has built her career steadily and systematically, concentrating on virtuoso and lyrical repertory, duo appearances with established stars and dates outside New York.

title: Mussolini in Balkans
description: To the Editor:

title: Texas Instruments In Taiwan Chip Deal
description: Texas Instruments Inc. said today that it had reached an agreement to produce computer memory chips at a new $250 million plant in Taiwan that it would build with Acer Inc., a broad-based electronics company that is also Taiwan's largest maker of computers and telecommunications equipment.

title: An Operatic Tale of a Strangelovian Cure for All Disease
description: London may have Andrew Lloyd Webber but - on a rather different scale of ambition and achievement - San Francisco has Paul Dresher. Both composers emerged from the shadow of better-known collaborators (Mr. Lloyd Webber from Tim Rice, Mr. Dresher from the San Francisco vanguard theater artist George Coates). They have both gone on to create veritable music-theater industries, working within a loose circle of constant collaborators.

title: Inventories Up, Sales Flat in March
description: Business inventories rose moderately in March and sales held steady, indicating a weaker economy, but economists said the trend was not worrisome yet.

title: CHEMICALS URGED FOR ALASKA SPILL
description: In a move likely to draw opposition from environmentalists, a top Coast Guard officer has told the Exxon Corporation to consider using powerful chemicals to break down the oil spill because other methods have proved ineffective.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the impact of drug addicts on hospitals in New York City misstated the period in which recorded cases of AIDS among intravenous drug abusers first outnumbered those among homosexual men. It was the first quarter of 1989, not 1988.

title: NBC Renews Its Tuesday Night Shows
description: Brandon Tartikoff, the president of the entertainment division of NBC, said yesterday that the network had renewed its entire Tuesday night lineup for the 1989-90 television season.

title: Patents; Patent Office Falls Behind Schedule
description: The Patent and Trademark Office, which has been publishing record numbers of patents in recent months, is now swamped by its own paperwork.

title: 8 States Plan Canada Office
description: Eight states bordering the Great Lakes plan to open a permanent office in Canada to take advantage of what they consider an improved climate for cross-border cooperation in tourism, economic development and the environment.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 11.

title: C. S. Harding Mott, 82, Head of Foundation
description: C. S. Harding Mott, who teamed with his father to develop and sustain what is now the nation's 12th largest charitable foundation, died Wednesday at a nursing home in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. He was 82 years old and had residences in Delray Beach, Fla., and Flint.

title: Letter: On the Mideast; To Counter P.L.O.'s Backdoor Strategy
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Securities Rise on Price Report
description: The Treasury securities market posted its strongest one-day gain yesterday since last September, sparked by a much smaller than expected rise in the Producer Price Index for April.

title: 16 Are Charged in Scheme To Launder Drug Millions
description: Sixteen people were charged yesterday with running a money-laundering operation that funneled $100 million a year from cocaine sales in New York to Colombia and Panama, Federal authorities said.

title: Counseling for Leach
description: Rick Leach, the Texas Rangers outfielder who disappeared in New York for 24 hours earlier this week and was issued a summons for marijuana possession, has been ordered to undergo drug counseling and testing, the baseball commissioner's office said yesterday.

title: For Elderly Policyholders, Confusion About 'Medigap'
description: Can elderly people have too much private health insurance? And do they pay too much for it? The answers are often yes, said witnesses at two Congressional hearings on policies that supplement the Government's Medicare coverage.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With Remote-Control Clutter
description: The first remote control in any household is a blessing and the second is a joy, but as these blessings mount, they clutter up your coffee table - and the one you want always seems to be under a newspaper or the cat.

title: CUNY Offered Deal On Tuition Increase
description: The Koch administration has told the City University of New York that it will propose a budget cut of only $1 million for the university's seven community colleges in the 1989-90 fiscal year.

title: A Star Once, Felled First By Drugs, Now Bullets
description: Four years ago Lloyd Daniels was hailed as the best high school basketball player to emerge from the streets of New York City in two decades. Sportswriters compared him to Connie Hawkins and Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and saw him as a future N.B.A. superstar.

title: Greek Court Backs Extraditing Palestinian to U.S.
description: The Greek Supreme Court today upheld an American request for the extradition of a Palestinian in connection with a 1982 bomb explosion aboard a Pan Am airliner.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the Exxon Corporation's decision to add an environmentalist to its board of directors misidentified Exxon's president. He is Lee R. Raymond. The article also misstated the composition of a proposed committee of Exxon directors to study environmental problems. It has not been determined how many members would be Exxon executives and how many outside directors.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Acmat Corp., East Hartford, Conn., purchased 3.45 million shares of United Coasts Corp. at $4 a share for a total of about $13.8 million.

title: Patents; A Speedier Transistor for Computers
description: Researchers at A.T.&T.'s Bell Laboratories this week received the first in what is expected to be a series of patents for a new generation of semiconductor devices known as ''hot electron transistors.''

title: Reviews/Dance; Ballet Theater Shifts Gears With Three Festive Works
description: American Ballet Theater offered its first mixed bill of the season on Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. The enchantments of ''Swan Lake,'' to which the company devoted the opening performances of its engagement, gave way to three festive ballets, including works by two of our century's greatest choreographers, Leonide Massine and George Balanchine.

title: Davis Suspension Lifted on NWA Bid
description: The Minnesota Commerce Commissioner, Michael Hatch, said he was lifting his suspension in Minnesota of the $90-a-share offer by Marvin Davis, the investor, for NWA Inc. Mr Hatch's decision comes one day after lawyers for Mr. Davis submitted additional financial information on his plans to run the airline if he gains control.

title: Dario Echandia, 91, Colombian Statesman
description: Former Vice President Dario Echandia Olaya, a senior statesman and Liberal Party leader who served four times as caretaker President, died on Sunday. He was 91 years old.

title: INSIDE
description: U.N. Unit Delays on P.L.O.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Lendl and Becker Gain: Ivan Lendl and Boris Becker, the top two seeded players, reached the semifinals of the German Open tournament yesterday in Hamburg, West Germany. Lendl beat Jonas Svensson of Sweden, 6-2, 6-2, and Becker advanced when his opponent, Paolo Cane of Italy, defaulted because of a strained hamstring. Lendl is ranked first in the $692,500 Nabisco Grand Prix clay court tournament, and Becker is No. 2. Svensson, ranked 21st in the world, upset Lendl in the quarterfinals of the French Open last year, but had little chance against him this time. (AP) Chang Withdraws: Sixth-seeded Jay Berger and unseeded Lawson Duncan advanced to the semifinals of the United States clay court championships yesterday after second-seeded Michael Chang withdrew because of a stomach virus. Chang, 17 years old, had a 103-degree fever, his coach, John Austin, said. It was the first time Chang had dropped out of a tournament since he turned pro in February 1988.(AP) Sabatini Gains: Top-seeded Gabriela Sabatini survived a first-set scare and overcame No. 6-ranked Sandra Cecchini of Italy, 7-5, 6-1, yesterday to advance to the semifinals of the Italian Open. Fourth-seeded Arantxa Sanchez of Spain and No. 14 Nathalie Tauziat of France also won quarterfinal matches in the $300,000 clay-court event at the Foro Italico. Sanchez beat unseeded Sabrina Goles of Yugoslavia, 6-0, 6-3, while Tauziat rallied from one set down to upset No. 7 Judith Wiesner of Austria, 1-6, 6-2, 6-2.(AP) GOLF Rodriguez Leads: Chi Chi Rodriguez fired a three-under par 67 yesterday to take a one-stroke lead after the opening round of the $400,000 Bell Atlantic-St. Christopher's Senior Classic in Malvern, Pa. Tommy Aaron, Mike Hill, Deray Simon and Orville Moody had 68's on the 6,710-yard, par 70 Chester Valley Golf Club course. (AP) CYCLING Phinney Wins Stage: Davis Phinney gained revenge and Greg LeMond ended more than a week of frustration as Americans finally won a race yesterday in the eighth stage of the Tour de Trump. Phinney had been edged in sprints four times by Eric Vanderaerden of Belgium in the last week. But he came out of the center of a large pack to claim the 67.2-mile Arlington (Va.) Circuit race by a half wheel-length in 2 hours 31 minutes 25 seconds. Michael Zanoli of the Netherlands finished second in the field sprint on the circular course near the Pentagon and Arlington National Cemetery. LeMond, recovering from the flu, placed third for his first top three finish in the 10-day race. Both were given the same time as Phinney. Phinney's teammate, Dag Otto Lauritzen of Norway, picked up five bonus seconds during a mid-race sprint on the 4.2-mile loop and increased his overall lead over Henk Lubberding of the Netherlands to 28 seconds. (AP)

title: Barr Accuses The F.D.A.
description: Federal Food and Drug Administration inspectors made an unusual visit to the Northvale, N.J., plant of Barr Laboratories Inc. 15 minutes after Barr had told a Congressional committee that the F.D.A. was improperly delaying its drug-marketing applications, the company said yesterday.

title: Surprise in the Andes
description: As democracy was being mugged in Panama, it was showing surprising resilience this week in Bolivia, a country once synonymous with instability. An orderly presidential vote produced no majority winner, so the final selection will again be made by the congress when it convenes in August. Strikingly, the front-runners are Gonzalo Sanchez de Lozada, the architect of a tough economic stabilization plan, and former President Hugo Banzer, who endorses it. Running third is the left-of-center Jaime Paz Zamora, who accepts the need for spending restraint, though he cavils at specific programs.

title: Hungary Moves to Abandon Dam Project on the Danube
description: A Government panel voted today to abandon a dam project on the Danube, calling it ''a symbol of Hungary's mismanaged economic development,'' the official press agency reported.

title: Pentathlete Reinstated
description: The Australian Olympic Federation has lifted a lifetime ban on the modern pentathlete Alex Watson, who was disqualified from the Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea, last year after failing a drug test.

title: Christopher Wright, 62; Analyzed Science
description: Christopher Wright, a physicist who studied science policies in relation to other aspects of contemporary life, died of lymphoma Tuesday at his home in Washington. He was 62 years old.

title: Third-Party Talks On Dunkin' Donuts
description: An investment group led by George S. Mann, the Canadian investor, said it was in talks with third parties interested in participating in a possible tender offer for Dunkin' Donuts Inc. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Mann did not identify the parties with whom he was talking.

title: Cardinal Meets Kin Of Attack Suspects
description: John Cardinal O'Connor met last night with relatives of two of the suspects in the rape and beating of a jogger in Central Park.

title: Andean Entertainment
description: A concert of traditional music and dance from the Andes is to take place at 8 o'clock tonight at Symphony Space, Broadway at 95th Street (864-5400). The music will be performed by Tahuantinsuyo on pipes, flutes, drums and stringed instruments; the group will be joined by 18 dancers. Tickets are $15 and $12; information, 206-1050.

title: Bush Chooses Head for F.T.C.
description: President Bush announced Thursday that he had selected Janet Dempsey Steiger, a longtime personal friend, to be chairman of the Federal Trade Commission.

title: Doctors Know Best?
description: LEAD: The editorial in the Journal of the American Medical Association put it this way: ''Libby Zion's death has changed residency training forever. The public is outraged that life-and-death decisions are made by residents working 36-hour shifts and 100-hour weeks . . . There is no turning back.'' That was three months ago, when there appeared to be no question that ''forever'' was safely berthed in New York.

title: Dow Up 56.82, to 2,439.70, a Post-Crash Peak
description: LEAD: A surprisingly bullish report on inflation helped the stock market break out of its recent doldrums with a stunning rally yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average soared 56.82 points, or 2.4 percent, to close at 2,439.70, its highest level since the October 1987 market crash.

title: Reviews/Music; Africa's Vast Variety, In Sights and Sounds
description: Pygmies from the rain forests of Zaire, their bodies dappled in paint, cross the stage in a loping crouch, singing in complex, staggered counterpoint. From Niger, two pipers with puffed cheeks (on the shawm-like alghaita) and two drummers, all in long robes, move in slow processional, playing starkly penetrating melodies. Peul acrobats from Guinea twist and bend and spin to the sputtering rhythms of drum and balafon (marimba); Pende dancers from Zaire, wearing austere masks, straw ruffles and stripes from head to toe, form a jubilant kind of chorus line.

title: Palestinian Is Slain in Gaza In Clash With Israeli Troops
description: Soldiers shot and killed a Palestinian today and wounded at least 10 others in clashes in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip, Arab reports said.

title: Bargaining on Bombs: Where the Arms Talks Stand
description: Strategic Weapons

title: Patents; A Method to Break Up Incinerator Toxins
description: A chemical engineer at the Westinghouse Electric Corporation has invented a plasma ''curtain'' to break up the hazardous byproducts in the smoke of municipal waste incinerators.

title: Worry on Government Recruiting Prompts Vote to Delay Ethics Law
description: Acting on a request by the Bush Administration, the Senate voted today to delay an ethics law that has prompted at least 36 high-level officials to resign from the Pentagon and the space agency.

title: A New Effort to Make Child's Play Less Deadly
description: Playground safety has taken on a new urgency this year.

title: McDonald Stock For ESOP Planned
description: The McDonald's Corporation said it intends to sell $100 million of a new issue of preferred stock, convertible into common shares, to its employee stock ownership plan. The preferred's dividend and conversion ratio will be determined at the time of the sale based on market conditions, the company said. Each share of preferred will have one vote.

title: Ito Bows Out as Takeshita Successor
description: In an embarrassing setback for Japan's political leaders, Masayoshi Ito today officially rejected the appeals of the governing Liberal Democratic Party to serve as Prime Minister, charging instead that party officials had blocked his proposals to end corruption.

title: Bridge
description: Congress went down to defeat in Washington Thursday, but it was an honorable defeat. Playing against some giants of the corporate world with much greater bridge experience, a group of Senators and Representatives lost by the narrow margin of 15 imps, 39 to 54.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 5 about President Bush's plans to nominate Gwendolyn S. King as head of the Social Security Administration misstated the number of Federal employees she would oversee. It is 65,000.

title: Delay in Filling Jobs
description: The slow pace of filling jobs in the Administration has brought complaints that nobody is in charge to solve a backlog of problems. Page 9.

title: For Solidarity, a Dab of Election Glitz
description: Clanking past Lodz's gracefully decaying Hotel Polonia, the gleaming trolley's flanks flashed red and white Solidarity slogans left and right.

title: Beirut Residents Seize Chance to Flee Shells
description: Beirut residents ventured out of their bomb shelters today as another cease-fire went into effect. But having seen six truces collapse since a new cycle of violence erupted in Lebanon two months ago, residents on both sides of the divided city capitalized on the respite from fighting to flee the city.

title: Marian Tyler Chase, Author, 92
description: Marian Tyler Chase, co-author of several books with her husband, the economist Stuart Chase, died of pneumonia May 4 at a nursing home in Danbury, Conn. She was 92 years old and lived in Redding, Conn.

title: BUSH VOICES HOPE ON SOVIET CHANGE, BUT WITH CAUTION
description: In a long-awaited speech on Soviet-American policy, President Bush said today that the United States was ready to welcome the Soviet Union ''back into the world order.'' But he cautioned that Moscow still had to earn the right to a new and warmer relationship with Western nations.

title: Gene Linked to Breast Cancer Is Found in Ovarian Tumors
description: A gene previously linked to breast cancer has also been found in ovarian tumors, researchers reported in a study published today.

title: Mom Says Every Day Is Mother's Day
description: LEAD: Every day is Mother's Day. Just ask my mother, Lola Wasserstein. However, should one decide to pay homage on the appointed time of recognition, Lola does offer a few key pointers. For instance, there's no need to give rubies or emeralds when something from the heart, a personal expression, would be so much more appreciated.

title: Four Guilty of Manslaughter In Death at Anti-Drug Center
description: Four members of a group intended to steer children away from drugs and crime were convicted of first-degree manslaughter today in the beating death of an 8-year-old girl.

title: Rutgers Protest On Tuition Rise Ends in Arrests
description: Hundreds of Rutgers University students protesting tuition increases occupied the office of the dean of students today in a demonstration that lasted several hours and led to the arrest of about 50 people.

title: Giants' Reuschel Beats Expos for His 200th Victory
description: Rick Reuschel won his 200th game and his 25th against the Expos tonight as the San Francisco Giants beat Montreal, 2-1.

title: Arnold P. Collery, Ex-Dean, 62; Led Columbia to Admit Women
description: Arnold P. Collery, an authority on international economics and former dean of Columbia College, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 62 years old.

title: Atlantis Group Seeks Rospatch
description: The Rospatch Corporation received an acquisition offer of $23.50 a share from Atlantis Group Inc., which already owns about 19 percent of the company''s stock. The Atlantis offer values the whole company, which has more than 2.5 million shares outstanding, at about $59 million. Its shares rose 50 cents today, to $21.75, in over-the-counter trading.

title: 2 Suitors for Europe; Bush and Gorbachev Try to Impress NATO Allies With Offerings of Peace
description: Moscow's plan to withdraw 500 nuclear weapons from Europe and President Bush's proposal for aerial surveillance flights throughout NATO and Soviet-bloc airspace marked an extraordinary week of public diplomacy intended to sway opinion in Western Europe.

title: Let's Not Praise Glasnost, Just Now
description: Is the West, in its eagerness to end the cold war, turning a blind eye to Soviet domestic policies that contradict Mikhail Gorbachev's engaging rhetoric of democratic renovation?

title: H.R.A. Chief Is Indignant On State Study
description: Angered by a scathing state review of his agency, New York City's welfare chief in effect challenged the state yesterday to take over the city's beleaguered social-service system.

title: Dotson Delivers as Yankees Beat Abbott
description: Richard Dotson continued his sudden rise from mop-up reliever to Yankee savior tonight when he pitched seven innings and earned his first victory of the season in a 5-2 decision over the California Angels at Anaheim Stadium.

title: Cynthia M. Welles
description: Cynthia M. Welles, the wife of Benjamin Welles, a former foreign correspondent for The New York Times, died on May 3 after a stroke at her home in Washington. She was 72 years old.

title: Your Money; The Family's Role In Writing a Will
description: As Surrogate of New York County, Renee R. Roth all too often sees ''families rent asunder'' when wills are challenged in court. ''The best way to avoid a probate contest is to sit down with members of your family and discuss what you intend to do'' before a will is drawn up, she said this week in a speech entitled ''Preserving the Family Through Financial Planning.''

title: Nathan Messner, 80; Led Millinery Union
description: Nathan Messner, a former president of the United Hatters, Cap and Millinery Workers, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Beekman-Downtown Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Reviews/Dance; 'A Fool for You' and 2 by Balanchine
description: The television crews taping the New York City Ballet's performance of ''A Fool for You'' on Thursday night for ''Live From Lincoln Center'' arrived at the New York State Theater after George Balanchine's ''Episodes.'' They left before Balanchine's ''Cortege Hongrois,'' taking some of the audience with them. That was a pity, for some of the best dancing of the evening took place in the opening and closing ballets.

title: Jackson Gets Passing Grade From Pitino but Not From Fans
description: One field goal, more than any of their other 46, symbolized the Knicks' 114-97 victory over the Chicago Bulls that tied their Eastern Conference semifinal playoff series at one game each Thursday night at Madison Square Garden.

title: David Glaser, Principal, 64
description: David Glaser, a former principal of the Elisabeth Irwin High School in Manhattan, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in Hyde Park, N.Y. He was 64 years old.

title: LTV Wins Round in Pension Fight
description: The Government agency that insures pensions for millions of retired workers cannot force the LTV Corporation to reinstate three steelworker pension plans that the company said it was unable to finance, a Federal appeals court in Manhattan ruled today.

title: SUITS ARE SETTLED IN SAN JUAN FIRE
description: A Federal judge today accepted a plan to pay up to $100 million to settle hundreds of lawsuits stemming from the December 1986 fire at the Dupont Plaza Hotel that killed 97 people.

title: Parade Tomorrow
description: The Cuban Day parade starts at noon at 44th Street and the Avenue of Americas, moving north to Central Park South, then west to Columbus Circle.

title: 80% of Senior Positions Under Bush Still Empty
description: Sixteen weeks after President Bush took office, 80 percent of the senior positions in Government departments and agencies have not been filled.

title: About New York; A 'Mother' Waits With Open Arms At Ports of Call
description: The big man at the top of the gangplank wore lots of tattoos and a leer. ''Hiya, sister,'' he said. ''Welcome to the love boat.''

title: Train Kills 2 Youths After Car Breakdown
description: Two Massachusetts teen-agers who had earlier told a state trooper they were on foot because their car had broken down were struck and killed by a passenger train Thursday night.

title: Rally of Thousands Reported in Capital Of Soviet Armenia
description: Hundreds of thousands of people gathered in the capital of the Armenian Republic on Thursday to renew their demands in a territorial dispute, an Armenian journalist said today.

title: Study Looks at Reasons for Hospital Closings
description: A Government study issued today found that 69 general hospitals with 4,233 beds closed in 1987, for reasons that included shortages of doctors and patients.

title: CHANGES ARE URGED IN JOB TRAINING ACT
description: The Bush Administration has proposed rewriting a major job training program that Vice President Dan Quayle helped to draft when he was a Senator. The proposed revisions would direct most spending under the program to teen-agers and the poor.

title: Record $4 Billion Bond Issue Marketed for RJR Holdings
description: Aided by a rallying bond market, bankers for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. and Merrill Lynch & Company yesterday completed the largest-ever underwriting of corporate debt, an estimated $4 billion of securities of the RJR Holdings Capital Corporation.

title: Kenneth Duchac, 66; Led Brooklyn Library
description: Kenneth Farnham Duchac, director emeritus of the Brooklyn Public Library, died of liver cancer Tuesday at the Bon Secours Extended Care Facility Hospice in Ellicott City, Md. He was 66 years old and lived in Ellicott City and Sarasota, Fla.

title: Esteban de Jesus Is Dead at 37; Former Lightweight Champion
description: Esteban de Jesus, the World Boxing Council lightweight champion from 1976 through 1978, died of AIDS yesterday at his home in San Juan, P.R. He was 37 years old.

title: Douglas F. Young, 77, An Ex-New York Judge
description: Douglas F. Young, retired justice of the State Supreme Court, died of complications from Parkinson's disease Thursday at St. Francis Hospital, Flower Hill, L.I. He was 77 years old and lived in Sands Point, L.I.

title: Soviets Seeking U.S. Soybean Oil
description: Increasingly eager to improve its food supply, the Soviet Union is seeking to buy at least 200,000 tons of soybean oil from the United States at subsidized prices that could cost American taxpayers about $30 million, people in the Administration, Congressional offices and the agriculture industry confirmed Thursday.

title: California Man Found Guilty in Killings of 16
description: Randy Kraft, a computer programmer accused of leading a double life as a brutalizer and killer of 37 young men in three states, was convicted of 16 murders today.

title: Pistons Take 2-0 Lead in Series
description: The Detroit Pistons needed a spark tonight and John Salley came off the bench to provide it.

title: U.S. Appeals Court Upholds Drug Tests for Boston Police
description: After three years of legal battles, a Federal appeals court ruled today that the Boston Police Department could conduct random drug testing of its officers.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Settlement Reached in Perry Wrongful-Death Suit
description: New York City has agreed to pay $75,000 to settle a $145 million wrongful-death suit filed by the mother of 17-year-old Edmund E. Perry, the prep school graduate who was shot to death by an undercover police officer in Harlem nearly four years ago.

title: WPP Said To Be Near Ogilvy Deal
description: The WPP Group appears close to an agreement to buy the Ogilvy Group in a deal that would create the second-largest advertising and marketing company in the world.

title: Still No Good Deed Goes Unpunished
description: To the Editor:

title: The Wrong Road to Auto Insurance
description: The California Supreme Court's recent decision on Proposition 103 contains a lesson for the nation: On the subject of automobile insurance, there's no free ride. Instead of seeking relief from high rates in plebiscites, consumers would do better to demand measured, rational legislative remedies, beginning with genuine no-fault insurance.

title: New York City's Land-Use Puzzle
description: Few matters incite the passions of New Yorkers like questions about the uses of land. How towering an office tower? Where to build a jail?

title: Guidepost; Things That Lock
description: This is the time to repair winter's wear and tear on locks, other door and window hardware and window sashes. Simple lubrication is almost always the remedy. Lightweight household oil is the standby. But newer products that contain silicone or Teflon do not stain as oil sometimes does, and won't harm paint or woodwork. Oil, including special lock oil, and the new sprays are available at hardware stores. An alternative for sliding wooden parts is to rub them with a candle or a piece of paraffin. $ Problem Lubricant Application Locks Lock oil with graphite; Spray on key and silicone or Teflon spray keyhole, insert key and operate lock several times Hinges; door and Light household oil; Use sparingly window latches silicone or Teflon on hinge pins or moving fluid or spray parts, work parts back and forth Sliding wood or Silicone or Teflon spray Spray thin layer on metal window sashes sliding surfaces, allow to dry Rusty casement Penetrating oil plus Saturate tracks; windows silicone or Teflon spray scrape rust away, then use spray Garage doors Silicone or Teflon spray Apply light coat to track and rollers

title: Hills Says Trade Pressure Pays Off
description: Despite complaints about bullying and threats of retaliation, the United States has reaped positive results from the pressure it put on its trading partners, the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said today.

title: The Vast Promise of a Laser Chip
description: A new electronic device holds promise for the creation of computers that will operate using internal laser beams rather than the conventional currents of electricity. The device enables a hundred tiny lasers to be packed onto a computer chip.

title: Ho Chi Minh City Journal; Saigon Holdover Sees His Stock Rise
description: Even to Nguyen Xuan Oanh himself, hardly a modest man, it all seems just a bit improbable.

title: PRODUCER PRICES POST MODEST RISE FOR SECOND MONTH
description: Sending a surprisingly encouraging signal on inflation, prices at the producer level rose a moderate four-tenths of 1 percent in April, the Labor Department reported today.

title: U.S. Steps Up Its Anti-Noriega Drive
description: President Bush's national security adviser, Brent Scowcroft, said today that the United States had begun consulting foreign governments to see whether any would accept Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama if he could be persuaded to give up power.

title: Motormen on PATH Approve a Contract, Avoiding a Walkout
description: With little more than 48 hours remaining before a threatened strike, motormen who drive the PATH trains between New York and New Jersey voted last night in favor of a new contract that gives them a $10,000 total pay increase over a five-year period, retroactive to 1985.

title: CATHOLIC CHURCH IN PANAMA ASSAILS NORIEGA'S REGIME
description: Panama's Roman Catholic Church today released a blistering attack on the regime of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, questioning his moral authority to govern and inviting the military to disobey repressive orders.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MAY 13, 1989
description: Economy

title: Joseph Boatner, Singer, 70
description: Joseph Boatner, a later member of the Ink Spots singing quartet, died on Monday at Lakes Region General Hospital in Laconia, N.H. He was 70 years old.

title: A Burst of Buying Opens the Chicago Art Fair
description: Now celebrating its 10th anniversary, the Chicago International Art Exposition is, by exhibitor and visitor consensus, one of the best and biggest art fairs in the world. Thanks to good management, a spectacular site on Navy Pier - a 1916 landmark that thrusts three-quarters of a mile into Lake Michigan - and the solid support of Chicago's art community, the fair draws dealers from all over the world. This year more than 200 exhibitors from 19 countries and the United States are showing, and the number of visitors is projected at 45,000.

title: 3 Killed in Bronx, but Infant Is Unharmed
description: Two men and a woman were found shot to death in a Bronx apartment yesterday afternoon, but the woman's 4-month-old daughter was found unharmed in her crib, the police said.

title: Not Only Rich Victims Deserve AIDS Drugs
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: A news analysis article on Thursday about President Bush's effort to win foreign support for the ouster of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama misstated Senator Bob Graham's attitude toward the Panama Canal treaties. Mr. Graham, Democrat of Florida, says it is premature to talk of canceling the treaties.

title: Black Wins $40,000 Under Stiff Housing Law
description: In a reflection of newly strengthened provisions of the Fair Housing Act, a Florida mobile home community has agreed to pay a black New Jersey woman $40,000 for discrimination.

title: Ethics Panel Seeks Bank Records Of Loan to Wright for Investment
description: The House ethics committee has requested the bank records of a $100,000 loan that House Speaker Jim Wright received in 1983 to finance his investment in a nursing home business, a bank official said today.

title: News Summary
description: International 3-7 President Bush's Soviet policy was outlined in a long-awaited speech. He cautioned that Moscow still had to earn warmer ties with the West and resurrected a proposal for East-West aerial surveillance. Page 1 Moscow's latest nuclear arms cut was welcomed by the Western allies, but diplomats said the move only aggravates the divisions within NATO over negotiations on curbing short-range missiles. 1 News analysis: Moscow's plan to withdraw 500 nuclear weapons and President Bush's proposal for aerial surveillance marked a week of diplomacy intended to sway Western European opinion. 7 Panama's Roman Catholic Church issued a blistering attack on the Government of General Noriega, questioning its moral authority to govern and inviting the military to disobey repressive orders. 1 Washington steps up its drive against Noriega 5 Survey finds support for Panama Canal treaties 5 A world treaty on global warming is supported by President Bush, who wants to begin negotiations on a ''framework'' for a treaty on global warming but is not ready to endorse specifics, the E.P.A. said. 9 A diplomatic nominee was opposed as he tried to convince Democratic senators that neither he nor George Bush knew about the Reagan Administration's secret effort to arm the contras until late 1986. 5 Eighty percent of top posts under Bush still unfilled 9 An embarrassing setback in Japan occurred when Masayoshi Ito rejected appeals of the Liberal Democratic Party to serve as Prime Minister, saying it blocked his anti-corruption proposals. 3 Muslims march in Beijing 3 A Palestinian move to join the W.H.O. as a member state was set aside. The application to join the World Health Organization had been opposed by Israel and the United States. 3 Greek court backs extraditing Palestinian to the U.S. 4 Solidarity is learning to campaign for approaching elections, attracting political workers and media advisers from across the country to a race that essentially pits the union against the Communist Party. 4 Probable successor to Botha calls for black political role 7 Canada screens fuel imports 4 National 8-9, 26, 48 Producer prices rose moderately in April, by four-tenths of 1 percent, the Government said. It was the second straight moderate increase, following two months of soaring prices at the beginning of the year. 1 Reacting to the inflation report, the Dow Jones industrial average soared 56.82 points, and the Treasury securities market had its biggest one-day gain since September. 33, 36 Airline reservations were disrupted when the nation's largest reservation system shut down for almost 12 hours, leaving travel agencies and a large part of American Airlines without flight information. 1 Delay in the start of a new ethics law, which erects new barriers to employment for Government officials, was approved by the Senate. The law has prompted the resignaitons of at least 36 high-level officials. 1 Speaker Wright's $100,000 loan to finance his investment in a nursing home business has received the attention of the House ethics committee. A Texas bank said the panel has requested records from it. 8 Under new anti-discrimination laws in the Fair Housing Act, a Federal district court awarded a black woman from New Jersey a $40,000 consent judgment against a Florida mobile home company. 1 Sixty-nine general hospitals closed in 1987, eliminating 4,233 beds, while 13 new hospitals opened, a Government study has found. Reasons for the closings include shortages of doctors and patients. 26 Gene linked to breast cancer is found in ovarian tumors 8 Powerful chemicals for the oil spill off Valdez, Alaska, have been suggested by a top Coast Guard officer because other methods have proved ineffective. The suggestion is likely to be opposed by environmentalists. 8 A California freight train derailed in San Bernardino, demolishing a row of houses, killing one crew member and two children and shaking the area like an earthquake, officials and residents said. 8 WPP Group appears close to a deal to buy the Ogilvy Group, creating the world's second-largest advertising and marketing company. 33 63% of semifinalists for scholarship are men, a study finds 9 Changes urged in job training 9 Regional 27-30 Richard Green's memorial service at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine included 5,000 New Yorkers, from schoolchildren to leaders of the city and state. 27 Ambulance response to Green's attack is disputed 30 A would-be great in basketball, Lloyd Daniels lay in critical condition after being shot three times in a dispute over drugs. He never overcame the pitfalls that snare many less-gifted youths. 27 16 are charged in $100-million-a-year money-laundering 29 New York has agreed to settle suit by family of slain youth 29 New York City's welfare chief challenged New York State to take over the city's beleaguered social-service system after the state released a scathing review of the agency. 27 News analysis: Charter revision in New York City faces a vote this November, and while some say change is coming too fast, others say postponement may mean surrendering power to the courts or special elections. 29 Judge says Bronx Senate seat is vacant but fight goes on 29 Delaware panel lifts drought warning 29 Housing for elderly homeless people provides 19 men and women in Port Jervis, N.Y., with private bedrooms for $229 a month. In the experimental program, the tenants share a kitchen, living room and bathroom. 27 Rutgers protest on tuition rise ends in arrests 28 PATH motormen approve contract 29 Awash in copies, O'Neill's aides denounce fax attacks 28

title: Review/Music; A Professor Takes the Stage
description: Raymond Jackson, a pianist and a professor at Howard University, wrote his doctoral dissertation at Juilliard on piano music by black American composers. He lectures frequently on the topic around the country and he is currently editing an anthology of black contributions to keyboard literature.

title: Survey Finds Support for Dispatch of Troops
description: In a week of increasing conflict in Panama, Americans grew much more supportive of the use of United States troops to restore order if necessary, a New York Times/CBS News Poll shows. But a clear majority said the treaties giving up the Panama Canal should not be breached.

title: Montedison S.p.A.
description: The Italian Cabinet approved a measure effectively giving the chemical giant Montedison S.p.A. a significant tax break on the planned merger of its chemical business with state companies in the sector. The decree would cut the capital gains tax liability of Italian companies involved in strategic mergers or joint ventures by 75 percent to encourage such alliances in the national economic interest. The venture, agreed upon nearly a year ago, is scheduled to be fully operational by the end of next month.

title: Dollar Ends Up Despite Intervention
description: The dollar swung wildly yesterday in hectic trading, falling sharply amid aggressive dollar-selling by central banks before rebounding to new highs for the year against the yen and the West German mark.

title: Untapped Revenue Under New York City's Nose
description: To the Editor:

title: E.P.A. Chief Says Bush Will Not Rush Into a Treaty on Global Warming
description: President Bush is committed to beginning negotiations on a ''framework'' for a treaty on global warming but is not ready to endorse specific elements, the Administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency said today.

title: Kremlin Move On Arms Adds To NATO Split
description: Western allies today welcomed Moscow's latest nuclear arms cut, but diplomats said the Soviet move had only aggravated the divisions in the NATO alliance over talks on reducing short-range nuclear weapons.

title: A Big Lead Even Zoeller Couldn't Predict
description: As unpredictable as the recent weather in Ohio, Fuzzy Zoeller left everyone gaping in disbelief today as he not only maintained his lead in the 14th annual Memorial Tournament, but also increased it from one stroke to five. He did so with an amazing nine-birdie second round of six-under-par 66 in a cold, miserable rain.

title: Flowers That Fit
description: Tomorrow being the 75th anniversary of Mother's Day, the subject is flowers. While the holiday has yet to become the biggest flower-giving occasion - that honor goes to Christmas - it ranks No. 2, nipping Valentine's Day in the bud. Mother's Day accounts for 13 percent of all flowers sold during the year.

title: Judge Says Bronx Senate Seat Is Vacant, but Fight Goes On
description: A judge declared today that the State Senate seat of Israel Ruiz Jr. is legally vacant, but several state officials said the lengthy skirmish over whether the Bronx Democrat is still a Senator is not over.

title: The Father Yearners
description: I am not surprised that half the world's scientists have dropped everything and rushed out to disprove, denounce and jeer at the fellows who claim they produced fusion in a jar.

title: Pirates Lose Gott
description: The Pittsburgh Pirates lost the reliever Jim Gott for the season yesterday because of a damaged ligament in the pitcher's right elbow.

title: Dispute Erupts on Response To Ambulance Call for Green
description: A dispute has emerged between the New York City ambulance service and Lenox Hill Hospital over a delayed response to the 911 emergency call during the asthma attack that killed Schools Chancellor Richard R. Green early Wednesday.

title: KEY RATES
Japonica Plans Tender for CNW
description: Japonica Partners said yesterday that it would begin shortly a tender offer for CNW, the owner of the Chicago and Northwestern Transportation Company. The offer would have a total value of more than $800. Japonica, which holds an 8.8 percent stake in CNW, has been seeking a friendly acquisition of CNW but has been rebuffed by the board, a company spokesman said. He said Japonica, through the tender offer, would seek to raise its holding to 90 percent of CNW's 16.4 million common shares and 90 percent of its three million preferred shares.

title: Transcript of Bush's Remarks on Transforming Soviet-American Relations
description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's remarks on Soviet-American relations today at Texas A & M University, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of Cable News Network. Because of a slip in Mr. Bush's delivery, one sentence, indicated by italics, is taken from his prepared text.

title: Jefferson and the West
description: To the Editor:

title: Patents; A Flying Saucer
description: Most people doubt the existence of flying saucers, but not Kyusik Kim, an engineer in Santa Barbara, Calif. He has designed one himself, and said it would be many times as fast as winged aircraft if it were ever built. ''Conventional aircraft have long wing spans, which create a lot of drag,'' Mr. Kim said. His patent, entitled ''induction lift flying saucer,'' envisions an aircraft that uses gasoline-powered jets to get started. Once the saucer is moving several times as fast as the speed of sound, it would recycle the heat created by air friction to power a steam generator that would yield additional thrust.

title: Savings Bond Sales Fall
description: Sales of United States savings bonds fell 11.1 percent, to $634 million, in April, the Government said Thursday. The Treasury Department said sales in April were down by $79 million from March, when sales had risen 3.2 percent. The drop, however, was only the second in the first seven months of the Government's fiscal year, which began Oct. 1. On May 1, the Government increased the rate on the bonds to 7.81 percent, from 7.35 percent, which had been offered in the previous six months.

title: Robert O. Geiger, Copywriter, 62
description: Robert O. Geiger, a copywriter and editor at Lord & Taylor for 15 years, died of cancer yesterday at New York Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Computer Chaos for Air Travelers
description: The nation's largest airline computer reservation system, the American Airlines Sabre system, shut down for almost 12 hours yesterday, disrupting the operations of about 14,000 travel agencies nationwide.

title: Padres Win in 12th; Carter on Disabled List
description: For openers, Gary Carter came to work with a swollen right knee and a .114 batting average, and was placed on the disabled list. After that, the evening rapidly deteriorated for the Mets, just when they came soaring home to face the West with a clear shot at first place in the East.

title: Russians Get Visa Cards
description: The Soviet Union's largest bank began issuing Visa cards to replace the passbook savings account, Visa International reported today.

title: 5,000 Pay Respects to a Chancellor Who Offered Hope
description: Before an altar ablaze with white candles, thousands of New Yorkers - from schoolchildren to leaders of the city and state -filled the Cathedral of St. John the Divine yesterday to commemorate Dr. Richard R. Green as a man of hope and inspiration.

title: Maryland Coach Quits Amid Controversy
description: Bob Wade, whose program has been under investigation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association for nearly three months, has resigned as basketball coach at the University of Maryland, the school's president, William E. Kirwan, announced yesterday.

title: Water Agency Ends Restriction For Reservoirs
description: The Delaware River Basin Commission ended its drought warning yesterday, making additional water available to New York City, as city officials considered lifting some emergency measures imposed before the drenching rains of recent weeks.

title: Keith Whitley Is Dead; Country Singer Was 33
description: Whitley, a rising star of country music, was found dead in bed at his suburban home Tuesday. He was 33 years old.

title: Emanuel Posnack, 92, Lawyer and Inventor
description: Emanuel R. Posnack, a patent lawyer, inventor and author, died of congestive heart failure last Saturday at his home in Great Neck. L.I. He was 92 years old.

title: Mingus Dynasty
description: Mingus Dynasty will play the music of Charles Mingus tonight and tomorrow at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South, at Perry Street (255-4037). Sets begin at 10 and 11:30 P.M. and 1 A.M.; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: For the Elderly Homeless, an Experiment in Dormitory Life
description: For years, Dorothy Miller lived in her sister-in-law's apartment. James Wood had a bed in a shelter for homeless men. Amelia Ryan shared a room in her granddaughter's house. None of them could afford anything else.

title: Disney Stock Soars
description: The stock of the Walt Disney Company gained sharply today for the second consecutive day, propelled by strong attendance at its new movie theme park and overall enthusiasm for the company's prospects, analysts said. Disney rose $5 a share today, to $92.125, after climbing $1.25 on Thursday. The movie park, which opened on May 1 as part of the Disney World complex in Orlando, Fla., is expected to increase total attendance at Disney's Orlando site by about 20 percent, said Christopher Dixon, an analyst for Kidder, Peabody.

title: Nat Adderley Sextet
description: Nat Adderley, a trumpeter, is leading a sextet that includes Sonny Fortune and Vincent Herring on saxophones, tonight and tomorrow at Sweet Basil, 88 Seventh Avenue South, above Bleecker Street (242-1785). Sets are at 10 and 11:45 P.M. and 1:30 A.M; there is a $12 cover and a $6 minimum.

title: Review/Theater; Shakespearean Comedy With an American Tone
description: The forest of Arden is transporting, magically turning the urbanized into the countrified and uniting lovers of contrasting guises. ''As You Like It'' is a blithe pastoral comedy that draws its strength primarily from the character of Rosalind, that most attractive and witty of Shakespearean heroines.

title: Bush Nominee Is Quizzed Over Illicit Contra Aid
description: A former senior aide to George Bush ran into fierce opposition today as he tried to convince Democratic senators that neither he nor Mr. Bush knew about the Reagan Administration's clandestine program to arm the Nicaraguan contras until late 1986.

title: Runaway Freight Train Derails, Killing 3
description: A speeding freight train hauling 69 carloads of potash derailed this morning in San Bernardino, demolishing a row of houses, killing a trainman and two children and shaking the area like an earthquake, officials and residents said. At least one person is missing.

title: Canada Screens Fuel Imports
description: Canada announced today that it was sharply reducing entry points for fuel tankers coming from the United States and establishing a special police task force to investigate a growing scare over tainted fuel from the United States.

title: Review/Music; Ravi Shankar, With Sitar,Runs the Gamut of Emotions
description: A great sitarist, like any other classical virtuoso, must have a command of extremes, from infinitesimal subtleties of pitch and timbre to crowd-pleasing displays of speed. Unlike Western classical musicians, a sitarist reveals his prowess in music that is likely to be almost entirely improvised.

title: What Barbados May Have Taught Washington
description: To the Editor:

title: POSTINGS: Hartford Brouhaha; Preservation
description: A proposal by the Society for Savings to develop a city block in Hartford across the street from the old Connecticut State House has triggered a series of legal squabbles involving city, state and Federal agencies. The Society for Savings, a major bank, wants to erect a 45-story office tower, which would be the tallest in the city, at 855 Main Street. The 700-foot-high building would cost $300 million and produce over a million square feet of commercial space. The original target for completion was 1992.

title:
Westchester Q&A;: Anthony J. Colavita;
Turning His Attention to the County
description: LEAD: FOR three-and-a-half years, Anthony J. Colavita has been wearing two political hats, as chairman of the Westchester County Republican Committee and chairman of the New York State Republican Committee. Last month, Mr. Colavita, an Eastchester lawyer and former Town Supervisor, announced he would leave the state post when his term expired in

title: Man or Beast, They Are Made For Music
description: Musical sculpture - slit gongs, horns, harps and drums in the shape of oxen, buffalo, horses, long-beaked birds or armless men - are silhouetted against the walls of the great hall at the Smithsonian's National Museum of African Art. These figural instruments include several that are monumental in scale and many more that convey movement or the music they were devised to bring alive.

title: In Housing Slump, Builders Focus on Affluent Elderly
description: A SLUGGISH housing market has brought most types of construction to a halt, but one conspicious exception is that intended for the affluent elderly.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Lehigh; Kegs Are Plugged As Law Restricts Campus Drinking
description: Lehigh University, known in some quarters as much for its legendary beer parties as its academic rigor, is among the Pennsylvania institutions that have begun to feel the effect of year-old state legislation to end drinking by people younger than 21.

title: Soccer Fans Break Calm
description: Fan violence during and after an English soccer game yesterday resulted in 25 arrests and the hospitalization of 16 people for minor injuries, shattering a month of calm after the Sheffield stadium tragedy.

title:
CONNECTCUT Q & A: LOIS HAGER;
'We Should Always Have a High Goal'
description: LEAD: IN less than two years, Connecticut will join a handful of Northeastern cities and states that recycle a large portion of their trash. The State Department of Environmental Protection has been laying the groundwork for recycling since 1986, when the General Assembly established a $10 million fund to implement the program.

title: SOCIAL EVENTS
description: Gift of Reading

title: Banker's Lady Wins Shuvee
description: Banker's Lady proved herself the new queen of American racing by running Winning Colors into defeat and then pulling clear to a 2 1/4-length victory over Rose's Cantina in the $174,300 Shuvee Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Not Quite
description: To the Editor:

title: Summer Music Center 'Back Home'
description: LEAD: ALEXANDER STONEHILL, founder of the Westchester Summer Music Center, remembers the days when the County Center was filled to the rafters with the music center's students: ''We had lessons on the steps, the balcony, wherever they could find a corner,'' he said.

title: THE UNDERVIEW
description: BOOMERANG By Barry Hannah. 150 pp. Boston: Seymour Lawrence/ Houghton Mifflin. $15.95.

title: IS JAPAN'S DEMOCRACY A SHAM?
description: THE ENIGMA OF JAPANESE POWER People and Politics in a Stateless Nation. By Karel van Wolferen. 496 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $24.95.

title: UP AGAINST THE FLAMES
description: FIRE ON THE RIM A Firefighter's Season at the Grand Canyon. By Stephen J. Pyne. 323 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $19.95.

title: THE GREAT OUTDOORS
description: Two friends of mine bought a tract of land on the New York-Vermont border with plans to build their dream house on the crest of a hill. Since then, on warm summer weekends they have left their urban lives behind and claimed their land - working, cooking al fresco and sleeping in an accommodating tent. In the process, they have raised outdoor cooking to an art.

title: Rally for Slain Korea Student
description: Riot policemen with sticks and shields clashed with thousands of marchers who gathered today to protest the death of a student, Lee Chul Kyu, whose body was found on Wednesday in a reservoir near Kwangju. Some of the 4,000 troops were beaten by protesters armed with bamboo sticks. The protesters said Mr. Lee was tortured to death by the police. The police denied involvement. The Government is conducting an investigation.

title: On Nature's Gentle Cusp, a Baby's First Spring
description: AT the corner of Harbor Road and Harbor Hill Road is a lonely, two-acre saltwater marsh surrounded by low, dark hills. The head of a harbor narrows to a swampy point across the road, and a couple of 100-year-old farmhouses are not-too-distant neighbors.

title: Johnson's World: Running in Place
description: Several days a week, a familiar form goes through the motions of training at the Metropolitan Toronto Track and Field Centre, a large, modern brick building on the campus of York University. It was here, for so many days leading to the Seoul Olympics, that Ben Johnson honed the skills that took him through the 100-meter final in 9.79 seconds, the fastest time ever run over that distance.

title: Musical Captures Composer's Heritage
description: WHEN Ginny Bales was a college student visiting her hometown in Kingsport, Tenn., she went to church with the women in her family - her mother, two grandmothers, and assorted aunts and cousins - who were all joining voices in a hymn.

title: Question Of the Week; Should the Yanks Have Traded Leiter?
