description: Syd Thrift just made the biggest mistake of his baseball career. I am not denying the team's need for offense, but is a .200 hitter the miracle cure? Thrift shot a hole through the Yankees' togetherness. They lost youth, enthusiasm and unparalleled potential. KARA YORIO Kinnelon, N.J.

title: Mission Decor in a Carolina Inn
description: WE were on an unsteady course toward the lounge. A friend and I had stopped for a drink at the Grove Park Inn in Asheville, N.C., and as we walked down a long, wide corridor, I was drawn left and then right, again and again. I wove this way toward a big hulk of an oak sideboard or that way toward a severe-looking couch with wooden slats at its sides and back. I was fascinated by this simple furniture, all straight lines and right angles. Though obviously old, it looked somehow modern.

title:
GARDENING;
Bleeding Hearts and Other Discentras
description: LEAD: THE common bleeding heart is one of those old-fashioned perennials that would have been found in most any flower garden at the turn of the century. A tall plant, reaching two and a half feet, it was just as apt to be planted along the backyard fence as in a flower bed.

title: Riverfront Plans
description: To the Editor:

title: Manila Uncovers Mass Grave
description: The Philippine military said today it had uncovered a grave with the bodies of at least 13 Communist rebels killed as spies by their comrades. An army statement said soldiers dug up the grave on Friday in the mountains south of Manila after a former rebel confessed that his companions had killed guerrillas suspected of being agents of the military. The former rebel, Severino Ranoda, who surrendered in January, led troops and reporters to the grave in the jungle of Laguna province, 37 miles south of Manila.

title: Review/Theater; Teen-Agers, A Car Crash And Guilt
description: Of all the perils of modern life, none casts the net of destruction further than drug and alcohol abuse. Phil Bosakowski examines one tragedy of such abuse in his short, taut play ''Crossin' the Line,'' which is being presented at the Lamb's Little Theater.

title: Brigham Young Selects Leader
description: Rex E. Lee, who served as Solicitor General in the Reagan Administration, was named Friday as the 10th president of Brigham Young University, the nation's largest private university. Mr. Lee, 54 years old, is to assume the presidency July 1. He succeeds Jeffrey R. Holland, who was appointed on April 1 to a leadership position in the Mormon Church, which owns the university. Mr. Lee was the first dean of the university's J. Reuben Clark Law School from 1972 to 1981.

title: Meals Anticipating The Bathing Suit
description: WITH summer - and bathing suits - around the corner, it is time for sensible eating. Low-calorie meals do not have to be boring, however, or even skimpy. It is simply a question of laying off the saturated fats. The recipes below are substantial enough for company; they have little fat but get plenty of flavor from marinades and light sauces.

title: Pitino Confronting Hard Night's Work
description: Rick Pitino walked off the court this afternoon with a worried expression. He knew the Knicks were in trouble. And he had less than 24 hours to do something about it.

title: MEDICAL JARGON
description: If Mrs. Hunt was describing her symptoms accurately, what difference does it make whose jargon she was using? If she understood the terms and used them comfortably in speaking to someone who also understood them, the only impediment to the transfer of information would be the arrogance of a physician who is threatened by an informed, intelligent patient. BETTY LUNDY LaGrange Park, Ill.

title: Bush Crime Proposal Relies On Deterrence, Aides Say
description: President Bush plans to announce a $1.5 billion anticrime proposal Monday aimed at increasing the number of prisons and law-enforcement officers as well as broadening the use of the death penalty for convicted murderers, Administration officials said today.

title: Times Change, Sentiment Endures
description: FINDING a Mother's Day card for my mom has never been easy. When I was growing up, the women depicted on the front of the cards didn't resemble my mom. In their aprons and print cotton dresses, they were the typical Donna Reed type mom of the early 1960's.

title: The Case of the Vanishing Art
description: It has happened again. Two months ago, several representatives from Christie's in New York appeared at the Frick Museum to remove from its walls a painting that had been on view there for nearly 20 years. Jacopo Pontormo's extraordinary rendition of a young man is to be auctioned on May 31, and Christie's expects the bidding to surpass $20 million.

title: A Cautionary Tale for Reviewers
description: To the Editor:

title: Debating States' Rights In South Asian Nations
description: LAST week, as ethnic Tamil guerrillas met with leaders of Sri Lanka for the first time, the hope in everyone's mind was that a political formula could be found for ending six years of civil war. The formula under discussion was the classic device used by democratic nations to make room for regional differences: federalism.

title: Give Only Venture-Capital Gains a Tax Break
description: To the Editor:

title:
PERSONAL FINANCE;
How to Protect a Big Pension Check
description: LEAD: As corporate America restructured itself over the last decade, several million people lost their jobs. Many of them, from top-level executives to middle managers to blue-collar workers, suddenly found themselves with two big checks, one for severance and the other a ''lump sum'' pension distribution.

title: When a Dancer Turns Choreographer
description: ''A few months ago, i was rehearsing a new ballet in Studio 3 and Twyla Tharp was in Studio 4 and Misha was in Studio 5,'' Clark Tippet, the 34-year-old dancer-turned-choreographer with American Ballet Theater, said recently, ''and I suddenly began thinking, 'What am I doing with this group?' When I choreographed my first few pieces, I had nothing to lose, but I realized the company was counting on me this time, and it spooked me.''

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: DRAMATIST'S ART A. R. Gurney, the playwright, will talk about his work at 8 P.M. tomorrow in a program titled ''Players and Playwright'' at the Rye High School on Parsons Street. His comments will be enhanced by readings from his plays by three actors who have performed in them on Broadway or in regional theaters. They are Frances Sternhagen; her husband, Thomas Carlin, and John Cunningham.

title: THE VIEW FROM BEHIND THE VEIL
description: WOMEN OF DEH KOH Lives in an Iranian Village. By Erika Friedl. 237 pp. Washington: Smithsonian Institution Press. Cloth, $24.95. Paper, $10.95.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's all over the ballpark. The grades seem to range from A to D with a lot of people giving him an Incomplete.'' - Thomas S. Winter, editor of the weekly Human Events, on conservatives' attitudes toward President Bush. [ 24:5. ]

title: The Editorial Notebook; Willie Bosket's Rage
description: Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York, steadfastly opposed to reinstating the death penalty, proposes to punish first-degree murder with a sentence of life in prison and no chance of parole. Those who oppose that idea point to a convict named Willie Bosket, who seems bent on causing as much trouble in prison as he did on the outside.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Sabatini and Sanchez Gain: Top-seeded Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina and No. 4 Arantxa Sanchez of Spain scored straight-set victories yesterday to advance to the final of the $300,000 Italian Open women's championships in Rome. Sanchez swept past No. 14 Nathalie Tauziat of France, 6-1, 6-3, in the first semifinal at the Foro Italico, and Sabatini followed with a 6-3, 6-1 triumph over a Bettina Fulco of Argentina.(AP) Rainout in Hamburg: Heavy rain yesterday in Hamburg, West Germany, halted the German Open semifinal between Ivan Lendl and Carl-Uwe Steeb and prevented Boris Becker from playing Horst Skoff of Austria. Weather permitting, the semifinals will be completed today, to be followed with the final shortened to a three-set contest. Lendl, seeded first, dropped the first set, 6-4, but was leading by 5-0 in the second when the rain forced a stop. (AP) Berger and Duncan in Final: Sixth-seeded Jay Berger and unseeded Lawson Duncan advanced to the final of the United States clay court championshps yesterday in Isle of Palms, S.C., setting up a meeting of two former Clemson stars. Berger, the only seeded player to make the semifinals, outlasted Javier Frana of Argentina, 4-6, 6-2, 6-4. Earlier, Duncan beat Tim Wilkison, 7-6, 6-3, in the first tournament meeting between the two North Carolinians, who often practice together. Berger, who is ranked 42d in the world, and Duncan, ranked 75th, will meet for the championship today at Wild Dunes resort.(AP) Golf Hill and Dent in Tie: Dave Hill, atoning for a poor putting performance in the opening round, shot a four-under-par 66 yesterday to move into a first-place tie with Jim Dent in the $400,000 Bell Atlantic-St. Christopher's Seniors Classic in Malverne, Pa. Dent, appearing in his first seniors event, shot his second straight 69, matching Hill's two-day total of two-under-par 138. Chi Chi Rodriguez, who led by a stroke entering the second round, and Orville Moody both missed putts on the last hole that would have given them a share of the lead. They were among six players at 139.(AP) Track and Field Rutgers Wins: Rutgers won the Metropolitan Intercollegiate championship yesterday at Baker Field in Manhattan. The Scarlet Knights had 108 points to 106 for Manahttan. Steve Keating and Jim Siedliski led Rutgers, with Keating setting a meet record of 17 feet in the pole vault and Siedliski winning the 800 meters in 1:49.98, a personal best. White Plains Senior Wins 400: Barbara Selkridge, a senior at Randolph Campus in Manhattan, won the girls' 400-meter dash in 55.35 seconds yesterday at the Loucks Games at White Plains High School. Her time is the fastest for the event in New York State this year. Jermaine Johnson, a sophomore at White Plains, posted a state class record in the boys triple jump at 49-5. Reynolds Wins in 200 Meters: Butch Reynolds, world record-holder in the 400 meters, won his first competitive 200-meter dash in two years yesterday at the Jesse Owens Classic at Ohio Stadium in Columbus, Ohio. Reynolds, who set the 400 mark of 43.29 seconds a year ago, was timed in 20.52 in the 200. Reynolds, an Olympic silver medalist in the 400, ran the 200 to work on speed and start. Running for Athletics West, he did not enter the 400 yesterday. The meet's only multiple winner was Dannette Young of Reebok Racing, who won the women's 100 meters in 11.36 seconds and the 200 in 22.71.(AP) Harness Racing Jaguar Spur won the $200,000 George Morton Levy Memorial Pace by two lengths last night at Yonkers Raceway.Matts Scooter, the world's fastest harness horse, finished fifth. Jaguar Spur won the one-mile race in 1:55 2-5 and paid $4.40.(AP)

title: 'Intellectuals'
description: To the Editor:

title: AN ALL-OUT ASSAULT ON FUN
description: AGAINST JOIE DE VIVRE Personal Essays. By Phillip Lopate. 335 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. $18.95.

title: Crafting 'Roe v. Wade': Tiptoeing on a Tightrope
description: For NBC, the timing of tomorrow night's television movie ''Roe v. Wade'' could not be better - or worse.

title:
DINING OUT;
Genuine Cantonese Cuisine in Tenafly
description: LEAD: FIVE months ago, the sixth in Sammy Chin's chain of Chinese restaurants - they're all named Lum Chin - opened just opposite the railroad tracks, on the corner of Mahan and Piermont Streets, in Tenafly.

title: Adaptive Use
description: To the Editor:

title: CRUSADER ON THE CHARLES
description: It is an anomaly that people would pay thousands of dollars to go to a school, then condemn the man who has assured that their diplomas are worth the investment. WAYNE S. KREGER Malibu, Calif.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE MIDNIGHT CLUB. By James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $17.95.) From high-priced brothels to yacht parties on the Hudson and press conferences at the Waldorf, the latest police novel from the Edgar Award winner James Patterson reaches for the exotic - and settles for the half-baked. At its center is a handsome, charming psychopath, Alexandre St.-Germain, who's eager to turn organized crime into a respectable business; St.-Germain has celebrated his rise to power by personally ambushing, and nearly killing, a New York police lieutenant named John Stefanovich.

title: Cast in the Role of Legend: On Tour With Lucille Ball
description: WHEN I heard the terrible news that Lucille Ball had died, a picture sprang immediately into my mind: Lucille kneeling at my feet in my dressing room at the Biltmore Theater in San Francisco, hemming my dress.

title: IN THE NEW YORK REGION: Long Island A High-Tech Center Is Emerging Near SUNY's Stony Brook Campus
description: LEAD: A MILLION-SQUARE-FOOT industrial and office park now under construction in East Setauket less than two miles from the State University of New York at Stony Brook - one of the nation's premier research institutions - is expected to signal the start of a high-technology center that could have major implications for Long

title: Philip Quaranta Plans to Be Wed To Miss Borman
description: June wedding plans for Wendelin Knowlton Borman and Philip Quaranta have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Earle K. Borman Jr. of Old Greenwich, Conn. Mr. Quaranta is the son of Mrs. Leslie Egenhauser of Rye Brook, N.Y.

title: Susan Kiley Wed To K. M. Osborn In New Canaan
description: Susan Cordiner Kiley, a daughter of Patricia C. Kiley of Norwalk, Conn., and Timothy M. Kiley of Los Angeles, was married yesterday at Waveny House in New Canaan, Conn., to Kevin Michael Osborn, a son of Marjorie P. Osborn of Teaneck, N.J., and Norman V. Osborn of San Diego. David Howland, a justice of the peace of New Canaan, officiated.

title: What DNA Is
description: To the Editor:

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: For Mothers of Multiples MANY Long Island mothers of twins are resting today, but not because it's Mother's Day. They are recovering from last weekend, when 332 mothers of twins descended on the Long Island Marriott for the annual New York State Mothers of Twins Clubs convention.

title: A British Outsider Examines the Rules of the Club
description: ''It's not a bad hotel room, is it?'' the British director Martin Stellman says, gesturing nonchalantly at the casual luxury of an elegant piece of the City of Angels called Le Reve. ''Very seductive, very pleasant, and I don't mind a bit of it. It is a relief from shooting a film in the middle of a damp, dark London winter.''

title: No Points, No Excuses
description: His first shot missed. His second shot missed. Sooner or later, Johnny Newman figured, he would make a shot. He never did. Newman, the Knicks' second-leading playoff scorer, was 0 for 8 in shooting today during New York's 111-88 loss to the Chicago Bulls. He missed Friday's practice with a sore left knee, but he did not use the injury as an excuse.

title: Keeping Hotel Phones From Ringing Up Charges
description: IF you are staying at a minimum-service economy motel, miserly phone service should not be a surprise. At the Econo Lodge on International Drive in Orlando, Fla., for instance, guests cannot use the telephone in a room for any outside call, whether collect, credit-card or whatever, until a $10 deposit is received by the front desk. But a guest can get zapped on phone service almost any place.

title: Prospects; The Dollar Flies Higher
description: Last week the dollar rallied against the world's other major trading currencies, reaching a 30-month high against the West German mark, an 18-month high against the British pound and an eight-month high against the Japanese yen. Although the central banks of the major industrial powers - the G-7 - have intervened in the currency markets to push down the dollar, the effect has been negligible. Four experts assess the dollar's strength. Walter J. Simon Assistant vice president for currency options, Bank Julius Baer.

title:
GARDENING;
Bleeding Hearts and Other Discentras
description: LEAD: THE common bleeding heart is one of those old-fashioned perennials that would have been found in most any flower garden at the turn of the century. A tall plant, reaching two and a half feet, it was just as apt to be planted along the backyard fence as in a flower bed.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Southern Methodist; For Athletes, a Course On Unsullied Athletics
description: Southern Methodist University, whose winning football program was derailed by the National Collegiate Athletic Association on accusations of illegal payments to team members, will begin the 1989 season with a team educated to say no to illegal offers.

title: ARTFUL SURVIVOR
description: ''MY LIFE,'' SAYS HELEN FRANKENTHALER, ''IS square and bourgeois. I like calm and continuity. I think as a person I'm very controlling, and I'm afraid of big risks. I'm not a skier or a mountain climber or a motorcyclist. And I'm not a safari girl - I never want to go on a safari. My safaris are all on the studio floor. That's where I take my danger.''

title: Sports of The Times; Mark Jackson and His Pilot's License
description: The fans were too busy at Chicago Stadium yesterday afternoon cheering for Mile-High Jordan, whooping for Long-Range Hodges and hooting the erstwhile Bull, Plucky Oakley, to bother much with booing the jazzy Mark Jackson.

title: Switch by Hispanic Catholics Changes Face of U.S. Religion
description: In a huge cultural transformation that is changing the face of religion in the United States, millions of Hispanic Americans have left the Roman Catholic Church for evangelical Protestant denominations.

title: IN THE NATION: Houston; A Disney Creation for Visitors To the Johnson Space Center
description: SINCE 1964, when what is now the Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center was built on 1,600 acres of prairie land donated to the National Aeronautics and Space Administration by Rice University, the aerospace industry has been an integral part of Houston's identity as well as its economy.

title: Pretoria's Forces Halt Pursuit of Namibian Rebels
description: South African Army units stopped their search for rebels in northern Namibia and returned to their bases today under an international agreement that requires insurgents of the South-West Africa People's Organization to withdraw at least 90 miles inside Angola.

title: Ms. Ruttenberg Weds Fellow Lawyer
description: Victoria Arden Ruttenberg and Gregory Ferenbach, cum laude graduates of Yale University who received law degrees from the University of Virginia, were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's father and stepmother, Mr. and Mrs. Colin Ferenbach, in Royal Oak, Del. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles B. Ruttenberg of Washington.

title: Only the Desperate and Lucky Get Out of Jalalabad
description: When the helicopters land, the men with the bundles of possessions and the women in the head-to-toe shrouds rush forward, elbowing and shoving in a desperate effort to board before the machines soar back into the air.

title: Composerless Music?
description: To the Editor:

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE OUTERMOST DREAM: Essays and Reviews. By William Maxwell. (Knopf, $19.95.) William Maxwell is a master storyteller. This is not a surprise to those who know him as a novelist, a short-story writer and the former fiction editor of The New Yorker. The pleasure of ''The Outermost Dream,'' a collection of essays and reviews (most of which were originally published in The New Yorker), is to see what engages Mr.

title: Does the World Need More Rumanias?
description: To the Editor:

title: Schools Without A Chancellor Or a Plan
description: RICHARD R. GREEN may have been unfamiliar with many peculiarities of New York City when he arrived to take over the public schools in March 1988, but he was certainly aware of one feature of the city: the reverence afforded the concept of decentralization. At first he was careful not to criticize the system, in which elementary and junior high schools are run by 32 locally elected boards.

title: Dust Blown Off, Paper Reveals Lincoln's Hand
description: LEAD: The first time it was sold, the framed document fetched $10 to help care for wounded Union soldiers. This time the autographed souvenir copy of the Emancipation Proclamation should bring enough money to keep a small Massachusetts library going.

title: Family Reaps Benefit in Fresh Air Fund
description: WHEN Watts and Elizabeth Wacker volunteered to become a Fresh Air Fund family, caring for an underprivledged boy for two weeks during the summer, they knew they were aiding a child in need. But they found that they were also helping themselves.

title: EXCESSIVE DESIRES
description: THE 13th HOUSE By Adam Zameenzad. 202 pp. New York: Random House. $15.95.

title: Did the Penalty Fit the Crime?
description: FOR DR. SHERVERT FRAZIER, there was nothing special about that April day last year.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing; Hyde Park Mansions And a Small-Town Inn
description: It was called the Summer White House. Franklin D. Roosevelt and Winston Churchill are said to have planned the first atomic bomb here. Eleanor Roosevelt ran a cottage industry that produced furniture, pewter and cloth. A generation of Roosevelt children grew up here.

title: My Many Mothers
description: WE have many mothers to remember today, not only the women who gave us birth, but also the countless others who nurtured us. I think first and lovingly of my own mother and then of the special women who added meaning to my life.

title: A Link for All Operating Systems
description: Novell Inc., which already holds a majority of the market for personal computer networking software, last week introduced a product that analysts said could continue its dominance into the 1990's.

title: Pianist With Many Talents and a Mission
description: LEAD: WHEN audiences applaud Nina Deutsch for her theatrical portrayal of Clara Schumann, pianist and wife of the composer Robert Schumann, they appreciate Miss Deutsch's considerable talent as a pianist, singer, actress and writer. But rarely do they suspect that she has won critical acclaim for her mastery of some of the most difficult passages ever composed for the keyboard.

title: Beth Allen Wed To an Executive
description: At the Marble Collegiate Church in New York, Elva Elizabeth Allen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mancill Allen of Houston, was married yesterday to John Frederick Allen, a son of Margaret Allen of Springfield, N.J., and the late Frederick J. Allen. The Rev. Dr. Arthur Caliandro, a Methodist minister, officiated.

title: KOCH AND CUOMO END FUND DISPUTE
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor Edward I. Koch said yesterday that they had agreed to use part of a disputed $100 million to expand New York City's Tactical Narcotics Team program to three additional areas.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: WICHITA, KAN.;
Huge Project Defies Trend
description: LEAD: DEVELOPMENT of northeast Wichita's Comotara community is moving forward despite sluggish renting and 20 percent vacancy rates elsewhere in this city of 300,000.

title:
MUSIC;
Lully Rediscovered, Helas!
description: LEAD: When the production of Jean-Baptiste Lully's opera ''Atys'' that opens at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Wednesday night was presented in Europe in 1987, more than one critic in the French press raised their eyebrows in embarrassment. The first large-scale staged revival of an opera anywhere in two centuries by this French cultural monument had been left to - mon Dieu!

title: New Help In Drive for JObs
description: LEAD: A TRADE association and local unions for the first time this year are joining corporations and Government in an effort to help low-income youths in the county to get experience in the corporate and skilled-job worlds this summer and at the same time raise their career aspirations.

title: JERSEYANA
description: LEAD: WHAT is perhaps the most unusual theatrical event in the history of the New York theater occurred on June 7, 1913, when 1,000 New Jersey workers appeared on stage at Madison Square Garden to present ''The Pageant of the Paterson Strike.''

title: Amy Rabinowitz to Wed Next Month
description: Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Rabinowitz have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Amy Phyllis Rabinowitz, and Louis Saul Dubrow, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Dubrow of Trenton.

title: Water Rules Near End After Rain and Thrift
description: With millions of twists of the wrist, New Yorkers have saved about 5 billion gallons of water since a drought emergency was declared almost two months ago, helping set the stage for the possible lifting of some water-use restrictions tomorrow.

title: For Gallery, Luck and Location Paid Off
description: LEAD: IN 1965, when Emanuel and Elaine Benson bought a house on Main Street in Bridgehampton with the idea of opening an art gallery, ''everyone told us we were crazy,'' Ms. Benson recalled. The town, she was advised, ''couldn't sustain a real gallery because people would always go into New York to buy.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: PHELPS MEMORIAL HOSPITAL;
In the Maternity Unit, a 'Lifelong Commitment' Begins
description: LEAD: RANDI BRODY, 29 years old and on the verge of giving birth for the first time, took a deep breath - contractions were coming close together - and offered some thoughts on motherhood. ''It's a lifelong commitment,'' she said, a beatific smile crossing her face. ''The best type of commitment.''

title: Abby Levine, N.Y.U. Dance Instructor, Marries
description: Abby Lynn Levine, a dance instructor at New York University, and Dr. James Connor Saxon, a resident in internal medicine at St. Vincent's Hospital and Medical Center, were married last evening at the Tower Suite at Rockefeller Center. The Rev. Martin T. Geraghty, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Burt A. Siegal officiated.

title:
IN THE NEW YORK REGION: Westchester;
Growing Office Park Lifts Sagging Yonkers Image
description: LEAD: WHILE most developers have scaled back their building plans in Westchester in recent years, Robert Martin Company of Elmsford, one of the county's largest developers, has continued to build, most notably at its 140-acre South Westchester Executive Park in Yonkers.

title: In Spain, Land of Gamblers, Help for Addicts
description: Manuel Melgarejo's voice still trembles when he remembers the excitement of winning $155,000 at a new casino on Spain's Costa Brava and then setting off on a wild gambling binge that kept him away from home for the next nine months.

title: Soviet Politics Go Rough-and-Tumble
description: The democratization of the Soviet political process has taken a turn familiar to Western voters as a candidate for the national congress used a freewheeling television debate to issue sensational 11th-hour charges of a cover-up of corruption in which he dropped the name of a leading member of the Politburo.

title: MOTHERS BEARING A SECOND BURDEN
description: America's mothers are finding more than ever that the empty nest left by grown children is quickly refilled by frail parents or other aging relatives in need of care, according to a private study.

title: Correction
description: The Works in Progress column of The Times Magazine today, about building a reproduction of Columbus's fleet, includes an incorrect description of the ships, received from the Washington office of Spain '92.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Chicago; 700 at Camp-Out To Beat the Rush For Fall Classes
description: By any standard, it was a huge camp-out: 700 undergraduates on the main quad at the University of Chicago last weekend braving 30-degree weather not to raise money for charity, buy concert tickets or demonstrate for or against some cause, but to enroll in next year's classes.

title: MAESTROS ON PARADE
description: A HISTORY OF ORCHESTRAL CONDUCTING In Theory and Practice. By Elliott W. Galkin. Illustrated. 893 pp. New York: Pendragon Press.

title: Miss Peabody, Lawyer, Weds
description: At the First Parish Church-Congregational in Manchester, Mass., Verlinda Chandler Peabody was married yesterday to Thomas Boushall Moore. The Rev. John Hughes, the minister of the church, and the Rev. James Purdy, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony. The bride is a daughter of Grigsby Chandler Peabody of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Pamela Townsend Peabody of Manchester. Mr. Moore is a son of Mrs. Ralph Norman Tottenham-Smith of Princeton, N.J., and the late John Leonard Moore Jr. Mrs. Moore, a graduate of St. Timothy's School and the University of Vermont, received a master's degree in education from Northwestern University and a J.D. degree from the Suffolk University Law School. She is a lawyer for the estate-tax bureau of the Massachusetts State Department of Revenue in Boston. Mr. Moore, a management consultant, graduated from the Princeton Day School and Bowdoin College and received an M.B.A. degree from Dartmouth College.

title: Reviews/Music; Ralph Moore's Saxophone
description: Ralph Moore, a young tenor saxophonist who knows how to nudge a beat until it rolls sleekly, came to Fat Tuesday's on Wednesday night leading a quartet that included Kenny Barron on piano, Peter Washington on bass and Victor Lewis on drums. Mr. Moore is a regular sideman around New York and his appearance as a leader indicates that he is deservedly moving up in rank.

title: INFERNO IN CHINA: FINALLY THE RAINS CAME
description: THE GREAT BLACK DRAGON FIRE 1 A Chinese Inferno. By Harrison E. Salisbury. Illustrated. 180 pp. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $17.95.

title: Gained In Translation
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuba to Hold U.N. Crime Conference Despite U.S. Opposition
description: The Bush Administration has suffered its first serious setback in the United Nations, failing by a wide margin to stop Cuba from being the host of a big international conference on crime prevention next year.

title: A Leader of P.L.O. Is to Speak
description: LEAD: THE appearance here tomorrow by an official of the Palestine Liberation Organization signals a new momentum and sophistication for a local movement that earlier consisted of a spirited but informal dialogue between Arabs and Jews.

title: The Perfect New England Village
description: ON three summer days in 1681, the Puritan settlers of Hingham, midway between Plymouth and Boston, raised the frame of their new meetinghouse. For inspiration, they drew on what they remembered of church architecture in England, then dominated by the Elizabethan Gothic style. But because they lacked the stone or bricks of the home country, they used the available local material, large virgin timbers. Being ship's carpenters by trade, they fashioned the beams in the only way they knew how, like a ship's hull turned upside down. The result was a soaring ceiling recalling the late medieval heritage of the first colonists.

title: BRITAIN'S BOAST
description: You are no doubt aware that, along with vodka and the samovar, the Russians invented the light bulb, the automobile and the airplane. At least that's what some have claimed at one time or another. But you probably didn't know that the English invented Champagne. Well, neither did anyone else, but over the years that's exactly what some articles in British publications have claimed.

title: STORMING MONTANA'S WILDERNESS
description: As an Easterner who has recently fallen in thrall to the West, I read Jon R. Luoma's article ''Storming Montana's Wilderness'' (April 16) with consternation.

title: Why Can't the Movies Play Ball?
description: A couple of baseball movies have come to town recently on the coattails of last year's hit ''Bull Durham'' in the timeless tradition of bad to so-so movies chasing good ones until you never want to see another of that particular kind as long as you live. In the 40's it was bildungsroman musicals (or sons of ''Yankee Doodle Dandy''), and in the 50's it was westerns - at which point sociologists with a license to babble declared that America obviously saw itself as a frontier once again, but all it had really seen was ''High Noon'' and the best of John Ford.

title: Miss Kang to Marry
description: Kim Chook-Saeng of Cheju Island and Seoul, Korea, has announced June wedding plans for her daughter, Sue Kang Kyung Sook, and Gregory W. Neumann, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy G. Neumann of Darien, Conn., and Naples, Fla. Miss Kang, also the daughter of the late Kang Doo-Bong, is a chief purser for Cathay Pacific Airlines in Hong Hong. Mr. Neumann is the manager of the corporate finance department in the Hong Kong office of Morgan Stanley & Company.

title: In the Subway, a Measure of Control Is Up
description: It started in a big way in 1970, when ''TAKI 183'' was scrawled on walls around the city. Other youths began spray-painting ''tags'' - their nicknames and street numbers - everywhere, especially on subway cars, and by the early 1980's more than 95 percent of the cars bore layers of multicolored hieroglyphics and sometimes also the murals called ''pieces.''

title: Sadly, Affliction of Weak-Hitting Catchers Is Catching On
description: Gary Carter, hitting .114, is forcing the Mets to ponder a difficult decision.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''I.B.M. thinks I should roll over. I've got kids to put through college.'' Jeffrey Alnwick, owner of Big Blue Products, which is in a dispute over its name with I.B.M.

title: Making Homes With 'Sweat Equity'
description: LEAD: LAST July, Millard Fuller, founder of Habitat for Humanity, stood in the pulpit of the First Baptist Church in Riverhead and announced:

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Was Mark Jackson Treated Fairly?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: 17 Shacks on Cape Cod Given Historic Status
description: Seventeen rustic shacks on Cape Cod's outer dunes, whose fate has been the subject of a dispute between Massachusetts officials and the Boston regional office of the National Park Service, have been given national historic status by the Federal agency's headquarters here.

title: New Contract
description: The St. Louis Cardinals' eight-time All-Star shortstop, Ozzie Smith, signed a two-year contract extension worth a guaranteed $4.3 million yesterday.

title: House Cleaning
description: Ever since he took over as president and general manager of the Kansas City Chiefs last December, Carl Peterson has been cleaning house. After starting out by replacing the coach, Frank Gansz, with Marty Schottenheimer, and making several other personnel changes, Peterson recently turned his attention to the grounds and stables.

title: How Do You Spell Mother? Any Old Way
description: Happy Mother's Day, godmother, grandmother, stepmother, mother-in-law. Thinking of you, best friend's mother, other mother, mother-to-be and like-a-mother-to-me. Because you care, care-giver, baby sitter and nanny, the greeting-card makers have come up with Mother's Day messages just for you.

title: Chamber Ensemble
description: Members of the New York Philharmonic will play a program of chamber music at Merkin Concert Hall, 129 West 67th Street, today at 3 P.M. The program includes Gordon Jacob's Suite for Eight Violas, Prokofiev's Quintet (Op. 39), Dohnanyi's Serenade (Op. 10) and shorter works by Handel and Shostakovich. Tickets are $10. Information: 362-8719.

title: Officials Prescribe Car Pooling as an Antidote to Traffic Jams
description: CAR POOLING is Carol Dee Angell's business, and she makes sure she practices what she preaches.

title: NAVAJO COPS ON THE CASE
description: ON A STARK, SNAKEWEED-IN-fested plain in northwestern New Mexico sits an enormous mound of hardened lava that was squeezed out of the earth in the Pleistocene Epoch. It's called Mitten Rock, and some Navajo Indians believe it to be inhabited by witches. Tony Hillerman steers his four-wheel Isuzu Trooper up for a close look at the monolith. He plans to kill a man, and because Navajos avoid the rock, especially at night, he thinks it might be a suitable place to dump the body.

title: Fighting for Life Itself in a Nazi Boxing Ring
description: Sometimes on the set during filming, the brutality of it all becomes just too much, and that's when they begin to play little games, like the one where you spot resemblances between the Polish extras and Hollywood stars.

title:
HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: SOUNDINGS;
Space Age Orff Via Synthesizer
description: LEAD: Lying somewhere between an oratorio and a football jamboree, Carl Orff's ''Carmina Burana'' is the work conductors haul out when they want to let their hair down. The Latin text (a mixture of church and gutter varieties), sounds sacred until you read it and discover just how earthy the Middle Ages could be.

title: Oil's Political Power In Alaska May Ebb With Spill at Valdez
description: The black stains left by the Exxon Valdez have left a mark not only on Prince William Sound but also on Alaska's political landscape, blotting out much of the influence that the oil industry has enjoyed in state government for the last decade.

title: Steps to Ban Alar Announced
description: The Environmental Protection Agency today announced steps to prohibit the use of Alar on apples and other foods but said final action is not likely for at least 18 months. A recent private study said the chemical, used by some growers to prolong the shelf life of apples, can cause cancer and is particularly harmful to children. The E.P.A. announced in February that it would take steps to ban the chemical. Today it estimated that as much as 15 percent of last year's crop may have been sprayed with Alar.

title: The Speed of Sound: Second Thoughts
description: If Alfred MacLennan, in his letter ''The Speed of Sound: A Matter of Fact'' [ Letters to the Westchester Editor, March 26 ] , had simply presented his value for the speed of sound at sea level [ regarding Robert P. Levine's essay ''When the Ballpark Cost Just a Nickel'' ] in a straightforward manuever, that would have been fine. However, the gratuitous manner he chose to do so prompts this letter. He complains of the erroneous information provided by Mr. Levine (and The New York Times) to young students. Unfortunately, if these young students take, as absolute, his value of 1,080 feet per second (give or take a few feet depending on atmospheric conditions), they will still be in trouble.

title: PASTIMES: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: After the soil has dried out, continue planting, especially container-grown perennials and shrubs. Indoors use at half-rate, a water-soluble fertilizer on seedlings, which will be transplanted to the garden later this month. Snap faded flowers off daffodils, tulips and other spring blooming bulbs to avoid the formation of unwanted seed pods. On Mulches

title: Barbara Olsen Marries

The Rev. James P. Swiader officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Mary. The bride is a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Olsen. Mr. Pascale is the son of Mrs. S. T. Pascale of Manhasset and the late Dr. Pascale.

description: The Phoenix Suns felt right at home on the road again today, and as a result, they are going back to Arizona with a 3-1 lead in the Western Conference semifinals, and cold-shooting Golden State is a game away from heading home for the summer.

title: New Capacity Threatens Disk Makers
description: Personal computer users have a voracious appetite for floppy disks. Even with the growing popularity of high-capacity hard-disk drives, computer users still need floppy disks - the metal-oxide-coated plastic wafers - to load new programs and to store copies of data.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
From Minor Leagues to a Major Project
description: LEAD: AFTER five years of delay primarily caused by contaminated soil, a $150 million, 1,176-unit condominium community is about to rise where Roosevelt Stadium used to stand along Newark Bay in Droyers Point, part of the Greenville section of Jersey City.

title: Tyson Called A Poor Example
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Drenttel Doyle Partners - Advertising and Graphic Designers
description: To Stephen Doyle, a 32-year-old co-conspirator behind the design of the magazines Spy, In Fashion and The New Republic, graphic design is a bit like driver's education. ''You communicate through layout,'' he said. ''Type tells the reader when to speed up and when to put the brakes on.''

title: Group Would Buy Eastern And Put Carlucci in Charge
description: An investment group headed by Joseph Ritchie, a Chicago options trader, yesterday submitted a proposal to buy Eastern Airlines that would temporarily put Frank C. Carlucci, the former Defense Secretary, in charge of the troubled carrier.

title: Debuts; A Clarinetist, a Flutist And a Pianist in Recitals

title: Q and A

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Washington State; Fraternities Make Parties Contingent On Good Grades
description: Across the Washington State University campus, dozens of fraternity men are sipping cold beers in the sun, but they may not be doing so for long. Student leaders, trying to change the university's party-school image, are imposing sanctions next fall that will prohibit beer drinking in fraternities that have low grade-point averages.

title: A Spring of Drought Restrictions Shrivels Busines at Nurseries
description: MAY is the equivalent of the Christmas buying season for those who sell ornamental plants, shrubs and trees. But on a recent afternoon, thousands upon thousands of plants, trees and flats of seedlings covering six acres at Tony's Nurseries in Larchmont were still waiting for the hundreds of buyers who never came.

title: Koch Urges Tougher Action on Juvenile Offenders
description: In response to the attack on a jogger in Central Park, Mayor Edward I. Koch has proposed an eight-point program to toughen state laws governing the way juveniles are tried and punished.

title: Citizens Gain in Anti-Developer Wars
description: WITH an uneasy ceasefire in the battle over what will be built on the site of the New York Coliseum, neighborhood groups allied with environmental organizations are mounting sophisticated new campaigns to influence planning and real estate development across New York City.

title: The French System For High-Speed Trains
description: According to your recent news article (''Maglev: Fast Trains of the Future?'' April 30), Europe is working on a network of high-speed railroads, but it will use the French high-speed railroad as the preferred system, not the experimental Maglev one. The French is fast enough, is well-proven and does not have the hazards that are likely if the superconductivity of the Maglev system fails.

title: An Update on Status Of Dental Students
description: The New Jersey Weekly recently reported that Fairleigh Dickinson University plans a one-year phaseout of its College of Dental Medicine. Since no follow-up story has been written, here is accurate current information on the status of our dental students.

title: Altered Shuttle Schedule Delays Launching of Telescope in Space
description: A new shuffling of the space shuttle schedule will cause a delay of three to five months in the launching of the Hubble Space Telescope, space officials and scientists said last week.

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: Most experienced tournament players distrust radical early violent mating attacks - they've seen too many of them flop - so it is a terrible embarrassment when one of these coffeehouse adventures achieves a smashing success.

title: In the West Bank, Self-Confidence Edges Out Reality
description: HIS voice brimming with boastful conviction, Mahdi Abdul-Hadi, a leading Palestinian militant, proclaimed: ''The Israelis are opening their eyes and receiving the true message of the intifada. We are building a new society, and it is deep rooted. The Israelis will have to accept it.''

title: Managua and Its Rivals Spar Over Voting Laws
description: More than two weeks after political organizing for national elections was to have begun, the Government and its opponents remain locked in a dispute over the rules that will govern the vote.

title: Preparing the Show at Old Salem Farm
description: LEAD: SO impeccable are the steeds lodged at the Old Salem Farm here that it is easy to imagine a crew of grooms rushing from stable to paddock to dust them off on the quarter hour.

title: Rhea K. Brecher Is Married To Stephen Glenn Dignam
description: Rhea Kemble Brecher, the chief assistant district attorney of Brooklyn, was married yesterday to Stephen Glenn Dignam, the president and owner of Virgil Mountain Inc., a printer of appellate-court documents in New York. The Rev. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: ANIMAL DRAWINGS Peggy Westphal's expressive drawings of animals in pastels, pencil and conte crayon are on on view at the Silo in New Milford, her second solo show there.

title: A Village Art Shop Owner Is Shot to Death
description: The owner of three Manhattan art galleries was found shot to death in what the police believe was an attempted robbery near one of his galleries in Greenwich Village.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: THE HELIOTROPE WALL: And Other Stories. By Ana Maria Matute. Translated by Michael Scott Doyle. (Columbia University, $25.) A lyric energy propels these adroit translations of seven stories by Ana Maria Matute, one of Spain's most highly regarded writers, but they are not always resolved in a satisfying way.

title: Special Education Isn't Sacrosanct
description: Concerning the article ''Tax Revolt Builds on Long Island'' (April 16) and James F. McNicholas's letter [ ''Start Tax Revolt With School Budgets,'' Feb. 26 ] :

title: Q and A
description: Arbitrating With Tenants

title: Fresh Air Fund Expands Horizons
description: UNTIL Luis Saez was 7 years old, he knew only the walls of his apartment building and the daunting streets of the northern Bronx. The attractions of Manhattan and the greenery of Westchester lay short train rides away, but he had experienced neither. Even the world-renowned Bronx Zoo, only minutes from his home, was foreign to him.

title: Limelight Sought for L.P.G.A.
description: Since he became commissioner of the Ladies Professional Golf Association five months ago, Bill Blue has been working feverishly to upgrade the image and increase the exposure of women's golf.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Yale; Literature Majors Favor Black On Their Backs
description: Beatniks did it. Intellectuals did it. Even Japanese designers did it. Now, Yale University's literature majors seem to be doing it, too - wearing black, that is. Often consciously, and always conspicuously.

title: Mothers, Kids And Feminism
description: LEAD: In the 30's and 40's, Georgie Jessel stepped out on a hundred vaudeville stages, got down on one knee and sang, with a catch in his voice and a tear in his eye: ''God's gift from above, The one unselfish love, I've found in my mother's arms.''

title: NONFICTION
description: A WOLVERINE IS EATING MY LEG. By Tim Cahill. (Vintage, Paper, $8.95.) In this collection of adventure stories, Tim Cahill, a columnist for Outside magazine, says offhandedly that ''every once in a while, I like to flirt with some physical challenge in which the price of failure is death.'' He recounts, in much the same manner, such challenges as squeezing through barely passable openings a half-mile beneath the earth, diving off the Philippines for poisonous sea snakes and hiking Death Valley in the summer. No wolverines, though; the title ''A Wolverine Is Eating My Leg'' is a play on adventure-magazine headlines. What seems to draw him to his chosen subjects is a combination of fear and fascination with death. The closer he gets to what he calls ''Grand Terror,'' the sharper his perceptions and the tighter his writing; his article about Jonestown after the Jim Jones tragedy is one of the best in the book. Even on the way to witness a total solar eclipse in Montana, Mr. Cahill makes a detour to find the shadow of death at a lake where a man had recently drowned. In a piece on observing gorillas in Rwanda, he lingers over the murdered gorilla expert Dian Fossey's collection of photos of the dead animals. None of this is as morbid as it may sound. Mr. Cahill manages to balance a sense of peril with playfulness and tells stories that are often suspenseful, educational and fun to read. As the adventure magazines like to say, he laughs in the face of death, and we laugh along.

title: The Soviets and Chinese Get Down to Business
description: JUST 10 years ago, a group of American Congressmen touring the Soviet Union were startled when a provincial politician launched into a remarkably candid and seemingly heartfelt tirade about the menace of China.

title: Ms. Messina Wed To Michael Aron
description: Francesca Rose Messina, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Matthew J. Messina of Brooklyn Heights, was married yesterday to Michael Stanley Aron, a son of Jon Aron of New York and Nantucket, Mass., and Cynthia Cleveland Cox Farris of Bethel, Conn. The Rev. William Leydon performed the ceremony at the Immaculate Conception Roman Catholic Church in New York.

title: Samuel McCleery Marries Tania Tassie in Princeton
description: Tania Lawson-Johnston Tassie and Samuel Adams McCleery were married yesterday at Trinity Episcopal Church in Princeton, N.J., by the Rev. Jean R. Smith. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Peter Lawson-Johnston and Mr. and Mrs. William McCleery, all of Princeton.

title: Brodsky's Challenge Cheers Democrats
description: OFF to an early start, Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky's bid for the County Executive post held by Andrew P. O'Rourke has filled Democrats with an optimism that seems to outweigh the considerable difficulties the Democatic challenger faces in ousting his experienced Republican rival.

title: The Brouhaha Over Drug Ads
description: A little pink stomach with legs and a smile talks about ulcers.

title: Office in a Flat
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance; A Team of Young Stars In ABT's 'Swan Lake'
description: Amanda McKerrow was the new Odette-Odile and Wes Chapman made his debut as Siegfried in American Ballet Theater's new production of ''Swan Lake'' Wednesday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: Japan's New Farm Belt
description: In California's agricultural belt, a meat-packing plant that had been closed for years reopened recently with new financial backing - Japanese. In the same city, Fresno, a Japanese textile company, is building what will be the first cotton mill west of the Mississippi River.

title: PASTIMES: Camera
description: There's no arguing about the usefulness of filters. With slide films they are virtually a necessity, since you can't fiddle much with the image after it has been shot. But even those of us who use color-negative films, which can readily be color-corrected in the printing stage, find good reasons to put filters in front of our lenses.

title: At Funeral for Green in Minneapolis, Fond Memories of an Avid Educator
description: The flag at City Hall here flew at half-staff today as Minneapolis bade farewell to Dr. Richard R. Green, a resident since his childhood, who rose from a housing project to the school superintendent's chair before he moved to New York City to head the nation's largest school system.

title: Ardsley Perspective On the Soviet Union
description: ''Soviet Travel: Friendship and Flexibility'' by Roberta Hershenson [ April 9 ] brought back memories. My son John, a 15-year-old Ardsley High School sophomore at the time, was with his teacher, Larry Mayer, on that first trip to the U.S.S.R. That was 10 years ago this month.

title: Drug Offers Promise on Gum Disease LBy LUBA VIKHANSKI
description: SCIENTISTS studying periodontal disease at the State University of New York at Stony Brook are exploring a new property of tetracycline, a well-known antibiotic.

title: FAILED JOURNEYS TO THE WRONG PLACE
description: ON THE RIVER STYX And Other Stories. By Peter Matthiessen. 208 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the interests of Vice President Dan Quayle's wife, Marilyn, misstated the ages of their children in some editions. Tucker is 14, Benjamin is 12 and Corinne is 9.

title: Conville Cup To Temple
description: Temple re-established its rule over its hometown Schuylkill River course today, winning the Tom Conville Cup for men's varsity eights in the 51st annual Dad Vail Regatta.

title: CRUSADER ON THE CHARLES
description: As a member of the ''very badly bred generation of students'' John Silber found at Boston University when he became president in 1971, I read Helen Epstein's article with great interest.

title: Drug Arrests Crowd County Jails
description: LEAD: DRUG arrests on Long Island have pushed the number of jail inmates toward levels at which both Nassau and Suffolk Counties may soon again be in violation of state regulations and Federal Court orders.

description: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted. Classical
