description: Sheila Marie Matthews, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Elmer M. Matthews of Bernardsville, N.J., was married there yesterday at Our Lady of Perpetual Help Roman Catholic Church to John Joseph Goggins 3d, a son of Myra M. Goggins of the Bronx and Mr. Goggins Jr. of Dover, N.J. Archbishop Theodore E. McCarrick of Newark performed the ceremony, assisted by Msgr. Richard A. Behl and the Rev. Donald C. Matthews, an uncle of the bride.

title: PASTIMES: Stamps
description: The short and not very happy reign of Edward VIII as King of England produced a set of stamps that are strikingly severe in design, almost plain. But the story behind the design is interesting.

title: TOWARD WIDER HORIZONS
description: CONNECTIONS TO THE WORLD The Basic Concepts of Philosophy. By Arthur C. Danto. 281 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $22.95.

title: Putting Computers In their Place
description: A recent article, ''Determining Family Computer Needs'' by Paige Sheard Jaeger [ Westchester Opinion Page, April 16 ] , made several points about computers that may not accurately reflect the place of the computer in education today.

title: Fresh Air Fund Camps Teach Teamwork and Camaraderie
description: Pursued by unfriendly natives deep in the jungle, a group of 10 young explorers must find a way to cross a piranha-infested river. They see a rope hanging from a branch above the water. One by one they grab hold and swing across, Tarzan-style.

title: FICTION
description: ECHO OF LIONS. By Barbara Chase-Riboud. (Morrow, $19.95.) In this, her third novel, Barbara Chase-Riboud takes on one of the most fascinating episodes in the history of the slave trade, the successful rebellion of a group of Africans on board the Spanish slave ship Amistad. Led by the man who would be known in America as Joseph Cinque, the intended slaves killed the captain and crew of the ship and, with no maritime knowledge, attempted to sail back to West Africa. Instead they charted a wandering course up the coast of the United States and ended up in Sag Harbor, L.I., where they were imprisoned and made to endure four years of trials (which eventually reached the Supreme Court, where the defense was led by John Quincy Adams). Ultimately the survivors of the Amistad were declared free men who had fought for their liberty and were allowed to return to Africa. Considering that this took place years before the Dred Scott decision or the Civil War, it is an extraordinary story - and Cinque is an extraordinary character. Unfortunately, Ms. Chase-Riboud renders the events and the men who lived them only sporadically interesting. In the novel's opening sections she partially succeeds in conveying the unrelenting horror of the Middle Passage, but as the story proceeds Ms. Chase-Riboud's attempts to give the story an epic feel too often result in overblown and awkward prose. The novel is also damaged by rather flat characterizations, particularly in the case of Cinque, and by an overabundance of arcane historical detail. Within the story of the Amistad mutiny, there may be a great novel. But ''Echo of Lions'' isn't it.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Scranton, Pa.;
Ski Center Spurs Building
description: LEAD: WHEN Montage Inc., a nonprofit civic organization, opened the $17.2 million Montage Ski Area in 1984 on about 400 acres three miles off an I-81 interchange, it hoped it would attract business and tourism to the area.

title: Inflation Fears Given Some Relief
description: Inflation worries eased considerably in response to some new statistics. Wholesale prices for April showed an increase of four-tenths of 1 percent, much less than expected. Gasoline prices, up 7.2 percent, had their steepest monthly rise in nearly two and a half years, but were offset by declines in food and auto prices. The rise in the Producer Price Index matches the March increase and is well below the 1 percent monthly increases recorded early this year. Other statistics pointing to a slowing economy also helped ease inflation worries. April retail sales were up only four-tenths of a percent, about half what had been anticipated. Business inventories in March rose three-tenths of a percent, while business sales were flat. *

title: Puckett's 4 Doubles Pace Twins
description: Kirby Puckett tied a major league record with four doubles and drove in three runs today as the Minnesota Twins beat the Toronto Blue Jays, 10-8, for their fourth straight victory.

title: Correction
description: An article on March 5 incorrectly described the founding of the National Plastics Center and Museum in Leominster, Mass. The museum, which opens later this year, was founded by an unaffiliated group of individuals in the plastics industry.

title: In a Hot Art Market, Fear of Getting Burned
description: THE near desperate demand by the wealthy for works of art is reminding some Wall Street investors of the speculative frenzy that has characterized stock market booms. ''It does have a late 60's feel to it,'' said Dave H. Williams, an art collector and chairman of Alliance Capital Management. ''There is a certain hubris and confidence on the part of collectors and dealers that it only goes one way - up.''

title: A Debate About The Inevitability, And the Fragility, Of Democracy
description: IN the 19th century, it could be said that there were two alternative predictions about mankind's future. Marx proclaimed the inevitability of world socialism while Toqueville asserted that democracy, which he saw with some trepidation as rule by the consent of the governed, would surely replace rule by the few.

title: Pamela Jill Kirsch Is Wed
description: Pamela Jill Kirsch, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Kirsch of Westhampton Beach, L.I., was married yesterday at the Fox Hill Country Club in Baiting Hollow, L.I., to Michael Gerard Magnan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Harold Magnan of Watertown, Wis. Cantor David Benedict officiated. Mrs. Magnan, a graduate of the University of Delaware, is a special-education teacher at the Mental Health Institute for Children at the Allentown (Pa.) State Hospital. Mr. Magnan is an engineering consultant for Metropolitan Edison in Portland, Pa.

title: Beware the Winged Tyrant
description: ANYONE who has ventured into the bosky back country in our part of the world - the Northeast - knows how easily the Garden of Eden can turn into Monster Island. All it takes is bugs. For instance, I recall 30 years ago as a child being jammed under a big old Army tent with 27 other campers on a witheringly hot and rainy night in the New Hampshire woods. Roused from slumber out of a sleeping bag that felt like a steam bath, I chanced to shine my flashlight on the tent's ceiling. It appeared to be covered with thousands of tiny potatoes - little beige things - that presently began to move to and fro on hair-like legs, perhaps in response to the light. When I brought this curious phenomenon to the attention of my comrade, a scene ensued straight out of ''Riot in Cell Block D.''

title: Jay Doblin, Designer, Dies at 68; Clients Included Major Industries
description: Jay Doblin, a leading industrial designer who also taught for three decades at the Illinois Institute of Technology and directed its Institute of Design for 14 years, died of cancer Thursday at Lutheran General Hospital in Chicago. He was 68 years old.

title: AS POSTAL RATES RISE, PRIVATE CARRIERS PROSPER
description: Faced with rising postal costs, catalogue houses and other direct mailers are on the lookout for alternatives to Postal Service delivery.

title: KEEPING PACE
description: Power, control, raw sensual appeal - concepts car makers have used for years to tout their products, have been commandeered by the shoe industry to promote advances in athletic footgear. Stripped of their tony visuals, the new crop of ads offers no easy distinction between the ''ultimate driving machine,'' as the BMW bills itself, and what shoe specialists hope to sell as the ultimate running machine.

title: In Suffolk, Tax Revolt Gathers Steam
description: LEAD: IN an atmosphere of crisis over sharp increases in property taxes, a bill before the Suffolk County Legislature to roll back the county's share of property taxes next year to their 1987 level has deeply divided county officials.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: LASTING ATTACHMENTS. By Annette Sanford. (Southern Methodist University, $12.95.) The 11 spare and evocative short stories that make up the veteran Texas writer Annette Sanford's first collection share a single subject. With gentle humor, Ms. Sanford's stories offer love illimitable as a luminous possibility.

title: How Communities Try to Foster Middle-Income Housing
description: LEAD: FROM New Rochelle to Briarcliff Manor, communities in the county are increasingly taking steps to spur construction of housing priced at below-market rates for middle-income families.

title: IT GRIPES ME TO SAY THIS
description: Gripe did originally mean grip, as Roy Blount says in his article, but that's not the point here. An old meaning of gripe is intestinal pain, and because people with a bellyache often go around bellyaching, the word eventually acquired the slang meaning ''complaint.'' LOUIS JAY HERMAN New York, N.Y.

title: Joseph Williams Plans To Marry Gail Collins
description: Gail Ann Collins and Joseph Williams, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Williams of Jamaica, Queens, plan to marry in August, the prospective bride's parents, the Rev. and Mrs. Stewart Collins of Evansville, Ind., have announced.

title: Nepal
description: To the Editor: In regard to the article by Jeannie Pulston Fleming on trekking in Nepal with children (Travel, March 26), we have trekked there several times, the last time in November north of Gurkha with our 18-month-old daughter. The only other Westerners we ran into was the group of children from the International Lincoln School. Despite our best efforts at cleanliness, however, our daughter acquired a severe viral gastroenteritis with four days of diarrhea and dehydration, which we had to manage ourselves since we were several days from the nearest road or telephone.

title: Reviews/Theater; Repertorio Espanol in 'La Casa de Bernarda Alba'
description: Hatred, jealousy and despair come to life, almost as characters in their own right, in the Repertorio Espanol's Spanish-language production of ''La Casa de Bernarda Alba.'' But this new staging of the Federico Garcia Lorca play, under the direction of Rene Buch, moves so fast at times as to become a headlong rush to tragedy. It does not often give one the nearly intolerable apprehension of doom that pervades a more brooding and deliberate presentation.

title: Sanjay Patel Wed To Leslie Dickey
description: Leslie Stuart Dickey was married yesterday at the home of her mother and stepfather, Mr. and Mrs. Francis Fitz Randolph Jr., in Ridgefield, Conn., to Sanjay Hiralal Patel, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Hiru N. Patel of Bombay, India. Judge Romeo G. Petroni of the Court of Probate for the District of Ridgefield officiated.

title: Maureen Joy Gibbons, a Biochemist, Is Married to Eugene J. McCabe Jr.
description: The marriage of Maureen Joy Gibbons to Eugene Joseph McCabe Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. McCabe of New York and Rumson, N.J., took place yesterday at St. Lucy's Roman Catholic Church in Middletown, R.I. The Rev. James F. McCabe, a cousin of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: Shooing Elephants
description: HEADACHES ARE A-mong the five most frequent complaints brought to a family doctor - but no two people describe them in quite the same way. Nor are two doctors likely to interpret those complaints in the same way. So it's not hard to see why misdiagnoses are common and why they lead to failed treatments. Too often, headache therapy has been as scientific as a traveling salesman's all-purpose tonic.

title: Road Salt at Issue in Two Legal Suits
description: THE runoff from spring rains has been carrying an unhealthy element in many areas - particles of salt used to de-ice the highways in the winter - and one of the latest apparent casualties of the pollution is a nursery here.

title: At the Gas Station, Help Yourself To Less Service
description: AS gasoline retailers converted to self-service, drivers had to get used to the idea that they might not be able to count on their local service station to make repairs, change tires or even clean their windshields. Soon they may not even be able to drive in and ask the attendant for directions.

title: Conservatives Find Bush Troubling
description: The conservative movement, which has never regarded George Bush as one of its own, is uneasy over his first four months in office. It is troubled by his apparent eagerness to compromise with a Democratic Congress and worried that he lacks Ronald Reagan's sense of how to use the power of the Presidency.

title: In the Realm Of Pure Music
description: To the Editor:

title: I Know Where I Am; But Why?
description: I HAVE come into the kitchen for the third time today and I can not remember why. I am not over 60 years old, not suffering from Alzheimer's, but somehow a few of the cells in the overstuffed computer of my brain do not have room to remember why I came into the kitchen.

title: Afghan In Look And Taste
description: Men in traditional Afghan costume greeted 400 guests at the Ambassadors' Ball for Afghanistan Tuesday night at the Plaza. More than $75,000 was raised for the Afghanistan Relief Committee, which provides humanitarian aid.

title: Emma Bridgewater - Pottery Designer
description: Emma Bridgewater has never thrown a pot in her life - except perhaps in anger - and has no design training, yet in five years she has built a flourishing pottery company.

title: Zoeller Loses Lead, But Only Briefly
description: Fuzzy Zoeller continued his amazing performance in the cold and rainy 14th annual Memorial Tournament today when he chipped over a bunker and into the 18th hole for a birdie 3 to maintain his lead by a stroke over Bob Tway going into Sunday's final round.

title: The Melody Is Sicilian for a Change
description: NORTHERN Italian restaurants are in vogue on Long Island. Most are sumptuously elegant with prices and food closer to Paris than Rome.

title: DATA BANK: MAY 14, 1989
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Nepal
description: To the Editor: Seeking advice from a specialist in tropical and travel medicine should be foremost when a family is planning to bring youth along on a trek to a developing country. The incidence of typhoid, shigella, amebiasis, tuberculosis, diphtheria, meningococcal infections, dengue fever, hepatitis, rabies, hookworm and other intestinal parasites is high in Nepal and many other countries where trekking occurs. Although it is true that in Katmandu there are several clinics that provide certain inoculations, it is more prudent to acquire the inoculations prior to leaving home, since for complete protection from certain diseases it is necessary to be vaccinated long before the one or two days that one spends in Katmandu.

title: The Big News in Tiny Computers
description: Here in Silicon Valley, smallness has traditionally been equated with power, so it was not by accident that the Poqet Computer Corporation chose its name. These days, Poqet's future sits, appropriately enough, in the breast pocket of a jacket worn by the company's founder, Stav Prodromou.

title: Flawed Proposal
description: To the Editor; Commenting on the dilemma of ''Tilted Arc,'' Jan R. Harrington suggested [ Letters, April 16 ] that ''any piece of purely decorative public art be rented for display for no longer than five years,'' after which the rental could be renewed for up to 20 more years before a decision to purchase.

title: A CORRECTION
description: The Residential Resales column on April 23 omitted the listing broker in the sale of the town house at 55 Charles Street in Greenwich Village. It was Laurie Brant.

title: When a House Is an Impossible Dream
description: SOMETHING broke my concentration when I was reading. Annoyed, I tried to identify the source of the distraction. But I didn't hear a thing, just comforting silence. It was completely quiet in the middle of the afternoon in downtown Mineola!

title: PASTIMES: Numismatics
description: It's been nearly 75 years since the British passenger liner Lusitania was torpedoed by a German submarine. The ship's sinking slowly sucked the United States into World War I and inspired one of the most controversial medals ever made. That medal and others by the German sculptor Karl Goetz will be sold at auction today at the Omni Park Central Hotel at Seventh Avenue and 56th Street at 1 P.M. by Collectors' Auctions Limited.

title: Miss Egan Plans A June Wedding
description: Mr. and Mrs. Raymond R. Egan of Whitestone, Queens, have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Heather Ann Egan, and Thomas V. Leeds, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Leeds Jr. of Brookville and Southampton, L.I.

title: Louise Kennedy, An Editor, Weds
description: The marriage of Louise Avery Kennedy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Grafton S. Kennedy of Spruce Creek, Fla., and Nantucket, Mass., to George Langdon Gibson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George W. Gibson of New York and Hallowell, Me., took place yesterday at King's Chapel in Boston.

title: Colorful Pittsburgh Mayor Leads Challengers
description: The usual political suspects have been rounded up for the mayor's race here. To hear the candidates tell it, voters can choose among a fiscal watchdog, a high-tech visionary, a party and union insider and a former 1960's civil rights worker.

title: The Muddle in Eating 'Right'
description: I REMEMBER how my happy baby used to conduct imaginary orchestras with asparagus spears as her batons, how she pruned tiny broccoli trees proudly with her two teeth, and how she gummed cold chunks of apples to ease the pain of teething.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-19

title: The Northwest Reclaims a Lost Artistic Heritage
description: OF ALL THE TRIBES THAT INHABITED North America in the centuries before European visitors, few people had so much leisure time on their hands as the nations of the Northwest coast. Their main source of food, the tasty Pacific salmon, arrived at their doorstep every year without fail.

title: A Bronx Youth Finds A Fresh Air 'Brother'
description: SINCE he was 6 years old, Ronald M. Mayfield Jr. of the Bronx, now 13, has visited the Morgan family in Mount Arlington as a Fresh Air Fund child every summer. Each visit is kicked off with a huge sign across the Morgans' red ranch-style house that reads, ''Welcome Ron.''

title: A NEW PERSONALITY AND NAME: SAY HELLO TO 'MEGALOGS'
description: Stiffer competition and the higher cost of landing new customers has made catalogue retailers more appreciative of their old customers -and more eager to keep them. ''Cataloguers are now working very hard to establish a relationship,'' said Jo-Von Tucker, president of the JVT Direct Marketing Corporation, a direct-mail marketing firm. ''They're not looking for just a single hit.''

title: Miss Abeles to Wed Michael Sheldon
description: The engagement of Michele Leslie Abeles to Michael Lawrence Sheldon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David L. Sheldon of Boston and Caracas, Venezuela, has been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Edna S. Abeles and Arthur A. Abeles, both of New York. An August wedding is planned.

title: Louise Bond Wed To Robert Heck
description: Louise Cover Bond, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Calhoun Bond of Lutherville, Md., was married yesterday to Robert William Heck, the son of Mr. and Mrs. William L. Heck of Venice, Fla. The Rev. Malcolm J. Matthews performed the Episcopal ceremony at the home of Mrs. James Piper Jr., the bride's grandmother, in Stevenson, Md.

title: Review/Theater; 'Legends,' a New Kind of Revival Meeting
description: ''Legends in Concert,'' the glitzy Las Vegas revue that opened at the Academy Theater on Wednesday evening, presents nine performers doing mechanical impersonations of stars who have little in common beyond the fact that they are all dead.

title: Fare for the Family, Tex-Mex Style
description: LOBOS BAR AND GRILL occupies the basement of the old Veterans Hall, a landmark in New Canaan that faces the Town Hall on Main Street. Viewed from the street, there is merely an inconspicuous awning extending from what looks like an empty building. Yet the moment one opens the door, the scene changes radically. Inside, scores of people are seated, others are crowded together waiting in line, and the decibel level is high.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Amityville $149,990 20 Irving Road 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 45-year-old ranch; 60- by 100-foot lot, walk to beach; taxes $2,600. Hempstead $136,000 12 Brown Place 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 40-year-old Cape Cod; fireplace, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $1,500. Massapequa Park $183,000 372 Philadelphia Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 34-year-old split level; dining room, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,000. Mineola $187,000 404 Old Country Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old colonial; dining room, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,100. Rocky Point $265,900 Brookhaven Drive 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new colonial; dining room, fireplace, eat-in kitchen; taxes $5,000. Roslyn Heights $377,000 32 Farm Lane 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 39-year-old ranch; dining room, 2-car garage, brick and shingle siding; taxes $4,300. OTHER AREAS Neptune, N.J. $90,000 1531 Eighth Avenue 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 3-year-old ranch; front porch, hardwood floors, 1-car garage; taxes $1,134. Rye, N.Y. $271,500 11 Drake Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,549. Ivoryton, Conn. $135,000 22 Highland Terrace 5-bedroom, 1-bath, 55-year-old farmhouse; glassed-in porch, 0.67 acre; taxes $781.

title: Changes All Around
description: After a quarter century of trying to change the political order, Charles Evers has decided to change political sides. The civil rights campaigner said last week that he will leave the Democrats and join the Republican Party.

title: Concerts and Awards With the Young in Mind
description: THE care and cultural feeding of our young artists is essential to the future of music in America, so it is encouraging to note that many Connecticut organizations are tending to these vital tasks.

title: Can the U.S. Bail Out Thrifts Without Sinking Real Estate?
description: AS the Bush Administration's proposed savings and loan bailout works its way through Congress, more and more attention is being paid to a peculiar challenge: how to carry out the plan without worsening the depression in Southwestern real estate prices that helped cause the crisis in the first place.

title: INSIDE
description: Bush Urges Coup in Panama

title: A Classic With A Double Life
description: This has been a season of revivals of unusual works by George Balanchine. The Joffrey Ballet reconstructed ''Cotillon'' of 1932. Tulsa Ballet Theater offered the New York City premiere of the 1942 ''Mozart Violin Concerto.'' And the New York City Ballet has just given us ''Danses Concertantes,'' a ballet of 1944 - or, is it really from 1972?

title: D. L. Glovin Wed To Dr. Horwitz
description: The marriage of Dr. Elizabeth Anne Horwitz, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. S. Theodore Horwitz of Roslyn, L.I., to David Laurence Glovin, a son of Jerome Glovin of Lido Beach, L.I., and the late Arlene Glovin, took place last evening at Temple Israel in Lawrence, L.I. Rabbi Norman Kahan performed the ceremony. Susan Grace Horwitz was her sister's maid of honor, and Martin Tev Glovin was his brother's best man.

title: Question Of the Week; Should the Yanks Have Traded Leiter?
description: Should the Mets have traded Nolan Ryan? DAVID SELINGER New York

title:
GARDENING;
Bleeding Hearts and Other Discentras
description: LEAD: THE common bleeding heart is one of those old-fashioned perennials that would have been found in most any flower garden at the turn of the century. A tall plant, reaching two and a half feet, it was just as apt to be planted along the backyard fence as in a flower bed.

title: A Corporate Palace That Louis XIV Might Envy
description: Never mind the Louvre pyramid. Forget the monumental arch at La Defense, and the new opera house at Place de la Bastille, and have a look at a really monumental piece of new architecture in France: the sprawling headquarters of Bouygues (pronounced Bweeg), the multinational construction company, in this new town about 12 miles from Paris. Not only is the Bouygues complex far and away the most elaborate suburban corporate headquarters in Europe, it is so grandiose as to make virtually every American suburban office building look like a roadside stand.

title: IKE, EINSTEIN AND THE WOMEN'S CONSPIRACY FROM HELL
description: THE CROSSWINDS OF FREEDOM The American Experiment. Volume Three. By James MacGregor Burns. 864 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $35.

title: It's Alpha Time for the Omega Label
description: Omega Record Classics makes its impressive debut with 12 compact disks. Omega's founder, Seymour Solomon, characterizes his new label as ''seeking to meet the challenges imposed by the CD format, with its advanced technology and increased length.'' Unlike many entrepreneurs who start record companies, Mr. Solomon (who founded Vanguard Records and presided over it for 35 years) has already dealt with just about every problem that can befall a record producer. His experience gives Omega a head start.

title: POWER TO THE NEIGHBOR
description: THE LIVING CITY By Roberta Brandes Gratz. 414 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $21.95.

title: STORMING MONTANA'S WILDERNESS
description: Why do those who would rape our nation's public lands for direct personal profit label as elitist advocates for the preservation of the wilderness? It seems the elitist label belongs more aptly to those who stand to profit at the expense of the rest of us. JOHN L. TURNER Huntington, L.I.

title: CRIME
description: ''I don't like the administration, and what is worse, I don't trust them,'' declares our favorite campus snoop, Kate Fansler, in A TRAP FOR FOOLS (Dutton, $16.95), the ninth mystery by Amanda Cross - better known in scholarly circles as Carolyn G. Heilbrun, a feminist literary critic and the Avalon Foundation Professor in the Humanities at Columbia University.

title: Program Examines Sand and Chopin
description: In many ways, Amantine Lucile Aurore Dupin was a precursor of today's supermom: she supported her two children by writing about 80 novels (under the pseudonym of George Sand) and she was a staunch advocate of freedom in living for women. Her atypical dress and manner - not to mention tempestuous romantic proclivities - became the 19th-century symbol of the modern woman.

title: John Hugh Denton Marries Holly Whitmore in Jersey
description: Holly Whitmore, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Knight Whitmore Jr. of Essex Fells, N.J., was married there yesterday to John Hugh Denton, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard Todd Denton of Bethlehem, Pa. The Rev. Dr. David St. George, an Episcopal priest, and the Rev. Francis McNulty, a Roman Catholic priest, performed the ceremony at St. Peter's Episcopal Church.

title: Drawing a Lesson in Fiber and Fruit
description: IF Roy Doty has his way, Billy Buck Hightrail could become the first superhero in the fight against cancer.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
A 307-House Proposal for the Pine Barrens
description: LEAD: FROM the Hampton Hills Golf & Country Club in Riverside, a visitor can look out over thousands of acres of pine barrens. Robins Island and the Great Peconic Bay are visible to the east. On a clear day, houses lining Dune Road in Westhampton Beach and, to the north, Island Sound, can be seen.

title: TOP-NOTCH
description: FROM THE STREET, IT APPEARS THAT A LARGE PEDI-ment caps this 11-story building. But the classical silhouette actually tops french doors leading from the architect David S. Rockwell's living room to his rooftop terrace.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Brunch; Airy to Historic, 4 Suburban Settings
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in the Connecticut, Long Island, New Jersey and Westchester Sunday regional sections of The New York Times. Ratings at the end of each item - satisfactory, good, very good, excellent and extraordinary - are followed by the date of original publication. Reviews from the A La Carte column have no rating. Prices are current. Garden City Hotel

title: Virginia Beach: Big City by the Sea
description: SHORT on cachet and well within liberty range of the world's biggest naval base, Virginia Beach is one of those resorts that's easy for the uninitiated to dismiss. Indeed, in nearly a decade of living a half day's drive away, I never heard anybody even mention the place in the same breath as ''vacation,'' much less actually go. Rehoboth Beach, Ocean City, Nag's Head, and even Myrtle Beach in distant South Carolina, are where beachgoers of my acquaintance head.

title: Afghanistan, by Custom, Has Rebels Everywhere
description: ''LAND of the unruly'' - Yaghistan - was what the first modern ruler of Afghanistan, Amir Abdur Rahman Khan, called his country at the turn of the century. By another translation it means ''land of rebels.''

title:
ART;
Milan's Talents of the Renaissance Are Shown at Yale
description: LEAD: WITH ''The Sforza Court'' exhibition at the Yale University Art Gallery, we might have felt in over our heads. After all, the Sforza dynasty of Renaissance Milan, the equivalent of the Medicis in Florence, dominated politics, the economy and the arts. We do not have a contemporary equivalent of this phenomenon; the overarching

title: The Magic Moments Come the Year Around
description: THE real Mother's Days, to my mind, consist of the most magical moments of being a mother. The prime occasion may well be when the baby kicks for the first time during pregnancy.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Strip Shopping; Centers of New Size and Scope Explode in Northeast
description: AFTER languishing in the shadow of regional malls and office projects for many years, strip shopping centers have become the darling of Northeast developers, prompting some realty experts to fear the affair will end badly with a spate of half-empty centers.

title: MEDICAL JARGON
description: The letters from two physicians, Wendy S. Aronson and Carl Austin Weiss (April 16), critical of Morton Hunt's Body and Mind article ''Patients' Rights'' (March 5), merely serve to reinforce the extraordinarily cogent points Mr. Hunt was trying to make. To wit, too many doctors nowadays have become haughty, arrogant, too busy to listen, and clutching at the pedestals they themselves have erected on patients' backs. NED B. TUCK San Francisco

title: 'Intellectuals'
description: To the Editor:

title: NONFICTION
description: THE CHIP WAR: The Battle for the World of Tomorrow. By Fred Warshofsky. (Scribners, $22.50.) Fred Warshofsky has taken his tape recorder and toured the American semiconductor industry, recording the anguish of its leaders as they watch their markets relentlessly eroded by Japanese competition. He has also traveled to Japan and visited factories, universities and Government officials to paint a picture of a near-invincible rival. The image that emerges in ''The Chip War'' is of an industry that is dangling by a thread, in danger of going the way of the television and videocassette recorder industries before it. In his final chapter Mr. Warshofsky, a science writer, captures the bitter frustration of the president of a modest-sized Silicon Valley chip-making equipment company. The businessman is trying to match the investment of his Japanese competitors, with their easier access to capital and their insulation from greedy Wall Street shareholders who look no farther than the next quarter's profit-and-loss statement. Mr. Warshofsky's answer for bringing the American industry back from the brink? The Semiconductor Manufacturing Technology Institute, or Sematech, the fledging semiconductor industry research consortium, financed half by industry and half by the Government, is this country's best hope, he suggests. By imitating Japanese consortiums like the Ministry of International Trade and Industry we can match our Eastern competitors, combining American skill at technological innovation with a new-found mechanism for creating manufacturing excellence. But Sematech has gotten off to a ragged start. Its executives are squabbling and its members are complaining that it is transferring technology too slowly. Rather than creating a new bureaucracy, perhaps the answer to Japanese competition is a return to the entrepreneurial spirit that created Silicon Valley in the first place.

title: Turning On the Research Switch
description: Time was when most companies felt that research and development was something they had to do for themselves and technology developed by others was adopted only as a last resort. However, as international competitive pressures have grown and research has become more expensive, that ''not-invented-here'' syndrome has faded.

title: English Garden for a Historic Colonial House
description: A BIT of England will grace the grounds of the historic Glebe House in Woodbury when an English garden designed by Gertrude Jekyll is finished, more than a half-century after it was planned.

title: China's Hero of Democracy: Gorbachev
description: When Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrives on Monday for four days of talks designed to restore normal relations between China and the Soviet Union, he will be cast in the unusual role of champion of democracy.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: May 14, 1989
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 2 TO BE THE BEST, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Bantam, $5.95.) A department store dynasty undergoes emotional and financial stress. 2 3 LIGHTNING, by Dean R. Koontz. (Berkley, $4.95.) A mysterious stranger saves a woman from a series of dangers and disasters. 3 2 THE TAMING, by Jude Deveraux. (Pocket, $4.50.) Romance and chivalrous adventure in medieval England. 4 15 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Dell, $4.95.)
