The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: JOHN FALLS SHORT AGAIN AS YANKEES LOSE
description: Tommy John walked quickly through the clubhouse and out the door that leads to the playing field. He was wearing shorts, a T-shirt and running shoes, and there were beads of perspiration gathered across his forehead. He still had work to do. He did not stop, did not look up.

title: Owen's Bat Helps Expos Top Giants
description: Spike Owen tied the score with a two-run homer in the seventh inning and then singled home the winning run with two out in the ninth as the Montreal Expos beat San Francisco, 5-4, today, ending the Giants' five-game winning streak.

title: Louisville
description: To the Editor: I would like to note an inaccuracy in ''What's Doing in Louisville'' (Travel, April 9). The J.B. Speed Art Museum, while enjoying a close relationship with the University of Louisville, is not ''the University of Louisville's ... Museum,'' but a private institution, Kentucky's oldest and largest art museum, which has served this area of the county independently as an art museum for more than 60 years. Your writer's confusion perhaps stems from the fact that the museum is adjacent to the University of Louisville campus. KELLY SCOTT REED Director of Public Information The J. B. Speed Art Museum Louisville, Ky.

title: Man Imperils Sand Shaped by Eons of Winds
description: The cold spring wind off Lake Michigan carries the sounds of the new season: the rasp of saws, the pang of hammers and the rumble of bulldozers cutting roads into the steep-sided sand dunes that rise hundreds of feet above the shore.

title: Kidnapping of Briton in Beirut Is Reported
description: A British man was reported missing in Lebanon today, hours after a group asserted it had taken a hostage to win the freedom of comrades jailed in the slaying of a Palestinian cartoonist in London.

title: Hospitals Find New Ways to Keep Nurses
description: LEAD: IT used to take almost all morning for Dolores Dlugaszewski, a nurse in an oncology unit at Union Hospital in Union, to take patients' vital signs, help them wash and change their beds. If someone needed a wheelchair or a special drug, she would leave her floor to get it.

title: Thorny Issues From the Seeds Of Controversy
description: Claude Chabrol's latest film, ''Une Affaire de Femmes,'' is emotionally brutal, morally disturbing and probably one of the masterpieces of this decade. Yet it slipped in and out of New York recently, its United States premiere limited to two screenings at the Museum of Modern Art in a series devoted to the film's producer, Marin Karmitz. The film's somber tone and controversial subject certainly contributed to this low-key opening, which suggests that a little ambiguity is a dangerous, noncommercial thing.

title: CRUSADER ON THE CHARLES
description: I knew John Silber during my four years as superintendent of the Boston public schools. When the Boston schools needed help, John Silber was always there. When students, particularly minority-group students, needed scholarships or other assistance, John Silber and Boston University were at the forefront helping to provide them.

title: MEDICAL JARGON
description: In his response to Morton Hunt's article, Dr. Weiss insults a large portion of the public whose intelligent command of medical jargon is as natural to them as his own is to him. No one, especially the patient, is better served by the use of ''everyday names'' to describe symptoms. How can ''my belly hurts'' possibly supply nuances that a detailed description of the location, intensity and duration of pain would not? EDITH B. BLUM Trumbull, Conn.

title:
Focus;
Huge Discount-Outlet Center Opens in Philadelphia
description: LEAD: The completion of part of a 1.8-million-square-foot discount and outlet center in northeast Philadelphia is drawing attention to developers' blossoming interest in using large tracts for reduced-price retail developments.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Wisconsin; A Street Festival 20 Years Later: Fun, Not Protest
description: What a difference a couple of decades can make. In 1969, the University of Wisconsin's Miflin Street Block Party became the focal point for a three-day student protest that left 80 people injured, 20 of them police officers. These days it is just a happy one-day festival.

title: TALKING: Co-op Loans; An Effort To Ease Availability
description: WITH considerable fanfare, Fannie Mae (the Federal National Mortgage Association) announced last month that it was expanding its co-op loan program. As a result, borrowers were supposed to obtain mortgage loans for co-op apartments more easily and cheaply. The move was also designed to help lenders make fixed-rate loans on co-ops, which had been difficult to obtain in the past.

title: It's a Fan's Kind of Town
description: In this city, sports fans do not do The Wave. They do not wave hankies. They do not paint themselves in team colors or wear goofy costumes. They watch the game. And they shake the rafters. If it's mere entertainment you want, try City Hall. Sports is too serious for such shenanigans. As Shakespeare, had he grown up in Chicago, would surely have said: The game's the thing.

title: PERU FIGHTS TO OVERCOME ITS PAST
description: LONELY AND DEPRESSED, BROODING on the perfidy of a nation that once worshiped him, Peru's young President, Alan Garcia Perez, rarely emerges these days from his ornate, 19th-century palace in the heart of Lima. Twice last year, he tried to resign. Earlier this year, a military coup looked imminent. Several times he told friends that he hoped to be ousted. But now, condemned to serve out his five-year term, he hides out from the anger and scorn of the vast majority of Peruvians.

title: As California Tells Insurers What to Do, the Nation Listens
description: AS the nation's most populous state, and one of its more affluent, California is a market so large and lucrative that industries will suffer almost anything to succeed here.

title: No Loss for Words
description: Unaccustomed as he is to public speaking these days, Ronald Reagan has found that money talks, or at least that his talks bring big money. Lavish plans are being made in Japan to welcome him for 10 days of speeches and ceremonies in October. Despite a shadow cast by a scandal involving illicit payments to Japanese politicians by corporations, a bidding war is said to have erupted to be Mr. Reagan's sponsor. His emissary, Charles Z. Wick, former director of the United States Information Agency, designated the Fujisankei Communications Group, an information services conglomerate. Mr. Reagan's fee was not disclosed, but one report put it at $2 million, or more than he earned in eight years in the White House.

title: Sabina Martin Is Betrothed
description: Mrs. Michael Bender and William Redmond Martin, both of Shoreham, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mary Sabina Martin, to Joseph Hunter Milbank, a son of Jeremiah Milbank Jr. and the late Andrea Hunter Milbank of Greenwich, Conn.

title: Sports of The Times; A Visit to the Father of Champions
description: Considering that he has sired two winners of the Kentucky Derby, Halo did not look proud. What he looked was mean.

title: STIRRING ALL NIGHT
description: There are a number of reasons why I sometimes don't prepare the delicacies described in your food pages (''Food: Whetting the Appetite,'' by Bryan Miller with Pierre Franey, April 16). Often, the ingredients are not readily available, and many recipes seem too time consuming for my taste. However, you reached a new height with your recipe for Daube de Boeuf Bourguignonne. How does one conveniently marinate overnight, stirring occasionally? ALBERT C. SMITH JR. Rochester

title: Bobo Mangan, a Tennis Pro, Marries
description: Barbara Clement Mangan, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Mangan of Chatham, N.J., was married yesterday to Francis James De Laney, the son of Dr. John Joseph De Laney of Convent Station, N.J., and the late Ruth Anne De Laney. The Rev. Gerald Greaves performed the Roman Catholic ceremony at the Church of St. Rose of Lima in Short Hills, N.J.

title: No Headline
description: As a New York City schoolteacher, I have always been curious about education in other parts of the world.

title: Michele J. DeCarlo Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. DeCarlo of Rosemont, Pa., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Michele Joan DeCarlo, to Thomas Lowry Blum, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Blum of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Special Today; Commercial Property/Section 13
description: Looking toward the 90's; mergers and acquisitions and the office market; a Disney creation in Houston. Is it time to rebuild Park Avenue?

title: Barbara Lewis Affianced
description: A June wedding is planned for Barbara Gail Lewis, a daughter of Leon Lewis of Scarsdale, N.Y., and the late Elaine Lewis, and Seth Adam Kaplan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Kaplan of Teaneck, N.J. Ms. Lewis is a first vice president of the New York public-relations concern of Ruder-Finn. Mr. Kaplan is a partner in the New York law firm of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen & Katz.

title: Security at Airports Steadily Tightening
description: In the nearly five months since a terrorist bomb concealed in a cassette tape player tore apart a Pan American Airways 747 over Lockerbie, Scotland, security at Europe's airports and at Kennedy International Airport has grown steadily tighter.

title: Final Word?
description: To the Editor:

title: Summer Music Festivals Throughout the Land
description: Whether their taste runs to familiar orchestral chestnuts, gatherings of avant-garde composers, elaborate exercises in early-music performance or traditional jazz, music lovers will find much to savor at the festivals planned in North America this summer.

title: Addiction Needs Compassion If It Is to Be Cured
description: I RECENTLY saw a young man in the detoxification unit at the hospital. He had overdosed on synthetic heroin and was brought in unconscious and near death from respiratory failure.

title: James E. Pierce, 49, Presbyterian Leader
description: The Rev. James E. Pierce, a nationally known leader of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. who was the executive presbyter of Long Island, died of cancer Friday at his home in Commack. He was 49 years old.

title: Most on Board Are Seeking A New Chancellor by Fall
description: Most of the members of the New York City Board of Education say they hope to install a successor to Dr. Richard R. Green, the Schools Chancellor who died Wednesday, by the opening of school in September.

title: MOZART IN THE LAB
description: LEAD: THE PRIVILEGE OF BEING A PHYSICIST By Victor F. Weisskopf. Illustrated. 235 pp. New York: W.H. Freeman & Company. $17.95.

title: Singing For a Supper And a Cause
description: All eyes were on Julio Iglesias at the fourth annual Crystal Ball on May 4, which benefited Mount Sinai Medical Center. ''I came to sing tonight because you do such important work in saving lives,'' he told the 1,100 partygoers at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, before giving his rendition of ''To All the Girls I've Loved Before.'' The evening raised more than $1.5 million.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: 'M' IS FOR THE ..

title: Susan N. Brown Weds Professor
description: At Riverside Church in New York, Susan Norrine Brown, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pierce J. Brown of Ipswich, Mass., was married yesterday to Brooks Whitney Stoddard, a son of Whitney S. Stoddard of Williamstown, Mass., and the late Jean Read Stoddard. The Rev. Roger B. White, an Episcopal priest, performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Mariah Britton, a Baptist minister.

title: Question Of the Week; Should the Yanks Have Traded Leiter?
description: No, the Yankees should not have traded Al Leiter, especially not to a club in their division. Pitchers usually take more time than position players to fully realize their potential. Leiter is only 23 years old. At that age, Ron Guidry was pitching with a 5.26 e.r.a. in the Eastern League. JOE GARACE Astoria, Queens

title: ABOVE ALL, KEEP THE TALE GOING
description: LEAD: SPIDER WOMAN'S GRANDDAUGHTERS Traditional Tales and Contemporary Writing by Native American Women. Edited by Paula Gunn Allen. 242 pp. Boston: Beacon Press. $19.95.

title: IN THE NEW YORK REGION: Connecticut; For New Haven, a New $360 Million Neighborhood
description: EARLY next year a rubble-strewn, forgotten section of New Haven called Downtown South, just off Interstate 95 and a half mile south of the historic New Haven Green, will begin its transformation into a new $360 million neighborhood with 2.4 million square feet of commercial, retail, hotel and residential space surrounding a 3-acre park.

title: Despite New Stirrings, Dream of 'One Germany' Fades
description: WHAT with West Germany suddenly stamping its foot at NATO and resisting the battlefield nuclear weapons that other allies consider critical, the old fear has surfaced again: is it not the Germans' real goal to be one nation-state again, an economic and cultural powerhouse straddling East and West in the heart of Europe? Is not a deep yearning for reunification behind the Germans' longing for detente, behind their search for economic influence in the East, their balking at NATO demands?

title: Kenyon College Has a Streak
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Ayatollah's Curses Can't Kill Ideas
description: A FRIGHTENING moment of truth flashed before me as I was returning home from the Salem Free Public Library with a brand-new copy of ''The Satanic Verses'' lying intimidatingly beside me on the car seat. Salem is the fastest-growing town in Connecticut, in the heartland of the beautiful Connecticut River Valley on the edge of the pristine Devil's Hopyard. As we passed through Witch Meadow, I heard an eerie, high-pitched scream that precipitated me into a terminal state of fear that my old VW bus and I were about to be sent to the Promised Land by a heat-seeking Stinger missile launched by an Iranian terrorist lurking in the swamp.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: Hawaii is a popular destination and therefore a popular subject for guidebooks. Following are four of the most recent. 22 Days in Hawaii By Arnold Schuchter. 129 pages. John Muir Publications. $6.95.

title: Operating on the Unborn
description: HER EYES HUGE with fear, a young woman, 19 weeks pregnant, lies on an examining table at Hutzel Hospital in Detroit. Her husband stands beside her, saying nothing, looking grim.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Pittsburgh
description: Pittsburgh, long thought of as the smoky city of mills and factories on the banks of the Ohio, Allegheny and Monongahela Rivers, can no longer be regarded as ''hell with the lid off,'' as the journalist Lincoln Steffens once described it.

title: No Impostors in This Final
description: The unscientific playoff format of the National Hockey League, often a vehicle used by Cinderella squads to cling to contention until the championship round, was not fooled by pretenders this spring.

title: A Family Awaits Fresh Air Visitor
description: ''WHEN we see the summer's first fireflies, we know it's time for Dario to come,'' said Monica Willard, looking forward to the arrival of the family's Fresh Air Fund friend from Brooklyn.

title: A Deplorable Play
description: To the Editor:

title: Ashby's Choice
description: Beggars and 36-year-old catchers with .164 batting averages can't be choosers - even, as it turns out, if they have no-trade clauses in their contracts. That's the little lesson Alan Ashby has been learning after invoking such a clause to veto a trade that would have sent him from the Houston Astros to the Pittsburgh Pirates.

title: Hispanic Position On the Word 'Quota'
description: On behalf of the Association of Hispanic Professionals it is a pleasure to write this letter and to tell you how delightful it was for us to see the article ''Hispanic Residents Striving for Political and Economic Gains'' [ April 16 ] .

title: 'Drug-Free Zone': Some Quick Results
description: Regarding ''Effectiveness of Drug Law Questioned'' (April 9): The new ''drug-free zone'' law for 1,000 feet around schools may not be perfectly written, nor is it a cure-all, but in my experience it seems to work - and not only by arrests and sentencing, but by discouraging drug dealing near a school.

title: Bob Hiemstra - Fashion Illustrator
description: His talent is to be able to draw in such a way that the result always looks as if it had been done in a flash, even if, as Bob Hiemstra, a fashion illustrator, explained, ''It took five days rather than five minutes to get it off the drawing board.''

title: Correction
description: A headline last Sunday about the engagement of John H. Grady Jr. misidentified the bride-to-be. She is Ellen Canan. Patricia G. Canan is her mother.

title: The Mother Tongue
description: NOTHING PREPARES you for motherhood.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: PETOSKEY, MICH.;
description: A DECISION last month by the state's Department of Natural Resources has cleared the way for Three Fires Pointe, a $500 million residential resort with marina on the site of a long-neglected cement factory and abandoned quarry on the shore of Lake Michigan.

title: >Rational Behavior On House Prices
description: People are screaming about the number of houses for sale. They say it's the taxes and that nobody can afford to live here anymore.

title: Glued to the Wheels Of a Racer's Mind
description: I was standing near the start of the first stage over a week ago in Albany when Donald Trump came over to introduce me to Mario Cuomo. He said, ''Governor, I'd like to introduce you to one of the best cyclists in this country, Davis Phinney.''

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Bermuda Puts A Limit on Cruise Ships

title: Michele Ann Coyne Marries John Regan
description: Michele Ann Coyne and John V. Regan, graduates of St. Bonaventure University, were married yesterday at St. Augustine Roman Catholic Church in Ossining, N.Y. The Rev. Robert McCormick officiated.

title: Emily Murphy Weds Ronald D'Andrea
description: The marriage of Emily Eckart Murphy, a daughter of Mrs. Peter Ogden and R. Blair Murphy, both of Greenwich, Conn., to Ronald Vernon D'Andrea, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Rocco V. D'Andrea of Greenwich, took place yesterday at the First Congregational Church of Old Greenwich. The Rev. Thomas L. Stiers performed the ceremony. Mrs. D'Andrea, a graduate of Skidmore College, is the New York advertising manager at Parenting magazine in New York. Her father is the co-founder and president of Sullivan-Murphy Associates, an executive-search company in Stamford, Conn.

title: The Big Surprise on Seventh Ave.
description: American sporty themes, like parkas and oversized sweaters, in color palettes ranging from pale creams and cool neutrals to hot hues and molten golds. And there were enough variation of figure-clinging pants and cat suits to outfit an army of ''To Catch a Thief'' burglars.

title: Mattingly Shows Class
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 'The Fantasticks': At 29, a Pacifier More Than a Play
description: ''I must have seen 'The Fantasticks' seven or eight times,'' a 45-year-old woman tells me. ''How come?'' I ask. ''Because every boy I knew thought it was literary, sensitive and romantic.'' ''Didn't you tell any of them you'd already seen it?'' ''Not one.'' ''Why not?'' ''Because it was literary, sensitive and romantic.''

title:
FOCUS: Philadelphia;
1.8 Million Sq. Ft. Discount Center Opens
description: LEAD: THE completion of part of a 1.8-million-square-foot discount and outlet center in northeast Philadelphia is drawing attention to developers' blossoming interest in using large tracts for reduced-price retail developments.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: The Hudson Valley and Catskill Mountains By Joanne Michaels and Mary Barile. Harmony Books, New York. 306 pages. $14.95.

title: Oh, What a Campaign That Was, Argentines Say
description: One of the important subliminal issues of a political campaign that many describe as ''surreal'' was apparently cleared up this week as Argentines prepared to go to the polls Sunday.

title: PASTIMES: Bridge
description: Political leaders receive awards frequently, but a double ceremony tentatively scheduled to take place in New York City on May 30 will be distinctly different. Two awards will be given to one of the leaders of the People's Republic of China for services to bridge.

title: WHY AUSTRALIAN WRITERS KEEP THEIR HEADS DOWN
description: So a brash young country goes in for a checkup to the Great Cosmic Doctor. ''I don't know what it is, Doc, but I'm feeling kinda crook,'' he says. ''Something's going on with me, but I can't put me finger on it.''

title: Miss Brown Wed To G. J. Anderson
description: At the Union League Club in New York, Aimee Susan Brown, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Beau Brown of Westfield, N.J., was married yesterday to Gary John Anderson, a son of Irene Anderson of Hermitage, Pa., and the late S. Tedford Anderson. Judge Michael L. Pesce of Civil Court in Brooklyn officiated.

title: Largely Chaplin? More Like Indiana Jones
description: One of Bill Irwin's constant companions in the immensely funny entertainment known as ''Largely New York'' is a cane, a perfectly ordinary walking cane with which he does certain wondrous things. Actually, he does even more wondrous things with one of those remote controls that make television sets so obedient, but we'll get to that.

title: FOR THOSE WILLNG TO PAY, CATALOGUES OF CATALOGUES
description: The idea of charging customers for catalogues may seem ridiculous. But the concept could be just the ticket to offset retailers' higher postal expenses and winnow browsers from their mailing lists. People who pay for catalogues, after all, are more likely to place orders.

title: The Games of Girls: Kinder and Gentler
description: While the boys were disporting themselves on the streets of the city, in the days when it was still safe to play on the streets, hitting, slapping or punching among the sewers, the girls were engaged in kinder, gentler (though not wimpier) games. We played potsy, developing our sense of balance. We jumped rope, sharpening our timing. We manipulated jacks, increasing our dexterity.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu; Cooking Enough For Later
description: Many Italian dishes lose nothing by being frozen. Here is a basic recipe for lasagna, with or without meat, that makes a Sunday meal and has enough left over for dinner days later.

title: Phinney Is First By Four Inches
description: Davis Phinney of Boulder, Colo., survived his premature celebration today and won a 51-mile stage of the Tour de Trump bicycle race by 4 inches. Eric Vanderaerden of Belgium finished second, and when the 10-day race ends Sunday on the Atlantic City Boardwalk, Vanderaerden will be favored to win the first prize of $50,000.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;
GONZO THEOLOGY
description: LEAD: For reasons known only to Himself, God (the Big I Am) has passed on His grumpy musings about creation and its consequences to the British illustrator and erstwhile gonzo satirist Ralph Steadman. God's only caveat in THE BIG I AM (Summit, $24.95) is ''Remove nothing or suffer the consequences.'' Mr.

title: CRUSADER ON THE CHARLES
description: I went to Boston University in the pre-John Silber years. You could get a sound education, but it was despite the school not because of it.

title: Indy Trials Rained Out
description: An intermittent rain today wiped out the first day of what is expected to be record-setting qualifications for the May 28 Indianapolis 500.

title: Arab Oil-Exporting Group Readmits Egypt
description: The Organization of Arab Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed today to readmit Egypt, whose membership was suspended because of its peace with Israel a decade ago. The move was a further step in Cairo's return to the Arab fold after 10 years of ostracism.

title: MOSCOW CAUTIONS NATO ON REPLACING MISSILES IN EUROPE
description: The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, said today that if NATO decided to replace and improve its short-range nuclear missiles in Europe, the Soviet Union would consider either halting the dismantling of its own nuclear rockets or developing a new weapon.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My house has an unfinished attic that I can walk into. I use the attic frequently, but in summer the temperature climbs so high it is difficult to stay long. The attic floor is insulated with a layer of vermiculite, covered with a thick layer of fiberglass without a paper backing. This seems adequate to prevent heat filtering into the rooms below. To reduce the temperature inside the attic, I want to install fiberglass between the rafters. Should I use blankets with or without a paper facing? If the kind with a facing is best, which way should it face?

title: Penny Haft Is Married
description: Penny Haft, a daughter of Mrs. Bob Murphy and a stepdaughter of Mr. Murphy of New York and Jensen Beach, Fla., was married yesterday to Bill Thomason, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James Thomason of Bessemer, Ala., at Stephen's Episcopal Church in Birmingham, Ala., by the Rev. Douglas Carpenter.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Katonah, N.Y. $322,000 Allison Road 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 31-year-old farm ranch; country kitchen, fireplace, studio, screened porch, 1.5 acres; taxes $4,503. Pound Ridge, N.Y. $600,000 Trinity Pass 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 5-year-old colonial/Cape Cod; 2 fireplaces, country kitchen, family room, deck, hot tub, 3.9 acres; taxes $6,765. Rye, N.Y. $271,500 11 Drake Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 40-year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,549. Ivoryton, Conn. $135,000 22 Highland Terrace 5-bedroom, 1-bath, 55-year-old farmhouse; glassed-in porch, 0.67 acre; taxes $781. Lyme, Conn. $475,000 Hamburg Road 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 5-year-old colonial; dining room, electronic alarm system, 3-acres; taxes $1,847. Old Saybrook, Conn. $144,000 61 Bokum Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 30-year-old ranch; 1-car garage, 1.2 acres; taxes $880. OTHER AREAS Marlboro, N.J. $290,000 1 Secretarial Square 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 5-year-old colonial; inground pool, deck, wall-to-wall carpeting; taxes $4,000. Massapequa Park, L.I. $183,000 372 Philadelphia Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 34-year-old split level; dining room, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $3,000. Mineola, L.I. $187,000 404 Old Country Road 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 35-year-old colonial; dining room, basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,100.

title: Give Only Venture-Capital Gains a Tax Break; A Less Expensive Plan
description: To the Editor:

title: New 'Circle' Is Suburban Bluegrass
description: Tradition can be a tricky thing. In the broadest sense, just about all music is traditional, unless it uses unique instruments and brand-new structures. And in the narrowest sense, virtually no music is purely traditional since each new interpretation alters the tradition in some way - although that process is itself a traditional one, as oral traditions constantly sift promising innovations from indulgences and tangents. What most listeners recognize as traditional is somewhere in between, respectfully old-fashioned but not old hat.

title: Jacquelyn Helin, Pianist, Marries
description: Jacquelyn M. Helin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rudolph A. Helin of Redwood City, Calif., was married yesterday at St. Paul's Chapel at Columbia University to Robert Alan Glick, a son of Florence Weiskopf of Tamarac, Fla., and William Glick of Miami. The Rev. Dr. Richard H. Cox, a Presbyterian minister, and Rabbi Charles J. Davidson officiated.

title: Joan Scandurra Is Wed
description: Joan M. Scandurra, an assistant vice president at the Irving Trust Company, and John Michael Polcari, an assistant vice president at Citibank, both in New York, were married yesterday at St. Rose of Lima Roman Catholic Church in Massapequa, L.I., by the Rev. Charles Srion. Mrs. Polcari, a daughter of Joan Thompson of Massapequa Park, L.I., and the late G. Thomas Scandurra, graduated from St. John's University. Mr. Polcari, a graduate of Manhattan College, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Guy A. Polcari of Glen Cove, L.I.

title: Two Cities, Two Results In Housing The Poor
description: WITHIN 12 miles of each other across the Hudson River are some of the best and some of the worst examples of how public housing has met its noble aim of sheltering the poor.

title: INTRIGUE ON THE BOSPORUS
description: A WOMAN OF SINGULAR OCCUPATION By Penelope Gilliatt. 180 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $17.95.

title: New Buildings, Locales Luring Office Tenants
description: LIKE a family trading in a scratchy 1950's hi-fi for a compact-disc player with all the extras, office tenants in New York City today are going modern. Many space users, including some of the nation's largest legal and financial firms, are abandoning their old offices in favor of new buildings that can accommodate their computer systems and provide more efficient, comfortable conditions.

title: Crowded Field Ruined Derby
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
IN THE NATION: Santa Monica, Calif.;
A $300 Million Office Complex Designed to Please Pedestrians
description: LEAD: BY the size of its setting alone, 17 acres in an increasingly cramped coastal community, the Water Garden office complex now under way here seems like a creation from Fantasyland. The image is buttressed by the fact that the four cast-stone buildings in the complex will nestle in ornate landscaping embellished with a 1.4-acre artificial lake with fountains.

title: HAVING A GOOD TIME WITH OUR WORST FEARS
description: LEAD: IF THE RIVER WAS WHISKEYBy T. Coraghessan Boyle. 224 pp. New York: Viking. $17.95.

title: Maude Brickner Becomes a Bride
description: Maude Lillian Brickner and Rock Miller were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Philip W. Brickner of Riverdale, the Bronx, by Dr. Matthew Ies Spetter of the Riverdale-Yonkers Society for Ethical Culture. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Miller of Wichita, Kan.

title: With Few Bills Passed or Ready for Action, Congress Seems Sluggish
description: More than four months into the legislative session, the 101st Congress has passed few major bills and does not have many ready for floor action.

title: SHOOTING DOWNTHE GENERAL
description: DOUGLAS MACARTHUR The Far Eastern General. By Michael Schaller. Illustrated. 320 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $22.50.

title: Corporate Dynamics Complicate the Market
description: SEARS, ROEBUCK & COMPANY's announcement late last year that it was moving its headquarters out of the Sears Tower, putting the building up for sale and even reconsidering the company's commitment to a Chicago location is only one in a growing number of corporate moves with significant implications for commercial real estate.

title: IT GRIPES ME TO SAY THIS
description: I'm with you, Roy (''It Gripes Me to Say This,'' by Roy Blount Jr., April 16). I've been on a nonstop gripe-fest since your article appeared, and there's no telling when I'll stop. My husband has turned a deaf ear, the cats have skittered away, all from my unstoppable grousing. And it feels swell. What a welcome alternative griping would be to Uzis in the schoolyard, mass murder in Sonoma County, disgruntled postal workers picking off folks at McDonald's -not to mention child-beating, wife-beating, husband-beating and the like. A stockbroker in Boston blows away his boss for firing him. Why not try a simple ''I don't like your face!'' It may lead to a fistfight, but assault rifles? Nah.

title: To Save Cathedral: $6.4 Million Drive
description: ELEANOR BETTS has been urging fellow parishioners at Christ Church Cathedral in Hartford to say a special prayer that she wrote each and every day. The prayer begins: ''O God, who gives us a great work to do, give us also joy in the doing. Create in us thankful hearts for the opportunity and responsibility of helping to maintain and restore your holy church.''

title: ByIn 'Crimes of the Heart,' Three Sisters, One Bad Day
description: ''WE'VE got to learn how to get through these really bad days,'' a depressed Meg counsels the despairing Babe in Beth Henley's comedy, ''Crimes of the Heart.''

title: Miss Slusser Has Wedding
description: At St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in New York, Caroline Evelyn Slusser, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Peter Slusser of New York and Windsor, Calif., was married yesterday to Floyd McElroy Converse, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Chandler Bullock Converse of West Palm Beach, Fla. Msgr. Robert L. Charlebois performed the ceremony. The bride's sisters, Sarah Ann Slusser, Wendelin Bruce and Kathleen Mullen, were the maid and matrons of honor. Chandler Bullock Converse Jr. was best man for his brother.

title: Dead Silence on Lebanon
description: The silence is deafening. A reader of Lebanese origin writes to ask why her fellow Americans, so quick to vent outrage at wanton killing elsewhere, manage not to notice the daily rain of heavy artillery on Lebanese homes.

title: Give Only Venture-Capital Gains a Tax Break; Rich Get Even Richer
description: To the Editor:

title: Shoreham: Pressures and Prospects
description: LEAD: ACCORDING to Secretary of Energy James D. Watkins, if the 2.6 million residents of the Island do not rebel soon against the Shoreham plan, they will be ''footing the bill for one of the most foolish deals in the nation's history.''

title: Ben Singer, Guild Leader, 73
description: Ben Singer, president of the United Taxi Owners Guild in the late 1960's and early 1970's, died of lung cancer Tuesday at Delray (Fla.) Community Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Delray Beach.

title:
GARDENING;
Bleeding Hearts and Other Discentras
description: LEAD: THE common bleeding heart is one of those old-fashioned perennials that would have been found in most any flower garden at the turn of the century. A tall plant, reaching two and a half feet, it was just as apt to be planted along the backyard fence as in a flower bed.

title: If the Customer Has an Itch, Scratch It
description: For many companies, the good news is that they have finally managed to improve the quality of their products. The bad news is that their competitors have done the same. As a result, the locus of competition is shifting from quality to something broader: satisfying the customer in every way before, during and after a sale.

title:
IN THE NATION: Memphis;
To Round Out a Downtown Revival, The 300,000-Sq.-Ft. Peabody Place
description: LEAD: THIS city's officials and its commercial leaders are hoping to crown a downtown revitalization effort with a 1.2 million-square-foot, $200 million mixed-use project anchored by the famed Peabody Hotel.

title: POSTINGS: Six Screens on Second; Films For Fillmore East
description: The Beach Boys haven't played the house for a while, and neither have the Allman Brothers or Country Joe McDonald and the Fish. But entertainment finally will be returning to Fillmore East, the East Village theater that was a mecca for jazz and rock fans in the 1960's. The 2,600-seat theater has been closed for two years; indeed, for two decades it has been more dark than open.

title: Judge Drops Hiring Quotas For New York State Police
description: Nearly a decade after imposing strict quotas for the hiring of minorities and women by the New York State police, a Federal judge has lifted his court order and commended the department for its recruitment efforts.

title:
IN THE NEW YORK REGION: New Jersey;
Complex Swap Giving Seton Hall A Bigger Law School in Newark
description: LEAD: FOR the last 13 years, the Seton Hall University Law School has had a four-acre campus in the downtown business district of Newark. Now, through an unusual arrangement with a private developer and the city, it is exchanging a piece of the campus for a income-producing suburban office building and is getting a new and bigger school on the

title: Gooden Off Form; Mets Are Puzzled
description: Dwight Gooden coasts along pitching two-hit ball with 11 strikeouts for eight innings, then suddenly loses it, gives up three hits in a row in the ninth and then both Gooden and his lead are gone. Why? Davey Johnson said yesterday that he had no answer to Friday night's puzzle at Shea Stadium. Gooden was throwing some of his best fastballs in three years. He wasn't tired and he wasn't wild. But three singles in a row, and Johnson went to his bullpen. The Mets, however, booted away the game with three errors in the 12th inning and lost to the San Diego Padres, 4-3.

title: A THUG NO MORE
description: SOPHIATOWN Coming of Age in South Africa. By Don Mattera. 151 pp. Boston: Beacon Press.

title:
IN THE NATION: Cambridge, Mass.;
Rebuilding a Derelict Neighborhood on the Charles
description: LEAD: A DECADE ago, the Lechmere section of this city across the Charles River from Boston was a waterfront neighborhood of industrial derelicts and old homes, many of which were rundown. But in 1978, the city came up with a master plan to redevelop this 84-acre area. Four years later, it started to build a new Lechmere

title: Broadcast Delay
description: To the Editor:

title: Question Of the Week; Should the Yanks Have Traded Leiter?
description: George Steinbrenner's impatience has made his baseball ignorance known to everyone. So Al Leiter didn't become a star in his first season. Why give up on him? Frank Viola was 11-25 after his first two seasons in the big leagues. Pitching is 90 percent of the game and, unfortunately for Yankee fans, George Steinbrenner has proven his inability to grasp this concept. PAUL CASPERSON Hoboken, N.J.

title: FASHION: On the Street; Bringing Back A Proper Trim
description: A starched white collar and cuffs were de rigeur back in great-grandfather's day, and he was no fashion slouch. The proof is still with us, although today's women have taken it in a new direction.

title: Review/Music; Early Birthday Tribute For Ezra Laderman
description: The composer Ezra Laderman had a 65th-birthday party at Merkin Concert Hall last week, nearly two months early. Since his birthday -June 29 - falls too far outside the formal concert season for a performance on the actual date, three string quartets - the Audubon, Colorado and Blair - marked it on Tuesday evening with a concert of Mr. Laderman's recent music offered under the auspices of the Music Today series, with the composer in attendance..

title: Rachel Jacobson Becomes Bride of Robert Kramer
description: Rachel Jacobson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eliot S. Jacobson of Newton, Mass., and Camden, Me., was married last evening in Boston to Robert Michael Kramer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip C. Kramer of Greenwich, Conn., and Delray Beach, Fla. Rabbi Cathy L. Felix performed the ceremony at the Gamble Mansion.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Hull, Mass.;
Housing Sales Hit Roadblock
description: LEAD: THIS popular seaside resort, with 26 miles of shoreline on a hooked peninsula jutting out from the suburban town of Cohasset southeast of Boston, has hit a rocky stretch in its growth as a residential market.

title: I. M. Spinks Wed To Juliette Singer
description: Juliette Lee Singer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen L. Singer of Scarsdale, N.Y., was married yesterday to Ian Michael Spinks, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony M. Spinks of Centerport, L.I. Rabbi David Wolk officiated at the Rye, N.Y., home of Sidney Singer, a grandfather of the bride.

title: Why Exxon's Woes Worry ARCO
description: Lodwrick M. Cook, the Atlantic Richfield Company's chairman and chief executive, had some good news from Alaska a few weeks back. A test well drilled by ARCO at Point McIntyre on the North Slope just two miles from the giant Prudhoe Bay field showed encouraging signs of being a large oil find. ''It's obviously not another Prudhoe,'' Mr. Cook said, ''but it could be a significant commercial discovery.''

title: STREETSCAPES: 780 West End Avenue; Making a Tall Building Taller
description: THE sales office for 780 West End Avenue at 98th Street opened last month and the conversion of the building's 63 apartments into condominiums is under way. ''We bought it because it was so distinctive'' says Glen Siegel, a spokesman for Walter & Samuels, selling agents for the owner.

title: Margot Benedetto Married
description: At St. Vincent Ferrer Roman Catholic Church in Manhattan, Margot Benedetto, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter P. Benedetto of Huntington Bay, L.I., was married yesterday to A. Timothy West, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Chessman West of Hanover, Mass. Msgr. James P. Kelly officiated, assisted by the Rev. Thomas Seaver. Mrs. West is a sales associate with Malo-Cashmere USA in New York. She is a graduate of Providence College, as is her husband. Mr. West is the regional director in Stamford, Conn., of the Pacific Financial Corporation.

title: For a Page Out of Kafka, Legalize Crack
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet Deeds, American Words
description: President Bush finally offered a glimpse of his thinking about Soviet-American relations, and it seems a sensible one. Speaking in Texas on Friday, he wisely called for moving beyond containing Soviet expansionism to ''the integration of the Soviet Union into the community of nations.''

title: Baby Sitters for Creative Artists?
description: To the Editor:

title: A Youthful Subculture on Capitol Hill
description: They call themselves ''Hill people,'' a subculture of the recent college graduates who hold many of the 19,000 staff jobs in the offices of senators, representatives and congressional committees on Capitol Hill. They perform similar jobs, associate with similar friends, frequent the same night spots, survive on the same shoestring budgets and a good many of them are at least toying with the idea of devoting their lives to public service.

title: Is It Time to Redevelop Park Avenue Again?
description: MORE than any other thoroughfare in New York City, Park Avenue has been a street of surprising change. From the first grade-level railroad in 1834, to the sinking of the tracks and construction of middle-class housing after 1875 to the electrification of the railroad and the building of luxurious mansions and then apartments after 1900, the broad boulevard has consistently provided fascinating real estate news for more than a century and a half.

title: Blaik Eulogized At West Point
description: Earl (Red) Blaik, who coached the Army football team to national championships in 1944 and 1945, was eulogized Saturday in a memorial service at West Point.

title: Greenspan Addresses Group On America's Corporate Debt
description: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve, addressed top business executives today on corporate debt and met privately with John S. Reed, chairman of Citicorp, probably to discuss Mexico's debt.

title: Insuring Deposits
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Theater; Bickering Vaudevillians In 'The Sunshine Boys'
description: Among the more audacious ventures in theatrical circles is the revival of a play that, through the medium of film, has gained such popularity that it becomes the standard against which later productions of it are bound to be measured.

title: Magadan's Pinch-Hit Gives Mets Victory
description: Dave Magadan, the denizen of the dugout, sat on the Mets' bench in Shea Stadium yesterday afternoon. He heard the sellout crowd of 46,484 yelling. He saw the San Diego Padres walk Darryl Strawberry on purpose to load the bases with two down in the 11th inning and the score tied at 3-3. And he sensed that Davey Johnson was calling his name.

title: Oliver C. Colburn, Miss Birmingham Marry in Capital
description: Cecily Campbell Birmingham and Oliver Call Colburn were married yesterday at St. John's Church in Lafayette Square in Washington. The Rt. Rev. John T. Walker, the Episcopal Bishop of Washington, and the Rev. Dr. John C. Harper, the rector of St. John's, officiated.

title: Obscure Fairy Tale Becomes A Dramatic Children's Opera
description: OPERA is the thing this spring for children in the county. A symphony orchestra, a music school and even a nature preserve have focused their recent efforts on making this all-inclusive art form accessible to the younger set.

title: Nine Forecasts on What's in Store for the 1990's
description: As the nation ends a decade of fast-paced commercial development - overdevelopment in some areas - it is entering a period in which construction of new offices seems certain to slow down. But what will the 1990's bring?

title: A Comeback in Hard Disks
description: Manufacturers of hard-disk drives for personal computers have watched their stocks hit one new low after another, but now some are recovering. Last fall, Seagate Technology, the largest independent hard-disk company, announced that it had a glut of inventory, cut prices and took a loss, setting off an industry-wide binge of price cutting, losses and layoffs.

title: A Past of Packet Ships and Asia Trade
description: LEAD: NEWBURYPORT, Mass., has a way of making the present seem to fit into a vignette from the past: you can enter the time tunnel and take your pick of destinations. For example, 1929 will get you Fowle's Restaurant and News, an Art Deco relic where the salads are always fresh and the cigars wait silently in their humidors for a change in the social climate; 1835 will get you the granite Custom House and the brick merchant buildings near the waterfront; 1786 will get you several Federal mansions, including the Windsor

title: Coming to Terms With the J-Jitters
description: MY FATHER SAID, ''Don't let your mouth get in front of your mind, that's all.'' It was sage advice, if sometimes difficult for a stutterer to follow. Getting my mouth in front of my mind - words in front of the underlying thoughts - has been a problem for longer than I want to think about, like some threadbare sweater I can't get rid of, can't seem to shake out of my life.

title: Precisionism With Emotion
description: GEORGE AULT (1891-1948) was a Precisionist to the degree that he reduced architectural forms to a geometry inspired by Cubism. But where Charles Sheeler and other Precisionists purged their scenery of all human associations, Ault charged his with emotion.

title: POSTINGS: Renovation at West Point; Privatizing the Hotel Thayer
description: The Hotel Thayer, the famous inn on the grounds of West Point familiar to two generations of cadets and their families as well as countless tourists, will be renovated and probably be substantially enlarged.

title: THE WHITE SHIRT
description: You devoted five pages of your magazine to displaying five white shirts, none of which costs less than $132 (Fashion: ''The White Shirt,'' April 23). I suppose there are some who might pay $560 for a white shirt. The shirt itself is very good-looking. And the price tag may serve to convince them they've bought something stylish and elegant.

title: Speakers With Some Room to Move
description: Loudspeakers with variable patterns of sound radiation are rare. Any newcomer to their ranks is bound to arouse interest - especially if the design is musically competent and notably cheap.

title: Correction
description: An article in the Long Island Weekly on April 23 misstated the amount of money the Montauk Historical Society spent last year on an erosion project at the Montauk Point Lighthouse. The organization spent $7,000.

title:
DANCE;
A Celebration For Ailey
description: LEAD: MENTION the name Alvin Ailey, and the mind produces images of rousing movement exploding across a stage. The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, with a recognition factor that probably equals that of any dance company in the world, is celebrating its 30th anniversary with a national tour that includes six performances in New Jersey starting tomorrow.

title: Man Held in Wife's Slaying
description: A New York City subway motorman has been charged with second-degree murder in the shooting death of his estranged wife at her Long Island home, police said today. The Transit Authority motorman, Melvin Flood, 52 years old, argued at 10:45 P.M. Friday with 45-year-old Ruthie Flood at her home and shot her several times with a .38-caliber revolver, said Detective Sgt. Dennis Barry of the Nassau County Homicide Squad. Mrs. Flood, a cafeteria worker at Westbury High School, died at 11:25 P.M. at Mercy Hospital, Detective Barry said. Mr. Flood lives in Freeport.

title: A June Wedding For Bruce Cohen And Sarah Foote
description: Dr. and Mrs. Paul Richard Foote of Seneca Falls, N.Y., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Sarah Foote and Bruce Cohen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Cohen of Manalapan, N.J.

title: Van Slyke Is Back
description: Almost a month after he suffered a pulled rib-cage muscle, Andy Van Slyke, the Pirate outfielder, has been reactivated from the disabled list. Even so, he is not expected to return to the starting lineup for several days, in part because of a spell of cold weather that has slowed his recovery.

title: Boat People Defy Hong Kong 'Keep Out' Sign
description: Vietnamese boat people, ignoring a harsh new refugee policy adopted to discourage them from coming to Hong Kong, are pouring into the colony at a rate of 2,000 a week, the largest influx in a decade.

title: Anxiety Over the Science Police
description: CONGRESS, which approves billions of dollars for research, is so worried about possible scientific fraud that it recently brought the Secret Service into an investigation of one research project to examine the laboratory notebooks. But scientists, who spend the money on projects aimed at maintaining the nation's technological leadership, are worried about Congress intruding into their work.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Brattleboro, Vt.;
Renewed Hope In a Poor Area
description: LEAD: THE Brattleboro Area Community Land Trust, which has saved 14 apartments from the wrecking ball, is helping to preserve a low-income neighborhood at the south end of this city's bustling downtown.

title: Charter Panel Agrees on Planning Commission Role
description: The panel rewriting the New York City Charter proposed yesterday that members of a new City Planning Commission be appointed to serve full time for a single five-year term and agreed that the body should have the central role in controlling the use of land.

title: The Divas of Soul and Disco, With All Due R-E-S-P-E-C-T
description: In the years since Donna Summer and Aretha Franklin came to define whole schools of popular music and culture, the women of black radio have become the most competitive and, within their conservative limits, one of the most resourceful circles in contemporary music. Jody Watley, Anita Baker, Janet Jackson, Whitney Houston, Paula Abdul, Pebbles and a growing handful of others vie for producers, sounds, attitudes and chart positions.

title: Productivity's Little Secret: Hard Work
description: America's fall from grace - this anguish-producing subject - has been given intense scrutiny over the last 15 years. The primary lesson learned is that America cannot rule by technological ingenuity alone. But what has not been learned is that Americans must work and study harder to compete.

title:
Parsippany-Troy Hills Journal;
Neighbors Wary on Plan for Jail Near Mental Hospital
description: LEAD: ON a typical day, members of the staff at the state-run Greystone Park Psychiatric Hospital here report that at least one of the approximately 750 patients has walked off its 1,100-acre grounds.

title: Glenn Davis Is Applauded
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
DINING OUT;
Thai Cuisine Arrives in Mamaroneck
description: LEAD: A WELCOME arrival, Bangkok is the most recent addition to the area's fast-growing number of Thai restaurants. Rapidly becoming the cuisine of choice for those diners eager to escape the current Hunan-Sichuan culinary glut and rut, Thai food is at once exotic enough to be interesting and familiar enough to be comforting.

title: Rustic Comfort: Adirondack Furniture
description: AROUND the turn of the century, Adirondack guides and ''great camp'' caretakers whiled away winters fashioning chairs and tables out of logs and branches.

title: DATA UPDATE: May 14, 1989
Recycling or Incineration? Actually, We Need Them Both
description: THE issue of recycling versus incineration, to manage New Jersey's solid-waste crisis, is the focus of great controversy. To date, these solutions have been viewed as black or white - either we recycle or incinerate, and passionate arguments have been presented for each position.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: JANIS M. BEITZER;
Managing the Midtown Bus Terminal
description: LEAD: EVERY day, 200,000 commuters - most of them New Jerseyans - on 6,800 buses pass through the Port Authority Bus Terminal, at Eighth Avenue and 41st Street in Manhattan, on their way to and from work, making it the busiest bus terminal in the nation.

title: Reviews/Music; A Mystic Pays Homage to Dead Avant-Gardists of the 60's
description: La Monte Young has a deserved reputation as a musical mystic, arrayed in Indian garb and presenting periodic concerts in hieratic settings of his grandiosely protracted compositions. But he is also of this world, a hard-working promoter of his own works and, perhaps even more laudably, of others'.

title: In Search of A Better Law To Clear the Air
description: AFTER more than a decade of legislative deadlock, Congress and the White House may finally come to terms this year on an important revision of the Clean Air Act, a path-breaking but imperfect law enacted almost 20 years ago with the goal of sweeping pollution from the sky.

title: Plan to Raze Housing Irks Homeless
description: IN a city where shelters for the homeless are full and more than 6,000 families are waiting to get into public housing, the Jersey City Housing Authority is proposing the demolition of 312 apartments, with alternative housing to be provided at a cost of $32 million.

title: CRUSADER ON THE CHARLES
description: As a Boston University student (1971-75) and a writer in the publicity office there (1980-83), I have seen John Silber up close.

title: Baker Treated To Quickstep By Gorbachev
description: In the body language of internationial diplomacy their eyes and gestures spoke volumes.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: STRANGE GROUND. Americans in Vietnam, 1945-1975: An Oral History. By Harry Maurer. (Holt, $29.95.) An antiwar demonstrator who feigned a character disorder to avoid being drafted, Harry Maurer, who is currently on the staff of Business Week, has compiled a powerful chronicle of what is perhaps the most critically dissected American conflict of this century.

title: John Corrigan Jr. Wed To Kathleen Sullivan
description: Kathleen Mary Sullivan and John Joseph Corrigan Jr. were married yesterday at St. Francis de Sales Roman Catholic Church in Charlestown, Mass., by the Rev. Daniel J. Mahoney.

title: HOSPICE HELP
description: LEAD: THE more than 500 riders in this week's horse show at the Old Salem Farm in North Salem have made the checks for the entry fees payable to Hospice of the District Nursing Association of Northern Westchester County. The hospice program offers at-home care for terminally ill patients in northern Westchester and Putnam County, under the direction of the nursing association in Mount Kisco.

title: Wotan, Key To a 'Ring' In One Act
description: I know i am probably alone in this, but there are a few things in the ''Ring'' that I still do not understand, even after a season in which the Metropolitan Opera has considered the subject in rare detail. I am not talking about peripheral questions, like why Siegfried is vulnerable only to a spear in the back. Answers to those, as you probably have discovered for yourself, can be deduced from a close reading of the ''Nibelungenlied'' and the Norse Eddas. Some mysteries are also cleared up in Wagnerian scriptures such as Cosima's diaries and the librettos themselves.

title: CORRECTION
description: A caption on page 15 last Sunday with an article about Satyajit Ray misidentified the actor shown with the film maker. He is Subhendu Chatterjee.

title: Pamela Crimmins Becomes a Bride
description: The marriage of Pamela Lee Crimmins, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kevin Bates Crimmins of Noroton, Conn., to Carl Lawrence Gable, a son of Mrs. Carl Everett Gable of Twelve Mile, Ind., and the late Mr. Gable, took place yesterday at St. Vincent de Paul Roman Catholic Church in New York. The Rev. Michael Crimmins, a cousin of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: Miss Melchior, a Producer, Weds David Webster Ray
description: Katherine Sabin Melchior, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Kurt Werner Melchior of San Francisco, was married aboard the City of San Francisco, a motor launch, in San Francisco Bay yesterday to David Webster Ray, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Reginald Webster Ray Jr. of Westport, Conn. Judge Isabella Grant of San Francisco Superior Court officiated.

title: One-Act Plays on Weighty Themes
description: ''WHAT are all those new plays about?'' an observer of New Jersey's theater season is often asked. A visit to the Renegade Theater Company's fourth annual One-Act Play Festival, which lasts through next Sunday, prompts a weighty four-part reply: the roots of violence, the essence of manhood, the destructibility of civilizations and the collapse of the family.

title: CRUSADER ON THE CHARLES
description: At a time when the Oliver North trial again demonstrates the disdain that Presidents and members of the executive branch have for Congress and democracy, it is maybe not surprising that you should feature, as an educator, a university president who has complete disdain for students and faculty (''Crusader on the Charles,'' by Helen Epstein, April 23).

title: CHINA PARTY CHIEF APPEARS TO GAIN IN POWER STRUGGLE
description: An unannounced Politburo meeting has endorsed the moderate line of the Communist Party leader, Zhao Ziyang, toward student demonstrators, including more discussions with the students and limited steps toward greater democracy, Chinese with high party connections say.

title: To the Airport
description: To the Editor: The directory of ways to get to New York area airports (Travel Advisory, March 12) omitted two of the quickest and least expensive. To La Guardia, several subway lines, including the E, F, R and 7, run to Roosevelt Avenue or 74th Street-Jackson Heights, an interconnected station, from which the Q-33 bus goes to all La Guardia terminals except the Marine Terminal (Pan Am shuttle). Cost: $2. To Newark, the PATH trains from 33d Street and the World Trade Center to Penn Station Newark connect to the Airlink to the airport, for only slightly more than half the cost of express bus service.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: CHATTERTON, by Peter Ackroyd. (Ballantine, $8.95.) Keats wrote a sonnet to Thomas Chatterton, the young and unappreciated poet who killed himself in 1770 at the age of 17. Peter Ackroyd has made him a character in a story that takes place over three centuries and the result is ''a wonderfully vivid book,'' Denis Donoghue said here last year. SOMEONE WAS HERE: Profiles in the AIDS Epidemic, by George Whitmore. (Plume/New American Library, $8.95.) George Whitmore, the playwright and novelist, tells three true stories about victims of the AIDS virus. One is about a gay couple in Greenwich Village, one is about a Mexican-American mother who goes to San Francisco to bring her son home to Colorado to die, and one is about a hospital in the Bronx that treats infected drug addicts and their families. ''At their best, these snapshots give us crisp, sharp, well-focused glimpses of an almost impossibly large tragedy and help us begin to understand the disease,'' Stephen S. Hall said here last year. Mr. Whitmore died of AIDS on April 19. He was 43. MAMA DAY, by Gloria Naylor. (Vintage Contemporaries, $8.95.) On an isolated island off the coast of Georgia, a black matriarch named Mama Day exercises her magical powers. ''Gloria Naylor has written a big, strong, dense, admirable novel; spacious, sometimes a little drafty like all public monuments, designed to last and intended for many levels of use,'' Bharati Mukherjee said in The Book Review last year. THE LAST INTELLECTUALS: American Culture in the Age of Academe, by Russell Jacoby. (Noonday/ Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $9.95.) What, Russell Jacoby asks, ever happened to the likes of Edmund Wilson, Lewis Mumford and Malcolm Cowley? Instead of a new generation of versatile public intellectuals, we have specialists more interested in tenure and academic politics than in speaking to our cultural woes. Last year The Times's Christopher Lehmann-Haupt called this book narrow but absorbing. DALVA, by Jim Harrison. (Washington Square/ Pocket Books, $7.95.) In search of her lost illegitimate son, a middle-aged white woman leaves California for Nebraska and the land of the Sioux. ''The people in 'Dalva' emerge as full-blooded individuals, who almost incidentally embody much of the innocence, carelessness and urgency that played so large a part in the settling of this country,'' Michiko Kakutani said in The Times last year. ''Best of all, perhaps, are Mr. Harrison's descriptions of the land - the untamed deserts, plains, forests and arroyos of what was once the Western frontier.'' She said it is his best book since LEGENDS OF THE FALL, a collection of three novellas about revenge, which is being republished by Seymour Lawrence/Delta ($8.95). Delta is also reissuing four of Jim Harrison's novels, WOLF: A False Memoir, WARLOCK, A GOOD DAY TO DIE and FARMER, as well as his SELECTED AND NEW POEMS ($8.95 each). THE PEACEABLE KINGDOM: A Year in the Life of America's Oldest Zoo, by John Sedgwick. (Fawcett, $4.95.) For the good part of a year John Sedgwick observed the curious interactions between people and animals at the Philadelphia Zoo. Last year our reviewer, Harriet Ritvo, said the book is engaging and contains a ''wealth of fascinating anecdotes.'' AFTER DELORES, by Sarah Schulman. (Plume/New American Library, $7.95.) When her would-be lover Punkette, a go-go dancer in New Jersey, is murdered, the waitress who stars in this novel seeks the killer among the lesbian subculture of Manhattan's Lower East Side. Last year our reviewer, Kinky Friedman, said ''the book is as raw as fresh-shucked oysters and redolent with ragged charm. . . . Ms. Schulman writes with a stumbling grace, and she looks at the world from a fragile, refreshingly jaded angle.'' THE PRESENT AGE: Progress and Anarchy in Modern America, by Robert Nisbet. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $7.95.) The author believes that if the Founding Fathers were alive today they would be appalled by rampant militarism, big government and our decaying, materialistic culture. Robert Nisbet's arguments are forceful and eloquent but sometimes overstated, Richard Caplan said here last year. ''E'' IS FOR EVIDENCE, by Sue Grafton. (Bantam, $3.95.) Kinsey Millhone, the female sleuth in Sue Grafton's novel (there are four others, including '' 'D' Is for Deadbeat''), is framed when she investigates a fire in the Southern California town where she works as a private eye. This is ''the best detective fiction I have read in years,'' Vincent Patrick said in The Book Review in 1988. ELIA KAZAN: A Life, by Elia Kazan. (Anchor/Doubleday, $12.95.) Among the director Elia Kazan's movies are ''On the Waterfront,'' ''Viva Zapata,'' ''East of Eden'' and ''Splendor in the Grass.'' In this autobiography, which includes the story of his decision to name names before Senator Joseph McCarthy's House Un-American Activities Committee, is ''an indispensable account of American theater and film in our time and the impassioned testament of an artist who has done his valiant best to tell the truth about himself,'' Arthur Schlesinger Jr. said here last year. DOMESTIC REVOLUTIONS: A Social History of American Family Life, by Steven Mintz and Susan Kellogg. (Free Press, $11.95.) Americans have bemoaned the decline of the family for three and a half centuries, but there is no sign that this resilient institution is going to fade away. ''In 'Domestic Revolutions' we see, in fresh detail, just how the family has adapted to the stress of unprecedented change and how it has endured,'' Glenn Collins said here in 1988.

title: JoAnn Coleman Weds Neil Novikoff, Lawyer
description: JoAnn Coleman and Neil Novikoff were married last evening at the Helmsley Palace Hotel in New York by Judge Richard Owen of Federal District Court in Manhattan.

title: New Pain on Top of Little Rock's Old Weariness
description: Thirty-two years after Federal troops were summoned to integrate Central High School here, a demoralizing, seemingly endless battle is being fought with renewed intensity over the Little Rock schools.

title: The Three Sisters
description: THE PLANS ARE THUS: ON JULY 4, 1992, surrounded by an international armada of Tall Ships, a replica of Christopher Columbus's tiny fleet - comprising the Nina, the Pinta and the Santa Maria - will arrive in New York Harbor, commencing the party of the half-millennium. In celebration of the quincentennial of Columbus's first trans-Atlantic voyage from Iberia to the New World, the ships will stop in the Bahamas at San Salvador, now Watlings Island, the probable site of Columbus's first landing. (Historically, of course, this is in dispute.) There will be a reception for the boats in Santo Domingo. Then they will sail on to ports on the Eastern Seaboard, concluding with New York.

title: Opposition in Panama Urges Wide Strike to Rout Noriega
description: Struggling to devise new tactics in the face of increasing Government repression, the opposition to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega called today for a general strike starting on Wednesday.

title: Correction
description: A listing of new members of the National Academy of Sciences on April 30 misidentified one and omitted another. They are Ahmed H. Zewail, professor of chemical physics at the California Institute of Technology, and Donald B. Zilversmit, professor, section of biochemistry and molecular and cell biology, Cornell University, and career investigator for the American Heart Association.

title: Struggling to Hook Shoppers - and Keep Them
description: Catalogue Retailers face a test of wits.

title: 'Moyers: A Second Look' - More Than Meets the Eye
description: At one point in ''Cowboys,'' a documentary produced in 1976 (as part of ''Bill Moyers's Journal'') about the difficult but rewarding life of cowboys in northwestern Colorado, one of the subjects says, ''All we can know is our own time.'' For Bill Moyers, one of the most celebrated and at times controversial producers of documentary films, it is a key phrase: ''That is what compels me as a journalist, to know as much as I can of my own time.''

title: Correction
description: An article by The Associated Press on April 23 about a proposal to administer drugs to a criminal defendant misstated benefits of the drug Cogentin in countering possible side effects of anti-psychotic drugs. Cogentin can alleviate drooling and involuntary muscle movements, but can cause mouth dryness and blurring of vision and can aggravate a condition called angle-closure glaucoma.

title: Apoogies and Free Pizza After Racial Message Mix-Up
description: LAST Saturday, David Newell, the manager of Domino's Pizza in Ansonia, opened hop at 1 P.M., a few hours earlier than usual. He washed his hands, then carried out vats of tomato sauce, shredded mozzarella and trays of pizza dough from the walk-in refrigerator.

title: Guidelines for Marine Species
description: A better way to administer the management of marine fishes will have to be developed if the depletion of various species is not to continue, according to the Sport Fishing Institute.

title: A.C.L.U. Studies Its Image and Finds It Intact
description: To hear the American Civil Liberties Union tell it, all is well with its image, and George Bush's attacks in the 1988 Presidential campaign hardly made a dent.

title: Question Of the Week; Should the Yanks Have Traded Leiter?
description: If the Yanks were set on getting rid of their top pitching prospect, they should have dealt him for someone they needed: a third baseman. What happens when Mel Hall comes off the disabled list? And when Dave Winfield returns?

title: CRUSADER ON THE CHARLES
description: Irony fairly leaps from the page when you call John Silber a ''crusader.''

title: At the Beach, Jungle Prints Prowl and Colors Dazzle
description: Animal prints. Bright colors. Bikinis. Pareus. Sheer fabrics. Beach dresses. Polka dots. Molded bras. Neoprene. Want to be in fashion at the seaside this summer? Wear suntan lotion, a big straw hat and at least one of the above.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Susan Willet Bird was having a business dinner with a man recently. The waiter came over with the check and, although she hadn't asked for it, he placed it in front of her.

title: Article 734189 -- No Title
description: THE MIDNIGHT EXAMINER By William Kotzwinkle. 227 pp. Boston: Seymour Lawrence/ Houghton Mifflin. $17.95.

title: Stacy M. Schiff, An Editor, Weds
description: Stacy Madeleine Schiff and Marc de La Bruyere were married yesterday at the Blantyre, an inn in Lenox, Mass. Judge Charles R. Alberti of Massachusetts Superior Court officiated.

title: Pet Wolf Mauls a 3-Year-Old
description: A 3-year-old Staten Island boy was seriously wounded yesterday when a wolf kept in the family's backyard attacked him, the police reported.

title: TRAVEL BOOKSHELF
description: LEAD: Bantam Travel Guides Italy; 464 pages, $13.95. London; 272 pages, $8.95. Australia; 384 pages, $13.95. Great Britain; 544 pages, $13.95. Bantam Quick and Easy Guides London; 136 pages, $4.95. Washington; 136 pages, $4.95. Rome; 136 pages, $4.95.

title: Luxury of Apartheid
description: For the first nine months of his two years in detention, Zwelakhe Sisulu was in solitary confinement. All he was given to read was the Bible - in Afrikaans, a language he cannot read.

title: ''Choice'' Schools Isn't the Whole Answer
description: ''Move for Parental Choice in School Gains'' (April 16) seems to favor Gov. Thomas H. Kean's simplistic approach to improve the quality of education in New Jersey. Permit the parent of a child to have a choice of the school the child will attend, and educationally the child will succeed.

title: Cautious Optimism in Shore Pollution Fight
description: AS the days get warmer and schools of mackerel end their spring run up the New Jersey coast, state officials are hopeful that new laws and programs put in place since last year to reduce coastal pollution will make this summer a better one than the last three. But researchers and environmentalists remain cautious about how to address the long-term underlying causes of coastal pollution.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Asbestos Legislation; Mandating Inspections in New York City
description: THE New York City Council is considering a bill that would mandate inspections for asbestos in all buildings throughout the city.

title: In Shoreham War, Truth Is a Casualty
description: It has been said that the truth is the first casualty in a war. The same thing can be said of the protracted struggle over the Shoreham nuclear power plant and its grotesque denouement.

title: Figurative Allusion: Anniversary Show Of Robust Drawings
description: ''FIGURATIVELY SPEAKING'' is an apt title because the Neuberger Museum show that it designates is of drawings that allude to the figure rathern than describe it. The show itself, however, implies nothing if not commitment - by the seven artists represented and by its curator, Nancy Miller, who is also the museum's acting director.

title: BUSH HARDENS LINE ON NORIEGA OUSTER
description: Putting aside his usually cautious demeanor, President Bush today urged the people and military of Panama to overthrow Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My house has an unfinished attic that I can walk into. I use the attic frequently, but in summer the temperature climbs so high it is difficult to stay long. The attic floor is insulated with a layer of vermiculite, covered with a thick layer of fiberglass without a paper backing. This seems adequate to prevent heat filtering into the rooms below. To reduce the temperature inside the attic, I want to install fiberglass between the rafters. Should I use blankets with or without a paper facing? If the kind with a facing is best, which way should it face?

title: Ice Age Re-enacted At Glacier Bay, Alaska
description: LEAD: THE native peoples, who had the area to themselves for centuries, and who describe it today by saying ''God dwells here,'' never even knew it was there. The Russians established their provincial capital just 100 miles away at Sitka, but their nautical explorer Vitus Bering missed it in his forays in the 1740's.

title: Correction
description: A map on April 30 with an article about Salzburg mislabeled the country adjoining Austria, West Germany and Italy. It was Switzerland.

title: Lisa Becker Plans To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Ewing Becker of New Canaan, Conn., and Naples, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lisa Courtney Becker to Peter Seabury Adam, a son of Sydney C. Adam of New Canaan and the late Peter J. C. Adam. A June wedding is planned.

title: Using Scaffolding Instead of Ladders
description: FOR projects like house painting and installing new siding, scaffolding obtained from a rental center is easy and safe to use, and more efficient than ladders. Units are constructed from pairs of end frames linked by braces and covered by planks or platforms on which to stand. Joining units vertically creates a tower; joining them side by side creates a run.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: BRATTLEBORO, VT.;
Renewed Hope In a Poor Area
description: LEAD: THE Brattleboro Area Community Land Trust, which has saved 14 apartments from the wrecking ball, is helping to preserve a low-income neighborhood at the south end of this city's bustling downtown.

title: Parade Today
description: The Cuban Day parade starts at noon at 44th Street and the Avenue of the Americas, moving north to Central Park South, then west to Columbus Circle.

title:
ART;
Even If Distorted, Figure Still Has Power
description: LEAD: IN one of the coincidences that often seem to occur in the art world when something is in the air, the Smithtown Arts Council's gallery at Mills Pond House in St. James is presenting ''Figuratively Speaking,'' an exhibition that nicely complements the show of figure drawings now on view at the East Hampton Center for Contemporary Art.

title: Shifting Policy, Koch Will Begin New Measures to Deal With AIDS
description: In a major shift in policy, Mayor Edward I. Koch will announce today new initiatives for dealing with the AIDS crisis.

title: Helping the Poor With Legal Aid
description: Your article on the work of Nassau-Suffolk Law Services [ ''Legal-Aid Project Strives to Help Poor,'' April 2 ] managed to capture the enthusiasm and dedication of Victor Ambrose, who manages a burgeoning case load in the face of escalating costs and proportionately decreasing staff.

title: 2 New Indy Tapes On Different Paths
description: As with most sports in the home-video era, the approach of a big auto racing event brings highlight tapes onto the market.

title: Question Of the Week; Should the Yanks Have Traded Leiter?
description: Al Leiter has proven he talks a good game and nothing more. The Yankees needed Jesse Barfield's run-producing bat to protect the franchise, Don Mattingly. The gloom-and-doom prophets in the news media, who are openly rooting for Barfield to fail, can no more guarantee that Leiter is the next Sandy Koufax or guarantee that Barfield won't annually hit 30 plus homers and 100 plus r.b.i. for the next five years. MICHELLE HUMPHRIES New York

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
Attending a Wake at Forest Hills
description: LEAD: Last Monday afternoon I sat in Portal 2 high above the south baseline in the stadium at Forest Hills and watched Ivan Lendl destroy Jaime Yzaga in the final of the ill-fated Tournament of Champions.

title: When Dissidents Are Free, What Are They?
description: NOT so long ago, ''dissident'' was a widely used term whose meaning was obvious. As he spoke out on injustice from his banishment in Gorky in the Soviet Union, Andrei D. Sakharov was certainly a dissident. In Poland, Adam Michnik and Jacek Kuron were clearly dissidents as they condemned a system that retaliated by jailing them or keeping them out of work.

title: A July Wedding for Jana Strauss
description: July wedding plans for Jana Strauss and David E. Kleiser, a son of Dr. and Mrs. John R. Kleiser of Rosemont, Pa., have been announced by her parents, Joanne Strauss of Galveston, Tex., and Henry J. Strauss of Wimberley, Tex.
