title: Bosses, Embrace Your Workers!
description: The work ethic - producing goods and services through long hours of hard work - is no longer serving America well. The reason is that the work enviroment found in most American companies discourages people from working from the heart - from caring about the job they do and the people with whom they work. As a result, the work environment - the way we manage and define our jobs - discourages what we used to call ''labors of love.''

title: Effort to Discredit Wedtech Witness
description: The defense lawyers in the racketeering trial of E. Robert Wallach and two others sought last week to discredit the testimony of the prosecution's lead witness, who said the defendants had participated in crimes as consultants to the Wedtech Corporation.

title: See You in the Funny Papers
description: NOONTIME at the Elks Lodge in Huntington found Pat Marano munching on a tuna on rye, enjoying her luncheon date with Sally Seekamp, while a few feet away a group of men and women in gold sweatshirts emblazoned with the comic strip character Smitty were telling one-liners faster than Henny Youngman.

title: Crime and Punishment
description: In 1973, John P. Mack, then 19 years old, worked at a home furnishings store in a Virginia suburb of Washington. As he later confessed, Mr. Mack attacked a 20-year-old woman, Pamela Small, pounding her skull with a hammer and slashing her. He served 27 months in jail before being released to a clerk's job in the office of Representative Jim Wright of Texas. Mr. Wright's daughter was married to Mr. Mack's brother. The crime was not a secret on Capitol Hill, but when The Washington Post resurrected the story, it caused a furor and more trouble for Mr. Wright, the House Speaker, whose financial dealings are under investigation. Last week, Mr. Mack resigned from his current job as the Speaker's top political and legislative aide. ''I wish I could rewrite the past,'' he said, ''but unfortunately I can't.''

title: A Plea by Nicaragua's Indians
description: LEAD: With the signing of the most recent agreement by Central American presidents and the U.S. bipartisan accord on Nicaragua, this is an opportune moment for the Indian people of Nicaragua to return to their homelands on the Atlantic coast. We are pleased that the Nicaraguan Government at last seems ready to discuss our demands seriously.

title: Riding Gear for Paddock or Park Ave.
description: Not since Mr. Ed, the talking horse, wore hats - not all the time, but he wore them - has horse haberdashery had more of an audience. Horse wear showed up in nearly a dozen fall collections, reflecting either fashion's collective unconscious or a sudden surge in the equestrian passion.

title: Guilford Marks Its 350th With Old and New Crafts
description: CHISELS with handmade wooden handles, a wreath of human hair, a porcelain sink and a cedar canoe are among the items displayed in the gallery of the Guilford Handcrafts Center. The items were all handcrafted by Guilford residents and are part of ''Tri-and-a-Half Crafts,'' a show that celebrates the town's 350th anniversary.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: TriBeCa
description: ON a recent Sunday evening at TriBeCa's Odeon, a young couple, both dressed in black on black and wearing short, asymmetrical hair styles, lingered over their profiterolles and brewed decaf. He denounced the work of an artist as deconstructionist drivel; she railed against the ''esthetic hegemony'' of a gallery owner.

title:
PASTIMES: Gardening;
Herbs to Grow in Small Spaces
description: LEAD: While venturing out to the specialty herb nurseries for my annual supply of herbs my husband's demands rang in my ears, ''Our garden is small and there is limited space for the herbs. Be selective and only get the ones we use often.''

title: FICTION
description: THE GODCHILD. By Stephen Alter. (Andre Deutsch/David & Charles, $19.95.) Tricia, abandoned by her teen-age mother at a mission hospital in India, has been raised by adoptive parents in suburban Connecticut. Now, at the age of 20, she has returned to her native land, hoping to find Mamta, the mysterious tribal woman who she believes is her mother. In the process, she hopes to learn something about her own identity as well. Among the people she meets is Gautam, an angry young Indian trying to solve his own dual identity problems by abandoning Christianity for an idiosyncratic brand of communism. Mamta, the focus of their search, is an elusive, fascinating figure, a victim but also a proud survivor of the cruelest poverty. And it is her presence that unifies this skillfully plotted novel, with its rich variety of characters and voices. Mamta comes to life gradually, recalled in sorrow by the missionaries who cared for her, evoked with longing by the Indian man who loved her. When Tricia finally arrives at Mamta's ramshackle village, she finds she must learn to communicate with this woman in ways that transcend their two cultures. Stephen Alter, an American who has spent almost all his life in India, is at his best when evoking the mystery and complexity of that country. Though he sometimes makes the American missionaries too good to be true, he renders the singular world of the Indian Christian community with absolute authority. There is no colonial or neo-colonial condescension to be found in ''The Godchild,'' his third novel. Stephen Alter's vision is both unsparingly realistic and compassionate. He is a sensitive observer with an unusual ability to see a foreign culture from the inside out, making its people alive and compelling to Western readers.

title: Suzanne R. Lynde Is Wed To William F. Maguire 3d
description: Suzanne Russell Lynde and William Francis Maguire 3d were married yesterday at the Ralph Waldo Emerson Inn in Rockport, Mass., by the Rev. Donald A. Wells, a United Church of Christ minister.

title:
MUSIC;
Princeton Bach Festival Expands
description: LEAD: THE Princeton Bach Festival was created eight years ago with a clear philosophy concerning the musical relationship between the church and the community. Returning in a slightly expanded format this season, the festival, organized by Kenneth B. Kelley, director of music at the Nassau Presbyterian Church, will offer a major choral work by Bach, several shorter works, performance opportunities for youngsters and a collaboration between New Jersey and

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: HE'S A REBEL. By Mark Ribowsky. (Dutton, $18.95.) Though commercially inactive and nearly 50 years old, Phil Spector has earned a place in rock history for the songs he wrote and produced from the late 1950's to the mid-1960's. His work with the Crystals, the Ronettes and other ''girl groups'' defined the acne eroticism of such songs as ''He's a Rebel'' and ''Be My Baby.

title: Ileanna Tsarnas, Planner, Is Wed
description: At the Greek Orthodox Cathedral of St. Paul in Hempstead, L.I., Ileanna Tsarnas, a daughter of Capt. and Mrs. Elias L. Tsarnas of New York and Clearwater, Fla., was married yesterday to Dr. Thomas William Pappas, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Pappas of Merrick, L.I. The Rev. Nicholas Magoulias and the Rev. Joakim Valasiadis officiated. The bride, the deputy assistant commissioner of planning at the New York City Department of Transportation, graduated cum laude from Barnard College and received a master's degree in economic geography at Columbia University. Her father retired as a captain in the United States merchant marine.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: The Hollybush Festival in Glassboro will present a bouquet of flowers and an elegant boxed lunch (poached lemon chicken breast or seafood and shell pasta) to mothers who hold special tickets for this afternoon's performance of ''The Merry Widow.''

title: Held to Tie, U.S. Misses a Big Point
description: Long after disconsolate American fans had filed out of Murdock Stadium on the El Camino College campus today, the drums and cowbells were still beating out their rhythms in the stands.

title: Red Lobster Blues
description: To the Editor:

title: Noriega Isn't Giving In, To Panama or to Bush
description: THE people of Panama have learned to expect naked displays of power and force from Gen.

title: Kremlin Offers to Destroy Disputed Siberian Radar
description: The Soviet Union has informed the United States that it is prepared to totally dismantle a long-disputed radar in Siberia if the United States agrees to a strict interpretation of the 1972 Antiballistic Missile Treaty, according to Bush Administration officials.

title: Mothers, Babies and Crack
description: What better day than Mother's Day to think about the thousands of babies born this year that won't be going home to festooned bassinets and fancy strollers? Instead they will be tethered to tubes in intensive care units, and some eventually turned over to foster care.

title: Search for Compromise on Davids Island
description: LEAD: IF anything, the art of compromise, not the art of the deal, may ultimately get a small ''city'' of condominiums built on Davids Island off coast here.

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
Role-Players Training Budding Agents
description: LEAD: STEFAN and Dana are a married couple considering buying a house they have looked at in Westchester. But they are angry that the owners have removed some items they thought were part of the deal, such as a fancy chandelier. Dave, a real estate agent involved in the transaction, is listening to their complaints.

title: THE COUNT OF ROWAN OAK
description: LEAD: WILLIAM FAULKNER: AMERICAN WRITER A Biography. By Frederick R. Karl. Illustrated. 1,131 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $37.50.

title: CRUSADER ON THE CHARLES
description: It is always disappointing to read about John Silber's continuing authoritarian rule of my alma mater, Boston University (College of Liberal Arts, 1972).

title: Important Testimony
description: To the Editor:

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Itinerant Therapy What if psychotherapy were to come out of the closet and walk around in the world with the patient, like two peripatetic philosophers? This is how Max, the hero of Sara Vogan's novel ''Loss of Flight'' (Bantam), sees his patients.

title: Jack Grace to Wed Sherri A. Lipton
description: Dr. and Mrs. Lester Lipton of New York have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Sherri Alexandra Lipton and John Rovensky Grace, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert M. Grace of Palm Beach, Fla., and Newport, R.I.

title: Robin Beth Gold Weds
description: Robin Beth Gold and Paul N. Hoffmann were married in New York last evening at the Pierre by Rabbi Michael Levenson. Mrs. Hoffman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Laurence J. Gold of Brooklyn, graduated from New York University. She is an owner of Tocco D'oro, a boutique in Lawrence, L.I. Mr. Hoffman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David N. Hoffmann of Livonia, Mich., is a vice president and a partner with his brother of Matthew C. Hoffmann Jewelry Design, with stores in Ann Arbor, Mich., and Manhattan.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My house has an unfinished attic that I can walk into. I use the attic frequently, but in summer the temperature climbs so high it is difficult to stay long. The attic floor is insulated with a layer of vermiculite, covered with a thick layer of fiberglass without a paper backing. This seems adequate to prevent heat filtering into the rooms below. To reduce the temperature inside the attic, I want to install fiberglass between the rafters. Should I use blankets with or without a paper facing? If the kind with a facing is best, which way should it face?

title: STORMING MONTANA'S WILDERNESS
description: If we don't produce the minerals and energy we require from domestic sources, our only alternative is to get them from abroad, primarily from underdeveloped countries where few safeguards are applied to resource development. The wilderness advocate is having an ''esthetic experience'' in our forests, but he might ponder the morality of having this burden borne by people who live on a subsistence level.

title: Florida
description: To the Editor: I thoroughly enjoyed the article about Sarasota and its keys, but there was one misconception that needs clarification, especially for readers who may be traveling to Siesta Key.

title: Amid Horrors, Sri Lankans Scrape to Stay Alive
description: By the time Col. Cyril Ratanayake was sent to this guerrilla free-fire zone to set up some semblance of public services, it was too late to talk about winning hearts and minds.

title: POSTINGS: Newark Strip Shopping; Three Downtown Projects
description: Ground will be broken May 23 for the third retail development in downtown Newark to be started this year, a 54,000-square-foot strip shopping center at West Market Street and 12th Avenue, adjacent to the University of Medicine and Dentistry's University Hospital. The $5.5 million center, with 33 stores and restaurants, is to be Newark's largest minority-owned and -developed retail project. Cecil H. Sanders Jr., president of the C. H. Sanders Construction Company of Newark, is the principal developer in partnership with the Harsen and Johns Development Company of Rochelle Park, N.J.

title: At a Workshop, Only the Verse Is Free
description: WE pull up in Lenny's hot-mufflered car, park by the yard where some male prisoners are hanging around inside the shiny fence.

title: Two Suspects Held in Slaying of Cabdriver
description: An 18-year-old woman and a 20-year-old man were arrested today in connection with the execution-style killing Thursday of a New York cabdriver, the police said.

description: For Michael Jordan and for the Knicks, Game 3 of their Eastern Conference semifinal series provided stunning turnarounds today, and the Bulls emerged facing in the right direction.

title: Hilary Jacobs Engaged
description: A June wedding is planned for Hillary Lauren Jacobs and Jeffrey Stone Kaplan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward S. Kaplan of Memphis. Ms. Jacobs is a daughter of Gail Jacobs and Dr. Eugene L. Jacobs, both of New York.

title: Beth Trueman Becomes Bride
description: Beth Susan Trueman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter Trueman of Yonkers, was married yesterday at Restaurant Provence in New York to Paul Frederick Cody, a son of Rosemarie Cody of Quincy, Mass., and the late Frederick M. Cody. Richard Lee Price, an acting State Supreme Court justice, officiated.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about the First National Collegiate Poetry Fellowship misidentified the winner. She is Saskia Hamilton.

title: BASEBALL NOSTALGIA IS BEYOND PEANUTS
description: The sale of gloves, bats and uniforms used by star players, combined with the ever-popular trading cards and a growing market for autographs, has created a baseball memorabilia business that, according to collectors and industry sources, easily surpasses a billion dollars a year.

title: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL Josquin: 'L'homme arme' Masses The Tallis Scholars. Gimell CDGIM 019; CD and cassette. Every century or two a composer comes along whose music seems to transcend creative struggle completely. Bach and Mozart were such composers, and so was Josquin Des Pres, the great Flemish contrapuntalist. Though written around 1500, Josquin's two masses based on the chanson ''L'homme arme'' (and included together on a single, generous CD for the first time) contain the kind of elevated structural trickery (the tune sung forward and backward, against itself at different speeds and in various canons) that brings one to mind of both the Serialists and Minimalists of our century. But what is astonishing is how effortlessly and inevitably all the parts can mesh into moments of stunning beauty or rise to ecstatic heights. The Tallis Scholars can be a touch tame for such extravagantly expressive music, but the high voices are particularly lovely and the ensemble does very well when Josquin wants rapture. -Mark Swed Gounod: 'Faust' Marcel Journet, Cesar Vezzani. Conducted by Henri Busser. Legendary Recordings 1012; CD only; distributed by Koch Import Service. This fabled 1931 complete Paris Opera performance, now digitally remastered from 78 rpm pressings, is easily the most important ''Faust'' on compact disk because it is the most idiomatically French: Just listen to the way the singers wrap themselves vocally around the language. Even at 64, Marcel Journet - who made his debut when Gounod was still alive - sings Mephistopheles with a suave elegance that has vanished from most modern interpretations of the role. Vezzani's heroic Faust is equally striking, and Mireille Berthon's Marguerite is stylish. There are few cuts, and the quality of the early electrical sound is a surprise. -Barrymore L. Scherer Leyla Gencer: Arias from 10 Italian Operas With various orchestras. Nuova Era 2266-67; two CD's only. While Renata Tebaldi and Maria Callas pursued their international careers, their somewhat younger Turkish-born (in 1928) contemporary, Leyla Gencer, was acclaimed in Italy in a remarkable range of lyric and dramatic roles. Ten of these are represented in this set, embracing the years 1957-68. The early recordings reveal a Callas-like intensity of expression and a sovereign technical command. In the later years, the intonation becomes less dependable and the register separations more noticeable, but Gencer still comes across as a heart-rending Norma and an exciting Maria Stuarda. The audio quality ranges from barely acceptable to surprisingly good. -George Jellinek Mussorgsky: 'Pictures at an Exhibition'; Scriabin's 'Black Mass' Sonata (Op. 58), Balakirev Sonata in B flat minor Ronald Smith, piano. Nimbus NI 5187; CD only This generously packed collection of Russian works is not without drawbacks that, in the end, make it a marginal choice. Nimbus's resonant sound, effective on its orchestral disks, makes for muddy textures here, and within that haze Mr. Smith is not always as fastidious as one would hope. The ''Pictures'' reading itself is painted in faint watercolors rather than vivid oils. The Scriabin and Balakirev are more vividly played. -Allan Kozinn Schumann: The Four Symphonies The Cleveland Orchestra conducted by Christoph von Dohnanyi. Nos. 1 and 2, London 421 439-2; CD and cassette. Nos. 3 and 4, London 421 643-2; CD and cassette. Some 30 years ago the Cleveland Orchestra recorded the four Schumann Symphonies under George Szell in performances highly regarded at the time. These new recordings, under the orchestra's current music director, have some of the virtues of the Szell performances: lean textures, clear articulation, natural balance between the sections of the orchestra. But despite fine playing, the performances have an ordinary and faceless character with no sense of wonder or discovery. Even when Mr. Dohnanyi attempts some ''Romantic'' indulgences - slight retards at the end of some sections, for example - they sound calculated rather than spontaneous responses to the music's core. -Martin Bookspan POP/JAZZ Cyndi Lauper: ''A Night to Remember'' Epic 44318; all three formats. Anonymous vocals, songs full of submissive cliches and slapdash production make it hard to believe that ''A Night to Remember'' is a Cyndi Lauper album. Where her first album offered boisterous, eccentric intelligence and her second aimed for earnest benevolence, her third sounds like the work of a beginner cleaving to commercial formulas. Most of the songs are about romantic attraction or post-breakup loneliness, and where a pop gloss might have carried a few selections, the arrangements sound flat and unfinished. Only one song, ''Like a Cat,'' shows both spirit and verbal flair. -Jon Pareles Sarah McLachlan: 'Touch' Arista 8594; all three formats. On her debut album, the 20-year-old singer, songwriter and classical guitarist from Halifax, Nova Scotia, sings her own mystical ballads filled with vague pulsing emotions and overripe images of ''moonlight in the mist,'' ''dying swan songs,'' ''brooding storms'' and ''pristine velvet walls.'' Like the English singer-songwriter Kate Bush, who is an obvious inspiration, Ms. McLachlan sings in an ethereal soprano. Enhancing the echoey cathedrallike atmosphere are delicate textures of classical guitar, harplike keyboard, gentle whirring percussion and an occasional dusting of strings. -Stephen Holden 'ReR Records Quarterly Vol. 2 No. 3' Re 0203; LP only, available from NMDS, 500 Broadway, New York, N. Y. 10012. If the newest edition of ''ReR Records Quarterly'' says anything in its choices of underground music from around the world, it is that the underground they chose to compile is defined less by a style than by the sound of low-budget technology. Everything from bad art-rock fusion from Sweden to a funny, nonsequitur of a pop tune by the American group the Tone Dogs to Canadian John Oswald's computer-generated-and-stored two-minute sound poem all feel low-tech, gritty. And oddly, they all work together. -Peter Watrous Hadda Brooks: 'Romance in the Dark' Jukebox Lil JB-1107; LP only, available from Down Home Records, 10341 San Pablo Avenue, El Cerrito, Calif. 94530 In a typical story, Ms. Brooks, after studying classical music for most of her childhood, went into pop music in the 40's. Not knowing much about it, she went into boogie woogie, and came out with a career as a blues and boogie pianist. Not knowing much about singing, she went into it and came out with a career as a soaked-in-whisky singer of ballads. Together, her playing and singing made her famous, at least for a time, and ''Romance in the Dark,'' with its boogie versions of ''Hungarian Rhapsody,'' and ''Minuet in G,'' contrasting against rocking boogies and standards, give a view of both the commercial ideas of the time and the work of an unfairly forgotten pianist. -P. W. Joe Jackson: 'Blaze of Glory' A&M 5249; all three formats. As both a composer and a lyricist, Joe Jackson has a comprehensive sensibility that reaches out to encompass as much of the world as he can gather in. ''Blaze of Glory,'' his most sweeping album to date, offers a rough chronological history of his generation's feelings about love, politics and fashion, all filtered through a somewhat acerbic personal viewpoint. The inspirations for the album's 12 songs run from space travel to rock-and-roll mythology to television to aerobics. The songs trace an emotional path, from idealism to anger to tempered affirmation. While Mr. Jackson's edgy singing can't express the entire emotional range of the songs, the music is an interesting agglomeration of rock, Latin American, semiclassical and other textures translated by Mr. Jackson into a jangling personal style. -S. H.

title: Question Of the Week; Should the Yanks Have Traded Leiter?
description: No! Al Leiter for Jesse Barfield will go down as a Nolan Ryan for Jim Fregosi trade. George Steinbrenner and Syd Thrift should learn from the Mets that you build with young pitching.

title: Gorbachev's Move on The European Arsenal
description: EVEN as Mikhail S. Gorbachev prepared for his visit to China, the Soviet leader managed to throw a little gasoline on the fiery arms control debate within the Western alliance about nuclear short-range missiles.

title: William J. Ward, Teacher, 67
description: William J. Ward, a teacher and book editor who was a historian at Green-Wood Cemetery in Brooklyn, died of a heart attack Wednesday at Lutheran Medical Center. He was 67 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: 24 for Formal Dinner? Just Call a Famous Chef
description: LEAD: TWENTY-TWO women from New Canaan have discovered the secret of easy, elegant entertaining. Not only will top chefs go to their homes to plan menus and whip up dinner, but these hostesses also need not agonize over the guest lists. The New Canaan Historical Society will take care of that.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My house has an unfinished attic that I can walk into. I use the attic frequently, but in summer the temperature climbs so high it is difficult to stay long. The attic floor is insulated with a layer of vermiculite, covered with a thick layer of fiberglass without a paper backing. This seems adequate to prevent heat filtering into the rooms below. To reduce the temperature inside the attic, I want to install fiberglass between the rafters. Should I use blankets with or without a paper facing? If the kind with a facing is best, which way should it face?

title: Musical Delights Gathered From Flops
description: LUCKY audiences attending the American Stage Company's happy new revue, ''Ed Linderman's Broadway Jukebox,'' are instantly informed that the songs they'll be hearing won't be from ''South Pacific,'' ''Oklahoma!'' or ''Fiddler on the Roof'' but, more likely, from the likes of ''Hot September.'' ''Hot September''? That was a 1965 musical version of William Inge's ''Picnic'' that never made it to Broadway. Or there might be a song or two from musicals that never made it on Broadway, like ''Cyrano'' (49 performances in 1973). Even ''Carrie'' and ''Chess,'' both 1988 losers, are herein represented.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: LOVE AND MARRIAGE. By Bill Cosby. (Doubleday, $16.95.) A weekend at the beach is about how long it would take to polish off ''Love and Marriage,'' but leave the copy on the table for the next guests. The beach breezes should carry away the laughter so that the more dignified can bury their noses in the book and giggle with self-recognition.

title: Rev. James Sandmire, Gay Rights Leader, 59
description: The Rev. James E. Sandmire, one of California's best-known gay rights leaders, died of complications from AIDS Friday at San Francisco General Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived in San Francisco.

title: It's Autumn in Paraguay But Spring Is in the Air
description: The damp gray skies of an approaching South American winter have settled over this riverside capital. But on the chilly cobblestone streets below, young women have started wearing miniskirts.

title: FICTION
description: CLOSER. By Dennis Cooper. (Grove, $15.95.) The gay teen-age boys who populate this short, brutal novel are not entirely indistinguishable from one another, but their energetic couplings betray a fatal sameness that is only occasionally relieved by the homicidal fetishes of their older lovers. Some readers have found similarities between the novelist and art critic Dennis Cooper's work and that of Jean Genet or William Burroughs, but it must be said that he lacks the ordering instincts of the one and the wild comedy of the other. Indeed, Mr. Cooper's offerings seem to have more in common with run-of-the-mill pornography, particularly its grinding obsessiveness and fantastic lack of material consequences. In ''Closer,'' a novel whose action occurs in the mid-1980's and whose characters constitute a rather large circle of ever-shifting sexual partners, it's curious that the nightmare of AIDS is nowhere mentioned. Personal style, it seems, is the sole determinant of destiny (''He would have been nothing without punk''; ''His room was so dazzling it made the rest of the world seem as dull as a parking lot''), and human emotion is a continuing mystery (one boy reports experiencing something that might have been love, except that it ''was too manageable and kind of coldly interesting''). Certain of Dennis Cooper's people, particularly the older men, find their interests moving toward snuff movies, coprophilia and erotically inspired disembowelments; yet even their less dramatic activities are so gratuitous, so random and formless, that everything seems to gravitate naturally toward death.

title: Florida
description: To the Editor: Corinne K. Hoexter's article on Longboat and Siesta keys (Travel, March 12) captured the charm and ambiance of those delightful areas.

title: At the Victoria and Albert, A Collection of Missteps
description: Every so often, there surfaces in the international art world a truly terrible idea. An idea of precisely that order was approved unanimously not long ago by the trustees of the Victoria & Albert Museum in London. The essence of it was that henceforth the curatorial staff of the museum were to concern themselves entirely with scholarly pursuits, leaving the day-to-day work of the museum - the ''housekeeping,'' as it is now called - to a chain of command newly set up for the purpose and attuned to modern managerial methods. As a preliminary to this, and to make way for specialists in marketing, presentation and earning power, eight senior curators got the ax, and their posts were abolished.

title: Bus Crash Dead Are Honored
description: Young survivors of a bus crash that killed 24 children and 3 adults helped unveil a black granite monument today at a ceremony marking the first anniversary of the disaster, the nation's worst alcohol-related highway accident. More than 1,000 people attended the service at North Hardin High School's football stadium, which overlooks the cemetery where many of the victims of the accident are buried. The driver of the pickup truck that hit the bus, Larry Mahoney, will be tried in November on 27 counts of murder.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Guest List; A Party Fit for an Ambassador's 'Au Revoir'
description: It will be ''au revoir,'' not goodbye, at the Swedish Embassy residence as Ambassador Wilhelm Wachtmeister gives a final party as dean of the diplomatic corps.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Friday about the drought and the winter wheat harvest included an erroneous map label. The state shown as Colorado was Wyoming; the Colorado label should have appeared south of Wyoming, where an area of severe drought was shown.

title: Mothers Mourn the Children Who Died in Drug Violence
description: Several hundred mothers whose children have been killed in drug-related violence joined forces today with anti-apartheid activists here in a nontraditional Mother's Day observance.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Sabatini Keeps Italian Open Title: Top-seeded Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina overcame fourth-seeded Arantxa Sanchez of Spain, 6-2, 5-7, 6-4, yesterday to win her second consecutive Italian Open championship in Rome. Sabatini earned $60,000 for the victory.(AP) Agassi Tops Edberg: Second-seeded Andre Agassi won the $160,000 Aldi tournament in Ede, the Netherlands, defeating top-seeded Stefan Edberg of Sweden, 4-6, 6-1, 6-2, in the final. The match took 67 minutes.(AP) Lendl Advances: Ivan Lendl of Czechoslovakia defeated Carl-Uwe Steeb of West Germany, 4-6, 6-3, 6-1, to advance to the final of the German Open in Hamburg, West Germany. Boris Becker of West Germany was upset in the other semifinal match, losing to Horst Skoff of Austria, 7-6, 6-2.(AP) Berger Takes Title: Jay Berger won his first American title, beating Lawson Duncan, 6-4, 6-3, in the United States clay court championships in Isle of Palms, S.C. The match between the two former Clemson stars was delayed an hour because of rain. Berger, ranked 42d in the world, won $38,000. Duncan, ranked 75th, earned $19,000.(AP) BOXING Cruz Defeats Patterson: Stevie Cruz, a former World Boxing Association featherweight champion, floored Tracy Harris Patterson, the son of the former heavyweight champion Floyd Patterson, in the eighth round yesterday and controlled the rest of the fight to win a 10-round split decision. Cruz, 33-3 with 18 knockouts, dropped Patterson with a left hook in the final minute of the round. Cruz won on two of the three judges' scorecards: Tom Kaczmerek scored it 96-93 and Jean Williams had it 95-94. Richard Murry scored it 96-93 Patterson. Patterson is 30-2 with 20 knockouts.(AP) Chavez Knocks Out Mayweather: Julio Cesar Chavez won the World Boxing Council super-lightweight title Saturday night in Inglewood, Calif., with a 10th-round knockout of Roger Mayweather, who told the referee he could not continue because of abdominal cramps. The 26-year-old Chavez, from Culiacan, Mexico, has a 63-0 record with 53 knockouts. Mayweather, 28, a native of Grand Rapids, Mich., who lives in Las Vegas, has a 34-6 record.(AP) HORSE RACING Summer Secretary Triumphs: Summer Secretary, a 4-year-old daughter of Secretariat, outfinished Far East by half a length to win the $94,800 Beaugay Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park. Fieldy, the 2-to-1 favorite, was half a length back in third after a tough trip and Nastique was eighth as the top weight. Summer Secretary, owned by the Middletown Stable and trained by Allen Jerkens, ran the mile and a sixteenth on the grass in 1:43 2/5 under 109 pounds, including Jean-Luc Samyn, and paid $33.40 for $2 to win. The victory was her fifth in 24 career starts. GOLF Hill Wins in Playoff: Dave Hill watched Chi Chi Rodriguez miss a 12-foot putt, then sank a 4-footer on the third hole of a sudden-death playoff to win the Senior PGA Tour's St. Christopher's Classic at the 6,710-yard Chester Valley Golf Club in Malvern, Pa. Hill, who shot a two-under-par 68, finished regulation play tied with Rodriguez at four-under 206. Rodriguez had a 67, with six birdies and three bogeys.(AP)

Scottish Plant Destroyed
description: A stone-crushing plant in Scotland was destroyed in a fire Saturday night, and an anonymous caller said today that Scottish nationalists had blown it up because the quarry where it was situated was going to be used as a nuclear waste dump. The police have not commented on the cause of the fire at the Glensanda granite quarry near the west coast resort of Oban. There were no injuries. Press Association, the domestic news agency, said a caller claimed the plant was bombed by the Scottish National Liberation Army.

title: Fire on a Tanker Off Texas
description: A fire burned for nine hours in the engine room of a Liberian tanker carrying 450,000 barrels of crude oil from Galveston to Port Arthur today, but the Coast Guard said the cargo was not threatened. Two crew members of the 810-foot tanker, the Jalinga, were taken to the hospital for treatment of smoke inhalation. The Coast Guard has begun investigating the cause of the fire.

title: Peter Scott, 50, Leader In Cause of Gay Rights
description: Peter Scott, a champion of gay rights who canceled a campaign for the California Assembly after learning that he had AIDS, died of complications from the disease at his home Saturday. He was 50 years old. A lawyer who gave up his practice to advocate gay rights, Mr. Scott worked to defeat measures requiring the dismissal of homosexual teachers and requiring that people with acquired immune deficiency syndrome be registered with the state. He also led the fight in California to hasten testing of experimental AIDS drugs, a result of which was a drug-testing bill passed into law in 1987.

title: Bloom's Merger
description: Bruce J. Bloom, a New York agency, has merged with the Wellington Advertising Group, whose holdings include Wellington Communications Inc. and Wellington & Gardner Inc. The new company, called Euro-American Communications Inc., will provide advertising, promotional and public relations services.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Douglas & Lomason Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $660,000 gain from an accounting change.

title: Ewing's Failures Hold Back the Knicks
description: With 7 minutes 11 seconds remaining in the third quarter today, Patrick Ewing made a 15-foot jump shot. He never scored again.

title: Stage II Apparel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Sales represent net sales. Quarterly results for 1988 have been recast to conform with the company's new Dec. 31 fiscal year.

title: Critic's Notebook; At Cannes, Homage to Chaplin
description: ''We are all his children,'' said Federico Fellini by way of tribute when Charlie Chaplin died. The other night, at the opening of the 42d Cannes International Film Festival, it seemed briefly possible that what Fellini said was the literal truth.

title: Pfizer Goes to Saatchi
description: Pfizer Inc. said Friday that it had selected Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising to introduce a consumer product next year. Pfizer did not identify the product, but said its advertising budget would be $6 million to $8 million. The new account capped a successful week for Saatchi, which won the $15 million Herman's Sporting Goods account on Tuesday.

title: United on Civil Rights, Divided on Enforcer
description: Rare is the battle that would pit the Rev. Jesse Jackson against the head of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, that would make opponents out of Mayor Andrew Young of Atlanta and the Leadership Conference on Civil Rights, a coalition of more than 180 civil rights organizations.

title: But Still No Kitchen Sink
description: Mountainsmith, a company in Golden, Colo., has reinvented the tepee to accommodate a wood stove. The tent, called the Mountainshelter, comes with a cone-shaped opening at the top for fitting a stovepipe. The hole is lined with the same material that firefighters and race car drivers wear for protection against fire. This material, made of Kevlar, a high-strength woven fabric, and polymer, a chemical compound, will withstand heat up to 1,450 degrees Fahrenheit, Mountainsmith says.

title: Market Place; Some Are Betting On Ginnie Maes
description: FEW assets are as plentiful in the portfolios of troubled savings and loan associations as mortgage securities. That fact helps to explain the recent problems in the mortgage security market, which saw prices plunge last month.

title: Bush's 'New Path'
description: Emboldened by the success of his scheme to subvert NATO with a Russo-German Entente, Mr. Gorbachev has just issued an ultimatum: Unless the Western alliance drops its intention to modernize the short-range missile that helps Europe offset Soviet military superiority, the Soviet Union will violate the intermediate-range treaty it signed with such fanfare only last year.

title: Plans to Bury 1500's Theater Evoke a Protest in London
description: Several hundred history buffs, preservationists and Shakespeare enthusiasts, including the actors Alan Bates, Dame Peggy Ashcroft and Rosemary Harris, attended a demonstration here this noon. They called for Government intervention to preserve the newly discovered remains of the 16th-century Rose Theater, which are to be covered Monday to allow work to begin on a new office building.

title: Art Dealer Didn't Fear City Streets
description: When he was not managing one of his three Manhattan art galleries, Arnold Taufield loved to spend time in the gym, his business partner said yesterday. Mr. Taufield was an amateur bodybuilder who did not worry about being mugged.

title: BGS Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Piedmont Management reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $20,378. Latest first-quarter and year-ago first quarter results are after net realized investment losses of $382,000 and $80,000, respectively.

title: Death Penalty in Heinous Cases Is Appropriate; Prosecutors' Malice
description: To the Editor:

title: Union Valley reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $635,000 from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Promotion At The Times
description: The appointment of William L. Pollak as vice president for circulation at The New York Times was announced yesterday by Lance R. Primis, president and general manager of the newspaper.

title: 5 MAINE HOSPITALS OFFER AID TO ONE
description: Responding to a succession of deaths, lawsuits and a public outcry, the heads of five private hospitals around Maine have told Gov. Gov. John R. McKernan Jr. that they will help manage the troubled state mental hospital here. The response came after the Governor asked one of the hospitals to help.

title: Mercury General Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Should Uncle Sam Tilt to HDTV?; But: Waiving Antitrust Rules Means New Rules
description: The public rescue of an American HDTV industry can be a model of enlightened economic policy - or, instead, a model of private greed. The choice is up to Congress. It need not shrink from intervention if it legislates safeguards to protect the consumer and the taxpayer.

title: Campaign Matters; Board's Search May Determine Green's Legacy
description: The sudden death last Wednesday of Richard R. Green, the city's Schools Chancellor, prompted Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former Federal prosecutor, to postpone the celebratory news conference he had scheduled for later that morning to declare his candidacy for mayor. The enduring political impact of Dr. Green's death will depend largely on how long it takes to choose his permanent replacement and how boldly the new chancellor approaches the job.

title: Corrections
description: An article and a headline on Thursday about the 1989 Next Wave Festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music referred incorrectly to the festival's presentation of ''Laurie Anderson - Empty Places'' next October. It will be a New York premiere; the world premiere is scheduled for June 8 at the Spoleto Festival U.S.A. in Charleston, S.C.

title: Tandon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income During this year's first quarter the company incurred expenses of about $5 million relating to domestic work force reductions.

title: Endevco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $167,000. The company said the increase in revenue is attributable to the acquisition of Dubach & Calhoun Gas processing plant. The company also said latest quarter share earnings equaled less than one cent a share.

title: Ogilvy Vote Is Expected On New Bid
description: The board of the Ogilvy Group will vote today on a sweetened offer by the WPP Group to acquire the venerable American advertising company for more than $890 million, people close to their negotiations said yesterday.

title: Sunshine-Jr. Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income and included a $622,735 gain from an accounting change.

title: Workshop in Acting
description: Vladimir Ilyin, the director of the Mikhail Chekhov Artistic Center in Moscow, will present a workshop on the Mikhail Chekhov acting technique at New Dramatists, 424 West 44th Street, tonight at 7 o'clock. Mr. Chekhov, a nephew of Anton Chekhov, an actor and a pupil of Stanislavsky, came to the United States from the Soviet Union in 1935. Known in the United States as Michael Chekhov, he founded a school to train actors in a technique and philosophy based on his work with Stanislavsky. Contributions will be accepted at the door. Information and reservations: 595-1220.

title: A Split on the Value of 2-Hull Tankers
description: The Exxon Valdez would probably have survived its grounding on Bligh Reef without leaking crude oil, or leaking far less, if it had had a double hull, according to some shipbuilders and marine architects.

title: INSIDE
description: Church vs. Noriega Panamanians by the hundreds flocked to churches to hear a statement by the nation's bishops attacking the Government's legitimacy after last Sunday's election. Page A9. More U.S.-Soviet Trade President Bush is leaning toward the removal of high tariffs on Soviet imports, and Congress seems likely to support the move if changes are made in emigration policy. Page D1. Motorists and Their Wallets To pay for bridge and road repairs, New York State officials are considering large increases in driving-related taxes and fees. Page B1. Gloom Around Wright Although the ethics committee has yet to rule on Jim Wright's effort to have charges against him dismissed, the widespread feeling on Capitol Hill is that he is ''finished.'' Page B6. Brush With Madness Great art seems to make certain travelers perspire, faint, even fall into depression. A psychiatrist calls it the Stendhal Syndrome. Page A3.

title: Florence's Art Makes Some Go to Pieces
description: Here's a case from the files that's as good a starting point as any. Name: Lucy. Sex: Female. Age: 22. Occupation: Student.

title: Property Capital Trust reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included a gain from the sale of investments of $3,577,000 and $3,809,000 for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Korean Riot Police Break Up A March for a Slain Student
description: Riot troops broke up a march today by thousands of people protesting the death of a student they say was tortured and killed by the police.

title: Instrument Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After the reversal of a tax credit of $140,000. c-Net income and after tax credits of $625,000 for the quarter and $1,925,000 for the 6 months. Because of redeemable preferred dividend requirements, share earnings for the year-ago quarter were negative.

description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: 4 South African Churchmen To Discuss Apartheid in U.S.
description: Four leading South African churchmen are due to travel to the United States this week to explore the part Washington could play in ending apartheid peacefully.

title: The Weekly Newspaper Becomes a Hot Property
description: After 12 years as a big-city newspaper reporter and two years at Harvard Business School, Christopher E. Bogan set out last June to build a chain of weekly newspapers.

title: Koch to Seek $40 Million More for AIDS
description: New York City will spend $40 million more in the next fiscal year to expand AIDS programs and extend them to thousands of people with AIDS-related illnesses who were previously unserved, under a proposal announced yesterday by Mayor Edward I. Koch.

title: Joint Mars Shot Means Guns or Spaceships
description: To the Editor:

title: Tesoro Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest second quarter results included $2 million of additional costs relating to asset sales during fiscal 1988. Year-ago second quarter results included a favorable retroactive pipeline adjustment of $1.6 million.

title: A Question Mark For Sunday Silence
description: Sunday Silence, who won the Kentucky Derby nine days ago, is being treated for a bruised right front foot and could miss the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico on Saturday.

title: George A. Cornish, 87; Edited Herald Tribune
description: George A. Cornish, a former managing editor and executive editor of The New York Herald Tribune, died of a heart ailment yesterday at Saint Anthony's Hospital in St. Petersburg, Fla., where he lived. He was 87 years old.

title: Pan Am Gets Aid for a Bid
description: The Pan Am Corporation said yesterday that it had received a commitment of at least $400 million from Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. and the Airlie Group L. P. to support a possible cash bid for NWA Inc., the parent of Northwest Airlines.

title: M. Jordan: First in Flight
description: MICHAEL JORDAN, to the surprise of most, used wheels yesterday morning when he arrived at Chicago Stadium, and not wings. He motored into the parking lot before Game 4 of the playoffs in his red Ferrari, but the license plate was suggestive of the most notable propensity of the occupant:

title: Raising Fees For Drivers Is Pondered In Albany
description: Months after successfully imploring New York State residents to approve a $3 billion bond act to repair the state's deteriorating roads and bridges, officials here are already pondering large increases in driving-related taxes and fees they say will be needed when the money runs out in 1992.

title: Devon Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Washington National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest first quarter results included investment losses of $75,000, compared to net realized investment gains of $1,252,000, or 11 cents a share, in the year-ago first period. Results for 1988 were restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: Minven Gold Corp reports earnings for
description: The company was formed last August from the merger of MFC Mining Finance Corp. and Brohm Resources Inc. On a pro forma basis, the company would have had net income of $51,703 on revenue of $8,373,255 a year earlier. Results are in Canadian dollars.

Border Murders Stir Harmful Stereotypes
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Ameritech, Chicago, the telecommunications company, named Betty F. Elliott president of its subsidiary, Ameritech Credit Corp.

title: Central Park Case Puts Focus on Tough Juvenile Law
description: When five 14- and 15-year-olds were arrested in the rape and attempted murder of a jogger in Central Park last month, they came under a special category of criminal law that exists only in New York State.

title: First Marathon Inc reports earnings for
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Review/Ballet; Erik Bruhn Prize Given To American And a Dane
description: Silja Wendrup-Schandorff, a 20-year-old dancer in the Royal Danish Ballet, and Stephen Legate, a 21-year-old American who joined the National Ballet of Canada after training at its affiliated school, won the annual Erik Bruhn prize here on Saturday evening amid new controversy surrounding the year-old Canadian ballet competition.

title: East Germany Losing Its Edge
description: East Germany is the Communist world's vaunted economic success story, hailed as proof that traditional German values of hard work, discipline and thrift can translate Karl Marx's theories into reality.

title: Drug Wars Scar Capital's Children
description: Like soldiers who have seen too much combat, increasing numbers of children in the nation's capital are beginning to show signs of ''battle fatigue'' because of unrelieved exposure to the city's drug wars.

title: Fed Held Unlikely to Ease Policy
description: Despite widespread hopes that the Federal Reserve Board will soon move to ease monetary policy, a number of credit market analysts said that such a move is not only unlikely, but unwise.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Triathletes Put Fitness to the Test
description: LEAD: WHAT kind of people would want to swim, bike and run themselves into a state of near exhaustion, sacrificing outside interests and losing friends in the process, and then line up to do it again and again? ''Crazy.'' ''Out of their minds.''

title: 'Basket Trades,' Long Debated, Start Well
description: After more than a year of debate about whether stock exchanges should be allowed to trade the equivalent of a large portfolio of stocks in a single execution, the securities industry has finally had the chance to conduct such ''basket trades.'' The response from investors was strong.

title: Review/Music; 20th-Century Vocal Works
description: There was a pervasive sweetness to Thursday's 20th-century program by the Gregg Smith Singers. The title of this Brooklyn Philharmonic series at Cooper Union is Meet the Moderns, and what a gracious meeting it was.

title: Mott's Super Markets Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $309,521 for the latest first quarter and $459,204 for the year- ago period.

Claire's Stores reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-Net loss

title: Jury's Chief in North's Trial Had Cousin in Prosecution
description: The jury forewoman in the trial of Oliver L. North learned that her cousin was working as a secretary for the prosecution and neglected to inform Federal District Judge Gerhard A. Gesell of her discovery, a report says.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council Meets at 3 P.M. SOCIAL COMMITTEE - 10 A.M. TRUSTEESHIP COUNCIL - Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: Democrats Clash Over Party's Rules for the Primaries
description: When a group of top fund-raisers met last week they proved once again a maxim governing Democratic politics: Democrats can't get together to discuss party rules without having an argument.

title: Flames Set Back Canadiens by 3-2
description: Twice too many times, there was Al MacInnis, owner of the most unworldly slap shot in the league, taking unsympathetic aim at Montreal's Patrick Roy. The defenseman's two goals provided the foundation for Calgary's initial step toward its first Stanley Cup.

title: Review/Music; Youssou N'Dour Finds His International Groove
description: Youssou N'Dour, the Senegalese singer who performed at the Ritz on Tuesday night and who is one of Africa's most famous international musicians, didn't start his show until halfway through his set. Leading a band including three drummers, a guitarist, a bassist, a saxophonist and a keyboardist, he looked vaguely uncomfortable - as if the show were a minor irritant to his day. The audience, underwhelmed, spent as much time looking at the ceiling as at the band.

title: New Jersey's Strict Toxic Cleanup Law: Too Severe?
description: The turn-of-the century typewriter-ribbon factory and its towering smokestack are gone from the center of this Bergen County suburb, replaced by brick condominiums.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11 Mikhail Gorbachev arrived in China today to seal the reconciliation of the two largest Communist countries at a time when both are struggling through change. Page A1

title: Dinners Educating Parents (and Teachers)
description: Because of an invitation to a restaurant, a construction worker, Jaime Polomo, met his son's first-grade teacher and told her why he had not gone to school conferences this year.

title: Review/Dance; A New Cast for Ballet Theater's 'Sylphides'
description: American Ballet Theater got off to a slow though lovely start with ''Les Sylphides'' on Friday night at the Metropolitan Opera House, but from then on it was a triumphant evening. The inner vitality of the ballet, choreographed by Michel Fokine and set to music by Chopin, seems to elude most American companies. And though the lead dancers turned in beautifully conceived and realized performances here, the ballet did have its customary longueurs.

title: Congress
description: Republicans have perfected the good-cop, bad-cop strategy in their relations with Congressional Democrats.

title: Illness Forces Manilow To Halt a Performance
description: The pop singer Barry Manilow was taken to Lenox Hill Hospital on Saturday night during the intermission of his Broadway show after suffering what his press agent said was an adverse reaction to prescription medicine taken for a stomach ailment.

title: Dismal Day for Yankees
description: An attendant appeared at the door to the Yankees' locker room today, stuck a key into the lock and turned it once. It was not a time for visitors. Dallas Green, the manager sometimes known for his brief outbursts, was not done talking yet.

title: Books of The Times; Architect Adapts Reality to His Changing Dream
description: The Most Beautiful House in the World By Witold Rybczynski Illustrated. 211 pages. Viking. $18.95.

title: Southern Indiana Gas Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Trade Tempest Over Car Phones
description: At the core of the increasingly bitter United States dispute with Japan over access to the Japanese telecommunications market lies a trade barrier that has what at first seems a remarkably trivial result: a Motorola-made car telephone that works perfectly in Osaka becomes nearly useless as you drive toward Tokyo.

title: Valdez: Do-Gooders' Feeding Frenzy
description: LEAD: Hired by Exxon, I took a television camera to Valdez, Alaska, in late April. My mission, almost a month after the messy oil tanker accident, was to impartially document the scene, the activity and the clean-up. I learned that no lens is wide enough to capture the vastness of Prince William Sound.

title: ICO Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The latest periods included $1,259,000 extraordinary gain recognized on the completion of the refinancing of the company's secured bank indebtedness in January.

title: China Concerns Face Inquiry
description: The Chinese authorities have recommended fining five state-owned companies, including one founded by the eldest son of the leader Deng Xiaoping, for profiteering, the Economic Reporter magazine said.

title: Plan's Value to Peabody Questioned
description: A recapitalization of the Peabody Holding Company proposed last week would mean a significant financial gain for the Newmont Mining Corporation, which owns a 49.97 percent stake in Peabody. But analysts and executives of other coal companies say there appears to be no appreciable benefit for Peabody.

title: Should Uncle Sam Tilt to HDTV?; Yes: It's Pivotal to Industries of the Future
description: Washington is riveted on high-definition television, a development that displays sharper pictures on wider screens. The American electronics industry wants $1.35 billion of Government money to help it compete, belatedly, against Japanese and European companies. Secretary of Commerce Robert Mosbacher says the industry can't rely on ''Uncle Sugar,'' but he nonetheless offers a surprising sweetener: a proposal to relax the antitrust laws so as to allow co-production of equipment.

title: In China, Radio Is Still King
description: LEAD: While media critics debate the potential effects of global television in the emerging so-called global village, little is said of the power of global radio by such established services as the British Broadcasting Corporation and Voice of America.

title: Shaw Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Ideal Group of Companies reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a special gain of $500,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Marion Mack , 87, Silent-Film Actress, Dies
description: The silent-film actress Marion Mack, a small-town girl who became a Mack Sennett bathing beauty and Buster Keaton's co-star in the classic film ''The General,'' died of heart failure on May 1. She was 87 years old.

title: Children's Discovery Centers of America Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Magellan Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and after a tax benefit of $11,328. c-Net income and after a tax benefit of $81,173. The company is listed on the Pacific and Boston stock exchanges.

description: b-Net income

title: Growth Estimates Revised
description: The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development has raised its growth estimates for Japan and Western Europe, but said growth in the United States would be lower than it had forecast in December.

title: Los Angeles School Strike Looms
description: Teachers cast aside any chances for a last-minute resolution of their dispute with the school district and spent today preparing picket signs and each other for a strike.

title: Question Box
description: Two-Homer Innings Q. How many Yankee batters have hit two home runs in one inning and who was the last one to do it? A. Since 1900, the feat has been achieved 18 times in the major leagues, and of the eight American Leaguers to accomplish it, three were Yankees. But no Yankee has managed to do it since 1977, when Cliff Johnson became the third one in the history of the franchise to trot round the bases twice in the same inning. The other two were a couple of rookies named Joe: DiMaggio and Pepitone.

title: This Time, Many Candidates for Soviet Voters
description: Soviet voters, who rebelled six weeks ago at the attempt of Communist Party figures to arrange unopposed election victories for themselves, returned to ballot booths today to find feast where there had been famine.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Employers are aggressively bargaining with doctors and hospitals on health-care costs, and steering workers to the ones with the best price. Although the costs to these employers are lower, patients may lose some freedom of choice, and other companies and individuals may end up paying more. [ Page A1. ] INTERNATIONAL REPORT Soviet-American trade prospects are brightening as business contacts increase and President Bush leans toward easing a law that imposes stiff tariffs on Soviet imports. [ D1. ] East German growth may be grinding to a near halt, after serving as a symbol that a Communist economy can be highly productive. German leaders have flatly rejected the market-oriented reforms that are gaining favor in some Communist countries. [ D1. ] A new Zimbabwe investment code relaxes controls on profits earned by new investors. The changes mark a sharp departure from Zimbabwe's socialist orientation. [ D8. ] The environment has become a top economic concern of industrial nations, along with world debt and trade. But divisions remain over what to do, how soon to act and how much to spend. [ D5. ] THE MEDIA BUSINESS Ogilvy's board will vote today on a sweetened offer from WPP. As the $890 million deal is shaping up, David Ogilvy, the retired founder of the American firm, would become honorary chairman of WPP. The combined company would be the world's second-largest marketing communications concern, after Saatchi & Saatchi. [ D1. ] The number of magazine distributors is shrinking just as hundreds of new titles are reaching the market. [ D1. ] Big companies are aggressively buying weekly newspapers. Perhaps 50 percent of the nation's 7,600 weeklies are now independent, compared with an estimated 90 percent a decade ago. [ D6. ] Authors like Nancy Reagan are appearing in videotaped interviews. Aimed at the publishers' sales forces, the tapes are also sent to bookstores and producers of television programs. [ D6. ] Theater movies have made a modest comeback on network television. NBC and CBS both used movies to steal viewers from ABC's costly ''War and Remembrance.'' [ D6. ] New Jockey ads depict ''real people'' in a state of near undress, an example of a new advertising genre that spurns professional models. Sociologists say consumers react favorably to people who, like themselves, display some flaws. Advertising. [ D7. ] MARKETS The securities industry finally had a chance to conduct ''basket trades.'' The response from investors was strong on the American Stock Exchange and the Philadelphia Stock Exchange. [ D1. ] COMPANIES Cray Research is said to be considering several options for restructuring, including a sale or splitting of the company. [ D2. ] Peabody seems unlikely to benefit from a proposed recapitalization, analysts and coal industry executives say. The plan would increase its long-term debt to more than $1 billion. [ D3. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Legal scholars are continuing a debate on whether a proposal on corporate law will encourage lawsuits against company directors. Those involved must strike a delicate balance: making directors accountable for double dealing and fraud while discouraging nuisance suits. Business and the Law. [ D2. ] A move by the Fed to ease monetary policy is unlikely and unwise, analysts say, despite widespread hopes for such action amid signs that the economy has been slowing. Credit Markets. [ D5. ] Prices of mortgage securities have begun to recover. Some buyers have stepped forward to bet that the closing of troubled savings and loan companies will not lead to a wholesale selloff of these securities, like Ginnie Maes. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D4. ]

title: Authors Turn Cheerleaders, on Videotape
description: Addressing the Random House sales force 10 days ago, Nancy Reagan, dressed in a red suit and gazing earnestly into a camera, said she wanted to thank everyone in advance for all the work she knew would be done to sell her forthcoming memoirs, ''My Turn.''

title: How to Fix School Decentralization
description: How many corrupt board members were thrown out in New York City school board elections? How many concerned parents were voted in? The complete answers are days away. But one dismal return is already known: Despite recent revelations of abuses on local boards and an aggressive get-out-the-vote effort, only about 6 percent of voters went to the polls.

title: Baker Hints at Possibility Of Compromise on Missiles
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d hinted today that the United States might be ready to compromise with West Germany in the dispute over the future of NATO's short-range nuclear missiles in Europe.

title: Corrections
description: An article in some editions on Friday about a benefit in Manhattan for the Design Industries Foundation for AIDS located Roseland incorrectly. It is on 52d Street between Broadway and Eighth Avenue.

title: Shakeout Raises Concerns On Distribution of Magazines
description: Just as hundreds of new consumer magazines are hitting the market, the number of distributors is suddenly shrinking. The growing concentration has raised concerns in the competitive world of magazine publishing that a few major publishers that own the remaining distributors might develop a stranglehold on newsstand circulation.

title: Fairchild Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included gains from discontinued operations of $423,000 and $523,000 for latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively, and the year-ago quarter also included a tax loss carryforward of $1,748,000. The company said earnings also were reduced by legal and financial fees of about $2 million related to third party initiatives to acquire control of the company and certain financial transactions. The company restated year-ago results for the discontinuance of two small operations in the industrial products segment.

title: Rivals Use a Dusty Weapon To Deflate ABC Mini-Series
description: AS long ago as February 1988, NBC's program executives sat in a meeting plotting a strategy to blunt the expected success of ABC's mammoth project for the 1988-89 television season, the mini-series ''War and Remembrance.''

title: With His Allies Voicing Pessimism, Air of Gloom Hovers About Wright
description: Jim Wright's Democratic colleagues now readily concede that he is in desperate trouble and that his fate may be settled in a month or so, when the ethics committee rules on the Speaker's efforts to dismiss major charges against him.

title: Editors' Note
description: The Patterns column on the Fashion page last Tuesday reported that the Italian designer Gianfranco Ferre would take over the design responsibilities at Christian Dior, according to fashion executives in New York and Europe. While the executives confirmed the report, the column should have credited Women's Wear Daily with the disclosure, a day earlier.

title: Lakers Complete Sweep of Sonics
description: James Worthy scored 12 of his 33 points in the fourth quarter as the Los Angeles Lakers overcame a 29-point first-half deficit to edge Seattle, 97-95, today and sweep their Western Conference semifinal series, four games to none.

title: American City Business Jourals reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Review/Television; The Women Behind the Abortion Ruling, in 'Roe v. Wade'
description: ''Roe v. Wade'' is the sort of show that some people know they don't like before they see it. Several advertisers have withdrawn as sponsors of tonight's two-hour play about the famous abortion-rights case at the behest of the American Family Association of Tupelo, Miss. Its head, the Rev. Donald E. Wildmon, says he presumes ''Roe v. Wade'' is pro-abortion. That, no doubt, is enough to predispose other viewers in its favor. All parties can agree that the scheduling is timely, as the Supreme Court considers a suit involving restrictions on abortion in Missouri.

title: Cuomo Outlines Plan to Aid Kin Of Slain Police
description: Accompanied by the widows of three New York City police officers, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo yesterday outlined a program intended to help the families of officers killed in the line of duty.

title: United Financial of South Carolina Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''The church has told us that we are politically in the right, that we're morally on the only track that can be taken by decent people. But the only solution begins with the recognition of the results of the May 7 election.'' - Ricardo Arias Calderon, an opposition vice-presidential candidate in Panama. [ A9:2. ]

title: Advanced Medical Tech reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the results stated are for controlled therapeutics, a development stage enterprise acquired by Advanced Medical Technologies on March 27, 1989. The company also said the results do not include the losses of its Fidata Corp. unit prior to its acquistion, which was also on March 27. The company said Fidata's operating losses in the first quarter were $354,000.

title: SYRIANS LET EGYPT GO TO ARAB SUMMIT
description: In a shift of policy, Syria said today that it would not oppose Egypt's participation in an Arab summit conference scheduled to begin in Morocco on May 23.

title: G.E. to Cut 1,400 Workers
description: The General Electric Company said today that it would eliminate 1,400 jobs and close two factories to consolidate electric range manufacturing operations in its appliance division.

title: BRIEFS
description: * The European Community is expected to pass laws this week requiring health warnings on all tobacco products, despite opposition from Britain and Greece. The European Community Executive Commission wants all tobacco products sold in the 12-nation bloc after 1992 to carry two warnings: ''Smoking causes cancer'' and ''Smoking causes cardiovascular diseases.''

title: PERONIST IS VICTOR BY A WIDE MARGIN IN ARGENTINE VOTE
description: Led by Carlos Saul Menem, the man widely proclaimed as the political heir of Juan D. Peron, the Peronist movement swept to overwhelming victory tonight in presidential and congressional elections.

title: Leucadia National Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from an accounting change of $2.4 million. The latest first quarter included pretax net securities gains of $2,161,000, compared with $12,623,000 for the year-ago period.

title: Winslow S. Coates, 97, Conservationist on L.I.
description: Winslow Shelby Coates, a Long Island lawyer for six decades who specialized in conservation and zoning legislation, died in his sleep Wednesday at his home in Bayville. He was 97 years old.

Derby Data Hint a California Connection
description: When Sunday Silence ducked and veered his way to a 2 1/2-length upset victory over Easy Goer in the Kentucky Derby nine days ago, most handicappers began trying to figure out how the favorite had been beaten. Most Californians, however, saw nothing surprising about the result: For them, it was business as usual.

title: Fighting Infant Mortality With a Coupon Campaign
description: Edith McAfee and women like her are the targets of a new program aimed at giving babies a better chance of being healthy at birth and becoming healthy children.

Israeli Patrol Wounds Arab After He Shoots 2 Policemen
description: A Palestinian man shot at a police jeep today in northern Israel, slightly wounding two Israeli officers before being shot and seriously wounded himself, hospital officials and the Israeli radio reported.

title: Motor Club of America reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Down Into White Water, Then Up, Up and Away
description: SLOWLY and smoothly, the multicolored balloon floats over green rolling hills still wet with dew, over purple lupine and wild iris and daisies in a horizontal bouquet. Then, in deliberate motions, the balloon descends toward the rushing river until gurgling white water swirls into the wicker basket as it skims the rapids and rises back into the air.

title: Victorious Rarick Outpaces Lopez
description: Nancy Lopez drew the largest galleries and was the sentimental favorite, but Cindy Rarick upstaged her with steady golf and captured the Chrysler-Plymouth Classic today by two strokes over Laura Davies of Britain.

title: Inquiry in Fatal Derailment Is Focused on Faulty Brakes
description: Faulty brakes and overloaded cargo hoppers may have caused the train crash that flattened a row of suburban houses and killed four people, a Federal spokesman said today.

title: Miss Sutro Wed To Noel Sanchez
description: Cristina Johnson Sutro and Noel Joseph Sanchez were married yesterday at the Lotos Club in New York in a ceremony performed by the Rev. Dr. Robert Kaufman, a Unitarian Universalist minister, and the Rev. John A. Corcoran, an Episcopal priest. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Peter Colucci Sutro of Florence, Italy. Mr. and Mrs. Roger Twohey of Brooklyn are the bridegroom's mother and stepfather.

title: Dutch Treats for Marist
description: The search for gifted 7-foot athletes usually leads college basketball coaches to the high school gymnasiums and playgrounds of New York, Washington, Chicago and Los Angeles. But Dave Magarity, the coach of Marist College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., favors the Netherlands.

title: Twins Pound Blue Jays By 13-1
description: Frank Viola did his job today and so did the rest of his teammates.

title: New Savings Unit Rule
description: Federal regulators plan to draft rules to protect savings institutions from hostile takeovers after they convert from the mutual form of ownership to stock ownership. The Federal Home Loan Bank Board said it had directed its staff to rewrite the agency's rules so that the purchase of a savings institution's stock with hostile intent could be a ground for denial of a takeover application for three years after an institution converts to stock ownership.

description: Soviet-American trade prospects are brightening as the pace of the two countries' business contacts increases and as President Bush leans toward easing a 15-year-old law setting tariffs on Soviet imports up to 10 times higher than those from most other countries.

title: Harvard Pulls Away to Win
description: Harvard's varsity crew was true to form today in the final of the Eastern sprint championships. The Crimson eight came from behind with a strong effort over the last 500 meters of the 2,000-meter course to win the championship on Lake Quinsigamond before a crowd of 11,000.

title: Jordan Digs a Deeper Hole for Knicks
description: Michael Jordan began today's game with a noticeable limp. The groin-muscle injury that the Chicago Bulls' star aggravated Saturday also appeared to have slowed his usual quick first step to the basket, so much so that he didn't even try to dunk the ball.

title: U.S. Sees Summit as Positive Event
description: American officials and other Western experts cautiously welcome the summit meeting of Soviet and Chinese leaders this week, but acknowledge that there are some risks for the United States.

title: Churches in Panama Become Rallying Sites for Opposition
description: Four days after opposition leaders were beaten by paramilitary toughs, Panamanians flocked to churches today to cheer opposition figures and applaud a statement by the nation's Roman Catholic bishops denouncing the violence.

title: Copter-Plane Called a Cure jfor Crowded Airports
description: An unusual Government-industry coalition is expanding its efforts to promote civilian uses for a new kind of aircraft even as the Pentagon is halting development of a military version of the aircraft.

description: Rabbi Bernard L. Berzon, spiritual leader for 43 years of Congregation Ahavath Israel, now called Young Israel of Avenue K in the Flatbush-Midwood section of Brooklyn, died Thursday after heart surgery at New York Hospital. He was 76 years old and had lived in Jerusalem since his retirement in 1982.

title: For TV, the Underside of Soviet Life
description: The crime scene could not have been any more graphic unless the American camera crews roaming the underside of Soviet life had come upon some modern-day Raskolnikov with a smoking Saturday-night special yearning to confess.

description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev arrived in Beijing today to seal the reconciliation of the two largest Communist nations when both are struggling through profound economic and political changes.

description: The United States egg industry, already reeling from a five-year slide in sales, is in turmoil over government arguments that hens cannot lay low-cholesterol eggs.

title: Death Penalty in Heinous Cases Is Appropriate; Moral Standing
description: To the Editor Of course, we must do all we can to avoid executing innocent people (''Why Execution Is Dead Wrong,'' editorial, April 29). Therefore, at the least, no one should be sentenced to death unless it is absolutely certain (not merely proved beyond a reasonable doubt) that he or she committed a capital crime. (Clearly, to use an example you used, it was not absolutely certain at any time that Randall Adams committed the crime he was accused of in Texas.) But there remains another, too often neglected, argument against any use of capital punishment. It is an argument well illustrated by the case of Salman Rushdie.

Review/Music; When East and West Meet Without Mingling
description: Trying to build a cultural bridge across the Pacific Ocean usually ends up marooning creative engineers somewhere west of Hawaii. The expanse is great, and so distant are the two respective shores that messages from each are only dimly received. What begins as a melding of two cultures, in other words, ends up having distressingly little to do with either.

title: Constant Reality in a Project: Fear of Violent Drug Gangs
description: Mary Singleton says she knows two apartments in her building where people sell crack, bringing addicts and random gunfire to what was once a decent, safe housing project. But Ms. Singleton says nothing to the police. The last time she complained, she says, her teen-age daughter was attacked, beaten and threatened with a razor.

title: TWO DEAD IN FIRE ON NAVY CARRIER
description: An explosion and fire killed two crewmen on the aircraft carrier America, the Navy said today. It was the third fatal fire aboard a United States warship in less than a month.

description: New York State has paid millions of dollars to companies linked publicly with organized crime, The Sunday Albany Times Union reported today.

description: Thefts of rare birds at zoos around the country are prompting more stringent security and causing some zoos to remove the valuable animals from exhibits.

description: Two nonprofit groups now renovating 2,000 apartments for low-income tenants and homeless families in New York City will rebuild 1,000 more over the next 18 months, officials of the groups said.

title: Employers Cut Health Costs By Bargaining With Doctors
description: On their own or in coalitions, employers from Procter & Gamble to the State of Arizona are aggressively bargaining with doctors and hospitals eager for their business, and increasingly steering their employees to the ones agreeing to the best price.

description: Tests have confirmed that a tree transplanted from the White House lawn to the grounds of the North Dakota Capitol by President Bush carried the destructive gypsy moth.

title: Coelho Says Bonds Were Bought for Him
description: A savings and loan executive purchased and temporarily held $100,000 worth of junk bonds for Representative Tony Coelho, the House Democratic whip, while Mr. Coelho was arranging the financing to purchase the bonds himself, Mr. Coelho said today.

description: Leaders of popular political movements from the Soviet Union's three Baltic republics appealed today to the United Nations to help them become independent nations.

description: The police arrested 255 soccer fans on the last full weekend of the British season, and at least two people were seriously injured in brawls.
