description: Dame Lydia Dunn, a senior member of the colonial government here, is a seasoned politician as celebrated for her perfect British reserve as for her establishment views.

title: Jackson Is Not Ready to Give Up
description: The Knicks are in a position they never thought they would be in. They are trailing the Chicago Bulls, three games to one, in their four-of-seven-game playoff series. And while the Knicks are still talking with confidence, they are not playing as confidently as they sound.

Texaco Canada Petroleum Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds. The company began business in January after acquiring selected exploration and producing assets of Texaco Canada Inc. The company said its first-quarter results reflected exploration expenditures incurred in respect of contractual interests acquired from Texaco Canada Inc. in Brazil and Mauritania, income from Canadian producing properties and interest income on cash and short-term investments. During the quarter, the company also said it abandoned an exploratory well in Brazil and received a payment of $5 million from Pecten Marajo Brazil Co. in connection with the termination of a proposed Farmout agreement. Net income for the quarter reflected the cost of the abandoned well and an offsetting portion of the payment received from Pecten.

title: Review/Theater; 2 Asians and Hollywood's Bias
description: ''Yankee Dawg You Die'' - a cartoon exclamation tinged with both genuine anger and Hollywood camp - is the perfect title for Philip Kan Gotanda's piquant comedy at Playwrights Horizons. Mr. Gotanda's subject, soberly put, is the humiliation that Asian-American actors have suffered when enslaved by screen stereotyping, whether during the glamorous reign of Anna May Wong or in Michael Cimino's ''Year of the Dragon.'' Yet his tone is anything but preachy. Mr. Gotanda is a polemicist who sees both sides of a question, a writer whose grievances are balanced by a wicked sense of humor. He gladly embraces the ludicrous cliches of ''Godzilla'' or World War II P.O.W. potboilers if that's what it takes to turn their racism inside out.

description: b-Included tax credits of $310,000 and income of $183,000 from discontinued operations.

title: A German Relief Aide Is Released in Lebanon
description: A West German relief worker who was reported kidnapped in Lebanon 10 days ago was released today to a Shiite Muslim leader in southern Lebanon, the police and witnesses said.

title: People
description: * Dominick F. Rossi Jr., an executive vice president of N. W. Ayer, was promoted to director of national operations.

title: There's Little to Fear In a Unified Germany
description: LEAD: German reunification is the dirty little secret of United States foreign policy. No one wants to come right out and say that it soon will be the greatest danger facing the West, but that's what almost everyone thinks.

title: STUDENTS IN CHINA FLOOD MAIN SQUARE
description: Thousands of university students occupied Beijing's central square through the night, defying Government plans to seal off the area. They said they wanted to hold their own welcoming ceremony for Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, who arrived today for the first Chinese-Soviet summit meeting in 30 years.

title: PROTEST GOES ON
description: Deng Xiaoping and Mikhail S. Gorbachev shook hands today to signal the formal end of three decades of hostility between China and the Soviet Union.

title: Peronism Tamed?
description: LEAD: Thirteen years ago, Carlos Saul Menem was seized during the military coup that displaced the last Peronist Government and spent some time in military prison. In December, he is to sit in the Casa Rosada as president of Argentina and commander in chief of his former jailers. Argentine democracy has come a long way, but it still has a long way to go.

title: Pitino Is Searching for Ways to Defeat Bulls
description: The psyching began Sunday afternoon almost immediately after the Chicago Bulls had put the Knicks on the brink of elimination from the Eastern Conference semifinals.

New Polish Devaluation
description: Poland devalued its currency, the zloty, today for the sixth time this year, reducing it by 5.3 percent, according to rates published by the Government newspaper Rzeczpospolita. The zloty has now been devalued by the national bank by almost a third since Jan. 1, when the rate was 503 to the dollar. The paper quoted the new official rate, which applies to foreign tourists and foreign trade dealings, at 750 zloties to the dollar, up from 710 on Friday.

In addition the profit attributable to shareholders for the current quarter has been translated at the rates of exchange current at the end of March 1989 being based on Fl. 3.61 equals U.S. $1.69. Exceptions to these conventions have been made for the results arising in the current quarter in hyper-inflationary economies, which have been translated throughout at forecast closing rates for 1989.

title: Q&A
description: Drinking Like a Fish Q.What do whales and other marine mammals drink? What about fish? A.Marine mammals depend primarily on the water content of the food they eat, rather than on drinking sea water, according to Paul Sieswerda, a biologist who is collections manager of the New York Aquarium at Coney Island.

description: The United States Ambassador asserted today that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega ordered an attack on opposition leaders last week in an attempt to assassinate a top opposition candidate, but the Ambassador repeatedly declined to provide any evidence of the plot.

title: Ex-Klansman on Trial In Murder of a Youth
description: A former member of the Ku Klux Klan went on trial today on charges of being an accomplice in the killing of a black teen-ager. The defendant's brother-in-law is on death row for the slaying.

title: Thomas David Dickson, Sea Captain, 91
description: Thomas David Dickson, a retired sea captain, died Saturday at his home in Southbury, Conn. He was 91 years old.

title: Review/Music; A Frenetic Salute to Funk
description: It may be too much to ask that Cold Sweat, a 10-piece group convened by the trombonist Craig Harris to play James Brown's music, have the funk-machine precision and split-second timing of Mr. Brown's long-running band, the JB's. Yet for the best stretches of its late set Thursday at S.O.B.'s, Cold Sweat laid down a savagely propulsive groove that was a worthy tribute to the genius of funk.

title: Alan V. MacDonald, F.B.I. Agent, 44
description: Alan V. MacDonald, an F.B.I. agent who specialized in investigating the sexual abuse of children, died of an aortic aneurism May 8 while visiting relatives in Inverness, Scotland. He was 44 years old and lived in Swampscott, Mass.

title: Argentina's President-Elect in the Shadow of Peron: Carlos Saul Menem
description: The cheering has barely ended from the Argentine elections, but it is already evident that President-elect Carlos Saul Menem is caught in the contradiction between public expectations that he will revive the Peronist tradition of state largesse and the restrictions imposed by a prostrate economy.

title: James Kirkwood Memorial
description: A memorial service for James Kirkwood, the playwright, novelist and actor, is to be held at the Shubert Theater, 225 West 44th Street, on June 1 at noon. Mr. Kirkwood died on April 21 at the age of 58.

title: Vice President's Staff Chief To Depart at the End of June
description: Vice President Dan Quayle's chief of staff, Robert M. Guttman, is resigning at the end of June, a spokesman for Mr. Quayle said tonight.

title: By Design; Summer Classic
description: Sometimes the simplest style turns out to be the spiffiest. Think of how neat and breezy a classic cotton shirtdress is on a hot summer day.

title: Negotiate Short-Range Missiles Out of Europe; Too Close for Comfort
description: To the Editor:

title: U.S. Says Bomb Lost Off Japan Leaked Radiation
description: The United States has told Japan that a hydrogen bomb lost overboard from an American aircraft carrier 24 years ago almost certainly burst under intense water pressure and spread radioactive plutonium on the ocean floor.

title: MOSCOW FAULTED ON MISSILE THREAT
description: Responding to a Soviet threat to retain some short-range nuclear missiles banned by a 1987 treaty, the State Department said today that Moscow should think ''long and hard'' before taking such an ''outlandish'' step.

title: Alice-Leone Moats, 81, Journalist, Is Dead
description: Alice-Leone Moats, a journalist who was the author of nine books, died Sunday at Graduate Hospital, Philadelphia, after a long illness. She was 81 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: Tidewater Asset Sales Opposed
description: Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd., which controls a 10.3 percent stake in Tidewater Inc., said it ''would not tolerate'' any sale of the company's assets to Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis corporate raider, if it would involve a repurchase of Mr. Jacobs's stake in the company. Earlier this month, Mr. Jacobs withdrew his proposed $11-a-share offer for Tidewater but said he was still interested in negotiating a purchase of the company's air and gas compression unit. Tidewater, based in New Orleans, also has a marine equipment division.

title: American Primary Dealer Gets License From Japan
description: The Discount Corporation of New York, a primary dealer in government and Federal agency issues, said yesterday that it had received a license from Japan's Ministry of Finance to engage in the securities business in Japan.

title: Campaign Trail; Patronage Inquiry: Big Blast or Whimper?
description: The investigation of Joseph DeVincenzo, who was a top Koch administration insider, is like a ticking time bomb for the Koch campaign. Koch aides are concerned that Mr. DeVincenzo might be indicted in the middle of the mayoral campaign for lying about the job-dispensing operation he ran in the City Hall basement.

title: Poll Finds That Gorbachev's Rule Eases American Minds on Soviets
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's aggressive and inventive diplomacy has so transformed this country's view of the Soviet Union that two out of three Americans say Moscow no longer poses an immediate military threat to the United States and nearly three out of four consider nuclear war unlikely.

That is the direction the game is taking when sponsors arrange tournaments in which a small number of the highest ranking grandmasters on the International Chess Federation's computer list play a double-round event. Formerly, the 16-player single round-robin format was standard.

title: Iran Economic Plans
description: Iran's Planning and Budget Minister has predicted annual economic growth of 5 percent for the next five years, creating two million new jobs. The minister, Masud Roqani-Zanjani, said at a news conference in Teheran that the Government planned to sell some nonstrategic industries to the private sector and use the proceeds to develop strategic units. Mr. Zanjani, whose comments were reported by the Iranian press agency, said unemployment was expected to drop from the current 15.9 percent to 14.2 percent in 1993.

description: Completing a process it began two years ago, the Supreme Court ruled today that brokerage firms may enforce customer agreements requiring that disputes involving possible fraud be kept out of court and submitted instead to arbitration.

title: Our Towns; Fourth Graders Do Shakespeare For the Fun of It
description: Third graders at George Washington Elementary School do not do Shakespeare. ''In third grade I didn't know anything about Shakespeare,'' said Laura Mannino, 9 years old. ''All I knew, he was a writer in Elizabethan times. That's it. That's it.''

title: 'Heidi Chronicles' Wins Critics Circle Prize
description: ''The Heidi Chronicles'' by Wendy Wasserstein was named the best new play of the 1988-1989 season by the New York Drama Critics Circle at a meeting held yesterday at the Algonquin Hotel. The critics also named Brian Friel's ''Aristocrats'' as the best new foreign play and voted a special citation to Bill Irwin for his show ''Largely New York.''

title: ICH Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest first quarter results included a loss of $7,590,000, compared with income of $1,341,000 a year-earlier from the company's 20 percent equity investment in First Executive Corp. Year-ago earnings are restated because of an adoption of an accounting change.

title: Tech-Sym Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $864,000 from an accounting change.

title: Robert Bach, 71, Former Investment Banker
description: Robert Bach, for two decades a partner in the investment banking concern of Wertheim & Company, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 71 years old and also had a home in Pound Ridge, N.Y.

title: Adams Resources & Energy reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Passing of the Gray Fedora
description: In a gallery of the Museum of Modern Art there used to hang a Richard Oelze painting, titled ''Expectation,'' of a group of men and women gazing at a lowering sky. The men for the most part wore gray fedoras. The effect of the crowd of soft gray crowns, punctuated by the center creases by which fedoras are styled, was one of foreboding, foreshadowing the end of something.

title: Satellites and Lasers Help Track Continents' Drift
description: USING satellites, lasers and even the most distant objects in the sky, scientists are now able to directly monitor and record to the tenth of an inch the movement of the earth's continents, islands and mountain ranges.

title: Trans Canada Glass Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a $2,600,000 special gain. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Pitching Has Angels Hitting Stride
description: In their archives, the California Angels can recall bits of pitching glory: Nolan Ryan spun four of his no-hitters for them; Frank Tanana, in his dazzling youth, won 102 games in an eight-year period; Andy Messersmith once produced a 20-victory season.

title: Chase Unit Gets President
description: The Chase Manhattan Bank said yesterday that it had named Peter John Anderson the president of its Brazilian affiliate, Banco Chase Manhattan S.A.

title: Dow Up 24.19 to Another Post-Crash High
description: LEAD: The stock market continued its rally yesterday, although its advance fell short of Friday's stunning surge. The Dow Jones industrial average added 24.19 points to close at 2,463.89, yet another post-crash high. The Dow has now gained in four straight sessions.

title: Civility Sets Debate Tone In New Jersey
description: The first debate among Democrats running for Governor turned into a surprisingly gentle affair tonight, with three candidates performing a feat that New Jersey politicians often promise but rarely pull off: they attacked the issues and not each other.

title: Making Life Simple For WordPerfect Users
description: WORDPERFECT 5.0 is a popular word-processing program for I.B.M.-compatible computers that seems to offer every feature anyone could think of, and much more besides. But, as with other top-of-the line programs, there is a great deal to learn.

title: Koch Is Late in Picking 3 for New Ethics Panel
description: More than three months after a deadline approved by New York City voters in a referendum last year, the Koch administration has yet to nominate members of a new City Conflicts of Interest Board.

title: Land of Lincoln Savings & Loan reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Progress on Bullets, if Not Guns
description: Supporters of stronger Federal gun control found reason for disappointment yesterday in President Bush's crime speech. But the President at least showed some welcome flexibility where his predecessor had stood stubbornly indifferent to the concerns of police officers outgunned on the street.

title: Stewart Perowne, 87, Diplomat and Author
description: Stewart Perowne, a diplomat, archeologist and historian who wrote books on the history and antiquities of the Mediterranean, died Wednesday at Charing Cross Hospital here. He was 87 years old.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Company Briefs listing of Business Day on Saturday misidentified the company that has offered $8.90 a share for the Polymer International Corporation. It is Intertape Systems Inc. of Montreal.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Wednesday about New York's commodity exchanges described the relative trading volume of three stock index futures contracts incorrectly. The most active of the three is the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index futures contract traded at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. The New York Stock Exchange composite index future contract, traded at the New York Futures Exchange, is next. It is followed by the Major Market Index futures contract traded at the Chicago Board of Trade.

title: Interfund Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Medicare Surcharge Is Opposed
description: A group seeking a reduction in the surtax imposed on millions of America's elderly to pay for coverage for catastrophic illness under Medicare said today that a majority of older Americans who are familiar with the law oppose it.

title: Parks Sentenced
description: Jerry Parks, a former University of Oklahoma cornerback, began serving a jail sentence of nearly three months yesterday after pleading no contest in Norman, Okla., to a charge he shot and wounded a teammate, Zarak Peters. Parks is one of five Oklahoma football players arrested in a series of incidents in January and February.(AP)

title: Rothschild in Frankfurt
description: The Rothschild banking dynasty, which has its start here in the 18th century, plans to reopen an office in this city after an 88-year absence, the city treasurer said today. The Frankfurt office was closed in 1901 as the city's role as a financial center temporarily waned. The city treasurer, Ernst Gerhardt, said Rothschild planned to open an office with about 20 people this summer. He said it would be affiliated with both N. M. Rothschild & Sons of London and Rothschild Bank A.G., based in Zurich. Frankfurt is expected to take on even greater prominence when European Community countries eliminate internal trade barriers in 1992.

title: LSI Logic Names Manager
description: The LSI Logic Corporation, a semiconductor company based in Milpitas, Calif., said today that it had hired Gene Hill, a former head of microprocessor design for the Intel Corporation, to be the general manager of its new Sparc division.

title: Rate Rise Seen in Egypt
description: Under pressure from Western creditors, Egypt will increase its domestic interest rates, Egyptian newspapers said today. They did not say how much the increase would be, but central bank officials have recommended an increase of two to four percentage points on deposit rates and of one to two points on loans. Such a move would be in response to a demand by the International Monetary Fund for higher interest rates to attract savings now held abroad. Egypt has a $43 billion foreign debt.

title: Patrick Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Books of The Times; Biography of Nehru From a New Point of View
description: Nehru The Making of India By M. J. Akbar 609 pages. Viking. $24.95.

title: Israel Says Army Will Get Tougher If Palestinians Reject Offer of Vote
description: Defense Minister Yitzhak Rabin warned today that if Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza Strip did not accept Israel's offer of elections, he would order the military to deal more harshly with the Palestinian uprising.

title: Bond Table Incomplete
description: Because the computers that receive and transmit financial market data at The Associated Press were intermittently down yesterday, the New York Stock Exchange bond trading table reflects only those trades recorded after 1:30 P.M. Eastern daylight time. The listings for the Midwest and Philadelphia stock exchanges and certain summary information for the Nasdaq issues were also not available.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: U.S. Vehicle Sales Are Down By 8.2% in Early Days of May
description: Sales of new domestic cars and light trucks were off 8.2 percent in early May when compared with the corresponding period last year, which was unusually strong. Compared with last month, the market's overall strength was down only slightly.

title: N.F.L. Bans Wilson
description: Stanley Wilson, the Cincinnati Bengals' running back suspended for drug use on the eve of the Super Bowl, was permanently banned from the National Football League yesterday for his substance-abuse problem.

title: Traditional Defense Stressed in Jets' Mini-Camp
description: They call the equipment manager - and even the newspaper reporters -''Sir'' and read the notes on the bulletin boards and smile nervously at one another.

title: Heart Transplant Study Finds Gap in Expertise
description: Most hospitals where heart transplants were performed did too few of them to maintain the expertise required for such complicated surgery, the General Accounting Office reported today.

title: Review/Music; A Pianist and His Friends
description: Shelley Grossman, a pianist who has often performed locally over the years, returned to Weill Recital Hall Saturday afternoon for one of those ''. . . and Friends'' programs that have been gaining favor lately. He devoted his first half to accompanying wind players in a series of solo works and then to Mozart's E-flat Quintet (K. 452).

title: Alleghany Raises Stake in St. Paul
description: The Alleghany Corporation, a New York-based insurance company, said it had raised its stake in the St. Paul Companies to 9.5 percent from 8.4 percent. In a Securities and Exchange Commission filing, Alleghany also repeated its position that it intends to raise its stake in the St. Paul to 20 percent, subject to clearance from regulatory agencies. St. Paul stock closed today unchanged at $48.75 a share in over-the-counter trading. At that price, Alleghany's cost of raising its stake to 20 percent would be more than $238 million. St. Paul is an insurance and financial services concern based in St. Paul.

title: Williams Dropped; Gaston Fills In
description: When the season began, the Toronto Blue Jays generally were conceded to have the best talent in the American League's Eastern Division. Six weeks into the season, the Blue Jays have the second-worst record in the major leagues and a new manager.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Saatchi Reshuffles Division's Executives
description: The Saatchi & Saatchi Company announced yesterday that Roy Warman and Terry K. Bannister, the co-directors of its communications division, which includes its ad agencies, would take the jobs of co-chief executives of the division.

title: Coeur D'Alene Mines reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Suppose Men Feared Rape
description: LEAD: Fate is kind. Most men don't have to live with the fear of being raped.

title: Valspar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
London Journal; In the Midnight Streets, Shepherding the Destitute
description: As night crept toward dawn, hundreds of people walked along the city streets in search of despair.

title: American Israeli Paper Mills Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results in new Israeli shekels were translated into U.S. dollars at the rate of exchange in effect at March 31, 1989, of NIS 1.8195 to U.S. $1.

title: Volkswagen To Sell Diesel Cars in U.S.
description: Responding to higher gasoline prices and what it hopes is a group of eager buyers, Volkswagen A.G. said today that it would again offer a diesel car in the United States.

title: Valid Logic Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Apple Industry Says It Will End Use of Chemical
description: The apple industry, citing a sharp drop in sales that has already cost growers $50 million, said today that the growers would voluntarily stop using the chemical Alar by this fall.

title: Britain Delays Burying of Old Theater
description: Campaigners fighting to save the newly discovered remains of the 16th-century Rose Theater from burial under an office building won a last-minute reprieve today.

title: Lead Poisoning May Well Have Helped the Roman Empire Fall; Tomatoes Came Later
description: To the Editor:

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Court Expands Right of Wardens to Censor Inmates' Reading
description: Overruling part of a 15-year-old precedent, the Supreme Court today gave prison officials greater flexibility in censoring publications that prisoners may receive.

title: Loral to Buy Military Systems Unit
description: Schlumberger Ltd., the New York-based oil services company, said yesterday that it had reached an agreement to sell its military systems unit, Fairchild Weston Systems, to the Loral Corporation, a military electronics contractor in New York.

title: A Good Law for Bad Gas
description: New York State's new budget contains a welcome, overdue program to protect motorists against mislabeled and adulterated gasoline.

title: U.S. Reports April Pickup By Industry
description: The industrial sector picked up strength in April after a two-month pause, the Government reported today, but economists said the rebound might not signal a rekindling of inflation.

title: He Learned To Putt In the Dark
description: rrFor all his success in golf, Billy Casper is thought of primarily as a putter, up there with Bobby Locke as the two best in history. Now 57 years old, Billy Casper has always been long enough and straight enough, but on the greens he has a tender touch that others on the Senior PGA Tour still envy. When he won the 1959 United States Open at Winged Foot, he set an Open record with only 114 putts over 72 holes. When he won the 1966 Open in an 18-hole playoff with Arnold Palmer at Olympic, over 90 holes he never three-putted.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Bank International, a subsidiary of American Express Co., named Andre Sharon senior investment officer.

title: Pubco Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago first quarter net was less than 1 cent.

title: Blackstone Seeks Edgcomb
description: The Blackstone Group, a New York investment bank, announced yesterday that it was initiating a tender offer for the Edgcomb Corporation, a Philadelphia steel service-center company.

title: Optrotech Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Security Federal Savings & Loan Cleveand reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Includes an extraordinary charge of $80,000 from prepayment of debt. Per share figures for 1988 are not available because the company converted to stock ownership on Jan. 15, 1988.

title: Soviets Said to Halt Arms Aid to Nicaragua
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev informed President Bush this month that all Soviet weapons deliveries to Nicaragua were suspended at the beginning of 1989 and would not be resumed, an Administration official said tonight.

title: Baltek Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Previous Safety Violations Linked To 2 Railroad Men in Train Crash
description: The engineer and the brakeman of a runaway train that killed four people and demolished a row of suburban homes had been previously cited for safety violations, investigators say.

title: Teacher Strike Spreads Chaos In Los Angeles
description: At least 20,000 Los Angeles teachers went on strike today seeking higher pay and more administrative control, throwing the nation's second largest school district into chaos and jeopardizing the issuing of student grades as the school year neared its end.

title: Organogenesis Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Edward Schuldner, Executive, 49
description: Edward Schuldner, a senior partner in the Redford Group, an executive placement concern, died, apparently of an aneurism, Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 49 years old.

title: VSE Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said net for the latest quarter included nonrecurring realized gains on the sale of marketable securities of $374,000, or 21 cents a share.

title: Motrin Product
description: The Upjohn Company said it would begin trade shipments June 1 of Motrin IB, a nonprescription version of its popular Motrin ibuprofen pain reliever. The product, to be available in both tablets and caplets, will compete in the $2 billion United States market for internal analgesics, said Upjohn, which introduced Motrin in 1974.

title: Catholic Is Killed in Ulster And I.R.A. Office Is Shelled
description: A Roman Catholic worker was shot to death today, apparently in a sectarian attack, and the political wing of the Irish Republican Army said one of its offices was hit by a rocket.

title: Barbara L. Barry Becomes a Bride
description: Barbara Lee Barry and Christopher Anthony Coates were married Saturday at the Church at Waterloo in Waterloo Village, N.J., by the Rev. Rebecca Radillo, a United Methodist minister. The bride is the daughter of John J. Barry of New York and Sparta, N.J., and Edna H. Barry of Freehold, N.J. The bridegroom is the son of Sarah W. Coates of New Haven and the late Anthony R. Coates of Sherman, Conn.

title: Tour de Trump: Promising Start
description: Mike Plant remembers his fears of eight months ago, when he started to put together the first Tour de Trump bicycle race.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Agency's Head Follows A Passion for Bicycles
description: After leaving a copywriting job at J. Walter Thompson in 1985, Richard Rosenthal discovered bicycle touring. Four years later, he runs an agency that creates advertising for several leading bicycle makers and the United States Cycling Federation.

title: Riverside Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter included $187,000 in net realized investment gains and other income. The year-ago period included $730,000 in net realized investment gains and other income.

title: Sonesta International Hotels reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Bush Gift List: From Horseshoes to Caviar
description: Among the documents released in the capital today was one SF 278/ FPM Chapter 734/U.S. Office of Personnel Management, or the Financial Disclosure Report of Bush, George H. W.; position, President; position(s) held with the Federal Government in the preceding 12 months, Vice President, through Jan. 19.

title: Ivory Coast Cocoa Shift
description: Ivory Coast, the world's biggest cocoa producer, said today that it would sell its next crop through London in hopes of raising prices from their present 13-month lows. Ivory Coast's decision represents a shift in its marketing policy. The French trade house Sucres et Denrees played a key role in managing Ivoirian cocoa exports in 1988-89. The new crop year starts in October. In the last year, Ivory Coast kept its export prices above world levels, but lost market share as consumers switched to cheaper cocoa from Malaysia and elsewhere.

title: U.S. Invasion Is Debated in Panama
description: One of the happiest days in Martha D.'s life came last year when Washington began seeking the overthrow of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega; one of the unhappiest, the day she realized the United States would not invade.

title: Latin Aid Bank Is Offering Bonds
description: The InterAmerican Development Bank yesterday offered $300 million of 20-year bonds through an underwriting syndicate led by Salomon Brothers.

title: Michigan State Makes a Rare Tourney Bid
description: Michigan State, Adelphi's opponent tomorrow in the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I lacrosse tournament, lacks an imposing won-lost record - only 8-6 - but the Spartans have played some quality opponents and will not feel intimidated.

title: Winners of Visas Announced
description: A Pakistani bachelor, an Iranian mother living in West Germany and another bachelor from Kuwait were announced today as the first three of 20,000 winners of visas to the United States in a Government contest.

title: New York City Planning to End Its Water Curbs
description: A state panel recommended today that mandatory water restrictions in New York City and much of the downstate area be relaxed, but as a precaution, it suggested that Gov. Mario M. Cuomo leave his emergency drought declaration in place until September.

title: Holly Farms Defends Auction Plan
description: Officials of the Holly Farms Corporation said yesterday that they had received indications that Conagra Inc., one of its would-be purchasers, was prepared to pay substantially more than the $63.50-a-share offer on the table from Tyson Foods Inc., the other bidder.

title: Negotiate Short-Range Missiles Out of Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: Schwitzer Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Schwitzer is one of three manufacturing units spun off to shareholders of Household International Inc. last month.

title: Still No to Withholding
description: To the Editor:

title: Dollar's Puzzling Rise Continues; 30-Month High Against the Mark
description: The dollar jumped sharply yesterday against other major currencies, seriously undercutting the efforts of the United States and its allies to manage the foreign exchange market.

title: G.O.P. Talent Scouts Watch Giuliani
description: Politics, like hunting, tends to be a seasonal sport, and, in this off-year for national elections, there are only a few species of big game to stalk.

title: Charge Is Thrown Out In Trial of Gene Gotti
description: The most serious charge in the narcotics racketeering trial of Gene Gotti was thrown out yesterday when Judge John R. Bartels of Federal District Court in Brooklyn ruled that Federal prosecutors had not proved that Mr. Gotti and another defendant were guilty of the charge, running a continuing criminal enterprise.

title: Reds Rally in Ninth to Top Pirates
description: Herm Winningham's two-run, bases-loaded single capped a three-run rally with two out in the ninth inning tonight as the Cincinnati Reds beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6-5.

title: Alubec Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Mission Resources Partners LP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings are in units.

title: Vishay Intertechnology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Share earnings adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split on common stock and class B common stock paid on Nov. 18, 1988. The large increase in sales was primarily a result of the acquisitions made by the company in the second half of 1988. On July 1, 1988, the company acquired the remaining 50 percent of Dale Holdings Inc. and now owns 100 percent of Dale. In addition, effective Oct. 1, 1988, Vishay acquired Sfernice S.A., a manufacturer of electronic resistors headquartered in Nice, France.

title: Thermo Cardiosystems reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: Year-ago net is equal to less than one cent.

title: Reuter Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
How to Upstage Gorbachev
description: Once again, Mikhail Gorbachev has left the United States looking off balance and recalcitrant in the effort to reduce nuclear arms competition. Here's one American - and I suspect there are many - who'd like to see our side get the jump on Mr. Gorbachev, for a change. And a useful way to do it is at hand. Administration officials say the Soviet leader's plan for a small cut in his country's short-range nuclear missile force was mostly propaganda. No doubt; it certainly took the headlines away from James Baker's visit to Moscow. Still, these officials argue, President Bush need not compete with Mr. Gorbachev in what they call ''P.R.'' but should hold to a ''cautious'' course.

title: Blacks Shaped Language Of Apartheid, Linguists, Say
description: AFRIKAANS, the language that symbolizes white supremacy, has actually been heavily influenced by tribal dialects and is widely spoken by South Africans of mixed and black racial origins.

title: Stanley M. Levine, 69, A Water Commissioner
description: Stanley M. Levine, a business executive and member of the North Jersey District Water Supply Commission, died of heart disease yesterday at St. Joseph's Hospital and Medical Center in Paterson, N.J. He was 69 years old and lived in Paterson.

title: No Charges for Tyson
description: Mike Tyson, the heavyweight champion, will not face criminal charges in Los Angeles stemming from accusations he hit a parking attendant on April 10. Lack of witnesses and evidence made it unlikely the boxer could be convicted of the misdemeanor charges had that been under consideration, Assistant City Attorney Timothy Hogan said yesterday.(AP)

title: Menem, Peronist. What's a Peronist?
description: In despair over a crumbling economy, Argentine voters let hope prevail over caution in Sunday's presidential election. The victor by a solid electoral majority is the Peronist, Carlos Saul Menem. The U.S. can share the hope, acclaim a democratic election and yet keep in mind Peronist disasters past.

title: Amplicon Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a gain of $1,350,000 from the cumulative effect of a tax accounting change. Latest quarter results reflect the adoption of a new accounting method mandated by FASB's adoption of technical bulletin 88-1, which prohibits the company from restating prior periods where annual financial statements have previously been issued. The company said that because of 88-1, latest quarter and 9 months results are not comparable to prior periods. It said that results for the first and second quarters of this year will be restated to reflect 88-1, and that this will result in a downward revision of the company's previously reported revenues and profits for both quarters. Additionally, the company's third quarter results will change at year- end as a result of the restatement of the first two quarters.

title: Savings Rescue Bill Gives Special Treatment to Some
description: Lawmakers writing legislation to rescue the nation's troubled savings industry have adorned the complex bill with amendments that provide special treatment for a handful of institutions, banks and financial corporations.

title: Starrett Housing Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The results for both periods have been adjusted for dividends and discounts on non-convertible preferred stock of $451,000 for latest quarter and $340,000 for year-ago period.

title: First Calgary Petroleums Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a special gain of $156,754. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Asset Investors Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest quarter included a $2,800,000 charge to operations as the result of an adjustment to the carrying amount of three of the company's collateralized mortgage obligation excess cash flows.

title: Edgar Awards for Mysteries
description: The novelist Hillary Waugh has been named a Grand Master among mystery writers by the Mystery Writers of America, which has also announced the winners of the 1989 Edgar Allan Poe Awards. Mr. Waugh was honored for his four decades of work.

title: GF Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Advocates of Change Win More Seats in 2d Round of Soviet Vote
description: Change-minded candidates won more seats in the new Soviet Parliament in a second round of voting, according to results made public today, with the most resounding victory going to a criminal investigator who made charges of corruption at the highest levels.

title: Rig Count Climbs a Bit
description: The count of oil and gas rigs climbed by 7 last week, to 771, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. A year ago, the count totaled 883. The count, the widely watched industry index of drilling activity, reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil as of last Friday.

title: American Medical Buildings Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss Latest share earnings was less than one cent a share.

title: Kidder Names Head Of Investment Banking
description: Moving to overcome a series of recent defections, Kidder, Peabody & Company yesterday named Scott C. Newquist as the head of investment banking, effective on June 1.

title: Joint Venture For Housing In Rockaways
description: New York City named a private developer yesterday to build a $2 billion project of 10,000 condominium apartments on a two-mile stretch of beachfront land in the Arverne section of the Rockaways in Queens.

title: U.S. Looks to Latins on Noriega
description: Administration officials said today that they hoped that the Organization of American States would call this week for the replacement of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, but they expressed concern that the group would take a lesser step, like denouncing the Panamanian leader.

title: Check Technology reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $85,000 and $208,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Net loss and included a loss of $20,000 from the reversal of a tax credit for the quarter and the 6 months is after a $30,000 tax credit.

title: Farragut Mortgage Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a restructuring charge of about $160,000.

title: Parties to Namibia Pact Discuss Timetable
description: Negotiations to put Namibia's stalled independence timetable back on track opened today near this border town, where the first incursions by guerrillas infiltrating from Angola set off bitter fighting a month and a half ago.

title: Farm Credit System reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the major factor in the improved first-quarter results was an increase in net interest income of $93 million to $239 million, compared with $146 million for the same period last year. An increase of $12 million in gains of sales of other property owned compared to the same period last year also contributed to the improvement in net income.

title: Canstar Sports reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $1.4 milllion, mainly from the sale of assets. The company completed a recapitalization last year, and said year- earlier results do not provide a meaningfull comparison. It reported that it had a loss of $1.8 million on sales of $12.4 million in the 1988 first quarter. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: News Corp Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $17,905,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary gain of $127,653,000 for the 9 months. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary charge of $60,906,000. d-After an extraordinary gain of $9,851,000. The results are in U.S. dollars. Share earnings are in American Depositary Receipt (ADR) and each ADR represented two of the company's ordinary shares. Revenue and earnings of U.S. operations are stated in actual dollars, while those of Australian and U.K. operations have been converted from foreign currencies to U.S. dollars at the average rates of exchange prevailing in each period.

title: INSIDE
description: In Peron's Footsteps Carlos Saul Menem used an almost mystical personal manner to appeal to voters in Argentina. Page A3. Supercomputer Rivalry Seymour Cray, the nation's foremost supercomputer designer, will form his own company. Page D1. The Charter Revision Race New York City's charter panel completed its preliminary proposals. The plan so far, pages B1 and B4.

title: On Horse Racing; Sunday Silence Will Have a Foot to Run On
description: rrIt appears now that the bruise on Sunday Silence's right front foot will not keep the Kentucky Derby winner from running in the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico on Saturday. The injury, though, regardless of its severity, is certain to bruise the race.

title: Financial News Network Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said year-ago third quarter and 9 months ended May 31. The company changed its year-end to June 30 from Aug. 31 in June of 1988. The company attributed the lower net in the latest quarter to costs related to its expansion program.

title: WestAir Holding Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Sanmark-Stardust Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The latest periods' nets benefited from tax loss carryforwards, but the amounts were not given.

title: Ex-Kinney Chief Seeks DWG Role
description: Andrew N. Heine, former chairman and chief executive of Kinney System Inc., said he intended to wage a proxy fight to unseat Victor Posner, chairman and chief executive of the DWG Corporation, a Miami Beach company with interests in textiles, liquid petroleum gas and soft drinks.

title: Technology Report Finds U.S. Lagging
description: The Defense Department says Japan has a significant lead in developing 6 of 22 technologies that the Pentagon considers crucial to national security and ''the long-term qualitative superiority'' of American weapons systems.

title: Embassy Asks Trade Caution
description: As the Bush Administration approaches its first major decision on trade policy, the American Embassy in Tokyo is urging Washington to refrain from tough action to retaliate against Japan for its trade barriers.

title: Excerpts From the 2 Presidents' Remarks at Opening Banquet
description: Following are excerpts from remarks by Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, and Yang Shangkun, the Chinese President, at a state banquet yesterday in the Great Hall of the People in Beijing. Mr. Gorbachev's remarks were provided in translation by Reuters; Mr. Yang's remarks were provided in translation by The Associated Press. Remarks by Gorbachev

title: Helping Glasnost Grow
description: Early this spring, Mikhail Gorbachev signed a decree that retained and even strengthened some of the very provisions of Soviet law his despised predecessors invoked to throw political dissenters into prison.

title: Canada Southern Petroleum Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Carlsson Upset in Rome: Mark Koevermans of the Netherlands defeated third-seeded Kent Carlsson of Sweden, 6-3, 6-4, yesterday in the first round of the Italian Open in Rome. The 21-year-old Koevermans, ranked No. 98 in the world, used a strong serve and a steady baseline game to defeat the hard-hitting Swede, who is ranked ninth in the world. Mark Woodeforde of Australia, seeded 16th, became the first casualty among seeded players as he lost to Fernando Luna of Spain, 6-2, 6-3. (AP) Lendl Wins German Open: Ivan Lendl won his 78th Grand Prix title when he beat Horst Skoff of Austria, 6-4, 6-1, 6-3, in the rain-delayed final of the German Open yesterday in Hamburg, West Germany. Lendl, the top-ranked player in the world, had to struggle in the opening set as Skoff, ranked 31st, used his sharp, hard-hitting baseline play to catch Lendl out of position. Skoff, who beat second-seeded Boris Becker in the semifinals Sunday, broke Lendl's serve to take a 4-2 lead in the first set. But a double-fault at 40-30 in the next game cost him dearly. Lendl broke Skoff's serve in the seventh game as he went on a four-game sweep. Lendl faced little resistance after that. He won $135,000; Skoff won $67,500.(AP) HORSE RACING Victory for Honolulu Honey: Honolulu Honey came from far back to overtake Bold Wench and win the $47,000 Heavenly Ade purse for fillies and mares 3 years old and up yesterday at Belmont Park. Honolulu Honey, carrying 117 pounds under Jeff Carle, was a length ahead of Bold Wench, ridden by Jose Martinez and assigned 119 pounds. The victory was the third in seven starts this year for Honolulu Honey, who covered a mile and a sixteenth on the fast track in 1:43 1/5. Honolulu Honey earned $28,200 for Frank Stronach and paid $18.80, $7.20 and $3.00 for $2 across the board. (AP)

title: Peter Scott, 50, Leader In Cause of Gay Rights
description: Peter Scott, a champion of gay rights who canceled a campaign for the California Assembly after learning that he had AIDS, died of complications from the disease at his home here on Saturday. He was 50 years old. A lawyer who gave up his practice to advocate gay rights, Mr. Scott worked to defeat measures requiring the dismissal of homosexual teachers and requiring that people with acquired immune deficiency syndrome be registered with the state. He also led the fight in California to hasten testing of experimental AIDS drugs, a result of which was a drug-testing bill passed into law in 1987.

title: RESULTS PLUS

Jimmy Connors, seeded fifth, breezed past Cedric Pioline of France, 6-4, 6-2, in the first round. Sixth-seeded Emilio Sanchez of Spain also had a easy time in his opening match, defeating Eduardo Bengoechea of Argentina, 6-1, 6-2, in just over an hour.

description: In reconvening what amounts to a municipal constitutional convention, Frederick A. O. This would be a chance to take a government that seems to lurch from crisis to crisis and compel it to plan more effectively.

title: Isolation Researcher Loses Track of Time in Cave
description: An isolation researcher living in a 200-square-foot cubicle built inside a cave thinks she has two months to go in her underground hideaway when in fact she will see daylight for the first time since mid-January in just one week.

title: The Knicks' Learning Experience
description: Midway in the second quarter, with the Knicks having burst into a 56-47 lead, Patrick Ewing raised a clenched fist and Mark Jackson was whirling his right index finger. But as those two young Knicks hurried to the bench for a timeout, Trent Tucker confronted them. ''Don't be celebrating,'' Tucker said. Little by little, game by game, these young Knicks are learning more and more about how to compete and how to act in the National Basketball Association playoffs. If they had celebrated too early last night, they might not have been able to hold off Michael Jordan and the Bulls, 121-114. Instead, the Knicks narrowed the Bulls' lead to 3-2 in the four-of-seven-game Eastern Conference semifinal series, which will resume Friday night in Chicago.

title: Why Voters Wink at Scandal

title: New York School Board Ponders Interim Contract for Green Deputy
description: New York City's Board of Education is considering offering an interim contract to the acting schools chancellor while it conducts a full-scale search for a black or Hispanic candidate to run the nation's largest school system.

title: Koch Offers $500 Million Plan To Replace Armory Shelters
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch announced an ambitious plan yesterday to replace the city's 11 barrack-style armory shelters with smaller, more humane shelters and to give increased special attention to drug abusers, the mentally ill and those suffering from AIDS-related illnesses.

title: Corona Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company was formed July 1, 1988 from the merger of five companies. The company said those five companies had combined earnings for the 1988 first quarter of $7.5 million, or 6 cents a share, on revenue of $44.3 million. The average shares outstanding were 135.2 million in the latest period, compared with 121 million a year- earlier. The company said that including results from the Page-Williams Gold Mine at Hemlo, Ont., it had first quarter net of $6 million, or 4 cents a share, on revenue of $71.4 million. Ownership of the Page-Williams Mine is the subject of court action. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Oil Spill Hearings Open With New Evidence on Exxon Skipper's Drinking
description: Federal hearings into the Alaskan oil spill opened here today with new evidence that the captain of the Exxon Valdez had been drinking on shore in the hours before the tanker ran aground and with the ship's third mate recalling his own failure to control her.

title: Richard Jones 3d, Lawyer, 84
description: Richard Jones 3d, a retired lawyer with the firm of Simpson, Thatcher & Bartlett, died of Alzheimer's disease Saturday at a nursing home in Manhattan. He was 84 years old and lived in Delray Beach, Fla.

title: Eric Dean, 64, Leader of Religious Groups
description: The Rev. Eric Dean, a former leader of several national religious groups, died Saturday after a long illness. He was 64 years old and lived in Crawfordsville.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We don't think that capitalist countries have a monopoly on freedom, democracy and human rights. People in socialist countries should also enjoy freedom, democracy and human rights. China is prepared to improve these aspects of its political reform.'' - Prime Minister Li Peng of China. [ A1:6. ]

title: Buddy Jacobson, Horse Trainer And Convicted Slayer, Dies at 58
description: Howard (Buddy) Jacobson, a leading trainer of thoroughbred race horses who was convicted in 1980 of killing a rival for the affections of a Manhattan model, died of bone cancer early yesterday at the Erie County Medical Center in Buffalo. He was 58 years old and had been sent to the medical center on April 19 from the New York State prison at Attica.

title: Yevtushenko Is Elected
description: An editor and anti-Stalinist campaigner, Vitaly Korotich, has been elected to the new Soviet parliament along with a close associate, the poet Yevgeny Yevtushenko. Mr. Korotich, editor of the weekly Ogonyok, won 80 percent of the vote on Sunday in Kharkov, the Ukraine, his secretary said today. Mr. Yevtushenko was elected in another district of Kharkov. Poems and reminiscences by Mr. Yevtushenko, a radical advocate of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's changes, often appear in Ogonyok.

title: New York Funds To Support Exxon

In a statement, the trustees of the system cited Exxon management's agreement last week to recommend that a person with an environmental background be named to the company's board of directors and to recommend that a committee of directors be formed to consider environmental questions, among other steps. Exxon has come under scrutiny in the wake of the Alaska oil spill on March 24.

title: 3 Men Being Tried for 3d Time In Killing of a Detective in '86
description: A third effort to convict three men of charges that they murdered a police detective outside a Queens diner in 1986 began yesterday with a Federal prosecutor contending that the men ''eliminated'' the detective because they thought he was a threat to a gambling operation they ran for the Genovese crime family.

title: Fox Network Adds 4 Shows for Fall
description: The Fox Entertainment Group will add four shows to its television schedule in September when it begins offering original programming on Monday nights, the president of the company, Peter Chernin, said yesterday.

Supreme Court Justice Blocks An Abortion for a Teen-Ager
description: A Supreme Court justice today temporarily blocked a Florida teen-ager from having an abortion.

title: The Drought Beyond the Drought
description: In the wake of yesterday's downpour, the very word ''drought'' sounds almost silly. May showers have raised the reservoirs to more than 90 percent of capacity and washed away New York's fears of another drought, the third in the last decade to require emergency water conservation rules. The state drought management task force now recommends lifting the emergency. But no more than a momentary sigh of relief is permissible; a larger drought remains.

title: Trade Board in Ruling
description: The Chicago Board of Trade said today that for the first time it would require broker associations - groups of brokers who pool income - to register with the exchange. The measure was approved by the board's directors, presumably to stiffen enforcement in the wake of an undercover operation at the exchange by the Federal Bureau of Investigation. That operation has yet to result in any formal charges or indictments, but many industry experts believe that broker associations invite wrongdoing.

title: Scholars Seek Wider Reach for Women's Studies
description: Twenty years after women's studies programs were introduced at major colleges and universities, they have become a solid academic presence, with more than 30,000 courses being offered around the country. But to the frustration of feminists and specialists in the area, the field remains in a category of its own, rather than part of every student's education.

title: REBEL ISSUE STALLS PLAN FOR NAMIBIA
description: Namibia's United Nations-sponsored transition to independence is being stalled because of difficulty in determining whether Namibian insurgents have withdrawn from the territory and returned to their bases in Angola.

title: Hal Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said effective Jan. 1, 1989, it changed its method of accounting for scheduled heavy airframe overhauls on its L-1011 and DC-8 aircraft from the expense-as-incurred method to the deferral method. The effect of the change was to reduce the net loss for the 1989 first quarter by about $2,295,000. The cumulative effect of the accounting change on prior years was not material. The company had adopted the change on Jan. 1, 1988, the pro forma net loss for the 1988 first quarter would have been $1,041,000.

description: Amway, the privately held direct-selling company based in Ada, Mich,, said in a letter to the board of Avon Products Inc., that it would negotiate an increase in its offer of $39 a share for Avon if the cosmetics company furnishes it with non-public information. Amway also said it would probably keep the companies' distribution networks separate after a merger. John Cox, an Avon spokesman, declined to comment on Amway's letter.

title: Review/Television; 'Big Time,' on Three Lives And the Material World
description: The makers of ''Big Time,'' the ''American Playhouse'' presentation on Channel 13 at 9 this evening, are attempting, in the words of a press release, to ''play with the idea of the film making process itself.'' The target is nothing less than the emptiness of the materialistic world being marketed through contemporary filmmaking processes, from high-tech commercials to titillating music videos. It's an ambitious idea, executed for a distinguished television series by clearly imaginative people. But it doesn't quite work. ''Big Time'' began as a stage play by Keith Reddin. There are three principal characters. Fran (Mia Sara) is a fashion model yearning to find the true significance of life as a serious actress. Michael (Dennis Boutsikaris) is a successful investment banker with whom Fran lives. And Paul (Adrian Pasdar), Fran's paramour and Michael's friend, is a photographer and cameraman whose work ranges from photos of execution victims in Central America to glamorous television commercials for perfumes.

title: An Artist Waits
description: Dear Anna: Yes, it is unjust that the dead Picasso's self-portrait fetches $47.9 million while my own little - let us not call them newspaper columns - feuilletons, rather, bring in scarcely enough to support our occasional weekends at Asbury Park.

title: Exploration Co of Louisiana reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Why Discourage Democracy?; Four Good Ideas for Getting More People to Vote
description: When the country held the Presidential election last November, Americans yawned. Barely half the voting age population voted - the lowest turnout since 1924. Why? The arid campaign didn't help. But neither did America's system of registering voters - a 50-state hodgepodge so daunting that only two-thirds of the voting age population is registered. The House and Senate are now advancing similar proposals that would make it easier for Americans to register and vote in Federal elections. The proposals make excellent sense.

title: Blind Man Is Beaten As Officers Mistake Cane for a Weapon
description: Two police officers beat a blind man with their batons after mistaking his collapsible cane for an illegal martial arts weapon, the authorities said.

title: Voters in Denver Approve A New $2.3 Billion Airport
description: In a move that could ease air-traffic delays nationwide, Denver voters today approved a plan to build the first major new airport in the United States in 15 years.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: THE ECONOMY Construction of new homes slid last month to the lowest level in more than six years, the Government reported. The real estate industry said in a separate report that prices of existing homes were rising with much less force nationwide. [ Page A1. ] The Senate and House might have to relinquish some control over top military programs if the U.S. is to maintain the superiority of its military technology, a Congressional study said. [ D7. ] The Air Force suspended payment on Loral's contract to build a radar warning system for the F-16 fighter. [ D7. ] INTERNATIONAL The Senate defeated an attempt to block the Administration's agreement to build an advanced fighter plane with Japan. The 52-to-47 vote reflected lawmakers' anger over the $7 billion deal. [ D1. ] Robert Maxwell and Rupert Murdoch joined forces in a multimillion-dollar deal linking satellite and cable television. [ D1. ] Commerce Secretary Mosbacher called on Moscow to stop stealing high-technology secrets. [ D9. ] Talks resume today between Mexico and its commercial bank lenders on a debt reduction and restructuring package. [ D16. ] COMPANIES Minorco conceded defeat in its $4.2 billion bid for Consolidated Gold Fields. British law bars another bid for a year. [ D1. ] Home Box Office will enter the basic cable business with a 24-hour all-comedy channel. [ D1. ] Continental canceled its increase in discount fares, saying competitors had not matched its move. [ D5. ] . Procter & Gamble has put Crush International up for sale, the latest giant to fail in the soft-drink business. [ D2. ] Cray Research's stock plunged $6, or 10.8 percent, to $49.75, after the news that its founder would start a new company. [ D5. ] A Federal bankruptcy judge said Eastern Airlines' management was acting properly in seeking to sell the shuttle. [ D5. ] I.B.M. introduced, as expected, an ambitious set of software that addresses the changing role of the mainframe. [ D4. ] Southmark lost more than $1 billion in the first quarter. It said the loss reflected problem real estate loans. [ D4. ] MARKETS The S.E.C. charged a former paralegal with Skadden, Arps with violating securities laws by passing on insider information. [ D9. ] Stock prices fell after rising for four sessions. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 10.44 points, to 2,453.45. [ D10. ] Prices of Treasury securities were mixed in light trading, as longer issues outperformed short-term notes and bills. [ D16. ] Yields were flat for C.D.'s and bank money market accounts. [ D24. ] The dollar's rally stalled amid traders' nervousness over forthcoming Government data. [ D17. ] Grain and soybean futures prices plunged after forecasts of increased rain. [ D17. ] TECHNOLOGY Experimental vehicles that burn methanol are turning up with increasing frequency. [ D8. ] Someday, shoppers will dig through the onion bin reading labels on each onion that indicate its sweetness and pungency. [ D8. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Can America curb its addiction to fossil fuels? Fears focus on demand. Peter Passell: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Bergner's acquisition of Carson Pirie Scott shows how appealing regional retailers have become. Market Place. [ D10. ] David Ogilvy said he was ''miserable'' after Ogilvy agreed to be taken over by WPP. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D1. ]

title: 250 Cheer as a Byrne Killer Gets 25 Years to Life in Jail
description: As 250 police officers in the courtroom cheered lustily, a 23-year-old drug dealer was sentenced yesterday to the maximum of 25 years to life in prison for the murder of a rookie New York City officer last year.

title: CNW Executives Consider Buyout
description: The management of the CNW Corporation plans to make a buyout offer for the railroad company that would top Japonica Partners' $722 million hostile bid, the chairman of CNW said today. The executive, Robert Schmiege, announced the plan at the company's annual shareholders meeting.

title: The Mango Looks Beautiful Enough To Eat (and It Is)
description: LEAD: CHERRY blossoms, daffodils, the first robin and mangoes. Mangoes? Yes, they too are pleasurable harbingers of spring and the summer to come. To the mango lover, their arrival signals that this is the time to start dreaming of long summer days and the succulent flesh of the mango, poetically named samarbehisht in

title: NAKASONE SEEMS READY TO TESTIFY
description: In a step that could break a deadlock in Parliament and ease Japan's leadership struggle, former Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone reportedly agreed today to testify before fellow lawmakers about his role in the country's influence-peddling and bribery scandal.

title: Review/Music; Rough-Hewn Rockabilly From Stray Cats
description: The Stray Cats, a rockabilly trio from Long Island that came to international attention in the early 1980's, are one of the odder phenomena in recent pop history. Playing both covers of classic rockabilly and their own original material in the mold of the early masters, they managed to find a huge audience that this music's original practitioners couldn't find.

title: Antonia Fraser's Book of Warriors
description: Antonia Fraser's new nonfiction book, ''The Warrior Queens,'' celebrates commanding women. Lady Antonia's last historical panoply, ''The Weaker Vessel,'' chronicled the secret lives of women suppressed in 17th-century England. In contrast, her new book deals with women who conquered kingdoms, massacred their rivals and ruled with an iron lance.

A quirky first feature written and directed by Ghasem Ebrahimian, who was born in Iran and who settled in the United States in the 1970's, the film also takes a sharp, affectionate view of Iranian immigrants trying to merge their traditions with Manhattan living.

title: Lomas Examining Deals to Cut Debt
description: The Lomas Financial Corporation said it was analyzing four transactions, including the sale of its profitable credit-card banking subsidiary, as part of a plan to cut its long-term debt to $4 billion, from $5.5 billion. In an interview, Jess Hay, chairman and chief executive, described the Lomas Bank U.S.A., which is based in Wilmington, Del., as an attractive property. He said Lomas hoped to make a decision in 90 days. He did not say what other alternatives were being considered.

title: His Show's a Hit, but Soviet TV Chief Is Canceled

description: Negotiators from Mexico and its commercial bank lenders will resume discussions today on a debt reduction and restructuring package that would include ways in which the bankers could make the granting of new loans to Mexico attractive. title: Marcos's Condition Worsens With Return of Pneumonia
description: The ousted Philippine President, Ferdinand E. Marcos, was listed in critical condition today and has been put back on a respirator because of a recurrence of pneumonia, hospital officials said.

title: Senate Panel May Postpone Reauthorization of C.F.T.C.
description: The Senate Agriculture Committee might delay full reauthorization of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, the regulator for the futures industry, unless it receives more information about the Federal investigations of trading practices at the nation's commodity exchanges, the committee chairman, Senator Patrick J. Leahy, said today.

title: Treasury Security Prices Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury securities were mixed again yesterday, as dealers continued to sell short-term notes and bills and buy longer-dated maturities. The trading reflected a growing belief that the Federal Reserve is not likely to ease interest rates soon.

title: On the Other Hand
description: The weather has certainly mixed its blessings so far this year. The balmy winter was a pleasure and kept heating bills down. But on the other hand, as everybody kept saying, it may have been the ominous greenhouse effect. The endless spring rains have flooded cellars and made a mess of outdoor life. But on the other hand, we keep telling each other, it fills the reservoirs.

title: Kimmins Environmental Servce reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Kimmins Corp. and K Management merged with and into Kimmins Environmental Service in November 1988. Year-ago results do not give effect to this merger.

title: Campaign Matters; Tax Nightmares Haunt the G.O.P. In New Jersey
description: Republicans like running for re-election after a tax rise about as much as cats like a brisk swim in the ocean.

title: VMS Strategic Land Trust reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Canadiens Tie Series In Impressive Fashion
description: The second time the Canadiens scrambled their way to a two-goal lead tonight, they didn't back off, and their 4-2 victory at the Saddledome sent the Stanley Cup championship back to Montreal with the series even at one game apiece.

title: CROWDS IN STREET ASK DENG'S OUSTER
description: More than a million Chinese took to the streets of Beijing Wednesday in an extraordinary outpouring of support for more democracy.

title: Talking Deals; RJR 'Junk' Test Passed by Drexel
description: DREXEL BURNHAM LAMBERT INC. got a much-needed shot in the arm last week. In what is being called a watershed for the $200 billion ''junk bond'' market, the embattled firm was the principal underwriter of a sale of $4 billion of securities of the RJR Holdings Capital Corporation. The offering, which set several records, has received rave reviews from portfolio managers and bond traders.

title: Carter Begins to Shed Negative Public Image
description: The stock of Presidents goes up and down, and in an information age changes in standing can even be orchestrated. Richard M. Nixon, for example, has spent years at the painstaking work of restoring his image with a series of books and press interviews, offering a running commentary on the state of the world.

title: New York Curbs Gadfly Official In Wildlife Unit
description: The State Department of Environmental Conservation today reassigned a prominent wildlife pathologist and forbade him from talking with reporters or the public about his investigations without prior approval.

title: Investment Group Drops V Band Bid
description: An investment group led by Thomas E. Feil, the chairman of the V Band Corporation, has dropped its proposal to acquire the telephone equipment concern, based in Yonkers. Mr. Feil and KBA Partners L.P., a venture capital concern, had made a proposal to acquire V Band for a price in the range of $9 to $11 a share, for a maximum total purchase price of $57 million.

Airline Proposal Is Opposed
description: Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said today that a proposed merger of the reservation systems of American Airlines and Delta Air Lines Inc. was anti-competitive and should not be approved in its current form.

title: Market Place; New Form of Index Trading Has Foes in Powerful Places
description: The Philadelphia Stock Exchange and the American Stock Exchange introduced what they thought was an exciting new product last week. But it has run into a cold shoulder from some of Wall Street's biggest firms.

title: Academy-Institute Honors 60 in the World of Arts
description: The American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters inducted 3 members into the academy and 10 into the institute during the annual awards ceremony yesterday. It also named 4 honorary members and honored 43 artists, composers and writers.

title: Denver Seeks Money for Airport Backed by Voters
description: A day after Denver voters overwhelmingly approved construction of what would be the world's largest airport, Denver officials today discussed how to pay for it.

title: Beene Furs Show Utilitarian Luxury
description: FOR the second consecutive year, Geoffrey Beene has proven that his exemplary creative flair works as well in fur as it does in fabric. Some of the ideas that seemed offbeat a year ago in his first collection for Goldin-Feldman have become commonplace today as fur designs break away from their rigid, traditional course.

title: Why Short-Circuit the Wright Case?
description: People on both sides of the Jim Wright case suddenly seem eager to short-circuit the process of Congressional self-discipline, thus depriving the Speaker, Congress and the nation of needed ethical clarity.

title: Coup in Ethiopia Seems to Be a Failure, Diplomats Say
description: A coup attempt in Ethiopia appears to have failed, but military units outside the capital continue to hold out, Western diplomats there said today.

title: ALCOHOL CLEARED IN DEFORMITY SUIT
description: A Federal jury today cleared Jim Beam Brands of negligence for not stating on its whisky labels that alcohol consumption by pregnant women could cause birth defects in their children.

Under the program, students would receive tuition credits for higher education and teachers would receive cash.

title: Child-Labor Practices Scrutinized

title: GLOOM ON WRIGHT SHAKES GATHERING OF KEY DEMOCRATS
description: A group of influential House Democrats held an emotional private meeting today at which several of them stunned supporters of Jim Wright by openly discussing the possibility that he could not survive as Speaker of the House.

title: For Working at Home, Dressing Down
description: ON a recent Monday morning, Richard Adelson, dressed in a red, yellow and black Mickey Mouse sweatshirt, yellow sweat pants, a pair of socks and no shoes, sat down at his office desk in his Manhattan apartment. ''I don't have any problems deciding what to wear to work,'' said Mr. Adelson, who designs book jackets. ''All I care about is being comfortable.''

title: Slain Over a Baseball Cap
description: LEAD: The only sin committed by Ramon Rios Jr. was wearing a baseball cap that was the wrong color. In certain parts of Los Angeles, that can be deadly.

title: Hemispheric Group Asks Noriega to Yield Power
description: The Organization of American States tonight adopted a resolution condemning ''abuses by General Manuel Antonio Noriega,'' the Panamanian leader, and calling for the peaceful ''transfer of power'' from his regime to a democratically elected government.

title: Gorbachev's 'Gift' to Bush in Nicaragua
description: Mikhail Gorbachev's pledge to stop arms shipments to Nicaragua presents Washington with opportunities and dangers.

title: Hispanic Art Exhibition
description: ''Hispanic Art in the United States: 30 Contemporary Painters and Sculptors,'' an exhibition that includes painting, sculpture, works on paper and mixed-media objects, will run through Sept. 4 at the Brooklyn Museum, 200 Eastern Parkway, at Washington Avenue, in the Crown Heights section. Luis Cruz Azaceta, Robert Graham and Manuel Neri are among the artists whose work is on display. Bilingual gallery talks, visits to artists' studios, a symposium on June 18 and a Latin American outdoor concert series are to be presented during the exhibition. The museum is open Wednesdays to Mondays from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Suggested admission: $3, $1.50 for students, $1 for the elderly. Information: (718) 638-5000.

title: French Supermarkets Sold by TLC Group
description: TLC Group Inc., the New York investment company headed by Reginald F. Lewis, said yesterday that it had sold Societe Eurpoeene de Supermarches, a leading supermarket chain in France, to the Bouriez Group for a price in excess of $260 million in cash and assumed debt.

title: A New Iron Age Furniture
description: FOR the summer garden or patio, the furniture of choice by both architects and retailers is reproductions of metal garden furniture whose designs were first created in the 18th and 19th centuries.

title: Abbott Throws Shutout to Beat Clemens
description: Jim Abbott threw a four-hitter for his first major league shutout, while Roger Clemens lasted only two innings in his shortest outing of the year as the California Angels beat the Boston Red Sox, 5-0, tonight.

title: 600-Volt Arc From Rail Burns 3 Track Workers
description: Three subway track workers were badly burned yesterday in Brooklyn when a section of track they were removing for repair hit the third rail, shooting a 600-volt arc around them and setting their clothes on fire.

title: From Porticoes to Turrets, Hamilton Heights in a Day
description: AS a 16-year-old, Marguerite Marshall used to walk past the extraordinary 30-room limestone house at 10 St. Nicholas Place, at the corner of 150th Street, with her school friends Nellie and Edith and dream about what it would be like to live there. One day, she impulsively rang the bell and asked the owner, Bertha Koemple, if she could have the right of first refusal if the house was ever sold.

title: Workers Split at G.M. Plant
description: The results of a United Automobile Workers local election completed today show that union members are divided over the Japanese-style ''team concept'' management adopted a year ago at the General Motors Corporation's Camaro factory in Van Nuys, Calif.

description: One of the surprises of the Bush Administration is the irritation and uncertainty with which it has answered the initiatives of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader. title: Clost to Home
description: EVERY time the curtains fluttered open and revealed a slice of sun the nurse would close them. When the phone sounded its curiously muted ''brrr'' whoever answered spoke in a whisper. Those who read were careful turning the pages of their books and magazines, and often the only sound was of the water bubbling in the oxygen box. Feeling had fled this room, the patient's erased by morphine and her friends' numbed by tiredness. Scent, however, remained. Rubrum lilies were sending up great, claustrophobic draughts, and the air was like a blanket that had been too long in sachet.

title: Gorbachev Praises the Students And Declares Reform Is Necessary
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev today portrayed the popular uprising that has engulfed the Chinese capital as part of a painful but healthy worldwide upheaval in Communist countries.

title: Reviews/Theater; 40 Years of Hummable Memories From the Movies
description: ''Blame It on the Movies'' the perky new revue of movie songs at the Criterion Center, springs from a nearly sure-fire theatrical premise. Put eight singers and dancers on a set that evokes the velvet twilight of an old-time movie palace, hand them 40 years of mostly familiar film songs to perform, and somewhere along the way everyone will have at least one nostalgic button pushed. The concept is so enticing in fact that watching this innocuously pleasant entertainment, one is continually nagged by a realization of the many ways in which a terrific opportunity has been squandered.

title: Review/Theater; Between Living Together and Marrying, a Chasm
description: As a playwright, David Ives is the inventor of what could be called stop-and-go comedies. A scene begins, then is interrupted by a bell or a buzzer, and the scene starts again, with the characters revising, rejecting or repeating what was said before. This approach can work with splendid comic precision, as it did last year in Mr. Ives's one-act ''Sure Thing,'' in which he offered infinite variations on a young couple's first meeting.
