description: The latest first quarter results included the operations of Ina Life Insurance Co. and Investors Life Insurance Co. of North America, purchased on Dec. 28, 1988.

title: Reviews/Dance; Proof That Breath Control Is Not Just for Singers
description: Is it swimming? Is it dance? Waterworks, which performed on Saturday night at the handsome Manhattan Plaza Health Club pool, falls somewhere between. The performers are billed as swimmer-dancers. Choreographers were listed for each of the 10 pieces on the program, but they included competitive swimmers and a swimming coach. What is certain is that Waterworks, a five-year-old aquatic dance company based in New York City, is serious about making an art as well as a sport of synchronized swimming. But it is likely that the people who will most appreciate that art are swimming enthusiasts and those who have never seen an Esther Williams or a Busby Berkeley water spectacular.

title: LEBANESE GETS LIFE IN HIJACK KILLING

title: Review/Television; Life on 'L.A. Law' Grows Ever Odder
description: There it was again - the gorilla costume. The demise, in terms of quality and orginality, of ''L.A. Law'' (shown at 10 P.M. Thursdays on NBC) became evident. Not only are the committee-written scripts more disjointed than ever, not only are some scenes sloppily edited to disguise the absence during shooting of main characters who were supposedly present, but now the series is also falling back on old gimmicks. During the first season, in 1986-87, it was charming when Harry Hamlin's Michael got into a gorilla outfit to woo Susan Dey's Grace away from her fiance. This time around, apparently using the same costume, Michael seemed rather sad. So does ''L.A. Law'' these days.

title: Artra Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

title: British Airways Positive on Boeing
description: British Airways said it was confident that the latest version of Boeing's jumbo jet would come into service despite calls by four European nations for extra safety measures. The airline has ordered 19 of the new 747-400's, at a cost of more than $2 billion. The first is due to arrive next month. Although the 400-seat jet has been cleared by United States authorities, Britain, West Germany, France and the Netherlands have said they would not allow the aircraft to fly unless Boeing made changes in the wiring and in the upper-deck floor to strengthen it against explosions.

title: Guest Supply reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Lloyd Evans, Designer, Dies at 55
description: Lloyd R. Evans, a designer of sets and costumes for the New York City Opera and for television serials, died of AIDS on Thursday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 55 years old and lived in Manhattan and in Croton Falls, N.Y.

title: HOUSE DEADLOCKED ON SPENDING BILL
description: Under pressure from veterans' groups, House Democratic leaders scrambled unsuccessfully today to find a compromise on an emergency spending bill that includes money needed to maintain medical services at the Department of Veterans Affairs' hospitals and clinics.

title: American Shared Hospital Services reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
OE Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Unsigned Note Leads to Gotti Juror's Removal
description: The third heroin-racketeering trial of Gene Gotti and another defendant hit a snag Tuesday evening when a second juror was dismissed after prosecutors learned that he lived near the chief Federal agent in the case.

title: HEALTH: Cardiology; Exercise Seen as Help Regardless of Weight
description: Regardless of diet or weight loss, exercise reduces levels of fat in the bloodstream and may help prevent heart disease, a new study indicates.

title: Jogger Undergoes Plastic Surgery on Face
description: The jogger who was beaten and raped in in Central Park last month underwent surgery yesterday to repair parts of her injured face.

title: Surging Dollar Gets Lift From U.S. Trade Report
description: Propelled by a much-better-than-expected improvement in the United States trade deficit, the dollar roared ahead again yesterday, jumping more than two Japanese yen and more than three pfennigs against the West German mark.

title: Iverson Technology reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Upjohn Expecting Approval of Drug
description: The Upjohn Company, one of the nation's leading pharmaceutical companies, said it expects a speedy review by the Food and Drug Administration for a drug it is developing to treat head injuries. Under a recent interim rule for expedited drug development and approval, the F.D.A. has changed some procedures for testing new compounds for illnesses that have no other treatment and that might save lives.

title: Review/Music; Flutist From Iceland Plays New Works in Her Debut
description: Ashildur Haraldsdottir is an Icelandic flutist with considerable musical gifts, onstage charm and - from an American viewpoint - a wonderfully euphonious name. Miss Haraldsdottir, who was born in 1965 and who has studied in Boston and New York since 1983, gave a debut recital Monday night at CAMI Hall devoted entirely to contemporary music for her instrument.

title: Funds Show Little Change
description: Yields offered by money market mutual funds were little changed for the week that ended yesterday.

title: INSIDE
description: O.A.S. Urges Noriega To Yield Power The Organization of American States condemned ''abuses'' by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian leader, and called for the peaceful transfer of power from his regime to an elected Government.

title: Star for All Seasons
description: Last weekend, near the end of her third lacrosse season at Harvard University, which was preceded by her third ice hockey season, which was preceded by her third field hockey season, Charlotte Joslin discovered a means of extending her responsibilities.

title: Jaco Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a tax credit of $127,129. c-After tax credits of $244,000 for the quarter and $442,000 for the 9 months. Share earnings were adjusted for 10 percent stock dividends declared on May 14, 1988 and March 20, 1989.

title: A Cable TV Regulation Bid
description: Senator Albert Gore, Democrat of Tennessee, introduced legislation yesterday that called for re-regulation of the cable television industry. The bill, co-sponsored in the

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; One Response To Ogilvy Deal
description: Cotton Inc. yesterday became the first client of the Ogilvy Group to take action in response to its acquisition by WPP. A day after WPP and Ogilvy announced the agreement, Cotton, a textile research and promotion company, said it would ''accept invitations from other agencies for preliminary discussions'' on its $10 million account.

title: Reviews/Theater; Some People Play Revolution Better Than Others
description: Reine Barteve sifts through the trash heap of history in her new play, ''Alive by Night,'' being presented by Ubu Repertory Theater to celebrate the bicentenary of the French Revolution. Up to a point the play is about the surrender of the city of Verdun to Prussian forces in September 1792, when a number of European monarchs tried to stop the revolution and restore Louis XVI to the throne. The French version of the play will open in Verdun on Saturday as part of the official bicentennial festivities.

title: Energy Conversion Devices reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Reports Say Arthur Young and Ernst May Merge
description: Reports circulated throughout the accounting industry today that two of the biggest firms - Ernst & Whinney and Arthur Young & Company - would soon announce a merger that would create the world's largest accounting firm.

description: b-Net loss

title: Mets Beaten on Bases-Loaded Walk in 10th
description: Whether it was the threatening sight of Eddie Murray batting left-handed or the imposing sight of Tommy Lasorda standing in the third-base coach's box, Dave Johnson chose to gamble in the 10th inning last night. He lost.

title: Certron Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company said the year-earlier quarter is after a tax credit of $16,000.

title: Mexico Reaches Accord On World Bank Loan
description: Mexico's Finance Minister, Pedro Aspe, announced last night that his Government had reached an agreement on a $1.96 billion loan from the World Bank.

title: Orion Pictures Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Reviews/Music; A Jaunty Texas Rock Band Revels in Life's Rich Pageant
description: Poi Dog Pondering radiates lighthearted benevolence like no other 1980's band I've heard. The group is from Austin, Tex., and performed Monday night at the Knitting Factory. Poi Dog Pondering has its spiritual home in the San Francisco of the late 1960's, when psychedelic bands cheerfully crossed category lines to come up with hippie skiffle tunes that might dip into country, folk, pop, jazz and world music, sometimes all at once.

title: Repairing Beloved Old Typewriters
description: IN less than a decade, the peck of typewriter keys and the ring of the carriage have been replaced by the glow of the computer terminal and the buzz of the printer. Today the manual typewriter, with its steel body and sensual, rounded keys, is a relic of another era. Indeed, even the electric typewriter seems an anachronism. Still, some purists remain, many of them writers. They wouldn't give up their old machines for the world. But what do they do when a key sticks, the rubber platen gets pitted, or a ribbon grows faint?

title: Cucos Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 3
description: b-Net loss and after a $1,028,917 loss from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Snapshot; No Rush Yet to Place Reagan on Mountain
description: The way R. Emmett Tyrrell Jr. sees it, there would be as little dynamiting and chiseling as possible. Instead, the editor of the conservative magazine American Spectator suggests, giant versions of Ronald Reagan's nose and chin and ears could be cast in cement and then flown in and gently hung on Mount Rushmore next to the sculptures of George Washington, Thomas Jefferson, Abraham Lincoln and Theodore Roosevelt.

title: Arens Says Most Jews Will Leave Soviet Union Within a Few Years
description: Foreign Minister Moshe Arens of Israel said yesterday that he expected ''a majority'' of the Soviet Jews to leave the Soviet Union in the next few years.

title: Brokered Funds Cleared For Sick Savings Units
description: The chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that his agency was permitting sick savings and loan associations to continue soliciting high-cost deposits from money brokers and securities firms, even though their use contributed to the savings crisis.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Business Day yesterday about a Federal bankruptcy hearing for Eastern Airlines attributed a quotation incorrectly in some editions. The statement - ''It's time to put up or shut up,'' referring to the inadequacy of the offers made so far to buy Eastern - was made by David I. Shapiro, the examiner in the bankruptcy case, not by Burton R. Lifland, chief judge of the bankruptcy court.

The company said the results from continuing operations are for its patent licensing operations and do not include Geotek Industries Inc., which was spun off to Patlex shareholders of record as of Feb. 27. The company said its revenue included non-recurring past infringement settlements of $751,000 in the latest quarter and $1,473,000 in the year- ago first quarter. The company also said it intends to purchase all of its outstanding convertible preferred stock but it did not elaborate.

description: Bud Harrelson said yesterday he had turned down an interview for the Toronto Blue Jays' managerial job.

title: Koch Offers $1.2 Billion Expansion of Drug Treatment
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch proposed yesterday that an additional $1.2 billion be spent to treat tens of thousands of drug abusers in New York City during the next five years, although the effort would largely depend on state funds not yet committed and on therapies of uncertain effectiveness.

title: First Families Arrive in U.S.
description: The first evacuation of Americans in Panama under measures announced by President Bush last week has been completed with the arrival here of a chartered commercial jet carrying 276 Defense Department employees and dependents.

title: Infighting Paralyzes Japan's Quest for New Leader
description: Political jockeying and actions this week by investigators in Japan's influence-peddling scandal have left officials further than ever from selecting a new Prime Minister or removing the stain of corruption from government.

title: University of New Mexico Marking Bittersweet Centennial
description: The University of New Mexico is celebrating its centennial, and since September the campus has seen a stream of distinguished visitors, including the Royal Philharmonic, the historian Arthur Schlesinger Jr. and the Surgeon General of the United States, Dr. C. Everett Koop.

title: Reviews/Music; 3 Recent Experimental Works by Vierk
description: Lois V Vierk, a composer whose work combines elements of Minimalism, electronic music and Japanese traditional music, presented three of her recent works Sunday evening in a concert at the Experimental Intermedia Foundation.

title: Reviews/Music; Opera Ebony Sings Verdi
description: Opera Ebony, now 16 years old, has been branching out in ambitious directions. Last year, the company undertook a co-production of ''Porgy and Bess'' with the Finnish National Opera, taking it on tour in Finland and the Soviet Union. On Saturday night, in an unofficial cultural exchange, the company brought Eri Klas, the Estonian conductor who led ''Porgy,'' to make his American debut with the Verdi Requiem in Aaron Davis Hall at City College.

title: Bonn Hints at More Flexible Stand in Arms Dispute
description: West Germany signaled today that it was prepared to take a more flexible stance in its dispute with the Bush Administration over short-range nuclear missiles, as Bonn's Defense Minister arrived here for two days of talks on the issue.

title: Reviews/Theater; A Cross Section of Broadway Star Types
description: ''Prizes,'' the new musical at the AMAS Repertory Theater, offers the discomfiting sight of marginally talented singers, actors and dancers portraying fictional musical comedy legends at the peak of their powers.

title: A.T.&.T. Set To Reduce Rates by 0.9%
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it would cut its long-distance rates an average of nine-tenths of 1 percent on July 1 to comply with a new method of rate regulation adopted by the Federal Communications Commission in March.

title: Critic's Notebook; Old Favorites Are No More At Cannes
description: It's still anybody's guess how the 10-member jury will vote, but today, at the halfway point in the 42d Cannes International Film Festival, one thing is obvious: Directors who have been big festival favorites in the past seem to be running on empty.

title: Cuomo Aide to Lead Party
description: A political aide to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, John A. Marino, was unanimously elected state Democratic chairman here today. Mr. Marino, 40 years old, of Manhattan, had been executive director of the state committee. He succeeds Laurence J. Kirwan. A group of Republican county chairmen also met here to interview and endorse the person they expect to be their new chairman, J. Patrick Barrett of Syracuse.

title: Board Is Told Tanker Failed To Report Change in Route
description: The officers of the Exxon Valdez never notified the Coast Guard that they were taking the tanker outside approved shipping lanes on the night of the Alaska oil spill, and the Coast Guard's traffic controllers did not track the ship's course as she went aground, according to Federal investigators' documents and testimony presented today.

title: CZECH PLAYWRIGHT FREED FROM PRISON
description: The playwright and dissident Vaclav Havel was released from prison today after serving half of an eight-month term for anti-Government activities, and immediately pledged to speak out regardless of whether he is ''arrested or called a national hero.''

description: The company attributed the loss primarily to increased interest expense and non-recurring financing costs associated with three acquisitions in 1988.

description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $42,000. c-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $1,406,000.

title: Zeus at Whitney Draws Met Thunderbolt
description: A life-sized bronze statue of Zeus with a baseball bat in his right hand and a television monitor suspended from his loins has brought down the Olympian wrath of the Metropolitan Museum - which owns the statue -on the Whitney Museum of American Art.

title: Reviews/Theater; Perelman, a Literary Acrobat Made Literal
description: Though S. J. Perelman was pigeonholed as a humorist, he was, first of all, a literary artist - an acrobat with language - and his wit and erudition are imperishable. Feeling low? Enervated by ennui? Read Perelman and rejoice.

title: Flextronics Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Polish Dissident Given Degree One Year Late
description: Columbia University completed its 235th academic year yesterday with a commencement that had two features conspicuously absent from the ceremony last year, a Polish dissident and sunshine.

description: * Bell & Howell, Skokie, Ill., a publishing and information services company, promoted Nils A. Johansson to vice president of finance and chief financial officer.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error in some copies, an article yesterday about a lawsuit arising from the Attica prison uprising of 1971 gave an incorrect account of how guards and inmates died when the prison was stormed by the police. Investigations showed that police gunfire killed all 10 hostages and 29 inmates who died when the prison was retaken. None had their throats slit.

description: The Food and Drug Administration has approved a voluntary labeling system for nonprescription sunglasses.

title: L.P.G.A. Championship Seems Set to Leave Ohio
description: The L.P.G.A. Championship will probably move next year from the Jack Nicklaus Sports Center here, where it has been staged each May for the last 12 years. It would be held later in the season as the fourth and final women's major championship.

title: Review/Music; Choral Voices Tell the Tale Of Semele
description: Spring is the season when New York City's numerous and admirable small choruses address themselves to big things, like the oratorios of Handel. Tomorrow night at 8, the Dessoff Choirs will take on ''Israel in Egypt'' at Alice Tully Hall; Monday evening, the Choral Symphony Society under David Labovitz offered ''Semele'' at Merkin Concert Hall.

title: How Would We Feel?
description: Last year's treaty on intermediate-range nuclear forces required the Soviet Union to dismantle the 239 SS-23 missiles it had in Europe. Soviet officials had argued that the SS-23's range was just below the 300-mile threshold set in the treaty, but to meet American concerns they agreed to include it.

title: New Dispute Tangles Plan On Times Sq.
description: The white-hot glow over Times Square these days is not coming from the neon lights of Broadway but from an increasingly nasty eleventh-hour battle over the 42d Street redevelopment plan and whether New York City architects support or oppose the project.

title: Memos Suggest U.S.-Honduran Deal on Contra Aid
description: Classified Reagan Administration documents have cast fresh doubts on the Bush Administration's assertion that there was no deal between the United States and Honduras on aid to the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Reviews/Music; Kronos Quartet Presents a Program of Sight and Sound
description: The Kronos Quartet has always paid attention to how it looks as well as to how it sounds. On Saturday night at Alice Tully Hall, it brought in some help in the form of ''Assembly Required,'' a set of sculptural effects by Alessandro Moruzzi.

description: b-After tax credits of $638,000 for the latest first quarter and $942,000 for year-ago period.

title: See Florence and Swoon
description: For years, travelers to Florence have believed it was the Italian water that made them go funny all over -faint, hallucinate, perspire heavily, suffer palpitations and stomach cramps. Today, because of the researches of a psychiatrist named Graziella Magherini, the world knows better. It wasn't the acqua; it was the art.

title: Court Clears Southmark's Rival Slate
description: A Federal district court in Atlanta cleared the way today for three candidates supported by dissident shareholders of the Southmark Corporation to challenge directors nominated by the company's management.

title: EXCESS LOAD CITED IN TRAIN ACCIDENT
description: A runaway freight train that jumped track and killed four people may have been too heavily loaded for its locomotives' braking capacity, the investigators say.

title: The Long Demarche
description: Have you noticed how everybody confidently asserts that the end of the 30-year ideological war between Moscow and Beijing is a great boon for mankind?

description: Seven days after the auction at Christie's of eight pictures from the collection of Hal B. Wallis, the Los Angeles County Museum of Art filed suit yesterday in New York State Supreme Court against the Hal B. Wallis Foundation; its president, Brent Wallis, who is the son of the late motion picture producer, and Christie's, the auction house.

title: Lauder Proposes a $160 Million Anti-Crime Plan
description: Denouncing ''liberals who always blame society first,'' Ronald S. Lauder, a Republican candidate for mayor, yesterday called for tougher sentences for violent criminals and for an expansion of New York City's police force and court system.

title: Lindner Acquires Stake in Star Banc
description: Carl H. Lindner, the Cincinnati financier, has acquired a 5 percent stake in the Star Banc Corporation, a bank holding company, for a total purchase price of $29.4 million. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Lindner, the chairman of the American Financial Corporation, said he had no present plans to acquire control of the company but added that he might change his plans depending on future developments.

title: Books of The Times; Le Carre Takes Espionage Into the Age of Perestroika
description: The Russia House By John le Carre 353 pages. Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 10 about former New York City police officers who are now police administrators elsewhere misstated the position once held by Eugene (Bull) Connor in Birmingham, Ala. He served as Commissioner of Public Safety, or police commissioner, an elected official, and not as chief of police.

title: Essays Read for Signs of Crisis
description: Essay tests taken by 50,000 high school sophomores in Louisiana are being read for signs of personal crisis like suicidal tendencies or child abuse.

title: Canseco is Sued
description: Two promoters of baseball card shows, Jim Kelly and Kevin Boden of Rochester, N.Y., have filed a lawsuit against Jose Canseco, the star outfielder for the Oakland Athletics, for skipping an autograph session in February. The lawsuit claims Canseco breached a contract when he failed to show up in Rochester, where several hundred people paid to see him. Canseco has been sidelined for most of the season with a wrist injury. (AP)

title: Senate Votes to Raise Wage Base And Braces for Long Veto Fight
description: The Senate today gave final approval to a bill increasing the minimum wage to $4.55 an hour by 1991 and braced for a protracted veto battle with President Bush. The President wants a lower wage floor and a subminimum training wage unacceptable to Democrats.

title: Noriega Rejects Bush's Demand That He Quit, Calling It Meddling
description: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega today rejected President Bush's demand that he step down, calling it unacceptable intervention in Panama's affairs and an attack on the Panamanian people.

title: Morgan's Battle With Success
description: For the last few years, Morgan Stanley & Company has seemed to do everything right while its counterparts on Wall Street have been struggling. Now it must cope with the perils of success.

title: No More Excuses on the Homeless
description: For years, New York City's policy toward the homeless amounted to mean-spirited pragmatism: Don't make the shelters too pleasant lest the destitute show up in overwhelming, potentially bankrupting numbers. On Tuesday, Mayor Koch made clear that he had finally given up on a misguided approach that has done much to hasten the decline of New York to New Calcutta.

title: Results Plus

title: Q&A
description: Floor Paints and Caulks Q. The pine floor in our house has several coats of paint on it that are wearing off. The caulking between the widely spaced boards is firm, but cracked open. I plan to sand the paint without removing all of it, then apply fresh paint. Can I use some type of water base paint (low gloss preferred), and is there a paintable caulk that expands and contracts as the boards expand with humidity? A. There are latex (water base) floor paints, and most dry to a semigloss rather than a high gloss finish. As for the caulking, I'm afraid nothing will hold up long, as no caulking materials are made to be walked on. However, latex caulks stay more flexible than oil based caulks, so you might try one of these (test in a small section first).

title: A Brooklyn Company Is Indicted In the Dumping of Medical Waste
description: A Brooklyn medical laboratory and its vice president were indicted yesterday on Federal charges of illegally dumping glass vials contaminated with the hepatitis B virus off Staten Island.

title: Bronco II Performance Criticized
description: Citing test results and Government statistics, Consumers Union today criticized the Ford Motor Company's Bronco II for what it called ''poor emergency handling.'' The organization, which publishes Consumer Reports magazine, recommended that consumers avoid buying the compact utility vehicle.

title: In Praise Of Fragant Paulownia

The tree was only one year old, and it had been pruned back to the ground to give it a root system capable of supporting the rapid growth that was sure to follow that summer.

title: Levi Strauss to Sell Shares In Japan Unit to the Japanese
description: Levi Strauss & Company, the giant jeans manufacturer, which went private in a leveraged buyout in 1985, said today that it would sell stock in its Japanese subsidiary to the Japanese public.

description: A freelance writer said yesterday he had a copy of the report on baseball's investigation of Pete Rose, but he said he had decided not to sell it.

NWA Expands Severance Awards
description: The board of NWA Inc. has expanded the company's ''golden parachute'' severance agreements to include 200 more members of the management of Northwest Airlines Inc. and the Northwest Aerospace Training Corporation. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, NWA did not disclose how much the plan would cost a company that took over the airline holding company.

Interpublic announced a 3-for-2 split, by way of a 50 percent dividend, and did not announce a special 50 percent dividend.

title: Cabinet Scrapers For Fine-Tuning
description: LEAD: When good furniture is built, the surfaces are worked over with a cabinet scraper before the finish is applied. This fine-tuning is essential to remove ridges and any slight unevenness left after a smoothing plane has taken care of the saw marks. Such flaws, no matter how minor, would show up beneath a clear finish, particularly if the work was stained.

title: Review/Music; A Festival Where Art and Rock Collide
description: The Bang on a Can Festival, which began as a single marathon concert in 1987, has quickly established itself as both a showcase for an array of avant-garde styles and a lively burst of contemporary fireworks to brighten the end of the formal concert season. This year the festival has evolved into a series at the RAPP Arts Center, and in the final program, heard Saturday night (it was repeated on Sunday), three composers explored the intersection of art music and rock.

title: Among New Pilots for TV, 'Elvis' Defies Conventions
description: Of all the pilots fighting for a place on next fall's prime-time schedule, perhaps the oddest is ''Elvis: Good Rockin' Tonight.'' As ABC, NBC and CBS buy new series for the 1989-90 season, it is clear that the new year will look very much like the old. NBC has already purchased one show about an aging cop paired with a young cop (''Hardball'') and another about a nun in charge of a group of orphans (''Sister Kate.'') ''Elvis,'' at least, does not resemble anything else.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This is the fifth day of the students' hunger strike, so we have come to support them.

title: Two Veteran U.S. Drug Agents Held on Bribery Charges in Miami
description: Two veteran agents of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration have been arrested on charges of taking bribes from a drug suspect, officials said today.

title: Fleet Aerospace reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first half's net is after a one-time net charge of $380,000 associated with the relocation and consolidation of two subsidiaries into a larger facility.

title: Pentagon
description: The senators looked surprised as the three-star Air Force general sidestepped their questions on arms control and said with a grin on his round face, ''I'd rather not get into policy issues, if you don't mind.''

title: San Juan Airlines
description: San Juan Airlines will stop flying and close its headquarters here if the Canadian Government approves the sale of its four Canadian routes to Horizon Air Industries, San Juan's president, Jim Sherrell, said. San Juan will continue to operate its Shuttle Express ground transportation service at Seattle-Tacoma International Airport. San Juan describes itself as the nation's oldest commuter airline. Mr. Sherrell bought it in 1979. A decision on the routes is expected this summer from Canada's national transportation agency.

title: U.S. Raises Standard for Car Fuel Economy
description: American automakers will have to improve fuel economy to 27.5 miles per gallon on 1990 passenger models, Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner said today.

title: California Lawmaker and Ex-Aide Indicted
description: State Senator Joseph Montoya and a former aide were indicted here today by a Federal grand jury on charges of racketeering and extorting money in return for votes on legislation.

Kurzweil Music Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-Net income

description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Arrested in '88 Bombings Of a Small Town in Indiana
description: Two men were arrested today on charges that they planted 13 homemade time bombs under bridges and behind buildings in the small town of Salem last July. None of the bombs exploded, but three burned, causing minor damage.

title: Rutledge Re-Signs
description: Jeff Rutledge, starting his 11th season in the National Football League and his eighth with the Giants, has signed for the 1989 season. Although the 32-year-old quarterback was an unrestricted free agent from Feb. 1 to April 1, he received no offers from other teams. The Giants still have 14 unsigned veterans - Raul Allegre, the kicker; Jeff Hostetler at quarterback, George Adams and Lee Rouson at running back, Lionel Manuel and Stacy Robinson at wide receiver, Zeke Mowatt at tight end, Bart Oates at center, Jim Burt at nose tackle, Pepper Johnson and Gary Reasons at linebacker, and Terry Kinard, Kenny Hill and Herb Welch at safety.

title: American Oil & Gas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Reviews/Music; Going Beyong Flamenco
description: The ''Flamenco Fusion'' show at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine on Saturday night opened with one of those rare, clearly beautiful moments that seem to stop time. Dieguito, a gypsy singer from Madrid, sang a wavering melody in a deeply passionate and dryly husky voice that filled the dark and cavernous space of the cathedral. The audience gave a collective gasp.

title: Montana Recovering
description: Joe Montana, the quarterback for the San Francisco 49ers, underwent surgery on his left knee last Thursday at Sequoia Hospital in Redwood City, Calif. It was the quarterback's fifth operation since 1983 and the second on the same knee. He is expected to recover before preseason training camp begins in mid-July. The operation was not made public at the time because of the 49ers' policy of not announcing players' off-season surgery and was first reported by The Tiimes of San Mateo. (AP)

title: Isomet Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Biosearch Medical Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included tax benefits of $76,000 for the latest quarter and $379,000 for the year-earlier period.

title: Amway Withdraws Avon Offer
description: The Amway Corporation said last night that it was withdrawing its offer of $39 a share, worth a total of $2 billion, for Avon Products Inc., which earlier in the evening rejected its bid.

title: Fuller Brush Tries New Approach
description: Executives at the Fuller Brush Company faced a demoralizing reality about three years ago. With more women than ever working outside the home, there was often no one to answer the door when a sales representative came calling.

title: Notebook; Sunday Silence Pronounced Fit for Preakness
description: Sunday Silence's prospects for running in the Preakness Stakes Saturday were upgraded from 80 to 100 percent this morning by his trainer, Charlie Whittingham, even though he canceled the Kentucky Derby winner's scheduled workout.

title: Integon Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The latest first quarter results reflected the accounting changes required by FASB 97.

title: Xerox to Drop Deal
description: The Xerox Corporation has decided to stop making copiers for the A. B. Dick Company because the Chicago-based company's sales were cutting into Xerox's markets, a Xerox spokesman said today. Xerox has been making low- to mid-volume copiers for Dick, an office products company, since 1986 under a three-year agreement that is scheduled to expire next month, a Xerox spokesman, Arthur Zuckerman, said. It is the only private-label contract that Xerox, based in Stamford, Conn., has had for its copiers.

title: W. J. MacIntosh, Philadelphia Lawyer, 88
description: William James MacIntosh, a Philadelphia lawyer who was a senior partner of Morgan, Lewis & Bockius, died Monday at his home in Bryn Mawr, Pa., after a brief illness. He was 88 years old.

title: Raven Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30

description: A California researcher has acknowledged deficiencies in a study that found significant and sometimes dramatic improvement in the memories of a small number of people with Alzheimer's disease who were treated with an experimental drug.

title: Imagine Films Entertainment Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
President Is Named For Vanguard Group
description: John J. Brennan, who is 34 years old, was named president of 29 companies yesterday.

title: Hemotec Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The latest first quarter loss was due solely to $1,083,000 of expenses incurred by the company in defending against a hostile takeover attempt initiated by Quest Medical Inc. in January 1989.

Hills Department Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
Spinoff Plan Gains At Morton Thiokol
description: Morton Thiokol Inc. received permission from the Internal Revenue Service for a tax-free spinoff of its commercial businesses. The businesses, which produce specialty chemicals, salt and inflatable restraint systems, will operate under the name Morton International Inc. The company still awaits stockholders' approval of the move.

title: Northrop Plans 2,500 Job Cuts
description: The Northrop Corporation plans to eliminate 2,500 to 3,000 jobs, representing 6 to 7 percent of its work force, by the end of the year, its chairman, Thomas V. Jones, told shareholders today.

title: Home Improvement
description: OUTDOOR concrete steps often crack, chip or crumble. Moisture that enters through cracks and later freezes is particularly damaging.

title: Weddings: A Time for Giving and Returning
description: THIS is the season of surprise. Those who doubt it need only talk to Anne-Marie Bratton, a bride-to-be.

title: Anne Murphy, 62, Fordham Libraries Head
description: Anne M. Murphy, director of libraries at Fordham University, died of cancer yesterday at the Westchester County Medical Center in Valhalla, N.Y. She was 62 years old and lived in Bronxville, N.Y.

title: Polish Regime Gives Legal Status to Church
description: Parliament approved laws today that guarantee freedom of worship and give legal status to the Roman Catholic Church, formally ending the Communist Government's four-decade struggle with the church.

title: Biotechnica International Inc reports earnings for
description: b-Included a gain of $682,000 from the sale of an investment. c-Net loss The company said the increase in revenue for the latest quarter resulted primarily from the acquisition of two seed companies in January.

description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $32,000 and $84,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and both periods also included a loss of $199,000 on the sale of discontinued operations. c-Net loss and included income of $2,000 from discontinued operations. d-Included a loss of $19,000 from discontinued operations.

title: A New Fight in Affordable Housing: Taxes
description: A New Jersey court has been asked to rule in a case that could determine whether some of the state's affordable housing should be assessed for tax purposes at its lower purchase price or at its market value.

title: Ouster From Pros Urged for Second Offenders
description: The Federal narcotics chief, William J. Bennett, met here today with commissioners of professional sports leagues and heads of players' unions and suggested tougher penalties for athletes who take drugs.

title: Associated Natural Gas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the year-ago share earnings were less than one cent a share due to preferred dividend requirements.

title: One Victim's Campaign Changes Image of AIDS
description: Going public about having AIDS has changed Alison L. Gertz's life almost as much as the illness has.

title: Yanks Miss .500 and Drop Into 2d
description: Their stay in first place was a short one. The Yankees, who held a share of the American League East for one day, fell back to second tonight, losing a 3-0 lead to the Oakland Athletics, who relied again on their resilient bullpen to seal an 8-3 victory.

title: Hollinger Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $4 million. Year-ago figures have been restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Pavarotti Signs for Series
description: Luciano Pavarotti is to give one concert a year in the Great Performers at Lincoln Center series from 1990 to 1992, under the terms of an agreement announced by Nathan Leventhal, the president of Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts. Each of the tenor's performances is to be broadcast on the ''Live From Lincoln Center'' series on public television. The first concert, Pavarotti Plus, is scheduled for Feb. 7 and is to include several guest artists.

title: Football Flash No Flash In Pan
description: The jet-black BMW, with a woman at the wheel and the words ''Prime Time'' on its license plate, roared up to the chain-link gate. Prime Time himself, a.k.a. Deion Sanders, got out from the passenger side and slid quickly past the news media horde and into the dressing room.

title: We Are All Living In a Radioactive World
description: To the Editor:

title: Giuliani Announces Bid For Election as Mayor
description: Comparing himself to Fiorello H. La Guardia but sounding like Thomas E. Dewey, Rudolph W. Giuliani formally announced his candidacy for mayor of New York City yesterday.

title: Typographical Airers
description: National Secretaries' Week came and went last month without much notice in the Big Apple. But up in Maine, where there are fewer distractions, radio station WMGX staged an ''Office Olympics'' in downtown Portland.

title: VMS Mortgage Investors LP reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Fact-Finder Urges Los Angeles Teachers to Return
description: A fact-finder's report today urged striking teachers to end their three-day-old walkout. The strike has crippled education for more than half a million students in the nation's second-largest school district.

title: Repairs to Older Planes Ordered; Move Will Affect 2,200 Airliners
description: The Federal Aviation Administration yesterday ordered the first of a series of repairs to the nation's aging airliners that will eventually involve 2,200 airplanes and cost the airline industry hundreds of millions of dollars.

title: A Tenfold Rise In AIDS Is Seen
description: The World Health Organization today predicted that the number of AIDS cases worldwide would increase to five million by the year 2000, from 450,000 today.

title: Bush Meets Tutu and Vows to Press Pretoria
description: President Bush met with Archbishop Desmond M. Tutu at the White House today, and American officials said later that Mr. Bush had vowed to use ''pressure, influence and leverage'' on the South African Government.

title: Review/Film; Dizzy Plays A Gig in Havana
description: ''A Night in Havana: Dizzy Gillespie in Cuba'' documents the great jazz trumpeter's triumphal visit to Cuba, where he was invited in 1985 to headline the Fifth International Jazz Festival of Havana. For Mr. Gillespie, who is now 71 years old, the journey was a kind of spiritual homecoming. In the late 1940's, he had been one of the first American jazz musicians to incorporate Afro-Cuban polyrhythms into a big-band setting. But until quite recently, political conditions prevented him from traveling to the country whose music had inspired him four decades earlier.

title: Amway Pullout Sends Avon's Stock Reeling
description: The stock of Avon Products Inc. plunged $7.125 yesterday, to $33, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange, after the Amway Corporation said on Wednesday that it was withdrawing its $2 billion offer.

title: Hernandez Fractures Kneecap; Out 8 Weeks
description: One week after they lost Gary Carter with a swollen right knee, the Mets took an even worse jolt yesterday when they lost Keith Hernandez for eight weeks with a fracture of the right kneecap.

title: Albany Ties Energy Need To Pollution
description: A report on New York State's energy needs warned today that additional generating capacity must be built within three years but cautioned that reliance on traditional energy sources will cause ''alarming'' increases in acid rain and other airborne pollution.

title: Keillor on Radio
description: Garrison Keillor, the popular raconteur whose ''Prairie Home Companion'' stories about the mythical Lake Wobegon amused National Public Radio audiences for 13 years, announced today that he would return to radio this fall. Twelve shows of ''American Radio Company of the Air'' are to be broadcast live from New York, St. Paul and other cities on Saturday nights starting Sept. 30.

title: Call Sounded For Industry Confidence
description: WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W.Va., May 18 - It is a new era for the American advertising industry and the American Association of Advertising Agencies must respond to it, said Glen W. Fortinberry, the new chairman of the advertising trade group.

title: Yonkers Parents to Sue Over Search in School
description: Parents plan to sue the Yonkers school district over a strip search that was conducted in a junior high school class after one student claimed someone had stolen $28, a lawyer said today.

title: Notebook; Chavez-Camacho Bout Will Not Happen Soon
description: After Julio Cesar Chavez beat Roger Mayweather to win the World Boxing Council super lightweight title last Saturday, he issued a challenge to Hector Camacho, the World Boxing Organization junior welterweight champion.

title: No Borough Is an Island
description: ''Shall the borough of Staten Island separate from the City of New York?'' State lawmakers in Albany are toying with legislation that would submit the question to a binding referendum of Staten Island voters in November. It is a reckless move.

title: Long-Term Treasury Issues Rise
description: Long-term Treasury securities rose moderately yesterday as investors shrugged off a larger-than-expected seven-tenths of 1 percent increase in the Consumer Price Index for April.

title: Muscovites Welcome Peace But Lament Lack of Dessert
description: The most immediate tangible result promised here today from Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Beijing visit was Peking duck and a dozen other dishes. The arrival of 29 Chinese chefs is being expedited because of the summit meeting, according to officials working on the refurbishing of Moscow's dowdy, long-Russified Chinese restaurant.

title: Dining Out Guide: From the Grill
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current. Azzurro

title: At Auction, Cars, Cash and Blind Faith
description: At Pier 60 on the Hudson, at 20th Street, prospective buyers pursued their manifold destiny yesterday, milling around and peering into the 25 automobiles being auctioned by the Department of Motor Vehicles, which had snatched them from the streets because their owners had ignored wads of parking tickets.

title: C.I.A. Chief Wary of Pakistani Nuclear Program
description: William H. Webster, the Director of Central Intelligence, told Congress today that Pakistan was ''engaged in developing a nuclear capability'' while its rival India had begun research that could be used to make thermonuclear weapons.

title: Topics of The Times; Pension Power and the Big Spill
description: The Exxon Corporation has agreed to put an environmentalist on its board of directors, thanks in part to pressure from New York City's Comptroller, Harrison Goldin, and a small band of like-minded big stockholders.

title: Harold Mager Is Dead; Ex-Treasury Aide, 81
description: Harold Mager, a United States Treasury official in World War II and a State Department planner in the postwar period, died of kidney disease Tuesday at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: An MTV Comedy Channel Will Compete With HBO's
description: MTV Networks announced plans yesterday to form a cable television comedy channel, the second all-comedy channel announced this week.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Sukhothai West

title: Castle & Cooke May Split in 2
description: Castle & Cooke Inc. said today that it was considering splitting into two publicly traded companies, the Dole Food Company and a real estate development operation now called Oceanic Properties. David H. Murdock, Castle &

title: Mitterrand Straddles the NATO Missile Dispute
description: President Francois Mitterrand spoke out today against the elimination of short-range nuclear weapons in central Europe but insisted that NATO did not have to decide about replacing its own battlefield missiles until 1992.

title: Jalalabad Besiegers Bide Their Time
description: The Afghan guerrillas move around their captured Government outpost in short spurts, dashing across exposed spaces, then crouching in the protection of bullet-pocked adobe walls. But even with the enemy at Jalalabad Airport only half a mile away, two or three rebels are asleep, wrapped in shroud-like cotton shawls in their trenches and makeshift bomb shelters.

title: Lawyers and Judge Clash Over Contempt Citations
description: A Manhattan racketeering trial that involves the murder of a police officer has turned into an unusually harsh clash between defense lawyers and a Federal judge.

title: President's Job Is Filled At Figgie International
description: Figgie International Inc., a com-pany led by its strong founder, Harry E. Figgie Jr., said yesterday that it had named Vincent A. Chiarucci president. The post has been vacant since 1982.

title: Our Towns; A College Fights For 26 Flavors All Its Own
description: Several citadels of higher education dot this state's academic map: Yale, Wesleyan, Trinity. As for the University of Connecticut at Storrs, ''they call us a cow college,'' said a spokesman, Walt McGowan.

title: FATHER IS CLEARED IN ILL BABY's DEATH
description: A Cook County grand jury has refused to indict a man who disconnected his brain-damaged, comatose son from a life support system last month and held hospital workers at gunpoint until the boy died, the authorities said today.

title: No More Ifs for Butz
description: Dave Butz of the Redskins, who had been the oldest starting player in the National Football League, yesterday announced his retirement in Washington. The decision of the 38-year-old defensive tackle to retire had been rumored for several months even though he had another year remaining on his two-year contract that would bring him $550,000 next season. Butz played in 216 N.F.L. games. He was credited with 59 1/2 career sacks, second-highest total in Redskin history. (AP)

title: Melitta Again Places An Account at Ketchum
description: For Ketchum Advertising, doing business with Melitta USA has been a little like a game of ''now you see it, now you don't.'' The German coffee maker's United States subsidiary had twice awarded parts of its business to the Philadelphia office of Ketchum, only to snatch it away again.

title: On Stage
description: Shakespeare, in American

title: Columbia Law Review Broadens Its Outlook; Burden Is Increased
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: The TV Notes column yesterday understated the size of the audience for the ABC mini-series ''The Winds of War'' in February 1983. The program was watched by 53 percent of the viewing audience, not 43 percent.

title: Review/Film; One Against the Villains, in 'Road House'
description: In ''Road House,'' Patrick Swayze has the most laughable role since Tom Cruise juggled a few liquor bottles and danced to ''The Hippy Hippy Shakes'' in ''Cocktail.'' ''Road House'' is also set in a bar, where Mr. Swayze is a bouncer named Dalton. He's so famous he needs only one name like Cher or Sting, so tough that when knifed he calmly stitches his own arm, so cool that he stays perfectly serene while knives, fists, feet and chairs come flying toward his face. He's kind of a Zen bouncer, who instructs his staff of junior bouncers to ''Be nice.'' But his gigantic biceps telegraph that sooner or later he'll be pushed beyond nice.

title: New Jersey Man Charged in Rapes And Robberies at the Penta Hotel
description: A New Jersey man who was on parole for a series of rapes was charged last night with raping and robbing two women and is a suspect in the robbery of three other women at the Penta Hotel in Manhattan in the six weeks, the police said.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Here's Haran

title: Martin Beck, 88, Dies; An Architect and Artist
description: Martin L. Beck, an architect who taught at the Princeton School of Architecture from 1929 to 1942, died Tuesday at his home in Princeton, N.J. He was 88 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We've come too late. You have good intentions. You want our country to become better.

title: Kassebaum to Seek 3d Term
description: Senator Nancy L. Kassebaum, Republican of Kansas, announced today that she would seek a third term, dampening the hopes of Democrats for their first Senate seat from Kansas in 50 years. Mrs. Kassebaum, who had pledged in earlier campaigns not to serve more than 12 years, said she decided to run so the state would not lose the benefits of her seniority.

title: Topics of The Times; Vale 'Vice'
description: ''Miami Vice'' makes its farewell appearance on Sunday, but reruns will be around for years - still showing millions how to wear an Armani suit. (Over a T-shirt, with jacket sleeves shoved up.) Was there ever a city more beautiful, and more bloody, than this Miami? Were there ever two cops more handsome, or more reluctant to shave, than Crockett and Tubbs?

title: Lonrho Loses Final Round On Harrods
description: Lonrho P.L.C. today lost the final round of a court battle that all but ends the long struggle of its chairman, Roland W. (Tiny) Rowland, to wrest control of Harrods, the famed London department store, from the Fayed brothers of Egypt.

title: Chrysler to Buy Thrifty Rent-A-Car
description: In a move to cement a relationship with an important customer in the booming automobile rental market, the Chrysler Corporation said today that it had agreed to buy Thrifty Rent-A-Car System Inc., the nation's fifth-largest rental company, for $263 million.

title: Books of The Times; 2 Mysteries Borrow From Other Authors
description: Buried Caesars By Stuart M. Kaminsky 179 pages. Mysterious Press. $15.95 Death in Verona By Roy Harley Lewis 188 pages. Thomas Dunne/St. Martin's Press. $15.95

title: Hunger Strikers, Heart of China Protest
description: Xie Wanjun is a gawky, 21-year-old agriculture student who is so disarmingly meek and boyish that it is not easy to imagine him as part of the brigade of young people who in the last few days have handed the Government a crushing humiliation.

title: Tokyo Gives Hints That Rate Rise Is Near
description: Japanese officials today appeared to be inching toward an increase in the country's record-low discount rate, amid growing nervousness about the rise of the dollar and signs that inflation could be returning after an absence of many years.

title: New Chief for Space Station
description: The National Aeronautics and Space Administration today named a former astronaut, Dr. William B. Lenoir, to head the space station program. Dr. Lenoir, who flew a shuttle mission in 1982, is now a vice president of Booz-Allen & Hamilton, a consulting company. The space agency also announced that Richard Kohrs, the deputy manager of the space shuttle program at Johnson Space Center in Houston, will move to NASA's headquarters in Washington to be operational director for the space station, which is to be called Freedom.

title: Specs Toporcer, 90; Former Ballplayer Known for Glasses
description: George (Specs) Toporcer, the first major league baseball player other than a pitcher to wear eyeglasses on the playing field, died Wednesday after a fall in his home in Huntington Station, L.I. He was 90 years old.

title: Review/Theater; A Noh Blend of the Medieval and Modern
description: Ryo Noda, a young Japanese composer and instrumentalist, has written several works in which he has tried to find common ground between his country's traditional music and its Western-influenced contemporary school. It is not an easy task: each language has its own sense of tonality and timbre, reflected in its instrumentation, and its own kind of rhythmic and harmonic movement.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Allied-Signal Inc., Morristown, N.J., said it had received a contract to supply an air-traffic collision avoidance system, valued at $100 million, to USAir Group Inc., Winston-Salem, N.C.

title: Spotted Owl Isn't Out of the Woods Yet
description: To the Editor:

title: After 10 Years, Player Is Fulfilling a Promise
description: Commuting back and forth between the United States and South Africa prevents Gary Player from playing regularly on the Senior PGA Tour.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bangor Hydro-Electric Co., Bangor, Me., a utility, named Robert S. Briggs president and chief operating officer.

title: Cornelia Marsh Templeton
description: Cornelia Van Rensselaer King Marsh Templeton, a member of an old New York family, died of liver cancer Tuesday at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y. She was 78 years old and lived in Bedford, N.Y.

title: A Safer Spin on Sweeteners
description: The public has been chilled by reports of cyanide in Chilean grapes and alarmed by Alar residues in apples. Now come Washington's latest gyrations on cyclamate, the artificial sweetener banned in 1970. Consumers may well wonder what's safe, what isn't and whether regulators know what they're doing.

title: Review/Film; English Despair, Betrayals and Violence
description: From the British wave of angry new film makers, we have seen the bitterness of ''Sammy and Rosie Get Laid'' and the sardonic comedy of ''High Hopes.'' But none of the recent anti-Thatcherite works is as bleak, intense or tough-minded as ''For Queen and Country.'' The story of a working-class black man who returns to his old neighborhood after eight years in the army is the flip side of ''High Hopes,'' for the England of this film is a dim, claustrophobic, utterly hopeless place.

title: Shanghai Editor Now a Rallying Cry
description: In his lifetime, Qin Benli has been buffeted by a Nationalist purge, the Communist revolution, the anti-rightist campaign, the Cultural Revolution, the campaign against spiritual pollution and the campaign against bourgeois liberalism.

title: INSIDE
description: AIDS Restriction Eased The Government will let foreigners with AIDS enter the country for conferences or treatment. Page D16. No Charge in Baby's Death A man who unhooked his son's life support at a Chicago hospital won't face murder charges. Page. A12. New ads for Burger King In the largest switch of an advertising account, Burger King turned to D'arcy Masius Benton & Bowles and Saatchi & Saatchi. Page D1. Mets Lose Hernandez Keith Hernandez, the first baseman, will be out for ewight weeks with a fractured right kneecap. page B15.

title: Mitterrand Straddles the NATO Missile Dispute; German Confers in U.S.
description: West Germany's Defense Minister began discussions today with top American officials to try to forge a compromise in their dispute over short-range nuclear missiles as some German officials voiced optimism that differences could be resolved.

title: MAI Drops Motion On Prime's Defense
description: MAI Basic Four Inc., the computer company that has been pursuing Prime Computer Inc. since November, withdrew its legal action against Prime's ''poison pill'' defense. MAI Basic, based in Tustin, Calif., is offering $966 million for Prime, a minicomputer maker in Natick, Mass.

title: Yanks Are Treated Roughly By Athletics and Steinbrenner
description: In the hours before the Yankees played and lost again, Don Mattingly walked into the manager's dressing room, spoke for almost a half-hour with Dallas Green, then returned to his locker and began to dress. The meeting, Mattingly said later, was a chance to clear the air, to communicate.

title: Hungary Quits Danube Project, Angering Prague
description: Twelve years ago, when work started on a huge power dam project near the winding Danube on the border of Czechoslovakia and Hungary, leaders in both countries lauded the project as a symbol of Communist harmony.

title: Baker Opposes Jet Deal Curbs
description: The Bush Administration today renewed its strong opposition to Senate-passed restrictions on the $6 billion FSX fighter jet deal, with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d saying they would put the entire warplane agreement with Japan at risk.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the economics of fighting acid rain misidentified one environmental organization and gave an incorrect location of another. The group that represents a traditional approach to regulating air pollution is the Natural Resources Defense Council, not Defense Fund.

title: Program-Trade Dip in April
description: Program trading fell in April, the New York Stock Exchange said yesterday. It said program trading accounted for only 7.6 percent of the volume on the Big Board, the lowest level since the exchange began releasing figures last July.

title: Plenty of Need for City Council President to Act as a Watchdog; Increase Office's Power
description: To the Editor:

title: Evangelicals and the Bar Spar Over Law School
description: The graduating class of an evangelical Christian law school is facing limited job prospects because of the American Bar Association's reluctance to give its seal of approval to the school's legal education. Now the students have taken the A.B.A. to court, arguing that its power to accredit law schools has been used to stifle competition, not to control quality.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-11

title: Review/Art; Giving Voice to the Ephemera of the Urban World
description: For more than a decade, David Hammons has been erecting sculptures and carrying out performances on the streets of Harlem, where he lives, and elsewhere in Manhattan. He works a good deal with found objects, like discarded liquor bottles, and with ephemera, like hair from the floor of a barber shop. He will, for example, hang the empty green bottles on the limbs of a dead tree in an abandoned lot. Until quite recently a towering sculpture entitled ''Higher Goals,'' which he made from discarded telephone poles and topped with a basketball hoop, stood at another site. One winter, Mr. Hammons sold snowballs on a street corner (he made $20).

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY KIM NOVAK'S FILMS

title: Angry Shareholders Confront Exxon Chief Over Alaska Spill
description: The Exxon Corporation's chairman faced the company's owners for the first time today since the oil spill in Alaska eight weeks ago and showed a combination of confidence and exasperation amid hostile questions and calls for his resignation.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: Guest List; Early Risers Get Eggs, Bacon and Tower
description: ''There are two things that top the list of Washington dislikes: the obligatory stand-up cocktail party and the 8 A.M. breakfast,'' John G. Tower noted with a smile this morning as he played host at what was billed as a ''power breakfast'' at Joe & Mo's restaurant on Connecticut Avenue (starting at a presumably more civilized 8:30 A.M.). The purpose: to introduce a new book.

title: Article 456989 -- No Title
description: After months of grim warnings about New York City's fiscal prospects, Mayor Edward I. Koch yesterday presented the kind of budget on which politicians love to run, especially those facing re-election campaigns.

title: Sunday New York Post To Be a Smaller Paper
description: In an effort to stem losses of more than $300,000 a week on its Sunday issue, The New York Post will replace its multi-section Sunday newspaper with a version of its daily paper beginning next month, Valerie B. Salembier, the president of the New York Post Company, announced yesterday.

title: Libraries and Parks to Feel Budget Cuts
description: Small-scale but widespread, the cuts announced yesterday by Mayor Edward I. Koch as part of his proposed budget would be felt keenly around New York City, as library branches close some days, new playgrounds go unbuilt, museums curtail operations and parks get dirtier.

title: Surprise in Bonn: No Rate Increase
description: One of Karl Otto Pohl's standard comments on foreign exchange trading is that even the most powerful central banks can do little in the face of an overwhelming market trend.

title: Economic Scene; Growing Worries On Dollar's Rise
description: THE changing business climate, with the economy slowing, the inflation rate flattening and interest rates edging down, has called forth a burst of speculative buying of stocks, bonds and dollars. But the superstrong dollar is worrying business executives with goods to sell abroad and Government officials who fear that a rising dollar will, sooner or later, worsen the United States trade deficit and add to protectionist pressures.

title: Bridge
description: A New Jersey-Chicago squad was fast out of the blocks when the United States Bridge Championships began here Wednesday night. The tournament will determine the national team that will go to the World Championships in Perth, Australia, in September.

title: Rangers Top Twins In 11th
description: Pete Incaviglia's run-scoring single with two outs in the 11th inning gave the Texas Rangers a 6-5 victory over the Minnesota Twins tonight.

title: Capital Gains Fairness
description: To the Editor:

title: Macy's Denies Sale Rumors
description: Edward S. Finkelstein, the chairman and chief executive of R. H. Macy & Company, denied yesterday that the retailer had arranged to sell an interest to another concern or that any of Macy's store divisions were for sale.

title: Examine These Myths of the 80's
description: LEAD: In this decade, two ideas about poverty seemed to have gained wide currency. One is that middle-income people worry only about ''making it'' themselves and that they feel no obligation to care for the less fortunate. The other is that the poor -especially those in the so-called underclass who are trapped in the worst conditions - have lost hope of extricating themselves.

title: Kennett Square Journal; Foals Are Getting Help Starting in Life's Race
description: Nearly as rare as the colt that grows up to be a racing champion is the birth of twin foals. Yet a tiny and brave filly and her weaker twin brother grow stronger every day here in an intensive care unit for newborn horses.

title: A New Stage for High Art and High Finance
description: IT looks like a cross between a Buck Rogers spaceport, a post-modern palazzo and a latter-day Crystal Palace, yet it is one of New York's newest, largest and most innovative performing-arts centers.

title: Exploring Battery Park City
description: THE traffic just below North Bridge coursed turgidly through the broad, overflowing West Street, and Weekend Walker felt that the occasion of this outing called for a comment as grandiloquent as the skyline that overshadowed him and his companion, City Stroller.

title: Revenues Are Shrinking In Connecticut
description: Democratic leaders in the General Assembly, saying Connecticut's finances have worsened since Gov. William A. O'Neill proposed the largest tax increase in state history three months ago, today offered a package of 25 new or increased taxes to balance next year's budget.

title: In Panama Crisis, Depression Sets In
description: It has reached the point, one Panamanian said this week, where she can no longer keep food down; she feasts on antacids instead. Another, chronically healthy, has suddenly developed an allergy that makes her sneeze and sniffle uncontrollably. A third has begun having obsessive dreams.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Caribbean Combination

title: Ranks Hovis Deal Set
description: Sunningdale Holdings Ltd., a group linked with the British investors Jacob Rothschild and Sir James Goldsmith, said today that it had agreed to buy the 29.9 percent stake in Ranks Hovis McDougall P.L.C. that is owned by Goodman Fielder Wattie Ltd.

title: 1989 Is Not '1984'
description: What's striking about the China-Soviet thaw is the equanimity that greets it in Washington. Not so very long ago, in frostier days, any reunion between the two giants of the Communist world would have been viewed with dread. Some people even believed the China-Soviet split was a sham, just as a vocal minority now argues that this week's apparent reconciliation between Moscow and Beijing threatens freedom.

title: Low-Power Permit Given To Seabrook
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission today approved a license for low-power testing at the Seabrook nuclear plant in New Hampshire.

title: Review/Television; 'Austin City Limits': Live Music, No Frills
description: ''Austin City Limits'' has quietly outlived other pop-concert television shows by keeping things simple. The program books performers on grounds other than raw popularity, seeking out the deserving individualists who tend to land in the middle and lower reaches of the pop charts. And the show, which is produced by Terry Lickona and directed by Gary Menotti, simply puts those performers on a stage and lets them play, uninterrupted and unglossed.

title: KEY RATES
Overhaul U.S. Security Policy in Asia
description: LEAD: As this week's Chinese-Soviet summit meeting dramatically underscored, the cold war glacier is breaking up in Asia as well as in Europe. And as it does, a debate is emerging about United States security policy in the Asia-Pacific region.

title: Dispute Resolved Over Fees in Johnson Estate
description: A bitter court battle over millions in legal fees involved in settling the $500 million estate of J. Seward Johnson has been resolved in Surrogate's Court in Manhattan.

title: Burger King In Biggest Account Shift
description: In the largest account switch in the history of advertising, the Burger King Corporation yesterday transferred responsibility for its domestic business from N. W. Ayer to two agencies: D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, New York and Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising in New York.

title: Bradley's Game Back on Track
description: Pat Bradley was on top of the women's golf world in 1986. She won three of the four major tournaments, had five victories in all, won the Vare Trophy with the lowest scoring average that year, was leading money winner on the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour with a record $492,021 and earned L.P.G.A. Player of the Year honors.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums SPRING STREET FAIR, with games, craft booths where children can make collages, and jewelry, toys, books, sports equipment, entertainment and ethnic food, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. tomorrow, sponsored by the Columbia Grammar and Preparatory School, at 94th Street, between Central Park West and Columbus Avenue. Admission: free. Information: 749-6200. ''THE LION AND THE MOUSE,'' a puppet show by the Rainbow Puppet Works, with Toni Gustafson and Denny Goetz, 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at the Puppet Playhouse, Murphy Center at Asphalt Green, 555 East 90th Street. Tickets: $3.50. Reservations: 369-8890. CITY AND COUNTRY SCHOOL FAIR, from 7 to 11 tonight, with hayrides, music and dancing, children's entertainment, outdoor dining and a rooftop cafe, at the school, 146 West 13th Street. Admission: children, $1; adults, $4. Information: 242-7802. SHEEP-TO-SHAWL FESTIVAL, with demonstrations of sheep sheared in the traditional method, with hand shears, and spinning, weaving, rug hooking, quilting and a blacksmith exhibiting his craft, as well as early American music by the Folk Music Society of Huntington, and refreshments, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Sunday. At the Kissam house and barn, 434 Park Avenue, Huntington, L.I., sponsored by the Huntington Historical Society. Admission: children, 75 cents; adults, $2. Information: (516) 427-7045. FLEECE AND FIBER DAY, demonstrations of sheepherding by border collies, shearing, dyeing, spinning and weaving, paper making, sewing, with storytelling and baked foods to take home, 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. Sunday, at the Stamford (Conn.) Museum and Nature Center, 39 Scofieldtown Road. Admission: children and the elderly, $2; others, $3. Information: (203) 322-1646.

title: Mazda and Ford In Venture Talks
description: The Mazda Motor Corporation, the Japanese car maker, is discussing with its American partner, the Ford Motor Company, a venture in Europe, a top Mazda official said. Mazda's United States president, Osamu Nobuto, said a decision should be made by the end of 1990.

title: Review/Art; Diane Arbus and Alice Neel, With Attention to the Child
description: This exhibition, which brings together nearly 40 portraits of children by the photographer Diane Arbus and the painter Alice Neel, is a great and simple thing. Like a good question on an art-history exam - a classic case of compare and contrast - it can trigger a deeper understanding of both the making and the seeing of art that flows effortlessly into a meditation on life itself.

title: A Trial Begins For Fourth Man In Byrne Slaying
description: A Queens prosecutor charged yesterday that a South Jamaica man was part of a four-man team that murdered Edward Byrne, the rookie police officer shot to death last year while guarding a witness in a drug case.

title: Energy Unit Due At Dow Chemical
description: The Dow Chemical Company said it was putting its energy assets into a new subsidiary that is intended to expand the company's share in the $10 billion independent power market. The unit, called Destec Energy Inc., will be based in Houston and will be headed by Charles F. Goff Jr., Dow's current director of mergers and acquisitions.

title: 114 Incumbents Are Re-elected To School Seats
description: Despite a large effort to elect new members to New York City's local school boards, the great majority of incumbents who ran were re-elected.

title: Ethiopia Leader Tells of Execution of Coup Figure
description: President Mengistu Haile Mariam of Ethiopia, who rushed home from East Germany to put down a coup attempt, announced tonight that the leader of the largest rebellious army unit had been executed.

title: 17 Are Held in a Fight at Van Cortlandt Park
description: Seventeen Bronx teen-agers were arrested yesterday after a fight with two men working at the Van Cortlandt Golf Course in Van Cortlandt Park, the police said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY Gasoline prices posted their largest one-month increase on record in April, pushing the consumer inflation index up 0.7 percent. Without the volatile energy component, the April increase was 0.2 percent, leaving the financial markets cheering. [ Page A1. ] Prices in the New York metropolitan area rose 0.5 percent. [ D2. ] COMPANIES Ernst & Whinney and Arthur Young are expected to announce that they have agreed to merge, a combination that would create the largest professional services firm in the world. [ D1. ] Burger King transferred its domestic advertising to D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles and Saatchi & Saatchi. N. W. Ayer had the account. It was the largest transfer ever of an ad account. [ D1. ] Chrysler agreed to buy Thrifty Rent-A-Car for $263 million in a move to cement its relationship with an important customer in the booming rental market. The $27.75-a-share offer represents a 52 percent premium over Thrifty's market price. [ D1. ] The New York Post will replace its multi-section Sunday paper with a version of its daily paper beginning next month, in an attempt to stem losses of more than $300,000 a week. [ D5. ] MTV announced plans for a cable television comedy channel, the second all-comedy channel announced this week. [ D5. ] Exxon's chairman expressed both confidence and exasperation as he faced criticism from environmentalists. [ B6. ] Lonrho lost the final round of a court battle in its attempt to wrest control of Harrods from the Fayed brothers. [ D3. ] The stock of Avon Products plunged $7.125, to $33, in heavy trading after Amway said on Wednesday that it was withdrawing its $2 billion offer. [ D3. ] Macy's chairman and chief executive denied that the retailer had arranged to sell an interest to another concern or that any of Macy's divisions were for sale. [ D3. ] INTERNATIONAL A wave of dollar-selling by central banks helped slow the dollar's rally, pushing it lower against most major currencies. [ D1. ] The Bundesbank decided not to raise interest rates, apparently hoping that the dollar's rally cannot be sustained. [ D4. ] Japanese officials appeared to be inching toward an increase in the country's record-low discount rate, amid growing nervousness about the rise of the dollar and signs that inflation could be returning after an absence of many years. [ D4. ] Japan is likely to be cited for failing to open its market in supercomputers, despite sharp divisions in the Bush Cabinet on the usefulness of trade sanctions. [ D4. ] MARKETS Two dozen subpoenas have been served in the last few days on commodities and clearing firms in Chicago, as the Government investigation continues. [ D7. ] The stock market moved higher, and the Dow Jones industrial average reached its highest level since the October 1987 market crash, gaining 7.69 points, to 2,470.12. [ D6. ] Long-term Treasury securities rose moderately as investors shrugged off a larger-than-expected seven-tenths of 1 percent increase in the Consumer Price Index for April. [ D12. ] Precious metals futures prices fell sharply on the Commodity Exchange in New York as investors continued bailing out of the market because of the strong dollar. [ D13. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Some people worry that a rising dollar will add to protectionist pressures. Leonard Silk: Economic Scene. [ D2. ] Shares of Columbia Savings rose sharply as its president said he might take it private. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D6. ] The Four A's faces new challenges, said its new chairman, Glen W. Fortinberry. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D5. ]

title: Glendale Federal Unit Sets Offering
description: The Glendale Federal Savings and Loan Association, a unit of Glendale Federal, is offering $150 million of floating-rate notes due 1990 through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

title: Reid Leads Early Birds
description: J.R. Reid of North Carolina and Nick Anderson of Illinois led the list of 14 early entry candidates for the National Basketball Association draft June 27. The list, which was released by the league yesterday, included Vlade Divac, a center for the Yugoslav national team that won the silver medal at the Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea, and Andrew Gaze, the Australian who started for Seton Hall's N.C.A.A. runner-up team this season. Reid was an all-America selection as a sophomore, and he was a member of the bronze-medal winning American team in Seoul. Anderson was a starter for the Fighting Illini's Final Four team, which was eliminated in the semifinals.(AP)

title: Killer of Police Chief Is Executed in Georgia
description: Henry Willis 3d, who was convicted of shooting a small-town police chief to death one day before the victim was to leave for a new job, died in the electric chair tonight.

title: Dinkins Wins Support Of Manhattan Chiefs
description: The Manhattan Democratic Executive Committee last night overwhelmingly endorsed the mayoral candidacy of Borough President David N. Dinkins of Manhattan.

title: Samuel Rosenblatt, Lawyer, 81
description: Samuel Rosenblatt, a lawyer and former Commissioner of Public Works in Montclair, N.J., died Wednesday at Montclair Community Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Montclair.

title: Review/Pop; The Many Personalities of Eartha Kitt
description: Long before there was a musical called ''Cats,'' Eartha Kitt was projecting a sensuously feline image in cabarets and such musicals as ''New Faces of 1952.'' That catlike presence, underscored by her wide face and high cheekbones and her growling, gutteral manner of singing, are still part of her performance that opened on Tuesday at the Ballroom, 253 West 28th Street.

title: Renaissance Music
