description: Bart Folse will conduct I Cantori New York in a concert of Renaissance music at St. Peter's Church, in the Citicorp Center, 54th Street and Lexington Avenue, tomorrow evening at 8. The program includes works by Andrea and Giovanni Gabrielli, Claudio Monteverdi, Don Carlo Gesualdo, Orlando di Lasso and Giovanni Palestrina. Tickets are $12. Information: 928-4632.

title: Review/Music; Stephen Albert's Variations On a Theme of James Joyce
description: The New York Chamber Symphony's concert at the 92d Street Y got off to a late start on Sunday afternoon because one of the soloists in the opening work - Stephen Albert's ''Treestone'' - was caught in Mother's Day traffic at curtain time. Since the composer was in the audience, he was drafted to fill the time with a lecture about his piece. ''Treestone'' is one of several works by Mr. Albert inspired by James Joyce's ''Finnegans Wake,'' and the composer began by confessing that he had never read the entire book. He then offered a cogent analysis of the thematic crosscurrents and symbols in the sections of the text he used in ''Treestone,'' by which time the missing singer had arrived.

title: Tokyo Journal; Loyal Samurai's Suicide: An Alarm Bell for Japan?
description: A year ago, before friends could have predicted that a political scandal would lead him to suicide, Ihei Aoki wrote a telling message in his high-school alumni newsletter about the ugly side of Japanese politics.

title: Teen-Age Girl Held in Slaying
description: A 14-year-old Brooklyn girl was arrested Wednesday night and charged with second-degree murder after she stabbed another teen-age girl to death during a fight over a dog, the police said yesterday. The victim, Pacquita Braswell, 18, of 375 Blake Avenue in the Brownsville section, was stabbed once in the chest outside her apartment building about 11 P.M. She was pronounced dead a short time later at Brookdale Hospital. The suspect, Tomika Fleming, of 371 Blake Avenue, had apparently argued with Miss Braswell over the ownership of a dog, the police said.

title: Southmark Board Postpones Meeting
description: The board of the Southmark Corporation, the Dallas-based real estate and financial services company, postponed a special shareholders meeting scheduled for Friday in Atlanta at which the company's proxy holders were to vote on directors. Three incumbents are opposed by nominees from a group of dissident shareholders.

title: Market Place; Valuing Columbia Savings Shares
description: SHARES of the Columbia Savings and Loan Association, also known as the savings institution that ''junk'' built, rose sharply yesterday as its president complained it was undervalued and said he was thinking of taking it private.

title: A Life of Shostakovich, On 'Great Performances'
description: The two-and-a-half-hour film ''Testimony,'' the ''Great Performances'' presentation on Channel 13 tonight at 9, could be subtitled ''Montage Mania.'' This film biography of the Russian composer Dmitri Shostakovich (1906-1975) was produced, directed, designed and, with David Rudkin, co-written for Britain's Channel 4 by Tony Palmer. Film montage, basically using disparate elements and superimpositions, is Mr. Palmer's working signature. Other of his films seen here include ''Maria Callas: An Operatic Biography'' and the ''Wagner'' mini-series starring Richard Burton.

title: Mets Turn on Power, Turn Back Dodgers
description: Not many hours after they lost Keith Hernandez for the next two months, the Mets got the act together with a clatter last night and overpowered the Los Angeles Dodgers, 5-3, with one of their best pitching, hitting and wall-scaling performances of the season.

title: Review/Art; Arnulf Rainer: Backward to Respectability
description: One of the things that this critic least wants to do, ever again and even for quite a large sum in ready money, is to read another novel or sit through another movie about the contemporary art world.

title: McCall's Deal Is Said to Fail
description: Diamandis Communications Inc. withdrew yesterday from negotiations to acquire McCall's magazine because of unresolved issues involving subscription liabilities and differences over its value, publishing industry analysts and executives said.

title: Stocks Move Higher, With Dow Rising 7.69
description: The stock market moved higher again yesterday, and the Dow Jones industrial average reached its highest level since before the October 1987 market crash.

title: Wildcat Overture to Pitino Hits Sour Note at Garden
description: As if the Kentucky basketball program doesn't have enough problems with the N.C.A.A., now Madison Square Garden officials are mad at it, too.

title: House Ends Deadlock On Veteran Spending
description: The House ended weeks of partisan stalemate today and approved $1.2 billion for this year's veterans' programs, and the Senate finished unusually early Congressional action on the $1.17 trillion Federal budget for 1990.

title: Koch Offers Safer, but Dirtier, Streets
description: Mayor Edward I. Koch characterized the $26.6 billion budget that he released yesterday as one of ''choices and consequences.'' Nowhere were those difficult decisions more evident than in his proposals for New York City's uniformed services.

title: Dollar Off As Central Banks Act
description: A wave of dollar-selling by central banks helped slow the dollar's rally yesterday, pushing it lower against most major currencies.

title: A Marathon Fiesta of Fairs, Fancies, Parades and Food
description: WHEN it comes to public festivities, New York is like a perpetual-motion machine - a place with a never-ending procession of street fairs, parades and other outdoor entertainment. But this weekend, the machine threatens to become seriously overheated.

title: Students Told to Provide Free Service
description: The University of Pennsylvania Law School yesterday became the first major law school in the United States to require its students to provide voluntary legal services.

title: Review/Film; Rascals Roam the New West in 'Cold Feet'
description: Though it is set in Montana, where the glorious scenery is full of horses and mountains and cowboy hats, ''Cold Feet'' is the kind of film where Tom Waits, as a deeply stupid hit man, walks into a western clothing store and asks for some ''cowpoke stuff.'' The film does not send up the West, so much as it looks at westerns from a skewed point of view.

title: U.S. Will Ease Visa Restrictions For Some Who Suffer From AIDS
description: In a shift in policy, the immigration service will permit foreigners with AIDS to enter the United States on temporary visas to attend conferences or for medical treatment, a Justice Department official said today.

title: Columbia Law Review Broadens Its Outlook
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance; An Ensemble Taps Itself a Happy Birthday
description: The Jazz Tap Ensemble wished itself a happy birthday on Tuesday night when it opened a week's engagement at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street) as part of its 10th-anniversary season. The Los Angeles-based company dedicated its program to Charles (Honi) Coles, the great tap-dancer who was a teacher of Lynn Dally, the group's artistic director.

title: Elf Aquitaine Chief Replaced
description: The chairman of the state-controlled oil company, Elf Aquitaine, has become the first industry chief to be ousted by the Socialist Government that took over in France a year ago. An Elf spokeswoman said

title: Lithuanians Adopt a Declaration Seeking an Independent Republic
description: The legislature of the Soviet Republic of Lithuania declared today that the republic wanted independence.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on May 8 about the Japanese politician Takako Doi misidentified the head of the Democratic Socialist Party. He is Eiichi Nagasue, not Eiichi Matsunaga.

title: Contract for Acting Chancellor Divides Board
description: The Board of Education's deliberations on who should lead the New York City school system are focused on reservations voiced by the board's two minority-group members about a plan to offer an interim contract as schools chancellor to the acting chancellor.

title: Money Fund Assets Soar
description: The assets of the nation's 468 money-market mutual funds rose by $4.9 billion, to $311.95 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The 142 institutional funds jumped by $2.35 billion, to $79.14 billion. The 231 general-purpose funds were up by $644 million, to $101.42 billion. And the 95 broker-dealer funds increased by $1.91 billion, to $131.38 billion, the institute said.

title: Dispute Over Historic Gun Snags Estate for 22 Years
description: A stocky dark-haired man died in a Dallas prison in 1967, leaving only a suit, a watch, a ring and a .38-caliber pistol. Twenty-two years later, his lawyer and heirs are still arguing over the estate.

title: Will There Be A Tomorrow Tomorrow?
description: ''All anyone in New York is talking about,'' someone said yesterday, regarding the sports world, ''are two things: the Knicks against the Bulls, and Montreal against Calgary in the Stanley Cup finals.''

title: The Absent Americans
description: Finally, some part of the United States Government is opening its mind and heart to the Chinese people surging for freedom and is speaking to them and for them - at least some part.

title: Toni Matt Dies at 69; Former Ski Champion
description: Toni Matt, a pioneer in competitive and recreational skiing in the United States, died, apparently of a heart attack, on Wednesday in Pawling, N.Y. He was 69 years old. Mr. Matt, who was born in St. Anton, Austria, came to the United States in 1938 with a group of Austrian skiers. On April 16, 1939, he skied down Tuckerman's Ravine on Mount Washington in New Hampshire in 6 minutes 29.4 seconds, reaching a speed of 85 miles an hour. His time for the eight-mile run down slopes with, in some places, 65-degree drops has never been bettered.

title: Auctions
description: A Bierstadt Offered

title: Michael Dyne, 70, Writer of Dramas for TV
description: Michael Dyne, a playwright who also wrote many dramas and comedies for television, died Wednesday at his home in Linlithgo, N.Y. He was 70 years old and had colon and liver cancer.

title: British Joblessness Falls
description: The Government said today that unemployment had fallen sharply in March, by 60,200 workers, to 1,856,000. That is the lowest level since 1980 and the 33d consecutive monthly decrease. Average earnings increased at an annual rate of 9.25 percent in March for the second straight month, indicating a leveling off after a recent upward trend.

title: The Jets' Defensive Line Takes on Youthful Look
description: Despite the fact that their once famous Sack Exchange was gone, the Jets were second in the American Conference in sacking quarterbacks last season.

title: James Campbell, 37, Human Rights Lawyer
description: James M. Campbell, a lawyer for the New York City Commission on Human Rights, died of complications from AIDS Monday at his home in Brooklyn. He was 37 years old. Mr. Campbell joined the commission in 1986 in the law-enforcement bureau and helped to redraft the Human Rights Law and rules of practice. He worked on the AIDS panels of the State Bar Association, the National Lawyers Guild and the Greater New York Hospital Association.

title: 9 Enter Preakness; 8 Go, Rain or Shine
description: A field of nine, including the first six finishers from the Kentucky Derby, was entered today for the 114th Preakness Stakes at Pimlico on Saturday. Only eight horses, however, are likely to start.

title: Nominee's Role as Consultant Is Examined by Senate Panel
description: The Senate Foreign Relations Committee said today that it had opened an investigation of ties between President Bush's nominee as Ambassador to Luxembourg and a Federal housing program that Democratic lawmakers say was used by the Reagan Administration to benefit some prominent Republicans.

title: Key Sections From the Communique
description: Following are key sections from the Soviet-Chinese communique issued yesterday at the end of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's visit to China, as provided in translation by the Soviet press agency Tass: Exchange of Opinions

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Custom-Tailored Bond

title: Australia Raises Rates
description: Australia's central bank raised interest rates today for the fourth straight week as its dollar fell below 76 cents in United States currency, its lowest level in more than a year. The Reserve Bank raised its rediscount rate to 17.3 percent, from 17 percent - the highest in two years - the day after the bank's governor, Bob Johnston, called for restraint to cure Australia's ''state of self-indulgence.'' The rediscount rate, a financial market guide to central bank credit policy, has risen by almost a percentage point since April 27.

title: Ford Airbags Due
description: The Ford Motor Company named the nine car lines that will carry airbags as standard equipment in the 1990 model year, which begins this fall. The bags will be standard equipment in the Ford Mustang, Taurus and Crown Victoria, Mercury Sable and Grand Marquis, Merkur Skorpio, and the Lincoln Town Car and Mark VII. They will be offered as an option in the Ford Tempo and the Mercury Topaz. Ford's Lincoln Continental will continue to be the only American car to provide airbags on the driver's and passenger's sides.

title: Sale of Oil Leases Off Alaska Is Postponed
description: Responding to the Exxon Valdez spill, the Interior Department has announced a year's postponement in the Government's sale of an oil lease in the Gulf of Alaska.

title: Moving for a Cause or Just Because
description: New York-as-melting pot is to be celebrated in two large ethnic-heritage parades this weekend -one in Manhattan and the other in Brooklyn. Marchers will begin assembling for the seventh Turkish-American Parade at 1 P.M. tomorrow on the Avenue of the Americas at West 56th Street; at 2:30 P.M. 15,000 people are expected to begin following the parade route, which will go south on the Avenue of the Americas to 47th Street and east to the United Nations. Information: 513-7310.

title: Lemon And Lemonade
description: Is the yearlong shutdown of the reactors at the Savannah River nuclear plant a crisis or an opportunity? Can a lemon be made into lemonade?

title: Steel Imports Decline
description: Steel imports in March fell to their lowest level in six years and their share of the domestic market shrank to 17.2 percent, well within the maximum under the United States import quotas, the American Iron and Steel Institute said Wednesday. Exports rose in March to 606,000 tons, the largest monthly total since July 1974, the institute said. Another group, the American Institute for Imported Steel, said the 1.22 million tons of imports in March represented just 12.9 percent of the market when excluding 129,000 tons of semifinished steel that United States companies imported to supply their own mills.

title: Cartwright Handling Ewing in Pivotal Matchup
description: When the Chicago Bulls' practice ended today, Bill Cartwright headed straight for the whirlpool. He settled his 7-foot-1-inch body into the soothing water, and let out a satisfied sigh of relief.

title: Senate Panel Hears Manley Tell of Learning Disability
description: Dexter Manley told a Senate panel today that he has finally overcome childhood rejection and has gained self-respect since seeking help three years ago to learn to read and write.

title: Reviews/Film; Waiting in California for the Next Big Bang
description: The opening sequences of Steve DeJarnatt's ''Miracle Mile'' are so playfully disarming that the movie feels more like a kooky modern love story than a film about nuclear war.

title: About Real Estate; Project Offering Condo-Type Services
description: To combine features of urban and rural living, a real estate developer in northeastern Westchester County is offering home buyers the maintenance services characteristic of exclusive suburban condominium developments.

title: Dale Linx Orrin, 36, Dancer and Teacher
description: Dale Linx Orrin, a dancer, teacher and choreographer, died on May 5 at St. Joseph's Mercy Hospital in Ann Arbor, Mich. He was 36 years old.

title: Book on Valvano Gets A New Life, Less Flair
description: ''Personal Fouls,'' the book that once promised to expose widespread corruption in Jim Valvano's North Carolina State basketball program, has been scheduled for publication in September. But the book will be published without the sensational claims made by the original publisher before it withdrew from the project in February.

title: Wildlife Death Toll Climbs As Spill Clings to Alaska
description: Nearly two months after the biggest oil spill in American history, Alaskan officials say that not a single mile of beach has been completely cleaned and that the death toll of birds, fish and mammals continues to mount.

title: Israelis Lift Gaza Curfew but Still Bar Workers
description: Israel lifted the curfew over about one-third of the Gaza Strip today, though Gaza remained a closed military zone, meaning that about 60,000 workers were still prohibited from leaving for their jobs inside Israel.

title: Sullivan Rejoins Cast
description: Danny Sullivan, the winner of the 1985 Indianapolis 500 who crashed in a practice run for this year's race last Thursday, returned to a race car yesterday at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway. Wearing a special protective brace for the right forearm he broke when his Penske PC18-Chevrolet crashed into the wall on the third turn, Sullivan hopped into a similar race car a few minutes after the beginning of a practice session at the Speedway. (AP)

title: THE LAW: At the Bar; A black woman's 42-year trek from obscurity to recognition as a successful lawyer in Harlem.
description: When Cora T. Walker told her mother that she planned to become a lawyer, the mother minced no words. ''You're going to be another poor, hungry Negro lawyer,'' she said.

title: F.D.I.C. Found Fraud at Half Of Savings Units It Studied
description: The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation said today that after examining more than 200 insolvent savings associations at the request of President Bush, it had found evidence of criminal fraud and abuse at almost half the institutions.

title: Prices in the New York Region Were Up 0.5% Last Month
description: Consumer prices in the New York metropolitan area continued their rise, climbing one-half of 1 percent last month, the Labor Department's regional bureau reported yesterday.

title: 2 Pillars of Humility
description: In hockey's playoffs, when goaltending is either a team's trump card or its Achilles heel, the two goaltenders who have survived to duel in the Stanley Cup championship are engaged in a self-deprecating cold war.

title: Canal Treaty Violated Often, U.S. Says
description: A Defense Department official said today that Panama had violated the Canal treaties more than 1,200 times in the last 15 months by harassing United States military personnel and dependents.

title: No Action on Taylor
description: The N.F.L. said yesterday that it would take no action against Lawrence Taylor in the wake of his acquittal on drunken-driving charges. Taylor, the Giants' celebrated outside linebacker, was found not guilty May 10 in Saddle Brook (N.J.) Municipal Court. Taylor has been cited twice by the league for violating its substance-abuse policies. The first violation required a rehabilitation program, and the second violation resulted in his suspension for the first four games last fall. A third violation would result in a one-year suspension.

title: Lydia Pasternak Slater, Poet, Is Dead at 87
description: Lydia Pasternak Slater, a poet who translated some of the works of her brother, Boris Pasternak, the Russian Nobel laureate in literature, died in Oxford, England, on May 4 after a long illness. She was 87 years old.

title: GORBACHEV ENDS CHINA AMITY TALKS
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev left China today after a four-day summit meeting that ended 30 years of estrangement between the Soviet Union and China, taking with him promises of expanded party and government contacts and a general reduction of military tensions in Asia.

title: Review/Film; Armenian Homeland: A Flickering Flame
description: A century or so ago, when idealistic Zionists in Europe talked of returning to Palestine, it must have seemed as though they were nurturing an utterly impossible dream. One never knows, however, how things will turn out, which is one of the reasons hope springs eternal. A Swedish-made documentary, filmed in part in the shadow of Mount Ararat, the geographical and spiritual center of the Armenian homeland destroyed by the Turks during World War I, seems aimed at keeping the flame of hope alive. It returns frequently to the theme of an empty land waiting for the return of its people. And yet the very evidence the film presents shows just how dim the flame is.

title: Court Blocks Bid
description: The Income Opportunity Realty Trust, a real estate investment trust based in Emeryville, Calif., said a Federal court in California had issued a preliminary injunction against an offer from the DRF Acquisition Corporation and the Policemen and Firemen Retirement System and the General Retirement System, both of Detroit. It said the pension funds were blocked from proceeding with an offer of $9 a share for the stock of the trust, acquiring or attempting to acquire any of the trust's shares and making any public announcements about offers to acquire the stock.

title: CHINESE PREMIER ISSUES A WARNING TO THE PROTESTERS
description: BEIJING, Friday, May 19 - Prime Minister Li Peng warned Thursday that chaos in Beijing was spreading all over the country, but his demand for restraint was ignored by up to a million people who braved a driving rain to demonstrate once more for greater democracy.

title: It's Rollins Vs. Marsalis In a Duel At Carnegie
description: When Sonny Rollins, 59 years old, and Branford Marsalis, 28, two tenor saxophonists, step onstage tonight at Carnegie Hall, listeners might well sense a challenge. Jazz history is full of tales, authenticated and apocryphal, about the nights in which reputations were made, new styles were forged and pretenders were deflated in the jazz equivalent of one-on-one basketball or a duel of honor - the jam session or ''cutting contest.''

title: Federal Express Prices Notes
description: The Federal Express Corporation yesterday priced a $150 million issue of 10-year notes through underwriters led by Kidder, Peabody & Company, a unit of General Electric Financial Services Inc.

title: Chief Picked for Space Station
description: The space agency moved today to quickly fill vacancies in the management of the space station program, naming a former astronaut to head the program.

title: Farewell Tour For Shoemaker
description: Bill Shoemaker, the retiring jockey who has ridden 8,799 winners and won more than $120 million in stakes money, announced today that he would begin his worldwide farewell tour June 4 in Zurich, Switzerland.

title: Big Merger Indicated in Accounting
description: Two of the world's largest accounting firms -Ernst & Whinney and Arthur Young & Company - are expected to announce Friday that they have agreed to merge, people close to the two firms said today.

title: Supreme Court Clears Way for Florida Teen-Ager to Have Abortion
description: The United States Supreme Court today opened the way for a 15-year-old Florida girl to have an abortion without her parents' consenting to it or knowing about it.

title: Review/Music; Reviving An Opera, A Reputation And a Style
description: The Brooklyn Academy of Music's debut opera season is ending this weekend with the most impressive of the three highly impressive productions it has presented.

title: Results Plus
description: BRASEBALL Villanova Big East Champion: Gene Schall, the designated hitter, cleared the bases with a double in the eighth innning last night, sparking Villanova to a 10-7 victory over Providence and the Big East tournament title. Villanova earned its first trip to the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament since 1961. Villanova trailed by 7-6 entering the inning and Schall's hit snapped a 7-7 tie. Mike Wismer added three hits for the Wildcats, whose record is 39-11. Rafael Novoa, who saved Villanova's 8-7 victory over Seton Hall earlier in the day, earned the victory, pitching one and one-third innings in relief. Providence finished with a record of 27-16. The tournament was held in Bristol, Conn.(AP) TENNIS Connors Is Beaten: Sergio Bruguera of Spain beat Jimmy Connors, 6-1, 6-1, yesterday in the third round of the Italian Open in Rome. The 36-year-old Connors, who was seeded fifth, was no match for the unseeded 18-year-old Spaniard. Bruguera was joined in the quarterfinals by another unseeded player, Mark Koevermans of the Netherlands, and Jordi Arrese of Spain, both of whom registered three-set victories. Arrese upset 10th-seeded Darren Cahill of Australia, 3-6, 6-3, 7-5. Koevermans defeated Diego Nargiso of Italy, 6-3, 3-6, 6-1.(AP) Sabatini Advances: Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina defeated Radka Zrubakova of Czechoslovakia, 3-6, 6-4, 6-2, yesterday to advance to the quarterfinals of a women's tournament in West Berlin. Barbara Paulus of Austria stunned Helena Sukova of Czechoslovakia, 6-7, 7-5, 6-4, and Isabel Cueto of West Germany upset Katarina Maleeva of Bulgaria, 6-3, 6-3. Mary Joe Fernandez of the United States was eliminated, losing by 6-3, 6-3 to unseeded Regina Rajchrtova of Czechoslovakia. Helen Kelesi of Canada cruised into the quarterfinals by beating Andrea Temesvari of Hungary, 6-3, 6-2. Sylvia Hanika of West Germany trounced Laura Garrone of Italy, 6-1, 6-0.(AP) Stanford Woman Takes Title: Sandra Birch of Stanford beat Jennifer Santrock of Southern Methodist, 6-3, 6-3 yesterday in Gainesville, Fla., to win the National Collegiate Athletic Association women's individual tournament. Birch is a 19-year-old sophomore from Huntington Bay, L.I. (AP) HORSE RACING Pro Style Wins Belmont Feature: Pro Style, ridden by Eddie Maple, won by a neck in the feature race yesterday at Belmont Park. Sadr, who led most of the way, was runner-up in the field of eight, three lengths ahead of Once Over Knightly. The victory was Pro Style's third in 11 starts this year. The winner covered one mile on a fast track in 1:35 4/5 and paid $6 for $2 to win.(AP)

title: Restaurants
description: Turning around a senescent institution like the Edwardian Room in the Plaza Hotel is like trying to throw a loaded supertanker into reverse: the momentum of longstanding mediocrity is powerful. Memories of the last time I dined there, about two years ago (before Donald Trump bought the hotel), include a halibut fillet that had been roasted to within seconds of incineration and a wizened baked potato that should have been served with a carbon-dating kit.

title: U.S. Seen Citing Japan On Supercomputer Curb
description: Despite sharp divisions in the Bush Cabinet on the usefulness of trade sanctions, Japan is likely to be cited for failing to open its market in supercomputers, officials said today. They spoke after the first Cabinet meeting devoted to singling out unfair practices under last year's trade law.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball CINCINNATI (NL) - Activated Eric Davis, outfielder, from the 15-day disabled list. Assigned Skeeter Barnes, infielder-outfielder, to Nashville of the American Association. METS (NL) - Placed Keith Hernandez, first baseman, on the 21-day disabled list. Recalled Keith Miller, infielder, from Tidewater of the International League. OAKLAND (AL) - Placed Walt Weiss, shortstop, on the 15-day disabled list. Recalled Lance Blankenship, infielder, from Tacoma of the Pacific Coast League. Placed Jose Canseco, outfielder, on the 60-day disabled list retroactive to May 10. PITTSBURGH (NL) - Sold the contract of Orestes Destrade, infielder, to the Seibu Lions of the Pacific League in Japan. ST. LOUIS (NL) - Placed Ted Power, pitcher, on the 21-day disabled list. Called up Don Heinkel, pitcher, Louisville of the American Association. Football JETS (AFC) - Waived Darryl Hammond, cornerback. WASHINGTON (NFC) - Announced the retirement of Dave Butz, defensive tackle. Colleges COASTAL CAROLINA - Appointed Ed Green athletic director. PURDUE - Announced the resignation of Jim Elam, assistant football coach. WESTERN CONNECTICUT - Announced the resignation of Tim Camp, sports information director, to take a similiar position at St. Peter's College. >

title: Harry Nees, an Environmentalist, Dies at87
description: Harry F. Nees, an environmentalist and insurance company official, died Monday at the Somers (N.Y.) Manor Nursing Home after a long illness. He was 87 years old and had lived in Belleville, N.J.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Ruder Leaving S.E.C. To Return to Teaching
description: LEAD: David S. Ruder said yesterday that he would resign as chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission to return to teaching law at Northwestern University.

title: Telecable Is Put On the Block
description: The Telecable Corporation said last night that it was putting itself up for sale. A cable operator based in

title: Motion by Tyson Is Denied by Judge
description: The Delaware Chancery Court has denied a motion by Tyson Foods Inc. to block the sale of the Holly Farms Corporation. Judge Maurice Hartnett also denied a motion by Holly, the Memphis-based chicken producer, for a temporary restraining order to prevent Tyson and Conagra Inc. from reaching an agreement that might impair the bidding for Holly.

title: Papandreou May Be Too Charismatic for Greece
description: To the Editor:

title: Exxon Monitored Drinking by Captain
description: The Exxon Shipping Company monitored the alcohol habit of Capt. Joseph J. Hazelwood for four years before his tanker went aground in Prince William Sound on March 24, the company president testified today, but it found no evidence of a continuing drinking problem.

title: Marcos Undergoes Surgery; Internal Organs Are Failing
description: The former Philippine President, Ferdinand E. Marcos, is in very critical condition after undergoing an operation for kidney failure and may die at any time, a hospital spokesman said today.

title: Columbia Law Review Broadens Its Outlook; Shows Insensitivity
description: To the Editor:

title: White House
description: John H. Sununu was fuming.

title: Wright Predicts Victory in Ethics Case
description: House Speaker Jim Wright struggled for his political footing today, predicting victory in the legal challenge to the ethics charges he faces, while allies battled a deepening gloom in the House.

title: Consumer Prices Jump 0.7%, With Gasoline as the Culprit
description: Gasoline prices posted their largest one-month increase on record in April, pushing the consumer inflation index up seven-tenths of 1 percent, the Government said today.

title: Crossroads of Emigre History
description: The capital of the United States holds one of the smallest urban communities of Soviet emigres in the nation, a loosely knit group of professionals, scholars and writers whose common bond, if there is one, is to escape being typecast as emigres.

title: Limits on Assualt Guns Voted
description: California's Legislature today became the first in the nation to pass a broad ban on semiautomatic assault weapons.

title: New Subpoenas in Chicago
description: After months of relative quiet in the Federal investigation of trading activities at the nation's two largest commodity exchanges, in Chicago, about two dozen subpoenas have been served in the last few days, people involved in the case said today.

title: Reviews/Film; The Purim Story, With Modern Overtones
description: Amos Gitai's film ''Esther'' faithfully retells the familiar biblical story celebrated in the Jewish festival of Purim, but gives it a sharp contemporary resonance.

title: Minorco Files Plea on Ruling
description: Minorco S.A., the world's biggest gold mining company, said yesterday that it had filed an appeal in the United States Court of Appeals in New York against an antitrust ruling in an effort to clear the way for a new takeover bid for Consolidated Gold Fields P.L.C. of Britain, the world's No. 2 gold producer.

title: Fair Shake for Rose
description: Pete Rose can bring witnesses to his hearing with the baseball commissioner next Thursday, Francis T. Vincent Jr., the deputy baseball commissioner, said yesterday. ''It's certainly up to their side if they want to bring witnesses,'' Vincent said. ''It's certainly allowed. It's going to be a fair hearing.''

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: TV Ends Flight of Biggest Medicaid Thief
description: Five months after fleeing the New York City area to avoid a prison sentence for the largest Medicaid fraud to date, Sheldon Weinberg was arrested yesterday in Scottsdale, Ariz.

title: Prosecutor's Trip Through an Underworld
description: Lisa Mazure, an assistant Manhattan district attorney, was having a typical day of missing papers, missing people, bad arrests and bad crack.

title: Target: Gangs That Plague Housing
description: For years, the rules of life for the residents of the Rockwell Gardens public housing project here were decreed by armed young men patrolling the corridors. They decided who came and went. Sometimes they charged a toll. Sometimes they issued a curfew to residents so gang members could make drug deals without being disturbed.

title: Canada Northwest Energy Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss c-Net income and included a special gain of $4,763,000. Year-ago 6 months sales are restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Book Awards Chairman
description: Al Silverman has been elected chairman of the National Book Awards, it was announced Tuesday. Mr. Silverman succeeds Roger L. Stevens, who has been named chairman of the executive committee of the organization, which annually sponsors awards to authors. Mr. Silverman is senior editorial adviser to the Time Inc. Book Company and was the president of the Book-of-the-Month Club.

title: 'Exhaustion' Sidelines Sparky Anderson
description: Sparky Anderson, the manager of the Detroit Tigers, has been sent to his California home for treatment of exhaustion, the team said yesterday.

title: Daniel Smiley, Ecologist, Is Dead; Owner of Mohonk Resort Was 82
description: Daniel Smiley, an ecologist and one of the principal owners of Mohonk Mountain House, a national historic landmark in New Paltz, N.Y., died of cancer yesterday in Kingston (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived near Lake Mohonk.

title: Silvercrest Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said that of the loss in the latest third quarter, about $1.2 million was from discontinued operations.

title: Evans Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 25
description: b-Included a gain of $776,000 from an accounting change for both the quarter and year. Fiscal 1989 included a pretax charge of $2 million for reorganization and severance costs.

title: Czar Resources Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included special gains of $523,108 for the latest quarter and $551,910 for the year-earlier period. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: CHINA ORDERS END TO TV BROADCASTS
description: As American viewers watched live television coverage from China last night, Chinese officials ordered the networks to cease transmitting pictures and commentary from a portable station set up in Beijing.

title: Pitino Praises Bulls' Hero After Heartbreaking Loss
description: The Knicks ran out of miracles, they ran out of time, and they ran out of ways to extend their season tonight.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 52.

title: Disputed Nominee Is Making $284 a Day at Justice Dept.
description: William Lucas, whose nomination as Assistant Attorney General is opposed by a number of civil rights groups, is working for the Justice Department as a $284-a-day civil rights consultant while awaiting Senate confirmation, the department said today.

title: Gencor Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Chancellor-Hunt Given Deadline Falling After Election
description: The New York City Board of Education yesterday set itself a deadline of Dec. 31 to have a new schools chancellor in place, insuring that its nationwide search will be concentrated during the coming mayoral campaign.

title: Bralorne Resources Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,341,000 in the latest quarter and $1,780,000 in the year- earlier period. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Canadiens Win, 4-3, In Double Overtime
description: Neither team could wish a goal into the net tonight at the Forum, and Game 3 of the Stanley Cup championship, unresolved through four periods of hockey, required double overtime before Montreal's final rush on a controversial power play created the maneuver that gave the Canadiens a 4-3 victory.

title: Interpoint Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After an extraordinary expense of $54,000 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: KEY RATES
Digital to Delay U.S. Raises To Counter Computer Slump
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation said yesterday that it would delay salary increases for its 73,500 employees in the United States to help control costs amid a general slowdown in the computer industry.

title: Rise in Sea Levels May Indicate Earth Is Warming
description: The water in the world's oceans appears to have risen a tenth of an inch per year in the last century, a change that could indicate that the planet is indeed warming up, Canadian researchers reported Thursday.

title: Transcript of Remarks by Chinese Prime Minister Announcing Crackdown
description: Following is a transcript of Prime Minister Li Peng's remarks to Communist Party officials early today in Beijing (Friday morning in the United States), as provided in translation by the New China News Agency:

title: Administration Makes Choice a Top School Priority
description: Declaring that the nation can no longer ''just patch or just tinker'' to repair its educational system, Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos said today that the Bush Administration would work to let parents choose the schools their children attend.

title: FROM KOCH, MAJOR PLANS;
description: Reversing himself on New York City's fiscal prospects as well as some longstanding policies, Mayor Edward I. Koch proposed a budget this week that would provide more help for the homeless, people with the AIDS virus and drug abusers, along with money to add police officers, prosecutors and child-welfare caseworkers, among others.

title: Your Money; Time to Consider Shifting Assets
description: As long as the annual inflation rate hovered below 5 percent, investors could put their money into certificates of deposit or Treasury securities yielding 8 to 10 percent and get a real return. But in April consumer prices rose at an 8.1 percent annual rate, the Government reported, and if that continued, it would be more difficult to stay ahead of inflation, particularly on an after-tax basis. A more aggressive approach to portfolio management might be in order.

title: International Broadcasting reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
Review/Dance; Troupe Performs Among the Dinosaurs and Such
description: The opportunity to stage pieces in the American Museum of Natural History surely excited the participants in ''Dancing Into Natural History,'' which Dancing in the Streets presented at the museum Wednesday night.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on May 10 described a dispute at Princeton University after a sexual encounter between a professor and a graduate student. It reported that the professor had been suspended, and that some people at Princeton were dissatisfied with the university's handling of the case.

title: Hadco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
Rain May Limit Indy Qualifying
description: Drivers waiting to qualify for the Indianapolis 500 found something besides speed to worry about today.

title: About New York; A Little Help Down the Aisles Of America
description: ''Try some Taystee cake,'' the woman chirped. ''If you like it, it's been reduced from $1.89 to $1.39. And I can give you a 25-cent-off coupon too. Or maybe you'd like some chocolate milk? All samples are free, of course. No obligation.''

title: CBS to Add Nine Series in the Fall
description: CBS, the third-ranked network in the ratings, announced a fall schedule yesterday that overhauls its prime-time lineup, adding nine new series and changing the schedule every night of the week except Sunday.

title: Bradley Real Estate Trust reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Jet Camp Pleases Walton
description: The Jets ended their minicamp today, and Coach Joe Walton was so pleased that he called it off a session early.

title: 2 GET PROBATION IN COMPUTER CRIME
description: Two former employees of a Tampa television station were sentenced to five years' probation each today after pleading no contest to charges that they broke into a rival station's computer system.

title: Agency Takes Up Older Judges' Case
description: Seeking to persuade Federal courts to ban mandatory retirement ages for appointed state judges, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has taken three states to court on age discrimination charges and is investigating the claims of a 70-year-old Vermont Supreme Court justice who is fighting to keep his job.

title: Mets Walk to Victory in 10th Inning as Giant Pitchers Go Wild
description: Goose Gossage, once the most feared relief pitcher in baseball, was unhittable again last night, although this was not something he wanted to discuss at length afterward. The Mets, understand, didn't have to make contact with Gossage's pitches because almost none of them came in contact with the strike zone.

title: Panama Guards at U.S. Embassy Seized
description: Stepping up harassment of United States officials and employees here, Panamanian security forces have arrested at least 15 employees of the company that provides security for the American Embassy, officials said today. At least four security guards have taken refuge in the embassy.

title: Patents; An Ultrasonic Drill For Advanced Ceramics
description: Researchers at Los Alamos National Laboratory in Los Alamos, N.M., have developed an ultrasonic drill capable of boring through tough, space-age ceramic materials.

title: Zavitz Technology Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company has changed its fiscal year-end to Sept. 30 from Nov. 30. For the quarter ended May 31, 1988, net was $198,609, or 2 cents a share, on revenue of $2,405,775. For the 6 months ending May 31, 1988, net was $338,367, or 4 cents a share, on revenue of $4,396,773. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Man Is Guilty of Conspiring To Export Nerve Gas to Iran
description: A businessman accused of trying to export nerve gas bombs to Iran was found guilty of conspiracy today but was acquitted of trying to export the gas.

title: A.M.E.  Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Sierra Acquired By Halliburton
description: The Halliburton Company, the engineering and oilfield services company, said it had acquired Sierra Geophysics Inc., a privately held computer software company that designs programs used to develop maps for minerals and energy exploration, a technology with a rapidly growing market,industry analysts say. No price was disclosed for the company, which had revenues of about $10 million last year, according to a Halliburton spokesman.

title: Secom General reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: STOCKS ARE LIFTED TO 19-MONTH HIGH AS DOW TOPS 2,500
description: LEAD: A real bullishness crept into the spring rally on Wall Street yesterday and the stock market's blue-chip indicator, the Dow Jones industrial average, soared past 2,500, a level it has not seen since just before the crash of October 1987.

title: Patents; New Designs For Engines And Motors
description: Electric motors and internal combustion engines have been around for more than a century, and the basic principles have changed little. But in recent weeks two independent inventors have won patents for designs intended to make the machines simpler and longer lasting by doing away with some familiar components.

title: Crescott Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 33.

title: Samuel J. Moskowitz, Lawyer, 82
description: Samuel J. Moskowitz, a Manhattan lawyer for nearly 60 years, died of lung cancer yesterday at South Nassau Communities Hospital in Oceanside, L.I. He was 82 years old and lived in Hewlett Harbor, L.I.

title: 3 Lands Resolve Namibia Dispute
description: South Africa, Angola and Cuba said today that they had resolved their differences over Namibia and agreed that a United Nations independence plan for the territory should go ahead.

title: Is Broadway Afraid of Rocking the House?
description: To the Editor:

title: Ivaco Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,087,000 for the latest first quarter and $1,199,000 for year- ago period. Year-ago figures have been restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Donald Hiss, 82, Ex-U.S. Official And Lawyer in Washington Firm
description: Donald Hiss, a retired Washington lawyer and Government official, died of lung cancer Thursday at his home in St. Michaels, Md. He was 82 years old.

title: Astaphan to Tell All
description: Ben Johnson's physician said yesterday he would tell a Canadian Government inquiry everything its commissioner will allow about drug use in international sports when he testifies next week.

title: Henlys Group Ltd.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $76,608,000. c-Net income and after an extraordinary charge of $577,000. Year-ago figures have been restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Burden for the Poor Would Be Greater
description: To the Editor:

title: Brewery Shift In Australia
description: Alan Bond, who two years ago expanded his Australian brewing empire to the United States, is giving up control of the world's fifth-largest brewing company in a deal worth 3.5 billion Australian dollars ($2.7 billion American). Bond Corporation Holdings

title: TENNIS  Agassi Advances Twice
description: Andre Agassi acored two straight-set victories in four hours yesterday and top-seeded Mats Wilander was upset by Jay Berger of the United States at the Italian Open men's tennis championships in Rome. Agassi, seeded second, reached the semfinals and became the tournament favorite after Wilander was upset, 6-3, 6-4. Agassi began the day by completing a 6-3, 6-4 victory over Leonardo Lavalle of Mexico.

title: System Lashed as Police Honor 5 Slain on Duty
description: Five bronze plaques, so new they still gleamed, were unveiled yesterday at New York City Police Headquarters by the Mayor and the Police Commissioner, honoring officers who were killed last year in the line of duty. Then, in frustration, both men lashed out at the criminal-justice system.

title: Ex-Pentagon Official Calls Stealth Bomber Too Costly
description: The former chief of Pentagon weapon buying said today that he had recommended canceling the radar-evading Stealth bomber because of its high cost and because the manufacturer had not shown significant evidence that it is carrying out a quality-control program promised last year.

title: GMI Group Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $127,000.

title: Assault on College With Little Ammunition
description: If you are about 18 and have applied to college recently, this little teen-age comedy, which opened at neighborhood theaters yesterday, might have some appeal. Indeed, there are a few rare moments that might appeal to other people as well. ''How I Got Into College'' shows some sporadic cleverness at spoofing the getting-into-college culture. At any rate, the mostly teen-age audience seemed to laugh when the director, Savage Steve Holland, intended.

title: U.S. VOICES REGRET AT EVENTS IN CHINA
description: The United States expressed regret today that China had sent troops to restore order after a month of student demonstrations.

title: Rose's Stores reports earnings for Qtr to April 27
4 Are Slain in Gunfight in West Bank
description: Three Palestinians and an Israeli soldier were killed early this morning during an unusual gunbattle in a small village just south of here.

title: Man Held in Death Plot
description: An exterminator was ordered held without bail today, charged with paying an undercover police officer $500 to kill his estranged wife because she was demanding too much money in a divorce. The suspect, Carl Ibe, 48 years old, of Valley Stream, L.I., was arrested Thursday and charged with conspiracy to murder his wife, Carole, 45.

title: Ketchum & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Take Torture Out of Driver's License Renewal
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 731089 -- No Title
description: A bill was introduced in Congress yesterday to finance the creation of a nationwide ''data superhighway'' that would link supercomputers and develop an interagency Federal research and development plan for supercomputers and software.

title: M-A-R-C Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Transit Agency Makes It Harder To Beat the Fare
description: New turnstiles and higher railings at a Manhattan subway station have reduced fare-beating by 80 percent, Transit Authority officials told the authority's board yesterday as they outlined plans to revise the entire fare-collecting system.

title: Jordan Ends Knicks' Comeback and Season
description: Knick Coach Rick Pitino grimaced when Michael Jordan went to the free throw line with four seconds remaining in the game. He had a feeling the Chicago Bulls' guard would sink the two free throws.

title: Is Broadway Afraid of Rocking the House?; Hostility to Producers
description: To the Editor:

title: Hawker Siddeley Canada Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a special gain of $1,256,000. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: ALABAMIAN GUILTY IN KILLING OF BLACK
description: An all-white jury has convicted a former Ku Klux Klansman of murder for providing a rope and a pistol that were used in fellow Klansmen's assault on a black teen-ager who was strangled and hanged from a tree.

title: Rudolf Uhlenhaut, Automotive Engineer, 82
description: Rudolf Uhlenhaut, an automotive engineer who designed and engineered Mercedes-Benz racing and passenger cars, died of heart disease on May 8 at his home in Stuttgart, West Germany. He was 82 years old. Mr. Uhlenhaut began his 41-year career with Mercedes-Benz in 1931 as a test engineer. In 1936 he became head of the company's racing-car division and guided production of the Silver Arrow cars that dominated automobile racing in the late 1930's.

title: Miniscribe Calls Data Not Reliable
description: The Miniscribe Corporation has advised stockholders that the financial statements issued in the 1986 and 1987 fiscal years and in the first three quarters of 1988 were not reliable. Shortly after the announcement Thursday, the rating firm Standard & Poor's suspended Miniscribe's B-rating on $98 million of subordinated debt, saying it would be impossible to judge the company's financial condition. While the computer disk company made its May 15 interest payments on time, S.&P. said that ''the unavailability of audited financial statements may trigger a technical default.''

title: Solicitor General Confirmed
description: The Senate has approved the nomination of Kenneth W. Starr, a conservative Federal appeals judge, to be Solicitor General, the Government's chief representative before the Supreme Court.

title: Sterling Adding Goodrich Plant
description: Sterling Chemicals Inc., a highly successful petrochemical products manufacturer, said it had agreed to acquire a Calvert City, Ky., plant from The B.F. Goodrich Company for an undisclosed price. The factory manufactures more than one billion pounds of vinyl chloride monomer, the base of polyvinyl chloride, or PVC plastics, widely used in pipes and tubing.

title: Hextall Unrepentant
description: Ron Hextall, the volatile goalie for the Philadelphia Flyers, displayed no remorse for his attack on Chris Chelios, a Montreal defenseman, as he emerged Thursday from a hearing in Toronto with Brian O'Neill, the National Hockey League's executive vice president. With 1 minute 37 seconds left in the sixth game of the Wales Conference championship series and his team trailing, 4-2, and on the verge of elimination, Hextall attacked Chelios, slamming him with his stick.

title: Musical Closes
description: ''Blame It on the Movies!,'' a musical tribute to film songs, closed after the Wednesday performance at the Criterion Center, Stage Left, 1530 Broadway, at 45th Street. The musical, conceived and written by Ron Able, Billy Barnes and David Galligan and directed by Mr. Galligan, ran for 12 previews and three regular performances.

title: Pepper's Condition 'Serious'; Ill With a Stomach Ailment
description: The condition of Representative Claude Pepper, hospitalized since April 6 with a stomach ailment, worsened today, and an aide described him as ''in very serious condition.''

title: DISCLOSURE SOUGHT FROM POLICY GROUP
description: In a move aimed largely at former Secretary of State Henry A. Kissinger, the Senate Foreign Relations Committee has approved a measure requiring members of the President's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board to file public financial disclosure statements.

title: MAN IN THE NEWS: Li Peng; Cautious Gamesman
description: When Li Peng became China's Prime Minister in 1987, emerging as a leading member of the younger generation of Chinese leaders ready to take power from the country's aging revolutionaries, there was an obvious question about him: why this rather colorless bureaucrat and former minister of electrical power, who seemed not to have extraordinary experience or credentials?

title: Mickey Sells; Is He Now Oversold?
description: Is Mickey Mouse working a bit too hard?

title: PARTY HEAD MAY BE OUT, REPORTING IS CURBED
description: The Government called troops into the capital this morning and imposed martial law in parts of the city to crack down on China's growing democracy movement. But tens of thousands of people rushed out of their homes to block troops from reaching student demonstrators in the central square.

title: Preakness Will Solve Puzzles of Top 2 Colts
description: The 114th Preakness Stakes at Pimlico on Saturday will be bet and watched as a two-horse showdown between Sunday Silence and Easy Goer. While they are clearly the two best colts in the field of nine, they also are the two most puzzling. The race is as much a test of the true ability of both colts as a match between them.

title: Chinese in the United States Voice Their Disappointment
description: Chinese students and intellectuals in the United States expressed varying degrees of fear, anger and disappointment yesterday after the Chinese Government, taking a tough line, moved troops toward the demonstrators in Beijing.

title: Queens Symphony Director
description: The Queens Symphony has appointed Arthur Fagen as its music director to replace the ensemble's founder, David Katz, who died in 1987. Mr. Fagen is 38 years old and lives in Hewlett, L.I. He studied at Wesleyan University and with the conductor Max Rudolf at the Curtis Institute in Philadelphia.

title: A Melody Lingers On
description: ''Something could be going on here.''

title: Financiere Entraide-Coopernts Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $241,000 for the latest first quarter and $467,000 for the year-ago period. Revenue represented interest income. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Hollis Titman, Pastry Chef, And Eric H. Scott Marry
description: Hollis Weeks Titman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John DeWitt Titman of Brooklyn, and Eric Holmes Scott, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Scott of Los Angeles, were married yesterday at the Swedenborgian Church in San Francisco. The Rev. Edwin Capon officiated.

title: Spike Lee Stirs Things Up at Cannes
description: It's the dawn of a day that's going to be the longest and hottest of the summer. Mr. Senor Love Daddy, Bedford-Stuyvesant's favorite disk jockey, starts his wake-up show at top volume, ''doing the nasty to your ears, playing the platters that matter.''

title: Funeral Director Admits Guilt
description: A former funeral director, Bobby Wilks, 53 years old, pleaded guilty Wednesday to two counts of grand larceny for burying bodies without coffins or vaults their families had purchased. Mr. Wilks could be sentenced up to six years on each count. Investigators found Joseph Roath's body had been wrapped in cardboard and buried only three feet deep instead of without the coffin and vault his family ordered. Mr. Wilks also pleaded guilty to burying Ollie Hester without a vault that had been paid for.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 3-7 China began a crackdown on students and the growing democracy movement. The Government ordered army troops into Beijing, and tens of thousands of people rushed to the street to support the students. Page 1 The troops looked in bewilderment from their immobilized convoy of 21 trucks in western Beijing. Rather than dispersing the students, they found themselves being protected by the students from an angry mob. 1 Washington expressed regret that China had sent troops into Beijing to restore order and hope that a Government dialogue with students would continue. 6 Man in the news: Li Peng 7 Chinese in the U.S. express fear, anger, disappointment 7 China shuts down American news broadcasters 7 Washington is willing to negotiate with the Soviet Union on reducing short-range nuclear missiles in Europe, provided some stiff conditions are met, Western officials said. 1 Three Palestinians and an Israeli soldier were killed during an unusual gunbattle in a small village just south of Bethlehem. 3 Cairo journal: drug abuse threatens Egypt's security 4 Italy's Prime Minister resigned, succumbing to months of relentless political battering and, plunging the Government into a period of turmoil that some said could last for weeks. 4 A challenge to a new U.S. trade law was would be issued by the European Community, it said, if Washington accuses the community of unfair trading practices. 35 A smoldering conflict in Hungary within the Communist Party broke into the open when the party newspaper published an attack by communists advocating change, along with a reply from a party aide. 5 Panama arrested at least 15 workers recently from of the company that provides security for the American Embassy, officials said, as security forces step up harassment of U.S. officials and employees. 3 Three lands resolve Namibia dispute 3 National 9-10, 28, 33 The Dow Jones surged through 2,500, a level last seen just before the 1987 crash, as the stock market continued a rally fueled by falling interest rates. 1 A chance to raise air fares was rejected when some air carriers did not follow Continental Airlines's move last month to raise its discount fares as much as 18 percent. 1 Federal hearings into the oil spill off Alaska took on the tone of a debate as Alaska's environmental Commissioner clashed with the manager of the Alyeska pipeline consortium. 9 The battle over the spotted owl continued, with a Federal district judge in Oregon dismissing a challenge to Government plans to allow logging in the forests where the bird lives. 9 Ocean water appears to have risen a tenth of an inch per year in the last century, a change that may indicate that the planet is warming, Canadian researchers have reported. 28 Letting parents choose the schools their children attend is an aim of the Bush Adminintration, Education Secretary Cavazos declared. 33 To ban mandatory retirement ages for state appointed judges, the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission has taken three states to court on charges of discrimination. 9 Requiring financial disclosures from members of the President's Foreign Intelligence Advisory Board was approved by the Senate Foreign Relations Committee in a move aimed largely at Henry Kissinger. 10 Most senators accepted money last year in speaking fees from industries and trade associations with interest in legislation, according to financial disclosure reports. 10 Cancellation of the Stealth bomber has been recommended by the former chief of Pentagon weapon buying. He cited the plane's high cost, among other problems. 10 To wrest control of a housing project in Chicago and eject gangs that were selling drugs and terrorizing residents, the authorities have conducted ''Operation Clean Sweep,'' ousting 400 people in eight sweeps. 9 Ex-Klansman guilty in murder of Alabama black 33 Regional 29-32 New York City's child-care system has dozens of infants and toddlers living in understaffed, overcrowded group homes that routinely fail to meet city Health Department standards and violate state regulations. 1 A doctor who aided Joel Steinberg and Hedda Nussbaum in illegally adopting a baby boy had his medical license revoked by the New York State Board of Regents. 31 A new chancellor should be chosen for the New York City school system by December 31, the Board of Education said, setting itself a deadline and a policy course. 29 An assistant district attorney's job in Manhattan includes frantic days of missing papers, missing people, bad arrests and increasing numbers of drug cases. ''I love this job,'' says oneprosecutor, Lisa Mazure. 29 Bronze plaques honoring policemen who were killed last year in the line of duty were unveiled at New York City Police Headquarters by the Mayor and the Police Commissioner. Both assailed the justice system. 31 ?News analysis: The mayoral budget proposed for New York City this week includes major spending increases to help the needy and combat crime. But several major questions remain about paying for the program. 29 Lauder ad seeks to tie Giuliani to Noriega 31 Trying to counter the peer pressure that leads many of their friends to experiment with drugs, a group of New Jersey students starred in 23-minute film titled ''Dead End.'' 29 Accused of trying to export nerve gas to Iran, a New Jersey businessman was found guilty of conspiracy but was acquitted of trying to export the gas. 31 Transit Authority outlines plans to toughen fare collection 31

title: Electrolux Gets Regina's Assets
description: The Electrolux Corporation of Marietta, Ga., announced yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire the assets and business operations of the Regina Company, the Rahway, N.J., vacuum cleaner maker that sought Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection in April.

title: Suddenly, a Good News Budget
description: Deficits disappear as money materializes. Gloom and doom die. Rivals cry foul. Welcome to election-year budgeting, Ed Koch style.

title: Oshap Technologies Ltd. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in U.S. dollars and had been translated using exchange rate of BF 37.23 to U.S. $1.00, the exchange rate on Dec. 30, 1988. As of Dec. 31, 1987 the currency exchange rate was BF 32.90 to U.S. $1.00.

title: Xerox Outlook
description: The Xerox Corporation's chairman, David T. Kearns, predicted Thursday that the company's restructuring would improve pretax profit by $50 million to $60 million this year and more in coming years. The restructuring of business products and systems, announced in January, will cut costs enough to increase pretax profits by $100 million to $120 million in 1990 and following years, Mr. Kearns said at the company's annual meeting. Mr. Kearns also said the company intended to remain independent. He also indicated that the company had not been approached by a would-be acquirer.

title: Campbell Soup Co. Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Scott Barry, AIDS Counselor, 32
description: Scott Barry, a spokesman and counselor for AIDS victims, died of complications of the disease on May 11. He was 32 years old and lived in Los Angeles.

title: Fed Agreed to Stop Raising Rates, Minutes Show
description: The Federal Reserve decided in March to stop pushing up interest rates to slow inflation, the minutes of the Fed's policy-making meeting of March 28 disclose.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Drop 5% on the Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest fell 5 percent in the four-week period ended May 15.

title: Warning By Europe On Trade
description: The European Community warned the United States today that it would challenge the new American trade law before an international tribunal if Washington accused the community of unfair trading practices.

title: Edward Stanley, 86, Former NBC Executive
description: Edward Stanley, a former public-affairs director for NBC, died on Wednesday at the University Medical Center in Tucson, Ariz., after a brief illness. He was 86 years old.

title: Is Broadway Afraid of Rocking the House?; We Know the Score
description: To the Editor:

title: Terratech Resources Inc.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Year-ago net has been restated. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Cambridge Shopping Centers Ltd.  reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: In the Air, Safety and the Blind
description: With only two members dissenting, a Senate committee last week voted to bar airlines from refusing blind passengers seats in rows with emergency exits. That substitutes misguided compassion for common sense.

title: Storm Wrecks New Copters
description: A storm that struck Fort Hood in Texas last weekend caused at least $600 million in damage, the Army said today.

title: Graphic Scanning reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,547,000 for the quarter and $3,751,000 for the 9 months. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,230,000 for the quarter and $4,125,000 for the 9 months. d-Net income

title: A 12-Hit Volley Vaults Yanks Over Seattle, 9-5
description: This was their first explosion of runs in more than two weeks, and the Yankees seemed to relish every moment. They had fallen on hard times this week -12 runs in a six-game stretch - but tonight they hit a bonanza: a 9-5 rout of the surging Seattle Mariners at the Kingdome.

title: Endotronics Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Comparable year-ago results are not available due to the reorganization and recapitalization of the company on April 4, 1988.

title: U.S. Economy Walks Tightrope
description: Poring over recent statistics, many economists have concluded that the economy is managing to walk the line between inflation and recession. It is apparently growing enough to stave off a big rise in unemployment but not enough to push prices up sharply.

title: Quebecor Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said losses incurred at its 14-month-old tabloid, the Montreal Daily News, amounted to $2.3 million. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Pressures Foil Airlines' Efforts to Raise Fares
description: When Continental Airlines announced last month that it was raising its discount fares as much as 18 percent, it expected the other airlines to follow suit. But some did not, and this week Continental had to retract its increases, bringing a halt to a steady escalation in the price of an airline ticket.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MAY 20, 1989
description: Markets

title: Quantum Sues Sony
description: The Quantum Corporation, a disk drive manufacturer based in Milpitas, Calif., said today that it had filed a lawsuit against the Sony Corporation charging unfair competition and patent infringement.

title: B&H Bulk Carriers reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter revenue included interest income of $36,966.

title: Dorothy R. Pirone, 68, Babe Ruth's Daughter
description: Dorothy Ruth Pirone, whose father was Babe Ruth but who did not learn the identity of her natural mother until she was 59 years old, died yesterday at her home in Durham, Conn. She was 68 years old.

title: Great American CommunicaFtions reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain from discontinued operations of $1,722,000. c-After a gain of $1,477,000 from discontinued operations. The latest quarter included a net gain of $4.7 million on the sale of an affiliate. The year-ago period included a net gain of $17.8 million on the sale of United Brands stock. Discontinued operations represented earnings from Great American's insurance subsidiary. The company said non-cash charges for depreciation and amortization in its first quarter were $14.1 million.

title: Boston Five Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
CSM Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the total revenues are presented March 31, 1989 and March 31, 1988 to reflect the treatment of receivables on long term contracts not billed to customers as revenues. The amounts reflect the proportionate elements of profit as revenues based on the stage of completion of the long term contracts.

title: A Poor Land Torn by a Rich Craving
description: Until recently, Ahmed Kahlawi was best known among Egyptians as a singer of religious songs. Then came the raid.

title: Staten Island: Monaco in New York Bay?
description: LEAD: When the U.S.Supreme

title: Tainted Mushrooms Recalled
description: The Federal Food and Drug Administration is recalling institutional-sized cans of mushrooms from China because of three outbreaks of food poisoning in February and April, including one at the Peninsula Hospital Center cafeteria in Queens. The 68-ounce cans carry the packer designations ''TM'' in the top line or ''T3'' or ''M2'' in the middle line of a three-line code.

title: Detection Systems reports earnings for Year to March 31
Brenda Mines Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $3,867,000. c-Net income The company said the loss was due partly to lower grades, higher operating costs and the expensing of $1.4 million of previously deferred exploration costs on the Kaolin project. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Ninth Avenue International Food Festival, Ninth Avenue between 37th and 57th Streets will be closed from 8 A.M. to 7 P.M. today and tomorrow.

title: More Strategists Pushing Stocks and Bonds
description: Many Wall Street strategists and institutional investors continue to scramble aboard the rallying stock and bond markets.

title: How to Avoid Another Valdez
description: LEAD: It will be years before we know the full extent of the damage wrought to Prince William Sound by the Exxon Valdez.

title: Kentucky's Basketball Program And 2 Players Heavily Penalized
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association today placed the University of Kentucky's basketball program on probation for three years for recruiting and academic violations, and took the unusual step of banning one Kentucky player, Eric Manuel, from further N.C.A.A. competition. Another player, Chris Mills, was barred from playing at Kentucky.

title: Colleen P. Keller Marries Dr. J. F. McPartlin on L.I.
description: St. Dominic's Roman Catholic Church in Oyster Bay, L.I., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Colleen Patricia Keller, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Keller of Oyster Bay, to Dr. John Francis McPartlin, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis McPartlin of Elmhurst, Queens. The Revs. Lawrence D. Costello and Sean Winters officiated.

title: 3 U.S. Navy Warships Arrive In Shanghai on Courtesy Call
description: Three American Navy ships steamed into Shanghai for a courtesy call today, one day after the Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, visited the city.

title: PEC Israel Economic Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included provision for income taxes in 1989 of $655,312 and in 1988 of $1,102,351.

title: Agnico-Eagle Mines Ltd.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a special gain of $500,000. c-Net income and included a special gain of $4.1 million. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: U.S. Charges Rep. Rose With Disclosure Lapses
description: The Justice Department today filed a civil suit accusing Representative Charlie Rose of failing to report on his Federal financial disclosure statements $138,694 in loans obtained over six years.

title: Schools Chancellors: Kings, Scapegoats
description: With the death Dr. Richard R. Green, the Chancellor of the New York City public schools, a new round of kingmaking has commenced, once again raising unreasonable hopes for a sudden improvement of a severely ill system, once again illustrating how little changing the executive at the top can accomplish the necessary rehabilitation below.

title: Juilliard School
description: Mike Nichols, the director whose films include ''The Graduate'' and ''Working Girl,'' and the philanthropist Avery Fisher were among five people who received honorary degrees yesterday from the Juilliard School at its commencement at Lincoln Center.

title: Scott Shuts Out Pirates on 1-Hitter
description: Mike Scott pitched no-hit ball for seven innings and finished with a one-hitter tonight, and Bill Doran knocked in all of Houston's runs as the Astros beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 3-0.

title: A Promise Of Brighter Smiles
description: Cosmetics for teeth? Now there's a product that claims to go beyond ordinary toothpaste in brightening a smile. While many dentifrices aim to polish away plaque and other stains, EpiSmile is the first product, its manufacturer says, to include a chemical whitener, calcium peroxide or CalProx.

title: Italy's Premier Resigns After Months of Squabbles Within Coalition
description: Prime Minister Ciriaco De Mita succumbed to months of relentless political battering and resigned today, plunging the Government into a period of turmoil that some commentators said could last for weeks.

title: U.S. Posts Big Surplus
description: An unusually large surge in April income tax payments helped produce a record budget surplus of $41.45 billion for the Government last month, the Treasury Department said today.

title: Aquino Will Not Let Ailing Marcos Return
description: With former President Ferdinand E. Marcos reported gravely ill, his successor, Corazon C. Aquino, reaffirmed today that she would not allow him to return or to be buried in the Philippines.

title: Raymond Blackman, a Military Editor, 78
description: Raymond V. B. Blackman, one of the world's leading experts on foreign navies and a former editor of the military reference work Jane's Fighting Ships, died on Wednesday, his family said today. He was 78 years old.

title: Rose Seeking Delay
description: Pete Rose's lawyers yesterday asked for a 30-day postponement of a hearing scheduled for Thursday before the baseball commissioner, A. Bartlett Giamatti, who is investigating allegations against the Cincinnati Reds' manager.

title: Lauder Advertisement Seeks To Link Giuliani and Noriega
description: Ronald S. Lauder, a Republican candidate for mayor, is airing a television commercial this weekend that seeks to link his main opponent, Rudolph W. Giuliani, with Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the Panamanian leader who faces drug-smuggling charges in the United States.

title: Venmar Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Aircoa Hotel Partners reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Players Out, But Kentucky Survives
description: Rick Pitino or any other basketball coach should be able to live with the penalties handed to the University of Kentucky yesterday.

title: Percy Bugbee, 90, a Fire Prevention Expert
description: Percy Bugbee, former chief executive of the National Fire Protection Association, died Tuesday at his home in Plymouth, Mass. He was 90 years old.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With Watering the Lawn
description: Although rainfall is filling reservoirs and saturating the ground, now is the time to think realistically about watering the garden during the long, hot days of summer.

title: Lands' End Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
U.S. Offers to Talk On Battlefield Arms, But With Stiff Terms
description: The United States is willing to hold negotiations with the Soviet Union on reducing short-range nuclear missiles in Europe, provided some stiff conditions are met, Western officials said today.

title: Frances Steloff Memorial
description: A memorial service for Frances Steloff, founder of the Gotham Book Mart, is to be held in the Celeste Bartos Forum at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and 42d Street, on Monday at 2:30 P.M. Mrs. Steloff died April 15 at the age of 101.

title: B&H Maritime Carriers Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company went public on Feb. 3.

title: Job Cutbacks Minimized in Ernst Link
description: Moving swiftly to allay fears that a merger of their firms would mean closing numerous offices and laying off hundreds of people, the chairmen of Ernst & Whinney and Arthur Young & Company said yesterday that they expected actually to increase staffing after the two huge accounting firms combined.

title: COMPANY NEWS;
description: United Airlines today ordered 16 extended-range Boeing 767 wide-body jets and took options on 16 more, in a deal valued at $3 billion.

title: In Jersey Film, Youths Warn Other Youths About Drugs
description: Through a grim form of ''show and tell,'' a group of Hudson County students is trying to counter the peer pressure that leads many of their friends to experiment with drugs.

title: Charles's 63 Ties Course Mark
description: The players took advantage of the impeccable fairways and receptive greens of the Sleepy Hollow Country Club course and posted low numbers today in the opening round of the Nynex/Golf Digest Commemorative senior tournament.

title: Ted B. Westfall, 69, Ex-I.T.T. Executive Who Led Company
description: Ted B. Westfall, a telecommunications executive, died of congestive heart failure Thursday at the University of Virginia Hospital in Charlottesville. He was 69 years old and lived in Charlottesville.

title: Paramount Funding Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

description: An Israeli and 3 Arabs Die in West Bank Gun Battle
