title: Speaking Fees Bolster Senators' Pay
description: Most senators earned speaking fees last year from industries and trade associations with interest in legislation, according to financial disclosure reports released today.

title: Loewen Group Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: John Hancock Income SecuriFties reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Assets represented net assets.

title: Let No One Forget The Bobovikovs
description: To the Editor:

title: Slowdown Is Seen, but No Recession
description: Judging by the rally in the stock market, the chorus of economic statistics released over the last two weeks hit the right note:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''You are our Army. You are our brothers and sisters. You are Chinese. Our interests are the same as yours. We believe you have a conscience. You must not crush the movement.'' - Linda Liu, a businesswoman, as she went from truck to truck pleading with soldiers sent to end the sit-in in Tiananmen Square. [ 1:3. ]

title: Victoria Creations Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Holly Farms Corp.
description: The unusual efforts by the board of the Holly Farms Corporation to end its auction for the company appear to have misfired, leaving it without any new offers to consider. Tyson Foods Inc., the chicken processor based in Springdale, Ark., that has been trying to acquire Holly Farms since October, objected to the Holly board's revised terms, which were sprung on the company last Friday. It refused to change its bid. ''I don't see any reason to play with the rules out now,'' said James Blair, Tyson's general counsel.

title: Sparks Fly at Alaska's Oil Spill Inquiry
description: Dennis Kelso, Alaska's top environmental official, was on the witness stand at Federal hearings into the Valdez oil spill, and his interrogation by William Howitt, the manager of the Alyeska pipeline consortium, had taken on the tone of a debate.

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about a 28-acre park to be built atop the North River Water Pollution Control Plant in Harlem omitted the names of the designers of the plant, whose work won the Albert S. Bard Award for excellence in architecture and civic design from the City Club of New York. The firms involved were TAMS Engineers, Architects and Planners; Gibbs & Hill, and Feld, Kaminetzky & Cohen, all of New York. The project architect was C. Theodore Long of TAMS.

title: MICC Investments Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $1.2 million. c-Included a special gain of $6.3 million. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Sad but Defiant, Chinese Stand Up to Troops
description: The 1,000 troops looked out in bewilderment from their immobilized convoy of 21 trucks in western Beijing today to find that their world had been turned upside down.

title: Fewer Savings Units
description: A United States savings industry regulator predicts there will be 1,000 fewer savings and loan associations in 10 years. Darrel Dochow, head of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board's Office of Regulatory Activities, said the number of savings institutions would be reduced to 2,000 from 3,000 in a decade.

title: Ferdinand F. McAllister, Surgeon, 77
description: Dr. Ferdinand F. McAllister, a surgeon and an emeritus professor of clinical surgery at Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons, died yesterday at Indian River Memorial Hospital in Vero Beach, Fla. He was 77 years old and had lived in Nyack, N.Y. until two years ago, when he moved to Vero Beach.

title: Teacher Carries Gun Into a Bronx School
description: A substitute teacher was charged yesterday with carrying a handgun for which he held no New York City permit into a Bronx public school, the police said.

title: BCE Development Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said there were no earnings applicable to common shareholders in the year-ago period after payment of preferred dividends. Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Health Violations Cited at Child Group Homes
description: Dozens of infants and toddlers in New York City's foster-care system have been living in understaffed, overcrowded group homes that routinely fail to meet city Health Department standards and violate state regulations.

title: Interest Rates Move Sharply Lower
description: Interest rates tumbled yesterday as investors flocked to buy long-term Treasury and corporate bonds before yields decline further.

title: A Husband Tells His Wife's Other Love Story
description: Mary and Richard A True Story of Love and War By Michael Burn 249 pages. Arbor House/William Morrow. $18.95.

title: Navigators Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Newt Gingrich's Glass House
description: Without a doubt, the charges raised against Newt Gingrich, the combative House Republican whip, arise out of partisan fury. Representative Gingrich had partisanship on his mind when he filed charges of ethical impropriety against Speaker Jim Wright last year. But even if such accusations are politically inspired, they may nevertheless have merit, as the Wright case demonstrates. The House ethics committee has a duty to open a window into Mr. Gingrich's glass house.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Breaking Away
description: As temperatures rise, bicyclists by the thousands take to the streets and parks of the city and the back roads of the countryside. Before you join them, it is a good idea to have your bicycle overhauled by a qualified mechanic. A thorough job by a bikeshop can cost anywhere from $45 to $75 or more for a 12- or 18-speed. If possible, bring your bicycle in during the week - when the shop is less busy and more likely to pay closer attention to both you and your machine. Here are some key repairs: Brakes: Adjust for quick, smooth response by tightening cables; replace old, worn brake shoes Brake and Gear Cables: Replace frayed cables; repack cables with fresh grease; replace worn cable housings Hubs, Bottom Bracket and Head Set: Clean and repack with fresh grease once a year; replace ball bearings if necessary Chain: Clean; replace if necessary (especially if rusted); replace freewheel when replacing chain Wheels and Tires: Wheels should be true (round without any side-to-side wobble); spokes should be tight; rims should have no bulges; tires should be properly inflated. Replace tires if badly worn or cut

title: Mother Fights to Ruin the Taste of Poison
description: On March 6, a mother in Oregon watched a public television report about British companies that were discouraging children from eating poisonous household products by lacing them with Bitrex, the world's bitterest flavoring agent.

title: Okamoto Makes a Run But King Takes Lead
description: Ayako Okamoto has come close to winning a major American women's golf championship several times in recent years, but has not quite made it. The 38-year-old Japanese golfer led the L.P.G.A. Championship after three of four rounds twice, and did not hold on to win. Each of the last three years she finished in a tie for third.

title: Soviet Prime Minister Faulted Over Ecology
description: Prime Minister Nikolai I. Ryzhkov was criticized today as ''ecologically illiterate'' by a Soviet legislator who said his possible replacement will be debated when the new congress meets next week.

title: Bridge; Playoffs in Memphis determine which U.S. players will head for the World Championship.
description: The final playoff to determine the 1989 United States World Championship team will begin tonight, and it is highly probable that the contestants will be a Californian squad headed by Chip Martel of Davis and a New Jersey-Chicago squad led by David Berkowitz, Old Tappan, N.J.

title: Orbit Instrument reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Latest quarter results included $2,466,000 writeoff of goodwill of the company's voice response subsidiary, Computer Integration Associates Inc.

title: A Paris Wedding For Ann Patton
description: Ann Rosamond Patton and Curtis Gray Viebranz were married yesterday at the American Cathedral in Paris. The Rev. James R. Leo, the dean of the cathedral, performed the Episcopal ceremony.

title: Lassonde Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Pan Atlantic Re reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Environmental Power reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
2 Dozen People See Man Slain in Subway
description: A 44-year-old Manhattan man was chased into a Harlem subway station and stabbed to death last evening by three youths in front of more than two dozen witnesses, the police said.

title: ew Boeing Jets Arrive in Europe
description: The first of the new Boeing 747-400 jumbo passenger jets destined for the European market landed today at Amsterdam's Schiphol airport after a ferry flight from Seattle. The plane is one of 13 purchased by the Dutch flag carrier KLM.

title: Review/Dance; How a Work Can Age, Both in Time and in Spirit
description: American Ballet Theater's latest novelty for New York is not exactly a ballet or a modern-dance work. ''The Garden of Villandry'' is a minor piece of movement theater by Martha Clarke and two colleagues about a woman who has a relationship with two men - a situation she embodies by constantly sandwiching herself between them.

title: Votrax Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The latest first quarter loss included several one-time charges to income totaling $2,568,000.

title: Steinberg Ally Loses License To Be a Doctor
description: The New York State Board of Regents yesterday revoked the medical license of Dr. Peter J. Sarosi, the Manhattan physician who pleaded guilty last year to helping Joel B. Steinberg and Hedda Nussbaum illegally adopt a baby boy.

title: Omega Hydrocarbons Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: John Hancock Investors Trust reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Assets represented net assets.

title: ROBERT WEBBER, ACTOR, DIES AT 64
description: Robert Webber, a prolific character actor whose sleek appearance and clenched-jaw look made him believable as the elegant businessman of sleazy character he played in hundreds of films and television dramas, died of Lou Gehrig's disease yesterday at his home in Malibu, Calif. He was 64 years old.

title: B&H Ocean Carriers Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company began operations on Aug. 17.

title: Taxi Agency a Disgrace That Preys on Cabbies
description: To the Editor:

title: Hungary Leadership Conflict Breaks Into the Open
description: A smoldering Communist Party conflict over leadership broke into the open today when the party newspaper published an attack on the party leader by Communists advocating change and a reply by one of the leader's aides.

title: Article 720789 -- No Title
description: The Omnicom Group, the advertising company that owns BBDO Worldwide and DDB Needham Worldwide, today announced its willingness to pay $202 million for the Boase Massimi Pollitt Partnership, the parent of the Ammirati & Puris agency in New York.

title: Effort to Save Spotted Owl Suffers Setback in U.S. Court in Oregon
description: Environmentalists lost one battle in a continuing war over the spotted owl Thursday when a Federal district judge in Oregon dismissed a legal challenge to Government plans to allow logging in the ancient forests where the rare bird lives.

title: Limits on Mace: The Debate Flares Anew
description: The rape and attempted murder of a jogger in Central Park last month focused new attention on the use of Mace or a similar tear gas to disable an attacker temporarily. And once again there is controversy over whether the chemical should be made a legal weapon for self-defense.

title: Review/Rock; New Pylon Exhibits Its Old Drive
description: Rock rhythm sections stepped forward at the turn of the 1980's in bands like the B-52's, Public Image Ltd., Gang of Four, Talking Heads, Bush Tetras and the Contortions. Pylon, a band from Athens, Ga., was working its way up on the alternative-rock circuit when it broke up in 1983; the band reunited last year, and when it performed Monday at a jammed Pyramid Club, its blunt, implacable drive was intact.

title: A Confessed Killer To Plead Insanity
description: The lawyer for Steven Smith said yesterday that his client would plead insanity in the rape and murder of a Bellevue Hospital Center physician he confessed to killing.

title: Who's Going to Clean Up Wall Street?
description: LEAD: The eminently respectable chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, Richard Whitney, went to Sing-Sing on April 11, 1938, for stock market abuses originating during the Roaring 20's and extending beyond the 1929 crash. By the time Mr. Whitney was locked up, public outrage had fostered a whole raft of new laws tightening the regulatory noose around Wall

title: Review/Art; Juxtaposing the New From All Over
description: ''Magicians of the Earth,'' which opened Thursday at the Pompidou Center and La Villette, brings together contemporary art from all over the world, juxtaposing artists from New Guinea and Italy, Australia and England, Tibet and the United States. Every culture and countless artistic approaches have been appropriated in a spectacular post-Modern bazaar in which everything seems equally valid and available.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Anheuser-Busch Cos. Inc., St. Louis, said its Busch Agricultural Resources Inc. subsidiary would build a malt processing plant in Idaho Falls, Idaho, for about $50 million.

title: ABC Producer Leaves Planned News Program
description: Phyllis McGrady resigned yesterday as executive producer of a new ABC News program that will feature Sam Donaldson and Diane Sawyer as co-anchors. Richard Kaplan, the executive producer of ''Nightline,'' another ABC News program, will replace Ms. McGrady, Roone Arledge, the president of the network's news division, said yesterday.

title: Grain and Soybean Prices Are Mixed in Light Trading
description: Grain and soybean futures prices were mixed today in light trading on the Chicago Board of Trade as investors retreated from the market to see if growing conditions improve.

title: Is Broadway Afraid of Rocking the House?; Who Said It?
description: To the Editor:

title: Booking Soviet Musicians Is Not Yet a Bowl of Borscht
description: With all due respect to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, doing business with the Soviets, whether the product be ballet or ball bearings, can evoke Dostoyevsky and the Marx Brothers in equal measure. Just ask the American impresarios who regularly import Soviet dancers and musicians. Their horror stories of the tangled bureaucracy at Goskontsert (the Soviet state entertainment agency), their woeful tales of lost Telexes, late visas, ignored artists, wild goose chases and last-minute cancellations, their exasperated accounts of endless squabbling over hard currency and airline ticket are almost enough to make one wonder why anyone would bother to bring over any Soviet ballerinas and pianists at all.

title: Miss Fields Is Married
description: Luanne Fields, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William A. Fields of Birmingham, Ala., was married there yesterday to Foxhall Keene Miller, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew J. Miller of Round Hill, Va. The Rev. Dr. Victor L. Baer, a Presbyterian minister, and the Rev. Dr. Huey M. Hudson, a Methodist minister, performed the ceremony at the Bluff Park United Methodist Church.

title: GLOBE-TROTTING TAKEOVER ARTIST: Jeffrey J. Steiner; Transforming Nuts and Bolts Into Big-Time Deals
description: He grew up in Istanbul during World War II, after his family fled Hitler's advance into Vienna. At one point, he was an executive at Texas Instruments Inc., at another, an owner of a Paris-based engineering firm doing business in the Middle East. He helped fund Carl Icahn's first forays and is a buddy of the corporate raider Nelson Peltz.

title: Marine Patrols to Seek Bad Boaters
description: BEGINNING Friday, with the start of the Memorial Day weekend and the traditional opening of the summer season, marine patrol officers will be on the lookout for drunken, speeding and reckless boaters.

title: Yorktown School Fields Winning Creative Team
description: THEY have rewritten and performed a new ending for Moby Dick; designed, built and powered a car that fits into a suitcase; and thought of all the meanings of a glass of water. But until this year, no team from a Westchester school has ever won the statewide level of the Odyssey of the Mind competition, a national creative problem-solving contest now in its 11th year.

title: Violence Flares at Berkeley Park During Event Marking 60's Battle
description: May 20 - A rampage that began Friday night raged into this morning during a commemoration of the 20th anniversary of the violence that followed the takeover of People's Park by the University of California.

description: DODGE DYNASTY The Car and the Family That Rocked Detroit. By Caroline Latham and David Agresta. Illustrated. 360 pp. San Diego: Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. $19.95.

title: Medical Advances Brighten Jogger's Prognosis
description: A month after suffering severe head injuries from a vicious attack while jogging in Central Park, a 28-year-old woman faces a long rehabilitation struggle to regain her physical and mental functions.

title: Historian Puts the Past on Videotape
description: LEAD: SEVERAL coastal communities are celebrating their 350th anniversaries this year with a variety of special events, but Guilford is the recipient of an unusual birthday gift: a videotaped history of its first three and a half centuries, donated to the town's library and schools.

title: A Truth-in-Politics Bill Gains, But Then How Could It Not?
description: A proposal to try to stop politicians from lying during campaigns has been gaining ground, even though many lawmakers think the idea is stupid. The problem, they say, is that if they oppose the bill they could appear to be anti-truth.

title: POSTINGS: Firehouse Sale; City Auction
description: In the view of some discriminating New Yorkers, owning and living in an old firehouse is the statement about your knowledge of the city and its housing nuances. Firehouses are comfortable, roomy, often historic and relatively rare, which makes them highly desirable.

description: LEAD: Shortages of qualified mathematics and science teachers have bedeviled the U.S. for the past 30 years. Although various initiatives to encourage potential teachers have been launched in recent years, they suffer from a short-term perspective.

description: Let me ask you a question,'' said Arthur B. Hancock 3d, emphasizing the ''me'' and the ''you.''

description: The State Department recommended today that Americans planning to visit China delay their trips for the next 72 hours because of the political unrest there.

King Bhumibol Adulyadej, Rama

description: Nina Bang-Jensen and Jeffrey W. Kampelman were married in Washington yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Max M. Kampelman, by Judge Henry H. Kennedy Jr. of the Superior Court of the District of Columbia.

title: Facing the People, the Soldiers Fall Back
description: When a small convoy of military trucks used to launch tear gas and to spray water on rioters rolled through eastern Beijing early this morning, the soldiers met their first unexpected challenge. An old woman street cleaner rushed up and lay down on the road in front of the trucks.

description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that the Bush Administration was increasingly concerned about China's political crisis.

Koch made gloomy predictions about New York City's fiscal prospects and appeared to be readying himself to run for re-election as ''the Mayor who could say no.'' Last week, as he proposed a $26.6 billion budget for the coming fiscal year, he seemed to have switched his line to, ''Yes, but. . .''

description: In the April 30 article ''Efforts Are Under Way to Expand Hospihe Care,'' reference was made to'the hospice at Roosevelt Hospital. While we appreciate mention of our hospice, we hope you will correct an error. Roosevelt Hospital is not ''planning a renovation.'' The hospital is constructing the first freestanding hospice in New Jersey.

title: How George Washington Made His Return
description: ON April 21, 1789, the nation's first President-elect, George Washington, crossed the Delaware River by ferry and rode in triumph into New Jersey. In 1989, the third of four years celebrating the Bicentennial of the United States Constitution, New Jerseyans have had the privilege of beholding and joining George Washington in his inaugural journey.

title: WELCOME TO THE BARGAIN BASEMENT
description: THE NEW COMPETITORS How Foreign Investors Are Changing the U.S. Economy. By Norman J. Glickman and Douglas P. Woodward. Illustrated. 374 pp. New York: Basic Books. $19.95.

title: Fleeing Jackson Hole's Bustle of Jackson Hole
description: JACKSON HOLE looks too good to be true. The great, glaciered peaks of the Tetons, arguably the continent's most classically beautiful mountains, soar more than a mile into the air from the valley floor. A half-dozen pristine alpine lakes puddle at the base of the range, and the braided channels of the Snake River meander through the valley's lush meadows, sagebrush flats and groves of willow, cottonwood and aspen. Best of all, most of the area's splendors are encircled by the protective boundaries of Grand Teton National Park.

title: Commander Says Coast Guard Couldn't Have Stopped Spill
description: The Coast Guard's controllers of ship traffic could not have prevented the tanker Exxon Valdez from running aground in Prince William Sound, the commanding officer of the station said today at hearings into the Alaska oil spill.

description: A picture caption with the ''Nine Forecasts'' article in the Commercial Property section last Sunday referred incorrectly to a Trammell Crow Company building in Dallas. The building, called Trammell Crow

title: Kimberly Cavender Wed
description: Kimberly Dawn Cavender, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles E. Cavender of Colchester, Conn., was married yesterday to Theron McKean vanDusen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Phillips Buick vanDusen of Princeton, N.J., at the Unitarian Church of Charleston, S.C. The Rev. J. David Scheyer officiated. Miss Cavender is an executive account manager for the real-estate firm of Howard Perry & Walston in Raleigh, N.C. Mr. vanDusen is a first-year student at the Duke University School of Law.

title:
GARDENING;
Alternatives to a Well-Manicured Lawn
description: LEAD: MANY gardeners are having second thoughts about lawns. They are the most extravagant users of time, energy and water in the landscape.

title: Streets Are the Set for a Drama of Local Politics
description: For some directors, making a movie in the streets of New York City can be a quick route to an ulcer. Not so for the Naples-born Francesco Rosi, who seems to revel in the unpredictability of it all.

title: A Camcorder Wins a Battle, But Can It Win the War?
description: Now in its fifth year, the rivalry between camcorder formats seems endless, pointless and confusing. But videophiles are willy-nilly forced to take sides. They must choose one of the two contesting formats - VHS or 8-millimeter - when buying a camcorder, and naturally they'd like to pick the winner. What are the odds? The balance in this conflict keeps shifting, and, in the latest skirmish, the 8-millimeter format has taken the technological lead with the new Hi8 method.

title: Reviews/Music; Joan Osborne Sings Blues
description: The blues-bar circuit doesn't exactly encourage subtlety or originality. For up-and-coming performers who are attached to blues and old-fashioned soul music, however, it's the only circuit there is, and every so often there's a glimpse of real bluesy depth. Joan Osborne, who sang Thursday night at Mondo Cane, doesn't pretend to be anything other than white and northern. But like Bonnie Raitt, one of her obvious models, she sings with forthrightness and finesse, illuminating every phrase with the flickering feelings - sultry, lonely, defiant, wounded, tender, jocular, sly - that the blues can capture.

title: Dialogue Of the Deaf?
