title: Arming Cambodian Non-Communists Will Check Khmer Rouge
description: To the Editor:

title: For House Sellers, a Long Wait
description: WHEN Dwight Harvey retired last year from International Business Machines in Rye Brook, he and his wife, Carol, immediately made plans to build a home in the suburbs of San Francisco. Mr. Harvey dreamed of taking language courses and of buying a small sailboat, while Mrs. Harvey - a professionally trained singer - looked forward to becoming acquainted with musicians in their new community.

title:
The View From: Park Hill;
Touring a Neighborly Enclave Of Fine Architecture
description: LEAD: ANYONE who thinks of the suburbs as a mundane collection of split-level houses might visit Park Hill in the southwestern corner of this city. This eight-square-mile enclave, between the Saw Mill River Parkway and Broadway, sits on a 300-foot promontory overlooking downtown streets, the Hudson River and, beyond that, the

title: WHERE EVERYONE WAS UNDER 30
description: LEAD: WOODSTOCK The Summer of Our Lives. By Jack Curry. Illustrated. 337 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $19.95.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Brunch; In Manhattan, Hearty Ways to Begin the Day
description: This is a listing of Manhattan restaurants that have been reviewed by Bryan Miller in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have ratings. Prices are current. Chelsea Central

title: Michele Brodsky Weds R. G. Federici, a Lawyer
description: Michele Brodsky, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sheldon Brodsky of Annadale, S.I., was married yesterday to Robert G. Federici, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William V. Federici of Brooklyn. Rabbi Alfred Landsberg and the Rev. Joseph Grimaldi, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated at the Manor, a restaurant in East Orange, N.J.

title: Susanna N. Gioia, Interior Designer, Becomes a Bride
description: Susanna Natalia Gioia, a daughter of Emilio Gioia and Iris Gioia of New York and Southampton, L.I., was married yesterday to Anthony Giordano, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Salvatore Giordano Jr. of Bernardsville, N.J. The Rev. Stan Moseley officiated at the Roman Catholic Church of St. Thomas More in New York.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: MY FATHER'S HOUSE: A Memoir of Incest and of Healing, by Sylvia Fraser. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $8.95.) Emerging from partial amnesia, a Canadian novelist realizes that as a child she developed an alternate personality to repress the fact that she had a sexual relationship with her father. Sylvia Fraser has written ''a case history that doubles as literature,'' Jill Johnston said here last year. ''But it's something more as well - a fast-moving detective story in which the author uncovers her own past as victim.'' THE WOMAN WARRIOR: Memoirs of a Girlhood Among Ghosts, by Maxine Hong Kingston. (Vintage International, $6.95.) Before ''Tripmaster Monkey: His Fake Book,'' her recent novel about a Chinese-AmericanJU playwright who tries through his art to make sense of his strange cross-cultural experiences, Maxine Hong Kingston wrote two surrealistic memoirs that seem to blur the line between fact and fiction. In ''The Woman Warrior,'' she writes of her childhood ''with bitter and relentless love,'' Jane Kramer said in The Book Review in 1976. ''Her voice . . . is as fierce as a warrior's voice, and as eloquent as any artist's.'' Vintage International has also reissued CHINA MEN ($7.95), in which she tells the story of Chinese immigrants laboring in the alien land called America. In 1980 Mary Gordon called it ''a triumph of the highest order of imagination, of language, of moral perception.'' ELEPHANT MEMORIES: Thirteen Years in the Life of an Elephant Family, by Cynthia Moss. (Fawcett Columbine, $10.95.) A denizen of Kenya's Amboseli National Park tells what she has learned from her life in a community of elephants. ''However much one may resist at the start, one is soon swept away by this 'Babar' for adults,'' Christopher Lehmann-Haupt said in The Times last year. ''By the end, one even begins to feel an aversion for people. One wants to curse human civilization and cry out, 'Now God stand up for elephants!' '' CAPTIVITY CAPTIVE, by Rodney Hall. (Fireside/Simon & Schuster, $7.95.) Isolated on a farm called Paradise, an Australian family descends into a pathological life of brutality and violence. The novel ''is as grim and harrowing and beautiful as the wilderness it evokes, a raw spiritual landscape that brings to mind Flannery O'Connor and William Faulkner,'' Joyce Reiser Kornblatt said here last year. ''This is a book that makes demands on the reader's soul.'' SPIRIT SEIZURES, by Melissa Pritchard. (Collier/Macmillan, $8.95.) It is appropriate that this collection of stories about the physically and spiritually afflicted won the Flannery O'Connor Award for Short Fiction, Elizabeth Tallent said in The Book Review in 1987. ''Melissa Pritchard treats odd, cruel dilemmas with dispassion, and as if by some fictional law the absence of overt charity toward deprived or crippled characters produces in the reader a sense of their memorably unmediated presence on the page.'' ELLEN TERRY: Player in Her Time, by Nina Auerbach. (Norton, $10.95.) Trapped by her society's notions of what a woman should be like, the British actress Ellen Terry had to play as many roles off stage as on. In 1987 our reviewer, Margot Peters, said Nina Auerbach ''brings her considerable skills of analysis, scholarship and persuasion'' to ''a richly colored, challenging and often illuminating piece of work.'' COME SUNDAY, by Bradford Morrow. (Collier/Macmillan, $10.95.) An expert on longevity is offered the opportunity to meet a 500-year-old Spanish conquistador who walked away from his own beheading. Last year our reviewer, Lawrence Thornton, said that he had mixed feelings about this novel, but that it was written ''with considerable panache and virtuosity.'' SEASON OF GLORY, by Ralph Houk and Robert W. Creamer. (Pocket, $4.50.) Sharing the stage with the veteran baseball writer Robert W. Creamer, the manager who took over the job from Casey Stengel tells about the 1961 Yankee team, which most baseball fans consider one of the Yankees' two best. Last year our reviewer, Diane Cole, said the book ''overflows with vintage baseball lore - the kooky stories, cagey insights and esoteric statistics that no fan can resist.'' In SIXTY-ONE: The Team, the Record, the Men (Fireside/Simon & Schuster, $9.95), Tony Kubek, who was the Yankees' starting shortstop, and Terry Pluto, the coeditor of ''A Baseball Winter,'' tell their version of the story. ''Peppered with anecdotes (like the time Whitey Ford and Mickey Mantle put pine tar in Mr. Ford's deodorant - which Yogi Berra had the annoying habit of borrowing), this is an insider's view: lively, entertaining and, perhaps best of all, nostalgic,'' Charles Salzberg said here in 1987. BLOOD SHOT, by Sara Paretsky. (Dell, $4.50.) On a visit back to her dying old neighborhood in south Chicago, V. I. Warshawski uncovers a chemical company's crime against the environment. Sara Paretsky ''does her best and boldest work to date in creating a criminal investigation that is a genuine heroic quest,'' Marilyn Stasio said here in 1988. LAST LETTERS: Prisons and Prisoners of the French Revolution 1793-1794, by Olivier Blanc. Translated by Alan Sheridan. (Noonday/Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $9.95.) On a search through the French National Archives, the author came across letters home from prisoners condemned to death during the Terror. He ''asks us to look at the victims, and to approach them as individuals, without any intervening theory,'' John Gross said in The Times in 1987. ''The result is both moving and full of interest.''

title: Okamoto Leads the Pack
description: Five of the world's best women golfers - Ayako Okamoto of Japan, Patty Sheehan, Nancy Lopez, Betsy King and Pat Bradley - sit atop the field going into the final round of the 35th annual Mazda L.P.G.A. Championship.

title: Reviews/Dance; Harlem Ground Is Broken For National Black Theater
description: While neighborhood residents, office workers and guests cheered, ground was broken Thursday for a new National Black Theater. The complex at Fifth Avenue and 125th Street will be the first mixed-use cultural facility to be built in Harlem, and will include a 288-seat theater, offices, workshops and retail and commercial space.

title: How to Organize an Annual Event
description: PERHAPS THE OCCASION IS A FAMILY reunion. Or maybe an antiques show, a Fourth of July parade or a summer festival presents an opportunity to gather long-lost friends. But whatever the cause to celebrate, there's sure to be a crowd. And for the host, that's bound to be a challenge.

title: Cut the Weeds, Prepare the Rooms: The Tourists Are Icumen In
description: AS her cat, Mouse, looked on, Olla Adema knelt on the grassy grounds of the Boulders Inn on Lake Waramaug in New Preston, planting patches of purple pansies to welcome the summer visitors who will soon begin to descend on the inn in growing numbers. For Mrs. Adema, these last days before the Memorial Day weekend are busy ones.

title: Congress Shows Signs of Spending To Fight Infant Deaths
description: WITH progress in reducing the infant mortality rate in the United States seemingly stalled, Congress is considering a host of new measures intended to address what has become a notorious symbol of national failure.

title: From Japan: Buying Your Own Regatta
description: A Japanese entrepreneur has offered to pay the travel expenses for an international fleet of 50-foot sailboats and their crews to race in his home waters.

title: BRIGHT BUGS, BIG CITY
description: ALBERT & VICTORIA By Deborah Gangloff. Illustrated by Bill Woodman. 72 pp. New York: Crown Publishers.

title: PRETTY IN PUNK
description: FAMILY POSE By Dean Hughes. 184 pp. New York: Atheneum. $13.95. (Ages 8 to 12) WEETZIE BAT By Francesca Lia Block. 88 pp. New York: A Charlotte Zolotow Book/ Harper & Row. $12.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title: Karen Fisher, a Producer, Marries Thomas Misisco
description: At the Metropolitan Club in New York, Karen Fisher, the daughter of Arnold Fisher and Mrs. Jack G. Schwartz, both of New York, was married last evening to Thomas Mahon Misisco, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Emil J. Misisco of New York. Rabbi Burt Aaron Siegel and the Rev. Joseph Dispenza, a Roman Catholic priest, officiated. Mrs. Misisco, a graduate of the Lenox School and Emerson College, is a freelance television producer. Her father is a senior partner in the New York real-estate firm of Fisher Brothers. Her stepfather is the president of Gaines Service Leasing and Dillinger/Gaines Coachbuilders, limousine services in New York.

title: Summer Activities for Children
description: LEAD: MUSIC or ecology, dance or tennis - it seems there is a summer program in the county for every age child and every interest.

title: Honors Sought for a Women's Rights Leader
description: A FADED 150-year-old farmhouse, set so far back from Hooten Road here that it is hidden from passing cars, may be on the verge of a new life.

title: WHO KIILLED THE TOWN LOLITA?
description: ''F'' IS FOR FUGITIVE By Sue Grafton. 261 pp. New York: Henry Holt & Company.

title: Fulsome Is As Fulsome Does
description: In response to Ms. Berman's letter (''Praise that isn't fulsome,'' April 23), I do appreciate it.

title: Paul Gambal Wed To Anne Murray
description: Anne Elizabeth Murray, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Y. Murray of Elmira, N.Y., was married there yesterday to Paul Sergius Gambal, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Sergius Gambal of Alexandria, Va. The Rev. Richard F. Kuenkler performed the ceremony at Grace Episcopal Church.

title: New-Wave Preserves
description: SUMMER IS THE SEASON OF EXCESS, delivering its many fresh fruits and vegetables with surfeits first of one variety, then another. To take advantage of this bounty, and to preserve its fragrance and flavor, I use my microwave oven to make jams and jellies, relishes and pickles. Having a selection of colorful and tasty preserves on hand, ready to serve, is always convenient, especially when guests drop by.

title: DRAWING ON THE DARK SIDE
description: One can only presume, after reading Joe Queenan's report on skyrocketing sales of DC and Marvel comics, in his article ''Drawing on the Dark Side'' (April 30), that the comic-book publishers have become a little complacent recently. How else to explain the omission from their title list of a comic-book adventure series based on the real-life exploits of our very own hardball playing, all-American superhero, Harvey Lee Atwater, national Republican Party chairman? Surely, he's the kinda guy who would know how to ''satisfy the appetite of their audience.'' Judging from the stories his friends like to tell about him (in Eric Alterman's article ''Playing Hardball,'' April 30), Lee would be a big hit with teen-age males, even without the archfiend Willie Horton or the scantily but patriotically clad P.A.C. (Pledge of Allegiance Christian) Girls Choral Society in every issue.

title: Afghanistan Is Appointing a Panel for Peace Talks
description: Under intensifying military pressure, the Soviet-backed Government of President Najibullah announced today that it would appoint a three-member commission to negotiate without conditions to end Afghanistan's 10-year war.

title: Site Specificity Won't Wash
description: To the Editor:

title: Crime Knows No Boundaries
description: WE all dream of providing safe and secure lives for ourselves and our children. We stretch our budgets to the limit to live in the best town with the assurance that we will feel isolated from all the crime and injustices the rest of the world is exposed to each and every day.

title: A Daughter's Choice
description: IT is easy for people to tell my mother to sell her apartment and move to Florida. It is hard for me.

title: PASTIMES: Camera
description: The raft of recently introduced color films, including Polaroid's one-size-fits-all OneFilm, brings into high relief a question that nags many beginning photographers: How fast a film speed to use?

title: WHERE GET-UPS AND GADGETS OUTSELL THE BIKES
description: The days of the greasy, hole-in-the-wall bike storefront are numbered. Independent bicycle shops are moving toward a tonier image, offering not just bikes but fashionable accessories and gadgets.

title: Elizabeth Bartle And a Consultant Marry in Boston
description: Elizabeth Dowling Bartle and David Mark Boghossian were married yesterday at the Emmanuel Episcopal Church in Boston. The Rev. Theodore H. Evans performed the ceremony. Marion Stuart Bartle was the maid of honor for her twin sister. Paul Boghossian 3d was best man for his brother.

title: Danger: Keep Off the Grass
description: MY neighbor has tiny green flags posted in a casual array on his perfectly manicured front lawn. They stand, inconsequential and unimportant, close to the sidewalk as if a child had set out to play a harmless game whose purpose could only amaze and elude adults.

title: MITTERRAND BACKS U.S. IDEA FOR NATO
description: The Bush Administration received support from President Francois Mitterrand of France today in its effort to resolve the dispute in the Western alliance over short-range nuclear missiles.

title: Ellerbee - Bad to the Last Drop
description: LEAD: Say it ain't so, Linda Ellerbee. A pox on your Maxwell House. The woman who built (and undermined) a network news career through uncompromising intellectual honesty and wry detachment from the absurd machinations of the broadcast news industry has sold her soul to General Foods Corporation.

title: IT'S ALL RIGHT TO BE INNOCENT AGAIN
description: AFTER a long period of decline, innocence is reclaiming its lost ground in American children's literature. Bookshelves in stores and libraries are stocked with brand-new old-fashioned mysteries, children's adventure stories and cheerful fiction series like ''The Fabulous Five'' and ''The Kids of the Polk Street School.'' Thanks in part to the current gee-whiz conservative climate, in part to the new baby boom, we're seeing a renewed craving for community, a yearning for the sunny side of childhood.

title: Greenburgh Moves On Rezoning Issues
description: LEAD: AS part of its continuing effort to limit commercial development and provide more housing, Greenburgh will hold a public hearing Wednesday on a plan to rezone part of the Landmark at Eastview property, the former Union Carbide Technical Center.

title: Primitive Dreams Are Hitting The Big Time
description: ''The natives are extremely fond of painting,'' wrote Thomas Watling, an Australian convict, almost 200 years ago. The aborigines, who have inhabited the Australian continent for an estimated 50,000 years, have been painting on sand, bark and their own bodies for the last 30,000. Suddenly their fondness for painting, now in acrylics on canvas, is landing them squarely in the lap of the international art world, for which they are adapting their grand creation myths, maps of the land and ceremonial symbols to the West's easel- painting tradition. Once, the rectangular format of Western painting was totally foreign to the aborigines. Today they are earning small fortunes by converting their traditional imagery into a commodity.

title: These Comics Are Never Seen On the Home Screen
description: It is Friday night - show night - at Fox Studio's Stage 17. For much of the evening, although nobody concerned will ever admit it, the star of the show is a woman named Claire Berger.

title: POSTINGS: Cutting Red Tape; Landmarks
description: Among the problems facing those who wish to alter their landmarked buildings, or even their individual apartments, in structures in historic districts is the repair or replacement of windows. Such changes must be approved by the Landmarks Preservation Commission.

title: DRAWING ON THE DARK SIDE
description: In recent weeks, the public has been bombarded with news reports about the rape of a woman jogging in Central Park. People are shocked by the extreme violence of the incident.

title: In the Defiance, Shades of Chairman Mao
description: ALTHOUGH their banners call for such profoundly un-Maoist goals as a free press and elections, the students' challenge to the Communist Party leadership in Beijing owes a debt to Mao Zedong's Cultural Revolution. In the late 1960's, it was Mao who unleashed bands of youthful Red Guards to oust many of his rivals. He clearly preferred some chaos to what he saw as the increasingly stultifying party bureaucracy.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Philadelphia;
96 Condos In a Pier Shed
description: LEAD: NINETY-SIX condominiums, the first for-sale residential units on the Delaware River here, are going up within a cargo pier's steel framework.

title: Mexican Teachers Win Raises and End Strike
description: After five months of wildcat strikes, mass marches, sit-ins and embassy takeovers, the one million members of the Mexican teachers' union have returned to their classrooms with a 25 percent salary increase.

title: PASTIMES: Stamps
description: Looking back over a year's worth of mail from readers, two problems seem so common that they deserve some solutions in print.

title: Laura D. Roosevelt Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Erasmus Helm Kloman of Washington have announced the engagement of Mrs. Kloman's daughter Laura Delano Roosevelt to Dr. Charles Henry Silberstein, a son of Mrs. Herbert F. Storfer of New York and the late Dr. Richard M. Silberstein. A January wedding is planned.

title: ARGENTINA REELING IN POLITICS VACUUM
description: ''No Man's Land'' read a newspaper headline today describing the political vacuum here as this ailing nation embarks on a seven-month vigil before President-elect Carlos Saul Menem takes office.

title:
DINING OUT;
Hearty Seafood on Inlet in Port Chester
description: LEAD: THE county can use a restaurant serving the earthy, vibrantly flavored dishes of Portugal, and it seemed, 10 years ago, that Pearl of the Atlantic was destined to fill that bill. At that time the menu offered winy chunks of pork garnished with clams after the style Alentejana; steak with a fried egg, a basic Portuguese ingredient; and bacalhau, or cod - so popular that the Portuguese are said to have 201 ways of preparing this fish - combined with boiled potatoes, onions and egg in a savory style called

title: DRAWING ON THE DARK SIDE
description: I have recently become a comic-book addict, although I hardly fit the description of the typical comic-book reader. I am a 45-year-old mother of two sons, 11 and 15 years old, and I have a Ph.D. in biochemistry. I think Joe Queenan has made a mountain out of a molehill about the dark side of comic books. He deplores the ''new'' violence in such old favorites as Superman and Batman, and contrasts them with ''wholesome'' comics, such as the Archie series. The Archie comics are just as rampantly anti-intellectual and sexist now as they were 30 years ago. Archie and his friends attend a high school in which learning has the lowest priority. Betty and Veronica, the two female protagonists, are mindless dolts without ambition.

title: On the Road With 'Legends!' And Its Legends
description: I don't remember when the idea struck me to write a play about two feuding actresses, legends in their time, who were somewhat over the hill, had made one film together that was a box-office hit but represented personal hell during the making. What if one of them, Sylvia, always played the Joan Crawford parts, the one who started out scrubbing dishes in a diner and was going to make it to Chicago if she had to step over her mother, 12 orphans, several politicians and 23 lovers. And suppose the other was named Leatrice, a sweet, dear thing for all outward appearances, fresh, scrubbed, usually played nurses, saints and nuns. But underneath she had a streak of steel, the kind of actress for which the term Iron Butterfly was coined.

title: New York Loses 10% of Its Farms in 5 Years
description: A sharp decline in the number of farms in New York State was reported this week by the United States Census Bureau.

title: In the Mutable World of Chic, Designers' Initials Are Out, Simplicity Is In
description: Bambi Lyman celebrated her 35th birthday the other evening in a pink and red Emilio Pucci blouse from the early 1960's and incredibly uncoordinated Lilly Pulitzer pants from the early 70's. Mrs. Lyman's husband, Lincoln, also sported Pulitzer trousers in an outspoken print. So did many of their 40 or so guests, although there was stiff competition from a cluster of madras plaids. The Lyman's guests had, in fact, been requested to wear such sartorial status symbols of yesteryear.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
A Master Plan for Central Islip Hospital
description: LEAD: FOR residents of Central Islip, the late 1960's was a time of crisis. As the Central Islip State Hospital, the area's major employer, began discharging its psychiatric patients under a state mandate, many of the community's 40,000 residents were thrown out of work.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: East Burke, Vt.;
Historic Farm Getting Condos
description: LEAD: A 19TH-CENTURY gentleman's farm in northeastern Vermont will be converted into 44 condominiums under a plan tentatively approved by the state's environmental commission.

title: Maria Louise Mack to Wed
description: Maria Louise Mack, an associate editor at Bantam Doubleday Dell Publishing Group, and Peter Bragg D'Amario, an associate at Goldman, Sachs & Company, both in New York, plan to be married next month, the parents of the prospective bride, Mr. and Mrs. James P. Mack of Birmingham, Mich., have announced. Miss Mack graduated from Denison University. Mr. D'Amario, a graduate of Brown University, received an M.B.A. from the University of Pennsylvania.

title: PASTIMES: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Set out annual flowers, container-grown perennials and shrubs; be sure to work the planting holes well and incorporate organic material to aid the soil's water retention and improve its tilth. Finish pruning forsythia, kerria and other spring-flowering shrubs by cutting out one third of the older canes to ground level. Stake peonies. Cut lilacs in the morning. Allow daffodil foliage to yellow naturally and do not cut it back; flower buds for next year are forming in the bulbs now. The Smotherers

title: Charles Shoots 65 To Lead By Four
description: When he's playing golf on the rolling hills of the Sleepy Hollow Country Club, Bob Charles is a man at peace with his game.

title: Defeated and Now Disfavored, Dukakis Fights Rejection at Home
description: Since losing the 1988 Presidential election, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis of Massachusetts has fallen just about as far and as fast as a politician can, short of impeachment.

title: Guard Members Begin Anti-Drug Duties on Border
description: Swarming over trucks at the Mexican border, drilling tiny holes in the ribs of cargo containers at ports and airports, members of the National Guard have begun carrying out a $300 million program that expands the role of the military in anti-drug efforts.

title: Not Guilt, but Liability Is Issue in Park Attack
description: To the Editor:

title: And the Babies Had Fun, Too
description: WHEN I WAS growing up, my mother tells me, every neighborhood had a play group. For three hours or so, in the morning or the afternoon, they met at someone's house, and the children ran in circles amusing themselves while the mothers drank iced tea and giggled. ''Oh, we giggled a lot,'' my mother, who is not the giggly sort, tells me. ''You kids were so funny.''

title: Warren G. Magnuson Dies at 84; Held Powerful Positions in Senate
description: Former Senator Warren Magnuson of Washington, one of the country's most formidable lawmakers and politicians until the Reagan tide wrote an end to his 44 years on Capitol Hill, died yesterday. He was 84 years old and lived in Seattle.

title: Survivors Heal Slowly Where 5 Children Died
description: At recess at the Cleveland Elementary School here, children cower near the building so they can run for cover if the shooting starts again. Teachers scan the adjoining streets wondering which stranger is an intruder, and parents gather outside the chain-link fence, worried and watchful.

title: BEYOND THE QUARK
description: It would be foolish and wasteful to spend $4.4 billion on the Superconducting Supercollider when newer and superior technology -plasma particle accelerators, as reported in the March issue of Scientific American - is being proposed. The whole question of the S.S.C. deserves another look. We should pursue the development of a machine that could prove to be much cheaper and produce more power (faster particles).

title:
New Jersey Q & A: Rabbi Tovia Singer;
Helping Jews Return to Judaism
description: LEAD: TOVIA SINGER is the New Jersey director of Jews for Judaism, a nationwide organization dedicated to countering the efforts of Christian groups at converting Jews. According to a July 1988 article in The International Bulletin of Missionary Research, the number of Jews joining Christian groups has grown to 140,000 from 1,000 in the 18 years from 1970 to 1988.

title: Jib Ellis Marries Jean W. McCabe
description: At St. Andrew's Episcopal Church in Edgartown, Mass., Jean Woodford McCabe, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. James E. McCabe of Palm City, Fla., and Vineyard Haven, Mass., was married yesterday to John Arden Ellis, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. George M. Ellis of Lancaster, Pa. The Rev. William W. Eddy performed the ceremony.

title: Noise Drives Recording Musicians Into Quiet Westchester
description: THE music playing on your stereo may have been recorded at a theater near you. Record companies, in their quest for silent surroundings, regularly transport their artists and equipment to the county. Two frequently used sites are the Sommer Center at Concordia College in Bronxville and the Performing Arts Center at the State University at Purchase.

title: ETHIOPIA'S LEADER REGAINING CONTROL
description: As residents of the Ethiopian capital nervously resumed their daily routines after an unsuccessful coup attempt this week, it appeared that the President, Lieut. Col. Mengistu Haile Mariam, had regained his grip on authority.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-25

title:
IDEAS & TRENDS;
Japan Discovers the American Range
description: LEAD: IN southwestern Montana's Centennial Valley, Japanese investors now own one of Beaverhead County's largest spreads, the 80,000-acre Selkirk Ranch. Zenchiku Land and Livestock, a Tokyo meat importing firm, purchased the ranch for $13 million last fall to produce beef for the Japanese market, where consumption of red meat is expected to grow phenomenally when tariffs on beef imports expire in 1991.

title: SHAKING UP JUSTICE
description: NOT LONG AFTER DICK THORNBURGH assumed control of the Department of Justice from his embattled predecessor, Edwin L. Meese 3d, he summoned the agency's employees to hear what he expected of them. The language was blunt: ''no surprises,'' no ''counterproductive confusion,'' no ''giving aid and comfort to our adversaries and ill-wishers.'' Top leadership, he added, ''must give forth clear and explicit signals'' of what is proper. ''To do otherwise allows informal and potentially subversive codes of conduct to be transmitted with a wink and a nod.''

title: Review/Dance; 'A Midsummer Night'
description: There is a magical forest in George Balanchine's production of ''A Midsummer Night's Dream.'' The choreographer tells Shakespeare's story of lovers' quarrels and rapprochements with imagination and humor. As in his ''Nutcracker,'' Balanchine takes care of the story in the first act, preparing the way for sheer dance in the second. And a performance of the work by the New York City Ballet on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater gave full value to each of those elements.

title: A Buffet Dish For Serving Cold
description: WITH Memorial Day weekend coming up, thoughts turn to summer entertaining. Buffet dishes that do not have to be served hot are among the best choices.

title: Moonwalk on the Champs-Elysees
description: THE BICENTENNIAL CELEBRATION of the French Revolution probably does call for some flamboyance. Alors, among the acts that will parade the length of the Champs-Elysees on the night of July 14 is the marching band of Florida A.& M. University doing the Michael Jackson ''moonwalk''; and two Russian ice skaters, one dressed up as a bear, the other as a ballerina, performing on a mobile rink.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: GLORIA C. MARKUSON;
A Lawyer a Bit Ahead of Her Times
description: LEAD: WHEN Gloria C. Markuson was a young girl, she really wanted to hold a seat on the stock exchange like her father. But because it was something women by custom did not do, she turned to law - a profession only slightly less restrictive in its attitudes toward women.

title: Thousands of Chinese Rally in the U.S.
description: Chinese nationals and emigres in major cities across the United States rallied to the support of China's widening democracy movement yesterday with protests against the Beijing Government and calls for the resignation of Prime Minister Li Peng.

title: WHAT, ME ANGRY?
description: Maggie Scarf's article made me anxious and a little angry. Outspoken feminists often are portrayed unjustly as angry women. Yet, if our predecessors had not spoken up out of anger and indignation, women in America would not today have the rights these women argued for. PAMELA J. SPAAN Ithaca, N.Y.

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: Most players, no matter how practical, flexible or free from dogma, like to see their strategies stand up for a while - if not forever. But these days that seems quite impossible.

title: Jessica Feder and Adam Birnbaum Are Married
description: The Alder Manor in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., was the setting last evening for the wedding of Jessica Feder and Adam Birnbaum. Rabbi Emily Faust Korzenick officiated.

title: Change Is Advocated In Refuse Payments
description: Westchester recycling programs won't get very far until the county's system of paying for garbage disposal is overhauled. The problem is that, under the present set-up, the major costs of recycling are paid by local government but the savings go to the county government.

title: U.S. Businesses Loosen Link to Mother Country
description: With a new surge of investment abroad, many American companies are shedding the banner of a national identity and proclaiming themselves to be global enterprises whose fortunes are no longer so dependent on the economy of the United States.

title: Ellen Casey Is Married
description: Ellen Joan Casey and Francis William Connolly, who expect to receive law degrees next week from Georgetown University, were married yesterday at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in the Georgetown section of Washington. The Rev. John T. O'Hara performed the ceremony. Mrs. Connolly, who received her undergraduate degree from Georgetown, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Timothy Francis Casey of Northport, L.I. Mr. Connolly, a graduate of the University of Chicago, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Francis William Connolly of Rockville, Md.

title:
FOCUS: New Lebanon, N.H.;
Dartmouth Ventures Into Real Estate
description: LEAD: ALONG a two-lane stretch of Route 120 lined mostly with pine trees and a few steel fabricated buildings is the 137-acre hillside site chosen by Dartmouth College for its first joint real estate venture. On the Lebanon-Hanover border, it is two miles south of the Georgian-style brick buildings that make up the

title: In Memory of A 'Wild Genius'
description: To the Editor:

title: Welfare Changes Endangered, Governors Say
description: The nation's governors, who won Congressional support last year for their overhaul of the welfare system, maintain that the Administration is undermining the new law.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Two years ago, we had a new stoop of reddish fieldstone built on top of our old concrete one. The mason advised us to coat it with a silicone sealer; however, I read that this was not needed and so I did not apply any. Now the stoop is gradually turning green. How can I remove this discoloration, and after that should I apply a sealer?

title: ...AND OF THE VINE
description: FOR YEARS, ITALIAN WINE ENTHUSI-asts kept Friuli pretty much to themselves. But now, this lovely, still unspoiled region is being discovered by the rest of the world. Most of Friuli, or Friuli-Venezia Guilia, as the area is officially known, was originally part of the Venetian Republic, and is one of the oldest of all wine regions in Europe. No one knows exactly when the vine first came to these low hills and valleys, but Aquileia, which is now just a village some 20 miles from Trieste, was once a Roman city and a center for the wine trade 200 years before Christ.

title: A Rare Bird Receives Tips on Flying From a Human
description: LEAD: BIRDS of a feather cannot always flock together, especially if the bird is a rare condor on the endangered species list that is 3,000 miles from home and being taught to soar by a human.

title: English Politeness
description: To the Editor:

title: Fourth of July, Vermont Style
description: FOR SOMEONE WHO OWNS A CLASSIC clapboard house with a sloping lawn overlooking the route of one of Vermont's most popular Fourth of July parades, it would seem positively unneighborly not to ask a few friends over to watch. Early in the 1970's, soon after buying her Warren, Vt., home as a refuge from her life in Manhattan as a sportswear designer, Monika Tilley did just that. Since then, she said, in a voice that bears the stamp of her native Austria, ''the party just grew. I love to use an event as an excuse for a party.''

title: Ogilvy's New Place In WPP's Empire
description: The Ogilvy Group relented, accepting an offer of $864 million from the British WPP advertising group. The price was $54 a share, up from $45, which WPP first offered at the beginning of the month. Just two years ago, Martin Sorrell, head of WPP, bought another top name in American advertising, the J. Walter Thompson operation, in what was then a record $566 million deal. The WPP empire will now be the world's second-largest marketing communications company, with 21,500 employees in more than 50 countries and billings exceeding $13.5 billion. Saatchi & Saatchi, another British firm, is slightly larger. Ogilvy is the parent of Ogilvy & Mather, whose work for blue-chip clients created well-known phrases like ''Maxwell House is good to the last drop'' and ''Merrill Lynch is bullish on America.'' *

title: Cary Pepper: Video Copywriter
description: Assigned a short story in the third grade, Cary Pepper remembers writing a 10-chapter book. A seventh-grade project turned into a 30-page play.

title: Conflicting Values
description: With millions of dollars riding on big-time collegiate athletics, the N.C.A.A. has strict rules prohibiting colleges from paying players more than the value of their athletic scholarships. The rules are intended to avoid bidding wars that could divert some of those profits from collegiate coffers into the pockets of the players who earn them.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
ESCAPE FROM COPENHAGAN
description: LEAD: NUMBER THE STARS By Lois Lowry. 137 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin. LISA'S WAR By Carol Matas. 111 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday about the growing number of Hispanic Americans who practice Protestantism misstated the estimate. It is four million, not 20 million.

title: WEST VIRGINIA REDUCES DROPOUTS BY DENYING THEM DRIVER'S LICENSE
description: The dropout rate in West Virginia high schools has been reduced almost a third by a new attendance law that lifts the driver's licenses of students who choose dropping out over education.

title: All Sides Need 'Opening'
description: Some important but subtle changes are going on behind spectacular developments in international affairs. Whatever happens in China now - repression, upheaval, or piecemeal accommodation - history has taken another spin.

title: Jamie Herzlinger: Sportswear Designer
description: Jamie Herzlinger says she ''was conceived in the fashion business.'' Her grandfather Samuel Herzlinger was a coat manufacturer known as ''the king of the foxes.'' Her mother, Nan, designed sportswear and her father, Jack, produced it.

title: Ms. Sandstrom, A Nurse, Weds
description: The marriage of Lauren Elaine Sandstrom, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Sandstrom of Lake Oswego, Ore., to Robert Harvey Steindorf, a son of Frank Steindorf of West Palm Beach, Fla., and the late Ruth Steindorf, took place last evening at the Williams Club in New York. Cantor Bruce L. Ruben officiated.

title: The Old Met
description: To the Editor:

title: Correction
description: Because of an editing error, an article on May 7 about the closing of Fort Scott, a Roman Catholic summer camp in Ohio, misidentified the caretaker. He is Ed Shannon.

title: What's Big? The Big Bag
description: If life were a Somerset Maugham story, everyone would show up in some exotic South Seas port like Pago Pago clad in rumpled white linen and carrying a grip, a single leather bag with handles, containing every worldly possession, for an indeterminate stay.

title: Tainted Mushrooms Recalled
description: The Food and Drug Administration is recalling institutional-size cans of mushrooms from China because of three outbreaks of food poisoning in February and April, including one at the Peninsula Hospital Center cafeteria in Queens.

title:
WESTCHESTER OPINION;
A 17-Year Journey Comes to an End As the Last Passenger Graduates
description: LEAD: THERE will be no more driving to school. Seventeen years ago it started, with the car pool to nursery school. I would deliver a carload of small round people to the nursery school on the main street, stopping a line of traffic while they staggered in their snowsuits out of the car and into the arms of the patient teachers.

title: The Press Wars: Weeklies Expand
description: THIS WEEK almost became last week for Stan Henry. On the eve of publishing the first edition of This Week, his new free weekly newspaper, Mr. Henry's new $2.7 million state-of-the-art printing presses broke down.

title: Gail Tubridy Wed To Justin O'Neill
description: Gail Marie Tubridy and Justin Thomas O'Neill were married yesterday at the Roman Catholic Church of St. John the Evangelist in New York by Msgr. Michael J. Wrenn, who was assisted by the Rev. Anthony I. McHale. Mrs. O'Neill, the daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Arthur F. Tubridy of New York and Milford, Conn., graduated from Ladycliff College, and received a master's degree in secondary education at Fordham University and an M.B.A. degree at Pace University. A former teacher, she is a securities analyst at the New York Life Insurance Company in New York.

title: Now We Know: Home Is Where the Art Is
description: It's all a matter of perspective, of ratio.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption last Sunday about school desegration in Little Rock, Ark., referred incorrectly to Central High School. Central, where Federal troops were sent 32 years ago to protect nine black pupils, is now 58 percent black and 42 percent white. It is not one of the schools with overwhelmingly black enrollment that would get increased funds for remedial programs as part of a current desegregation proposal. The proposal was also characterized incorrectly. It is a local, not a state, proposal.

title: A LIFE IN LIMBO
description: I became so absorbed when I read Peter Brandon Bayer's story about his experiences with hemophilia and HIV that I consciously had to relax my sweaty, clenched hands and fight back emotion (''A Life In Limbo,'' April 2). For the first time in three and a half years, I did not feel alone.

title: Tiny Town Didn't Let Stardom Go to Its Head
description: It is often by accident that tourists drive into this northern New Mexico town, on their way to fishing spots or other sightseeing destinations.

title: In Friuli, Enjoying the Fruits of the Sea...
description: UP IN FRIULI, THE ITALIAN RE-gion wedged into the northeastern corner of the country between the Alps and the Adriatic, people take great pride in what they like to call their native reserve. Walter Filiputti, the winemaker at the Abbazia di Rosazzo, a winery on the grounds of an 11th-century abbey that is an hour's drive north of Venice, is a typical Friulano. ''We Friulians are very discreet,'' he said, by way of introduction. ''We're very withdrawn and hard to get to know.''

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Two years ago, we had a new stoop of reddish fieldstone built on top of our old concrete one. The mason advised us to coat it with a silicone sealer; however, I read that this was not needed and so I did not apply any. Now the stoop is gradually turning green. How can I remove this discoloration, and after that should I apply a sealer?

title: WHO'S THAT MAN WITH MARILYN HORNE?
description: My husband and I enjoyed reading Barbara Jepson's article on accompanists and are glad to see they are getting the recognition and payment due them (''Who's That Man With Marilyn Horne? April 16). They have indeed come a long way from the time when my father-in-law, Harold Craxton, accompanied singers such as Nellie Melba, Clara Butt, John McCormack and Fyodor Chaliapin in England many years ago.

title: Justice for a Hijacker
description: The 10-month trial in West Germany of Mohammed Ali Hamadei was closely watched by the United States to see whether justice would be done. Last week, the verdict was announced and Washington was satisfied. Mr. Hamadei, a pro-Iranian militant from Lebanon, was convicted by a five-judge court of hijacking a Trans World Airlines jet in 1985 and murdering an American hostage.

title: All Must Share In Health Care
description: In ''The Sickening Cost of Getting Sick'' (Opinion page, April 30), Richard Elsberry expresses dismay that patients like himself ''smart enough to have health insurance or money in the bank'' are forced to support medical care for the ''poor and indigent.'' Until the state finds a ''kinder and gentler way'' (do I read lips in assuming this does not mean raising taxes?), he proposes an interim solution: the less smart should ''seek more affordable care out of state.''

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: KITE CHAMPIONSHIPS

title: Anne Senelly Wed To R. B. Kyle 3d
description: Anne Senelly, the managing editor of Model magazine in New York, and Robert Blodgett Kyle 3d, the production coordinator for Tangram International Exhibitions in Irvington-on-Hudson, N.Y., were married yesterday at the Riverview in Hastings-on-Hudson. Earle W. Zaidins, a lawyer and a former Village Justice of Hastings-on-Hudson, officiated.

title: Corrections
description: A caption with a listing of music festivals on April 30 misidentified the composer of ''Il Ritorno d'Ulisse in Patria.'' It is Monteverdi. The listing also misidentified the violinist Ivo Pogorelich in connection with the Sintra Music Festival. He is from Yugoslavia.

title: Successful Failures
description: To the Editor:

title: The World Catches Takeover Fever
description: The financial revolution of the 1980's has given us a glimpse of a truly borderless global village of finance and business. The results of these tumultuous times have become manifest in four major trends that have affected all businesses in the 1980's and that will continue to affect them in the decade ahead. No country is isolated from these changes and no business is immune. Companies around the world are restructuring to achieve leadership in the borderless village of the 1990's.

title: U.S. Withdraws a Plan to Ease Meat Inspections
description: Responding to intense opposition, the Agriculture Department has withdrawn a proposal that would have reduced Federal inspections at major processing plants turning out hot dogs, chicken soup and other meat and poultry products.

title: BALLET WITHOUT THE DANCING
description: SWAN LAKE Retold by Margot Fonteyn. Illustrated by Trina Schart Hyman. Unpaged. San Diego: Gulliver Books/Harcourt Brace Jovanovich.

title: Great Summer Traditions
description: LEAD: SUMMER! IT IS A TIME FOR THE SENSES. IT ABIDES IN THE taste and smell of a sun-sweetened tomato, the exquisite relief of an ice-beaded glass of something cool to drink, the gleam of a child's bare leg scissoring through the dusk. From the ''Molten Blue'' of Emily Dickinson's summer sky, to the smothered giggles of children who wait for that same sky to darken enough -finally!

title: Q and A
description: Churchill

title: Lottery First Prize Isn't Quite Clear
description: Nine teams hope to get lucky when the National Basketball Association holds its fifth annual draft lottery today at the Equitable Center in New York.

title: Unsolved Crimes That Piqued Public Interest
description: MURDERS evoke great amounts of public passion and curiosity. While the crimes described provoked much interest, long investigations have produced neither motive nor culprits.

title: Ms. Lyman Wed In Massachusetts To a Psychologist
description: Griselda Lyman, a daughter of Mrs. John Lowell Lyman of Needham, Mass., and Sedona, Ariz., and the late Mr. Lyman, was married yesterday to Dr. Duncan Alexander White, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Linden Harris White Jr. of Nantucket, Mass. The Rev. Thomas Niblock performed the Unitarian ceremony at the Dover (Mass.) Church.

title: Lorene Geiger Weds
description: At St. Pius X Roman Catholic Church in Scarsdale, N.Y., Lorene Geiger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Glenn Geiger of Scarsdale, was married yesterday to Daniel Carlton, a son of Col. James Carlton, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Carlton of Ketchikan, Alaska. The Rev. William J. Hill officiated. Mrs. Carlton, a graduate of Middlebury College, is an account executive at Salem Associates, an executive-recruiting firm in New York. Mr. Carlton, a graduate of the University of Washington at Seattle, is a group representative for the Guardian Life Insurance Company in New York.

title: Cards Top Braves, 1-0, in 13 Innings
description: Terry Pendleton's run-scoring single with two out in the 13th inning tonight gave the St. Louis Cardinals a 1-0 victory over the Atlanta Braves.

title: Lost in the Library
description: I CAN'T use the public library anymore. I only know how to read.

title: District 9 Trustees Describe Suspended Board's Abuses
description: Trustees sent in to clean up a troubled Bronx school board six months ago have discovered a system in which educational programs were subordinated to politics, sound budgeting practices were ignored and much time and money were devoted to publicizing local board members.

title: Dr. Mattone Wed To Dr. N. J. Volpe
description: Dr. Francesca R. Mattone, a daughter of Joseph M. Mattone of Douglaston, Queens, and the late Irene M. Mattone, was married yesterday to Dr. Nicholas J. Volpe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nicholas G. Volpe of Howard Beach, Queens, and Putnam Valley, N.Y., at St. Anastasia Roman Catholic Church in Douglaston by Msgr. Michael J. Cantley.

title: Long Island Needs Military Spending
description: Who would have ever thought that some Long Island congressmen would actually be strongly against jobs for Long Island (''U.S. Decision to Curb F-14 Sends a Jolt to Economy,'' April 30). What I hope the people of Long Island are finally realizing is that when a congressman is anti-defense, he is anti-Long Island. How can we expect the Bush Administration to support defense programs on Long Island when Congressmen like Downey and Mrazek vote consistently against authorizing any major defense program?

title: Plan Due For Park in Somers
description: LEAD: THE county is developing a plan to use the 207-acre Lasdon Park in Somers largely as open space and for passive recreation, to satisfy the wishes of residents in northern Westchester.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Accommodating Wheelchairs; Handicapped Access Law Shapes Design
description: THE doors are wide. The kitchens have more floor area. The inside corridors in the two-bedroom apartments are roomier. But there is less kitchen cabinet space, a little less closet space and a unfamilar arrangement of the bathroom equipment.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months.

title: Marcos Loyalists Urge His Return to Manila
description: Hundreds of supporters of former President Ferdinand E. Marcos marched to the presidential palace today to demand that the ousted strongman, who is critically ill in a Hawaiian hospital, be allowed to return to the Philippines.

title: Britain Warns U.S. on Short-Range Missile Talks
description: The British Government has told the Bush Administration that any offer now to negotiate with the Soviet Union on short-range nuclear missiles in Europe would be a mistake and a personal setback to Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, British and American officials said today.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing; The Tranquility of Port Washington
description: There is a place, just 20 miles from Manhattan, where white sails stretch against a blue sky, boat motors purr through the bay and masts bob at their docks as the sun goes down.

title: Kirsten Kimball Wed To James C. Kapteyn
description: Kirsten Morgan Kimball, the daughter of Mrs. Stephen Heartt of Medomak, Me., and Naples, Fla., and Dr. Peter G. Kimball of Marblehead, Mass., was married yesterday in Marblehead to James Cornelius Kapteyn, the son of the late Mr. and Mrs. James A. Kapteyn of Great Barrington, Mass. The Rev. George A. Westerberg performed the ceremony at St. Michael's Episcopal Church.

title: A Day at the Races, French Style
description: EXPECTANCY swelled the chilly spring air at the race track in the Bois de Boulogne. Seated in a warm indoor restaurant at the top of the grandstand at Longchamp, we were looking over a vast field of green, the grass so resolutely lush that not a single dandelion or patch of dirt dared to violate it. Off to the east, the Eiffel Tower soared to a graceful peak over the spring woods while just to the left of the track, a cherry tree in full blossom graced a 12th-century windmill. Only the cars, instead of belle epoque carriages, pouring in to park in the infield, and the closed circuit televisions focused on the paddock below reminded us we were not in an Impressionist painting.

title: BAD NEWS FOR SPIES
description: LEAD: THE RUSSIA HOUSE By John le Carre. 353 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: Money Is The Problem
description: To the Editor:

title: LIFE WITH THE LENIN SISTERS
description: TRESPASSERS WELCOME HERE By Karen Karbo. 190 pp. New York: G.P. Putnam's Sons. $19.95.

title: NATIONAL NOTEBOOK:Rock Hill, S.C.; Capitalizing On Land Values
description: THIS city of 45,000, where 70 percent of the labor force once worked in textiles, has capitalized on one asset - land - to participate in the economic growth of the metropolitan Charlotte, N.C., region.

title: Cherie Hart Wed To John I. Bleho
description: Cherie Hart, a daughter of Virginia S. Hart of Palm Harbor, Fla., and the late Edward Hart, was married yesterday to John Imrich Bleho, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Imrich Bleho of Montreal. The Rev. Richard Leonard, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the Church Center for the United Nations.

title: An Abridged ''Pinafore'' Staged for Young People
description: SOME choice attractions fill the afternoon today, with two chamber programs, a piano recital, a choral concert and even an opera for children.

title: Reviews/Theater; Mark Medoff Tells of Softness in a Macho World
description: One would have to search hard to find a playwright more obsessed with machismo, heroism and psychic emasculation than Mark Medoff. In his first successful play, ''When You Comin' Back, Red Ryder?'' a gun-toting drifter terrorizes the occupants of a roadside diner into confronting ''the truth'' about themselves. The title character, Stephen Ryder, is a 19-year-old milquetoast whose James Dean-like self-image is savagely assailed.

title: Catskill Hotels Put Housing on the Menu
description: FOR Sidney and Esther Gerber, it seemed a perfect combination of personal privacy and public convenience: a house of their own, but with all the services of a Catskills resort hotel only a few steps away, from a supper club to a health club, from tennis courts to country walks.

title: Two Nights of Toasting Works in Progress
description: On Monday, some New Yorkers shuttled between two cocktail parties. At the ''21'' Club, the topic was this October's Rita Hayworth Gala, to support the Alzheimer's Association. Princess Yasmin Aga Khan, daughter of Miss Hayworth, who died of the disease, said, ''The theme is the 100th anniversary of the Eiffel Tower, which will be projected onto the Seagram building with lasers.'' M. Eiffel, meet Philip Johnson.

title: Restoration For the Rookery
description: A NEWLY formed development company is restoring and renovating one of this city's most important commercial landmarks, the 12-story Rookery Building, for office use.

title: Reviews/Theater; Sending Up Musicals, In 'Laughing Matters'
description: At the very end of their two-person revue, ''Laughing Matters'' (in the Theater at St. Peter's Church), Linda Wallem and Peter Tolan perform three brief, delirious musical spoofs of widely divergent Broadway songwriters.

title: Traffic Alert
description: Because of the Ninth Avenue International Food Festival, Ninth Avenue between 37th and 57th Streets will be closed from 8 A.M. to 7 P.M. today. Because of the Amsterdam

title: A WEstport Tribute To Dorothy Parker
description: ''I NEEDED someone with a quicker wit than mine,'' Prince sang in his ''Ballad of Dorothy Parker'' in 1987. That ought to give pause to those who presume that Parker, the Jazz Age writer reknowned for her caustic wit, is unknown to younger generations.

title: Beyond Wine: Napa's Resorts
description: NOT everyone who visits the Napa Valley goes only to sample its most famous wares. The weather that produces the world-renowned wines is as agreeable for people as it is for grapes.

title: 'A Funny Thing': One in a Million
description: REMEMBER an overbearingly cute song called ''Freedom'' from the high-minded musical ''Shenandoah''? And how it purported to tell us all those things the word really meant?

title: Playgrounds That Are Child Designed and Community Built
description: FOR those who have helped design and build one, a Robert S. Leathers playground is more than just a playground: it is the stuff of children's dreams and the fruit of a community's labor.

title: Question Of the Week; Was Mark Jackson Treated Fairly?
description: I attended the game marked by the booing of Mark Jackson. I booed, too. However, my displeasure was directed toward Coach Rick Pitino. He was substituting Jackson for a ''hot'' Rod Strickland. I was booing Pitino's removal of Strickland from the game, not Jackson's entry into the game or his performance. If Pitino is such a great coach, why can't he find more minutes for Strickland, who can use his quickness to create in the halfcourt oriented playoffs? Jackson and Strickland should play together. BILL POWELL Brooklyn

title: Kenneth Williams Weds Jann Wolfe
description: Jann Catherine Wolfe and Kenneth Scott Williams were married yesterday at the Americas Society in New York. Dr. D. Newell Williams, a professor of church history at the Christian Theological Seminary in Indianapolis and the brother of the bridegroom, performed the ceremony.

title: Evangelical Group Urges Conversion of Jews
description: Fifteen evangelical Protestant theologians have issued a statement warning that creating a dialogue with Jews cannot substitute for converting them. The theologians urge Christian churches to put a high priority on proselytism.

title: In Beijing Protests, Changes By Deng Return to Vex Him
description: If as is widely presumed Deng Xiaoping made the key decision to call in the army to crack down on the demonstrators in Beijing - protesters who have demanded his retirement - he becomes a paradoxical, possibly even tragic figure.

title:
PASTIMES: Gardening;
A Backyard Hybridizer Enhances Dwarf Plants
description: LEAD: Although Frank A. Arsen admits he lacked patience as a young man, he now cultivates the trait as carefully as he does his garden. He has been collecting and breeding dwarf and slow growing rhododendrons and azaleas for over three decades in his Lindenhurst garden located on Long Island's South Shore.

title:
CHILDREN'S BOOKS;
READING ALONG WITH BARBARA BUSH: THE ENDINGS ARE MOSTLY HAPPY
description: LEAD: Why a First Lady of the United States chooses one cause over others isn't always clear. But Barbara Bush's personal campaign on behalf of reading has the ring of genuine, abiding commitment. It comes from a stable childhood immersed in reading; from the rigors of raising five children of her own, including one who was dyslexic, in a succession of homes; and from a determination to be more than just a good-enough grandmother.

title: Pepper in Serious Condition
description: Representative Claude D. Pepper, Democrat of Florida, remained in serious but stable condition today with an undisclosed stomach ailment, said Rochelle Jones, an aide. Mr. Pepper, who at 88 years old is the oldest member of Congress, has been hospitalized at Walter Reed Army Medical Center since Monday after receiving treatment at the Johns Hopkins University Hospital in Baltimore.

title: When New Plays Are Made From Old
description: At least since Shakespeare, playwrights have been tempted to rewrite the works of others. Usually they resist that temptation; if not, they should take on that role with trepidation. Michael Frayn, who has translated Chekhov's four major plays and has also written his own freehanded adaptation of Chekhov, ''Wild Honey,'' admonishes that it is ''a presumptuous enterprise'' to rewrite someone else's play. This, of course, has not deterred him or any of his colleagues. They do it for diverse reasons - as an act of homage to a favorite writer; to complete a play that was left unfinished (as was the case with ''Wild Honey''); as commentary; to improve upon a flawed original; or simply out of envy.

title: Friends and Antiques In New York
description: IN AUGUST, AS HAS BEEN THE CUSTOM FOR 15 years, Albert and Murray Douglas threw a buffet in honor of The Shaker Museum's Antiques Festival in Old Chatham, N.Y. The relaxed and informal party belied the prodigious planning talents of the hostess, a senior vice president of the fabric house Brunschwig & Fils.

title: A CACOPHONY OF QUACK-QUACKS
description: OLD MacDONALD HAD A FARM Illustrated by Carol Jones. Unpaged. Boston: Houghton Mifflin. $10.95. (Ages 4-8) OLD MacDONALD HAD A FARM Illustrated by Glen Rounds. Unpaged. New York: Holiday House. $14.95. (Ages 4 and up)

title: Strong, Vulnerable; Vulnerable, Strong
description: Jessica Lange has not always chosen film roles wisely, but she always plays them well. As a sophisticated city woman or a gritty farm wife, she reaches into characters to suggest the strength of vulnerable women and the vulnerability of the strong.

title: Putnam Landfill Plans Raise an Outcry
description: WHEN Putnam County released a list ranking 20 potential sites for a countywide landfill three months ago, its neighbors in northern Westchester paid little attention. But now they have discovered that four of the sites are in their backyards.

title: Why Risk Planning Paralysis?
description: Yielding to misguided populism, New York City's charter commission proposes a new planning policy so flawed that it's almost guaranteed to fail. The proposal, in its eagerness to distribute planning power, risks destroying it.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: May 21, 1989
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 3 TO BE THE BEST, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Bantam, $5.95.) A department store dynasty undergoes emotional and financial stress. 2 4 LIGHTNING, by Dean R. Koontz. (Berkley, $4.95.) A mysterious stranger saves a woman from a series of dangers and disasters. 3 16 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Dell, $4.95.) A woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family. 4 3 2061: Odyssey Three, by Arthur C. Clarke. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $4.95.) A sequel to ''2001'' and ''2010.'' 5 3 THE TAMING, by Jude Deveraux. (Pocket, $4.50.) Romance and chivalrous adventure in medieval England. 6 6 THE DRAWING OF THE THREE, by Stephen King. (Touchstone/S&S, $9.95.) Spiritual inspiration. 5 49 THE POWER OF MYTH, by Joseph Campbell with Bill Moyers. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The ways in which mythology illuminates the stages of life. 6 22 CHAOS, by James Gleick. (Penguin, $8.95.)
