More ''Calvin and Hobbes'' cartoons. 2 4 WILDLIFE PRESERVES, by Gary Larson. (Andrews & McMeel, $5.95.) The 10th collection of ''Far Side'' cartoons. 3 43 CODEPENDENT NO MORE, by Melody Beattie. (Hazelden/Harper & Row, $8.95.) How to solve your own problems while caring for other people's afflictions. 4 2 THE DANCE OF ANGER, by Harriet Goldhor Lerner. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $7.95.) Ways in which women can improve their personal relationships. 5 19 RAND McNALLY ROAD ATLAS. (Rand McNally, $6.95.) The 1989 edition of a guide to the United States, Canada and Mexico. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 38,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Educators Tackle Ethics Role
description: LEAD: SCHOOLS and colleges must bring a moral dimension to the material they are teaching to help young people learn about values, educators were told at a recent conference here.

title: Tenor From Utah Wins Naumburg Competition
description: Stanford Olsen, a 29-year-old tenor from Salt Lake City, was awarded first prize in the International Vocal Competition in Concert Repertory on Wednesday at the 92d Street Y. The prize consists of $5,000, two Alice Tully Hall recitals, and a recording for the Musical Heritage Society.

title: INSIDE
description: Palestinian Press Power

title: BIGGEST BEIJING CROWDS SO FAR KEEP TROOPS FROM CITY CENTER; PARTY REPORTED IN BITTER FIGHT
description: Huge throngs, possibly amounting to more than one million Chinese, took to the streets today to defy martial law and block troops from reaching the center of the capital, effectively delaying or preventing the planned crackdown on China's democracy movement.

title: Medical Insurance for the College Grad
description: A new crop of college graduates will soon be leaving the campus. While some will begin jobs immediately, others may first take a long vacation. Still others are putting off the job search until after graduation.

title: Yellow-Fever Epidemic Raising Concern in Bolivia
description: An epidemic of yellow fever has broken out in the central jungles of Bolivia, and officials are concerned that the deadly disease may spread to heavily populated areas as well as to neighboring Brazil.

title: Drew University
description: Arno A. Penzias, a Nobel laureate and author, told graduates at Drew University's 121st commencement yesterday that career success will depend on their ability to think creatively.

title: Why Schnabel's Mozart Works So Well
description: Old recordings are antiques, but antiques of a most ephemeral kind. Indeed, collecting them points up an important difference between music and the visual arts. To hold 18th-century majolica in the hand, for example, is to know the true thrill of possession, a thrill impossible without the presence of ther object.

title: Hong Kong Turns Out in Protest Against Its Once and Future Ruler
description: Braving gale-force winds and drenching rains from Typhoon Brenda, demonstrators turned out by the thousands today in Hong Kong and Macao in support of the Beijing student protests, and against the Chinese Government's hard line.

title: About Cars; Nissan's New Z Is a Curvaceous Beauty
description: This is another one of those cars.

title: A Silk To Suit The Faded Denim Set
description: Washed, or sueded, silk is competing with cotton and linen as a uniform for spring and summer.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Wisconsin; Racist Acts Inspire A Call for Control Over Fraternities
description: The incidents began in the spring of 1986, when the University of Wisconsin's chapter of Kappa Sigma fraternity held a party featuring a ''Harlem room.'' Watermelon and fried chicken were served in the room, which had trash on the floor and graffiti on the walls. Members wore Afro wigs and blackface makeup.

title: A Great Player, A Great Man
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Susan J. Sarao, Editor, Becomes Bride of Lawyer
description: Susan Jean Sarao, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Sarao of Cambridge, Mass., was married yesterday to James Ripley Westmoreland 2d, the son of Gen. William Childs Westmoreland, U.S.A. retired, and Mrs. Westmoreland, of Charleston, S.C. The ceremony was performed at Christ Episcopal Church in Cambridge by the Rev. Thomas Dix Bowers, an Episcopal priest, and the Rev. Lucien Richard, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: The Hiss, Creak and Spin of Love

title: 17th Medallion Awards for Continuous Leaders
description: LEAD: IF it's the third week in May, the Medallion Awards Dinner must be just around the corner. The 17th yearly presentation of these awards to prominent community members will take place Wednesday night at a dinner at Westchester Community College in Valhalla.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: DESIGNER WINE LABELS Baron Philippe de Rothschild, one of France's most prestigious vintners, was the first to bottle wine on the estate, rather than ship it in barrels for others to market.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Two years ago, we had a new stoop of reddish fieldstone built on top of our old concrete one. The mason advised us to coat it with a silicone sealer; however, I read that this was not needed and so I did not apply any. Now the stoop is gradually turning green. How can I remove this discoloration, and after that should I apply a sealer?

title: New U.S. Arms Line Would Slow NATO Cuts
description: The Bush Administration's conditions for holding American-Soviet talks on short-range nuclear missiles would delay the negotiated reductions of those weapons for a substantial period of years, according to Western officials.

title: Aditional Factors In Seeking Child Care
description: Because of the lack of affordable quality child-care programs, most parents are at a disadvantage when searching for a child-care program. The April 20 article ''For Preschool Programs, Parents' Search Starts Early'' gave parents a brief overview of the services available without providing sufficient information on the quality issues:

title: WEEK IN BUSINESS: May 21, 1989
Dining on Trains
description: To the Editor: The article ''Not a Lost Art: Dining Aboard in Europe'' (Travel, March 26) reminded me of a trip I made from Dublin to Sligo.

title: HELPING THE WATER BABIES
description: STERLING The Rescue of a Baby Harbor Seal. By Sandra Verrill White and Michael Filisky. Illustrated. Unpaged. New York: A New England Aquarium Book/ Crown Publishers. $14.95. (Ages 4 to 8) RESCUE OF THE STRANDED WHALES By Kenneth Mallory and Andrea Conley. Illustrated. 64 pp. New York: Simon & Schuster. $14.95. (Ages 8 to 12)

title: Southern Methodist
description: Jim Lehrer, co-anchor of ''The MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour,'' yesterday urged graduates to take risks in life as he addressed the 74th commencement of Southern Methodist University in Dallas.

title: Hannah Toffey Wed to Editor
description: Hannah Toffey and James Christopher Mauro were married yesterday at St. Peter's Roman Catholic Church in Great Barrington, Mass., by the Rev. Merle Lavoie.

title: SONGS OF A CURMUDGEON
description: COLLECTED POEMS By Philip Larkin. Edited by Anthony Thwaite. 330 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

title: Taking It Easy
description: Fussy makeup and hair are antithetical to summer weekends, when dressing amounts to little more than a bathing suit and cooking means lighting the grill. The traditional approach - packing away the makeup and baking in the sun - is no longer a reasonable solution. Even those who like a bit of sun are wise to its hazards.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Are Indy Speeds Getting Too Fast?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y., 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title:
DINING OUT;
A Blend of Sophistication and Simplicity
description: LEAD: IT has been about a year since hands changed at Toto. That's when Dennis Foy left to open Mondrian in Manhattan and Edward Lloyd took over the reins of the attractive restaurant, just off Summit's main shopping street. After a subsequent turnover of chefs, Toto appears to be on a fairly even keel, and the time seemed right for a return visit.

title: Miss Prescott Marries James Richard Kuster
description: Cynthia Lee Prescott and James Richard Kuster were married yesterday at the West Copake (N.Y.) Reformed Church by its minister, the Rev. James Chase, and the Rev. James Adelman, a United Church of Christ minister. The couple work for the Chase Manhattan Bank, she as an associate in the primary industries finance division and he as an associate in the media and entertainment finance division.

title: Commitment to the New at East Coast Arts
description: WHILE it is fashionable to deplore the chances of getting a new play produced on Broadway, with the prohibitive costs and hit-or-miss mentality, it appears that the Off Broadway play is flourishing. Likewise, regional theaters nationwide are consistently coming up with scores of new scripts.

title: Amazin' '69 Mets In Another Bow
description: O.K., so they weren't exactly Amazin'. Their uniforms stretched in odd places and their limbs no longer bent in the old familiar ones. It mattered not at all. The 1969 Mets, reunited, if not rejuvenated, were together and playing again. It lasted only a couple of moments, but it was a marvelously minor miracle all the same.

title: LIFE IS JUST A BOWL OF CINDERS
description: CINDERELLA Retold by Barbara Karlin. Illustrated by James Marshall. Unpaged. Boston: Little, Brown & Company. $12.95. (Ages 4 to 8)

title: Q & A
description: Succession Rights

title: 'Ahead of Her Time'
description: Some called her ''the conscience of white South Africa.'' Others called her worse. Whatever the view, all sides joined last week in praising Helen Suzman, South Africa's best known white campaigner against apartheid, who decided to retire from Parliament after 36 years. For years, Mrs. Suzman was the only legislator representing opponents of the legal policy of racial discrimination. At age 71, she said it was time for a younger person to represent her Johannesburg district. A spokesman for the governing National Party called her ''a courageous fighter who was ahead of her time.'' Mrs. Suzman said apartheid had not ended. ''But a number of important laws have been repealed, laws which I opposed when they were introduced,'' she said, ''and that's a source of considerable satisfaction for me.''

title: Children Show Urge to Win
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Elegant Ghosts Haunt 'Black and Blue'
description: Seeking an evening of pure entertainment, I went back to ''Black and Blue'' and was bowled over by an evening of sheer artistry. This return visit to the tap-studded revue at the Minskoff Theater for the first time since it began its run in January revealed how much more sharply the performances have been defined.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Michigan State; Condom Machines Are Removed After Poor Sales
description: Michigan State University has removed the condom machines it had installed in November in residence halls at the urging of students.

title: Meanwhile, Back at the Ranch
description: On a beach in Hawaii, long, long ago - May 30, 1977 - George Lucas and Steven Spielberg were taking a break from business, but talking, as they frequently do, about movies.

title: Nazi Scientists and Ethics of Today
description: Nearly 50 years after Nazi scientists performed brutal experiments on Jews and gypsies in the concentration camps, scientists are still struggling with ethical questions over use of the Nazis' data.

title: The Southwest Without Cliches
description: DORIS LOUIE melds impressions of the landscape of the Southwest with motifs from Native American weaving in her tapestry rugs. Repeated horizontal lines, which diminish in size, suggest the vastness of a desert horizon. Lightning-like zigzags that slash across her open skies are an adaptation of the basic motif in Navajo ''eye dazzler'' rugs of the 19th and early 20th centuries.

title: 'I-Must-You-Must': It Wasn't Just A Game
description: THERE'S so much talk lately about ''peer pressure'' and ''everyone else is doing it'' that, with the anniversary of my elementary school graduation imminent, I have to remember the day I learned that one needs to make one's own moral judgments.

title: One Less Moderate in An Immoderate Land
description: THE assassination last week of Sheik Hassan Khaled, the religious leader of Lebanon's 700,000 Sunni Muslims, lent credence to an adage produced here by 14 years of civil war:

title: Susan L. Quarles Marries Producer
description: Susan Linda Quarles and Geoffrey Stephens were married yesterday at the Heights Town House in Brooklyn Heights by the Rev. Harris Riordan, a Unitarian minister.

title: BEYOND THE QUARK
description: As a lay person, I read with fascination James Trefil's lucid discussion of the proposed Superconducting Supercollider and the scientific discoveries it may yield (''Beyond the Quark,'' April 30). As a cynic, I am moved to wonder what military applications could motivate Congress to spend $4.4 billion on the project. Is this the search for a Big Bang in reverse? PETER MOST Washington

title: My Uncle Terwilliger On the Art Of Eating Popovers
description: LEAD: My uncle ordered popovers from the restaurant's bill of fare. And, when they were served, he regarded them with a penetrating stare. Then he spoke great Words of Wisdom as he sat there on that chair: ''To eat these things,'' said my uncle, ''You must exercise great care. You may swallow down what's solid .

title: Michael Devlin Is the Bridegroom Of Miss Anspach
description: Roxanna Bodne Anspach and Michael William Devlin, both law students at Duke University, were married yesterday at the Union League Club in New York. Judge Milton Pollack of Federal District Court in Manhattan officiated.

title: WHY WOULD PITINO WANT KENTUCKY?
description: For Rick Pitino, the question of his possibly deserting the Knicks for the University of Kentucky isn't so much ''Will he?'' as it is ''Why would he?''

title: Pedaling Fast to Recapture Slowing
description: Bicycling seems to have replaced running and swimming as the solo-sport of choice among upwardly mobile adults in America. More people today are using bikes for commuting and vacationing, and racing and riding them for fun and charity.

title: Pet Parade: Cats Climb Into First
description: LEAD: THE English springer spaniel of President and Mrs. Bush that gave birth to five puppies earlier this spring also spawned a run on the breed at pet shops across Long Island.

title: Luxembourg
description: For years, perhaps for centuries, Luxembourg has usually been an afterthought on a European tour. Although poets as disparate as Racine and Goethe sang its low-key charms, the vest-pocket country was usually a rest stop on the way to the station or a jumping-off place for wine tasting in the Moselle Valley. The country's castles and monasteries, folded in the ancient hills, were bypassed for the pleasures of more cosmopolitan spots.

title: Sugar Pies
description: To the Editor: The article on sugar pies brought back some fond memories - not of Montreal, but of Brussels. I discovered the pastry while on a morning ramble in the St. Josse section, where I lived. On gray and damp Sunday mornings, I often wandered the neighborhood, ending up at one of the many bakeries to purchase something to go with my morning coffee. In my favorite bakery one morning I noticed that most of the patrons ahead of me were asking for a tarte au sucre, and deciding that was recommendation enough for me, I also went home with one. For the rest of my stay in Belgium, I never bothered with a different kind of pastry. I thought it only fitting that it was in a Belgian restaurant in Montreal that your author sampled her first. MARTHA M. FERRY New York, N.Y.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Bronxville
description: LEAD: IN the midst of bustling, densely populated southern Westchester, Bronxville has managed to retain both a small-town feel and a sense of history.

title: MORE DONE UNTO THAN DOING
description: MIDDLEPOST By Antony Sher. Illustrated. 383 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: DRAWING ON THE DARK SIDE
description: To read your article, one would think the modern comic book is distinguished from its predecessors solely by today's explicit sex and violence. You ignore the laudable differences: a variety of nonwhite heroes, strong female characters (one series, ''The X-Men,'' has for years offered a rare role model: a black woman as the leader of the group) and socially relevant issues, from the Arab-Israeli conflict to drug abuse. CHRIS COOPER New York, N.Y.

title: Correction
description: A table last week showing the volume of weekly bond trading on the New York Stock Exchange included two errors. The numbers shown for 1988 and 1989 should be reversed. In addition, the year-to-date figure in terms of par value for 1988 was listed incorrectly. It is $2,905,375,000.

title: Can Diplomacy Alone Dislodge a Dictator's Stranglehold on Power?
description: UNITED States officials were pleasantly surprised when the Organization of American States adopted a resolution calling for Gen.

title: 'Fallout'
description: To the Editor:

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;
In Lagartera, an Intricate Tradition
description: LEAD: AT first glance Lagartera appears no different from any of the hundreds of villages dotting the arid sun-drenched plains of Castile. Yet Lagartera is unique, its fame international. This village of only two thousand is responsible for much of Spain's fine needlework, and just about every female here engages in the traditional skills of embroidery and drawn-thread work.

title: Alexandra Davis, Lawyer, Weds Anthony DiPentima
description: Alexandra Davis, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Otis B. Davis of Kent, Conn., was married there yesterday to Anthony Francis DiPentima, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Panteleone R. DiPentima of Sunrise, Fla. The Rev. Roger B. White performed the ceremony at St. Andrew's Episcopal Church. Mrs. DiPentima is a partner at the Hartford law firm of Moller, Horton & Fineberg. Her father is the senior master at the Kent School. The bridegroom is a senior partner at the law firm of Short & DiPentima in Hartford. His father retired as a lithographer.

title: Sometimes, Soviet Arms-Control Offers Mean Something
description: IN recent months, the pace of Moscow's unilateral arms control initiatives has been fast and furious.

title: 'People Are So Fed Up, So Angry'
description: VIOLENT crimes are increasing in Connecticut and throughout the country, according to state and national statistics. Many of those crimes never make the news, but others, like the recent attack on the jogger in Central Park, not only make headlines, but cause many people to react as well.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Commencements; Washingtonians Speak And Graduates Listen
description: At the halfway point of the commencement season, members of the Bush Administration have proved to be the stars plucked most eagerly by America's colleges and universities.

title: Liverpool Wins, and Mourns
description: Ian Rush, a late substitute, scored two overtime goals today as Liverpool beat local rival Everton, 3-2, in the English F.A. Cup final.

title:
FOCUS: New Lebanon, N.H.;
Dartmouth Ventures Into Real Estate
description: LEAD: ALONG a two-lane stretch of Route 120 lined mostly with pine trees and a few steel fabricated buildings is the 137-acre hillside site chosen by Dartmouth College for its first joint real estate venture. On the Lebanon-Hanover border, it is two miles south of the Georgian-style brick buildings that make up the Dartmouth campus.

title: Blue Jays Get 18 Hits to Stifle the White Sox, 11-1
description: Ernie Whitt had four hits, including a three-run homer, and drove in four runs, and Lloyd Moseby batted in three additional runs as the Toronto Blue Jays beat the Chicago White Sox, 11-1, tonight. Nelson Liriano also had four hits.

title:
INVESTING;
Building a Portfolio of Housing Stocks
description: LEAD: Housing starts, which fell to a six-year low in April, may be depressed, but that does not mean that all home builders are suffering. Indeed, analysts say home builders with strong niches are prospering and predict that the stocks of several companies will perform particularly well if mortgage interest rates continue their recent decline.

title: Next Summer, I'll Be Married
description: IT WAS FEBRUARY AND the hard sell was blowing in.

title: FASHION: On the Street; A Studied Ragamuffinry
description: Jeans have been through a lot in their day. They've been pegged, bell-bottomed, cut off, bibbed, bleached and dyed in all manner of psychedelic hues. That last was in an age past, the 60's: a millennium ago in fashion terms.

title: Know Where Your Children Are?
description: To the Editor:

title: TV Steps Into the Fray, and Alters It
description: Nothing so confirmed the power of television as a force in world opinion as the dramatic live broadcasts to the United States on Friday night of Chinese bureaucrats shutting the networks down.

title: A Sculptor Who Rejects Nothing
description: For Joel Shapiro this has been a very good year. Three of his sculptures were in the Carnegie International in Pittsburgh. Two more, including one that was in the Carnegie, are in the Whitney Biennial. And the four sculptures in his gallery show at the Paula Cooper Gallery in SoHo (through June 3) - including another that was in the Carnegie - are further proof that the formal intelligence and emotional weight of this leader of post-Minimalist sculpture demand attention.

title: Cray's Future Without Cray
description: For the third time in his career, Seymour R. Cray is starting over. In breaking away last week from Cray Research Inc., the supercomputer company he founded 17 years ago, the brilliant and reclusive computer designer once again is fleeing a company that outgrew his need for a simple, unfettered environment.

title: Fires in Canada Take 'Enormous' Toll on Timber
description: Fires in Canada have ravaged 3.9 million acres of timber and park land, killing one person, forcing the evacuation of 1,500 others and destroying at least 100 homes.

title: Tasmania and the Raised Eyebrow
description: To the Editor:

title: Old Favorites, New Tastes
description: FASHIONS IN FOOD COME AND GO, but each season brings perennial favorites.

title:
VIEWS OF SPORT;
The Coach Who Ate, Slept and Dreamt Football
description: LEAD: Four huge buses, preceded by a motorcycle police escort, roared away from Baltimore's Municipal Stadium after a football game. The first two buses were decorated with blue and gold streamers of the Navy, while those in the rear displayed the Army colors, black, gray and gold.

title: Murders That Torment Those Left to Mourn
description: HELEN NANNERY is not prone to emotional outbursts, but she could not hold back her feelings as she watched the residents of Horton Road in Valley Stream parade across her television screen and plead with the police to arrest someone for the murder of young Kelly Tinyes. ''It's been a week already,'' the mob shouted. ''Try two and a half years,'' said Mrs. Nannery.

title: Ralph Corbin Jr., 54, Jersey Bank Chairman
description: Ralph A. Corbin Jr., a New Jersey banker for the last quarter-century, died of kidney failure at Mountainside Hospital in Glen Ridge, N.J., yesterday. He was 54 years old and lived in West Caldwell.

title: Lieut. Helen Masek Weds
description: Lieut. Helen Helm Masek, U.S.N.R., and Capt. Christopher Jan Keesing, U.S.A., were married yesterday at the Ware Episcopal Church in Gloucester, Va., by the Rev. Daniel O. Worthing Jr. The bride, a graduate of the Virginia Polytechnic Institute and State University, is a daughter of Capt. William Masek Jr., U.S.N. retired, and Mrs. Masek of Gloucester. Captain Keesing, a graduate of the University of Arizona, where he also received a master's degree in history, is a son of Mrs. Ralph A. Keesing of Manhasset, L.I., and the late Mr. Keesing.

title: Pop's Angry Voices Sound the Alarm
description: Corruption, poverty, crack, racial tension, AIDS and a poisonous environment: the plagues of the late 80's and the nightmarish anxieties they arouse are darkening popular music.

title: CALCUTTA IS THE MEASURE OF ALL THINGS
description: SHOW YOUR TONGUE By Gunter Grass. Translated by John E. Woods. Illustrated. 224 pp. San Diego: A Helen and Kurt Wolff Book/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich. Cloth, $34.95. Paper, $19.95.

title: An Exercise In Inactivity At a Spa
description: AT Stobo Castle Health Spa, what I really need is to have my head examined. But what is offered is algotherapy, aromatherapy, thalgo seaweed bath, moor peat bath condition, collagen eye treatment, elastin lip treatment, cathiodermy and steam cabinet, not to neglect reflexology, ionithermy and biopeeling. To think that I could even contemplate any of these ventures into the skin trade! My curiosity about what it's like at a Scottish health spa will have to be satisfied without the courage of vanity. It's valorous enough simply to endure the perils of carrot juice and lettuce leaves.

title: Near Miss for an Astronaut
description: For Navy Capt. David M. Walker, the easy part was commanding the space shuttle Atlantis on a four-day flight around the earth earlier this month. The more hazardous part was getting to Washington from Houston last week for a Presidential reception honoring the shuttle crew. About 30 miles west of Washington, aviation officials said, a jet training plane piloted by Captain Walker came within 500 feet of a Pan American World Airways wide-body jet carrying 176 people and bound for Paris, prompting the Pan Am pilot to report a ''near midair collision.'' The 44-year-old astronaut, who has logged 5,000 hours as a pilot, said he would cooperate in investigations of the incident by three Federal agencies. As for his version, he said, ''All the facts have yet to be established.''

title: No Headline
description: IF there must be music festivals - and these days, that seems to be the best way to market the classics - then Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart is an ideal composer around whom to wrap a few weekends of concerts.

title: Flyers Sign Sinisalo
description: He spent most of the 1988-89 season on the injured list, but at the age of 30, Ilkka Sinisalo, the Philadelphia Flyers' high-scoring right wing, still has some goals left in him.

title: Corrections
description: An article on April 23 about Portland, Ore., misstated the addresses of two restaurants. The Bangkok Kitchen is at 2534 Southeast Belmont; Thanh Thoa is at 4005 Southeast Hawthorne Boulevard. A map with the article mislabeled the body of water adjacent to Oregon. It was the Pacific.

title: From the Garden
description: LEAD: APOLOGIES ARE NO LONGER necessary when the main course goes meatless, such as the one suggested here. Nor does convention dictate at what point in a meal fruits and vegetables can appear, for produce alone may star from hors d'oeuvres through dessert. Further, the varieties available today are decidedly untraditional.

title: In Run for Ph.D., Costs and Hurdles Get Higher; Many Poor Students
description: To the Editor:

title: Clapping For Money At Auctions
description: Not so long ago, art auction rooms were the refuge of a tiny group of professionals who sat in silence, barely moving an eyelid, as lot followed lot and the auctioneer deciphered their every tiny twitch. It was almost true - though not quite - that, as the ads for the New York State lottery say, all you needed was a dollar and a dream. The auction room, in those days, was a private place.

title: Judge Enjoins Some Federal Drug Testing
description: A Federal district judge has temporarily blocked planned drug tests covering 30 employees in the executive office of the President and hundreds of workers in the General Services Administration.

title: Studies Link AIDS Development to Age
description: The older people are when they become infected with the AIDS virus, the more quickly they become ill, researchers are finding.

title: Correction
description: An article on page 31 of the Arts and Leisure section today about aboriginal artists misstates the commission that the John Weber Gallery receives for sales of their work. It is 40 percent, not 10.

title: Designer's Rooms Done in Miniature
description: FOR Barbara Ostrom of Upper Saddle River, an interior designer, an 11-by-14 room poses no particular problem - unless it's 11 by 14 inches. And that was the challenge she faced when she was invited to do a room for a dollhouse at the prestigious Kips Bay Decorator Show House.

title: A One-of-a-Kind Experience
description: THE American Hotel dates to 1846, when Sag Harbor and its whaling fleets were in their heyday. Seventeen years ago, it was restored and its restaurant has earned high marks for fine food and a voluminous wine list ever since.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; Recent Sales
description: Danbury, Conn.$178,00 33 Grammar School Drive 3-bedroom, 1-bath, 24-year-old ranch; remodeled kitchen, vinyl siding, 0.75 acre; taxes $1,775. Darien, Conn.$539,000 23 Blueberry Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 32-year-old farmhouse; golf-course view, 2 decks, 1.3 acres; taxes $4,534. West Hartford, Conn.$190,000 67 Riggs Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 50-year-old colonial; new roof, hardwood floors; taxes $2,408. Bedford, N.Y.$442,500 10 Ferris Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 9-year-old colonial; fireplace, finished basement, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $5,997. Bronxville, N.Y.$545,000 100 Dellwood Road 7-bedroom, 3-bath, 69-year-old colonial; 3 fireplaces, sun room, kitchen/breakfast room, playroom, 2-car garage; taxes $6,974. Ossining, N.Y.$255,000 4 McCarthy Drive 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 11-year-old raised ranch; fireplace and cathedral ceiling in living room, eat-in kitchen, study, patio, 2-car garage; taxes $4,719. OTHER AREAS Maplewood, N.J.$255,000 55 Highland Avenue 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 13-year-old split level; c/a, dining room, full basement; taxes $5,920. Sayville, L.I.$250,000 191 Candee Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 90-year-old Victorian; fireplace, screened porch; taxes $4,700.

title: Beware: Retiree Within
description: SELDOM does one read of wives in retirement. They don't retire. When the husband arrives at the threshold, it is a big event. Parties are given, dozens of cards are sent and comments such as ''Enjoy,'' ''Congratulations,'' ''Get out of the rat race'' are made. A life of leisure awaits the man of the house, but what about Mrs. Housewife? For her, retirement means three meals a day to prepare, with an ''assistant'' to lift the covers from the pots and ask, ''Isn't this ready yet?''

title:
ART;
Exploring Interaction, Human and Esthetic
description: LEAD: IN the current group exhibition at the Discovery Gallery in Glen Cove, five artists represent five very different points of view.

title:
THE NATION;
In the West, A Mix of Religion And Politics
description: LEAD: ANNETTA L. CONANT, a white-haired woman who wears a rhinestone lapel pin that says ''Jesus'' and packs a pistol to protect herself and her dog from coyotes around her desert home, is something of a power in Arizona politics.

title: Cos Cob Plant
description: To the Editor:

title: Bridge Team From California Takes Lead at Championships
description: Some of the players in today's finals of the United States Bridge Championships will earn trips to Perth, Australia, in September to compete in the World Championship.

title: A Scarcity of Beds For Amtrak Passengers
description: WITH the growing popularity of overnight train travel in North America, passengers are finding it difficult to book sleeping accommodations on either Amtrak or Via Rail Canada. This revival of interest in crossing the continent at a leisurely pace has resulted in a rush to line up accommodations, especially in the summer.

title: At Two Museums, Youthful Exuberance
description: Two of New York's major museums turned their lobbies into ballrooms for parties recently. In each case, the idea was to attract the younger crowd and get it to join their money-raising ranks.

title: Tavern on Green Draws Tourists Despite Pickets
description: Tourists visiting New York City kept Tavern on the Green on their whirlwind itineraries yesterday, despite a bitter labor dispute that has led to three weeks of noisy picketing out front.

title: June B. Eckstein Engaged to Wed
description: Mrs. Otto Eckstein of Lexington, Mass., and Palm Beach, Fla., has announced the engagement of her daughter June Beth Eckstein to Russell Stephen Higgins, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Royle Higgins of Toronto. A June wedding is planned.

title: Correction
description: The headline of the bridge column last Sunday misidentified Wan Li. He is Chairman of the National People's Congress in China, not Deputy Prime Minister.

title: Sugar Pies
description: To the Editor: What a pleasure to learn about Montreal's sugar pies (Travel, March 12). I knew them in childhood and loved them, and I'm not from Quebec. People we know in New Jersey find ours not only strange but too sweet.

title: Again, Democrats Agonize Over the Rules
description: WHILE Democrats in the House of Representatives sink ever deeper into a dismal mood over Speaker Jim Wright's ethical troubles, party political apparatchiks are embroiled in the latest round of what has been a two-decade-long Democratic fight over the rules under which the party selects its Presidential nominees.

title: A Taste of Brass and Electronics
description: WITH a program ranging from Bach to Fats Waller, the Beacon Brass Quintet of Boston is taking its turn today in the New Britain music series at the South Congregational-First Baptist Church.

title: What I've Learned From Books
description: THE only time I hate books is at moving time. Like so much of the flotsam of life that hibernates in closets, attics and cellars, unseen and untouched except when transported from one dwelling place to another, most books slumber on shelves undisturbed until their keepers grow restless.

title: Anne Gillman Weds Thomas Skakel, A Real-Estate Broker, in Connecticut
description: Anne Maitland Gillman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter M. Gillman of Boxford, Mass., and Southbury, Conn., was married yesterday in Greenwich, Conn., to Thomas Reynolds Skakel, a son of Rushton W. Skakel of Greenwich and the late Anne Reynolds Skakel. The Rev. Alastair Votaw performed the ceremony at Christ Episcopal Church, assisted by the Rev. Douglas Tufaro, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Greco: Makeup Artist
description: After Greco has applied makeup to a woman's face, he sometimes has to resist the impulse to sign his name - in eyebrow pencil - on the chin, perhaps, or beside a dimple. The 35-year-old makeup expert once studied art and now considers the face his canvas. He refuses to work in artificial light, and has been known to wander from room to room in clients' homes in search of sun. ''I take my palette to the window,'' he said.

title: Sanctions to Hurt Kentucky Income
description: University of Kentucky officials confirmed Friday that the school could lose close to $2 million in the next two years as a result of the sanctions imposed on it by the National Collegiate Athletic Association as a response to recruiting and academic violations in the basketball program.

title: LONG ISLAND JOURNAL
description: Horse Doctor SPRINGTIME is a special time at Long Island's horse farms. Gangly foals on legs twice too big for them greet visitors shyly from the security of their mothers' flanks. The one-month-old filly curiously eyeing a visitor at the Faux Pas Horse Farm in Brookville, recently, was no exception. She was as awkward and as appealing as any newborn horse. Her heritage, however, sets her and her siblings apart from the other foals now romping in Long Island's green pastures.

title:
FARE OF THE COUNTRY;
Bath's Biscuits, Buns and Sally Lunns
description: LEAD: BATH, after London one of the most visited spots in England, is jammed with 19 centuries of landmarks. It also has a baker's dozen museums. This concentration of attractions can set off a condition known as museum malaise. Fortunately, however, an effective antidote is available. In that British restorative the tearoom, the peckish tourist may savor a trio of distinguished baked treats.

title: Reviews/Music; Renaissance Sounds
description: The first half of Calliope's program Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall brought the familiar piping, buzzing, tinkling and droning sounds of a Renaissance consort playing works by Praetorius, Isaac, Des Prez and their less-known or unknown fellows. It was pleasant and jolly in the usual way: the sounds of the old instruments have lost little of their piquant flavor; the actual music making is a little on the light side; the Calliope foursome's determinedly down-home vocal contributions create the right atmosphere. After intermission, things were different.

title: Uncertain Economy Divides Analysts
description: LEAD: IRWIN L. KELLNER, chief economist for the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company and a resident of Port Washington, could not remember seeing so many houses for sale, an indication, he said, that the Long Island economy is rolling downward at a quickening pace.

title: Woman Leads Auto Salvage Group
description: LEAD: FORGET paper dolls, play stoves or a dollhouse - Cynthia Reilly reached for the Matchbox cars every time.

title: Pension Funds Are Acting More and More Like Big Shareholders
description: LED by the giant state and city pension funds, institutional investors are challenging corporate executives in increasingly provocative ways during the current round of annual shareholder meetings. In growing numbers they are becoming more demanding as they insist on playing a bigger role in deciding how the companies they have a stake in should manage themselves.

title: Palestinian, 12, Dies in Gaza After Being Shot by Israelis
description: A 12-year-old Palestinian boy who was shot in the chest during a violent clash with Israeli troops in a Gaza Strip refugee camp on Friday died this morning in a Gaza hospital, Palestinians said.

title: Kendal Kerrigan Wed To Andrew P. Gaillard
description: Kendal Kerrigan, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Robert Kerrigan of Norwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Andrew Planten Gaillard, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William Dawson Gaillard of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. David Cannon performed the ceremony at St. James Episcopal Church in Preston, Conn.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Everybody's All American 1988. Warner Home Video. 2 hours, 7 minutes. $89.95. Laser disk, $29.95. Closed captioned. R. Over a period of 25 years a Louisiana football hero named Gavin Grey (Dennis Quaid) gradually goes from the top of the heap to over the hill while his wife, Babs (Jessica Lange), blossoms from Magnolia Queen into a strong woman with plenty of grit behind her Dixie sweetness. Miss Lange gives a ''stellar performance,'' both breathlessly sexual and touchingly authentic. Mr. Quaid establishes himself as an actor of ''real weight and mutability.'' The film, by the director Taylor Hackford, matches his ''Officer and a Gentleman'' in the ''sharpness of its sense of place, the sureness of its storytelling momentum and the larger-than-life performances of its stars.'' (Janet Maslin) Coming to America 1988. Paramount Home Video. 1:56. No price suggested. LD, $24.95. CC. R. As Prince Zamunda, an African prince who travels to New York to find a wife, Eddie Murphy tries his hand at what is supposed to be a romantic comedy but is more often a series of in-and-out comic gags set amid hookers and hustlers in Queens. Arsenio Hall, as the prince's friend Semmi, performs some amusing cameos, and James Earl Jones and Madge Sinclair, as the Zamunda's regal parents, ''display comic authority that is not evident in the rest of the film . It's possible that [ John ] Landis, the director of what is still Mr. Murphy's best comedy, 'Trading Places,' couldn't care less about consistency.'' (Vincent Canby) Another Woman 1988. Orion Home Video. 1:21. $89.98. LD (Orion/Image Entertainment), $39.95. CC. PG. Woody Allen's film concerns Marion, a beautiful and respected professor of philosophy (Gena Rowlands) who has just turned 50 and is feeling much in need of self-reassessment. Something's missing. Children, for one thing. Passion, for another. Unfortunately, there is no shortage of stuffily successful Upper West Siders who talk too elaborately and way too much. What's also missing is Mr. Allen, who takes no role. He ''is becoming an immensely sophisticated director, but this screenplay is in need of a merciless literary editing.'' Still, the film is his ''most personal and self-searching . . . utterly serious and from both the head and the heart.'' (Canby) Burning Secret 1988. Vestron Video. 1:47. $89.98. LD (Image), $39.95. PG. It's 1919 and 12-year-old Edmund (David Eberts), asthmatic and sheltered, journeys to Switzerland for treatment with his beautiful, proper mother, Sonya (Faye Dunaway). There they encounter the Baron (Klaus Maria Brandauer), suitably cynical and charming, who captivates the boy and seduces his mother. The Baron, one of the war's bitter walking wounded, is a ''fully conceived character . . . When playing a genteel lady, [ Ms. Dunaway ] becomes very actressy.'' The first feature directed by Andrew Birkin, the film is ''tasteful, rather remote in time in a way that is soothing and e

title: Hriniak Teaching White Sox to Hit 'Em Where They Ain't
description: On a trip during the winter, Jeff Torborg, the new manager of the Chicago White Sox, was talking to Harold Baines about hitting.

title: Martha Wolcott Is a Bride
description: Martha Ann Wolcott, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Henry Wolcott of Rutland, Vt., was married yesterday to J. Staige Davis, a son of Mrs. Charles B. Colmore Jr. of Baltimore, and the late Dr. W. Bowdoin Davis. The Rev. Robert Senghas officiated at the Unitarian Church of Burlington, Vt. A graduate of the University of Vermont, as is her husband, Mrs. Davis is the director of Shelburne House, a National Historic Trust property in Vermont that is devoted to environmental education. Mr. Davis, a graduate of the Kent School, is the general manager of Long Associates, a real-estate brokerage and investment concern in Burlington.

title: Increasingly, State's Farms Grow Beauty, Not Food
description: A DRAMATIC growth in sales by nurseries and greenhouses is changing the face of agriculture in Connecticut, according to new census figures.

title: What Elements Do to a Windowsill
description: WOODEN windowsills suffer greatly from weather. Even though they are designed to shed moisture, snow and rain often accumulate on them and remain for long periods of time, fostering decay.

title: BEING FAIR TO SHYLOCK
description: PLOTS AND PLAYERS By Pamela Melnikoff. Illustrated by Ted Bernstein. 160 pp. New York: Bedrick/Blackie. $9.95. (Ages 12 and up)

title: Mets Are Done In By Power, Pitching
description: There really wasn't much Darryl Strawberry could do. He moved slightly in pursuit of Will Clark's enormous shot before conceding the inevitable and stopping, not even bothering to look. He looked a little longer at and ran a little farther after Kevin Mitchell's rocket five pitches later before acknowledging that it, too, was out of the park. No sense wasting energy.

title: Legislators Enact a Tax Exemption for Veterans
description: IN a move whose value was acknowledged to be more symbolic than financial, county legislators acted last week to reduce property taxes for some of Westchester's estimated 100,000 veterans.

title: Atop the Great Smokies
description: NOW in midspring, the blackpoll and Cape May warblers have flitted north through the high tops of the tulip and sweetgum trees around Cades Cove.

title: In Video, Too, Vending Rises To the Occasion
description: Industry lookouts have spotted them coming. The big new contraptions, with their display screens flashing promotional trailers and their robotic arms responding to on-board computers, are elbowing their way in among soda and candy dispensers in apartment, hotel and office building lobbies around the country.

title: Colorful Majolica Tells Vivid Tales Of Six Centuries
description: Italian Majolica - pictorial pottery brilliantly emblazoned with medieval and Renaissance images - creates gloriously colored displays throughout the central court of the Robert Lehman Wing at the Metropolitan Museum of Art. The great platters, pitchers, jugs and jars on view in the exhibition entitled ''Majolica'' are exuberantly painted with armorial emblems, grotesques, aristocratic portraits, ancient battles, mythological beasts and legendary love scenes.

title: Alison Sondhaus Wed to A. J. Carroll, A Peace Corps Lawyer, in Washington
description: The wedding of Alison Jean Sondhaus to Anthony J. Carroll took place yesterday at St. Matthew's Roman Catholic Cathedral in Washington. The Rev. Gregory Weider performed the ceremony.

title: Thunder Out of China
description: History happening before our eyes: That was our awed feeling as we watched the scenes in Tienanmen Square, until the Chinese Government cut the international television links. Here was a giant society stirring against a regime that was suddenly, amazingly, vulnerable.

title: Pregnant Teens Facing Cuts in Aid
description: THE growing problem of teen-age pregnancy on Long Island is prompting heightened efforts by state, county, local and private agencies to provide outreach, information, family planning, prenatal, education and referral services.

title: A SHELTER FOR DREAMS
description: THE MOST BEAUTIFUL HOUSE IN THE WORLD By Witold Rybczynski. Illustrated. 211 pp. New York: Viking. $18.95.

title: REFORGING THE 'GENEEN MACHINE'
description: Earlier this year, Rand V. Araskog, the chief executive of the ITT Corporation, held the company's first worldwide management meeting since 1981. Someone at the meeting asked what he thought ITT would look like in the year 2000. All Mr. Araskog could do was laugh.

title:
NEW JERSEY OPINION;
Too Much Money for Dismissal
description: LEAD: EMPLOYEES are being awarded millions of dollars in suits alleging wrongful termination of employment. Six-figure jury awards have become routine.

title: Gilda Radner, 42, Comic Original Of 'Saturday Night Live' Zaniness
description: Gilda Radner, the Emmy Award-winning comedian who created the nasal-voiced broadcaster Roseanne Roseannadanna, the nerdy teen-ager Lisa Loopner and the bumbling complainer Emily Litella for the television show ''Saturday Night Live,'' died of cancer early yesterday at a hospital in Los Angeles. She was 42 years old.

title: Democrats Grow More Combative in Jersey Debate
description: Representative James Florio, the leading candidate for the Democratic nomination for governor, lashed out today at an opponent who taunted him for months.

title: The Rugged Profile of the Tetons
description: WITHOUT the introduction of foothills, the glacier-scoured sawtooth peaks of the Grand Teton Range soar straight up, rising more than 6,500 feet from the Snake River Plain. Among the world's most recognized mountain profiles, these granite skyscrapers are the centerpiece for Grand Teton National Park, a 310,000-acre reserve in Wyoming, adjacent to the southern boundary of Yellowstone National Park.

title: Carey Schach and Daniel North Marry
description: Carrington Coburn Schach, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Oscar Schach of Pittsburgh and Christiansted, V.I., was married yesterday to Daniel Covington North, a son of Judge and Mrs. John Cannon North 2d of St. Michaels, Md. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Arthur McNulty at the Calvary Episcopal Church in Pittsburgh.

title: But Noriega Benefits and Opponents dither
description: Two weeks after opponents of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega appeared to sweep to an overwhelming electoral victory, the opposition is plagued by indecision and cowed by the military leader's crackdown despite having grown much stronger in the last year.

title: STREETSCAPES: The Carroll Street Bridge; Getting a Landmark in Shape for Its 100th Birthday
description: THE Department of Transportation is racing to meet a deadline for reopening the little Carroll Street Bridge across the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn. The unusual 1889 retractile-type bridge - the oldest in the country - has been left open since 1986, but the department has been repairing it since last December and it should be working in time for its 100th anniversary on Sept. 19.

title: Pitcher Perfect
description: IN THE LAND OF SHADE TREES AND PEONY beds, of linen shirts and bare feet, of friends bunched on the deck and families strewn all over the lawn, the cocktail can no longer be assumed to be king. More and more, an icy pitcher full of punch - which used to seem such a throwback, such an archaism, such a dodge - strikes a lot of people as up-to-the-minute and just right.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: PHILADELPHIA;
96 Condos In a Pier Shed
description: LEAD: NINETY-SIX condominiums, the first for-sale residential units on the Delaware River here, are going up within a cargo pier's steel framework.

title: Selective Craziness Builds Aura of Fear
description: If Ron Hextall were trying to enlarge the impression that he's an erratic blowtop who commits acts of violence when under pressure, his staging was perfect.

title: HOW THE WEST WAS ONE
description: FORGING THE ALLIANCE NATO, 1945-1950. By Don Cook. 306 pp. New York: Arbor House/ William Morrow & Company. $22.95.

title: Question Of the Week; Was Mark Jackson Treated Fairly?
description: I am appalled at the way some fans have treated Mark Jackson. It is obvious that they have short memories.

title:
DANCE;
A Ballet Festival In Newark
description: LEAD: WHEN the world of the arts links arms with academia, anything can happen. In the case of this month's partnership between the Garden State Ballet and Essex County College, the result is Ballet-O-Mania, a festival of five free performances at the Mary B. Burch Theater for the Performing Arts on University Avenue in

title: TALKING: Co-op Boards; Making A Minority Effective
description: VIRTUALLY all the rental buildings in and around New York City converted to co-op ownership each year achieve their new status through the ''noneviction'' method, permitting rent-regulated tenants who choose not to buy to stay on indefinitely.

title: Neon Signs
description: To the Editor:

title: Despite Island's Push, Its Deer Aren't Moving
description: The people on Mason Island have dropped their plans to move the island's deer population elsewhere after learning that the state would not approve such an evacuation.

title: L.P.G.A. Weighs 3 Sites for Home
description: The Ladies Professional Golf Association has narrowed to three the number of sites it is considering for its new national headquarters.

title: Japanese Find State Fertile for Business
description: SONY, Toshiba and Panasonic. Those are the names that come to mind when people think of Japanese companies in New Jersey. But there are also J. A. Auto Body, Dorcas Bakery, Anzen Automobile Driving School, Murao Insurance and Akane Beauty Salon. They are the small businesses owned and operated by Japanese immigrants in New Jersey.

title: Burying the Dead Acknowledges a Life
description: A 68-YEAR-OLD relative of mine has just been damned with faint praise by some family members for having finally purchased a burial site. From my point of view, he wasn't fooling around. It isn't one of these above-ground pink marble waterproof jobs. It is a real, in the ground gravesite, in a cemetery where some of his ancesters he never met are buried. He got one for himself and one for his wife. Cozy. Very family-oriented, I guess. Some members of the family, however, sniffed quietly and said: ''Well, he should have done it a long time ago. And the least he could have done was pick out his casket, his undertaker and left instructions for the services and the funeral. It would make it much easier on us.''

title: Reviews/Dance; Love's End in Armitage 'Contempt'
description: There is a lot of Jeff Koons and his ultra-ironic art of sleek surfaces and mass-media iconography in Karole Armitage's new ''Contempt,'' performed at the New Ritz on Tuesday night. Mr. Koons designed the decor and costumes with David Salle, and ''Contempt'' is one of the handsomest dances of recent memory. But for all her exploration of disco-ballet, a province of disjointed themes and energies and apposite conventions, Ms. Armitage, too, seems overwhelmingly concerned with surfaces. She is onto something. The question is whether that something has much point.

title: TASS GIVES DETAILS OF CHINA'S TURMOIL
description: Soviet television viewers tonight received their most accurate account so far of the political turmoil in the streets of Beijing, including a brief glimpse of troops using force against the demonstrators.

title:
INVESTING;
A Retreat From U.S. Real Estate
description: LEAD: Two pension funds of the British Coal Corporation that have accumulated an estimated $1 billion worth of American real estate since the late 1970's are liquidating their portfolios, and analysts expect them to make a big profit. Their holdings include the Watergate, the famous office and apartment complex where a burglary led to the resignation of President Richard M.

title: Anne E. Teare, a Teacher, Is Married
description: Anne Elizabeth Teare, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm M. Teare of Summit, N.J., and Albert Michael Freedman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Freedman of Philadelphia, were married yesterday in a Quaker ceremony at the Westtown (Pa.) Friends Meeting.

title: NOBODY'S PUPPET
description: TO MAKE A WORLD SAFE FOR REVOLUTION Cuba's Foreign Policy. By Jorge I. Dominguez. 365 pp. Cambridge, Mass. Harvard University Press. $35.

title: A Successful Alliance Gropes for a Purpose
description: WASHINGTON

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis Agassi Moves Into Final: Second-seeded Andre Agassi of the United States overpowered unseeded Sergi Bruguera of Spain, 6-3, 6-4, yesterday and moved into the final of the Italian Open in Rome. Alberto Mancini of Argentina, seeded 11th, beat unseeded Jordi Arrese of Spain, 6-2, 6-4, in the other semifinal on the slow red clay of the Foro Italico. The final will be played today.(AP) Graf to Play Sabatini: Top-seeded Steffi Graf of West Germany and second-seeded Gabriela Sabatini of Argentina advanced to the final of a women's tournament in West Berlin yesterday. Graf defeated Helen Kelesi of Canada, 6-2, 6-0, and Sabatini beat Isabel Cueto of West Germany, 6-2, 6-1. (AP) Golf Baker-Finch Leads by Four: Ian Baker-Finch of Australia shot a five-under-par 65 yesterday and stretched his lead to four strokes in the third round of the Colonial National Invitation tournament in Fort Worth. Baker-Finch has completed 54 holes over the Colonial Country Club course in 200, 10 under par. Nick Price of Zimbabwe was second at 204.(AP) Diving Ferguson Takes Three-Meter Event: Kent Ferguson of Boca Raton, Fla., held off Tan Liangde of China, the 1988 Olympic silver medalist, to win the men's three-meter springboard event yesterday in the Alamo Challenge meet in Fort Lauderdale, Fla. Ferguson and Mark Bradshaw of Columbus, Ohio, represented the United States against China and the Soviet Union. Bradshaw finished third in the first triangular meeting of the three nations. A pair of young Chinese divers dominated the women's 10-meter platform event. Chen Xiaodan, 15 years old, and Guan Xueqing, 16, took the top two spots.(AP) Lacrosse Hobart Wins Title Again: Hobart extended its record in Division III men's play yesterday by winning the national championship for the 10th consecutive time. The Statesmen defeated Ohio Wesleyan, 11-8, on their home field in Geneva, N.Y., as Lance Savage led the scoring with three goals. Coach Dave Urick's teams have won the championship every year since its inception in 1980. Hobart extended its National Collegiate Athletic Association record for consecutive team championships. Penn State and Harvard in Final: Penn State defeated the defending champion, Temple, and Harvard remained unbeaten by turning back Princeton yesterday in Division I semifinal games at the N.C.A.A. women's tournament in West Chester, Pa. The Lady Lions had an easy time in trouncing the Owls, 9-3. The Crimson beat the Tigers, 7-5. Penn State will meet Harvard today for the championship. Track and Field Penn State Shot-Putter Wins: C. J. Hunter of Penn State won the IC4A shot-put yesterday in the championship meet at Villanova University. Hunter's winning put of 58 feet 1/2 inch helped Penn State take a lead of 42 1/2 points to 22 over George Mason. Steve Brown and Barry Walsh also won events for the Nittany Lions. Brown took the 10,000 meters in 30 minutes 21.91 seconds and Walsh the decathlon with 7,472 points. Top 800-Meter Time: Cheri Goddard of Saratoga Springs High School ran the fastest schoolgirl 800 meters in the country this year when she won the event in 2:10.49 yesterday at the Eddy Memorial meet at Union College in Schenectady. Brad Sumner of Jesuit McQuaid High School of Rochester ran the fastest schoolboy 800 meters in New York State this year when he won in 1:51.05. Uniondale of Long Island was the boys' team winner and Saratoga Springs was the girls' champion. Dog Show Young Afghan Is Best: An 18-month-old brindle Afghan, Ch. Triumph of Grandeur, owned by Roger Rechler and Michael Canalizo of Mill Neck, L.I., led a field of 1,722 dogs yesterday at the 83d all-breed show of the Ladies Kennel Association of America at Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I. It was the fourth top award for Triumph, who was handled by Canalizo.

title: The City's Low-Rise Side Stands Up
description: IN this city of skyscrapers and giant apartment blocks, a low-rise mingling of row houses and one- or two-family houses covers half the land. As housing costs rose, developers used a zoning loophole to scatter boxy, bulky apartment buildings through many of these neighborhoods.

title:
GARDENING;
Alternatives to a Well-Manicured Lawn
description: LEAD: MANY gardeners are having second thoughts about lawns. They are the most extravagant users of time, energy and water in the landscape.

title: On the Binghams
description: To the Editor:

title: 'THE WORLD HAS CHANGED ON US'
description: Cray Research Inc., the nation's biggest maker of supercomputers, announced last week that it would split into two companies. After the announcement, its chairman, John A. Rollwagen, met with reporters and editors of The New York Times to discuss the future of supercomputing and how this development affects it. Question: There has been a lot of attention on supercomputers recently. Is Cray a national resource? Mr. Rollwagen: Yes. Certainly we are perceived that way. Q. If so, what should President Bush do to help Cray? Mr. Rollwagen: First, recognize that we are in a critical period in the industry in the U.S. To have an industry you need at least two thriving, profitable companies. He has to recognize that splitting into two means a certain period of vulnerability for both companies. The best way to support those efforts is to buy from both. That could really accelerate the development of both. Q. Is that all? Mr. Rollwagen: No. Second, he has to recognize that these two companies are competing on a global scale and that they have tough competition from Japan. They need help doing more business in Japan. And he has to look at export control policy, and not just for supercomputers, but in general. He needs to ask: ''What should our policy be on technology exchange?'' Q. Are export controls a problem? Mr. Rollwagen: Yes, every time we want to sell outside this country. Obviously, some countries are more sensitive than others. The world has changed on us and we have to recognize that. Q. What has changed? Mr. Rollwagen: The value added in a product now comes from the design, the technology, the information. That changes the nature of the transaction. For instance, it does not cost a whole lot to build a Cray computer. So why do we charge so much? The value is in the design, the information. Q. How does the exchange of high technology affect trade? Mr. Rollwagen: If I sell you a supercomputer, I am selling you information and at the end of the day, I have your money and I still have my information. That sounds like a good deal, but it is actually a bad one for me. Sure you do not have your money anymore, but you have my information and your information as well. Now you have a tremendous competitive advantage over me. So the best transaction is to trade information. Q. You have talked about relations with Japan. Are national boundaries becoming less important? Mr. Rollwagen: They are certainly becoming blurred. Fujitsu is a key supplier of ours, but Fujitsu in Japan is our key competitor. It is ridiculous to think of Japan or the United States totally creaming the other. If we fight to the death and one wins, we both lose. That might be better recognized here than there. But we have a lot to gain by working together. Q. Often when we ask a company about American competitiveness, we get a puzzled response. They say, ''We think about being globally competitive,'' as if they've moved past the notion of identifying their fate with the national fate. Mr. Rollwagen: If you ask about Cray Research, yes, we are a global competitor. We will get our parts and people where we can. We don't think of ourselves in that sense as a U.S. company. However, the world is not perfect, either. It is very clear in Japan that we are not able to compete on the same footing as our Japanese competitors. Q. Would you ever consider allowing one of the big Japanese computer companies to take a 10 or 15 percent interest in Cray Research? Mr. Rollwagen: We would not seek it out, but we would not get terribly upset if it happened. It depends on their intentions. If they got close to a controlling interest, then you would get worried. You would have to ask what their intention is. If Fujitsu bought us to shut us down, it would not be a good deal. Q. But what if they bought you in order that you all prosper? Are you such a national resource that the nation, as a matter of public policy, could not sit still for foreign ownership of Cray? Mr. Rollwagen: Let's turn it around. Say Fujitsu bought us and said they were going to make us prosper. What are they really thinking about? At a minimum, access to technology to build into products made in Japan, maybe insist on using all Fujitsu parts in new computers. If they were totally passive shareholders who owned the company, obviously that does not make any difference. It is not enough to say, ''What if they bought 10 or 15 percent?'' We have to know what the next step would be. Q. How do trade issues figure in this? Mr. Rollwagen: We have to look at the business on a global basis. But on the other hand, if you looked at it from Washington's viewpoint, it is clear there are countries and borders and they have a role.

title: Backpacking Along the Pacific Shore
description: CIVILIZATION clings to the water, so shorelines number among our most domesticated landscapes. It is a dismaying reality for the backpacker, who longs for the seaside but wants to escape humanity and its artifacts. A happy exception is found in Washington's Olympic National Park, at the upper-left-hand corner of the map, where an unexpected wilderness stands as wild today as it was when 16th-century mariners worked their way up the West Coast in search of the elusive Northwest Passage.

title: GETTING A YEARFUL
description: LEAD: PRIZE STORIES 1989: THE O. HENRY AWARDS Edited and with an introduction by William Abrahams. 387 pp. New York: Anchor Books/Doubleday. Cloth, $18.95. Paper, $8.95. THE PUSHCART PRIZE XIII Best of the Small Presses. Edited by Bill Henderson with the Pushcart Prize editors. Introduction by Richard Ford.

title: Lakers Defeat Suns in Opener
description: James Worthy scored 32 points and Magic Johnson returned midway through the fourth quarter today, pushing the Los Angeles Lakers past the Phoenix Suns, 127-119, in the opening game of the N.B.A. Western Conference finals.

title: Staying Put In the Snow Belt
description: IT ranks with ''Is it hot enough for you?'' It's up there in the Hall of Fame of Annoying Sentences alongside ''So what's new?'' and ''Have a nice day.'' Only you may not have heard it.

title: Precision for Precision's Sake in a Show by Virtuoso Realists
description: ART revolutions come and go, but Andrew Wyeth still plays to packed houses. It is not Mr. Wyeth's work that is now at the Squibb Gallery, but something almost as popular - a selection of portraits, still lifes and landscapes done by virtuoso realists.

title: What If Airlines Banned Laptops?
description: The plastic explosive that destroyed Pan Am's Flight 103 over Scotland last year was hidden in a portable radio. Some Government and airline safety officials have concluded that it might just as easily have been concealed in a portable computer or another small electronic device.

title: Intermarriage: Public Issue, Private Fear
description: EGON MAYER, professor of sociology at Brooklyn College, is widely regarded as the nation's leading expert on the growing phenomenon of Jewish-Christian intermarriage.

title: Votes in Congress
description: Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York Senate 1. FSX Jet: Vote on a measure to disapprove the Administration's proposal to jointly develop and produce with Japan the new FSX jet fighter. Rejected 52 to 47, May 16. 2. FSX Jet: Vote on a measure that calls for the United States to get at least 40 percent of the work in production of the plane, including work on spare parts. Approved 72 to 27, May 16. 3. Minimum Wage: Vote on a bill to raise the minimum wage from $3.35 an hour to $4.55 by October 1991. Approved 63 to 37, May 17. 4. FY 1990 Budget: Vote on a $1.17 trillion budget proposal for the fiscal year beginning October 1, 1989. Approved 63 to 37, May 18. $ Y1 Y2 Y3 Y4 Connecticut Dodd (D) Y Y Y Lieberman (D) Y Y Y Y New Jersey Bradley (D) N N Y Y Lautenberg (D) N Y Y N New York D'Amato (R) Y Y Y Y Moynihan (D) A A Y N House FY 1990 Budget: Vote on passage of a $1.17 trillion budget proposal that is intended to guide Congress in passing spending bills for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, 1989. Approved 241 to 185, May 17. $ Connecticut 1. Kennelly (D) Y 2. Gejdenson (D) Y 3. Morrison (D) N 4. Shays (R) N 5. Rowland (R) Y 6. Johnson (R) Y New Jersey 1. Florio (D) N 2. Hughes (D) N 3. Pallone (D) N 4. Smith (R) Y 5. Roukema (R) N 6. Dwyer (D) N 7. Rinaldo (R) Y 8. Roe (D) Y 9. Torricelli (D) N 10. Payne (D) N 11. Gallo (R) Y 12. Courter (R) A 13. Saxton (R) N 14. Guarini (D) Y New York 1. Hochbrueckner(D) Y 2. Downey (D) Y 3. Mrazek (D) N 4. Lent (R) Y 5. McGrath (R) Y 6. Flake (D) Y 7. Ackerman (D) Y 8. Scheuer (D) N 9. Manton (D) Y 10. Schumer (D) Y 11. Towns (D) Y 12. Owens (D) N 13. Solarz (D) Y 14. Molinari (R) A 15. Green (R) Y 16. Rangel (D) N 17. Weiss (D) N 18. Garcia (D) N 19. Engel (D) Y 20. Lowey (D) N 21. Fish (R) Y 22. Gilman (R) Y 23. McNulty (D) Y 24. Solomon (R) N 25. Boehlert (R) Y 26. Martin (R) Y 27. Walsh (R) Y 28. McHugh (D) N 29. Horton (R) Y 30. Slaughter (D) Y 31. Paxon (R) N 32. LaFalce (D) N 33. Nowak (D) N 34. Houghton (R) Y KEY: Y Yea; N Nay; (A) Absent or did not vote; (P) Present.

title: AFTER THE BOMB, A MUSHROOM CLOUD OF METAPHORS
description: Exercise: In narrative prose of anywhere from 200 to 5,000 words, describe what happened from 5:29 to 5:31 A.M. on July 16, 1945, at the place called Jornada del Muerto, or Journey of Death, in the desert near Alamogordo, N.M. Get it right and keep it fresh.

title: Students Need Support For Community Work
description: The appearance of not one but two articles about community service across Connecticut college campuses on April 9 is a welcome affirmation of the importance of student involvement (''Two Colleges With No Room for the Selfish'' and ''The View From Fairfield University: Where a Complete Education Includes How to Serve Others'').

title: Abigail Marshall Is Married
description: At the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York, Abigail Story Marshall, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph R. Marshall of New York and Stony Brook, L.I., was married yesterday to Landis Paik Zimmerman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George Zimmerman of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and Harborside, Me. The Rev. Dr. Herbert B. Anderson performed the ceremony.

title: Every Day, 5,000 Chinese Meals
description: Anyone unfamiliar with Saugus might consider a little place like this an unlikely spot to construct a giant copy of Beijing's Imperial Palace where 1,500 people can eat Chinese food, some of it kosher.

title: DRAWING ON THE DARK SIDE
description: To characterize an entire industry as ''determined to dispel any lingering notion that its products are for children'' is incorrect. One need only glance at the comics issued by Archie Comic Publications (''Betty and Veronica,'' ''Jughead''), Father Tree Press (''Elfquest''), Another Rainbow/Gladstone (''Mickey Mouse'' and ''Donald Duck'') and the revival of Classics Illustrated by the Berkley Publishing Group, First Publishing and Classics Media Group. RICK OBADIAH President, First Publishing Chicago

title: THE KINGDOM OF DOUBLETHINK
description: DOING WHAT COMES NATURALLY Change, Rhetoric, and the Practice of Theory in Literary and Legal Studies. By Stanley Fish. 613 pp. Durham, N.C.: Duke University Press. $37.50.

title: DRAWING ON THE DARK SIDE
description: For the most part, I think comics are soap operas for men. My husband is an avid fan, and when he tries to explain the goings-on of the various heroes, I can't help thinking about my soap operas - complicated fantasies full of bizarre plot twists.

title: Armed Only With Optimism, China's People Rise Again
description: ONE of the greatest living Chinese writers, Bo Yang, a 69-year-old social critic now living in Taiwan, was deeply depressed when he visited Beijing late last year after a 40-year absence. ''I went to Beijing University and spoke to some students,'' he recalled in an interview earlier this year, ''and they gathered round and asked me: 'How can we save China? How can we make China strong and democratic.' And I thought, nothing has changed. These are exactly the questions that I asked when I was a student, and that my parents asked a generation earlier. We have come nowhere.''

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: FROM SHEEP TO SHAWL Having spent the winter keeping warm under their luxurious fleece, sheep now know that the time has come to lose that extra something. In Huntington, that time is today, when the local Historical Society holds its annual Sheep-to-Shawl Festival.

title: Pitino Talks With Knicks
description: Coach Rick Pitino, who had refused to talk about a possible move from the Knicks to Kentucky, did so yesterday when he met for about 30 minutes with the Knicks at their practice center at SUNY-Purchase.

title: Science, Religion and Evolution
description: To the Editor:

title: WHERE PIGS CURTSY
description: AN OCCASIONAL COW By Polly Horvath. Illustrated by Gioia Fiammenghi. 133 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $12.95. (Ages 8 to 12)

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: GARDENING TIPS It's about now or never as far as getting that garden planted. And just in time comes a program at Muscoot Farm Park in Somers that offers some free advice on planting and caring for herb, vegetable and flower gardens.

title: POSTINGS: A Piece of 'Village' Roof; The Sky's No Co-op Limit
description: First there was the co-op apartment, which was followed eventually by the condo marina and then the condo garage. Now comes the newest wrinkle in the condo/co-op craze - the co-op roof.

title: BEST SELLERS: May 21, 1989
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 1 12 THE SATANIC VERSES, by Salman Rushdie. (Viking, $19.95.) Two emigres from Bombay enact the roles of good and evil in contemporary London. 2 2 4 THE NEGOTIATOR, by Frederick Forsyth. (Bantam, $19.95.) An American expatriate tries to thwart terrorists' attempts to prevent the signing of a disarmament pact. 3 8 2 WHILE MY PRETTY ONE SLEEPS, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The murder of a gossip writer creates a storm in New York's high-fashion world. 4 3 7 THE JOY LUCK CLUB, by Amy Tan. (Putnam, $18.95.) The tensions and bonds shared by Chinese- American women and their immigrant mothers. 5 9 3 THE TEMPLE OF MY FAMILIAR, by Alice Walker. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) The relations of the species, races and sexes through the past 5,000 centuries. 6 4 13 STAR, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) The crossed paths of a man and a woman who are destined for stardom in different professions. 7 1 PLAYMATES, by Robert B. Parker. (Putnam, $17.95.) The private eye Spenser on the trail of scandals in the world of college basketball. 8 5 9 A PRAYER FOR OWEN MEANY, by John Irving. (Morrow, $19.95.) A schoolboy who accidentally killed the mother of his best friend turns into a prophet with a message for our times. 9 7 7 WE ARE STILL MARRIED, by Garrison Keillor. (Viking, $18.95.) Stories, poems and satirical pieces, mostly reflecting life in Minnesota. 10 15 2 STRANGER IN SAVANNAH, by Eugenia Price. (Doubleday, $19.95.) The vicissitudes of three families during the Civil War. 11 10 3 THE DIAMOND THRONE, by David Eddings. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $18.95.) Magic, chivalry and high adventure in a fantasy kingdom called Elenia. 12 6 6 KILLSHOT, by Elmore Leonard. (Arbor House/ Morrow, $18.95.) Two thugs out to assassinate a man and a woman who discovered their crime. 13 1 THE NAKED HEART, by Jacqueline Briskin. (Delacorte, $19.95.) Romantic fantasies and a desire for revenge carry a woman from Paris during the Nazi occupation to postwar America. 14 11 32 BREATHING LESSONS, by Anne Tyler. (Knopf, $18.95.) The many facets of a 28-year marriage are revealed during a drive to a friend's funeral. 15 13 14 CAT'S EYE, by Margaret Atwood. (Doubleday, $18.95.) A woman's visit to her native Toronto leads her to reflect on the changes time has wrought. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Nonfiction 1 9 2 A WOMAN NAMED JACKIE, by C. David Heymann. (Lyle Stuart, $21.95.) A biography of Jacqueline Kennedy Onassis. 2 1 29 ALL I REALLY NEED TO KNOW I LEARNED IN KINDERGARTEN, by Robert Fulghum. (Villard, $15.95.) Inspirational essays about everyday matters. 3 2 4 LOVE AND MARRIAGE, by Bill Cosby. (Doubleday, $16.95.) Observations on the elations and frustrations of romantic relationships. 4 4 10 ''FUNNY, YOU DON'T LOOK LIKE A GRANDMOTHER,'' by Lois Wyse. (Crown, $12.95.) An advertising woman's reflections on her role as the grandparent of eight. 5 3 57 A BRIEF HISTORY OF TIME, by Stephen W. Hawking. (Bantam, $18.95.) A scientist reviews efforts to create a unified theory of the universe. 6 5 6 CITIZENS, by Simon Schama. (Knopf, $29.95.) A history of the French Revolution. 7 * 7 2 THE NIGHT THE BEAR ATE GOOMBAW, by Patrick F. McManus. (Holt, $15.95.) Twenty-six semiautobiographical yarns by a devoted outdoorsman. 8 14 2 ABOUT FACE, by David H. Hackworth and Julie Sherman. (Simon & Schuster, $24.95.) A career Army officer recalls his experiences in the Korean and Vietnam wars and in the Berlin wall and Cuban missile crises. 9 12 13 INNUMERACY, by John Allen Paulos. (Hill & Wang, $16.95.) Americans' mathematical illiteracy and its consequences for our culture. 10 13 6 WORDSTRUCK, by Robert MacNeil. (Viking, $18.95.) The co-host of the ''MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour'' recalls his boyhood in Canada. 11 11 4 GOLDWYN, by A. Scott Berg. (Knopf, $24.95.) The life of the pioneering motion picture producer. 12 6 5 OUT OF THE BLUE, by Orel Hershiser with Jerry B. Jenkins. (Wolgemuth & Hyatt, $17.95.) The autobiography of the Los Angeles Dodgers' pitcher. 13 1 YOGI: It Ain't Over . . ., by Yogi Berra with Tom Horton. (McGraw-Hill, $18.95.) The reminiscences and witticisms of the baseball catcher, manager and coach. 1 4 1 NOT THAT YOU ASKED . . ., by Andrew A. Rooney. (Random House, $15.95.) More than 200 essays on as many topics by the journalist and television personality. 15 8 17 BLIND FAITH, by Joe McGinniss. (Putnam, $21.95.) The family tragedy that came to light after the 1984 murder of a Toms River, N.J., woman. Weeks This Last On Week Week List Advice, How-to and Miscellaneous 1 1 4 GOING WITHIN, by Shirley MacLaine. (Bantam, $18.95.) A ''guide for inner transformation'' through meditation. 2 1 THE T-FACTOR DIET, by Martin Katahn. (Norton, $18.95.) A new regimen for weight loss. 3 2 98 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level. 4 3 17 WEALTH WITHOUT RISK, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) A Florida entrepreneur's advice about how to make a personal fortune. 5 14 THE WAY THINGS WORK, by David Macaulay. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.95.) Explanations in pictures and text. These listings are based on computer-processed sales figures from 3,000 bookstores and from representative wholesalers with more than 28,000 other retail outlets, including variety stores and supermarkets. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) IF THE RIVER WAS WHISKEY, by T. Coraghessan Boyle. (Viking, $17.95.) Many strange people and beings, including the Devil, show up and exhibit themselves in Mr. Boyle's new collection of daring, irreverent and (now and then) deeply moving short stories. WILLIAM FAULKNER: AMERICAN WRITER. A Biography, by Frederick R. Karl. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $37.50.) A whopping (1,131 pages) work of scholarship that explores in depth the paradox-ridden conservative Southern modernist and his work. THE ENIGMA OF JAPANESE POWER: People and Politics in a Stateless Nation, by Karel van Wolferen. (Knopf, $24.95.) A Dutch journalist with long experience in Japan finds the economic juggernaut politically rudderless and its future endangered. DOUGLAS MacARTHUR: The Far Eastern General, by Michael Schaller. (Oxford University, $22.50.) A one-sided but nevertheless powerful case against a general whose skill at image manipulation may have exceeded his military competence. AGAINST JOIE DE VIVRE: Personal Essays, by Phillip Lopate. (Poseidon, $18.95.) There's a grouchy crust on Mr. Lopate, all right, but fun breaks through, and the prevailing tone of these essays is that of a mind taking fresh thought for itself.
