THE CROSSWINDS OF FREEDOM: The American Experiment.

title: ADVISER TO BUSH GETS H.U.D. SUBSIDY
description: A top campaign strategist for both President Bush and Ronald Reagan is benefiting from a Federal housing subsidy progam that is under investigation because of the large number of prominent Republicans who have been able to obtain millions of dollars in payments as consultants or developers.

title: Something For the Fans
description: Baseball memorabilia may be big business these days, but not every player is cashing in on the opportunity to sell everything from autographs to uniforms.

title: The Mommy Track vs. the Fast Track
description: The January-February issue of the Harvard Business Review contained an article by Felice N. Schwartz, president of Catalyst, a not-for-profit research and advisory organization that works with companies to advance the careers of women. The article, called ''Management Women and the New Facts of Life,'' contained a number of provocative ideas, including the assertion that it costs companies more to employ women than men. The reason it costs more, according to Ms. Schwartz, is that women have greater turnover than men in similar management positions. In addition, women's careers are often interrupted - or ended - when they have children.

title: AMERICAN MODELS TAKE THE ROUGH TERRAIN
description: Imports may be dominating the United States bicycle market, but domestic bike makers are finding ways to stay in the race.

title: Catherine Mary McMahon Marries Thomas Toomey
description: Catherine Mary McMahon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles F. McMahon of West Orange, N.J., was married there yesterday to Thomas Michael Toomey, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas E. Toomey of Manchester, Conn. Msgr. Harrold J. Murray performed the ceremony at St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church.

title: An Unbalanced Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The United States does not have an automatic call on our resources. There is no mindset that puts this country first.'' - Cyrill Siewert, chief financial officer at the Colgate-Palmolive Company. [ 1:1. ]

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Stanford; Student Channel Tries Gay Version Of 'Dating Game'
description: As tension mounted in the audience, the host on X-TV, Stanford University's student-run television channel, informed the game-show participant that she would have 30 seconds to pick one of three fellow students to take out on a date.

title: Monique Vos Weds Arthur Merrill Jr.
description: Monique Jeannette Vos, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arend Willem Daniel Vos of Pittsburgh and Paris, was married yesterday to Arthur Cushman Merrill Jr., a son of Mrs. David J. Mahoney of New York, Bridgehampton, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla., and Mr. Merrill of Locust Valley, L.I., and Boston. The Rev. Dr. F. Morgan Roberts, a Presbyterian minister, officiated at the Duquesne Club in Pittsburgh.

title: WRITERS BEWARE WRITERS
description: What an experience it must have been to be friends with Henry James, a man whose standards of behavior were almost ineffable, who might well have quailed under the brutal impact of a simple declarative sentence. Just to hear him out would have required a heroic patience. Yet it must have been wonderful, too, his incredible scrupulosity that pursued every thought to the end of its tether. A friendship like a gorgeous paranoia.

title: Cities Move to Curb Summer Crime Increase
description: Local and Federal law-enforcement officials say they fear that drug-related violence, which has already reached new heights this year, will climb this summer in several major cities. In anticipation, many cities are planning special efforts to curb crime, from outreach programs to putting more officers in drug-ravaged neighborhoods.

title: Clare Cullen Weds
description: Clare Danielle Cullen and William Francis Zelenka, assistant district attorneys in the Bronx, were married yesterday at St. Anastasia Roman Catholic Church in Douglaston, Queens. The Rev. Joseph N. Grisaitis performed the ceremony. Mrs. Zelenka, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph Cullen of Douglaston, graduated from New York University and the St. John's University School of Law. Mr. Zelenka, a graduate of Clark University and the Brooklyn Law School, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frank Zelenka of Closter, N.J.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article in Long Island Weekly today discusses free weekly newspapers, including This Week, a publication of Chanry Communications Ltd.

title: PASTIMES: Numismatics
description: A reader writes ''I would like to know whom I can contact as to the value of a number of gold coins.''

title:
BODY AND MIND;
Tempo of the Heart
description: LEAD: MEDICAL STUDENTS memorize more than facts.

title: Jerseyans' Sculpture Is Banned
description: LEAD: A SCULPTURE by three New Jersey artists protesting terrorism and artistic censorship has been banned from an exhibition at a New York City building.

title: Song of the Fat Lady
description: FAT people of the world, unite. A crisis is imminent. Every magazine, newspaper, and television show you see screams the evils of fat and the beauty of ''thin.'' Unless we react to this crisis, we may have nothing to gain and everything to lose. We must remain on guard.

title: This Versatile Stereo Receiver Adapts to Changing Habitats
description: The close resemblance between different brands of stereo receivers is easily explained. Their manufacturers mostly imitate each other, which is the safe and sensible thing to do in the absence of a better idea. Occasionally, however, a flash of originality sets certain models apart. A case in point is the expandable receiver by Rotel, a company renowned in Britain and lately gaining deserved recognition in this country.

title: Michele Cameron Is a Bride
description: At the First Presbyterian Church in Rumson, N.J., Michele Diane Cameron, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul A. Cameron of Rumson and Key Largo, Fla., was married yesterday to Edwin Poulton 2d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin Poulton of Columbus, Ohio.

title: Susan Bugarija Is a Bride
description: Susan I. Bugarija and Juerg Grimm were married yesterday at the Croatian Roman Catholic Church of St. Raphael in New York. The Revs. Marko Puljic and Grgo Sikiric performed the ceremony. Mrs. Grimm, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Bugarija of Dongan Hills, S.I., is a vice president of Kidder, Peabody & Company in New York. She is a magna cum laude graduate of St. John's University, where she also received an M.B.A. degree. Mr. Grimm, a son of Mrs. Thea Grimm of Winterthur, Switzerland, and the late Max Grimm, is an investment manager of United States pension funds at S.B.C. Portfolio Management International in New York. He graduated from the Business School of Administration in Zurich.

title: POSTINGS: Jersey Farmland Development; Houses Amid Rolling Hills
description: When James Pitney took title to his brother Jonathan's farm in 1771, the property was one of the most extensive in northern New Jersey. It had been assembled by Pitneys since the first of them, also named James, settled in the area earlier in the century. There was little more around then than gently rolling hills, woodlands and meadows, criss-crossed here and there by streams and by narrow, winding paths.

title: April Tax Receipts Brighten 1989 Federal Deficit Outlook
description: Unexpectedly strong income tax payments pouring into the Treasury are prompting analysts to predict that the Government's budget deficit this year may be below official projections.

title: Gunman Kills Four Children And Himself in Ohio House
description: A man shot and killed four children, then used the gun to kill himself this morning, the police said.

title: For a Defense That Makes Sense
description: IT IS NO SECRET THAT THE NATO Alliance, which celebrates its 40th birthday next week, is going through a midlife crisis. For more than a month now, Americans and Germans have been locked in a loud cross-Atlantic argument over the alliance's short-range nuclear missiles in Europe, one that is likely to continue at the North Atlantic Treaty Organization's coming meeting in Brussels. On the surface, the point at issue is whether the Atlantic alliance should negotiate with the Soviet Union over the future of these missiles; but the argument goes deeper, to differences within the alliance over how to deal with Mikhail S. Gorbachev's Soviet Union. It is, in short, about the alliance's future.

title: Take Me to Your Leader
description: Imagine that an alien spaceship approached Earth and sent the message: ''Take me to your leader.'' Who would that be? Without doubt, Mikhail Sergeyevich Gorbachev.

title: Julia Carpenter, Lawyer, Is Wed
description: Julia Moore Carpenter and Paul Gerard Wolfteich, graduates of the College of William and Mary, were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in Hendersonville, N.C., by the Rev. John Coffee Neville Jr., assisted by the Rev. Art Bromschwig, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Outdoors; Spinning Tales of Techniques
description: If the magazine maintains its pace, ''Fly Fishing Quarterly'' will please those who cannot resist seeking better ways to catch a wide variety of fresh -and saltwater fish with tackle that less than 40 years ago was generally confined to the pursuit of trout, Atlantic salmon and, to a lesser degree, smallmouth bass.

title: A New Place for Meat Binges
description: BEEF and pork sales may be down, but many people still have the occasional urge for a meat binge, often especially for an old-fashioned, Southern-style barbecue spree.

title: PORTRAITS OF THE ARTISTS
description: MICHELANGELO'S WORLD Written and illustrated by Piero Ventura. Unpaged. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons. MEET EDGAR DEGAS By Anne Newlands. Illustrated. Unpaged. New York: J. B. Lippincott. $13.95. (Ages 8 to 11) THE ART LESSON Written and illustrated by Tomie dePaola. Unpaged. New York: G. P. Putnam's Sons.

title: Reviews/Music; Jamie Avins's Constructions
description: Jamie Avins is an architectural choreographer. That was evident from the clear-cut gestures of ''Center and Circumference,'' the program she presented Thursday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater. It was even more apparent in the sets she designed for her productions. The environments in which her dancers found themselves affected the ways in which they moved. Occasionally the scenic devices even threatened to overwhelm the choreography.

title: Vatican Assures Jews on Relocation of Convent at Auschwitz
description: The Cardinal who oversees Catholic-Jewish relations for the Vatican has assured Jewish leaders of his conviction that a Carmelite convent established in 1984 on the site of the Auschwitz death camp will be relocated.

title: How the Iran-Contra Affair Came Back to Bush
description: IN this city, all ideas are reduced, sooner or later, to personalities. So it is that the persistent doubts about the role of President Bush in the Iran-contra affair have come to be embodied, at least for the moment, in the travails of Donald P. Gregg.

title: Fringes, Fairness and Taxes
description: Section 89 of the tax code, little known to the public, has become a famous horror for employers. Its purpose is simple enough: to regulate taxation of health insurance provided by employers. But along the way, Section 89 got ferociously complex. Corporations growled. Some even dropped health insurance entirely rather than put up with the hassle of dealing with the Internal Revenue Service. Then the Treasury Department wisely postponed enforcement until Oct. 1.

title: Health Efforts Widen on a Fetal Danger
description: WHEN Joanne B. learned that she was pregnant, she was determined to have a healthy baby. She quit smoking. She stopped taking over-the-counter cold medicines. She sought medical advice about drinking and was assured that ''one drink won't hurt.''

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Chicopee, Mass.;
From Air Base To Mixed Use
description: LEAD: A PROPOSAL to convert 190 acres of city-owned property on a former military base here to mixed uses at a cost of $125 million was approved last week by officials of this onetime mill town on the Connecticut River.

title: Reviews/Dance; Feet Provide the Music In Tharp's 'Fugue'
description: One of the uncertain aspects about Twyla Tharp's new association with American Ballet Theater came into play Friday night when the company presented ''The Fugue'' for the first time in New York, at the Metropolitan Opera House.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu; Stuffed Papaya Halves Hold a Bounty of Spices
description: Years ago a variation of this recipe was served at the Mauna Kea Resort in Hawaii. At the time it was impossible to buy papayas on the East Coast, so pineapple made an acceptable substitute. Today, papayas are almost as common as bananas in supermarkets, and they are the best choice for this simple dish. It makes a grand brunch with muffins, or a light supper served with bread. It can be made ahead and refrigerated for up to two days. Stuffed Papaya 1/4 teaspoon ground coriander 1/2 to 3/4 teaspoon cumin 1 cup low-fat cottage cheese 1 cup cream cheese 2 teaspoons dry vermouth 1/2 teaspoon curry powder 2 tablespoons chopped chutney 2 tablespoons golden or dark raisins 1/3 cup water chestnuts, sliced very thin 2 ripe papayas, cut in half and seeded.

title: SCIENCE FICTION
description: There was a time - after H. G. Wells and before the advent of paperback novels - when the best science fiction appeared in the form of magazine stories. However brief, these stories dealt with big issues: human nature (in the guise of the alien), human strengths and weaknesses (in the guise of technology), human destiny (in the guise of evolution). That the authors' reach usually exceeded their grasp should come as no surprise; but at least they were never guilty of padding - a flaw so common to today's multivolume interstellar epics that a reader must husk through page after page of stultifying verbiage for a few fresh kernels of insight and invention.

title: A Healthy Brubeck Keeps the Jazz Flowing
description: DAVE BRUBECK is back, restored to health and hard at work. Mr. Brubeck, the 69-year-old jazz pianist, composer and lecturer, underwent quadruple-bypass surgery at Yale-New Haven Hospital in February, was back performing two months later and now is working in the studio at his Wilton home on new pieces both sacred and secular.

title:
GARDENING;
Alternatives to a Well-Manicured Lawn
description: LEAD: MANY gardeners are having second thoughts about lawns. They are the most extravagant users of time, energy and water in the landscape.

title: Inflation's Web
description: To the Editor:

title: Gail L. Blaustein Is Wed to a Lawyer
description: Gail Lauren Blaustein, an assistant vice president of telecommunications for the Continental Insurance Company in Neptune, N.J., was married last evening to Marc P. Weingarten, a partner in the Philadelphia law firm of Greitzer & Locks. Rabbi Gerald Wolpe officiated at Har Zion Synagogue in Penn Valley, Pa.

title: CHAOS AND CONFUSTICATION
description: NONSTOP NONSENSE By Margaret Mahy. Illustrated by Quentin Blake. 120 pp. New York: Margaret K. McElderry Books.

title: Corina Noel Wed To a Consultant
description: St. Catherine of Siena Roman Catholic Church in Riverside, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Corina Noel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Walter M. Noel Jr. of Greenwich, Conn., and Andres Piedrahita, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Piedrahita of Bogota, Colombia. The Rev. Mark Connolly officiated.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester; New Britain Changing Its Collar to White
description: ONCE an ailing industrial center that was the butt of vaudeville jokes, New Britain has been discovered by office developers. They are drawn to the city's recently enhanced telephone system, a potential labor pool of disgruntled commuters, one of the best mass transit systems in the state and an urban renewal area that has been designated an enterprise zone.

title: Sullivan Is In
description: With his fractured right forearm cushioned in a plastic brace, steering was somewhat awkward and the fit was a bit tight, but nine days after he broke his arm in a practice-run crash, Danny Sullivan squeezed into his backup Penske-Chevrolet race car yesterday and qualified for next Sunday's Indianapolis 500.

title: JAM FOR TEA, CHURCH ON SUNDAY
description: PACK OF CARDS And Other Stories. By Penelope Lively. 323 pp. New York: Grove Press. $19.95.

title: BLURRING THE LINE BETWEEN FACT AND FICTION
description: As a television commodity, ''reality'' is being packaged for market faster than sneaker commercials these days. Major based-on-fact network movies in the last few weeks have included ''A Deadly Silence'' with its account of an incest case in Long Island, ''Guts and Glory'' and its version of the rise and fall of Oliver North, and ''Roe v. Wade'' tracing the background of the landmark Supreme Court decision on abortion.

title: WHAT, ME ANGRY?
description: I believe that Maggie Scarf's concluding suggestion in ''What, Me Angry?'' (Hers column: April 23), that she deal with her anger by taking a Valium, was meant in jest; however, I feel the joke may be lost on many. As a society, we tend to accept the idea of medicating our feelings - if not with Valium, then with alcohol.

title: A Gesture To the 'Good' Rockefeller Center
description: Almost everybody loves Rockefeller Center, or at least the original part of it constructed in the 1930's between Fifth Avenue and the Avenue of the Americas. This is not just a cluster of buildings in New York City: it is a national symbol of distinguished corporate design, far and away the finest grouping of skyscrapers ever built. Rockefeller Center has been the model for dozens of complexes around the world, but not one of them has come up to its quality.

title: Lotto Is Financed by the Poor and Won by the States
description: THE happiest person in Pennsylvania last month may have been Alverta Handel, a housekeeper from the town of Portage who beat 9.6 million-to-one odds to win an $8.2 million share of the record-breaking $115 million lotto jackpot. But the biggest winner by far in Pennsylvania's lottery is the state treasury, which last year netted $593 million from ticket sales.

title: Giuliani, Riding High, Faces Some Tripwires Set by His Enemies
description: IT'S not easy being the sheriff in the white hat. As Rudolph W. Giuliani, one of the most aggressive Federal prosecutors in New York City in many years, finally strode into the shoot-out for Mayor last week wearing his anti-crime and anti-corruption badges, some of his enemies had already circled the wagons.

title: COOL HEAD, HOT IMAGES
description: IN THE MINUTES BEFORE the first public test-screening of Brian De Palma's new movie at a theater in Boston, a young man approaches Steven Spielberg, De Palma's friend and fellow director who is sitting in the audience with a baseball cap pulled down over his brow, and asks him if he is Steven Spielberg.

title: The Past Needs to Look Ahead
description: After one calling-card concert, it is too soon to say with confidence that the arrival of Trevor Pinnock's Classical Band has filled a gap in New York's musical picture. The space, however, is certainly there waiting: until now we have not had an opportunity to hear with regularity how the late-18th- and early-19th-century orchestral repertory sounds on period instruments when played by professional musicians immersed in the practices of the Classical era.

title: Lisa Ranieri, a Social Worker, Marries
description: Lisa Anne Ranieri, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. S. Anthony Ranieri of Oceanside, L.I., was married last evening to Peter Jakobson Jr., a son of Mrs. Alan Denzer of Greenwich, Conn., and Mr. Jakobson of New York and Elberon, N.J. Rabbi Albert L. Sturmer and the Rev. Dr. Melvin Hawthorne, a Baptist minister and the chaplain at the Church Center for the United Nations, officiated at the Century Country Club in Purchase, N.Y.

title: Financial Decision
description: When Oral Roberts University withdrew from the National Collegiate Athletic Association earlier this month, the official explanation was offered by the basketball coach, Ken Trickey. He said the switch to the low-key National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics was strictly a financial decision to save the beleaguered university $500,000 to $1 million a year.

title: The Vanishing Contractor
description: ALL I said was: ''Do you think we ought to enclose our porch?''

title: Boom in Movies Brings Profit to Towns and Fame to Neightbors
description: IN 1979, the film director Mark Rydell visited Connecticut to scout out a location for a movie about a retired college professor and his wife who live on a tranquil New England pond. Convinced that the Inn on Lake Waramaug in New Preston fit the script's setting, Mr. Rydell contacted the state's tourism office to find out how he could rent the property.

title: Kids + Restaurants - A Growing Trend
description: WHEN JACK JELENKO AND HIS wife, Margaret, dine out near their home in Sonoma County, California, their priorities are not always titillating cuisine or an enchanting atmosphere. Rather, they tend to look for a place where tables are uncluttered, service is rapid-fire and much of the food is plain and familiar. The Jelenkos are not unromantic or finicky eaters - they are simply realistic, for they often bring along their restless and resolute sons, Jamie, who is 3 years old, and Jon, who is 4 1/2.

title: Hair Care At the Dream Factory
description: I just became a first-time customer of Nubest Hair Salon [ ''About Long Island: The Dream Factory,'' April 30 ] . The owner is obviously a manager in the classic, textbook sense of the word, and does have a monopoly of providing service.

title: Giamatti Playing Position Strictly by the Book
description: The first time Bart Giamatti was approached by a handful of baseball owners interested in making him their commissioner, he declined, but burned no bridges. Instead, he made it clear to any owners within earshot that talking with them from soup to nuts about baseball was his idea of Eden.

title: For 7 Palestinians Accused in the Uprising, Common Thread Is Journalism
description: In a military court outside Tel Aviv, seven Palestinians are being tried on charges of leading the Palestinian uprising, and they have at least one thing in common: every one is a journalist.

title: CONSUMER RATES
DRAWING ON THE DARK SIDE
description: Today's comic books cater to an older audience - the same audience that sees acts of sex and violence shown nightly on the news. To call for the whitewashing of such events in any form of literature is a denial of the world we live in today, and a form of censorship. At least in the fictional world of comic books, the bad guys usually get their just deserts. ROBERT KIRK Norcross, Ga.

title: DIONYSUS IN THE OUTBACK
description: LEAD: THE GROTTO By Coral Lansbury. 538 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Brielle $515,000 925 Cole Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 30-year-old ranch; sun porch, rear patio, 2-car garage, 2 acres; taxes $5,358. Maplewood $255,000 55 Highland Avenue 4-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 13-year-old split level; c/a, dining room, full basement; taxes $5,920. Mount Arlington $184,000 678 Reba Road 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, year-old ranch; eat-in kitchen, hardwood floors, close to beach; taxes $2,777. Jersey City $148,880 343 Sip Avenue 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 24-year-old ranch; new kitchen, c/a, hardwood floors; taxes $2,342. South Orange $155,000 366 Meeker Street 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 34-year old Cape Cod; finished basement, dining room, 1-car garage; taxes $3,276. Springfield $359,500 3 Shadow Lawn Drive 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 21-year-old colonial; fireplace, Florida room, eat-in kitchen; taxes $5,668. OTHER AREAS Darien, Conn. $539,000 23 Blueberry Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 32-year-old farmhouse; golf-course view, 2 decks, 1.3 acres; taxes $4,534. Bedford, N.Y. $442,500 10 Ferris Lane 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 9-year-old colonial; fireplace, finished basement, deck, 2-car garage; taxes $5,997. New Hyde Park, L.I. $330,000 81 Lee Avenue 5-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 20-year-old splanch; family room, dining room, 2-car garage; taxes $4,800.

title: Correction
description: A caption last Sunday about Elaine Benson, an art gallery owner, misidentified the sculpture beside her. It was ''Young Venus'' by Molly Mason.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Life hasn't been easy these past few weeks. Walking in rain that seemed almost constant required not only agility but also planning - and a dash of prescience. The reservoirs may now be in good shape, but pedestrians are still recovering from maneuvering on walking surfaces that turned into wet battlefields.

title: EVERY KID NEEDS A FRIEND
description: NED AND THE JOYBALOO By Hiawyn Oram. Illustrated by Satoshi Kitamura. Unpaged. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

title: Tanning Units Tied to Injuries
description: Devices used in cosmetic tanning have caused skin burns and eye injuries and could cause skin cancer, the Federal Centers for Disease Control says.

title: Putting Spaceship Earth on Course
description: OIL, air and water do not readily mix, but problems related to them do. Each one represents a growing ecological concern, a problem in themselves, but in combination a threat to our quality of life and standard of living. As an evolving conservationist, I feel that our current problems can only grow worse if we choose to ignore them.

title: The Annual Event: Family Cookout On Long Island
description: THE YEARLY CLAMBAKE, ONE OF TWO annual McGuinness family reunions, began at dawn on a typically foggy late-July morning in Lloyd Harbor on the North Shore of Long Island. By 6 A.M., with the mist settling on top of the trees, 6 of the 31 people who would ultimately cram into the McGuinness house on this day had set off to comb the beach at Cold Spring Harbor for mussels. Ten minutes later, with persistent gnats chewing away, a chorus of voices pleaded for relief. But it took a half-hour before sufficient mussels, 75, could be gathered.

title: At C.L.&P., Steps To Keep the Power On
description: Robert A. Hamilton's article on April 30, entitled ''Utility Blackout Report Bleak,'' quite fairly pointed out the simple reality that 1988 was a very bad year for customer outages on the distribution system of the Connecticut Light & Power Company.

title: A Wilderness Named for the Gods
description: DEEP inside the Olympic rain forest on the far western edge of the continent, there is not a fingerprint of the 20th century, nor the 18th century for that matter. The trees in this part of world were seedlings when Leif Ericson stumbled upon Greenland a thousand years ago; they were mature firs when Columbus landed in the Caribbean islands and towering giants when the Declaration of Independence was signed.

title: DRAWING ON THE DARK SIDE
description: Joe Queenan might have added a little light by reporting that Marvel also publishes inspiring comics, such as ''Mother Teresa of Calcutta'' and ''The Life of Pope John-Paul II.'' Marvel Comics should also be given credit for casting light on such subjects as drugs and child abuse, through a series of free instructional comic books. JOHN TARTAGLIONE Centerport, L.I.

title: Reviews/Music; Authentic Gershwin
description: The Harmonie Ensemble celebrated its 10th anniversary on Tuesday evening with an Alice Tully Hall concert devoted mostly to music by George Gershwin. The performances were offered in the spirit of authenticity, in the sense that several of the works typically heard in posthumous rescorings were performed here in their original versions.

title: Elderhostel: Learning As You Go
description: THOUGH low-cost camping, educational and vacation opportunities have been available to elderly people in various parts of the country for some time, a Boston-based program called Elderhostel has drawn a greatly increasing number of participants and institutions in recent years.

title: Bradford Holmes Wed To Katherine H. Hax
description: Katherine Heileman Hax and Bradford Jameson Holmes were married yesterday at the Nichols United Methodist Church in Trumbull, Conn. The Rev. Harold V. W. Vink performed the ceremony.

title: DATA UPDATE: May 21, 1989
Elizabeth Medford Wed in Delaware
description: Elizabeth Wetherill Medford, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. William L. Medford Jr. of Centreville, Del., was married at her parents' home yesterday to Thomas Brenner Mester, a son of Mrs. Franklyn D. Church of Roslyn Heights, L.I., and Jack W. Mester of West Palm Beach, Fla. Rosalie S. Obara, the Clerk of the Peace of New Castle County, Del., officiated.

title: Thorn Welden Married
description: At St. John's Episcopal Church in Pine Meadow, Conn., Thorn Thenebe Welden was married yesterday to Ivan Valev Ivanoff, a son of Mrs. Kapka M. Nedeva of Sofia, Bulgaria, by the Rev. Richard A. Ellis. The bride, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Richard C. Welden of New York, is a consultant on rare books in London. The bridegroom is a consultant on nonferrous metals at the London office of E.N.I., an industrial conglomerate in Rome.

title: Samuel J. Landau, Developer, 80
description: Samuel J. Landau, a New York real-estate developer, died of cardiac arrest yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Juilliard; Trumpets Herald A Rite of Spring For Music Makers
description: The life of a classical musician can be all play. Last week at the Juilliard School in Manhattan was no exception. After a grueling exam week of singing and playing for their professors, Juilliard students played some more.

title: Trial in Spain on Toxic Cooking Oil Ends in Uproar
description: Amid angry protests from a crowded courtroom, three Spanish judges dismissed murder charges today against distributors of an adulterated cooking oil that was found to have caused almost 700 deaths since a mass poisoning disaster occurred here in 1981.

title: STRANGE LIGHTS IN ANCIENT STREETS
description: SUMMER IN THE STREET OF THE PROPHETS and A VOYAGE TO UR OF THE CHALDEES Novels One and Two of ''The Palace of Shattered Vessels.'' By David Shahar. Translated by Dalya Bilu. 434 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $22.50.

title: Miss Finlayson Weds L. G. DeGarmo
description: The marriage of Sarah Jean Finlayson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Finlayson of Ponte Vedra, Fla., to Lindley Grant DeGarmo, a son of Elsie DeGarmo Smith of Pine Plains, N.Y., and the late Lindley S. DeGarmo, took place yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church in New York. The Rev. Dr. Kenneth Jones performed the ceremony.

title: Raising Caine In the Kitchen
description: IN A MOVIE CAREER SPANNING MORE THAN 30 years and films from A (for ''Alfie'') to Z (for ''Zulu''), the 56-year-old Michael Caine has played everything from foppish Victorian officers to cold-war spies and contemporary con men. But there is one role he has never played: chef. That he reserves for his private life.

title: Some Fits and Starts In Crossroads 'Spooks'
description: IN ''Spooks,'' at the Crossroads Theater Company, Howard and Karen are an upwardly mobile black couple. In their BMW, they have driven from New York to the Virginia mansion - ''the dream house'' - that Howard purchased. It's late at night, which is just the time to move into ''a big old house in the middle of nowhere.'

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: New Times Square Hotels; 3 Hostelries to Join the Marquis, a Hit on Broadway
description: A HOTEL construction boom surpassing any that Times Square has seen in more than half a century is now under way, and by late next year three new hotels will be competing with one prosperous pioneer, the Marriott Marquis, which opened four years ago amid predictions that the area's seedy reputation would do it in.

title: Stamping Out the Fire Of Religious Violence Is as Hopeless as Ever
description: LATE last month, three members of an outlawed Protestant terrorist group from Northern Ireland were arrested in Paris for trying to sell a South African diplomat a British-made antiaircraft missile, presumably in exchange for supplies of weapons and ammunition.

title: Sunday Silence Wins Preakness by Nose
description: Sunday Silence, who raised more questions than he answered when he beat Easy Goer by two and a half lengths in the Kentucky Derby two weeks ago, proved himself a worthy Triple Crown contender today by winning the 114th and closest Preakness Stakes ever at Pimlico Race Course. The blackish colt from California raced head and head with Easy Goer for the length of the stretch before regaining the lead in the final yards to win by a long nose.

title: Diplomats Say China Is Mired in Crisis It Could Have Averted
description: A former American Ambassador to China said today that the Beijing Government was making ''a stupid and potentially tragic mistake'' by trying to suppress demonstrations by students demanding greater democracy.

title: ON THE ROAD TO 'DUMBO'
description: BILL PEET An Autobiography. Written and Illustrated by Bill Peet. 190 pp. Boston: Houghton Mifflin Company.

title: Penn Breezes on the Charles
description: Pennsylvania's heavyweight crew swept the Burk Cup regatta against Northeastern and guest entrant Stanford today, making the rigors of the 2,000-meter pull look effortless.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
A 450-Unit Golf Community for Neptune
description: LEAD: CONSTRUCTION is expected to begin this summer on Neptune's first planned residential community. With little land left for housing, the project, Heritage Village at Jumping Brook, may also be the last sizable residential development in the 8-square-mile southern Monmouth County township.

title:
GARDENING;
Alternatives to a Well-Manicured Lawn
description: LEAD: MANY gardeners are having second thoughts about lawns. They are the most extravagant users of time, energy and water in the landscape.

title: From Yellowstone Ashes, New Life and Approach
description: It is the spring after the fires in Yellowstone Park, and as the snow melts on the high ridges and the mountain flanks, new life is stirring among the ruins.

title: WHO'S TO JUDGE?
description: DR. ELIZABETH MORGAN, 41 YEARS OLD, A HAR-vard-, Oxford- and Yale-educated plastic surgeon and author of four books, adjusts a recalcitrant snap on her orange prison jumpsuit, leans forward in the glass-walled room of the Washington, D.C., jail and explains a decision she made that sent her to prison 21 months ago: ''I had to face the fact that for one year I sent my child off to her rapist.'' She is referring to her former husband, Dr. Eric A. Foretich.

title: Stab in the Back
description: FAMILIAR PHRASES can have hidden resonances; a figure of speech can be innocent to me but drive you right up the wall. Take >stab in the back.

title:
ART;
Hudson River Nature by Day, but Victoriana in the Evening
description: LEAD: AN exhibition about the life styles of Hudson River School painters is almost inevitable, given the way interest in 19th-century American landscape has soared in recent years. The Hudson River Museum of Westchester is the host to that exhibition, seemingly a companion to last year's investigation of artistic life in the

title: The Cure Provides Company for Misery
description: In rock's commercial sweepstakes, the Cure might seem to be a sure bet for also-ran. The British band's songs are an anatomy of melancholy, breaking now and then into anger or delirium; its lead singer and lyricist, Robert Smith, has a strangulated, whiny yelp of a voice. Even when the band rouses itself for an uptempo song, Mr. Smith sounds panicky, desperate, his voice breaking again and again as he strains to get his words across.

title: PRESENT AT THE ASSASSINATION
description: IMPOSSIBLE DREAM The Marcoses, the Aquinos, and the Unfinished Revolution. By Sandra Burton. 483 pp. New York: Warner Books. $24.95.

title: Green Shows Signs of the Agony of Defeat
description: Through the early losses and the inconsistency of play and the growing discontent in the clubhouse, Dallas Green has remained unchanged. The face, the demeanor and the hard-line approach are the same today as they were in February or March, when the Yankees showed their first signs of unsteadiness.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;
Driver, Thy Name Is Vanity
description: LEAD: ONE look at the back of a family car on the Long Island Expressway is worth a thousand Dun & Bradstreet ratings. Follow a car for half a mile and you find out more about the owner than an F.B.I. background check. Bumper stickers, for example, proclaim the owner's intentions to the world (''I Brake for Aliens'') or which candidate he supports ('

title: SPORTS DISCOUNTERS BET ON BETTER BRANDS- AND SERVICE
description: It's not just specialty shops that are changing as bicycle retailing gets more competitive. Sporting goods discount stores and mail-order outlets are transforming their trade, as well.

title: In Run for Ph.D., Costs and Hurdles Get Higher; Advisers Who Fail
description: To the Editor:

title: The S.E.C.'s Top Cop Moves On
description: On a spring day in 1986, after deflecting a series of hostile questions from a Congressional committee about corruption accompanying the mergers that were sweeping through corporate America, several senior staff members of the Securities and Exchange Commission piled into a cab to head back to their offices.

title: 'Your Children Are Calling to You for Help'
description: RECENTLY, while experimenting with a form of prose bordering on minimalist fiction, I wrote a story about two girls who were pushed to the edge of nervous breakdowns by problems within their families. I am proud of that story; it has moved some readers to tears and caused others to remark that they thought it had been written by someone older than my 17-year-old self.

title: Flames' Goalie Is Beaten And Beat
description: It was not a good time to be a goaltender.

title: In Stamford Exhibit, Art Imitates Life
description: THE Stamford Museum and Nature Center was not idly named, for its founders' purpose was to point up the symbiotic relationship between art and the living world. But visitors unaware of this can easily be detained by nature at the bottom of the hill - farm animals and the lake with its contingent of ducks and Canada geese.

title: SCANDAL UNNERVES JAPAN'S TOP PARTY
description: Faced with the possibility that they could lose control of Japan's political system for the first time in three decades, leaders of Japan's ruling party have embraced measures that would require politicians to disclose their financial assets and would abolish intraparty factions.

title: A Centennial Effort to Add Cancer Unit
description: PORT CHESTER, February 1889. Fourteen Port Chester matrons, concerned over the plight of the sick and infirm in the community, form the Ladies Hospital Association, ''to serve humanity, to save lives and to relieve suffering.'' During the next several months they hold cake sales, lawn fetes and entertainments until they raise enough money to rent space for a hospital.

title: In Run for Ph.D., Costs and Hurdles Get Higher
description: To the Editor:

title:
ART;
The Challenge of the Figure
description: LEAD: AT one time or another, every artist draws from the figure. Those who find the challenge absorbing are motivated by a desire to try their own interpretations of a classical theme and by a fascination with the variety of forms, postures, gestures and meanings that can be interwoven.

title: Cooking to Win
description: YOU ARE WHAT YOU SERVE.

title: BEWARE OF S-T-R-A-N-G-E-R-S
description: LEAD: USEFUL GIFTS By Carole L. Glickfeld. 209 pp. Athens: The University of Georgia Press. $14.95.

title: PETE BRAVADO'S WAR AND PEACE
description: BUFFALO AFTERNOON By Susan Fromberg Schaeffer. 535 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $19.95.

title: A Place to Rest When the Whirling and Music Ends
description: WHEN the New England Carousel Museum in Bristol opens tomorrow, youngsters will be able to glimpse a world that has almost disappeared.

title: A Club Comes In a Small Package
description: Tucked behind an unmarked stainless-steel door between a dry cleaner's and a bakery in the Yorkville section of Manhattan, a new ripple has appeared in the wave of New York night life.

title: Sad Ending as Knicks Miss Their Chance
description: It was Friday morning over breakfast. The Knicks were at Chicago Stadium preparing for the sixth game of their Eastern Conference semifinal. A loss to the Chicago Bulls would end the season, a victory would force a seventh game at Madison Square Garden.

title: Harry J. Donnelly, 68, Ex-Justice in New York
description: Harry J. Donnelly a retired acting justice of the New York Supreme Court and a former New York City Highway Commissioner, died of cancer yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 66 years old and lived in Breezy Point, Queens.

title: A SOVIET UPROAR OVER CORRUPTION
description: Two Soviet state prosecutors, in a defiant test of the new policy of openness, are causing an uproar with charges that the Kremlin is quashing their inquiry into state corruption that they say might reach all the way to the Politburo.

title: Blair W. Smith Wed in Florida To Miss Cassidy
description: St. Mark's Episcopal Church in Jacksonville, Fla., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Catherine Stirling Cassidy, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arch Wilson Cassidy, to Blair Webster Smith, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Kaye Smith of Potomac and Solomon's Island, Md., and John's Island, Fla. The Rt. Rev. Frank Stanley Cerveny, the Episcopal Bishop of Florida, and the Rev. Barnum Willis Coker McCarty officiated.

title: Prospects; A Trade Law With Teeth
description: By May 30, the trade representative, Carla Hills, must issue a list of countries that unfairly restrict United States imports. According to section 301 of the Omnibus Trade and Competitiveness Act of 1988, once a country is put on the list, the trade representative must begin negotiations to correct the unfair practices. Negotiations must be concluded within 18 months. If the offending country has not opened its markets within three years after the negotiations, the United States may then close its market to the offending country. Four experts assess the law, dubbed Super 301. Jerry K. Pearlman Chairman and president, Zenith Electronics Corporation.

title: Correction
description: A chart in some copies last Sunday about the New York City subways gave incorrect figures for ridership. The number of riders on an average weekday rose from 3.52 million in the first quarter of 1985 to 3.71 million in the same period this year.

title: THE BRUTALITY OF THE BRUTALIZED
description: FOR EVERY SIN By Aharon Appelfeld. Translated by Jeffrey M. Green. 168 pp. New York: Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $15.95.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Two years ago, we had a new stoop of reddish fieldstone built on top of our old concrete one. The mason advised us to coat it with a silicone sealer; however, I read that this was not needed and so I did not apply any. Now the stoop is gradually turning green. How can I remove this discoloration, and after that should I apply a sealer?

title: The Business of Etiquette
description: THE MANNERS MAVEN Letitia Baldrige likes to tell the tale of a hapless young executive who took one of his prized clients to lunch at a fancy restaurant. When the wine steward handed him the cork, a puzzled furrow came over the young man's executive brow. He then made an executive decision: He bit off a piece of the cork and ate it.

title: Question Of the Week; Was Mark Jackson Treated Fairly?
description: The fans did not boo Mark Jackson for missing a shot at a critical point in the first playoff game against Chicago. The fans have no other civilized way to express their disapproval for an incredibly dumb, egotistical attempt to hit a bomb with seven seconds left in a tie game. (He was closer to half court than he was to the three-point line.) His responsibility was to work the ball for a good shot. Until he understands that, he will not be as good as he thinks he is. GERALD STERN White Plains, N.Y.

title: GIRL AT THE WHEEL
description: HOW GEORGINA DROVE THE CAR VERY CAREFULLY FROM BOSTON TO NEW YORK By Lucy Bate. Illustrated by Tamar Taylor. Unpaged. New York: Crown Publishers. $12.95. (Ages 3 to 6)

title: Reunion in Virginia
description: THIS SUMMER, AS FOR THE LAST 30 years, the Spencer family will gather outside a farmhouse in Cullen, Va., west of Richmond. It was the family matriarch, Mary Spencer, who started the custom, according to her children. ''She felt that the family should get together at least once a year, and not just for a funeral, but when we could smile instead of being sad,'' said Earl, the youngest of her nine sons and daughters.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending May 6 MANHATTAN Chelsea $695,000 161 West 15th Street 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 2,100-sq.-ft. penthouse co-op in prewar loft building; dining area, maid's room, fireplace, hardwood floors, terrace; maintenance $1,100, 68% tax-deductible (Broker: Delson-Ginsberg Real Estate) Greenwich Village $960,000 77 Charles Street 4-family, 4-story brownstone; 2 bedrooms, 1 bath, large kitchen in each unit; north garden, original moldings and details, 20- by 95-ft. lot; taxes $6,270 (Broker: Ambrose Mar-Elia) Kips Bay Area $148,000 245 East 24th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 700-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, hardwood floors, balcony; maintenance $538, 42% tax-deductible (Broker: D.J. Knight) Upper West Side $307,500 290 West End Avenue (74th St.) 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 1,100-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, manned elevator, dining room, renovated, large kitchen; maintenance $800, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Klara Madlin Real Estate) Upper West Side $190,000 382 Central Park West (97th St.) (Olmstead) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 800-sq.-ft. postwar condo; 24-hr. doorman, dining el, terrace, partial Central Park view; common charge $300, taxes $1,320 (Broker: Eden Realty) Washington Heights $40,000 804 West 180th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 520-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; high-ceilings, hardwood floors, renovated lobby; maintenance $241, 39% tax-deductible (Broker: Robert Stein Real Estate) BRONX Einstein Hospital Area $135,000 1183 Sackett Avenue 3-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, detached frame house; dining room, finished basement, laundry room, detached 2-car garage, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,200 (Broker: Jacqueline Kyle Kall) Riverdale $160,000 3200 Netherland Avenue (Steven Lee) 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 950-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; dining foyer, remodeled kitchen, 4 exposures; maintenance $420, 60% tax-deductible (Broker: Marilyn & Morris B. Sopher) BROOKLYN Fort Greene $542,500 175 Lafayette Avenue 6-bedroom, 5-bath, single-family, 5-story, attached brownstone; dining room, large kitchen, 8 fireplaces, library, original moldings and details, 20- by 81-ft. lot; taxes $2,184 (Broker: William B. May) Prospect Heights $162,000 230 Park Place 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,400-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; part-time doorman, dining room, sunken living room, Manhattan skyline view; maintenance $508, 52% tax-deductible (Broker: Warren Lewis Realty) QUEENS Jackson Heights $270,000 24-34 78th Street 2-family, attached brick house; 2 bedrooms, dining room in primary unit; 1 bedroom in other; 1 bath, large kitchen in each; attached 1-car garage, rear patio, 22-by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,500 (Broker: Century 21/Metalios Real Estate) Jamaica $95,000 123-08 155th Street 2-bedroom, 1-bath, single-family, detached Cape Cod; dining room, large kitchen, detached 1-car garage, 40- by 99-ft. lot; taxes $683 (Broker: Century 21/Elms Realty) STATEN ISLAND Grymes Hill $77,500 16-B Arlo Road 2-bedroom, 1-bath, 650-sq. ft. postwar co-op; large kitchen, hardwood floors, optional garage space; maintenance $501, 65% tax-deductible (Broker: J. P. Walsh) Tottenville $219,000 221 Bedell Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, detached frame house; dining room, large kitchen, insulated windows, full basement, 1-car garage, rear deck, 78- by 325-ft. lot; taxes $900 (Broker: Weichert Realtors)

title: Donations to Fresh Air Fund Underwrite Summer Dreams
description: For Marisol Nina, this summer means returning to a farm in Granville, N.Y., and a reunion with a calf she adopted last year.

title: Miss Nahrwold Wed To J. E. Waesche 4th
description: St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan, Conn., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Nancy Ann Nahrwold, the daughter of Mrs. Morton Frederick Nahrwold of New Canaan, and the late Mr. Nahrwold, to Joseph Edward Waesche 4th, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Waesche 3d of Melville, L.I. The Rev. Roland Jones performed the ceremony.

title: People's Army, Faced by the People, May Be Opening a New Chapter
description: A new chapter seemed to open in the history of China's Army yesterday as students and others faced military units on Beijing's streets trying to persuade them not to interfere with the huge protests going on in the center of the capital.

title: Government Penalizes Nonprofit Groups
description: To the Editor:

title: HEALY ADDRESSES FORDHAM'S GRADUATES
description: ''It's good to be home,'' said the Rev. Timothy Healy as he addressed the 144th commencement of Fordham University.

title: Colleges Acting On Bias Issues
description: LEAD: UNDERGRADUATES at Westchester colleges are heading home for the summer but college officials are continuing their efforts to ease the racial tensions that prompted demonstrations at several local campuses earlier this year.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Ammirati Role In Bid for Boase
description: If the Omnicom Group succeeds in acquiring the Boase Massimi & Pollitt Partnership of Britain, it could result in Ammirati & Puris, Boase's chief American holding, buying back its independence.

title: Outburst In 10th Boosts Cards
description: The Cardinals scored five runs in the 10th inning today for a 6-1 victory, aided by an Atlanta error, but set up when Manager Whitey Herzog switched from a sacrifice to a hit-and-run.

title: Mystery of Harvard Square Dimes Solved
description: To the Editor:

title: 7 Crack Dilemmas in Search of an Answer
description: Public anger about drug dealers, street crime and violence is justifiable. But outrage will only get us so far. In thinking about what might work and what won't, we must appreciate the conundrums law-enforcement officers face when trying to combat crimes involving the sale of an illegal, highly addictive product.

title: Kings Win Lottery But Await Jackpot
description: Ever since the National Basketball Association started holding its lottery in 1985, the team that won usually unveiled a jersey with the name of the player it intended to make the first pick in the draft. But yesterday the Sacramento Kings added a twist to the tradition.

title: Stock Sales by Neuharth
description: Allen H. Neuharth, who retired on April 27 as the chairman of the Gannett Company, sold 193,550 Gannett shares earlier this month for $7.3 million.

title: Peter Evans, an Actor in Theater, Films and Television, Dies at 38
description: Peter Evans, an actor who originated leading roles in plays by David Rabe, David Mamet and Arthur Miller, died of complications from AIDS Saturday at Century City Hospital in Los Angeles. He was 38 years old.

title: Cellular Communications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included an $808,000 loss from early extinguishment of debt.

title: Cable Operators Worry About Feeling Too Good
description: Cable has never had it so good.

title: Campbell Soup Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included a credit of $32.5 million from the cumulative effect of an accounting. The company said last year's third quarter earnings were depressed by $30.8 million due to restructuring charges.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-12 The Chinese blocked new advances by the army, thwarting a crackdown on the democracy movement. Several dozen legislators began quietly preparing a strategy to revoke martial law. Page A1

title: Review/Ballet; Twyla Tharp's Champion Wears Boxing Trunks
description: There are two Twyla Tharps. One is the brainy and major American choreographer whose gift for putting movement together is second to none, and the other is Miss Tharp's worst enemy - herself.

title: Granges Exploration Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Since Martial Law, Protest Crackles With Fury at Deng
description: As daylight wanes, a defiant exuberance seems to swell among the throngs clogging the intersections along roadways leading to Beijing's central square. But in the small homes of the capital, in the moments shared by friends away from the comfort of the masses, the darker side of what it means to live under martial law emerges.

title: Chateau Stores of Canada Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Polls Show Contrasts in How Public and E.P.A. View Environment
description: The American public and the Environmental Protection Agency rank environmental threats quite differently, with the public's fear focused most sharply on hazardous waste sites that the Government views much less seriously, a pair of surveys show.

title: Sex Education: Too Little, Too Late
description: More than 85 percent of adult Americans say they favor sex education for school-age children. But are those children learning enough to live in a country that has experienced a sexual revolution? Their teachers say no. According to a new report from the Alan Guttmacher Institute, sex education instructors are somewhat more apt to teach about AIDS and protection from other sexually transmitted diseases than they are about birth control. The reason, they say, is pressure - from state education agencies and large school districts that would rather tell kids how to avoid diseases than how to avoid pregnancy.

title: Nancy Fischbein Is Wed in Boston
description: Nancy Jane Fischbein, who is to receive an M.D. degree next month from Harvard University, was married yesterday to Dr. Paul Richard Billings at the Ritz-Carlton in Boston by Rabbi Terry Bard.

title: Diane C. Aronson, Gemologist, Wed
description: Diane Carol Aronson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Louis V. Aronson 2d of Oldwick, N.J., was married yesterday at her parents' home to Jeffrey Baker Bilgore, a son of Mrs. H. David Frank of Westbrook, Conn., and Russell Bilgore of New York and Captiva, Fla. Rabbi Barry H. Greene performed the ceremony.

title: Reading of Short Stories
description: Claire Bloom, Jane Curtin and others will read in ''Selected Shorts: A Celebration of the Short Story,'' to be held Wednesday at Symphony Space, at Broadway and 95th Street. The program, which will include Gail Godwin's ''St. George'' and Emma Tennant's ''Philomela,'' begins at 6:30 P.M. Tickets are $10, $6 for the elderly and students. Information: 864-5400.

title: Policy Shift On the Dollar
description: Worried that its policy to keep the dollar stable is floundering after more than three years of relative success, Washington is seeking new, more flexible alternatives.

title: Promise to the Mentally Ill Has Not Been Kept; Rooms Upstate?
description: To the Editor:

End Aid To the Afghan Rebels
description: The Bush Administration missed an important opportunity to bring an end to U.S. involvement in Afghanistan when Secretary of State James Baker failed to pursue the subject during his visit to Moscow last week.

title: Admiral Financial reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
A Man, 85, Is Killed In an Apartment Fire
description: An 85-year-old man died in a fire that started in the bedroom of his Brooklyn apartment early yesterday morning, the police said.

title: Detroit and the Dinosaur
description: How, at a stroke, can America trim oil imports, cut the trade deficit, reduce smog and help avert global warming? By inducing Detroit to make more fuel-efficient cars. Last week, in a notable reversal of Reagan Administration policy, Washington took one of the necessary steps: Secretary of Transportation Samuel Skinner told the protesting auto industry that its 1990 model cars must average 27.5 miles per gallon. But to wean consumers from gas guzzlers, a more profound change is necessary - a hefty increase in the gas tax.

title: Angels Win, 12-9, Aided by 4 Homers
description: Claudell Washington hit two homers and drove in four runs and Bill Schroeder hit the second grand slam of his career today, leading the California Angels past the Milwaukee Brewers, 12-9.

title: Jamesway Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: Trinity Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Year-ago quarter results included a gain of $1.6 million from the divestment of minority interest in a jointly owned marine company. Latest quarter and year sales included gains of $11.3 million and $52.8 million, respectively, from the adoption of FASB No. 94. Year-ago quarter and year results are restated to include gains of $10.8 million and $39.8 million, respectively, from the adoption of FASB No. 94.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Executives Defending Their Craft
description: Only the advertising industry can turn soul-searching into an exercise in assertiveness training. As the American Association of Advertising Agencies concluded its 71st annual meeting at the Greenbrier hotel here, several top ad executives alternated between pondering and pontificating about the power of big ideas.

title: Yearnings of Youth: An Old Pattern
description: When one of China's student hunger strikers said last week that his demand was for ''a beautiful, perfect system,'' he was not merely being naive. He was reflecting in somewhat naive-sounding terms the yearning for restored national greatness that has led Chinese youth several times this century to take to the streets to demand change from what they saw as incompetent or dictatorial governments.

title: Unlikely Pair Stars As Yanks Win, 6-2
description: In the warmth of a Florida spring, when jobs were being won and lost in the Yankee camp, Clay Parker and Bob Geren dressed and played and hoped to be noticed. But when the team flew home on the final day of March, both were back in the minors again.

title: Cracker Barrel Old Country Store Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
description: Share earnings are adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split in February.

title: Review/Recital; Rorianne Schrade, Pianist
description: Rorianne Schrade, who gave a recital of piano music by Rachmaninoff, Messiaen, Ravel, Liszt and Chopin at Weill Recital Hall Saturday afternoon, is in many ways an accomplished and attractive musician. Her control of balances and sensitivity to color in Messiaen's ''Sons Impalpables du Reve,'' and her clarity of contrapuntal voicing in the first movement of Chopin's B minor sonata were thoroughly admirable.

title: Angeles Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Jury Calls for Death Penalty In Murders of 3 in Las Vegas
description: The jury that convicted a former Los Angeles policeman of murdering a wealthy Las Vegas woman and two other people decided today that the death penalty should be imposed for each of the three killings.

title: Reviews/Music; Sonny Rollins's Twist on Calypso and Pop
description: The tenor saxophonist Sonny Rollins hit the Carnegie Hall stage in high gear Friday night. Mr. Rollins and his group were to be joined by a guest musician, Branford Marsalis on tenor saxophone. That format has produced memorable concerts (notably one with the trumpeter Wynton Marsalis, Branford's brother, at the Beacon); the audience was primed for an event.

title: Jewish Groups Hear Koch and Rivals
description: As the first mayoral candidate to appear yesterday at a campaign breakfast in Brooklyn, Mayor Edward I. Koch begged off making the obligatory self-introduction. ''If you don't know who I am after 12 years, then I'm a failure,'' Mr. Koch told an audience of representatives of Jewish organizations.

title: Andrea Kummel Marries a Lawyer

Burke of Short Hills, N.J., took place yesterday at the Martinsville (N.J.) Inn. Rabbi Barry H. Greene performed the ceremony.

title: CORPORATE GIFTS FALL MORE EVENLY
description: Corporations continue to donate more money to private colleges and universities than they do to public ones, but the public institutions are catching up, according to a newly released study.

description: Toyota and Nissan are developing radically different advertising strategies to accomplish the same goal: Persuade affluent Americans to spend almost $40,000 on a large, new and unknown Japanese luxury car.

title: WestMarc Communications reports earnings for Qtr to March 31

Latest quarter results included a pretax gain of $7,184,000 on the sale of assets, while the year-ago period's results included a pretax gain of $1,842,000 on the sale of marketable securities.

description: The company cited the loss of Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston as a customer, which resulted in about $1 million of the revenue decline.

title: Japan Wholesale Prices
description: Wholsesale prices in Japan rose 2.5 percent in April, the Government said Friday. The figure was lower than expected, and it reduces the chance that the Bank of Japan will raise its key discount rate. Financial markets here had speculated that a 3 percent consumption tax on goods and services introduced April 1 would stimulate inflation and put pressure on the central bank to act.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Tiananmen Square has become a holy spot for Chinese democracy. If we stay here longer, we will contribute more to China's democratization, and increase our influence. If we withdraw, we will let down the citizens who have defended us. We will stay until our victory.'' - Wang Dan, a student leader in Beijing. [ A10:5. ]

title: In Hong Kong, Too, a Throng Marches
description: Huge crowds took to the streets of Hong Kong today, voicing their support of the pro-democracy campaign in Beijing with the largest demonstration in the colony's modern political history.

title: Petrie Stores Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-Included a gain of $8,300,000, or 18 cents a share, on the extinguishment of long-term debt. The latest quarter net does not include the company's equity earnings in Paul Harris Stores Inc. which has not released earnings for the current period. For the year-ago first quarter, the company's share of the loss reported by Paul Harris Stores totaled $1,156,000 after taxes. In addition, the company as of May 1, 1988 stopped accounting for its investment in the common stock of Toys 'R' Us Inc. on the equity method. The year-ago first quarter results included income after taxes of $4,533,000, or 8 cents a share, from the company's share of earnings in Toys 'R' Us.

title: Printronix Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 25
description: b-Net income The company said the loss in the latest quarter was due to an operting loss of $2,955,000, as factories were operated at less than the sales rate in order to consume excess inventory, and a provision of $2,816,000 to cover restructuring expenses associated with closing two facilities in the United States and one in Holland. The company also said the latest quarter results included an income tax benefit of $2.4 million resulting from the satisfactory resolution of certain international tax matters.

title: U.S., in Test Case, Seen Limiting Defections From Savings Insurer
description: Federal regulators plan to reject a request by one of the nation's most profitable savings and loan associations to leave the industry's deposit insurance fund in favor of the much stronger fund that insures bank deposits, an official of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board said today.

Susan Goldstein Is a Bride
description: Susan Beth Goldstein and Andrew Martin Parower were married yesterday at the Biddle Mansion in Tarrytown, N.Y., by Rabbi Douglas E. Krantz. The bride, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Goldstein of Bedford Village, N.Y., graduated from Washington University. She is an assistant product manager in New York for Macy's. The bridegroom, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lester B. Parower of White Plains, graduated from Washington University and received an M.B.A. degree from Fordham University. He is a financial analyst for Chase Manhattan Bank in New York.

title: Now, a Portable Court
description: A new tennis teaching device allows you to practice strokes when you don't have access to a court.

description: The Chicago Bulls continued their remarkable march through the National Basketball Association playoffs and Michael Jordan added to his growing legend this afternoon as the Bulls upset the Detroit Pistons, 94-88, in the opening game of the Eastern Conference final.

description: ''I was just a normal person before,'' said Ron Olshwanger, a furniture dealer, ''and all I did was take a picture.''

title: The Iran-Copter Affair
description: Donald Gregg, who was Vice President Bush's national security adviser during the Iran-contra affair, can't explain how the words ''resupply of the contras'' appeared in two memos about a White House meeting he and Mr. Bush attended in the spring of 1986. One reason he needs to explain those words is that both he and Mr. Bush deny early knowledge of the illegal arming of the rebels in Nicaragua. Another is that President Bush has nominated him to be Ambassador to South Korea.

title: John J. Muccio, 89; Was U.S. Diplomat In Several Countries
description: John J. Muccio, the first United States Ambassador to South Korea, died of heart failure on Friday in Washington. He was 89 years old and lived in the capital.

description: b-Net income c-After a loss of $7 million on the extinguishment of debt. Intermark said that its fiscal 1989 profit was sharply reduced by a $16 million provision announced May 8 by its 50 percent owned partner company, Sunbelt Nursery Group, for loss on disposal of unprofitable stores. Intermark said that as of March 31, it recorded a charge, net of minority interest, of $8 million, representing its proportionate share of the Sunbelt provision. The company said its 1989 results were also negatively affected by its share of a $5 million loss sustained by Dynamark Ltd., a 50 percent owned partner company. The latest year's results included income of about $15 million, or $1.65 a share, attributable to a gain realized in the third quarter by its partner company, Triton Group Ltd., on the sale of its 89 percent interest in Continental Graphics Corp. Similarly, the prior fiscal year included a gain of $14.6 million, or $1.72 a share, attributable to Triton's gain on the sale of Simplicity Pattern Co.

title: Dire Need For Nurses Is Perplexing To Hospitals
description: Sophie Maroot's job begins at 7:30 A.M. Patients with severe diarrhea must be constantly cleaned. Some, stricken with dementia, repeatedly tear their respirators loose. Others must be restrained to keep them from wandering around out of the hospital. Almost all, vulnerable to common infections, require hourly rounds for medication.

title: New Delhi Journal; Sister Burnishes Nehru's Image, Lest India Forget
description: Vijaya Lakshmi Pandit, 88 years old and just recovered from a stroke, came down the other day from her retirement home in the hills of Dehra Dun for a meeting on how to mark the 100th anniversary of the birth of her brother and India's first Prime Minister, Jawaharlal Nehru.

title: Linda Doll Wed To A. M. Jacobs

The Rev. Dr. Arthur Caliandro, the senior minister of the Marble Collegiate Church, and Rabbi Charles J. Davidson officiated at Leeds Pond Preserve in Plandome, L.I.

title: The 8 Disparate Decision Makers: Will They Be Able to Restore Calm?
description: As Beijing's political crisis grows more acute, the power to resolve the deadlock and end the struggle seems to be in the hands of a relatively small number of people. Only the popular uprising binds them together, for they range from Politburo members to university students.

But he has some reservations. He wishes, for instance, that it had included the boy's attempts to make his life with the occasionally fatherly kidnapper seem as normal as possible.

title: Avatar Holdings Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income The company said it adopted the installment method of profit recognition for homesite sales effective Jan. 1. The company also said the move shouldn't affect its liquidity, but that it results in a reduction of reported gross revenue from real estate operations. For the first three months of 1989, gross revenue was $44,614,000, of which $10,221,000 was deferred for recognition in future periods, resulting in reported revenue of $34,393,000. For the first quarter of 1988, results of operations were reported under the accrual method of profit recognition.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;
Exercise Becoming Par for the Course

description: A wounded Soviet defector landed in Turkey over the weekend, and his MIG-29 fighter was flown back to the Soviet Union today, Turkish officials said.

description: Saying he hoped that the crisis in China would not turn bloody, President Bush today urged pro-democracy forces there to follow a nonviolent path and ''stand up for what you believe in.''

title: Results Plus
description: Auto Racing Rutherford Out of Indy 500: The fastest 33-car field in racing history will start the Indianapolis 500 next Sunday without the three-time winner Johnny Rutherford, whose last-minute qualifying attempt blew up yesterday along with the engine in the car he borrowed from A. J. Foyt. The field average of 216.588 miles an hour smashed the Indianapolis record of 210.280 m.p.h. set in 1986. Rutherford was bumped from the lineup by Rich Vogler with fewer than 15 minutes remaining. But Foyt put Rutherford into a Cosworth-powered Lola and got the car onto the oval one minute before the scheduled close. Rutherford's crew said his warm-up lap was more than 217 m.p.h., well above what he needed to get back into the field. But less than 100 yards after taking the green flag for the start of a 4-lap, 10-mile qualifying run, smoke poured from the engine. It was the second year in a row that Vogler has been the final qualifier, bumping a former Indy winner. In 1988, he knocking Gordon Johncock out of the race.(AP) Wallace Wins Winston: Rusty Wallace won the Winston, Nascar's $800,000 all-star race, yesterday at the Charlotte Motor Speedway in North Carolina. Darrell Waltrip was leading in the final 10 laps when Wallace's car tapped him from behind on turn four and sent him across the infield and out of the running for the $200,000 purse. (AP) Track George Mason Takes Track Title: George Mason University, which came from behind to win the indoor IC4A track and field team title in March, did it again outdoors. The Patriots, trailing Penn State, 42 1/2 to 22, drew even by winning yesterday's first running event, the 400-meter relay, and the first field event, the high jump, with Tony Barton winning with a 7-foot-1 3/4-inch leap. Mason pulled away with a 1-3 placing in the 800 meters, won by John Cook in 1:48.47, and an 18-point contribution by Patrick O'Connor, who won the 200 meters. Mason ended up with 100Y points to Penn State's 68 1/2.(AP) Golf Baker-Finch Wins by 4: Ian Baker-Finch, helped by Tim Simpson's double-bogey on the 14th hole, got a four-stroke victory yesterday in the Colonial National Invitation tournament in Fort Worth. Baker-Finch, a 28-year-old Australian, needed only a closing round of par 70 to become the first wire-to-wire winner on the PGA Tour this year. He won his first American title with a 10-under 270 on the Colonial Country Club course. David Edwards was second with a 65 for a 274 total. Simpson, with a 68 for 276, was tied for third with the South African David Frost, 69. (AP)

title: ON YOUR OWN: Fitness; Heartburn for Fun And Profit: A Saga

He described how administering a prescription drug that suppresses stomach acid secretion to about a dozen runners before a run appeared to prevent the heartburn in many of them.

title: Question Box
description: Hometown Losses Q. Since World War II, St. Louis has lost the Browns in major league baseball, the Hawks in the National Basketball Association and the Cardinals in the National Football League, while retaining the Blues in the National Hockey League, as well as the baseball Cardinals. Among the cities in the United States with teams in the four major sports leagues - baseball, football, basketball and hockey - has any city fared worse than St. Louis over the last 40 to 50 years? A. Not really, though in franchise attrition, as well as in distance, Kansas City, Mo., is not a long way from St. Louis. In baseball, Kansas City picked up the Philadelphia Athletics franchise in 1955, then lost it to Oakland in 1968, a year before the Royals were created. In basketball, Kansas City also served as a hitching post for the Cincinnati Royals franchise, which became the Kansas City-Omaha Kings in 1972 and then moved on to become the Sacramento Kings in 1986. In hockey, Kansas City originated an expansion franchise, the Scouts, for the 1974-75 season, but it departed after two woeful seasons to become the Colorado Rockies, and eventually the New Jersey Devils. As for football, the Kansas City Chiefs have yet to leave town after arriving 26 years ago from Dallas, where they were the Texans of the American Football League.
