description: THE bigger the better, a law of satellite design for more than three decades, is being challenged as advances in miniaturization allow engineers to build unmanned spacecraft that are smaller, lighter, cheaper and smarter than ever before.

title: Deadline Near on Averting Tax Rise
description: The New York State Legislature is struggling to craft a bill by mid-June to avoid dramatic increases in property taxes on houses in New York City.

title: Bush's Sister Hurts 3 Officers
description: President Bush's sister injured three police officers in a minor car accident Sunday on the way to hear her brother speak at Boston University's commencement. The officers had been directing Nancy Bush Ellis to a parking area when the car suddenly lurched backward and struck the officers, causing minor injuries, the police said. There was no apparent negligence on her part and no charges were filed, the police said.

title: Southlife Holding Is to Be Acquired
description: The Southlife Holding Company agreed to be acquired by the Capital Holding Corporation, one of the nation's 10 largest stockholder-owned life insurance organizations. The agreement provides for each share of Southlife's common stock to be exchangeable for a share of Capital Holding common stock, valued at $8.80, plus $2.20 in cash, for a total value of of $11 a share. The deal is subject to adjustments. Southlife has more than 4.9 million common shares. Capital Holding, based here, will also start a tender offer at $11 a share for Southlife's almost two million shares of preferred stock.

title: Patient Gets Altered Genes in First Approved Test
description: THE first federally approved transfer of cells containing foreign genes into a human was accomplished yesterday at the Clinical Center of the National Institutes of Health in Bethesda, Md.

title: Charge Reduced Against Mother In Neglect Case
description: Brooklyn prosecutors reduced the most serious charge late last night against a teen-age mother who abandoned her 2-year-old daughter Friday in a women's restroom in Kings County Medical Center.

title: Testers, Not Women, Must Explain S.A.T. Gap; Near Zero Probability
description: To the Editor:

title: Financial Trustco Capital Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $75,000. c-Net income and after income from discontinued operations of $3,502,000. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: 'Right' Man on Trial In Three Murders, Prosecutor Tells Jury
description: After prosecuting the wrong man for a triple murder, the Queens District Attorney's office told a jury yesterday that it now had the right man and that he was sitting in the courtroom at the defense table.

title: Powerful Desktop Line Introduced by Compaq
description: The Compaq Computer Corporation yesterday announced a new desktop computer line based on a faster version of the Intel Corporation's 80386 microprocessor computer chip. The move follows similar introductions by a number of other I.B.M. compatible personal computer makers earlier this year.

title: First City Trustco Inc reports earnings for
description: Investment income totaled $105,243,000 for latest first quarter, compared with $91,745,000 for year- ago period. Year-ago figures have been restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Patten Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 2
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $330,000 from the extinguishment of debt. c-After extraordinary gains from the extinguishment of debt of $243,000 for the quarter and $1.5 million for the year.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day last Tuesday about legislation to help the savings and loan industry referred incorrectly to the liability of certain investors in a savings institution should that institution fail. Under a legislative amendment offered by Representative Peter Hoagland, Democrat of Nebraska, investors in a limited partnership that purchases an ailing savings institution would not be protected against losses should the institution fail. But the amendment does provide that investors in other limited partnerships that are controlled by the same general partner would not be liable for the losses of the failed institution.

title: Market Place; Changing Rules In Holly Auction
description: THE weekend auction for the Holly Farms Corporation, won by a bidder that supposedly was not planning to bid, was characterized by at least three different sets of rules, by a perhaps unnecessary late-night deadline and by a key negotiator being unavailable because he was out seeing the sights of New York.

title: Cochabamba Journal; A Nice Place to Live (Just Ask the Drug Barons)
description: For most Bolivians, this is the ideal city. It is not as high in the Andes as La Paz, the capital, and therefore not as chilly. It is also not as low and steamy as Santa Cruz, the thriving second city in the subtropical plains.

title: J.S. Satterthwaite, 85, An Investment Analyst
description: James Sheafe Satterthwaite, an investment analyst and an expert on municipal bonds, died Saturday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 85 years old and lived in Tenafly, N.J.

title: Upheaval in China; From Asian Neighbors, It's Silence and Anxiety
description: Asian governments are largely keeping silent on the upheaval in China, waiting to see whether Beijing will move toward further democracy or repression.

title: The Drama Desk Awards
description: ''Jerome Robbins's Broadway'' was selected by the Drama Desk yesterday as the outstanding musical of the 1988-89 theater season. Wendy Wasserstein's ''Heidi Chronicles'' was named best new play and ''Our Town'' best revival. The Drama Desk, formed in 1949, is an association of New York City critics, editors and reporters.

title: Economist's Shift on Rates
description: Wall Street's top-rated economist has joined the growing list of bears who have turned bullish. Edward S. Hyman Jr., chief economist for C. J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell Inc. told his institutional customers yesterday that he believed long-term interest rates had peaked.

title: Why Negotiating Short-Range Missiles Out of Europe Can Wait
description: To the Editor:

title: G.M. Unit Contract
description: Electronic Data Systems, a unit of the General Motors Corporation, said it had received a three-year, $100 million systems integration contract, with options for two one-year extensions, from Florida's Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services. It said it would provide for the transfer, implementation and operation of an integrated data access system for recipients.

title: India Reports Successful Test of Mid-Range Missile
description: India successfully fired its first medium-range surface-to-surface missile today, the Press Trust of India said in a report from the test site on the Bay of Bengal.

title: Donaldson Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $465,000 for the quarter and $1,093,000 for the 9 months.

title: Bridge
description: Some stars of the future gathered here for a special event over the weekend to select one pair for World Championship play. The winners, with a last-round surge, were David Rowntree of Boston, a graduate student at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, and Michael Klein, a student at the State University of New York at Albany.

title:
Talking Business with Steffens of Merrill Lynch;
Investors Called More Confident
description: LEAD: Ever since the stock market crash in October 1987, the retail brokerage business has been in the doldrums. Of course, this could change if the current stock and bond market rallies continue and draw in more individual investors.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aris Corp., Scottsdale, Ariz., said it would sell its shape-molding business for about $26.5 million to a company owned and controlled by Warren F. Florkiewicz, former president of Aris, and Melville B. Weir.

title: Comedy Channel Sues HBO
description: The Comedy Channel Inc., based in Los Angeles, said yesterday that it had filed a $25 million lawsuit against Home Box Office Inc., accusing the cable company of trademark infringement by stealing its name.

title: Bonn Had Informant in the Group Suspected in the Pan Am Bombing
description: A Jordanian explosives expert who belonged to a terrorist group suspected of bombing a Pan Am jumbo jet last December worked for West German intelligence late last year, American officials said today.

title: Far West Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: N.H.L. Gives Hextall 12-Game Suspension for Attack on Chelios
description: Ron Hextall, the Philadelphia Flyers' No. 1 goalie, was given a 12-game suspension by the National Hockey League today for his attack on Chris Chelios of the Montreal Canadiens in the sixth game of the teams' semifinal Stanley Cup playoff series.

title: Ex-Aide Says Pierce Ruled on Who Got Big Housing Grants
description: Samuel R. Pierce, Secretary of Housing and Urban Development in the Reagan Administration, personally selected or promoted projects to receive housing subsidies under a program now being investigated as a source of funds that improperly benefited prominent Republicans, a former senior H.U.D. official says.

title: Moscow Imposes Cuts In Staffing for British
description: The Soviet authorities announced today that the British Embassy and other British institutions in the Soviet Union would be required to cut their staffs. The move came after a week in which London expelled 11 Soviet nationals on suspicion of espionage and Moscow responded in kind.

title: Shortages and Anarchy Begin to Cripple Beijing
description: As the capital ends its third day of martial law, Beijing is finding itself crippled by shortages and disruptions of vital services. In the absence of an effective government in parts of the city, only student rule seems to have averted total collapse in the city.

title: Police, Citing Parolee, Shun Clearwater Fair
description: Westchester County police officers are refusing to volunteer to patrol next month's Clearwater Festival, and the County Executive has said Westchester will drop its sponsorship of the event, because Gary McGivern, the paroled murderer of a county deputy sheriff, is working for the Clearwater environmental group.

title: For Fall, a Flirtatiousness Shapes Elegant Fur Designs
description: The explosion of fashion in fur continued unabated through showings last week that started with the colors and patterned fabrics in Oscar de la Renta's presentation of styles for Wagner Furs and ended with the casual jackets shown with tights by Giorgio di Sant'Angelo for Robert Sidney. There were plenty of styles for traditionalists who like their minks long and flowing, but there was a wide choice of casual shapes and furs by fashion designers who put individual stamps on their collections.

title: Summer Cranks Up, Anti-Trash Armor Hits the Beach
description: As the traditional opening of the summer season approaches, beach operators on Long Island are combing trash from the sand with huge mechanical rakes and catamarans in New York Harbor are skimming garbage with steel nets, all in an effort to prevent a repeat of last year's closings of polluted beaches.

title: People
description: * David L. Tree has been named deputy chairman and chief creative officer of Campbell-Mithun-Esty/ Minneapolis.

title: Chronar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Hughes Supply Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Engineered Support Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss and 6 months is after a gain from a change in accounting of $500,000.

title: Of Chips and Buggy Whips: Reassessing Future Needs
description: A GROWING chorus is saying that the 80286-based personal computer is now ready to assume its place in history along with the black and white television and the rotary-dial phone. The new age of the 80386 is here, they say, and those who cling to the old ways are simply wasting their money.

title: Simms Wants More Money, but Is Expected at Minicamp
description: When the Giants take the field this morning for a four-day minicamp, Phil Simms will probably be there despite a contract dispute. Simms, the Giants' starting quarterback for most of the last 10 years, wants his contract extended at a higher salary.

title: Grain and Soybeans Slump; Copper Prices Also Decline
description: Prices of grain and soybean futures dropped sharply yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, reflecting investor reaction to forecasts of rain and the relentless rise in the dollar's value.

title: 2 Lines for Sale At Pillsbury
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the British conglomerate that earlier this year acquired the Pillsbury Company, said today that it would sell two of Pillsbury's product lines: Bumble Bee Seafoods and Van de Kamp's.

title: Forum Re Group reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter included a pretax gain of about $525,000 from the sale of a subsidiary.

title: System Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 22
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $11,071,000 for the quarter and $10,926,000 for the 9 months; the 9 months also included a restructuring charge of $12 million. c-Net income and after a loss of $107,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months. The latest quarter's loss from continuing operations is after a $12 million charge related to restructuring.

title: Bonn Sees Wide Gulf in Missile Dispute
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl today sent President Bush his response to the latest American proposals in the dispute over short-range missiles, but West German officials indicated that the two sides remained far from a resolution.

title: Forsyth, John Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Party Time in Prague, But Under Dark Skies
description: The party given on Wednesday in Vaclav Havel's apartment overlooking the Vltava River and the Prague cathedral was intended, technically at least, to celebrate Mr. Havel's release from prison. The noted Czechoslavak playwright and dissident had been freed earlier in the day after serving four months for supporting opposition rallies in the capital.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Deng to Retire in the U.S., And Other Chinese Rumors
description: Of all the rumors that have swept Beijing in the last week, perhaps the most astonishing was that in a nefarious attempt to kill demonstrators the Chinese Government had electrified the metal grates over the city's subways.

title: New Bedford Journal; For Troubled City, All-America Lift
description: At City Hall, it did not take long before the receptionists proudly began answering the telephone, ''Good afternoon, New Bedford, All-America City.'' Nor did much time pass before the local newspaper, The Standard-Times, hoisted ''New Bedford, All-America City 1988-1989,'' next to its nameplate on the front page.

title: Excerpts From Baker's Mideast Talk
description: Following are excerpts from a speech today by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d to the 30th annual conference of the American Israel Public Affairs Committee:

title: American Body Armor & Equipment reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Tutoring Japanese on Takeovers
description: It was a classic American business story when a dissatisfied group of takeover experts at the First Boston Corporation suddenly quit last year and formed Wasserstein, Perella & Company to do things their own way. And the story could not have been more Japanese when Nomura Securities, which later acquired 20 percent of Wasserstein, Perella, shipped five members of its staff to the new firm to learn the takeover game: the five were neither consulted nor told why they had been chosen.

title: Gottschalks Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-Included gains from an accounting change of $722,000 for the latest quarter and $166,000 for the year- earlier period.

title: Man Dies After Arrest In Assault
description: A 25-year-old unemployed handyman died of an undetermined cause early yesterday about 90 minutes after being arrested by housing police officers in the lobby of a public housing building.

title: Chess
description: Those rare players who succeeded in getting advantageous positions against Bobby Fischer can remember the demonic energy that that eccentric genius could marshall to upset the course of the game. The feeling of control that one has in a superior position would immediately be gone and one would be battling into the depths of a hurricane or diving into a seething sea of lava.

title: The High Price of Nostalgia for Things Cinematic
description: When a poster from the 1939 movie ''The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes'' sold for $4,000 at an auction this weekend, it was a clear sign that collecting movie posters has moved from hobby to high-stakes passion.

title: Zelo Schussheim, 62, Professor of Talmud
description: Rabbi Zelo Schussheim, a professor of Talmud for more than 40 years, died of a heart attack Sunday at Booth Memorial Medical Center in Flushing, Queens. He was 62 years old and lived in Kew Gardens.

title: After 26 Seasons, Is John Out of Time?
description: Tommy John turned 46 years old yesterday, but he hoped the day would pass quietly. He was going to play golf in the morning, help his two older sons set up a pitching machine at the park in the afternoon and have dinner with his wife and friends in Manhattan in the evening. It was going to be an easy, uneventful day, the kind any middle-aged man would enjoy on his birthday.

title: Higher Radon Levels In Summer Cast Doubt On Reliability of Tests
description: LEVELS of radon gas in the soil may be as much as 10 times higher in the summer than in the winter, when most testing for the cancer-causing gas is done, a Pennsylvania State University study has found.

title: Flames, Canadiens Play Copycats
description: The Flames are eager to be heading home to Calgary, a city that paints itself red at this time of year, where they intend to break the 2-2 Stanley Cup championship stalemate they earned with a 4-2 victory at Montreal on Sunday night.

title: KEY RATES
Dropout Prevention Needs More Support
description: To the Editor:

title: Schools Pinched by Cuts in Food Surplus
description: The amount of surplus dry milk and other dairy products that the Government distributes to school lunch programs has declined so much that school officials are scrambling for substitutes and probably will have to increase lunch prices this fall.

title: Interco Sets Sale Of Ethan Allen
description: Interco Inc., a diversified concern based in St. Louis, said that it would sell its Ethan Allen Inc. furniture unit to a company formed by the subsidiary's management and a group of investors led by Castle Harlan Inc. Interco put a value of $388 million on the deal, consisting of $357 million in cash, certain real estate assets and the assumption of debt. Interco said it would receive warrants to buy up to 8 percent of the new company's common stock during a five-year period.

title: Indians Batter Morris, And Tigers Reach .500 Mark
description: The Cleveland Indians beat Jack Morris for the first time ever in Tiger Stadium by hitting four home runs in the first three innings, defeating Detroit, 7-3, tonight.

title: 2-Year Car Registry To Start in New York
description: New York State's switch to a two-year automobile registration, a move intended to help close a potential state budget deficit, begins on June 16, state officials said yesterday.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Russians Talk of Nuclear Aid by U.S.
description: The official in charge of regulating nuclear power in the Soviet Union, on a tour of two reactors here, said today that his country might turn to an American company for help in designing reactors.

title: Lowe's Cos reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Avon Stock Up On Speculation
description: Amid speculation that the bidding for Avon Products Inc., the direct-selling cosmetics company based in New York, was not finished, Avon's share price rose $2.375 yesterday, to $34.625, in heavy trading on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Donald Wyckoff, 62, a Crafts Specialist
description: Donald Wyckoff, former president of the American Crafts Council, a national organization of artists and crafts people, died of Hodgkins disease Friday at his home in Amagansett, L.I. He was 62 years old.

title: Chalone Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Group to Urge Business Ethics
description: A group of 17 business leaders and educators yesterday announced the creation of the Business Enterprise Trust, a national organization intended to increase awareness of issues of corporate responsibility. At a news conference in Los

title: Researchers Enlist Bacteria To Do Battle With Oil Spill
description: FOR the first time in history, scientists are about to attempt a large-scale experimental attack on an oil spill by stimulating natural bacteria to break down poisonous components.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day yesterday with an article about Deutsche Bank carried incorrect labels. The dark gray bars represented the assets and income of the Deutsche Bank Group, the equivalent of a holding company.

title: Cato Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-Included a charge of $82,000 from discontinued operations.

title: A.T.&T. Union Backs a Strike
description: Members of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company's largest union have voted overwhelmingly to authorize a strike if a new contract is not reached by midnight Saturday, the union said today.

title: Frank Day Tuttle, 86, Radio Producer, Dies
description: Frank Day Tuttle, a theatrical and radio producer and director, died in his sleep Monday at the Actors Fund Home in Englewood, N.J. He was 86 years old.

title: Plessey Net Rises 14%
description: The British electronics company Plessey P.L.C. said today that pretax profits rose 14 percent, to $:195.5 million ($309 million), in the year ended March 31.

title: Reynolds Appointment Will Be a Homecoming
description: James W. Johnston, in charge of Citibank's consumer banking operations in the Northeast, will become chairman and chief executive of R. J. Reynolds Tobacco USA on June 1.

title: Ensource reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest quarter revenue included $727,000 related to gas contract settlements.

title: Stock Prices Mixed; Dow Inches Up 0.92
description: Stock prices were mixed yesterday after opening sharply higher in concert with a much stronger dollar.

title: Arab Talks Expected to Focus on P.L.O. and Syria
description: The Arab summit meeting that begins on Tuesday is expected to back a request by the Palestine Liberation Organization for an international conference to pave the way for a Palestinian state. Some Arab diplomats from the Persian Gulf region said the nations meeting here were also expected to put pressure on Syria to reduce its military presence in Lebanon, where there are about 40,000 Syrian soldiers.

title: Lendl Seeded First
description: Ivan Lendl, a three-time champion in Paris, tops the men's seedings for the $4.5 million French Open championships, officials announced yesterday. The event, the second Grand Slam tournament of the year, will be played May 29-June 11 on the red-clay courts of Roland Garros Stadium. Sixteen of the top 20 players in the world are entered.

title: Major British Advertiser: Government
description: The decade of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's rule has been a golden age for the British advertising industry, with agencies like Saatchi & Saatchi P.L.C. and the WPP Group P.L.C. growing quickly from infancy to become world leaders - and gobbling up much of Madison Avenue on the way.

title: New Surge Is Worrying White House
description: The White House said today that the dollar's rise could undermine progress in reducing the trade deficit, and it reasserted its commitment to coordinating economic policy with other countries to keep the dollar stable.

title: Santucci to Seek His Fourth Term As a Prosecutor
description: After months of indecision, District Attorney John J. Santucci of Queens, a focus of sharp controversies in recent years, said yesterday that he had decided to run for a fourth term.

title: Florida Investor Buys Celtics Stake
description: A Florida investor has acquired a 5.1 percent nonvoting stake in the limited partnership that owns the Boston Celtics, according to a filing made with the Securities and Exchange Commission. David Rhodin Murphey 3d, president of the Tampa-based Murphey Capital Inc., disclosed that he had bought 326,100 units in Boston Celtics L.P. The Celtics limited partnership, traded on the New York Stock Exchange, closed today at $13.625 a share, unchanged.

title: Blue Jays Talk to Piniella
description: Officials of the Toronto Blue Jays interviewed Lou Piniella yesterday in their quest for a new manager. Pat Gillick, the Blue Jays' general manager, called the two-hour meeting ''very preliminary,'' saying they exchanged ideas and philosophy.

title: Charles Schwab Sets First Payout
description: The Charles Schwab Corporation, parent of Charles Schwab & Company, the largest discount brokerage, declared its first dividend today. Schwab's board declared a quarterly cash dividend of 3 cents a share of common stock, payable on June 15 to stockholders of record as of June 1.

title: Reviews/Music; Sounds of the 18th Century
description: Capriccio Stravagante is an early-music ensemble that is based in Paris and specializes in music of 18th-century France and Italy. For its American debut, on Saturday afternoon at Florence Gould Hall, the group was joined by Guillemette Laurens, a French mezzo-soprano who is well known to collectors of early-music recordings, and who was also in New York as part of the Theatre National de l'Opera de Paris production of Lully's ''Atys.''

title: Cheers at Preakness Prove to Be Twofold
description: ''Come on, Pat! Ride him, Pat!''

title: Dawkins to Join Bain
description: Peter M. Dawkins, a Republican who unsuccessfully challenged Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, the incumbent Democrat, last fall in New Jersey, is joining Bain & Company, an international management consulting firm. Mr. Dawkins, 51 years old, will become executive vice president of the Boston-based company, responsible for the mid-Atlantic region. Mr. Dawkins was a managing director of the former Shearson Lehman Brothers Inc., now Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., before leaving to run for the Senate.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Disarmament Commission Meets at 10 A.M. Economic and Social Council Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Trusteeship Council Meets at 3 P.M.

title: Baltimore Gas & Electric reports earnings for 12mo April 30
CBL Medical Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said the latest first quarter is CBL Medical's first operating quarter as a public company.

title: Panel Votes Bill to Ban Incinerators
description: Apartment-house incinerators would be banned in New York City in four years, under a bill passed yesterday by a City Council committee.

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL ATLANTA (NL) - Placed Lonnie Smith, outfielder, on the 15-day disabled list. Recalled Dave Justice, outfielder, from Richmond of the International League. MILWAUKEE (AL) - Placed Paul Mirabella, pitcher, on the 21-day disabled list. TORONTO (AL) - Transferred Al Leiter, pitcher, from the 15-day disabled list to the 21-day disabled list, retroactive to May 11. Called up Alex Sanchez, pitcher, from Syracuse of the International League. BASKETBALL NETS (NBA) - Appointed Bob Moran vice president of promotional sales, vice president of broadcasting and corporate sales; Lou Terminello vice president of sales, and Timothy T. McLoone director of game operations and creative marketing consultant. FOOTBALL CHICAGO (NFC) - Signed Matt Suhey, fullback, to a one-year contract. JETS (AFC) - Announced the retirement of Robin Cole, linebacker. LOS ANGELES (NFC) - Announced the retirement of Carl Ekern, linebacker, and Mike Guman, fullback. SAN DIEGO (AFC) - Released Curtis Adams, running back, and Shawn Hicks, safety. TAMPA BAY (NFC) - Waived Bud Keyes, quarterback; Billy Knighten, punter, and Peter Drew, kicker. HOCKEY NATIONAL HOCKEY LEAGUE - Suspended Ron Hextall, Philadelphia Flyers goalie, for the first 12 games of the 1989-90 season for his attack on the defenseman Chris Chelios of the Montreal Canadiens in Game 6 of their Stanley Cup semifinal series. COLLEGES KENT STATE - Appointed Chris Davis assistant men's basketball coach. SAN DIEGO STATE - Announced that Earnest Riggins, head women's basketball coach, will not return. SOUTHERN CAL - Appointed Carl Neufeld assistant men's tennis coach. SOUTHERN CONNECTICUT - Announced the resignation of Bob Dikranian, head soccer coach, so he may become director of recreation and intramurals. U.C.L.A. - Appointed Ken Barone volunteer assistant men's basketball coach. YALE - Appointed Steve Ulrich sports information director.

title: Review/Theater; Fiddling While a Rome of Our Time Burns
description: Lounging on an elegant terrace of a beach house, the characters in ''The Investigation of the Murder in El Salvador'' are exemplars of an aristocracy of wealth. As they watch the sun set on several empires, they drink, talk and sometimes do not even pretend to listen to one another, exchanging half-remembered, bizarre anecdotes and interrupted dreams.

title: Rose Granted 32-Day Delay
description: Pete Rose, facing the task of responding to apparent allegations that he bet on baseball games, yesterday received a 32-day delay in his hearing before A. Bartlett Giamatti.

title: Analysis & Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
PATTERNS
description: An Eye on China

title: Guzman Out for Year
description: Jose Guzman, who was second on the Texas Ranger staff last year in earned-run average, innings pitched and strikeouts, will miss the 1989 season because of a partial tear of his right rotator cuff muscle, the club said yesterday. Guzman will be examined by Dr. Frank Jobe next Monday in Los Angeles and is expected to undergo arthroscopic surgery. (AP)

title: Cam Data Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
2 Are Shot in Chase In a BMT Station
description: A 15-year-old boy was shot in the chest yesterday at a subway station when he chased a man he thought had robbed his friend, the police said. The gunman also hit a bystander, possibly with the same bullet.

title: Upheaval in China; Army May Be Trying to Avoid Crisis
description: The active-duty leadership of China's army is a ''transitional generation'' that in recent years has stressed the goal of becoming a professional military force removed from politics, and it is anxious to avoid direct involvement in the Beijing democracy protests, several American experts said today.

title: Federal Resources Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $481,000. c-After net from discontinued operations of $250,000. The company said share earnings was less than one cent a share for the year-ago period. The company said it did not report year-ago revenue because it is all from discontinued operations. Federal Resources' principal operating subsidiary, Kenyon Home Furnishing Ltd. was acquired the first quarter of 1988.

title: The Tides
description: Q. Why are there two high tides and two low tides each day? A. ''We have all been taught that the tides are chiefly the result of the gravitational attraction of the Moon on the waters of the Earth's oceans, but there are actually two rotational systems involved,'' and two bulges of water, explained Reinhard E. Flick, oceanographer for the California Department of Boating and Waterways at the Scripps Institution of Oceanography in La Jolla, Calif.

title: Lawsuit Raises Issue of Color Bias Between Blacks
description: When Tracy Lynn Morrow sued her employer two years ago, her complaint was a common one: She said she had been harassed and discriminated against by her supervisor because of the color of her skin. What made her suit less common was that both she and her supervisor are black.

title: Jets' Cole Retires
description: The Jets linebacker Robin Cole, a veteran of 12 seasons in the National Football League, retired yesterday to devote his time to a marketing job and a car dealership in Pittsburgh. Coach Joe Walton had offered to make Cole an assistant coach.

title: Beijing Creates A No-Win Situation
description: LEAD: Like generals fighting the last war, China's leaders have been struggling to contain the previous revolution.

title: South, in One Volume: Myths and Moon Pies
description: Weighing in at nearly 8 pounds and nearly 1,600 pages, the Encyclopedia of Southern Culture has been completed. The chronicle, 10 years in the making, tries to define the South with scholarly treatments of the popular culture of pickups and mobile homes as well as the roles played by race, violence and religion in shaping the region's character.

title: Review/Television; My Lai: Hard to Forget, Hard to Remember
description: Of all the painful memories of Vietnam, none cut more deeply into America's vision of itself than the massacre at My Lai. ''Remember My Lai,'' tonight's quietly powerful ''Frontline'' documentary on Channel 13 at 10, brings back the terrible day of March 16, 1968, when American soldiers killed hundreds of Vietnamese villagers.

title: Amerada Pays Big Price for Reserves
description: The Amerada Hess Corporation agreed today to buy most of the energy reserves of Transco Exploration Partners for $911 million in cash, a value that analysts said was surprisingly high.

title: Secord Enters Plea of Not Guilty To Later Iran-Contra Indictment
description: Richard V. Secord, the retired Air Force major general facing new charges in the Iran-contra affair, pleaded not guilty today to charges of covering up profits from selling arms to Iran and the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Greenspan Sees Freer Trade
description: Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve's chairman, said today that advances in technology and communication made it more difficult for countries to protect themselves from foreign competition, even though many were trying harder to do so.

title: Testers, Not Women, Must Explain S.A.T. Gap; Gender Restriction
description: To the Editor:

title: Tanzania Acts on Ivory
description: Following a lead set by neighboring Kenya two weeks ago, Tanzania has called for a global ban on the ivory trade to try to stop the illing of elephants by poachers, officials said today.

title: Eastern Air Slots Issued
description: America West Airlines Inc., a growing regional airline making a push into East Coast markets, was a big winner today in a Government lottery for airline slots vacated because of the Eastern Airlines strike.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The dollar swept past two more milestones in its continuing advance, despite more concerted central bank intervention and a strong signal of concern from the White House. The dollar rose to more than 2 marks, a level last seen two and a half years ago. Against the yen, the dollar hit 142, its highest level since October 1987. [ Page A1. ] The dollar's rise could undermine progress in reducing the trade deficit, the White House said, reasserting its commitment to coordinating economic policy with other countries to keep the dollar stable. [ D6. ] Prices of precious metals plunged to 33-month lows, with dealers tracing much of the selling of bullion to Hong Kong, where many people, frightened by the upheaval in China, have been converting their gold into dollars. [ D1. ] The Soviets may turn for help in managing nuclear reactors to a U.S. company, said a Soviet regulatory official who was touring two American reactors. [ D5. ] COMPANIES Time and Warner swept away a big obstacle in their $18 billion merger by settling their dispute with Chris-Craft over the interpretation of a five-year-old agreement between Warner and Chris-Craft. [ D1. ] Amerada Hess agreed to buy most of the energy reserves of Transco Exploration Partners for $911 million in cash, a value that analysts said was surprisingly high. [ D1. ] The New York Times Company agreed to acquire McCall's magazine from Working Woman/McCall's Group. Terms were not disclosed but the price was reported to be a little more than $80 million. [ D1. ] Compaq announced a new desktop computer line based on a faster version of Intel's 80386 microprocessor chip. [ D2. ] Du Pont agreed to buy Howson-Algraphy, the leading British supplier of lithographic plates, from Vickers for more than $400 million in cash. [ D5. ] Avon's shares rose $2.375, to $34.625, in heavy trading amid speculation that bidding for the company was not finished. [ D5. ] K-III Holdings will acquire a book club division from Macmillan and the assets of Intertec Publishing, a magazine publisher, for a total of $310 million. K-III is a new investment company associated with Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts. [ D29. ] NBC has persuaded its affiliates to accept a fundamental change in the way they are compensated, after years of unsuccessful attempts by the three major television networks to change the way they pay local stations for carrying their programming. [ D29. ] MARKETS Stock prices were mixed after opening sharply higher, with the Dow Jones industrial average finishing up only 0.92 points, yet still hitting another post-crash high of 2,502.02. [ D12. ] In Hong Kong, investors reacted swiftly to the crisis in China, with the Hang Seng index plunging 339 points, or nearly 11 percent, in the biggest one-day drop since the '87 crash. [ A14. ] Prices of Treasury bonds and notes exploded, spurred by the rising dollar, and yields on some securities fell to their lowest levels in more than 14 months. [ D24. ] Prices of grain and soybean futures dropped sharply, reflecting investor reaction to forecasts of rain. [ D25. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS The retail financial services business is not as weak as many suspect, says John L. Steffens, president of consumer markets at Merrill Lynch. Talking Business. [ D2. ] The weekend auction for Holly Farms, won by a bidder that supposedly was not planning to bid, had at least three different sets of rules. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D12. ] Villeroy & Boch, one of the world's largest dinnerware makers, has just found that for years it has been trying to sell its china to the wrong American consumers. Advertising. [ D29. ]

title:
COMPANY NEWS;
Du Pont Deal to Buy Printing-Plate Maker
description: LEAD: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said yesterday that it had agreed to buy Howson-Algraphy, the leading British supplier of lithographic plates, from Vickers P.L.C. for more than $400 million in cash.

title: Washington Talk; Politics
description: The political direct-mail specialists, who send out all those letters begging for money for this candidate or that cause, prefer their politics tough and personal. They need heroes and devils and threats that Western civilization is about to end unless you send your $25, more if you can.

title: The Leaders, on Video
description: Jack O'Dwyer, chronicler of the public relations business, has entered the video age - releasing a videocassette of interviews with 10 leading industry executives. In the video, Mr. O'Dwyer, who publishes a newsletter on the industry, quizzes the chief executives of the 10 largest agencies on current industry issues. The 45-minute video was introduced on Wednesday at a meeting of the Publicity Club at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel and is on sale for $35 a copy.

title: Rights Chief Defends Acts Again
description: The chairman of the United States Civil Rights Commission has defended his involvement in the adoption case of a 14-year-old Apache girl and has criticized Congress for its treatment of Indians.

title: Lilco Schedules Meeting for Shoreham Vote
description: The Long Island Lighting Company has scheduled a meeting of its shareholders for June 28, setting the stage for the final vote on Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's deal to close the utility's Shoreham nuclear power plant.

title: Circle K Seeking Offer for Company
description: After a review of strategic alternatives, the Circle K Corporation announced it was looking for potential buyers. But Karl Eller, chairman and chief operating officer of Circle K, may propose to acquire the company in a leveraged buyout. The company said it had received indications of interest in an acquisition deal but no specific offers.

title: Integrated Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said preferred stock dividends exceeded net in the latest and year-ago first quarters. Year-ago first quarter results are restated to reflect the adoption of SFAS 97, accounting and reporting by insurance enterprises for certain long duration contracts and realized gains and losses from the sale of investments.

title: Florida Court to Speed Abortion Consent Case
description: The Florida Supreme Court said today that for now, minors are free to get abortions without an adult's consent, but it moved up a hearing on the validity of the law.

title: ABC Announces Fall Prime-Time Lineup
description: Capital Cities/American Broadcasting Companies yesterday announced its prime-time schedule for the fall. The lineup includes six new half-hour comedies, including one for the comedian Jackie Mason, two new hourlong dramas and ''Prime Time,'' a program developed by the network's news division featuring Sam Donaldson and Diane Sawyer as co-anchors.

title: Girl Dies in Fire-Escape Fall
description: A 1 1/2-year-old Brooklyn girl was killed yesterday afternoon when she crawled on a fire escape and fell to her death in an alley five floors below, the police said. The accident was at 5 P.M. at 930 Myrtle Avenue in the Bedford-Stuyvesant area, said a police spokesman, Sgt. Peter Berry, who added that her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Santiago, were in another room at the time.

title: Kean Remaining Neutral In Governorship Primary
description: Gov. Thomas H. Kean decided today not to endorse any candidate in the Republican primary for governor.

title: New Drive, New Target For Villeroy
description: VILLEROY & BOCH, one of the world's largest dinnerware makers, has just found that for years it has been trying to sell its china to the wrong American consumers.

title: Federal Realty Investment Trust reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Tanker Captain Indicted on Felony Counts
description: A grand jury indicted the captain of the Exxon Valdez today on three felony counts for his role in the nation's worst oil spill.

title: Scientists Fear That a Parasite Will Spread in Transfusions
description: A PARASITE usually found in South and Central America, where it is a major cause of heart disease, has been detected after blood transfusions in the United States. The infection, Chagas' disease, has been diagnosed in two patients in three years, and one of those died.

title: Boston's Teachers Pact To Decentralize Schools
description: Joining a handful of districts that are seeking new ways to improve education, Boston school administrators and teachers have tentatively agreed on a contract that would give far more authority to individual public schools on hiring, curriculum and budgets.

title: Reviews/Dance; City Ballet Students in Balanchine and Bournonville Pieces
description: The School of American Ballet presented its 25th annual Spring Workshop program Saturday night at the Juilliard Theater. The school, which is affiliated with the New York City Ballet, appears to be blessed with talent.

title: Campaign Trail; Gifts for Giulianis: Lengthy List
description: Among the many indignities suffered by candidates for mayor in New York City is the public dissemination of the smallest details of their private lives, from tax returns to stock holdings. For Rudolph W. Giuliani, that includes the donors of wedding and baby gifts.

title: 12 Striking Teachers Arrested
description: Twelve teachers were arrested at a protest today as the strike by 23,000 teachers against the nation's second-largest school district entered its second week. Those arrested were among 100 teachers who staged a sit-in at the school headquarters after union negotiators walked out of contract talks Sunday night.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Leader in Southmark Battle Seeks to Recoup Investment
description: LEAD: After watching the value of his stake in the Southmark Corporation dwindle from a high of $9 a share in 1987 to $1 last year, Herbert B. Parks began a battle in October to gain control of the troubled company and to take a role in its management.

title: By Design; A Mere Hint of Flowers
description: Proceed with caution if you're planning to wear a flower print. It's a fashion that has blossomed for this summer. In theory, the beautiful colors and luscious shapes should enhance. In fact, though, they often do not.

title: Reviews/Music; 2 Countries, 3 Languages And the Compas Sound
description: As Caribbean music seeks an international audience, small and large changes set in. Friday's binational, trilingual double bill at the Ritz -with Tabou Combo, from Haiti, and Wilfrido Vargas and his band, from the Dominican Republic - offered a progress report from the island of Hispaniola, which Haiti and the Dominican Republic share. Both the Dominican merengue and the Haitian compas direct (each country's dominant dance music) now allow interludes of English-language rapping, funk drumming and various Caribbean styles; both are reaching out to cities like New York and Miami, and to each other. At the end of the concert, the two groups performed together.

title: Dodge Classic Postponed
description: Last week's heavy rainfall is still affecting a number of golf courses in the metropolitan area, including the Rockaway River Country Club in Denville, N.J.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; New York Trials Allowed in Suits Over Cruise Ship Takeover
description: The Supreme Court today cleared the way for damage suits from the 1985 hijacking of the cruise ship Achille Lauro to be tried in a Federal district court in New York rather than in Italian courts.

title: Mojo Holders Approve Sale of 2 Units to HDM
description: Shareholders of Mojo MDA, the Australian ad agency, yesterday approved the sale of two subsidiaries to HDM. The units, Mattingly advertising agency and Marketing Communications Holdings will become part of a new company, called HDM Mattingly Group, which is controlled by HDM.

title: Campus AIDS Survey Finds Threat Is Real But Not Yet Rampant
description: The first national survey of AIDS virus infection among college students indicates the AIDS threat on campus is real but not yet rampant, researchers said today.

title: Istec Industries & Technoloies reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income of $1,079,272 from the issuance of shares to the public by its Healthcare Technologies Ltd. subsidiary. c-Net loss All figures were converted into U.S. dollars from adjusted new Israeli shekels using the exchange rate as of March 31 of 1.8195 adjusted new Israeli shekels to $1.

title: Hormel, George A & Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
Sun's Age Revised
description: REFINED estimates of the age of meteorites and new theories on stellar evolution have led an astronomer at Yale University to conclude that the Sun is about 200 million years younger than had been assumed: approximately 4.49 billion years old, instead of 4.7 billion years.

title: Dynamic Homes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
After the Students Go Home
description: As much as Americans rightly salute Beijing's rebellious students, they know that their protest cannot go on forever. Sooner or later, the everyday bustle of Tiananmen Square will be restored. The only question is whether this monumental uprising, watched by the world, will end in violence. The answer depends on the outcome of a larger, invisible struggle - to decide who will succeed Deng Xiaoping as China's chief leader and shape China's relations with the world.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''For Israel, now is the time to lay aside, once and for all, the unrealistic vision of a greater Israel.'' - Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d. [ A1:2. ]

title: Books of The Times; Russell Baker Tells of His Life in Print
description: The Good Times By Russell Baker Illustrated. 351 pages. William Morrow & Company. $19.95.

title: The Sun in the 'Greenhouse'
description: LEAD: Stories in the news media give the impression that a consensus exists among scientists, and Government scientists in particular, that the global warming of the 1980's is primarily the result of increased ''greenhouse'' gases in the atmosphere.

title: Nurses Strike at St. Luke's in Dispute Over Pay and Staff Shortages
description: Hundreds of registered nurses struck St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan yesterday in a dispute over what they called rising staff shortages and nursing workloads that have eroded patient care and morale at one of the city's largest voluntary hospitals.

title: Topics of The Times; The Man Who Beat the Knicks
description: What Baryshnikov is to dance and Pavarotti is to singing, Michael Jordan is to basketball. He is grace and dazzle, sweat and savvy, power and discipline. In a league where exceptional ability is virtually the norm, he reduces everyone else on the court to a supporting role.

title: Fruehauf Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $2,731,000 and $7,161,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively, and the latest quarter also included an estimated loss on the sale of discontinued operations of $236,000,000. Year-ago results are restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: John Cage Celebration
description: ''Celebrate Cage,'' a tribute to the composer John Cage and a benefit for the Cunningham Dance Foundation, is to be held Thursday at 7 P.M. at the Pierre Hotel, Fifth Avenue and 61st Street. The program will feature ''Rozart Mix,'' a tape-loop composition conveying in word and sound the appreciation of Mr. Cage's work by 120 composers, writers, performers and artists. Tickets are $500; benefactor tables are also available. Information: 255-8240.

title: Cantor for High Holy Days Fights Dismissal by Concord
description: A man who worked 21 years as cantor at the Concord Resort Hotel in the Catskills, leading vacationing Jews in prayer on the High Holy Days, has sued the hotel for $5 million, contending he was dismissed last fall because he has cancer.

title: Corrections
description: The Company Index in Business Day on Thursday carried an erroneous listing for the Southern Pacific Railroad's parent company. Referring to an article about the derailment of a freight train, the index should have shown Rio Grande Industries; the railroad is no longer owned by Santa Fe Southern Pacific, which is now the Santa Fe Pacific Corporation.

title: New York Liberal Party Has Also Been Divisive
description: To the Editor:

title: People And Trucks
description: In the autumn of 1966, I had a memorable glimpse of the real ''power of the people.'' While covering the Congressional elections that year, I was led by one candidate - Robert Scheer, now a reporter for The Los Angeles Times - to a rally outside a napalm plant in California.

title: Circle Express reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest quarter loss included a provision for a loss of $2,475,000 on a note receivable.

title: Marsh Supermarkets Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Mitel Corp reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Included extraordinary gains of $22 million and $8.3 million for the latest and prior years, respectively. c-Net loss The company said the $22 million gain included $6.2 million from the sale of a vacant manufacturing facility and $15.8 million from tax credits. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Chris-Craft Ends Fight On Warner
description: Sweeping away what may be the last big obstacle in their $18 billion merger, Time Inc. and Warner Communications Inc. announced yesterday that they had settled their dispute with Chris-Craft Industries over the interpretation of a five-year-old hands-off agreement between Warner and Chris-Craft.

title: Washington Talk: Districtspeak; What's in a Name? Honor for a Navy Family
description: If the capital is a city of tradition, then the military branches are sizable suburbs, each with its own customs and mores, its own nomenclature and lingo.

title: Hungary's 'Reform Circles': A New Leaf
description: The Molnar Dixieland Septet worked hard and enthusiastically at warming up the crowd, and the two guiding lights of the Communist Party's reformist wing were the main speakers.

title: U.S. Savings Rules Tighter
description: Federal regulators announced new regulations today requiring savings institutions to meet more stringent standards in documenting their securities activities, the latest in a series of steps to tighten supervision of the troubled industry.

title: A Handy Electronic Go-Between
description: CROSSFILE can streamline certain tasks for a personal computer user or, more likely, an officeful of them, running a variety of application programs. In short, it takes the data created for one kind of program and passes it to another.

title: Flowmole Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Fay's Drug Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pontiac Head Is Moved To Oldsmobile Division
description: The General Motors Corporation yesterday transferred the head of Pontiac, its best-performing car divisions in recent years, to the helm of Oldsmobile, one of its most troubled.

title: Chinese Aide, Visiting U.S., Sees Room for Compromise
description: A top Chinese official met today with Vice President Dan Quayle and Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and said there would be no bloodshed in Beijing if the demonstrators continued to exercise restraint, an Administration official said.

title: Energy Development Partners reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest first quarter included $15,218,000 in cash received from take- or-pay gas contract settlements.

title: Dotoronix Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: What to Call Mr. Wright's Royalties
description: Representative David Obey, a Wisconsin Democrat and an ethical pillar of the House, argues that one of the key charges against Speaker Jim Wright is a bum rap. He thinks the ethics committee is misinterpreting the House's rules on members' income from book royalties.

title: Margot Zemach, 57, Author, Dies; Also Illustrated Books for Children
description: Margot Zemach, an award-winning children's book illustrator and author whose witty, lively works reinterpreted folk tales for younger readers, died of Lou Gehrig's disease Sunday at her home in Berkeley, Calif. She was 57 years old.

title: First American Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Baker, in a Middle East Blueprint, Asks Israel to Reach Out to Arabs
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that it was time for Israel to ''lay aside once and for all the unrealistic vision of a greater Israel'' and ''reach out to Palestinians as neighbors who deserve political rights.''

title: NBC Alters Affiliates' Payments
description: After years of unsuccessful attempts by the three major television networks to change the way they pay local stations for carrying their programming, NBC has persuaded its affiliates to accept a fundamental change in the way they are compensated.

title: Jack Henry & Associates Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Only Radical Steps Can Save Wildlife In Kenya, Leakey Says
description: WITH Kenya's wildlife facing relentless threats from tourists, poachers and a swelling population, Richard E. Leakey, the paleontologist who recently became the country's Wildlife Services director, is urging radical changes in a land where vast herds once roamed unfettered.

title: Ross Stores Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
Treasury Notes and Bonds Soar
description: A sharp and unexpected run-up in the dollar caused prices of Treasury bonds and notes to explode yesterday, market participants said, and yields on some securities fell to their lowest levels in more than 14 months.

title: Frances Steloff Is Fondly Recalled By Patrons of Gotham Book Mart
description: Longtime patrons of the Gotham Book Mart and friends of its founder, the legendary Frances Steloff, the most independent of American independent booksellers who died on April 15 when she was 101 years old, offered homage to her memory and bravery yesterday afternoon in the vaulted Celeste Bartos Forum in the New York Public Library.

title: Wright to Begin His Defense Today Amid Swirl of Rumors and Turmoil
description: The case of Jim Wright has now reverberated far beyond the personal and political travails of the House Speaker, leaving Democrats almost numb and Republicans fired with a sense of opportunity, according to officeholders and political analysts in both parties.

title: Savings Unit Plea Rejected
description: The Federal Home Loan Bank Board today rejected a bid by the Great Western Bank of Beverly Hills, Calif. to leave the savings and loan industry deposit insurance fund to join the bank insurance fund.

title: Pitino and Kentucky Begin Their Talks
description: Rick Pitino and his wife, Joanne, arrived here this afternoon and spent the day touring the city and the University of Kentucky campus and meeting with city and University of Kentucky officials about the school's vacant head-coaching position.

title: Eljer Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest first quarter's pro-forma net was $1,491,000, or 21 cents a share, compared with $1,129,000, or 16 cents a share, for year-ago period. The company was spun off to shareholders of Household International Inc. on April 14, 1989. The pro-forma figures make certain assumptions about operations as if the spinoff had been completed as of Jan. 4, 1988.

title: Thatcher the Issue in Vote on Europe
description: With the rest of the British political spectrum undergoing the most significant shift in years, Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and her resistance to European political and economic union have suddenly become the most heated issue in the campaign for elections for the European Parliament next month.

title: Hearings on Wright Opening
description: As the ethics case of Jim Wright reaches a critical juncture, the worries of the Democratic Party reach beyond his fate. Page A26.

title: Barden Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Upheaval in China; Radio Broadcasts Report Pro-Student Demonstrations Breaking Out All Over China
description: Chinese radio broadcasts monitored by the United States Government show strong support for Beijing student protesters in provinces all around China.

title: Upheaval In China; STANDOFF PERSISTS IN BEIJING; 7 TOP EX-COMMANDERS WARN ARMY 'MUST NOT ENTER CITY'
description: In a major blow to the authority of Prime Minister Li Peng, seven senior military figures formally objected on Monday to the Government's plan to bring troops into the capital and suppress China's democracy movement.

title: DOLLAR UP AGAIN, DEFYING EFFORTS OF CENTRAL BANKS
description: Defying another round of concerted central bank intervention and a strong signal of concern from the White House, the dollar swept past two more milestones yesterday in its relentless advance.

title: Farah Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The first quarter of fiscal 1988 included a credit of $1,262,000 for cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: INSIDE
description: Prague and the Hard-Liners While some Czechoslovak allies are moving toward change, Prague seems to risk drifting into the company of its hard-line allies. Page A8. Bacteria to Combat Oil Spill An experiment on an oil-fouled beach in Alaska could be a landmark in the use of microbes against toxic chemicals. Science Times, page C1. Japan Studies Merger Game In an unusual cross-cultural experiment, Japanese securities professionals get a crash course in a uniquely American business. Page D1.

title: Soviet Pollution Hurts Finnish Wilderness
description: THE Finns, who have lived a careful life of political neutrality for more than four decades, are now confidently offering criticism and advice to their big neighbor to the east on a problem they did not even suspect until last year: damage to northern Finnish wilderness areas from Soviet air pollution.

title: Fireman's Fund Fills Post
description: The Fireman's Fund Insurance Company said today that Joseph W. Brown Jr., its vice chairman, executive vice president and chief financial officer, has been elected president.

title: Trans World Music Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The latest quarter net was reduced by a one-time, after-tax charge of about $1.5 million for costs associated with litigation relating to the use of a discontinued service mark. The latest quarter's results also included the closing of 17 Crazy Eddie stores.

title: Our Towns; They've a Certain Primitive Naif. Note the Art, Too.
description: The annual art show opened the other night at the New Rochelle Public Library and once again, the age-old question arose: ''What is art?''

title: Diet in Beijing: Fast Then Feast
description: While Beijing's university students won much of their renown for the hunger strike by 3,000 students in the center of the capital, the strike has ended and for most of the tens of thousands of students in the area, fasting is nearly impossible.

title: San Francisco City Benefits Extended to Unwed Couples
description: The city Board of Supervisors today unanimously approved the nation's first law allowing unmarried people who live together as lovers to register their partnerships publicly.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: Hanson Plc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary income of $157 million for the quarter and $435 million for the 6 months. c-After extraordinary income of $356 million for the quarter and 6 months. The results are in U.S. dollars. The exchange rate used for both March 31, 1989 and March 31, 1988 was the March 31, 1989 rate of 1 pound sterling equals U.S. $1.688 and at March 31, 1988, 1 pound equals $1.888. The 6 months' figures to March 31, 1989 included an additional one month's contribution from Kidde, acquired Nov. 1, 1987, compared with 1988. The year-ago quarter and 6 months included sales and profits from businesses since sold. Share earnings represented American Depositary Receipt (ADR) and each ADR represented 5 ordinary shares.

title: Cat Stevens Gives Support To Call for Death of Rushdie
description: The musician known as Cat Stevens said in a British television program to be broadcast next week that rather than go to a demonstration to burn an effigy of the author Salman Rushdie, ''I would have hoped that it'd be the real thing.''

title: Addenda
description: * ABC Publishing acquired Decorative Products World magazine, a publication of Business News Publishing Co.

title: Rift in Continent
description: One of the most ambitious studies of a single geologic feature has found that the rift valley in midcontinent contains the deepest accumulation of volcanic material known in the world.

title: America's Trade Curbs Are Unfair, Too
description: On the eve of Washington's crackdown on so-called ''unfair'' trade restrictions by other countries, an international panel has ruled that one of America's most outrageous restrictions is unfair, too: the quota on sugar imports. The timing is coincidental, but the message is clear. Unfair trade, like fair trade, works both ways.

title: Testers, Not Women, Must Explain S.A.T. Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: Champion Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 3
description: For fiscal 1989, the company's manufactured housing segment loss included a provision of $2,775,000 for the disposal of the company's retail subsidiary, Global Homes Inc. Fiscal 1989 operating income for the recreation vehicle and bus segment included a $1,920,000 gain from an insurance settlement. Real estate segment income for fiscal 1989 included a gain of $532,000 from the sale of two manufactured housing community developments. Fiscal 1988 included a $900,000 gain from the sale of a parcel of land under development. The company said the 1988 loss included a charge of $2,973,000 from the writeoff of prepaid income tax benefits.

title: Topics of The Times; The Economists' Economist
description: To economists, Sir John Hicks, who died Saturday at 85, was a Promethean figure even in the company of fellow Nobel laureates. Along with Paul Samuelson, Dr. Hicks helped explain the Keynesian revolution in economic thinking.

title: Let's Make Mike Tyson A Linebacker
description: In other years boxing was a business of noble cruelty. ''But it's not boxing anymore,'' the old trainer Ray Arcel was saying recently. ''It's exploitation.'' And day by day, it's almost wrestling.

title: Precious Metal Prices Fall; Hong Kong Gold Sales Cited
description: Prices of precious metals plunged to 33-month lows yesterday as the dollar continued to soar. Dealers traced much of the selling of bullion to Hong Kong, where many people, frightened by the upheaval in China, have been converting their gold into dollars.

title: New Law Limiting Dissent Is Softened by Soviet Court
description: Responding to concerns over a new decree on the limits of dissent, the Soviet Government today issued a ''clarification'' stating that there would be no criminal proceedings merely for voicing criticism of the state.

title: Landlords Suing the Housing Court as Unfair
description: Taking a new step in the tug of war between landlords and tenants, a landlords' group yesterday sued the judges who administer the New York City housing court, contending that the court was systematically unfair to property owners.

title: Nicolet Instrument reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $759,000 for the quarter and $3,364,000 for the year, and a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $10,489,000 for the both periods. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $836,000 for the quarter and $48,000 for the year.

title: New Head of Manhattan Music School
description: Dr. Peter C. Simon was named president of the Manhattan School of Music yesterday, Gordon K. Greenfield, chairman of the school, announced. Dr. Simon, a 39-year-old pianist and the director of academic studies at the Royal Conservatory of Music of the University of Toronto, will succeed Gideon W. Waldrop, who resigned in December.

title: Menotti And His Spoleto Festival
description: Gian Carlo Menotti, artistic director of the Spoleto Festival U.S.A., leaned forward and confided mischievously, ''We produce some things at the festival which I personally detest!''

title: Astro-Med Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
A New Clue to Food Poisoning and Toxic Shock
description: UNTIL now, medical scientists thought they knew how bacteria cause diseases like food poisoning or toxic shock syndrome. The bacteria produce toxins, and the toxins were thought to produce the disease symptoms.

title: Times Co. In Deal to Buy McCall's
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it had agreed in principle to acquire McCall's magazine from Working Woman/McCall's Group, a joint venture of Time Inc. and Dale W. Lang, a media investor.

title: Financial News Composite Fd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Assets represented total net assets. Share earnings represented net asset value.

title: Though Rarely Used, Leach Has the Right Stuff
description: Terry Leach spends his afternoons at his locker, reading the bible, drawing instruction and strength from the scriptures. Then, he almost invariably adjourns to the bullpen, where he spends his evenings reading the writing on the wall. The message generally is deciphered to this: No work likely tonight. From this, he tries to draw no conclusions too despairing.

title: Citicorp Subsidiary Offering 5-Year Asset-Backed Notes
description: Citibank (South Dakota) N.A., a subsidiary of Citicorp, offered $500 million of five-year asset-backed notes through a syndicate led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Johnson Is M.V.P. For a Second Time
description: Magic Johnson, who led the Los Angeles Lakers to their eighth consecutive division title this season, was honored yesterday with his second National Basketball Association Most Valuable Player Award.

title: Testers, Not Women, Must Explain S.A.T. Gap
description: To the Editor:

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING Win Returns to Winners Circle: Win, the popular 9-year-old New York-bred who returned to racing last month after an absence of three and a half years, scored his first victory since November 1985 when he won yesterday's featured Slightly Dangerous Handicap at Belmont Park. Win led all the way under Richard Migliore and held off Three Engines, the favorite, in a stretch duel to win by a head after a mile and a quarter on the grass in 2:027 2/5. Win, a Barachois gelding owned and trained by Sally Bailie, paid $9 for $2 to win. TENNIS Gomez Advances in Florence: Andres Gomez of Ecuador, the top-seeded player, breezed past Tore Meinecke of West Germany, 6-2, 7-5, in the first round of the City of Florence tournament in Italy yesterday. Luiz Mattar of Brazil, seeded third, survived a tough three sets to defeat unseeded Nicolas Pereira of Venezuela, 6-4, 3-6, 7-5, while seventh-seeded Lawson Duncan subdued Claudio Panatta of Italy, 7-5, 6-4. (AP)

title: 2 Legislators Are Indicted in Japan's Scandal

title: Tennessee Williams in Russian
description: Vitaly Solomin, a Soviet actor with a deep voice and a mesmerizing stare, broke off the dialogue and silently peered into the darkness beyond the rehearsal stage, looking for the rich abyss of Tennessee Williams's imagination.

description: The company said the year-ago fourth quarter included a land sale which generated a gross margin of $2.6 million.

description: * AT&T Network Systems, Morristown, N.J., a unit of American Telephone and Telegraph Co., named William B. Marx president. He succeeds E. Wayne Weeks, who retired.

The Truth of China
description: The truth of what has happened in China is so startling that even now the world hardly takes it in. For a time, the Government of the world's most populous country has lost its power to govern and control the nation. When that happens a Government is in effect overthrown until it shows it can resume control.

title: Burnett Moves To New Offices
description: The Leo Burnett Company will set off on a long trek this weekend - carting 36,000 boxes of personal belongings and 2.5 million pounds of office equipment five blocks across town to its new headquarters building on West Wacker Drive in Chicago.

title: Albert B. Dick 3d, 71, Manufacturer, Is Dead
description: Albert Blake Dick 3d, former president of the A. B. Dick Company, manufacturers of business machines, died Friday at Lake Forest Hospital in Illinois after a brief illness. He was 71 years old and lived in Lake Forest.

description: A Brooklyn judge yesterday formally executed her jail sentence against Sheldon Weinberg, who was convicted of Medicaid fraud, and admonished him for his ''crime of violence.''

title: Corrections

description: The Commercial Credit Company, a unit of Commercial Credit Group Inc., offered $100 million of 10-year notes yesterday through an underwriting syndicate led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company.

title: Corrections

title: A Palestinian Driver Is Killed By a Stone-Throwing   Israeli
description: A Palestinian was killed today by a rock thrown at his car by Israelis, and gunmen attacked the Israeli police in the West Bank and soldiers who were hitchhiking in the Negev Desert.

title: Laser Industries Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $1,977,000 from the termination of a product line and an extraordinary gain of $1,989,000 on the repurchase of debentures, both for the quarter and year. c-Net income and after a loss from the termination of a product line of $513,000 and an extraordinary gain of $265,000 on the repurchase of debentures. The company in 1987 changed its fiscal year-end from March 31 to Dec. 31. For the 9 months ended Dec. 31, 1987, the company reported net from continuing operations of $2,693,000, or 58 cents a share. In the year-ago 9 months, a loss from the termination of a product line of $513,000 and an extraordinary gain of $265,000 on the repurchase of debentures made final net $2,445,000, or 53 cents a share.

title: HONG KONG MARKET FALLS OVER UNREST
description: Hong Kong investors reacted swiftly and fearfully to the political crisis in China today, frantically selling shares and forcing the market's index down by almost 11 percent. It was the greatest plunge in a single day here since the worldwide market collapse of 1987.

title: Washington Talk; Why Bush's Nominees Are Caught in a Limbo

title: A Glass Premiere to Open Serious Fun
description: The New York premiere of Philip Glass's chamber opera ''The Fall of the House of Usher'' will kick off Lincoln Center's third annual Serious Fun festival on July 14 at Alice Tully Hall, Nathan Leventhal, president of Lincoln Center, announced yesterday.

title: U.S. House Leaders Disclose Speech Fees Near Legal Limit
description: House leaders in both parties received about as much as they legally could in honorariums last year, relying heavily on income from speeches before groups with an interest in legislation.

title: Macmillan Book Club Unit And a Publisher Being Sold
description: K-III Holdings Inc., a new investment company associated with Kohlberg, Kravis, Roberts & Company, agreed yesterday to acquire a book club division from Macmillan Inc. and the assets of the Intertec Publishing Corporation, a magazine publisher, for a total of $310 million.

title: Frances Bernstein, 57, Lawyer in Manhattan
description: Frances B. Bernstein, a lawyer and partner in Pavia & Harcourt law firm in Manhattan, died of cancer Thursday at her home in Tenafly, N.J. She was 57 years old.

title: Rig Count Falls Sharply
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United States plunged by 34 last week, to a total of 737, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today. A year ago, the count was 892. The count - the widely watched industry index of drilling activity - reflects the number of rigs exploring for oil as of last Friday.

description: To The Living Section:

description: Headlines here refer to him as ''the ambassador of dirty words,'' and Government officials complain privately, and newspapers publicly, that his appointment is proof of the low regard that the United States Government has for Italy.

title: Upheaval in China; Chinese take Umbrage At Attack on Mao Portrait
description: Mao Zedong's giant portrait on Tiananmen Square, a striking symbol of Chinese Communism, was defaced today by three men who splattered paint across its face.

title: Hello, Ms. 470-635-1, May I Help You?
description: JAY NEWMAN, who just moved to Miami from Philadelphia, found himself digging through the wastebasket recently in search of a discarded letter that might give him a clue to the ZIP code of his new office. No, Mr. Newman wasn't losing his mind. Just his ZIP codes, bank machine personal identification number, cellular phone number, office extensions, not to mention his new home address. Such is the joy of a new residence. Howard Kane never had such problems. Mr. Kane, who owns a public relations firm in Manhattan, boasts that he has about 10,000 numbers in his head and insists that he seldom forgets ''important ones.'' So why, one might ask, does he need that little black computerized watch with a capacity to remember 30 numbers?

title: Syntex Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Paying Congress Through the Back Door
description: House Speaker Jim Wright is hardly the only member of Congress with an ethics problem. Newly filed financial reports show that most representatives and senators continue to supplement their $89,500 annual salary by pocketing generous honorariums from Government favor-seekers.

title: Upheaval in China; Delay Urged in China Travel; Companies Cautious

title: Environment Is Security
description: Students at Copenhagen University, like most young people across Western Europe, have written off the defense issue. They want to get on with talk about the future. Some put it as shifting from East-West to North-South problems. Others, more appropriately, see it as facing the longer-term global threat to the environment as the threat of nuclear war seems to have receded.

title: Hong Kong Stocks Rebound

The market tumbled 339.06 points on Monday, a fall of 10.8 percent. But the colony's Hang Seng index shot back today to gain 261.08 points, to 3,067.65, the largest single-day gain since the stock exchange was created from four smaller markets three years ago, brokers said.

title: U.S. INVESTIGATORS FAULT ALOHA LINE IN FATAL ACCIDENT
