title: Ex-Official in Maine Guilty in Sex Offense
description: A former selectman in Kennebunk pleaded guilty today to a charge of unlawful sexual contact with a teen-ager and was sentenced to 364 days in jail.

title: Unions Reject A.T.&T. Offer
description: Negotiators for two unions, in intense talks over a new three-year contract with the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, today rejected a company package that included a reduction in health benefits.

title: Optical Coating Laboratory reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The year-ago 6 months included a $553,000 gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change.

title: Melcor Developments Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Morris A. Copeland, 93, Is Dead
description: Dr. Morris A. Copeland, an economist who specialized in the flow of money and the distribution of income in the United States, died of pneumonia May 4 in Sarasota, Fla., where he lived in retirement. He was 93 years old.

title: Metro Datelines; Gang Beating Leads To Arrest of 3 Youths
description: Twenty youths beat three other youths on Sunday in a park here, and two victims were taken to a hospital for treatment, the police said yesterday.

title: New York Restaurants Struggle
description: THE restaurant business in New York City is undergoing its worst setback in recent history, according to restaurateurs, restaurant consultants, food suppliers and others. They cite a wide variety of factors including hard times on Wall Street, an excess of new restaurants in Manhattan, changes in the tax law and the new cachet of dining at home.

title: Real Estate; New Jersey Condo Units For Industry
description: WHEN the Meadowlands, a sprawling, 32-square-mile mixed-use development district in New Jersey, was created more than 15 years ago, warehouses and light manufacturing companies were the first to find homes there.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on May 11 about a legal action by the International Business Machines Corporation against Big Blue Products Inc. over the use of the name ''Big Blue,'' which is an I.B.M. trademark, incorrectly described a statement in a letter from an I.B.M. lawyer to the Long Island-based computer-equipment company. The letter said that I.B.M. wanted Big Blue Products to agree within 30 days to discontinue using ''Big Blue'' to describe its company name or products and to let I.B.M. know when the words would actually be discontinued. The letter did not request that Big Blue Products drop the words within 30 days.

title: Savoring Coffee Down to the Last Bean
description: LEAD: THE inviting aroma of just-ground coffee lures passers-by into McNulty's, a 94-year-old specialty coffee store in Greenwich Village. Inside the shop, big burlap bags, old metal bins and huge glass canisters offer a wide selection of glistening brown coffee beans and fragrant tea leaves. At McNulty's and other merchants across the nation, the sensuous pleasures of fresh coffee beans and teas are enticing more and more customers to step inside and buy.

title: Williams-Sonoma Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Riser Foods reports earnings for Qtr to April 8

description: b-Included a special charge of $11,386,579. c-Net income Year-earlier figures have been restated. The charge in the latest period is due to a $11,386,579 writedown to $8,000,000 of the value of a gold mine. As reported, Louvem sold an undivided 50 percent-interest in the mine to Cambior Inc. in March. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: O. Rundle Gilbert; Auctioneer, 83
description: O. Rundle Gilbert, an auctioneer and appraiser, died of heart failure Sunday at his home in Waitsfield, Vt. He was 83 years old.

description: Revenue represented gross revenues (excluding revenues from sales of properties and investments.)

title:
Market Place;
Why Hilton Hints He Might Sell
description: LEAD: BARRON HILTON, chairman of the Hilton Hotels Corporation, cannot stop talking about selling his company.

title: Monitoring of Chemicals Splits Agencies
description: The Federal Government is at odds with many state and local authorities over how closely to monitor dangerous chemicals made or stored by industry.

title: Indiana Jones in Pursuit of Dad and the Grail
description: Before Indiana Jones can team up with his father to elude the Nazis and race them to the Holy Grail, he must travel halfway around the world. He leaves the cozy American campus where he teaches archeology, guides a beautiful woman through a rat-infested tunnel in Venice and makes his way to a castle swarming with Nazis on the Austrian-German border. There, Indiana swashbuckles his way into the room where Henry Jones is held prisoner and finds his tweedy, academic, mildly befuddled Dad. ''Junior?'' asks Sean Connery, and Harrison Ford answers, with years of exasperation behind him, ''Don't call me that, please.''

title: Exar Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included losses from Exar's 19 percent stake in Exel Microelectronics Inc. of $1,081,000 for the quarter and $1,949,000 for the year. c-Net loss and included losses from Exel of $5,088,000 and $12,752,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, which at the time was wholly owned subsidiary of Exar.

title: U.S. Banknote Sets Acquisition
description: The International Banknote Company, a New York-based company that prints certificates, currency and stamps, agreed to be acquired by the United States Banknote Company L.P. for $5.50 a share in cash plus $1.50 a share in junior subordinated debentures, or a total of about $125 million.

title: Karen Ulane, 48, Pilot; Who Had Sex Change
description: Karen Ulane, a Vietnam War combat pilot who was discharged by Eastern Airlines after a sex-change operation in 1980, was killed Monday in the crash of a charter plane. She was 48 years old and lived in Aurora.

title: Louis R. Bruce, Ex-Commissioner Of Indian Affairs, Is Dead at 83
description: Louis R. Bruce Jr., a former Federal Commissioner of Indian Affairs and an advocate of Indians' rights, died of cancer and heart disease Saturday at Crystal City Nursing Center in Arlington, Va. He was 83 years old and lived in Arlington.

title: Foreman Circles Closer to Tyson
description: A midafternoon rain falls on Houston. When it stops, roosters along Lone Oak, a street of bungalow-type homes set on cinder blocks, begin to crow.

title: Review/Ballet; With Icicles and Attitude, A Chilly 'Swan Lake'
description: On looks alone, the New York City Ballet's beautiful second-act production of ''Swan Lake'' is a triumph, with its glistening canopy of icicles and its distant rock and ice cliffs, their sheer slopes crowned forebodingly by what might be palaces. But Alain Vaes's sets and his chic costumes, with imaginative lighting credited to Ronald Bates, are not enough to warm an overly chilly performance. And cool distance was the order of the evening when George Balanchine's 1981 reworking of the piece was presented by City Ballet on Friday night at the New York State Theater.

title: U.S. FAULTS ACCORD ON LARGE FISHNETS
description: Secretary of Commerce Robert A. Mosbacher believes a tentative agreement with Japan on the use of huge fishing nets is inadequate and he will ask the State Department to negotiate a new one, a Commerce Department spokesman said today.

title: Why Youth Revolt
description: LEAD: The special role of students in fostering rebellion and radical politics, both of the left and right, now evident in China, Korea and other countries, is an old and continuing story.

title: For Anti-Drug Boot Camps
description: One solution to the drug scourge in our cities is readily available. Military bases that are scheduled for closing or partial deactivation could be quickly and economically turned into ''boot camps'' to treat and discipline first-time drug offenders and to punish repeat offenders.

The sale price was not disclosed. California Federal, a subsidiary of Cal Fed Inc. of Los Angeles, also bought four branch buildings from American Savings.

The solution he has proposed would raise taxes on one- two- and three-family houses a maximum of 6 percent, not 10.6 percent.

The program will include Bach's ''Brandenburg'' Concerto No. 5 and Beethoven's Symphony No. 1, and the actress Susan St. James is to read the Dr. Seuss poem ''Gerald McBoing Boing,'' set to music by Gail Kubik. Admission is by donation of at least $15. Information: 410-9823.

title: About New York; A Survivor's Life In the Shadow Of a 1904 Disaster
description: Catherine Connelly does not hear very well and has cataracts. But she has known the large joys of 11 children, 26 grandchildren and 10 great-grandchildren, with 2 more on the way. On Mother's Days, her East Side apartment blossoms like the botanic gardens. And small pleasures brighten her life - late-night pinochle games with a son, the Mets on television, church and the supermarket.

description: Stepping up its efforts to diminish the state's role in the economy, the Mexican Government announced today that it would sell its majority share in Mexicana de Aviacion, the country's leading airline, and that foreign investors would be encouraged to acquire a minority stake in the flag carrier.

description: Three men were arrested yesterday and charged with pelting a police officer with rocks they were throwing at motorists on the Harlem River Drive, the police said.

title: Seafood: Right at Home On the Barbecue
description: WHEN backyard cooks fire up the grill for the first time this season, the sizzling steak is likely to be swordfish, not sirloin. Since people are eating more fish these days, according to food-industry statistics, it is only natural that it will be on the menu for summer cookouts. And once a dish has become popular in restaurants, as grilled fish has, it is bound to tempt the home cook, too.

description: After a 10-year absence from Arab summit meetings, Egypt called on other Arab countries today to stop ''wasting opportunities and time'' and to formulate a vision of peace in the Middle East.

title: Durables Orders Up a Strong 2.9% in April
description: Factory orders for durable goods rose by an unexpectedly strong 2.9 percent in April, the largest increase since December and a reflection of broad gains in the manufacturing sector, the Commerce Department said today.

description: With medicine preoccupied by AIDS, a question that doctors once only whispered has emerged as a subject of open medical debate: should doctors be allowed to help their patients kill themselves?

description: After five years of legal skirmishing, the battle over jet noise at the nation's busiest airport has finally cleared one hurdle - selection of the right arena.

description: ''You are a contracting officer in the Air Force,'' began the question in a first- of-its-kind class held here this week to teach ethics to Government procurement officials. ''A company sends to you at your office a paperweight in the form of a toy model of the F-43, with 'The Air Force F-43 by ''A'' Company' engraved on the top of its base.''

description: Prices of Treasury securities were narrowly mixed in light trading yesterday, despite a report that should have pushed yields higher for all maturities.

description: Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, the Iranian revolutionary leader, underwent surgery today to stop internal bleeding. He was later reported in good condition, but new questions about the Ayatollah's health heightened speculation about Iran's future leadership.

description: The city's Board of Supervisors on Monday approved an ordinance recognizing the unions of homosexuals and unmarried heterosexual couples. Gay rights advocates hailed the move.

title: Slayer of Sons Gets Life Term
description: Bartley James Dobben was sentenced today to life in prison without parole for murdering his two young sons in a 1,300-degree foundry ladle. Mr. Dobben, 28 years old, received the mandatory sentence from Judge James Graves Jr. of Muskegon County Circuit Court. Mr. Dobben was sentenced a week after a jury found him guilty but mentally ill on two counts of murder.

title: Wright Lawyer Asks Ethics Panel To Throw Out Main Accusations
description: Jim Wright's lawyer urged the House ethics committee today to throw out its main charges against the Speaker. The lawyer, Stephen D. Susman, said that even if Mr. Wright had taken gifts from a developer and made bulk sales of his book when he reached limits set on speaking fees, he had not broken House rules.

title: 7 Contend Correction Dept. Urged Abortions for Guards
description: Seven present and former New York City correction officers contended yesterday that the Correction Department regularly told pregnant officers to have abortions or resign.

description: Ending a week of deliberations and a tense, bizarre day in Federal Court in Brooklyn, a jury last night convicted Gene Gotti and an associate of running a multi-million dollar heroin ring.

description: When President Bush and other leaders of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization gather in Brussels next week to mark the organization's 40th anniversary, they will find alliance doctrine in disarray and Europe's political order facing potentially momentous changes.

title: Simms Stays Away From Minicamp to Pressure Giants
description: Phil Simms of the Giants wants to join 15 other National Football League quarterbacks with annual salaries of $1 million or more. So he boycotted the opening day of the Giants' minicamp today, and his agent, David Fishof, said Simms would also stay away from training camp two months from now unless his contract was extended.

description: Patterns built and crumbled and delicacy battled noise in Zeena Parkins's music Thursday evening at Roulette. Ms. Parkins, who plays harp, piano, synthesizer and electric harp, ran together two compositions - ''Angel, Angel,'' a piece commissioned by Roulette for eight musicians, and a trio version of a recent dance score, ''Ignasius Bright'' - in an uninterrupted 50-minute program that opened a three-night stand.

title: 25 School Bus Operators Indicted After Undercover Bribe Inquiry
description: Owners and employees of 36 school bus companies in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island were indicted yesterday on charges that they tried to bribe an undercover officer to overlook safety violations.

title: McEnroe Withdraws
description: John McEnroe, who was seeded sixth in the $4.5 million French Open, the second Grand Slam event of 1989, has been forced to withdraw because of back pains. McEnroe was injured recently in an exhibition in the Netherlands and withdrew from the Italian Open. He has won tournaments this year in Lyon, France, and Dallas.(AP)

title: Top Scientific Post Is Filled at I.B.M.
description: John A. Armstrong, a physicist and director of research at the International Business Machines Corporation, has been named to the company's top scientific post, vice president for science and technology. He will report directly to John F. Akers, chairman of the board.

title: Montclair Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Jack Henry & Associates Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Sematech Awards 7 Contracts
description: Sematech, the semiconductor industry's two-year-old consortium for manufacturing research, today awarded its first development contracts to seven companies for advanced equipment and supplies required to produce a new generation of computer chips.

title: Education; Panel Says Blacks Are Taught Poorly
description: Blacks in public schools remain ''largely isolated'' and receive an inferior education, despite Federal and state efforts to provide equal opportunities in the 35 years since the Supreme Court ordered the end of segregated schools, a panel of prominent black scholars asserted in a report issued today.

title: General Parametrics reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company said that in the 1988 first quarter it adopted FAS No. 96 which resulted in a one-time reduction of its tax accrual in the amount of $250,000, or 3 cents a share.

title: Showscan Film Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss Year-ago results restated to reflect an accounting change.

title: Oxford Energy reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The latest first quarter included $3,106,000 from the sale of a limited partership interest in a waste-to- energy facility, and a tax credit of $473,000. The latest first quarter revenue included $5,680,000 from the sale of the limited partnership interest mentioned above.

title: The Urgent Search for a Chancellor
description: Following the sudden death of Schools Chancellor Richard Green two weeks ago, New York City's Board of Education has wisely begun an immediate search for his successor. Whatever the uncertainties created by the mayoral campaign, the need is urgent for strong leadership of the city's troubled school system.

title: Hammond Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Angry Protest Assails Police In Man's Death
description: A few hours after a resident of the Queensbridge housing project died in police custody early Monday morning, the mood in the vast cluster of buildings where he was raised and lived was mostly one of sorrow and shock.

title: Newport Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Trac Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $19,308 for the quarter and a charge of $481,530 for the 9 months. The company has changed its fiscal year-end to June 30 from Jan. 31 and comparative figures were not available. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Lakers Still Perfect In Postseason Play
description: The Los Angeles Lakers, led by Byron Scott's 30 points, remained undefeated in postseason play by defeating the Phoenix Suns, 101-95, in Game 2 of the Western Conference final series.

title: Metro Datelines; Mason Tries to Block Inquiry on Conduct
description: A lawyer and adviser to the family of Tawana Brawley charged yesterday that a state investigation into his professional conduct violated his free-speech rights. He asked a Federal court to block the inquiry.

title: Strategic Arms Parley Set to Resume in June
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d said today that the United States and the Soviet Union would resume long-delayed negotiations on reducing strategic nuclear weapons on June 19.

title: Italy Gives Arab a Life Term In a 1982 Synagogue Attack
description: An Italian court imposed a life sentence in absentia today on a Palestinian convicted in a 1982 attack on Rome's main synagogue in which a 2-year-old boy was killed and 37 other people were wounded.

title: The Equipment: A Grill, a Basket and a Spatula
description: COOKWARE shops and catalogues are showing specialized equipment for grilling seafood. Among the newer items is the Griffo-grill, a perforated metal plate that sits directly on the grid of a barbecue and prevents small pieces of food from falling through the grill. It also makes it easier to turn delicate fillets or cumbersome whole fish and reduces sticking. A raised edge along one side prevents food from being pushed off by a spatula.

title: Pepper's Condition Is Stable
description: Representative Claude Pepper, Democrat of Florida, remained in ''serious but stable'' condition at Walter Reed Army Hospital today, his press secretary said. The aide, Rochelle Jones, said there had been no change in the condition of the 88-year-old lawmaker, who is suffering from a stomach ailment of undisclosed nature. He has been hospitalized for more than a month.

title: Roadmaster Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and after a tax benefit of $197,041.

title: Sikes Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 28
Rada Electronic Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Julie Andrews-Carol Burnett Show Is Canceled at Carnegie
description: A June 8 performance in which Julie Andrews and Carol Burnett were to star as a benefit for Carnegie Hall has been canceled because of a rehearsal-scheduling conflict between the hall and the show's producers. More than 2,000 tickets have been sold for the show, which was to have been taped for an ABC television special.

title: Final Countdown for a Basketball Hero
description: Late spring is never the best season in Los Angeles. Early morning and evening fogs often cloud the mood, leaving but a hole of sunshine in the middle. This season is worse: it's Kareem Abdul-Jabbar's last with the Los Angeles Lakers. Everybody here knows it and feels it, even those who aren't strictly fans or part of that Hollywood courtside coterie featuring the likes of Jack Nicholson and Dyan Cannon who have routinely graced the Lakers games with their glitz. They have made basketball in this town a very hot ticket.

title: Deadline Today on Eastern Is Faced by America West
description: America West Airlines has been given until 5 P.M. today to come up with financing for its offer to buy the Eastern shuttle. If it fails, Eastern will ask the bankruptcy court to approve the agreement it has with Donald J. Trump, the New York developer, to buy the shuttle for $365 million.

title: U.S. Giants In Research Consortium
description: Three of the nation's technology powerhouses - the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, the International Business Machines Corporation and the Massachusetts Institute of Technology - announced yesterday that they were forming a consortium to do research aimed at developing applications for new ''high-temperature'' superconductors.

title: Steven De Groote, 36, a Pianist And Cliburn Competition Winner
description: Steven De Groote, a South African pianist who won first prize at the 1977 Van Cliburn International Piano Competition, died Monday in Johannesburg. He was 36 years old.

title: A Spray Bottle Easier to Use
description: Small children and elderly people with limited use of their hands can have trouble operating the pump spray bottles used to deliver some medications, cleaning fluids and food products. Compressed gas in aerosol cans can provide the power needed, but aerosols are facing restrictions because of environmental concerns.

title: Caesars New Jersey Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Caesars World Inc. owns 86.6 percent of Caesars New Jersey.

title: Inter-Provincial Diversified Holdings Ltd reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $1,032,553. c-Net loss Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: A Mideast Speech to Remember
description: There's no more difficult terrain for diplomatic oratory than Arab-Israeli negotiations. A new word, a slight change in emphasis or tone - almost anything can set off wails from peoples who have known little but death, despair and hatred.

title: Deere & Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included a one-time gain of $28.7 million, or 42 cents a share, from accounting changes and $19 million of tax loss carryforwards.

title: Houston Journal; Orchestra Conductor Adapts to Texas Ways
description: Since Christoph Eschenbach became musical director of the Houston Symphony Orchestra last autumn his face has been immortalized on a champagne bottle label, his social life has been recorded regularly in gossip columns and his name has become so familiar in mansions and country clubs here that it is rarely even mispronounced anymore.

title: Fed Easing Unlikely, Member Says
description: Despite his belief that the risk of serious inflation has nearly vanished, a senior Federal Reserve official indicated today that the central bank was unlikely to move quickly to relax monetary policy and bring down short-term interest rates.

title: 2 MEN CONVICTED OF ALASKAN FRAUD
description: A Federal jury convicted two men of extortion, racketeering and fraud Monday for schemes in which they profited from the billion-dollar construction boom on Alaska's North Slope in the early 1980's.

title: Synercom Technology reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After gains from tax credits of $154,000 for the quarter and $381,000 for the 6 months. c-Net loss and the quarter was after a $29,000 charge from a reversal of operating loss carryforwards.

title: Fire Razes House With Priceless Furniture
description: Fire destroyed a house in Princeton, N.J., yesterday that was home not only to the family that owned it, but also to a large collection of works by George Nakashima -considered by many the elder statesman of American crafts.

title: Review/Film; Indiana Jones in Pursuit of Dad and the Grail
description: Before Indiana Jones can team up with his father to elude the Nazis and race them to the Holy Grail, he must travel halfway around the world. He leaves the cozy American campus where he teaches archeology, guides a beautiful woman through a rat-infested tunnel in Venice and makes his way to a castle swarming with Nazis on the Austrian-German border. There, Indiana swashbuckles his way into the room where Henry Jones is held prisoner and finds his tweedy, academic, mildly befuddled Dad. ''Junior?'' asks Sean Connery, and Harrison Ford answers, with years of exasperation behind him, ''Don't call me that, please.''

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Schindler Has President For Its U.S. Subsidiary
description: LEAD: David J. Bauhs yesterday was appointed president of the Schindler Corporation, a newly formed subsidiary of the Schindler Group of Switzerland, the world's second-largest manufacturer of elevators, after Otis.

title: TENNIS
description: Ever Advances: Top-seeded ChrisEvert defeated a qualifier, Sabine Hack of West Germany, 6-3, 7-6, yesterday in the first round of the Geneva European Open women's tournament. In the second round, Evert, the 1987 winner of the tournament, will meet the defending champion Barbara Paulus of Austria, who is unseeded.

title: Economic Scene; Airline Computer: Friend or Foe?
description: THE airline reservation systems used by travel agents are wonders of computer technology, capable of booking hundreds of thousands of seats each day and still remembering that you prefer the aisle to the window seat and the fruit plate to the mystery meat.

title: Reading & Bates
description: The Reading & Bates Corporation, a troubled offshore oil and gas drilling company that is being restructured, said it had sold its domestic oil and gas properties to Ramco Oil and Gas Inc. and Ramco-NYL-1987 L.P. for $74 million. Ramco Oil was established several years ago to acquire oil and gas properties, said Rolf Hufnagel, a senior vice president at Ramco Oil. Ramco-NYL is backed by New York Life Insurance, he said. Both are based in Oklahoma City. Proceeds of the sale, whose terms were not disclosed, will be used to repay debt, Reading & Bates said in a statement. The Houston-based company also said it had changed the date of its annual meeting to July 11 to allow completion of a regulatory review by the Securities and Exchange Commission. The meeting had been scheduled for next Tuesday.

title: Dell Computer Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 28
Jessica E. Holland; Historian, 42
description: Jessica E. Holland, an oral historian, died Monday when the bicycle she was riding was hit by a car in Nuit St. Georges, France, where she was vacationing. She was 42 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Apartheid Foe Looks Back, With Grit
description: ''It's nice to read one's obituaries while one is still alive,'' Helen Suzman mused on a recent day in her small, sunlit office. ''It's the sort of things they would have written about me when I'm dead.''

title: Four Agents Indicted
description: Four sports agents in Florida have been indicted on charges that they paid athletes at the University of Florida to sign professional contracts and then lied about it. The four, all officers of Professional Athletes Financial Advisors Incorporated, in Hollywood, Fla., surrendered on Monday and were charged with conspiracy, racketeering, mail fraud and wire fraud.

title: Savings Bill Battle Is Seen
description: Republicans in the House of Representatives will again mount a fight on Wednesday for an amendment to President Bush's bailout plan that would weaken the tough capital standards for the savings and loan industry that were approved earlier this month by the House Banking Committee.

title: Gradco Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for all periods reflected the implementation of FASB No. 96.

title: Westvaco Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Westvaco said the latest second quarter included a gain equaled to 17 cents a share from annuitizing the liabilities for retirees at or above a certain age, and costs equaled to 14 cents a share from renovations to two paper machines and a recovery boiler.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: COOKING seafood on a grill has a narrower margin of error than cooking beef does. But while you can't run off for a quick round of badminton while cooking seafood, it is otherwise simple.

title: MLX Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Leniency Asked For Ron Peters
description: Federal prosecutors are asking leniency in the drug and tax evasion case involving Ron Peters, who, according to authorities, has reported taking perhaps more than $1 million in bets on behalf of Pete Rose.

title: H Paulin & Co reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Robeson Industries Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Feb 24
description: The latest year included $1,050,596 gain on the sale of a building.

title: Justice in New York, Observed
description: The idea that cameras in courtrooms can inform the public without endangering the right of the accused to a fair trial once was hotly debated, but experience has quieted most of the arguments. The Supreme Court approved the concept eight years ago. Most of the states now permit filmed and televised trials. And New York, one of the holdouts, is completing an 18-month experiment with judge-supervised photography. In no instance has it even been alleged that cameras affected the outcome. There's every reason to make photography the rule and not the exception.

title: Cubs Win and Take Over First
description: Shawon Dunston hit a two-run homer and Scott Sanderson won his fourth straight decision as Chicago beat the Houston Astros, 5-4, tonight. It was the Cubs' seventh victory in their last eight games and moved them past the Mets into first place in the National League East with a record of 24-19.

title: Friendly Waiters and Other Annoyances
description: IT'S only been about 10 years since American parents began to be thrilled to announce that their son or daughter had become a chef. Now, being a chef is right up there with doctor or lawyer. The same cannot be said for being a waiter or waitress.

title: Xerox Will Broaden Key Software Licenses
description: The Xerox Corporation said today that it would make available broad, new licensing arrangements for its graphical user interface technology software.

title: CNW Directors Are Favored
description: The CNW Corporation said today that shareholders had voted in favor of incumbent directors over a slate proposed by dissident shareholders in the proxy contest at the company's annual meeting last week.

title: Bridge
description: An amending of a famous joke punch line about Philadelphia provides a perfect description of the Women's Team final that ended Sunday in Memphis: ''The first prize is a week of bridge in Perth, Australia. The second prize is two weeks of bridge in Perth, Australia.''

title: Alaskan Wildlife Dies as Exxon Cleanup Fails; Much Dirtier Pool
description: To the Editor:

title: Maxwell Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
NEW SOVIET OFFER ON EUROPE FORCES
description: The Soviet Union moved substantially closer today to the Western position on cutting conventional arms in Europe, Western officials said.

title: Upheaval in China; . . . As Chinese in U.S. Pierce a News Blockade
description: For Chinese students studying in the United States, being left out of the demonstrations sweeping Beijing and other parts of China has been frustrating. But some students are using fax machines to share in the events through a two-way exchange of information.

title: Yankee Cos reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $607,000 for the quarter and $7,115,000 for the 9 months. c-Net income d-After a loss of $5,899,000 from the disposal of discontinued operations and a $21,452,000 credit from extraordinary items, both for the quarter and 9 months. The company noted that the latest third quarter included a tax adjustment of $1 million to reflect the company's expected lower tax liability and that $788,000 of the latest quarter's pre-adjusted loss was attributable to the company's equity in Eskey Inc., its wholly owned oil field service subsidiary.

title: Review/Music; Familiar Sonatas, Intensely
description: Nadja Salerno-Sonnenberg is a performer who understands the importance of rhythmic energy and a sense of direction. Her bristling intensity informed and carried each of the three familiar sonatas she played with Robert McDonald Saturday evening at the 92d Street Y. But there came a point rather early in each piece when one began to wish for some of the other possible virtues of music making (and of violin playing), and then it was a matter of long waits and meager rewards.

title: K Mart Optimistic Despite Sales Drop
description: The K Mart Corporation's sales this month are falling behind the company's expectations, but the nation's second-largest retailer said it still hopes to meet its 1989 sales target despite a softening retail market. At a news conference after K Mart's annual shareholders meeting, the company's chairman, Joseph E. Antonini, said sales this month are behind K Mart's goal of 3.5 percent growth. The soft May sales come on top of a disappointing first quarter in which K Mart's net income fell 22 percent, to $94.1 million.

title: Manufactured Homes reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Tridel Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a gain of $18.5 million from the sale of residential rental property and a $2 million tax credit. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Goal Systems International reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Review/Music; From Nashville, Deja Vu
description: A lot of current Nashville country music could give rock listeners a sense of deja vu: It sounds like country rock from the late 1960's and early 1970's. The Byrds, Poco, the Eagles and Tom Petty and the Heartbreakers are the models for Nashville-based, nominally country groups like Restless Heart, the Desert Rose Band, the Nitty Gritty Dirt Band, Highway 101 and the best of the bunch, Foster and Lloyd, who performed Tuesday at the Bottom Line.

title: Woodward's Ltd reports earnings for
description: b-After a gain of $600,000. Results are in Canadian dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stck exchanges.

title: New Rallying Cry: Parents Unite
description: A PARENTS' movement is astir in the United States. Unlike other recent social movements, this one is not a battle for rights or equality, but for relief.

title: Sun Coast Plastics reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results for Plastics Manufacturing Co., acquired Jan. 8, 1988, is the principal reason for the revenue increase.

title: Law Barring Weapons Is Signed in California
description: Gov. George Deukmejian today signed the nation's first statewide law restricting the sale and possession of assault weapons.

title: How Abbott Has Changed Baseball
description: Almost weekly, another photographer from another magazine will descend on Jim Abbott and ask the same question: What do you do at home?

title: Minneapolis Gets 1992 Super Bowl
description: Amid shrieks of joy from members of the selection task force, Minneapolis today was named the host city and the Metrodome the site of Super Bowl XXVI in 1992.

title: Company News; CNW Deadline Is Set for Offers
description: A special committee of the board of the CNW Corporation set a deadline of June 2 for offers to acquire the Chicago-based railroad holding company. Citing ''uncertainties'' about the $722 million hostile offer from Japonica Partners L.P., the committee said it could not approve or reject the $44-a-share bid. The committee urged CNW's shareholders to defer tendering their shares until it could finish its investigation of all offers. A Japonica spokesman said the partnership had no comment on the matter.

title: Review/Television; Wright's Bad Fortune Is Turning Into Good Viewing
description: Although Tuesday's televised hearing before the House ethics committee was devoted only to a motion by Jim Wright's lawyer to dismiss its charges against the House Speaker, it had the spirit of a coroner's jury. The people who watch CNN and C-Span, which carried the daylong proceedings, had been alerted for more than a week on talk shows and in newspapers to the Speaker's probable demise. Stephen D. Susman, Mr. Wright's lawyer, made that point to the cameras at the start of his opening statement; he knew what he was up against.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on April 22 about a patent dispute between the Hughes Aircraft Company and the Federal Government misidentified the law firm where Tom Arnold, a patent attorney, is a partner. Mr. Arnold works for the Houston firm of Arnold, White & Durkee.

title: William Hampton, 70, A Housing Developer
description: William J. Hampton, a longtime aide to the late Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr. and a housing developer, died of cancer of the colon and liver Sunday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 70 years old and lived in Corona, Queens.

title: Dunkin' Donuts Inc reports earnings for 13wks to April 29
description: b-Included a pretax charge of $2,628,000 related to consolidation and restructuring expenses for both the quarter and 6 months.

title: Interest in 2 Wildcats
description: Brad Holland, an assistant coach on the U.C.L.A. men's basketball team, said yesterday that the Bruins were pursuing two players from the University of Kentucky''s basketball program, which is under heavy sanctions from the National Collegiate Athletic Association as a penalty for recruiting violations.

title: Com Systems Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The 1989 first quarter primary share earnings include a provision for preferred dividends of $226,000, where as during the like period in 1988 no preferred shares were outstanding.

title: Capital Gains Tax Cut Should Go Farther
description: To the Editor:

title: What East-West Policy?
description: President Bush yesterday delivered his fourth, final, flat and flimsy speech on East-West relations. What explains the chasm between this vacuity and the substantial ability and experience of Mr. Bush and his senior advisers?

title: West German President Upholds Assertive Stance
description: As West Germany marked its 40th anniversary today, it was assured by its President that it may not be a ''great power'' but that it would not be a plaything for anyone.

title: International American Homes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said for 1989, revenue of $8,917,000 and net income of about $1,000,000 are from the sale of land acquired for investment and resale. For 1988, revenue and net income from the sale of land were about $2,556,000 and $255,000, respectively.

title: Jacobs Rumor Sends Avon Up
description: Amid speculation that Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, might make a new offer for Avon Products Inc., the direct-selling cosmetics company based in New York, Avon's stock climbed $1.125 yesterday, closing at $35.875, on the New York Stock Exchange. Almost 3.2 million shares of

title: TV Doesn't Belong in High Court
description: To the Editor:

title: O.J. Simpson Fined
description: The former football star O. J. Simpson must pay $700, perform 120 hours of community service and continue psychiatric counseling following his plea of no contest to a charge that he beat his wife, Nicole, a municipal judge in Los Angeles ruled yesterday.

title: Time's Stock Up $5.50, to $130.75, on Takeover Rumors
description: Spurred by still more takeover rumors, Time Inc. stock jumped $5.50 a share yesterday, closing at a record $130.75, as 1.2 million shares changed hands. One big factor prompting the increase was a rumor that Allen & Company, the investment banker that represents the Coca-Cola Company, had put Time Inc. on its restricted list.

title: Virgil Geddes Is Dead; Ex-Playwright Was 92
description: Virgil Geddes, a playwright turned postmaster, died of cancer yesterday at the Veterans Affairs Medical Center in Togus, Me. He was 92 years old and had homes in Brookfield, Conn., and Swan's Island, Me.

title: Lacquer That's Chic And Hardy
description: HANAE MORI, the fashion designer, has been making lacquerware in her home in Japan for years. Now 20 of her designs are being introduced at her Manhattan boutique, 27 East 79th Street. The line, called Chiki-Chic, consists of such items as stacking boxes, shown above, bowls, dishes and trays.

title: Joseph Pink, Executive, 81
description: Joseph Pink, a business executive and a former trustee of the Textile Workers Pension Fund, died of congestive heart failure yesterday at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Paterson, N.J.

title: Dycom Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Policxe in Brazil Recover 10 Stolen Paintings
description: Ten paintings stolen from the small Chacara do Ceu museum here on May 3, including works by Dali and Matlisse, have been recovered, the police have said. They said that a tip led them to the home of Jose Carlos Gomes de Mattos, an antiques dealer with a long criminal record, last Wednesday and that the paintings were found there.

title: Oriole's Tibbs Finally Wions One
description: Jay Tibbs ended his 10-game losing streak tonight in his first start of the season and Mickey Tetleton hit his 10th home run as the Baltimore Orioles defeated the Chicago White Sox, 8-0. The victory put the Orioles into a tie for first place with Boston in the American League East.

title: Sniper Suspect Ruled Mentally Competent
description: A man who believes he is a Rambo-like commando is mentally competent to stand trial for the Long Island sniper shootings that killed one man and injured three others, a judge ruled yesterday.

title: CORNELL SUSPENDS COMPUTER STUDENT
description: Cornell University has suspended Robert Tappan Morris, the 23-year-old graduate student identified by school officials as the author of a software program that jammed a nationwide computer network last November.

title: Trooper Is Charged IN Theft of Cocaine
description: A state trooper was charged Tuesday with stealing cocaine from an evidence locker and using it to make an arrest, the authorities said.

title: Spectre In the Suburbs
description: ALTHOUGH prominent designers like Mario Buatta and Mark Hampton have tried marketing their designs for everything from furniture to pillowcases, none have had quite the commercial success of Jay Spectre, a Manhattan decorator.

title: Judges Quit Lonrho Case
description: Five British judges discharged themselves today from hearing a contempt of court action they had brought against the Lonrho P.L.C. conglomerate and its newspaper, The Observer.

title: Early Birders Catch Glimpses of Parks' Many Species
description: At that singular time of morning when the moon and the rising sun share the sky, six people gathered in Central Park to count birds.

title: 7th Grader Stabbed; Classmate Is Charged
description: A seventh grader was charged with assault yesterday after a classmate was stabbed in the back with a steak knife at their junior high school, the police said.

title: Webster Clothes Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
Market Place; Behind Pessimism Over 'Junk Bonds'
description: WHILE the stock market looks for an economic soft landing, recession fears seem to be lingering in the ''junk bond'' market, where yields remain stubbornly high. That is leading some junk bond managers to grow more bullish, hoping that junk bond prices will rise as investors get more optimistic about the economy.

title: United Illuminating Co reports earnings for 12mo April 30
description: b-After losses from accounting changes of $49,594,000 for 1989 and $86,624,000 for 1988. The latest 12 months included a $7.4 million non-cash charge related to Millstone Unit 3 and a $1.16 a share writeoff to recognize a probable extension of the commercial operation date of the Seabrook Unit 1 from July 1, 1989, to at least Oct. 1, 1990.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Slip
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds dipped slightly in sluggish trading yesterday, as dealers sold securities in advance of an auction of $8.75 billion worth of two-year Treasury notes.

title: Rev. Paul Beattie, 52, A Leader of Humanists
description: The Rev. Paul H. Beattie, a Unitarian clergyman who was a leader in the humanist movement, died Monday of complications following heart surgery at Presbyterian University Hospital in Pittsburgh. He was 52 years old and lived in Pittsburgh.

title: Death of an Old Highway, a Home for the Homeless
description: Robert Ing stood beside the ramshackle plywood shed he first built five years ago on the disused elevated portion of the West Side Highway and considered where he would go after work begins this morning to demolish the road.

title: When Left-of-Center Finds Itself in Mainstream
description: Nancy Donaldson, Washington director of Women's Action for Nuclear Disarmament, was astonished recently to find herself nodding in agreement as someone from the Heritage Foundation, a bastion of conservative thought, testified before Congress about arms control.

title: Poland Acknowledges Soviet-Nazi Pact on Its Fate
description: Poland took a further step toward candor in its treatment of Polish-Soviet history today when the Communist Party daily published an official report contending that the Soviet Union and Nazi Germany split Poland between themselves in 1939 under the terms of a secret agreement.

title: Matsushita Electric Industrial Co Ltd reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The results are in U.S. currency and had been translated at the rate of U.S. $1.00 equaled 132 yen. Share earnings represented American Depositary Share (ADS) and each ADS represented 10 shares of common stock. The 1988 results have been restated to reflect Matsushita's expanded consolidation basis and, for parent-alone results, its merger with Matsushita Electric Trading Co. Ltd., on April 1, 1988.

title: Others Reportedly Rejected Opera Post
description: Musicians and opera officials said today that Myung Whun Chung, the South Korean-born conductor who was chosen to head the new Bastille Opera, was picked after several prominent musical figures refused the post because they were solidly booked for the next few years or because they feared major problems with the opening of the 2,700-seat opera house next year.

title: MAN PUT TO DEATH FOR TEXAS MURDER
description: A man was executed by injection early today for raping and then helping to kill a young woman who was abducted in 1981 as she awaited help in her disabled car.

title: TRITIUM ESTIMATES CALLED OPTIMISTIC
description: Congressional investigators told the House Armed Services Committee today that it will take longer than previously believed to build and operate two new plants to produce tritium, a vital component in nuclear weapons.

title: Oil-Dri Corp of America reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Review/Opera; Alternate Principals For 'Atys'
description: The star of Lully's ''Atys,'' the path-breaking Paris Opera production that has just visited the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is its conductor, William Christie, whose vision is responsible both for the restoration of Lully's reputation as a composer of worth and for the formation of the extraordinary Arts Florissants ensemble that has been able to demonstrate that worth. But the individual singers in the cast have their own claim to the kind of stardom that can be achieved within a closely coordinated ensemble, and so the alternate principals who took the Friday night performance are worthy of separate notice.

title: New Editorial Writer at The Times
description: Leon V. Sigal, professor of government at Wesleyan University, is joining the editorial board of The New York Times, it was announced yesterday by Jack Rosenthal, editorial page editor.

title: A Warning on Laughing Gas
description: The Nassau County police are cracking down on stores that sell laughing gas to minors, County Executive Thomas Gulotta said today. He said the police have been receiving complaints about teen-agers sniffing laughing gas - nitrous oxide - to get ''high.'' State law prohibits selling the gas to minors. The director of the Nassau County Medical Center's poison control center, Dr. Howard Mofenson, said nitrous oxide can cause a loss of memory, cardiac arrest and spinal problems.

title: Upheaval in China; In China, Chaos Among the Leaders
description: American analysts of China acknowledged today that they had little reliable information about the power struggle unfolding in Beijing. But they said that everything they did know suggests it will be a bitter and protracted fight in which half the leaders on one side or the other may lose their positions.

title: Marble, Brass, Neon And Fries
description: THE latest McDonald's restaurants to open in Manhattan have a more sophisticated look than the roadside stands that have dotted the landscape for two decades. No longer cookie-cutter designs in red, yellow and white plastic, they feature marble, Vermont slate and polished brass.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''All the students in my year face the same problem. Our main task as students is to study, and we know that when we leave the university, we must earn a living based on what we have learned here. But what preoccupies us is the environment we will end up in. Will it be free and democratic, or will it be repressive?'' - Wu Qiaohong, a senior at Beijing University. [ A1:2. ]

title: Media Business: Advertising; Pro Bono
description: * Taylor-Gordon, Aarons, a four-year-old ad agency, has been selected to create pro bono advertising for the Highbridge Community Life Center, a nonprofit organization in the South Bronx that helps people with AIDS.

title: SPEAKER CONCEDES HE MUST QUIT POST, HIS FRIENDS REPORT
description: After months of combat, House Speaker Jim Wright today accepted that the political damage from an ethics investigation has become too great and that he will have to step down, supporters and Democratic colleagues reported.

title: Some in G.O.P. Deserting Bush On Savings Plan
description: The Administration's savings and loan rescue plan met with serious opposition from President Bush's own Republican ranks today in a confrontation that reflected heavy lobbying efforts by the industry and could signal problems for the plan when it reaches the House floor.

title: Fire Raging in Everglades
description: Firefighters from as far away as California today battled a fire that has scorched more than 75,000 acres of the Everglades. The smoke caused a haze over much of the Miami metropolitan area. The fire is centered in Everglades National Park about 30 miles from downtown Miami. Lightning started it May 16.

title: A Cipher for Civil Rights?
description: The nomination of William Lucas as Assistant Attorney General for Civil Rights has split the civil rights movement in an odd way. The disagreement isn't over his views; he hasn't compiled much of a record. It's between those who are deeply offended by the choice of a civil rights nonentity and those who are willing to settle for one.

title: Going to the Movies, Staying at Home
description: IN the basement of a Victorian brownstone in the Park Slope section of Brooklyn is a playroom right out of the movies: a 1,000-square-foot Art Deco-style theater equipped with 10 red velvet seats and the latest technology.

title: Middlesex Water Co reports earnings for 12mo April 30
Books of The Times; James Jones's Letters Contrast With His Fiction
description: To Reach Eternity The Letters of James Jones Edited by George Hendrick Illustrated. 380 pages. Random House.

title: Baby's Skull Is Broken; Father Is Held in Death
description: A father in Brooklyn was arrested Tuesday and charged with murder after his infant daughter died from skull fractures, the police said.

title: Q&A
description: Cleaning Oak Cabinets

title: A Sudden Ascent To the Top in Opera
description: Until two days ago, the musical world knew Myung Whun Chung as a promising young conductor building his credentials in the traditional way - leading an orchestra in Saarbrucken, West Germany, and climbing the ladder at the Metropolitan Opera with two quietly successful engagements conducting revivals of standard works.

title: PRESIDENT WISHES GORBACHEV WELL ON SOVIET CHANGE
description: In his most positive assessment so far of Mikhail S. Gorbachev's policies, President Bush said today that he wanted the economic and political changes to succeed and welcomed recent Soviet arms control proposals.

title: Communication Cable Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Share earnings results are restated for a 5 percent stock dividend declared March 13, 1989.

title: Topics of The Times; India as International Bully
description: Americans ought not to remain silent as India continues a harmful and indefensible blockade of Nepal.

title: Topics of The Times; Times Square Tango
description: What ever happened to the tango? It is being danced, with considerable panache, at the Times Square stop of the Seventh Avenue subway.

title: Baker Draws A Line in the Sand
description: LEAD: Secretary of State James Baker's speech Monday to the American-Israel Public Affairs Committee may have angered Israel's Prime Minister and some, though not all, American Jewish leaders.

title: SPI-Suspension & Parts Inustries Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income

title: Article 877689 -- No Title
description: Frederic Edwin Church's 1852 frontier painting ''Home by the Lake'' was sold yesterday by the Walker Art Center of Minneapolis at Sotheby's for $8.25 million, the highest price ever paid at auction for a pre-20th-century American painting.

title: Bat Thrower Suspended
description: The Cincinnati Reds suspended the reliever Rob Dibble for two days yesterday for throwing a bat against the home-plate screen after yielding a run-scoring single to Terry Pendleton of the Cardinals Tuesday. Dibble, 25 years old, was ejected from the game and faces a minimum fine of $200 from the National League. (AP)

title: Head of Group At MCA Quits
description: Stanley Newman resigned yesterday as president of the MCA Corporation's consumer products group, which includes the Putnam Berkley Group, a book publishing subsidiary.

title: Hudson Bass Survived Shoreline Expansions
description: To the Editor:

title: 100,000 Rally in Hong Kong On the Fifth Day of Protests
description: About 100,000 people jammed the streets of Hong Kong for a fifth straight day to support the pro-democracy movement in China.

title: Can a Pianist Sway a Competition Jury?
description: The problem of winning a music competition is relatively basic: persuading a jury to vote for you. At competitions, democracy and the arts come head to head. And when music submits to the ballot, campaign strategies are in order.

title: Politics
description: In a time when scandals seem to involve things like funneling the proceeds from arms sales to third countries or selling books to get around rules on honorariums, the mess at the Department of Housing and Urban Development has the comfortable feeling of a battered old armchair.

title: Iowa Blast Inquiry Turns to Possibility of Foul Play
description: Navy investigators are looking into the possibilities that improper storing of gunpowder last summer or foul play led to the gun-turret explosion that killed 47 men aboard the battleship Iowa last month.

title: Stocks Rise Slightly as Dow Advances 5.86
description: Stock prices rose slightly yesterday as turnover contracted moderately.

title: Ravitch to Be Endorsed By Queens Democrats
description: The Queens Democratic organization will endorse Richard Ravitch for mayor today - a move that virtually assures him a place on the primary ballot and that will have significant impact on other Democratic mayoral contenders.

title: Busch Project in Spain
description: The Busch Entertainment Corporation, a subsidiary of the Anheuser-Busch Companies, plans to build a $300 million resort and theme park in Spain, a company spokeswoman said today. The company, which owns the Busch Gardens theme park in Florida and three other parks in the United States, has filed applications for the park with the regional government of Catalonia in northeastern Spain.

title: Upheaval in China; Power Struggle Goes On in Tense Beijing
description: As an intense power struggle continued behind the walled compound that houses the Communist Party headquarters, there were signs that the hard-line faction of Prime Minister Li Peng may have gained army support and consolidated control over the news media.

title: Repairing Davenports (Desks, Not Sofas)
description: LEAD: There is some doubt as to the exact year when a Captain Davenport commissioned a compact writing desk in London; the date is put around the turn of the 19th century. But in doing so he gave his name to this very English piece of furniture.

title: Company News; Revised Plan For Hillhaven
description: National Medical Enterprises Inc. said today that it had revised its plan to spin off the Hillhaven Corporation, a long-term care unit. Under the revamped arrangement, the company will retain ownership in 50 percent of the nursing homes owned by Hillhaven, rather than divesting itself of all of them.

title: Open Positions on Short Sales Increase by 3.4% on Nasdaq
description: The National Association of Securities Dealers yesterday reported a 3.4 percent monthly increase in ''short interest'' for the most active over-the-counter securities in its national market system.

title: Report Cites Unequal Pay for Female Film Writers
description: Women who write for movies and television earn just 63 cents for every dollar earned by their male counterparts, according to a report released today by the Writers Guild of America, West.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Tuesday with an article about the British advertising industry mislabeled the dollar amounts shown with the names of Britain's top five advertisers. The numbers represented spending, not revenues.

title: Company News; Pan Am Planning Friendly NWA Bid
description: The chairman of the Pan Am Corportion, Thomas G. Plaskett, said the airline company expected to make a friendly bid next week for NWA Inc., which owns Northwest Airlines. He said the bid would be friendly even though Pan Am had declined to sign a confidentiality agreement with the St. Paul-based NWA. The accord would have given Pan Am access to non-public information, but would have limited its options in the case of an unsuccessful bid.

title: Steel Import Quota Fight
description: As steel industry executives today pressed their case for an extension of import quotas beyond their expiration date in September, Commerce Department officials said that there would be an announcement within two weeks about extending the measures with modifications.

title: Horton Journal; Seeing a Prison Project As Economic Freedom
description: Not everybody wants a prison in his backyard, but people here are so eager for one that they have refused to take no for an answer. When Horton lost out recently as a possible site for a new state penitentiary, the town decided to build a prison of its own.

title: Joanna Roos, 88, Dies; Actress and Playwright
description: Joanna Roos, an actress, died of a ruptured aorta on May 13 at the Medical Center at Princeton (N.J.) She was 88 years old and lived in Hightstown, N.J.

title: Personal Health
description: Some people, like the singers Johnny Cash and Rod Stewart, make millions on their scratchy or gravelly voices. For others, like basketball coaches, political campaigners and cheerleaders, hoarseness is an occupational hazard that might be taken as a sign of a job well done.

title: JRM Holdings Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Company News; I.B.M. Buys Stake
description: The International Business Machines Corporation bought 5 percent of Management Science America Inc., an Atlanta-based applications software developer. I.B.M., based in Armonk, N.Y., said it had bought directly from Management Science 882,060 shares of its common stock at $11.50 each, or for a total of more than $10.1 million. Management Science said it would use the proceeds for general corporate purposes, including continued product development based on I.B.M.'s Systems Application Architecture software standards.

title: Leeds Journal; Soaps With Sound and Fury: As They Like Them
description: Francesca, who is married to Jools, is bored, unfulfilled and flirting with the idea of having an affair with Neil, who is married to Claire.

title: George P. Schmidt, 95, Ex-Professor of History
description: Dr. George P. Schmidt, professor emeritus of history at Douglass College of Rutgers University and a writer, died of cancer Monday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 95 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: Blind Man Who Was Beaten By the Police Files a Claim
description: A blind man beaten by police officers who said they thought his folding white cane was a martial arts weapon has filed a claim against the city.

title: 'Ghetto' to Close Sunday
description: ''Ghetto,'' a play by Joshua Sobol, will close after the matinee on Sunday at the Circle in the Square Uptown, 254 West 50th Street. Directed by Gedalia Besser, the show will have run for 33 regular performances and 25 previews.

title: 'Ubu' Is Postponed
description: The Lincoln Center Theater production of ''Ubu,'' which was to have begun preview performances on Tuesday night at the Mitzi E. Newhouse Theater, has been postponed to next Tuesday. A spokesman for the theater said the delay was caused by difficulty in smoothing out the show's 34 scene changes. The official opening has been postponed from June 15 to June 25.

title: Dance Equivalent to Shakespeare's Words
description: The Montagues and the Capulets did battle once more, this time on Tuesday night at the Metropolitan Opera House in the American Ballet Theater production of Sir Kenneth MacMillan's sumptuous ''Romeo and Juliet.'' Swords clanged, bodies flew and three rather innocent harlots worked the crowd. And then there were the lovers, magnificently danced and acted by Alessandra Ferri and Ricardo Bustamante.

title: VGC Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The 1989 net included a $109,000 charge for non-operating expenses. The company said in fiscal 1989 it consolidated the results of operations of its VGC Credit Corp. unit, and as a result certain information related to fiscal 1988 has been restated.

title: Ennisteel Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: The Shuttle Going to Trump
description: Donald J. Trump, the New York real estate developer, won permission from a Federal bankruptcy court yesterday to acquire the Eastern Airlines shuttle for $365 million, culminating a deal he made with the airline last October before it was virtually grounded by a strike.

title: Presenting the Cliburn Jury Members
description: The jury for this year's Van Cliburn International Piano Competition has 14 voting members. John Giordano, the music director and conductor of the Fort Worth Symphony and the Fort Worth Chamber Orchestra, serves as the nonvoting chairman of the panel, a position he is holding for the fifth time. These are the voting members of the jury: JOHN CORIGLIANO, the composer of a number of works. His first full-length opera is to be performed by the Metropolitan Opera next year. SERGEI DORENSKY, a Soviet pianist, educator and administrator who is the chairman of the piano faculty at the Moscow Conservatory. He has been a Tchaikovsky Competition juror four times. JAN EKIER, a Polish composer, pianist, educator and editor who won the 1937 Chopin Competition. He is a Chopin Competition juror. NICOLE HENRIOT-SCHWEITZER, a pianist and a professor at the Royal Conservatory in Brussels. She is a well-known interpreter of Ravel. JOHN LILL, a British pianist and a winner of the Tchaikovsky Competition. LI MINGQIANG, a pianist and educator who serves as an assistant professor and deputy director of the piano department of Shanghai Conservatory. He was a prize winner in the Chopin and Smetana Competitions, and was a juror at the last Cliburn. CRISTINA ORTIZ, a Brazilian pianist and the only woman ever to have won the Cliburn. JOHN F. PFEIFFER, a composer and an executive producer for RCA Records. GYORGY SANDOR, a pianist and educator who teaches at the Juilliard School in Manhattan. ABBEY SIMON, a pianist and educator who teaches at the Juilliard School and also holds the Cullen Chair of Music at the University of Houston. LAWRENCE LEIGHTON SMITH, a conductor and pianist. He is the music director of the Louisville Orchestra and the artistic director of the Music Academy of the West in Santa Barbara, Calif. TAKAHIRO SONODA, a Japanese pianist and a member of the Imperial Academy of Arts. JOAQUIN SORIANO, a Spanish pianist and a winner of the Vercelli Competition. He teaches at the Madrid Conservatory. RALPH VOTAPEK, a pianist and the winner of the first Cliburn Competition, in 1962.

title: Police Officers Aren't Athletes in a Competition
description: To the Editor:

title: Paul Jasperson
description: Paul Jasperson, who sued a nail salon two years ago, contending that he was refused a pedicure there because he suffered from AIDS, died of the disease on May 15. He was 37 years old.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council Meets at 10 A.M. and 3 P.M. Trusteeship Council Meets at 10:30 A.M.

title: Questions on Noriega Stall the Guiliani Campaign
description: Since Rudolph W. Giuliani, the former United States Attorney in Manhattan, declared his candidacy last week, his campaign has been stalled as he struggles to answer - or occasionally avoid answering -questions about the staid law firm of White & Case, which he joined in February just as he began to shape his campaign Rather than talking about ''battling crack, crime and corruption,'' the theme Mr. Giuliani set out for his campaign, he has faced questions from his opponents about his firm's clients and practices.

title: Outdoors; A Lure That Fits All Occasions
description: rrIf I were asked to name a single lure to be included in a life raft's survival kit, it would be the venerable lead-headed bucktail jig.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a computer keyboard error, an article in Business Day on Tuesday about the settlement of a dispute between Warner Communications Inc. and Chris-Craft Industries omitted the name of Chris-Craft's lawyer and identified his law firm incompletely. He is Peter Fishbein of Kaye, Scholer, Fierman, Hays & Handler.

title: Trans-National Leasing reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: US Shoe Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
Budget Scissors
description: Even though Congress feels burdened by the Federal deficit, it has been unwilling to cede the power of the purse to the President. Thus, Congress has been wary of giving the President the power of the line-item veto. But there is a better way to cut spending.

title: Zale to Acquire Gordon Jewelry
description: The Gordon Jewelry Corporation, a Houston-based retail jewelry company, agreed today to be acquired by the closely held Zale Corporation for $36.75 a share, or about $311 million, the companies said today.

title: Review/Theater; Gastronomics as Horseplay and History
description: Theodora Skipitares has taken her brief puppet play with music, ''A History of Food,'' and reconstituted it. The result is an improved and expanded version entitled ''Empires and Appetites.'' Both works have Ms. Skipitares's characteristic piquancy, but the new musical play is more nourishing and more clearly the work of a social commentator. It is also a case of an artist realizing the potential of her art.

title: Mattingly Hits but Yankees Lose
description: In his 159th official time at bat this season, Don Mattingly finally hit his first home run after three earlier singles last night, but the Yankees lost to the California Angels, 11-4, in Jim Abbott's debut at Yankee Stadium.

title: Company News; Inland Discloses Simmons Filing
description: Inland Steel Industries said that Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas investor and corporate raider, had filed for permission from Federal antitrust regulators to acquire up to 14.9 percent of the Chicago-based steel manufacturer's shares. Inland said Mr. Simmons sought permission from the Federal Trade Commission and the Justice Department to buy more than $15 million worth of its stock.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a brief article in Sports Pages on Tuesday about the postponement of the Dodge Charity Classic golf tournament at the Rockaway River Country Club in Denville, N.J., gave the rescheduling date incorrectly. The tournament will be held in late September.

title: PARENT & CHILD
description: THE end of a school term is marked by celebrations, graduations and, for almost every level from kindergarten through graduate school, report cards. Whether it is an old-fashioned, handwritten folio or a computer-generated transcript, the response of both students and parents to this printed summary of teachers' evaluations is usually the same: a quick scan of the letter grades for A's or F's, followed by a sigh of relief, a yelp of excitement or a muttered curse.

title: Litton Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Richard E. Bader, 56, City-Planning Adviser
description: Richard E. Bader, whose experience in government and the arts ranged from expediting construction of police headquarters in New York City to co-ownership of a theater, died Monday at Mount Sinai Hospital. He was 56 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Bank of England Raises Interest Rate
description: Britain raised its interest rates today to defend its sagging currency and curb inflation. The move is a further indication that the dollar's strength is creating problems for economic policy makers outside of the United States.

title: Golfers Seek Wilson Cup
description: Dick Siderowf, a two-time British Amateur champion, heads the list of 112 golfers who will tee off at the Scarsdale Country Club tomorrow for the 18th annual Wilson Cup championship tournament.

title: A New York Forum For Fresh Design
description: THE International Contemporary Furniture Fair, a four-day event that opened Sunday at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in New York, offered ample proof that the world of contemporary furniture has taken a number of new turns.

title: Reviews/Dance; Examining the Imagination's More Dangerous Realms
description: Swiss dancers and choreographers now living in New York - and some of the American dancers with whom they may be working - were featured in the Swiss Institute's second annual Dance/Performance Series, at the institute.

title: Excerpts From President's Address
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's foreign-policy address yesterday to graduates of the United States Coast Guard Academy in New London, Conn., as provided by the Federal News Service:

title: Undercover Agents To Check Taxicabs
description: Taxi and Limousine Commission inspectors will pose as drivers and passengers in a search for speeded-up meters and refusals to carry passengers and to monitor cabby safety, the commission said yesterday.

title: Berkeley Announces Plan to Overhaul Its Admissions Policy
description: After a year of study, the University of California at Berkeley announced plans yesterday to substantially change the university's overall admissions policies.

title: Giuliani Faces Liberal Challenge
description: Already under attack from the right in the Republican mayoral primary, Rudolph W. Giuliani came under fire from the left yesterday as the former state chairman of the Liberal Party announced that he would challenge Mr. Giuliani in the Liberal Party primary.

title: FIRE THREATENED A SHIP'S A-BOMBS
description: A fire that gutted a guided missile cruiser after she collided with an aircraft carrier in 1975 threatened to engulf the cruiser's nuclear weapons, according to a Government document made public today.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-15

title: India Trade Dispute Brings Austerity to Nepal
description: The Nepalese Government, digging in for a long siege in a trade war with India that is being seen here as a test of Nepalese sovereignty, has introduced austerity measures and started reordering its development plans, officials here say.

title: Teen-Ager in Ohio Testifies To Sex With a Congressman
description: A teen-ager who says she had sex with Representative Donald E. Lukens testified today that she appeared uninvited at his home with a 19-year-old girlfriend and that the three of them went to bed together.

title: Pitino Gets, and Mulls, Kentucky Offer
description: Rick Pitino said this afternoon that he had been offered the basketball coaching job at the University of Kentucky. Pitino met with the university president on Tuesday and discussed a contract with the athletic director, C. M. Newton.

title: New Polish Devaluation
description: Poland devalued its currency, the zloty, by 6.25 percent Monday, the seventh devaluation this year, according to rates published by the Communist Party newspaper Trybuna Ludu. The new official rate, which applies to tourists and foreign trade dealings, was quoted as 800 zloties to the dollar, compared with 750 on Friday.

title: For Legislators In Odd Years, Risk-Free Races
description: For a public official whose term ends in an even year, an odd-year election is a wondrous thing. It's like one of those miracle exercise machines advertised on late-night television: it lets you run while standing in place!

title: U.S. Credibility in Panama Election Questioned
description: To the Editor:

title: KEY RATES
HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: BEFORE repainting or making repairs to exterior house paint, it pays to examine deteriorated areas and eliminate their causes. Otherwise, the problems may recur, sometimes quickly. Here are some flaws in exterior painted surfaces that appear frequently, together with their causes and cures:

title: Scat Hovercraft reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
China Again Cuts Off TV News Transmission
description: In their second reversal in as many days, Chinese officials yesterday abruptly halted the transmission of foreign television news reports from Beijing. They also barred foreign broadcasters from recording and transmitting news reports by China's state-run network.

title: MOSCOW SUPPORTS U.S. ON TROOP CUTS
description: Moscow has embraced the basic framework of the Western position for cutting conventional arms in Europe even as the two sides remain far apart on the separate issue of short-range nuclear missiles, Administration officials said today.

title: Review/Music; Voices Spanning Cultures
description: The Western Wind, a vocal sextet, devoted most of its 20th-anniversary program, on Sunday evening at Merkin Concert Hall, to works composed with its particular blend in mind.

title: Stopping the Killers
description: If Americans can agree on anything in foreign policy, it is that the Khmer Rouge should never be allowed back into power in Cambodia. When its fanatics ruled the country, from 1975 through 1978, they murdered about one million people, a seventh of the population.

title: Little Rooms With Hedges, Not Walls
description: TO Americans, the image of an English garden is one of grandeur: lush, intricately planned and planted landscapes that surround great manor houses.

title: Cuomo Political Armor Is Beginning to Show Dents
description: Seven years after Mario M. Cuomo was elected Governor, his domination of New York State politics appears to be waning, and even some administration officials acknowledge that Mr. Cuomo's influence has diminished recently.

title: First Soviet Bank Office In U.S. Is to Open Soon
description: In the spirit of perestroika, executives of the Bank for Foreign Economic Affairs are preparing to open the first American office of a Soviet bank.

title: Unigesco Inc reports earnings for Year to March 25
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $2,089,000 for the latest year and $6,991,000 for 1988. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Lithuania Declares A Moscow Tax Law To Be Non-Binding
description: Lithuania has became the first Soviet republic to defy Moscow's taxing authority, announcing today in official newspapers that Lithuanians will not be obliged to pay a new nationwide highway tax.

title: Free the Baltics
description: In light of the decennial eruption that threatens Communism in China, the newly elected delegates to this week's Congress of People's Deputies in Moscow are hard pressed by a challenge to Communist rule much closer to home: a courageous independence movement is sweeping the Baltic States.

title: Metcalf & Eddy Co reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Trade Amendment Only a Paper Tiger
description: To the Editor:

title: Intensity Resources Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss The company said the share earnings in the latest quarter was less than one cent a share. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Review/Dance; A Dutch Troupe Explores Battle Between the Sexes
description: Robert Kovich and the Dansgroep Krisztina de Chatel presented a program that was full of quirky ideas and good dancing on Sunday afternoon at the 14th Street Dancecenter at the Emanu-El Midtown Y. And sly humor bubbled out of ''Blue Pacifica,'' created by Mr. Kovich for the engaging Dutch company, which was making its New York debut.

title: Calgary Goes After the Cup Tonight
description: Calgary has never won a Stanley Cup. Montreal has never lost a cup final at home. Both things could change Thursday night.

title: Business People; Ethan Allen Chief Ready To Build Up Operation
description: Farooq Kathwari leads a management group that has bought Ethan Allen Inc., a manufacturer and retailer of traditonal-style furniture, for $357 million from Interco Inc. of St. Louis.

title: Sirhan Denied Parole In Slaying of Kennedy
description: Sirhan Sirhan, serving life in prison for assassinating Senator Robert F. Kennedy, has been denied parole for the 10th time despite his saying he felt ''very remorseful'' about the slaying.

title: 5 Youths Held in Sex Assault On Mentally Impaired Girl, 17
