description: Five teen-agers, including twin brothers who were co-captains of their high school football team, were arrested this morning and charged with sexually assaulting a 17-year-old mentally handicapped girl in the basement of the brothers' home.

title: Stuarts Department Stores reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-Net income Sales represented total store sales.

title: Talks on Early Transition Fail in Argentina
description: Argentina's ruling Radical Civic Union is preparing emergency plans to prop up the ailing economy after President Raul Alfonsin said he would not move up the scheduled date for transferring power to President-elect Carlos Saul Menem.

title: Eugene T. Ferraro, 76, Ex-Air Force Official
description: Eugene T. Ferraro, an educator, executive and a former deputy undersecretary of the Air Force, died Sunday at the Boulevard Manor Nursing Home in Boynton Beach, Fla., after a long illness. He was 76 years old and lived in Delray Beach, Fla.

title: Finance/New Isues; First Nationwide
description: First Nationwide Bank priced a $100 million offering of three-year notes. The notes, which will mature June 1, 1992, carry a 9 1/2 percent coupon and were priced at $100, or 70 basis points over the prevailing yield on three-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing. Salomon Brothers acted as lead manager for the underwriting. The issue is rated A-1 by Moody's and A-plus by S.&P. First Nationwide Bank is a subsidiary of the Ford Motor Company.

title: Article 970489 -- No Title
description: Defying the prospect of a Presidential veto and the admonitions of its own leadership, the House today approved a $3.7 billion emergency spending bill that breaches budget ceilings by including nearly $1 billion in new spending to fight illegal drugs.

title: Black Executive Avoiding Spotlight
description: While controversy swirls in Toronto over the status of Cito Gaston, the Blue Jays' black interim manager, Bob Watson quietly goes about his business in Houston.

title: Solidarity Says Warsaw Is Playing Campaign Tricks
description: Solidarity accused the Communist authorities today of using dirty tricks to upset its election campaign and of seeking to drive a wedge between the newly legalized union and its most ardent supporters.

title: Kennedy Assassination Relic Is Given to Exhibit in Dallas
description: The movie theater seat in which Lee Harvey Oswald was arrested has been donated to an exhibit at the former Texas School Book Depository.

title: Bill Offered to Restrict Raises for Legislators
description: The Legislature's ability to vote on its pay raises after re-election but before a new term would be prohibited under a bill introduced today.

title: Reviews/Music; New Violin Sonata in Recital
description: The centerpiece of Maria Bachmann's violin recital Tuesday night at Merkin Concert Hall was the New York premiere of George Rochberg's Sonata (1988). The Rochberg influence even went so far as to encompass the other long work of the night, the Brahms Sonata No. 1 in G (Op. 78), which Mr. Rochberg selected to complement his own score.

title: Company News; Vehicle Sales Rose by 2.7% In Mid-May
description: Mid-May sales of domestic cars and light trucks were up 2.7 percent from the comparable period last year, but analysts said they were still weak enough to raise fears that the industry might have to cut its production plans.

title: Strawbridge & Clothier reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
DNA Findings Are Disputed By Scientists
description: In a case that may lead to challenges in hundreds of criminal cases around the nation, expert witnesses for a defendant accused of murder in the Bronx have contested the validity of sophisticated genetic testing used to identify suspects.

title: Ailey to Move in Fall
description: The Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater Foundation has announced that it will move its offices and studio facilities to new headquarters at 211 West 61st Street in the fall. Mr. Ailey estimated a cost of $1.5 million to relocate from the company's home of 10 years, the Minskoff Building at 1515 Broadway, which did not renew the Ailey lease. The move involves the Ailey company, the Alvin Ailey American Dance Center (its school) and the Repertory Ensemble (its junior company). The foundation has signed a 15-year lease with 211 Wesst 61 Associates.

title: Smithfield Cos reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Chipwich reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and included a loss of $686,000 from discontinued operations. Latest quarter results reflect two months of operations of the Peltz Food division, acquired on Feb. 1.

title: Andreas Hillgruber, 64, Historian In West German Dispute, Is Dead
description: Prof. Andreas Hillgruber, a prominent West German historian who was involved in a controversy bearing on the ''final solution,'' died May 8 in a hospital in Cologne after a long illness, his widow, Karin, confirmed when reached by telephone at their home yesterday. His death, at the age of 64, had been reported in the West German press.

title: Putting Consumers in the Driver's Seat
description: THE four cars were scattered around the huge room in Stouffer's Westchester Hotel, each in a shade of maroon, each from a different manufacturer. People opened and shut doors, climbed in, peered at this, touched that. They checked head room and driving position. They marked their clipboards.

title: 1989 Fuel Standard To Remain at 26.5, Highway Unit Rules
description: The fuel-economy standard for 1989 passenger cars will remain at 26.5 miles per gallon, the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration said today.

title: Doctor Says That He Treated Johnson With Steroids for 5 Years
description: On his first day of testimony before a Canadian Government commission investigating athletes' use of performance-enhancing drugs, Ben Johnson's physician for five years before the Seoul Olympics said that he had provided Johnson and 13 other Canadian athletes with anabolic steroids and other banned substances.

title: Europe Offers Soviet Accord
description: The European Community this week proposed a 10-year trade and economic cooperation agreement with the Soviet Union and improved its offer for a similar accord with Poland. The European Community's

title: New Soviet Congress Set for Opening Debates
description: The Soviet Union prepared today for the opening session Thursday of its new national Congress of People's Deputies, with the debate promising to be turbulent but the first steps largely foreordained.

title: Company News; Liposome Deal Off
description: Liposome Technology Inc. of Menlo Park, Calif., and the Liposome Company, based in Princeton, N.J., said they had called off their planned merger. Mike Ullman, a vice president of Liposome Technology, said the companies discovered it would be hard to realize the benefits they had expected when they agreed to merge in February. The companies specialize in encapsulating drugs in tiny fat globules, which allow the drugs to be administered more safely or effectively in certain situations.

title: Money Fund Yields Down
description: Yields for money market mutual funds eased in the week ended yesterday, mirroring the general trend in interest rates, with yields on longer certificates of deposits falling to the lowest levels since February 1988.

title: Carme Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Panama Opposition Leaders Lead March to O.A.S. Talks
description: Panama's opposition leaders led a march to a meeting with delegates of the Organization of American States today, defying a Government ban on demonstrations.

title: Stew Leonard's, Believe It or Not!
description: To Stew Leonard, the distinction between a supermarket and an amusement park is slight, and not necessarily useful.

title: Safety Board Assails Air Traffic Control South of Los Angeles
description: The National Transportation Safety Board, in a report documenting serious lapses in the air traffic control system in Southern California, has criticized the Federal Aviation Administration for ''inadequate, ineffective and unresponsive'' management.

title: BRIDGE
description: The Eastern Championships, the world's oldest regional tournament, dating to 1929, begins tomorrow at the Penta Hotel, Seventh Avenue and 33d Street.

title: Aspiring Party Leaders At Forefront of Revolt
description: Many of the early leaders of the student demonstrations in Beijing were sons or daughters of ranking Communist Party officials studying at People's University, a school intended to produce future senior Communists, an American scholar who has been doing research there says.

title: SUNY Plans Increase In Out-of-State Tuition
description: The trustees of the State University of New York, rebuffed in their attempt to raise tuition for New York State residents, increased it today by $750 a year for undergraduates from out of state.

title: Nordson Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Nassau's System For Assessments Is Ruled Illegal
description: In a decision that could dramatically shift the residential tax burden in Nassau County, a judge today declared the county's system of tax assessment unconstitutional and ordered the county to reassess every one-, two- and three-family residence within its borders.

title: Japan Reports Illegal Export to East Bloc
description: The Japanese police said today that they had raided the offices of a Tokyo electronics and machinery manufacturer after finding evidence of a series of illegal exports of nuclear material to East Germany.

title: Review/Pop; Lorna Luft's Hollywood
description: Lorna Luft, unlike many second-generation performers, is a staunch upholder of the traditions she inherited from her show-business family. During Tuesday's opening-night show of her two-week engagement at Rainbow and Stars (30 Rockefeller Plaza), the daughter of Judy Garland and Sid Luft more than once expressed her pride in the family trade and her reverence for the old-time Hollywood movie songs that her show celebrates.

title: OPEC Shift Is Urged
description: The president of OPEC said in an interview published today that an increase in the organization's output is needed if members want a price of about $18 a barrel through 1989. In an interview published in the Saudi Arabian weekly magazine Al Yamamah, Rilwanu Lukman, who is also Nigeria's oil minister, said that OPEC should have a ''moving ceiling'' on production that it can raise or lower to maintain price levels. The ministerial council of the 13-nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will meet June 5 in Vienna to consider production and pricing policy for the rest of the year.

title: Mets Win on Their First Shutout of Season
description: Things being what they are, the Mets' long-suffering pitchers reacted with all due respect tonight when their wayward offense endowed them with three runs: In the team's 42d game of the season, Ron Darling and Rick Aguilera combined to pitch the Mets' first shutout of the season.

title: Former Union Chief Assails Giamatti Inquiry
description: Commissioner A. Bartlett Giamatti's investigation of Pete Rose, the manager of the Cincinnati Reds, drew verbal fire yesterday from Marvin Miller, the retired executive director of the Major League Baseball Players Association, who believes that one of his foremost accomplishments was setting up a grievance procedure for players. Under the procedure, an impartial arbitrator decides disputes. No such procedure exists for managers.

title: Classic Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $115,000 for the quarter and $390,000 for the 9 months.

title: Company News; Nestle Unit Stake In Culinary Brands
description: Nestle Enterprises Inc. has bought a minority stake in Culinary Brands Inc., a small company based in Sausalito, Calif., that makes gourmet meals packed in vacuum pouches. Carl H. Randall, the president of the private Culinary Brands, said the investment totaled about $20 million.

title: Trains Collide in Philadelphia, And at Least 17 Are Injured
description: A runaway Conrail car loaded with coal smashed into a single-car passenger train returning from the airport today, injuring at least 17 people.

title: For Youths Who Love Saying Giddyap
description: LEAD: ''IT'S a horse romance,'' said Allison Dyer of East Moriches, L.I., about her 9-year-old daughter's love of horses. ''She has a poster in her room of Tom Cruise,'' the 35-year-old Ms. Dyer said, ''and right next to it, one of horses.'' Jennifer Dyer has lots of model horses, her mother said, ''and of course one for her Barbie.

title: 3 in Mayoral Race Offer Plans To Fight Hunger in New York
description: The plight of the hungry and homeless in New York City must receive the highest priority in a new administration, three mayoral candidates agreed yesterday as they outlined steps they would take to ease the suffering.

title: SCIENTISTS DISPUTE FINDINGS ON FUSION
description: Several teams of scientists said at a conference today that their experiments on low-temperature nuclear fusion had produced a few neutrons, suggesting that something curious was going on but nothing that would revolutionize the world's production of energy.

title: Texas Foreclosure Measure Could Affect Savings Rescue
description: In a move that could increase the cost of Federal rescue programs for troubled Texas financial institutions, the State Legislature is considering drastic changes in procedures for real estate foreclosures.

title: New Life for Old Ties (Bow Ties, Too)
description: ''GUYS come in here and love to tell you, 'This stain is from spaghetti, this one from coffee,' '' said Andrew Tarshis, president of Tiecrafters, a 36-year-old company in Manhattan that specializes in the care of ties.

title: U.S. Seizes Woman in Inquiry
description: A Staten Island woman was arrested yesterday and charged with making false statements about the whereabouts of Constabile (Gus) Farace, the chief suspect in the Feb. 28 slaying of a Federal drug agent on Staten Island.

title: Phone Measure Wins Backing
description: A House panel today approved a bill that would allow Federal price regulation of the myriad new phone companies that provide operator services in such places as airports, hotels and hospitals.

title: ADC Telecommunications Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Upheaval in China; 7 on New York Chinese Newspaper Quit in Protest
description: Half the editorial staff of a New York-based Chinese newspaper quit in anger yesterday after the publisher demanded that they print a commentary he wrote urging China's leaders to call in troops to keep order in Beijing.

title: Researchers Say Age at Menopause Appears to Be a Gauge of Longevity
description: The age at which women reach menopause has been linked to their risk of early death in a study of more than 5,000 women.

title: Vornado Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
Rangers Pull a Surprise: Esposito Is Dismissed
description: ''Enough waiting.''

title: BRIEFS
description: * Dunkin' Donuts Inc., Randolph, Mass., said the National Advisory Council, which represents owners of about 1,700 stores, had expressed support for the current management of the company and would resist any takeover attempt.

title: Medicaid's Hodgepodge on AIDS
description: A new nationwide survey found inconsistency among state Medicaid agencies regarding their coverage of drugs used by AIDS patients and those infected with the virus.

title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS Loss Cools Evert to French Open: Chris Evert said yesterday that she may forgo the French Open next week and not finish the circuit this year after an unseeded opponent beat her in the second round of the Geneva European Open. ''I'm not in the right frame of mind for Paris,'' the top-seeded Evert said after losing, 6-4, 6-1, to Barbara Paulus of Austria. ''This weekend, I'll decide about the French Open, but if I'm not motivated, I'm not going. I would like to finish up the year but if it's a struggle, I won't.'' Evert, 34 years old and currently ranked fourth in the world, was outhit by Paulus, 18, the defending champion, at Geneva.(AP) Czech Leads Strasbourg: Second-seeded Jana Novotna of Czechoslovakia led a quartet of seeded players to victories yesterday in the Strasbourg Open women's tournament. Novotna beat Stacey Martin of the United States, 6-2, 4-6, 6-3, in the second round. Novotna is the highest-seeded player left after the No. 1 player, Katerina Maleeva of Bulgaria, lost Tuesday. Susan Sloane of the United States, No. 3, also advanced to the quarterfinals with a 6-3, 6-2 victory over Linda Ferrando of Italy. Bettina Fulco of Argentina, No. 4, beat Mercedes Paz of Argentina, 6-1, 4-6, 6-0, and Ann Grossman of the United States, No. 8, beat Elna Reinach of South Africa, 6-2, 4-6, 6-4. (AP) Argentina Gains in Team Cup: Argentina upset Sweden, 2-1, and Australia swept Czechoslovakia, 3-0, at the World Team Cup tournament yesterday in Dusseldorf, West Germany. The unexpected victory over the defending champions gave Argentina a 2-0 record in the Red Group. The team needs only one point from Friday's match against the Czechoslovak team to reach the semifinals. Stefan Edberg, the Wimbledon champion, gave Sweden an early lead by trouncing Guillermo Perez-Roldan in the opening singles, 6-1, 6-1. Edberg needed only 54 minutes to avenge a fourth-round loss to the Argentine at last year's French Open. The tournament is played on red clay and serves as a major warm-up for the French Open, which begins Monday. Martin Jaite beat Jonas Svensson, 6-2, 6-3, to even the score. Gustavo Luza and Javier Frana then outlasted Edberg and Anders Jarryd, 6-4, 2-6, 6-4, in the doubles to put Argentina atop the group.(AP) N.C.A.A. Favorites Fall: Francisco Montana of Georgia upset top-seeded MaliVai Washington of Michigan, 6-4, 6-3, yesterday in the first round of the National Collegiate Athletic Association individual championships, at Athens, Ga. ''I'm going to lose my share of matches like everyone else,'' Washington said. ''It just happened to be in the first round of the N.C.A.A.'s,'' He has been ranked No. 1 in the Volvo collegiate rankings all season. Four of the top five seeded players were eliminated. The only survivor, second-seeded Mike Brown of Arkansas, rallied from being down 3-5 in the third set to take a 6-4, 5-7, 7-6 victory against John Falbo of Kansas. Pat Crow of Long Beach State defeated third-seeded Johan Kjellsten of Louisiana State, Paul Mancini of West Virginia defeated fourth-seeded Mark Kaplan of California-Irvine and Byron Black of California beat fifth-seeded Steve Bryan of Texas.(AP) CYCLING Swiss Is Victor in Italy: Rolf Jaermann of Switzerland won the fourth stage of the Italian cycling tour yesterday in Cosenza, Italy, covering the 127-mile leg in 5 hours 59 minutes 40 seconds. The Italian veteran Silvano Contini, who finished a few seconds behind the winner, retained the pink jersey of the overall leader. Jaermann, a member of the all-Swiss Frank-Magniflex team, sprinted ahead in the final miles and maintained a narrow lead to the finish. Contini, who won the pink jersey in Tuesday's against-the-clock race for teams in Messina, held a 14-second lead over Acacio Da Silva of Portugal in the overall standing. (AP) HORSE RACING Harp Islet Wins at Belmont: Harp Islet, ridden by Craig Perret, got a 1 1/2-length victory in the feature race yesterday at Belmont Park. Silver Comet was second in the field of seven, nine lengths ahead of War. The race, scheduled to be run on the turf, was run on the sloppy main track instead. Harp Islet ran the mile and a sixteenth in 1:42 1/5 to earn $28,200 for his owner, Bertram R. Firestone, in his second victory in five starts this year. He returned $10.40, $6.60 and $4 for $2 across the board. Silver Comet paid $6 and $3.80 and War returned $4.20 to show.(AP)

title: Maggi McNellis, 71, TV Hostess
description: Maggi Newhouse, a former radio and television talk show hostess who appeared under the name Maggi McNellis, died of heart failure yesterday at her home in Manhattan. She was 71 years old.

title: Article 017689 -- No Title
description: An Atlanta investor won a $3.1 million judgment yesterday against Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. and a former broker with the firm for allegedly manipulating her securities account to generate commissions and making risky investments. Securities industry officials said they believed it was the largest such award ever to an individual.

title: An Exultant Jose Carreras Returns to Carnegie
description: ''I always thought that one day I would recover, and that I would be able to sing again,'' the Spanish tenor Jose Carreras said the other day, recalling the nine months he was hospitalized with leukemia. ''This hope was always with me.''

title: Upheaval in China; Unnerving Day of Reckoning Looms for Students: Exams
description: Wu Qiaohong, hunched over a stack of notes and books that cluttered a library desk, was taking a rest from protesting so she could finish her senior thesis.

title: Texas Foreclosure Plan
description: In a move that could raise the cost of Federal bailout programs for the state's financial institutions, Texas legislators are considering making it more difficult for lenders to recover losses in delinquent loans. Page D1.

title: Fugitive Nazi Collaborator Seized From a Catholic Priory in France
description: A wartime intelligence officer in a pro-Nazi French militia was arrested today at a Catholic priory, 16 years after he was charged with crimes against humanity.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Duplex Products Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
Lacrosse; Syracuse Scorers Put Fear Into Their Opponent
description: It rained Tuesday and yesterday in College Park, Md., and Dick Edell, the Maryland lacrosse coach, won't mind if the precipitation continues right through Saturday afternoon.

title: Company News; ITT to Cut Rates
description: International telephone rates to 27 countries will drop by as much as 9 percent on June 1, ITT Communications Services Inc. said. The reductions will apply to the first minute of calls during the standard daytime period, which covers the hours of business for the country being called. Calls from the continental United States will fall 9 percent for the first minute to some nations, while those to other countries will drop 8 percent, 7 percent or 6 percent.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about the Nederlander organization misstated the ownership of the Palace Theater.

title: Simms and Taylor Head No-Shows List
description: Phil Simms was scheduled to report Tuesday for the opening of the Giants' minicamp and did not. Lawrence Taylor is scheduled to report Thursday with most of the veterans and will not.

title: MILITARY GAS USED IN SOVIET GEORGIA
description: A toxic tear gas used as a chemical weapon in World War I was used on demonstrators in Soviet Georgia last month, according to a report by three American doctors who just returned from a visit to the republic. The Soviet military has never acknowledged using the gas, chloropicrin.

title: Pretoria and U.N. in New Dispute Over Namibia
description: A new dispute has erupted between the United Nations and South Africa over the organization's troubled Namibian independence plan.

title: Europe Limit On U.S. TV
description: The European Parliament adopted proposals today for a law that would limit the number of United States television programs shown in Europe, despite intense lobbying from the United States.

title: Bare Heads And Bicycles Are Deplored In New Study
description: Bicycle riders who wear helmets dramatically reduce their risk of head injuries, but most children do not use them, a new study concludes.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Travisano And Cousin Doing Well
description: RON TRAVISANO and his cousin are doing quite well, thank you.

title: Diamandis Acquires 2 Magazines
description: Diamandis Communications Inc. said yesterday that it had purchased the subscription lists and trademarks of High Fidelity and Modern Photography magazines from ABC Consumer Magazines Inc., a subsidiary of Capital Cities/ABC.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: WE are sitting around a dinner table, six reasonably intelligent, reasonably well-educated people. We have opinions on everything short of economics and fusion, and we can defend most of them with some skill. So far tonight we have discussed the affairs of the day, a Broadway musical and whether New York City has a future. We twiddle with our bread; we sip delicately at our white wine. Then one of us says, ''I've been reading about how the Duchess of Windsor changed her nail polish every day.'' Animation overtakes us. ''Where?'' we ask in unison.

title: Southern Co reports earnings for 12mo April 30
Aetna Resumes California Role
description: The Aetna Life and Casualty Company, which had stopped writing new property and casualty insurance policies in California to protest restrictions on insurance rates, said today that it would resume accepting new business in the state.

title: Robert E. Heathcote, Manufacturer, 72
description: Robert E. Heathcote, a retired manufacturer, died Monday at his home in Sebastian, Fla., after a long illness. He was 72 years old.

title: Topics of The Times; More Than a Mall
description: Elsewhere it is half past spring. In New York, as anyone with eyes to see, ears to hear and a mouth to munch with knows, it is the Street Fair Season.

title: Business Digest
description: Economy

title: Canadian Marconi Co reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Included a tax credit of $1,110,000. The company said results for the most recent year included the operations of Cincinnati Electronics Corp. acquired last September. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Calendar: Botanical Drawings On Display
description: Science and Beauty,Gottesman Hall, the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue at 42d Street; 212-869-8089.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Shea, Paschall Lures Bankers Trust Official
description: Neil H. Powell, Jr., a 48-year-old executive who built the private placement department at the Bankers Trust Company into one of the top five in the country, has left the bank to set up a private placement operation at Shea, Paschall & Powell, a small New York-based investment banking firm affiliated with Hambros Bank Ltd. of London.

title: Southmark Board Grows
description: Succumbing to pressure from a dissident shareholder, Herbert B. Parks, the Southmark Corporation has agreed to expand its board to give Mr. Parks and his group represention on its board, the two parties said today.

title: Executive Life Deal Opposed
description: A Dallas investment firm that controls 9.6 percent of the Los Angeles-based First Executive Corporation has raised questions about the insurance company's recent deal to sell a subsidiary, the Executive Life Insurance Company of New York, and may submit a bid.

title: MDC Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After special charges of $509,734 for the latest first quarter and $119,249 for year-ago period. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Historic Auditorium in Los Angeles Burns
description: A fire destroyed the vacant Pan Pacific Auditorium tonight, and the blaze sent up a column of black smoke that was visible at least 35 miles away.

title: I.B.M. Buys American
description: To the Editor:

title: 2 Masters of Crafts at Twining Gallery
description: Two leading figures in the contemporary crafts movement are showing their work at the Twining Gallery at 568 Broadway, near Prince Street.

title: Racial Remark Leads to Resignation in Houston
description: The president of the Greater Houston Convention and Visitors Bureau has resigned after weeks of criticism over derogatory remarks he made about minority-group members of the Houston City Council.

title: INSIDE
description: Opening of Soviet Congress

title: Cal-Star Financial Services Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Finance/New Issues; Finnish Notes Are Offered
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company acted as lead underwriter for a $200 million offering from Finnish Export Credit.

title: Quayle Tells Cadets of Technological Future
description: Vice President Dan Quayle told 1,011 soaked but enthusiastic graduating cadets at the United States Military Academy today to be prepared to lead a ''revolution in military affairs.''

title: Occidental Petroleum Prices $500 Million in Debentures
description: Occidental Petroleum Corporation priced a $500 million issue of 30-year senior debentures yesterday through an underwriting syndicate led by Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc.

title: Talking Deals; Ross's Rich Pact At Time-Warner
description: MUCH has been made of the estimated $120 million in salary, bonus and long-term compensation that Steven J. Ross, the flamboyant chief executive of Warner Communications Inc., stands to gain over the next 10 years after his company merges with Time Inc. But it is only upon a closer reading of his 80-odd page employment contract that the full potency of his arrangement becomes clear.

title: Brothers Die in Ohio As Police Standoff Ends in House Fire
description: Two brothers in their 60's who kept police at bay for seven hours died early Tuesday in a fire that was apparently started by firebombs they were throwing out of their house at the officers, the authorities said.

title: Libraries Reach the Youngest Audience
description: SANDRA TORRES, who just turned 2 years old, went to her local public library the other morning. With Sandra was her mother, Rita, and her soundly sleeping infant sister, Gloria.

title: For the Windowsill, A Little Landscape
description: THEY do not rank among the world's great landscapes, but window boxes do bring color to barren streets, spirit to lifeless buildings and pleasure to those who tend them. All this in less than 30 inches - and they are not even a modern invention. As long ago as first-century Rome, Pliny the Elder wrote of villas with blossom-filled windowsills where ''every day the eyes might feast on this copy of a garden as though it were a work of nature.''

title: Oceaneering International reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: A World View In 4 Speeches
description: President Bush's foreign-policy speech today was the last of four before a Western summit meeting next week.

title: State Dept. Aide Accused of Misleading Panel
description: The chairman of an influential House subcommittee today accused a State Department official of misleading the panel on whether the Reagan Administration made a secret deal with Honduras in 1985 to aid the Nicaraguan rebels.

title: Thomas Coley, Actor, 75
description: Thomas Coley, an actor in 15 Broadway plays as well as the 1940 film ''Dr. Cyclops'' and many television shows, died of a heart attack Tuesday at his home in Tyringham, Mass. He was 75 years old.

title: A Judge Delays Suffolk's Limits On Plastic Use
description: A Suffolk County law banning plastic grocery bags and many plastic containers cannot take effect until Suffolk officials conduct a thorough environmental impact study, a State Supreme Court justice ruled today The law, which was to take effect July 1, would prohibit fast-food restaurants and other retail establishments from using plastic-foam coffee cups, plastic utensils and the foam ''clamshells'' used to package hamburgers.

title: I.M.F. Loans for Philippines and Costa Rica
description: Clearing up some big uncertainties about the Bush Administration's new approach to third world debt, the International Monetary Fund said today that it had approved a three-year loan to the Philippines of up to $1.18 billion and another for one year to Costa Rica for $52 million.

title: Rax Restaurants Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 24
description: b-Net income and the 9 months included a tax credit of $478,000. The latest 9 months included an unusual charge of about $2.5 million principally associated with the sale, closing or refranchising of 11 Minnesota restaurants.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Express Co. named James T. Colby 3d vice president for investments.

title: Upheaval in China; Canton's Prosperous Students March
description: In Canton, young women may march for democracy carrying pretty parasols to protect them from the sun, and young men may ride buses rather than walk to a rally, but those relatively prosperous, privileged students are turning out in the tens of thousands to support their tougher, more political counterparts in Beijing.

title: Finance/New Issues; Northern Telecom
description: Northern Telecom Ltd. offered $200 million of five-year notes through a syndicate led by Salomon Brothers. The issue, which is noncallable for life, will mature on June 2, 1994. It carries a 9 1/4 percent coupon and was priced at $100, or 58 basis points over the prevailing yield on five-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing. The issue is rated AA-3 by Moody's and A-plus by S.&P.

title: Co-operative Bank of Concord reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included pretax restructuring charges of $1,128,000. c-Included a pretax gain of $2,838,000 from the sale of loan servicing rights.

title: Out of an Empty Space, A British Show House
description: ALTHOUGH decorator show houses have been held in this country for more than 30 years, they are relatively new in England. The first, in London, was only seven years ago.

title: Cosmetics Duty Plan Criticized
description: The American cosmetics industry, which imports $9 million worth of ingredients a year from Japanese suppliers, said today that it would be injured if Washington decided to punish Japan by setting 100 percent duties on its cosmetics imports.

title: CNN Basks in Reaction to Its Beijing Coverage
description: These have been glory days for the Cable News Network. Its coverage of the upheaval in Tiananmen Square in Beijing has won praise from press analysts and attracted thousands more viewers, especially in the six days last week that CNN was able to transmit from its own satellite facilities in Beijing.

title: Midland Doherty Financial Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a charge of $13,246,000 for the quarter and year. c-Net income The company said the fourth quarter loss included a provision of $1 million for loss on doubtful accounts. It also said it made a provision of $13.2 million for non-recurring purchase and restructuring costs arising from the acquisition of two investment firms in the last 18 months. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Penske Wins Big at Detroit Diesel
description: Roger S. Penske has three cars competing in the Indianapolis 500 race on Sunday, a contest he has dominated with four victories in the last five years. Winning again would be sweet for a man who first achieved renown as a champion driver during the 1960's.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Book That Supports Case for Brand Loyalty
description: Browsing through an advertising library two years ago, David N. Martin came across a rare book listing the dominant brand names in 1923. Most of the names had a familiar ring -Ivory, Gold Medal, Kellogg's Cornflakes, Heinz and Del Monte among them. Mr. Martin, an advertising executive, realized that a roster of dominant brand names today would virtually duplicate the 66-year-old list.

title: Lonely Young Aliens Pose Problem for U.S.
description: If Reynaldo had been 18 years old when the Border Patrol caught him crossing the Rio Grande, he would have been issued a bright orange jumpsuit and locked behind barbed wire in a nearby detention center.

title: Advanced Products & Techologies reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
U.S. Issues Fall in Slow Trading
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds slid in slow domestic trading yesterday as traders uneasily tried to assess information about the economy, the dollar and the nation's trade policy.

title: Grain and Soybeans Mixed; Precious Metals Prices Rise
description: Grain and soybean prices were mixed in light trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade, but received some strength from a weaker dollar.

title: CHOICE OF HOSPITAL SEEN AS KEY IN AIDS
description: AIDS patients are nearly four times more likely to survive a common form of pneumonia when treated in a hospital that is highly experienced in caring for the disease than in one that is less experienced, a study has found.

title: Varity Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-After a special gain of $2.9 million for the latest first quarter and a gain of $7.1 million for year-ago period, and charges of $8 million and $6.3 million for the latest and year-ago period, respectively.

title: Bush's Selection as Secretary of Army Withdraws to Avoid Grilling
description: Richard L. Armitage, President Bush's choice as Secretary of the Army, withdrew his name from consideration today rather than undergo confirmation hearings expected to include questions about his role in the Iran-contra affair and his relationship with a woman convicted of illegal gambling.

title: Raymond Woodrow, Research Scientist, 76
description: Raymond Woodrow, a research scientist and former director of the office of research administration at Princeton University, died of a chronic obstructive lung disease Wednesday at the Medical Center at Princeton, N.J. He was 76 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: O'Connor Begins Beirut Trip To Draw Attention to the War
description: Despite the continuing violence that has repeatedly forced John Cardinal O'Connor to postpone a trip to Lebanon, he departed last night for Beirut. The first stop is Rome, where the Cardinal is to meet with Pope John Paul II today.

title: Youth Symphony
description: Samuel Wong will lead the New York Youth Symphony in its final concert of the season - Mr. Wong's first as the orchestra's music director - at Carnegie Hall on Sunday at 3 P.M. The program includes Mozart's ''Magic Flute'' Overture; the world premiere of Mark Gustavson's ''Waves,'' a work commissioned by the orchestra; Richard Strauss's ''Death and Transfiguration,'' and the Prokofiev Violin Concerto No. 1. The soloist in the Prokofiev will be Hong-Ying Ho, the orchestra's concertmaster. Admission is free. Information: 581-5933.

title: Parker & Parsley Sold by Southmark
description: The Southmark Corporation completed the sale of the Parker & Parsley Petroleum Company, an oil and gas syndication concern, for about $49.6 million in cash to Parker & Parsley Development Partners L.P. The acquiring partnership includes Parker & Parsley's management and the JM Petroleum Corporation, a Dallas-based affiliate of the Wesray Capital Corporation.

title: Diner's Journal
description: La Metairie

title: Behind the Surge Of the Dollar
description: THE strength of the dollar has surprised economists and raised fears that the United States trade deficit will worsen this year and next. And it may breed protectionism, inflation abroad and a global slump.

title: Alice Lee Welcher Erickson, Missionary Official, 105
description: Alice Lee Welcher Erickson, a representative of the Congregational Home Missions and the Board of China Colleges in the 20's and 30's, died in her sleep Saturday at her home in Hartford. She was 105 years old.

title: The Garden Needs a Plan For Rangers
description: rrIt used to be easy to say that Gulf and Western did not have a clue about running a sports team. But then the corporation lucked out on the lottery and won the rights to Patrick Ewing, and everybody got a little smarter right away.

title: PEN Remains Critical Of Threats to Rushdie
description: To the Editor:

title: Leonard Sunshine, Manufacturer, 69
description: Leonard Sunshine, a clothing manufacturer, died of lung cancer yesterday at Memorial-Sloan Kettering Cancer Center. He was 69 years old and lived in Easton, Conn., and Waynesboro, Ga.

title: Town in New Jersey Jarred by Rape Case
description: The day after five teen-age football players were charged with sexually assaulting a mildly retarded 17-year-old girl, the small, comfortable suburb of Glen Ridge is divided and emotional.

title: Texas Meridian Resources reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Celebrations in 3-State Region
description: From the early-morning quiet of a hot-air balloon ride to the roar of the racetrack and the slap of an old-fashioned riverboat paddle, Connecticut will celebrate Memorial Day in motion.

title: Sandra Price Wed To David Epstein
description: Sandra Louise Price, a daughter of Dorothy M. Price of Maumee, Ohio, and William H. Price 2d of Cody, Wyo., was married yesterday to David Michael Epstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Martin J. Epstein of West Long Branch, N.J. Rabbi Joseph Goldman performed the ceremony at the Belmont Country Club in Perrysburg, Ohio.

title: Chung's Appointment To Bastille Is Official
description: The Bastille Opera opened its doors today for the first time to permit Pierre Berge, the czar of all the capital's opera houses, to introduce his bold choice as its music director: a non-French-speaking, 35-year-old South Korean-born American.

title: S.E.C. Opens Option Trades To More Than One Board
description: In a decision that will fundamentally alter the structure of the nation's options markets, the Securities and Exchange Commission voted unanimously today to allow options on exchange-listed securities to be traded on more than one exchange.

title: Hasbro-Coleco Hearings Delayed
description: Bankruptcy court hearings on a proposal to allow Hasbro Inc. to buy most of ailing Coleco Industries for more than $85 million have been adjourned until next Wednesday. A Coleco lawyer, Daniel Golden, said all pending matters will be taken up then in United States Bankruptcy Court in New York.

title: Holiday Weekend
description: Broadway between 72d and 79th Streets will be closed from 8 A.M. to 7 P.M. tomorrow for the Spring Festival. Second Avenue between 42d and 53d Streets will be closed from 8 A.M. to 7 P.M. on Sunday for the Turtle Bay Fair.

title: Jalalabad Wounded Strain Red Cross
description: From the Jalalabad battle front, it takes a wounded guerrilla at least four hours by four-wheel drive on a road scarred by bombs and tank treads to reach the nearest hospital in Peshawar, Pakistan. But since the end of March, in a lone mud house halfway between Jalalabad and the Pakistani border, an Afghan doctor has provided intravenous fluids and stabilized patients before they are sent on their way.

title: Central Park Rally Draws 400 in a Call To Stop the Violence
description: A rally denouncing violence of all kinds drew about 400 people to the Central Park Bandshell yesterday evening.

title: Albertson's Inc reports earnings for 13wks to May 4
Child World Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
NIEMAN'S CURATOR LEAVING PROGRAM
description: Howard Simons stepped down yesterday as curator of the Nieman Foundation, which since 1938 has brought journalists in midcareer to Harvard University for a year of study and reflection.

title: Mr. Baker Makes a Speech
description: Considerable good or great evil can come out of the speech on the Middle East delivered by Secretary of State James A. Baker this week. To a large extent the choice will rest with him and the President he serves.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Addenda
description: * Eastern Exclusives Inc., a direct-response firm based in Boston, will change its name to Bronner Slosberg Associates Inc.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: For fans of live music, a long holiday weekend means one thing: Sunday night becomes Saturday Night II, when enjoying a late set doesn't mean a bleary work day. While many New Yorkers flee the city for the Memorial Day weekend, music lovers who stay put can enjoy a fine assortment of performers, from a visiting African superstar to jazz stalwarts. Here are some selected concerts and club dates that make staying in town worthwhile: Soca at S.O.B.'s

title: Let There Be a Lot More Light in Central Park
description: To the Editor:

title: Nightmare in Princeton
description: LEAD: Daylight Savings Time had extended the afternoon light, so there was plenty of time left after church and lunch with a friend for my mother to work in the garden. It was a quiet Sunday in Princeton, N.J., last April 2, and showers had softened the ground for planting. It was not a time for murder.

title: Charge Dropped In Case of Baby Left in Restroom
description: The Brooklyn District Attorney's office yesterday dropped charges against the teen-age mother who left her 2-year-old daughter in a hospital restroom last week with a note saying she could no longer ''handle the pressure'' of raising the child.

title: The Law; One Word, and He Might Be a Judge
description: ''Judge Brian Dowling for District Judge,'' read the cards that an Alabama lawyer had printed to advance his 1986 campaign for the district court in Houston County, Ala.

title: Allegheny Halts Merger Accord
description: Allegheny International Inc., under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection for 15 months, today called off a merger with Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Inc., a New York investment banking firm. The deal was to be presented for approval today in a hearing in United States Bankruptcy Court.

title: North American Ventures Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After a charge of $1,593,000 from discontinued operations.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: For fans of live music, a long holiday weekend means one thing: Sunday night becomes Saturday Night II, when enjoying a late set doesn't mean a bleary work day. While many New Yorkers flee the city for the Memorial Day weekend, music lovers who stay put can enjoy a fine assortment of performers, from a visiting African superstar to jazz stalwarts. title: Results Plus
description: TENNIS Maleeva Gains in European Open: Third-seeded Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria scored a 6-1, 6-0 victory over Beverly Bowes of the United States yesterday to advance to the quarterfinals of the European Open. Maleeva will play Elise Burgin of the United States, who advanced by defeating Celine Cohen of Switzerland, 6-4, 7-5. Earlier, Belinda Cordwell of New Zealand defeated Camille Benjamin of the United States, 6-2, 2-6, 7-6.(AP) GOLF Blake Leads: Jay Don Blake, who ranks 109th on this season's PGA Tour money list, shot a six-under-par 66 yes-terday to take a one-shot lead in the opening round of the Atlanta Golf Classic. Blake had seven birdies and one bogey on the 7,018-yard Atlanta Country Club course in Marietta, Ga. Mike Hulbert in second place with a 67. (AP) Coe Takes Over: Dawn Coe and Cindy Hill shot four-under-par 67's yesterday to share the first-round lead of the L.P.G.A.'s Corning Classic. Tracey Kerdyk was one shot behind. (AP)

title: Afghans' Sole Prize: Kabul, Not Jalalabad
description: LEAD: As the stalled mujahedeen offensive against Jalalabad drags on, backers of the Afghan resistance are beginning to question the American and British strategy of pursuing a quick military victory followed by the formation of a broad-based Afghan government. There is now even talk of a negotiated settlement with the Soviet-backed Government in

title: New Safety Plan at Nuclear Weapons Plants Ignites a Debate
description: In his first major action since becoming Secretary of Energy nearly three months ago, Adm. James D. Watkins has announced a plan to change the way safety programs are managed at the Energy Department's nuclear weapons plants.

title: Review/Film; An Homage to a Film Maker, Made in His Own Medium
description: ''Directed by Andrei Tarkovsky'' is a loving memoir about the making of the Soviet expatriate director's last film, ''The Sacrifice.'' It will be shown with ''The Sacrifice'' at the Public Theater beginning today. The documentary may be unintelligible to anyone who has not seen ''The Sacrifice'' and unilluminating to anyone who has, but it provides a wonderful excuse to see Tarkovsky's eloquent, lyrical, magnificent final film once more.

title: Abortion and Shrinking Birth-Control Choices
description: To the Editor:

KEY RATES
Open Mind Pursues Fillies' Crown
description: D. Wayne Lukas thought Open Mind was not quite good enough to win the Kentucky Derby earlier this month, so he ran her instead in the Kentucky Oaks for fillies the day before, and she won.

title: From Spain, in Martha Graham's Footsteps
description: There will be dancing this weekend at Casa de Espana, the handsome, intimate cultural center run by the Spanish Government at 314 East 39th Street (689-4232). But there won't be a castenet or zapateado in sight. Instead, seven modern-dance choreographers from Spain will show their work in free programs tonight and tomorrow at 8:30.

title: A Slower Pace for Economy
description: In a report viewed as encouraging, the G.N.P. for the first quarter grew at a 4.3 percent pace, not the 5.5 percent initially estimated. Page D1.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Nathan's Famous fast-food restaurants and John Morrell Co., to Kirshenbaum & Bond, with a combined budget of $5.5 million.

title: Metro Datelines; Youth Won't Testify In Rape of Jogger
description: A 14-year-old who was charged but was not indicted in the beating and rape of a jogger in Central Park will not testify before the grand jury, the prosecutor in the case said yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error in some copies, an article in the Health pages yesterday about a menopause study omitted the name of the journal where it appeared. The study was published in the June issue of The American Journal of Public Health.

title: Cracks Found in Hull Of a New Nuclear Sub
description: Navy officials are investigating two cracks in the outer steel hull of a nuclear submarine under construction at the Electric Boat shipyard in Groton, Conn., officials said today.

title: Algonquin Mercantile Corp reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $305,000 for the latest year and $470,000 for the year-earlier period. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Review/Art; Elegant Bad Boy of France's Establishment
description: From the moment he took up art at the relatively advanced age of 42, Jean Dubuffet was among the most articulate and tireless opponents of the art establishment and of everything for which it stood. In place of experience he favored forgetfulness; in place of the studied and elegant, he favored the wild and brutish. It was not to the established masters that Dubuffet tipped his hat but to madmen, derelicts, graffitists and prisoners, whose paintings and drawings he collected and emulated. Nor was the standard array of oil paints enough for Dubuffet, who also saw fit to incorporate tin foil, weeds and other equally unlikely substances into his work. Born in the city of Le Havre, which had nurtured artists like Georges Braque and Raoul Dufy, Dubuffet never acknowledged kinship with the great modernist tradition of French painting.

description: Pontormo Portrait

title: Georgi Tovstonogov, 75, a Soviet Producer
description: Georgi Tovstonogov, one of the best-known theatrical producers in the Soviet Union, died Wednesday in Leningrad, the Soviet press agency Tass reported. He was 75 years old. Leningrad television said he died in a car accident. Mr. Tovstonogov was chief producer at the Maxim Gorky Bolshoi Drama Theater in Leningrad.

title: Salomon Is Censured For Short-Selling Stock
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission censured Salomon Brothers Inc. yesterday and settled accusations that the firm illegally executed short sales of about $12.5 million of stock on Oct. 19, 1987, the day the market crashed.

title: Debating Next Step, Japan Calls U.S. Trade Move Unfair
description: Japanese officials today accused the United States of a ''lack of fairness'' and said America was undermining international accords by threatening unilateral action against its trading partners.

title: From an Artist Who Isn't Starving or Living High on the Hog
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Promotions at A.N.A.
description: The Association of National Advertisers announced a slate of promotions yesterday, naming Daniel L. Jaffe executive vice president; Peter F. Eder and E. Clark Holt senior vice presidents, and Frank J. Mortensen and Renee E. Paley vice presidents. In his new job, Mr. Jaffe will head the A.N.A.'s Washington office. He was previously senior vice president of government relations at the American Advertising Federation.

title: I.B.M.-Fujitsu
description: Two independent arbitrators in a software dispute between the International Business Machines Corporation and Fujitsu Ltd. said that a special facility had been created to permit Fujitsu to develop and maintain an I.B.M.-compatible operating system. Under an arbitration ruling arrived at last November Fujitsu agreed to pay I.B.M. an additional $237.2 million to settle the seven-year-old dispute over its copying of software necessary to build computers compatible with I.B.M.'s most powerful mainframe computers.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Christopher M. Tinkham has joined Lois/GGK New York as senior vice president and media director.

title: The Law; The Multi-Jury Trial: A Delicate Balancing Act
description: As the detective described how the defendants had been captured, the jurors at the murder trial listened raptly - all 24 of them.

title: The Law: At the Bar; A pioneer in personal-injury advertising still finds himself on the cutting edge.
description: In the first, heady days of legalized advertising by lawyers, Philip Damashek was the king of the New York classifieds - and the crown prince and regent, too. While others hesitated to hawk themselves a decade ago, whether out of taste or timidity or frugality, Mr. Damashek went unabashedly ahead.

title: Let There Be a Lot More Light in Central Park; Olmsted on Safety
description: To the Editor:

title: Mazal Rudach, Social Worker, 47
description: Mazal Rudach, a bilingual social worker with the New York City Board of Education, died of complications of diabetes Wednesday at Brookdale Hospital Medical Center in Brooklyn. She was 47 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

title: Atlanta Investor Gets $2 Million
description: An Atlanta businessman has been awarded $2 million by a three-member arbitration panel of the National Association of Securities Dealers in connection with a complex stock options program under which he said he lost more than $1.7 million in four days.

title: Review/Film; In Rigid Provincial France, A Tale of Love and Power
description: ''Pattes Blanches,'' a stormy romantic melodrama filmed in 1949 by the French director Jean Gremillon, takes its title from the contemptuous nickname - translated as ''white spats'' but meaning, literally, ''white paws'' - that the children in a Breton village fling at a local, down-at-the-heels aristocrat named Keriadec. As moody as ''Wuthering Heights,'' even more erotic than the John Garfield-Lana Turner ''Postman Always Rings Twice,'' the film, which opens today at the Public Theater, is a fascinating mixture of fairy tale and film noir that explores the relationship between class and desire.

title: Lyondell Offering For $300 Million
description: The Lyondell Petrochemical Company offered a total of $300 million worth of debt securities yesterday in a two-part issue consisting of $150 million in 7-year notes and $150 million in 10-year notes. The 7-year notes were priced at $100 and carry a coupon of 9.95 percent, 1.25 percentage points over the prevailing yield on 7-year Treasury notes at the time of pricing.

title: Pamela Zelman Weds Executive
description: At the East River Yacht Club in New York, Pamela Grace Zelman and Robert Evan Sonnenblick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack E. Sonnenblick of Mamaroneck, N.Y., Boca Raton, Fla., and New York City, were married yesterday by Rabbi Joseph Potassnik.

title: Gelman Sciences reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included a gain of $240,000 from an accounting change.

title: Canal Capital Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included income of $820,000 and $1,184,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, from the art antiquities operations, and the 6 months also included unrealized depreciation of $295,000. c-Net loss and included unrealized appreciation of $1,034,000. Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the latest 6 months. The company was formerly United Stockyards Corporation. The company said year-ago second quarter and 6 months revenue have been restated to include gross sales of real estate operations.

title: Dining Out Guide: Westchester County
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in the Westchester Weekly section of The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Bistro 22

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Maggi McNellis Newhouse, former host of radio and television talk shows, misidentified her late husband, Clyde Newhouse. He was the president of a Manhattan art gallery; he was not a member of the Newhouse publishing family.

title: Wright Said to Be Uncertain On When and How to Resign
description: With Democrats now considering it certain that House Speaker Jim Wright will resign from Congress, attention turned today to when he will leave and who will succeed him.

title: Los Angeles Teachers Accept 3-Year Pact, Ending a Strike
description: Public school teachers ended their 10-day strike today and ratified a new contract with the Los Angeles school board.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Metro Datelines; 2d Woman Charged In Murder of Lawyer
description: A second woman was arrested yesterday and charged with murder in the slaying of a lawyer in his town house, the police said.

title: Cool Presence in Phoenix
description: Most athletes have a ritual they use to relax before games. Some listen to music. Others meditate.

title: G.M. and Beretta Settle Lawsuit
description: The General Motors Corporation formally settled a trademark infringement lawsuit filed against it last summer by Fabbrica d'Armi Pietro Beretta S.p.A., the Italian gun maker. In a ceremony held in Italy and attended by each company's chairman, G.M. contributed $500,000 to a Beretta cancer foundation and exchanged a Chevrolet Beretta GTU coupe for a Beretta hunting rifle and shotgun.

description: The initial session of the new Congress of People's Deputies was striking for the blunt oratory of many members and aggressive questioning of Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader.
