description: After years of sporadic negotiations, three of the Soviet Union's premier hockey players, including the celebrated defenseman Vyacheslav Fetisov, have apparently been given clearance to join the National Hockey League teams that drafted them as long as six years ago.

title: New Soviet Congress Has Young People Astir
description: Zigmas Vaisvila was working in a physics institute in the Lithuanian capital last year when the Soviet Communist Party approved a new electoral system.

title: News Programs With Ads Barred in California Schools
description: Lawyers for the California public school system said yesterday that news programs carrying advertising may not be shown in schools that receive public funds. The opinion, an interpretation of the state's education law, would mean that California public schools cannot use ''Channel One,'' a news program created by Whittle Communications Inc. that carries advertising and is being offered free to participating schools around the country. The opinion was delivered specificly because of the ''Channel One'' program.

title: Plessey Company Plc reports earnings for 52wks to March 31
description: b-After extraordinary charges of $53.6 million. c-After extraordinary gains of $21 million. The results are in U.S. currency and had been translated from pounds sterling into dollars for both years at the rate of $1.69 to the pound, the approximate rate at March 31 1989.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Coca-Cola Co., Atlanta, said it would acquire Pernod Ricard's S.P.B.G. subsidiary, a bottler and distributor of Coca-Cola products in France. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a protest at a New York-based Chinese newspaper, The Center Daily, referred incorrectly to the publisher's daughter, Candace Fu. Although she has an office at the newspaper's building in Long Island City, she says she does not work for the paper. In some copies, the article and a caption incompletely described the status of some of those involved in the protest. Two reporters, Peter Lee and Harry

title: Post Editor May Leave
description: Jane Amsterdam is on the verge of leaving her job as editor of The New York Post, people at the newspaper said yesterday. Ms. Amsterdam and Peter S. Kalikow, owner and publisher of The Post, discussed ''an imminent parting of the ways'' in a meeting late yesterday, said a person close to the situation who asked not to be identified.

title: 2 at Candidates' Forum Attack Holtzman Plans
description: Two potential candidates for New York City comptroller touched off fireworks in ''the invisible race'' yesterday, when they called on the Brooklyn District Attorney, Elizabeth Holtzman, to resign if she runs for comptroller.

title: National Bank of Canada reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The bank said provision for loan losses was $41.8 million for the latest second quarter, compared with $63 million for year-ago period. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Review/Theater; Shakespearean Comedy, From the Acting Company
description: In Paul Giovanni's production for the Acting Company, ''Love's Labor's Lost,'' that most literate of Shakespearean comedies, has been turned into a tedious exercise in artifice. The poetry is sacrificed along with the impetuousness of the romance, which should proceed magically, four by four - the King of Navarre and the Princess of France, each accompanied by a trio of followers who conveniently fall in love with one another.

title: Ford Shuts Escort Plant For 2 Weeks
description: The Ford Motor Company has suspended production at its Edison, N.J., assembly plant for two weeks, the first time in six years the company has laid off workers at a United States plant to trim inventory.

title: Janet Stanton, Executive, Weds
description: Janet Stanton, a vice president and a management representative at the New York advertising agency of Backer Spielvogel Bates, and Bruce John MacEwen, a vice president and a senior lawyer at Dean Witter Reynolds in New York, were married in New York yesterday at the Brick Presbyterian Church. The Rev. Leslie Merlin performed the ceremony.

title: Malibu Journal; An Open Invitation, and an Uproar
description: The actor Martin Sheen, honorary mayor of this beach-front community of celebrities and surfers, declared Malibu a ''free-speech zone'' last week, but the place was already in an uproar.

title: A. A. Schechter, 81, And Wife Die in Crash
description: A. A. (Abe) Schechter, the first news director for NBC-TV and the first executive producer of the ''Today'' show, and his wife, Fritzi, died Wednesday in a car accident. He was 81 years old, and she was 82. They were residents of Palm Beach, Fla., and Westhampton, L.I.

title: Metro Datelines; Mother Is Charged After Fall Kills Girl
description: A woman whose 2-year-old daughter fell to her death from a fifth-floor window was charged with murder yesterday, and her husband was charged with beating their two other young children, the authorities said.

title: Former Editor In Settlement
description: S. G. (Rudy) Ruderman, the former editor of broadcast operations for Business Week, today settled Federal civil charges that he illegally bought securities of more than 50 companies that he knew were to be subject of favorable articles in upcoming editions of the business magazine.

title: Guilty Plea In Drug Case
description: A former supervisor for the Food and Drug Administration pleaded guilty to racketeering charges stemming from a 10-month Federal investigation of corruption in the administration's generic drugs division, Federal prosecutors said today.

title: INSIDE
description: Changes in Nuclear Safety The Department of Energy has reorganized safety programs at its nuclear weapon plants. Page A10. Arabs Deadlocked Arab leaders deadlocked over Syria's refusal to consider withdrawing its 40,000 troops from Lebanon. Page A4. Sailor in Inquiry Transferred The Pentagon said it was transferring a sailor under inquiry in the Iowa blast as a ''prudent'' step. Page A12.

title: Dr. Robert R. Sears, 80, Is Dead; Child Pyschologist and Educator
description: Robert Richardson Sears, a prominent child psychologist and educator and a former dean at Stanford University, died Monday at his home in Menlo Park, Calif. He was 80 years old and had been ill for some time.

title: Gamelan Instruments
description: Neil Rolnick, a composer, and Gamelan Son of Lion, a contemporary music ensemble and composers' collective that performs on its own Western variety of gamelan instruments (bamboo xylophones and gongs), will perform new music by Mr. Rolnick tonight at 8 o'clock at Washington Square Church, 135 West Fourth Street. Tickets are $10. Information: 206-1050.

title: Soviets Print Report Saying Stalin Agreed to Split Poland With Hitler
description: The Soviet Government tacitly conceded some disputed points of wartime history today when it published an official report that said Moscow had violated international law in its treatment of Poland.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-9 Mikhail S. Gorbachev was elected to the newly enhanced post of President, but not before he an aggressive public interrogation. Page A1

title: Anti-Takeover Law Is Upheld
description: A Federal appeals court has upheld the constitutionality of Wisconsin's anti-takeover law, providing a victory for the Universal Foods Corporation in its fight against a hostile acquisition bid. Lawyers were notified

title: Milan Wins Soccer Cup
description: A. C. Milan's 4-0 victory over Steaua Bucharest in the European Champions' Cup soccer final Wednesday night was nearly as lopsided on the field as the Italian vocal victory in the stands.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 468 money market mutual funds increased by $126.50 million, to $312.07 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. Those of the 142 institutional funds increased by $273.40 million, to $79.41 billion. The assets of the 231 general-purpose funds were down by $192.60 million, to $101.23 billion. The 95 broker-dealer funds increased by $45.70 million, to $131.43 billion, the institute said.

title: Pickens Fails To Get Seat
description: T. Boone Pickens, the Texas investor and corporate raider, said today that the board of the Koito Manufacturing Company of Japan had denied his request for representation on its board.

title: The Canal Treaties to the Rescue?
description: He's still riding high in Panama, seemingly untouchable. Having voided an election won by his foes, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega countenances thuggery and ignores worldwide outrage, knowing that his armed forces support him. Nor need he worry seriously about censure from the fact-finding mission of the Organization of American States. But there is a chink in his armor: the Panama Canal treaties, which his regime is accused of repeatedly and routinely violating.

title: Dollar Falls Sharply in Market 'Correction'
description: The dollar dropped sharply yesterday as the rapid advance of the last three weeks lost some steam.

title: Kwangju Journal; A Splash in the Dark, Then a Martyr
description: A late-night police chase in the woods outside town. A splash in the dark heard by some, but not others, at a nearby reservoir. A body washed up days later with a wad of cash.

title: Bethlehem Steel Accord
description: Officials of the United Steelworkers of America said today that union employees of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation had voted to ratify a new contract with the company. A union spokesman said its Bethlehem members voted 11,386 to 3,009 to ratify the 50-month pact, which will take effect June 1. The agreement restores wages immediately to their 1982 level and includes wage increases starting in 1991.

title: New Grand Jury Asked In Choking-Death Case
description: A special prosecutor asked today that another grand jury look into the 1986 choking death of a black man after he had a scuffle with a white off-duty policeman.

title: Cautious Path for Bush's Europe Trip
description: On the eve of President Bush's departure for Europe, White House officials say the Administration will stick with its basic cautious policy approach to East-West relations. But they concede that the criticism of Mr. Bush's seeming passivity has created strains within the alliance and left the White House struggling to forge its own international public relations offensive.

title: International Technology Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss and the year included net from discontinued operations of $321,000 and a $110,069,000 loss on the disposal of discontinued operations.

title: Topics of The Times; Family Values
description: New York City's Family Court grapples with some of society's toughest social issues: child abuse, domestic violence, juvenile delinquency and foster care placements. Yet its dilapidated courthouses hardly inspire confidence. A new study by the Fund for Modern Courts, a watchdog group, documents the sorry state of Family Court facilities in each of the five boroughs. Faced with a rising caseload, the court has resorted to holding hearings in makeshift courtrooms the size of broom closets, the study notes. Battered women must sit together with their abusers in crowded, grimy waiting rooms. Public restrooms are too few, and frequently lack basic amenities.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Top Executive Leaving Saatchi
description: Gary Susnjara resigned yesterday as president and chief operating officer of Saatchi & Saatchi DFS to pursue a career as an independent consultant.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Ex-Housing Secretary Says Aides Were at Fault in Disputed Program
description: Samuel R. Pierce, the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development in Ronald Reagan's Administration, acknowledged today that he shared the blame for lax supervision of a Federal housing program. But he suggested that former aides were responsible for political abuses uncovered in a recent audit.

title: Armenak Mardirossian, Developer, 83
description: Armenak (Albert) Mardirossian, a real-estate developer and philanthropist, died of a stroke Monday at Passaic (N.J.) General Hospital. He was 83 years old and lived in Clifton, N.J.

title: Upheaval in China; Students Plan for Hurdle: Zhao's Fall
description: Six students lay crunched on a single sleeping bag near a plastic tent in preparation for a long night and possibly many more, as they began to discuss their plans for demonstrating if the rumors were true that their main supporter in the leadership was to about to fall.

title: To-Fitness Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
J. A. Campbell Dies; Chemist and Dean, 72
description: James Arthur Campbell, an educator, chemist and former dean of faculty at Harvey Mudd College in Claremont, Calif., died of Lou Gehrig's disease Monday at his home in Claremont, Calif. He was 72 years old.

title: Evert Withdraws From French Open
description: Chris Evert yesterday withdrew from the French Open, an event she has won a record seven times, saying her heart wasn't in her game.

title: Reviews/Art; Stabiles by Calder, Architect of Fun, at Pace
description: Alexander Calder was in many ways an ideal mix of homo faber and homo ludens. As homo faber - builder, engineer, master of stress and strain - he carried on as if he could have built the Brooklyn Bridge single-handed, had he been around at the time. As homo ludens - humorist, prankster and inventor of strange creatures - he was in a class of his own.

title: The Rumors Stop Here: Langston Sent to Expos
description: Months of speculation ended tonight when the Seattle Mariners traded Mark Langston, the hard-throwing left-hander, to the Montreal Expos for three pitchers: Randy Johnson, Brian Holman and Gene Harris.

title: Tracking Shares To Foil Raiders
description: IT is very difficult to prove a negative. That is one reason why Greyhound's chairman, John Teets, was noticed when he insisted that no one was planning a raid on his company.

title: Celebrations in 3-State Region
description: This weekend marks the start of New Jersey's tourist season, and state and local officials are looking for a recovery from last year's drop in beach front business caused by reports of ocean pollution. Resorts along the coast are to be presenting freshly painted boardwalk rides, meticulously combed beaches and a few added attractions.

title: Waste Recovery reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
How to Lobby for a Charter: Plenty of Persuasion Helps
description: For 50 hours this month and last, the 15 citizens drafting a new government for New York City worked in public sessions as fumbling and querulous, open and unpredictable as democracy itself. In front of hundreds of people, they fought over questions from representative government to revenue estimates.

title: A Seabrook License Is Due
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that it would issue a low-power license for the Seabrook, N.H., nuclear plant Friday morning in the absence of a court order blocking low-power atomic testing.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Chief of Halliburton Becomes Its Chairman
description: LEAD: Taking steps to provide for an orderly succession of its senior management, the Halliburton Company has named its president and chief executive, Thomas H. Cruikshank, to be its chairman.

title: George Jacobson, 76, A Colonel in Vietnam
description: Col. George D. Jacobson, a retired United States Army officer who headed the pacification program in Vietnam in the early 1970's, died of a lung disease on May 18 at the Walter Reed Army Medical Center in Washington. He was 76 years old and lived in Vienna, Va.

title: Carrot, Stick and Chaos Mix in Collapse of Talks
description: In the closing moments of Wednesday's ill-fated discussions to ease Representative Jim Wright out of the Speaker's chair sooner rather than later, a blunt threat was delivered by the House ethics committee.

title: White Supremacist Sentenced to Death By a Pretoria Court
description: A white supremacist who went on a rampage in the streets of Pretoria was sentenced today to hang for killing eight blacks.

title: Israel Soldiers Acquitted In Death of Palestinian
description: A military court acquitted four Israeli soldiers of manslaughter today in the beating death of a Palestinian last year, but found them guilty of brutality.

title: Review/Ballet; Frame of 'Romeo and Juliet' Shows Off 2 New Casts
description: Sir Kenneth MacMillan's ''Romeo and Juliet,'' set to Prokofiev's ballet score, was always a crowd pleaser when the Royal Ballet brought it from Britain, beginning in 1965. And a shrewdly programmed crowd pleaser it has remained since American Ballet Theater staged it in 1985.

title: Air Shuttle Offers Test For Trump
description: In the next few days, Donald J. Trump is expected to pay $365 million and take over the Eastern Airlines shuttle. The maiden flight of what will be called the Trump Shuttle will follow shortly after that.

title: 'Where's Benno?' New Refrain at Yale Belies Record
description: By many standards, Benno C. Schmidt Jr., the president of Yale University, should be collecting high praise these days. He skillfully captained the university's finances through troubled times. He negotiated two major labor accords without strikes. He improved relations with New Haven. He began an ambitious plan to renovate many of the school's old neo-Gothic halls.

title: With Giants in Transition, Parcells Plans to Go With Youth
description: The Giants will have a different look this year, Coach Bill Parcells indicated today, and many old faces will be gone. Though Parcells said this would not be a rebuilding year, at least a face lift seemed certain.

title:
About Real Estate;
In a Forest in Queens, Condo Units Will Rise
description: LEAD: A tranquil pond and 14.5 acres of dense forest, in the heart of Queens, will be the setting for a 224-unit town house condominium, Oak Park at Douglaston, on which the DeMatteis Organizations will start construction next month.

title: G.N.P. Rate Cut to 4.3% In Quarter
description: The economy grew in the first quarter at a pace considerably slower than initially estimated, the Commerce Department said today. But the Administration and economists alike viewed the slower growth rate as generally encouraging.

title: Winnipeg Names Coach
description: Bob Murdoch, a National Hockey League defenseman for 12 years with Calgary, Atlanta, Los Angeles and Montreal, was named yesterday as the coach of the Winnipeg Jets, who this year finished out of the Stanley Cup playoffs for the first time in eight seasons.

title: JLG Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
A Tale of a Tub; Swift Repair Work After Crash Keeps Indy Racer in Second Row
description: Jim Crawford's car circled the Indianapolis Motor Speedway today at more than 214 miles an hour, a leisurely pace compared with the speed at which it has been flying round the world in the last week.

title: Fitzsimmons Honored
description: Cotton Fitzsimmons, whose Phoenix Suns showed a 27-game inprovement in their 1988-89 record over the previous season, was named The Associated Press's N.B.A. coach of the year for the second time. He also won the award in 1979, when he led the Kansas city Kings to a division title.

title: Garden Will Take Time To Fill Ranger Vacancies
description: It was Wednesday afternoon and raining, and the connection from Richard Evans's car phone was imperfect. The line crackled and faded, but the message was clear: the Rangers will not compound their organizational problems by rushing to fill their vacant general manager's and coach's slots.

title: Wiener Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
Pippen, Walker Fined
description: Scottie Pippen of the Chicago Bulls was fined $3,000 and Kenny Walker of the Knicks $1,500 for their parts in a fight during the sixth game of the National Basketball Association Eastern Conference semifinal playoff series on May 19 in Chicago. The fight occurred late in the third quarter of the Bulls' 113-111 victory, which eliminated the Knicks. Both players were ejected from the game. Pippen was assessed the larger fine because he started the fight, according to Rod Thorn, the N.B.A. vice president of operations.(AP)

title: James River Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
On Stage
description: Patinkin in Concert

title: Bhutto Ousts Powerful Intelligence Chief
description: Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto has dismissed the powerful military intelligence chief who controlled hundreds of millions of dollars in American aid to the Afghan guerrillas.

title: Celebrations in 3-State Region
description: The Hudson Valley is bursting with new growth this weekend, presenting visitors with rural vistas as well as holiday activities.

title: Ambro Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Anti-Mob Panel Established
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo issued an executive order today meant to help state agencies avoid doing business with contractors linked to organized crime. The order establishes a Council of Contracting Agencies, which will serve as a clearinghouse for information about contractors. The order comes after reports that in the last four years, the state paid $12.5 million to 22 companies with ties to organized-crime figures.

title: Washington Talk; Justice
description: June may mean weddings and graduations and other pleasant events in most parts of the United States, but at the Supreme Court, it is a four-letter word.

title: Britain Orders the Expulsion Of 4 Czechoslovak Diplomats
description: Britain ordered the expulsion of four Czechoslovak Embassy employees today but said the move was not related to last week's expulsion of 11 Soviet diplomats and journalists.

title: Dutch Anti-Pollution Plan
description: The Government made public an ambitious plan today to clean up the Dutch environment by the year 2010, but it said 80 percent of the nation's forests may die even if the measures are put into effect. The anti-pollution measures are likely to be a major issue in elections scheduled for September. Controversy surrounding them brought down the Government headed by Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers.

title: California City's 2d Disaster in 2 Weeks
description: Thirteen days after a runaway freight train killed four people and demolished a row of houses here, a gasoline pipeline under the accident site sprang a leak today and exploded, killing two more people and burning down 10 more houses in the stricken neighborhood.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; D'Arcy Creates Position To Help Creative Side
description: After winning Burger King and while waiting on Maxwell House, D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles/ U.S.A. took another long step toward creative reformation by announcing the appointment yesterday of John Nieman as the division's executive creative director, the first in the agency's history.

title: Assix International reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The company said share net in the latest periods only reflected adoption of the treaury stock method of determining earnings per share.

title: Treminco Resources Ltd reports earnings for
description: The company was not in commercial production a year earlier. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Voters Return 6 to a Board Under Fire
description: Six incumbents have been re-elected to a Brooklyn school board that has become, its critics contend, a symbol of what can occur when a local board subordinates educational interests to political concerns.

title: ARAB CONFERENCE IS SPLIT BY SYRIA
description: An Arab League summit meeting was deadlocked today over Syria's refusal to consider the withdrawal of its 40,000 troops from Lebanon.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Agfa Corp., Ridgefield Park, N.J., a photographic-equipment manufacturer and a subsidiary of Bayer USA Inc., named Michael Kochman executive vice president and president of its Matrix division.

title: AM International Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $3,180,000 for the quarter and $12,827,000 for the 9 months. Year-ago third quarter share earnings was less than one cent a share because of preferred stock dividend requirements.

title: Drabek Ends Losing Streak As Pirates Win 4th in Row
description: Doug Drabek pitched six solid innings to snap his losing streak at five games, and the Pittsburgh Pirates extended their longest winning streak of the season to four games tonight with a 7-3 victory over the slumping Atlanta Braves.

title: Books of The Times; A New Work on Faulkner, Linking His Life and His Art
description: William Faulkner: American Writer A Biography By Frederick R. Karl Illustrated. 1,131 pages. Weidenfeld & Nicolson. $37.50.

title: Reviews/Art; Collages That Seek to Fuse Beauty and Feminism
description: Nancy Spero's exhibition at the New Museum of Contemporary Art is not as extensive as this artist deserves, but for the time being it will do quite well. The show originated at the Everson Museum of Art in Syracuse and is now making the final stop on a six-museum tour. It looks good at the New Museum - no mean feat considering the tall, narrow galleries - and a second phase, opening June 14, will rotate in additional works. In all, the show effectively encapsulates both the elegance and savagery of Ms. Spero's achievement, paying tribute to a 30-year struggle to fuse art and feminist politics.

title: Astaphan Taped Calls About Use of Steroids
description: On Jan. 27, 1988, Dr. George (Jamie) Astaphan secretly taped telephone conversations with Ben Johnson and two other athletes in which they acknowledged using the anabolic steroids he had given them.

title: Celebrations in 3-State Region
description: LEAD: A Mozart Festival, an exhibition of animated dinosaurs, a Renaissance Faire and a ballet company's Long Island debut are among the events on Long Island during the Memorial Day weekend. The festivities also include meeting artists in Southampton and watching wool turned into shawls in Setauket.

title: At the Movies
description: Japanese Tradition

title: International Broadcast Sysems reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Ocelot Industries Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-After tax credits of $400,000 for the latest first quarter and $23.3 million for year-ago period. Year-ago figures have been restated. The company said the year-earlier results included those of the oil and gas operations just before the disposition of Ocelot's oil and gas assets. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Jersey Brokers Are Indicted
description: Three former brokers for First Jersey Securities have been indicted in connection with what prosecutors described as a $1 million money laundering scheme.

title: CUNY Graduate School
description: Three weeks after protesting students chained shut its only building, the Graduate School and University Center of the City University of New York celebrated its 25th commencement yesterday at Town Hall in midtown Manhattan.

title: Leslie Overlock, 69, Photocopier Executive
description: Leslie C. Overlock, an early marketing administrator in the photocopier business, died Monday at his home in Sun City, Ariz., where he had moved in 1985 from Greenwich, Conn. He was 69 years old.

title: Washington Talk: Guest List; Sails of the A.C.L.U. Catch a Fresh Breeze
description: About 500 card-carriers convened at the Omni-Shoreham Hotel Wednesday night. ''It's the sort of evening where everyone knows each other,'' said Martha J. Toomey, coordinator of the occasion, a $75-a-plate dinner in support of the American Civil Liberties Union Fund of the National Capital Area.

title: Baker's Even Hands
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir may say that James Baker's forthright advice to the Israelis and the Palestinians was ''useless''; but the Secretary of State probably put his finger on Mr. Shamir's real complaint when he replied:

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday FLORAL ART The main branch of the New York Public Library is always a garden of delights, but during the next three months the venerable institution will be abloom with more than 150 historic botanical illustrations. The show, ''Nature's Mirror,'' includes watercolors, drawings and illustrated books by such botanical artists of the 18th, 19th and 20th centuries as Pierre-Joseph Redoute and Robert Thornton. The works on display not only present an overview of floral art, but also offer a historical account of the discovery of new plants and the scientific influence of botanical drawings. Many of the works were created for Curtis's Botanical Magazine, a 202-year-old British journal that is said to be the world's longest-running horticultural publication. The exhibition - which draws on the collections of the library as well as of the Royal Botanic Gardens in London and the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx -will continue through Sept. 2. Free guided tours are offered daily at 12:30 and 2:30 P.M. The show at the library, on Fifth Avenue and 42d Street, is open Mondays through Saturdays from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission is free. Information: 869-8089. ONE-ACT MARATHON

title: Leonard Horton, 83; Led a Securities Firm
description: Leonard M. Horton, a former president and chairman of Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a dealer in Treasury securities, died on Saturday in Delray Beach, Fla., where he lived in retirement. He was 83 years old and had lived for many years in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Unflustered Calgary Wins First Stanley Cup
description: For a change, and for a first, the Stanley Cup went to the Calgary Flames, the team that proved itself to be the league's best in both seasons - the regular season and the season that for Calgary had always been the elusive one, the playoffs.

title: Irish Prime Minister Seeks Election to Win a Majority
description: The Irish Prime Minister, Charles J. Haughey today asked President Patrick J. Hillery to dissolve Parliament and called for a general election on June 15.

title: Tenement Homecomings
description: The building at 97 Orchard Street, just off Delancey, is a 135-year-old tenement. Now it is also a museum - as telling as a Jacob Riis photograph - that commemorates the successive waves of immigrants who lived, worked, loved and died on the Lower East Side, some within this building's very walls.

title: Reader's Digest Plans Stock Offer
description: The Reader's Digest Association Inc., since 1922 one of the most private publishing companies in America, has decided to give the public a very modest stake in the form of a stock offering.

title: Airgas Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $324,000 and a gain from the sale of cylinder manufacturing operations of $3,501,000. c-After a loss of $200,000 for the quarter and income of $55,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations; a loss on the sale of engineering design operations of $248,000 for both the quarter and year, and the year also included an extraordinary gain of $167,000 from the repurchase of bonds at a discount. Year-ago quarter and year results reflect a pretax gain of $645,000 from the termination of two pension plans. Prior year results reflect a $625,000 pretax restructuring charge in connection with the contribution of its calcium carbide operations to a joint venture. The company said share earnings for all periods assume the exercise of all outstanding options and warrants. Year-ago quarter and year results are restated to reflect the company's engineering design services operations and cylinder manufacturing operations as discontinued operations.

title: New York Officials Join Forces To Keep Merrill Lynch Jobs in City
description: In an effort to keep the financial giant of Merrill Lynch from moving thousands of back-office jobs to New Jersey, top officials from both the Koch and Cuomo administrations met yesterday with company executives.

title: Points of Light, Growing Dimmer
description: President Bush got lots of credit last fall with his pledge to create and personally lead a foundation to promote voluntary youth service. Four months into his Administration, however, those who looked for leadership on the issue are starting to ask, ''Where's George?''

title: Inacomp Computer Centers Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
An Arena of Stars Burns
description: Fire has destroyed the Pan Pacific Auditorium, the streamlined Art Deco arena where Elvis Presley made his West Coast debut in the 1950's and Sonja Henie skated in the 1930's. The fire broke out Wednesday evening. The building was abandoned and had been sealed, the authorities said. The building was featured in the film ''Miracle Mile.''

title: Morris on Disabled List
description: Jack Morris, a Tiger right-hander who has missed only two starts in his 13-year major league career, was placed on the 21-day disabled list yesterday for the first time. Morris has an injured right elbow.(AP)

title: Sexual Assault Splits a New Jersey Town
description: Charges that five teen-age football players sexually assaulted a mildly retarded 17-year-old girl have left this small, comfortable suburb gripped by division and emotion, both in its high school's hallways and on its handsome main boulevard.

title: The Jungle Is Given a Certain Cachet
description: They came by subway, limousine and Range Rover to a benefit at the Brooklyn Academy of Music Wednesday night: artists and earth scientists, fashion designers and film directors, models and rappers, teeny-boppers and their mothers. Madonna and Sandra Bernhard played Sonny and Cher. Deadheads danced in the aisles. Vogue dancers did their rubber-limbed couture-model mambo. Socialites and movie stars headed for the exits when the music got too loud. It was all for a worthy cause: the future of the world.

title: Intelogic Trace Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: b-Net income c-Included a gain of $2,481,000 from retirement of debt for the quarter and 9 months.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; 8,000 Stations Will Go Silent
description: For 30 seconds this morning, millions of Americans will shave, do pushups, butter their toast or drive to work without radio in the background.

title: Alamo Rent A Car Fills Vacant Post of President
description: Alamo Rent A Car Inc., the nation's fifth-largest car-rental company, has named Charles D. Platt president and chief operating officer.

title: Johnson Is Impatient With Mets
description: On an afternoon when Gary Carter took his right knee to Los Angeles for a medical examination that could determine his future, the Mets kept creeping along in the slow lane, searching for their bats, losing again to the San Diego Padres, 2-1.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Absolut Campaign Wins Prize
description: A FUNNY-LOOKING vodka bottle contained more lucre than liquor last night for TBWA Advertising. Its campaign for Absolut vodka won the Magazine Publishers of America's $100,000 Stephen E. Kelly Award for the best magazine advertisement of the year.

title: Wagner and Strauss
description: Zubin Mehta will lead the New York Philharmonic in ''Ein Heldenleben'' by Richard Strauss and Wagner's ''Rienzi'' Overture and the Act I Prelude and ''Good Friday Spell'' from his ''Parsifal,'' tonight at 8 at Avery Fisher Hall. The program is to be repeated tomorrow evening at 8. Tickets are $40 to $7.50. Information: 580-8700.

title: Potomac Electric Power Co reports earnings for 12mo April 30
Articles on Speaker's Top Aide Prompt an Ethical Debate by Journalists
description: News coverage of an assault on a woman 16 years ago by a man who later became House Speaker Jim Wright's principal aide has prompted an ethical and journalistic debate over publishing such an article. At issue is the propriety of delving into the criminal past of a person after his apparent rehabilitation and doing so at a time when the disclosure would be particularly damaging to Mr. Wright.

title: Bass Group to Add To Medical Stake
description: Three members of the wealthy Bass family of Fort Worth said they had received clearance from Federal antitrust regulators to increase their holdings in American Medical International Inc. beyond 15 percent. The Bass group now controls 11.6 percent of American Medical's 68.5 million shares outstanding.

title: Gemini Technology Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Memorial Day '89: Fanfares On the Starting Line of Summer
description: ONCE again, spring seems to have come and gone in a blink of the eye, barely pausing to remind New Yorkers that a season really does exist between winter and summer. Indeed, with Memorial Day weekend already upon us, summer has all but officially begun, and New York will herald the new season with a three-day extravaganza of fireworks, festivals, parades and outdoor concerts. And for all those sun-worshippers who have been patiently waiting for the sun during these last soggy months, the city's beaches officially open tomorrow.

title: Home Resales Down 1.2%
description: Sales of existing homes fell by 1.2 percent in April, the fourth consecutive monthly decline, as rising mortgage rates continued to take their toll on the housing industry, the National Association of Realtors said today.

title: S&K Famous Brands reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
Toromont Industries Ltd reports earnings for
description: The company said the increase in revenue reflected the consolidation of 51 percent owned Enerflex Systems Ltd. in the latest quarter, along with improved revenue from the refrigeration group. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Penn Central Hunt For Acquisition
description: The Penn Central Corporation, still hunting for a big acquisition, has enough money to make a multibillion-dollar takeover, its chairman, Carl Lindner, told shareholders Wednesday. The Cincinnati-based telecommunications company and military contractor is 31 percent owned by Mr. Lindner's American Financial Corporation.

title: Out of New York's Military Past
description: Fort Hamilton's batteries of big iron-barreled guns facing Lower New York Bay are long gone and its days as a battle-ready Army fort are past, but this 177-acre Brooklyn citadel remains heavily armed with history.

description: It was live, in color and impertinent, and the people could not believe the wonder of it all.

description: Shows, Nature, Museums

title: Beverly O'Malley, 48, Advertising Executive
description: Beverly Black O'Malley, a senior vice president of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising, died of liver cancer Wednesday at her home in Darien, Conn. She was 48 years old.

title: Piniella Still a Candidate
description: The Toronto Blue Jays are not pursuing Lou Piniella vigorously, but he remains the No. 1 candidate in their managerial search. They reiterated that fact yesterday at a club board of directors meeting.

title: Eastwood As a Tracker In 'Pink Cadillac'
description: When it's time to look back on the strange sweep of Clint Eastwood's career, from his ambitious direction of ''Bird'' to his coarse, classic Dirty Harry character, ''Pink Cadillac'' will probably settle comfortably near the bottom of the list. It is the laziest sort of action comedy, with lumbering chase scenes, a dull-witted script and the charmless pairing of Mr. Eastwood and Bernadette Peters.

title: Dow Falls 1.28 as Broader Indexes Rise
description: LEAD: Stock prices were mixed yesterday, with blue chips generally making a mediocre showing.

The company said 1988 figures have been restated to reflect the sale of the hosiery division.

description: Prime Minister Li Peng appeared on television today, declaring that his Government was in control, and there were more signs that at least for now he is gaining in the power struggle that is racking China.

title: A 'Soft Landing' Is Forecast
description: Top business economists predicted today that the United States economy is headed for a ''soft landing'' this year in which growth slows enough to tame inflation and interest rates without toppling the country into a recession.

description: The vice chairman of Mary Kay Cosmetics Inc., a cosmetics company that relies on door-to-door sales, said today that it was interested in acquiring Avon Products Inc., which has a similar but much larger business.

Our Towns; A Great Car Pool: Decorum, Faith And a Manual
description: On Wednesday morning the car pool dispatcher, Sandy Toineeta, rechecked her clipboard to make sure she had everyone in the pool, then jumped in herself, signaling the two vans for takeoff. As they have for 26 years, car pool members peeked at their watches. It was 7:18. Not ideal, (7:15); but not a violation either, (7:21).

title: Washington Talk; Librarian of Congress: New Skills, More Roles
description: James Hadley Billington, the Librarian of Congress, cannot hit his conversational stride sitting down. When he starts to talk about knowledge and those who have sought to define, preserve and animate it, he rises from his chair and paces, his arms sweeping through empty air to clear a path for the thoughts of Leibniz and Jefferson.

title: California Court Widens Limit on Employee Suits
description: In another California court victory for employers, the state's Supreme Court today made retroactive an earlier decision that restricts the right of people dismissed from jobs to sue their former employers for damages.

description: Results are in Canadian dollars. The bank is listed on the Toronto, Montreal and Vancouver stock exchanges.

title: Pitino Home To Decide On Job
description: LEAD: Rick Pitino, still pondering whether he will remain as coach of the Knicks or accept the reported $7 million, five-year contract to be the basketball coach at the University of Kentucky, returned yesterday to his home in Mount Kisco, N.Y. Pitino flew back in the same private plane that brought him to Lexington on

title: Nicaragua Orders 2 U.S. Envoys to Leave, Linking Them to Strikes
description: Nicaragua today ordered the expulsion of two American diplomats and asserted that they had been fomenting strikes by teachers in the Nicaraguan countryside.

title: Metro Datelines; 3 Get Life Sentences For Shooting Agent
description: Three men were sentenced yesterday to life in prison without parole for shooting a Federal Drug Enforcement Administration agent in the face during a sweep of a Manhattan apartment in September.

title: Restaurants
description: In the halcyon days of rail travel, when a train whistle signaled escape and adventure in a grand style, a fitting place to begin a journey was the Oyster Bar and Restaurant in majestic Grand Central Terminal. Rail travel has lost much of its romance over the years; so, too, has this once-classy landmark restaurant.

title: Abrams Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: The company said all share earnings figures are based on the company's 4-for-3 stock split announced yesterday.

title: No Wright Bargain Is Called For
description: Why have Speaker Jim Wright and the House ethics committee even mentioned a deal to settle the charges against Mr. Wright?

title: TV Weekend; When It's Better to Watch Food Than Gorge on It
description: Holiday weekends and food can be infuriatingly compatible. Too often, between all those ''traditional'' meals, the temptation is to loll about, all the while sipping drinks and munching tidbits that make waistlines runneth over. A thought: If there is anything at all to the concept of sublimation, watching food might serve as a substitute for eating it.

title: Familiarity May Decide New Jersey Vote
description: With the primary less than two weeks away, four of the five Republican candidates for governor appear to be within striking distance of their party's nomination. But one, Representative Jim Courter of Warren County, may be enjoying a small advantage.

title: Pentagon Transferring Crewman Under Investigation in Iowa Blast
description: The Defense Department announced today that it was transferring a sailor who is under investigation in connection with the explosion aboard the battleship Iowa.

title: Collision-Avoiding Device Needs Uncrowded Skies; Problems Abound
description: To the Editor:

title: Inmate Killed in Riot At California Prison
description: A prisoner was killed and 48 others were reported injured today after violence erupted in an exercise yard at Folsom Prison.

title: Celebrations in 3-State Region
description: In Westchester County, the Memorial Day weekend will be celebrated with a flurry of outdoor activities, from boisterous events like the Big Apple Circus to more serene ones like a nature walk to observe the mating games of horseshoe crabs.

title: Yankees Rally To Down Angels
description: Tommy John's 700th career start had ended much as had his 699th and several before: earlier than he would have liked and less elegantly than perhaps the Yankees can continue to afford.

title: F.A.A. to Keep Rule Barring Airline Pilots Over 60
description: The Federal Aviation Administration will tell a group of commercial airline pilots today that they will not get exemptions from the rule requiring them to retire before they turn 60 years old, officials said yesterday.

title: Review/Music; Songs of France And England By the Y Chorale
description: Amy Kaiser's Y Chorale, which has participated valuably in so many symphonic and oratorio concerts at its home in the 92d Street Y, gave a mostly pleasing mixed concert there Tuesday evening. The first half was all French, with good diction, a feeling for flavor and - occasionally, in Poulenc's ''Sept Chansons,'' to poems of Eluard and Apollinaire - some fuzziness of tuning in difficult harmonies.

title: Canamax Resources Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: G.M. Lifts Rebates
description: The General Motors Corporation today increased certain cash rebates and extended its general incentive program for an additional month, after Wednesday's report of sluggish industry sales in the mid-May period. The Chevrolet division offered buyers of its previously undiscounted Caprice Brougham a choice between a $750 rebate or low-rate financing; it also increased the rebate on its S-10 Blazer truck to $750 from $500. GMC Truck raised the rebate on its S-15 Jimmy trucks to $750 from $500. Wednesday, the Pontiac division increased rebates on various models of its LeMans subcompact, which is imported from Korea.

title: Moscow Offers To Narrow Gap On Troop Cuts
description: Moscow made another proposal today in the Vienna talks on cutting conventional forces in Europe that further narrows the differences between the West and the Soviet bloc, Western officials said.

title: MOSCOW CONGRESS GRILLS GORBACHEV, THEN ELEVATES HIM
description: The Soviet Union began an experiment in parliamentary politics today as a new congress elected Mikhail S. Gorbachev to the newly enhanced post of President, but not before he endured an aggressive public interrogation about his policies, his ambitions and his privileges.

title: Quiksilver Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Nakasone Says He Took Gifts But Asserts, 'I Am Innocent'
description: In cool but defiant tones, former Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone reluctantly faced Parliament today and denied charges that he was a central figure in the influence-peddling scandal that has leveled Japan's political leadership and undercut its new international role.

title: Fourth Man Is Seized In $4 Million Robbery
description: A fourth man was arrested in connection with an armored car robbery of $4.4 million in Clifton last year, and a father and son have admitted their guilt in the incident, authorities said yesterday.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I am overwhelmed with shame that such a scandal happened while I was the head of the Cabinet. I apologize for causing public distrust in politics.'' - Yasuhiro Nakasome, former Prime Minister of Japan. [ A1:3. ]

title: Petro-Canada Issue
description: Petro-Canada offered $200 million of 30-year debentures through an underwriting syndicate led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The issue has a ''put'' on the bonds during the 15th year at par, or $100. The debentures carry a coupon of 8.8 percent and were priced at par, 13 basis points over the prevailing yield on 10-year Treasury securities at the time of pricing. Ten-year securities are used as a benchmark for a security whose maturity may be less than 30 years. The issue is rated AAA by both Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's.

title: Salvadoran Guerrillas Attack An Army Barracks in Capital
description: Leftist guerrillas attacked the main army barracks in San Salvador today and fought with troops in several parts of the city.

title: Lin Broadcasting Plans TV Spinoff
description: Fast-growing cellular telephone properties have become so valuable that they have begun to overshadow the other businesses of the media companies that own them. So, Lin Broadcasting Inc. said yesterday that it would split into two independent companies so it could concentrate on its cellular phone business.

title: Upheaval in China; Wishful Thinkers?
description: It might be called the Chinese paradox: the more vigorously Chinese demand democracy, the less they get.

title: U.S. CITES JAPAN, INDIA AND BRAZIL AS UNFAIR TRADERS
description: Taking strong action on an issue that has divided his Cabinet and threatens new trade friction, President Bush today named Japan, India and Brazil as unfair traders, subjecting them to special negotiations and possible sanctions if their import barriers are not lowered. The decision incensed the foreign governments.

title: British Defamation Study
description: A jury's libel award of $960,000 against Private Eye, the satirical British magazine, this week has prompted the Government to undertake a review of defamation law.

title: Trade Deficit Is Narrower
description: The United States trade deficit improved sharply in the first three months of the year, narrowing to $27.6 billion, the smallest quarterly imbalance in four years.

title: Hispanic Inspector Rises to Deputy Chief
description: A 57-year-old police inspector was promoted to deputy chief yesterday, making him the highest-ranking Hispanic officer in the New York City Police Department and the first person of Puerto Rican descent ever named a chief.

title: Joe Clark to Undergo Surgery
description: Joe Clark, the principal known for his tough disciplinary measures, has been hospitalized and is scheduled to undergo open-heart surgery, officials said today. Mr. Clark, the principal of Paterson's Eastside High School, was admitted Wednesday to Beth Israel Hospital in Newark, said Vincent Fusco, his personal manager. ''He's been rundown,'' Mr. Fusco said. ''He had pneumonia a couple of weeks ago.'' Neither Mr. Fusco nor a hospital spokesman, Tom Casey, knew when the surgery would be performed.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost; Planning for Picnics
description: It's time for picnics again, and if you are preparing the fixings from scratch it pays to know how much chicken for chicken salad you can expect to strip from the carcass of a typical broiler or fryer and how many sandwiches a can of tuna will make. Salads can be stretched by adding diced vegetables, cucumbers, celery, peppers and tomatoes. How many slices of bread are in a packaged loaf? You have to read the label and then figure it out: the nutritional information gives the number of slices in a serving, and the number of servings in the package. Here are the yields for some picnic staples. $ Amount Yield Servings 1 chicken, 3 1/2 pounds 4 cups for salad 8 to 10 sandwiches 1 can tuna, 6 1/2 ounces Z cup for salad 2 sandwiches 1 large egg, hard boiled Y cup for salad 1 sandwich 1 small cabbage, 1 pound 5 cups for slaw 8 side dishes 1 pound new potatoes 2Y cups for salad 4 side dishes 5 lemons 1 cup juice for lemonade Add 3 cups water, lemonade 1/2 cup sugar plus ice for 4 to 5 servings

title: ARRIVING IN ROME, BUSH IS OPTIMISTIC
description: President Bush arrived here tonight for the start of a weeklong European trip, emphasizing that ''new challenges and unparalleled opportunities'' face the Western alliance in view of Soviet initiatives.

title: SCS Acquires Stake in SPIN
description: SCS Communications, a company owned by Stephen C. Swid, has acquired a controlling interest in SPIN magazine with an investment of $4 million in the four-year-old publication.

title: Ohio Congressman Is Convicted in Sex Case, but Aide Says He'll Run for Re-election
description: Representative Donald E. Lukens, Republican of Ohio, was convicted today in a case in which prosecutors said he had sex with a 16-year-old girl.

title: A 42d Street Trolley Is Feasible for New York
description: To the Editor:

title: Kazuko Takatsukasa, Hirohito Daughter, 59
description: Kazuko Takatsukasa, the elder sister of Emperor Akihito, died of heart failure at a Tokyo hospital early today, Imperial Palace officials said. She was 59 years old. Mrs. Takatsukasa was the third daughter of the late Emperor Hirohito, Japan's longest-reigning monarch, who died on Jan. 7.

title: Accused Princeton Professor to Retire Early
description: A literature professor accused of making sexual advances to a male graduate student will take early retirement because of a growing controversy over Princeton University's handling of the matter, his lawyer said today.

title: Letter: On College Sports; Barring Freshmen Solves Nothing
description: To the Editor:

title: India Tractor Wreck Kills 13
description: A farm tractor pulling a wagon loaded with wedding guests fell into a canal today, killing 13 people, a news report said. About 30 people were riding on the tractor or in the wagon near West Godavari, about 825 miles southeast of New Delhi, the United News of India said. Among the dead were three children.

title: Superconducting Equivalent Of a Transistor Is Reported
description: Researchers at the University of Houston said yesterday that they had developed a superconducting equivalent of an electronic transistor, a crucial step toward building superconducting computers and other electronic equipment.

title: Patents; Preventing Jaundice In Babies
description: Researchers at the Stanford University Medical Center in Palo Alto, Calif., have patented a new method of preventing jaundice in newborn babies.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping; With Confusion at the Pump
description: There was a time when gasoline buyers needed only to tell the attendant to ''fill 'er up,'' regular or high-test, and then pay the amount shown on the pump.

title: Shevardnadze to Visit Greece
description: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union will visit Greece and Cyprus next week after attending the opening of a human rights meeting in Paris. The Foreign Ministry spokesman, Gennadi I. Gerasimov, said Mr. Shevardnadze would probably visit Greece from Wednesday to Friday and go to Cyprus on Saturday and Sunday.

title: A Real-World Cold-War Mystery
description: The Salonika Bay Murder Cold War Politics and the Polk Affair By Edmund Keeley Illustrated. 395 pages. Princeton University Press. $24.95.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST, SATURDAY, MAY 27, 1989
description: Markets

title: U.S. Urged to Take Guru's Land Near Yellowstone
description: Ever since an eclectic religious colony settled on the edge of Yellowstone Park in 1981 and began developing a scenic valley into a thriving community, its members have found themselves at odds with neighboring park officials, environmentalists and townspeople.

title: Finks Among Finalists
description: Tom Benson, the owner of the New Orleans Saints, said yesterday that he had reluctantly given permission for the National Football League search committee to talk to Jim Finks, the general manager of the Saints. The action confirms that Finks is on the final list of candidates to replace Pete Rozelle as league commissioner. ''I said yes, but I have mixed emotions about this,'' Benson said. ''I was told they will contact Jim in the next week or so.''

title: A Tarnished Triumph in China
description: The students in Beijing appear to have lost to the aging Deng Xiaoping and his colorless, hard-line protege, Prime Minister Li Peng. But it's far from certain that the defeat is permanent; whether the students have truly won or lost will only be determined when Mr. Deng departs and a new leadership emerges.

title: Not All Human Rights Groups Are Equal
description: To the Editor:

title: Lewis to Join Boycott Of T.A.C. Title Meet
description: Carl Lewis, a six-time Olympic gold medal winner, and a group of other American Olympic medalists in track and field say they plan to boycott the national outdoor championships next month at the University of Houston to express their unhappiness with The Athletics Congress, the governing body of track and field in this country.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Wednesday about William J. Hampton, an aide to the late Representative Adam Clayton Powell Jr., misidentified a surviving daughter. She is Gail McKeller.

title: Big Cable Merger
description: Stockholders and directors of United Artists Communications Inc. and the United Cable Television Corporation approved the merger of the two companies to form the United Artists Entertainment Company. The merger makes United Artists Entertainment the nation's third-largest operator of cable television systems and the largest motion-picture theater operator.

title: Foul Shots Give Lakers Victory and 3-0 Lead
description: Since the National Basketball Association playoffs began, the Los Angeles Lakers have never been better.

title: Bank Shifts To A.T.&T. Unit
description: The Bank of New York is transferring its mutual-fund shareholder accounting services to American Transtech, a unit of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company.

title: Talks Go Down to Wire
description: Mark Langston said yesterday that the Seattle Mariners tried to sign him to a new contract minutes before trading him to the Montreal Expos on Thursday night.

title: Once Again, Irish Leader Goes on Quest for a Majority
description: ''I love elections,'' a former Irish Prime Minister, Garret FitzGerald, confessed this morning as he hurried into the Georgian parliament building, where he is a member of the opposition. ''It's the dull parts in between I can't stand.''

title: Majority Leader Will Expel Ruiz
description: The Majority Leader of the State Senate will inform Gov. Mario M. Cuomo next week that Israel Ruiz Jr., a Bronx Democrat, convicted in February on a Federal felony count, is no longer a member of the Senate, an aide said yesterday.

title: Looking for Savings as Gas Prices Rise
description: At the gasoline pump this summer, the oil companies will have the upper hand. But experts say smart shoppers can limit the damage to their wallets.

title: Dollar In Rebound After Drop
description: The dollar rebounded yesterday to close around Thursday's levels after dropping sharply in the morning in the face of a concerted round of central bank intervention.

title: Harris Buys Out Partner in Venture
description: The Harris Corporation exercised its option to buy the 50 percent interest held by the Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company in a joint venture, Harris/3M Document Products Inc. Harris said it had paid about $190 milllion.

title: Bonn Reported Split on NATO Arms
description: West German politicians said today that the governing coalition was torn by a bitter struggle over its stand on short-range nuclear weapons. Chancellor Helmut Kohl emerged so politically isolated, they said, that a compromise with Washington at the NATO summit meeting was no longer considered feasible.

title: Minister Is Convicted Of Rape and Assault
description: A Manhattan jury yesterday convicted an East Harlem minister of rape and other sexual attacks on three church members.

title: Review/Music; Carreras Evokes High Emotion
description: When Jose Carreras, the Spanish tenor, walked onto the Carnegie Hall stage Thursday night, he received a standing ovation, complete with a ''Jose Carreras Society of America'' banner, before he had uttered a note.

title: All That Heat on Pete Rose . . .
description: The Cincinnati Reds manager, Pete Rose, is facing allegations that he was involved in gambling on the very sport he played and coached for so many years. It is even alleged that he bet on his own team.

title: Paul McGoldrick Weds Miss Engel
description: Patricia Anne Engel, a daughter of the late Mr. and Mrs. Alexander R. Engel of Greenwood Lake, N.Y., and Paul Joseph McGoldrick, a son of Mrs. Charles G. Tierney of Pelham, N.Y., and the late Warren P. McGoldrick, were married yesterday at the Davenport Shore Club in New Rochelle, N.Y., by Mayor Joseph E. Durnin of the Village of Pelham.

title: India Assails U.S. on Trade Action
description: India today assailed Washington's decision to place the country on a list of unfair traders.

title: Quarters, Mints and Marks: Little Things Can Mean a Lot
description: The United States Mint has inadvertently struck a new collector's item: an unknown number of 1989 quarters with no mint mark.

title: Optimism in Minicamp
description: On the next-to-last day of the Giants' minicamp, Coach Bill Parcells came up with a mini-report card.

title: Connecticut Sewage Leak Halts Swimmers
description: Swimming off beaches in Stamford, Darien and West Haven will remain closed pending the outcome of water tests after more than 300,000 gallons of sewage spilled into Long Island Sound Thursday from a malfunctioning pump at a Darien treatment plant.

title: Mets Rout Hershiser; Carter Sidelined 6 to 8 Weeks
description: If adversity builds characater, the Mets built a pile of it today.

title: Flames Finally Prove They're N.H.L.'s Best
description: When they rolled out the red carpet Thursday night and carried the Stanley Cup across it to center ice, it was the ingenue Calgary Flames rather than the venerable Montreal Canadiens who were left alone on the Forum ice to claim it.

title: Finley's One-Hitter Beats Sox at Fenway
description: Chuck Finley, whose best game in 43 previous major-league starts was a five-hitter, held Boston hitless until Jody Reed's looping single with two out in the eighth inning tonight as he pitched the California Angels to a one-hit, 5-0 victory over Roger Clemens and the Red Sox.

title: Salvadoran Army and Rebels Clash in the Capital
description: Government troops and leftist guerrillas clashed early today in some of the heaviest fighting in the capital in several years.

title: Journalists Again Strike BBC
description: Journalists and technicians at the British Broadcasting Corporation today staged the fourth in a series of 24-hour strikes over wages, disrupting radio and television programs. The spokesman for the National Union of Journalists, Don Brind, said 10,000 employees were on strike, but BBC spokesmen said it was too early to say how many of the 28,000 employees were out. Mr. Brind said three unions representing 20,000 workers went on strike after the BBC refused to reopen talks or increase its wage offer of a 7 percent increase. The unions want a 16 percent increase.

title: Ex-Congressman Eugene Keogh, Pension Plan Sponsor, Dies at 81
description: Eugene J. Keogh, who as a Congressman from Brooklyn was the principal sponsor of the pension-plan legislation that bears his name, died of pneumonia yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Pitino Reminded He Has a Pact
description: If Rick Pitino decides to remain as the Knicks' coach, all he has to do is say so.

title: Parents of Child In Fatal Plunge Had Won Praise
description: The Bronx woman who was charged with throwing her 2-year-old daughter to her death Wednesday night and her husband, who was charged with abusing the child and her two siblings, were depicted by city caseworkers three months ago as a ''strong and motivated'' couple.

title: Italy Moves to Resolve Its Government Crisis
description: A few hours before President Bush arrived tonight for a two-day visit, Italian leaders took tentative steps to put their crumbled Government back together again.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about a pipeline explosion in San Bernardino, Calif., carried inconsistent references in some editions to the parent company of the Calnev Pipeline Company. It is the GATX Corporation, not the Union Pacific Corporation.

title: Chinese Hard-Liner Tightens Grip As Attacks on His Rival Multiply
description: With Prime Minister Li Peng apparently winning China's power struggle, documents criticizing his rival, Zhao Ziyang, have been circulated among senior officials, evidently in preparation for a formal decision to dismiss Mr. Zhao as Communist Party leader.

title: Piniella Is No. 1 Choice for Blue Jays' Job
description: The Toronto Blue Jays will offer Lou Piniella their managing job, if they receive permission from George Steinbrenner to do so.

title: Shanghai Protesters: A Finger on the Switch of China's Industrial Dynamo
description: In a testament to China's economic liberalization, the streets of this city are clogged with merchants of all sorts - young men displaying gold necklaces or earrings, elderly women selling five-flavored tea-soaked eggs.

title: Faint Echo of the Cultural Revolution
description: There is a new joke around here that Jiang Qing, the widow of Mao Zedong, has asked to be released from the prison where she is serving a life sentence for crimes during the Cultural Revolution.

title: New Ford Cut On Escort Cars
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it would idle its Wayne, Mich., assembly plant for one week to trim the number of unsold Ford Escort subcompact cars.

title: Old Country Looks Good to Immigrants' Children
description: In 1925, Fabiana Ghigliani's grandfather left Italy for Argentina, a land of hope in the New World.

title: KEY RATES
Ethiopia Names Commanders
description: President Mengistu Haile Mariam has named new armed forces commanders to replace those killed last week in an abortive coup, the Government radio announced. Diplomats say nearly the entire military high command was killed in the three-day revolt and the subsequent purge here.

title: Substances Can Mask Steroids, Doctor Says
description: Ben Johnson's personal physician today named eight substances that athletes are using routinely to hide the presence of anabolic steroids in their systems. A leading American expert in sports medicine said that current technology may not be sophisticated enough for laboratories to detect two of them.

title: Liven Up Passenger Safety Messages, Airlines Are Advised
description: Safety specialists generally agree that safety information given on airplanes is boring, that most people do not pay attention and that even if they did they still might not know what to do in an emergency.

title: A Triple Crown Tuneup
description: Sunday Silence, who will try to become the first Triple Crown winner in 11 years when he runs in the Belmont Stakes on June 10, worked three furlongs in 37 2/5 seconds at Belmont Park this morning. It was the colt's first workout since winning the Preakness Stakes last Saturday. Sunday Silence is expected to face between 5 and 10 opponents in the Belmont, led by Easy Goer, the Derby and Preakness runner-up. Other likely starters are Rock Point, third in the Preakness; Hawkster, fifth in the Derby and Preakness, and Le Voyageur, a Seattle Slew-Davona Dale colt who is being flown in from France.

title: BURNS & CO. QUELL YANKEES ALMOST PERFECTLY
description: His career with the Oakland Athletics has been short, his roles varied. Todd Burns has pitched long relief, middle relief, as a spot starter and as an occasional closer.

title: John L. Jeffers, 46, a Lawyer for Pennzoil
description: John L. Jeffers Jr., a senior partner in the law firm of Baker & Botts in Houston who was a leading lawyer in the Pennzoil Company's successful court battle against Texaco Inc., died of complications arising from a brain tumor at Methodist Hospital in Houston Thursday. He was 46 years old.

title: BUSH IS EXPECTED TO END SANCTIONS AGAINST MOSCOW
description: In a gesture both to American allies and to Moscow, President Bush is expected to act next week to remove the remaining economic sanctions imposed on the Soviet Union after its military intervention in Afghanistan 10 years ago, Administration officials said today.

title: Test Permit For Seabrook
description: The Nuclear Regulatory Commission said today that it had issued a license to the Public Service Company of New Hampshire and other owners to begin low-power testing of the $6 billion Seabrook nuclear plant.

title: Message on the Dangers of Pesticides Needs to Get Through
description: To the Editor:

title: New Cabinet Is to Address Argentina's Economic Woes
description: President Raul Alfonsin swore in a new cabinet today to draft and carry out an emergency plan to prop up the battered economy.

title: COELHO TO RESIGN HIS SEAT IN HOUSE IN FACE OF INQUIRY
description: Representative Tony Coelho of California, the No. 3 Democrat in the House and the leading contender to become majority leader, said today that he was resigning from Congress rather than put his party and his colleagues through a protracted investigation of his personal finances.

title: Alabama Executes Man in Death of a Widow
description: A man convicted of killing a widow and stealing her Christmas presents was executed in Alabama's electric chair early today after the United States Supreme Court denied his appeal.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page headline in some editions yesterday about charges of sexual assault against a group of high school football players in Glen Ridge, N.J., misstated the nature of the case.

title: Jury in Illinois Refuses to Charge Mother in Drug Death of Newborn
description: A grand jury in Rockford, Ill., has refused to indict a woman accused of causing the death of her newborn baby by using cocaine before she gave birth.

title: Pacific First Stake
description: An investment group that includes Alpine Associates of New Jersey said it had acquired 7.4 percent of the Pacific First Financial Corporation, a savings and loan holding company based in Tacoma, Wash. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, the group said it had bought the stake as an investment. Shares of Pacific First rose 25 cents today, to $23.25, in over-the-counter trading, giving it a market value of about $177 million. The group said it had paid from $23 to $24.375 for its stake.

title: Review/Music; Mehta's Old Acquaintances
description: The New York Philharmonic's final subscription program of the year offered Zubin Mehta in music of the kind for which his affinities have generally been considered strongest: orchestral excerpts from Wagner and a big Strauss tone poem.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * Andrews Group Inc. said it had received commitments from Manufacturers Hanover Trust Co. to provde financing to buy New World Entertainment Ltd., for $8.95 a share.

title: Sea Containers' Stock Soars After $50 Offer
description: Stena Holding A.B., a Swedish ferry operator, and Tiphook P.L.C., a British container-rental company, offered yesterday to pay $50 a share, or $815 million, for Sea Containers Ltd., a Bermuda company with interests in containers and British ferries.

title: Michigan U. Is Sued Over Anti-bias Policy
description: A graduate student has filed suit in Federal District Court against the new anti-discrimination policy of the University of Michigan, which the student contends violates his First Amendment right to discuss his research ideas in class.

title: Interest Rates Continue to Move Lower
description: Interest rates continued to slide yesterday as prices of short- and long-term Treasury securities rose in an abbreviated pre-holiday weekend session.

title: U.S. Envoy Slain in London
description: The police said today that they were investigating the death of an American diplomat from New York state found stabbed to death in a central London apartment. The envoy, Marie Burke, 63 years old, worked in the visa section of the American Embassy. She was found in her bed on Thursday afternoon and had apparently been attacked as she was waking up. The police were looking for a purse missing from the apartment. She is listed as a second secretary at the embassy, having worked for the Consular Service since the late 1970's.

title: Marion P. Mack, Politician, 94
description: Marion Pierce Mack, vice chairwoman of the Westchester County Republican Committee for 33 years, died yesterday at a nursing home in Rockport, Mass. She was 94 years old and lived in Rockport.

title: Mexico Is Given Approval For $4.08 Billion I.M.F. Loan
description: The International Monetary Fund approved $4.08 billion in loans to Mexico late today, officials of the fund said. Most of the money was tentatively approved last month.

title: Counting on Oven-Brewed Coffee
description: The people at Farberware Inc. have taken a hard look at the cup of coffee, and say they have discovered a better way to brew it.

title: Raymond Weinberg, Camping Director, 69
description: Raymond Weinberg, the former director of summer camps and community centers for the Boys' Athletic League in Manhattan, died of complications from Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases Thursday at his home in Tamarac, Fla. He was 69 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I want to give my party a chance to move on.'' - Representative Tony Coelho. [ 1:6. ]

title: Schoolboy Streak Ends
description: Jon Peters, who set the national high school record of 51 consecutive victories last month, lost his first game as a scholastic pitcher Thursday night when West Orange-Stark of Texas beat Brenham, 3-0, on a no-hitter.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: YACHTING Trimaran Staggers to Mark: The crippled trimaran Great American sailed through the Golden Gate Bridge yesterday, breaking a three-month-old New York-to-San Francisco sailing record by three days after an exhausting 77-day, 14,500-mile voyage. The Great American crossed the finish an hour short of 77 days after departing New York for the arduous journey round Cape Horn. The skipper, Georgs Kolesnikovs, 46 years old, of Niagara Falls, Canada, and his crewman, Steve Pettengill, 37, of Newport, R.I., broke the 80-day, 20-hour record set Feb. 12 by Warren Luhrs's sloop, Thursday's Child.

title: Tensions on Eve of Cliburn Contest
description: Some 1,000 celebrators will gather at the Worthington Hotel tonight for a gala dinner opening the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition. But it's a good bet that most of the 38 contestants will make their way home to bed early. That's because the serious competing in the important quadrennial event is to begin at 9:30 A.M. tomorrow.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 11 about the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition misstated the location of Youri Egorov's 1978 debut concert in New York. It was Alice Tully Hall, not Carnegie Hall.

title: Honda Shifts A Top Official
description: The Honda Motor Company will replace its top executive in North America at the end of June.

title: Queens Man Said to Have Died From Cocaine
description: The death of a Queens man in police custody, which sparked two days of angry protests, was caused by ''acute cocaine intoxication,'' the Medical Examiner's office said yesterday.

title: Coelho's Statement: 'I've Always Said There's a Life After Congress'
description: Following is a statement by Representative Tony Coelho, Democrat of California, at the beginning of an interview today with The New York Times:

title: Man Is Saved by Plugging of Holes in Heart
description: A surgeon saved a gunshot victim's life Thursday by plugging the bullet holes in his heart with her fingers and massaging the heart to keep it beating in a 14-minute helicopter ride to a trauma center.

title: Your Money; Planning Ahead To Retire Early
description: The majority of Americans would like to retire early, but few have done the serious retirement planning that would enable them to do so comfortably, a survey by Merrill Lynch & Company shows.

title: Editor of New York Post Is Dismissed by Kalikow
description: Peter S. Kalikow, owner and publisher of The New York Post, dismissed his top editor, Jane Amsterdam, in a meeting late Thursday afternoon, persons close to each of them, who asked not to be identified, said yesterday.

title: June Watkins Is Dead; A Former Actress, 73
description: June Watkins, a former actress who was active in civic and political affairs, died of cancer yesterday at her home in Providence, R.I. She was 73 years old.

title: U.S. Extends Travel Warning
description: The State Department warned Americans today against traveling to China until further notice because of the crisis there. Washington had previously issued advisories against travel to China from May 20 to May 26.

title: ANSWERS TO QUIZ
description: Questions appear on page 12.

title: Dow Up 11.18 but Off 7.33 for Week
description: LEAD: The stock market moved broadly higher yesterday in slow pre-holiday trading.

title: Frederick G. Fisher, 68; Was a McCarthy Target
description: Frederick G. Fisher, a Boston lawyer who in 1954 became a target of Senator Joseph R. McCarthy at a dramatic turning point in hearings involving the Senator and the Army, died of a heart attack Thursday in Tel Aviv, Israel. Mr. Fisher, 68 years old, was at a lecture sponsored by the Israeli bar.

title: New Fallout Over Ethics
description: Representative Tony Coelho's decision to leave Congress rather than face a siege of questioning over his finances dramatizes the extraordinary climate in Washington on the issue of ethics.

title: Postjudice
description: LEAD: A friend has coined a word that ought to become a staple in the English language. The word is ''postjudice'' - judgment after experience. Postjudice can be as unsettling as prejudice.

title: Poison Ivy: Kill Carefully
description: Poison ivy is reaching its full leaf stage now. When all the leaves are open, kill it but don't touch it.

title: 2 Top Commodity Boards To Discuss a Joint System
description: After months of vigorous and competing marketing efforts, the nation's two largest commodity exchanges have decided to try to cooperate in their development of after-hours electronic trading systems, the exchanges announced yesterday.

title: About New York; Be It Brain Scans Or Scallops, Only The Best for Pets
description: The reason that newspapers will always print animal stories is because they distract from all the news about nasty things men and women do to each other day in and day out. Accordingly, today's column rambles from cemeteries to saloons, ferreting out the mysteries of dwarf rabbits, loving cats, tropical birds and the odd tarantula.

title: U.S. Authors to Read In Benefit for AIDS
description: American writers will read from their own works on three evenings in June at the Poetry Center of the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue, to benefit the American Foundation for AIDS Research.
