title: Bridge; The experts fail to top the standings at a New York charity tournament.
description: The 27th annual U.J.A.-Federation Charity tournament played Thursday night at the Harmonie Club, 4 East 60th Street, had one important difference from previous years. As usual, the efforts of Tubby Stayman and her committee raised more than $50,000 for Jewish charities. And as usual, there were some 50 experts taking part, many of them owning national and international titles, each playing in an impromptu partnership.

title: SATURDAY NEWS QUIZ
description: Questions are based on news reports in The Times this week. Answers appear on page 46.

title: Indiana Jones's Costume Goes to the Smithsonian
description: The leather jacket and fedora worn by Harrison Ford in the Indiana Jones movies were added today to a Smithsonian Institution collection that includes Frank Sinatra's bow ties and Judy Garland's ruby slippers from ''The Wizard of Oz.''

title: Prague Expels Four Britons In Response to London Move
description: Czechoslovakia expelled three British diplomats and a businessman today in what the Foreign Office called an unjustified retaliation for the recent expulsion of four Czechoslovaks from Britain.

title: National Steel Reaches Labor Accord
description: The National Steel Company, the nation's sixth-largest steel producer, said yesterday that it had reached a tentative agreement with the United Steelworkers of America on a 50-month contract that would raise wages and benefits by about 12 percent over the period.

title: Raisa Gorbachev Hits Back: 'The Women Are All for Me'
description: For a woman who the night before had been likened unflatteringly to Napoleon's Empress Josephine on nationwide television, Raisa Maksimovna Gorbachev was showing no signs of post-glasnost depression this morning.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International 2-7 An end to U.S. sanctions on Moscow that were imposed after the Soviet military intervention in Afghanistan is likely to be announced by President Bush next week, Administration officials said. Page 1 President Bush arrived in Rome for the start of a European trip. Continuing his upbeat tone, he said Soviet initiatives have presented ''new challenges and unparalleled opportunities'' to the Western alliance. 7 Italy races to resolve crisis 7 Bonn divided on NATO arms 6 A new kind of Soviet government continued to be sought by the Congress of People's Deputies in a process that laid bare divisions of class, geography, nationality and outlook. 1 Reporter's notebook: Raisa Gorbachev answers critics 1 Senior Chinese officials have been circulating criticism of Zhao Ziyang, possibly in preparation for a formal decision to dismiss Mr. Zhao as Communist Party leader. 1 Faint echo of Cultural Revolution in the student movement 5 Shanghai protesters: a finger on China's industrial switch 5 News analysis: U.S.-Japanese ties may be damaged by Washington's naming Japan an unfair trading partner, but experts say the action could also benefit relations by focusing attention to festering problems. 29 The Arab League did not sway Syria to withdraw its 40,000 soldiers from Lebanon at the end of a four-day meeting. Syria's stand is expected to draw Iraq deeper into Lebanon. 3 A South Africa judge sentenced 14 blacks to hang for the murder of a black policeman in a rural town three and a half years ago. 3 Awaiting Ferdinand Marcos's death, the Philippines is consumed with what some are calling ''necropolitics.'' It has created an intricate mixture of squabbling and piety. 2 A majority in Ireland's Parliament is the goal of the nation's popular Prime Minister, Charles Haughey, in the approaching elections. He says he wants to win a national mandate and break legislative gridlock. 3 Salvadoran troops and leftist rebels clashed in some of the heaviest fighting in San Salvador in years. 4 Buenos Aires journal: economic decay drives young to Europe 4 National 8-10, 24 Tony Coelho said he was resigning his post as the House Democratic whip as well as his seat in Congress to avoid putting his party and colleagues through what he expects to be a long inquiry into his finances. 1 News analysis: Mr. Coelho's decision to leave Congress rather than face a year of questions over finances dramaticizes in bold terms the extraordinary new climate in Washington on the issue of ethics. 1 Text of Coelho's statement 9 A collector's coin has been made inadvertantly by the United States Mint. An unknown number of 1989 quarters with no mint mark was the result, and the first one was discovered recently in Boston. 1 A sailor from the battleship Iowa under an investigation into the ship's explosion said that he had nothing to do with it and that he was the victim of a Navy ''looking for a possible scapegoat.'' 8 Part of a gas pipeline that exploded on Thursday, killing two people in San Bernardino, was not checked after a train plowed across it two weeks earlier, the line's owner said. 8 A religious colony near Yellowstone has set up housing complexes for its disciples, bulldozed roads and built warehouses, leading to a clash between the public trust and private property rights. 8 Forest Service bills two men $3 million for park fire 8 A jury has refused to indict a woman arrested earlier this month in the death of her baby. Prosecutors say the baby died as a result of the mother's use of cocaine during pregnancy. 10 The extra border patrol agents and other personnel sent to Brownsville, Tex., in February to stem a surge of illegal aliens are being reassigned. The Government calls the mission successful; critics disagree. 10 Ogilvy & Mather was dropped as the advertising agency for Maxwell House coffee. 29 A hard look at the cup of coffee has been by the people at Farberware Inc., and they say they have found a better way to brew it. 29 Student files suit against Michigan U. anti-bias policy 8 Ohio congressman convicted in sex case, but may run again 9 Murderer dies in the electric chair in Alabama 24 Regional 25-27, 46 A former homeless man was killed in a park after making tentative steps to rejoin society. His family, social workers and his neighbors search for meanings in his eccentric life and violent death. 1 New parks rules have been rewritten in New York City so that they no longer seem to single out the homeless. Advocates for the homeless last month found the rules ''mean spirited'' and ''misguided.'' 26 The editor of The New York Post, Jane Amsterdam, was dismissed by the paper's publisher, Peter S. Kalikow, on Thursday afternoon, say persons close to each of them, who asked not to be identified. 25 State police enforcing speed limits over the holiday weekend are confronting the force of public habit. Most motorists across the region appear to be ignoring 55 M.P.H. laws. 25 Stripers are abundant in the Hudson, scientists and fishermen say. But they are of no commercial value because of the fish's high levels of PCB's. 25 Approval of a Connecticut budget of $6.8 billion for the year beginning July 1 advanced in the Legislature, even as sharp debate continued about how to pay for it. 25 A student told a school official about the sexual assault of a mildly retarded girl in Glen Ridge, N.J., within two days of its occurrence, a lawyer for the boy said. 27 A Bronx mother charged in the death of her 2-year-old daughter and a father charged with abusing the child and her two siblings were depicted by case workers three months ago as a ''strong and motivated'' couple. 27 Queens man arrested Monday said to have died from cocaine 27

title: Plea Is Entered in Case Of Baby Left on Plane
description: A mother who abandoned her newborn daughter in a jetliner's restroom before a cross-country flight has pleaded no contest to charges of child endangerment.

title: Arab League Fails to Sway Syrians on Lebanon
description: The Arab League ended a four-day summit meeting today without persuading Syria to withdraw its 40,000 soldiers from Lebanon.

title: Use Lottery for Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Sailor Under Investigation Denies Links to Iowa Blast
description: A sailor under investigation in the explosion aboard the battleship Iowa said today, in his first public appearance since being linked to the blast, that he had nothing to do with it and that he was the victim of a Navy ''looking for a possible scapegoat.''

title: Growth Lags For Income; Spending Up
description: Growth in personal income slowed for the third consecutive month in April, but consumer spending rose substantially as car buyers took advantage of rebates and low financing offers, the Government reported today.

title: Random Death Claims a Man Who Struggled to Regain Life
description: For much of six years, James Reginald Jarvis lived in a cave in Inwood Hill Park at the northern edge of Manhattan with his prized possessions: a sleeping bag, a collection of rocks and fossils and sheet music of sonatas by Bach and Beethoven.

title: Patents; Service to Analyze Japanese Patent Filings
description: Two Japanese companies are beginning an English-language service that reports and analyzes all new patent applications in Japan.

title: Patents; A Recipe to Breed Higher-Yield Corn
description: The Sungene Technologies Corporation of San Jose, Calif., won patent approval for a recipe of nutrients to help breed higher-yielding corn.

title: London Broadcasting Ban On Ulster Militants Upheld
description: A court today upheld the Government's ban on the broadcasting of interviews with members of militant groups in Northern Ireland.

title: Shareholder Group Blocks Nestle Plan
description: A small group of shareholders has temporarily blocked plans by the Swiss food giant Nestle to change its corporate statutes and to proceed with a $460 million sale of securities. The plans were approved at Nestle's annual meeting in Lausanne, Switzerland, but they were put on hold when the dissenting shareholders took their complaint to the registrar of companies in Vevey, where Nestle is based.

title: Thermo May Bid For Milton Roy
description: The Thermo Electron Corporation said it had acquired a 5.9 percent stake in the Milton Roy Company and was interested in acquiring the St. Petersburg, Fla., concern. Milton Roy's stock jumped $1.125 today, to $17.625 a share, on the New York Stock Exchange. With 5.6 million shares outstanding, Milton Roy has a market value of more than $98 million.

title: Editors' Note
description: The ''At the Bar'' column on the Law page yesterday discussed lawyers' use of advertising, legalized 10 years ago. Describing the use of newspaper ads by some kinds of law firms, it said: ''One will never see Sullivan & Cromwell alongside the bartending schools or high school equivalency courses. Most are personal-injury firms, whose names, like Longi & Loscalzo or Gersowitz & Libo, seem lifted from the log at Ellis Island rather than the pages of Martindale-Hubbell.''

title: Parks Department Revises Rules to Show Sensitivity to the Homeless
description: Rules governing the use of New York City parks that were found to be ''mean spirited'' and ''misguided'' last month by advocates for the homeless have been rewritten by the Parks and Recreation Department.

title: 1939 Fair Exhibition
description: ''The Last Fair on Earth: The New York World's Fair, 1939/40'' will open on Thursday at the New York Public Library, Fifth Avenue and 42d Street. The exhibition, running through Nov. 11, features 100 photographs and letters, posters, drawings, blueprints and memorabilia from the fair. Admission is free. Hours are 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Monday to Saturday. Information: 869-8089.

title: Shadow of an Ailing Marcos Hangs Over Politics in Manila
description: As the Philippines awaits the death of Ferdinand E. Marcos, the nation is consumed with what some are calling ''necropolitics,'' a morbid mixture of squabbling and expiation so intricate that it needs a psychoanalyst or a priest to unravel.

title: Negotiations Are Rejected By Japanese
description: Japan said today that it would refuse to negotiate trade issues with the United States while American officials ''brandished the threat of unilateral sanctions'' against trading partners who did not accede to their demands.

title: Learning the Ropes, Pit Stop by Pit Stop
description: The joke about the driver who made a dozen pit stops at the Indianapolis 500 to ask for directions is not as absurd as it sounds, once you talk to Scott Pruett.

title: Morris Neiman, 79, Educator and Author
description: Dr. Morris Neiman, an educator and author, died from complications of cancer surgery Thursday at the Mount Sinai Medical Center. He was 79 years old and lived in Rego Park, Queens.

title: A 42d Street Trolley Is Feasible for New York; Buses Got in the Way
description: To the Editor:

title: Owner Didn't Inspect Part Of Pipeline That Blew Up
description: A section of gasoline pipeline that ruptured in a fatal explosion Thursday was not checked for damage after a runaway train plowed across it two weeks earlier, the line's owner said today.

title: Making the Best of a Bad Trade Law
description: Following a script as stylized and deliberate as Noh drama, the Administration has accused Japan of unfairly restricting imports of three major American products - and cited Brazil and India for three other offenses. The decision was an awkward straddle to placate Congressional protectionists without overly offending the Japanese in particular. Tokyo may yield, turning this exercise into a triumph. But arrogant bashing could also lead to a trade war, in which American consumers would suffer along with the Japanese.

title: Bridge Collapses as Flooding Strikes Southwestern Ohio
description: A temporary bridge across the swollen Great Miami River collapsed today and as many as four cars fell into the flood waters. The occupants of the cars were feared dead.

title: Patents; Helping Scuba Divers Monitor Their Ascent
description: Three Canadian inventors have developed a $50 device to help scuba divers accurately monitor their rate of ascent to the surface.

title: Turn 'Em Loose, Dean
description: We went to a commencement.

title: Noriega Refuses to Meet With Opposition
description: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega told representatives of the Organization of American States today that the crisis over the annulled Panamanian elections had to be resolved among the political parties and that he would not talk directly with opposition leaders.

title: FEUDING SETS TONE IN SOVIET CONGRESS
description: The Soviet Union today struggled to give birth to a new kind of government in a process that laid bare bitter divisions of class, geography, nationality and outlook.

title: Time for Courage on Property Taxes
description: Eight years ago, after a court found that downstate real property taxes were being improperly calculated, Albany imposed temporary fixes in order to avoid painful choices. Now it is about to approve yet another temporary fix, but has an opportunity to do so in a more constructive way.

title: Cash for Alfa Ruled Illegal
description: The European Commission's competition chief has decided that an injection of state cash to the car maker Alfa Romeo before it was sold to Fiat in 1987 was illegal and must be repaid, commission sources said today.

title: Far-Off Silver Lining In Dispute With Japan
description: The United States' decision to name Japan as an unfair trading partner does some immediate damage but could bring long-term benefits to the overall relationship between Tokyo and Washington.

title: Ralph Winsor, 53, Head of Food Company
description: Ralph Winsor, chairman of Curtice-Burns Inc., a food processing company based in Rochester, died, apparently of a heart attack, on Thursday at his dairy farm in Harpursville, N.Y. He was 53 years old.

title: Student Says He Told Officials of Sex Assault
description: A high school senior told a school official about the sexual assault of a 17-year-old mildly retarded girl here within two days of its occurrence on March 1, a lawyer for the student said today.

title: Chip Futures Are Proposed
description: The Twin Cities Board of Trade said today that it had applied to the Federal Commodity Futures Trading Commission for permission to set up the first cash and futures markets in computer chips.

title: Labor Talks at Regional Theaters End
description: The Society of Stage Directors and Choreographers and the League of Resident Theaters have broken off talks on a contract, and the society announced that beginning today it would withhold its members' services from plays at league theaters across the country that have not begun rehearsals.

title: Fishing Guide and Client Billed $3 Million by U.S. for Forest Fire
description: A Montana fishing guide and his client got a bill this week from the United States Forest Service, along with a pre-addressed envelope. The service wanted reimbursement for the cost of fighting a fire last fall in southern Montana.

title: Maxwell House Lost By Ogilvy
description: Less than two weeks after relinquishing its independence to the WPP Group, the Ogilvy Group lost another battle yesterday when Kraft General Foods dropped Ogilvy & Mather as its advertising agency for Maxwell House coffee and gave the account to D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles/ New York.

title: INSIDE
description: New Tensions in Trade: Hope in U.S., Scorn in Japan

title: Beverly Majteles Becomes a Bride
description: Beverly Rachel Majteles, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Majteles of New York and Southampton, L.I., was married yesterday at Temple Emanu-el in New York to Daniel Maxwell Floersheimer, a son of Dr. Stephen Floersheimer of Zurich and the late Eliane Goldmuntz Floersheimer. Rabbi Ronald Sobel and Cantor Bruce Halev performed the ceremony.

title: Hudson's Striped Bass Are Tasty, Abundant and Off Limits
description: ''Relax!'' Andy Kahnle yelled at a thrashing striped bass as he plucked it from a huge net in the Hudson River, 97 miles above New York Harbor.

title: Terri Barr Wed In Connecticut
description: Therese Marie Barr, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Roy Stevans Barr of Farmington, Conn., and Robert Adam Schrecengost, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Eugene Schrecengost of North Huntington, Pa., were married last evening at St. Patrick's Roman Catholic Church in Farmington. The Rev. Thomas M. Ginty officiated.

title: Pitino and That Rich Tradition
description: Like a good five-cent cigar, a good million-dollar teacher is very hard to get these days.

title: Ushers Center Stage
description: ''Ushers Onstage,'' a free show featuring performers who also work as ushers at Lincoln Center, is to take place on June 8 at Alice Tully Hall, 66th Street and Broadway, at 7:30 P.M. The performers - singers, pianists, dancers and a guitarist - were selected at a juried audition. Tickets are available at Alice Tully Hall box office. Information: 877-1800, extension 425.

title: Review/Jazz; Anita O'Day Draws on Lots of Memories
description: After singing for more than 50 years, Anita O'Day has arrived at a peak in her career as she approaches her 70th birthday. At Michael's Pub, 211 East 55th Street, where she will be singing through June 17, she is drawing on her repertory and experience, including her scintillating years with Gene Krupa's orchestra..

title: 55 M.P.H.? Not the Way Many Drive
description: State police officers cracking down on speeders over the holiday weekend are confronting the force of public habit: most motorists across the New York metropolitan region appear to be ignoring the 55-mile-an-hour speed limit.

title: Palme's Legacy
description: LEAD: An interesting experiment has just been brought to a close. It was carried out not in a laboratory but around a series of conference tables. First gathered by Olof Palme, the late Prime Minister of Sweden, 16 men and women in 1980 set out to chart a way out of what seemed to be a nearly hopeless tangle of international conflicts.

title: Latest Soviet Hockey Intrigue: A Secret Agent
description: Five of the Soviet Union's most acclaimed hockey players and a well-known coach have spurned the Soviet Ice Hockey Federation and secretly signed representation agreements with an American classical-music impresario, even though the defiance could jeopardize their freedom to leave the Soviet Union and join the National Hockey League, the impresario said yesterday.

title: Philharmonic to Begin Park Series on July 24
description: The New York Philharmonic's 25th season of free parks concerts in New York City and Suffolk, Nassau and Westchester Counties will begin on July 24 on Central Park's Great Lawn at 8 P.M.

title: U.S. Reassigns Texas Agents, Calling Border Push a Success
description: The Immigration and Naturalization Service has begun to reassign the extra border patrol agents who were sent to Brownsville, Tex., in February to stem a surge of illegal aliens.

title: Confused Puppies
description: LEAD: When Yigor Ligachev attacked Mikhail Gorbachev's ''new thinking'' last summer, calling it a betrayal of ''the class struggle against capitalism,'' he said such changes only confuse ''our friends abroad.'' At the time, I thought the only confused friend he had in mind was Gus Hall, chairman of the U.S.

title: Chase in Biggest Purchase Of a Credit Card Business
description: In the largest purchase ever of a credit card business, the Chase Manhattan Corporation is buying about 1.2 million Visa and Mastercard accounts with more than $1.1 billion of outstanding debts from the Michigan National Corporation.

title: Review/Dance; Liepa and Browne as Romeo and Juliet
description: Andris Liepa and Leslie Browne looked splendidly and desperately in love in American Ballet Theater's ''Romeo and Juliet'' Thursday night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Would that this kind of emotional rapport existed in every performance of Sir Kenneth MacMillan's three-act version of Shakespeare's tragedy.

title: F.C.C. Denies MCI Protest On Phone Job
description: Clearing the way for work to begin on the Government's huge new telephone system, the Federal Communications Commission yesterday rejected charges by the MCI Communications Corporation that the American Telephone and Telegraph Company had set prices below cost to win a multibillion contract to build the network.

title: Judge Condemns 14 South Africa Blacks
description: A South African judge today sentenced 14 blacks to hang for the murder of a black policeman in the rural town of Upington three and a half years ago.

title: Holiday Weekend
description: Broadway between 72d and 79th Streets will be closed from 8 A.M. to 7 P.M. today for the Spring Festival. Second Avenue between 42d and 53d Streets will be closed from 8 A.M. to 7 P.M. tomorrow for the Turtle Bay Fair.

title: Brazil Cites Large Debt In Its Defense on Trade
description: Responding to American accusations of unfair trade practices, Brazilian officials said today that import barriers allowed the nation to build up a surplus that in turn helped it to make payments on its large foreign debt.

title: For the Cannes Winner, Untarnished Celebrity
description: It was 2 A.M. in the nearly empty bar of the Majestic Hotel, many hours after the close of the 42d Cannes International Film Festival on Tuesday night, though the night hadn't ended. The center of attention at a corner table was Steven Soderbergh, the 26-year-old American who had just become the youngest director ever to win the festival's top award, the Palme d'Or.

title: Can We Give Noriega A New Identity?
description: To the Editor:

title: ALL THIS BUT NO OSCAR
description: MARLENE By Marlene Dietrich. Translated by Salvator Attanasio. Illustrated. 273 pp. New York: Grove Press. $18.95.

title: Lee Grimsbo: Gift Basket Maker
description: Some rustic gift baskets brimming with fruits, flowers and confections must be hand-delivered; they're too delicate, their maker believes, to encase in shrink-wrap and ship cross-country.

title: We Shouldn't Envy Canada's Health System; Better Than You Think
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: U.S. Atom Aid to France

title: Lewis M. Kessler And Ms. Jaycox, Lawyers, Married
description: Tamara LaForge Jaycox and Lewis Maier Kessler, 1987 graduates of the Harvard Law School, were married yesterday at the Samuel Powel House, a historic site in Philadelphia, by Judge James T. Giles of the Federal District Court for Eastern Pennsylvania.

title: STREETSCAPES: Readers' Questions; A Mystery Monogram and a Building Out of Sync
description: This is another in a series of columns answering questions about New York's changing streetscapes.

title: Outdoors; Earning Stripes With Bass
description: As a native New Yorker, I found that my first morning in North Carolina did not match my preconception of a temperate southern dawn. The Piedmont air was near freezing and as it passed over the warmth of the Roanoke River, it kicked up a ribbon of vapor that coursed like a wall over the river channel. My guide, Jerry Medlin, steered his johnboat more by memory than by sight through the thick fog and among the large boulders that give the nearest town its name, Roanoke Rapids.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week; Should Contracts Be Honored Or Ignored?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Anita Alvin Wed To Fredrik Nilert
description: At the Brick Presbyterian Church in New York, Anita von Kantzow Alvin, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ib Alvin of New York, was married yesterday to Fredrik Tore Nilert, a son of Catharina Bernadotte Nilert of Stockholm and Tore H. Nilert of Divonne les Bains, France. The Rev. Leslie Merlin officiated. Mrs. Nilert graduated from the Spence School and Georgetown University and received an M.B.A. degree from Columbia University. She is the director at Jan Eric von Lowenadler Fine Art, a dealer in New York. Her father, a former vice president for North America at the Danish-owned Moller Steamship Company-Maersk Line in New York, is the vice president of the Danish-American Society in New York. Her mother, Elfi Alvin, is a scenic and interior designer and the director of the art program at the American Scandinavian Society of New York.

title: Reviews/Dance; Bennington Alumni On Display
description: The audience sat in chairs - none of them elevated - on a flat floor, the same flat floor on which the dancers performed. As a result, it was impossible to see much of ''Bennington in New York,'' the program presented Monday night at the Twining Gallery by three alumni of the dance department of Bennington College in Vermont. If a dance can't be seen, it doesn't really exist.

title: A Wild Card Who Is Not for Puny Natures
description: Launched in May of last year at the Ashmolean Museum in Oxford, England, a traveling exhibition called ''Lucian Freud: Works on Paper'' can be seen through June 24 at the Brooke Alexander Gallery, 59 Wooster Street.

title: Successor to Takeshita Reported Chosen
description: Seeking to defuse Japan's long-running leadership crisis, top leaders of the governing Liberal Democratic Party have settled on the choice of Foreign Minister Sosuke Uno to serve as the country's next Prime Minister, news organizations reported this morning.

title: COMIC-BOOK COLLECTORS
description: I am 14 and have been drawing comics very seriously for five or six years. I also collect comic books.

title: New Plays Galore, but to What End?
description: A VISITOR on a tour of the state's theaters in late September could have been fooled. There were ''The Glass Menagerie,'' ''La Cage aux Folles,'' ''Born Yesterday'' and ''Little Shop of Horrors,'' all set to start the season in four major theaters, all bespeaking theatrical balm in New Jersey.

title: Dennis Hedlund: Videotape Distributor
description: Ever since he was a boy growing up in Amarillo, Tex., Dennis Hedlund has had a passion for the classics, relying on television programs like those showing Leonard Bernstein's concerts for his early cultural enrichment.

title: Rockefeller Foundation Elects 5
description: The Rockefeller Foundation has elected five new trustees, including Alan Alda, the actor and director, and Henry G. Cisneros, the retiring Mayor of San Antonio.

title: Question Of the Week; Are Indy Speeds Getting Too Fast?
description: Are horse races getting too fast? Are basketball players jumping too high? Are baseball players hitting the ball too far?

title: A Lure of the Season: The Desire for Fitness
description: Like furry animals emerging from a long hibernation, adults and children alike are rediscovering the process of moving their limbs.

title: SOCIAL EVENTS
description: 'Harlem Comes to Roseland'

title: Reporter's Notebook; Panama Opposition Wrestles With Its Image
description: A couple of months ago, Guillermo (Billy) Ford was a virtually unknown businessman, even to Panamanians.

title: Alan S. Murphy 3d Planning to Marry Ann S. O'Reilly, an Editor, in August
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gerald A. O'Reilly of Pelham Manor, N.Y., have announced the engagement of Mr. O'Reilly's daughter, Ann Steiner O'Reilly, to Alan Searight Murphy 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murphy Jr. of Orlando, Fla. Miss O'Reilly is also a daughter of the late Maureen Buckley O'Reilly. An August wedding is planned.

title:
GARDENING;
Clues to Those Mysterious Deaths
description: LEAD: IT is frustrating to watch a tree or shrub die. Despite the best possible care, including watering and fertilizing, failure still strikes. A popular shrub may help provide an answer.

title: Seoul Alarmed as Anti-U.S. Mood Takes Hold
description: No one was surprised when student radicals declared the other day that they would devote the next two weeks to anti-American themes. ''We're used to it,'' an American diplomat said.

title: Games for Disabled Challenge Youngsters
description: TWELVE-YEAR-OLD Donald Sorokin of Massapequa Park has been in training for the last two months.

title: Wittgenstein And Jabberwocky
description: To the Editor:

title:
FOCUS;
Outdoor 'Air-Conditioning' for a Phoenix Complex
description: LEAD: A $500 million mixed-use complex meant to provide a comfortable outdoor environment even when the temperature soars above 100 degrees is rising on eight downtown blocks in this city known as the Valley of the Sun.

title: Some Recipes That Keep Baby in Mind
description: AS an infant in a highchair, I was encouraged to stamp on pieces of boiled potato with my fist (the result is known as ''smashed'' potato), to squeeze bananas through my fingers, and later to eat spaghetti by sucking it up strand by strand. My grandmother called it ''experimenting with textures.''

title: Marcy Corbett, Executive, Marries Ellis Joseph Verdi
description: Marcy Ann Corbett and Ellis Joseph Verdi were married last evening at the Hotel Pierre in New York by Rabbi David Weiss.

title: J. W. Annan Weds Hope Kent
description: Hope Parkhurst Kent, a daughter of Mrs. Harry D. Watts Jr. of Delray, Fla., and the late William Man Parkhurst of New York, and John William Annan, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. David H. Annan of Lake Forest, Ill., and Gulf Stream, Fla., were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed at the Bath and Tennis Club in Palm Beach, Fla., by Judge Gavin G. K. Letts of the District Court of Appeal, a state court in West Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Nancy Reagan Ends Support of Drug Center
description: Nancy Reagan has withdrawn her support for plans for a drug treatment center, and the organization undertaking the disputed project said the center would not be opened.

title: Behind Coelho's Troubles
description: Tony Coelho's fund-raising ability never extended to personal finances.

title: The Changes Go Deep
description: The drama of the news these days has induced vertigo, intoxication with the idea that if some things can change so fast and so unexpectedly, everything can and must be changed overnight.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: NEW AND SELECTED ESSAYS. By Robert Penn Warren. (Random House, $24.95.) Armed with the methods of the New Criticism and the metaphors of a poet, Robert Penn Warren plunges deep into our literary heritage to rescue the hidden meaning of some of our most famous literary works. These 13 ''New and Selected Essays,'' considered his finest by Mr.

title: Christina M. Holz Marries Wayne Eckerson in Maine
description: Christina Milbank Holz and Wayne Wilks Eckerson were married yesterday at St. Thomas' Episcopal Church in Camden, Me., by the Rev. David Edman. Mrs. Eckerson, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Peter Holz of Camden, is a graduate of Connecticut College. She is a production associate in Boston for Bulfinch Press/Little, Brown & Company. Her father is a pediatrician in Camden. She is a granddaughter of the late Dr. Luther Emmett Holt, a chairman of pediatrics at New York University.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Jamestown, R.I.;
A New Bridge Raises Hopes
description: LEAD: WHEN the bridge that links this nine-mile-long island in Narragansett Bay to mainland Rhode Island is replaced in 1992 with a new $118 million, four-lane bridge now under construction, traffic will move more swiftly. Developers are hoping it will have the same affect on the home-sales market.

title: Homer for Parrish
description: Larry Parrish, a former major leaguer, hit his 17th home run, a bases-empty shot, as the Yakult Swallows edged the Yokohama Taiyo Whales, 2-1, in Japanese baseball today.

title: Flatbush Youths Harass Strollers In the Village
description: A group of about 40 youths raced through Greenwich Village Friday night, snapping gold chains from the necks of strollers, harassing women and pushing and menacing anyone who came in their path, the police said yesterday.

title: Working the Floor at a Job Fair
description: ''What's the pay like? Rotten, as usual?''

title: So Much Twaddle?
description: To the Editor:

title: Jill Kirkwood Is Married
description: At the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ann in Flushing, Queens, Jill Adrienne Kirkwood, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Kirkwood of Flushing, was married yesterday to Anthony Michael Ronda, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Michael J. Ronda of New York. The Rev. John J. Maduri performed the ceremony. Mrs. Ronda is a manager of advertising and sales promotion for Thomson McKinnon Securities in New York. Mr. Ronda is a vice president and the marketing director of the Apple Bank for Savings in New York.

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut; Recent Sales
description: Bedford, N.Y. $330,000 Appleby Drive 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 27-year-old farmhouse; cathedral ceiling in living room, fireplace, 1-car garage, 3.4 acres; taxes $3,059. Harrison, N.Y. $760,000 Haviland Road 5-bedroom, 4-bath, 53-year-old colonial; 2 fireplaces, 2 family rooms, finished basement, patio, 2-car garage; taxes $7,061. Scarsdale, N.Y. $380,000 96 Edgemont Road 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 32-year-old split-level; fireplace, eat-in kitchen w/skylight, deck, 1-car garage; taxes $7,891. Meriden, Conn. $192,000 40 Oxbow Drive 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 23-year-old colonial; fenced-in yard, potential office in home, 0.67 acre; taxes $1,973. Enfield, Conn. $128,000 533 George Washington Road 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 10-year-old Cape Cod; mint condition, fireplace, 90- by 154-foot lot; taxes $1,491. Greenwich, Conn. $895,000 75 Taconic Road 5-bedroom, 3 1/2-bath, 12-year-old contemporary; pool and fitness complex, 4 acres; taxes $5,992. OTHER AREAS Selden, L.I. $128,000 6 Remington Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 22-year-old high ranch; den, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,400. Westbury, L.I. $275,000 6 Robin Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old split level; dining room, eat-in kitchen, den, 2-car garage; taxes $5,300. Lebanon, N.J. $200,000 140A Rosemary Way 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 18-year-old ranch; new kitchen, c/a, hardwood floors; taxes $2,920.

title: THE HISTORIAN KEPT HIS COOL
description: ARNOLD J. TOYNBEE A Life. By William H. McNeill. Illustrated. 346 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. $24.95.

title: Alison Schmults, Banker, Is Wed To C. H. Burns
description: Alison Creighton Schmults and Cameron Horatio Burns were married yesterday at Christ Episcopal Church in Greenwich, Conn., by the Rev. Terence L. Elsberry. Kelly Dixon Cooper was the matron of honor. Seth Shepherd Burns was best man for his brother.

title: Kohl Visits the Netherlands
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl flew to the Netherlands today for talks with Prime Minister Ruud Lubbers about proposed Soviet-American talks on short-range nuclear weapons. Mr. Lubbers has offered to mediate a dispute between West Germany and the United States over the timing of such talks, which Bonn wants to start soon. The United States has reversed its opposition to such talks to avoid disunity in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, but wants progress on conventional forces first.

title: Is a Premiere The First Time? Not Necessarily
description: A few days ago, I attended a new piece of musical theater by Paul Dresher and Rinde Eckert called ''Power Failure.'' The production was part of the American Music Theater Festival season in Philadelphia, and the first night of its two-week run was therefore the world premiere.

title: 'Angels' Find Heaven in the Canadian Bush
description: There's no chance that the actors Robert De Niro and Sean Penn, the writer David Mamet and the producer Art Linson would ever claim to be angelic characters. So they think it's a bit of a joke that they were all involved in a film called ''We're No Angels,'' which was very definitely not a remake of the 1955 movie of the same name.

title: MORE WAYS THAN ONE TO BE GOOD
description: MAPPING THE MORAL DOMAIN A Contribution of Women's Thinking to Psychological Theory and Education. Edited by Carol Gilligan, Janie Victoria Ward and Jill McLean Taylor, with Betty Bardige. 324 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $30.

title: Quina Fonseca, a Designer, to MarryJ. J. Marvel, an Architect, in October
description: The engagement of Quina Fonseca to Jonathan Jova Marvel has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Elizabeth K. Fonseca of New York, East Hampton, L.I., and Venice, and Gonzalo Fonseca of New York and Seravezza, Italy. Mr. Marvel is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas S. Marvel of San Juan, P.R., and Bear Island, Me. An October wedding is planned.

title: Two Can't Go . . .
description: A federal judge in San Francisco has denied a request by a former Olympic athlete and a coach to lift suspensions barring them from amateur competition because they participated in a South African sports event despite an international boycott to protest apartheid.

title: Resources for Treating Child Sexual Abuse
description: There can never be enough said about child sexual abuse [ ''The Lasting Scar of Sexual Abuse,'' April 23 ] , a topic too long and too often shrouded in secrecy. As we as a society continue to lift the lid on this pot boiling over with shame and turmoil, it is important to note all the resources we have on Long Island that are effectively dealing with this terrible problem.

title: Storm Causes Power Failures
description: Thousands of homes were without power in Putnam and Dutchess counties after lightning struck a power station in Fishkill during a rainstorm. More than 22,000 homes lost their electricity Friday at about 9:15 P.M.

title: A WAL-MART KIND OF LIFE
description: SORT OF RICH By James Wilcox. 278 pp. New York: Harper & Row. $17.95.

title: Common Ground Through Computers
description: LEAD: THE messages that came over computer lines in two Long Island high schools last Oct. 24 (United Nations Day) were sincere and simple.

title: Review/Music; Alexis Golovin, Pianist, Makes New York Debut
description: The pianist Alexis Golovin has had a curious career odyssey, one result of which was that his New York debut Wednesday night at the 92d Street Y, with an audience full of piano fanciers, presented a fully formed musical personality.

title: College Graduates With a Difference
description: LEAD: AMONG the graduates receiving diplomas from Westchester's colleges this spring are several students for whom the ceremony holds a special significance, because of the effort it took to achieve that recognition.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;
Coping With Termites - and the Law
description: LEAD: ONE evening in March, Lillian Marx found a swarm of winged insects on the kitchen floor of her Old Bethpage split level. For the first time in 30 years of ownership, she discovered she had termites.

title: Alaska Oil Spill Is in Hands of Georgia Lawyers
description: The environmental damage is in Alaska, but much of the legal strategy surrounding the Exxon oil spill will depend on the findings of lawyers in Georgia.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some of the most notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted. Classical

title: Voters to Decide Fate of Nuclear Plant
description: At the Rancho Seco Nuclear Generating Plant here, where cows graze in the shadow of the twin cooling towers, contingency plans are being made to turn off the plant, move the fuel into storage, lay off hundreds of workers and buy power from alternative sources.

title: Jordan Basket Wins It
description: In what seemed too tall a task even for Michael Jordan, the Chicago Bulls erased a 13-point deficit in the final six minutes today to stun the Detroit Pistons, 99-97, and take a lead of 2 games to 1 in the Eastern Conference championship series.

title: Correction
description: An article last week on the bicycle business incorrectly identified the first American winner of the Tour de France. He is Greg LeMond, who won the race in 1986.

title: A Leg Up
description: IT MAY NOT YET BE AS POPULAR as, say, arena football, but according to Sorin Balaianu, you can bank on it: foot tennis is coming to your neighborhood. Balaianu, once a Rumanian national wrestling champion, is now the executive director of the International Foot Tennis Federation, a governing body based in Phoenix whose stated purpose is to organize and sanction ''recreational and professional tournaments throughout the world.'' So far, there have been two, both in Arizona; a third is scheduled for June 23 and 24, in Scottsdale. A fourth, with prizes totaling $7,000, is to be held in Tucson in August. According to Balaianu, foot tennis is already played professionally in Hungary, and informally, without standardized rules, in soccer-playing nations worldwide. By the dictates of his new federation, the game is to be played on a regulation doubles tennis court with either three or four players on a side, who use their heads, shoulders, knees or feet to bat the ball back and forth across the net. A serve, with the feet, must bounce in either service box. Returns may be volleyed or allowed to bounce once, each team having a maximum three hits to keep the ball in play. Scoring resembles that used in Ping-Pong. An official ball is still in development; for now, it's a slightly deflated volleyball.

title: About Cars; Now Unser Is First to Start
description: It has been eight years since Bobby Unser led the pack at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, but the veteran racer will be out there again today when the green flag drops on the 73d running of the Indy 500.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: WOODPECKER POINT & OTHER STORIES. By Carmel Bird. (New Directions, $19.95.) It may be simply a coincidence that the author of ''Woodpecker Point & Other Stories'' is surnamed Bird, but to judge from her penchant for onomastic metaphors and the sly humor of her work, it probably isn't. This slim volume of 24 tersely written sketches (culled mainly from Carmel Bird's first collection, which was privately printed in

title: DALEY CONFOUNDS CRITICS IN CHICAGO
description: When Richard M. Daley was elected Mayor here six weeks ago, his critics did not quite predict that a small clique of old-fashioned machine politicians would take over City Hall, then build a moat around it filled with alligators to feast on liberals and government reformers. But that was the impression they left.

title: Corrections
description: An interview on May 7 with Jack Krumpe about the convention and trade-show business misstated his current positions. Mr. Krumpe left the Madison Square Garden Corporation in October 1986 to become chairman and chief executive of the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.

title: THE SELF IN STRANGE PLACES
description: IN TRANSIT Twenty Stories. By Mavis Gallant. 229 pp. New York: Random House. $17.95.

title: The Retiring Kind
description: WHAT WILL YOU do?''

title: Who Is the Eptest Of Them All?
description: SOME DEMOCRATIC members of the Senate Judiciary Committee suspected that the Bush Justice Department was applying an ''ideological litmus test'' to its judicial nominations, and demanded that several nominees 'fess up to the kind of questioning they had undergone before being offered the jobs.

title:
MUSIC;
Composers Guild Making Strides
description: LEAD: THE Composers Guild of New Jersey is considered among the most prominent and effective organizations in the nation at fostering the acceptance of new music by American composers, with a focus on New Jersey composers. With its first major festival this week, the Ship Bottom-based guild will be taking a giant step forward in showing the scope and appeal of today's composers.

title: PASTIMES: Gardening; An Alert for Some Insect Nuisances
description: A home gardener is in charge and can choose a way to get rid of pests that is least harmful to the environment. Too often when chemical weapons are used for complete eradication, the good is destroyed with the bad.

title: Samaranch Leaves Hospital
description: Juan Antonio Samaranch, president of the International Olympic Committee, left today with a clean bill of health after a checkup during a two-day stay.

title: The Auvergne's Well-Bred Beef
description: THE natives of Cantal - in the rugged south-central Auvergne region of France - love to report that their department has 150,000 inhabitants and 450,000 cows. And a good number of those cows are the Salers breed, raised for their golden rich milk as well as their tender, finely muscled, reddish-brown, delicately marbled beef.

title: Robert Beguelin And Miss Jones Exchange Vows
description: Susanna Adams Jones and Robert Dayton Beguelin were married in New York yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest by the Rev. Hugh Hildesley.

title: Nigeria Police Fire on Crowd Protesting Austerity Program
description: The Nigerian police opened fire on protesters in Benin City on Friday night as demonstrations against the Government's austerity program continued for a third day.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: LIGHT, by Michael I. Sobel. (University of Chicago, $14.95.) A physicist shows that understanding light can lead to an appreciation of every level of the universe, from atoms to animals to stars. The author ''is a popularizer in the best sense, the expert witness clearly and concisely explaining complex concepts,'' James Cornell said here in 1987. ''He makes points with conviction and considerable grace, and highlights his straightforward narrative with some fascinating insights.'' THE SUGAR MOTHER, by Elizabeth Jolley. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $7.95.) When Cecilia, his barrenJU obstetrician wife, goes off on sabbatical, an introverted professor named Edwin Page finds that his neighbor and her beautiful daughter, Leila, want to move in. This is Elizabeth Jolley's ''warmest novel, her most moving and possibly the best introduction to her fiction,'' Stephen McCauley said here last year. '' 'The Sugar Mother' gently lures the reader into Ms. Jolley's world. The eccentric (often delightful, sometimes nightmarish) extremes of her other novels are relatively muted here. But beware of the book's seductive charm.'' THE ADAMS WOMEN: Abigail and Louisa Adams, Their Sisters and Daughters, by Paul C. Nagel. (Oxford University, $9.95.) In the Adams family, the men got to be Presidents while the women stayed home and assumed the enormous burden of putting up with them. ''In this worthy sequel to 'Descent From Glory,' his study of the Adams men, Paul C. Nagel again proves himself a shrewd psychologist and a gifted biographer,'' Jan Lewis said in The Book Review in 1987. THE TOYNBEE CONVECTOR, by Ray Bradbury. (Bantam, $3.95.) In the title piece of this collection of short stories, an inventor tries to cure the world of its cynicism by perpetrating a hoax: a time machine that brings back news of a wonderful future. ''For all the familiarity of his materials, Mr. Bradbury, in his best work, demonstrates a sure-footed storytelling talent, creating tales that boast the sort of easily accessible morals so dear to high-school teachers and that also stand up as memorable pop entertainments,'' Michiko Kakutani said in The Times last year. RUSSIA AND THE NEGRO: Blacks in Russian History and Thought, by Allison Blakely. (Howard University, $12.95.) This history of how blacks have influenced Russia and vice versa includes a cast of characters ranging from Pushkin to Angela Davis. In 1987 our reviewer, William C. Fuller Jr., said the book is ''unusual and entertaining.'' It won an American Book Award in 1988. OUT ON THE MARSH, by David Updike. (Plume/New American Library, $7.95.) Last year our reviewer, Joyce Reiser Kornblatt, said that the best work in this first collection of short fiction by David Updike is characterized by a ''Zenlike repose.'' A HISTORY OF THEIR OWN: Volume One. Women in Europe From Prehistory to the Present, by Bonnie S. Anderson and Judith P. Zinsser. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $12.95.) Most of the history of the world has been written by men. Last year our reviewer, G. W. Bowersock, said that some of the feminist analysis in this report from the other side is too simplistic but that the book is ''an honorable initiative in giving women the history they deserve.'' NOT THAT SORT OF GIRL, by Mary Wesley. (Penguin, $6.95.) When her husband dies after half a century of marriage, Rose Peel must decide whether to take up with Mylo, who has been her sometime lover for all those years. Last year our reviewer, Julian Moynahan, said Mary Wesley ''pushes things to excess in an imaginative, sometimes idiosyncratic way.'' HOW CAN AFRICA SURVIVE? by Jennifer Seymour Whitaker. (Council on Foreign Relations, $12.95.) The best thing the West can do to help Africa solve its own problems, the author argues, is to provide support without trying to impose ideology. This is ''a clear-sighted examination of why Africa has been unable to fulfill the promises of independence and how, with luck, courage and serious planning, it may one day be able to play a meaningful role in the global community,'' David Lamb said in The Book Review last year. CAROLINA SKELETONS, by David Stout. (Mysterious Press, $4.95.) A black journalist tries to discover whether his uncle really killed two white girls 40 years ago. Based on the story of a real murder, this novel ''is full of compassion and understanding,'' Newgate Callendar said here last year. ''It is a plea for people of different ethnic and social backgrounds to understand one another and come together.'' BUYING INTO AMERICA: How Foreign Money Is Changing the Face of Our Nation, by Martin Tolchin and Susan Tolchin. (Berkley, $4.95.) One of the unexpected effects of our laissez-faire system is that it has allowed foreigners to gain control quietly over our economic and political affairs. ''It is the Tolchins' great accomplishment that they manage to explore the benefits, costs and policy questions raised by disproportionate foreign investment without ever becoming alarmist or jingoistic, yet still persuading the reader that a real problem exists,'' Robert Kuttner said here last year. LETOURNEAU'S USED AUTO PARTS, by Carolyn Chute. (Perennial/Harper & Row, $7.95.) The author of ''The Beans of Egypt, Maine,'' tells more about what it is like to live on hot dogs and baloney in a trashy trailer park from which there is no escape. ''Carolyn Chute, along with Russell Banks, Raymond Carver and a few others, shatters the myth that characters have to be Southern to be grotesque,'' Clarence Major said here last year. ''To her credit, unlike Steinbeck, Ms. Chute makes no attempt to preach a philosophy of liberation.''

title: Evelyn S. Bolten Weds in Capital
description: The marriage of Evelyn Susanna Bolten to James Laurence Connaughton took place yesterday at Holy Trinity Roman Catholic Church in Washington. The Rev. James Conn performed the ceremony.

title: A Gotti Is Convicted
description: Gene Gotti, the 42-year-old brother of John Gotti, was convicted of running a multimillion-dollar heroin ring, but it wasn't easy. The case began in 1983, resulted in two mistrials and became one of the oldest unresolved matters on the Federal docket. A third mistrial was narrowly averted in Brooklyn when one of the 12 jurors whose identities were supposedly secret said that two men had threatened him in his driveway. After the juror was dismissed, the remaining 11 last week returned a guilty verdict against Mr. Gotti and an associate. Defense lawyers said they would appeal. John Gotti, the reputed boss of the nation's largest organized-crime group, was charged in January with ordering the shooting of a union official.

title: UPHEAVAL IN CHINA: Reporter's Notebook; For Foreigners, Beijing Turns Chilly
description: For a foreigner in China these days, this is a season for farewells.

title: 11 Make the Cut for N.F.L. Job
description: Nearly everyone associated with the National Football League meeting here last week left with the same burning question: ''Who's on the list of 11?''

title: Unrest Over Inflation Sets Off Argentine Looting
description: Supermarkets in at least four cities were looted and one was set afire on Friday night in unrest prompted by high inflation. No injuries were reported, but more than 90 people were arrested.

title: PLAYING HARDBALL
description: Amnesia has reached a new high. When George Bush was Republican Party chairman during the Watergate days, he could not recall any Nixon wrongdoing. Now he cannot remember having been ''in the loop'' of the Iran-contra affair. The current G.O.P. national chairman, Lee Atwater, can't recall any of his past racist or anti-Semitic smears. Is there abroad some kind of memory-destroying virus? After all, even our populace seems to have developed a short attention span. THOMAS R. HORTON White Plains

title: Fair Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: CRUSADER ON THE CHARLES
description: John Silber, like the philosopher Allen Bloom, feels strongly that the chief objective of a university should be dedication to the learning process. It is good to know that there are men in responsible positions like this crusading educator who are willing to make difficult and unpopular choices in support of the stern moral precepts laid down by the American pioneers. HENRY REGENSTEINER New York, N.Y.

title: Mets Have a Night They'll Remember
description: Was it the night to remember for the Mets, the night they broke out?

title: Matthew Roth to Wed Pamela L. Lippmann
description: Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Robert L. Lippmann of New York of the engagement of their daughter Pamela Linde Lippmann to Matthew Adam Roth, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Roth of Peekskill, N.Y. An August wedding is planned.

title: Crack; A Disaster of Historic Dimension, Still Growing
description: The little pellets first appeared on the West Coast in the early 1980's, the product of brilliant marketing. Someone figured out how to boil down powdered cocaine into crystals that could be smoked rather than snorted. Inhaling this ''crack'' gives a brief, intense high - followed by a crash that leaves the user desperate for more. Each crystal sells for $10 or less, compared with $100 or more for a gram of cocaine powder.

title: In Stamford, a World Invisible to the Naked Eye
description: LEAD: PHOTOGRAPHIC blowups of magnifications transform fine white powder into a ball of star shapes, a brass disk into lacy crochet work, and a sprig of wheat into a multi-textured sponge. What at first glance looks like an eye-catching black-and-white geometric design show, turns out to be a probing scientific exhibition.

title: COMIC-BOOK COLLECTORS
description: I am 13, an avid comic-book reader and a frequent customer of my local comic-book store (''Drawing on the Dark Side,'' by Joe Queenan, April 30).

title: Foreign Owners Are Shaking Up the Competition
description: Foreign ownership of American companies has radically changed the competitive dynamics in a number of industries. Here is a look at several. Chemicals

title: A Crisis That Money Alone Won't Solve
description: EVEN as New York City hospitals bid up nursing wages to levels unimagined only a few years ago, hospital administrators and public health experts are concluding that money alone will not end the shortage of nurses.

title: Coelho's Deftness as a Deal Maker Fails to Extend to His Personal Finances
description: The deft touch for raising political contributions that helped propel Tony Coelho into the Democratic leadership in the House never extended to his personal finances, leaving the California Congressmen financially insecure for much of his political career.

title: HOW ILLITERACY MAKES ATHLETES RUN
description: Dexter Manley, the All-Pro defensive end for the Washington Redskins, recently came out with an embarrassing confession. He almost made it to the age of 30 without being able to read.

title: Spike Lee Raises the Movies' Black Voice
description: Role models are useful up to a point. It's good to be able to note that Eddie Murphy, Bill Cosby, Oprah Winfrey and Michael Jackson are among the biggest personalities in American show business today. However, what effect have these individual success stories had on the lives of the members of America's black underclass? Not much. That's the laconic answer supplied by Spike Lee, the writer, director and star of ''Do the Right Thing,'' the exuberant new melodrama that was one of the most original and truly controversial entries at the just-concluded 42d Cannes International Film Festival.

title: Burma
description: To the Editor: Steven Erlanger glossed over the truly splendid and unusual things to see in Burma. I found it totally refreshing to be one of only 50 to 75 tourists in the whole country. While Burma isn't geared for tourists yet, it was wonderful to visit the various sites and not be inundated with gawking tourists and hordes of tour buses.

title: A Funny Thing Happened to Soviet Architecture Photo of ''Ascencion to the Peak, Glass Monument for 2001,'' by V. Saitsev and L. Vatalov (Karin Hill)
description: Among all the arts exported from the Soviet Union since the 1950's, architecture has been conspicuous by its absence. The reason is simple. While Stalin favored inflated, wedding-cake-style architecture to express the state's authority, Khrushchev wanted quantity - especially mass-produced housing, roughly built with large prefabricated panels. What had been an elitist profession under Stalin became subsumed within a centrally planned, bottom-line-only bureaucracy intent on the industrialization of all building. In 1957, Khrushchev abolished the Academy of Architecture; some architecture schools closed; enrollment in others declined. Diminished responsibilities and freedoms lowered expectations and reduced the profession's ability to attract talent. Architecture was humbled and marginalized.

title: AFTER HIROHITO: WHAT REMAINS SACRED
description: IN ACCORDANCE WITH AN OLD TRADITION, THE GRAND shrine at Ise, in central Japan, is pulled down every twenty years and built up again in exactly the same form, that of an ancient wooden hut for storing rice. There, sometime in the seventh century, a princess of the imperial court decided the sun goddess Amaterasu was to be worshipped. There, one is told, amid the manicured paths of sacred pebbles and the ancient evergreens, Japanese feel the true spirit of nature. And there, the Emperor, as the highest priest of the Shinto religion, performs his sacred rites each year.

title: Is the Use of Latin 'Pro Bono'?
description: During the Presidential campaign and many times since we have heard President Bush say, ''Read my lips,'' and this we have been doing.

title: Blacks Are Better Athletes
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: PASTIMES: Camera
description: The news that Modern Photography magazine has come to the end of the road was no less depressing for being predictable. Not long after Capital Cities-ABC sold the magazine to Diamandis Communications, Diamandis announced that it was shutting it down, as of the July issue. Diamandis owns Popular Photography, Modern Photography's competitor, so the move has a certain business logic.

title: Nurses at St. Luke's Approve Contract After a 6-Day Strike
description: Registered nurses at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital overwhelmingly approved a contract aggreement yesterday, ending a six-day strike over salary and other grievances.

title: SPORTS STARS BUMP GENERALS FROM THE INDEX
description: Keeping up with the ever-expanding world of information becomes more difficult for encyclopedias each year. Last year, World Book spent $3 million and thousands of hours revising its encyclopedia for the 1989 edition. Encyclopedia Britannica went through a similar process.

title: BEIRUT DIARY
description: APRIL 17, 1989: Sporadic shelling this morning. I drive home from my office at midday with a 25-liter canister of gasoline for my electric generator. Just moments after I pass the state-run Lebanese University, a mortar shell strikes the campus. The blast causes my car to wobble, but I make it home to my apartment building on the rue Bachir al-Kassar, in West Beirut. In the afternoon, a lull in the fighting allows me to turn the generator on and use my electric typewriter. I write my daily story for The Times.

title: For Central Asset Accounts, New Allure
description: With the stock market hitting post-crash highs and the bulls once again in ascendance, so-called central asset accounts have a fresh allure.

title: New Jersey Reviews Care for Neglected Children
description: Three months after a 5-year-old Newark girl was beaten to death in a state-approved foster home, New Jersey officials are re-examining the way the state cares for abused and neglected children.

title: The Shareholder as Interviewer
description: For those who have an opportunity to talk with fund managers, either individually or at an annual shareholders' meeting, here are some pertinent questions to ask:

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: There is perhaps someone somewhere who has never wished to get even about something. In fact, a surprising number of people claim to be that someone, but they know in their hearts it isn't true.

title: Bush Speaks of Allied Troop Reductions
description: President Bush told Italian leaders today that recent Soviet proposals to reduce conventional arms in Europe had opened the way for cuts in allied forces, including those of the United States.

title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
Politicians Lead Us Into Decade Of the Deadlock
description: LEAD: EVEN without the benefit of the 20-20 hindsight historians often apply to mark milestones and turning points, it has become obvious that our region is, once again, undergoing a major transformation.

title: Seeking a Formula For Liberty and Order in the Park
description: EACH year, three million people make fourteen million visits to Central Park. On a beautiful summer day, there might be 250,000 people in its 843 acres.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: AGENT OF INFLUENCE. By David Aaron. (Putnam, $19.95.) Jayson Lyman, a gung-ho merger and acquisition specialist, has driven his Wall Street firm to the top ranks of deal-making. But even though his ethics are less than sturdy, he's aghast when his boss tells him that the French media mogul Marcel Bresson plans to take over News/Worldweek, the largest communications conglomerate in the United States.

title: One, Two, Three . . . And Four
description: To the Editor:

title: The Anticipated Spanish Fare Is Cuban
description: THE sign at Freeport's Victoria De Las Tunas reads Spanish Restaurant, but diners expecting standard Spanish fare will be disappointed.

title: From Broadway to London, With Some Surprises
description: The advertising logo is unchanged, and Eiko Ishioka's set has retained its sweeping blood-red sheen, but something seems to have happened to David Henry Hwang's ''M. Butterfly'' in its trip across the Atlantic. The latest of a dozen or so recent American shows to open in London this season, the local production of Mr. Hwang's Tony-winning drama illustrates the risks of such crossings. While visitors to London often bypass homegrown fare in search of plays unavailable in New York, comparison theatergoing has its rewards. Sometimes, as in ''M. Butterfly,'' one gets only an outline of the New York impact; elsewhere, as in ''Steel Magnolias'' and ''Speed-the-Plow,'' fresh faces lend unexpected resonance, even though all three plays opened here to largely mixed reviews.

title: Israelis Report Killing Armed Arab Infiltrator
description: An Arab who tried to infiltrate Israel from Jordan opened fire and slightly wounded two Israeli soldiers this morning before he was shot and killed, the Israeli Army said. An army spokeswoman said that around 6:30 A.M., an army patrol was fired on from near the border fence opposite Kibbutz Hamadya, 12 miles south of the Sea of Galilee.

title: Basketball's 2 Stressful Worlds Offer Coaches a Tough Choice
description: It is the same sport but a different game, with the rules, the duties and even the environment influencing the way a basketball coach approaches his job at the college or the professional level. There is, however, at least one similarity. As Rick Pitino has discovered, a coach with a high-profile job at any level is subject to intense public scrutiny.

title: Kaylie Ann Jones, a Writer, Is Married
description: Kaylie Ann Jones, the daughter of Gloria Jones of Sagaponack, L.I., and the late James Jones, the novelist, was married yesterday at her mother's home to Andrew Curtis Mackenzie, the son of Linda Bird Francke of Sagaponack and G. David Mackenzie of Fairfield, Conn. Acting Justice Shirley Fingerhood of State Supreme Court in Manhattan performed the ceremony.

title: Grade Inflation: Widespread Travesty
description: Teachers are notorious for inflating grades (''Schools Say Inflated Grades Cut Grants,'' May 7). Nowadays, in most schools the ''good'' students are almost always given A's, the ''mediocre'' students B's and the ''poor'' students almost never less than C's, despite their dubious achievements.

title: Open Mind Wins the Acorn
description: Open Mind beat ten 3-year-old fillies so impressively in the $186,600 Acorn Stakes yesterday at Belmont Park that her handlers are now thinking about running her against colts in the Belmont Stakes June 10.

title: Whose Patrimony Is It, Anyway?
description: To the Editor:

title: Hero Lifts Team Spirit
description: The Sharpstown Pirates Little League team lost its last game of the season, but after the final inning, a 15-year-old Pirates player with cerebral palsy was hoisted amid cheers onto the shoulders of his teammates.

title: NONFICTION
description: THE VANDERBILT ERA: Profiles of a Gilded Age. By Louis Auchincloss. (Scribners, $19.95.) The ''frivolous society'' of turn-of-the-century New York, Edith Wharton claimed in her 1905 novel ''The House of Mirth,'' ''can acquire dramatic significance only through what its frivolity destroys.'' In this volume, Louis Auchincloss - like Wharton, a novelist of manners and a scion of the patricians he chronicles - calls this the society of ''The Vanderbilt Era.'' There are several handsome group portraits among its illustrations of three generations of Vanderbilt physiognomy and architectural indulgence. But the accompanying prose amounts less to a group portrait, or even the ''profiles of a gilded age'' announced in the subtitle, than to a slight collection of biographical highlights, of which the nine-page treatment of Cornelius, the patriarch, is by far the longest. Mr. Auchincloss has a fine ear for anecdote, and his accounts are burnished with family feeling: his wife, Adele, is descended from Cornelius Vanderbilt, while his mother's uncle, Edmund C. Stanton, merits a chapter as the general manager, from 1886 to 1891, of the Metropolitan Opera House, one of William Henry Vanderbilt's projects. Of the Commodore's famous family, Mr. Auchincloss disarmingly writes, ''I chose them because they were richer and more numerous than any of the other clans that dominated business in the decades that followed the Civil War, and because they made a greater splash with their money.'' His assertion that this splash was crucial in generating the American Renaissance manifests itself in treatments of magisterial figures like Augustus Saint-Gaudens, Henry Adams and Stanford White. These, alas, reveal the sketchiness of his sketches and undermine his opportunity to offer for the Vanderbilt decades other criteria than their destructive frivolity.

title: Federal War On Crime Seems to See No End
description: A GROWING fear of crime. A new President who campaigned on promises to get tough with criminals. A springtime anti-crime package.

title: President's Little Secret: Boola Boola. Loved It
description: There was a time, not so long ago, when George Bush did not talk much about his Ivy League education. As a candidate desperately trying to shed an upper-crust image, Mr. Bush bragged more about his taste for pork rinds and Tabasco sauce than he did about his years at Yale University.

title: Poets Recall Bond To Walt Whitman
description: LEAD: TO be a poet in residence at the Walt Whitman Birthplace in Huntington Station - and there have been eight already - the poet must have an affinity for Whitman.

title: Reviews/Music; Frenchified Flute Recital
description: Sara Stern, a flutist born and based in Washington and a performer of more than usual accomplishment, appeared Monday evening at Weill Recital Hall. Her program, like her training under Marcel Moyse and Julius Baker, was French-oriented: after Bach came Henri Dutilleux, Walter Piston, Georges Enesco and Andre Jolivet.

title: Christian-Israeli Rift in Lebanon 'Security Zone'
description: For the first time since it established its ''security zone'' in southern Lebanon four years ago, Israel is facing opposition from some of the Christian residents in the area.

title: Fund Investors, Know Thy Manager
description: When choosing a mutual fund, it is as important to consider the fund manager as the fund itself, for without a capable captain to plot the fund's course, a fund can be lost in the market's often murky sea.

title: Enough 'Reality'
description: To the Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My bathroom ceiling was wallpapered and now I want to paint the ceiling. I have removed most of the wallpaper, but some cementlike paste remains in several areas. I am tired of trying to smooth this ceiling further. Can I paint with a sand-textured paint and are there any disadvantages to this?

title: Thai Policy Promotes Piracy Against Refugees
description: To the Editor:

title: HOME LIVES OF THE WEIRDOS
description: CONFESSIONS OF A BAD GIRL By Bette Pesetsky. 211 pp. New York: Atheneum. $16.95.

title: For Some Players, 'Life Begins at 40' Has Many Side Effects
description: Rick Reuschel is 40 years old, but he has an 8-2 record and a sizzling 2.06 earned run average so it's clear he is not finished as a major league pitcher. Nolan Ryan, even though he is 42, is not ready for forced retirement either; he has a 5-2 record and 79 strikeouts in 65Y innings.

title: Mark Caparosa And Midge Alter Engaged to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert H. Alter of Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter Midge Alter to Mark A. Caparosa, a son of Dr. Ralph J. Caparosa of Lebanon, Pa., and Patricia E. Caparosa of Forest Hills, Pa. A September wedding is planned.

title: Our Cabinet System Is a Charade
description: At his first Cabinet meeting, shortly before his inauguration, President Bush urged his newly designated department heads to think big, challenge the system and fight hard for their positions until he makes the call.

title: U.S. Toughens Its Trade Stance
description: Three nations were accused of unfair trading by President Bush. The action means that Japan, India and Brazil are subject to special negotiations with the United States and could face trade sanctions if they do not lower barriers to American imports within 18 months. Japan was cited for trading practices involving satellites, supercomputers and forest products; Brazil for general import licensing requirements and India for restrictions on foreign investments and on foreign insurance companies. All three Governments protested the action. Carla A. Hills, the United States trade representative, said the move was ''not intended to be offensive'' and that she hoped there would be no backlash. The authority to take the action comes from a provision of the trade law enacted last year, and many members of Congress have been urging a tough trade stance. *

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Alabama; The Untimely Demise Of Half a Million Mice Stymies Researchers
description: It's midnight in the world of medical research. Do you know where your mice are?

title: DATA BANK: May 28, 1989
Wilding - as American as Tom Sawyer
description: LEAD: Wilding. For more than a month, the word has chilled and titillated us. In two staccato syllables, it encapsulates the slithery dread many New Yorkers feel at the menace lurking out there in the dark.

title: Sociology's Long Decade in the Wilderness
description: THE 1980's have not been kind to sociology. The field has become impoverished, fragmented, vulnerable, precisely the kind of subject sociologists like to study.

title: Principal Is Charged With Molesting Girl
description: An East Harlem elementary-school principal was arrested Friday and charged with molesting an 11-year-old female student.

title: Fresh Air Fund Council Plans for Halloween
description: It may seem early, but the Fresh Air Fund Council has begun planning its fourth annual Halloween Ball, which it hopes will raise more than $100,000 to help New York City children enjoy a summer in the country.

title: Kathryn Untermeyer to Wed
description: The engagement of Kathryn Patricia Untermeyer and James Aldridge Atwood has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mrs. Harold Aks of New York and Rhinebeck, N.Y., and Walter Untermeyer of New York and East Hampton, L.I. Mr. Atwood is a son of Mr. and Mrs. John O. Atwood of Summit, N.J., and Narragansett, R.I. An August wedding is planned.

title: Republicans Vow to Press Attack on Ethics While Digging in for Democratic Reprisals
description: Capitol Hill braced today for more partisan bloodletting after the announcement by Representative Tony Coelho, the third-ranking Democrat in the House, that he would resign to spare his family and his Democratic colleagues the turmoil of a lengthy investigation of his finances.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;
For Vernon, a Condo Hotel Plus Housing
description: LEAD: SINCE it was built 18 years ago, the 617-room hotel off Routes 517 and 94 in Vernon has been unable to capture a healthy share of the resort trade. Once a Playboy Club, it has changed hands four times; it closed in the spring of 1988, and to many it has become a white elephant.

title:
The View From: Carl J. DelFino Park;
After a Hard Day's Work, Diamonds Are a Man's Best Friend
description: LEAD: IT'S that time of year again. The sun is still high in late afternoon, the office starts to seem like an air-conditioned prison, the green fields - especially those with white diamonds chalked on them - beckon.

title: Ann Remley Is a Bride
description: The marriage of Ann Kathleen Remley and Maximilian Felix Scheder-Bieschin, graduates of Stanford University, took place yesterday at St. Elizabeth Seton Roman Catholic Church in Rohnert Park, Calif. Deacon Tony Albers officiated. The bride, a daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Joseph Remley of Cotati, Calif., is studying for an M.B.A. degree and a Master of Science degree in industrial engineering at Columbia University. The bridegroom, a son of Renata Scheder-Bieschin of Rye Brook, N.Y., and the late Max A. W. W. Scheder-Bieschin, is a vice president in the real-estate group at Bear, Stearns & Company in New York.

title: Study on Dolphin Deaths Criticized
description: THE sight of dead and sick dolphins stranded on Jersey Shore beaches during the summer of 1987 created a concern in the state that the mysterious affliction would threaten other marine life or even beachgoers.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Texas; Always on Call To Do Legwork For Lawmakers
description: Two floors below the polished Senate chamber, in a plain basement office dubbed ''the Pit,'' University of Texas students dash to the rescue in response to a stream of phone calls from above.

title: CHINESE STUDENTS URGE END TO SIEGE OF BEIJING SQUARE
description: China's student leaders today called for an end to their two-week occupation of Tiananmen Square, in the center of the capital, but said that they would continue to hold large-scale demonstrations to press for greater democracy and the resignation of Prime Minister Li Peng.

title: Credibility Is in Question
description: In three days of testimony last week, the doctor who managed Ben Johnson's steroid program for five years showed himself to be a witness of questionable credibility. At the same time, Dr. George (Jamie) Astaphan might have provided a smoking gun that could doom Johnson's chances of ever running in the Olympics again.

title: Reviews/Music; Chamber Sound Offers Standards and Rarities
description: Chamber Sound, an ensemble of young freelance instrumentalists who have been working together in various combinations for eight years, played an interesting program of comparatively light rarities and meatier standard repertory works Tuesday evening at Weill Recital Hall. One could not have asked for livelier or more expertly turned performances.

title: Holiday Weekend
description: Second Avenue between 42d and 53d Streets will be closed from 8 A.M. to 7 P.M. today for the Turtle Bay Fair.

title: Not Imperial, but Still Faberge
description: Everything seems royal about the diamond-encrusted ''Pine Cone'' Easter egg that the Russian jeweler Peter Carl Faberge made in 1900. Everything, that is, except its pedigree. This exquisite bauble is royal blue, an enameled triumph. When it was auctioned on May 10 by Christie's in Geneva, it fetched the princely sum of $3 million. The figure surpassed all other amounts realized at auction for works by Faberge, including prices paid for his Imperial Easter eggs.

title: Susan Katzmann, Producer, to Wed
