description: Mr. and Mrs. John Katzmann of Forest Hills, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Susan Janet Katzmann, to Dr. Neil Brian Horner, a son of Shirley J. Horner of Mountainside, N.J., and the late Robert G. Horner. A June wedding is planned.

title: Private Rail Cars
description: To the Editor: I thought the response (Q & A, April 9) to G. J. in Gainesville, Fla., about the rental of private railroad cars was one-sided.

title: Enticing and Keeping the Older Worker
description: TIMES change. In 1976, when the first seminar to encourage business to hire older workers was held in Westchester, the reaction from the corporations was not enthusiastic, said Mae Carpenter, director of the County Office for the Aging.

title: HUMAN RIGHTS IN CHINA
description: Orville Schell's trenchant article ''Human Rights in China: An Act of Defiance'' (April 16), about the surrealistic odyssey of Fang Lizhi in Beijing is important. Mr. Schell paints a chilling picture of human rights in China. The persecutions continue, with the acquiesence of the United States.

title: Democratic House Jobs Play Crucial Role in Party's Destiny
description: The impending shake-up of the Democratic leadership in the House has set off intense jockeying for the top three positions, coveted posts that are critical to the fortunes of the party, its agenda and the careers of the members.

title: ABOUT BOOKS
description: WE wait for summer, and then our thoughts call up the rewards of reading in pleasant, relaxed surroundings. The good book before us will point out some long-forgotten vista, refresh our imagination about the landscape or stir a wish to explore further. The following books by New Jersey authors or about the state promise such illuminating experiences and more.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Brunch; Food That's Memorable Amid Nostalgic Decor
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in the Connecticut, Long Island, New Jersey and Westchester Sunday regional sections of The New York Times. Ratings at the end of each item - satisfactory, good, very good, excellent and extraordinary - are followed by the date of original publication. Reviews from the A La Carte column have no rating. Prices are current. Atlantic Club

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: MYRA L. SCHULTZ;
Smoothing the Way to Summer Camp
description: LEAD: FOR even a seemingly well-adjusted child, summer camp, orsleep-away camp, can be a traumatic experience. Whether the child is a first-time camper or a veteran, a bout of homesickness is not uncommon. At the same time, the child is being asked to make new friends, abide by new rules and deal with new freedoms.

title: Is the Pap Test Valid?
description: REPORTS IN RECENT MONTHS about the high rate of ''false negatives'' for Pap smears were frightening to women. A false negative, in medical lingo, is a screening test that says ''no cancer'' when all the while a cancer is, in fact, growing undetected. Pap smears, which can detect cancer of the cervix, are now said to have a false negative rate of 20 to 40 percent. For years, women have been told that the most effective preventive medicine they could practice was getting an annual Pap smear. Yet here, suddenly, were women like Barbara Arbuckle of Seattle, telling a Congressional hearing that, even after two of these tests had indicated she was fine, she really harbored a fast-growing cancer. The woman, who had no children, was forced to have a hysterectomy at age 23. Her cancer, at the opening of the uterus, could have been treated simply by burning or freezing the damaged tissue, had it been detected in time.

title: Family Redefines Itself, And Now the Law Follows
description: AS a growing number of unmarried couples claim legal rights, governments, courts and private employers are struggling to decide how to define a family.

title: EAT YOUR NICE MAGGOTS, HERBERT
description: THE GROTESQUE By Patrick McGrath. 186 pp. New York: Poseidon Press. $17.95.

title: Fresh Ideas Created by Student Designers
description: From the long, well-lighted runway to the keen young models, the annual student design show at the High School of Fashion Industries in Manhattan looked every bit as professional as Seventh Avenue's sleek productions.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Kissing History

title: Robin Williams, the Comic, Confronts Robin Williams, the Actor
description: ''It's a breath mint,'' says Robin Williams, spurred by it's-impossible-to-say-exactly-what. ''No, it's a paper,'' he continues, and now it's getting clearer. The rhythms of the contrast come from an old TV commercial for Certs. But where is he going?

title: Modular Housing Gaining Acceptance
description: AFTER more than two decades of trying to obliterate their house-trailer heritage, manufacturers of modular houses are finally persuading skeptics to buy housing off the assembly line.

title: Worthy Quietly Leads Lakers
description: Because James Worthy is soft-spoken, his presence in the Los Angeles Lakers' locker room is unassuming. Because he plays for a star-laden team, his importance is sometimes unappreciated.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It is very difficult to continue our sit-in. As leaders, we have responsibility for students' health, and the difficulties are obvious. Hygiene is extremely bad and the food is insufficient.'' - Wuer Kaixi, a student leader in Beijing. [ 1:3. ]

title: Yankee Demands Thwart Piniella
description: Lou Piniella dropped out of contention for the Toronto Blue Jays' managerial opening yesterday. The Blue Jays' failure to meet the Yankees' demands for player compensation caused the discussions to end, leaving Piniella in the broadcast booth and as an occasional hitting instructor.

title: For Many In Need, A Helping Hand
description: LEAD: A FAMILY is burned out of its apartment, and the men on the block start a drive to raise some emergency funds. Someone loses his job, and buddies and co-workers take up a collection to keep him afloat for a while.

title: YOU HAVE REACHED A DISCONNECTED PERSON
description: LEAD: WE FIND OURSELVES IN MOONTOWN By Jay Gummerman. 174 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $16.95.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My bathroom ceiling was wallpapered and now I want to paint the ceiling. I have removed most of the wallpaper, but some cementlike paste remains in several areas. I am tired of trying to smooth this ceiling further. Can I paint with a sand-textured paint and are there any disadvantages to this?

title: Forget HDTV, It's Already Outmoded
description: The world is on the verge of a technological transformation that will make current televison as obsolete as the hot-air dirigible. This new technology will also radically enhance the competitiveness of American technology and the richness and variety of video programming. This new development is not high definition television, which offers only a fourfold increase in picture quality over existing television. The real advance is the telecomputer, which couples digital and video technology and fiber optics.

title: Louisville
description: To the Editor: I would like to note an inaccuracy in ''What's Doing in Louisville'' (Travel, April 9). The J. B. Speed Art Museum, while enjoying a close relationship with the University of Louisville, is not ''the University of Louisville's . . . Museum,'' but a private institution, Kentucky's oldest and largest art museum, which has served this area of the county independently as an art museum for more than 60 years. Your writer's confusion perhaps stems from the fact that the museum is adjacent to the University of Louisville campus. KELLY SCOTT REED Director of Public Information The J. B. Speed Art Museum Louisville, Ky.

title: Airlines in Retreat From Frequent-Flier Plans
description: IN frequent-flier programs, 1988 was the year of triple mileage, when many participants were spending weekends bouncing around on short trips to ''earn'' two first-class tickets to Europe or Asia. This year will probably be the year the airlines experienced a hangover and began to cut back on frequent travel programs.

title: Sharing a View From Leonard's World
description: In response to Margaret J. Peterson's account of her brother Leonard, ''My Brother's Unknowable World'' (Opinion page, April 23), I would like to share a view from Leonard's environment. As staff members who dedicate our lives to the care of special people, we do not question God's wisdom, but rather we've come to realize there are many roads to salvation - not all of which are smoothly paved.

title: Long Island Journal
description: The Centereach 500 ENGINES revved in pit row. Tension mounted. The four-wheel-drive modified class A final was about to begin. ''Drivers to the track,'' shouted the track director, Bob Constantino of Coram.

title: THE IMPRACTICALITY OF POWER
description: BARBARIAN SENTIMENTS How the American Century Ends. By William Pfaff. 198 pp. New York: Hill & Wang. $19.95.

title: WESTCHESTER BOOKCASE
description: My Weeds A Gardener's Botany By Sara B. Stein Harper & Row. 229 pages. $19.95.

title: George Soule Wed To Nancy Kaneb
description: St. John the Evangelist Roman Catholic Church in Wellesley, Mass., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Nancy Ellen Kaneb, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert J. Kaneb of Weston, Mass., to George deLancey Soule, the son of Richard H. Soule of Canterbury, N.H., and Emily M. Soule of Darien, Conn. Msgr. Dennis Sheehan performed the ceremony.

title: A Lesson in Citizenship
description: WHAT happened last summer on our beaches and in our skies made us more aware of the vulnerability of our environment as no other event since the bombing of Hiroshima. Media exposure and the visibility of the dangers caused our reac tions to be more immediate and widespread. My own experience, in a small way, bears witness to its impact. I am a teacher at the Hillside Elementary School in Hastings-on-Hudson. With the encouragement of our principal and the help of other teachers I organized a Green Committee of third, fourth and fifth graders. Our purpose was to teach the children about the importance of the environment and the extent of the dangers that threatened it.

title: Batman's 50th
description: Batman's 50th anniversary will be celebrated at a convention in the Days Inn Hotel, 440 West 57th Street, from 11 A.M. to 8 P.M. today. Toys, comic books and collectibles will be displayed. Admission is $5. Information: (718) 266-1853.

title: Mia L. Attalienti To Marry in June
description: Dr. and Mrs. Anthony Attalienti of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Mia Lisa Attalienti, and Scott Leon DeMatteis, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick DeMatteis of Old Westbury, L.I.

title: A Tabloid Titan
description: To the Editor:

title:
LONG ISLAND INTERVIEW: ELIZABETH C. STONE;
Lost City of Mesopotamia Has Lessons for Urban Dwellers
description: LEAD: EARLIER this year, Elizabeth C. Stone, an archeologist at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, discovered one of the oldest lost cities of lower Mesopotamia, a city that flourished between 2050 and 1750 B.C. and then collapsed dramatically.

title: Duality of Existence in Latin Works
description: THE show entitled ''Latin Roots/American Visions'' is a small one - 32 paintings, drawings and photographs by nine artists - and its catalogue is modest. Yet, in word and image, this production, at the New Jersey Center for Visual Arts here, does as much as any large survey to enlighten its beholders about the Latin contribution to contemporary American art.

title: Why Segregate the Elderly?
description: IN today's chronological lexicon, I am considered ''an old man.'' No precise age given, to protect the patently guilty! Given the untenable alternative, I accept my elderly status, however grudgingly.

title: Partisan Rancor Fuels Warfare Over Ethics
description: FIFTEEN years ago, a Democratic Congress forced a Republican President from power, striking a blow against what had come to be called ''the Imperial Presidency.'' Ever since, Republicans have bemoaned the rise of what they called ''the Imperial Congress.''

title: U.S. AGAIN PRESSES ITS MIDEAST ROLE
description: Without saying so publicly, the Bush Administration is gradually assuming the role of a mediator between Israel and the Palestine Liberation Organization.

title: Arts Dollars: Pinched As Never Before
description: Representative Jim Jeffords, the genial, boyish-looking Vermont Republican, had just finished telling a group of arts advocates gathered in Washington last month how devoted he was to cultural pursuits - his grandfather, he said, was an architect and his mother an art teacher. Then he came to his main point.

title: Burma
description: To the Editor: I disagree with the advice given by Steven Erlanger. He writes, ''The children behave as if they haven't seen candy since martial law, so bring or buy lots of it. Kids of a more discerning age will prefer pens.'' This advice, if followed, will certainly promote the image of the ''ugly American'' abroad. Does Mr. Erlanger want foreigners coming into his country, throwing candy and toys at his children and turning them into little beggars? I am sure he would strongly protest this behavior.

title: Outcry in Soviet Congress: 'Aggressively Obedient Majority'
description: Debate in the new Congress of People's Deputies became heated today after many of the Soviet Union's political mavericks were denied seats in the Supreme Soviet. Following are excerpts from the debate. Yuri N. Afanaseyev Director of the Institute Of Historical Archives

title: Setting the Record Straight
description: To the Editor:

title: ANCIENT ANGERS
description: BLOOD AND FAMILY By Thomas Kinsella. 89 pp. New York: Oxford University Press. Paper, $9.95. SUN By Michael Palmer. 86 pp. San Francisco: North Point Press. Paper, $9.95.

title: Popovers at the Algonquin
description: To the Editor:

title: For Steve Reich, War and Rediscovery
description: Composers, or their publicists, are always talking about breakthroughs. No sooner is a new work introduced than it is touted as an unprecedented advance, a break with the past. Perhaps this obsession with forging ahead is a legacy of modernism that lingers in our post-modern era.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: Tennis West Germany Tops U.S.: West Germany defeated the United States, 2-1, yesterday at the World Team Cup tournament in Dusseldorf, West Germany, advancing to a showdown today against Argentina in the final. The West German star, Boris Becker, defeated Tim Mayotte, 6-4, 6-3, in the first singles match, and Carl-Uwe Steeb overpowered Aaron Krickstein, 6-2, 6-2, in the second. Becker, ranked No. 2 in the world, displayed good form in his victory over Mayotte, defeating the American in 1 hour 31 minutes. In doubles, the United States team of Rick Leach and Jim Pugh pulled out a 6-3, 6-7, 6-3 victory over Eric Jelen and Patrick Kuhnen but the victory came too late. A day earlier, Argentina gained the final by defeating Czechoslovakia, 2-1.(AP) De la Pena Beats Gomez: Sixth-seeded Horacio de la Pena of Argentina trounced top-seeded Andres Gomez of Ecuador, 6-1, 6-1, yesterday to reach the final of the City of Florence tournament. De la Pena will compete for the $18,680 first prize with 17-year-old Goran Ivanisevic of Yugoslavia, who reached the first final of his career by winning his semifinal match against seventh-seeded Lawson Duncan of the United States, 6-3, 6-4.(AP) Novotna and Tarabini in Final: Second-seeded Jana Novotna of Czechoslovakia breezed into the final of the Strasbourg Open in France yesterday with a 6-1, 6-2 victory over unseeded Jo-Anne Faull of Australia. Novotna, ranked 16th in the world, will play Patricia Tarabini of Argentina, who beat Wiltrud Probst of West Germany, 6-3, 6-3.(AP) Maleeva to Play Martinez: Third-seeded Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria and fourth-seeded Conchita Martinez of Spain advanced yesterday to the final of the European Open tournament in Geneva. Seventeen-year-old Martinez won by 4-6, 7-5, 6-2 in her semifinal against Barbara Paulus of Austria. Maleeva struggled past an early 2-0 deficit to win her semifinal against Laura Garrone of Italy, 6-3, 7-5. (AP) Soccer England Defeats Scotland: Chris Waddle scored midway through the first half and Steve Bull added a late goal as England defeated Scotland, 2-0, yesterday in Glasgow in the 107th annual match between the nations. Clashes between fans in the streets surrounding the Hampden Park stadium led to about 100 arrests before the start of the match. (AP) Arsenal Edges Liverpool: After a nine-month season filled with drama and scarred by tragedy, Arsenal won the English League title from Liverpool in the closing seconds of the final game of the year Friday night. Michael Thomas scored on a breakaway to help give Arsenal a 2-0 victory at Liverpool. Both teams finished the season with 76 points, and the two-goal margin for Arsenal left the teams with identical goal differentials against each other. The Gunners claimed their first title since 1971 because they scored more goals over all this season. (AP) Golf Blake Recaptures Lead: Jay Don Blake tapped in a short birdie putt on the final hole yesterday to complete a two-under-par 70 and take the lead after three rounds of the Atlanta Classic in Marietta, Ga. Blake, who missed a long eagle putt on the par-5 finishing hole, held a one-shot advantage over Duffy Waldorf, who had a 71 on the hilly, 7,018-yard Atlanta Country Club course. Blake, who also led after the first round, had a nine-under 207 total for 54 holes in the $900,000 event that will be worth $162,000 to the winner today.(AP) 5-Stroke Lead for Okamoto: Ayako Okamoto overcame winds yesterday and shot a four-under-par 67 to open a five-shot lead over Beth Daniel after three rounds of the L.P.G.A. Corning Classic in Corning, N.Y. Okamoto had a 54-hole total of 11-under 202. Daniel, who trailed by only one stroke going into the third round, had a 71 for 207. The wind has affected play each round at the 6,006-yard, par-71 Corning Country Club course, and only five golfers were below par after three rounds. (AP) Geiberger Holds On: Al Geiberger, who had led by two, saw his lead dwindle to a single stroke when he shot a one-under-par 71 yesterday in the second round of the PGA Senior Tour's Southwestern Bell Classic in Oklahoma City. Geiberger, who birdied the first and final holes and also had a bogey, reached the 36-hole mark with a 137 total. Bobby Nichols was alone in second place after his second straight 69. (AP) Dog Show Terrier Is Tops: Ch. Rightly So Original Sin, a Norfolk terrier owned by Virginia Hedges and Julius Rumpf, was gaited by Rumpf to best in a field of 1,520 dogs yesterday at the Monmouth County Kennel Club on Wolf Hill Farm in Oceanport, N.J. It was the fifth top award for the little redcoat, who answers to the name Ziggy. Boxing Hill Retains Title: Virgil Hill retained his World Boxing Association light heavyweight title yesterday, stopping a former sparring partner, Joe Lasisi, in the seventh round in Bismarck, N.D. Hill (25-0) proved much quicker in the ring than the power-hitting Lasisi (22-1), scoring well with left jabs and hooks to the challenger's head and body. (AP)

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Howard; Business Ideas Enlisted to Help Nonprofit Ideals
description: What started as an idea in a retail-management class by seven undergraduates at Howard University has become a reality with the release of their first record album last week.

title: U.S. Secretly Helped France Develop Nuclear Weapons, an Expert Writes
description: In a highly secret arrangement, the United States has long provided substantial covert assistance to the French nuclear weapons program, apparently in violation of American law, an authority on international relations says.

title: PLAYING HARDBALL
description: ''Atwater and his fraternity brothers,'' we are told, ''used to rent black-and-white pornographic movies and charge 50 cents to see them. '' 'You can bet nobody asked for their damn money back on those flicks,' he volunteers, sitting with his wife and parents [ emphasis mine ] in the family living room.''

title: CRIME
description: With certain nations owing certain other nations $100 billion or so, what can you say about a guy who's into another guy for a couple of ''bones'' ($2,000), plus a weekly ''vigorish'' (interest) of two ''smalls'' ($200)? Robert Campbell has a mouthful to say about a chump like that, and in JUICE (Poseidon, $18.95) he says it with grand panache, in the colorful patois of Hollywood ''gamooshes'' and ''juicemen.'' (No translation available.) Billy Ray, a gamoosh who cons his dying mother out of the money she's been saving for an operation so he can bet on the horses, starts the action in this caper when he falls behind in payments to his juiceman, Alfonso (Puffy) Pachoulo, just as the Los Angeles Police Department establishes a special task force against loan sharking. Since everyone in L.A. seems to be doing business with Puffy and his pals in one way or another, even a straight cop like Panama Heath gets himself caught in the squeeze when the lawmen and the usurers, along with their various lovers and lawyers, collide in a heap.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: May 28, 1989
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 4 TO BE THE BEST, by Barbara Taylor Bradford. (Bantam, $5.95.) A department store dynasty undergoes emotional and financial stress. 2 5 LIGHTNING, by Dean R. Koontz. (Berkley, $4.95.) A mysterious stranger saves a woman from a series of dangers and disasters. 3 17 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Dell, $4.95.) A woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family. 4 7 THE DRAWING OF THE THREE, by Stephen King. (Plume/NAL, $12.95.) The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above.

title: Bush Picks Envoy to Pretoria To Lead the Foreign Service
description: President Bush said Thursday that he would nominate Edward J. Perkins, a career diplomat and most recently the Ambassador to South Africa, as director general of the Foreign Service.

title: March Moore Weds Broker
description: At All Saints' Episcopal Church in Chevy Chase, Md., March Victoria Moore, a daughter of Guy Will Moore of Arlington, Va., and the late Hazel Cartwright Moore, was married yesterday to Christopher Lockwood Dodge. The Rev. Dr. H. Stuart Irvin officiated.

title:
ART;
At Yale, the Picturesque Way of Viewing the Landscape
description: LEAD: ''FAIREST ISLE'' at the Yale Center for British Art is a resourceful exhibition. For all of its wonder, it was gathered close to home from the center's collections.

title: Bhutto's Foes Gain as Strife Hits Province
description: A wave of nationalism in Sind, Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto's home province, is putting new pressure on her Government and giving her political opponents opportunities in a region where they have never been strong.

title: France's New Attack Of National Insecurity
description: ''FRANCE must keep its standing,'' President Francois Mitterrand declared earlier this month in a news conference. ''Its standing is high among the nations of the world.'' The setting of his remarks was imperial, designed to impress: the high-ceilinged, gilded Salle des Fetes of the Elysee Palace, with Prime Minister Michel Rocard and his entire Cabinet in attendance.

title: Phineas Newborn Jr., 57, Top Jazz Pianist
description: Phineas Newborn Jr., a leading jazz pianist, died at his home in Memphis, Tenn., Friday. He was 57 years old.

title: Stigma? I'll Take The Burbs Any Day
description: WOULD someone explain to me the stigma of living on Long Island? I've encountered it numerous times from Manhattanites, and I'm sick of it.

title:
PASTIMES: Gardening;
Research on Natural Defenses Leads the Way
description: LEAD: For thousands of years wild plants have battled with insects and diseases. The ongoing struggle may result in a victory for gardeners because in the process many species have developed an intricate armory. On the front line are physical barriers, which keep insects and diseases at bay, often supported by a secondary defense, a sort of plant inner chemical warfare.

title: Graduations Will Carry On Family's Legacy
description: THROUGH the coincidence of transferring from one school to another, changing majors and adding courses, our three children will graduate from college this spring.

title: We Shouldn't Envy Canada's Health System; Facing the Challenge
description: To the Editor:

title: Jane Dinsmore Marries
description: Jane E. Dinsmore and Mark S. O'Keeffe were married yesterday in Morristown, N.J. The Rev. Thomas Sheffield performed the ceremony at the Presbyterian Church-on-the-Green. Mrs. O'Keeffe, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald E. Dinsmore of Convent Station, N.J., graduated from the University of New Hampshire. She is an assistant vice president of the Fiduciary Trust Company International in New York. Mr. O'Keeffe, a son of Mrs. Thomas B. Wheeler Jr. of Loudonville, N.Y., and the late Dr. John C. O'Keeffe, graduated from Hamilton College. He is a vice president in New York of the First National Bank of Chicago.

title: Burma
description: To the Editor: The box accompanying Steven Erlanger's article on Burma (Travel, April 2) may confuse readers planning to travel to that endlessly fascinating country. You report that the State Department has warned Americans not to fly on Burma Airways because of the airline's appalling record of fatal crashes in the past two years. But then you add that two tour operators, Journeyworld International and Diethelm Travel, fly groups from Bangkok to Rangoon on Thai Airways.

title: Public's Knowledge of Civics Rises Only a Bit
description: The American public's factual knowledge about civics and politics has improved only marginally in the past 40 years, and many Americans still lack basic knowledge of the country's political system, according to a new national poll.

title: Laying Bricks With Sand
description: LAYING bricks with sand instead of mortar is an easy way to create walkways, patios and even driveways.

title: Accuracy Is a Lagniappe
description: To the Editor:

title: Tested in the Fires Of Infertility
description: I have just tucked my 3-year-old and year-old sons in bed, and opened to the article ''Waiting for Motherhood'' by J. L. Klein (Opinion page, May 7).

title: THE MIND AND THE PINOCHLE FACTOR
description: LEAD: UNSTABLE IDEAS Temperament, Cognition, and Self. By Jerome Kagan. 318 pp. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. $25.

title: Stephen Sell, 47, Dies; An Orchestra Director
description: Stephen Sell, executive director of the Philadelphia Orchestra since 1982, died of lung cancer Friday at Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 47 years old and lived in Philadelphia.

title: Yonkers Council Candidates: New Faces, Familiar Stands
description: THE Yonkers City Council, where a continuing dispute over a court-ordered housing-desegregation plan has dominated the agenda in recent years, may look a lot different after this November's elections. But the legislative results could remain the same. All six district seats are being contested, as is the mayoralty, the Council's seventh vote. At least one incumbent Councilman, Henry Spallone, will not be back. Mr. Spallone, a fierce opponent of compliance with the housing order, is running for mayor as a Republican, against the Democratic incumbent, Nicholas C. Wasicsko, who favors complying with the order.

title: Reviews/Theater; 'Showing Off,' an Incisive Look at Manhattan Life
description: Enthusiasts of the perky cabaret revues once so prevalent in New York who - in an access of ungrammatical nostalgia - like to say ''They just don't make 'em like they used to,'' should take note: a visit to ''Showing Off'' shows that they do.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey; Recent Sales
description: Bradley Beach $107,000 100 Ocean Avenue 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 6-year-old town-house condominium; c/a, patio; monthly maintenance $118, taxes $3,412. Howell $185,000 6 Lindner Lane 4-bedroom, 2.5-bath, 8-year-old colonial; family room, fireplace, 2-car garage; taxes $3,550. Jackson $119,900 23 Colonial Court 3-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 1-year-old town-house condominium; eat-in-kitchen, c/a; monthly maintenance $90, taxes $1,700. Lebanon $200,000 140A Rosemary Way 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 18-year-old ranch; new kitchen, c/a, hardwood floors; taxes $2,920. Short Hills $490,000 25 Burnside Drive 4-bedroom, 3-bath, 24-year-old expanded ranch; fireplace, dining room, 2-car garage; taxes $7,252. West Orange $170,000 5 Rollinson Street 4-bedroom, 2-bath, 41-year-old colonial; fireplace, den, screened porch, 1-car garage; taxes $3,060. OTHER AREAS Coram, L.I. $180,500 16 Marlow Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 2-year-old ranch; dining room, den, 2-car garage; taxes $2,800. Scarsdale, N.Y. $380,000 96 Edgemont Road 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 32-year-old split-level; fireplace, eat-in kitchen w/skylight, cathedral ceiling, deck, 1-car garage; taxes $7,891. Meriden, Conn. $192,000 40 Oxbow Drive 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 23-year-old colonial; fenced-in yard, potential office in home, 0.67 acre; taxes $1,973.

title: Nassau Studying Sludge as Filler
description: LEAD: IF Nassau County has its way, Long Islanders will be buying fertilizers and soil fillers made from county sludge, rather than sludge from Milwaukee and Philadelphia.

title: Cruise Ships Still Plying Gulf of Alaska
description: LATE spring through summer is the season for cruises to Alaska, which in recent years have experienced a decided upsurge in popularity. But when the Exxon Valdez went aground in Prince William Sound on March 24, spilling almost 11 million gallons of crude oil, many people wondered if there would be a rapid change in course for the cruise lines that had announced itineraries for Alaskan waters.

title: Reviews/Dance; Swiss Institute Bill Belies Stereotypes
description: The program of dance presented by the Swiss Institute on Thursday night would have surprised anyone who thinks of the Swiss as a relatively sedate lot. To start, there was a bit of agreeably zany fun called ''Swiss Export,'' choreographed by Elfi Schafer-Schafroth. And there followed a knockabout Afro-Swiss-American ritual called ''Lines,'' choreographed by Estelle Eichenberger.

title: Nurses in Vietnam: Beyond TV's Stereotypes
description: When portraying people in the professions, television often rushes straight to the stereotype. Certainly this is true in the case of women, most of them nurses, who served in combat zones during the Vietnam war. ''You have standard images,'' says Joan Furey, a former Army nurse who worked at the 71st Evacuation Hospital in Pleiku, South Vietnam, in 1969 and '70. ''Characters end up being either superhuman people or rip-roaring flakes.''

title: BLUEGRASS FLAVOR
description: A wild notion that Louisville lay in the sunny South inspired me to make Kentucky my home back in the 1970's. Geographically and climate-wise, I was off a bit, but I was right on the Mason-Dixon line when it came to the food.

title: Harness Racing Off to New Start
description: Harness racing, a sport that achieved its highest levels of popularity and financial success in the 1970's, has for more than a decade been experiencing steadily declining attendance and smaller betting handles. Standardbred racing is now trying to recapture the lost interest of the betting public with modifications that promise a better deal, more winners and higher payoffs.

title: Two Can't Go . . . but Four Will
description: Contrary to the expectations of Carl Lewis, the Olympic gold medalists Louise Ritter, Roger Kingdom and Evelyn Ashford, along with the middle-distance runner Steve Scott, plan to compete in the Mobil championships in Houston.

title: Spain to Compete In '92 Cup Sailing
description: Spain will compete in the 1992 America's Cup with a Spanish-designed vessel, the president of a group in charge of organizing the country's effort said today.

title: FICTION
description: THE ICE AT THE BOTTOM OF THE WORLD. By Mark Richard. (Knopf, $16.95.) Abandoned children, bereaved lovers, victims of flood and other devastations - these are the characters who inhabit Mark Richard's first collection of short stories. Set somewhere in the South in bleak landscapes that mirror the futile existence of those who live there, the stories depict a world wracked by emotional, economic or natural disaster. Though their lives have been whittled down by harsh circumstances, most of Mr. Richard's characters can claim one victory: they are survivors. It is what they survive on - sharp, insightful humor; friendships that sustain betrayal; the games and fantasies that distract children from the vagaries of their elders - that is most intriguing. The stories about children are especially convincing. ''This Is Us, Excellent,'' for example, is an account of domestic violence, told in the breathless language of a tough little boy whose life tumbles chaotically from his own rough games to his father's brutal beatings, which in turn are followed by riotous family outings to amusement parks and restaurants. Skillfully handled, the kaleidoscopic contrast is chilling. Unfortunately, other stories that have more elliptical themes, including the title piece (a contemplation of marriage and other bonds), are weak in comparison. This is due, in part, to Mr. Richard's style. His attempts to duplicate colloquial language sometimes seem self-conscious and contrived, and they slow the reader down. However, the best stories in this collection tell, in an authentic, clear voice, the ways in which adversity strips character and relationships down to their most rudimentary and durable elements.

title: When Maps Are Tied to Data Bases
description: Pizza Hut wants to find neighborhoods with just the right balance of different types of people, as well as enough traffic to make a new store's success likely. The World Bank wants to see how cattle might be displaced by a pipeline in Tanzania. Politicians want to redraw political boundaries. The fire department wants to know, when a 911 emergency call comes in, where the nearest hydrant is. Or a company needs to sort its customer data base by ZIP code and see the results on a map, allowing the sales manager to redraw territories to minimize travel costs and maximize sales potential.

title: Great Shakes In a Small Town
description: IT is tempting to drive through Garden City, Utah, too quickly, pausing only at the stop sign where Route 89 skitters up to Bear Lake and then curves sharply to avoid it. To tourists in the West, after all, towns are just interruptions along the great, shimmering highway that stretches toward the horizon.

title: Peter Blauner Will Marry Peg Tyre, a Fellow Editor
description: A June wedding is planned by Peg Tyre and Peter Blauner, the parents of the bride-to-be, Thomas E. Tyre of Mohegan Lake, N.Y., and Frances Tyre of Ossining, N.Y., have announced. Mr. Blauner is a son of Sheila Druckman of New York and Greenwich, Conn.

title: Turkey Rebuffed U.S. Plea To Examine Defector's MIG
description: Turkey rebuffed a frantic plea from high-level United States military officials to examine an advanced Soviet fighter plane flown into the country by a defecting pilot, Administration officials said. The decision deprived the West of a significant intelligence coup, the officials said.

title: Susan W. Walton Becomes a Bride
description: Susan Whitney Walton, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Walton of Glen Cove, L.I., was married yesterday to Michael Armistead Klaveness, a son of Rosalie A. Klaveness of Houston and the late Capt. Odd Klaveness. The Rev. Bruce Page, assisted by the Rev. W. Cameron Allen, performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in Glen Cove.

title: Dolores Janes-Garcia, a Teacher, Weds
description: At the Fifth Avenue Presbyterian Church in New York, Dolores Janes-Garcia, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Janes of Kew Gardens, Queens, was married yesterday to Wesley D. Wheeler by the Rev. Dr. R. Maurice Boyd.

title: The Weak Case For High Taxes
description: Kenneth P. Marion, in his letter of May 14 (''Rational Behavior on House Prices''), makes a weak case for continued steep school and property taxes in the Five Towns.

title: COMIC-BOOK COLLECTORS
description: The graphic violence in the comics discussed by Joe Queenan is of less importance than the violence that exists in comics of even the most mundane, newspaper variety. If a door-to-door salesman is obnoxious, Dagwood kicks him away, and the police are never involved. Dagwood's boss pummels him, although in real life the boss would then be on the wrong end of a lawsuit. Beetle Bailey's sergeant smashes the private, although no sergeant could keep his stripes if it ever really happened. SIDNEY TOBY Piscataway, N.J.

title: Children Learning ABC's of Drug Abuse
description: LEAD: ''CRACK is very bad for you,'' Jon Draskovich, a first grader at Middlebrook Elementary School in Trumbull, wrote in his essay. For Jon and the 15 other children in Amy Traggianese's class, putting pen to paper that day was not part of a writing lesson. Instead, they were taking part in a curriculum aimed at preventing drug abuse.

title: Big Farm Companies Try Hand at Organic Methods
description: Spring planting, always a season of hope, has taken on a heightened sense of expectation this year in California's bountiful valleys as some of the nation's largest farms begin experiments in growing fruits and vegetables without synthetic chemicals.

title: A Buying Boom Pulls Publishers Into the Fold
description: After nearly two decades of flat sales, the encyclopedia business is looking up. Children of the baby boomers are now in school, bringing about a surge in sales that industry analysts have been anticipating for years. ''Encyclopedias are bought mostly by parents whose kids are 10 to 12 years old,'' said J. Kendrick Noble, an analyst with Paine Webber Inc. ''Births were up in the mid-1970's, so it was logical that the mid- to late 80's would be a growth period.''

title: Monitoring the County's Beaches From Dead Fish to a Sewage Spill
description: LEAD: COUNTY Health Department officials who will be monitoring the local beaches this season consider small amounts of medical debris, dead fish and algae to be a minor problem. But they will close beaches if there is a sewage spill or high bacteria counts from polluted runoffs into bathing areas.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: A WOMAN NAMED JACKIE. By C. David Heymann. (Lyle Stuart, $21.95.) If an alien from outer space, literate but unfamiliar with Americana, read ''A Woman Named Jackie,'' he might wonder why so much scrupulous research and first-rate reporting were spent on such an astonishingly uninteresting subject.

title: Burma
description: To the Editor: Some tourists really might not care that their tour payments go to Tourist Burma, which provides the junta with the foreign exchange to purchase the ammunition vital to maintaining its privileged position astride a degraded country.

title: PASTIMES: Chess
description: There is no greater opportunity for the aspiring young grandmaster than to be taken on as second to a principal of world championship caliber, but there is also the hazard of becoming awestruck.

title: BEWARE OF MOSCOW CHIC
description: THE LONG ROAD TO FREEDOM Russia and Glasnost. By Walter Laqueur. 325 pp. New York: Charles Scribner's Sons. $21.95.

title: Review/Music; A Program Built on 'Seasons of Life'
description: When a director takes up the challenge of building a cohesive program around a broad theme - as Clara Longstreth did with the New Amsterdam Singers program she conducted Wednesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall - we are reminded that programming can be an art.

title: Students in Yonkers Bring Old-Time Radio Back to Life
description: LEAD: WILL the evil magician Baloboo triumph? Why did Paul, the good magician, disappear? Will his fair daughter, Sylvia, ever find him?

title: LOOKING UP AFRICA - BY PUSHING A BUTTON
description: With the encyclopedia of the near future, looking up Africa would be the next best thing to being there. You'd walk through the jungle, hear the lions roar and see tribal rituals - all on your television screen. Pressing a button on the controller could bring you face to face with a Zulu warrior.

title: Mozart's Librettist
description: To the Editor:

title: Food Chains Sued Over Bottle Redemption Policies
description: A class-action suit has charged seven New York City supermarket chains with widespread violations of state law by limiting the numbers of bottles and cans that homeless people can redeem for their deposits.

title: Thousands of Muslims Rally Against Rushdie in London
description: Thousands of Muslims occupied Parliament Square this afternoon to demand that the novel ''The Satanic Verses'' be banned.

title: Experts and Novices Jam Computer Shows
description: ON a recent Saturday morning at 4:30, Robert and Evelyn Irons left their home in Juliustown and drove three hours to William Paterson College in Wayne to be first in line for Ken Gordon's sold-out show.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: COLUMBUS, OHIO;
Static From Radio Church
description: LEAD: PLANS for the Villages at Rocky Fork, a golf course and housing development on 4,200 acres 20 miles northeast of Columbus, have run into an obstacle.

title: Reading, Writing and Abracadabra
description: RICHARD ROY waved his hands a few times and appeared to make a short rope long and then short again. A few minutes later, he asked a visitor to pick a card from a freshly shuffled deck and, without looking, was able to tell what was picked. ''Magic,'' Mr. Roy says, ''is something that happens that's not supposed to happen.''

title: Museum Toy Exhibit
description: The Museum of the City of New York, at Fifth Avenue and 103d Street, is exhibiting ''Family Treasures: Toys and Their Tales'' through April 1990. Reflecting the social history of New York, the toys include expensive European imports, modest domestic inventions of the 19th and early 20th centuries, and dolls commemorating such events of local importance as the Seventh Regiment Armory Fair of 1879. Museum hours are 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Tuesdays through Saturdays and 1 to 5 P.M. on Sundays and holidays. Suggested donation is $3; $1.50 for the elderly and students and $1 for children. Information: 534-1034.

title: Reviews/Theater; Lerner-Loewe 'Gigi' on Smaller Scale
description: Any musical that depends as much upon evoking a high-style period ambiance as Lerner and Loewe's ''Gigi'' is bound to be compromised by a production that fails to offer at least a modicum of opulence. In the Equity Library Theater's cheery but threadbare revival, the few props chosen to suggest turn-of-the-century Parisian grandeur look like moth-eaten relics from a second-hand shop. By the end of the show, one feels starved for the spectacle of glamorous sophisticates wallowing in luxury.

title: PASTIMES: Stamps
description: Another wave of United States issues is building up for the summer and fall, and another wave of criticism as well.

title: Court Rules Schools Must Take All Disabled
description: Public schools must provide education for all handicapped children, no matter how severe the disability or how little they might benefit, a Federal appeals court panel has ruled.

title: CRUSADER ON THE CHARLES
description: Your article on John Silber is aptly titled, but what is he crusading for? Excellence, he says, and he frankly embraces elitism. But people who are truly wise (Einstein, Dostoyevsky, Rembrandt, for example) are compassionate. As the Greeks understood, there is no wisdom (sophia) without compassion (aidos). MARVIN MANDELL West Roxbury, Mass.

title: Rose vs. Peters
description: The lawyers for Pete Rose will question Ronald Peters, one of Rose's accusers, before Rose's hearing June 26 with Commissioner A. Bartlett Giamatti. The hearing was originally scheduled for May 25, but Rose's lawyers were granted a delay to cross-examine accusers of their client and prepare a defense.

title: Andrea S. Booth Marries a Doctor
description: Andrea Susan Booth and Dr. Steven Marc Wolf were married last evening in the Eastchester, N.Y., home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lewis Wolf. Rabbi Joseph Gelberman officiated.

title:
HIGHLANDS JOURNAL;
Lighthouse Attracts a Family and Crowds
description: LEAD: TOM LAVERTY lives on a piece of real estate that few in his neighborhood or, for that matter, in the state could afford to buy if it were for sale.

title: In Celebration of Two Princes of the Arts
description: ''Shakespeare is quite addictive, a bit like oysters or cheese. You find them disgusting at first, only to discover you rather like them.''

title: Washington Adjusts Its Embrace of Israel to Arm's Length
description: IN the cycles of Middle East diplomacy, last week's speech by Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d was a turning point. It signaled the end of a honeymoon era in American-Israel relations that existed for the last four years under the Reagan Administration and a return to a more evenhanded United States approach to the Middle East.

title: Up in the Air
description: To the Editor:

title: ATHLETES AND THE ZONE
description: In my doctoral dissertation, on baseball batting slumps, I am studying the precise details of optimal performance states - ''the zone'' (''Finding 'The Zone,' '' by Lawrence Shainberg, April 9). We know that athletes are able to reach the zone with simple stimulus-response patterns, such as the snapping of one's fingers. Just as aromas proliferating from a bakery may trigger profound memories of Mom's apple pie, so too can stimuli be used to elicit powerful and specific past experiences in sport. For example, Denise Parker, the Olympic archer, might use the simple action of taking an arrow out of her quiver as the stimulus - or anchor - that enables her to attain the zone. This anchor (or optimal performance state) comes about through the continued association of the stimulus with the zone state. The more frequently the anchor is activated, the more automatic the response becomes.

title: 2 Marines Killed in Collision Of Copters in Nevada Desert
description: Two Marine helicopters collided this morning during maneuvers about 70 miles east of here, killing two of the nine marines aboard.

title: The Rosenbach
description: To the Editor: Because my uncle William H. McCarthy Jr. was the first curator of the Rosenbach Library I can add a footnote to your recent story about the library (Travel, April 23).

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: SHAKE DOWN THE STARS. By Frances Donnelly. (St. Martin's, $18.95.) Frances Donnelly's appealing first novel is, like the film ''Casablanca,'' a World War II story whose ordinary plot is distinguished by stylish characterization and the heart-touching drama of love and loss. ''Shake Down the Stars'' explores the war's effect on the destinies of three young women from a village in Suffolk, England: the headstrong, aristocratic Virginia, who escapes a neurotic mother for an independent life in London; a teacher-in-training, Beattie, whose obsessive love for

title: New Jersey G.O.P. Race Is a Low-Tech Struggle
description: With no clear front-runner in New Jersey's Republican gubernatorial primary, the race is becoming a game of numbers. Campaign staffs are looking at registration figures and trying to guess how many of the 737,707 registered Republicans will go to the polls and whether they can turn out more of their supporters than the competition.

title: GUESSING GAMES
description: Someone once asked Harry Waugh, the grand old man of the English wine trade, how long it had been since he'd mistaken a Bordeaux wine for a Burgundy. ''How long is it since lunch?'' he replied. No single part of wine lore is more beset by myth and misinformation than the vague area of wine tasting. Fiction is filled with stories about legendary feats of wine detection. At some climactic point, while the rest of the characters hold their breath and the tension is almost painful, the hero, brow furrowed and eyes closed in concentration, swirls his glass a bit and says: ''I may be wrong, but I'd say this is a '64 Bordeaux and, because it's a bit light, it was probably one of the chateaux that picked during the awful rain that year. Because of the water, there isn't much body, but the structure is there and the elegance one finds only in Pauillac. I'd say it's the 1964 Chateau Pontet-Canet.'' And, of course, it is. In the story, anyway. Bordeaux wine people play these games from time to time, but only among themselves, because they know the reality of wine tasting. One can pull off astonishing feats of detective work one day and not recognize one's own wine the next.

title: Q and A
description: Eviction for a Relative

title: PASTIMES: Bridge
description: The United States will be strongly represented in the this year's World Team Championships scheduled to start mid-September in Perth, Australia. Both American teams will start as favorites although their chief rivals are as yet unknown: The European Championships, which determine two teams in each series, will begin in Turku, Finland on July 1.

title: Q and A
description: The Adriatic

title: At Oxford's Market, A Lexicon of Foods
description: NOW that it's spring in England, the windows of H. F. Richards poultry, game and pork shop in the Oxford Covered Market have lost their winter plumage. Since the feathered game season ends in February, overhead racks of wild mallard, teal, wood pigeon, grouse, widgeon, partridge and scores of pheasant from nearby Blenheim Park are empty. Now the windows display eggs - tiny speckled quail ($2 a dozen), black-headed gull (70 to 8 cents each as the season progresses), oversized goose and duck eggs (about 75 cents each) as well as free-range chicken eggs ($1.50 to $1.65 a dozen).

title:
DINING OUT;
Flavors of the Outdoors in Hawthorne
description: LEAD: NIGHTINGALE'S has a number of things going for it. Its location on the Taconic Parkway couldn't be more convenient; the menu lists interesting-sounding dishes from many corners of the United States; a mesquite grill adds the flavor of the great outdoors to meats and fish; daily specials are printed, dated and clipped to menus; dining areas are pretty and comfortable; private rooms (some now in renovation) can seat both business and family groups.

title: Track Reopens In Birmingham
description: As it did on opening night two years ago, horse racing attracted a large crowd as the sport began a comeback in Birmingham.

title: TALKING: State Loans; Rate Rise Dictates a 2d Look
description: WHEN interest rates are low, as they were until recently, the allure of state-chartered mortgage programs providing inexpensive loans to first-time buyers tends to fade.

title: Books for Beating Commuter Blues
description: Is there just no cure for the commuter time blues? Perhaps not, but luckily Nancy Rupp (''Suburban Steeplechase: The Commuter Derby,'' May 7), whose starting line is Northport, has some fellow travelers whose dash to the platform is now prefaced with a dash through the station house. Why? Because the Northport-East Northport Public Library's new Read-Ride-Return program is easing their daily plight. Morning commuters are now picking good reads galore to help them through the first leg of their trek! STEPHANIE HEINEMAN Director Northport-East Northport Public Library

title: Amanda and Ann Snowden Plan Bridals
description: Mrs. George Grant Snowden 3d of Greenwich, Conn., has announced the engagement of her daughters Amanda Ashley Snowden and Ann Farr Snowden to Alexander Bulazel and David Collins Johnson, respectively.

title: She Begs to Differ
description: To the Editor:

title: We Shouldn't Envy Canada's Health System
description: To the Editor:

title: 'Destructive Generation'
description: To the Editor:

title: High School Teacher Held in Cocaine Sales
description: A 34-year-old teacher at Amityville High School accused of selling five ounces of cocaine to undercover agents was held on $800,000 bail today.

title: Bush on Troops
description: President Bush told Italian leaders that Soviet proposals to reduce conventional arms could lead to reductions in U.S. forces in Europe. His spokesman said the issue would be discussed at the NATO summit talks on Monday and Tuesday. Article, page 18.

title: Dr. Jeffrey Wint Engaged To Faith T. Schwartzman
description: The engagement of Faith Tara Schwartzman to Dr. Jeffrey Craig Wint has been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Nathan Schwartzman of Princeton, N.J., parents of the bride-to-be. Dr. Wint is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald Wint of Manhasset Hills, L.I. An August wedding is planned.

title: N.B.A. Honors Colangelo
description: Jerry Colangelo, president and chief executive officer of the Phoenix Suns, has been selected the National Basketball Association's executive of the year by The Sporting News.

title: Connecticut Agency Dismisses State Lottery Chief
description: The chief of the Connecticut State Lottery was dismissed Friday after he refused to recommend a change in the state's Lotto game that will reduce a bettor's chances of winning.

title: A Family's Spreading Pool Of Resemblance
description: EVERYONE is gone now. When I return ''home'' to New Hampshire, as I drive up Interstate 91, I find myself holding imaginery conversations with my aunt or mother, pointing out something they would enjoy - a frisking colt or rosy sunset. I hear the genial timbre of my father's voice saying, ''Oh, Sure!'' - his favorite words of reassurance, the sound, the accent as identifiable as a fingerprint. I think of John Hall Wheelock's poem: As life goes on, it becomes more in tense because there are tremendous numbers of associations and so many memories.

title: Survey Says Morale of Air Controllers is Low
description: An extensive survey of air traffic controllers by the General Accounting Office paints a picture of low morale, heavy workloads and a lack of experience and training. In contrast, it shows a corps of managers who believe things are not so bad.

title: Despite Distraction, Cubs Come Up With Victory
description: Rick Sutcliffe was paying as much attention to the Bulls as he was to the Reds.

title: THE DANGEROUS CHARM OF THE WIDOWER
description: THE EVENING WOLVES By Joan Chase. 295 pp. New York: Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $18.95.

title: SPA LIFE
description: I eagerly read Linda Wells's article ''Spa Life'' (May 7), hoping to find some spas in the United States like the ones I enjoyed so much during the three years I lived in Hungary. I was disappointed to see that the spas you mention are more like modern resorts, with fitness facilities. These resorts may be pleasant places to spend some time; however, they are not built around mineral springs, as are European spas. In Europe, spas have been part of popular culture for centuries. Many of them are not expensive.

title: DATA UPDATE: May 28, 1989
States Sell Chances for Gold As a Rush Turns to Stampede
description: Driven by the explosive growth of state-sponsored lotteries, gambling is becoming a national pastime.

title:
GARDENING;
Clues to Those Mysterious Deaths
description: LEAD: IT is frustrating to watch a tree or shrub die. Despite the best possible care, including watering and fertilizing, failure still strikes. A popular shrub may help provide an answer.

title: In Name of Free Trade, U.S. Shifts Protectively
description: AMERICA fired a shot heard round the world of commerce last week when President Bush named Japan, Brazil and India as the most unfair competitors in trade with the United States. He accused them of blocking American access to their markets, and by implication in Japan's case, of breaking the grip the United States once had on the products and technologies of tomorrow.

title:
DINING OUT;
Interesting Cuisine in a Serene Setting
description: LEAD: THERE is an attractive upscale 18-month-old restaurant in Hoboken called Talbot's. The restaurant, which is reached by an outer staircase, is situated just a little west of the Stevens Institute of Technology on Sixth Street, between Hudson and Washington Streets.

title: The Same Old Response, But Not the Same Old China
description: IT was as if the clock in China had been set back decades, to the politics of intrigue and purge. Suddenly, instead of the exuberance of people power in the streets of Beijing, instead of throngs of joyful students marching for democracy, the focus shifted last week to a secret power struggle at the top of the Communist Party hierarchy.

title: POSTINGS: Building in Harlem; Housing the Aged
description: In an effort to provide more housing for the elderly in Harlem, the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development has teamed up with one of the city's largest black churches to build an apartment house at 2177 Frederick Douglass Boulevard at 118th Street. The building will be named Wyatt Tee Walker Senior Housing. Mr. Walker is the pastor of the nearby Canaan Baptist Church of Christ, the main sponsor.

title: The Rules of the Game For the Summer House
description: ALONG with the deed to the new summer home, every real-estate agent should present a manual to every first-time owner of a beach house. This should be a slim, neat book of rules guaranteeing every homeowner a peaceful, workfree, stress-free summer.

title: Yankee Fan Has Had It
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: 'Timelessness Is Actually a Luxury'
description: THERE is more to a successful retirement than careful financial planning, according to Susan Fitzgerald, an adult development specialist and director of the Fairfield Adult Career Educational Services at Fairfield University. Planning for the psychological and emotional hurdles of retirement is equally as important.

title: Businessland's Life Without Compaq
description: In Businessland Inc.'s early days, Stewart Alsop, a knowledgeable observer of the computer industry, used to say derisively that the company was ''masquerading'' as a personal computer retailer. By this he meant that its numerous storefronts across the country were merely a facade, and that the real engine behind sales was its huge sales force that called directly on corporate customers.

title: PASTIMES: Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Plant: tomatoes, peppers, sweet corn, melons, cucumbers, begonias, geraniums, marigolds, petunias, sweet alyssum. Prune back any overgrown shrubs that bloomed earlier this season; be sure the cutting tools are sharp so the bark is not torn. Daylilies/Lilies

title: STILL GROWING UP: A REPORTER'S JOURNEY
description: THE GOOD TIMES By Russell Baker. Illustrated. 351 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $19.95.

title: Votes in Congress; Tally Last Week in Connecticut, New Jersey and New York
description: House 1. Emergency Spending Bil: Vote on passage of a $3.7 billion emergency spending bill that includes $822 million in new anti-drug spending and $1.2 billion for the Veterans Affairs Department. Approved 227 to 197, May 24. 2. Anti-Drug Abuse: Vote on a proposal to shift $862 million from the Strategic Defense Initiative to drug control programs. Rejected 213 to 205, May 24. $ Connecticut 1. title:
LONG ISLAND OPINION;
How Thieving Squirrels Met Their Match
description: LEAD: WE like squirrels. We love to see them cavorting in our back yard. They consume mounds of peanuts that are part of my wife's regular shopping list. They no longer cost peanuts.

title: Deputies in Soviet Congress Learn That Party Still Wins
description: Ultimately, the early issues before the single-party new Soviet congress are evoking the scene of a bare-knuckled American party convention with a rock-solid majority starting to roll, its path greased by control of the rules.

title: All-Star Casts Are the Problem
description: To The Editor:

title: No 'Lull' This Year in the Concert Schedule
description: NOT very long ago early June was intermission time in Westchester: the spring season was over, and summer events had not yet started. Only sporadic musicales broke the performing silence. No longer. Next weekend will bring two festival openings; chamber, choral and orchestral concerts; jazz and even flamenco.

title: BEST SELLERS: May 28, 1989
description: $ Weeks This Last On Week Week List Fiction 1 3 3 WHILE MY PRETTY ONE SLEEPS, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) The murder of a gossip writer creates a storm in New York's high-fashion world. 2 6 14 STAR, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $19.95.) The crossed paths of a man and a woman who are destined for stardom in different professions. 3 2 5 THE NEGOTIATOR, by Frederick Forsyth. (Bantam, $19.95.) An American expatriate tries to thwart terrorists. 4 5 4 THE TEMPLE OF MY FAMILIAR, by Alice Walker. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) A ''guide for inner transformation'' through meditation. 2 2 2 THE T-FACTOR DIET, by Martin Katahn. (Norton, $18.95.) A new regimen for weight loss. 3 4 18 WEALTH WITHOUT RISK, by Charles J. Givens. (Simon & Schuster, $19.95.) A Florida entrepreneur's advice about how to make a personal fortune. 4 3 99 THE 8-WEEK CHOLESTEROL CURE, by Robert E. Kowalski. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) How to lower your blood cholesterol level. 5 3 LEADERSHIP SECRETS OF ATTILA THE HUN, by Wess Roberts. (Warner, $16.95.) Advice about management techniques. The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States. *An asterisk before a book's title indicates that its sales, weighted to reflect the book-selling industry nationally, are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. AND BEAR IN MIND (Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest) THE MOST BEAUTIFUL HOUSE IN THE WORLD, by Witold Rybczynski. (Viking, $18.95.) The extraordinary interior conversation, exploring the connections between architecture and everything else, of an architect who built his own house. THE RUSSIA HOUSE, by John le Carre. (Knopf, $19.95.) His pot of bleakness boiling, Mr. le Carre delivers an up-to-the-minute political parable in which the world of intelligence is intellectually fascinating, morally degrading and politically pointless. BUFFALO AFTERNOON, by Susan Fromberg Schaeffer. (Knopf, $19.95.) The war in Vietnam, in a frightening novel that reconstructs the experience, from ignorance through breakdown to recovery, in the heart of a young man from Brooklyn. FORGING THE ALLIANCE: NATO, 1945-1950, by Don Cook. (Arbor House/Morrow, $22.95.) An extensively researched, crisply written history of an exhausted postwar Europe and the painfully difficult construction of a successful defensive organization. FOR EVERY SIN, by Aharon Appelfeld. (Weidenfeld & Nicolson, $15.95.) The distinguished Israeli novelist addresses the horrors of the Holocaust through the stunned migrations that followed it, his hero a man totally isolated because of what he has known. SHOW YOUR TONGUE, by Gunter Grass. (Helen and Kurt Wolff/ Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) A one-man band of a book: journals, a poem and 112 pages of drawings, hot with political passion, the result of a sojourn in Calcutta in 1987-88. COLLECTED POEMS, by Philip Larkin, edited by Anthony Thwaite. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.50.) The clipped, lucid, heartbreaking meditations of a poet whose life seemed one of constant refusal; 83 of the poems are previously unpublished.

title: County Outlines Plan On Recycling Plant
description: WESTCHESTER is on the verge of a ''true recycling adventure,'' County Executive Andrew P.O'Rourke said Monday as he announced plans for a sophisticated plant to separate and process recyled goods into marketable materials.

title: Projectionist Keeps Films on Track, 10 at a Time
description: LEAD: SPLA-A-T went the film as it broke, and the machine automatically shut down. Earl Van Horn, the projectionist, pounced on it quickly, with splicer in hand, and within a minute the movie at the Loews Tenplex was playing again.

title: Housewife Wants It All
description: I BRISTLE at the thought of being ''only'' a housewife. I do make apologies, all the time now, it seems. And despite the fact that my children have grown into fine human beings, I definitely do have regrets.

title: Cynthia D. Jeck Bride Of Jeffrey Blaine Davis
description: Cynthia Denise Jeck, a doctoral candidate in pharmacology at Columbia University, and Jeffrey Blaine Davis, who is studying for an M.B.A. at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, were married yesterday at the First Presbyterian Church of New Vernon, N.J. The Rev. Dr. George Chorba officiated. A graduate of Colby College with two master's degrees in pharmacology from Columbia, Mrs. Davis is a daughter of Beverly Braniff Jeck of Far Hills, N.J., and the late Robert VanHouten Jeck, who was a vice president of the Engelhard Corporation, manufacturer of chemical products in Edison, N.J.

title: Technology Trims The Rabbit Ear
description: Rabbit ears may look good to (and on) a rabbit. But they lack charm as indoor antennas.

title: Colleges Mount Efforts on Substance Abuse
description: FOR at least one Rutgers senior, the road to graduation may have been unorthodox, but it represented a victory that was almost unthinkable a few years ago.

title: Question Of the Week; Are Indy Speeds Getting Too Fast?
description: Speeds at Indianapolis are not too fast. Today's racing machines are far safer than those driven just a few years ago. As design engineers build stronger and safer cars, I see no reason why speeds shouldn't continue to rise.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD: CANOE JAMBOREE More than 100 models of canoes and kayaks will be available for viewing and test paddling (life jackets provided) at the ninth annual Canoe Jamboree in Freehold on Saturday.

title: Syracuse to Face Hopkins in Final
description: One of those early rat-tat-tat scoring sprees that have been the team's distinction broke open the Syracuse-Maryland game today and led to an easy 18-8 victory for the Orange in a semifinal match of the National Collegiate Athletic Association's Division I lacrosse tournament.

title:
ART;
At Juried Show, Dominant Esthetic is Abstract and Gestural
description: LEAD: ONCE again, the Huntington Township Art League's annual Long Island Artists juried exhibition, on view through June 11 at the Heckscher Museum in Huntington, attracted more than 700 entries. But this year's show is very different in both form and content from the league's previous annuals and, indeed, from most juried shows in general.

title: Cars for the Sunny Side of the Street
description: Plugging a car into an electric socket is against the rules in the Tour de Sol auto race, so competitors here were delighted by the sunshine.

title: Prospects; As OPEC Prepares to Meet
description: The 13 member countries of OPEC will meet in Vienna on June 2, when they will consider requests for increases in the production quotas of some members and a proposal by Saudi Arabia to set a $15-a-barrel floor price for crude oil. Four experts consider what the outcome of the meeting could mean for oil supplies and prices. Cyrus H. Tahmassebi Chief economist and director of market research, Ashland Oil Inc.

title: Taking the Plunge Into Marriage - at 40
description: I NEVER thought I'd get married, but a few years ago I met the type of man no one believes still exists. And so, at 40, I'm taking the plunge.

title: Candidates Seek Wider Base in Primaries
description: WITH Gov. Thomas H. Kean moving to the sidelines in January, New Jersey's major parties are poised to pick the candidates they hope will have broad enough voter appeal in November to succeed the popular Republican executive.

title: Gehrig's Mark One of Quality
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Cynthia Lehrman Becomes a Bride
description: Cynthia Hanako Lehrman, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Nat Lehrman of Chicago, and William Joseph Hochswender 3d, the son of Roselyn Hochswender of New York and Mr. Hochswender Jr. of New York and South Kent, Conn., were married yesterday in a Buddhist ceremony at the Myosetsuji Temple in Flushing, Queens, by the Rev. Jisei Nagasaka.

title: The Promotion of the Rest of Alaska
description: DAYLIGHT lingers till nearly midnight in many parts of Alaska this time of year, and the showcase attractions of the last frontier - deep-blue glaciers, whales breaching in hidden fjords and skies crowded with bald eagles - are on maximum display.

title: Question Of the Week; Are Indy Speeds Getting Too Fast?
description: The 1989 Indianapolis 500 starting grid of 33 cars had qualifying runs between Rick Mears, on the pole, at 223.885 m.p.h., and Bernard Jourdain at 213.105 m.p.h. This is the fastest field ever assembled. Only a few years ago, a qualifying speed of 212 m.p.h. won the pole; now such a speed will not make the field.

title: Question Of the Week; Are Indy Speeds Getting Too Fast?
description: I have watched with excitement from the days when the 150 m.p.h. barrier was first broken at Indy.This year 220 m.p.h. was surpassed. Speed is the measure of progress, and only in racing (of any form) is it so readily measurable.

title: Eccentricity At an Old Spa In the Ozarks
description: ON a cold winter morning in the early 1870's - the chronicles are not exact - two long-haired, bearded brothers drew their revolvers and stopped the stagecoach on the edge of what is now Eureka Springs, Ark., and politely requested the passengers to dismount. Among the five men on board was one wearing a clerical collar.

title: HUMAN RIGHTS IN CHINA
description: The Great Wall Sheraton Hotel in Beijing, unlike the American Embassy, is not foreign territory. Thus, the Chinese police were within their rights when they prevented Fang Lizhi from attending the banquet to which he and his wife had been invited by Bette Bao Lord, without consulting the Chinese Government.

title: Hill's Safety Role Not So Safe
description: As the Giants' strong safety for the last five years, Kenny Hill has built a reputation as a hitter. Now Hill is almost 31 years old, his ankles are bad and he seems about to yield his job.

title: IF YOU'RE THINKING OF LIVING IN: Old Westbury
description: LEAD: WHEN Old Westbury was incorporated in 1924, a local newspaper dubbed it Millionaire Village. It is still an exclusive enclave of the well-to-do that has managed to keep its rural flavor even though its boundaries are marked by high-speed highways and the Long Island Expressway cuts it in two.

title: FASHION: On the Street; T's of Summer
description: So what's the latest on T-shirts, now that T-shirt weather is once more with us? The bustle of weekend activity in the city always presents a golden opportunity to get outside and survey the scene. Now the results have been tabulated and the semiofficial assessment made. It is that arty and skimpy are in, wordy is out. The picture T-shirt won hands down over the message T-shirt, at least among those on view in the sign-up line for the New York City Marathon (yes, we know it's not until November, but it never hurts to get an early start when you have more than 26 miles to go), the AIDS Walk New York, and various neighborhoods in lower Manhattan. Among the more memorable shirts, artistically speaking, was one displaying a Mona Lisa with her hair in rollers and another decorated with the cartoonlike renderings by the artist Keith Haring. Indian motifs were also big, and several dozen members of the New York City Ballet contingent in the AIDS walk wore T-shirts with an eye-catching purple logo. Some T-shirts, cut off to expose the midriff, had suspenders printed on them, and real clasps to hold them to the pants. Among dogs surveyed, the favorite T-shirt was one emblazoned with the caricature of a Harley-Davidson Hog.

title: THE DIVINE FLOW CHART
description: ARCHBISHOP Inside the Power Structure of the American Catholic Church. By Thomas J. Reese. 401 pp. San Francisco: Harper & Row. $17.95.

title: Sense of Continuity Helps Stamford Synagogue Flourish at 100
description: LEAD: WHEN Harold F. Bernstein, a 28-year-old lawyer, joined a law firm in New York City, he decided to live in Stamford, where he was born and raised. In particular, he said, he wanted to remain a member of Congregation Agudath Sholom, where his children would represent the fifth generation of the family's involvement in the synagogue since its founding 100 years ago.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: GYPSIES. By Robert Charles Wilson. (Foundation/Doubleday, $16.95.) According to Huey Lewis, ''everybody's looking for the perfect world,'' and the appeal of Robert Charles Wilson's third novel derives from this, our collective dream. In ''Gypsies,'' a brother and two sisters are born with a ''talent'' for traveling from one invented world to another, but this gift often seems more like a burden.

title: A First-Year Look At County Center
description: IT is just a little more than a year since the County Center officially reopened. And the word from many Westchester officials is that the $16.2 million face-lifting taxpayers agreed to four and a half years ago has been well worth the cost despite the problems.

title: PLAYING HARDBALL
description: In his article ''Playing Hardball'' (April 30), Eric Alterman refers to Lee Atwater as a ''true-blue American archetype.'' Not in my book; he seems more like a young man consumed with hate.

title: Reluctant Rebel Joins Students' Cause
description: When Gao Xiqing, a former Wall Street lawyer, spent the night on Tiananmen Square in solidarity with students of his who were demonstrating for democracy, he was shaken awake at 2 A.M. by a friend who told him that armed troops were trying to move in on them.

title: Antarctic Oil Leak Is Still Imperiling Wildlife
description: An Argentine Navy supply ship that ran aground and capsized in Antarctica four months ago continues to leak oil, and approaching winter weather has virtually ended efforts to limit the damage, United States authorities and environmentalists say.

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: York, Me.; Open-Space Easements
description: IN the last two decades, about 325 conservation easements have been put in place in Maine to protect 60,000 acres of land, including 135 islands and 29,000 acres of shoreline.

title: As The Arts Contribute More to the Economy, They Must Be Protected
description: MANY of us recognize that Connecticut is a culturally vibrant state. That is one reason this is a great place to live. Now economists have uncovered the outline of an industry underlying that vitality. It is a growth industry, but one vulnerable to the special sources of its capital.

title: Cordoba's Hymn to Islam
description: HE was standing in the courtyard of the Great Mosque of Cordoba in southern Spain when I saw him, gargling water from the ritual fountain there. Three times he took a mouthful and spat it out; three times he sniffed water up his nostrils and snorted; three times he washed his face and ears and then his hands and forearms as far as the elbow, to purify all five senses. This young man in the tweed jacket was a foreign tourist, as I was, but he was a Pakistani, a doctor and an army major, I learned in the next few minutes, and an imam besides, a Muslim holy man considered knowledgeable enough to lead prayers.

title: O'Connor Arrives in Lebanon To See Both Sides of Civil War
description: John Cardinal O'Connor, the Archbishop of New York, arrived in Lebanon today, his first visit to the war-torn country in three years.

title: Romantic Bistro Dining in Ridgefield
description: WHEN Le Coq Hardi, the stylish French restaurant near Town Hall in Ridgefield, metamorphosed into La Cave in mid-February, it did more than just change its name. It changed its entire persona.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Boston;
Demilitarizing 'Combat Zone'
description: LEAD: THE Boston Redevelopment Authority, the city's planning agency, is reviewing plans by Campeau Massachusetts to rebuild an unsuccessful but centrally located shopping mall, a proposal with long-term significance for downtown retailing and cultural life.

title: New Issue Delays Trial in Iran-Contra Case
description: The Iran-contra trial of a former Central Intelligence Agent is being pushed back two weeks because of his charge that the prosecution is using the testimony he gave to a Congressional panel.

title: Fortinbras and Hamlet Play the Russian Tea Room
description: A couple of days ago I got a phone call from a successful American movie producer. He was stopping off in New York for one day on his way from Moscow to Malibu, which may be the most heavily traveled traffic route today. My heart jumped; when I had met him before he had mentioned that he might be interested in doing some theater, and I happened to have a play in my desk drawer. It's called ''Fortinbras Gets Drunk.'' I haven't been able to find a producer for it yet but I am not discouraged. I have been waiting for the production not even a full four years. I was born in the Soviet bloc, and have an Asian sense of time, so I know that four years can't be considered a serious period.

title: HITLER'S GOOD RIGHT ARM
description: GORING A Biography. By David Irving. Illustrated. 573 pp. New York: William Morrow & Company. $22.95.

title: He Came, He Saw, He Conquered, He Inspired
description: Having subdued the Ottomans and swept through what is now central Asia, Iran, Iraq, Syria and northern India, Timur was in the midst of his most ambitious military campaign when he died suddenly in 1405. He had hoped to capture China and reconstitute the nomadic empire that had been ruled by Genghis Khan nearly two centuries earlier.

title: Thomas Macdonald Wed To Cynthia Susan Keller
description: Cynthia Susan Keller, a rating officer at Standard & Poor's Corporation, and Thomas Philip Macdonald, an account executive at the real-estate firm of Brown, Harris, Stevens, both in New York, were married yesterday in Summit, N.J. The Rev. William H. Strain performed the ceremony at Calvary Episcopal Church.

title: A Salute To Forgotten Soldiers
description: FROM the southern coastal plain to the rocky fastnesses of the Northeast, the old gravestones dot New Jersey's African-American cemeteries. They have a characteristic silhouette, and when you get used to it you can readily pick them out. Occasionally you'll see a Grand Army of the Republic stanchion stuck in the ground alongside, and there are always the flowers on Memorial Day. Someone remembers, but most people don't.

title: Foreign Companies Pay Too Much
description: Politicians and chief executives, best sellers and cover stories by major publications lament the sale of corporate America to foreign buyers. Recent foreign acquisitions of American companies provide further fuel for the controversy. But some of these acquisitions may be based on false assumptions.

title: Gephardt Takes Lead in Scramble for House Majority Leader Post
description: Representative Richard A. Gephardt all but officially entered the race for House majority leader today and became the instant front-runner as his colleagues prepared for a sweeping leadership change, Democrats on Capitol Hill said.

title: School Vote: It's Bigger in Cleveland
