description: The 6 percent turnout for the recent school board elections in New York City was far below the participation in school elections in many other cities, officials elsewhere say.

title: FAILINGS REPORTED AT F.B.I. AND C.I.A.
description: A new book contends that American intelligence agencies bungled inquiries into the death or disappearance of three men entrusted with some of the nation's most closely held secrets.

title: Victory for Agent
description: The Alabama Supreme Court has let stand a lower court decision that prosecutors ''utterly and completely failed'' to prove that Jim Abernethy, a former sports agent in Atlanta, violated criminal law when he paid an Auburn University football player. The state's highest court issued no opinion Friday as it refused to alter an Alabama Court of Criminal Appeals ruling that dismissed Abernethy's misdemeanor conviction for game tampering.

title: China Exchange: From Gossip to Trash Bags
description: The message went up on the international computer network that links thousands of corporations, universities and research centers around the world: the students demonstrating in Tiananmen Square in Beijing needed garbage bags.

title: Getting Out Of the Rain With Gusto
description: There was water, water everywhere and not a taxi in sight, but the rain didn't keep hordes of well-known partygoers home Tuesday. They deluged Hubert's Restaurant on Park Avenue to applaud Grace Mirabella, the editor Vogue dismissed, and Mirabella, her new magazine.

title: Private Rail Cars
description: To the Editor: We at Classic Rail Cars also provide premium rail transportation. Generally, costs start at about $3,000 a day, including food and beverage service, transportation and a staff of four. We also offer the availability of multiple-car operations for parties or weddings and even private trains.

title: Ross Perot and General Motors
description: To the Editor:

title: Rules for the Homeless And the Girl Scouts
description: IN warm weather, thousands of homeless people move from winter shelters to a more pleasant refuge in the city parks. In March the city proposed new park rules that, at the least, implied they were not welcome.

title:
FOCUS: Phoenix;
'Air-Conditioning' the Outdoors Downtown
description: LEAD: A $500 MILLION mixed-use complex meant to provide a comfortable outdoor environment even when the temperature soars above 100 degrees -which it does in Phoenix on an average of 87 days a year - is rising on eight downtown blocks.

title: Cruise LInes Are Riding a High Tide
description: LAST year, when a heat wave combined with fouled beaches, the resourceful found a way to the water. If they couldn't be in it, they could be on it, and boat tour operators suddenly found themselves rich in passengers. They are bracing for another banner season this year.

title: Offbeat Feet
description: Playful slippers are stepping out of folklore. Whether authentic or interpreted by designers, they add a festive note to the simplest summer clothing. Toes are extended, pointed and even turned up. Embellishments include sequins, mirrors, trading beads, coins, glass marbles, charms, jewels, tiny bells, silken tassels and even calligraphy. Influences are Indian, Persian, Turkish, Moroccan, Sioux and Apache.

title: THE CASE AGAINST LAWNS
description: Anyone new to the experience of owning a lawn, as I am, soon figures out that there is more at stake here than a patch of grass. A lawn immediately establishes a certain relationship with one's neighbors and, by extension, the larger American landscape. Mowing the lawn, I realized the first time I gazed into my neighbor's yard and imagined him gazing back into mine, is a civic responsibility.

title: Julie Stern to Wed in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Burton Stern of New Rochelle, N.Y., have announced November wedding plans for their daughter Julie Ann Stern and Michael Alan Dorfman, a son of Shirley Dorfman and the late Harry Dorfman of Commack, L.I. Miss Stern is the director of youth services at the Samuel Field Y.M./Y.W.H.A. in Little Neck, Queens. Mr. Dorfman is a sales representative with the Xerox Corporation in Plainview, L.I.

title: James P. Coleman Weds Miss Rees, Graduate Student
description: St. Thomas More Roman Catholic Church in New York was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Sarah Hilleary Peachy Rees and James P. Coleman.

title:
IN SHORT;
FICTION
description: LEAD: MY MOTHER GETS MARRIED. By Moa Martinson. Translated by Margaret S. Lacy. (Feminist Press, Cloth, $24.95; Paper, $9.95.) In the late 19th century, Sweden's farm and factory laborers suffered such appalling poverty that many emigrated to America. Moa Martinson's autobiographical novel, ''My Mother Gets Married,'' shows the desperation of those who remained behind.

title: Is Life in Made-for-TV Films Worth Living?
description: Consider the land of the made-for-TV movie. You probably know it's there, but you haven't been paying that much attention to it. Made-for-TV movies don't hang around like ''theatrical'' movies. Even a really horrible theatrical movie will be advertised for a couple of weeks or so and is more noticeable than ''Everybody's Baby: The Rescue of Jessica McClure'' on ABC last Sunday or ''Out on the Edge'' (CBS, May 14). I don't think the Smithsonian will be calling for videotapes of Brigitte Nielsen's ''Murder by Moonlight'' (CBS, May 9) either. If you haven't been paying attention to them, you probably think that a lot of people are getting sick and dying in TV movies. That's the general perception, but in reality only certain people are dying. Kids are dying. Women are getting extremely ill, being diagnosed as terminal, defying expectations and bouncing back. (''Leap of Faith,'' CBS). Women are doing very well. In ''Jesse'' (CBS) a nurse starts giving medical care to people in a little town out on the desert. A bunch of medicalschool types gang up on her and accuse her of practicing medicine without a license. Much moral ground is covered. ''Nyahh, nyahh, Doctor Bigshot, you were dead wrong'' is the frequent theme in these films. About twice a month we can expect a movie that might have ''nyahh, nyahh'' in its title.

title: The West May Not Be the World, but It's Ours
description: It would appear that we now have a brand-new, shiny, politico-cultural Hula Hoop with which to do our academic-artistic gyrations: anti-Eurocentrism.

title: CRUSADER ON THE CHARLES
description: Having been quoted and even photographed for Helen Epstein's article on the Boston University president, John Silber, I hope you will be interested in my reaction (''Crusader on the Charles,'' April 23). I was as happy as if I were a Jew in Germany in 1936 (well before the Holocaust), hoping to get the word out to the world about what was going on in my country under Hitler and reading an article in The New York Times entitled ''Reformer on the Rhine.''

title: Judge Warns Jail Officials on Davis's Safety
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday ordered New York State and New York City correction officials to halt ''all actions that threaten the safety'' of Larry Davis, who is serving 5 to 15 years on a weapons conviction stemming from a 1966 shootout with the police.

title: Fear, Hatred, Retaliation
description: The conflict between Israelis and Palestinians is stoked by fear: mutual fear. We at a distance know that as a generality, as we know it of Northern Ireland or any inter-communal conflict. But we cannot really know the blinding personal intensity of the emotion.

title: Leftist Plans Rebirth of Sao Paulo's Schools
description: Twenty-five years ago, Paulo Freire's world as a radical educator crashed around him.

title: Drug Hides All Steroids
description: Dr. George (Jamie) Astaphan called it ''the golden boy'' of blocking agents, a drug that would hide the presence of ''any type of steroid.''

title: Cuban Immigrant Held in Hijacking Attempt
description: An escaped mental patient who said he had a bomb ordered the pilot of a Miami-bound jetliner to fly to Cuba today, Federal officials said. But the plane put down here instead, and the man was arrested after two hours of negotiations, during which 150 passengers sat by helplessly on board the jet.

title: Housing Policy
description: To the Editor:

title: CAMPUS LIFE: St. Michael's; 25% of Students Donate Services To the Community
description: When Brian Donahue graduated from St. Michael's College in 1988, he planned to become a salesman. ''My career goal was to make some money and then go into politics,'' Mr. Donahue said.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''It's a question of dignity. We will not be treated like children sent to bed without dinner for not following their parents' wishes.'' A senior Japanese diplomat reacting to the American trade move.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-19

title: No Headline
description: I was delighted to read about William B. Styple's book about Gen. Philip Kearny (''About Books,'' April 23). It brought back memories of my early youth in my birthplace, Kearny, in the early 1920's.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My bathroom ceiling was wallpapered and now I want to paint the ceiling. I have removed most of the wallpaper, but some cementlike paste remains in several areas. I am tired of trying to smooth this ceiling further. Can I paint with a sand-textured paint and are there any disadvantages to this?

title: PANEL QUESTIONS TIME-WARNER PLAN
description: A plan that would leave the impending Time-Warner combination with control of cable television in 60 percent of New York City's households has encountered a rough reception at the Board of Estimate.

title: Vivaldi for Brass, a Recital for Winners
description: AT long last, the Canadian Brass is coming to Bushnell Hall. The renowned brass quintet was scheduled to perform last September at the opening of the Hartford Symphony's season but became the first casualty of the orchestra's musicians' strike.

title: Yucatan
description: To the Editor: I read, with fondness and approval (Travel, Feb. 26), Budd Schulberg's evocative article about the beautiful Yucatan coast away from the bright lights and crowded beaches of Cancun.

title: Nancy Demmon Plans to Be Wed To Allen Fowlkes
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roy Earl Demmon of Washington and Atherton, Calif., have announced the engagement of their daughter Nancy Bailey Demmon to George Allen Fowlkes Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Fowlkes of New York and Nantucket, Mass. An October wedding is planned.

title: From L.I. to Lone Star State: Transplanted Officers Adjust
description: ''I EXPECTED tumbleweeds and horses,'' said Eric Olsen, recalling his image of Texas before he arrived in 1983. Now this taciturn native of Merrick is a SWAT officer with the Houston Police Department.

title: TOMES DEVOTED TO SUICIDE, SEX AND THE SOUTH
description: It covers everything from ''alligators to zydeco,'' said William Ferris, co-editor of the new Encyclopedia of Southern Culture. Scheduled to appear in book stores in July, the 1,600-page book chronicles the history, manners and mores of the South.

title: Time on Her Hands
description: Getting away from it all was taken to new heights, or depths, by Stefania Follini, who last week completed 130 days without human contact in a sealed cave in Carlsbad, N.M. It was an experiment to help researchers learn how people could be affected by long periods of isolation during interplanetary travel. The 27-year-old Italian interior decorator, who volunteered for the experiment, will undergo tests to determine what happened to her mind and body. In the absence of night, day or clocks, her menstrual cycle stopped, she stayed up 20 to 25 hours at a time, sleeping about 10 hours, and she believed that two months had passed instead of four months and 10 days.

title: Susan W. Dryfoos to Marry Daniel Selznick, a Producer
description: Mr. and Mrs. Andrew Heiskell of New York and Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of Mrs. Heiskell's daughter Susan W. Dryfoos to Daniel Mayer Selznick, a son of Irene Mayer Selznick of New York and the late David O. Selznick of Los Angeles. An October wedding is planned.

title: We Shouldn't Envy Canada's Health System; Free Ride for Chrysler
description: To the Editor:

title: How to Know a Dirigible From a Blimp
description: To the Editor:

title: In Stamford, a World Invisible to the Naked Eye
description: LEAD: PHOTOGRAPHIC blowups of magnifications transform fine white powder into a ball of star shapes, a brass disk into lacy crochet work, and a sprig of wheat into a multi-textured sponge. What at first glance looks like an eye-catching black-and-white geometric design show, turns out to be a probing scientific exhibition.

title: Texas Got H.U.D. Funds After Republican's Call
description: The son of Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher has acknowledged that the Department of Housing and Urban Development quickly approved financing for a low-income housing project in Texas after he sought assistance from the chief aide to the former Secretary of the department, Samuel R. Pierce.

title: For Summer, Jackets Try On New Looks
description: THIS summer, the classic blazer may not be dead, but it's certainly being upstaged. Some of the most appealing jackets for working in air-conditioned offices, or for tossing over a T-shirt and jeans, are quirky. Some have an odd detail, like a tie in the back or front. Others have unusual silhouettes.

title: Gil Evans: A King Among Texturalists
description: When the composer Gil Evans died last year, he left a jumble of reputations, some stronger than others. In the 1950's, as a collaborator - his best-known musical personality - he created luminous arrangements on albums such as ''Miles Ahead'' and ''Porgy and Bess'' for his friend Miles Davis's chillingly passionate trumpet. As a bandleader, he came into his own in the 1970's, conducting a regular Monday-night orchestra at Sweet Basil in Manhattan. In between, he worked occasionally and recorded infrequently.

title: Will Andretti's Luck Shift?
description: In May 1969, a couple of months before man's first lunar landing, Mario Andretti drove into Victory Lane at the Indianapolis 500 for the first time. For 20 years, the Moon has been the easier return trip.

title: Yankees Shut Out Again
description: He was still aching from the loss, from another day gone by without so much as a mild threat or a late-inning rally. The crowd had booed when the game was over, and in the quiet moments afterward, Dallas Green again continued to search for answers.

title: What's a Musical Comedy For?
description: To the Editor:

title: Increase in Visitors Poses Challenge for Water Gap Park
description: EVERY year 2.5 million people visit the 70,000-acre Delaware Water Gap National Recreation Area, a Federal preserve straddling the Delaware River in northwestern New Jersey and eastern Pennsylvania. Despite all the visitors, the park has remained a quiet retreat, a peaceful valley of hiking trails and fishing brooks rich in natural beauty, wildlife and historic landmarks.

title: 200,000 at Hong Kong Rally Pledge to Continue Struggle
description: About 200,000 young people attended a daylong open-air pop concert in Hong Kong today to raise money for the pro-democratic demonstrations in China.

title: Reviews/Music; Bostonians in Orpheus Permutations
description: Last season, Joel Cohen brought his Boston Camerata to Manhattan for an interesting, slightly quirky production of Monteverdi's ''Orfeo.'' Since then, Mr. Cohen and his ensemble have been back with programs exploring other themes, but at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday evening they took another look at the Orpheus legend, in an oblique way.

title: PASTIMES: Numismatics
description: Arrowhead coins of the ancient Scythians pose an interesting question: When does an object become a coin and cease to be an object of barter?

title: Commuters Overtake a Rustic Bridge
description: LEAD: WHEN Linda and Michael Palomba moved with their family to Somers four years ago from a small town in Massachusetts, they decided to buy a house in the Deans Bridge area. With its tree-lined country roads, stone walls and a picturesque 85-year-old bridge, the neighborhood reminded them of New England.

title: Flying Over the Rainbow
description: WHAT if there was an airline that made travel as easy as if you were wearing those ruby slippers made famous in ''The Wizard of Oz'' (MGM 1939)? What if it was as luxurious as ''Grand Hotel'' (MGM 1932)?

title: GUIDE
description: BIKING FOR CHARITY The goal of the eighth annual ''Down to the Sound Bike Tour'' is to raise $100,000 for the Western Connecticut Chapter of the National Multiple Sclerosis Society. Check-in time will be 8:30 A.M. next Sunday at Sherwood Island State Park in Westport.

title: FICTION
description: EMILY L. By Marguerite Duras. Translated by Barbara Bray. (Pantheon, $15.95.) Marguerite Duras, the Goncourt Prize-winning author of many novels, including ''The Lover,'' again combines her gifts for the literary and visual arts in this arresting novella. In a French quayside cafe in late summer, the French narrator, accompanied by the man with whom she's been having an affair that is ''taking forever to die,'' grows absorbed by a British couple sitting nearby. Impelled by an inescapable fear that is her ''main point of reference,'' the narrator, a writer, projects onto the wan Englishwoman a life history that seems inextricably tied to her own. The Englishwoman, the narrator imagines, has been with the British captain all her adult life; in fact, he was her first lover. But, as is often the case with Miss Duras, love is accompanied by destruction. The woman, whom the narrator calls ''Emily L.,'' had written poems in her youth, poems that years later win high praise; the captain, however, is unable to understand them (or the part of her that needs to create) and destroys the most important one, the poem-in-progress that would have cast light on the ''internal difference where the meanings are.'' The poem remains unfinished, the couple remains together, the woman remains unfulfilled. Barbara Bray's restrained translation never obtrudes on the precision and spareness of Miss Duras's prose, the deadly accurate realism juxtaposed against the surrealism. With a depth that shines through the minimalist surface of her story, Miss Duras raises probing questions about love, art, fear and haunting sadness.

title: New Jersey Q & A: Arthur Groom; Dealing in the World of Gems
description: WITH a sparkle not far removed from the diamonds and Burmese rubies spread before him, Arthur Groom's eyes radiate excitement when he talks about business.

title: Book of Genesis, As Told by Shaw
description: GEORGE BERNARD SHAW wrote much that was dramatic, but not everything he wrote was theatrical. A case in point is ''In the Beginning,'' the current production at Long Island Stage in Rockville Centre.

title: Maglev Transit: Out of Place on L.I.
description: The Maglev thing seems to be out of place on Long Island. No doubt someone could build one, but what need would it serve? Manhattan to Riverhead? How many people make the trip between those two points? Many to the North Fork or to the Hamptons, but just to Riverhead? When you get off the Maglev there, how do you get to Aquebogue or Mattituck or Shelter Island or Montauk? Those gadgets can't continue on either highways or ordinary railroad tracks.

title: Capturing Impressions Of the Past
description: ON a recent tour of Westminster Abbey my wife and I found a dank, chilly enclosure in the cloisters crowded with tourists of many lands leaning over benches and industriously rubbing wax of various colors onto black paper laid over engraved brass plaques.

title: Gubicza Pitches 7-Hitter To Finally Win at Home
description: Mark Gubicza pitched a seven-hitter to win at home for the first time in five starts this year and Jim Eisenreich had a single and two doubles today as Kansas City beat the Detroit Tigers, 5-1.

title: Remedy Exceeds the Problem
description: THE State of Connecticut is interesting for many reasons, one of which is its practice through the Department of Transportation to allocate contracts for the construction of sound and sight barriers along our main highways.

title: Young Inventors Gain Recognition
description: UNABLE to reach his coat because the hangers in the closet of his Wall Township home were too high, 7-year-old Nicholas Giammanco - 40 inches tall - used to leave it crumpled on the closet floor. Eventually his parents hung it up, and to get it down again, he tugged at the sleeves, knocking down other coats, too.

title: Griswold v. Connecticut: Landmark Case Remembered
description: LEAD: WHEN Thomas I. Emerson recalled the 30 minutes he spent arguing before the United States Supreme Court what was later to be considered a landmark case, he laughed softly, then said: ''It's a rather nerve-racking situation. Here you are in front of the best legal minds in the country and you have to be pretty fluent and spontaneous with your responses.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: SAN MATEO, CALIF.;
Affordables Yield To Luxury Units
description: LEAD: SIXTY to 70 expensive homes will be built on a site previously intended for moderate- and low-cost housing in this well-to-do community just south of San Francisco.

title: George T. Hutton And Miss Sawyer Wed in Stanford
description: Wende Ellen Sawyer, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert F. Sawyer of San Mateo, Calif., was married yesterday in Stanford, Calif., to George Thompson Hutton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert W. Hutton of Greenwich, Conn., and Seattle. The ceremony, at the Stanford Memorial Church, was performed by the Rev. Dr. Ernle W. D. Young, an Episcopal priest, and the Rev. Dr. Paul Watermulder, a Presbyterian minister.

title: LIPA Role Under Attack In Shoreham Settlement
description: LEAD: WHEN the Securities and Exchange Commission approved a Long Island Lighting Company proxy statement last week that described the utility's agreement with Gov. Mario M. Cuomo for closing the Shoreham nuclear-power plant, the company moved closer to resolving the risks and uncertainties that very nearly put it out of business.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island; Recent Sales
description: Coram $180,500 16 Marlow Drive 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 2-year-old ranch; dining room, den, 2-car garage; taxes $2,800. Farmingville $285,000 379 Bluepoint Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, new contemporary; dining room, basement, 2-car garage, 1 acre; taxes $3,800. Medford $187,000 95 Jamaica Avenue 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 25-year-old high ranch; dining room, family room, 1-car garage; taxes $3,200. Ridge $150,000 107 Medford Road 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 16-year-old colonial; dining room, den, basement, 2-car garage; taxes $2,800. Selden $128,000 6 Remington Avenue 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 22-year-old high ranch; den, finished basement, 1-car garage; taxes $2,400. Westbury $275,000 6 Robin Lane 4-bedroom, 2 1/2-bath, 30-year-old split level; dining room, eat-in kitchen, den, 2-car garage; taxes $5,300. OTHER AREAS Scarsdale, N.Y. $380,000 96 Edgemont Road 3-bedroom, 3-bath, 32-year-old split-level; fireplace, eat-in kitchen w/skylight, deck, 1-car garage; taxes $7,891. Meriden, Conn. $192,000 40 Oxbow Drive 4-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 23-year-old colonial; fenced-in yard, potential office in home, 0.67 acre; taxes $1,973. Bradley Beach, N.J. $107,000 100 Ocean Avenue 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 6-year-old town-house condominium; c/a, patio; monthly maintenance $118, taxes $3,412.

title: SOVIET DISSENTERS DENIED MAJOR ROLE IN NEW PARLIAMENT
description: Advocates of more radical change in the Soviet Union suffered a bitter defeat today when many of the most outspoken political insurgents were denied seats in the country's new legislature.

title: Buyer, Be Calm
description: To the Editor:

title: Jennifer Kemp, A Teacher, Weds Allen S. Andrews
description: Jennifer Kemp, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jack F. Kemp of Bethesda, Md., and Hamburg, N.Y., was married yesterday at the Fourth Presbyterian Church in Bethesda to Allen Scott Andrews, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Coleman Andrews Jr. of Richmond.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: THE DEMOCRATIC IMPERATIVE: Exporting the American Revolution. By Gregory A. Fossedal. (New Republic/Basic Books, $19.95.) The proliferation of undemocratic regimes is by no means inevitable, and American efforts to spread democracy can be both ethical and effective, writes Gregory A. Fossedal in ''The Democratic Imperative,'' a witty, carefully reasoned, consistently fair, optimistic look at the state of democracy in the world and what the United States can do about it.

title: ONCE AND FUTURE ADDICTIONS
description: JIGSAW An Unsentimental Education. By Sybille Bedford. 328 pp. New York: Alfred A. Knopf. $18.95.

title: Texas Tory Democrats Go The Way of the Armadillo
description: THE pink granite State Capitol had the air of a country auction last week as the Texas Legislature raced to complete its session. Clerks read lists of bills, and gavels were hammered down after quick electronic votes.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Mandatory Recycling; Lots of Grumbling, but Some Cautious Optimism, Too
description: NEW YORK CITY'S plan for mandatory recycling of some garbage is causing widespread grumbling among landlords and managers of commercial property.

title: Miss Erskine Wed in Oregon
description: Eliza Maxwell Erskine, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert S. Erskine of New York, and Theodore Scott Drummond, a son of Mrs. Russell E. Drummond of Indianapolis and the late Mr. Drummond, were married yesterday in Elmira, Ore. The Rev. Sally Bryan, a Unitarian minister, performed the ceremony at the couple's home. Mrs. Drummond, who attended the Chapin School and graduated from Milton Academy and the School of Visual Arts in New York, is a school-bus driver in Elmira. The bridegroom, a graduate of North Central High School in Indianapolis and the University of Oregon, is an owner of Second Growth, a reforestation company in Eugene, Ore.

title: Mere Beep Comes to the Rescue of the Socially Shipwrecked
description: She has put on her best Calvin Klein -O.K., her only Calvin Klein - to meet her blind date for drinks at Mortimer's. She has been told he is a California bachelor visiting New York who drives a Porsche and works in high-tech.

title: Sports of The Times; The Langston Deal Provokes Questions
description: The day Mark Langston arrived at spring training, his Seattle Mariner teammates greeted him with a chorus of ''New York, New York.'' Among the Mariners, it was understood that the 24-year-old left-hander was about to be traded, along with Jay Buhner and a minor league first baseman, Jim Bowie, to the Mets for Howard Johnson, Sid Fernandez, David West and a minor league right-hander, Kevin Tapani.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: WELCOME, SUMMER The Nynex Yellow Pages is sponsoring a weekend of free ''Just for Fun'' events at county recreation sites, ushering in the summer season. ''Fifties Night at Playland'' is the opener from 8 P.M. to midnight Friday, with Jenny and the Wanderers providing live music for listening and dancing in front of the Ice Casino, and Joel Breeden disk jockeying a series of 1950's tunes.

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;
Yonkers Getting a New Medical Condo
description: LEAD: WHEN the Riverhill Professional Pavilion in Yonkers, now under construction on North Broadway across from St. John's Riverside Hospital, is completed in late September, it will join about 40 other complexes with roughly 400 units in Westchester County that offer doctors and medical services an opportunity to own rather than rent their offices.

title: Kirsten Woodward: Milliner
description: When British society goes to the races at Royal Ascot next month, some of Kirsten Woodward's favorite hats will be on parade.

title: Down-Home Postcards From Two of Country's Frontier Women
description: On the cover of her new album, ''Absolute Torch and Twang'' (Sire/Warner Bros. 25877; all three formats) K. D. Lang is pictured standing in a golden field under a deep blue prairie sky. Clad in denims, her hair short and spiky, the Canadian country singer casts a flinty gaze over the landscape toward the horizon.

title: Now, the Camera's Eye Turns Inward
description: It has been 150 years since photography, that most literal of image-making media, appeared on the scene. To say that it has changed the way we view the world and ourselves is perhaps an understatement; photography has transformed our essential understanding of reality and, in the process, transformed itself. No longer are photographic images regarded as innocent ''mirrors with a memory,'' merely reflecting the world back at us in a simple, one-to-one translation. Rather, they construct the world for us, helping to create the comforting illusions by which we live.

title: Ms. Fischer Has Bridal
description: Kristina L. Fischer, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Fischer of Darby, Pa., and Michael Botein, a son of Marian Botein of New York and the late Justice Bernard Botein, were married yesterday at the New York Law School Faculty Club. The Rev. Dr. Everett C. Parker, the former director of the Office of Communication of the United Church of Christ, officiated.

title: Mall Walkers Leave Shopping and the Weather Behind
description: SPORTING the sort of smiles not often seen on a Monday morning, people with various shapes and personalities descend upon the Cross County Square Mall here. They are not here to eat, although they might sneak in some coffee, and they are not here to browse, although they cannot avoid window shopping.

title: Charles P. Lykes, 72, Grower and Cattleman
description: Charles Parkhill Lykes, chairman of a cattle, citrus and meatpacking empire and patriarch of one of the state's most prominent families, died Thursday. He was 72 years old.

title: Yugoslavia
description: To the Editor: As a specialist in Near East history I take issue with Claire Frankel's description of Mostar as ''an area that was host to the Romans and Turks centuries before the Christian presence (''A Yugoslav City of Minarets,'' Travel, April 16).

title: Suburban Doors Closed To Black Teachers
description: I read with a great deal of interest the article on the racial disparity of teaching staffs (''Schools' Problem of Racial Disparity Also Reflected in Teaching Staffs,'' May 7). While I do not wish to take anything away from the tone and quality of concern voiced by local administrators regarding their attempts to recruit minority teachers, I would like to take this opportunity to recount what has happened to me as I have attempted to find positions in suburban locales.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Milwaukee
description: There are those who still associate Milwaukee with that script writer's concoction - the beer, brats and bowling mecca of the ''Laverne and Shirley'' television show. But people familiar with the real Milwaukee know it as a city in transition, from a quiet, conservative factory town to a lively, diverse, cosmopolitan city.

title: THE WORLD: A Voice From Warsaw; A 2-to-1 Shot at Freedom Isn't So Bad
description: LAST night in my garden, something like a memorial mound sprang up. Under the earth are hidden lost hopes, among them the remains of a calf bought cheap from a farmer. Why cheap? Because the farmer was upset by the price of the dollar, the only real currency in the country, constantly jumping up, and the stories of so-called economic reforms that would only make his life worse. So he hacked the meat into such little chunks that no one wanted to buy them.

title: CAMPUS LIFE: Mount Holyoke; Under Pressure? Try a Club That Howls
description: Having completed final examinations and papers, the answers for Mount Holyoke College mwomen seeking to let off a little steam has been the Lunar Howling Club. The club, which at last count had a mailing list of 101, meets to howl at the full moon and whimper at the new moon. ''We howl to let off stress and to have a good time,'' said one member, Staci Dumoski, a sophomore and American studies major from Placentia, Calif.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Burma Extends Tourist Visas To 14 Days

title: Portnoy's Complaint From Queens
description: After watching the pro basketball playoffs for the past few weeks, I realize why I did not become a great player like Michael Jordan: I was taught the wrong game.

title: A Leaderless Japan May Prove More Combative
description: EVEN before the Bush Administration declared Japan an unfair trading partner last week, it was hard to miss the cracks spreading across the thin shell of smiles and bland assurances of ''close cooperation'' that masks the tensions in the United States-Japan alliance.

title: WHAT THEY'RE WEARING: Short Hair
description: At the showings of the American fall collections, the snappy short haircuts on a number of models were among the more arresting bits of news. These photographs are evidence.

title: Review/Dance; Bill by Balanchine, Robbins and Feld
description: The New York City Ballet, now rightly considered the repository of George Balanchine's ballets, presented what could be called a disparate program on Friday night. Those who recall the company's more eclectic first two decades would not have found it that unusual.

title: Suffolk's Big Plan to Preserve Pine Barrens Is Yielding Small Results
description: In 1987 and again last year, Suffolk County residents agreed to a quarter-cent increase in their sales tax so that the county could buy thousands of acres of Long Island's most ecologically sensitive land, the Pine Barrens.

title: Lingering Effects of a Virus
description: The computer virus spread like wildfire last November, copying itself into as many as 6,000 computers connected by networks at universities, private corportions and military installations. It took several days to clear the virus from the computers, but it has taken longer to take care of the rest of the matter. Last week, Cornell University said it had suspended Robert Tappan Morris, the 23-year-old graduate student a school commission said was the author of the rogue program. A school official called it an academic decision ''entirely separate'' from any other action that might be taken. Although a Federal grand jury has considered the case, no criminal charges have been filed against Mr. Morris, who now lives with his family in Maryland.

title: POSTINGS: Educating the Pros; Mortgage Conference
description: Real estate professionals often do not know as much as they should about ways to make home mortgages, and therefore homes, more affordable. To try to educate salesmen, brokers, lawyers, bankers and appraisers in the nuances and intricacies of home loans for moderate-income families, the Brooklyn Board of Realtors will hold a conference Thursday from 10 A.M. to 3 P.M. at El Caribe restaurant, 5945 Strickland Avenue in the Mill Basin section. Admission is $10.

title:
GARDENING;
Clues to Those Mysterious Deaths
description: LEAD: IT is frustrating to watch a tree or shrub die. Despite the best possible care, including watering and fertilizing, failure still strikes. A popular shrub may help provide an answer.

title: A Turnaround at Dayton Hudson
description: When the Minneapolis-based Dayton Hudson Corporation acquired Mervyn's, the California apparel chain, a decade ago, it got a powerhouse - an innovative and much emulated retailer that could contribute mightily to the parent corporation's earnings. But, as Dayton Hudson learned after Mervyn's drifted into serious problems, benign neglect is no substitute for hands-on management.

title: Miss Murdaugh, A Lawyer, Weds
description: At St. Saviour's Episcopal Church in Bar Harbor, Me., Anne Wycliffe Murdaugh, a daughter of Dr. H. Victor Murdaugh Jr. of Columbia, S.C., and Salisbury Cove, Me., and the late Sara Huckle Murdaugh, was married yesterday to James Benjamin Holston 3d, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Holston Jr. of Thousand Oaks, Calif. The Rev. Malcolm A. Hughes performed the ceremony.

title: Miss Arrington and M. A. Adams Wed in Oklahoma
description: Elizabeth Anne Arrington, a daughter of John L. Arrington Jr. of Tulsa, Okla., and Anne W. Leonard of Chicago, was married in Tulsa yesterday to Michael Augustine Adams, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bertis H. Adams 3d of Suffield, Conn. The Rev. David Fox officiated at St. John's Episcopal Church.

title: POSTINGS: North of Princeton's Campus; From Timber to Town Houses in Three Short
description: The tract of forest and meadow in central New Jersey near Princeton first attracted the attention of eagle-eyed London speculators, John Lord Berkeley and Sir George Carteret, in the 1650's; they acquired it from the Crown. Later, it was owned by William Penn, the Quaker leader, and, at the time of the Revolutionary War, it was the property of Richard Stockton, one of the signers of the Declaration of Independence. The area had been used to grow timber and corn, but it in recent years it had lain fallow. Now town houses are sprouting on 20 acres of it.

title: An Era EndsFor Canada's National Ballet
description: The National Ballet of Canada has recently presented ''Tagore,'' a premiere by Glen Tetley, and staged here, for the second year, its International Competition for the Erik Bruhn Prize. The competition - limited to four companies with which Bruhn was associated - may continue, albeit in modified form. But Mr. Tetley, an American who has largely pursued a freelance career, will no longer be serving as the National Ballet's artistic associate and, in effect, its resident choreographer.

title: Bard College
description: In its 129th commencement yesterday, Bard College graduated 143 undergraduate and 8 graduate students.

title:
IN SHORT;
NONFICTION
description: LEAD: ZERO MOSTEL: A Biography. By Jared Brown. (Atheneum, $22.50.) Zero Mostel was, in one critic's words, ''a wonder of nature, an elemental force.'' The actor, who dominated Broadway in the early 1960's with Tony Award-winning performances in ''Rhinoceros'' and ''A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum,'' achieved immortality in 1964 in the role of Tevye in ''Fiddler on the Roof.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: HAPPY HOLIDAY For those who like to celebrate Memorial Day with more than a backyard barbecue or a look at the holiday parades that have survived Long Island's suburbanization, there's plenty to do this weekend.

title: Let the Voters Choose 'None of the Above'
description: To the Editor:

title: Wendy Herrick Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Peter Herrick of Bronxville, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Wendy Jo Herrick, to Jeffrey Stuart Mahan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Donald C. Mahan of Baltimore. An August wedding is planned.

title: A Community Welcomes Back Its Bridge to Business
description: IN February 1986 the State Department of Transportation began what was supposed to be 14 months of repair to a bridge on Route 12 at the southern edge of Jewett City. But the job went on for almost 40 months, and businesses watched as not only traffic from nearby Interstate 395 dwindled, but also their profits.

title:
NATIONAL NOTEBOOK: JAMESTOWN, R.I.;
A New Bridge Raises Hopes
description: LEAD: WHEN the bridge that links this nine-mile-long island in Narragansett Bay to mainland Rhode Island is replaced in 1992 with a new $118 million, four-lane bridge now under construction, traffic will move more swiftly. Developers are hoping it will have the same affect on the home-sales market.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ending May 13 MANHATTAN Carnegie Hill $225,000 1199 Park Avenue (94th St.) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 850-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, concierge, dining area, windowed kitchen; maintenance $458, 44% tax-deductible (Broker: Klara Madlin Real Estate) Chelsea $655,000 444 West 23d Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,600-sq.-ft. co-op in a prewar brownstone; large kitchen, 2 fireplaces, terrace; maintenance $335, no tax deduction (Broker: Kingman Associates) East Midtown $1.03 million 340 East 50th Street 2-family, 5-story brownstone; 3 bedrooms, 3 baths, maid's room, fireplace, terrace in owner's triplex; 2 bedrooms, 2 baths in duplex; dining room, large kitchen in each; 20- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $13,000 (Broker: Ambrose Mar-Elia) Greenwich Village $545,000 15 West 11th Street 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,200-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; manned elevator; dining area, large kitchen; three exposures; maintenance $1,306, 42% tax-deductible (Broker: Kanelba & Robilotti) Greenwich Village $760,000 247 West 12th Street (Greenwich House) 2-bedroom, 2-bath, 2,000-sq.-ft. loft co-op; 24-hr. doorman, fireplace, large closets, two exposures; maintenance $1,190, 65% tax-deductible (Broker: Fields-Eychner) Kips Bay Area $154,000 201 East 25th Street 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 750-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; 24-hr. doorman, large living room, parquet floors; maintenance $475, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Eden Realty) BRONX Gun Hill Road Area $212,000 1462 Knapp Street 2-family, detached brick house; 2 bedrooms in primary unit; 1 bedroom, dining room in other; 1 bath, large kitchen, heated porch in each; full basement, detached 1-car garage, 25- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $988 (Broker: J.A.V. Realty) Wakefield $155,000 4358 Wilder Avenue 3-bedroom, 2-bath, single-family, detached frame house; dining room, large kitchen, 1-car garage, 50- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $1,100 (Broker: Marland Real Estate) BROOKLYN Park Slope $245,000 298 Garfield Place 2-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, 1,300-sq.-ft. prewar, duplex co-op; dining area, fireplace, remodeled kitchen; maintenance $644, 50% tax-deductible (Broker: Joseph Berman Realty) Red Hook $132,000 39 Dikeman Street 2-family, 3-story, detached frame house; 2 bedrooms, dining room, large kitchen in primary duplex; 1 bedroom in other; 1 bath in each; 1-car garage, 40- by 100-ft. lot; taxes $800 (Broker: Carl F. Peek) QUEENS Briarwood $119,000 83-11 139th Street (Broadmore) 3-bedroom, 2-bath, 1,000-sq.-ft. postwar co-op; dinette, windowed kitchen, hardwood floors; maintenance $550, 52% tax-deductible (Broker: Kraham Realty) Forest Hills $164,000 110-07 73d Road (Wakefield) 1-bedroom, 1-bath, 1,000-sq.-ft. prewar co-op; part-time doorman, dining room, renovated kitchen and bath; maintenance $402, 52% tax-deductible (Broker: Rhona Realty) STATEN ISLAND Great Kills $183,000 67 Walnut Avenue 3-bedroom, 1 1/2-bath, single-family, semi-attached brick house; dining area, large kitchen, c/a, 29- by 89-ft. lot; taxes $1,449 (Broker: Weichert Realtors) West Brighton $172,500 112 Taylor Street 2-family, detached, frame house; 5 bedrooms in primary duplex; 2 bedrooms in other; 1 bath, dining room, large kitchen in each; 50- by 120-ft. lot; taxes $900 (Broker: Rand Properties)

title: All That Smithsonian Jazz, Now on Five Compact Disks
description: The Smithsonian Institution's massive best-selling ''Collection of Classic Jazz,'' first issued in 1973, became what The Times's jazz critic John S. Wilson called an ''instant classic.'' In 1987, a revised and updated version was described by another Times reviewer, John Rockwell, as a ''blockbuster summation'' of jazz, although Mr. Rockwell questioned whether the set was forward-looking enough.

title: PERSPECTIVES: The Sunnyside Yards; Amtrak's Grand Vision for Its Air Rights
description: NOW it's Amtrak's turn at trying to make use of the huge development opportunity at the Sunnyside railyards in Long Island City, Queens. The national passenger railroad has taken on a development manager and started planning that could open 150 acres of land there for large-scale commercial and residential development over the next decade and beyond.

title: COMIC-BOOK COLLECTORS
description: Mr. Queenan is an editor at Forbes, a magazine that extolls the pursuit of empty materialism and the virtues of greed, featuring such stalwarts as Ivan Boesky and Michael Milken. In comparison, a little straightforward violence in the battle against crime is a downright relief. I'd rather my child's heroes be characters with a sense of honor and a willingness to take responsibilty for the consequences of their actions, like Wolverine and Batman, than Oliver (Just Following Orders) North or Jimmy (God Forgave Me, Why Can't You?) Swaggart. DAVID SINGBAND Yorktown, N.Y.

title: 'My Name Is Steven' No. 2 Mini-Series
description: ''I Know My Name is Steven,'' which was broadcast by NBC on Monday and Tuesday nights, was the second-highest-rated mini-series of the season, according to the A. C. Nielsen Company. The four-hour program had an average rating of 24.5 and was seen by 39 percent of the viewing audience.

title: Reviews/Dance; Additional Segments Of Kei Takei's 'Light'
description: Kei Takei has done it again. On Tuesday night at the La Mama Annex the Japanese minimalist deposited a group of performers in another of her barren landscapes and provided them with another of her stark and mystic rituals. Once again she bored at least one viewer nearly to death. And once again she has created a theater-dance piece of undeniable and unforgettable power, this time in ''The Last Rice Field,'' a new work that is Part 27 of her 20-year ''Light'' series.

title: Corrections
description: An article on May 14 about new uses for the antibiotic tetracycline misstated its effect on the tissue-destroying enzyme collagenase. Collagenase is believed to be a factor causing rheumatoid arthritis. Tetracycline reduces the enzyme's activity by 67 percent, not 6 to 7 percent.

title: For the U.S. And Soviets, A Nuclear Exchange
description: NOT long ago, the details of running a nuclear reactor were guarded by the United States and the Soviet Union as secrets vital to national security. But last week it seemed that the superpowers were rushing to bare all.

title: POSTINGS: Upscale Downtown; Condos in a Stable
description: A century ago the New York architectural firm of D. & J. Jardine designed a decorous upscale stable for horses at 125 East 12th Street, between Third and Fourth Avenues, even incorporating representations of horses' bits into the six terra cotta capitals on the front of the building. And now in another of the bizarre transmogrifications that ginger the New York real estate market, workmen are converting the East Village stable into an upscale apartment house for people.

title:
GARDENING;
Clues to Those Mysterious Deaths
description: LEAD: IT is frustrating to watch a tree or shrub die. Despite the best possible care, including watering and fertilizing, failure still strikes. A popular shrub may help provide an answer.

title: Where to Go When Sun and Sand Beckon
description: LEAD: THERE are those who love the solitude of beaches off-season. The weather may be cold or overcast, but they can walk alone or with someone special. Bundled in a sweater, they feel the wind in their faces and watch the seagulls overhead. They love the rhythm of the tides and don't care if the water is too cold to get even their toes wet.

title: BUT DUCK WHEN HE SMILES
description: LEAD: ON THE FIRING LINE The Public Life of Our Public Figures. By William F. Buckley Jr. Illustrated. 533 pp. New York: Random House. $22.50.

title: After 15 Months, Mob Trial Nears End
description: After 15 months and testimony by 200 witnesses, a Federal prosecutor last week began closing statements in one of the longest organized-crime trials in recent history.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing; Relishing the Nautical Life in Croton-on-Hudson
description: An hour's drive from the heart of New York City can take sailing enthusiasts to a world of their own. Here on Senasqua Bay, where the Hudson River is at its widest, you can learn to sail, brush up on boating skills or charter a boat for a day cruise.

title: Mini Field for Maxi-Race
description: Ireland's first entry in the Whitbread round-the-world race, a massive white and green maxi-yacht, was being wheeled out of a repair shed in Portsmouth, R.I., last week. The yacht's crewmen had a race to think about, but it wasn't around the world. It was to be across the Atlantic Ocean, a mere sprint by Whitbread standards. But the trans-Atlantic race will also be a valuable prep for the global match later this summer.

title: The Fast Track to New Markets
description: Some have said that high definition television is simply a problem for the computer industry to solve by sending digital information over a fiber optics highway. This could not be farther from the truth. No one industry, technology, or company can meet the challenge of HDTV - not even the computer industry.

title: GIVE WAR ITS DUE
description: A COUNTRY MADE BY WAR From the Revolution to Vietnam - The Story of America's Rise to Power. By Geoffrey Perret. Maps. 629 pp. New York: Random House. $22.50.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu; Alice's Chinese Chicken
description: Remember Alice from ''Alice's Restaurant Massacree,'' a song Arlo Guthrie made famous in the 60's?

title: HUMAN RIGHTS IN CHINA
description: I would like to add to your report on human rights in China that, no matter how badly intellectuals and activists are treated, it cannot compare with Chinese brutality in Tibet. I was expelled from Lhasa on March 9, with approximately 100 other tourists, for one reason - so that there would be no witnesses to the army's actions against Tibetan demonstrators. I have never seen such vicious behavior. Thousands of machine-gun-carrying soldiers were packed in the backs of trucks fitted with swing-type machine guns, which I always thought were for shooting down airplanes. The soldiers were kicking the Tibetans and hitting them with their rifles. What had started as a peaceful protest was deliberately escalated into a bloodbath. I'm willing to bet that the Chinese will not open fire on Han students in Beijing as they did on Buddhist monks and nuns in Tibet. ANDREW FAILES Petersburg, N.Y.

title: Vera Wang Plans to Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Cheng Ching Wang of New York and Pound Ridge, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Vera Wang, to Arthur Paul Becker, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Arnold H. Becker of Avon, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title: Joan Harrison Marries
description: Joan Elizabeth Harrison, the special-events coordinator for the Canadian Mission to the United Nations, and David Ng, the day city editor of The New York Post, were married yesterday at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration in New York. The bride, who will retain her name, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John Harrison of Birmingham, England. Mr. Ng is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Ng of New York.

title: The Pendulum Swings Again; A Friend Returns
description: MY beautiful antique clock hung mute on the wall. It slowly worked down, gradually losing time until its handsome brass and ebony pendulum stopped swinging altogether.

title: CONSUMER RATES
Lori G. Meltzer, an Executive, Weds Peter Starer
description: Lori Glazier Meltzer, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Murray A. Meltzer of Tenafly, N.J., was wed last evening to Peter Desider Starer, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward Starer of Tenafly. Rabbi Jack Bemporad officiated at Bridgewaters at the South Street Seaport.

title: Not a Fan Of Darling
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Bound for Broadway? Look to Off-Broadway
description: WITH the Broadway season's supply of new plays falling to near an all-time low, as reported by the League of American Theaters and Producers, the notion of a work being broken in for Broadway by a regional theater is more an illusion than a probability.

title: A Crucible of Cultures in Andalusia
description: SEVILLE is not just a great city of the past. It is the vibrant modern center of western Andalusia, as the traffic and the crowds make plain. Situated in one of the most fertile provinces of Spain, the Guadalquivir River that flows through it was navigable until the last century. The university thrives, as it has done for centuries, and during the school year students throng the city center and fill the bars with noise as the young have done since the days when Muslims ruled, when the students, merchants and tourists of those days first crowded the avenues. It is a city of dark-leaved orange trees, clouded in blossoms or brilliant with fruit, unplucked - since even a beggar can afford an orange in Seville.

title: Resident Of a Halfway House Shares Victories
description: AS I stand here tonight, overriding even my jitters at speaking in public i an instinctual sense of irony in having been chosen to share with you the experience of my home. Six months ago, I would have referred to it as my ''place of residence,'' my ''living quarters'' or ''this institution.''

title: Linda Silberman, Professor, Is Wed
description: The wedding of Prof. Linda Silberman and Dr. Victor Goldberg took place last evening at D'Agostino Hall at the New York University School of Law. Judge Phyllis Gangel-Jacob of Manhattan Civil Court officiated.

title: Will the Beaches Be Clean and Crowded?
description: LEAD: AS the summer season begins, major efforts are under way to avoid a recurrence of last year's beach closings, which cost the Long Island economy $1 billion. But some uncertainty remains.

title: Suit Challenges Appalachian Trail Incursion
description: A coalition of environmental groups is suing the Interior Department and the National Park Service over an agreement that would allow ski trails and a ski lift across the Appalachian Trail, saying it is the most serious threat to the trail in its history.

title: WRITE TILL YOU DROP
description: People love pretty much the same things best. A writer looking for subjects inquires not after what he loves best, but after what he alone loves at all. Strange seizures beset us. Frank Conroy loves his yo-yo tricks, Emily Dickinson her slant of light; Richard Selzer loves the glistening peritoneum, Faulkner the muddy bottom of a little girl's drawers visible when she's up a pear tree. ''Each student of the ferns,'' I once read, ''will have his own list of plants that for some reason or another stir his emotions.''

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. My bathroom ceiling was wallpapered and now I want to paint the ceiling. I have removed most of the wallpaper, but some cementlike paste remains in several areas. I am tired of trying to smooth this ceiling further. Can I paint with a sand-textured paint and are there any disadvantages to this?

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL Bach: ''Magnificat'' (S. 243); Vivaldi: ''Gloria'' (R. 589) Dawn Upshaw, Penelope Jensen, Marietta Simpson, David Gordon, William Stone and the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra and Chamber Chorus conducted by Robert Shaw. Telarc CD-80194, CD only. The unsurpassed smoothness of these performances may surprise listeners accustomed to the lean, accented style of presenting Baroque music currently in favor. Both works are exceptionally rich in beautiful melodies, and certainly lend themselves to Mr. Shaw's uncomplicated, pervasively musical treatment. The many solo arias and duets are so handsomely sung by the soloists that stylistic questions subordinate themselves to sheer musical enjoyment. By allowing Bach and Vivaldi to speak for themselves without distortion, Mr. Shaw's excellently recorded versions have earned their place in the enormous discography of both works. -Paul Turok Brahms and Ligeti: Trios for Violin, Horn and Piano Bridge BCD 9012; CD only. There is a small but notable tradition of composing works to ''go with'' existing masterpieces for unusual combinations of instruments. The trio of Gyorgy Ligeti recorded here falls more frankly into that category than most; it is openly subtitled ''Hommage a Brahms,'' and puts the idiomatic horn-call motives of Brahms's Op. 40 through various transformations. It is hard to hear it as much more than an appendage, gloss, recollection or commentary - but it is one that engages the attention. William Purvis's first-rate horn playing links the works; he has ''new music'' collaborators (Rolf Schulte and Alan Feinberg) for the Ligeti and ''standard rep'' collaborators (Daniel Phillips and Richard Goode) for the Brahms, an intent but somewhat sluggish performance. -Will Crutchfield Haydn: Symphonies Nos. 26, 52 and 53 La Petite Bande; Sigiswald Kuijken, conductor; Virgin Classics VC 7 90743; CD and cassette. Haydn's symphonies before the familiar clutch of late masterpieces are full of gems still undiscovered by all but specialists, and these scores most definitely fall into the gem category. Whatever one may feel about Beethoven on original instruments, there can be no doubt that Haydn benefits from the clarity of texture and pungency of timbre of groups like the 25-member Petite Bande. And Mr. Kuijken's interpretations sound particularly buoyant and rhythmically alive. -John Rockwell New Computer Music. Works by Paul Lansky, Curtis Roads, James Dashow, Clarence Barlow, Stephan Kaske, Michel Waisvisz Wergo 2010-50; CD only. The six works in this collection of 1980's electronic music show different ways of manipulating the genre's increasingly sophisticated gadgetry. Paul Lansky, for instance, makes interesting textures and rhythms out of the unintelligible, computer-generated voices in ''Idle Chatter.'' Curtis Roads's ''Nscor'' and James Dashow's ''Sequence Symbols'' are of the more traditional bleep and buzz school, but unfold with a sense of drama and direction. Clarence Barlow's ''Relationships'' is for all intents and purposes a jazz-rock work, for synthesizer bass and drums. -Allan Kozinn Havergail Brian: Symphony No. 3 BBC Symphony Orchestra, Lionel Friend, conductor. Hyperion CDA66334; CD only. The English composer Havergail Brian (1876-1972) was a legend during his lifetime, if only for the indomitable self-confidence that allowed him to compose 32 symphonies (among other works) in the face of nearly total neglect. Toward the end of his life, there was a modest surge of interest in his music. The Third Symphony, dating from 1932, is a monumentally conceived work that easily accommodates two pianos into its immense orchestral fabric. It is Malherian in scope, Elgarian in sound and has a ruggedness particular to its composer. The performance is powerful, the recording superb. -P. T. POP/JAZZ Buster Poindexter: 'Buster Goes Berserk' RCA 9660; all three formats. No rock-and-roller generates a more infectious sense of fun than Buster Poindexter. On his second album, as on his debut, the best cuts are those that suggest scenes from a wild party in progress where the host is the rambunctious, half-pickled singer, who has immersed himself in the persona of a funky soul man. The performances of soul standards (''Hit the Road, Jack'') and obscure soul novelties (''International Playboy''), and of original funky novelties (''DeBourge Yourself'') are uproarious turns full of fun and personality. But when Mr. Poindexter turns introspective for the Frank Sinatra standard ''Deep in a Dream,'' his personality becomes dull, his singing merely crude. -Stephen Holden Loudon Wainwright III: 'Therapy' Silvertone 1203; all three formats. During his nearly 20-year recording career, Mr. Wainwright has accumulated a body of brutally candid comic songs that has almost become a folk genre unto itself. The chemistry between Mr. Wainwright's simple good-timey melodies, his cheerfully acidic singing and his cathartically confessional light verses can elicit laughter at things one usually sheds tears over. In recent years, Mr. Wainwright's humor has darkened. Beneath the smart-aleck tone one senses a profound bemusement. The cast of characters in ''Therapy'' includes ex-wives, children, aging parents and other folk singers. Much of the writing is first-rate, and the confessions cut more deeply than ever. Consider this the latest absorbing chapter in a lifelong oeuvre. - S. H. Darling Buds: 'Pop Said . . . ' Columbia 45208; all three formats. A decade after the Go-Go's and Blondie, Great Britain is enjoying a miniwave of guitar-charged, pop-centered girl groups, among them Voice of the Beehive, the Primitives and now the Darling Buds, from South Wales. Yet where their cohorts undercut old girl-group attitudes, the Darling Buds proceed without irony. In most of their songs, by Andrea Lewis (vocals) and Harley Farr (guitar), the singer lives for romance and awaits absent boyfriends' whims; only ''Shame on You'' takes a 1980's twist. But as the guitars surge and the catchy choruses pile up, the Darling Buds supply unrepentant pop pleasure. -Jon Pareles Bill Frisell: 'Before We Were Born' Elektra-Musician 60843; all three formats. Bill Frisell is a master of the amorphous guitar sound - eerie sustained melodies, floating tones that seem to peek in from another time-space continuum, splotches and spatters of distortion. While he has worked with jazz's structural experimenters, his own albums have been relatively conventional - until now. ''Before We Were Born'' includes ''Hard Plains Drifter,'' a series of country-tinged tunes and abstract interludes shredded and patched together by John Zorn; ''Some Song and Dance,'' a string of bop-flavored tunes with a saxophone section, and ''The Lone Ranger,'' a slow-building dream-waltz. By following through on the implications of his unfettered sounds, Mr. Frisell has made his best album. -J. P. Djivan Gasparian: 'I Will Not Be Sad in This World' Opal/Warner Bros. 25885; all three formats. From absolute stillness comes a sound that floats, croons, quivers as it carries an ancient melody - the sound of Djivan Gasparian playing the Armenian duduk, a double-reed instrument with a rich, doleful, flutelike tone. On ''I Will Not Be Sad,'' a collection of folk melodies recorded in 1983, Mr. Gasparian is accompanied only by a second duduk carrying a quiet, steady drone. As with the Bulgarian choirs on ''Le Mystere des Voix Bulgares,'' the silence of the studio brings out every sustained nuance of inflection, and the songs are almost heartbreaking in their eerie slow motion. -J. P.

To executives in Firestone's Chicago headquarters, who had watched the company steadily decline and shrink in the past decade, the purchase signaled a much-needed renaissance.

RESULTS PLUS
description: TENNIS Becker Leads West Germany: Boris Becker led West Germany to a 2-1 victory over Argentina yesterday in the World Team Cup tournament in Dusseldorf. Becker gave West Germany the lead after defeating Guillermo Perez-Roldan, 6-0, 2-6, 6-2, in the first singles match. But Martin Jaite of Argentina rallied and defeated Carl-Uwe Steeb, 6-4, 6-3, in the second singles match. Becker and Eric Jelen clinched the victory by defeating Javier Frana and Gustavo Luzauss, 6-4, 7-5, in the doubles. The West German team won $320,000. (AP) Maleeva Takes Geneva Final: Third-seeded Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria defeated fourth-seeded Conchita Martinez of Spain, 6-4, 6-0, yesterday in the final of the Geneva European Open. Maleeva, ranked ninth in the world, said she was fit and confident on the eve of the French Open championship, where she is seeded sixth. The 22-year-old Maleeva needed slightly more than an hour to win her 16th Grand Prix title and the $17,000 first prize.(AP) Argentine Wins in Florence: Sixth-seeded Horacio de La Pena of Argentina won the City of Florence tournament yesterday with a 6-4, 6-3 victory over Goran Ivanisevic, 17, of Yugoslavia. First place was worth $18,600. It was the second career Grand Prix victory for de la Pena, ranked 63d in the world. (AP) Novotna Wins Easily: Jana Novotna, 20, of Czechoslovakia won her first tournament since 1986 as she routed Patricia Tarabini of Argentina, 6-1, 6-2, yesterday in the final of the tournament in Strasbourg, France. The second-seeded Novotna won in less than an hour. She won $17,000. She is ranked 16th in the world after starting the year at 44.(AP) Leaycraft Gets N.C.A.A. Title: Donni Leaycraft of Louisiana State, down by 2-3 in the final set, won the last four games to defeat Steven Jung of Nebraska, 6-1, 4-6, 6-3, yesterday and win the National Collegiate Athletic Association men's individual championship. Eric Amend and Byron Black of Southern California edged Trevor Kronemann and Mike Briggs of California-Irvine, 7-5, 6-7, 7-5 to win the doubles.(AP) BASEBALL Consecutive No-Hitters Set Record: Tom Drees threw his second consecutive no-hitter yesterday as the Vancouver Canadians defeated the Edmonton Trappers, 1-0, in a seven-inning Pacific Coast League game in Vancouver, British Columbia. The consecutive no-hitters were the first in this league's history. Drees, 25, a left-hander, pitched a nine-inning no-hitter last week, beating the Calgary Cannons, 1-0.(AP) CYCLING Surprise Victor in Italy: John Carlsen, 27, of Denmark climbed through snow-covered mountains yesterday to win the eighth stage of the Tour of Italy race in a surprise victory. The overall lead changed hands, with Erik Breukink of the Netherlands taking the pink jersey away from Silvano Contini of Italy, who had held it for five stages. Breukink finished fourth in yesterday's 111-mile leg, which began just north of Rome and took the cyclists through rain and hail into the Apennine range. Carlsen took 5 hours 21 minutes 40 seconds to reach the finish line. Lucio Herrera of Colombia was second; Marino Lejarreta of Spain, third. (AP) AUTO RACING Waltrip Becomes 5-Time Winner: The defending champion, Darrell Waltrip, yesterday to become a five-time winner of the Coca-Cola 600 Nascar race in Concord, N.C. After the pole-sitter Alan Kulwicki's Ford blew an engine 30 laps from the finish, Waltrip outran Sterling Marlin to win by 99 hundredths of a second at the Charlotte Motor Speedway's 1.5-mile tri-oval.(AP) SOCCER Trinidad and Tobago 1, Costa Rica 1: Philbert Jones scored with 21 minutes remaining last night to give Trinidad and Tobago a 1-1 tie with Costa Rica at Port of Spain, Trinidad, in a qualifying match for the 1990 World Cup. Costa Rica (2-2-1) leads the North and Central American and Caribbean qualifying group with 5 points. The United States (1-1-1) is second with 3 points. Trinidad (0-0-2) is tied for third with 2 points along with Guatemala, 1-1. El Salvador has yet to play. The top two countries qualify for the 24-team finals in Italy. In other games, Ireland beat Malta, 2-0, in Europe Group 6, and Japan and Indonesia played to a scoreless tie in Asia Group 6.(AP)

title: Question Box
description: Batters Up and Down Q. Thirty years ago last week, Harvey Haddix of the Pittsburgh Pirates pitched one of baseball's masterpieces, working 12 perfect innings, retiring 36 batters in a row, but, incredibly, losing the game in 13 innings to the Milwaukee Braves. Counting his game before that one, how many straight batters did Haddix retire over the two games and is that a major league record? A. Before Haddix set down 36 batters in a row, the left-hander had knocked off the last two batters in his previous start, on May 21, 1959, so the perfect effort versus the Braves on May 26 gave him 38 in a row, which stood as the major league mark for 13 years. Then in 1972, Jim Barr, a right-hander with the San Francisco Giants, won consecutive shutouts against Pittsburgh (8-0) on Aug. 23 and St. Louis (3-0) on Aug. 29, and in doing so, retired the last 21 Pirate batters he faced and the first 20 Cardinal batters. That total of 41 erased the Haddix record and is still the big-league standard.

title: Soviet Wheat Purchase

The wheat purchase was the latest under a 1.5-million-metric-ton subsidy offer President Bush extended to Moscow on May 2. The department said the wheat sale was subsidized at $8.89 a ton, for a total subsidy of about $2.7 million.

title: Review/Theater; Enter the Martyred Maid, But Without 1950's Voices
description: In ''The Lark,'' Jean Anouilh's drama about Joan of Arc, the playwright's sharpest image of his heroine is expressed by the worldly Englishman, Warwick, who sits as one of her judges. The character, who represents the voice of secular reason in a play that steams with religious fervor, compares Joan to a lark that sings ''a joyous, crazy song of courage.'' Warwick is the only character who recognizes that Joan's execution might elevate her into a martyr with far more mythic power than any force she could wield were her life spared.
