title: Are You Satisfied With a Federal Career?
description: The Federal Executive Institute, established by Presidential order in 1968 and based in Charlottesville, Va., prides itself on being a civil servant's equivalent of a war college. Here is a sampling of the results of a poll of 2,231 members of the institute's Alumni Association on whether they would do battle again, and related subjects.

title: One Killed, One Hurt In Restaurant Shooting
description: A teen-ager was killed and his cousin wounded in a shooting Saturday night in a McDonald's restaurant at 208 Dyckman Street in the Inwood section of Manhattan, the police said.

title: A National Sports Daily Is Planned for Autumn
description: Peter O. Price, the co-owner of Avenue magazine and the former publisher of The New York Post, plans to introduce a national daily newspaper on sports this fall.

title: New Competition in Spain's Media
description: In a country where only 15 years ago most newspapers and all television stations were still owned by the state, the media picture is being rapidly transformed. Powerful local and foreign investors are now warring to control Spain's lucrative market. The latest battlefield is television, where Rupert Murdoch and Silvio Berlusconi are among international communications investors bidding for licenses to run the country's first three commercial stations. The Government will give up its television monopoly next year.

title: Weldotron Corp reports earnings for Year to Feb 28
Markets Closed
description: The nation's stock, bond and commodity markets will be closed today in observance of Memorial Day. Most banks and Government offices will also be closed.

title: Rohr Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: Both year-ago periods' results were restated to reflect an accounting change for the company's subsidiaries.

title: In Week of an Infamous Rape, 28 Other Victims Suffer
description: From poor women, whose suffering rarely makes headlines, to bankers on the fast track, to little girls in pigtails, vulnerability to rape is shared by all women and girls, experts say.

title: Dr. Lisa Florence Imundo Is Bride Of Dr. Jonathan Matthew Barasch
description: Dr. Lisa Florence Imundo, a daughter of Isabel S. Imundo of White Plains and Richard Imundo of New York, was married yesterday to Dr. Jonathan Matthew Barasch, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Clarence S. Barasch of New York. Rabbi David Posner officiated at the Terrace at Butler Hall at Columbia University.

title: King of Ashanti in U.S. Stresses Cultural Pride
description: Surrounded by his counselors and shrouded in traditional robes hand-woven from bright yellow cloth, the diminuitive Nana Opoku Asamoah sat, his royal suite weighing and debating his every word in hushed tones.

title: Michael L. Vallon, 82, Ex-New York Official
description: Michael L. Vallon, a former New York City Purchase Commissioner, died of pernicious anemia Saturday at the Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Westport, Conn.

title: Imbibe Rallies In the Stretch
description: Imbibe, a small colt with a powerful late run, probably earned himself a start in the Belmont Stakes on June 10 by scoring a six-length victory over Irish Actor yesterday in the $183,600 Peter Pan Stakes at Belmont Park.

title: G.O.P. KEEPING UP ETHICS PRESSURE ON THE DEMOCRATS
description: Republican Party leaders sought today to keep the pressure on House Democrats to prevent the expected resignations of Speaker Jim Wright and Representative Tony Coelho from pushing the Democrats' ethics problems out of the public mind.

title: East-West Friction: The NATO Years
description: March 1946 Winston Churchill, the leader of Britain's Conservative opposition, warns of Soviet expansionism in his Iron Curtain speech at Fulton, Mo. With President Truman present, he calls for the United States and Britain to unite as guardians of the peace. March 1947 The Truman Doctrine begins with economic and military aid to Greece and Turkey, initiating the policy of containment. February 1948 Stalin completes the takeover of Eastern Europe as the Communists gain control in Czechoslovakia. June 1948 Stalin blockades West Berlin; the Allies respond with the Berlin airlift. April 4, 1949 The United States, Canada and 10 European countries form NATO; Greece and Turkey join in 1952 and Spain in 1980. May 6, 1955 West Germany joins NATO. May 14, 1955 The Soviet Union signs the Warsaw Treaty with its East European allies. 1966 President Charles de Gaulle removes French forces from the alliance's command structure and asks NATO units to leave France. 1979 NATO decides to deploy cruise and Pershing 2 nuclear missiles in Europe but to seek talks on reducing such intermediate-range forces in Europe. 1983 Despite major antinuclear protests, deployment of intermediate-range nuclear forces begins in Britain, West Germany and Italy under the 1979 agreement. 1985 President Reagan starts his Strategic Defense Initiative, known as ''Star Wars.'' December 1987 Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, and President Reagan sign an agreement to eliminate their land-based intermediate-range nuclear arms in Europe, leaving French and British weapons in place. Giving their consent, NATO allies suggest further superpower talks about conventional forces and short-range, or battlefield, nuclear arms. March 1988 Mr. Gorbachev, in Yugoslavia, calls for an integrated Europe with fewer weapons and more economic coherence. December 1988 Mr. Gorbachev, at the United Nations, asks for basic changes in relations between the superpowers. He announces cuts in Soviet military strength and phased withdrawals from Eastern Europe. April 1989 Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany demands prompt superpower talks on short-range nuclear weapons, most of them in Germany and under American control. May 1989 Mr. Gorbachev surprises Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d by announcing the removal of 500 short-range nuclear weapons from Eastern Europe and detailed proposals on conventional forces.

title: Debt Request To Citibank
description: Five South American countries have called on Citibank to reverse its seizure of $80 million from Ecuador for arrears in the payments of its foreign debt.

title: Hiding Billions, 'Off-Budget'
description: Washington has a rising appetite for a form of fakery called ''off-budget,'' and there are two towering new examples. President Bush proposes a new Federal agency to handle the savings and loan bailout. Its operations would not show in the budget; that's nothing more than a maneuver to shrink the apparent size of the deficit. Likewise, he and Congress have agreed to remove the Postal Service from the budget.

title: Buyer of Drexel Funds Sees Need for Buildup
description: The decision of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. to get out of the mutual fund business has given Eugene J. Glaser a chance to run his own fund company in partnership with Martin E. Zweig, a star money manager who writes a well-known investment newsletter.

title: Outdoors: Another Cast at the Fast, Feisty Bluefish
description: HERALDED by a saucer-shaped flare of brilliant red, the sun was rising over the ocean and a waning moon was setting when I reached Wasque Point on Martha's Vineyard Island for my second bluefishing foray of the year.

title: Business and the Law; New York Court's Significant Cases
description: ASK a corporate litigator which state has the most influential courts and you will probably be told Delaware, home to many major companies and the place where judges routinely determine the outcome of enormous takeover contests.

title: Finale Features Contrast in Styles
description: Gary Gait, the Syracuse midfielder, and Quint Kessenich, the goalie for Johns Hopkins, are representative of what their teams stand for in intercollegiate lacrosse: offense in the Orangemen's case and defense in the Blue Jays'. On Monday, the styles will clash here at Byrd Stadium on the University of Maryland campus, with the national championship at stake.

title: WASHINGTON TALK: ENVIRONMENT
description: When the National Security Council set up a committee on oceans, environment and science earlier this year, it gave expression to a growing awareness among policy makers in Washington and around the world that the traditional definitions of national security are no longer adequate.

title: Runners Grab Social Gusto
description: ASK Michael Polansky, the president of the Plainview-Old Bethpage Road Runners Club on Long Island, about his organization's achievements, and he boasts not of racing times and team trophies, but of social events that attract new members and contribute to the runners' high.

title: They Served Country and Conscience
description: In the midst of World War II, 20 young men volunteered for the ''guinea pig unit'' at the University of Rochester's medical school.

title: Lakers Make a Full Sweep Into Final
description: After throwing everything they had at the Los Angeles Lakers today, the Phoenix Suns finally got the message. The Lakers' desire to win a third straight National Basketball Association championship is relentess. And they are playing with such robot-like efficiency they appear unfazed by any situation they encounter.

title: The Impasse Over Infant Care
description: Lucky is the poor black woman who is pregnant in Mississippi rather than in New York. She is three times more likely to receive early prenatal care.

title: Dollar Rides Rising Tide
description: The remarkable rise in the dollar's value this month seems to have been the result of several events coming together to set off a rally that then took on a life of its own.

title: Tacy E. Schafer Marries Todd Matthew Foreman
description: Tracy Ellen Schafer and Todd Matthew Foreman, graduates of Emory University, were married yesterday at Rodef Shalom Temple in Pittsburgh by Rabbi Mark Staitman.

title: Move to Extend Coffee Pact
description: Several leading Latin American coffee-producing countries will seek the support of all producing members for a two-year extension of the International Coffee Organization agreement at talks starting here June 5, the group said Friday.

title: Central Capital Corp reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included special gains of $4,003,000 for the latest quarter and $5,787,000 for the year-earlier period. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Honda Motor Co Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: The U.S. dollar amounts have been translated from yen at the rate of 132 yen equaled U.S. $1, the approximate exchange rate prevailing on the Tokyo foreign exchange market on March 31, 1989. Share earnings represented American Depositary Share (ADS) and each ADS represented 10 shares of Honda common stock. Revenue represented net sales and other operating revenue. The period that ended March 31, 1988 was an adjusted year.

title: JeriAnn Geller, Editor and Illustrator, Weds Michael Ruscoe in Connecticut
description: JeriAnn Michele Geller and Michael Richard Ruscoe were married yesterday at the Fox Hill Inn in Brookfield, Conn. Rabbi Solomon B. Acrish officiated.

title: Race Tracks Step Lively to Keep Up With Bettors
description: As the eyes of the horse racing world focused on the prestigious Preakness Stakes at Pimlico Race Course in Baltimore nine days ago, that track's most favored and well-heeled customers spent the afternoon in an opulent gambling den.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Incumbents and Unions Did Well in School Vote
description: Several trends emerged in the slow tallying of the May 2 New York City school board vote, which finished last week and awaits certification this week. Most incumbents were re-elected. Parents scored some gains but will be in the minority on every board. Union-backed candidates also generally did well. And at least two dozen candidates who entered the race not knowing whether they would be able to serve were elected.

title: Big Cast of Characters In Steel Quotas Debate
description: With the steel import quotas negotiated by the United States and 20 steel-producing countries scheduled to expire in September, the debate on the necessity of the limits has become decidedly more pitched.

title: Ms. Tepper Wed To D. I. Robinov
description: Jacqueline Gail Tepper, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin B. Tepper of Sands Point, L.I., and David Ian Robinov, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gil Robinov of Harrison, N.Y., were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents by Rabbis Norton D. Shargel and Mordecai Waxman and Cantor Bernard Dienstag.

title: Taking a Chance on East Europe
description: A growing number of Western companies in industries ranging from accounting and hotels to copiers and computer software are rushing to invest in the Soviet Union and other Eastern European nations to take advantage of changes in economic policies.

title: Leeanne Olicker Becomes a Bride
description: Leeanne Chari Olicker, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley Olicker of Williston Park and East Moriches, L.I., was married yesterday to Dr. Joshua Port, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen Port of Altoona, Pa. Rabbi Ian Jackniss officiated at Temple Beth Sholom in Roslyn, L.I.

title: Storm Kills 52 in Vietnam
description: A tropical storm last week in central Vietnam killed 52 people, injured at least 37 and left 100,000 homeless, radio reports said today. The storm destroyed 36,000 houses and sank or damaged 700 vessels in and around Da Nang last Wednesday and Thursday, the Voice of Vietnam radio said.

title: River Oaks Industries Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Net income c-Included a loss on the disposal of discontinued operations of $341,000 for both the quarter and 9 months, and the quarter included a charge from the reversal of a tax credit of $150,000 and the 9 months included a tax credit of $114,000.

title: Etz Lavud Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in U.S. dollars. All figures are adjusted to the rate of exchange of the new Israel shekel to the U.S. dollar as of March 31, 1989. The decreases in profits were mainly attributable to the losses incurred in the Laser Industries Ltd.'s affiliates. In the latest quarter, ETZ Lavud's share in Laser's results was a loss of $366,000, compared with a loss of $292,000 in the year-ago period.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Alfin Fragrances Inc. appointed Raymond Ricci senior vice president of finance and chief financial officer.

title: 2 Crewmen of Freight Train Die in Amarillo Derailment
description: A slow-moving freight train slammed into about 30 parked railroad cars early today, killing the brakeman and the conductor and injuring two other crewmen.

title: Rev. Philip A. Carey, 81, a Priest Who Helped Combat Union Graft
description: The Rev. Philip A. Carey, who taught workers how to be active in union work and clean up locals rife with corruption, died of a heart attack Saturday at St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived in the Jesuit community of St. Francis Xavier in Chelsea.

title: McDowell Balks And Loses in 12th
description: It took 4 hours 7 minutes on the clock and 12 innings on the field, but the Mets found a new and absolutely maddening way to lose a game today. With runners on second and third base, nobody out and the Mets and Los Angeles Dodgers tied at 3-3, a balk was called against Roger McDowell and the winning run was waved home by the umpire.

title: Piedmont Natural Gas Co reports earnings for 12mo April 30
Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Tuesday about a memorial service for Frances Steloff, founder of the Gotham Book Mart, incorrectly described lectures given in her name at Skidmore College. The lectures, given annually by people in the arts, were endowed by Miss Steloff; they were not about her.

title: Hitachi Ltd reports earnings for Year to March 31
description: The results in U.S. currency had been converted at the rate of 132 yen equaled U.S. $1.00, the approximate exchange rate as of March 31, 1989. Share earnings represented American Depositary Share (ADS) and each ADS represented 10 shares.

title: Portugal Customs Strike
description: Portuguese customs workers staged a one-day strike Friday, stopping goods from entering the country and causing long lines of trucks at border points, a union spokesman said. Travelers at airports and border crossings were not affected by the stoppage by the 3,000 customs employees, who are demanding wage increases. The workers called for a slowdown for the next two weeks. The spokesman said only urgent shipments, like live animals and medicines, were being processed.

title: Shakers' Quest Takes Them Along a Bumpy Road
description: The Shakers, a celibate religious community, stress pacifism, equality and the communal ownership of material goods. Now they have to worry about a road.

title: Pedestrian and Passenger Die In Harlem Motorcycle Crash
description: A man walking along a Harlem street and a passenger on a motorcycle were killed Saturday evening when the driver of the motorcycle lost control of it, the police said.

title: Prab Robots Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income

title: Entertainment Marketing Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Included gains from extinguishment of debt of $644,750 for the latest quarter and $501,925 for the year- earlier period.

title: Changes Proposed in Israel
description: Finance Minister Shimon Peres said Friday that he plans to cut taxes and liberalize Israel's capital markets to revive the economy after an 18-month slowdown.

title: Ms. Resnick Wed To E.J. Peterman
description: Ellen Beth Resnick, a Harlan Fiske Stone Scholar at the Columbia Law School, and Eric James Peterman, an associate in the New York law firm of Wachtell, Lipton, Rosen and Katz, were married yesterday at Tempke Emeth in Chestnut Hill, Mass. Rabbi Alan Turetz officiated.

title: Bush Arrives for Talks With a Divided NATO
description: President Bush arrived here tonight on the eve of a summit gathering of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization with the alliance deeply divided over Bonn's insistence on reducing the threat of short-range nuclear missiles to German territory.

title: Deltak Corp reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
Best of Political Counters Is Counting Himself Out
description: The basis of politics is knowing how to count, and not many could do it as well as Tony Coelho.

title: Deborah Anker Is Married
description: Deborah Eve Anker and Richard Adam Green were married yesterday by Rabbi Joseph Potasnik at the Palm House in the Brooklyn Botanic Garden. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Irving Anker of Jamaica Estates, Queens. Mr. Green is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Green of Los Angeles.

title: Inga M. Carmel Marries Stephen Mark Wechsler
description: Inga Marie Carmel, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Tord Carmel of Westport, Conn., was married yesterday to Stephen Mark Wechsler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Monroe S. Wechsler of Ames, Iowa. The Rev. Margot Gross, a Unitarian minister, officiated at the Cain Winery in St. Helena, Calif.

title: Chinese Hold Rally in Manhattan
description: About 1,200 people, most of them graduate students from China, rallied in Manhattan yesterday in support of pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing.

title: Graf in Step for Another French Title
description: With Martina Navratilova pointing toward Wimbledon and Chris Evert too blase to play, the path is clear for Steffi Graf in her bid for a third straight French Open title and sixth consecutive Grand Slam victory.

title: Near Upset on Savings Vote Shows Power of Lobbyists
description: Late last Monday afternoon, Representative Charles E. Schumer, the Brooklyn Democrat, placed an emergency call to the White House.

title: Debra R. Kamerling Is Bride of Dr. Robert Stern
description: At the Four Seasons Hotel in Philadelphia, Debra Rachel Kamerling was married yesterday to Dr. Robert Marc Stern. Rabbis Albert Lewis and Murray Kohn officiated.

title: A.T.&T. and Unions Agree on 3-Year Pact
description: American Telephone & Telegraph Company and its unions agreed today on three-year contracts providing workers with salary increases, a new profit-sharing plan and a package of family benefits that includes a $5 million fund to support child care centers.

title: Pitino Says He's Still Unsure
description: When basketball is discussed these days, the most frequently asked question is: Will Rick Pitino remain as coach of the Knicks or take the job at the University of Kentucky?

title: Court Finds Berkley Books Breached Contract on 'Hunt'
description: Berkley Books breached its contract with the Naval Institute Press when it allowed the paperback edition of ''The Hunt for Red October'' by Tom Clancy to go on sale early, a Federal appeals court has ruled.

title: Robin Worley Married To Robert Glen Chassin
description: Robin Lynn Worley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip E. Worley of Canton, Conn., was married yesterday at the Old Statehouse in Hartford to Robert Glen Chassin, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Jameson L. Chassin of New York. Rabbi Eugene Lipsey officiated.

title: Diane Rommelsbacher Wed
description: Diane Gerette Rommelsbacher, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Rommelsbacher of North Bellmore, L.I., was married yesterday in North Merrick, L.I., to Timothy Joseph Frost, a son of Duaine Frost of Portland, Ore., and the late Victoria Frost. Msgr. John F. Bennett officiated at Sacred Heart Roman Catholic Church. Mrs. Frost is a marketing manager at DRI/McGraw-Hill, a division of McGraw-Hill Financial Services in New York. The bridegroom is an associate at Booz Allen & Hamilton, management consultants in New York.

title: Review/Television; 2 Views of Mideast Conflict: A Delicate Balance for PBS
description: Two documentaries on the Arab-Israeli conflict, similar in theme and technique, are very different in essence: ''Arab and Jew: Wounded Spirits in a Promised Land'' is an exploration of the emotions on both sides of a seemingly intractable issue. ''Days of Rage: The Young Palestinians'' is a tract for the Palestinian cause.

title: Neiman-Marcus Group reports earnings for Qtr to April 29
description: The latest and year-ago quarters' share earnings were less than 1 cent a share after preferred stock dividend requirements. Year-ago quarter's net was restated to reflect an accounting change. Year-ago 9 months' net was after a charge of $10,542,000 to reflect adoption of new accounting policies.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-7 A cut of 30,000 U.S troops in Europe has been proposed to Western leaders by President Bush as part of a far-reaching agreement to cut non-nuclear forces, Western diplomats said. Page 1

title: Bridge
description: The 61st Goldman Open Pair Championship, one of the country's most prestigious events, began Saturday at the Penta Hotel in Manhattan. Leading into the two final sessions yesterday were Win Allegaert and Allen Kahn, both of Manhattan. Their closest pursuers were Gene Prosnitz, Brooklyn, and Ira Ewen, Jamaica, Queens, with Henry Bethe and Marty Fleisher, both Manhattan, in third position.

title: The Essence of Polish Reforms: Ambiguity
description: LEAD: American policymakers have always seen Eastern bloc Communism in black and white terms. Glasnost and perestroika haven't changed that. As a result, events in Eastern Europe are placed into pigeon holes regardless of fit. And too often the compartment that something lands in determines our judgment of it.

title: Space Programs Aren't for the Faint of Heart
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSH GIVES ALLIES PLAN FOR CUTTING G.I.'S AND AIRCRAFT
description: President Bush, in a confidential letter to other Western leaders, has proposed that NATO offer a cut of about 30,000 American troops in Europe as part of a far-reaching agreement to reduce non-nuclear forces, Western diplomats said today.

title: For First Time in a Year, Rockets Explode in Northern Israel
description: For the first time in more than a year, rockets were fired into northern Israel, exploding in the town of Metulla early today, an army spokesman said.

title: Logging in Lush Alaskan Forest Profits Companies and Costs U.S.
description: Here in the emerald panhandle of southeastern Alaska, where rain is measured in feet and the legacy of Russian America can still be seen in onion-domed churches, the Forest Service sells 500-year-old trees for the price of a cheeseburger.

title: Campaign Matters; Call Him Provost Or Chamberlain Or Just Employed
description: What do you call a city official who is responsible for resolving citizen complaints, monitoring municipal programs, recommending reforms, succeeding a mayor who is no longer able to serve and, incidentally, presiding over a legislative body in which he exercises virtually no power?

title: Cummings Is Traded For 2 Spurs Starters
description: The Milwaukee Bucks traded the forward Terry Cummings, their leading scorer in the last five seasons, to the San Antonio Spurs today for the guard Alvin Robertson, the forward Greg Anderson and future considerations.

title: No Public-Office Ban For Party Officials
description: To the Editor:

title: York Theater Benefit
description: Barbara Cook is to sing and Angela Lansbury is to present the first Oscar Hammerstein Award during ''Celebrate York 20,'' a gala benefit at the Church of the Heavenly Rest, 2 East 90th Street, on June 7 at 8 P.M. The event will mark the 20th anniversary of the founding of the York Theater Company. The composer Stephen Sondheim is the award's recipient. Tickets are $75 and $35; with a pretheater cocktail party included, tickets are $500, $300 and $200. Information: 534-5366.

title: Beware The Shmethicist
description: My job in the Nixon Administration was to turn off the lights after a meeting was over and call back into the darkened room, while unknown recorders still whirred, ''But it would be wrong!''

title: Jackpot Enterprises Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included after a credit of $423,000 in connection with an accounting change.

title: Dr. Paul Winum Wed to Ms. Irwin
description: Laura Diane Irwin, the supervisor of intake and home-finding at Brookwood Child Care in Brooklyn, and Dr. Paul C. Winum, the assistant executive director of the Grand Street Settlement in Manhattan, were married yesterday at the Inn at Buck Hill Falls, Pa. The Rev. Daniel Shenk, a Baptist minister, performed the nondenominational ceremony.

title: Even the Best of Times Are Tough in Zambia
description: Accidents that would be mere inconveniences in other countries become disasters in Zambia, underscoring the fragility of an economy that totters on the brink of ruin in the best of times.

title: Katrina Louise Eadie Wed to C. J. Brandon
description: Katrina Louise Eadie, a daughter of Mrs. Charles E. Smith and John M. Eadie, both of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., was married yesterday to Carter Jeffrey Brandon, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Chester Brandon of Woodside, Calif. The Rev. Donna Hardee, a minister of the Assemblies of God, officiated at the Pasadena Inn in Royal Oak, Md.

title: Regina Kilhenny Marries
description: Regina Terese Kilhenny, a partner with her father in Kilhenny, Fuchs & Kilhenny, and David Mason Murphy, an associate with Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom, both New York law firms, were married yesterday at Our Lady of the Lake Roman Catholic Church in Sparta, N.J. The Rev. Oliver Whyte performed the ceremony. The bride, who will retain her name, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas T. Kilhenny of Flushing, Queens. Mr. Murphy is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kevin Laurence Murphy of Rocky Hill, N.J.

title: Jeff Duncan, 59, Choreographer And Dance Workshop Founder
description: Jeff Duncan, a choreographer and dancer who founded Dance Theater Workshop, a leading showcase for modern dance in New York City, died of complications resulting from AIDS on Friday in Baltimore at the Don Miller House, which offers care to AIDS patients. He was 59 years old.

title: Friedman Industries reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Latest year results included a gain of $758,000, or 18 cents a share, from the liquidation of LIFO inventories.

title: Eric D. Amsel, Professor, Is Married to Judith Suben
description: Judith Gundersheimer Suben, a vice president of Lawrence Erlbaum Associates, publishers in Hillsdale, N.J., and Eric David Amsel, an assistant professor of psychology at Vassar College, were married yesterday at Bargemusic in Brooklyn. Rabbi Marshall Meyer officiated.

title: Help Youth, Asks Speaker At Wesleyan
description: Marian Wright Edelman, president of the Children's Defense Fund, yesterday urged graduates of Wesleyan University to participate in public service and called for a new campaign to help poor children.

title: Space Programs Aren't for the Faint of Heart; High-Yield Investment
description: To the Editor:

title: Fearing Republican Edge, Democrats Set Initiative on Crime
description: Democrats around the country, seeking to blunt what they see as a strong Republican advantage on the crime issue, are planning a political offensive that will cast President Bush's crime proposals as inadequate.

title: Langston Hits, Runs, Wins
description: Mark Langston showed why so many teams wanted him by allowing only 4 hits and striking out 12 over 8 innings in his debut with Montreal today, leading the Expos to a 10-2 victory over the San Diego Padres. In this, his first start in the National League, Langston also hit a run-scoring single and scored a run.

title: Cynthia Levine Marries
description: Cynthia I. Levine, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin A. Levine of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Joseph David Kropp, a son of Mrs. Thelma Taylor of Peabody, Mass., and the late Nathan Kropp of Franklin, N.H., were married last evening at the Harmonie Club in New York. Rabbi Joel S. Goor officiated. The bride is the international and group sales manager for the ABC International travel service company in Boston. Mr. Kropp is an associate with the Boston law firm of Bonin and Zalcman.

title: Review/Music; Japanese Ensemble in Its New York Debut
description: The Senzoku Tokyo Ensemble, a group formed last year by faculty members at Senzoku Gakuen College near Tokyo, gave its first New York performance Saturday afternoon in Weill Recital Hall. The program presented eight members in two cornerstones of the German chamber-music literature, giving readings that were creditable and sometimes expert if not always stirringly expressive.

title: Accusations Cloud Race In New Jersey
description: Charges of scandal, some against Democrats, others against Republicans, are casting a shadow over the race for Governor of New Jersey, and could threaten the fortunes of the two leading candidates.

title: Paloma Petroleum Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Vestar Inc reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
The Avenging Angel Parachutes In
description: MICHAEL JORDAN has been a lot of things on the basketball court in his time: a helicopter, a crab, a jeep, a jack-in-the-box, thunder, lightning, a rainbow. He is Edison the way he invents shots, Picasso the way he draws crowds, Samson the way he carries his team. On Saturday afternoon, he was something new. He was an avenging angel, in white shorts. This is what happened: His team, the Chicago Bovines, was losing to the Detroit Pistons, the self-styled Bad Boys, the roughnecks and no-goodniks of basketball, by 14 points with 7 minutes to go in the last quarter of Game 3 of the Eastern Conference finals in Chicago Stadium.

title: Aurizon Mines Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included a writedown of $169,497. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: For Scandal-Baring Paper in Japan, a Scandal
description: A hoax perpetrated unwittingly by one of Japan's leading newspapers led to the resignation last week of the paper's top executive. The episode was another instance of the public's rising sensitivity to unethical behavior in high places.

title: At 19, Griffey Jr. Strides Into Senior Role
description: AS the ball headed toward the 379-foot mark on the left-center-field wall late last Tuesday night, no one in Fenway Park could have known that the next moment would link one play on a springtime evening to a chilling moment for another generation.

title: Diane E. Siesel,Banker, Marries
description: The marriage of Diane Elizabeth Siesel, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Siesel of Mamaroneck, N.Y., to Stephen Dominick Muratore, a son of Mr. and Mrs. A. Raymond Muratore of Brooklyn, took place yesterday at the Tappan Hill restaurant in Tarrytown, N.Y. Rabbi Abraham Krantz officiated.

title: Sailor Says He Had No Role in Blast
description: Kendall Lee Truitt, frustrated that he was not getting his point across, picked up a pen and sketched the No. 2 gun turret of the battleship Iowa.

title: Capitol Hill - or Capital Hill?
description: The cost of winning a Congressional election is going through the roof. It took $4 million to win an average Senate race last year. This was nearly double the cost for the same 33 seats six years ago. What's behind this surge?

title: Memorial Day
description: NEW YORK Parade: Begins at noon at Broadway and 72d Street, travels north to 86th Street, then west to the Soldiers' and Sailors' Monument at 90th Street and Riverside Drive. Parking: Sunday rules. Sanitation: No collection or street cleaning. Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only; main office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Closed. Financial markets: Closed. Transportation: Buses, subways, Metro-North and Long Island Rail Road on holiday schedules. NEW JERSEY Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Option to close. Schools: Local option. Transportation: N.J. Transit on Sunday schedule. CONNECTICUT Government offices: Closed. Post offices: Express Mail and special delivery only. Banks: Closed. Schools: Closed. Transportation: New Haven line on holiday schedule.

title: Bush's New Direction; NATO Officials Hope President Will Begin To Meet Policy Challenge From Gorbachev
description: For more than four months, President Bush and his chief national security advisers have been watching, listening, studying, pondering. They have refused to be rushed into words or deeds that they considered rash or hasty.

title: France Confirms U.S. Helped Its Nuclear Weapons Project
description: France today confirmed a report that it had received technical help from the United States in its nuclear weapons program, but stressed that its nuclear deterrent remained totally independent.

title: STUDENTS RENEW CALL FOR CHANGE IN BEIJING MARCH
description: About 100,000 people on foot and on bicycles streamed through the capital today to demand more democracy and the resignation of Prime Minister Li Peng. The police and soldiers made no move to interfere despite martial law restrictions and the Government's strict warnings against demonstrations.

title: Susan Popkin Is Married on Cape Cod
description: The marriage of Susan Brandeis Popkin, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jordan J. Popkin of Boston and Chatham, Mass., to Leon Simon Cahn, the son of Mr. and Mrs. A. L. Cahn of Meridian, Miss., took place yesterday at the Chatham Bars Inn in Chatham. Rabbi Harold Robinson officiated.

title: Simpson Triumphs In Sudden Death
description: Scott Simpson tapped in a putt on the first hole of a sudden-death playoff today to beat Bob Tway and capture the Atlanta Classic.

title: TV Notes
description: 'Kwitny Report' Report

title: No More Wet Feet on Deck
description: Timberland, a company based in Hampton, N.H., recently introduced a boat shoe that comes with its own drainage system. The Hydro-Tech looks at first like a running shoe. Its leather, mesh and rubber exterior disguises six interior vents that funnel water into two drain cups embedded in the plastic midsole. One is in the forefoot; the other, at the heel.

title: Relieving Stress Stresslessly
description: IT is lunchtime on an idyllic day in May and Rees Jones, 76 years old, is sitting on a bench in Central Park. In the foreground, his friends are playing the ancient game of lawn bowling, their gentle movements set against the backdrop of a carefully tended and close-cropped lawn, beds of blooming irises and the verdant fecundity of spring. Not a drop of sweat is to be seen.

title: New President Named by Sloan Foundation
description: The Alfred P. Sloan Foundation, which ranks among the 20 wealthiest philanthropies in the United States, has named one of its trustees, Dr. Ralph E. Gomory, as its new president. Dr. Gomory, the senior vice president for science and technology at International Business Machines Corporation, will retire from I.B.M. after 30 years and take over his duties at the foundation next month.

title: The Voters in El Paso Elect Woman Mayor for First Time
description: Suzie Azar became the first female mayor in El Paso history Saturday with a landslide victory over a fellow member of the City Council in a runoff election.

title: Review/Dance; Mirroring Human Tragedies In a Modern Spanish Idiom
description: Six Spanish modern dancers were represented Saturday night at Casa de Espana in the final presentation in the series called Spanish Choreographers in New York.

title: United Tote Inc reports earnings for Qtr to April 30
description: b-Net income and the 6 months was after a credit of $207,862 in connection with an accounting change.

title: Katyn Numbers
description: To the Editor:

title: Menil Collection Seeks $35 Million
description: Faced with financial problems two years after its opening, the prestigious Menil Collection in Houston is out to raise $35 million in endowment money. The need, quite frankly acknowledged by the museum's founder and chief patron, Dominique de Menil, comes as a surprise to many in the art world who had assumed that the future of the institution was assured.

title: These Honored Peacetime Dead
description: Not only is the United States not at war; President Bush has gone to Europe in a time of remarkable prospects for world peace. All the more reason on this Memorial Day, therefore, to remember that American sailors and soldiers are still dying, and to do them honor.

title: J. K. Shapiro Wed To Terri Marlowe
description: Terri Jean Marlowe, a daughter of Mrs. Robert McElfresh of Vero Beach, Fla., and Irving Marlowe of Freeport, L.I., was married yesterday to Jeffrey Kemble Shapiro at the Chilmark, Mass., home of his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Jerome G. Shapiro of New York and Chilmark. John S. Alley, a justice of the peace in West Tisbury, Mass., officiated.

title: Shattered Book Titles
description: Appearances are not always what they seem. That would appear to be the case, anyway, with ''Personal Fouls,'' Peter Golenbock's book about the North Carolina State basketball program.

title: Automotive Industries reports earnings for Qtr to April 1
Protesters in Istanbul Assail Bulgaria Treatment of Turks
description: A group of Turks stoned and broke the windows of the Bulgarian Consulate today to protest Bulgaria's treatment of its ethnic Turkish minority, the Anatolia news agency said.

title: Awaiting Trial, Garcia Fights Hushed Tones
description: Marching through the halls of Congress or taking lunch in the members' dining room, Representative Robert Garcia is greeted with broad grins, firm handshakes and fraternal slaps on the back. When his colleagues talk about him, however, it is generally in hushed tones of sympathy and dread, the way one speaks about a friend stricken with a deadly disease.

title: Ms. Davies Wed To Alan Michaels
description: Sharon Lee Davies and Alan C. Michaels, who are both graduates of the Columbia University School of Law and former editors of The Law Review there, were married yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Roger A. Michaels, in Kitchawan, N.Y. Judge Wilfred Feinberg of the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit officiated.

title: Central Guaranty Trustco Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to March 31
description: b-Included special gains of $3,286,000 and $2,470,000 for the latest quarter and year-earlier period, respectively. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Two Irish Parties Form An Anti-Haughey Bloc
description: Ireland's two main opposition parties have agreed to form a coalition in an attempt to thwart Prime Minister Charles Haughey's effort to gain a majority in a general election.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Magazines; In Mirabella's First Issue, Things New and Not So New
description: THERE seems to be as much need for a new fashion magazine as there is for a new Italian restaurant. Still, Elle magazine, which aims at a swingy young crowd, established what looks like a secure place for itself three years ago. And it was followed last year by Lear's, beamed at the more mature woman.

title: Afghan Rebels Stage New Jalalabad Attack
description: The Government reported a new guerrilla offensive around Jalalabad today, but said its soldiers had repulsed the insurgents with artillery fire.

title: Hope Mehlman Wed in Princeton
description: Hope Dana Mehlman, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Myron A. Mehlman of Princeton, N.J., was married there yesterday at the Jewish Center to Eli Hurowitz, the son of Dr. Shula Prigason of Plainsboro, N.J., and Dr. Bertram D. Hurowitz of Hamilton Square, N.J. Rabbi Melvin Glazer performed the ceremony.

title: President's Statement on the New Arms Plan
description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's statement today announcing a four-point arms initiative:

title: Obituary; Alan Boles, 82, Dies; Insurance Executive
description: Alan E. Boles, a vice president of the General Reinsurance Corporation in Manhattan from 1937 until he retired in 1969, died Wednesday in Wesley Long Hospital in Greensboro, N.C., where he lived. He was 82 years old.

title: Bush Is Right About Moscow
description: LEAD: At the 40th anniversary meeting of NATO, which concludes today in Brussels, and in the cautious foreign policy addresses of President Bush, a new sense of skepticism is evident about events in the East, and especially in Moscow.

title: Pitino Leaving, Reports Say
description: Rick Pitino, the Knicks' coach, has informally agreed to become the University of Kentucky's head basketball coach, according to reports.

title: French Lead Libyan Bid
description: The French construction group Bouygues will lead a consortium of eight European companies in a bid for a $6 billion contract in Libya, the company's chairman, Francis Bouygues, said today. ''It is the biggest construction project I have ever seen,'' Mr. Bouygues said, adding that the plan was to dig an artificial river to make some areas in Libya arable. He said the consortium included the West German construction firm Bilfinger & Berger Bau A.G. But he declined to name other partners.

title: Israeli Civilians Kill Palestinian Girl, 14, In West Bank Town
description: Civilians firing a submachine gun shot and killed a teen-age Palestinian girl in the occupied West Bank today, despite new official warnings to Israelis to avoid taking the law into their own hands.

title: Bill Allows Surrogacy Pacts
description: The Nevada Assembly voted 31 to 9 today in favor of a bill to legalize surrogate motherhood agreements, a measure described by its advocates as the first of its sort in the nation.

title: Officer Is Shot in Brooklyn; 2 Are Arrested
description: A New York City police officer was shot and critically wounded during an exchange of gunfire last night in Brooklyn that ended with the arrest of two gunmen, the police said.

title: Californian May Run for House Whip
description: Jockeying for the second- and third-ranking House leadership posts intensified today as a new contender emerged for Democratic whip and a candidate for majority leader vowed to stay in the race despite earlier doubts that he could win.

title: Review/Television; The Series for These Ambiguous Times
description: ABC's ''Thirtysomething,'' which has just finished its second season, could very well be the prototypical television series for the 1990's. The Reagan years gave us ''Dynasty,'' a fantasy of money, power and glamour. They also left us with profound questions about morals and ethics, questions being distilled in today's headlines concerning politicians and stockbrokers, not to mention obviously troubled teen-agers and growing contingents of the homeless.

title: A Loyal Gorbachev Aide At Last wins a Top Post
description: Anatoly I. Lukyanov was his nondescript, nearly bashful self today as he was summoned into the national limelight by sharp-tongued critics demanding he explain his career role as Mikhail S. Gorbachev's indispensable cipher.

title: Oglivie in Class AA
description: Ben Oglivie, a former Milwaukee Brewers outfielder, has signed a contract with the team's Class AA Texas League affiliate at El Paso.

title: Mark Morris to Perform In Dance Workshop Benefit
description: Dance Theater Workshop, established in 1965, began as a showcase for a group of modern-dance choreographers and their friends. But even those who have seen the organization grow from its modest beginnings in a narrow Chelsea loft with protruding ceiling pipes into a leading theater for new dance might be surprised at the programs it will present tomorrow and Thursday.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Perjury Trial of a Former Congressman Is Under Way
description: The Federal perjury trial of former Representative Patrick L. Swindall has opened amid suggestions that the 38-year-old Republican would try to return to elective office if he is acquitted.

title: People
description: * Jack Bruemmer has joined DMB&B/Chicago as executive vice president and director of client service.

title: Tests Begin At Seabrook
description: Operators of the Seabrook nuclear power plant began the low-power testing process today and are planning to initiate the first atomic chain reaction at the plant within 7 to 10 days. The Nuclear Regulatory

title: In Beijing Shouting Match, Students Are Overpowered
description: For the first time in years, propaganda loudspeakers boomed out today over the low-slung houses and orange-tiled imperial monuments of Beijing, all but submerging with the sheer power of sonic amplification the lesser loudspeaker belonging to pro-democracy protesters still occupying Tiananmen Square.

title: Westchester to Operate Recycling Plant by '90
description: Westchester County has decided to build a $10 million plant in Yonkers to recycle newspapers, glass, cans, aluminum and plastics, reducing the pressure on a garbage-to-energy incinerator in Peekskill and providing savings for the county's cities and towns. The plant is scheduled to begin operations next summer.

title: Workers' Resistance Lags in Beijing
description: Zhang Quan slipped out of work several times earlier this month to join pro-democracy rallies, and he donated $27, two-thirds of his monthly salary, to the student demonstrators.

title: Chess
description: If you're the champion, the world hangs with bated breath on your every sneeze. That was evident from what happened in the Fourth World Cup Tournament, which ended April 20 in Barcelona, Spain.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Electric Power Service Corp., Columbus, Ohio, named Armando A. Pena vice president of finance.

title: Bangladesh Cyclone Kills 84
description: A cyclone that tore across Bangladesh and eastern India on Saturday killed at least 84 people and left more than half a million homeless, officials and news reports said today. Tens of thousands of mud and straw huts were blown away during the storm, which was accompanied by winds of up to 85 miles per hour, they said. At least 49 people died in India and 35 in Bangladesh, they said. Officials said the death toll was likely to rise because at least 150 fishermen were missing and feared dead in the Bay of Bengal.

title: Cliburn Pianists Are Heard, as Is Much Chopin
description: Since early Saturday morning, 38 contestants at the Van Cliburn International Piano Competition have been engaged in a long and laborious handshake with the 14-member jury assembled to decide their fate. They are also getting to know Fort Worth's ardent auditors who daily and nightly fill the Ed Landreth Auditorium at Texas Christian University here in order to select their favorites and urge them onward.

title: Drug Addicts Among the Homeless: Case Studies of Some 'Lost Dreams'
description: The major role that drug or alcohol abuse plays in causing homelessness has emerged in recent comments by advocates for the homeless, who estimate that addicts constitute a higher proportion of the homeless than do the mentally ill or other identifiable subgroups.

title: Barry Gingell, 34, Medical Expert On Treating AIDS Patients, Dies
description: Dr. Barry D. Gingell, who helped AIDS patients seeking speedier testing of experimental drugs and broader access to them, died of AIDS at St. Vincent's Hospital yesterday. He was 34 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Patterns; By Woody Hochswender
description: Optimistic Furriers

title: Economic Calendar
description: Listed below are the major economic indicators scheduled to be released this week. Tuesday New Home Sales April Wednesday Farm Prices May Leading Indicators April Thursday Construction Spending April Productivity 1st qtr. Friday Unemployment May

title: Egypt Wins 2 Contracts
description: Egypt today was formally awarded two contracts worth nearly half a million dollars for the production of spare parts for the F-16 fighter jets made by the General Dynamics Corporation. A cooperation protocol was signed by Gen. Ibrahim Orabi, the chairman of Egypt's Arab Organization for Industrialization, and Lowen Simpson, a vice president at General Dynamics. The deals, worth a total of about $460,000, involve production of more than 3,000 sheet-metal and machine parts in two Egyptian factories over 34 months for F-16 multirole fighters built in the United States. Egypt has taken delivery of 80 out of 120 F-16 fighters it has on order.

title: Washington Talk; Congress
description: The members of Congress are in a bind. The virtual decapitation of the Democratic leadership will heighten the pressure for ethics reform, while making it that much more painful to enact.

title: If It's Spring, It Must Be Belmont
description: If you are a stickler for the calendar, your year is quartered by solstices and equinoxes. If you are a horseplayer in New York, there are four very different seasons.

title: Cotton Inc. Sticks By Ogilvy & Mather
description: Ogilvy & Mather's loss of the $50 million-plus Maxwell House coffee account on Friday was softened somewhat by the news that another longtime client has opted to stay put.

title: Careers; Challenges And Risks In Buyouts
description: MANAGERS at companies that have been involved in a leveraged buyout face a degree of risk but also a challenge that can be valuable to their development, executives at management recruiting firms say.

title: How Rent Control Hurts the Poor
description: With a flourish of oratory, the two tenant representatives on New York City's Rent Guidelines Board quit last week after it tentatively approved 6 and 9 percent increases. They complained they had received too little information with which to appraise landlords' costs. Nothing on the record suggests that they cared to know anything about tenants' ability to pay.

title: Alexopoulos's Long Climb
description: The year was 1975, and George Balanchine was in Chicago looking for promising young student dancers to fill children's roles in the New York City Ballet's season there. Girls and boys danced by their teacher, Maria Tallchief, a former City Ballet star. Suddenly Balanchine pointed into the crowd. ''That Hawaiian girl,'' he said. And Helene Alexopoulos was on her way.

title: Delaware Courts Get Tough Toward Investment Bankers
description: Investment bankers are being sharply criticized in the Delaware courts, the nation's most important forum for takeover battles, for playing favorites when they oversee auctions of companies and for giving arbitrary investment opinions about the value of bids.

title: As Hospital Crisis Deepens, Attacks on Axelrod Intensify
description: After more than a decade of winning praise both in New York and across the country for innovative cost-cutting policies and improvements in patient care, Dr. David Axelrod, the state's Health Commissioner, is under growing attack as New York's hospitals sink deeper into crisis.

title: Minorities: Figures Differ
description: It has become part of the conventional wisdom that black, Hispanic and Asian New Yorkers now account for more than half of the city's population. Elected officials frequently make the claim, as do newspapers, political candidates and members of civic groups.

title: 4 People Slain in New Jersey; Relative Held
description: A Memorial Day neighborhood picnic in Springfield, N.J., turned into a nightmare yesterday afternoon when a 23-year-old man grabbed a 10-inch knife and fatally stabbed his mother and one of his three brothers and then ran into a nearby backyard, killing a family friend and a neighbor, Union County officials said.

title: Calling for a Bigger U.S. Health Role
description: Many business leaders, worried that in the long run they may be hit with the cost of health care for millions of uninsured people, are beginning to advocate a greater role for the Federal Government in extending coverage to all Americans.

title: Rate Rise By Japanese Is Expected
description: Japan is expected to raise its discount rate on Tuesday for the first time in nine years, ending an era of loose money policy here that fueled Japan's economic boom through this decade.

title: Business and Health; A Debate Over Malpractice Rates
description: OFFICIALS and legislatures in dozens of states have been reaching for ways to ease the problems of patients, doctors and insurers who battle in court in multimillion-dollar medical malpractice lawsuits. But a case in Minnesota illustrates how complicated and controversial the issues of malpractice insurance can be.

title: Wilander, Graf Coast In First French Matches
description: Steffi Graf, playing at the top of her game, and slumping Mats Wilander opened defense of their French Open titles by coasting to straight-set victories today.

title: Closing of Church Protested
description: About 50 members of a Roman Catholic parish held a Mass outside their shuttered church Sunday, but an archdiocese spokesman said the service was just a stunt. The church, Mother of Our Saviour, which had 57 member families, was one of 30 Detroit parishes with dwindling congregations that were ordered closed by Edmund Cardinal Szoka to save money. The move set off criticism from some Catholics, who argued that it was discriminatory to close inner city churches.

title: Reporter's Notebook; NATO Leaders Try to Keep Lid on Widespread Disunity
description: If anyone thought it was easy to forge a common stance on a very complex issue among 16 very different countries, the full scope of the challenge became apparent only after a glance at the parties involved.

title: Dollar's Rise Keeps Down Rates
description: Despite some signs of softness, the economy is still growing and the chances of a serious slowdown or recession are remote, a number of analysts contend.

title: Fast Track on Arms
description: The new proposals for cutting conventional forces made by President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev have brought Western and Soviet bloc nations well down the road toward an agreement that could transform the military equation in Europe.

title: Obituary; Bob Waters, 50; Active as a Coach Despite Long Illness
description: Bob Waters, who had continued as head football coach at Western Carolina University for five seasons while suffering from the degenerative nerve-cell disease amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, died this morning at his home. He was 50 years old.

title: Mets' Going Gets Even Tougher
description: The pain poured over the Mets in waves today: Gary Carter underwent surgery on his right knee and will be gone nearly two months. Davey Johnson will try to avoid or delay surgery on the two ruptured disks in his back, but does not know if he can. The hitters have collectively been so weak that the brass will hold a series of summit meetings this week to try to head off a collapse.

title: Klima Arrest Reported
description: Petr Klima of the Detroit Red Wings was arrested last night by Bloomfield Township police, according to reports by the Detroit television stations WJBK and WXYZ.

title: Chinese Students, in About-Face, Will Continue Occupying Square
description: Reversing their earlier position, thousands of university students resolved on Monday to maintain pressure on the Government by continuing their round-the-clock occupation of Tiananmen Square for at least three more weeks.

title: BMW Gives Daimler-Benz a Race
description: Eberhard von Kuenheim, the chairman of Bayerische Motoren Werke A.G., exudes confidence as he contemplates the automobile business from his office atop the company's distinctive high-rise headquarters here.

title: Teachers and Their Unions Help Children Learn; You'll Never Get Rich
description: To the Editor:

title: Swede With a Violent Past Is Charged With Murdering Olof Palme
description: A 42-year-old Swede with a history of criminal violence and drug abuse was charged today with murdering Prime Minister Olof Palme in 1986.

title: Market Place; Events Fuel Talk Of Icahn and USX
description: WAITING for Carl C. Icahn, the corporate raider, to do something about his investment in the USX Corporation is a bit like waiting for Godot, but speculation of action is again on the rise, fueled by two coincidental events happening in early June.

title: Search for President Serves as a Test for Radcliffe
description: Under President Matina S. Horner, Radcliffe College attained for its women undergraduates what had long been the school's dream: all the rights and privileges of the men of Harvard College.

title: Schmidt Retires After 17 Years and 548 Homers
description: Mike Schmidt, one of the greatest home run hitters of all time, retired today in an emotional farewell to baseball. The 39-year-old Philadelphia Phillies third baseman made the announcement at Jack Murphy Stadium hours before his teammates played the Padres.

title: Correction
description: An article on May 21 about charges against seven Palestinian journalists in the Israeli-occupied territories misstated the status of one of them.

title: Japan Ends Inquiry In Political Scandal
description: Prosecutors in Japan's influence-peddling scandal said they had not found enough evidence to charge Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita or any other top political leader with committing criminal acts. The announcement ended the eight-month investigation that forced Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita to resign.

title: Bush's Popularity
description: To the Editor:

title: Teachers and Their Unions Help Children Learn; Real Reform
description: To the Editor:

title: A Summer Prologue: Sunning
description: Lorraine McCusker did not dare brave the waves. There she was on Jones Beach in her two-piece brown-and-black bathing suit. And there were the breakers, crashing less than a hundred yards away. But - wouldn't you know? - the water was an almost arctic 52 degrees.

title: 'So-Called Hardened Criminals Don't Stop Being Human Beings'
description: To the Editor:

title: Sahara Yields Hints About Evolution of Man
description: DIGGING into valleys detected by space shuttle radar under the Sahara's sands has shown that during three separate periods up to 212,000 years ago they were vegetated and densely inhabited by makers of stone axes.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Ramco Oil's Founders See A Prototype for the 1990's
description: LEAD: The Ramco Oil and Gas Company of Oklahoma City, the fast-growing energy company that paid $74 million for Reading & Bates' domestic properties last week, is a prototype oil company of the 1990's, its founders, William W. Talley 2d, who is chairman, and Larry E. Lee, who is president, say.

title: Toshiba to Develop Computers Based on Sun Technology
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. has signed up one of Japan's leading computer companies to support its microprocessor and software.

title: Pentagon Wanted a Smart Truck; What It Got Was Something Else
description: At the start of this decade, when scientists were enthusiastic about building computers that would think like humans, the Pentagon embarked on a huge program to harness the technology for military use. Among the most publicized goals was a truck that could plot its own course and steer by itself.

title: MOSCOW MAVERICK, IN SHIFT, IS SEATED IN SUPREME SOVIET
description: In the face of mounting public indignation, the four-day-old Soviet congress reversed itself today and voted to give Boris N. Yeltsin, the maverick Communist, a seat in a new legislature.

title: Accounts
description: * Seagram Beverage Co. retained Chiat/Day, New York, for Soho Natural Sodas, after a review. A budget has not been set.

title: 4 Charged With Racial Attack in California
description: Four neo-Nazi ''skinheads'' attacked a Jewish couple, their infant, and a black man who tried to help them Sunday, the police said.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-13

title: John to Leave Yanks but Continue 300-Victory Goal
description: The uniform was still hanging from his locker. He had taken it off when the game was over, changed back into his street clothes and left for home, where he could be with his family.

title: Treasury Will Auction 3 Bills This Week
description: This week's new Treasury issues include tomorrow's auction of new three-month and six-month Treasury bills and Thursday's auction of a new one-year bill.

title: Bridge
description: The winners of the prestigious Goldman Pairs, concluded Sunday night at the Penta Hotel, were Michael Radin of Manhattan and Carol Simon of Summit, N.J. They came out of the pack in the last session with a score of almost 70 percent, overtaking Win Allegaert and Allen Kahn of Manhattan, who placed second.

title: INSIDE
description: 4 Fatally Stabbed in Jersey A 23-year-old man who graduated summa cum laude from Yale but has been unemployed is charged with killing his mother, brother and two others in Springfield, N.J. Page B1. A Contract for the Family The three-year accord reached by A.T.&T. and two major unions is being described as novel in its handling of family care issues. Page A14. Clues on Early Americans Tantalizing clues, which threaten conventional views, suggest that the first migrants to the Americas may have arrived as early as 45,000 years ago. Science Times, page C1. Charter Panel's Race Issue Many people want to improve minority group input in New York City government, but there are sharp differences over how to do it. Page B1. Mike Schmidt Retires The Phillies' Mike Schmidt, who hit 548 homers, retired. The Yanks said they would release Tommy John today, but the pitcher said he wasn't retiring. Page D13.

title: Head of Indian School Cleared of Nepotism Charge
description: An official in the Department of the Interior has cleared the beleaguered president of Haskell Indian Junior College of charges of nepotism and conflict of interest, and has temporarily reinstated him at the small campus in nearby Lawrence, Kan.

title: Children as Sexual Prey, and Predators
description: The crimes appear both aberrant and sporadic: High school football captains accused of the degrading sexual assault on a mildly retarded girl in a New Jersey suburb; high school hockey players in a Minneapolis suburb accused of the hotel room rape of a 13-year-old fan; a 15-year-old inner city youth saying he raped a 12-year-old neighbor because ''she really wanted it.''

title: For Criminals, Camp Is No Vacation
description: Lieut. Eddie Cash parked his face just an inch from the nose of 18-year-old Heath Partlow.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY The Strategic Computing Program has not given the Pentagon what it wanted - a truck for the Army that can navigate itself and a cockpit computer for the Air Force that can offer advice to the pilot in the heat of combat - but it may have led to important developments in computer science. The program illustrates how difficult it is to set goals for technological innovation and how results achieved may not be the ones that were expected. [ Page A1. ] The Delaware courts have criticized investment bankers for giving arbitrary opinions or playing favorites when giving opinions in takeover battles. Bruce Wasserstein, of Wasserstein, Perella & Company, was singled out for criticism in a recent court decision. Mr. Wasserstein said the Delaware court reached its decision on ''verifiably erroneous facts.'' [ D1. ] INTERNATIONAL Japan is expected to raise its discount rate for the first time in nine years, ending a loose monetary policy that fueled Japan's economic boom through the decade. Japanese news reports said the discount rate would increase to 3.25 percent, from 2.5 percent. The expected increase would come in response to fears of inflation and the surge of the American dollar. [ D1. ] Japanese officials are hoping to rally European countries against American trade policies. Last week, the United States cited Japan, India and Brazil for unfair trade practices. The annual ministerial meeting of the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development is expected to discuss the American action, which has been strongly criticized. [ D3. ] A.T.& T. and two large unions say their labor agreement has broken new ground because of the way it handles family and child-care issues. [ A14. ] COMPANIES Kinder-Care is planning a restructuring in which its child-care operations will be separated from its financial-services and retail businesses. The move pleased analysts, who had been puzzled by the child-care company's earlier acquisitions. [ D1. ] Sun Microsystems has signed up Toshiba, one of Japan's leading computer companies, to develop low-cost personal computers based on Sun's microprocessor and software. [ D6. ] MARKETS Many U.S. investors remain wary of the stock market despite the recent rally, and many investment managers question whether the market's rally can be sustained. But program traders and foreign investors have helped the Dow Jones industrial average gain 400 points since November. [ D4. ] Traders in the credit markets seem mesmerized by the dollar's stunning rise and are ignoring economic reports that could normally push up interest rates. Analysts expect rates to remain stable through the middle of the summer. [ D7. ] The dollar surpassed the two-mark level in quiet trading in Europe, recouping losses incurred when 11 central banks intervened to force it down last week. It also moved close to the 143-yen level. Markets in the United States and Britian were closed. [ D8. ] TODAY'S COLUMNS Dozens of states are seeking ways to ease the problems of patients, doctors and insurers who battle in court in multimillion-dollar malpractice lawsuits. But a case in Minnesota illustrates how complicated and controversial the issues of malpractice insurance can be. Business and Health. [ D2. ] Speculation is rising that Carl C. Icahn plans to do something about his investment in USX because of two events: USX will get a new chairman this week, and Mr. Icahn will get a special dividend of $144 million from Texaco. Floyd Norris: Market Place. [ D6. ] Backer Spielvogel Bates will hold its worldwide conference this week and, unlike last year, the people from the two predecessor agencies are expected to be talking the same language. Randall Rothenberg: Advertising. [ D10. ]

title: Suit on Contras Is Said To Stall Latin Accord
description: Progress toward a Central American peace accord has been blocked by a new dispute between Nicaragua and Honduras over a World Court case, the United Nations Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar, said here today.

title: Teachers and Their Unions Help Children Learn
description: To the Editor:

title: Doctor Sends Canada Inquiry Into Confusion
description: In a long and often contentious day of testimony, the doctor who managed Ben Johnson's drug program for five years continued today to deny any complicity in Johnson's positive drug test at the Seoul Olympics last fall.

title: Unions Say A.T.&T. Pact Sets New Standards for Family Benefits
description: Two years ago, in a poll of 50,000 employees, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company found that its work force was interested in more than salaries. The survey revealed a growing concern among employees, more than half of them women, about tending to their families, particularly young children.

title: Economy, Poland's Top Problem, Is Ignored by Candidates
description: Although the economy appears to be Poland's most pressing problem, it is not an issue in the nation's freest election campaign since the Communists took power after World War II.

title: Review/Theater; Is It Love? Or Is It Hate? Or Just Self-Absorption?
description: In the advanced state of self-absorption in which modern life exists, it is sometimes hard to determine with any degree of accuracy whether the emotion one feels toward another person is love or hate. It is even difficult to remember whether one is alive or dead.

title: Review/Opera; A Tender, Intimate 'Figaro' In Small Charleston Theater
description: The Spoleto Festival U.S.A. offers its performances in several theaters, auditoriums and churches around Charleston, some of which are striking for historical or architectural reasons. But the best place in town to hear music is the Dock Street Theater, a 463-seat hall built in 1736 and reconstructed in the 1930's.

title: Nestle Reversal On Offering
description: The Swiss food giant Nestle S.A., in a turnabout from a position it took last week, said today that a planned securities offering to raise nearly 800 million Swiss francs, or about $460 million, would go ahead despite initial objections from a group of stockholders.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Ethyl Group Is Spun Off And Its Chief Is Named
description: LEAD: The Ethyl Corporation of Richmond has announced it will spin off its aluminum, plastics and energy units to its shareholders and has named John D. Gottwald president and chief executive of the new concern, Tredegar Industries.

title: Misfire by the Charter Commission
description: One of the trickiest problems facing New York City's Charter Revision Commission is to save the five borough presidents from political extinction. To that end, the commission would give them discretionary authority over part of the city budget. It's a generous idea but it can only complicate budgeting.

title: At Conference On Cold Fusion, The Verdict Is Negative
description: THE great hope known as low-temperature nuclear fusion suffered its worst setback yet last week at the first Federal conference to assess the phenomenon.

title: Q&A
description: Quinine in Tonic Q. Is there enough quinine in quinine water to have a medicinal effect? A. It would not be much help against its original target, the fever of malaria, though it might be of some slight help against leg cramps.

title: Lilliquist Helps Braves Edge Cubs
description: Derek Lilliquist, a rookie, allowed one run and seven hits in seven innings today as the Atlanta Braves beat the Chicago Cubs, 2-1.

title: Syracuse Captures N.C.A.A. Title
description: With the game down to its last second, John Dressel of Johns Hopkins took a last shot at the Syracuse goal today in a final attempt to tie the score. But the goalie Matt Palum blocked it, and the Orangemen won their second consecutive National Collegiate Athletic Association lacrosse championship.

title: Jews Protest Convent Near Site of Auschwitz
description: About 300 Jewish women stood silently today near the gate of the Auschwitz death camp in southern Poland to protest the presence of a convent of Roman Catholic nuns at the site where millions of Jews were killed by the Nazis.

title: Residents Begin to Go Back To Site of Pipeline Explosion
description: Some of the 270 residents who were forced to flee after a gasoline pipeline explosion killed two people last week began returning to their homes today.

title: Missile Test Is Successful
description: A Navy Tomahawk cruise missile launched this morning from the Gulf of Mexico successfully completed a 450-mile test flight over Florida and Alabama, a Department of Defense spokesman said. The land-attack missile was launched about 9:15 A.M. from a submarine and was recovered after making a parachute landing in Eglin's test range, said Bob Holsapple of the Cruise Missile Project.

title: Las Vegas Transformation: From Sin City to Family City
description: Never has Las Vegas, the glittery and gaudy capital of American gambling, faced more competition for the gambling dollar and yet never have its casinos been more popular - and profitable. Las Vegas has responded to the new realities of gaming by trying to transform itself from sin city into family entertainment zone, where wagering seems as routine as taking in a movie.

title: French-Saudi Trade Talks
description: A French trade delegation has met with Saudi Arabian officials in Riyadh to discuss setting up more joint projects, the official Saudi news agency said today.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I think it shows the growth of the level of democratization in the congress itself. Step by step, from the first day, people have begun to figure out the atmosphere.'' - Boris N. Yelstin, on finally winning a seat in the new Soviet legislature. [ A8:5. ]

title: Commencements; Aerial Protest Darkens Ceremonies at Yale
description: An aerial protest by graduate business school students briefly darkened Yale University's 288th commencement in New Haven yesterday.

title: Commencements; Colgate University
description: Eleanor Holmes Norton, a law professor at Georgetown University, told the 700 graduates in Colgate University's 168th commencement Sunday that they belonged to an ''elusive generation'' in the shadow of the baby boom.

title: From Sales to Credit, Letters to Do Business
description: THERE are many men and women, otherwise capable and canny, who quail at the thought of writing a business letter. Perhaps they are less than confident of their command of grammar, syntax or spelling, or maybe they think a business letter requires the formal, stuffy style of the era of the steel nib and inkwell.

title: Town Seeks Star's Role In History of Television
description: The sign on the outskirts of town reads, ''Welcome to Rigby - Birthplace of TV,'' although considering how much television has changed the rest of the world, it doesn't seem to have done a great deal to for Rigby.

title: Backer and Spielvogel, Meet Bates
description: LAST year, when Backer Spielvogel Bates's top executives gathered for their first worldwide management conference ever, their talk was of creativity, and the reaction among agency observers was incredulity.

title: Mayor of Glen Ridge Urges Rejection of 'Universal Guilt'
description: The Memorial Day speech by the Mayor of Glen Ridge was not a tribute to war heroes this year. Rather, Mayor Edward M. Callahan took the occasion today to reject the idea of collective guilt over charges that five members of the high school football team had sexually assaulted a 17-year-old mentally retarded girl.

title: Our Towns; A Fallen Sailor And a Matter Of Recognition
description: On Memorial Day, 1988, Jim Macfarland started thinking it wasn't right that Navy Seaman Joseph Bowden's name was omitted from the Mountain Lakes World War I boulder. After all, the 14 local men killed in World War II were listed on the World War II boulder. ''This guy was robbed,'' Mr. Macfarland said.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Security Council Meets at 11 A.M. General Assembly WORKING GROUP ON THE DRAFTING OF AN INTERNATIONAL CONVENTION ON THE PROTECTION OF MIGRANT WORKERS - 10:30 A.M. and 3 P.M.

title: Saving the Elephant Takes a Worldwide Effort
description: To the Editor:

title: Heroes of the Kremlin
description: It is time now to talk about men and women whose dreams and sufferings are shaping great events but whose names and very lives are hardly ever mentioned.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of May 30, 1989: TUESDAY DQE Inc Stanhome Inc Ipalco Ent Inc Zemex Corp Reese Corp Ma WEDNESDAY Deere & Co New Jersey Res Corp Home Depot Inc Philip Morris Cos Inc Kellwood Co Portland Gen Corp Mapco Inc Stanley Wks THURSDAY Alleg Pwr Sys Inc Gen Host Corp Angell R E Co SPS Tech Inc Atlantic Energy Inc NJ Wal Mart Stores Inc Brown Group Inc Wash Natl Corp Dav Wat & Waste Inds Inc FRIDAY Chubb Corp

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE BASEBALL Arkansas Edges Le Moyne: Troy Eklund hit a grand slam home run in the seventh inning yesterday as Arkansas came from behind to edge Le Moyne of Syracuse, 6-5, in the championship game of the N.C.A.A. Division I Northeast Region tournament at Waterbury, Conn. The victory, the 700th in the career of the Arkansas coach, Norm DeBriyn, gave the Razorbacks (50-14) a berth in the College World Series, which starts Friday in Omaha. His homer gave Arkansas what appeared to be a safe 6-2 lead and helped erase what had been a 2-0 Le MoyEe lead. But Le Moyne battled back with three runs in the eighth. (AP) Texas Defeats New Orleans: Kirk Dressendorfer struck out 11 and got plenty of offensive support as Texas won the N.C.A.A. Midwest Regional tournament yesterday in Austin with a 9-3 victory over New Orleans. The Longhorns (51-17) earned their 25th trip to the College World Series. Texas batted around in the first inning, scoring four runs, and that was enough for Dressendorfer, a sophomore who posted his 16th victory against two losses with an eight-hitter. (AP) GOLF Faldo Wins by Two Shots: Nick Faldo used four consecutive birdies midway through the final round at Virginia Water, England, yesterday to ease to a two-shot victory over Ian Woosnam for his record fourth European PGA Championship title. Faldo finished with a 16-under-par total of 272. (AP)

title: Proper Reality Noses Into Winner's Circle
description: Proper Reality slipped inside the dueling stablemates Seeking the Gold and Dancing Spree in the final furlong and bobbed his nose down at the wire first to win the $589,000 Metropolitan Handicap yesterday at Belmont Park.

title: Caution on Oat Bran
description: Go easy on the oat bran or it may go hard on you, doctors advise.

title: Navy Accused of Hiding Nuclear Accident on Sub
description: Private researchers contended today that the Navy covered up a nuclear accident on a submarine 16 years ago because the incident was not mentioned on the ship's logs.

title: Where Are the Gas Stations of Yesteryear?
description: To the Editor:

title: By Design; Summer Sweaters
description: A lot of women like to live in sweaters year round. They can be worn many different ways for plenty of occasions. And the fact that they're knitted gives them more ease than a top made of woven stuff. But summer has always been a problem: lightweight sweaters have been hard to find. Not this year, though.
