title: More Speed and Power With Prices to Match
description: COMPAQ rolled out three new computers last week, all of them 33-megahertz versions of the Deskpro 386 personal computer. The Deskpro 386/33 Models 84, 320 and 650 set new standards for power and performance in desktop systems.

title: Books of The Times; The Writer as Dweller in the Gap of a Double Life
description: My Secret History By Paul Theroux 511 pages. G. P. Putnam's Sons. $21.95.

title: How a Frustrated Bush Moved to Out-Gorbachev Gorbachev on Weapons
description: Ten days ago, a handful of the highest-ranking officials of the Bush Administration gathered in George Bush's Kennebunkport home on a rocky promontory overlooking the Maine coast. Mr. Bush told the group he wanted to take ''a bold step'' to deal with Mikhail S. Gorbachev's initiatives.

title: Hammer Is Re-elected
description: Dr. Armand Hammer, the 91-year-old chairman of the Occidental Petroleum Corporation, was re-elected Friday to another term as a director by the company's shareholders. Meanwhile, a proposal to set a mandatory retirement age for directors was defeated. Dr. Hammer, who has led the company since 1957, was re-elected along with four other directors to three-year terms that expire in 1992. The shareholder proposal would have set a mandatory retirement age of 72 for the board if it did not adopt its own policy. Nine of the company's 17 directors are older than 72.

title: Kinder-Care To Separate Operations
description: Kinder-Care Inc., the nation's largest child-care service company, yesterday announced a restructuring in which its child-care operations would be separated from its financial-services and retail businesses.

title: The Peripatetic Sammy Davis
description: Sammy Davis Jr. is sitting in the Presidential Suite of a midtown hotel, 85 blocks south and 63 years west of his childhood Harlem home.

title: Royals May Put Wilson On the Disabled List
description: After further examination of Willie Wilson's right shoulder yesterday, doctors said the Kansas City Royals center fielder would probably go on the disabled list for a couple of weeks. The 11-year veteran was diagnosed as having tendinitis of the right rotator cuff.

title: The Perils of Driving Down the Dollar
description: The dollar is soaring in value. Just this month it has risen about 6 percent against the Japanese yen and West German mark. Ordinarily, that would be reason for American consumers to cheer: they are collectively richer.

title: Ford Foundation's Study of Welfare Was Aimed at Attention of 'Players'
description: Every year, hundreds of analytic studies are churned out about the American social welfare system without measureable impact. The Library of Congress alone has catalogued 447 titles on public welfare since 1986.

title: Commencements; Vassar College
description: Charles Gibson, the co-host of the ABC news program ''Good Morning America,'' addressed Vassar College's 125th commencement Sunday, telling the 584 undergraduates receiving degrees that college should have provided them with four years of contemplation ''from which you would hopefully emerge with a critical, analytical mind.''

title: Hooker May Sell Assets
description: The Hooker Corporation, a real estate and retail group, said today that it was negotiating the sale of $1 billion in assets as part of a debt-reduction program over the next 12 months. The company did not disclose its debt level. Operations that might be sold, Hooker said, include all Australian retail activities and, in the United States, its home-building business and Merksamer Jewelers. In addition, a number of real estate assets are being sold or put into joint ventures. Hooker also said it would reduce the proportion of resources invested in the United States. Hooker expanded aggressively into the United States in 1986 and 1987, acquiring the Bonwit Teller retail chain and Merrill Lynch Commercial Real Estate.

title: New Research Links Depression With Asthma Deaths in Children
description: THE combination of depression and asthma is potentially lethal in children, a new study suggests.

title: Hijacking Raises New Questions On Los Angeles Airport's Security
description: After an attempted hijacking of an American Airlines jet, the authorities are asking how a Cuban exile wearing green military fatigues and a bomber-style jacket and carrying a starter's pistol and two knives was able to elude X-ray devices and other security measures at Los Angeles International Airport Saturday.

title: O'Connor Tries to Assure Muslims After Canceling West Beirut Visit
description: John Cardinal O'Connor of New York telephoned Muslim leaders today to assure them that his mission to this war-torn country was for humanitarian reasons.

title: Ally & Gargano President Quits
description: Ally & Gargano lost its president on Friday when Bill Bishop resigned to become chairman of CHC Advertising, a small health care advertising agency based in Woodbridge, N.J. William Luceno, chairman of the New York agency, said Mr. Bishop's departure was unexpected, but added, ''Bill has always wanted to run his own agency.''

title: A Rally Many Investors Fear to Join
description: The Dow Jones industrial average has recovered three-quarters of the ground it lost in the 1987 decline, and foreigners have shifted into the United States stock market in large numbers. But many domestic investors are still unwilling to embrace this rally.

title: Washington Talk; Competition to Head Endowment for Arts Is Genteel but Intense
description: Cultural politics being as hot as any other kind here, rumors are flying about who will be named to head the National Endowment for the Arts, and when.

title: Women to the Fore! (What Would Franco Say?)
description: First there was the sexual harassment case in which the judge ruled that an office manager fondled a 16-year-old clerk because he experienced an uncontrollable ''biological or psychological reaction'' to the girl's miniskirt.

title: Jordan Reigns As World's Best Athlete
description: Ever since King Gustav V of Sweden told Jim Thorpe, ''You, sir, are the greatest athlete in the world'' in 1912, the Olympic decathlon champion has been accorded that unofficial title. Bob Mathias, Milt Campbell, Rafer Johnson, Bill Toomey, Bruce Jenner and Daley Thompson have basked in the golden glow of that description. But quick, who is the reigning Olympic champion?

title: Absurd Rules for N.Y. Parks
description: Congratulations to you, Henry Stern, New York City's Parks and Recreation Commissioner, for strengthening security in Central Park before the gang attack on a female jogger, and for properly and promptly adding more police muscle after the attack. But now, in defiance of common sense, you are beefing up patrols to enforce absurd new restrictions on everyday park users.

title: Opera in New Jersey
description: Mozart's ''Marriage of Figaro'' will open the sixth season of the June Opera Festival of New Jersey at 8 P.M. June 16 at the Allan P. Kirby Arts Center of the Lawrenceville School, at Route 206 and Route 546 in Lawrenceville. There will be evening performances as well on June 23 and July 1, and matinees at 3 P.M. on June 18 and 25. All performances will be in English, with the orchestra of original instruments under the direction of Michael Pratt. Tickets are $42 to $15; picnicking is permitted before performances. The festival will also present ''The Mikado'' and a concert of songs by Schubert, Brahms, Schoenberg and Cage. Information: (609) 737-7722.

title: Markets Closed
description: All stock, bond and commodity markets in the United States were closed yesterday in observance of Memorial Day.

title: D. H. Blair Appoints Surgeon to High Post
description: By her own admission, Marlene Krauss has a lot of energy. She is a surgeon and ophthalmologist, and she has just been named a managing director of corporate finance at D. H. Blair & Company.

title: Minority Groups on Council: Competing Approaches
description: The lines of the 25th District of the New York City Council form a rectangle in the heart of Brooklyn, encompassing most of the Flatbush and East Flatbush areas. Seventy percent of the district's population is black or Hispanic; the Councilwoman is Susan D. Alter, who is white.

title: Japan Turns To Europeans In Trade Rift
description: Japanese officials are hoping to use a gathering of the industrial world's economic and finance ministers here Wednesday to rally European countries against United States trade policies.

title: Thomas Strikes With 27 Points for Pistons to Tie Series, 2-2
description: The Chicago Bulls needed more 11th hour heroics from Michael Jordan today, but they didn't receive any. Instead, the Detroit Pistons outmuscled the Bulls, 86-80, to tie the four-of-seven game Eastern Conference championship series at two games apiece.

title: Physicians Rate Patient Welfare Above Truth
description: Many doctors say they would withhold information or mislead a patient's family to protect the patient, a new survey shows. But some doctors indicated that they would also practice such deception to protect themselves in extreme circumstances.

title: BUSH WINS BACKING FOR HIS ARMS PLAN FROM NATO ALLIES
description: President Bush won tentative approval from the European allies early today for proposals that he said could lead to ''a revolutionary conventional arms control agreement'' with the Soviet Union. And he seemed to have made major headway toward mending a split on arms policy within the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Philippine Workers on Strike
description: Thousands of workers nationwide went on strike for higher pay today, defying an appeal by President Corazon C. Aquino, who said labor unrest would discourage needed foreign investment. The Government said the general strike affected 169 companies employing more than 137,000 workers. Unions said half a million workers on central Luzon island alone stayed home.

title: Review/Dance; Two Choreographers Offer Varying Views of Life
description: Dance Theater Workshop presented two modern-dance choreographers with strong voices but quite different views of life in its ''Split Stream'' program on Sunday night at the Bessie Schonberg Theater.

title: Gucci Rehires Ex-Chairman
description: Guccio Gucci S.p.A., the Italian leather goods and fashion chain, has reappointed Maurizio Gucci as its chairman after a weekend shareholders' meeting here.

title: Concern Rising Over Harm From Pesticides in Third World
description: ARIF JAMAL, an agronomist and pesticide specialist, had traveled from Khartoum to tell the story haunting him since droves of animals were killed last August in the Dinder wildlife reserve in the Sudan.

title: Japanese Prosecutors End Scandal Inquiry Without Indicting Major Figures
description: Prosecutors investigating Japan's explosive influence-peddling scandal announced the end of their inquiry today, declaring that they had not found sufficient evidence to charge Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita or any other major political leader with criminal activity.

title: Chip Futures: Second Plan
description: The Pacific Stock Exchange said today that it planned to propose a futures contract for computer chips, moving to offer competition for a similar contract announced last week by the Twin Cities Board of Trade.

title: Accord Near on Proxy Plan For Life-Support Decisions
description: After a Catholic group dropped its opposition, lawmakers appear close to an agreement on legislation that would allow patients in New York State to authorize other people to make life-and-death decisions about their medical treatment.

title: Evidence of a 'Plume' in Indian Ocean
description: AGREAT plume of molten rock, rising from deep in the earth, created the Indian Ocean by pushing India, Antarctica, Australia and Africa aside, according to a scenario devised by British and Canadian researchers.

title: Jersey City Fire Darkens Sky
description: An oil fire in an isolated industrial section of Jersey City burned out of control for nearly four hours yesterday afternoon, sending up clouds of dark smoke visible as far as Long Island and Westchester County. Fire and police officials said the blaze burned from about 3:20 P.M. to 7:10 P.M. on a site close to the Hackensack River where it flows into Newark Bay.

title: Fittipaldi Isn't Retiring Type
description: When Emerson Fittipaldi retired from Formula One racing, he could not imagine coming back to drive at Indianapolis. Now, Fittipaldi, the winner of this year's Indianapolis 500, says he rarely thinks about retiring.

title: Dollar Surpasses 2 Marks In Quiet Trading in Europe
description: The dollar surpassed the two-mark level today in quiet holiday trading in Europe, recouping losses incurred when 11 central banks intervened to force it down last week.

title: Scandal in the House
description: Because the Democrats have been in command in the House of Representatives for more than 30 years, even during the Administrations of five Republican Presidents, does that mean power has corrupted the Democratic majority? Is that the reason Representative Tony Coelho has resigned and Speaker Jim Wright - also facing ethics charges - has little choice but to follow?

title: Virus Outbreaks Thwart Computer Experts
description: COMPUTER experts are exploring a variety of cures for the nation's epidemic of computer viruses, but they see no sure way to stop outbreaks that threaten all but the most isolated and elaborately protected systems.

title: A Wrap? A Stole? The Fling's a Hit
description: They are calling it the fling. It goes by other names as well, including stole, shawl, poncho, ruana, rebozo or just plain scarf. But fling is what it does, whether it is a long rectangle, perfect square or a series of undulating curves that arch around the neck and dip in front and back. It wraps cozily around the body, offering warmth, color and a graceful look to day and evening clothes.

title: Blood Test Found to Predict Risk of Heart Attack
description: A SIMPLE blood test commonly used to measure kidney function is a highly accurate predictor of heart attack and stroke in patients with high blood pressure, a new study indicates.

title: Massachusetts Warned Of Public Health Crisis
description: Massachusetts faces a public health crisis that threatens dramatic service cuts if the state fails to meet its financial obligations, a broad range of health-care providers have warned.

title: For Inmates, the Living is Easier on 'Love Boat'
description: Last summer, when the Bibby Venture was docked in the East River, the inmates dubbed it ''the Love Boat'' - an odd name for the country's first offshore floating jail.

title: Fruit in the Fridge
description: To The Living Section:

title:
Education;
For Slow Learners, an Accelerated Curriculum
description: LEAD: For 25 years, educators have used slow-paced remedial instruction as their main method of teaching pupils who seemed least prepared for basic studies and who were already behind their peers, struggling to reach average levels.

title: Saudis Urge OPEC to Drop $18 Oil Target
description: In a notable policy shift, Saudi Arabia said today that OPEC should abandon its target price of $18 a barrel for oil and depend on production quotas to sustain the price.

title: Review/Ballet; Clark Tippet's 'Rigaudon,' A Gloss on the Baroque Era
description: ''Rigaudon'' is Clark Tippet's fifth ballet and the last new work of American Ballet Theater's current season. Its New York premiere Monday night at the Metropolitan Opera House confirmed Mr. Tippet's unquestionable talent as a still developing choreographer and showed him moving in a new direction - with some distance still to go.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: A FRIEND writes:

title: MIM to Vote Stake For Oak Dissidents
description: MIM Ltd., the British investment firm that is the largest shareholder in Oak Industries, said it would vote its 24.9 percent stake in favor of the dissident group waging a proxy fight for control of the San Diego-based manufacturer of electronic communications equipment. The group is led by Roderick H. Hills, the former chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, and it is seeking to replace five of Oak Industries' eight directors. The remaining directors are MIM Ltd. representatives.

title: Machinists Bid for Northwest
description: In an unexpected development, the union representing 22,000 machinists at NWA Inc., the parent of Northwest Airlines, made a formal bid today for the carrier.

title: Perfection in the Air
description: To The Living Section:

title: Market Place; Minorco Stance On Gold Fields
description: THE word around Minorco S.A. these days seems to be 'we're never going to give up.''

title: Broadway Sets a Record With a 'But'
description: Broadway set a box-office record in the 1988-89 season, but attendance and the number of new productions declined, according to figures released yesterday by the League of American Theaters and Producers. There were more new plays than in the previous year, but there were decidedly fewer new musicals.

title: Employee Group Will Buy LTV's Steel Bar Division
description: The LTV Corporation, which operates the nation's second-largest steel company and also has interests in aerospace and defense, said yesterday that it had signed an agreement to sell its steel bar division to an employee group. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Cuba Plans Ocean Liner
description: Cuba has completed plans for a $250 million, 1,200-room ocean liner that it hopes would serve as a floating hotel and attract more European tourists, the official press agency Prensa Latina said today.

title: 4 Found Killed In an Apartment In East Harlem
description: Four people were found handcuffed and shot to death yesterday in an apartment in East Harlem, the police said.

title: Economic Scene; Fed Fiddles, Dollar Booms
description: IS neglect of the dollar truly benign?

title: Mangoes in the Surf
description: To The Living Section:

title: Metro Datelines; Gunmen Wound 2 At School Cafeteria
description: A custodian was shot in the head and a student suffered leg wounds yesterday when at least two men began shooting outside a cafeteria in East Orange High School, the authorities said.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Herring Season Is Here

title: A New Way to Speed Computers
description: Like highway engineers adding extra lanes to freeways to eliminate traffic jams, computer designers are searching for new strategies to permit computers to execute several instructions simultaneously and thereby dramatically increase their speed.

title: QFB to Buy Propane Unit
description: QFB Partners, a new partnership formed by Quantum Chemical Corporation and CS First Boston Inc., has agreed to buy Petrolane Inc.'s propane gas business, the second largest in the country, for $845 million.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: AN abundance of fresh sage in my garden prompted some quick experimentation with recipes to take advantage of it. Fresh sage has a delightful woodsy aroma with a touch of citric sharpness that interacts particularly well with mild-flavored meats like veal, chicken and pork.

title: As World Closes In, a Refuge Fights Back
description: LEAD: IT is comforting to know that in California, this land of freeways, microchips and booming real-estate development, there is still an Ojai.

title: At Co-op City, Worship in Transition
description: On a lower shopping level of Co-op City, beneath a supermarket and a shoe store, sits God's Row, an arid concrete plaza with a Catholic church at one end and an Orthodox synagogue at the other.

title: San Francisco Grants Recognition To Couples Who Aren't Married
description: The city's Board of Supervisors today passed an ordinance giving legal recognition to the ''domestic partnership'' of homosexuals and unmarried heterosexual couples.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;
United Artists Fills Chief Executive Job
description: LEAD: David Evans, a Hollywood executive for five years and former president of an Australian television network, yesterday was named president and chief executive of the United Artists Corporation.

title: Fresh Herbs Inspire Fresh Ideas in Cooking
description: AS a teen-ager growing up in Connecticut, David Bouley rode his bicycle to a neighbor's farm one day and had an experience, he says, that changed his life. It was an impulsive act: he spotted several strange plants growing on the lawn and took a bite of each.

title: George Homans, 78, Sociologist And Harvard Professor Emeritus
description: George C. Homans, a professor emeritus of sociology at Harvard University, died of a heart ailment Monday at Cambridge Hospital. He was 78 and lived in Cambridge, Mass..

title: DEMOCRAT ASSAILS REPORT OF INQUIRY
description: Representative William H. Gray 3d, the fourth-ranking Democrat in the House and a candidate for majority whip, said tonight that two F.B.I. agents visited him on Memorial Day to ask about allegations of wrongdoing by an employee. But he denied a report by CBS News that a financial deal in which he was involved was the subject of a criminal investigation.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Markets

title: Warsaw Pact Offers Details of Its European Arms Proposals
description: The Warsaw Pact today filled in parts of its proposals for reducing conventional arms in Europe, but Americans objected to some of the specifics.

title: For I.B.M., an Engineer President
description: In a move that seems to indicate a growing concern with competing in advanced computer technologies, the International Business Machines Corporation yesterday appointed its highest-ranking engineer, Jack D. Kuehler, president.

title: Sven Nyeboe Is Dead; Fashion Designer, 45
description: Sven Jesper Nyeboe, a fashion designer for many years, died of complications of AIDS yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 45 years old.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Scali, McCabe Awarded Trump Shuttle Account
description: When Donald J. Trump offered $365 million for the Eastern Airlines shuttle in October, the real estate developer said he would turn the airline into a ''diamond.'' Yesterday, Scali, McCabe, Sloves won the assignment to polish Mr. Trump's diamond and sell it to business travelers.

title: Fuel Leak Nearly Forces Jetliner to Ditch in Pacific
description: A Trans World Airways jumbo jet made an emergency landing after developing a leak and running low on fuel, but airline officials said they were not sure how close it came to a forced ditching in the Pacific.

title: Book Notes
description: West's Vatican Series Morris West has written two best sellers about the Vatican, ''The Shoes of the Fisherman'' and ''The Clowns of God.'' Last week, he sold the third novel in the Vatican trilogy, ''Lazarus,'' to St. Martin's Press for a substantial six figures. And ''Lazarus'' has already earned an additional $1 million from its sale to publishers in Britain, France, Italy, Spain and West Germany.

title: 3 Supercomputer Products Are Introduced by I.B.M.
description: The International Business Machines Corporation introduced three products yesterday that it said would significantly increase the speed of its most powerful 3090 mainframe computers for scientific computing applications. The company said the move reflected its commitment to expanding its role in the growing supercomputer market.

title: Isosceles Sweetens Offer for Gateway
description: Isosceles P.L.C., a group of dissatisfied British institutional shareholders in the Gateway Corporation, raised its hostile bid for the British food retailer to $:1.87 billion, or $2.9 billion, but Gateway quickly rejected the offer. The sweetened offer gave Gateway holders a choice between 210 pence, or $3.30, a share in cash or 195 pence, or $3.06, in cash and at least 15 pence, about 24 cents, worth of Isosceles stock. The original cash offer was made on April 18, totaling $:1.7 billion, or about $2.7 billion, or 195 pence, about $3.06, a share.

title: 'Brown Tide' Leaves Long Island Waters But Puzzle Remains
description: The huge algae masses that muddied waters and devastated the rich marine ecosystem of eastern Long Island have subsided as mysteriously as they first appeared four years ago.

title: Metro Datelines; Judge Orders Exam For Larry Davis
description: A State Supreme Court justice yesterday ordered that Larry Davis be given a complete physical examination at Bellevue Hospital Center after accusations by his attorneys that he had been ''brutally beaten'' by guards at Rikers Island last week.

title: Edwards Gains Ground in New Jersey Race
description: Even though he entered the last week of his campaign for the Republican gubernatorial nomination sniffling and coughing with a cold, W. Cary Edwards was in fine spirits today.

title: Waxman Offering For $100 Million
description: Waxman Industries, Bedford Heights, Ohio, a manufacturer of plumbing, electrical and hardware products, is offering $100 million of 13 3/4 percent senior subordinated notes due 1999 at a price of 100 through Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. as sole underwriter.

title: Green Parties Look for Gains in European Voting
description: From Britain to Greece and Italy, in the press and in meeting halls, environmental parties are busily campaigning for the elections of the European Parliament next month, confident that their future has never looked so good.

title: Getting a Good Seat: A Shutout Before the Game
description: Americans are going to sports events in record numbers, and that national obsession has made many tickets scarce and ''hot'' tickets almost unobtainable.

title: >Webster to Kings?
description: Tom Webster, a former coach of the Rangers, reportedly has been hired as coach of the Los Angeles Kings.

title: Critic's Notebook; Goodbye Minimalists; Hello Tellers of Tales
description: Wittman Ah Sing, the garrulous hero of Maxine Hong Kingston's daring new novel ''Tripmaster Monkey'' (Alfred A. Knopf, $19.95) is a compulsive teller of tales. Like Coleridge's ancient mariner, he's constantly pulling aside people to tell them an anecdote or story. It's more than a way of simply seducing women and wrangling favors from friends; it's a way of ''building worlds, inventing selves.''

title: Tories Seek Heath's Ouster For Attacks on Government
description: Leading Conservatives demanded the expulsion of former Prime Minister Edward Heath from Britain's ruling party today for a string of attacks on the Government that deeply embarrassed its European Parliament election campaign.

title: Poland Says U.S. Aids Solidarity's Election Campaign
description: Poland has accused Western governments, and specifically the United States, of interfering in the campaign for national elections this Sunday. The American Embassy immediately denied the charge.

title: Blades and Pants
description: The newspaper columnist's many duties include an obligation to inflate the inconsequentialities of daily events by noting their parallels with great historical moments.

title: Tapes by Gold Star
description: The Gold Star Company will produce videotapes at its electronics plant in Huntsville, Ala., beginning in September. Officials said production facilities capable of turning out a million tapes a year are being installed at the plant, which has been operating since 1982.

title: Giuseppe Patane, 57, a Specialist In the Conducting of Italian Opera
description: Giuseppe Patane, an Italian conductor noted for his idiomatic and rhythmically vital opera performances, died yesterday in Munich, West Germany, where he held the post of principal conductor for Italian repertory at the Bavarian State Opera. He collapsed during a performance of ''Il Barbiere di Seviglia'' on Monday evening, apparently of a heart attack, and was taken to a local hospital. He was 57 years old.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Shandwick Promotes Smallness
description: TO hear Peter Gummer tell it, public relations is the last bastion in business of E. F. Schumacher's dictum, ''Small is beautiful.''

title: O'Connor Meets With Pope To Discuss Visit to Lebanon
description: Pope John Paul II met with John Cardinal O'Connor of New York today for a briefing on Cardinal O'Connor's visit to Lebanon.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Philadelphia
description: LEAD: WHEN Georges Perrier left France in 1967 to take command of the kitchen at La Panetiere, a restaurant in Philadelphia, he was an ambitious 23-year-old chef who found himself an artist without paint. ''There was no really fresh produce, no fresh herbs, no magrets de canard, no good dairy products and'' - a particularly painful memory - ''no fois gras,'' he recalled.

title: Helen L. Robinson, 44, Research Scientist
description: Dr. Helen L. Robinson, a former research scientist at Dartmouth College working in the field of thyroid hormonal activity, died of multiple sclerosis Monday at a nursing home in New Haven. She was 44 years old and lived in New Haven.

title: No Headline
description: Doug Williams pulled into a Shell station in this Vancouver suburb on a recent Friday evening to fill his 1973 Ford LTD for the weekend. But instead of using a gasoline pump, he opened the hood and attached what looked like an air hose to a fitting in the engine compartment.

title: Tax Increases Are Adopted in Connecticut
description: The General Assembly gave final approval tonight to the largest one-year tax increase in Connecticut's history, including a jump in the state sales tax rate from 7.5 percent to 8 percent.

title: Rate Rise Fails to Halt The Dollar
description: The dollar rose against the West German mark and the Japanese yen yesterday despite an increase in Japan's key interest rate and dollar selling by central banks in Tokyo and Europe.

title: Trump Name Is Challenged
description: Although Donald J. Trump has purchased Eastern Airline's East Coast shuttle, a Washington company says it has the rights to the name ''Trump Shuttle'' and is prepared to challenge Mr. Trump in court for it.

title: Review/Television; Problems of Being Prime Time's Top Hunk
description: ''Magnum, P.I.'' with Tom Selleck is no longer in production. Neither is ''Miami Vice'' with Don Johnson. Putting aside sitcoms, that leaves Ken Wahl of CBS's ''Wiseguy'' as prime-time television's reigning male sex symbol, what the agents call top hunk. Mr. Wahl, who is fast developing a reputation for being reclusive and what publicity agents term uncooperative, might easily be mistaken for a trendy perfume-ad version of Sylvester Stallone. In case you hadn't noticed, posters for the series show him in brooding close-up, complete with black leather jacket. The copy reads: ''If looks could kill.''

title: Indiana Jones Conquers Box-Office Competition
description: ''Indiana Jones and the Last Crusade'' became the first movie to sell $10 million worth of tickets on a single day and broke nearly every other box-office record in its opening week as Hollywood began its 1989 summer season.

title: Ernst Friedheim, 89, Developer of Drugs For Ills of the Tropics
description: Dr. Ernst A. H. Friedheim, a pathologist, microbiologist and chemist who developed drugs that saved the lives of three million victims of sleeping sickness and other tropical parasitic diseases, died of kidney cancer Saturday at his home in Manhattan. He was 89 years old.

title: Justice in Bronx Goes on Leave Amid Inquiry by the U.S. Attorney
description: A State Supreme Court justice in the Bronx, facing the prospect of an indictment in a Federal investigation, has agreed not to take any new cases and has gone on leave, the borough's chief administrative judge said yesterday.

title: Bilzerian Defense Set Back
description: Paul A. Bilzerian, the Florida investor who last year gained control of the Singer Company, was dealt a significant setback yesterday in his defense against charges of securities fraud.

title: Soviet Deserters Face New Enemies: Guilt and Uncertainty
description: As Sgt. Mykola Movchan picked his way through the mines surrounding his outpost near Ghazni, Afghanistan, he wondered whether he was more likely to be killed by the Afghan guerrillas he was trying to desert to or by his own Soviet Army officers if he were caught.

title: Supreme Court Roundup; Ruling Limits Scope of Law on Sharing Military Pensions in Divorce
description: The Supreme Court today narrowed the scope of a law intended to insure that divorced military wives could receive a share of their former husbands' retirement benefits.

title: New York Post Is Said To Select New Editor
description: Jerry Nachman, a columnist for The New York Post, is expected to be named editor of the newspaper today, executives at The Post said. He would replace Jane Amsterdam, who was formally relieved of her job yesterday by Peter S. Kalikow, The Post's owner.

title: In Shift, Sweden Dailies Identify Palme Suspect
description: Ten Swedish newspapers today published the name and picture of the man charged with murdering Prime Minister Olof Palme, defying the Swedish press association's code of ethics, which discourages the publishing of names and pictures of people who have not been convicted.

title: Torrent of History
description: It was the heaviest rainstorm that had ever been recorded in western Pennsylvania. When the dam broke, 15 miles above Johnstown, it loosed a torrent that swept away 2,209 lives. The Johnstown flood, 100 years ago today, remains the worst such disaster in U.S. history.

title: Zinka Milanov, Soprano, Is Dead at 83
description: Zinka Milanov, the leading dramatic soprano of the Metropolitan Opera for nearly 30 years until her retirement in 1966, died yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. She was 83 years old and had suffered a stroke on Saturday.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on May 23 about radon defined a picocurie, a measurement of radiation, incorrectly. It is one-trillionth of a curie, not one-thousandth.

title: Sabo, Palmeiro Cited
description: Chris Sabo, the Cincinnati Reds' third baseman, was named National League player of the week yesterday after hitting .421 with four homers in five games last week.

title: Metro Datelines; Vietnam Veterans Planning a Festival
description: Vietnam War veterans are organizing a three-day festival in New York that is being billed as a Woodstock for soldiers who fought in Southeast Asia.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball YANKEES (AL) - Waived Tommy John, pitcher. SEATTLE (AL) - Placed Dave Valle, catcher, on the 21-day disabled list. Purchased the contract of Bill McGuire, catcher, from Calgary of the Pacific Coast League. Optioned Edgar Martinez, infielder, to Calgary. Activated Tom Niedenfuer, pitcher, from the 21-day disabled list. Basketball KNICKS (NBA) - Released Rick Pitino, head coach, from his contract. Colleges BIG EAST CONFERENCE - Named Peter Frechette director of broadcast services; Chris Plonsky assistant commissioner, and Lisa Silva Zanecchia adminstrative assistant. BROCKPORT STATE - Named Joe Bock defensive line coach. CLEMSON - Announced the resignation of Don Hogan, assistant athletic director, to become assistant basketball coach at Davidson. FURMAN - Named Barclay Radebaugh men's assistant basketball coach. KUTZTOWN - Dismissed Al Zellner, wrestling coach. Named Dan Hinkel wrestling coach. Announced the resignation of Jim McCarthy, assistant football coach. ROBERT MORRIS - Named Susan Hofacre women's softball coach. WILLIAM JEWELL - Announced the resignation of Stan McGarvey, head football coach. Named Dan Carter head football coach. Football CALGARY (CFL) - Signed Terrence Jones, quarterback, to a four-year contract. DENVER (AFC) - Extended the contract of Dan Reeves, head coach, through 1992. OTTAWA (CFL) - Signed Steve Howlett, slot back. PITTSBURGH (AFC) - Announced the retirement of Buddy Aydelette, offensive tackle. Hockey PHILADELPHIA (NHL) - Named John Paddock assistant general manager. ST. LOUIS (NHL) - Signed Randy Skarda and Adrien Plavsic, defensemen, and Vincent Riendeau, goaltender, to multiyear contracts.

title: Non-Communist Cambodia Rebels Would Get Arms Under Bush Plan
description: After months of internal debate, the Bush Administration has decided to seek Congressional backing for a covert program to supply rifles and other weapons to non-Communist Cambodian guerrillas, Administration officials said today.

title: Bridge
description: For many of New York's tournament players, Memorial Day was a beginning, or an end, or both. It was the start of the Reisinger Knockout Team Championships, with 12 teams surviving last night from an original entry of 40. Play will end Saturday.

title: WINE TALK
description: IT came 15 or so years too late, but it was gratifying recently to read the British writer Jancis Robinson's description of Muscadet as ''the blind taster's bete noire.'' It was just about that long ago when a prominent Muscadet producer, Louis Metaireau, invited me to Nantes, the unofficial capital of Muscadet country, to taste his wines.

title: Nomination Set For I.R.S. Head
description: Fred T. Goldberg Jr., a 41-year old Washington lawyer, will be nominated to head the Internal Revenue Service, the White House has announced.

title: Top-Level Appointment Is Made by Amerifirst
description: Alfred L. Teti, the chief operating officer of the Centrust Savings Bank in Miami, is moving to another Miami financial institution, the Amerifirst Bank, on a turnaround mission.

title: Review/Music; Verdi and Rutter Requiems By 19 Massed Choruses
description: Sunday evening's Carnegie Hall presentation by MidAmerica Productions was the latest installment in a series of multi-choir performances run by the conductor Peter Tiboris. Nineteen choruses from eight states joined forces for the Requiems of John Rutter (conducted by the composer) and Giuseppe Verdi (conducted by Mr. Tiboris).

title: Let the Osprey Superhelicopter Program Go On; Civil Applications
description: To the Editor:

title: Soviet TV's Biggest Hit: 200 Million Watch Political Drama
description: Olvar V. Kakuchaya chain-smoked his way through another day as the nation's chief of broadcast news, wondering if there will ever be a letup in what is now the biggest television hit in Soviet history, the daily eight hours of live coverage of the new Congress of People's Deputies.

title: Reactions Emotional As Pitino Makes Move
description: For weeks, David Stern, the commissioner of the National Basketball Association, watched and listened as Rick Pitino first thought about Kentucky, then talked to Kentucky, then visited Kentucky, all during the time when basketball fans are usually wrapped up in the N.B.A.'s premier event and nothing else: the playoffs.

title: Most U.S. Bonds Rise; Bill Rates Up at Auction
description: Most Treasury bond prices showed modest gains yesterday, generally reflecting the movement of the dollar in the currency markets. A major and significant exception was the bellwether long-term Treasury bond, which soared in the first half of the session and then sank in the evening.

title: Education; Professor of Protest at UMass
description: A series of campus protests this spring against Pentagon-financed research at the University of Massachusetts' Amherst campus have brought the arrests of dozens of people. Just one is a professor.

title: 20 ISRAELIS HELD IN DEATH OF ARAB
description: At least 20 Jewish settlers were detained for questioning today in connection with the killing of a 14-year-old Palestinian girl in an Arab village near Nablus, the police said.

title: Kidnapping Suspect Is Sought in Officer's Shooting
description: The police were searching yesterday for a man accused of shooting a police officer and a woman Monday night, just weeks after the man was released on his own recognizance in a kidnapping and weapons case.

title: Pemex Export Unit
description: The Government oil monopoly, Pemex, has formed an international affiliate for the export of crude oils worldwide, the company announced on Monday. Pemex said the affiliate would be known as PMI Comercio Internacional S.A. de C.V. and would ''be charged with bringing to the world market Mexican petroleum products.''

title: Beijing Reports Arrest of 11 Protesters
description: The Government said today that it had arrested 11 workers involved in China's democracy movement, and official news programs bitterly condemned a copy of the Statue of Liberty that students put up in Tiananmen Square in central Beijing.

title: Wingate H. Lucas, Ex-Congressman, 83
description: Wingate H. Lucas, a former Congressman who represented the Texas district now served by House Speaker Jim Wright, died Friday at his home in Bristol, Tenn. He was 83 years old.

title: Indian Troops Also Torture Sikhs in Punjab
description: To the Editor:

title: Rhubarb: A Tart Taste Of Spring
description: AFTER a steady diet of exotic fruits and winter-stored apples, few things gladden the heart more than the sudden appearance of fresh, field-grown rhubarb. From mid-May through early July, this seasonal delight is available nationwide from Washington State and Michigan and from farmers in the Northeast who may grow as little as one acre.

title: China Buys U.S. Wheat
description: Private exporters say China has purchased 200,000 metric tons of soft red winter wheat for delivery this market year, the Department of Agriculture reported today. The market year begins Thursday.

title: Angels' Abbott Captures 3d in Row
description: Jim Abbott won his third consecutive start, combining with two relievers on a three-hitter tonight as the California Angels beat the Milwaukee Brewers, 3-2.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; People
description: * Dennis Fogarty has been named executive vice president of account services and strategic planning at Bohbot Communications.

title: About New York; Lotto Dreams: Even Fantasies Need a Script
description: Alan Charoff (''I'd buy a place in the country. The country of Spain'') still lives in the city. Jim Wind (''I'd buy a baseball team for Brooklyn'') is still no other-borough Steinbrenner. Pam Bovell (''I'd buy out my company and have my boss work for me'') is still an employee, not an employer.

title: Conventional Arms: 6 Months of Offers
description: Dec. 7, 1988: In a speech to the United Nations, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the Soviet leader, says that by the end of 1990, the U.S.S.R. will withdraw six tank divisions from East Germany. Czechoslovakia and Hungary and reduce Soviet troops in East Europe by 50,000. Dec. 8, 1988: NATO froeign miniters approve the basic elements of NATO's proposal to set ceilings on tanks, artillery and armored troop carriers at levels slightly below numbers currently possessed by the West. Feb. 2, 1989: The Mutual and Balanced Force Reduction talks in Vienna, involving 12 NATO members and 7 Warsaw Pact nations, officially close after 15 years and little headway. March 6, 1989: Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet union outlines proposal detailing a three-stage reduction in nonnuclear weapons and military personnel in Europe at opening of East-West conference on security issues. The Soviet-bloc plan agrees with several broad principles of the Western plan but calls for limits on aircraft and troops, which the West rejects. March 9, 1989: New negotiations on conventional armed forces in Europe open in Vienna. May 11, 1989: During a visit with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, Mr. Gorbachev proposes overall ceilings on the number of tanks and armored personnel carriers that parallel the limits proposed by the West. May 23, 1989: Soviet-bloc arms negotiators propose ceilings on weapons that generally parallel measures proposed by the West. May 28, 1989: President Bush suggests to Western leaders that NATO purpose a ceiling of 275,000 on the number of American and Soviet troops based on foreign soil. This would involve a reduction of 30,000 American troops and 325,000 Soviet troops. Mr. Bush also proposes that the West accede to the longstanding Soviet desire for the inclusion of aircraft in the conventional weapons pact.

title: New-Home Sales Up By 10.9%
description: Sales of new homes were up a strong 10.9 percent in April, the Government said today, but housing economists said the industry would remain sluggish at least into summer because of high interest rates.

title: U.P.I. Reporter Is Dismissed In Dispute Over Manuscript
description: United Press International has dismissed a reporter who is co-author of a book about the news service's recent history because he would not submit his manuscript for review by U.P.I.

title: HONG KONG SHUNS VIETNAM REFUGEES
description: The Hong Kong Government today sent 400 Vietnamese men, women and children to a remote, nearly uninhabited island where they will live at first on cold rations without even rudimentary shelter.

title: Education; New Project to Help Students Transfer to 4-Year Schools
description: The American Council on Education and the Ford Foundation announced yesterday that they were planning a major new program to improve the educational quality of two-year community and junior colleges and to increase the number of students from such colleges who go on to four-year schools.

title: Eastern Deal With USAir Is Opposed
description: In a signal of increasing concern over declining competition among airlines, the Transportation Department told the Justice Department today that it opposed the plan by Eastern Airlines to sell several of its Philadelphia gates and routes to USAir Group Inc.

title: John, Cut by Yanks, Clings to Career
description: When he awoke early yesterday morning, Tommy John had just one thing on his mind: 5 o'clock.

title: Corrections
description: The calendar of cultural events in the New Jersey Weekly on Sunday misstated the location, ticket prices and telephone number for a performance of the Pro Arte Chorale on Saturday at 8 P.M. It is at the John Harms Center for the Arts in Englewood, N.J. Tickets are $15 for adults and $12 for students and the elderly.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Bissell to Chiat/Day
description: Chiat/Day, New York won a $10 million account yesterday from Bissell Inc., a home appliance manufacturer. The agency edged out Lord, Einstein, O'Neill & Partners in the competition for the account, and will create broadcast and print ads for the company. The account had been handled by Chickering & Associates, a small agency in Grand Rapids, Mich., where Bissell is based.

title: Prague May Rejoin I.M.F.
description: Czechoslovakia has been talking with the International Monetary Fund and World Bank about the possibility of rejoining the two international lending agencies, monetary officials said today.

title: GORBACHEV URGES A POSTPONEMENT OF LOCAL VOTING
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that nationwide local elections that are supposed to bring about the decentralization of political power should be postponed because the country is not yet ready for them.

title: Review/Film; The Odyssey of a Band of Lonely Gadgets
description: It's wake-up time in an empty mountain cabin, and the first appliance in the house to rouse itself is a jazzy-looking bedside radio that blares out an Al Jolson-style song. The noise quickly wakens the other appliances. The doggy-faced desk lamp flashes on, Kirby, the cranky, growling vacuum cleaner is ready for action, and Blankey, the meek, frightened electric blanket peeps awake. The most optimistic gadget is a toaster with a perky voice, big round eyes and a cute bowed smile. On this particular morning, the toaster tries to organize everyone into doing their usual chores. But without their master to use them, their existence seems lonely and purposeless.

title: Let the Osprey Superhelicopter Program Go On
description: To the Editor:

title: Miss Ritter, Executive, Is a Bride
description: Valerie Ritter, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Arthur Ritter of New York, was married yesterday to Jeffrey Paley, the son of Dorothy H. Hirshon of Glen Cove, L.I., and William S. Paley of New York. The Rev. John Brown Macnab performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church in New York.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Accounts
description: * Carteret Savings Bank, to Korey, Kay & Partners, with an undisclosed budget.

title: Tritium Cutoff Needs Weapons Agreements
description: To the Editor:

title: Global Communications Net Planned by G.E. for Its Staff
description: The General Electric Company said yesterday that it planned to create an international telecommunications network that would permit its employees to communicate worldwide, using voice, video and computer data, by simply dialing seven digits on a telephone.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: AMCA International Ltd., Hanover, N.H., an engineering and construction-products manufacturer, appointed Joseph A. Scopelliti senior vice president and chief financial officer.

title: Reporter's Notebook; Races for House Posts: The Rules Are Peculiar
description: Any election among 260 professional politicians is bound to be peculiar. So go the Democratic leadership races in the House of Representatives.

title: In Quest for Democracy, a Mini-City Is Born
description: A few hundred yards from the center of Chinese bureaucracy, where the Communist Party leadership is engaged in a bitter power struggle, a smaller group of less experienced bureaucrats on Tiananmen Square is building its own society, a virtual city of protest.

title: NATO Decides to Tango
description: A senior Pravda commentator here for the NATO summit meeting was asked by an American newspaperman, ''Has Gorbachev lost the initiative?'' He chuckled. ''Well,'' he said, ''let's have a competition of initiatives now. Then we'll all be pacifists.''

title: Motive Sought In Slaying of 4 In New Jersey
description: As investigators looked for a motive, a young man charged with stabbing his mother, his brother and two other people to death in a suburban Springfield neighborhood appeared today before a Criminal Court judge, who set bail at $4 million and remanded him to the County Jail.

title: Education; More Minority Foreign Affairs Specialists Is Goal of Lincoln University's New Institute
description: World capitals like Beijing, Moscow and Harare, Zimbabwe, seem far from the verdant rolling countryside surrounding Pennsylvania's Lincoln University, a leisurely hour's drive from Philadelphia.

title: Soviet Military Budget: $128 Billion Bombshell
description: Mikhail S. Gorbachev's announcement of what he said was the ''real'' Soviet military budget caused an audible stir in the Congress of People's Deputies, but it is likely to produce some consternation among Western analysts of the Soviet military.

title: Battles of the Sexes, Ruthless and Cheerful
description: The Leader of the Band By Fay Weldon 196 pages. Viking. $18.95. Polaris and Other Stories By Fay Weldon 237 pages. Penguin. $6.95.

title: Interest Rates Up At Citicorp Auction
description: Interest rates rose for the first time in more than a month yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of commercial paper.

title: Real Estate; Offices Near Grand Central Are Renewed
description: UNTIL recently, their prime locations and reasonable rents were enough to keep the small, older Manhattan office buildings on the side streets near Grand Central Terminal filled with small service companies.

title: Has the Growth of Legal Gambling Made Society the Loser in the Long Run?
description: Americans lost 11 cents on every dollar they wagered last year. But that was not the full price they paid for legal and illegal gambling.

title: In Manhattan: No Radio. Soon, No Car?
description: My tired 1981 Datsun had paid its dues.

title: Excerpts From Joint Communique by Leaders at NATO Summit Meeting
description: Following are excerpts from the joint communique of the leaders of NATO member countries, whose meeting in Brussels ended yesterday, and from the key section on short-range nuclear forces of a NATO report outlining the alliance's general approach to arms control and disarmament. JOINT COMMUNIQUE Challenge to the East

title: Alabaman Wins Race Of Solar-Powered Cars
description: A professor of environmental studies and humanities at the University of Alabama has won the American Tour de Sol, a four-day road race for solar-powered cars.

title: Police in Argentina Battle Looters As Unrest Over InflationSpreads
description: Four bombs shook the Argentine capital's financial center today, and police troops fought slum residents looting supermarkets in the city's poor suburbs as violence set off by inflation mounted.

title: Chocolate Cake and Brownies, When Carob Just Won't Do
description: AT culinary benefits where more than one dessert is served, something with chocolate is inevitable. To chocolate fiends, it doesn't make much difference if the fruit tart isn't up to snuff, or if the puff pastry, filled with whatever, is soggy. But if the chocolate dessert isn't perfect, we feel cheated.

title: Pyramid Landfills and Incinerators Make Garbage Crisis Worse
description: To the Editor:

title: Manila Reaches Debt Accord
description: The world's leading creditor nations have agreed to reschedule $2.2 billion of the Philippines' debt over a 10-year period, Finance Secretary Vicente Jayme said today.

title: Four-Year Extension For Broncos' Reeves
description: The Denver Broncos' coach, Dan Reeves, has received a four-year extension on his contract that will carry him through the 1992 season, Pat Bowlen, the owner of the team, announced yesterday.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''Robbery is not the solution for the grave crisis.'' - President-elect Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina. [ A9:5. ] ''The Government discovered eight million agitators disguised as hungry people.'' - Patricio Echegaray, Secretary General of the Argentine Communist Party. [ A9:6. ]

title: Bank C.D. Yields Slide
description: Yields for certificates of deposit and bank money market accounts slipped lower for the week ended yesterday, as falling interest rates have caused more investors to choose longer maturities.

title: York Journal; A County by a New Name Doesn't Smell as Sweet
description: The disregard that the British sometimes show for their historical heritage is amazing, even to Americans. Roman and Elizabethan ruins are excavated and covered up again by commercial construction, and the elegant Wren spires of the City of London are overwhelmed by a hodgepodge of undistinguished commercial office buildings.

title: Thelma Kineer Vint, Educator, 90
description: Thelma Kineer Vint, an educator and former assistant dean of students at Hunter College, died Monday at the home of friends in Iselin, N.J., where she lived for the last two years. She was 90 years old.

title: Democracy Versus Hunger in Argentina
description: Outsiders may find it odd that food riots are convulsing Argentina, a leading producer of grains and beef. Yet hyperinflation and speculation have devalued the national currency by some 90 percent in just three months. The average Argentine's economic plight has grown desperate.

title: Buffett Urges Tough Savings Capital Rules
description: Saying he hoped to help persuade Congress to impose tough new capital standards on savings and loan institutions, Warren Buffett, the Omaha investor, denounced the savings and loan industry's principal trade group yesterday and said the savings institution he controlled was withdrawing from the organization.

title: EATING WELL
description: LEAD: WHETHER ordering takeout Chinese from a neighborhood spot or sitting down to a seven-course dinner at an Italian restaurant, selecting healthful dishes from ethnic menus presents special challenges. Yet there is no reason to place any cuisine off-limits.

title: Education; Laws of Physics and Fun
description: More than 4,000 students outfitted with a map of an amusement park, a few instruments and a questionnaire spent a day riding roller coasters and other amusement rides to learn more about physics.

title: Sinking Feeling Deepens For Mets
description: ''It's not a sinking ship,'' Howard Johnson said, surveying the sad state of the Mets. ''But it's not fun, the way it should be.''

title: Free Shows in the Park
description: Summerstage, Central Park's summer performing-arts series at the 72d Street Band Shell, will include 35 free music, dance, opera and poetry performances between June 21 and Sept. 3. The series, which began in 1986, is to open on June 21 with Tito Puente and Koko Taylor, and include these among its other performances: June 29, July 6, 13 and 20, New York Grand Opera. June 30, Marta Renzi and Dancers. July 15, the singer Lucinda Williams. July 21, the writers Studs Terkel and John Sayles. July 28, the poet Amiri Baraka and the David Murray Trio. July 30, the reggae band Toots and the Maytals. Aug. 26, the rock musician Mitch Ryder. Sept. 2, the rock musician Bo Diddley.

title: Ben Hill Brown Jr., 75, A Former Ambassador
description: Ben Hill Brown Jr., a former Ambassador to Liberia and a former Deputy Assistant Secretary of State, died of cancer on Thursday at Georgetown University Hospital in Washington. He was 75 years old and lived in Alexandria, Va.

title: Corrections
description: An article yesterday about a prison barge in Brooklyn referred incorrectly to the status of a lawsuit seeking to block its move to Pier 40, off Greenwich Village. On April 24, the Appellate Division of the State Supreme Court lifted a preliminary injunction halting construction work at the pier, but left in place a temporary restraining order against mooring the barge there. The lawsuit challenges the city's environmental review procedures, and a final ruling is expected soon.

title: Could Garden Have Kept Pitino?
description: rrThe Rick Pitino years, all two of them, will be remembered for frantic action, back and forth, up and down, sudden traps and changes of pace.

title: Mr. Bush Takes the Lead
description: When a President of the United States offers a sensible plan for improving East-West relations, NATO usually stops squabbling and follows along. President Bush almost waited too long to test that proposition. Now, however, he has responded -imaginatively and seriously - to the Soviet proposal for deep cuts in European-based forces.

title: The Sightless Learn Dancing, and More
description: DOROTHE SINSKI did a series of plies and releves at the barre in Studio 2 at the Alvin Ailey American Dance Center. She did floor stretches, African-Caribbean dance steps and sang a Congolese work song.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 An elaborate NATO compromise was unveiled. It meets Bonn's call for negotiations with Moscow on short-range missiles but appears to rule out the elimination of such weapons from the NATO's arsenal. Page A1

title: Washington Talk; Bush Appears Set to Follow Reagan By Putting Conservatives on Bench
description: Ronald Reagan's strategic effort to alter the ideological face of the Federal judiciary created a model for President Bush to follow in stamping his personal imprint on the courts.

title: Woman's Body Is Recovered At Ohio Bridge Collapse Site
description: A woman's body was pulled from the Great Miami River today in the first recovery of a victim from the collapse of a bridge last week that plunged at least two vehicles into the rain-swollen river.

title: Wright Still Adamant That He Did No Wrong
description: Jim Wright, wrestling with the most agonizing decision of his life, today clung to his insistence that he had done nothing wrong, but said he was ready to do what was best for his family, his reputation and the Congress.

title: Sailor Says Inexperience of Crew Probably Caused Iowa Explosion
description: The Navy gunner's mate who has been a key figure in the investigation of the explosion aboard the battleship Iowa said today that he thought it was caused by an inexperienced, hastily assembled crew.

title: Bush in Action: Arms Plan, Swift and Unexpected
description: The stands were full, the world was watching on television and not a few important people were questioning his ability to hit big-league pitching when President Bush arrived in Brussels on Sunday for the 40th-anniversary summit meeting of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Bank of Japan Lifts Discount Rate
description: Japan raised its key interest rate, the discount rate, by three-quarters of a point today, driven by fears of inflation and concern that the resurgent dollar could worsen its trade situation with the United States.

title: Benazir Bhutto, Islam and Politics
description: LEAD: The arrival of Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan in the United States later this week will come not a moment too soon. The continuing row over Salman Rushdie's ''The Satanic Verses'' has fueled Western fears of a hostile Muslim monolith stretching from Morocco to Indonesia. We are told that this is the day of the

title: Education; Lessons
description: A famous line about ''lies, damned lies and statistics,'' attributed to Benjamin Disraeli, might well have been prompted by a child's applying to college.

title: A Tiny but Notable Winery Is Sold
description: MOUNT VEEDER, a tiny Napa Valley winery known for intense and fruity cabernet sauvignons, has been purchased by Franciscan Vineyards, a Napa neighbor.

title: Washington Talk; The Capital
description: It was only a single word, underlined for emphasis in the text of the communique, but it did a power of good for the reputation of James A. Baker 3d of Houston, Tex., and Washington, D.C.

title: Retired Lalonde Plans to Break a Sweat on Other Fronts
description: What's ahead for Donny Lalonde, the former World Boxing Council light heavyweight champion who retired Sunday, only weeks before he was to try to regain his title from Dennis Andries, because he felt a conflict about administering pain?

title: Sonoma, Calif.
description: WHEN Jay Smith climbs 29,000 feet up Mount Everest this summer, he will be carrying only the vital necessities. And for Mr. Smith, who scaled the west ridge of the Himalayas three years ago, these essentials always include six or eight wheels of dry Monterey Jack cheese.

title: NATO CHIEFS AGREE TO A COMPROMISE IN MISSILE DISPUTE
description: The leaders of the North Atlantic Treaty Organization announced an elaborate compromise today that met West Germany's insistence on negotiations with Moscow on short-range missiles but appeared to rule out the elimination of such weapons from the alliance's arsenal.

title: Dow Tumbles by 18.22 in Heavy Trading
description: LEAD: The stock market fell sharply yesterday, although a late rally pared a much larger decline that was caused by heavy program trading. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 18.22 points to close at 2,475.55.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising; Staff Is Buying Doyle Graf Raj
description: Doyle Graf Raj, a small New York agency known for its innovative print advertising, will be sold to its employees by its principal owner and chief executive, William S. Doyle.

title: Results Plus
description: CYCLING Breukink 2d, but Takes Lead: Lech Piasecki of Poland won the 10th stage of the Tour of Italy cycling championships yesterday, edging Erik Breukink of the Netherlands, who regained the overall lead.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Atlas Corp., Princeton, N.J., a natural resources company, said it would move its headquarters to Denver and consolidate its minerals division offices, now in Colorado, with those in Denver.

title:
AT THE NATION'S TABLE;
Seattle
description: LEAD: LITTLE patches of land set aside in neighborhoods for gardeners who lack backyards are common enough. The American Community Gardening Association estimates that 90,000 acres of urban land are cultivated by community food gardeners throughout the nation. The P-Patch Gardening Program in Seattle stands out among its peers as the biggest all-organic community gardening program in the United

title: INSIDE
description: Saudi Shift on Oil Saudi Arabia said OPEC should abandon its target price of $18 a barrel for oil and depend on production quotas to sustain the price. Page D1. What Price Gambling? Americans lost 11 cents on every dollar wagered last year. The cost to the social fabric was higher. Page A18. Ex-Met Soprano Dies Zinka Milanov, a leading soprano of the Metropolitan Opera for nearly 30 years, has died at age 83. Page A20.

title: Trial to Decide Owner Of Mosaics Begins
description: A trial to determine the ownership of four precious sixth-century mosaics opened here today, in a case that may have important consequences for buyers of works of art considered national treasures by their countries of origin.

title: Zvereva, Finalist in '88, Is Upset by Reggi in Paris
description: Natalya Zvereva of the Soviet Union, who was beaten in the final last year, returned to center court at the French Open today and crumbled again on the dusty, red clay as Raffaella Reggi staged a comeback to beat her, 3-6, 7-6, 6-2 in the tournament's first major upset.

title: Pitino Wants to Go, and Knicks Grant Wish
description: Rick Pitino yesterday became free to return to his first love, college basketball, when he was released from the remaining three years of his contract with the Knicks and accepted an offer to coach the troubled program at the University of Kentucky.

title: Chief Resigns From Matilda
description: Sandra Yates, the president and chief executive of Matilda Publications Inc., which owns Ms. and Sassy magazines, resigned last week to ''work on other publishing projects,'' the company said.

title: French Open Reflects New Era
description: Like an endless baseline rally, their thoughts bounce from one extreme to the other nowadays, their outlooks changing on a whim. For instance, Martina Navratilova says that several weeks of rest this spring have restored her enthusiasm for tennis, although the test will come when she begins playing competitively again. Chris Evert - the other half of the game's most enduring rivalry - is contemplating retirement once more, however, after another demoralizing defeat.

title: Buoyed by Agreement, Bush Visits Bonn
description: President Bush arrived here today to emphasize the closeness of the American ties to West Germany in the aftermath of the sometimes bruising debate on the issue of negotiating reductions of short-range nuclear weapons with Moscow.

title: The Pop Life
description: De La Soul in Code

title: FICO Issue at 9%
description: The Financing Corporation, an arm of the Federal Home Loan Bank system that raises money for the Federal Savings and Loan Insurance Corporation, plans to offer $520 million of 30-year bonds today through competitive bidding. Only companies that are part of the regular selling group for FICO or the Federal Home Loan Bank are being invited to bid for the bonds. The issue will carry a coupon of 9 percent and have a maturity of June 6, 2019.

title: KEY RATES
Newmark & Lewis To Reduce Prices
description: Newmark & Lewis Inc., the 47-store appliance and electronics chain based in Hicksville, L.I., announced a new pricing policy in which its products would be cut in price by 5 percent to 20 percent. The prices will take effect on June 1 in all stores in New York, Connecticut and Massachusetts.

title: Jones's First Start Is Spoiled by Griffey's Homers
description: Ken Griffey Jr. strode to the plate in the eighth inning last night and a dozen or so fans began to make their way into the stands in right field. The small relocation was a tribute to the promise of the 19-year-old rookie center fielder. They wanted a souvenir, and figured they might as well get a jump on the rest of the crowd of 15,275 at the Stadium.

title: Floresville Journal; At Harvest, More Chaff Than Wheat
description: At first glance everything seemed right with the farmers' world around Floresville. The big combines were rolling across the fields, gathering in the golden grain at the start of another wheat harvest.

title: Immigrants Seek to Be Doctors Again
description: Tired of working as janitors and cab drivers and automobile mechanics, 400 immigrants who were doctors in Nicaragua are pressing the state of Florida to change its licensing rules so they can practice medicine in this country.

title: America On Tape: An Archive Of Accents
description: Sam Waterston listened to some of the tapes housed in the Library of Congress to prepare for his role as Abraham Lincoln in a television movie. A Florida woman heard the voices of her great-grandmothers on other tapes.

title: Focus of H.U.D. Inquiry: A Woman of Influence and Ambition
description: The closer that Congress and Federal auditors look at apparent political abuses in a multimillion-dollar housing rehabilitation program, the more curious they become about Deborah Gore Dean, a former aide at the Department of Housing and Urban Development.

title: Claude Pepper, Fiery Fighter For Elderly Rights, Dies at 88
description: Claude Pepper, the unabashed liberal Representative and former United States Senator from Florida who became a champion of the elderly in a political career that spanned 60 years, died yesterday afternoon at Walter Reed Army Hospital. The oldest member of Congress, he was 88 years old and lived in Miami.

title: 14 Missing as Copter Crashes
description: A Marine helicopter crashed at sea in training operations off Okinawa, Japan, today and 14 of the 22 Marines aboard are missing, the Navy said.

title: Sequa Settles S.E.C. Case
description: The Sequa Corporation has settled Federal disciplinary charges that it failed to disclose promptly its intention to acquire more than 20 percent of the Atlantic Research Corporation in October 1987.

title: Johnson's Attorney Assails Doctor at Canadian Inquiry
description: Ben Johnson's attorney said today that the sprinter was probably ''very fortunate'' to have tested positive for a banned substance at the Seoul Olympics last fall so that Johnson's doctor, George (Jamie) Astaphan, and others involved in managing the steroid programs of athletes would be exposed.

title: Libyan Oil Talks Stalled
description: Talks between Libya's National Oil Corporation and five American oil companies on resuming operations in the North African country are deadlocked, the Middle East Economic Survey reported on Monday. The newsletter said the negotiations, which began in Vienna last month, were continuing, with both sides aiming for an agreement by June 30, the deadline set by the Libyans. The companies - the Marathon Oil Company, Conoco Inc., the Amerada Hess Corporation, the Occidental Petroleum Corporation and W. R. Grace & Company - have equity holdings in Libya.

title: Barclays Sets Note Program
description: The New York branch of Barclays Bank P.L.C. announced yesterday that it had established a $1 billion medium-term note program for issuing fixed- and floating-rate notes with maturities ranging from nine months to 15 years.

title: Dunkin' Donuts Board Backs Plan
description: Dunkin' Donuts Inc. said its board had approved a plan to repurchase 1.4 million shares. The company also plans to sell 28,000 shares of a new series of cumulative convertible preferred stock to the General Electric Company's GE Capital Corporation unit for $28 million. Proceeds from the preferred stock sale will be used to repurchase the common shares.

title: Klima Arrested Again
description: The Detroit Red Wings' forward Petr Klima, who vowed in December he would never drive drunk again, was in jail yesterday morning after his arrest on another drunken-driving charge, the police said.

title: Let the Osprey Superhelicopter Program Go On; No Uncle Sugar Daddy
description: To the Editor:

title: Mary Kay Executive Is Rebuffed by Avon
description: Avon Products Inc. yesterday rebuffed an executive at Mary Kay Cosmetics Inc. who expressed interest last week in acquiring the direct-selling cosmetics company.

title: City Planner Retires As Vision Loses Favor
description: The painting on the door leading to John P. Keith's office shows the dream: A woman rises above the cityscape, her face shining with virtue and wisdom. ''City Planning'' are the words above her head; ''Enlightenment,'' the word below.

title: Foreign Investment in U.S.
description: Foreign investors spent $65 billion to acquire or establish United States businesses last year, up sharply from the $40.3 billion spent in 1987, the Government reported today.

title: Excerpts From the President's Speech and News Conference
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference today at the conclusion of the NATO summit meeting: OPENING STATEMENT

title: Oil Copter Pilots Strike
description: Helicopter pilots who operate traffic to Norway's North Sea oil platforms began a three-day strike on Monday, but the action is not expected to seriously disrupt crude production. Reidar Webster, a Government-appointed mediator, said he had presided over 14 hours of talks between pilots and management, but the sides failed to resolve a wage dispute. ''The differences are so great that the pilots decided to strike,'' he said. ''But they have said they will only strike until midnight on June 1.''

title: Propriety, Not Piety, in Congress
description: Congress churns over ethics. Speaker Jim Wright won't say whether he'll fight charges against him or quit, but his predicament prompts members to campaign for leadership posts. The Republican whip, Newt Gingrich, waves a list of unnamed Democrats he says also face scrutiny. One of his targets, Tony Coelho, the Democratic whip, unexpectedly quits. He and others complain that members are being judged by trivial or inflated tests of public morality. Suddenly, the idea of applying ethical standards is derided as sanctimony.

title: War on Crack: More Arrests With Fewer Long Sentences
description: ''You want to buy these?'' William Thomas asked Ricardo Kelly, offering three vials of crack as they stood at 216 East 111th Street. Unknown to Mr. Thomas, Ricardo Kelly is a plainclothes police officer, and with a quick sale, Mr. Thomas joined a host of others arrested by a special police narcotics squad in Manhattan.
